title: How Competitive Is the Wireless Industry?
description: To the Editor:

title: In China, Political Outsiders Turn to Microblog Campaigns
description: BEIJING  For at least some candidates seeking parliamentary seats in local Chinese elections this year, the winning formula is the very antithesis of what works in the United States.

title: Homeless Families
description: To the Editor:

title: Failed Solar Companys Auction Draws Bargain Hunters
description: FREMONT, Calif.  To some people, the bankruptcy of the solar-module maker Solyndra shows the folly of government trying to pick winners in technology markets. To others, the furor over its $535 million federal loan guarantee represents an attack on the solar industry and the Obama administrations clean energy policies.

title: Time Warner Trims Its Excesses
description: The sprawling taupe-colored offices of Jeffrey L. Bewkes, Time Warners chairman and chief executive, overlook Central Park from the 11th floor of one of Manhattans most plum pieces of commercial real estate. Mr. Bewkes cannot wait to move out.

title: Unnecessary Horn Honking
description: To the Editor:

title: Picturing 7 Billion
description: Update | View the visual time capsule here.

title: Yanks Keep Sabathia, Giving Ace Extra Year
description: The Yankees avoided a potential pitching calamity Monday when their ace, C. C. Sabathia, agreed to a contract extension just hours before the deadline for him to opt out of his current deal and become a free agent.

title: A Dictionary Updated, and a Campaign to Spread the Word
description: TRYING to sell a $60 print dictionary in 2011 is like trying to sell a silent movie.

title: Florida: Prison Privatization Plan Is Scrapped
description: A plan by the State of Florida to transfer 29 of its prisons to private management is dead, at least for now. Gov. Rick Scott has decided not to appeal last months court decision that called the plan unconstitutional. The judge said in the ruling that Florida lawmakers had erred in tucking the measure into a budget bill to get it passed. The judge said the privatization plan  a substantive policy change  merited its own debate and should have been presented as a stand-alone bill.

title: Congress Questions the I.R.S. About Delays in Its Oversight of Nonprofit Hospitals
description: In August, the Illinois Department of Revenue moved to revoke the property tax exemptions enjoyed by three major nonprofit hospitals after a court ruling determined that a fourth hospital in the state did not provide enough charity care to justify the tax benefit.

title: South Carolina: U.S. Challenges Immigration Law
description: The federal government filed suit against South Carolina on Monday to block a recently passed state law that would require the police to check the immigration status of every person they detain. The Justice Department argued in the suit that South Carolinas law, which takes effect on Jan. 1, undermines federal authority on immigration. The department has filed similar challenges to immigration laws in Alabama and Arizona. Pushing undocumented immigrants out of one state and into another is not a solution to our immigration challenges, Tony West, assistant attorney general, said in a news conference. A spokesman for Gov. Nikki Haley said the state would continue with plans to implement the law.

title: Postcard From L.S.U.: Geaux? Just Go With It
description: BATON ROUGE, La.  Louisiana is famous for its Cajun French influences, its gumbo, crawfish toufe and Mardi Gras. It is famous for laissez les bon temps rouler, as the saying goes, or letting the good times roll.

title: Domestic Oil Drilling
description: To the Editor:

title: The Quality of Homework
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Lets Nashville Protesters Stay
description: A federal judge on Monday ruled in support of dozens of protesters in Nashville who were arrested over the weekend.

title: By Deadline, 7 Bids in Science School Contest
description: New York City officials have been dreaming for months about a new graduate school bearing a prestigious brand name like Cornell or Stanford. But what about Amity University?

title: Central Park Cleanup Has Sunday Deadline for Marathon
description: The weekend snowstorm that upended the plans of many trick-or-treaters is also messing with another autumn ritual: the running of the New York City Marathon on Sunday.

title: Dissenting, or Seeking Shelter? Homeless Stake a Claim at Protests
description: LOS ANGELES  Robert Gaffney, who came here from Oklahoma 10 years ago, settled on a scrap of burlap the other day on a grassy hill outside City Hall, surveying the tents and crowd that make up Occupy Los Angeles. For many of his neighbors at City Hall Park, this is a center of protest and political grievance. For Mr. Gaffney, it is the latest piece of land that he calls home.

title: For Pakistan, Deep Ties to Militant Network May Trump U.S. Pressure
description: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton and other senior administration officials visited Pakistan in October to demand that Pakistans spy agency either deliver the Haqqani network, a virulent part of the insurgency fighting American forces in Afghanistan, to the negotiating table or help fight them in their stronghold in Pakistans rugged tribal areas.

title: Israel and the Apartheid Slander
description: THE Palestinian Authoritys request for full United Nations membership has put hope for any two-state solution under increasing pressure. The need for reconciliation between Israelis and Palestinians has never been greater. So it is important to separate legitimate criticism of Israel from assaults that aim to isolate, demonize and delegitimize it.

title: City Hall Admits Mishandling Technology Projects
description: The Bloomberg administration acknowledged on Monday that it had mismanaged its major information-technology projects, vowing to revamp its oversight of them.

title: President Is Tobacco Free, and Fit at 50, Doctor Finds
description: WASHINGTON  Forget the rumors that he has been sneaking cigarettes; President Obama is tobacco free, the presidents doctor said in reporting the results of the presidents second physical since he took office.

title: Libya Names an Engineer as Premier
description: TRIPOLI, Libya Libyas provisional leaders named an engineer as its new prime minister Monday, taking the first step toward assembling a new transitional government after the killing of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi and the formal end to the uprising that ended his nearly 42 years in power.

title: Iraq Arrests More in Wake of Tip About Coup
description: BAGHDAD  The government of Iraq continued to respond vigorously on Monday to a tip from the new interim leaders in Libya that former members of Saddam Husseins military and Baath Party were plotting a coup  so much so that critics are now saying that the information has become a pretext for arresting its political opponents.

title: Documents Reveal Reactions to Disputed A.T.F. Investigations in Arizona
description: WASHINGTON  The head of the Justice Departments criminal division, Lanny A. Breuer, was told in April 2010 that Arizona-based agents of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives had allowed a gun trafficking ring to buy hundreds of weapons and send them to Mexico as part of an investigative tactic, according to newly disclosed documents.

title: MF Global Bankruptcy Rattles Wall St. Firms
description: The markets were haunted this Halloween by the ghosts of the past financial crisis.

title: Tales From the Supercommittee
description: There are only three weeks left for the Congressional supercommittee to come up with a plan to reduce the federal deficit by at least $1.2 trillion, and there is no sign that the panel is anywhere close to reaching an agreement. Only one side, in fact, seems to be trying  the Democrats  and it is being far too accommodating, given the fierce obstructionism of the other side, the Republicans.

title: Postcard From Alabama: The Choice: Memories Or Cash
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala.  Students surely choose to attend the University of Alabama for a variety of reasons: its academic reputation, a diverse student body, an accomplished faculty.

title: My Life Report
description: Last week my colleague David Brooks made a request I couldnt refuse. He asked people over 70 to write a brief report on your life so far, an evaluation of what you did well, of what you did not do well and what you learned along the way. Well, here I am, reporting in.

title: In Stare-Down With Protesters, Governor Blinked
description: ALBANY

title: Mets Roster May Get Makeover, Too
description: On a day when the Mets officially announced that they would make significant changes to the dimensions at Citi Field, Sandy Alderson, the teams general manager, offered some measured insight into what the team that will play there next year may look like.

title: Uncle Mo Upstages Havre de Grace as Favorite in Breeders Classic
description: The Breeders Cup Classic usually shines a light on the horse of moment while the race run two before it, the Juvenile, tries to identify the colt whose name will be on everyones lips at the Kentucky Derby on the first Saturday of May. Those lines may have been blurred Monday at the post-position draw of the Breeders Cup when Uncle Mo was made the 5-2 morning-line favorite in the $5 million Classic.

title: The Ticket-Fixing Scandal
description: The arrest of 16 New York City police officers in the Bronx last week, 11 of them for fixing tickets, was bad enough. What added to the outrage was the thuggish behavior of a crowd of off-duty police officers who went to the courthouse to support their accused colleagues. Some chanted Down with the D.A.! in reference to Robert Johnson, the Bronx district attorney whose office is prosecuting these cases. Others mocked welfare recipients who were lined up at a benefits office near the courthouse.

title: Punishing Poverty
description: Being poor and needing public assistance is not a crime. Yet some states and cities, including New York City, are gratuitously inflicting punitive measures on people who seek government help.

title: Egyptians Rally for Blogger Jailed by Military
description: Egyptian activists marched in Cairo on Monday night to demand the release of an imprisoned blogger and an end to military trials for civilians. Supporters of the blogger, Alaa Abd El Fattah, chanted slogans demanding his freedom as they rallied outside his cell.

title: A Storm Out of Season
description: It sounds like the pitch for a Tim Burton movie: White Halloween. But Saturday night and Sunday morning were more frightful than amusing. The astonishing snowstorm that swept across the region left millions without power. Everywhere from West Virginia to New Hampshire, the landscape was a chaos of downed limbs, felled trees and snapped utility lines. Monday began in many places without school and electricity; in some, it looked as though even Halloween might be put on hold until the cleanup was further along.

title: Its Lonely Without the Goldman Net
description: He was from Goldman Sachs.

title: After a Kidnapping, Hackers Take On a Ruthless Mexican Crime Syndicate
description: MEXICO CITY  The hackers message, delivered via YouTube by a man wearing a red tie and a Guy Fawkes mask, was as bold and risky as anything produced by the Zetas, Mexicos most ruthless crime syndicate. But this time, the Zetas were the target.

title: Congressional Voting Records Show Few With Perfect Attendance
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Don Young of Alaska likes to get around his home state, and he does not let his voting schedule get in the way. One Tuesday in July when his fellow House Republicans voted for their signature budget measure, known as Cut, Cap and Balance, Mr. Young was the only one among them to miss the vote, for a charity fishing trip in Whittier.

title: Lottery Numbers
Capitals, Off to Hot Start, Know Thats Not the Goal
description: WASHINGTON  For the past week, visitors to the Madame Tussauds here have lined up to have their pictures taken with a newly unveiled gap-toothed wax figure wearing a gaudy red hockey sweater. No matter that the real Alex Ovechkin plays three blocks away at Verizon Center. In the nations capital, there is no bigger sports celebrity than Ovechkin.

title: Cain Confronts Claim From 90s of Sexual Harassment
description: Herman Cain, a surprise leader in the Republican race for the presidency, acknowledged Monday that he was accused of sexual harassment while chief of the National Restaurant Association in the 1990s, but he denied wrongdoing in an episode that has consumed his rising candidacy.

title: The Napoleon of the American Republic
description: Around 4 a.m. on Nov. 2, 1861, a party of officers and the newly appointed general in chief of the Union armies rode through the rain-slicked streets of Washington toward the B&O train station. Their mission: To see off the nations longest-serving general, who was boarding a train for New York and retirement. For over half a century, Winfield Scott had fought for the United States, commanding troops during the War of 1812, the Mexican War, the Black Hawk War, the Second Seminole War and the current War of Rebellion.

title: Portraying the Face of Job Growth
description: The presidential campaign of Gov. Rick Perry of Texas started broadcasting its second television ad on Monday in Iowa.

title: Corzine Crashes Like Its 2008
description: When Goldman Sachs went public on May 4, 1999, Jon Corzine, who was then the firms chief executive, held a stake that was suddenly valued at $305 million. So, perhaps, its uncharitable to complain about the piddling $12 million severance he was poised to gain if he had managed to sell his current firm, MF Global Holdings, over the weekend.

title: High Fatality Rate Found for Low-Cost Buses
description: The low-cost bus industry, which has revolutionized transportation for students and other budget-conscious travelers, has racked up an alarmingly high number of fatal accidents and safety violations over the last few years, and regulators are having a hard time enforcing federal safety standards, according to a government study released on Monday.

title: After a Bye, the Jets Are Eager to Pick Up Where They Left Off
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Calvin Pace, a Jets outside linebacker, apparently likes playing football a lot more than watching football. He spent Sunday flying to New Jersey after six blissful days off, paying little attention to how the axis of the football world tilted back the Jets way.

title: Trial Opens in Court-Martial of Soldier Tied to Afghan Killings
description: JOINT BASE LEWIS-McCHORD, Wash.  The soldier accused of leading an Army unit that killed three unarmed civilians in Afghanistan last year believed he was engaging in legitimate combat at the time and has been made a scapegoat by others accused of the crimes, his lawyer said Monday.

title: The Wrong Inequality
description: We live in a polarizing society, so perhaps its inevitable that our experience of inequality should be polarized, too.

title: Giants Gaining Lots of Ground, but Not the Way They Expected
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  There can be little debate about what has been the biggest surprise this season for the Giants. After all, even Victor Cruz would not have imagined that he would be showcasing his salsa dance in the end zone as often as he has over the Giants first seven games.

title: Activists Denounce Film Deal in China
description: BEIJING  The Hollywood producers of a slapstick comedy that began shooting last week in a city in Chinas eastern Shandong Province describe their feature about a young man facing a birthday, 21 and Over, as an epic misadventure of debauchery and mayhem.

title: Fresh Scars on the Body Politic
description: Oh, to have been in that room in Juba, the capital of South Sudan, on Oct. 16. Thats when the leadership of the worlds newest country met with Xanana Gusmo, the prime minister of East Timor, the first new country of the 21st century [1]. Surely, Mr. Gusmo must have lectured on the nitty gritty of starting up a brand new country. And undoubtedly, talk must have turned to borders: how to demarcate, secure and police them. (Yes, such are the daydreams of borderspotters like myself.)

title: Tuesday: Forum Cheer
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  I know Ive mentioned this before, but if you havent seen the documentary Wordplay, for which this blog is named, you should definitely give it a whirl. Its a very interesting peek into the world of crossword construction and competitive solving. Some of the people whose bylines you see in The New York Times crossword make an appearance in the film.

title: O, That Rowdy Passage From Celibate to Celebrate
description: The grassy green rectangle that occupies most of the stage is considerably smaller than a football field. But it is the setting for a dangerous sport, the kind that sends its players hurtling to the ground with cranium-rattling impact. The game is love. And though it may at first feel like a mild diversion, as contact sports go, it soon becomes clear that no one is leaving the field without injuries.

title: Hay Shortage Compounds Woe in Drought-Stricken Texas
description: TERRELL, Tex.  Dozens of ranchers waited for hours for the donations, in a line of pickup trucks that stretched for a mile in this rain-starved region east of Dallas.

title: Marathon Weather Has Been Taken to Extremes
description: Had last weekends snap of winter weather struck a week later, it would have created a gigantic mess for the New York City Marathon, which would have had a hard time proceeding through a Central Park littered with hundreds of downed trees. Fortunately, the forecast calls for a much more normal early-November day this Sunday, when the marathon is to be run. If the forecast holds true, it will be 58 degrees and sunny.

title: Report on Low-Cost Bus Safety Is Released
description: The National Transportation Safety Board released its Executive Report on Curbside Motorcoach Safety on Monday, after six months of research.

title: Report Says New York Fed Didnt Cut Deals on A.I.G.
description: WASHINGTON  The findings of a federal investigation released Monday raised new questions about the Federal Reserve Bank of New Yorks handling of the 2008 bailout of American International Group.

title: Race, Religion and Same-Sex Marriage
description: Without drawing much attention to it yet, one of the leading groups promoting same-sex marriage has taken an interesting tack, one that implicitly acknowledges the complicated relationship between gay Americans and another minority group not firmly on their side.

title: An Exceptional Change in Zambia, and via the Ballot Box, Too
description: LUSAKA, Zambia  Guy Scott stood the other day in the middle of the Zambian National Assembly, where a stuffed lion and a stuffed leopard lounged on the floor, and trumpeted, This country is the envy of Africa!

title: Tom McNeeley, Challenger to Patterson, Is Dead at 74
description: Tom McNeeley, a knockout artist who challenged Floyd Patterson for the heavyweight championship in 1961, losing an action-packed four-round bout that featured at least nine knockdowns  it depends how you count  died on Oct. 25 in Weymouth, Mass. He was 74.

title: Second Look Needed on Pay
description: Eugene Isenberg, the chairman and chief executive of Nabors Industries, is pocketing $100 million just to give up one of his two titles. That seems absurd. But the board of Nabors, a $5.3 billion oil drilling company, was hamstrung by an old contract. Even so, the stock of Nabors has underperformed for a decade.

title: Intentions at Heart of Arms-Trafficking Case
description: At the time of his arrest in 2008, Viktor Bout was either an illegal arms dealer intent on selling 100 tons of explosives, grenade launchers and other weapons to terrorists  or an innocent and broke businessman in a scheme to sell a pair of old airplanes. At least, those are the two portraits of the 44-year-old Russian that have been offered in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: City to Pay $70 Million in Medicaid Suit
description: New York City will pay the federal government $70 million to settle a lawsuit that accused the city of overbilling Medicaid by improperly approving home care for frail and elderly clients, both parties said on Monday.

title: Special Parking Rules
description: On Tuesday, because of All Saints Day, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations in New York City will be suspended. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Rangers Shake Their Malaise With a Thrashing of the Sharks
description: The Rangers awoke from their long slumber Monday night, putting together their strongest effort of the season in a 5-2 rout of the San Jose Sharks.

title: Liberia: Presidential Candidate May Still Boycott Runoff Vote
description: The presidential candidate Winston Tubman said Monday that he could still withdraw from next weeks runoff elections even after his demand for the resignation of the head of elections was met. When it happened, we felt that we had made a gain but we didnt think that was all, Mr. Tubman said by phone. We need to make some administrative arrangements to allow us to observe the process more closely. His party, the Congress for Democratic Change, had said it would boycott the elections after claiming the first round of voting was fraudulent. Mr. Tubman came in second, but President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf did not win the majority needed to avoid a runoff.

title: In Haiti, a Step Toward the Rule of Law
description: A trial of police officers implicated in a prison massacre is a seminal event for Haitis troubled criminal justice system.

title: Raucous Trial Is a Test of Haitis Legal System
description: LES CAYES, Haiti  It is a legal spectacle unlike anything Haiti has seen: the government trying 13 of its own police officers  including high-ranking prison officials and riot squad members  on charges of murder, attempted murder or other crimes stemming from a prison massacre here last year.

title: Media Distrust May Shield Cain From the Rights Critiques
description: Do political scandals sting less than they used to?

title: Mayor's Award for a Special School That Embraces the Arts
Joyce Clifford, Who Pushed for Primary Nursing Approach, Dies at 76
description: Joyce C. Clifford, a nurse who advocatedapartnership of equals between doctors and nurses in the treatment of patients, and whose ideas were adopted in some of the nations best hospitals because they reduced medical errors and improved survival rates, died on Oct. 21 in Boston. She was 76.

title: Chinas Copycat Culture
description: This is the first post in Latitude. Read more about the blog

title: Union President Fisher Assures N.B.A.s Players That He Will Stay the Course
description: In the face of collapsed negotiations, canceled games and unsourced reports of fractures in his union, Derek Fisher moved to reassure N.B.A. players on Monday with a letter that reaffirmed his loyalty to them and his commitment to the best deal possible.

title: Dodge Grand Caravan, Chrysler Town and Country and VW Routan Earn Top Rollover Marks from I.I.H.S.
description: On Tuesday, the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety released test results relating to the roof strength of five minivans. This was the first time the models were subjected to rollover tests, the primary dynamic tool for measuring roof strength, by the institute, which is financed by the insurance industry.

title: A Thanksgiving Feast, No Turkeys Allowed
description: Are you ready to reimagine Thanksgiving without the turkey?

title: Corrections: November 1
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Wells Vegetarian Thanksgiving 2011
description: Are you ready to reimagine Thanksgiving without the turkey? All month, we present delicious no-meat recipes for your holiday table from some of your favorite chefs and cookbook authors.

title: Word of the Day | evocative
description: evocative \i-v-k-tiv\ adjective

title: Rangers Expect a Spark, but Not Too Much, From Averys Return
description: Sean Avery will receive a heros welcome from the majority of the Madison Square Garden crowd when he makes his expected return to the Rangers lineup Thursday. There will be a detectable buzz in the arena and jump in the Rangers step, and for good reason. The feisty shift disturber has an undeniably charismatic presence, whether anyone likes it or not.

title: Seeking a Billionaires Halloween Treats
description: Amid the slightly frenzied atmosphere of Halloween on the Upper East Side, three fathers and their sons walked west on East 79th Street with purpose.

title: NYT Front Page for 11/01/2011
description: NYT Front Page for 11/01/2011

title: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Tuesday
description: The political storm created by the 2G spectrum scam continues to dominate headlines, as a joint parliamentary committee meeting devoted to the issue Monday witnessed a fiery exchange (Hindustan Times). Opposition members accused the government of concealing relevant information and, in particular, of having rewritten a word in the internal note of March 25 from the finance ministry to the prime ministers office. That document appeared to blame the previous finance minister, P Chidambaram, for failing to prevent the scam. According to a two-page letter from the current finance minister, Pranab Mukherjee, to the prime minister, Manmohan Singh, the note was drafted after detailed consultations with the prime ministers office and the cabinet secretariat, and issued at the behest of the prime ministers office. (Times of India).

title: South Korea Sentences U.S. Soldier to 10 Years
description: SEOUL, South Korea  A South Korean court sentenced an American Army private to 10 years in prison on Tuesday for raping an 18-year-old South Korean woman, the most severe such ruling in almost 20 years.

title: News Quiz | Nov. 1, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: The Ra.One Marketing Mania
description: Shah Rukh Khans manic marketing campaign for his new film Ra.One culminated with a whirlwind tour of the globe. The Hindi-film star, who acted in and co-produced the superhero movie, traveled first to Dubai, then went on to London before landing in Toronto. His 1,000-watt charisma appeared to suffer no jet lag. No wonder Cameron Bailey, co-director of the Toronto International Film Festival, which hosted Mr. Khan and his movie Ra.One, declared on Twitter that Mr. Khan is the hardest-working man in show business.

title: Nov. 1, 1952 | First Hydrogen Bomb Test
description: On Nov. 1, 1952, the United States conducted its first nuclear test of a fusion device, or hydrogen bomb, at Eniwetok in the Marshall Islands. News of the event surfaced more than two weeks later, when The New York Times reported : The Atomic Energy Commission announced tonight satisfactory experiments in hydrogen weapon research  In a three-paragraph announcement, the Commission did not go so far as to state that a full-scale hydrogen bomb had been detonated, but it did say experiments contributing to hydrogen bomb research had been completed.The origins of the hydrogen bomb date to the early 1940s, when the Italian-born physicist Enrico Fermi suggested to the Hungarian-born Edward Teller that a weapon based on nuclear fission was possible. Dr. Teller, a member of the Manhattan Project assigned to build the atomic bomb for the Allies, advocated for a hydrogen super bomb instead.

title: Haiti: The Police on Trial
description: A public theater in Les Cayes, Haiti, has been transformed into a courtroom as over a dozen police and prison officials stand trial in connection with a prison massacre last year.

title: Taken by Storm
description: WHO died as a result of a freakish October snowstorm that hit the Northeast on Saturday?

title: Champions League Tuesday Preview: Reruns in New Theaters
description: The Champions League group stage makes the turn for home with what are essentially second-leg games from Matchday 3. Several of the favorites that won at home that day  Chelsea, Bayer Leverkusen, A.C. Milan, Barcelona  will be looking to repeat the feat on the road and lock up places in the knockout stages. Several others will just be looking to make their lives easier, and maybe separate themselves from the pack in their groups.

title: Test Yourself | English, Nov. 1, 2011
description: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article, Wall St. Protest Isnt Like Ours, Tea Party Says.

title: Greek Revolt on Bailout Vote May Oust Prime Minister
description: ATHENS  The government of Prime Minister George Papandreou teetered on the verge of collapse on Tuesday, threatening Greeces adherence to the terms of a new deal with its foreign lenders and plunging Europe into a fresh bout of financial turmoil.

title: Does Pop Culture Deserve Serious Study?
description: Last week, an academic conference was held where scholars discussed the reality television show Jersey Shore. Are shows, movies and other elements of popular culture just as worthy of serious study as novels and art films? Would you like to take an academic course focusing on reality TV or mainstream movies?

title: Bengals Dalton and Green Making Rare Rookie Magic
description: With two minutes left in the first half, the Bengals led the Seahawks, 10-3, on Sunday. Cincinnati called a play-action pass, but the pocket collapsed on the rookie quarterback Andy Dalton as he began to execute the fake handoff. With multiple Seahawks players crashing toward him, Dalton stepped up and fired a bomb into the end zone. At the same time, the rookie receiver A.J. Green had gained a step on Seattle safety Earl Thomas. As Green reached the end zone, Daltons pass hit him perfectly in stride for a 46-yard touchdown. It was the fifth touchdown reception for Green this season, and the fourth time hes connected with Dalton for a score (Bruce Gradkowski was responsible for Greens first touchdown catch as a pro). If Green and Dalton can connect six more times over the next nine weeks, they will become the first pair of rookie teammates to combine for 10 passing touchdowns.

title: New Prague Gallery Offers Contemporary Works
description: Theres a new stop in Prague for contemporary art  Vernon Depot (U Pruhonu 22) has opened in the industrial-chic Prague 7 neighborhood of Holesovice. Part of the Vernon family of galleries, Vernon Depot will show works by the gallerys artists as well as a rotating schedule of exhibitions.

title: The Early Word: Scrutiny
description: In Todays TimesHerman Cain rejected as false the past complaints of sexual harassment that have surfaced against him but conflicting statements about how much he knew about the cases have prompted greater scrutiny of the Republican presidential candidate, Michael D. Shear and Jeff Zeleny report.

title: A Close Look at the Perry Tax Plan
description: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of the coming book The Benefit and the Burden.

title: Study: Few Hospitals Qualify for Digital Funds
description: Though hospitals are eligible for billions of dollars in federal stimulus money to bring their facilities into the digital age to save money and improve the quality of health care, just one in 10 is ready to meet government standards to qualify for the funds, a new analysis shows.

title: Microrevolutions Off Tahrir Square
description: CAIRO  It has been nearly three months since the last really big, unmanageable crowd converged on Tahrir Square and threatened to stay until its demands were met. On the eve of Ramadan, in early August, the Egyptian military smacked and clubbed that group  a broad but woefully inarticulate coalition opposing the Supreme Council of the Armed Forces hold on power  out of the square. And much to the protesters horror, the majority of Egyptians seemed fairly satisfied with the pushback, preferring a return to order even if it came with a military policemans truncheon.

title: Credit Suisse Plans More Job Cuts Even as Profit Rises 12%
description: 6:28 p.m. | Updated

title: A Start-Up Tries to Eliminate Food Deserts
description: Last year, M.B.A. students at the Bainbridge Graduate Institute in Seattle began hunting for a business-based solution to the problem of food deserts  low-income neighborhoods lacking access to healthful, affordable food. (More than 23 million Americans live in such places, according to the Department of Agriculture, which maps them here.)

title: After Years of Clearing Boards, Charles Oakley Takes to Buffing Cars
description: On a recent sunny afternoon, unaware drivers who pulled into the car wash on Central Park Avenue in Yonkers might have thought they had seen an apparition when they saw a 6-foot-9 man in a black T-shirt and jeans vacuuming and wiping down cars.

title: Syria Says Its Accepted Plan to End Crackdown
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syria said Tuesday that it had reached agreement with an Arab League delegation on a road map to end more than seven months of bloodshed and start a dialogue between the opposition and the government of President Bashar al-Assad.

title: Check Your Receipt: It May Be Tainted
description: Over eight billion pounds of bisphenol-A, a chemical compound used in making plastic products and the linings of tin cans, are produced annually worldwide. Known as BPA, the substance turns up in human tissues, too.

title: G4S Pulls Bid for Rival Security Firm ISS
description: LONDON  G4S, the worlds largest provider of security services, has abandoned its roughly $8.2 billion bid for a rival, ISS of Denmark, after G4S shareholders balked at the takeover plan.

title: Artists File Lawsuits, Seeking Royalties
description: When the taxi baron Robert Scull sold part of his art collection in a 1973 auction that helped inaugurate todays money-soused contemporary-art market, several artists watched the proceedings from a standing-room-only section in the back. There, Robert Rauschenberg saw his 1958 painting Thaw, originally sold to Scull for $900, bring down the gavel at $85,000. At the end of the Sotheby Parke Bernet sale in New York, Rauschenberg shoved Scull and yelled that he didnt work so hard just for you to make that profit.

title: Pixars John Lasseter Answers Your Questions
description: Pixar Animation Studios hasnt made a big deal of turning 25 this year. But it can celebrate several achievements, including its perfect 12-hit record at the box office, capped this year by Cars 2, which is being released on DVD on Tuesday. It hasnt been an easy year, though: There was the passing of Steven P. Jobs, who helped build Pixar Animation Studios and who was crucial to the companys success, and unusual for a Pixar film, Cars 2 met with mixed critical reaction. Still at this quarter-century milestone, John Lasseter, the studios chief creative officer, agreed to answer selected reader questions. Here are his responses, submitted by e-mail.

title: When Spell-Check Cant Help

Corzine, a former New Jersey governor and United States senator, several people briefed on the matter said on Monday.

title: Eurodmmerung
description: Things are falling apart in Europe; the center is not holding. Papandreou is going to hold a referendum; the vote will be no. Italian 10-years at 6.29 at pixel time; thats a level at which the cost of rolling over the existing debt will force a default, even though Italy has a primary surplus. And with everyone simultaneously pushing for fiscal austerity, a recession seems almost certain, aggravating all of the continents problems.

title: Goldikova in Position to Add to Her Record in the Mile
description: At last years Breeders Cup, somewhat obscured by the blazing mare Zenyatta, Goldikova made history by winning her third Breeders Cup Mile. This week Goldikova is at Churchill Downs preparing to take home an unprecedented fourth victory in the Mile.

title: BB&T to Buy Assets From BankAtlantic
description: BB&T agreed on Tuesday to buy the bulk of BankAtlantic in a move to expand BB&Ts footprint in the Southeast.

description: The architect Robert A.M. Stern has been selected to design the American Revolution Center museum just steps from Independence Hall and the Liberty Bell in Philadelphias historic area, the center announced Tuesday.

title: Groupon Amends Its Prospectus, Again
description: Another day, another amended Groupon prospectus  this one only days before the company prices its initial public offering.

title: The Power of Myth, Kid-Lit Version
description: Of the many gifts Rick Riordan has bequeathed to the world of childrens literature, the one most fervently embraced by teachers and librarians may well be the interest in mythology he has awakened in children. Other authors have been following his lead, with two excellent new nonfiction books for middle graders, Gifts From the Gods, by Lise Lunge-Larsen, and Treasury of Greek Mythology, by Donna Jo Napoli, out now. Classics majors, linguists and otherwise literary-minded parents will greatly appreciate these books  as will their actual intended audience of young readers.

title: Graduates Versus Oligarchs
description: Dean Baker raises an important point here: its really awfully late in the game to be saying that the important inequality issue is college graduates versus non-graduates. Its not clear that this was ever true, and it certainly hasnt been true for a while.

title: China Seeks $2.4 Million in Taxes From Dissident
description: BEIJING  Ai Weiwei, the dissident artist whose detention earlier this year stirred an international outcry, has been given two weeks to pay $2.4 million in back taxes and penalties, he said Tuesday.

title: What Were Reading
description: Salon: Some help for those trying to resist the temptation of leftover Halloween swag: a sobering morning-after trek through the unsavory history of candy. Snake oil, slavery, exploitation of immigrants: it all helped build that little fun-size bomb youre craving.  Patrick Farrell

title: Cellphones: Why Not Use Them to Teach?

title: Q&A: Holiday Vacation for a Family of Four
description: Were a family of four with two 7-year-olds. We live in Washington, D.C., and New York City and are looking for an active family vacation within driving distance of either for four or five nights during the week between Christmas and New Years. Ive looked at Mohonk Mountain House and at Wintergreen Resort. Any great ideas? We dont necessarily need a big resort type of place, but rustic alone wont work; we need some activities.

title: JPMorgan Shuffles Its Capital Markets Leadership
description: JPMorgan Chase has reorganized the management of its capital markets operations, naming separate global leadership teams to oversee both equity and debt capital markets, the firm announced in an internal memorandum reviewed by DealBook on Tuesday.

title: F.T.C: No App to Cure Acne

title: Japanese Official Drinks Water From Fukushima Reactor Buildings
description: After insisting for weeks that water collected from reactor buildings at the stricken Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant posed no threat to human health once it was decontaminated, a Japanese government official poured himself a glass of the liquid and drank it on live television on Monday.

title: Auto Sales Reach an 8-Month High, Helped by Stable Gas Prices
description: DETROIT  Consumers took advantage of stable gas prices and bought more trucks and sport utility vehicles, which helped push up the sales of new automobiles in the United States to an eight-month high in October.

title: Its Never Too Early to Start Handicapping
description: The fields have been drawn for both days of this years Breeders Cup. With the benefit of post positions and morning-line odds, its time to get down to the business of handicapping racings greatest day(s). Some initial thoughts:

title: The Elephant in the Room
description: The connection between population growth and environmental degradation seems clear enough  the more people there are, the more greenhouse gases are emitted and the more resources are consumed. But as I report in Tuesdays Times, the population issue has been conspicuously absent from the public discourse on global warming in the United States.

title: Detective Is Found Guilty of Planting Drugs
description: The New York Police Department, already saddled with corruption scandals, saw its image further tainted on Tuesday with the conviction of a detective for planting drugs on a woman and her boyfriend.

title: Romney and Cain Pass on Iowa G.O.P. Dinner
description: On the campaign trail, Mitt Romney likes to quote Ronald Reagan, quipping that liberals arent ignorant  its just that what they know is wrong.

title: Before Kim and Kris, There Was Ethel and Ernest
description: It was a storybook celebrity marriage that captured a publics imagination, and then suddenly it was over before they even had a chance to complete their wedding registry. No, not Kim Kardashian and Kris Humphries, who devastated the American populace when Mrs. filed for divorce from Mr. on Monday; were talking about a couple whose all-too-brief union makes the 72 days of Kardashian-Humphries nuptial bliss seem as old as the cosmos itself. That would be Ernest Borgnine and Ethel Merman, who separated after five weeks of marriage in 1964.

title: Shearling Breaks Out
description: DESIGNERS have not been content to confine their use of shearling this season to linings and trim; its all over their accessories. Viktor & Rolfs high-heel platform booties are completely covered  best for a non-snow day. Among the bags, a Cline mini-luggage model, a Marni tote and a Miu Miu with a braided top handle are carpeted in the curly stuff. We like this Jerome Dreyfuss shearling one, with black or burgundy leather. Carrying it is like throwing your favorite shearling-lined leather jacket over your arm. But the pockets are deeper.

title: Prayer for Relief to Miss Breeders Cup Classic
description: The West Virginia Derby champion Prayer for Relief is out for Saturdays $5 million Breeders Cup Classic at Churchill Downs after failing to board a flight from Southern California early Tuesday morning along with other contenders trained by Bob Baffert.

title: It Takes a Village
description: Youll have to find your own spot at the folding metal table that Deirdre Foley-Mendelssohn and Peter Stella use when entertaining at their apartment on Christopher Street. Neither believes in seating charts, opting instead to let guests fend for themselves among the mismatched plates, found silverware and batik napkins from Indonesia. Stella, 29, a medical and M.B.A. graduate student, grew up in the neighborhood, and the couple takes full advantage of their local farmers market and the many West Village specialty stores. Super-simple ingredients make everything better, says the 28-year-old Foley-Mendelssohn, a senior editor at The Paris Review, who carries provisions in a wicker basket on her vintage Schwinn bike. Peters more of a traditionalist when it comes to cooking, inclined to think that a pasta with too many ingredients is actually a salad. Go to slide show >>

title: Dorothy Rodham, Mother and Mentor of Hillary Clinton, Is Dead at 92
description: Dorothy Rodham, who overcame years of struggle to become a powerful influence on the life and career of her daughter, Hillary Rodham Clinton, the first lady, senator from New York, presidential candidate and now secretary of state, died on Tuesday in Washington. She was 92.

title: Civility on the Brink
description: Scholars of Southern culture see manners on the decline, eroded by modern life and its complexities.

title: A Last Bastion of Civility, the South, Sees Manners Decline
description: ATLANTA  One August night, two men walked into a popular restaurant attached to this citys fanciest shopping mall. They sat at the bar, ordered drinks and pondered the menu. Two women stood behind them.

title: CME Investigating MF Global
description: The investigation into hundreds of millions of dollars in missing money at MF Global has widened, as the CME Group confirmed on Tuesday that the brokerage firm failed to keep customer money separate from company money.

description: Time to strap on your green visor and sharpen your red pencil.

title: For N.F.L. Quarterbacks, Days, and Plays, to Forget
description: Today, we welcome San Diego quarterback Philip Rivers to the sports dartboard. Step right up, Mr. Rivers. Yes, youve been here before. Tim Tebow will happily give up the seat for you, although, Mr. Tebow, you didnt actually seem to mind your time there. You seem dart-proof, which comes in handy when youre Tim Tebow. We hear the Broncos are starting you again Sunday, so well see you again on Monday.

title: Company Ordered to Stop Selling Uninspected Poultry to Retailers
description: A Queens slaughterhouse that had been selling thousands of pounds of uninspected poultry to local supermarkets has been enjoined from the practice by a court-approved decree announced Tuesday by federal prosecutors.

description: Elementary and middle school students have improved greatly in math, but their reading skills have stagnated over the last two decades, federal officials said on Tuesday.

description: The record-breaking late-October snowstorm, which buried some northern New England towns in snow (up to 31 inches) and snapped trees like twigs, may be the final blow to an already lackluster foliage season.

title: London Cathedral Stops Legal Action Against Protesters
description: LONDON  St. Pauls Cathedral has suspended legal action to evict hundreds of anti-capitalist protesters camped outside its doors, according to a statement on Tuesday.

title: Herman Cain and the Liberal Media
description: Ive always been impressed, well alarmed really, at how quickly the right wing jumps on an issue almost in unison. This week, it was the news that Herman Cain, one of the contenders for the Republican presidential nomination, was accused of sexual harassment when he was running the National Restaurant Association.

description: One problem with blogging is that at any given time many of your readers dont know about ground youve already covered. Ive tried to remedy that in part with my list of macroeconomics posts over to the right  before commenting on my macro analysis, you might want to read them. Still, it sometimes helps to repost an earlier argument.

title: Cashman, With His Own New Deal, Sets Pitching as Yankees Priority
description: In a matter of hours, the Yankees resolved their two biggest off-season issues. They announced Tuesday morning that General Manager Brian Cashman had signed a three-year contract extension, less than a day after they agreed with C. C. Sabathia on a contract extension that will keep him in pinstripes at least through 2016.

title: $10 Million Gift for Study of White House History
description: WASHINGTON  More than a million visitors traipse through the White House each year, hoping for a glimpse of its occupants, yet there is no central place for the study of the building itself. Now the nonprofit White House Historical Association has received a $10 million gift toward a long-held goal of converting its historic headquarters  including a carriage house that contains a rare example of urban slave quarters  into a National Center for White House History.

title: For Bird Lovers, a Race to the Finish
description: When people think about birds in games these days, they are usually of the angry variety. But a different kind of game is unfolding on the Web, with 34 pecking and chirping species just daring users to catch them.

title: Readers Respond: Not-So-Super Committee
description: Todays lead editorial takes the deficit-reduction supercommittee to task, scolding the Republicans for their continued fierce obstructionism, and the Democrats for being too accommodating. The editorial board argues that the Democrats proposed cuts to domestic spending and social-insurance programs are so large as to be imprudent.

title: Ex-Treasurer Pleads Guilty to Embezzling From Brooklyn PTA
description: Providence Hogan, the former PTA treasurer at Public School 29 in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, pleaded guilty to three counts of grand larceny in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn on Tuesday and handed over a check for $50,000, while agreeing to pay back the remainder of the money she embezzled  $32,392.91  over two years.

title: Investors Check Out Honeymoon in Vegas Workshop
description: A long-gestating musical adaptation of the 1992 movie Honeymoon in Vegas, which is perhaps best remembered for its skydiving team of Flying Elvises, was staged in a private workshop last week for theater investors with an eye toward a future production in New York or regionally, according to one of its producers.

description: As Herman Cain continues to face intense questioning about sex harassment allegations, some have wondered whether his wife, Gloria, will come forward to make a statement of support.

title: What We Learn (or Dont) From Test Scores
description: I was devastated by Michael Winerips article on how the No Child Left Behind Act has affected the creative teaching at a New Hampshire middle school. It used to be that eighth graders at Oyster River Middle School chose semester-long genre projects in English class. Theyd pick a subject area like mysteries, read masters like Agatha Christie, study the writers craftsmanship (Explain how the author foreshadows doom), then draft their own. In science class they would spend two weeks building a real underwater vessel; in social studies they re-enacted the Boston Massacre.

title: In Cheating Verdict, a Milestone for Crickets New Era
description: LONDON  After a trial that many saw as a turning point for the game of cricket, a jury found two former members of Pakistans national team guilty Tuesday of conspiracy to cheat in a contest with England last summer at Lords, the London ground that is regarded as the spiritual home of the game.

title: Pandora Extends Its Reach to Businesses
description: In six years, the Internet radio service Pandora has made its way to more than 100 million personal computers, cars and home entertainment systems. Now, in an effort to find new sources of income, it also is coming to shopping malls, doctors offices and restaurants.

title: Art World Watches Closely as Auction Season Starts
description: As the fall auction season kicks off on Tuesday night in New York, the art world will be watching closely to see how the turmoil in the worlds financial markets affects the bidding. This week, all eyes will be on the sales of Impressionist and modern art at Christies (Tuesday night) and Sothebys (Wednesday), where hundreds of millions of dollars worth of work by masters like Degas and Picasso, Giacometti and Magritte will be up for sale. As has happened in the past, collectors may feel safer investing in a painting or sculpture than in the stock market, making for a buoyant round of auctions. Or, as has also occurred, nerves and outright fear could lead to stagnant sales and flat prices. Stay tuned.

title: After the Series, Appreciating Tony La Russa One Last Time
description: He wasnt the most popular manager in the game. Matter of fact, maybe he was the least popular.

title: Avery, Demoted Agitator, Is Poised to Rejoin Rangers
description: Sean Averys career with the Rangers, thought to be finished not long ago, has resumed.

title: On Our Radar: Smog Dispute in Beijing
description: With smog blanketing Beijing, residents take issue with the Chinese governments estimates of air pollution, citing different readings from the American Embassy. The government acknowledges the concerns and says it uses a different metric to measure the pollution. [CNN]

title: Flatter Than Ever?
Clip: The Other F Word
description: In this clip from the documentary The Other F Word, Fatt Mike, the lead singer of NOFX, tends to his second job, that of parenting his daughter.

title: New Leader Says U.S. Base in Kyrgyzstan Will Be Shut
description: OSH, Kyrgyzstan  In one of his first statements as Kyrgyzstans new president, Almazbek Atambayev said Tuesday that he would seek to close an important American military base when its lease runs out in 2014, reviving a threat dropped by past leaders after the United States agreed to increased payments.

title: The Sugar Stimulus
description: Before Halloween, the National Confectioners Association estimated that Americans spent more than $2.2 billion on candy  a new record. That works out to approximately $7.36 per person. Confectioners produced some 35 million pounds of candy corn for the season, or 27 syrup-cones for each and every one of us.

title: City Finds Possible Cause of Fire at Harlem Sewage Plant
description: The four-alarm fire that shut down a Harlem sewage treatment plant in July, sending hundreds of millions of gallons of wastewater into New York Citys waterways, was probably caused by a single, improperly tightened nut, according to a report the citys Department of Environmental Protection released on Tuesday.

title: COPO Camaro: A Quarter-Miler With an Insiders Pedigree
description: LAS VEGAS  Chevrolet is bringing back the quarter pounder.

title: Book Report: Who Speaks for the Climate?
description: Robert J. Brulle, a sociologist at Drexel University, has for years been been a valuable guide for me to the large, and largely under-appreciated, body of behavioral research illuminating why its so hard to gain traction on the super wicked problem of human-driven climate change.

title: Fraud and Loopholes Deliver Small-Business Contracts to Big Firms
description: Its been a busy season for combating fraud in government contracts for small business, for prosecutors enforcing the law as well as the legislators trying to improve it. But for both, it appears to be an uphill battle.

title: Hating Incumbency and Incumbents Too
description: WASHINGTON  One of the immutable laws of American politics has been that while voters typically loathe Congress, they tend to tolerate their own lawmaker. Now, with ratings for that institution in the root cellar and approval of individual lawmakers heading there, members of Congress and analysts are beginning to wonder if that law could be repealed next year.

description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. National Team Data Dive: Ratings, Stats and Opinions
description: Want to get a quick sense of how Albert Pujols performed in game 3 of the World Series? No problem. Simply find a box score and in a matter of seconds you can see that Pujols went 5 for 6 with three homers, four runs scored and six R.B.I. He batted third and played first base, and oh, by the way, he was 1 for 1 with runners in scoring position and drove in three two-out runs.

title: Is the Web Amplifying Consumers Voices?
description: First, Netflix dropped its plan to make customers have separate accounts for mail order and online movies. Now, Bank of America has reversed plans to charge a $5 monthly fee for some customers who use their debit cards to make purchases. Both decisions came after the original plans were sharply criticized by their customers.

description: Adapted from Adam Gopnik

title: Adam Gopnik on the Days of Great French Dining
description: YOU feel transported, Adam Gopnik said, moments after easing into a red banquette at La Grenouille, the Gallic grande dame on East 52nd Street that made its debut a few weeks after the Cuban missile crisis. This is a reminder of why there were great French restaurants, once upon a time.

title: Middle School Angst Gets Its Hour
Newspaper Circulation Figures Show Some Digital Growth
description: Some of the nations largest newspapers are recording gains in digital circulation as print circulation continues to weaken, a trend that is helping to ease what has become a relentless overall decline in recent years.

title: Reactor in Japan Restarts, a First Since the Tsunami
description: TOKYO  A nuclear reactor in western Japan began starting back up on Tuesday after a months hiatus, the first reactor in the country closed for any reason to win approval from a local government to resume operations since the Fukushima nuclear disaster.

title: As Miles Add Up, So Do the Unforgettable Moments
description: By nature, a marathon promotes melodrama. Weary minds make bad decisions. Overused muscles malfunction. Logistical challenges create unexpected mishaps. A zoned-in runner misreads the course and stumbles in midstride or falls. The latter happened to Bill Rodgers in the 1980 New York City Marathon when he fell over Dick Beardsley, who had tripped in a pothole, and finished fifth. Rodgers had won New York the four previous years.

title: For Trailing Candidates, Encouraging Words in Iowa
description: PELLA, Iowa  Mitt Romney wasnt there. Nor was Herman Cain. But for the five Republican presidential candidates who did appear, Terry E. Branstad, the Republican governor of Iowa, offered encouraging words, as they all gathered on Tuesday at a National Association of Manufacturers forum.

title: MoMA Plans New Antony and the Johnsons Work to Take Flight at Radio City
description: The Museum of Modern Art is not getting into the concert promotion business just yet, but its latest commission has, at least on paper, the components and the pedigree of a pop-music spectacle.

description: Arnal Choco

title: Drawing Dance: The Cunningham Company in Seattle
description: The Brooklyn artist Kenneth E. Parris III is on tour with members of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, documenting, through a series of drawings and paintings, their two-year Legacy Tour. After 58 years the company is scheduled to disband on New Years Day 2012. This is the 17th in a series of graphite drawings Mr. Parris plans to create from the road, providing a front-row seat to the final weeks of the companys journey. This weeks entry is from Seattle.

title: First Came the Egg | Nora Kogans Ode to Faberg
description: Nora Kogan, the Brooklyn jewelry designer behind St. Kilda, is known for costume pieces like the Surrealist-inspired Man Ray lip cuffs that are favored by fashion insiders like the blogger Garance Dor. Shes now designing higher-end baubles under her own name. The first Nora Kogan collection, Anastasia, is inspired by a Faberg egg that, according to family lore, her Russian grandfather acquired during World War II in exchange for a box of chocolates. The egg disappeared  presumably into the pockets of a Soviet customs official  when the family immigrated to Australia in the 1970s, but Kogan retains clear memories of it. It opened up into three sections, and in the center was a hand-painted icon, recalls Kogan, who riffs on Fabergs legendary craftsmanship and stylized nature motifs in pieces like these diamond drop earrings and ring. Designing this collection has been therapeutic for me as Im still often haunted by this loss.

title: Another View: Can Groupons I.P.O. Be Saved?
description: Anthony H. Catanach Jr. is an associate accounting professor at the Villanova School of Business and a Cary M. Maguire fellow at the American College. J. Edward Ketz is an associate accounting professor at the Smeal College of Business at Pennsylvania State University.

title: Survey Finds Chain Stores Spreading More Slowly
description: New York City may have reached its Dunkin point.

description: For decades, the New-York Historical Society has struggled against the architecture of its own building, which conveys  in its cold grandeur  an institution that is insular, impenetrable and inscrutable.

title: PTA Treasurer Admits Guilt and Will Pay Back What She Stole
Winter Squash With Anchovies, Capers, Olives and Ricotta Salata
description: Adapted from a recipe in Clifford A. Wrights book Mediterranean Vegetables, this is another Italian recipe for winter squash (or pumpkin, to Italians), this time from the southern region of Apulia. Its a delicious contrast of sweet and savory. Serve it as a side dish, toss it with pasta or use it as a topping for squash blini. The seasoning is provided by the anchovies, capers and cheese, a salty contrast to the sweet squash (the recipe is not for you if you cannot eat salt).

title: 10 Ways to Teach About Election Day
description: Any election  whether off-year, midterm or presidential and whether local, state or federal  presents opportunities for learning about civics and how government actually works as well as the importance of active citizenship.

title: Simple Provenal Winter Squash Gratin
description: Ive offered a few winter squash gratin recipes over the years, but none as simple as this one. Theres little more than squash here, seasoned with lots of garlic and fresh herbs. Dicing all the squash takes time, but then the work is just about done. If you want to use a food processor, you can, but you cant get even pieces that way. The recipe is based on one of my favorite recipes in Richard Olneys book Simple French Food.

title: Shaken Baby Syndrome
description: The Republican presidential candidates Newt Gingrich and Rick Santorum say the Ninth Circuit appeals court, based in San Francisco, should be abolished because they often disagree with its rulings. Apparently the appellate court has some detractors on the Supreme Court, too.
