description: Most politicians hate loss, but not when it applies to their waistline.

title: Tokyo String Quartet Losing Two Members
description: Two members of the Tokyo String Quartet, including its founding violist, will retire from the group at the end of next season, in June 2013, the ensemble said in a statement from its public relations firm on Tuesday. The violist, Kazuhide Isomura, 65, helped start the quartet in 1969. Also leaving is the second violinist, Kikuei Ikeda, 64, who joined in 1974.

title: Cashew Apples, VW Bugs and Waterfalls in Pirenpolis, Brazil
description: Sometimes in little towns in far-off lands, you do things you wouldnt do at home, like hanging on the back half of a motorbike as it jolts over unpaved country roads. In Pirenpolis, Brazil, a cute, cobblestoned colonial town 85 miles west of Braslia, moto-taxis are the public transportation system and the main way, if youre not part of a tour group, to get to the waterfalls that dot the surrounding hills. You get a helmet of your own and, if youre lucky, a driver named Wesley, who for one great Tuesday morning in early September also served as my de facto tour guide. We hiked on hilly trails and dived into waterfalls, and Wesley dashed into the brush to pluck juicy, tannin-packed cashew apples for us to snack on.

title: Coach Inc. Agrees to Occupy Third of Hudson Yards Tower
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said Tuesday that Coach Inc. would buy over 600,000 square feet in the first tower of the Hudson Yards site  in a major step forward for the long-gestating development project.

title: Charles Addamss New York
description: Images from an exhibit at the Museum of the City of New York.

title: A Few Drinks a Week Raises Breast Cancer Risk
description: Some women who drink to their health may want to reconsider. A new study shows that women who routinely have even small amounts of alcohol, as few as three drinks a week, have an elevated risk of breast cancer.

title: Pictures of the Day: Nepal and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Nepal, Afghanistan, Libya and Yemen.

title: Tigers Ponder Future, Which Will Not Include Ordonez or Guillen
description: Falling just short of the World Series, the Tigers now face an off-season of decisions, and while General Manager Dave Dombrowski is not considering a Yankees-style shopping spree, he does have some moves to try to make an already good team better. The Tigers lost the American League Championship Series to Texas in six games after a strong season that produced the teams first A.L. Central title since 1987.

title: In San Diego, Mulling the Second Life of an E.V. Battery
description: There is no denying how cost-intensive battery packs are for manufacturers of electric vehicles. A possible strategy for defraying those costs would involve giving them a second, stationary life as backup power for the electrical grid.

title: Obstacles Hinder Formation of Afghan Security Force, Report Says
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  President Hamid Karzais plan to disband private security companies that protect billions of dollars worth of aid projects and replace them with government forces is fraught with problems and unlikely to meet the presidents March deadline to complete the transition, according to a six-month assessment of the program.

title: More Seats for Lower Manhattan, But Not Right Away
Union Claims Nearly a Million Students Hit by Budget Cuts
Civil War Diarists Photo Collection to Go on View in South Carolina
description: Mary Boykin Chesnuts diary offers a first-person view of the Civil War from the upper reaches of Southern society. She details what it was like to sit atop a house in Charleston, S.C., and watch the shelling of Fort Sumter, and, later, what it was like in Chester, S.C., to receive news of Robert E. Lees surrender at Appomattox, with the Elite of the Confederacy  going and coming  and when night comes  more beds are made on the floor of the landing place. The whole house is a bivouac.

title: My Three Favorite New Yorker Cartoons
description: This week, a redesign of the Conde Nast Web site went live, including a change in the Cartoon Bank, which sells prints of old New Yorker cartoons and is one of my favorite places to visit. To mark the occasion, here are my three favorite New Yorker cartoons. By favorite in this exercise, I mean the three that shaped my image of what a New Yorker cartoon is. It may be nothing like your image of the quintessential New Yorker cartoon, but my tastes have always been simple, like the fictional New Yorker editor on Seinfeld whose justification for running a certain abstruse cartoon was: I like the kitty.

title: Coming Into a Crowded World
description: Lynsey Addario photographs a maternity ward in Delhi, India as the world population reaches seven billion.

title: #OccupyWallSt Roundup, Day 46
description: Snow and cold are on everyones minds, but downtown, there are other issues, too.

title: Few Treats for Networks on Halloween
description: Nielsen families must also be avid trick-or-treaters if the broadcast ratings from Halloween are any indication. Many network shows fell to season, or in some cases, series lows, on Monday night.

title: A 556-Horsepower Chevelle With Earnhardt Touches Introduces G.M.s Crate Performance Packages
description: LAS VEGAS  The Nascar driver Dale Earnhardt Jr. was on hand at the Specialty Equipment Market Association trade show this week to introduce a 1970 Chevelle SS with a 2011 twist: the first installation of a new powertrain system, called Connect and Cruise, being offered by Chevrolet Performance.

title: Michael Bloomberg, Ignoramus
description: Via David Dayen, the favored candidate of those who believe we need a smart centrist to solve our nations problems reveals himself to be completely ignorant about the causes of our economic crisis, someone who just swallows right-wing propaganda whole:

title: How Cains Story Has Changed
description: As soon as the sexual harassment allegations against Herman Cain surfaced on Sunday night, the candidate himself started talking. And with each interview, his story shifted.

title: Report Hashes Out Battle Plan Against Military Suicides
description: With military suicides remaining at a stubbornly high level in recent years, there has been no shortage of calls to action. But this week the Center for a New American Security, an influential military policy group in Washington, offered some specific recommendations for what the armed services, Department of Veterans Affairs and Congress could do to bring the rate down.

title: Olympus Scandal Reveals How Little Japan Has Changed
description: If there were any doubt remaining, the scandal surrounding the Olympus Corporation of Japan has proved Michael Crichton wrong. What does the late Mr. Crichton, the author of Jurassic Park among other books, have to do with this, you may be asking?

title: Rainbow Brights
description: When the designer Bibhu Mohapatra visited Rachel Dooleys studio in search of a birthday gift for a friend just months after theyd both been inducted into the CFDA Fashion Incubator, he found the Gemma Redux jewelry designer only too happy to make a swap. Necklace for a coat  sweet deal for me! Dooley says of the exchange. Soon thereafter the two friends started plotting a joint venture  the first to emerge from the CFDAs incubator program. Their 10-piece offering, which made its debut at Mohapatras spring presentation during New York Fashion Week, includes bangles with an iridescent finish that Dooley describes as totally trippy. The geode ring and pendant, which are cast in brass and then glossed in super-saturated prismatic hues, pair especially well with Mohapatras orange harem pants; the long brushed bronze earrings look best with the designers floor-skimming gowns. Those bar earrings just accentuate the collections linear silhouettes, Mohapatra explains. They add just enough shine.

title: How About Affirming That the Seas Are Still Shining?
description: From time to time someone in Congress floats the idea of a constitutional amendment to outlaw flag burning, which the Supreme Court has ruled is protected by the First Amendment. And from time to time, the editorial page reminds readers that such proposals are nothing more than pandering  by politicians on the right trying to please their base, or by politicians on the left hoping to look less, well, left. Flag-burning, as we wrote in 2005, hasnt been in fashion since college students used slide rules in math class and went to pay phones at the student union to call their friends. Even then, it was a rarity that certainly never put the nations security in peril.

title: Socializing for a Cause
description: The publicity firm founded by two New Yorkers who are no strangers to high society specializes in gathering their friends for charitable fund-raising events.

title: The World of Hunger Has a New Language
description: THE terms food desert and food insecurity are part of the new language of hunger.

title: H.P. Builds Servers With Cellphone Chips
description: Hewlett-Packard announced on Tuesday a new design for some of the worlds largest computer centers and says it could reduce power consumption in some cases by 90 percent.

title: Scene City: Heidi Klums Halloween Party
description: A Gremlin, Black Swans, Zoolander and a couple of simians party at the PH-D Rooftop Lounge.

title: In Doling Out Economic Incentives, Bloomberg Looks Outside Manhattan
description: Updated 6:47 p.m. | Under Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, New York City has continued to give tax breaks and other financial incentives to businesses, but he has spread them more widely around the city than his predecessor, Rudolph W. Giuliani, according to a study released on Tuesday by the citys Independent Budget Office.

title: Project Halloween
description: SOMEWHERE amid modeling for Victorias Secret, producing a reality TV franchise and designing clothing lines, Heidi Klum became known as the Queen of Halloween. In years past, she transformed herself with over-the-top costumes like Lady Godiva, the Hindu goddess Kali and a robotic superhero.

title: An Appetite for Discussion
description: You may have noticed that we have become, as a nation, kind of obsessed with eating. Obsessed in the same way that many of us used to be obsessed with listening to music.

title: Food Delivered, Fresh and Free
description: A nonprofit agency delivers fresh meat, produce and other healthful foods to hungry people in an area near Boston with no supermarkets.

title: Carriage Horse That Died Was Sickly, A.S.P.C.A. Reports
description: A carriage horse that collapsed and died on the job last week was not a healthy horse and suffered from stomach ulcers, among other things, the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals said.

title: Peanut Butter Plus
description: Abbott Laboratories is helping Haitians build a self-sustaining enterprise making a nutritional supplement.

title: A Peek at Punk Paternity as Rockers Raise Families
description: Dedicated to proving that punk rockers can not only procreate but also follow through with the aftercare, The Other F Word invites a cross-section of aging bad boys to dish on the demands of fatherhood.

title: Setting a Clubfoot Straight
description: Dr.Ignacio Ponsetis decades-old method of correcting clubfoot works in up to 98 percent of cases, and can be taught to nondoctors, making it a treatment that can be readily transferred anywhere.

title: The Upside of Gifts Made Directly From I.R.A.s
description: AN important tax break for retired people expired last year, then was renewed but too late for most eligible people to take advantage of it. Now the provision, which allows people who are 70 1/2 or older to make charitable donations of up to $100,000 directly from their I.R.A.s, is available through Dec. 31.

title: In the Company of Animals, Healing for Humans
description: SOPHIE is a goat whose taste in books leans toward popular best sellers, says Solana Mejia-Schnaufer, who reads aloud to her several times a week. I know she likes The Hunger Games because she didnt try to eat it. That wasnt true of Animal Liberation.

title: Marriage May End; Wedding Went On
description: When the news leaked at midday on Monday that one of the biggest stars on E!, Kim Kardashian, was divorcing her husband after a mere two months, the channel had a quick decision to make. Keep on its schedule the daily repeats of Kims Fairytale Wedding, a four-hour extravaganza that it reportedly paid millions of dollars to televise? Or yank the repeats now that reality had so rudely intruded?

title: Tax Rules Allow an Array of Givers to Be More Generous
description: IF you, like most charitably inclined people, wish you could afford to give more, the good news is that you probably can, simply by taking advantage of the tax codes provisions that effectively make Uncle Sam your partner in giving.

title: Speaking Up to Honor the Quiet Work of Librarians
description: IN a city where philanthropy has to rise to more than a $1 million to grab headlines, a gift of $2,000 may not seem all that noteworthy. But every year for the last 23 years, such a gift has made a great difference to two librarians in the New York Public Library who are selected by their colleagues to receive a $2,000 prize from the Bertha Franklin Feder Award program.

title: A Horoscope That Prompts a Long Journey
description: There are times when Five Star Day lulls you into thinking youre watching a pretty sophisticated movie. The writer and director, Danny Buday, shows flashes of subtlety and makes the occasional unexpected choice. But a drippy ending erases all the hopes youve built up and forces you to conclude that this wasnt such a well-thought-out film after all.

title: Sirius XM Profit Grows, but Subscription Growth Fails to Meet Expectations
description: Profit at Sirius XM Radio grew by more than 50 percent in the third quarter, and its subscription numbers hit a high of 21.3 million, the company reported on Tuesday. But analysts were disappointed by Siriuss subscription growth rate, and the stock fell 3.35 percent for the day, to $1.73.

title: In Afterword, Ravitch Brings Things Up to Date
Rosy Nostalgia and Sharp Reality Entwine in a Potent Jig
description: The narrator of Dancing at Lughnasa drifts back to his most vivid recollection of late summer 1936 when, he says, In that memory atmosphere is more real than incident and everything is simultaneously actual and illusory.

title: Reviewing Saxon & Parole
description: Back when I was on the restaurant beat full time, I used to know all the best places in New York to get a hamburger. Now I have to rely on other authorities to get my burger information.

title: Conjuring the Past, Feeding the Present
description: BRAD FARMERIE, the executive chef at the new NoHo restaurant Saxon & Parole, is nothing if not versatile. When his restaurant Double Crown, a culinary fantasy of British imperialism in Asia, closed this summer, Mr. Farmerie and his partners, AvroKO Hospitality Group, quickly created an entirely different mood, aura and menu in the same space, as if they were stagehands changing sets between acts at the Metropolitan Opera.

title: Honk-Honks and Melodies: Two Sides of the Atlantic Meet
description: On certain nights in the tiny town of Dingle, Ireland, residents can hear the strains of music coming from an ancient church, with musicians from around the world having made the long journey to the westernmost edge of the country. And on other nights  the local fishermen will swear by this  you can hear the distant sounds of Manhattan traffic leaping across the Atlantic into the mists just off the coast.

title: Two Shores Meet in the Village
description: Other Voices, an Irish television program, took up residence at Le Poisson Rouge last week.

title: Occupy Protesters Focus on Iowa Caucuses
description: A group called Occupy Iowa is urging like-minded protesters from across the country to descend on the Iowa headquarters of the presidential candidates the week before the caucuses, which will be held Jan. 3.

title: Empty Times Square Is Fantasy; The Stranger Stuff Is Science
description: You might want to think twice, if you cherish your notions of reality, before accepting a ride from Brian Greene.

title: Two Vendors at Metropolitan Museum Are Carted Away by Police
description: In the continuing battles over who gets to sell hot dogs in front of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the city cracked down on Tuesday on two military veterans who have each operated pushcarts in front of the museum despite city orders to stop.

title: A Busy Soloist, Working at Collaboration
description: Some soloists spend their lives shuttling around the world, trotting out standard works for the umpteenth time. Others often refresh their repertory and always seem to have some innovative project under way.

title: French Pastries Find a Home in SoHo
description: Dominique Ansel, below, who was the pastry chef at Daniel for six years and worked at Fauchon in Paris before that, opens his own pastry shop and cafe Wednesday. Besides croissants, macarons and clairs, he is baking a few specialties that are not everyday indulgences in New York. Among them is a tall fluted cake, the gteau battu, which comes from Mr. Ansels native Picardy, north of Paris, and is halfway between brioche and poundcake but lighter than either one. He sells the whole cake or slices, excellent with soft butter and jam. He is also baking kouign-amann, a flaky, crispy little Breton pastry, which a few American chefs are starting to feature on their menus. His take on the Paris-Brest, a filled ring of cream puff pastry, is called Paris-New York (above) and has caramel, peanuts and chocolate. His menu also includes savory items like sandwiches, quiches, soups and salads. The narrow space with an open kitchen has a few seats and a marble counter, an all-weather greenhouse for seating in the back and a garden.

title: Obama Goes Local in Round of Interviews
description: With his re-election campaign now in full swing, President Obama has been visiting swing states and attending fund-raisers almost every week. Unfortunately, this week hes obligated to travel to a place with no electoral votes: Cannes, France, for the Group of 20 economic summit.

title: U.S. Judge Bars a Suit for Victims of Madoff
description: For the second time this year, a federal judge has barred a court-appointed bankruptcy trustee from seeking billions in damages from big banks and other third parties to help compensate victims of Bernard L. Madoffs giant Ponzi scheme.

title: Euphoria Turns to Discontent as Egypts Revolution Stalls
description: GIZA, Egypt  Lurching around the Great Pyramids on a camel was part of the trip-of-a-lifetime experience that Farag Abu Ghaneima once touted dozens of times a day, but he recently sold three of his five camels to the butcher.

title: Lens: Turning Point  Lazar
description: Lens: Turning Point  Lazar

title: Cain Accuser Wants to Tell Story, Lawyer Says
description: The lawyer for one of the two women who accused Herman Cain of sexual harassment said Tuesday that she wanted to come forward but was bound by a confidentiality agreement with the National Restaurant Association.

title: Some Chase Accounts See Delay in Credit for Deposits
description: Because of a delay in the electronic batch posting of transactions on Monday night, some Chase bank accounts were not credited with deposits as they should have been, a bank spokesman said.

title: The Legend on the N.B.A. Logo, Running Scared
description: Like almost everyone who attended West Virginia University in the late 1950s, my father has a Jerry West story. West was, and is, West Virginias greatest sports legend. His fame was never larger there than in 1959, the year he led the Mountaineers to within one point of a national basketball championship. National championships  or positive recognition of any kind, really  didnt come that often to West Virginia.

title: The Thanksgiving Help Line Is Open
description: Although Sam Sifton wont be manning the Help Line this year, the Dining staff is ready to take your questions on Thanksgiving cooking, drinking, entertaining, or any other holiday hurdles. Tweet us at @nytimesdining using the hashtag #ThanksgivingQs, or post a question below. Theyll be answered in the coming weeks.

title: Postcard From L.S.U.: When a Stadium Was a Dorm
description: BATON ROUGE, La.  In 1931, the administration of Louisiana State University was at odds with Huey Long, the states governor.

title: Top Spanish Ham, Now Found in the United States
description: The top Spanish ham comes from purebred black-footed Ibrico pigs that feed on wild acorns. Now, it is available in the United States. The brand with the most cachet is 5 Jotas, in business for more than 100 years. It took four years to get final approval from federal agencies. At present, the front-leg ham, called the paleta, above, is available. The hind legs, which take longer to cure, will be available in a few months. Slices of 5 Jotas are silky and rosy, with no sign of drying, and a flavor thats irresistibly nutty-sweet, with succulent fat. Dehesa, another, less expensive brand  which says its hams are also from purebred Ibrico pigs, and are raised by members of Covap, a cooperative  will reach American stores in about two weeks. A preview sample of the Dehesa paleta was somewhat deeper in color than the 5 Jotas, but was also nut-sweet, satin-textured and mellow.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening

title: In Egypt, Tourism Remains in a Tailspin
description: Tourism, a buttress of the Egyptian economy, continues to suffer more than eight months after the fall of President Hosni Mubarak.

title: Exploring Bartoks Legacy With Plenty of Energy
description: Master is a term applied too loosely in classical music. To declare someone a master makes it sound as if an artist had reached some benchmark of skill and insight, and every performance said master gave would automatically be masterly. In fact great musicians work constantly and continually challenge themselves.

title: Butter-Blanched Mustard Greens With Mustard Oil
description: Adapted from Home Cooking With Jean-Georges (Clarkson Potter, 2011)

title: Frise Salad with Bloomed Mustard Seed and Mustard Oil
description: Adapted from Laurence Edelman, Left Bank, Manhattan

title: American Chefs Discover Mustard Oil
description: LAURENCE EDELMAN is not a chef who looks often to Asia for culinary inspiration.

title: Occupy Oakland Regroups, Calling for a Strike
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  A week after police in riot gear rousted and then tear-gassed Occupy Oakland protesters, supporters of the movement have rebuilt their encampment in front of City Hall and are calling for a general strike on Wednesday that will include an attempt to shut down the nations fifth-busiest shipping port.

title: Britain, Watching Europe, Seeks to Preserve Influence
description: LONDON  Even as Britain hopes for an end to the debt crisis plaguing the euro zone, it also fears an outcome that may threaten its influence in the European Union and Londons role as a financial center.

title: Putting Zuckerbergs Millions to Work for Schools
description: NEWARK

title: For Injured Veterans, Healing in Service to Others
description: WHILE working with refugees and landmine survivors in Rwanda, Bosnia and Cambodia in the 1990s, a Rhodes scholar named Eric Greitens had an epiphany about teenagers in traumatic circumstances: the ones who fared best were the ones who helped others.

title: Dance Devotee Stays in Motion
description: GIVEN that she is 77 years old and has been on the board of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater for 17 years, 11 as chairwoman, Joan H. Weill clearly does not need to serve any longer. She could simply be enjoying time with her husband, Sanford I. Weill, who recently retired as the head of Citigroup. They could be relaxing at their home in Californias wine country or spending more time with their four grandchildren.

title: Philanthropist Takes Hands-On Approach to Giving
description: WHEN Leon Levine, the founder of Family Dollar Stores, a chain of neighborhood discount retail stores based outside Charlotte, N.C., was running his company, he took what he called a hands-on approach.

title: Volunteering Rises on the Rsum
description: LYNN DOWLING BRUNO had never heard of the Wrens Nest, a nonprofit organization that preserves the home of the writer Joel Chandler Harris. Ms. Bruno, 49, lives in Northern California. Wrens Nest is in Atlanta. But when the opportunity arose to do volunteer work for the nonprofit this year, helping it raise its Internet profile, she jumped at it.

title: Donors Weigh the Ideals of Meaningful Giving
description: FOR 11 nights last month, several dozen homeless people slept on plastic sheeting and soiled blankets outside the gleaming new $500 million headquarters of the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation in Seattle. Their objective was a $30,000 grant to help reopen shelters that had been closed by cuts in government funds.

title: Somalias Agony Tests Limits of Aid
description: BENADIR HOSPITAL is a chunky block of a building in downtown Mogadishu, built in the 1970s by the Chinese. It has cracked windows, ceiling fans that dont turn and long, ghostly hallways that stink of human excrement and diesel fuel  all that the nurses have to wash the floors. Each morning, legions of starving people trudge in, the victims of Somalias spreading famine. Many have journeyed from hundreds of miles away. They spent every last dollar and every last calorie to make it here, and when they arrive, they simply collapse on the floor. Benadirs few doctors and nurses are all volunteers and all exhausted, and many wear tattered, bloodied smocks. The minute I walked in, I had a bad feeling I would find what I was looking for.

title: Finding Inspiration in a Doctors Legacy
description: MY morning sprint through the pages of this newspaper typically goes like this: the front page, the corrections, the sports section (during baseball season) and the obituaries.

title: Making Nutrition a Sustainable Business in Haiti
description: PHARMACEUTICAL companies around the globe are donating billions of dollars in free drugs to third world countries grappling with poverty and disease.

title: A Mobile Oasis in a Food Desert
description: BY 8:30 on a chilly late October morning, a crowd of almost 200 has formed outside the Germantown Neighborhood Center in Quincy, Mass.

title: German Anger Over Israeli Settlements Could Cost Israel a Submarine
description: In response to the Palestinian Authoritys successful bid for membership in Unesco, Israel decided to take a number of punitive steps on Tuesday, including the accelerated construction of 2,000 new homes for Israelis in East Jerusalem and the West Bank.

title: Its an Event for Charity, but Certainly, Its a Party
description: ITS just past noon on a Tuesday in late October, and Christine Mortimer Biddle is sequestered on a tuffet in a pastel pink powder room at the Metropolitan Club on the Upper East Side, her Herms bag by her feet and a laptop on her knees.

title: Putin Honors a Journalist Badly Beaten After Exposs
description: MOSCOW  Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin has bestowed an annual state prize on a muckraking journalist who was beaten nearly to death after investigating official corruption in Khimki, a Moscow suburb. The case of the journalist, Mikhail Beketov, has become a symbol Russias culture of impunity.

title: Airy Macarons That Rise Above the Rest
description: THE macaron is the anti-cupcake.

title: IHome Takes on Sonos
description: Amended 11/2/2011 to clarify iW1s feature set.

title: Special Election in Iowa Will, G.O.P. Hopes, Cement Grip on Power
description: By any standard, the midterm election had been a landslide for Iowa Republicans. Last November, the party won back the governorship, gained a majority in the General Assembly and nearly took the Senate, leaving a perilous 26-to-24 edge there as the Democrats sole claim to power.

title: The Brother-Sister Bond
description: I wept as I read Mona Simpsons eulogy for her brother, Steve Jobs, in The Times on Monday, and not just because the Willy Wonka of technology was taken from us too young. What really struck home with me was the rare public declaration by a sister of love for her brother.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Heres to a Beer Room

title: Benefits
description: Upstate Farmers

title: Whispers of Return to Drachma Grow Louder in Greek Crisis
description: The political upheaval in Athens has suddenly made the once unspeakable  Greek debt default  a distinct possibility.

title: Soul-Searching at Nomura
description: Western banks in Japan often complain that Nomuras long-term dominance means they cannot get a look in. It turns out that works both ways. Tough markets have hit Nomuras operations in the United States and Europe harder than most, driving the Japanese investment bank to a $589 million loss in the latest quarter. With far bigger rivals also set on shrinking, it is hard to see how Nomuras global ambitions will survive.

title: A Likely Favorites Long-Shot Story
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Charles Dickey walked into the Breeders Cup office at 9:05 on Monday morning and entered his best horse in the race of a lifetime at Churchill Downs.

title: Driven to Cast Charms Against Drug Lords Darker Forces
description: CATEMACO, Mexico  In the dimly lighted back room of a modest house in this tourist city now largely devoid of tourists, Luis Toms Marthen Torres, a warlock with 50 years of experience, closes his eyes and chants as he briskly rubs a stark white egg over the arms, chest and neck of a worried customer.

title: In God We Trust, With the Houses Help
description: WASHINGTON  Citing a crisis of national identity and mass confusion among Americans about their nations motto, the House on Tuesday voted on a resolution reaffirming In God We Trust as the official motto of the United States.

title: Know Your Cuts
description: A new wave of butcher shops offers cuts of meat rarely seen at supermarkets.

title: No More Doubts: Smith Is 49ers Leader
description: SANTA CLARA, Calif.  Some players make their team during minicamp. In June, San Francisco 49ers quarterback Alex Smith used minicamp to make his team his.

title: The Lost Art of Buying From a Butcher
description: PATRICK MARTINS summed it up in a single slab: pork belly. Thats the cut that people ask for the most, he said. Evidently they cant find it in their supermarkets.

title: Israel Plans to Speed Up Settlement Growth
description: JERUSALEM  Israel said on Tuesday that it would accelerate the construction of 2,000 housing units in contested areas of East Jerusalem and in two West Bank settlements. The announcement came a day after the Palestinians won full membership in Unesco in the face of staunch Israeli and American opposition.

title: A Political Battle Over the Courts Power
description: To the Editor:

title: Arriving at the Finish Line, Days Before the Race
description: For a moment, it was as though Fred Lebow, the founding father of the New York City Marathon, were back, moving steadily along the route in Central Park where more than 45,000 runners will plow through the final leg of the race this Sunday.

title: Helping Madoffs Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: Kids and Fast Food
description: To the Editor:

title: School Lunch Proposals Set Off a Dispute
description: WASHINGTON  The government has some thoughts on how to make the federally financed school lunch program more nutritious: A quarter-cup of tomato paste on pizza will no longer be considered a vegetable. Cut back on potatoes and add more fresh peaches, apples, spinach and broccoli. And hold the salt.

title: Veterans Mental Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Catching a Wave, and Measuring It
description: SUNNYVALE, Calif.  James Gosling wants to network the worlds oceans.

title: Local Food: No Elitist Plot
description: Im not a jingoist, but Id prefer that more of my food came from America. Itd be even better, really, if most of it came from within a few hundred miles of where we live. Wed be more secure and better served, and our land would be better used. And Id feel prouder, as if we had a food culture rather than a food fetish.

title: Talking Trash, Just to Be Heard
description: Long ago, when N.F.L. pregame shows lasted 30 minutes and sports arguments were more common in barrooms than on cable television, former players did not cause many ripples from the broadcast booth.

title: New York Sea Levels
description: To the Editor:

title: State Department Defends Contractor Chosen for Pipeline Study
description: The State Department defended its decision to award a sensitive environmental impact study on the Keystone XL pipeline to a company that had previous ties to TransCanada, the company seeking a permit for the 1,700-mile project, which would run from the tar sands of Alberta to the Gulf of Mexico.

title: Postcard From Alabama: Days Away, but So Close They Can Taste It
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala.  By Tuesday, Alabama football fans had already arrived in anticipation of Saturdays game against top-ranked Louisiana State.

title: Despite Losses, Investors Stick With Paulson
description: John A. Paulson, the billionaire hedge fund manager who made his fortune betting against subprime mortgages, has been fodder for Wall Street gossip as rivals wondered whether investors would bolt after suffering staggering losses this year.

title: LG Brings Ad Capability to Internet-Connected TV
description: A LEADING marketer of consumer electronics is adding an advertising capability to its Internet-connected televisions through an agreement with a video advertising technology company. And a charter sponsor has already been signed to join them.

title: Bloomberg and Koch Deeply Split Over Blame on Fiscal Ills
description: For Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, a pragmatic alumnus of Wall Street, arguing over who is to blame for the nations financial crisis is a waste of time.

title: California: Jacksons Doctor Wont Testify
description: Michael Jacksons personal doctor told a Superior Court judge Tuesday that he would not testify in his involuntary manslaughter trial in which he is accused of giving Jackson a fatal dose of a powerful anesthetic. The Los Angeles County district attorneys office said closing arguments in the trial of Dr. Conrad Murray would begin Thursday. Defense lawyers say Jackson gave himself the fatal dose of propofol, a powerful anesthetic usually used under medical supervision in a hospital, not in a private home, on June 25, 2009.

title: How to Prop Up the Euro
description: Heres the critical takeaway from last weeks European rescue plan: Nothing in it addresses the endemic economic weaknesses that nearly propelled the euro zone into a meltdown.

title: How to Feed the Hungry, Faster
description: On Friday, I wrote about how people in Dhobley, Somalia, are getting emergency food despite a guerrilla war that is keeping out aid workers  and food. Instead of trucking in sacks of food, World Concern and its partner, the African Rescue Committee, distribute vouchers that people in Dhobley use to buy what they need from local merchants.

title: City Reports More Suspensions, but Serious Crimes Declined
In Libya, Fighting May Outlast the Revolution
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Many of the local militia leaders who helped topple Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi are abandoning a pledge to give up their weapons and now say they intend to preserve their autonomy and influence political decisions as guardians of the revolution.

title: Mr. Corzines Big Bet
description: Why did Jon S. Corzine make the risky bets that have now plunged MF Global Holdings into bankruptcy court? We dont know, but the likely explanations are disturbing.

title: In the Oval Office, a Passage to Freedom
description: Washington, Nov. 1, 2011

title: Cain Accuser Got a Years Salary in Severance Pay
description: WASHINGTON  The National Restaurant Association gave $35,000  a years salary  in severance pay to a female staff member in the late 1990s after an encounter with Herman Cain, its chief executive at the time, made her uncomfortable working there, three people with direct knowledge of the payment said on Tuesday.

title: Under Color of Federal Law
description: The Supreme Court ruled three decades ago in Carlson v. Green that a federal prisoner could sue for money damages from prison employees who abused his constitutional rights. On Tuesday, in Minneci v. Pollard, the court heard the government and others contend that a prisoner held in a facility operated by a private contractor cannot bring this kind of action.

title: Arms Flying Into Somalia for Militants, Kenya Says
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  The Kenyan government said Tuesday that aircraft were delivering weapons to Islamist insurgents in southern Somalia, widening the international nature of a war that has already engulfed several African nations.

title: Vital Drugs in Short Supply
description: President Obama has issued an executive order that takes reasonable, if modest, steps to ease disruptions in the supply of certain important drugs. Congress could address the problem even more aggressively by passing legislation that has been languishing for months.

title: Federal Inquiry of MF Global Escalates
description: Federal officials are escalating an investigation into MF Global, the bankrupt brokerage firm run by Jon S. Corzine, as the search continues for roughly $600 million in missing customer money.

title: The Widening Gyre
description: Once in a great while, a beachcomber in Hawaii or the Pacific Northwest will find treasure: a lustrous sphere of translucent green glass, sometimes as big as a basketball. It is a Japanese fishing float, which had worked loose from a rope net and circled the Pacific Ocean for years before wind and current finally nudged it to shore.

title: Drug Terms Reduced, Freeing Prisoners
description: There are some big meals on the way for Darryl Flood.

title: Wednesday: Elegantly Dressed Bloke
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  It always gives me a little thrill (O.K., its more of a big thrill) when people I get to know as solvers make the big leap into crossword construction and eventually get published here in The New York Times. Seeing your name in the byline is different from anything else you can experience. Why, I remember back in the day when I had my first puzzle published, blah blah blah fame, glory and untold riches yada yada yada its really not about you, Deb. Stay focused on the story.

title: Teenage Motherhood Is Serious, Especially With Baby Bling at Play
description: The three young women chirping away like baby birds in a feathered nest in the opening scene of Milk Like Sugar, a provocative new play by Kirsten Greenidge that opened on Tuesday night at the Peter Jay Sharp Theater, dont seem to have much of anything special on their minds. With blinged-out cellphones clutched permanently in elaborately manicured hands, they are killing time in a tattoo parlor, exchanging texts with boys, arguing over whose phone is the coolest (Slider phones are kaput), and whats the best kind of ink to be getting: a rose or a ladybug?

title: Austerity Faces Test as Greeks Question Their Ties to Euro
description: PARIS  The crisis of the euro zone has finally hit the potholed road of real politics, with the Greeks now openly questioning whether their commitment to Europe and its single currency still matters more to them than control over their own future and economic well-being.

title: Cain Not Able
description: WASHINGTON

title: For Whistle-Blower in Medicaid Suit, Finding Guidance in Parents and Capra
description: It has not always been a wonderful life for Dr. Gabriel Ethan Feldman. He has been bankrupt, unemployed and penniless. He has been forced to move back to his mothers house. At this very moment, he lives in a 275-square-foot rent-stabilized studio apartment in a frumpy building on the Upper West Side.

title: Co-op Ends Fight With City Over Its East Side Backyard
description: An exclusive East Side co-op has released its ownership claim on a 10,000-square-foot patch of its elevated backyard overlooking the East River, ending a decade-long boundary dispute with the city.

title: A Long List of Suckers
description: Agra, India

title: Dismal Tale of Arrest for Tiniest of Crimes
description: The arresting officer came by the cell, Samantha Zucker said, to make snide remarks about finding her with a friend in Riverside Park after its 1 a.m. closing.

title: United They Stand, Huge Fine Aside
description: Micky Arison employs two of the N.B.A.s most electrifying talents. They came two wins short of the championship last June. Their arena is packed every night. Arisons wildly profitable franchise, the Miami Heat, is worth an estimated $425 million.

title: A Silver Lining to Americas Waning Influence
description: WASHINGTON  President Hu Jintao of China will arrive in Cannes, France, this week pondering a plea from Europe for tens of billions of dollars to help the continent get out of its debt crisis. And President Obama will arrive with a smile, some hearty handshakes, and his own plea: that Greece get its act together and that Europe fix its economic ills, which he has called one of the biggest drags on the United States own ailing economy.

title: Corruption Trial Opens for Lawmaker From Brooklyn Political Family
description: An assemblyman from one of Brooklyns most prominent political families struck a secret deal to use his influence in Albany on behalf of a hospital chief executive in return for a sham consulting job that paid him about $175,000, a federal prosecutor said Tuesday.

title: Stone-Washed Blue Jeans (Minus the Washed)
description: SAN FRANCISCO   From the cotton field in rural India to the local rag bin, a typical pair of blue jeans consumes 919 gallons of water during its life cycle, Levi Strauss & Company says, or enough to fill about 15 spa-size bathtubs. That includes the water that goes into irrigating the cotton crop, stitching the jeans together and washing them scores of times at home.

title: The Pawlenty Surge Was Never Coming
description: With several Republican candidates struggling in the nomination race and no Chris Christie or Mitch Daniels to save them, those underwhelmed by the current field have instead turned their attention toward the one who already dropped out: Gov. Tim Pawlenty of Minnesota.

title: Deficit Panel Is Warned That It Must Not Fail and Is Urged to Compromise
description: WASHINGTON  A co-chairman of President Obamas fiscal commission told members of a powerful Congressional panel on deficit reduction Tuesday that he feared they would fail, and he said the consequences of such failure could be calamitous.

title: Long Dodgers Ordeal May Soon Be Over
description: The battle over the Los Angeles Dodgers spanned the entire baseball season.

title: In Corzine Comeback, Big Risks and Steep Fall
description: When Jon S. Corzine joined MF Global last year it seemed like a strange choice  the firm had none of the glamour, let alone the profits or footprint of Goldman Sachs, the bank he ran during the 1990s.

title: Lottery Numbers
Russia Stays Transfixed by a Switch at Birth
description: MOSCOW  For several weeks, Russian television has followed the story of two 12-year-olds in the Siberian city of Kopeysk: pale, light-eyed Anya, who is being raised by a Tajik man according to the precepts of Islam; and black-haired Irina, the beloved daughter of an ethnically Russian blond woman.

title: K.K.R. in Talks With Samson Investment
description: After a string of smaller deals in the oil patch over the last two years, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts is gearing up for a potential blockbuster takeover.

title: Citi Field Fits In With History of Ballpark Changes
description: When the Mets alter the playing dimensions at Citi Field  installing new outfield fences closer to home plate  the changes will symbolize an admission that the club, after enduring three seasons of grief and long flyouts, had erred in its original design.

title: When Each Bad Storm Means More Dark Days
description: First came the heavy snow in February that crushed the hangar and destroyed the vintage Piper J-5A airplane he housed in Dutchess County, N.Y. Then came the tornado in June that ripped out an ancient oak tree in his backyard in Roxbury, Conn. When Tropical Storm Irene blew through in August, another huge oak fell  this time on his house, blasting a hole through a back bedroom. In each case, electricity was lost.

title: Challenges Facing Leaders in the European Debt Crisis
description: Leaders of European countries face new challenges in the debt crisis.

title: Afghanistan and Pakistan Agree on Joint Inquiry Into Envoys Murder
description: ISTANBUL  Afghan and Pakistani leaders agreed on Tuesday to conduct a joint investigation into the assassination in September of the leader of Afghanistans peace process.

title: As Polls Slip, Perry Gets First Bounty of Super PAC Ads
description: A new super PAC co-founded by Gov. Rick Perrys onetime chief of staff has begun running campaign ads in Iowa and South Carolina, marking the first advertising by a major super PAC in the Republican presidential primary and serving as a reminder of the Texas governors formidable financial resources despite his recent slide in the polls.

title: Spurring Growth on Bostons Waterfront
description: BOSTON  When Vertex Pharmaceuticals agreed this year to move into an as-yet-unbuilt waterfront office complex, it made history as the citys largest commercial lease at 1.1 million square feet, with a rent of $72.5 million a year. But more important for the city over all, the huge deal has spurred growth and eased the way for financing other projects.

title: To Survive, Medical Companies in New Jersey Are Building New Hospitals
description: HOPEWELL, N.J.  The dazzling new hospital that will open here on Sunday looks more like a five-star resort than a medical center. It may also be the best hope for survival of its corporate parent, Capital Health, a nonprofit company that operates three health care facilities in New Jersey.

title: Turkey: Activists Ordered Held
description: An Istanbul court on Tuesday ordered the detention of more than 20 pro-Kurdish political activists, including a prominent political science professor and a leading human rights activist, on terrorism-related charges. The move was criticized by a pro-Kurdish political party and hundreds of intellectuals who issued a joint statement calling the arrests a heavy blow against the efforts to achieve real democracy within equality, peace, social justice, as well as academic and political freedoms. The suspects denied that they were members of the outlawed Kurdistan Workers Party, or P.K.K. The arrests come as a major military offensive in pursuit of Kurdish militants based in Iraq continues. The government has been debating constitutional changes to help the Kurds.

title: The Big East Is on the Verge of Adding New Members
description: PHILADELPHIA  The Big East, in a effort to pull the conference back from the brink, moved to extend invitations to several universities after a unanimous vote by the league presidents at their annual meeting Tuesday.

title: 4 Georgia Men Arrested in Terror Plot
description: Four Georgia men who were part of a fringe militia group were arrested on Tuesday in what the Justice Department described as a plot to use guns, bombs and the toxin ricin to kill federal and state officials and spread terror.

title: Britain: Tabloid Records Published
description: British lawmakers published internal documents from Rupert Murdochs now-defunct tabloid The News of the World on Tuesday, raising further questions over the extent to which the phone hacking scandal there was covered up. The documents, unearthed during Parliamentary investigations into allegations the tabloid illegally intercepted the voice mails of thousands of newsworthy figures, include e-mails between senior executives at the British arm of Mr. Murdochs global media empire and their lawyers.

title: Credit Where It's Due
description: Ben Roethlisberger's off-the-field behavior has tarnished his on-the-field success, says William C. Rhoden.

title: Colombia: Spy Agency Dissolved
description: President Juan Manuel Santos dissolved the countrys main intelligence agency, the sprawling Administrative Department of Security, or DAS, after a series of scandals that severely damaged the agencys credibility. DAS illegally spied on human rights activists, judges and political leaders, and its former spymaster, Jorge Noguera, was recently convicted of collaborating with paramilitary assassination squads in the murder of a prominent scholar. Mr. Santos, above, in an executive order issued late Monday, said about 3,000 DAS employees would migrate to the attorney generals office, while the Interior Ministry, National Police and Foreign Ministry would absorb almost 2,000 other employees. A new intelligence agency is to be created.

title: Iran: Finance Chief Survives Vote
description: Irans finance minister survived a vote in Parliament on Tuesday to remove him from office over the countrys banking scandal, the state-run Islamic Republic News Agency reported. More than two dozen lawmakers had submitted a motion to impeach the minister, Shamseddin Hosseini, an ally of President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad who oversaw countrys economy during the time Iranian authorities have said a record $2.6 billion banking fraud occurred. Mr. Ahmadinejads conservative critics have tried to link his close associates to the alleged fraud. It was unclear what affect the vote would have on Parliaments request to summon Mr. Ahmadinejad himself for questioning.

title: A Fateful Stop for Candy for a Helper to So Many
description: There have never been enough causes for Marion Salmon Hedges, but always enough time.

title: Video: Credit Where Its Due
description: Ben Roethlisbergers off-the-field behavior has tarnished his on-the-field success, says William C. Rhoden.

title: Markets Rebound but Remain on Edge
description: Stocks pushed higher Wednesday as investors weathered continued uncertainty over the sovereign debt crisis in Europe and a lowered growth forecast for the United States.

title: Florida: Miami Beach Mayor Wins Another Term
description: Matti Herrera Bower was re-elected Miami Beach mayor Tuesday, winning a final term before she retires in two years. Ms. Bower, 72, a former dental assistant and longtime Miami Beach commissioner, was first elected mayor in 2007. She faced three challengers, including Steve Berke, a comedian who ran on a pro-marijuana, pro-casino, pro-economic development platform. Ms. Bower, who had the support of police officers and firefighters, won nearly 60 percent of the vote. Mr. Berke was second, with 23 percent of the vote.

title: Plane Lands in Poland Without Landing Gear
description: An LOT Polish Airlines flight slid into a Warsaw airport on its belly on Tuesday, sparks flying and smoke hissing, crash landing onto the runway without the aid of its landing gear, which refused to drop.

title: Gilbert Cates, Producer of Oscar Shows, Dies at 77
description: LOS ANGELES  Gilbert Cates, a director and producer who shaped Hollywoods labor relations through the Directors Guild of America and its glamour scene through a record 14 Oscar telecasts, died here on Monday. He was 77.

title: Degas Ballerina Among the Works Unsold at Christies
description: Against a backdrop of reeling financial markets and nervous collectors, paintings and sculptures by Degas and Picasso, Matisse and Giacometti went unsold at Christies on Tuesday night.

title: Tom Keith, Creator of Radio Soundscapes, Dies at 64
description: For more than 30 years Tom Keith conjured animals, gunshots, screeching tires, even a man falling into piranha-infested waters, for a live national audience that reached nearly four million, using only his vocal cords and an array of props.

title: Curbing Holiday Weight Gain With Exercise
description: The next few months, filled with holiday feasting, represent a dire threat to most peoples waistlines. Even those of us who normally eat a wholesome diet can find ourselves gorging on fatty, high-calorie foods and gaining the annual Christmas inner tube. But several new studies promote a simple and effective response: Run or walk from the buffet. Even if youve already overindulged, the studies suggest, exercise can lessen or reverse the unwelcome consequences.

title: Arizona Governor and Senate Oust Redistricting Leader
description: PHOENIX  Arizonas Senate on Tuesday night ousted the chairwoman of the citizens commission charged with redrawing political boundaries, igniting a fierce legal battle over whether the states Republican leaders were interfering in a redistricting process that voters sought to insulate from politics.

title: Word of the Day | wallow
description: wallow \w-()lo\ verb and noun

title: Dorothy Rodham Dies at 92
description: Dorothy Rodham was a powerful influence on the life and career of her daughter, Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: Bloggingheads: Herman Cains Blackness
description: John McWhorter, left, of The New Republic and Glenn Loury of Brown University debate race and Herman Cain.

title: Beryl Davis, British Singer With Big Bands, Dies at 87
description: Beryl Davis, a British singer who was beloved in England for carrying on with her cabaret performances during the bombing of London in World War II, and who later performed with Frank Sinatra and the big bands of Benny Goodman and Glenn Miller, died on Friday in Los Angeles. She was 87.

title: Fisher Fights Back Against Reports
description: A day after defending his honor in a letter to N.B.A. players, the union president Derek Fisher issued another statement Tuesday, this time denouncing news reports that accused him of betraying the unions trust.

title: Leaders Reflect on Highs and Lows
description: Michael R. Bloomberg, Edward I. Koch and David N. Dinkins spoke Tuesday at a breakfast event in Midtown Manhattan. Here are some highlights:

title: NYT Front Page for 11/02/2011
description: NYT Front Page for 11/02/2011

title: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Wednesday
description: Pakistani cricketers Salman Butt and Mohammad Asif were found guilty Tuesday of taking bribes to fix part of a match against England during the Lords Test last August. A third cricketer, Mohammad Amir has already pleaded guilty but this was not reported earlier since he was only at 18 at the time (The Hindu). Mr. Butt and Mr. Asif face up to seven years in jail or large fines. The case followed a sting operation by the now defunct News of the World newspaper (The Indian Express).

title: God Plans, Man Laughs
description: LONDON  God walked into the nave in high heels and dictated tweets to an angel. Ruth and Naomi held hands and kissed. A voice spoke from a tomb. Men and women challenged Him and werent struck down. There were trysts in chapels; a man was imprisoned beside the cloisters; somewhere a Bearded Lady was breaking a Strongmans heart. This was Westminster Abbey on Oct. 21, when it played host to a 12-hour performance of Sixty-Six Books, a collection of monologues, songs, and short plays commissioned by the Bush Theatre for the 400th anniversary of the King James Bible.

title: Agreeing to Sell, McCourt Gives Dodgers Fans Hope
description: First, Frank McCourt tried to buy his hometown Boston Red Sox. Then he sought the Anaheim Angels. Finally, in late 2003, McCourt, a land developer, triumphed: he and his wife, Jamie, bought the Los Angeles Dodgers for $430 million.

title: Hyper-Connected: Video from the India Ink Launch Party
Corrections: November 2
description: NATIONAL

title: Nov. 2, 1976 | Carter Defeats Ford in Presidential Election
description: On Nov. 2, 1976, Jimmy Carter defeated the Republican incumbent Gerald R. Ford, becoming the first United States president from the Deep South since the Civil War.

title: Archbishop of Canterbury Urges Debate of Tax on Bankers
description: LONDON  A day after St. Pauls Cathedral suspended legal action to evict hundreds of anti-capitalist protesters camped outside its doors, the Most Rev. Rowan Williams, the archbishop of Canterbury and the spiritual leader of the worlds Anglicans, was quoted on Wednesday as expressing sympathy for their cause.

title: Test Yourself | Math, Nov. 2, 2011
description: Test your math skills with this question created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the Economix blog post, Kardashianomics.

title: Satirical Magazine Is Firebombed in Paris
description: PARIS  The office of a French satirical magazine here was badly damaged by a firebomb early on Wednesday, the publisher said, after it published a spoof issue guest edited by the Prophet Muhammad to salute the victory of an Islamist party in Tunisian elections. The publication also said hackers had disrupted its Web site.

title: Behind the Scenes With Scorsese
description: Photographs from Martin Scorseses first movie in 3-D, Hugo.

title: Martin Scorseses Magical Hugo
description: Last year, Martin Scorsese began working on a film version of The Invention of Hugo Cabret, a graphic novel by Brian Selznick about a 12-year-old orphan named Hugo who lives inside the walls of a 1930s Paris train station. Hugo (Asa Butterfield) oils and maintains the station clocks while guarding a magnificent secret: a broken-down automaton and a notebook, left by his father (Jude Law), with incomplete instructions on how to bring it to life. An encounter with a bitter toy salesman and his goddaughter (Chlo Moretz) leads Hugo into the world of the real-life magician and grandfather of science-fiction film-making, Georges Mlis (Ben Kingsley). Scorsese talks about updating Mliss celluoid fantasies a century later  and in 3-D.

title: Looking for Gold in a Distant Jungle
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Squeezed between the Pacific Ocean and the Andes, covered by thick, forbidding jungle and drenched by so much rain that its among the wettest places on Earth, the Colombian region of Choc was described by the anthropologist Michael Taussig as one of the most remote regions of the world.

title: Champions League Wednesday Preview: Real Madrid Looks to Keep Rolling
description: Real Madrid will try to join Barcelona in the Round of 16 of the Champions League, because heaven forbid one of the Spanish rivals be able to claim something the other cannot. (A.C. Milan also advanced to the knockout stage on Tuesday, and Benfica and Bayern Munich can go through with the right results on Wednesday.)

title: Celebrating the 7 Billionth
description: This edition of 6 Qs About the News draws from a variety of recent Times articles and features about world population. Each question links to the place in which an answer for it can be found.

title: News Quiz | Nov. 2, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: British Court Says WikiLeaks Founder Can Be Extradited for Questioning
description: LONDON  A British court ruled Wednesday that Julian Assange, the WikiLeaks founder, can be extradited to Sweden for questioning over allegations of sexual abuse made against him by two women there last year. He will seek a final appeal at Britains highest court, according to a person close to him.

title: Do You Have Good Manners?
description: An article laments the decline of civility in the southern United States, a region where manners were once considered an important cultural marker. How would you define good manners? Do you agree with those who say that civility in general is declining everywhere? Do you think you have good manners yourself?

title: Numbers Aside, Indias Newborns Face Challenges
description: Usha Kumars wails sounded like the cries of a wounded animal, guttural and wrenching, her screams seeping through the corridor of Kasturba Hospital in Delhi,until, finally, mercifully, Ms. Kumar pushed out her baby boy.

title: New Video Attacks Romney
description: Priorities USA Action, the pro-Obama super PAC, is marking the start of the yearlong countdown to Election Day 2012 by releasing a video entirely devoted to attacking former Gov. Mitt Romney of Massachusetts, painting him as a cold-hearted businessman disconnected from the pain of ordinary Americans.

title: How Unemployment Benefits Became Twice as Generous
description: 12:48 p.m. | Updated  to revise reference to standard benefit period.

description: Slap Shot contributor Christopher Botta recently interviewed Pat Brisson, of the Creative Artists Agency, on his offseason negotiations with the New York Islanders on a six-year contract extension for John Tavares. Heres their conversation:

title: Paris Exhibit Showcases Unusual Medium: Wool
description: Glance quickly at some of the items on display at La Maison du Danemark and you might think you just saw a gun, a pair of high heels, a set of dice. Look closer, though, and youll see that the works are made of an unlikely material: everything is wool.

title: Greek Premier Pledges Vote in December on Debt Deal
description: CANNES, France  Prime Minister George A. Papandreou of Greece emerged from a meeting with Europes leaders here on Wednesday pledging to hold a referendum on a new European debt deal on Dec. 4 or 5.

title: With $600 Million Building, John Jay College Gains a Whole Campus
description: For nearly 50 years, the John Jay College of Criminal Justice has made do with secondhand space, scattered through an odd variety of buildings, with nothing like a campus to unite its 15,000 students. Its visual identity has been that of an old high school  a distinguished old high school, to be sure, but an old high school all the same.

title: Mounting Woes Prompt Sony to Predict Another Annual Loss
description: TOKYO  A strong yen, flooding in Thailand and tepid sales in the United States and Europe all conspired to knock Sony to a net loss for the latest quarter, putting the company on course for a fourth unprofitable year in a row.

title: Comcast Posts 4.7% Profit, With Mixed Results From NBCUniversal Acquisition
description: 4:51 p.m. | Updated An increase in high-speed Internet customers and NBCUniversals trove of profitable cable networks helped increase third-quarter profits at the Comcast Corporation, the company announced Wednesday.

title: Will Bernanke Take Aim at G.D.P.?
description: Its a safe bet that the hottest topic in monetary policy is going to be raised when the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, takes questions from reporters Wednesday afternoon.

title: Could Smart Textiles Prove Toxic?
description: The growing practice of weaving electronics into the fiber of clothing could add to the already monumental challenge of e-waste disposal. Some fifty million tons of electronic waste already accumulate annually in soaring mountains of refuse, the United Nations says.

title: Leonardo DiCaprio on Film
description: A look back at some of the notable films from Leonardo DiCaprios 20-year film career.

title: A Star Who Isnt Afraid to Take Risks
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Pilot Error Found in Crash That Killed Russian Hockey Players
description: MOSCOW  Russian air safety officials said Wednesday that a September plane crash that killed an elite hockey team was caused by an extraordinarily basic human error: one of the pilots accidentally pressed the brakes on the landing gear, so that the aircraft was moving too slowly when it tried to take off.

title: Och-Ziff Profit Falls 4% on Market Turbulence
description: Och-Ziff Capital Management, the hedge fund firm run by Daniel S. Och, reported on Wednesday that profit fell 4 percent in the third quarter as a result of market turbulence and higher expenses.

title: From Horsemans Vision Comes the Breeders Cup
description: Its the first weekend in November, and the Breeders Cup approaches; the two-day festival of horse racing that attracts the worlds top juvenile and older male and female horses with 15 races on grass and dirt varying from sprints to the mile and three-quarters marathon. Since its inception in 1984, the Breeders Cup has produced some of the sports most thrilling finishes.

description: Here we go again, having to hear political candidates and television commentators exploit some of the most brutal and disgraceful chapters in history to score points.

description: Federal Inquiry of MF Global Escalates | Federal officials are stepping up an investigation of MF Global, the bankrupt brokerage firm run by Jon S. Corzine, as the search continues for about $600 million in missing customer money.

title: Now Playing | Parallax, the New Album by Atlas Sound
description: Inscrutable? Cryptic? Finding the right word to describe Bradford Cox is not easy. The Atlanta-based musician, lead singer of the popular indie rock band Deerhunter and mastermind behind the more esoteric solo project Atlas Sound, is tall and lanky and moves with a long, excited gait thanks to a genetic condition of the connective tissue called Marfan Syndrome. Hes gone through wild periods of provocation involving onstage cross-dressing and fake blood. Hes written song lyrics inspired by subversive Dennis Cooper novels. Spending time with him is a roller coaster ride that sweeps those around him up through various random-seeming whims and high-strung emotions. Despite all of this, or more likely because of all this, he is prolific with at least eleven albums and EPs to his name since 2005. His latest album, Parallax, released under his solo moniker, further proves Coxs lo-fi genius, showcasing his deftness at weaving multilayered lyrics through harmonizing electronic tones and across undulating beats to create catchy but complex pop songs. Its worth noting that the albums title refers to the optical effect wherein our perceptions of various objects relative positions depend on our distance from them  if you drive down a highway, the tree line whizzes past while faraway objects like the sun barely move at all. Its one of those facts in nature that seems intuitive and yet, upon examination, gets quite confusing quite fast. The same can be said of Coxs songs. Here we present an exclusive stream of the complete Parallax album (out next week, Nov. 8, from 4AD), along with a few words from Cox explaining the meaning of and inspiration behind four of his favorite songs  explanations he offers in his own signature fashion, without making any distinction between the technical, musical, literary or lyrical aspects of his work.

title: Asana Introduces a Souped-Up To-Do List to Organize Work
description: Two years after a Facebook co-founder and one of the early employees, Dustin Moskovitz and Justin Rosenstein, started their own clandestine business software company, called Asana, they are finally ready to open it to the public.

title: And Now, a Limerick From Salman Rushdie
description: Mr. Rushdie is a winner of the Booker Prize for Fiction and a two-time winner of the Whitbread Novel Award whose works of fiction include Midnights Children, The Satanic Verses and The Moors Last Sigh. He is also familiar with reality television.

title: Staying the Hand of Vengeance in Libya
description: SURT, Libya  Libyas real test, now that Muammar el-Qaddafi is gone, is whether the instinct for vengeance can be blunted. Surt, Qaddafis hometown and the city in which he met his end, is anxiously watching and waiting for the answer.

title: Relatives of Flight 93 Victims Run to Keep Memories Alive
description: They are an extended family now, holding reunions in places that would have seemed odd 10 years 2 months ago  Shanksville, Pa., for example, and an old fort on Staten Island, the starting line for the New York City Marathon.

title: Wednesday Reading: A Few Drinks a Week Raise Breast Cancer Risk
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog and on his personal Web site, BehaviorGap.com.

description: Very nice event for the Economic Policy Institute last night. They put together a video about, well, me, that will make my parents happy.

description: In another challenge to the European Unions plan to regulate emissions from the worlds airlines, 26 countries including China and the United States are backing a resolution urging that non-European airlines be exempted.
