title: Invitation to Veterans, Their Friends and Families
description: The editors of Home Fires are requesting the participation of readers for a post on Veterans Day, Nov. 11. If you are a veteran, or friend or relative of someone who served in the military and would like to share a written message or recollection, or a photograph recalling a veteran or their service, you can send it to us via e-mail at opinionator@nytimes.com. Please put HOME FIRES in the subject line of your message.

title: Can Egypt Overcome Its Travel P.R. Problem?
description: WHEN the Arab Spring spread to Egypt on Jan. 25, culminating in the ouster of President Hosni Mubarak 17 days later, it brought an electrifying sense of achievement and  as travelers and tour operators know all too well  an unwelcome side effect: the crippling of Egypts tourism industry, the countrys major source of revenue and jobs.

title: Home Cooking With Jean-Georges
description: When the celebrated chef Jean-Georges Vongerichten turned 50, he decided it was time to start enjoying weekends again. Four years later, the chef and owner of several restaurants says he has also rediscovered the joy of cooking at home.

title: What Were Reading
description: Towleroad: Groups have examined the most recently available 990 tax forms from the Chick-fil-A chain and charge that the company gave $1.7 million to nonprofits that have opposed gay civil rights like Focus on the Family and the Fellowship of Christian Athletes.  Glenn Collins

title: Climate Change and the Developing World
description: The United Nations Development Program delivered some dire news Wednesday in its annual Human Development Report. By midcentury, it said, the development progress of the poorest countries will be halted or even reversed if bold steps are not taken to forestall the effects of climate change.

title: Vain Glorious | Buttermilk Falls Inn & Spa
description: Who: Buttermilk Falls Inn & Spa

title: TerraCycles Quest to Create Negative-Cost Marketing
description: TerraCycle has always had an unusual relationship with marketing. We have essentially never spent money on advertising, and we have a big aversion to doing so in the future. Instead, we have tried to leverage the publicity we are able to generate about our unusual business model, and we have taken that one step further to develop what we call negative-cost marketing.

title: A Boarding Pass on Your Screen
description: IN 2007 Continental Airlines started testing what was then a novel technology: allowing passengers to receive an electronic boarding pass on their mobile phones. Four years later, it is finally gaining traction. Now most of the major carriers offer mobile boarding passes at many airports in the United States and some abroad. With a growing number of travelers carrying smartphones, the era of paperless boarding may have finally arrived.

title: Temperamental Opera Star Acts Up Again: Ring Set Malfunctions at Met
description: The giant mechanized set for the Metropolitan Operas new production of Wagners Ring cycle has continued its balky behavior into Siegfried, the third work in the series. At the performance on Tuesday night a malfunction prevented the set from creating the proper configuration for the final scene between the title character and Brnnhilde, when Siegfried awakens her from sleep amid perpetual fire around her and they sing a love duet, the Met said in a statement.

title: Painful Baby Boom on Prime-Time TV
description: So much screaming. So many complications. If I had any money, Id invest it all in birth-control stocks.

title: Q. and A. With the Red Bulls Thierry Henry
description: HOBOKEN, N.J.  Thierry Henry is nearing the end of his second season in Major League Soccer, which could end Thursday, Sunday or in the league championship game on Nov. 20.

title: Islanders Are Skating at Junction of Ice and Ink
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  Jay Fields had been tattooed before, but never in the concourse of an arena as a hockey game was being played. So there Fields sat last week, between the first and second periods of an Islanders-Penguins game at Nassau Coliseum, as an artist who goes by Irish Jay patiently inked the word Believe on Fieldss right biceps.

title: Hotel Deals for 11/11/11
description: With Veterans Day falling on 11/11 this year, many hotels are offering by-the-numbers deals for military and civilian guests. Heres a sampling:

title: An Opening Day Without the N.B.A.
description: In case you had not noticed  and what the N.B.A. should really worry about is if you didnt  Tuesday night was supposed to be opening night in the N.B.A. In a normal year, when the owners dont decide their billions are not enough to run their franchises, the Dallas Mavericks would have been unfurling a championship banner, LeBron James would have done something to annoy large amounts of people and Knicks fans would have been turned upside down and relieved of every last cent they own.

title: Peter Horbury, Volvo Design Chief, Is Moving to Geely
description: In a press release, the Volvo Car Corporation announced that Peter Horbury, its vice president of design, would be taking up the role of senior vice president of design at Geely, Volvos corporate sibling under the Zhejiang Geely Holding Group.

title: Crats, Maybe, But Not Much Techno
description: Atrios complains, rightly, about the description of the policies being followed in Europe as technocratic. His point is that

title: A Trainer Bets on Himself
description: Sometimes you got to bet on yourself, or so thought Cot Campbell one day last winter when he was assessing the strength of his Dogwood Stable, one of the pioneers in horse racing partnerships.

title: A Permanent Souvenir From the Game
description: Why get an Islanders T-shirt when you can get a tattoo at the game?

title: Shrugging Off the Chill
description: BLANKET ponchos, in woolly hide-under-the-covers fabrics, are big this season  and a fresh way to achieve a cool off-duty look.

title: Home Sleek Home
Yvonne McCain, Plaintiff in Suit on Shelter for Homeless Families, Dies at 63
description: Yvonne McCain, a once-homeless mother of four whose years of living in a fetid, ramshackle welfare hotel in Midtown Manhattan led to a landmark court ruling requiring the city to provide decent shelter for homeless families, died Saturday in her rent-subsidized, middle-income apartment on Staten Island. She was 63.

title: For Parched Times, a New Water Calculus
description: In my article about efforts by Levi Strauss & Company to adapt to climate change by reducing its water consumption, I mention the companys estimate that each pair of 501 Levis jeans will consume 919 gallons of water during its life cycle. That includes everything from irrigating the cotton crop, to rinsing the jeans during the manufacturing process, to lots of home launderings.

title: Mixed-Race Families and Same-Sex Ones
description: Frank Brunis column on the resistance among African-Americans to the legalization of same-sex marriage (and an effort by the Human Rights Campaign to change that) got me thinking about the link I see between civil rights and gay marriage.

title: At a News Conference, Cain Avoids Questions
description: 4:53 p.m. | Updated ALEXANDRIA, Va.  Its getting rougher on the campaign trail for Herman Cain  and for the people who cover him.

title: More on Energy and Climate Paths for California and Beyond
description: Building on my weekend Reality Check on Ambitious Climate Targets, here are two Your Dot views of energy and climate paths for California and the rest of the planet, one offered by Alan Nogee, an energy consultant who was until recently the leader of the Clean Energy Program at the Union of Concerned Scientists, and Thomas J. Crowley of the University of Edinburgh, a veteran of decades of climate research who here writes primarily as a resident of a place, Scotland, where energy prices are very high.

title: The G-20 Blues
description: There was a time  wasnt there?  when meetings like this Thursdays summit of the countries known as the G-20 might have generated talk about the worlds biggest economies getting together to come up with bold ideas. There was even a notion that the richest might find ways to help the poorest prosper.

title: Video Supporting Romney Compares Perry to Jerry Brown
description: That didnt take long.

title: Mens Clothing Firm Wants to Expand Into Online Sales
description: J. Hilburn is a 50-employee luxury mens clothing brand based in Dallas. Using a direct-sales and multilevel marketing model similar to that of Avon, J. Hilburn sells clothing that is custom fit using measurements taken by company sales representatives, known as style advisers, who make house calls and who share in the profits of other sales advisers that they recruit.

title: Tough Choices for a Clothing Company Using Multilevel Marketing
description: A case study weve just published profiles the bind faced by J. Hilburn, a Dallas-based direct-sales company that sells custom clothing.

title: New Hampshire Claims Its Usual Early Spot on the Republican Primary Calendar
description: 8:33 p.m. | Updated The hotels can be booked now, along with the rental cars. Restaurants are taking reservations. And the Republican presidential candidates finally know where they will be early next year.

title: Lawyer to Look Into Cain Campaign Finances
description: A spokesman for Herman Cains presidential campaign said on Wednesday that it had asked an outside lawyer to review allegations that the campaign had accepted tens of thousands of dollars in goods and services from a tax-exempt organization founded by his chief of staff.

title: Latest Updates on Occupy Oakland Protest
description: The Lede is following protests in Oakland, Calif. on Wednesday, where Occupy Oakland protesters have called for a general strike. Follow Malia Wollans reports from the city here and on Twitter at @mwollan.

title: Time to Repeal the Cellphone Ban, Students Say
Finding Patterns in School Suspension Figures
Got N.F.L. Questions? Battista Has Answers
description: Are the Eagles really on track? How shaky is the Patriots defense? Why are the Ravens such a puzzle? Judy Battista, The Timess N.F.L. reporter, will again answer selected questions from readers this week. Use the comment field below to ask your questions, and the answers will appear on The Fifth Down on Friday.

title: Readers Respond: Is Regulation the Solution?
description: The lead editorial views MF Globals bankruptcy as a warningthat the financial system is still too vulnerable, and that the work of regulatory reform is not yet finished.

title: Audie Cornish to Fill In on NPRs All Things Considered
description: Audie Cornish will fill in for Michele Norris on the NPR program All Things Considered next year, the public radio organization said Wednesday.

title: Nobel Winner Joins Hedge Fund
description: Hedge funds have a reputation for attracting the best and brightest on Wall Street, but the industry has a knack for pulling heavyweights from academia, too.

title: Another Hospital Hazard for the Elderly
description: Hours before she fell and broke her hip, my mother, 85, lucid and whip-smart, was doing what she always did in the morning: drinking an entire pot of coffee and digesting both The New York Times and The Baltimore Sun.

title: Wall St. Protest Is Hurting Areas Families, Bloomberg Says
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who has defended the free-speech rights of Occupy Wall Street protesters while objecting to their message, said Wednesday that he had become more concerned about how the Occupy Wall Street encampment in Zuccotti Park was affecting residential and commercial life in Lower Manhattan.

title: The Boldfaced and the Beautiful
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Henry Rises to Defend Red Bulls Style of Play
description: HOBOKEN, N.J.  The Red Bulls enter their playoff game with the Los Angeles Galaxy on Thursday with the unenviable task of needing a victory on the road against Major League Soccers top club to keep their season alive. They will do so with the label of dirtiest team in the league, affixed to them by Landon Donovan, the Galaxys star forward.

title: Climate Change Imperils Global Prosperity, U.N. Warns
description: A new report from the United Nations Development Program warns that if drastic measures are not taken to prepare nations for the impacts of climate change, the economic progress of the worlds developing countries could stall or even be reversed by 2050.

title: Have a College Football Question? Pete Thamel Has Answers
description: What are the keys to the Alabama-L.S.U. game? What happened to Wisconsin? Whats next in conference realignmentand will it ever end? Pete Thamel, The Timess college sports reporter, will answer selected questions from readers this week. Use the comment field below to ask your questions, and the answers will appear on The Quad on Friday.

title: Sothebys Sells Suite of Four Matisse Back Sculptures
description: All weekend, art lovers flocked to Sothebys 10th-floor galleries to see the paintings, drawings and sculptures up for auction there this week. Among the stars was the first of a suite of four bronze sculptures of a womans back that Matisse created over a 23-year period starting in 1908, the works becoming more radical as the years went on.

title: Fed Lowers Its Forecast for Growth, but Takes No Steps
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve significantly reduced its forecast of economic growth through 2013, acknowledging that it had once again overestimated the nations recovery from the 2008 financial crisis.

title: Court Rules Against F.C.C. Fine in Janet Jackson Case
description: WASHINGTON  A federal appeals court on Wednesday again threw out a $550,000 fine against CBS by the Federal Communications Commission forJanet Jacksons wardrobe malfunction during the 2004 Super Bowl halftime show.

title: Is Herman Cain Finished?
description: David Brooks: Gail, I know youre busy with a book deadline on top of everything else, so I will try not to impose any heavy lifting. My simple question is this: If the Greeks end up rejecting the E.U. bailout offer, how should the French and German banks restructure their amortization schedules?

title: SEMA Anoints the Hottest Car, and in an Upset, Its an Italian
description: LAS VEGAS  What were the years best cars for customizing and accessorizing?

title: American Students Gaze Across the Atlantic and See College
description: To a packed room at the Peninsula Hotel in New York City last month, Isabelle Dufault, admissions officer at the cole Htelire in Lausanne, Switzerland, outlined her institutions undergraduate application process. The rapt audience of prospective students and their parents scribbled down notes on essays, deadlines and tuition. Nearly all were residents of the New York area.

title: Ahead of Classic, Uncle Mo Evokes More Questions Than Answers
description: Uncle Mo is the morning-line favorite for the Breeders Cup Classic. Personally, I dont get it. I dont get why he is running in the Classic, and I dont get why he has been selected as the favorite over accomplished horses who have run races over the Classic distance, something that Uncle Mo has not yet done.

title: Rebecca Musical Gets a Theater and a Star
description: Sierra Boggess (The Little Mermaid, Love Never Dies) has been cast to play the second Mrs. de Winter in a Broadway production of Rebecca, a musical version of Daphne du Mauriers gothic novel, the producers announced on Wednesday. They also said they had nailed down the Broadhurst Theater for the musical, no small feat given that producers of several shows must jockey for available theaters in an unusually tight real estate market on Broadway.

title: The Lost Secret of Running
description: Christopher McDougall demonstrates a lost running technique from the 1800s called the 100-Up.

title: Harassment Allegations Could Cut at Core of Cains Appeal
description: Ive spent a lot of time on this blog defending Herman Cain against what I think are overconfident conclusions from the press and political scientists about the viability of his candidacy. So I think its only fair to tell you when I think he might have a real problem on his hands. And Ive become convinced that the sexual harassment allegations against Mr. Cain are a real problem.

title: Timescast | November 2, 2011
description: Greece's cabinet supports the call for a referendum; WikiLeaks' founder can be extradited to Sweden; and the legacy of lies and misinformation in the Libyan conflict.

title: Tenant Sues to Stay Off List of Tenants Who Are Sued
description: James Whelan has a little piece of every New York tenants dream: a rent stabilized apartment. Its a quiet one-bedroom on the Upper East Side where he has lived for 17 years, and it costs him less than $1,500 a month.

title: Supreme Court Looks Again at Methods of D.A.s Office in Louisiana
description: NEW ORLEANS  For the third time in 16 years and the second time in two, the Orleans Parish district attorneys office must explain itself before the United States Supreme Court.

title: Why Do Some People Climb Mountains?
description: For many of us in Colorado, a state that boasts more than 50 peaks rising over 14,000 feet, summer is not complete without bagging a fourteener.

title: Fossil Teeth Put Humans in Europe Earlier Than Thought
description: The fossils seemed hardly worth a second look. The one from England was only a piece of jawbone with three teeth, and the other, from southern Italy, was nothing more than two infant teeth. But scientists went ahead, re-examining them with refined techniques, and found that one specimens age had previously been significantly underestimated and that the others dating and identity had been misinterpreted.

title: A Look at the Films in DOC NYC
description: DOC NYC, a film festival that rounds up some of the years most notable documentaries, returns to two Manhattan locations, the IFC Center and the Skirball Center at New York University. This years festival opens Wednesday night with Werner Herzogs latest work, Into the Abyss, which looks at the effects a triple homicide has on one Texas town. The festival, which runs through Nov. 10, features an array of documentaries, from possible Oscar contenders to works covering well-known figures. Above is a look at a selection of films from the schedule. Tickets and showtimes can be found at the festivals Web site.

title: Ford Focus Electric to Be Priced at $39,995
description: Ford began taking orders for its Focus Electric on Tuesday, pricing the purely electric hatchback at $39,995, inclusive of a $795 destination charge.

title: The Campster | Dartmouth Country
description: In this new column, Jeff Thrope stakes out sublime weekend excursions for the city-dwelling camper.

title: Deficit Panel Could Seek Deadline Extension
description: UPDATE 4:35 p.m.: The special Congressional committee set up to find ways to trim more than $1 trillion from the federal deficit could request an extension from Congress if its members do not reach an agreement before their Nov. 23 deadline, a Democratic leader said on Wednesday.

title: Tom Brown, a Star for Five Decades, Dies at 89
description: Tom Brown, who reached the mens singles final of United States Tennis Championships at Forest Hills in 1946 and at Wimbledon in 1947, losing both times to Jack Kramer, died Oct. 27 in Castro Valley, Calif. He was 89.

title: Scouting Report
description: OPENINGS

title: In Every Note, the Pangs of the Heart
description: Every emotion is larger than life in the songs of Evanescence, the band that performed at Terminal 5 on Tuesday night with its first studio album since 2006, Evanescence (Wind-up), which reached No. 1 on the Billboard chart for a week. The death of a loved one, the breakup of a romance or a crisis of self-doubt all send Amy Lees voice aloft, to wail with unbridled drama while her band thrashes and roars. Im everything you cant control/Somewhere beyond the pain there must be a way to believe, she sang as the set opened with What You Want, the new albums first single.

title: Guilty Verdict for Russian in Arms Trial
description: Viktor Bout, a former Soviet Air Force officer who became known as the Merchant of Death for running what American officials have described as an international arms-trafficking network, was found guilty on Wednesday of conspiring to sell antiaircraft missiles and other weapons to men he believed were Colombian terrorists intent on killing Americans.

title: A Reward for Bird-Friendly Buildings
description: Green buildings usually conjure images of super-efficient, high-tech constructions, not stunned or dead birds. Unfortunately, some of the buildings that rate highest in energy efficiency and other green factors are also among the biggest bird killers.

title: Japanese-American Veterans Are Awarded Medal
description: Congress awarded its highest civilian honor on Wednesday to Japanese-American soldiers who fought in World War II, including Senator Daniel K. Inouye of Hawaii.

title: An Insider Intro to Performa 11
description: If insider repartee about the art world served up by two accomplished British actors is your idea of a good time, then Performa 11 got off to a brisk start on Tuesday night. The fourth incarnation of the visual art performance biennial founded in 2005 by the art historian-impresario RoseLee Goldberg opened at the Skirball Center for the Performing Arts at New York University (one of scores of venues) with the American premiere of Happy Days in the Art World, a short three-act play by the Scandinavian performance-art duo Michael Elmgreen and Ingar Dragset, directed by Toby Frow. (It is among several works commissioned for Performa and will be performed again on Thursday night.)

title: Cain Accusers Lawyer to Meet With Trade Group
description: A spokeswoman for the National Restaurant Association said Wednesday that the lawyer for one of the women who accused Herman Cain of sexual harassment when he was the associations chief executive would discuss the issue with representatives of the association on Thursday.

title: Players Lament Loss of Opening Day
description: Tuesday would have been opening night of the N.B.A. season, but the fun and excitement of the first real jump ball was replaced by mournful musings on what might have been. The ongoing N.B.A. lockout has canceled the leagues games through November and as of now, the new start date is not in sight.

title: Coldplay Rules the World
description: In a busy week on the music charts Coldplays new album sailed to No. 1 around the world, Tom Waits reached the Top 10 for the first time, and Rihanna scored her 11th No. 1 single.

title: Putting Your Hair in New Hands
description: MY mother used to share a bottle of wine with Yvonne, her trash-talking, male-bashing, bouffant-wearing stylist, during her monthly hair appointments in 1980s North Carolina. Sometimes Id go with her and read Seventeen while they cackled and clinked glasses, scissors a-flutter. I knew they had something special.

title: Winstons Champagne Bar
description: PERHAPS it was inevitable that the expanding Venn diagrams of bottle service and old-timey cocktail bars would reach an expensive intersection. Brian Gefter and Michael Satsky, who own the Provocateur nightclub in the meatpacking district, embrace this hybridization at Winstons Champagne Bar, an ornate little lair that opened in September beneath the Gansevoort Park Hotel.

title: Obama Does Interviews, and Romney Follows
description: As much of the news media was chasing Herman Cain on Wednesday, Mitt Romney was chasing the interviews of President Obama.

title: A Dead Dictator Who Draws Tens of Thousands in Italy
description: PREDAPPIO, Italy  The dress code was rigorously black. The chants nostalgic, a medley of Fascist truisms peppered with clipped bursts of Duce, Duce, Duce that was sharply shushed when the straggly parade entered the cemetery in this central Italian town late last month to arrive at its mecca: the tomb of the former Fascist dictator, Benito Mussolini.

title: Homes for $1.5 Million
description: A shingled house in Marin County, Calif; a 1906 mansion in Southern New Jersey; and a duplex in Salt Lake City.

title: What You Get for ... $1.5 Million
description: Salt Lake City

title: Company Anonymously Challenges Consumer Web Site
description: Thanks to Mitt Romney, we know that corporations are people. But should that also mean that a big business gets to file lawsuits anonymously under the name of Company Doe?

title: Diagnosis Cancer: Creating Fact Sheets About Screening, Prevention and Treatment
description: Overview | In this lesson, students consider their knowledge about and associations with cancer. After reading up on new recommendations to limit cancer screenings, they develop patient fact sheets about cancer, focusing on treatments and screening techniques.

title: Purging Cells in Mice Is Found to Combat Aging Ills
description: In a potentially fundamental advance, researchers have opened up a novel approach to combating the effects of aging with the discovery that a special category of cells, known as senescent cells, are bad actors that promote the aging of the tissues. Cleansing the body of the cells, they hope, could postpone many of the diseases of aging.

title: Fantasy Politics
description: Americans must be the most polled people in the world. Every mornings news brings at least half a dozen headlines purporting to tell me how the public feels about their government, or other peoples governments, or maybe other peoples pets. My favorites, for sheer entertainment, are the ones that present completely hypothetical situations.

title: After Storm, Some Early Decision Deadlines Are Extended
description: The freak snowstorm that swept the Northeast last weekend left many families without electricity at a particularly inconvenient time  just as early applications were due.

title: Red Bulls Supporters Go Big and Loud
description: In case you missed it, there was a party going on in the New York Red Bulls supporters section this season. A collection of drums, megaphones, smoke bombs, flags, and hundreds of passionate fans make up what is known as the South Ward, populated by the Red Bulls most boisterous proponents. And for 90 minutes of every Red Bulls home game, they create one of the most festive and vociferous atmospheres in American soccer.

title: X Factor Gets a 2nd Season on Fox
description: Foxs new singing competition, The X Factor, has won a second season. The network said Wednesday that it would bring the series back next year, potentially extending the scheduling pattern that features X Factor in the fall and American Idol in the spring.

title: With 2012 Lineup, Coil Festival Gets Real
description: A new work about feminism from the downtown playwright Young Jean Lee and a show that incorporates music from the band Of Montreal are among the productions to be presented in January at Performance Space 122s Coil festival of contemporary performance. The seventh annual event will run from Jan. 5-29, 2012, at multiple locations across New York City.

title: Graphic Content | Eames Words
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: The Next Steps in the Investigation of MF Global
description: With the Federal Bureau of Investigation looking into possible missing customer money at MF Global, executives of the now-bankrupt commodities and securities firm will be hiring lawyers and dealing with questions that go beyond just how the firm will be liquidated. The issue of whether there were any financial improprieties means the government will be digging through the firms books to see where the money went, and whether any records or reports were falsified.

title: Santorum, in Iowa, Questions the Focus on Perry
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Iowa  Rick Santorum, the former Pennsylvania senator, said he was frustrated that the national news media had focused so much attention during the Republican presidential race on Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, even though Mr. Perry has been scoring well below the front-runners in recent polls.

title: Fears of Fission Rise at Stricken Japanese Plant
description: TOKYO  Nuclear workers at the crippled Fukushima power plant raced to inject boric acid into the plants No. 2 reactor early Wednesday after telltale radioactive elements were detected there, and the plants owner admitted for the first time that fuel deep inside three stricken reactors was probably continuing to experience bursts of fission.

title: Obama Taunts G.O.P.  for Ignoring Jobs Bill
description: President Obama on Wednesday visited another bridge in need of repair  this one somewhat closer to home, between Washington and Virginia  to promote his job-creation proposals as the Senate began the latest partisan debate over his plans.

title: The Buzz
description: A PREVIEW of the must-attend parties, talked-about openings and fashionable night spots for the week ahead.

title: Libya's War of Lies
description: C.J. Chivers reports on the war of misinformation and propaganda by both loyalists and rebels in the Libyan conflict earlier this year.

title: The Worlds Condom, Electricity and Climate Divides
description: Our fine Economix blog has a post up on the new Human Development Report from the United Nations (Twitter feed). The trends are mainly good in the words most struggling places  reprising findings from a year ago. But the reports authors stress that human-driven climate change could easily derail progress in the worlds least developed places.

title: #OccupyWallSt Roundup, Day 47
description: Updated, 5:07 p.m. | A Zuccotti Park kitchen worker was arrested Wednesday afternoon in connection with two sexual assaults at Occupy Wall Street. [Metropolis]

title: Harry Potter Leads Time Warner to Sharp Gain
description: Helped by the final Harry Potter film, Time Warner reported a sharp rise in its quarterly earnings on Wednesday and a record quarter at its film unit, Warner Brothers.

title: A Historic Home in the Center of Bruges
description: This four-story three-bedroom home, draped in vines and dating to 1895, is on the market for $1.35 million.

title: House Hunting in ... Belgium
description: A HISTORIC HOME IN THE CENTER OF BRUGES

title: The Once and Future Way to Run
description: When youre stalking barefoot runners, camouflage helps. Some of them get kind of prancy when they notice you filming, Peter Larson says. They put on this notion of what they think barefoot running should be. It looks weird. Larson, an evolutionary biologist at Saint Anselm College in New Hampshire who has been on the barefoot beat for two years now, is also a stickler about his timing. You dont want to catch them too early in a run, when theyre cold, or too late, when theyre tired.

title: Propaganda in a Time of War
description: This video shows one mans fast-moving effort to generate propaganda in war. Shot during the long-running battle for the Libyan town of Brega in the spring, it presents a doctor working with anti-Qaddafi forces in Ajdabiya as he displayed items he had removed from the pockets of a freshly killed Qaddafi soldier. The doctor then used these items to try to convince two journalists that the soldier was a paid mercenary and that he had been carrying exploding bullets in battle.

title: Concerns About Labor Dispute Prompt Increased Security at Sothebys
description: With the world economy in such an uncertain state, Sothebys fall auction of Impressionist and modern art Wednesday night was bound to be tense anyway. But the auction houses continuing contract dispute with its unionized art handlers  who have been locked out for three months and have been staging increasingly publicized demonstrations  recently prompted it to institute much stricter security measures surrounding the fall sale.

title: Relief Is Slow to Reach Cambodia Flood Victims
description: BATTAMBANG, Cambodia  The high water is devastating even for a country inured to monsoon rains and waterlogged rice fields: wide swaths of Cambodias countryside have become giant lakes, with villagers and livestock marooned on scattered patches of dry land.

title: Djibouti Adds 850 Soldiers to Peacekeeping Force in Somalia
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  The tiny country of Djibouti will send about 850 soldiers to an African Union peacekeeping mission in Somalia this month, a spokesman for the mission said Wednesday. It is only the third country to do so after a series of unmet promises from a number of African nations.

title: Euro Crisis Shifts Mood for G-20
description: FRANKFURT  The Group of 20 summit meeting in Cannes was supposed to be a chance for Europe and the events host, President Nicolas Sarkozy of France, to shine. Instead, the two-day meeting is coming at an extraordinarily dark time for the Continent, with Europe in political disarray, its economy tipping into recession and the future of the euro zone in doubt.

title: Photo Replay: Nov. 2
description: A view of the day in sports, including Albert Pujols in bronze.

title: Rethinking McGwire
description: It was hard to ignore Mark McGwire during the baseball post-season. His position at the near end of the dugout made him seem larger than life on the television.

title: Arab League Says Syria Accepts Its Plan for Talks; Protesters Are Skeptical
description: CAIRO  Syria accepted an Arab League plan meant to halt violence and lead to dialogue with the opposition within two weeks, league officials announced Wednesday, but government opponents and others voiced doubt that Damascus could or would change tactics so abruptly.

title: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Afghanistan, Thailand, Ukraine and Yemen.

title: College Majors Matter
description: We write a lot on Economix about whether college is worth it. In a piece in Investors Business Daily, Alex Tabarrok, an economics professor at George Mason University, suggests that Americans are focusing on the wrong question. They shouldnt be debating whether college in general is worth it; they should instead be thinking about whether the specific college degree theyre considering is marketable.

title: A Mind Is A Terrible Thing To Lose
description: OK, I see that some people are doubling down on the claim that rising inequality is all about education  when what the CBO report drives home is that this is all wrong, the big increase has come from gains at the very top. I have to admit that I have a sneaking suspicion that this is in part driven by KDS (DS for derangement syndrome): some people will rush to take a position precisely because I have debunked it. But anyway, its really, really wrong.

title: TimesCast | Assange Extradition Possible
description: November 2, 2011 - Ravi Somaiya at a London courthouse, where judges ruled that WikiLeaks' founder, Julian Assange, can be extradited to Sweden.

title: TimesCast | Supporting the Referendum
description: November 2, 2011 - Rachel Donadio reports from Athens, where Greece's prime minister is rallying more support for a referendum on Europe's aid package.

title: CME Raises Suspicions on MF Global Transfers
description: 5:48 p.m. | Updated

title: Strike at US Foods Takes Aim at Private Equity
description: 7:00 p.m. | Updated

title: Honors For Two City Groups, and a Visit With the First Lady
Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Afghanistan, Thailand, Ukraine and Yemen.

title: New Girl and Glee Return to Lineup but Fall Short
description: After a month of riding the pine in favor of playoff baseball, New Girl and Glee returned to the Fox lineup on Tuesday night, only to be welcomed by diminished audiences. Both shows fell 18 percent in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic compared with their last new episodes, on Oct. 4. New Girl was accompanied by a series low of 7.5 million total viewers, while Glee dropped to 7.4 million (although Glee had shown signs of audience deterioration even before the break).

title: On Location | Azores
description: Pedro Correia and his wife, Graa, were looking for a dream home for their expanding family on So Miguel Island in the Azores.

title: Johns Hopkins Student Applies Dark Energy to the Black Art of Racing
description: The team that won the 2011 American Le Mans Series Drivers and Team Championships was a bit different than most. In addition to engineers, mechanics, drivers and pit crew, Dyson Racing also retained the services of Dillon Brout, a college student.

title: A Dream Home Almost a Decade in the Making
description: SO MIGUEL ISLAND, THE AZORES  Pedro Correia and his wife, Graa, had lived their entire lives on So Miguel, the largest of nine volcanic islands in the Azorean archipelago. They were content for many years with their two-bedroom bungalow on the north coast of this lush island pocked with cobalt crater lakes and overrun with hydrangeas. But with a growing family and a tight-knit clan of about 50 relatives to entertain, the couple decided about decade ago that it was time to build a larger home.

title: The Civil Wars: Billie Jean
description: Just because.

title: What Money Can Buy
description: Million-dollar horses make headlines, but these days, thats mostly when they pass through the sales ring. In the winners circle, a decidedly more blue-collar group is taking home the cash. At this years Prix de lArc de Triomphe, the most prestigious and richest race on the European calendar, a crowd of more than 50,000 was stunned into silence when Danedream, a cheap filly from Germany, crossed the line well in front of millions of dollars worth of allegedly the worlds finest bloodstock. Danedream was purchased as a yearling for just 9,000 euros (or around $12,500). Her earnings now top 2 million euros.

title: Woman Who Accused Cain Wont Go Public, Lawyer Says
description: 8:40 p.m. | Updated Joel P. Bennett, the lawyer for one of the women who has made accusations against Mr. Cain, said that his client had decided not to go public or to make a public statement herself in an effort to shield herself from the media frenzy swirling around the situation.

title: The Overblown Islamist Threat
description: Washington

title: Artifacts | Spartacus Chetwynds Monster Divas
description: Desperately seeking an antidote to the slick over-professionalism that is flat-lining contemporary art? Look no farther than Spartacus Chetwynd, a 38-year-old British performance artist whose insistently awkward productions are as comic-heroic as her adopted first name.

title: Rocking Like Clapton, on Batteries
description: You might not suppose that, after more than a thousand years, theres much room for improvement in the noble guitar. Apart from an electric spinoff about 80 years ago, its pretty much always been the same: a body, a neck and six strings.

title: Not Following the Leader
description: Almost everywhere Ive traveled this fall, people have asked me whether its true that Justice Clarence Thomas is the real, if under-appreciated, intellectual leader of the Supreme Court.

title: A Congregation in Skinny Jeans
description: ONE recent Sunday night on the south side of Williamsburg, Brooklyn, a crowd of more than 100 men and women in their 20s and early 30s gathered.

title: Israel Tests a Long-Range Missile
description: JERUSALEM  Israel tested what experts said was a long-range ballistic missile on Wednesday morning, firing it out to sea from an Air Force base just south of Tel Aviv and causing jittery Israelis who saw the launch on their way to work to jam emergency lines.

title: Commemorating Mussolini
description: Italian authorities sought to hide the burial site of Benito Mussolini after he died, in 1945. But the graves location rapidly became a matter of intense interest.

title: Amtrak Expands Wi-Fi Service on East Coast Routes
description: On Monday, Amtrak expanded its free Wi-Fi service, adding wireless Internet connectivity to 12 East Coast train routes.

title: Mobile Game Favorites of the Experts, of All Ages
description: With well over 50,000 mobile games on the market, shopping for a new one can be a game in itself.

title: The One Best Way to Run
description: The best-selling book Born to Run popularized the notion of barefoot running, and as a result, scores of runners have given up cushioned shoes and opted to exercise barefoot or in barely-there running shoes. But as the books author, Christopher McDougall, explains in this weeks New York Times Magazine, many barefoot runners still dont know how to run.

title: The Rebirth of Cool in South Soho
description: Once devoid of retail, Soho has become a mecca for stylish shoppers.

title: 12 Are Charged in Medicare Fraud Schemes Said to Cost $95 Million
description: Federal agents swarmed several medical clinics and homes in New York City on Wednesday, arresting 10 people on charges of running Medicare fraud schemes that bilked the government out of $95 million, federal officials said.

title: Rangers to Keep Lineup; Avery Wont Play
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Sean Avery will not play for the Rangers on Thursday, Coach John Tortorella said. But Avery is fine with that. He is simply happy to be back with the team.

title: South SoHo, Hips Home on the Fringe
description: SOHO is dead. Long live SoHo.

title: Tennessee Williams Play Set Nowhere Near the South
description: What really stands out about the title of Tennessee Williamss late one-act Now the Cats With Jewelled Claws is not the stylish image, a menacing relative to that more vulnerable feline on a sweltering roof. Its that unexpected first word. Its urgent and oddly apt, evoking a ringmaster selling his next act.

title: Distilling the Spirits of Sages
description: His quotes could belong to Christopher Hitchens. Men face reality. Women dont. Thats why men need to drink.

title: A Once-Peaceful Yemeni City Under Siege
description: While the violence in Taiz is just one piece of the complicated conflict that has torn apart this country over the past 10 months of political uprising, it is perhaps the most pertinent as Taiz once was a city where law, order and civil society once flourished more than in any other part of Yemen. Now its civilians live with urban warfare on a daily basis.

title: Vogue Encyclo Is Looking for Contributors
description: Want to pitch a story idea toVogueItalia? Earlier this month, the venerable magazine startedVogue Encyclo, a kind of online fashionencyclopediathat invites users to contribute articles on fashion, designers, cinema and other topics, much like a wiki. Vogue Italia editors will vet and assign ideas, with articles published onVogue Encyclo with the users byline.

title: Q&A: Locking Up a USB Drive
description: Q.

title: Fox Renews The X Factor
description: Foxs new singing competition, The X Factor, has won a second season. The network said on Wednesday that it would bring the series back next year, potentially extending The X Factor in the alternating annual schedule it has set up with American Idol (Factor in the fall, Idol in the spring). Regular telecasts of The X Factor, created by Simon Cowell, have averaged about 13.5 million viewers since the series started in September. It has sharply improved Foxs performance on Wednesday and Thursday nights, but it has underwhelmed the television industry, partly because Idol is higher rated and partly because Mr. Cowell said ahead of time that he expected 20 million viewers to tune in. In an interview last week he said that he had overstated the ratings potential of the series but expected the ratings to pick up as the viewer voting period began on Wednesday night.

title: Using Gmails Canned Responses
description: If you are tired of sending out the same e-mail response from your Gmail account  say, for an item on eBay that has already sold or directions to your party  the Canned Responses feature from Gmail Labs can save some time and typing. When you turn on the setting, you can save short messages and send them repeatedly as replies with a quick mouse click.

title: An Opening for Some Song and Dance
description: Wanted: Singing, dancing, comedy, romance and, most of all, original music. When: By the end of April. Where: A Broadway theater, if available (a big if).

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,811 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: 3 Prospective 2013 Candidates Find a Stage
description: Scott M. Stringer, the Manhattan borough president, stressed the need to improve education and infrastructure while he criticized the Bloomberg administrations stop-and-frisk policing tactics and poor understanding, as he put it, of Albany.

title: The China Conundrum
description: What seems at first glance a boon for American colleges and Chinese students is, on closer inspection, a tricky fit for both.

description: Lens: Abd

title: South SoHo: One-Stop Shopping
description: ONE of the draws of SoSoHo is its motley assortment of shops, from fashion and high design to skateboards and scooters. Theres something fun for the whole family  in chic and slimming black, of course.

title: After a World Title Is Lost, a Board to Scrutinize
description: When you lose a long match by 4.7 international match points, there will be several deals on which, in hindsight, you could have turned the result around. But the ones that come in for the closest scrutiny are those from the final session.

title: All the Texts, Without All the Costs
description: Frank Radice, the former president of the National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences and now a media consultant, is a compulsive texter. But after racking up more than $1,000 in texting charges on a monthly mobile phone bill two years ago, he began searching for a less expensive way to communicate.

title: Catch-22 Alive and Well in Guantanamo Bay
description: There are many reasons why it has been a horrible mistake to dump this countrys effective and tested federal court system in favor of an ineffective and untested system of military tribunals for prisoners suspected of terrorism  well actually for Muslim prisoners suspected of terrorism. One particularly compelling reason is that tribunals do not seem to have the authority to actually free defendants.

title: Digital Diary: A Kindle Disconnect?
description: I just finished reading The Marriage Plot, Jeffrey Eugenidess latest novel.

title: Apple Admits Software Bugs Hurting Battery Life in iPhone
description: Apple has finally broken its silence on battery life of its latest iPhone, the 4S, saying software bugs in its latest operating system are causing the issues.

title: Styled to a T | Mika Rottenberg
description: The Artist

title: Now Showing | Mika Rottenberg
description: Mika Rottenbergs video installations depict dreamlike assembly lines that parse animal, vegetable and mineral elements down to their base materialities, and, through strenuous, ritualized monotony, catalyze the production of weird junk: relatable daily circumstances for most of the worlds population. The Buenos Aires-born artist, raised in Israel and based in New York, casts her workers for their unusual corporeal commodities  jumbo figures, endless hair, freaky joints  and they often seem to perform their tasks without the knowledge of why, or of their ornate connections to one another.

title: Shopping for Bathroom Faucets
description: The architect Katherine Chia searched for faucets with clean lines.

description: An excerpt from Mika Rottenberg's film, "Dough."

title: The High-Tech Home Office
description: WORKING from home has its charms. My home office is quiet (except when the baby stirs), theres no dress code, I can choose my own music and I have my own executive washroom. The only downside is that my buildings super  my wife  wont allow cigars.

title: Bathroom Faucets
description: THE architect Katherine Chia usually spends her time thinking about buildings and interiors, but recently she has been focusing her attention on smaller-scale design. Her firm, Desai/Chia Architecture, which she runs with her husband, Arjun Desai, has been developing a line of bathroom fixtures.

title: Ayala Serfatys Light Sculptures on Display
description: The ethereal glass filament-and-polymer Soma light sculptures created by the Israeli designer Ayala Serfaty appear to be incredibly delicate, yet a handful of them has safely made the journey to Manhattan for her solo exhibition, In Vein, which opened this week at the Cristina Grajales Gallery.

title: Global Tables New Northern Outpost
description: After 15 years in SoHo, Global Table, the tabletop and home accessories store, is opening a second location, on the Upper West Side.

title: A Barstool That Offers a Seat on the 50-Yard Line
description: GrassSit offers a fresh spin on the classic barstool. The stainless steel base is topped with ersatz grass recycled from local school football fields  sometimes complete with a yard line.

title: In Karen Knorrs Photography, an Ironic Sense of Place
description: Karen Knorr is an American photographer living in London who was born in Germany, grew up in Puerto Rico and went to art school in Paris and London. Fittingly, she has made a career out of examining the meaning of places: investigating rooms, houses and monuments, and using them to comment on taste, class, gender, art, history and literature. That sounds like an earnest business, except that Ms. Knorrs images manage to be either wickedly funny or thunderously lovely, or both. In any case, it all began with real estate.

title: From a Jail Cell, Egyptian Blogger Decries Military Rule
description: In an essay composed in a Cairo prison cell two days after he was detained for refusing to recognize the authority of a military prosecutor, a prominent Egyptian blogger and activist accused the countrys military rulers of insolence.

title: A Minimalist Loft, With Touches of Chipotle
description: MARK CRUMPACKER, a branding expert who created the original Chipotle Mexican Grill logo in the 1990s, became the companys chief marketing officer three years ago. His partner, Tim Wildin, is the corporate director of concept development, a job Mr. Crumpacker helped him land.

description: OBERLIN, Ohio

title: College Graduates Debt Burden Grew, Yet Again, in 2010
description: Students who graduated from college in 2010 with student loans owed an average of $25,250, up 5 percent from the previous year, according to a report scheduled for release Thursday.

title: From School to the Stage, the Fast Way
description: The pianist George Li is fresh faced even by the standards of the Young Concert Artists series, which presented him in his New York recital debut on Tuesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall.

title: Long Live the Pixies
description: So I happened to be in Portland, Me., last night, attending a concert by the Pixies at the State Theater. The bands frontman, alternatively known as Black Francis and Frank Black, has said that these reunion shows are purely about cashing in on the bands indie-rock credibility. However, having now seen them live, I can tell you that this is not the whole story. They simply played too well, and were too obviously moved by the unconditional love of the crowd, which cheered as vociferously for the B-sides as for the singles. Frank howled as ferociously as ever, and it was inspiring to see Kim Deal, the bass player, in such apparently sound mental and physical health. This I did not expect. In 2002, a story in this magazine by Ethan Smith detailed the problems, personal and otherwise, she had making a record for her other band, the Breeders. It included this memorable exchange between Kim and her twin sister, Kelley, who had been in and out of the band a few times:

title: Egyptian Entrepreneur Shares Lessons From Her Playbook
description: DUBAI  When Hanan Abdel Meguid started her first technology company in Cairo nearly 20 years ago, the Web was not publicly available in the Middle East and many big global players like Microsoft did not operate there.

title: Market Ready
description: Q. Our wood floors look worn. Is it worth the cost and disruption to refinish them before selling?

title: Can Yahoo Be Rescued?
The Wilde Boys Salon, for Poetry or Maybe a Hot Date
description: A FEW weeks ago, a gaggle of young men gathered at a large, art-filled apartment on lower Fifth Avenue to discuss poetry. Stylishly disheveled and slimly tailored, they took stock of one another at the bar before settling into the parlor, which was tastefully furnished with books, Midcentury Modern chairs and a large painting by Jay Davis.

title: Selling Chessy Rayners Treasures
description: When the legendary decorator Chessy Rayner died more than 13 years ago, she left behind several homes full of treasures. About 750 of those items will be available at the first estate sale on One Kings Lane, in a 72-hour online event that begins on Saturday at 11 a.m. Eastern time.

title: In an L.A. Childhood, the First Mysteries
description: MY first memory and so, in some essential way, the beginning of my life starts with me on my knees in front of an old console television set. I was 3 years old and didnt know where I was or even that the TV was there because my eyes were closed. There was a sense of excitement tingling in my shoulders and thrumming at the back of my head; an electricity that made me want to laugh out loud, but I didnt laugh.

title: A Minimalist Loft in Greenwich Village
description: Two Chipotle executives didnt intend on creating a luxury version of the restaurant in their home, but colleagues have noticed connections.

description: Claire Cain Miller discusses the recent update to the Google TV software and Nick Wingfield reports on user complaints about the battery life of the iPhone 4S.

description: Sheep lawnmowers, chicken coops built to order in Brooklyn, and other small agricultural businesses.

description: Frank Pizzurro, the owner of Brooklyn Denim Co. answers questions; blankets are worn as ponchos; and shearling bags.

title: Short Sainthood for Steve Jobs
description: THE glowing obituaries appeared moments after Steve Jobss death was announced on Oct. 5. Silicon Valleys radiant Sun King, eulogized The San Jose Mercury News. His name was floated for Time magazines Person of the Year, though the honor traditionally goes to the living. Even Gawker, the snarky media blog, adopted the sober tone of a state funeral.

title: When in Germany
description: The United States mens under-23 and under-20 national teams will hold training camps in Duisburg, Germany, from Nov. 7 to 16 at the Sportschule Wedau, a German sporting school.

title: Running Game Looms Large for Alabama and L.S.U.
description: When Louisiana State played at Alabama two years ago, the game was so physical the Tigers were carting players off the field. The injured included running back Charles Scott, who broke his collarbone in the 24-15 loss.

description: To the Editor:

title: 26 Nations Defy Europe on Airline Emissions
description: China, the United States and 24 other nations backed a declaration on Wednesday urging that their airlines be exempted from the European Unions Emissions Trading System.

title: Vonnegut in All His Complexity
description: Charles J. Shields got nowhere with Harper Lee when he tried to interview her for the 2006 biography Mockingbird. But he got lucky with Kurt Vonnegut. Mr. Shields found a lonely talkative octogenarian who had scores to settle and a reputation that badly needed restoring. Vonnegut had once told Martin Amis that the only way he could regain credit for his early work, those books from the 1950s and 1960s once so beloved by college kids, would be to die. He died on April 11, 2007, less than a year after Mr. Shields first approached him. And the two did not spend much time together. But Vonnegut gave the go-ahead that has allowed Mr. Shields to construct And So It Goes, an incisive, gossipy page-turner of a biography, even if its hard to tell just how authorized this book really is. Denied permission to quote from Vonneguts letters, Mr. Shields relies on paraphrases and patchwork to create a seamless-sounding account. Astonishingly, this book has nearly 1,900 notes to identify separate sources and quotations. But it doesnt sound choppy at all.

title: Homeless at the Protests
description: To the Editor:
