description: To the Editor:

title: Arizona Senate, at Governors Urging, Ousts Chief of Redistricting Panel
description: PHOENIX  A decision by Gov. Jan Brewer and Arizonas Senate to oust the chairwoman of the citizens commission redrawing the states political boundaries prompted legal challenges on Wednesday as critics of the move accused Republicans of meddling in a redistricting process that voters sought to insulate from politics.

title: Rent Deal Aids Ailing East Village Bookstore
description: A deal has been reached to reduce the rent for St. Marks Bookshop, an East Village institution whose problems over the past year prompted an outpouring of support from neighbors and literary figures.

title: Flamenco Fusion With Argentine Flair Salted by Traditional Modes
description: The form of the flamenco singer Diego el Cigalas concert on Tuesday night at Town Hall wasnt much of a story. The members of his five-piece band walked on and off, according to arrangements. The modes and rhythms of traditional flamenco dominated the two-hour concert, no matter where the songs came from originally, and made it feel like one long song. El Cigala, in a dark sharkskin suit, gold jewelry and black velvet slipper shoes, stayed mostly stationary on a high stool at center stage, speaking between a few songs while pulled back from the microphone, as if he had no worries about clarifying or tending to his identity.

title: A Look at How Brooklyn Nannies Are Paid
description: The going rate for nannies in brownstone Brooklyn in 2011: $15 an hour.

title: Capturing Subtlety in Spare Sounds
description: In his New York recital debut on Sunday afternoon at the Frick Collection, the young German pianist Martin Helmchen demonstrated the qualities that have already propelled him to a major career in Europe.

title: Explorations, With Nature as Her Guide
description: History is filled with cautionary tales of people who tarried too long on the stage. This is especially true of older women; we like to tell them when its time to go.

title: Trying to Alter Perceptions, Mexico Uses Candid Chitchat
description: CAMPAIGNS that feature hidden-camera commercials are popular among marketers seeking to change perceptions about products because they offer consumers a chance to watch other consumers share candid opinions. Examples include spots for Folgers instant coffee, Burger King, Pizza Hut and Ford Motor.

title: Justices Weigh Judges Duties to Assess Reliability of Eyewitness Testimony
description: WASHINGTON  Though studies and lower court decisions have found that eyewitness testimony can be both unusually problematic and unusually persuasive, the Supreme Court on Wednesday did not seem inclined to rule that the Constitution requires judges to view such evidence with special skepticism. Ordinary trial procedures, several justices suggested, should be adequate to address the potential unreliability of eyewitness identifications.

title: Two French Singers With Mixed Languages and Gender Roles
description: Triumphal regular visits from William Christie and his exceptional French ensemble Les Arts Florissants have proved time and again that New Yorkers show a passion for relatively obscure French operas of the Baroque and Classical periods, as long as they are handled with the regal pomp for which they were designed.

title: A Once-Peaceful Yemeni City Under Siege
description: While the violence in Taiz is just one piece of the complicated conflict that has torn apart this country over the past 10 months of political uprising, it is perhaps the most pertinent as Taiz once was a city where law, order and civil society once flourished more than in any other part of Yemen. Now its civilians live with urban warfare on a daily basis.

title: AOL Says Ad Revenue Continues to Increase
description: AOL said Wednesday that it had increased its global advertising revenue for the second consecutive quarter, indicating some improvement at the beleaguered digital media company.

title: Australian Connection to a Premier Matchup
description: An Australian walks into a bar in Calgary during the 1988 Winter Olympics. He meets a fellow reveler, from Baton Rouge, La. They bond over shots of tequila, and a friendship forms that lasts to this day, as do others that sprang from it.

title: The Joys, and Frustrations, of Snow Days in November
description: With the start of winter still weeks away, the Millburn School District in New Jersey used the last of its three allotted snow days on Wednesday, with three of its seven schools still without power, Internet or phone service since the weekend snowstorm.

title: A Once-Peaceful Yemeni City Under Siege
description: The violence in Taiz, a city where law and order once flourished, demonstrates the complicated conflict that has torn Yemen apart since the political uprising began 10 months ago.

title: Renewed Health and Star Filly Have Trainer in Breeders Cup Classic
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Two years ago Larry Jones pulled his white cowboy hat over his eyes and rode off the racetrack and into the sunset, swearing he was done training horses. He was cranky on his way out, too, blaming his owners and their incessant demands for taking all the joy out of the only thing he had ever wanted to do.

title: Ancient City Anchors Political Standoff in Yemen
description: TAIZ, Yemen  This ancient city among the steep cliffs of central Yemen, once known as the commercial and intellectual hub of this south Arabian nation, has emerged as the violent center of a long political standoff between a president who refuses to step down and demonstrators who want him out.

title: Years Later, Lawsuit Seeks to Recreate a Wedding
description: Of all the many things that make up a wedding, few are more important than the photographs.

title: Running From Poverty to Fame and Tragedy
description: Gemma Atwals documentary Marathon Boy, a film-festival favorite that will be shown on HBO on Thursday night, is a wrenching experience largely because it uses the moods and methods of true crime and pulp fiction to tell a story that is nominally about poverty, politics and the toxic mingling of celebrity culture and national pride in modern India.

title: A Giants On-Again, Off-Again Role
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The intricacies of N.F.L. roster machinations are not necessarily common knowledge in places like LaPlace, La., a town about 25 miles west of New Orleans that is perhaps best known as the Andouille Capital of the World. And this is why Barbara Gibbs hears the same questions when she stops in at the market or even when she is sitting in church.

title: Georgia Men Held in Plot to Attack Government
description: TOCCOA, Ga.  At the Waffle House here, no one can believe that the gray-haired men who came in almost daily for egg sandwiches and coffee could have been terrorists plotting to blow up government buildings and kill masses of people using poison from a bean plant that people in this rural part of the state grow to ward off moles.

title: Cable TV and Movies Buoy News Corp. Profits
description: News Corporation used its quarterly earnings report on Wednesday to highlight the success of its cable television and film units while trying to redirect investors attention from a phone hacking scandal at the companys British newspaper unit.

title: Poster Boys
description: Hollywood is full of weird little jobs. You see some of them on the credits at the end of the movie: Gaffer, Best Boy. In a lot of cases, the people in those mysterious-sounding occupations seem to get there by mistake, side-tracked en route to some other career. In fact, Los Angeles is chockablock with talented people who wound up in an entirely different profession from the one theyd originally started out in. I know painters who became art directors and set designers, a singer who started life as an actress and screenwriter. Two would-be novelists who both ended up film editors, though one of them eventually quit to become a yoga teacher.

title: The Silent Majority: Directors Statement
description: THIS film, The Silent Majority, was born out of a larger project. We are making a feature-length documentary using the Super 8 home movies of some of Richard M. Nixons aides. As we combed through the home movies, we fell in love with these long shots of crowds out to meet the president. Filming over Nixons shoulder, the cameramen lingered on the faces of these ordinary, anonymous Americans. We began referring to this footage in edit-room shorthand as the Silent Majority footage.

title: The Silent Majority
description: Consisting of rare footage filmed by President Richard M. Nixons aides, this experimental documentary revisits Nixons campaign to win an elusive majority.

title: Loosening Rules, China Allows Facial and Neck Tattoos to Join Army
description: BEIJING  Seeking to broaden its appeal to Chinas better-educated and perhaps more hip youth, the Peoples Liberation Army has dropped a longtime bar to enlisting in the service: now, recruits can sport tattoos on their faces and necks.

title: Fall for Dance
description: The dance festivals third program at City Center was a mixed bag of ballet, tap and contemporary European dance.

title: Of Gemini and Fauns and Glimpses of the Past
description: On Tuesday night at City Center the Fall for Dance Festival offered its third program, a mixed bag of ballet, tap, contemporary European dance  the generic variety  and, most mercifully, the Israeli choreographer Ohad Naharin. He defies categorization. The sight of Hubbard Street Dance Chicago performing Mr. Naharins Three to Max gave the evening a welcome lift.

title: Lottery Numbers
Comcast Rises on Cable; Film Helps Time Warner
description: Increases in high-speed Internet customers and advertising sales at NBCUniversals trove of profitable cable networks helped increase third-quarter profits at the Comcast Corporation, the company said Wednesday.

title: Firing Sought for One of Two Officers in Bell Shooting Case
description: Prosecutors with the New York Police Department recommended on Wednesday that one of the two officers being tried in connection with the killing of Sean Bell five years ago should be allowed to stay on the force while the other should be fired.

title: High-Tension N.B.A. Talks Resume, but Theyre Between Union Officials
description: Another tense meeting to address the N.B.A. lockout will take place Thursday in Manhattan  only this time without owners or league officials and without a prospect for a deal. If a consensus emerges, it will be solely between the leaders of the players association.

title: Sending Texts by E-Mail
description: For people who prefer the ease of texting using a computer keyboard rather than fumbling with the tiny buttons or touch screens on cellphones, there is a way to text via e-mail without charge.

title: Many Alarms Rang Before MF Global Crashed
description: A little before 2 a.m. on Monday, Jon S. Corzine was in MF Globals offices in Midtown Manhattan, scrambling to cut a deal to save his firm. Haggard from too little sleep, at times pacing the hallways, he at least had a handshake agreement with one suitor for the firm.

title: Note to Readers
description: As part of its digital expansion, the opinion department introduces Op-Docs, a forum for short, opinionated documentaries, produced with wide creative latitude and a range of artistic styles, about current affairs, contemporary life and historical subjects. Documentary submissions by both renowned and emerging independent filmmakers and artists are welcome.

title: Low Cash Flow Threatens China
description: The robust earnings growth among Chinese companies does not tell the full story. Despite strong growth in net income, operating cash flow deteriorated sharply in the first half of the year. Many companies lent more to customers to drum up sales as demand weakened. Any resulting bad debt could hit companies and their lending banks. Similar debt triangles haunted Chinese companies in the 1990s.

title: Fraud Case Seen as a Red Flag for Psychology Research
description: A well-known psychologist in the Netherlands whose work has been published widely in professional journals falsified data and made up entire experiments, an investigating committee has found. Experts say the case exposes deep flaws in the way science is done in a field, psychology, that has only recently earned a fragile respectability.

title: Cain Says Perry Is Orchestrating a Smear Campaign
description: WASHINGTON  A defiant Herman Cain accused Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, a Republican rival, of orchestrating a smear campaign to destroy his presidential candidacy, as additional accusations emerged Wednesday that Mr. Cain made unwanted sexual overtures to women while he led the National Restaurant Association more than a decade ago.

title: Trial Begins for Man Charged With Falsely Accusing Ex-Girlfriend
description: A little more than a year after she accused her ex-boyfriend of rape, Seemona Sumasar was pulled over by the police near her Queens home. Before she had a chance to speak, she said, she was handcuffed.

title: In Local Races, Cuomo Lends a Hand, and a Face and a Voice
description: ALBANY  Gwyn Mannion, an engineer, mother of six and political novice who is running for a seat in the Onondaga County Legislature, is sending a postcard to voters presenting, on its face, a Jeopardy-style clue: Two leaders who work across party lines to deliver real results.

title: Who Speaks for the Silent Majority?
description: Ann Arbor, Mich.

title: The Storm That Nearly Lost the War
U.S. Considered Taking Partial Ownership of Solyndra
description: In the days just before the solar panel maker Solyndra sought bankruptcy protection, the Obama administration considered another emergency debt restructuring that would have made the government the owner of 35 to 40 percent of the company, according to e-mail messages provided to House investigators.

title: Experts Say N.Y. Police Dept. Isnt Policing Itself
description: Seven narcotics investigators are convicted of planting drugs on people to meet arrest quotas. Eight current and former patrol officers are charged with smuggling guns into the state. Another is charged with making a false arrest, apparently as a favor for his cousin. Three more are convicted of robbing a perfume warehouse.

title: Day of the Armadillo
description: Important News You May Have Missed Dept.: While you and I have been spending the fall worrying about the secret talks of the Congressional supercommittee or trying to determine whether it would be a fun idea to dress as Rick Santorum for Halloween, other even more fascinating news events have been occurring.

title: Special Manhattan Court Trims Case Backlog, but Defense Lawyers See Drawbacks
description: The request, made in Manhattan Criminal Court, seemed rather routine: A lawyer, Logan Germick, was asking a judge to postpone his clients trial, and for only a day, at that.

title: The Birth Control Solution
description: What if there were a solution to many of the global problems that confront us, from climate change to poverty to civil wars? There is, but it is starved of resources. Its called family planning, and it has been a victim of Americas religious wars.

title: Cain to Review Links to a Nonprofit
description: An outside lawyer will review allegations that Herman Cains presidential campaign accepted tens of thousands of dollars in goods and services from a tax-exempt organization founded by his chief of staff, a spokesman for the candidate said Wednesday.

title: Conservative Bloggers Cool to Cain
description: Reacting to new harassment allegations against Herman Cain, the Republican presidential candidate, on Wednesday, some conservative bloggers began tempering their defense of him.

title: Thursday: One Without a Title
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  When I started here at Wordplay, I promised you all that we would enjoy the variety of ways in which constructors slice, dice, shuffle and mince words. Today, we have a perfect example of that.

title: The Company to Call for Help With Your Exit Strategy
description: Goodbye, cruel world!

title: Greece on the Brink
description: We are no fans of political referenda, with their simplistic yes or no answers to complicated policy questions. But we understand the dire circumstances that led Prime Minister George Papandreou of Greece to suddenly call for a national referendum in December or January on the terms of the latest European bailout plan.

title: Deficit Committee Could Seek More Time, a Top Democrat Says
description: WASHINGTON  A top House Democrat said Wednesday that a bipartisan committee seeking ways to slash the budget deficit could seek an extension if it was unable to meet its deadline, just three weeks away.

title: Oaklands Port Shuts Down as Protesters March on Waterfront
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  Thousands of Occupy Oakland protesters expanded their anti-Wall Street demonstrations on Wednesday, marching through downtown, picketing banks and swarming the port. By early evening, port authorities said maritime operations there were effectively shut down.

title: Health Guideline Panels Struggle with Conflicts of Interest
description: When a federal panel recently recommended against prostate cancer screening for most men, it tried to steer clear of any suggestions of commercial bias.

title: Plan to Issue New Permits for Parking Is Debated
description: Nine blocks from the steel shadow of Atlantic Yards in Brooklyn, Gib Veconi circles Prospect Heights nightly in his 13-year-old Volvo wagon looking for a parking spot, like a buzzard scouring for a meal.

title: Whistling in Cannes
description: The European debt crisis is not the only threat to the global economy, which is already slowing perilously. When leaders of the worlds 20 big emerging economies meet in Cannes, France, on Thursday and Friday, they should agree on an agenda to boost growth. We dont hold out much hope.

title: A Tsunami Defense Under Scrutiny
description: Japanese authorities plan to rebuild a $1.6 billion breakwater even though experts are divided over whether it was effective in protecting against the tsunami.

title: With an App, Your Next Date Could Be Just Around the Corner
description: Christina Wang has her date-night routine down pat. She combs her hair, fixes her makeup and then checks her phone, hoping to find Mr. Right, who might just happen to be nearby, right now.

title: Mets Eyes Are on Reyes as Free Agency Begins
description: Jim Duquette laughed as he recalled the time, more than a decade ago, that he first heard Jose Reyess name.

title: Japan Revives a Sea Barrier That Failed to Hold
description: KAMAISHI, Japan  After three decades and nearly $1.6 billion, work on Kamaishis great tsunami breakwater was completed three years ago. A mile long, 207 feet deep and jutting nearly 20 feet above the water, the quake-resistant structure made it into the Guinness World Records last year and rekindled fading hopes of revival in this rusting former steel town.

title: Postcard From L.S.U.: Tiger Seen as Too Tame
description: BATON ROUGE, La. A logo is often the visual embodiment of a team, and a point of pride for fans. The logo on L.S.U.s helmets is simple: a round tiger head with purple stripes, in full growl.

title: Conflicts of Interest on Federal Guidelines Panels
description: New rules for writing clinical practice guidelines.

title: The Stumbling Campaign of Herman Cain
description: It is hard to imagine Herman Cain as a major presidential candidate, but, nonetheless, there he sits atop several respected opinion polls as the Republican Partys nominating contests draw ever closer.

title: Postcard From Alabama: The Routine of Preparation
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala.  During a week like this one, with a marquee matchup against top-ranked Louisiana State looming on Saturday, players and coaches for No. 2 Alabama are focusing on staying focused.

title: Having the Watchdogs to Tea
description: Congress rarely remembers that it is responsible for overseeing the Federal Election Commission  the party-hack-ridden agency that enables campaign abuses. The House elections subcommittee has now summoned commission members to a rare hearing on Thursday about its work. Rather than a severe grilling, its more likely to be a meet-and-greet smile among professional backslappers.

title: Meeting Iowans, County by County, Table by Table
description: SIGOURNEY, Iowa  Three reporters, four campaign workers, a teenage boy, a few prospective voters and one Rick Santorum gathered at the Copper Lantern restaurant here at 8 oclock Wednesday morning.

title: Jets Again Relying on Greene and Running Game
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Shonn Greene says he has enough people to listen to at the Jets practice facility, where he spends almost all of his time, anyway. He never heard fans or commentators grumbling about how he might not really be the best candidate for his job.

title: Italy Strains to Resist the Tug of the Debt Whirlpool
description: ROME  As if European leaders needed any more motivation to deal with the mounting debt crisis, one fear stands above all others: Italy may be the next Greece, and if it is, united Europe may not have a future.

title: Meeting With Chinese, Official Tests Limits Set by Congress
description: WASHINGTON  A fight over whether a White House official broke the law by meeting with Chinese officials has opened a rare window into how executive branch lawyers, working across administrations of both parties, get around legal limits imposed by Congress.

title: Lots of Debate, Little Value to Awards
description: It is entirely possible that the amount of thought that goes into arguing over the winners and losers of the Gold Glove and Silver Slugger awards far outweighs the amount of effort that went into the actual voting by the coaches and managers.

title: Colorado: Boulder Votes to Remove Power Company
description: Voters in Boulder passed two measures on Tuesday that would allow the city to lay plans to start a municipal utility and cut ties with Xcel Energy, its current, corporate power provider. Proponents say the move will give the city greater leeway to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. The ballot measures, which pave the way for the homegrown utility and include a nearly $2 million tax increase to pay for legal and logistical fees, each passed narrowly by 51.78 percent and 50.27 percent, respectively, according to unofficial election results from Boulder County. Xcel Energy contended that it was better positioned to provide the city with energy at a far cheaper rate.

title: Sothebys Strong Sale Revives Art Market in One Night
description: Rowdy art handlers  who have been locked out of Sothebys over a labor dispute since the summer  blew whistles and shouted insults at the crowds who poured into Sothebys Upper East Side auction house on Wednesday night for its auction of Impressionist and modern art. But for all the anger outside the building, inside there was excitement and a great deal of relief as an international crowd of collectors and dealers watched the auction market come back to life.

title: Tech Talk Podcast: Google TV Redux
description: Google TV, Googles set-top box software for melding the Internet with the television, was not a huge success when it arrived last year. But while the hardware is staying the same for now, Google announced a software update for Google TV last week with a new user interface, better search tools and new objectives. Claire Cain Miller, a technology reporter in the San Francisco bureau of The New York Times, drops in to explain Googles latest angle for getting into the living room.

title: Brownsville Parents Ask Chancellor to Spare Their Schools From Closing
Jimmy Savile, TV Personality, Dies at 84
description: Jimmy Savile, an acclaimed English television host whose dress, hair and verbal flummery made all other comers in a nation renowned for eccentrics look like Puritans, was found dead last week at his home in Leeds, in the north of England. He was 84.

title: Liz Anderson, Who Wrote Hit Country Songs, Dies at 81
description: Liz Anderson, who wrote breakthrough hits for Merle Haggard and other country singers and recorded songs of her own about faithless men and beleaguered women, died on Monday in Nashville. She was 81.

title: Langoustines With Oysters and Seaweed
description: Time: About 30 minutes

title: Word of the Day | analogy
description: analogy \-na-l-je\ noun

title: Biggest Public Firms Paid Little U.S. Tax, Study Says
description: Warren E. Buffett, take note. It is not just a few wealthy individuals paying unusually low taxes to the federal government. Corporate America is not far behind.

title: Japan's Failed Breakwaters
description: Nori Onishi reports on the failure of breakwater systems in protecting against large waves along Japan's coastline.

title: Worker Dies While Using Lawn Mower for Warmth
description: As the cold, heavy snow pelted a disbelieving city last Saturday, a landscaping crew  thoroughly chilled after hours spent working outside a church in the Bronx  loaded their equipment into two trucks and headed back to Queens, ready to call it an early day.

title: Afghanistan Consults Neighbors on Security
description: ISTANBUL  In the largest meeting of its kind to date, representatives of Afghanistan and 12 nearby countries gathered in Istanbul on Wednesday to discuss regional efforts to rebuild security and stability in and around Afghanistan as NATO-led forces prepare to pull out of the country by the end of 2014.

title: Corrections: November 3
description: NEW YORK

title: Russia Declares Deal to Join Trade Group
description: MOSCOW  A Russian negotiator announced late on Wednesday that Russia had reached an agreement with Georgia that would clear the path for Russia to join the World Trade Organization after 18 years of delay, ambivalence and frustration.

title: Principals and City Reach Impasse in Bargaining
Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Thursday
description: Pakistan has finally granted India most-favored nation trade status, reciprocating Indias granting of the same status to Pakistan in 1995. The move is largely technical, but is a crucial step in the careful reconciliation under way between the two nations. Experts say that trade between the neighbors could reach $8 billion in five years. (The Hindu)Seeking to counter Anna Hazares battle against corruption, the government plans to introduce a bill in Parliament in the winter session that will give citizens the right to demand redressal of their grievances against government departments. According to the draft of the bill, the Hindustan Times reports, citizens will be able to complain via telephone or text message, and if their complaint isnt dealt with in 15 days, it automatically goes to the head of the concerned department.

title: NYT Front Page for 11/03/2011
description: NYT Front Page for 11/03/2011

title: Wartime Ink
description: China announced on Wednesday that recruits with neck or face tattoos can serve in the Peoples Liberation Army if the decorations are no larger than two centimeters wide, or about 0.8 inches.

title: Hot Jazz and the Cold War in 1950s Mumbai
description: One evening in 1958, the pianist Dave Brubeck and his quartet gathered in the home of a jazz-loving industrialist on Mumbais Malabar Hill to chat with a group of Indian musicians led by the sitar maestro, Abdul Halim Jaffer Khan. Then they picked up their instruments and put their new knowledge to work. The jam session with Mr. Khan, the American pianist said later, changed the way he approached his art. His influence made me play in a different way, Mr. Brubeck told Jazz Journal International. Although Hindu scales, melodies and harmonies are different, we understood each other  The folk origins of music arent far apart anywhere in the world.

title: A Site for Data Scientists to Prove Their Skills and Make Money
description: Airlines, insurance companies, hospitals and many other organizations are trying to figure out how to corral all their data and turn it into something useful.

title: Medvedevs Time
description: MOSCOW  What time is it? asked Ksenia.

title: Greek Leader Calls Off Referendum on Bailout Plan
description: ATHENS  In a tumultuous day of political gamesmanship, Prime Minister George A. Papandreou called off a referendum on Greeces new debt deal with the euro zone on Thursday after winning a measure of support from his opposition and managing to repair, at least for a day, a major rupture in relations with Europe.

title: News Quiz | Nov. 3, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Nov. 3, 1936 | Franklin Roosevelt Re-elected in Landslide
description: On Nov. 3, 1936, President Franklin Delano Roosevelt was re-elected in a landslide over his Republican challenger, Kansas Governor Alfred M. Alf Landon. The president won over 60 percent of the popular vote and 523 of the 531 electoral votes, losing only Maine and Vermont.

title: Test Yourself | English, Nov. 3, 2011
description: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article, All That Authenticity May Be Getting Old.

title: Oakland Police Clash With Fringe Protesters
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  Protesters and city officials here took a deep breath and tried to calm the waters Thursday after a night of vandalism and tear gas disrupted an orderly day of anti-Wall Street marches. But tensions remained high, both between demonstrators and the police and between Occupy Oakland protesters and a belligerent fringe group that seemed intent on clashing with law enforcement and destroying property.

title: What Are the Chances for Republicans?
description: Nate Silver models the likelihood of each candidate winning the popular vote.

title: Is Obama Toast? Handicapping the 2012 Election
description: Americans are usually forgiving when they vote a man into the White House and he wants a second term. Of the last eight elected presidents, all but two  George H. W. Bush and Jimmy Carter  got their four more years. Which is why the conventional wisdom long held that Barack Obama would most likely weather his midpresidency slump to win another term.

title: Choose Obamas Re-Election Adventure
description: In conjunction with my New York Times Magazine article on President Obamas re-election prospects, my colleagues Matt Ericson and Shan Carter have designed an interactive feature that allows you to handicap Mr. Obamas re-election odds based on the assumptions of your choosing.

title: Can Anyone Really Create Jobs?
description: The current economic downturn has been called a housing crisis, a financial crisis and a debt crisis, but the simplifying logic of the political season has settled on what is really more a result than a cause. We are now, according to nearly everyone running for office, in a jobs crisis. Every politician currently has a jobs plan, very often a list of vague proposals filled with serious-sounding phrases like budget framework and regulatory cap that are designed, for the most part, to mean both everything and nothing at all.

title: The China Conundrum
description: This article is a collaboration between The New York Times and The Chronicle of Higher Education, a daily source of news, opinion and commentary for professors, administrators and others interested in academe. Tom Bartlett is a senior writer at The Chronicle covering ideas and research; Karin Fischer is a senior reporter covering international education.

title: The European Debt Crisis and the G-20 Summit Meeting
description: Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is the co-author of 13 Bankers.

title: In a Fragile Nation, Visible Realities
description: This slide show contains images some viewers could find disturbing.

title: Exploring Time, Space and the Universe
description: WHO is Brian Greene?

title: What Causes Should Philanthropic Groups Finance?
description: This years edition of the annual Giving special section includes an article about how the economy has prompted many philanthropic organizations and individuals to reflect on, and sometimes shift, their priorities. What do you think institutions and people should give money to, and why?

title: Stocks Climb After Interest Rate Cut in Europe
description: Stocks rose strongly in the United States and in Europe on Thursday after the European Central Bank, concerned about an economic slowdown, cut its benchmark interest rate and Greece abandoned a planned referendum on its latest bailout deal.

title: The Early Word: Time and Money
description: In Todays Times:

title: Musical Finds on Offer at London Fair
description: Music lovers who still like the sound and feel of vinyl and CDs should find Musicmania at the Olympia exhibition center (Olympia 2, Hammersmith Road), on Nov. 12 and 13, a terrific hunting ground. The annual event brings together thousands of independent music retailers selling rare recordings, memorabilia, out of print books, clothes, posters, videos and magazines.

title: Automakers Try to Extract Real Sales From a Virtual World
description: Drive One, Ford says in its recent advertisements. But consumers are testing the brands vehicles far beyond the vicinity of any dealership.

title: Week 9 N.F.L. Game Probabilities, Including Patriots vs. Giants
description: This Sundays game between the Giants and the Patriots will be the first meaningful game between the two franchises since Super Bowl XLII. This time around, the Giants have just as high-flying a passing attack as the Patriots. The big difference between them is the ground attack; the advantage clearly belongs to New England.

title: Pakistan-India Trade to Benefit Consumers
description: Pakistans decision to normalize trade relations with India could be a boon to consumers and, over time, might help improve political relations between the countries and provide a boost to the struggling Pakistani economy, analysts said.

title: Civilian Contractor Attacked by Insurgents in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Insurgents attacked a logistics company that works with NATO in the western city of Herat on Thursday, igniting a three-hour gun battle that left two Afghan security guards and five insurgents dead, local officials said.

title: Writers New Form: Tweet-Up Comedy
description: ON a recent Tuesday, Jen Statsky was negotiating a move across Manhattan with all the usual headaches: movers, endless stuff, two buildings to appease. In the midst of it all she pulled out her iPhone and wrote to her 7,045 Twitter followers: Moving to the West Village today. Cant wait to be just like that character in Sex and the City  Girl In Coffee Shop #2!!!

title: Growing Pains at Growing Businesses
description: Getting a business to grow can be hard enough. Managing that growth successfully can be even harder. Recently, members of our business group discussed some of the challenges they face as their businesses expand.

title: Birds Fly in the Face of Climate Change Expectations
description: As we noted here in a recent post, a substantial body of research indicates that species tend to become smaller  as a result of global warming and other climate change patterns.

title: A City Shrinks, or So the Census Says
description: Honey, theyve done it again. Theyve gone out and shrunk the city. This time its the Census Bureau. According to its latest calculations, New York City has shrunk by more than two square miles, or the equivalent of Central and Prospect Parks combined.

title: Market Volatility Weighs on Man Group Earnings
description: LONDON  The Man Group, the worlds largest publicly traded hedge fund, announced on Thursday that pretax profit dropped 14 percent, to $195 million, in the six months ended Sept. 30, as the European sovereign debt crisis and global market volatility took its toll on the firm.

title: City's Struggling Schools List Grows to 47
Comedy Stars of TV Commanding the Stage
description: If youd rather see a household name than unknowns who might someday become one, the New York Comedy Festival, running Wednesday through Nov. 13, is full of them, including the guy who just might be at the top of the comedy heap at the moment.

title: Fortress Profit Declines 45%
description: Good news was tough to come by this quarter for the Fortress Investment Group, a publicly traded hedge fund manager run by Daniel H. Mudd.

title: Off-Kilter, Laid-Back Stand-Up
description: The stand-up comedian Hannibal Buress was poking fun at a woman in the front row at the Upright Citizens Brigade Theater in Chelsea recently when he paused to wonder aloud if it was possible to remain likable while insulting the audience.

title: New York City Ballets Nutcracker Coming to Movie Theaters
description: New York City Ballet  has joined the corps of cultural institutions presenting performances on the big screen. The company said on Thursday that its Dec. 13 performance of George Balanchines The Nutcracker will be transmitted live in high definition to more than 500 movie theaters around the country. In a statement, the companys executive director, Katherine E. Brown, said City Ballet hoped it would be the first of many such transmissions.

title: Most Young Adults in U.S. Now Own Smartphones, Survey Says
description: Smartphone ownership in the United States is on the rise. But a survey by Nielsen suggest that it is happening among some age groups faster than others.

title: Obama Urges European Solution to Debt Crisis
description: CANNES, France  President Obama plunged Thursday into the fast-moving European debt crisis, arriving here to exhort European leaders to get their financial house in order.

title: 3 Pakistan Cricket Players and Agent Get Prison Terms in Fixing Case
description: LONDON  The judge in Londons monthlong cricket corruption trial imposed prison sentences Thursday on the four men involved, including a 30-month jail term for Salman Butt, the captain of Pakistans national team.

title: High-Profile Owners a Slam Dunk for the Sport
description: This summer, I wrote an article for The Rail about how horse racing just might be getting hip again in the United States, as it was in the days of Bing Crosby, Fred Astaire and Cary Grant.

title: Primary Election Days: Is Three a Charm?
description: While much of the political world concerned itself with Herman Cain and whether he had straying eyes and hands, New Hampshire gave the presidential race definitive shape on Wednesday. It announced that its primary, traditionally the first, will be held on Jan. 10, a week after the Iowa caucuses.

title: Opinion Report: Crisis Management
description: From the editorial page

title: Transatlantic Rejects Raised Validus Bid
description: The battle for the reinsurance company Transatlantic Holdings continued on Thursday, as Validus Holdings failed to win approval for its latest bid even after increasing the offer.

title: Its Cash Dwindling, Kodak May Try to Raise $500 Million in New Financing
description: Eastman Kodak may not survive unless it is able to cash in on its portfolio of patents or find some other way to raise cash, like issuing more debt, the company stated on Thursday.

title: BNP Paribas Writes Down Greek Debt as Earnings Slump
description: PARIS  BNP Paribas, the largest French lender, announced a sharp decline in third-quarter profit Thursday and said it was writing off 60 percent of the value of all the Greek debt it holds, a belated acknowledgment that the loans are largely unrecoverable.

title: Syria Killed at Least 12, Opposition Says, Despite Deal to End Violence
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syrian forces killed at least 12 people in the restive city of Homs on Thursday, opposition activists said, a day after the Arab League brokered a plan to halt violence and convene talks between the government and the opposition in two weeks.

title: X Factor Watch: So Many Voting Options, So Little Time to Sing
description: Twelve acts, a two-hour show. Even allowing, say, an hour for Pepsi commercials, thats still five minutes per act. So why were the performers on Wednesday nights X Factor still singing annoyingly truncated versions of their songs?

title: European Central Bank, Under New Chief, Cuts Key Rate
description: FRANKFURT  The new president of the European Central Bank, Mario Draghi, quickly responded to the latest developments in the sovereign debt crisis on Thursday, overseeing a cut in the euro zones benchmark interest rate while warning of a mild recession.

title: Timely | Christopher Harth
description: Christopher Harth has always been good with his hands. After moving to Manhattan, Harth, who was raised on a farm in Minnesota, found his skills proved less than useful and ended up working as a model and producer for the photographer Ryan McGinley. But late last year he started NYCutlery and put his hands back to work carving knife handles out of scraps of furniture-grade walnut and grinding blades from reclaimed steel, all in his backyard in Fort Greene, Brooklyn. His eco-conscious knives are made to measure for both fit and function. A few days after finishing a foraging knife with a short, curved blade for cutting back toward the thumb, Harth used it himself to gather chanterelles for a delicious ravioli.

title: Growing Economies, Stagnant Wages
description: In the midst of the Occupy protests, the income gains going to the top 1 percent have gotten a lot of attention. Another way to understand the economic frustrations of the Occupiers is to look at how much middle-class living standards have changed, and how much the overall economy has grown.

title: U.S. Report Accuses China and Russia of Internet Spying
description: WASHINGTON  American intelligence agencies, in an unusually blunt public criticism of China and Russia, reported to Congress on Thursday that those two foreign governments steal valuable American technology over the Internet as a matter of national policy.

title: Thursday Reading: Student Debt Grew 5% Last Year
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Distributor Says S to Spanish-Language Will Ferrell Film
description: Whats the Spanish word for strategery?

title: For Amazon Prime Readers, a Lending Library
description: With less than two weeks to go before the new Kindle is in the hands of the masses, Amazon is aiming to stoke sales with more benefits. Wednesday night it announced a new program that loans eligible customers a free e-book every month.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: Many Alarms Rang Before MF Global Crashed | While the commodities and derivatives broker MF Global fell apart with ferocious speed, the collapse came after regulators raised warning flags for more than four months. They told MF Global it needed to raise more capital, and they asked about risky transactions involving European debt.

title: In Pakistan, a Census Count Turns Into a Body Count
description: KARACHI, Pakistan  Here in Karachi, more than 1,100 people have been victims of target killings  the local name for politically motivated assassinations  in the first seven months of this year. A major reason is anxiety about what a long-overdue census might reveal about the shifting ethnic and political balance.

title: Dear Ben: Its Not 2007 Anymore
description: The Federal Open Market Committee has spoken. It expects very high unemployment for at least the next three years, while it expects inflation to be below target. By any interpretation I can think of, the Fed therefore expects to fail to honor its dual mandate of price stability and full employment. To deal with this shortfall, it proposes doing  nothing.

title: An Era That Offered Much More Than Modernists
description: Three puzzling artworks welcome visitors to Youth and Beauty: Art of the American Twenties, an expansive and exhilarating exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum. A large self-portrait by Thomas Hart Benton pictures the bare-chested, muscular artist standing heroically at the beach with his wife sitting before him, Jane to his Tarzan, in a black one-piece bathing suit. On a pedestal nearby is a sandstone sculpture of a nude male torso by Cecil de Blaquire Howard that could be mistaken for an ancient Roman artifact. And on a wall adjacent to the Bentons is a grisaille painting of a 1928 Ford Trimotor airplane, its body of corrugated metal rendered in Precisionist style by Elsie Driggs.

title: What Chefs Feed Their Kids
description: When it comes to feeding children, do chefs have an advantage over the rest of us?

title: Inequality Trends In One Picture
description: Just an addendum on the role of the top 1 percent versus the college-noncollege differential. Here, from the CBO report, are the changes, in percentage points, of the shares of income going to three groups. The top quintile excluding the top 1 percent  which is basically the abode of the well-educated who arent among the very lucky few  has only kept pace with the overall growth in incomes. Just about all of the redistribution has taken place from the bottom 80 to the top 1 (and we know that most of that has actually gone to the top 0.1).

title: Vain Glorious | Takamichi Moves to the Bowery
description: For the devoted group of New Yorkers whove experienced Takamichi Saekis scissor work firsthand, there is no going back from the Takamichi cut. Now this former gallerist, avid soccer player and longtime resident of the Lower East Side is moving his salon and team of eight stylists from the loft on Great Jones Street thats been the home of Takamichi Hair since 2004 to a stylish new studio on the Bowery. Designed by the Belgian architect Sandra van Rolleghem to feel more like an apartment than a designer hair factory, the new space features custom touches, including hand-painted storage cabinets; an origami light fixture by a French designer, ric Guen; artwork by the downtown pioneer Richard Hambleton and the Barcelona, Spain-born Santi Moix  both friends of Saeki  and a reproduction of a round Herms mirror with leather trim from the 1920s. We wanted it to feel like a home, the architect told me on a recent visit. With neighbors like the New Museum, Sperone Westwater gallery and the much-anticipated Bowery Diner, Takamichi Hairs new location fits this stretch of the Bowery like the perfect cut.

title: The Blame Game on Herman Cain
description: 1:48 p.m. | Updated The game of whom to blame for Herman Cains mess is in full swing in Washington. But no one seems to agree  not even supporters of Mr. Cain.

title: Poetry Pairing | Barber
description: This weeks Poetry Pairing matches Larry Bradleys Barber with a first-person Thursday Styles piece, Trust Issues in Finding a New Hair Stylist, by Hilary Howard.

title: The New James Bond Movie Has a Title. And That Title Is Skyfall.
description: The James Bond franchise has yielded some of cinemas most memorable titles, some taken directly from Ian Flemings novels  From Russia With Love, The Spy Who Loved Me; Live and Let Die  and others spawned from the fertile minds of creative screenwriters and producers  The World Is Not Enough. (Also, there was one, from a Fleming short story, called Octopussy. We cant change that.)

title: After Failing Inspection on Monday, Frankies 457 Passes a Follow-Up
description: Ryan Sutton noticed Wednesday that the city health department had ordered Frankies 457 restaurant in Brooklyn closed after it scored 58 violation points on an inspection on Monday. But Thursday morning, the departments Web site showed that inspectors  found only 4 points worth of violations in a follow-up inspection on Tuesday. While the restaurant is currently listed as having a grade pending, a score of 4 would qualify it for an A rating, like those at the Frankies on the Lower East Side and in the West Village.

title: Jefferies Shares Swing on Sovereign Debt Fears
description: 4:09 p.m. | Updated

title: On Our Radar: Fracking Protest in Britain
description: Protesters scale a drilling rig at a hydraulic fracturing site in northern England after a report links the controversial gas drilling process to two minor earthquakes. The area, between Southport, Blackpool and Preston, is the only place in Britain where fracking has occurred. [The Financial Times]

title: What Were Reading
description: The Chicago Tribune: Families of those who died in the recent listeria outbreak are critical of the Food Safety Modernization Act signed by President Obama last January and hope that the outbreak will increase financing and attention given foodborne illness.  Glenn Collins

title: Roundup: Loan Debt Grows, Majors Matter and All Those Chinese Applications
description: The Timess Web site is peppered this morning with articles and posts that should be of interest to college applicants and their parents.

title: Ready to Break Ground on Waterfront Project Near Northern Tip of Manhattan
description: Construction is to start this month on a waterfront development project in the Inwood section of Manhattan designed by the architect Andrew Franz. The Dyckman Marina project, comprising two new buildings with a restaurant and caf on the Hudson River, is to open in the spring.

title: Growth in Retail Sales Slowed in October
description: In a potentially troubling sign for the holiday shopping season, retailers released data on Thursday suggesting that Americans were slowing down spending and hunting for discounts.

title: True Equality, for All Americans
description: It has been 47 years since the passage of the Civil Rights Act, and 46 years since the passage of the Voting Rights Act. And yet the political leaders of this nation of liberty cannot seem to muster the courage and principle to sweep away one remaining example of institutionalized, government-sanctioned discrimination: The 1996 law that denies the right of marriage to same-sex couples.

title: The 99% Onstage: Attention Must Be Paid
description: WAS that the ghost of Willy Loman I spotted in Zuccotti Park the other day, swapping grievances with the spirits of Joe Hill and Woody Guthrie? Probably not. Willy, the title character of Arthur Millers Death of a Salesman, went to his grave paying lip service to  and perhaps even still half-believing in  the American dream. Anyway, being part of a public protest would have embarrassed a guy who put his trust in the conquering power of a smile and a shoeshine and who wanted, above all, to be well liked.

title: Guess Where This Is
description: Its time again for our weekly contest: guess the location of the photograph above.

title: Cuba to Allow Buying and Selling of Property, With Few Restrictions
description: MEXICO CITY  Cuba announced a new property law Thursday that promises to allow citizens and permanent residents to buy and sell real estate  the most significant market-oriented change yet approved by the government of Ral Castro, and one that will probably reshape Cubas cities and conceptions of class.

title: When Is a Homage More Than a Homage?
description: In the age of the Internet, its hard to make anything without referencing something else. (This, often, is the whole point; see Tarantino, Quentin.) Its also hard to do this without someone else noticing it and pointing out what youve done.

title: E.P.A. Fracking Study Due in 2014
description: Having heard public comments at meetings across the country, the Environmental Protection Agency has announced its final research plan on the impacts of hydraulic fracturing. The initial research results will be released to the public next year, and the final report is due in 2014, the agency said.

title: Soul Brothers
description: On the cusp of the baby boom, an otherwise ordinary couple named Louise and Minor Carson brought forth into Dallas a trio of peripatetic and eccentric sons. Once grown, the three made their various ways around Americas underground satirizing things, and although none developed a signature line of eyewear, each in his own way reground the lens through which we see our world.

title: Irish Teenager Rides YouTube Song to Breeders Cup
description: Mark Boylan, 14, has only ever wanted to be one of two things: a musician or a jockey.

title: G.O.P. Senators Letter Clouds Talks on Deficit
description: WASHINGTON  As a powerful Congressional committee searched desperately for ways to reduce the federal budget deficit, conservative Republicans and progressive Democrats hardened their positions on Thursday by drawing lines that will make it more difficult for the panel to find consensus.

title: Why Parents Lie to Let Kids Join Facebook
description: Its been clear for a while that parents lie about their childrens ages so they can join Facebook. A survey by Consumer Reports published in June found that there were 7.5 million users under age 13 (the sites threshold for membership); more than 5 million were under 10. Over the year leading up to the report, a million children said they were harassed or threatened on the site.

title: Chinas Space Program Bolstered by First Docking
description: BEIJING  With a kiss more than 200 miles above Earth, a pair of Chinese spacecraft successfully coupled early Thursday morning, bringing the country one step closer to its four-decade quest for manned space exploration.

title: Petition Drive Challenges Medical Marijuana Ban in Rural California County
description: BAKERSFIELD, Calif.  Kern County is not exactly the kind of place where you would expect a voter rebellion, what with its conservative rural residents, its live-off-the-land values and its almost unshakable devotion to the Republican Party.

title: Glaxo Settles Cases With U.S. for $3 Billion
description: The British drug company GlaxoSmithKline said Thursday that it had agreed to pay $3 billion to settle United States government civil and criminal investigations into its sales practices for numerous drugs.

title: Gender Gap on Wages Is Slow to Close
description: First, there was the mancession that made the downturn much worse for men. Then, what my colleague Catherine Rampell has called the he-recovery, which has put more men than women back to work. What has remained consistent is that women remain on the wrong side of the wage gap.

title: Gensler Testifies on MF Globals Downfall
description: The top regulator tasked with overseeing the bankrupt brokerage firm MF Global said Thursday that the search continued for more than $630 million in missing customer money, warning that the protection of client assets is essential to doing business on Wall Street.

title: Pakistan: More Indian Imports to Be Allowed
description: Pakistans cabinet agreed Wednesday to normalize trade relations with India in a move that could improve political relations between the countries and bolster Pakistans struggling economy. Pakistans information minister said that Indian exports would be treated as favorably as those from Pakistans other trading partners. Currently, Pakistan admits fewer than 2,000 types of Indian products. Both countries have said they want to more than double trade between them, to $6 billion a year. Consumers in Pakistan are likely to benefit more from the change, gaining access to more and cheaper Indian goods. Pakistani businesses will likely face stiffer competition, especially in auto parts, pharmaceuticals and consumer goods. Policy makers also hope the move encourages progress on other trade issues, like Indias product-quality standards, which Pakistan says inhibit its exports.

title: L.S.U.-Alabama Will Turn Up the Volume
description: Because Thursday seems like a good day for a moral dilemma, we shall begin to contemplate Saturdays gargantuan college football clash between No. 1 Louisiana State and No. 2 Alabama. No, neither the Tigers nor the Crimson Tide are embroiled in any N.C.A.A. scandal that we know of. There is no need to root against one team because the quarterbacks father tried to auction him off like a painting to the highest bidder and the origins of no ones tattoos has been called into question.

title: From 2,000 New Products, a Few Blue-Ribbon Ideas Emerge at SEMA
description: LAS VEGAS  Despite there being 1,500 customized vehicles on display at the Specialty Equipment Market Association event here, it is not a car show. Not officially, anyway. Its a showcase for automotive products.

title: Less Than $26 Billion? Dont Bother.
description: Everyone  conservative and liberal  agrees that $2.6 trillion a year is too much to spend on health care, and that we have to cut costs. But they dont agree on who is to blame or what is to be done.

title: The 2011 Best Illustrated Childrens Books
description: The New York Times Book Review has announced its list of the 10 Best Illustrated Childrens Books of 2011. Artwork from this years winners will appear in the special Childrens Book section of the Book Reviews Nov. 13 issue.

title: New Grand Theft Auto to Cruise Some Familiar Streets
description: Rockstar Games said on Thursday that the next title in its popular and influential Grand Theft Auto series would be set in a digital version of Los Angeles (Los Santos). Color me slightly disappointed.

title: OneID Aims to Unite Devices to Fight Hackers
description: Assume your computer, your cellphone and your iPad are all insecure, subject to hackers. All three of them working together to protect your information  would that be better?

title: Prostate Cancer Drug Shows Promise in Study
description: Yet another experimental drug has shown it can extend the lives of men with advanced prostate cancer.

title: Face Time | Ta Leoni
description: They say laughter is the best medicine, and after a few days of working with Ta Leoni I was feeling pretty healthy. She was doing press and the premiere for her new movie, Tower Heist, opening Nov. 4. She plays a special agent in the movie, which also stars Alan Alda, Ben Stiller and Eddie Murphy. I believe her glowing beauty is due, in part, to her honesty, humor and refreshing approach to life. And some products even I had never heard of!

title: Behind Lens, Vets Find Respite From Troubled Pasts
description: The 50 or so people chatting and clinking wine glasses in the gallery in SoHo on Wednesday night did not distract Milton Douglas from fixating on his framed masterpiece, an explosion of orange light spraying up from the horizon: Coney Island at sunset.

title: Lens: Photo League
description: Lens: Photo League

title: Wheelies: The Midcycle Refresh Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Eat Local: A Clarification
description: A little elaboration on yesterdays column.

title: Web Sites for Choosing a New Bank
description: Even though the countrys largest banks have dropped plans to charge fees for debit card use, a movement encouraging customers to consider switching to community banks or credit unions remains energized. Promoters of Bank Transfer Day are urging dissatisfied big bank customers to open accounts at smaller institutions on Saturday.

title: Raj Rajaratnam Assigned to Massachusetts Prison
description: Raj Rajaratnam and Bernard L. Madoff will not be prison mates after all.

title: Reports of Unreported Crime at Zuccotti Park Bother Bloomberg
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg called on Occupy Wall Street protesters on Thursday to report crimes taking place at their encampment in Zuccotti Park, saying that any failure to do so endangers all New Yorkers.

title: An autumn aggro special, including an interview with Trash Talk, the California hardcore band, and a critical assessment of Lulu, the new album by Lou Reed and Metallica.
description: This week: an interview with Trash Talk, the California hardcore band; a critical assessment of Lulu, the new album by Lou Reed and Metallica; and reviews of new releases. Ben Ratliff is the host.

title: Award-winning chef, television personality and author, Jacques Pepin, discusses his career and culinary techniques with New York Times food writer Jeff Gordinier.
description: Award-winning chef, television personality and author, Jacques Pepin, discusses his career and culinary techniques with New York Times food writer Jeff Gordinier.

title: Millionaire For A Day
description: I see from comments here and elsewhere that the usual obfuscators are rolling out the old income mobility defense: sure, a few people get a lot of the income, but its different people every year, so no harm. I think its coming from the Tax Foundation this time.

title: The Brave New World of Mobile Dating: Cool or Creepy?
description: On Thursday I reported on the rise of new mobile applications that help people meet up with potential mates using location-based technology on their cellphones.

title: Hard Decisions for Learning Disabled
description: The admissions process can be stressful for even the most gifted, organized students. But to applicants with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder or learning disabilities, the path to college can feel like a maze. The Choice addresses some of the issues such students face.

title: Taking Questions on Applying with a Learning Disability
description: In the next issue of The Timess Education Life supplement, which will be published in newspapers this weekend, Ive tried to provide some advice to those with learning disabilities and other impairments who are applying to college.

title: Clip: 'J. Edgar'
description: Leonardo DiCaprio in a scene from "J. Edgar," directed by Clint Eastwood.

title: 2011 HCIR Workshop at Google
description: credit: Nicholas Belkin

title: Hometown Discount for Reyes, Mets? Unlikely
description: Will Jose Reyes give the Mets a hometown discount?

title: Popular Food Network star, cookbook author and restaurateur, Guy Fieri, proves he is not all burgers and barbecue in this discussion with New York Times food writer Julia Moskin.
description: Popular Food Network star, cookbook author and restaurateur, Guy Fieri, proves he is not all burgers and barbecue in this discussion with New York Times food writer Julia Moskin.

title: Prince of Denmark
description: Whether Copenhagens Noma is the worlds best restaurant doesnt matter: Ren Redzepi, its chef, has responded to his well-deserved recognition with the kind of inspiration and energy that guarantee hell be around for a while. Redzepi, soon to turn 34, is also a sweet guy running an oddly nonhierarchical kitchen, and talented people from all over the world are flocking to Denmark to work for him.

title: Democrats Target Romney on Reproductive Rights
description: President Obamas re-election campaign has been hammering Mitt Romney from many angles in recent weeks. And now Democrats are beginning a new push against him, this time using the issue of reproductive rights in a bid to raise doubts about Mr. Romney among women.

title: White-Fish Fillets With Grilled Cabbage
description: Time: About 45 minutes

title: Amazon Lights the Fire With Free Books
description: Today, Amazon unveiled something radical: the Kindle Owners Lending Library.

title: Lionel Trillings Life of the Mind
description: In 2008, the critic Louis Menand wrote Regrets Only, an extended essay on Lionel Trilling, the pre-eminent literary intellectual of the 1950s. Published in The New Yorker, it depicted Trilling as the symbol of midcentury America, a time when art was placed on a pedestal and the earnest critic stood on a pedestal almost as high. Trillings best-remembered book, The Liberal Imagination, Menand wrote, belongs to the age of (it feels a little funny just typing the words today) heroic criticism. This was an age before the 60s, before the old heroes had been retired and new ones put in their place, before the nostalgic condescension of Mad Men.

title: Theater Talkback: When Actors Write the Words
description: In our era of practically mandatory multitasking  and, for that matter, free-floating financial insecurity  it is probably to be expected that more actors would try their hand at playwriting. In the past few months Ive reviewed three new plays by established actors, at three of the citys significant nonprofit theaters. I cant recall another similar flurry in the more than a dozen years Ive been reviewing.

title: Giants Rushing Woes Deepen With Bradshaws Broken Foot
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Giants running game has been a concern all season, and on Thursday the cause for worry only grew. Starting back Ahmad Bradshaw has a cracked bone in his right foot, according to a person briefed on the injury, and his playing status for the future is uncertain.

title: Is There a Favorite in the A.F.C.?
description: With 11 out of 16 A.F.C. teams tied for first place in their divisions or no more than a game out, the answer seems to be no.

title: New Melanoma Screening Device Approved
description: After a lengthy review by the Food and Drug Administration, Mela Sciences of Irvington, N.Y., has won approval for a screening device for melanoma.

title: Google Changes Search Algorithm, Trying to Make Results More Timely
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Acknowledging that some searches were giving people stale results, Google revised its methods on Thursday to make the answers timelier. It is one of the biggest tweaks to Googles search algorithm, affecting about 35 percent of all searches.

title: I.B.M.s Chief on Corporate Longevity and Leadership
description: I.B.M. finished off its string of 100th anniversary events on Wednesday evening, with a lecture by the companys chairman and chief executive, Samuel J. Palmisano.

title: The Glory of the Knicks
description: Who made the most dramatic entrance in New York City history? A historian might say it was George Washington, who led 800 soldiers into town on Nov. 25, 1783, as the British evacuated the city. For New York sports fans of a certain age, that is wildly off the mark; we all know it was Willis Reed. The captain of the Knicks strode  not limped, strode  onto the hardwood court of Madison Square Garden on the evening of May 8, 1970, moments before the start of the seventh and deciding game of the National Basketball Association finals, rallying from a crippling injury, inspiring his teammates to vanquish the Los Angeles Lakers, winning New York its first N.B.A. championship. That game  that moment  was the high point of a seven-year run, from the late 60s to the mid-70s, when the Knicks became the object of some of the most inflamed passions this side of Rudolph Valentino, Elvis and the Beatles. From the asphalt courts of Harlem and Brownsville to the blue-collar gyms in St. Albans to the tables at Elaines, the Knicks were admired  worshiped, really  not just because they won, but because of how they won.

title: Le Bernardin chef Eric Ripert and his protg Jennifer Carroll are interviewed by New York Times food writer Jeff Gordinier
description: Le Bernardin chef Eric Ripert and his protg Jennifer Carroll are interviewed by New York Times food writer Jeff Gordinier

title: The Nurturing of JFK
description: As President Obama struggles to find his political footing, it is hard to avoid the suspicion that at least some of his woes may be rooted in a historical Democratic Party presidential divide. On the one side are what might be called loners; on the other, dynasts. The loners  Woodrow Wilson and Jimmy Carter  were brilliant professorial types who campaigned as moralistic, independent reformers and came to grief. By contrast, the members of family dynasties  Franklin D. Roosevelt and John F. Kennedy  were intimately familiar with rivalries and power politics long before they entered the Oval Office.

title: Amos Ozs Tales of Love and Darkness
description: In his remarkable memoir, A Tale of Love and Darkness, Amos Oz created a richly detailed, vibrant and nuanced portrait of his young self, of his family and of the young nation of Israel growing around him. It is, for all its profound sadnesses, an exuberant account, overflowing with life and with a joy in language. But Oz is a versatile writer, and he returns, in his fine new story collection, Scenes From Village Life, to a spare, almost allegorical style, in which the silence around the words also signifies. Admirably rendered in English by Ozs longtime translator, Nicholas de Lange, these linked stories prove achingly melancholy, a cumulative vision of anomie and isolation in an apparently cozy Israeli village.

title: Styled to a T | Tino Seubert
description: The Designer

title: TimesCast | November 3, 2011
description: Greece calls off its referendum as the Group of 20 leaders meet in Cannes, France; and Herman Cain accuses his rival Rick Perry of a smear campaign.

title: House Panel Votes to Subpoena Solyndra Documents
description: Over the protests of its Democratic minority, a House subcommittee voted on Thursday to authorize the chairman of the Energy and Commerce Committee to subpoena documents from the White House related to the solar manufacturer Solyndra.

title: Raising a Killer
description: The making of a murderous child is the bleak subject of THE END OF THE WASP SEASON (Reagan Arthur/Little, Brown, $25.99), the second novel in Denise Minas new series of realistically gritty procedurals set in Glasgow and featuring a gutsy cop named Alex Morrow. Since Morrow is pregnant with twins, her mates on the Strathclyde police force try to shield her from the savagery done to the victim of a home invasion in the exclusive suburb of Thorntonhall. But when she realizes the prudish cops are actually revolted by the dead womans provocatively exposed body, Morrow feels sheer, suffocating pity for the victim, whose battered face and half-naked corpse have nullified both her identity and her dignity.

title: Starting Out in the 70s
description: False modesty is running amok. In the past month or so, these memoirs have been published: Luck and Circumstance, by Michael Lindsay-Hogg; Lucky Bruce, by Bruce Jay Friedman; and now Lucking Out, by James Wolcott. Any one of these authors might have borrowed the title Making It from Norman Podhoretz, who could have used a little false modesty.

title: Its Not Too Late for Imprudent Speculation About Other Republican Candidates
description: With the recent struggles of Herman Cain and Rick Perry, we may be in for yet another round of rumors about Republican candidates entering the presidential race late.

title: Analyzing Day 1
description: Rich Perloff of TVG handicaps Fridays Breeders Cup races:

title: LuPone and Metcalf to Square Off on Broadway in New Mamet Play
description: David Mamets new play, The Anarchist, is built for two actresses who are expert at spitting nails. The drama centers on a female inmate with a radical past, pleading for parole with the prisons female warden; a battle of words and wits ensues over politics, money and religion. On Thursday the Broadway producers Jeffrey Richards and Jerry Frankel said they had found a duo who, no question, know something about stage combat: The Tony Award winner Patti LuPone (Gypsy, Evita) will play the inmate and the Emmy winner Laurie Metcalf (Roseanne) will play the warden in a Broadway production scheduled to open in fall 2012.

description: As the non-Mitt Romney portion of the Republican nomination contest grows ever more bizarre and baroque, Jay Cost speaks the cold, hard truth:

title: The Civilians: 'Let Me Ascertain You'
description: Greg McFadden as a member of the Tea Party in a scene from the Civilians' show "Let Me Ascertain You: Occupy Wall Street," performed last month at Joe's Pub. (Video courtesy of the Civilians.)

title: Up Front: Jeff Greenfield
description: Jeff Greenfield may have written a book called The Worlds Greatest Team: A Portrait of the Boston Celtics, 1957-69, but he grew up a Knicks fan. I have fond memories of Harry (the Horse) Gallatin, whose rebounding skills presaged Dave DeBusschere, and the ball-handling of Sweetwater Clifton, the first black ever signed to an N.B.A. contract, he wrote in an e-mail. Greenfield, who reviews Harvey Aratons When the Garden Was Eden, added: I am much less devoted to the N.B.A. than in years past, probably because of the decade of Knick ineptitude, the ticket prices and, more broadly, a style of play across much of the league that calls into question the definition of a team sport. (One passing thought: the Knicks ownership is a powerful case for a confiscatory pre-mortem inheritance tax.)

description: Photographs from California, France, Greece and China.

title: Politicians Demand a Panel to Investigate Police Corruption
description: 7:18 p.m. | Updated Pointing to several unrelated corruption cases involving the New York Police Department, a chorus of politicians on Thursday called on Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to create an independent commission to investigate what they said was systemic corruption.

description: A view of the day in sports, including young cricketers in India and golf at the HSBC Champions tournament in Shanghai.

title: Study Finds Big Spike in Poorest in the U.S.
description: WASHINGTON  The number of people living in neighborhoods of extreme poverty grew by a third over the past decade, according to a new report, erasing most of the gains from the 1990s when concentrated poverty declined.

title: Readers Respond: Greece on the Brink
description: Todays editorial on Greece makes two basic points. 1) Although its understandable that Prime Minister George Papandreou wants a mandate to press forward with onerous austerity reforms, political referenda are not generally a good idea with their simplistic yes or no answers to complicated policy questions. 2) European leaders should pay more attention to the distress of ordinary Greeks, and should emphasize growth in a new bailout deal.

title: A Dear Cousin Recalls His Childhood Playmate, Anne Frank
description: He is the closest surviving relative of the young woman who more than any other has personified the Holocaust.

title: Joyce Theater Announces Spring and Summer Lineups
description: The Joyce Theaters programming is always eclectic and the 2012 spring and summer lineups are no different. Choreographers and companies from around the world representing a variety of styles will perform from Feb. 7 to Aug. 18.

title: Tailgating Recipes: Diesel Bloody Mary
description: Tailgating life is easier when your game starts in mid-afternoon or later. But an early game shouldnt be an impediment. That said, while its true that its always noon somewhere, beer might not be right for everyones palate in the morning.

title: Public Workers Union Accepts Concessions and Averts Layoffs
description: LATHAM, N.Y.  The states second-largest union of public workers has agreed to accept a revised package of wage and benefits concessions sought by the Cuomo administration, saving thousands of union members from layoffs that would have begun Friday if the deal had been rejected.

title: Protesters Arrested Outside Goldman Sachs Building
description: Police officers arrested more than a dozen protesters from the Occupy Wall Street movement on Thursday after large group of the demonstrators marched to the headquarters of Goldman Sachs in Lower Manhattan.

title: For Better or Wurst
description: Talk about sausages for a style magazine based in New York? Tremendous! wrote Sam Baron in response to our questions about the T he created for our Design and Living issue. Turns out Baron, who is the design director at Fabrica, is also an avid foodie, and splitting his time between Paris, Portugal and Treviso, Italy, where Fabricas headquarters are located, has taught him quite a lot on the subject of sausages (glass and otherwise). Here, the designer indulges in some of his favorite saucisson.

title: Pro-American Militia Members Die in Blast in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  Six members of a pro-American Sunni Awakening militia died in an explosion while waiting in line for their salaries near Baquba, northeast of Baghdad, on Thursday. The attack highlighted growing Sunni frustration with how the Shiite-dominated Iraqi government deals with their security.

title: Papandreou Scraps the Referendum
description: As I mentioned yesterday on this blog, I am no fan of referendums. (The editorial board isnt keen on them, either.) But I was still shocked to hear that Greek Prime Minister George Papandreou had decided to scrap his plan to hold a referendum on the proposed bailout package a single day after his cabinet approved the national vote. I asked David Unger, whos been following the European debt crisis for the board, to weigh in on what, exactly, just happened. David writes:

description: The toughest part of counting calories can be figuring out how many are actually on your plate. But what if your Android or iPhone could do it for you?

title: Another Tibetan Nun Dies by Self-Immolation in China
description: BEIJING  A Buddhist nun in southwest Sichuan Province died Thursday after setting herself on fire, becoming the 11th Tibetan to embrace a grisly protest against Chinese rule and at least the sixth to die doing so.

title: 36 Hours in Braslia
description: DESPITE the modernistic monuments by the legendary Oscar Niemeyer, Brazils retro-futuristic capital city  erected on an expanse of dry plains in central Brazil in the late 1950s and 60s  has generally drawn few visitors who didnt have business with the federal government. But as Brazils economy booms and its world influence increases, Braslia is coming of age, gaining a new museum here, a cool bridge there, top-shelf restaurants everywhere. Braslia is also safer and calmer than Rio de Janeiro or So Paulo, unless you count the stress of trying to understand its maddening address system. Adding to the charm are awe-inspiring sunsets, samba hot spots and something even the greatest urban planners in the world couldnt have given it upon its inauguration in 1960: a half-century of tradition and history.

title: 36 Hours in Braslia
description: Braslia is coming of age, gaining a new museum here, a cool bridge there, top-shelf restaurants everywhere.

description: ATLANTA  It is going to be some task finding a safe spot on the field against the defenses Saturday night in Tuscaloosa. Alabama is No. 1 in the country in total defense; Louisiana State is No. 4.
