title: A Flu-Ridden Rihanna Cancels Sweden Shows
description: As one of her singles climbed to the top of the pop music charts in the United States, Rihanna canceled a second show in Sweden because of illness and exhaustion. The pop diva has been touring without a break since early June, performing nearly 60 concerts on three continents to promote her album Loud (Def Jam). A concert promoter for Live Nation in Sweden, Kristofer Akesson, told the Associated Press that Rihanna, who is 23, is exhausted and doesnt feel well. Her publicist in New York said she was suffering from the flu. The singer called off a concert in Malmo in southern Sweden on Monday, and sent a photograph of her arm with the tube from an intravenous drip to her followers on Twitter with a note saying, Sorry Malmo!!! She was not hospitalized as some news outlets reported. She performed Tuesday night in Stockholm, then called off a second performance on Wednesday night after consulting with a doctor.Rihanna joins several high-profile performers who have cancelled major concerts for health reasons this year, among them Adele, who is undergoing surgery to repair bleeding in her vocal chords, Taylor Swift, who had a bout of laryngitis, and Caleb Followill, the lead singer for Kings of Leon, who cancelled half his bands tour to rest his voice. Rihannas decision to cancel two shows came as her single, We Found Love, featuring Calvin Harris, rose to No. 1 on the Billboard Hot 100 songs chart. It was the 11th No. 1 single she has recorded, giving her the same number as Whitney Houston and more top singles than Stevie Wonder or Janet Jackson.

title: Ferran Adria, the chef behind Spains El Bulli discusses his career and cookbook, The Family Meal: Home Cooking with Ferran Adria. Interviewed by former Times restaurant critic Frank Bruni.
description: Ferran Adria, the chef behind Spains El Bulli discusses his career and cookbook, The Family Meal: Home Cooking with Ferran Adria featuring recipes for the at-home cook, based on meals he served his staff at El Bulli. Interviewed by former Times restaurant critic Frank Bruni.

title: Neighborhood Joint | Kaufmans Army and Navy
description: Kaufmans Army and Navy, a tiny 73-year-old institution, is stuffed with mountains of military paraphernalia as well as civilian gear.

title: Excerpt: 'Other Desert Cities'
description: Stacy Keach and Rachel Griffiths in Jon Robin Baitz's play, which opened on Broadway at the Booth Theater. (Courtesy of Lincoln Center Theater.)

title: Being a Med Student, Take Two
description: When medical students are handed their diplomas, they are technically full-fledged doctors, but most would admit their only true expertise is taking tests. Medical training is an ongoing saga of standardized tests that culminates in the board certification exams at the end of residency.

title: Why Not Give Greeks Their Say?
description: The fundamental nature of European governance is about to change.

title: Amid Flurry of Attention, a Kardashian Book Blitz
description: The ending of Kim Kardashians unusually brief marriage happened to be beautifully timed with a planned Kardashian book blitz.

title: Murakamis Mega-Opus
description: Its April of 1984, and a young woman in a taxi is stuck in a Tokyo traffic jam. As she frets about being late for a meeting, the driver tells her she has an option: She can get out of the cab, descend a nearby emergency stairway and take the subway  but, he warns her, the world might never be the same. The woman abandons the taxi, walks down the freeway, takes off her high heels, hitches up her miniskirt, steps over the guardrail, climbs down the stairs and proceeds to her appointment. Whereupon two things happen: First, she performs a felonious act with a homemade stiletto. Second, per the cabbys prophecy, she finds herself in, literally, a new world.

title: A Bialy Shops Unlikely (Pakistani) Saviors
description: When the owner of Brooklyns oldest bialy store, Coney Island Bialys and Bagels, announced last summer that he was closing up shop, fans began mourning the impending loss of a 91-year-old piece of Jewish culinary history.

title: The Caucus | Cain Campaign Woes
description: November 3, 2011  Herman Cains campaign is in crisis mode, fending off mounting accusations that Cain sexually harassed several women in the 1990s.

title: A Rare Work Acquired by the Met
description: Keith Christiansen, chairman of European paintings at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, knew he had something special when he glimpsed a two-sided panel by the German Renaissance artist Hans Schufelein just before an auction of old masters at Sothebys in London this summer.

title: Cain Adviser Walks Back Perry Accusation
description: Watchthe latest video at video.foxnews.com

title: Forget New Hampshire. X Factor Voting Begins
description: Fresh off the news of a second-season renewal, The X Factor on Fox returned to its regular Wednesday night time slot with a two-hour live-performance episode and the first show of the season on which viewers could cast votes. It drew an audience of 11.5 million, almost exactly the same number as its last Wednesday show, on Oct. 5.

title: Meet the Beetles
description: At the Milan Furniture Fair this year, the design mecca Spazio Rossana Orlandi was infested with beetles. The culprit was Thomas Eyck, an adviser at the  Zuiderzee Museum in Enkhuizen, the Netherlands, and also the producer of a growing collection of strange and wonderful things, including this set of bug vases called Schwarm. Each year at the time of the fair, Eyck switches gears from curator to editor by selecting a different designer with whom he delves into a traditional material and craft. Past explorations have yielded flax rope furniture and lighting by Christien Meindertsma, brightly colored striped woolen blankets and pillows by Scholten & Baijings, and pewter objects by Studio Job. For Schwarm, he worked with the German artists Beate Reinheimer and Ulrike Rehm, known as RaR, who are fascinated with the dizzying diversity of the animal kingdom, particularly among insects. To wit, Schwarm features 10 different shapes, or genuses, and 63 species, each with a different glaze. They are being sold as a limited-edition set or individually, for the less entomologically inclined. For more information, go to thomaseyck.com.

title: For Civilians Who Want Military Style
description: TO walk into Kaufmans Army and Navy on 42nd Street across from the Port Authority is to step into the chaos of pre-Giuliani Times Square, but without the imminent danger to life and limb.

title: Caucus Video: Cain Campaign Woes
description: Jeff Zeleny reports on Herman Cains campaign in crisis mode, fending off mounting accusations that Mr. Cain sexually harassed several women in the 1990s.

title: Exploring Artworks While Recumbent
description: THE publication of Panorama, a book tied to a retrospective of the German artist Gerhard Richter at the Tate Modern in London, is a perfect occasion for starting this column. After London, the exhibition will travel to Berlin and later to Paris. Most of us, I suspect, wont be able to catch up with Mr. Richter overseas. But the book based on the show  a paper gallery, if you will  can be gazed at and grazed on from the plush comfort of couch or recliner.

title: Amazing Denials
Corporate Tax Dodgers Report
description: A study, prepared by the left-leaning advocacy group Citizens for Tax Justice, examined the regulatory filings of American companies to compute each years federal taxes.

title: Crime Doesnt Pay. Oh, Wait.
description: Rich guys are among the most reliable villains in Hollywood movies, and it takes no special insight to point out that the guys who make and star in those movies tend to be pretty well off themselves. You can call this hypocrisy, but I prefer to think of it as one of the cultural contradictions of capitalism that all of us have to live with.

title: Lens: Misha Erwitt
description: Lens: Misha Erwitt

title: Memories of the Bush Administration
description: The administration of George W. Bush has already produced a remarkable body of contemporary history from a large group of talented journalists and writers  Jane Mayer, Thomas E. Ricks, James Risen, Ron Suskind, Susan Faludi, Seymour M. Hersh, James Mann and many others. But in the last year, several members of the Bush administration have retaliated with books of their own. Among the most significant are former Secretary of Defense Donald Rumsfelds Known and Unknown and former Vice President Dick Cheneys In My Time, memoirs by perhaps the two most important figures (other than the president) in the years of terrorism and war. Both books have received mostly negative reviews  largely deserved. Rumsfelds book is dense and bloated, although modestly candid. Cheneys is clearly written (with help from his daughter Liz Cheney), but with the exception of its last chapters, dry, earnest and dull. None of this seems to have had much impact on their sales. Both spent time at the top of the best-seller lists.

title: Considering the Future of Reading: Lessons, Links and Thought Experiments
description: How is the definition of reading changing? How does the experience of reading with new technologies affect the transaction between text and reader? What is the future of the book industry? What does all this mean for schools, students and literacy rates?

title: Chancellor on the Cellphone Ban: Its the Policy
Fewer Americans Confident About Retirement Savings, Survey Finds
description: The sluggish economy is taking a toll on Americans confidence in their retirement savings, a new survey found.

title: Being Charles Dickens
description: Robert DOUGLAS-FAIRHURST, the Oxford scholar who is one of Charles Dickenss two new biographers, rightly calls his subject at once the most central and most eccentric literary figure of his age, and the investigations into the dark corners of that eccentric life began with Dickens himself. In 1849 he showed a short account of his early years to his close friend John Forster, revealing a story he never told his own family: the shame-inducing months he spent, while his father was in a debtors prison, as a 12-year-old laboring hind in a factory that bottled shoe-blacking. The first volume of the biography hed wanted Forster to write  which made the blacking-factory episode public  appeared in 1872, two years after Dickens died at the age of 58, and its successors keep coming. The Dickens biographies published just in the past 25 years make an impressive stack. Given his uncanny genius and the vivid complexity of his life, thats not a complaint.

title: HTC Unveils Rezound, a Phone With Beats Headphones in the Box
description: HTC was recently declared the top smartphone seller in the United States for the third quarter by Canalys, a research firm, beating out competitors like Apple, Samsung and LG.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE GUN,  by C. J. Chivers (Simon & Schuster, $16.) Chivers, a foreign affairs correspondent for The New York Times (and a former Marine), examines the history of the crude but devastatingly effective AK-47  or as it is often called, after its designer, the Kalashnikov  from its use in East Germany and Hungary in the 1950s to the current conflict in Afghanistan.

title: Science, Faith and First Principles: A Response
Enter The Draghi
description: Working on other things today, so Im late to this. The ECB cut rates  which everyone knew was going to happen eventually, but people thought they would delay to save face. And Papandreou was bullied convinced to call off the referendum. And the markets cheered.

title: 50 N.B.A. Players Considering Dissolution of Union
description: Negotiations to end the N.B.A. lockout will resume Saturday amid a new threat to labor peace: a disillusioned faction of players.

title: Getting Beyond Who Had It Worse
description: I meet veterans of the Vietnam War all the time but I rarely have good conversations with them. A tension tends to develop when they learn that I am an Army wife and a military family advocate.

title: Carousel of Misbehavior in the Folk Art World
description: In the seamy underbelly of folk-art collecting, owners over the past century have muddied the attributions of works, brazenly added new flourishes to old woodcarvings, and let bird droppings and paint spatters gather on canvases in storage.

title: In Utah, a New Home for Natural History
description: The new Natural History Museum of Utah is so in tune with its environment that it almost blends into the landscape. Called the Rio Tinto Center, the museum sits on 17 acres, terraced along the foothills of the Wasatch mountain range in Salt Lake City. We tried not to disturb the site too much because the building is really about the land, Todd Schliemann of Ennead Architects, who designed the museum, said. Its like a great rock outcrop covered in copper.

title: California Rebates for Hybrids and E.V.s Live On, in Reduced Form
description: California is the largest early-adopter market for electric vehicles in part because of incentives like single-driver access to H.O.V. lanes and financial subsidies. The state offered cash rebates of as much as $5,000 for zero-emission vehicles, or ZEVs, through the Clean Vehicle Rebate Project, subsidies that mostly went to new owners of the Nissan Leaf.

title: Where the Lenape Trod
description: I thought I knew about old forests. First impressions came from childhood, when all woods can seem deep, fearsome and immense. Then from books: They are where Shakespeares characters magically shed their identities, where Hester Prynne is released from shame, where natures healing forces are harbored. I have also walked amid the red cedars of the Pacific Northwest, feeling a hushed awe in the presence of the forest primeval.

title: Editors Choice
description: PAULINE KAEL: A LIFE IN THE DARK,  by Brian Kellow (Viking, $27.95.) Kellow has written a fair-minded and deeply reported biography of the provocative, brilliant and maddening writer whose essays about movies transformed American pop-culture criticism.

title: Original Spider-Man Director Taymor Will Be Eligible for Tony
description: Julie Taymor will be eligible for a 2012 Tony Award nomination as best director of a musical for Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark, the committee that oversees the annual Broadway theater honors announced on Thursday, despite Spider-Man being overhauled considerably after she was fired from the show in March.

title: A Voice of Gray Moods, Joined by 100 Whistlers
description: Feist spent 90 minutes on Wednesday night believing out loud that a pop concert can be a ritual of happenstance magic. She did what she could to provoke it, and in the end she got it, although there were some less magical parts to endure first.

title: A Dancing Machine Built Of Sculpture and Humans
description: In Connected, a work by Gideon Obarzanek for the Australian company Chunky Move, the action starts almost immediately. As a portentous electronic score begins  its rough static sound mirrors the ominous setting  the dancer Harriet Ritchie whips her arms and legs in awkward directions and writhes on her back. Others join in. But as their bodies slip in and out of control, theres something else vying for your attention.

title: Othellos Wife Gives Her Side of the Story
description: The irreverent director Peter Sellars has said he thinks Othello is a terrible play, but does he need to work so hard to prove it to us?

title: Soft Music and Martial Lunges
description: The power dynamic between dancers and choreographers is a hard one to shake. While there have been dramatic changes in dance over the years, it is still almost always the case that performers audition for creators, who decide if they are the right individuals for a given project or company.

title: Spare Times: For Children, for Nov. 4-10
description: MID-AUTUMN CHILDRENS FESTIVAL

title: Whats Behind That Mona Lisa Smirk?
description: A lesson to be gleaned from Charlotte Rampling: The Look, Angelina Maccarones fascinating and frustrating documentary portrait of an enigmatic star, might be that it would be foolish to suppose that Ms. Rampling is anything like the transgressive women she portrays on the screen. The same is true of her photographic image, that of a heavy-lidded femme fatale. Could The Look be an accident of physiognomy? In this evasive film neither the director nor the star is about to speculate.

title: Gloria Cain Wont Do Fox Appearance
description: Herman Cains wife, Gloria, will not be appearing on the Fox News Channel on Friday night after all, a person close to the talks told the Caucus.

title: Chuck D. Sues Universal Music Over Digital Royalties
description: Chuck D. of Public Enemy has become the latest major artist to sue the Universal Music Group over royalties for digital music.

title: Bank of America Plans Stock Swap to Cut Debt
description: Bank of America has developed a plan to issue nearly $3 billion in common stock to raise capital and reduce debt, changing course after saying for months that it did not intend to sell new shares.

title: Tale of Antarctic Explorers, Lives Hanging by a Thread
description: In 69S., which opened Wednesday night at the BAM Harvey Theater, Ernest Shackleton and his five shipwrecked crew members look decidedly stoic.

title: When in Germany  Teil 2
description: Being the worlds policeman does have its benefits, and for the United States a small part of that payoff could end up being on the soccer field.

title: Before the Marathon, Students Run in Central Park
Spare Times for Nov. 4-10
description: The La MaMa Cantata (Monday and Tuesday) Before her death in January, Ellen Stewart was the driving force behind the East Village experimental theater space La MaMa, which she founded 50 years ago. Festivities last month in celebration of the theaters new season included a gala that featured an excerpt from The La MaMa Cantata, a new musical by Elizabeth Swados that tells of the life and work of Ms. Stewart through her words as well as those of others. (Above from left, Charnele Crick, Alicia Miles, Grace McLean and Starr Busby, with other cast members, at last months gala.) On Monday, which would have been Ms. Stewarts 92nd birthday, a cast of 23 will perform the full work at 7:30 p.m. in the theater that bears her name. The show, a blend of pop and world music, will also be performed at the same time on Tuesday. Tickets are $50. Box office information: (212) 475-7710, lamama.org. The theater is at 66 East Fourth Street. You cant miss it; just look for the sign at Second Avenue and East Fourth Street that reads Ellen Stewart Way. (Anne Mancuso)

title: The Art of the Novel
description: In London recently there was an exhibition of paintings by Atkinson Grimshaw. The name might not ring a bell, but his paintings will be familiar to you. Victorian street scenes at twilight. The amber-lit windows of homes through the bare branches of trees  the seasons always fall or winter. Shop windows reflected in rain-slick streets. Solitary walkers. Moonlight, tattered clouds, turquoisey sky. An atmosphere of mystery, elegy, lingering anticipation.

title: #OccupyWallSt Roundup, Day 48
description: It has been a noisy couple of days at the Goldman Sachs building in Lower Manhattan. After a mock trial at Zuccotti Park Thursday morning ended with the investment bank being found guilty of corruption, protesters marched to the banks headquarters and staged a sit-in.

title: Joan Didion Mourns Her Daughter
description: Somewhere in his published diaries the playwright Alan Bennett observes that when misfortune befalls a writer the effect of it is in a small but significant measure ameliorated by the fact that the experience, no matter how dire, can be turned into material, into something to write about. Thus Joan Didion, after her husband, John Gregory Dunne, died suddenly of a heart attack on Dec. 30, 2003, made out of her bereavement a remarkable book, The Year of Magical Thinking, which became an international success, speaking directly as it must have not only to those who themselves had been recently bereaved, but to hundreds of thousands of readers wishing to know what it feels like to lose a loved one, and how they might themselves prepare for the inevitable losses that life sooner or later will cause us all to suffer.

title: An Action Hero Who Needed No Words
description: He was a star of the silent screen, who enjoyed a glittering second life as a television star in the 1950s with some 40 million fans and dozens of merchandising deals. He was reportedly given a key to New York City and treated like a dignitary almost everywhere he went. The director Sergei Eisenstein was a fan, and the poet Carl Sandburg wrote that he had such expressiveness in his movements that he qualified as one of the leading pantomimists of the screen.

title: Print Fair: International Fine PrintDealers Association
description: Park Avenue Armory

title: Pictures of the Day: Oakland and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from California, France, Greece and China.

title: Eija-Liisa Ahtila
description: Marian Goodman Gallery

title: Josephine Halvorson: What Looks Back
description: Sikkema Jenkins & Company

title: Anne Ryan: The Black-Line Woodcut, 1945-48
description: Susan Teller Gallery

title: Inside the List
description: THE LITERARY JOBS: Ever since Walter Isaacsons biography of Steve Jobs hit the mediasphere with hurricane-level force, blogs have been buzzing about the revelation that the one book the tech visionary kept on his iPad 2 was Autobiography of a Yogi. But far less has been made of another startling literary revelation: that Jobs once had a relationship with the future Pulitzer Prize-winning novelist Jennifer Egan.

title: Urs Fischer
description: Gavin Browns Enterprise

title: Walking Again, With Help From an Exoskeleton
description: Robert Woo gripped the handles of his walker, muscles twitching beneath his black T-shirt. He was ready for his first step.

title: A Master of the Piano Whose Performances Receive No Applause
description: Pianos dont cry out in pain, even when their listeners do; they go out of tune, warp and crack. Yet to watch Stefan Knpfer delicately prod the insides of a Steinway concert grand Model D  a 990-pound, 12,000-part behemoth made of wood, metal and wool  is to witness a procedure akin to laparoscopic surgery, if done with animal glue. Mr. Knpfer, blond, bespectacled, boyish, is the technician hero of Pianomania, a documentary about those who fix, love, play and wildly obsess over these beauties, tweaking and all but disemboweling them in search of the sublime.

title: Philharmonic and Glass Meet for Movie Night
description: However much credit Alan Gilbert may deserve for beginning to update the New York Philharmonics repertory, the slowness with which it has come to the music of Philip Glass says a lot about its distance from todays repertory. Though Mr. Glass has composed nine symphonies, about a dozen concertos and numerous short orchestral scores, the Philharmonic had never played a note of his work until Wednesday evening, when it joined forces with the Philip Glass Ensemble and the Collegiate Chorale to perform Koyaanisqatsi (1982) at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Playing Melancholy Music, And Having Fun With It
description: It seemed a good bet that Brooklyn Rider, the young, genre-bending string quartet, would turn its Zankel Hall concert on Monday evening into a Halloween party, but it was hard to know for sure at first. The group wore mostly black, but then it often does, and it could have been a coincidence that Nicholas Cords, the violist, wore an orange tie. And though Colin Jacobsen, who alternates on first violin with Johnny Gandelsman, peppered his between-works comments with vampire and zombie references, and Mr. Cords mentioned that the group would be playing music by composers dead and undead, the frivolity could have easily ended there.

title: On Road to Reconciliation, Libya Meets Trail of Anguish
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  The present and future are daunting enough for the wobbly authorities here, but then there is the tormented past to consider as well: four decades of state crimes whose wounds demand attention.

title: The Blame Game for Herman Cain
description: As accusations emerge that Herman Cain made unwanted sexual overtures to women while he led the National Restaurant Association more than a decade ago, his campaign staff deals with its first major crisis.

title: Domestic Disturbances in Bicultural L.A.
description: The literature of Los Angeles must discern shadows in the sunshine if it hopes to transcend mere entertainment. Hctor Tobar knows this. A native of the city, Tobar knows the dark and the light, the high and the low; he knows the spas and the salvage shops, the wrought iron and the barbed wire; he knows the West Side, the Valley and downtown  and he has put it all into his big new novel, The Barbarian Nurseries. Mercifully, Hollywood did not make the cut.

title: Cain Revives Charge Against Perry, Shifting Message Again
description: 9:11 p.m. | Updated Herman Cain lashed out again on Thursday at his accusers, his rivals and the news media, plunging back into the sexual harassment controversy swirling around his presidential campaign and casting himself as a victim of gutter politics.

title: Lens: Cityroom Friday
description: Lens: Cityroom Friday

title: Youth Movement, the Early Years
description: MY 3-year-old daughter, Meenakshi, rocked back and forth to the catchy music coming out of the speakers in our living room. She followed along intently as the encouraging voice prompted her to raise her arms, shuffle from side to side and shake her body. She was engaged for almost a half-hour  quite an accomplishment for any toddler  before her attention shifted to another activity.

title: Stephen Karams, Sons of the Prophet
description: Stephen Karams, Sons of the Prophet

title: Meat Week Showcases Food in Manhattan
description: Jimmy Carbone knows carnivores: You say meat, and everybody thinks barbecue, you know? That kind of real delicious, fatty kind of indulgence. Oh, yes, I do know. For this Miser, the recent chill in the air has inspired thoughts of steaming stew, juicy steak and plump pork tenderloin. But that also means worrying about hormone-filled cattle, processing plants and, of course, how to get a quality cut at a fair price.

title: A Suspension of Willful Disbelief
description: Is Maurizio Cattelan quitting while hes ahead or before he lags too far behind? The question hangs over that Italian artists much anticipated 21-year retrospective at the Guggenheim, where, as is widely known by now, all the art is up in the air, too.

title: Following a Child of the City
description: MY love affair with New York, Marc Aronson says, is a continuation of my parents love affair with New York.

title: Jock Soto and Luis Fuentes
description: SOMEONE trying to describe Jock Soto and Luis Fuentes  and their relationship  might turn to Washington Irving and his description of Ichabod Crane: a happy mixture of pliability and perseverance and yielding, but tough; though he bent, he never broke.

title: Mets Name Director of Amateur Scouting
description: The Mets on Thursday named Tommy Tanous as their director of amateur scouting.

title: Breadth of History in One Bite
description: Since it opened 10 years ago the Neue Galerie has stayed true to its narrowly focused mission: to showcase German and Austrian art and design of the early 20th century. That mission was determined by its two founders, Serge Sabarsky (1912-96) and Ronald S. Lauder, who bonded over their shared passion for Klimts, Schieles and the like.

title: Movie Listings for Nov. 4  10
description: Movies

title: Its Mud and Blood, All the Livelong Day
description: The Transcontinental Railroad tamed the Wild West, but the building of it was one of the more savage adventures in American history. Thats the crux of a new western on AMC, Hell on Wheels, which is, if nothing else, ambitious. Even at a highfalutin channel its pretty unusual for television producers to list their literary and cinematic influences. Its a little like a councilman thanking Winston Churchill in a sanitation bill  or a TV critic assessing The X Factor with a nod to Roland Barthes.

title: Long Island City High School Wants Elective Courses Before and After School
When to Talk

title: News Corp. Executive in New York Resigns
description: Beryl Cook, News Corporations chief human resources officer and a trusted colleague of James Murdoch, resigned on Thursday, the company said, and will return to the Asia Pacific region to be closer to her family. Jeff Mook, senior vice president for global compensation, will succeed her.

title: Rock and Pop Listings for Nov. 4  10
description: Pop

title: Look of the Moment | Kirsten Dunst
description: The Look:  Seasonal Bouquet. A coral coat looks bravely to winter, but bare legs say summer hasnt been forgotten.

title: Wall Street Protests, Person by Person
description: If your inclination is to take the Occupy Wall Street protests a little less than seriously, watching Im Occupying Wall Street, the latest episode of MTVs occasional documentary series True Life, wont change your mind. Rough footage from Saturdays show, which was still being edited a few days before broadcast, portrayed the scene in Zuccotti Park as summer camp with protest signs, a rolling festival of exasperation and navet, stone-faced cops and Hacky Sack  Fuming Man.

title: Among the Trees
description: Photos of the Thain Family Forest at the New York Botanical Garden.

title: Maurizio Cattelan: All
description: More images from the exhibition at the Guggenheim Museum.

title: Data Links High Doses of Bone Drug to Cancer
description: A Medtronic product, when used in high doses during spinal fusion procedures, might increase patient cancer risks, according to data released Thursday at a national conference of spine surgeons.

title: For Civilians Who Want Military Style
description: To walk into Kaufmans Army and Navy on 42nd Street across from the Port Authority Bus Terminal is to step into the chaos of pre-Giuliani Times Square, but without the imminent danger to life and limb.

title: Jazz Listings for Nov. 4  10
description: Jazz

title: What to Look For in Fridays Jobs Report
description: The Labor Department will release its monthly jobs report on Friday morning, and economists are expecting that once again the news will be mediocre.

title: Irish and Canadian Boats Head for Gaza
description: Update | Friday | 8:33 a.m. Canadian activists who helped organize the latest attempt to breach Israels naval blockade of Gaza reported on Twitter minutes ago: Two Israeli warships have surrounded our boats and we have lost all contact. My colleague in Israel, Isabel Kershner, will have more on the apparent interception of the ships soon.

description: Classical

title: Dance Listings for Nov. 4  10
description: Dance

title: Lower Attendance Hurts Live Nation Revenue
description: Live Nation Entertainment, the music and ticketing giant, had a slight decline in revenue and flat earnings for its third quarter, as the company improved over last years weak concert season yet experienced a decline in ticketing and other segments of its business.

title: Red Bulls and Galaxy Pulling No Punches
description: The Red Bulls face the Galaxy in a few hours in a game that will eliminate one of them from the M.L.S. playoffs (11 p.m., ESPN2). After the teams ended the first leg of the two-game, total-goals series trading punches and shoves, Landon Donovan called the Red Bulls the dirtiest team in the league. Thierry Henry, in an interview with Jack Bell of The Times, pushed back at the implication that the Red Bulls had become an undisciplined team capable of winning without overly physical play.

title: In an I.P.O., a Clamor for Groupons Deal
description: 9:09 p.m. | Updated

title: A Sort of Homecoming to an Unexpected Fate
description: The title character in The Last Rites of Joe May, played by Dennis Farina, is a hustler of a particular breed: a small-time idealist who always believes hes one score away from the big time. Joe wears (sports) a pinkie ring, leather coat and ankle boots, and if this were a mafia movie, he would be the third wiseguy from the left. When the writer and director Joe Maggio is in a lighter mood, the character could have stepped out of one of Elmore Leonards lowlife comedies, though Mr. Maggio isnt often in a light mood.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for Nov. 4  10
description: Art

title: Romney Previews His Economic Speech
description: EXETER, N.H.  Mitt Romney took on fiscal responsibility and spending cuts Thursday evening at Exeters town hall, an old building that local residents and high school students filled to almost overflow capacity as they came out to hear Mr. Romneys thoughts on turning around the economy.

title: Detroits Mayor Says Budget Gap May Require Emergency Manager
description: Detroit, wrestling with a budget gap and a shrunken tax base, may soon require intervention from a state-appointed emergency manager to save itself from financial ruin, Mayor Dave Bing has told other city leaders.

title: A Cop From the Projects and a Boys Guilty Secret
description: The density of surreal urban grit  filthy kitchens, graffiti-stained hallways, broken-down furniture, castoff junk and layers of caked blood and dirt  cannot camouflage the fundamental fatuity of Dito Montiels police corruption drama, The Son of No One.

title: Ireland Will Close Embassy to Vatican
description: The government said Thursday that it would close its embassy to the Vatican, but Deputy Prime Minister Eamon Gilmore said the decision was made on purely economic grounds and not as a result of a rift with the Holy See over the handling of allegations of child sexual abuse. Mr. Gilmore said recent controversies had no bearing on the decision, citing the governments need to reduce expenses under the terms of a European Union bailout package. The government is also closing embassies in East Timor and Iran, he said. The Vatican withdrew its ambassador to Ireland in July after an Irish government report said the Vatican had discouraged bishops from reporting cases of sexual abuse to the police, a charge the Vatican rejects. The Vatican said Thursday that every state was free to decide whether or not to have an envoy in Rome, but what counts are diplomatic relations, and these are not in question with regards to Ireland.

title: Clever Spanish Dynamo Revs Up Manchester City
description: VILLARREAL, Spain  He walked off the field holding his lower back in the 65th minute, his hair not quite a shaggy mop top, but close to it. Applause rang out from the traveling English supporters and also from the fans of the home team, Villarreal, known as the Yellow Submarine.

title: Catholic Paper Apologizes for Homosexuality Column
description: The official newspaper of the Roman Catholic archdiocese of Boston has apologized for a column that said that homosexuality is caused by Satan. The columns author, Daniel Avila, is a lawyer and policy adviser at the Catholic bishops conference in Washington, where he works in the office that opposes the spread of same-sex marriage. Mr. Avila wrote, The scientific evidence of how same-sex attraction most likely may be created provides a credible basis for a spiritual explanation that indicts the devil. The churchs Boston newspaper, The Pilot, apologized for having failed to recognize the theological error in the column before publication, and it deleted the column from its Web site. A spokeswoman for the bishops conference said that Mr. Avilas column was not approved by the bishops, and that the church does not have a definitive theory on the origins of same-sex attraction.

title: A Titan of Romanticism at Work and at Play
description: Hunter S. Thompson, the godfather of Gonzo journalism, would seem to have little in common with Johann Goethe, the polymathic superstar of German Romanticism. How curious, then, that the recent movies based on their lives should be so similar. Like The Rum Diary, which opened last week, Young Goethe in Love tells the story of a fledgling writer who endures a crummy job with an unfriendly boss, falls in love with another mans fiance and spends a lot of time drinking and carousing and a little time in jail on his way to literary greatness.

title: Jury Hears a Final Round of Finger-Pointing in the Trial of Michael Jacksons Doctor
description: LOS ANGELES  Michael Jacksons death was caused by a doctor who was more concerned with making money and protecting himself than caring for his patient, prosecutors said in closing arguments on Thursday in the trial of the man who served as the pop singers private physician in the final months of his life and is now charged with manslaughter.

title: Gaza: Israel Kills 2 After Sniper Attack
description: Israeli forces killed two Palestinians in the northern Gaza Strip on Thursday shortly after two snipers on motorcycles fired at Israeli troops patrolling the border fence, witnesses said. The Israeli military said its soldiers, aided by the air force, hit the terrorist squad, but the witnesses said that the snipers managed to flee and that those killed were farmers. The armed wing of Hamas said that one of those killed was a member, but that he was not taking part in fighting at the time.

title: Israel and the Lightning-Rod Word
description: To the Editor:

title: Icahn Raises His Stake in WebMD to 9.49%
description: The billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn disclosed late Thursday that he had increased his stake in the WebMD Health Corporation, an online information provider, to 9.49 percent.

title: In Rick Perrys Speeches, a Growing Anti-Washington Theme
description: JOHNSTON, Iowa  As controversy swirls around rival Herman Cain, the evolving strategy of Gov. Rick Perry of Texas as he readies for the Iowa caucuses in two months has become clear: To paint himself as the most anti-Washington candidate in the Republican field.

title: Yours, Mine and Ours, Defined for a New Era
description: Youve probably heard little about In the Family, a remarkably fresh and unpredictable drama set in the American everytown of Martin, Tenn. This off-the-map independent production was rejected by 30 festivals before its October premiere at the Hawaii International Film Festival and is now playing on a single Manhattan screen as a self-distributed release.

title: Congress Considers Increased Financing to Study Alcohol Interlocks
description: Cars that prevent intoxicated drivers from operating them may be rolling a little closer to reality, if only legislatively.

title: Nicaraguan Leader Elicits Disgust and Support, Often From the Same People
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua  Ivn Romero, 37, has many colorful ways of describing President Daniel Ortega: mosquito, crook, tyrant, propagandist.

title: The Myth of the Alou Brothers
description: Baseball is full of legends, and one is that the Alou brothers  Felipe, Jesus and Matty, who died Thursday  started in the same outfield one day in 1963.

title: Following Her Heart, Owner Now Has Juvenile Favorite
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Phyllis Wyeth knows the horse business. She grew up in Middleburg, Va., watching her parents, James and Alice Mills, build Hickory Tree Farm and Stable into an international breeding and racing operation. She understands both how to trust her gut and how to make hard decisions.

title: Sporting K.C.: Livestrong and Prosper
description: KANSAS CITY, Kan.  After a season in which Sporting Kansas City opened a new stadium, put together a 14-game unbeaten streak and jumped to first place from last in Major League Soccers Eastern Conference, Coach Peter Vermes is finally ready to acknowledge that his team has accomplished something special.

title: Funny Girl Revival Is Postponed, Its Producers Say
description: The producers of a Broadway-bound revival of Funny Girl, that was to star Lauren Ambrose as Fanny Brice and was to be directed by Bartlett Sher, announced on Thursday night that the production had been postponed, citing economic difficulties.

title: F.D.A. Officials, Hoping to Stave Off Critics, Point to Increased Drug Approvals
description: Federal drug officials on Thursday claimed credit for an increase in the approval of new drugs and argued that the results demonstrated the need for legislation to continue financing the current drug approval system.

title: The College Essay: Write Well, Write Short
description: To the Editor:

title: The Hopeful Jobless
description: To the Editor:

title: In Surprise, A.I.G. Posts Wider Loss
description: The American International Group posted a $4.1 billion quarterly loss on Thursday as a result of declines in the value of mortgage investments, charges at its aircraft leasing unit and a write-down of its stake in a former Asian subsidiary.

title: Interest Groups Try to Catch Debt Committees Ear
description: WASHINGTON  Facing billions of dollars in possible cuts, advocates for the poor are resorting to some creative tactics to grab the attention of Congress: Getting lawmakers to try eating on $4.50 a day, just as some 46 million food-stamp recipients already do.

title: Amid Wall Street Protests, Smaller Banks Gain Favor
description: Vince Siciliano  a Birkenstock-wearing, organic food-eating, public transportation-riding sympathizer of Occupy Wall Street who earns $240,000 a year  is far from a banking baron.

title: Loopholes for Lobbyists
description: To the Editor:

title: CBS and DirecTV Results Attest to Media Strength
description: Flying in the face of a weak economy, the CBS Corporation said Thursday that advertising revenues were stable in the third quarter of the year.

title: A Holiday Up in Smoke
description: Top athletes know it. Leading politicians know it. And with the opening of A Very Harold & Kumar 3D Christmas, stoners will know it too: No matter how good you are at what you do, theres always someone younger and hungrier coming up, threatening to take your crown.

title: Modern Air Power
description: To the Editor:

title: Palestinians Inch Closer to Rejection at U.N. Body
description: The Palestinian bid for membership at the United Nations, which was doomed from the start by the threat of an American veto, moved another notch closer to rejection on Thursday at the Security Council, diplomats said.

title: Playing Music, With Apps
description: To the Editor:

title: Union Reversal on Givebacks Averts 3,500 Layoffs by State
description: ALBANY  Five weeks after rejecting a package of wage and benefit concessions sought by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, members of the states second-largest union of public workers have overwhelmingly agreed to accept a nearly identical deal, saving thousands of jobs.

title: Arms Dealers Own Words Convicted Him, Juror Says
description: As a prospective juror in the trial of Viktor Bout, Heather Hobson told defense lawyers and prosecutors that she knew nothing of Mr. Bouts reputed exploits as an international arms dealer.

title: Romance Overnight
description: Richard Linklaters 1995 romantic gem Before Sunrise followed Julie Delpy and Ethan Hawke, portraying travelers meeting on a train, on a stroll through after-hours Vienna. In Brady Kiernans winning debut feature, Stuck Between Stations, Casper (Sam Rosen) and Becky (Zoe Lister-Jones) take an overnight jaunt through Minneapolis. The charm, if not the history, of its principals is similar.

title: After Tough Year, a Chilean Miner Returns to Run
description: The darling of last years New York City Marathon, Edison Pea, was back in the spotlight Thursday in Central Park, but this time he did not display a radiant presence, made no bold statements and declined to impersonate Elvis Presley.

title: School Has a Charter, Students and a Strong Opponent: Its District
description: MOUNT VERNON, N.Y.  Charter schools, publicly financed but independently operated, have encountered fierce resistance in many suburban communities, criticized by parents and traditional educators who view them as a drain on resources.

title: Drinking on the Peoples Tab
description: Kiev, Ukraine

title: For Our Allies, Death From Above
description: London

title: As Regulators Pressed Changes, Corzine Pushed Back, and Won
description: Months before MF Global teetered on the brink, federal regulators were seeking to rein in the types of risky trades that contributed to the firms collapse. But they faced opposition from an influential opponent: Jon S. Corzine, the head of the then little-known brokerage firm.

title: For a Close Aide to Herman Cain, Scrutiny Comes on Two Fronts
description: Until this week, Mark Block was famous as the guy who inhaled in a Herman Cain campaign Web video that went viral.

title: Political Class Clowns
description: For a Republican Party that has spent the better part of its presidential campaign proving that most of its candidates are not smarter than a fifth grader, the real scandal around frontrunner-of-the-moment Herman Cain is not what he knows. Its what he doesnt know.

title: Oligarchy, American Style
description: Inequality is back in the news, largely thanks to Occupy Wall Street, but with an assist from the Congressional Budget Office. And you know what that means: Its time to roll out the obfuscators!

title: Striving to Be Just Like You, Too
description: What could have been a moderately entertaining short film is yanked to intolerable lengths in Killing Bono, a shapeless rock-music caper that, like its deluded antihero, just doesnt know when to stop.

title: The Troubling Connecticut Power Failure
description: The moneyed folk inhabiting the Connecticut environs of the hedge fund town Greenwich wield plenty of power. But many of them have lately been powerless. For the second time in barely more than two months, a huge swath of the two million captive customers of Northeast Utilities, the power company that covers territory from the Constitution State up through western Massachusetts and into New Hampshire, have spent too many days without electricity.

title: A Subculture of Random Hedonism
description: Seamlessly dovetailing style and subject, Dragonslayer, a poetic and affectionate portrait of the professional skateboarder Josh Sandoval, known as Skreech, vivifies a subculture of random hedonism and future myopia.

title: Shale Gas Revolution
description: The United States is a country that has received many blessings, and once upon a time you could assume that Americans would come together to take advantage of them. But you can no longer make that assumption. The country is more divided and more clogged by special interests. Now we groan to absorb even the most wondrous gifts.

title: Get Me Something in Economy Size
description: COMPARING his cost of living to his standard of living, Brad Hock concluded it was no longer worthwhile to live, rent-free, at home with his parents and endure a tedious commute. So he set out to buy a place in Manhattan, aiming to spend as little as possible.

title: Lottery Numbers
Another Version of Star-Crossed Love
description: The Capulets and Montagues here are Circassians and Bedouins. The two need to live as neighbors when a group of Circassians emigrates from Istanbul to what is now Jordan in 1900. (Mr. Quandours film sketches in this history in its first minutes.)

title: Putting Millionaires Before Jobs
description: Theres nothing partisan about a road or a bridge or an airport; Democrats and Republicans have voted to spend billions on them for decades and long supported rebuilding plans in their own states. On Thursday, though, when President Obamas plan to spend $60 billion on infrastructure repairs came up for a vote in the Senate, not a single Republican agreed to break the partys filibuster.

title: Workers of the World, Employed
description: More than 60 percent of the worlds gross domestic product comes from global trade. This is double what it was in the 1980s. Most economists agree that the astonishing increase in trade over the past quarter century has boosted economic growth and job creation, and, in many countries, led to a decline in absolute poverty. But while the economic superhighway has spread around the globe, in many parts of the world there are still not enough on-ramps.

title: Israel Faces Questions About News Reports of Eyeing Iran Strike
description: JERUSALEM  Israels top leadership has spent the week answering and evading questions about widespread reports that it is once again considering a strike on Irans nuclear complexes, while President Obama said Thursday that he and his allies would maintain unprecedented international pressure on Tehran to keep it from producing a nuclear weapon.

title: Mr. Draghi Makes a Start
description: Amid Europes financial and political disarray, the new president of the European Central Bank, Mario Draghi, made a sensible decision on Thursday to cut the euro-zones benchmark interest rate by a quarter of a percentage point to 1.25 percent. He acknowledged that Europe was headed into recession, and he argued that growth would be much lower than expected next year  offering hope that the bank would cut rates again next month.

title: Bleak Portrait of Poverty Is Off the Mark, Experts Say
description: WASHINGTON  When the Census Bureau said in September that the number of poor Americans had soared by 10 million to rates rarely seen in four decades, commentators called the report shocking and bleak. Most poverty experts would add another description: flawed.

title: At Abu Ghraib, Ambivalence on Americas Departure
description: ABU GHRAIB, Iraq  On a recent day off, Hussam Saad stood at a roadside vegetable stand across the highway from the prison where he says he works.

title: For Bills Quarterback, Losing (Wedding Ring) Is Not an Option
description: Ryan Fitzpatrick, married for nearly five and a half years, says he never removes his wedding band. Not when he clips his nails. Not when he changes diapers. Not when he slings footballs around the field on Sundays for the Buffalo Bills.

title: For Perry, Private Jets Have Been Key to Public Job
description: On a July morning in 2008, Gov. Rick Perry of Texas and several aides boarded a plane for Washington to lobby on ethanol use, an issue important to corn growers and livestock owners in his state.

title: Somalia: Sierra Leone to Send Troops
description: Sierra Leone will send 850 soldiers to an African Union peacekeeping mission in Somalia, a military official said Thursday. The official, Lt. Col. Ronnie Harleston, Sierra Leones military attach to the United Nations, said the troops would deploy in the middle of next year. They will join approximately 9,000 peacekeepers from Uganda and Burundi, who are currently trying to secure the Somali capital, Mogadishu, from Islamist rebels. Djibouti plans to contribute 850 troops to the force this month. The force has a mandate for 12,000 peacekeepers, but African Union officials say they would need 20,000 to try to pacify the entire country, which has been in a state of civil unrest for roughly 20 years.

title: TPG Capital Enters the Fray for Yahoo
description: The private equity firm TPG Capital has signed a nondisclosure agreement with Yahoo, making it one of the first potential suitors to begin formal due diligence work on the company, which is weighing a sale, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Thursday.

title: 26 Miles, Each One an Affirmation
description: At age 6, lunatic-boy-age, Kevin Dwyer was running around backstage at his ballet class and banged his head on a cinder-block wall. The puddling blood from the gash froze the other kids and their parents.

title: Demonstrators Test Mayor, a Backer of Wall St. and Free Speech
description: Shortly before noon on Wednesday, the barricades that impeded foot traffic along Wall Street for weeks came down. Elected officials praised the mayor. Shopkeepers breathed sighs of relief.

title: Woman Said to Have Felt Hostility at Work After Complaining About Cain
description: WASHINGTON  One of the women who accused the Republican presidential candidate Herman Cain of sexual harassment while working for him at the National Restaurant Association in the late 1990s complained that the workplace turned hostile after she alleged that he made advances toward her during a work-related outing, several people familiar with her account at the time said in interviews.

title: Market Anxiety Grows Over Italy
description: When Italy issued 3 billion euros in bonds last week at an interest rate of more than 6 percent, it was about 1.5 percentage points higher than it had to pay as recently as last summer  and the most expensive 10-year money it had borrowed since joining the euro a decade ago.

title: Outerwears Spokesman Does Without Outerwear
description: A NEW  commercial for Columbia Sportswear opens on a snowy landscape in the Lapland region of Northern Finland, where a bearded man runs barefoot, wearing only shorts and running across a frozen lake. After jumping into a hole cut into the ice, he resurfaces from another hole, and then is buried up to his neck in snow in an acrylic glass box.

title: Tainted Witness
description: The Supreme Court heard arguments this week on a critical question about the use of witness identification. In Perry v. New Hampshire, the State Supreme Court ruled that a trial judge cannot exclude witness identification based on suggestive circumstances, unless there was improper police manipulation of the identification. That ruling takes the law backward and should be firmly rejected by the Supreme Court.

title: A Bus Terminal, Overshadowed and Unmourned
description: THE demolition of Pennsylvania Station in 1963 is still an open sore. People who werent even alive then burn with indignation; its a kind of permanent ache. But is there no one to mourn the sleek little Greyhound bus station of 1935?

title: A Star Turn in Housing Court, Then a Bit of a Letdown
description: It was an invitation to a performance not to be missed. An Oscar-winning actress left a voice mail message hinting that she might make her debut in a courtroom drama on Thursday. The show would feature personal conversations with a New York judge and a sober confrontation with a menacing adversary. Further checking showed that even the performance space sounded intriguing: Room 1164B.

title: Costas Kondylis
description: Mr. Kondylis, 71, is the principal of Kondylis Architecture, which is based in New York. Over the last three decades, he has designed dozens of residential and commercial buildings throughout the city, including several for the Trump Organization, like the Trump World Tower.

title: Oversight of Brokers Scrutinized
description: Who was in charge of regulating MF Global?

title: Q & A
description: A Big Jump in the Rent

title: Landlords No Fans of Fido
description: FRANK P. JAKLITSCH, 38, recently divorced and looking for a new home, has weekend visitation rights with his two children  a son, 4, and a daughter, 3  and full custody of Bandit, the family dog, the latter being both a curse and a blessing. The problem is that even though his owner says he is no more ferocious than a kitty cat, Bandit is a 116-pound Rhodesian Ridgeback, and when prospective landlords meet him, they tend to cringe.

title: Afscme Chief to Step Down After 30 Years
description: Gerald W. McEntee, president of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees for three decades, said on Thursday that he would step down next June when his two-year term expires.

title: A Bright Spot in the Condo Market
description: HOBOKEN

title: Friday: Gets Bent Out of Shape
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  BLAST OFF! What a neat way to open a crossword puzzle. Once you leave the [launch] pad, so to speak, the solving is Berry smooth, which is pretty much what one expects of a Patrick Berry puzzle.

title: Log On and Spread the Word
description: BOB LIPP, the owner of a marketing business and a resident of the Great Neck area for 27 years, wondered why the community hadnt taken any initiative to promote its proximity to Manhattan, world-class hospitals, great schools and outstanding parks.

title: Dr. Mullers Findings
description: Richard Muller, a prominent American physicist, was so skeptical about data showing a gradual warming of the Earths surface that he decided to investigate for himself. The results of his two-year inquiry  partially bankrolled by the Charles Koch Foundation, whose founder is a prominent global-warming denier  are now in. And, voil, the Earth is indeed warming, just as most scientists have been saying for years.

title: Painful Family Secrets Laid Bare
description: All family reunions should be this satisfying. Having spent months apart and suffered losses that might have leveled a less resilient clan, the Wyeths of Other Desert Cities have reassembled on Broadway at the Booth Theater, and absence and adversity (as theyre supposed to but so seldom do) have made them closer than ever. This means they have even more power to nurture, delight and wound one another and, not incidentally, move to tears anyone who visits them.

title: Triggers of Lender Scrutiny
description: IN recent years, lenders have stepped up fraud-prevention investigations and checks on mortgage applications. For borrowers, this may mean facing questions on actions like accepting cash gifts from relatives for the down payment or signing up for new credit cards during the application process.

title: Designing a Duplex
description: Michael Mentesana lives with his fiance, Nancy Schueneman, and Derby in a sleek duplex on West End Avenue.

title: Queens Neighborhood Gets a Little TLC
description: SOMETIME this fall ground will be broken in Astoria, Queens, on Hoyt Plaza, a rental building with 34 units, from studios to three-bedroom penthouses, with amenities that include an expansive lobby, a gym, a laundry room, a pool, terraces and a rooftop garden.

title: Allen J. Bernstein, Owner of Mortons Steakhouses, Dies at 65
description: Allen J. Bernstein, who greatly expanded the high-end Mortons of Chicago steakhouse chain during his 17 years as chairman, applying what some in the industry called a Big Mac approach to filet mignon, died on Tuesday at a hospital near his home in Manhasset, N.Y., on Long Island. He was 65.

title: Bradshaw Injury Will Give Jacobs an Opportunity
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Brandon Jacobs has not been subtle in expressing displeasure over his role with the Giants this season. He spent much of his time with the news media last week explaining the candid (and critical) comments he made about his future with the organization in a recent magazine interview. Days later, he was booed off the field by the home fans after struggling against the Miami Dolphins.

title: The House of Annotated Corks
description: MICHAEL MENTESANA, the grandson of Italian immigrants on both sides of his family, grew up in a red brick house in Marine Park, Brooklyn, on a quiet street not far from Sheepshead Bay. His father was a dental technician; his mother was a nurse. There was a basketball court in the backyard, along with his mothers small garden, heavy on roses and mums.

title: For Some, Halloween in November Is a Sour Idea
description: Hitting the reset button on Halloween is proving harder than expected. Some communities, in the wake of a snowed-out Halloween, have rescheduled the festivities for this weekend, like Little Falls, Montclair and Chatham, N.J., which are having them Friday night, and Brookfield and Naugatuck, Conn., which are planning to have trick-or-treating Saturday.

title: Gaborik, Poor in Shootouts, Lifts Rangers With Winner
description: Marian Gaborik is one of the top goal scorers of his generation, with 288 goals in 651 career games, including 5 this season. But he is not very good at shootouts: he was 2 for 19, or 11 percent, in his career going into Thursday nights game against the Anaheim Ducks at Madison Square Garden.

title: Bloggingheads: Global System Failure
description: Heather Hurlburt, left, of the National Security Network and Daniel Drezner of ForeignPolicy.com debate about global political dysfunction.

title: Living In | SoHo
description: A cosmopolitan atmosphere and crowds of tourists all packed into a historic district that offers an embarrassment of visual riches.

title: Wealth, Beauty and Their Many Lovers
description: TAKING up residence in SoHo is for neither the light of wallet nor the faint of heart. Home to the worlds largest collection of buildings with cast-iron facades, the area possesses a powerful aesthetic allure, no less for luxury retailers and swarms of tourists than for homeowners.

title: Surfs Up Locally, Just Right for the Pros
description: The Association of Surfing Professionals surprised many people this spring when it chose Ocean Beach in San Francisco for its premier surfing contest, which began this week. The city is hardly known for surfing, and even hard-core surfers often malign Ocean Beach  a notoriously deadly, dirty and foggy six-mile stretch of shoreline  for its fickle, and occasionallyfurious, surf.

title: A Different Portrait of Poverty
description: The Census Bureau has developed alternate measures to calculate poverty rates that consider cost of living, taxes, medical expenses and benefits like food stamps and housing subsidies.

title: A Place at School Where Students Can Unload Stress and Worry
description: Last week about 20 students sat in Room 466 at Galileo Academy of Science and Technology, writing down all the ways that people abuse one another. Rapes and beatings topped the lists. One boy asked, What if you just have someone tell you youre not going to get far in life?

title: The Perils of Taking on the Voters in a Proposition-Happy City
description: Scott James writes a column for The Bay Citizen.

title: Oaklands Symphony Season Opens, Mixing It Up
description: Michael Morgan, music director of the Oakland East Bay Symphony, said he did not mean to brag. But with Occupy Oakland demonstrations tearing through the city this week, he said he deserved some kind of Nostradamus award for programming The Age of Anxiety into the orchestras concert on Friday, the opening of its 2011-12 season.

title: New Attention Paid to Homeless Youth and Families
description: More than 10,000 homeless students are enrolled in Chicagos classrooms this fall, a 16 percent increase over last year and a record high, according to Chicago Public Schools data for September.

title: A Universitys Emphasis
description: If Louisiana State wavers Saturday, my sister will sprinkle her television in pursuit of divine intervention.

title: A New Linkage Offers Possibilities in the Anti-Obesity Campaign
description: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: A Parade of Protesters, in a Court Just for Them
description: Inside a blandly lighted courtroom, a lawyer stood before packed rows of protesters who had been arrested in September, laying out their options: They could take the prosecutions offer to have their cases dismissed after six months, or ask for a trial.

title: Matty Alou, Batting Champion for Pirates, Dies at 72
description: Matty Alou, a left-handed slap-hitting outfielder who won a batting championship as a Pittsburgh Pirate and who as a San Francisco Giant once shared an outfield with his brothers Felipe and Jess, has died in Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic. He was 72.

title: Knowing Where the Police Are Posted
description: To provide greater City Hall transparency, Mayor Rahm Emanuels administration recently presented information on every one of about 4.7 million crimes reported in Chicago since 2001 at data.cityofchicago.org. The police departments critics have long suggested more closely matching officer assignments with the greatest concentration of points on a map representing those crimes  the cops on dots theory.

title: Victories, Not Symbolism
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala.  There are games where the hype looms heavily beforehand and games that appear larger in the rear view. Such was Alabama-Louisiana State in 1958, the season opener for the Crimson Tide, played at Ladd Memorial Stadium in Mobile, Ala.

title: Epstein & Co. Pass Over the Obvious Choice
description: Dan McGrath writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Ricky Wyatt, 57, Dies; Plaintiff in Landmark Mental Care Suit
description: Ricky Wyatt was a rambunctious Alabama teenager who had broken windows, overturned a school desk or two, and been in and out of group homes. His probation officer decided he needed to be committed to a mental institution. His aunt, his legal guardian, agreed.

title: Mary Hunt Kahlenberg, Native-Textile Expert, Dies at 71
description: Mary Hunt Kahlenberg, a curator and collector of native textiles whose traveling exhibition on Navajo blankets, organized at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art in 1972, broke with tradition by presenting Navajo weaving as fine art, died on Oct. 27 at her home in Santa Fe. She was 71.

title: After 20 Years in Partnership, an Educational Combo Is Getting a Messy Divorce
description: BROWNSVILLE  This weekend, along the borders southern tip, homecoming at the University of Texas at Brownsville and Texas Southmost College will be bittersweet for many. It will be one of the last, at least for the unique partnership between a community college and an upper-division university that operated as one institution for 20 years.

title: Jets Still Looking for Their First Road Victory This Season
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Jets Coach Rex Ryan said Thursday that Ralph Wilson Stadium in Orchard Park, N.Y.  the Ralph, as the locals call it  was an intimidating place to play even when the home team, the Buffalo Bills, were not as good as they are now.

title: Shockingly, Cains Mystery Tipster Turns Campaign into High Drama
description: Herman Cain, accused, accuses Rick Perry.

title: NYT Front Page for 11/04/2011
description: NYT Front Page for 11/04/2011

title: Former G.M. of Dodgers Is Interested in Buying
description: Fred Claire, a former general manager of the Los Angeles Dodgers, said Thursday that he was part of a group that wants to buy the team. He will almost certainly be one of many potential suitors for the marquee franchise, which was placed in bankruptcy in June by its owner, Frank McCourt.

title: Being Texan Doesnt Mean You Support Perry for President
description: Texans have elected Rick Perry governor three times with almost 55 percent of the vote in 2010 but that does not mean Texas Republican establishment is falling in line to help elect him president.

title: Postcard From Alabama: Serenade in the Key of Victory
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala.  It is one of the most feared victory chants in sports. So much so that there have been groups that have tried to get the N.C.A.A. to prohibit fans from doing it after victories.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

title: Corrections: November 4
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Postcard From L.S.U.: A Home Worth Roaring About
description: BATON ROUGE, La.  At Louisiana State, the mascot has his own jungle.

title: X-Factor Watch: Paula Abduls Predicament
description: The first X Factor results show got rid of an act that needed to go, but man what a slog getting to that morsel of drama.

title: Couple Donate $150 Million to Fight Poverty in Developing Nations
description: Stanford University will open an institution aimed at alleviating poverty in developing nations, using $150 million donated by a Silicon Valley investor and his wife.

title: Word of the Day | eccentricity
description: eccentricity \ek-()sen-tri-s-te\ noun

title: U.S. Soccer Coach Names Roster
description: The United States national teams coach, Jurgen Klinsmann, unveiled his roster for two coming international friendly games, at France on Nov. 11 and at Slovenia on Nov. 15. The list includes the known (Jermaine Jones and Timmy Chandler), the lesser known (Danny Williams and Fabian Johnson) and the who-is-this-guy (Alfredo Morales).

title: Calculating Poverty
description: To preview how the Census Bureaus new Supplemental Poverty Measure may change the portrait of poverty, The New York Times consulted multiple alternate measures that researchers have quietly published in recent years.

title: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Friday
description: The Special Central Bureau of Investigation court on Thursday dismissed the bail application of Kanimozhi Karunanidhi, a DMK Member of Parliament and one of the accused in the 2G spectrum case. The agency said no concession could be given merely because she is a woman (The Hindu). The court also rejected the bail plea of seven others accused in the case. A weeping Ms. Karunanidhi, 43, hugged a tearful Rajathi Ammal, her mother, while her 10-year-old son, Aditya, broke down, as well. Its unfair  there is some conspiracy, she said, moments before being led away to the court lock-up (The Telegraph).

title: Player Ratings: Galaxy (2) vs. Red Bulls (1)
description: Say good night.

title: Rangers Ride Lundqvist to Another Shootout Victory
description: The shootout victory has become routine for the Rangers. Whether they hang on to stay even with opponents or tie the score late, the Rangers enter the shootout for the win (and second standings point) feeling good about their chances. They have Henrik Lundqvist on their side.

title: Becoming Bionic
description: Robert Woo regains the ability to walk with help from an exoskeleton.

title: The Mythology of Cold Start
description: A small group of lawmakers gathered last month in Pakistans army headquarters, where the countrys head of military operations, Maj. Gen. Ashfaq Nadeem, stiffened their resolve about the threat from India. He warned of one Indian capability in particular: Indias Cold Start army doctrine.

title: Sick in America, Aching for Africa
description: CHICAGO  I came down with my first African disease in America. It happened after I traveled to Nigeria last April to witness my country elect a new government. I landed with notebooks and questions, but not antimalarial medication. I had been more prudent on dozens of prior stays, but, I thought, no matter: I had already been running around the continent for months with no mishaps. After three rounds of free and fair voting, I returned to my apartment in Nairobi, buoyant about democracy in Africa.

title: News Quiz | Nov. 4, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

description: CARSON, Calif.  The bane of the Red Bulls season  conceding goals on dead-ball plays  proved costly in Major League Soccers Western Conference semifinals Thursday night.

title: Nov. 4, 2008 | Obama Is Elected President
description: On Nov. 4, 2008, Barack Obama was elected the 44th president of the United States, defeating the Republican nominee John McCain. Mr. Obama, a United States senator from Illinois who was the son of a Kenyan father and a white mother from Kansas, became the first black commander in chief.

description: WHO called the euro zone the ultimate contagion machine?

title: Greek Leader Survives Vote, Bolstering Deal on Europe Debt
description: ATHENS  Prime Minister George Papandreou of Greece survived a crucial confidence vote in the Greek Parliament early on Saturday, a vote that signaled approval of the comprehensive deal reached by European leaders last week to stabilize the euro and to help Greece avoid defaulting on its debt.
