title: Vatican Gardens Open to Public Tours
description: The reforms of Pope Benedict XVI extend beyond strictly liturgical matters. During his six-year reign, there has been greater and more streamlined access to the Vatican and its various complexes, including an easy-to-use public reservation system for the Vatican Museums, regular after-hours visits to the Museums Collections and, most recently, regular visits to the Vatican Gardens, once accessible on a more limited basis.

title: Week 9 Matchups: Identifying the Best
description: Packers (7-0) at Chargers (4-3)Sunday, 4:15 p.m.Line: Packers by 5.5.

title: College Is Cheaper Than You Think
description: Judith Scott-Clayton is an assistant professor at Teachers College, Columbia University.

title: The Entertainer Caste Hangs on to What it Knows
description: On a Sunday evening on a traffic island in the midst of south Mumbais Colaba Causeway, three children are at work.Raja, age 16, is banging on a dhol, or drum, hanging around his neck, while the younger children begin a series of slow somersaults.

title: Coming to Terms With Being the Boss
description: Every November, as we start winding down another year and reflecting on what we accomplished, what worked, what didnt and what we should be planning, I yearn for some time and space to really have some good, deep thought about where we are going and how to get there. I also yearn to reconnect with that girl on fire who started my ad agency 17 years ago.

title: Spit Takes and Other Topics for a Comedy Critic
description: If a stand-up comic kills in the forest, does it make a sound? I dont know, but whats more certain is that no critic from a major paper will review it. Every night in this city, scores of artists take the stage and perform for large, enthusiastic audiences, and are usually ignored by critics in the media capital. Most of those comedians are ordinary or bad, but a few may become the next Richard Pryor of David Letterman.

title: Mount Vernon District Fights a Charter School's Arrival
The Lasting Financial Impact of a Layoff
description: Losing a job you wanted to keep is never a good thing. But for those who lost their jobs during the Great Recession, the long-term consequences will probably be very significant.

title: Japans Kirin Buys Stake in Brazilian Brewer for $1.35 Billion
description: The Japanese brewer Kirin Holdings said Friday it had agreed to pay $1.35 billion for the outstanding stake in the Brazilian beer maker Schincariol Participacoes e Representacoes it does not already own as part of the companys expansion into emerging markets.

title: Corzine Is Said to Hire Criminal Lawyer
description: Jon S. Corzine has hired Andrew J. Levander, a leading white-collar criminal defense lawyer, according to three people briefed on the matter, as the former New Jersey governor deals with fallout from the collapse of MF Global, the brokerage firm he has run since last year.

title: Corzine Resigns From MF Global
description: Jon S. Corzine has resigned from his posts at the embattled brokerage firm MF Global, the company announced on Friday.

title: On Our Radar: A Chinese Mine Accident
description: A sudden rupture of a rock face in a coal mine in central China has killed four miners and trapped 50, Chinese news reports say. Last year, an estimated 2,400 people died in coal mine accidents in China as the industry rushed to meet the countrys growing energy demands. [Reuters]

title: A Sporting Chance
description: Professors are using sports to teach probability and statistics. Here are some examples lifted from their tests.

title: The Hidden Meaning of Hand-Raising
description: A psychoanalysis of the different ways to raise your hand in class.

title: Know-How for Hire
description: Student photographers shoot their classmates. This issue: knitters, tuners, bakers, coffee makers.

title: Where the Women Are: Biology
description: INCREASING the number of women in science and technology has been an important goal for universities and industries, and substantial progress has surely been made. More women than ever major in so-called STEM fields.

title: Being a Legacy Has Its Burden
description: HOPE. Fear. Ambition. Desire. Guilt. All parents of children applying to college go through a set of stomach-churning emotions, but parents who graduated from Ivy League schools experience their own particular set of competing emotions and expectations.

title: My Own Private Librarian
description: FEARFUL that the only search students can do is on Google, librarians are eager to show off what they can do. The latest effort is the personal librarian.

title: Profile of a Changing Freshman Class
description: EDUCATORS believe, strongly, that exposure to students of different cultures makes for an enriched educational environment. For this issues Data column, we asked colleges and universities for a profile of this falls freshman class and, for context, matriculants of five years ago. Clearly, the statistical landscape is shifting (some numbers are preliminary).

title: The Half-Empty Nest
description: ANOTHER day, another how-to book. With every alarming landmark that loomed ahead of my college-bound son  rifling school catalogs, prepping for the SAT, embarking on the college tour, taking the SAT, gathering recommendations, taking the SAT again, writing the application essay, arranging the personal interview, filling out financial aid forms, taking the SAT again  I felt compelled to seek out advice. Friends who had survived the process offered tips, of course, but I kept returning, with touching innocence, to what I came to think of as The Books.

title: The Evolution of Higher Education
description: WHAT with shrinking government funds and growing competition from online for-profit institutions, American colleges and universities are facing hard times, and being forced to rethink what they do.Richard A. DeMillo, director of the Center for 21st Century Universities at Georgia Institute of Technology, discusses the evolution of universities in his new book, Abelard to Apple: The Fate of American Colleges and Universities. Drawing on his experience as the first chief technology officer at Hewlett-Packard, director of the National Science Foundations computer and computation research division, and dean of Georgia Techs College of Computing, Dr. DeMillo offers an engineers view of the challenges facing higher education.

title: Tweets on Grad School
description: @cindy091896 I will be inspiring today if it kills me.

title: The Bibliotech: Library of the Future, Now
description: THE University of Chicagos new Joe and Rika Mansueto Library is a futuristic bubble of a building with nary a stack in site. Many of its nearly one million items  special collections, journals, dissertations, documents  can be accessed online.

title: Credentials, the Next Generation
description: HAVE a marketable skill, unappreciated and unverified? Or maybe your talents are outside the domain of college certification?

title: At Moneyball U, What Are the Odds?
description: WATCHING a baseball telecast may not be the best way to learn basic probability.

title: The Online-College Crapshoot
description: LAST June, when U.S. News & World Report announced plans to add online programs to its college kingmaking franchise, skeptics said it couldnt be done. Predicted to be published in October, the ranking is now promised only for some time when its cold out, says Eric Brooks, the data research analyst tasked with developing a methodology.

title: College Radio Heads: Off the Dial
description: INSIDE a broadcast booth, at the radio station of the State University of New York Fredonia, Jud Heussler was presiding over his hourlong comedy show The Morning Inferno.

title: Why Science Majors Change Their Minds (Its Just So Darn Hard)
description: LAST FALL, President Obama threw what was billed as the first White House Science Fair, a photo op in the gilt-mirrored State Dining Room. He tested a steering wheel designed by middle schoolers to detect distracted driving and peeked inside a robot that plays soccer. It was meant as an inspirational moment: children, science is fun; work harder.

title: Closing the Girl Gap in Science
description: GIVE me an S! Give me a T! Give me an E! Give me an M! Yaaaaay STEM!

title: Making Sense of the Breeders Cup Is a Workout
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  As a fan, the Kentucky Derby is an interesting race to prepare for. You spend months tracking talented 3-year-olds as they star in various Derby prep races. You start off with a list of over 300 horses, which is finely honed until the top 20 graded-stakes earners are revealed. You come to the track with all the knowledge you can gather about the entries with statistics, past performances and every prediction you can find.

description: From the editorial page

title: U.S. Adds a Modest 80,000 Jobs; Rate Drops to 9%

title: Friday Reading: Government Aims for More Accurate Poverty Picture
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Before Signing On: A Checklist
description: WHEN looking for an online program, ask a lot of questions. And remember that call centers are staffed by single-minded salespeople, so speak to someone who isnt hawking courses, like a program director.

title: A Need-to-Know List
description: On campus tours, science and engineering schools love to show off their high-tech equipment and promote how many graduates work for Google. But dont expect them to mention how tough they grade or how many students wash out. To cut through the hype, here are questions to ask each school to gauge where you have the best chance of succeeding:

title: The Return of Mein Kampf
description: VIENNA  In Viennas leafy Augarten Park stand two enormous flak towers  vestiges of World War II. Beige and hulking, with walls four feet thick, they are as imposing as they are ugly. Impossible to ignore, they force a conversation.

title: Not So Super Mario
description: The half-life of eurozone pseudo-solutions has been steadily dropping over the past two years. It used to be that a new plan that would allegedly finance troubled debtors while they austeritied their way to recovery would buy six months of relative calm in the markets. Then that dropped to a month or two, then a week.

title: Merchants Of Doubt
description: Jonathan Chait has a terrific takedown of inequality deniers. Its similar in spirit to my own version, but packaged somewhat differently and Id say more effectively.

description: JERUSALEM  The Israeli military intercepted activists sailing toward Gaza on Friday, boarding their two small boats in international waters and leading them instead to the Israeli port of Ashdod.

description: Thailand is under water, and as a result, someInternet companies could be facing problems.

title: Gone, but Still Moving People to Help Young Latinos
description: Before they had mortgages, children or just lifes commonplace commitments, Lisette Nieves and her friends had each other, time and a cause. They rallied to help Puerto Rican youth, organizing an annual conference called Muvete  Move Yourself  raising issues and consciousness among teenagers from the South Bronx to Brooklyns south side.

title: Welcome to the Church of Godspell
description: GODSPELL, the 1971 musical about Jesus and his apostles, brings to the stage a vision of spirituality so earnest that it can veer perilously close to self-parody. With its thrift-store costuming and vaudeville-style song-and-dance numbers, the show is the ultimate in accessible feel-good Christianity. In the 2000 movie Meet the Parents Ben Stillers future in-laws ask him to say grace, and the only words he can conjure are the lyrics to Day by Day, the Godspell ditty that the composer Stephen Schwartz set to lyrics from a 13th-century Roman Catholic prayer. Everyone, even a nervous Jew under the watchful eye of a C.I.A. agent father-in-law, remembers those tunes.

title: Fast and Easy Vegan Dishes
description: Every dish on the Thanksgiving table doesnt have to involve hours of preparation. Thats why Wells Vegetarian Thanksgiving series is offering four new vegan dishes that can be prepared in 30 minutes or less.

title: Early Economic Projections Could Haunt Obama in 2012
description: A year out from Election Day: an eon in political time, sufficient to alter circumstances substantially for or against either party. But Fridays tepid jobs report brings a fresh reminder of the stubborn difficulty President Obama and his team face in overcoming one of their most enduring mistakes, one made before he even took office.

title: 33 Waterfront Acres for Sale (but Read the Fine Print)
description: Anybody interested in 33 acres of waterfront property in New York City?

title: What Were Reading
description: Eater: What do top New York sommeliers like to drink with Chinese food? Talia Baiocchi reveals their secrets, along with a few of their favorite Chinese restaurants.  Eric Asimov

title: Anxious Over Jobs and Europe, Wall St. Falls for Week
description: Stocks dipped on Wall Street after sinking in Europe on Friday as the Group of 20 nations ended a summit meeting with seemingly little headway in resolving the debt crisis in the euro zone.

title: Now Booking | The St. Regis Florence
description: Perpetually swarmed with tourists, Florence, Italy, is at last trying to make things a little easier for visitors with across-the-board improvements to its tired infrastructure and dated hotel scene. The abysmal Amerigo Vespucci Airport is nearing completion of an expansion and upgrade to its terminals, and both boutique and big-name hotels, like Il Salviatino and the Four Seasons, are adding much needed up-to-date accommodations. The St. Regis made the biggest splash last month with a $25 million renovation of a 1492 Brunelleschi pile that was once the Grand Hotel Florence.

title: The Enthusiast: Mae Whitman of Parenthood
description: Enthusiast: Starlee Kine, essayist

title: The Norquist Rebellion
description: It seems like every day brings a fresh reminder of how polarized and paralyzed Washington has become. On Thursday, the Senate took up Mr. Obamas proposal to spend $60 billion on repairs to roads, bridges, airports  the things that get lumped under the poetic-sounding instrastructure. Not a single Republican voted to break their partys filibuster of this bill, despite the fact that many, if not all of them, have supported such spending before.

title: The Fall of the House of Plastic Flowers, and Its Rebirth
description: Maybe plastic flowers can die, after all.

title: Rolls-Royce Recalls Nearly 600 Ghost Models for Fire Hazard
description: Rolls-Royce is recalling almost 600 of its 2010 Ghost models for a possible fire hazard, the automaker has told the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

title: Italy Agrees to Allow I.M.F. to Monitor Its Progress on Debt
description: CANNES, France  Acceding to pressure from European leaders, Italy invited the International Monetary Fund on Friday to look over its shoulder to ensure that Rome is carrying out changes devised to keep the country from succumbing to Europes sovereign debt crisis, signifying a new moment in global economic management.

title: Damage and Snow Below, With Better News Above
description: See a larger version of the forest from this week. Compare with the blow-up of last week.

title: In a Year of Lockouts, Games Worth Watching
description: O.K., its a big sports weekend ahead, so we hope you have prepared properly. Snacks and beverages? Check. New batteries in the DVR remote? (You dont actually watch this stuff totally live, do you?) Check. Full tank of the-N.C.A.A.-is-a-farce denial potion? Check. Freshly dusted Bill Belichick voodoo doll? Check!

title: From Roughnecks to Bosses, Ministry Seeks to Save Souls in the Oilfields
description: JEWETT, Tex.  With a box of Bibles as cargo, John Bird steered his Chevy Suburban off a two-lane road in the oil patch of East Texas and pulled up to the isolated derrick of Energy Drilling Company Rig 9. He was delivering the holy books to a man named Robert Bailey, the site superintendent, known in industry jargon as a tool pusher.

title: Cain Allegations Not Affecting Support, Poll Finds
description: A poll released on Friday found that the sexual harassment controversy surrounding Herman Cain had not affected his level of support in the 2012 presidential campaign, with most Republicans saying the controversy would have no impact on their likelihood of supporting Mr. Cain.

description: Television

title: A Composer Echoes in Unexpected Places
description: AT home one day in 1956 George Avakian, then one of the top executives and producers at Columbia Records, received a telephone call from the classical music composer Alan Hovhaness, who told him, Theres a terrific musician from India who is here, and you should meet him. His friend was so adamant, Mr. Avakian recalled recently, that a few minutes later Hovhaness was knocking on the door, with Ravi Shankar in tow.

title: Keeping Operas, And His Life, In Brisk Motion
description: WHAT role does the government have in the home? the American composer Nico Muhly asked recently over tea in a Midtown cafe. Its a complicated and interesting question.

title: Tebow, the Colts, the Jets: Judy Battista Answers Your Questions
description: Q.

title: Animation Joins Jazz At the Next Wave Festival
description: NEXT week the large-ensemble jazz composer Darcy James Argue and the graphic novelist Danijel Zezelj will be collaborating for four nights on Brooklyn Babylon, as part of the Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. It is an hourlong performance involving an 18-piece band conducted by Mr. Argue, with nearly continuous animation and live painting by Mr. Zezelj on a 36-foot long panel.

title: DealBook: Groupon Shares Spike 40%, to Open at $28
description: Groupon  an Internet darling with no profits but plenty of momentum  stunned Wall Street on Friday with a premiere that echoed the dot-com boom.

title: At Least 15 Are Killed, Activists Say, as Syrias Stance on Talks Is Tested
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syrian forces killed at least 15 people on Friday, opposition groups reported, in a spate of bloodshed that activists and some Western officials said called into question the Syrian governments commitment to a plan brokered this week to halt months of violence.

title: Weekend TV Guide, Nov. 5-6: National Team Preening
description: The United States national team will assemble in Paris on Monday to begin training for the two final exhibition matches of 2011  a Nov. 11 match against France and a game against Slovenia four days later. Coach Jurgen Klinsmann announced his roster selections Thursday and has ambitious plans for the 22 players who made the cut.

title: Where Does Groupons I.P.O. Rank?
description: Groupon bolted out of the gate in its initial public offering Friday, trading around $28 a share, 40 percent higher than its opening price.

title: Online Ad Defends Cain, Invoking Clarence Thomas
description: An independent political action group supporting Herman Cains bid for the Republican presidential nomination released a ferocious ad in defense of the former pizza executive, charging that the allegations of sexual harassment are a racist attack.

title: Readers Respond: Marriage Equality
description: In a blog post yesterday I argued that Congress should repeal the Defense of Marriage Act, which denies the right of marriage to same-sex couples. I also suggested that we remove the ability of churches to bestow legal legitimacy on marriage. We should imitate France, where marriages must be performed by a civil authority, and religious ceremonies have no legal status.

title: Ending Bullying by Fixing the Victims?
description: An article in The Atlantic magazine on elementary school anti-bullying curricula is sure to be controversial. Its headline suggests the way to go is to Fix the Victims. But would a more accurate wording be Blame the Victims?

title: Notes From a Young American in Congo: A Rebel Speaks
description: Are you happy? I asked.

title: Design Bookshelf | Great Houses of Havana
description: Hermes Malleas Great Houses of Havana (The Monacelli Press) is one of several books on that city to appear this season, but it may be the most personal. For Mallea, a Cuban-American architect who is based in New York, the book grew out of a longstanding fascination with his familys history. One of his great-grandfathers was a photojournalist, and Mallea began to collect vintage Cuban photography. I loved the information that those photographs contained, he recalled, and visualizing what life was like at those points in time. Mallea was invited to Havana to give a presentation on his research, which led to more talks, and before he knew it, the architect had a book contract. He made eight trips in all, accompanied by his partner in life and in the firm M(Group), the interior designer Carey Maloney, who served as a stylist  but only in a manner of speaking, given what Mallea called the almost guerrilla-style photography of the book. (He worked with two different photographers in Havana and also used archival photographs.) Lots of people let me in, he explained, but no one wanted me to stay long, so you wont see flower arrangements.

title: Weekend Fare
description: The New York City Marathon takes place on Sunday, and throughout the weekend restaurants will reach out to runners looking to load up on carbs, and more sedentary types simply celebrating the race. The Z NYC Hotel, 11-01 43rd Avenue (Vernon Boulevard) in Long Island City, is offering a $16 four-course race-themed menu all day Saturday that includes three pasta dishes and a dessert. Danny Meyers Union Square Hospitality Group, the official food and beverage partner for the marathon, will hold various events throughout the weekend, including opening the Blue Line Lounge in the marathon pavilion at Central Park West and West 67th Street, where spectators can order food and drinks at the end of the race. Ca Va Restaurant, at the InterContinental New York Times Square Hotel, 300 West 44th Street (Eighth Avenue), will offer a $30 carb menu for dinner on Saturday. On Sunday from 4:30 a.m. to 8 a.m., the restaurant will stock a special buffet for runners and their families, with brown rice, oatmeal, pasta, cereal and other hearty choices. Asellina, at the Gansevoort Park Avenue, 420 Park Avenue South (East 29th Street), will feature extra-large pasta portions for $20 a plate. At Spina, 175 Avenue B (East 11th Street), freshly made pastas will be sold for half-price all day Sunday to runners and their guests who bring a marathon bib.

title: The Arts Bloom in Greeces Second City
description: IT was early August, and clouds of tear gas drifted through much of Athens, the remnants of protests against austerity measures. But the countrys financial woes seemed far from the minds of the smartly disheveled young Greeks packed onto the roof terrace of the newly opened Fragile bar in Salonika, about 320 miles north of the capital. T-shirt-clad art students shouted over a mix of vintage doo-wop and 90s alt-rock, or ducked into the covered bar area, which evoked a vaguely postal theme, its corkboard-lined walls cross-hatched with packing tape.

title: Salonikas Art Scene
description: Salonika is home to architectural marvels that testify to its centrality in Byzantine, Ottoman and Sephardic Jewish history.

title: Big Ten, S.E.C, and Big East: Pete Thamel Answers Your Questions
description: Q.

title: Big Ticket | Sold for $8.5 million
description: With its cast-iron lattice work, limestone facade, inset Juliet balconies and oversize apartments, the Laureate, a condominium building at 76th and Broadway, was designed to echo the grand prewar elegance of older, better-established neighbors like the nearby Apthorp.

title: An Undertaker With Purple Nails
description: SOMETIMES you got to do it all yourself, said Doris V. Amen late one recent weeknight as she hopped up onto the back of her hearse, clamped her high-heeled pumps onto the back bumper and yanked a stubborn corpse on a stretcher out onto a windswept Brooklyn street.

title: A Basketball Film About So Much More
description: Melissa Johnsons new documentary, No Look Pass, is alternately a basketball buddy film; a Love Story for modern times; and, as Ms. Magazine describes it, a feminist Hoosiers. But while the film is ultimately more American dream than Hoop Dreams, it does not fit neatly into any category.

title: Video of Israeli Navy Intercepting Boats Bound for Gaza
description: Updated | 3:38 p.m. My colleague Isabel Kershner reports that the Israeli Navy intercepted two small boats bound for Gaza on Friday, apparently ending the latest effort by international activists to breach Israels maritime blockade of the Palestinian coastal enclave.

title: Introducing a Very Quick Read
description: This is your nemesis calling, Will Arnett tells me in his distinctive, grovelly, mock-sinister voice after spending the morning filming his hit NBC sitcom, Up All Night (and brushing up on his hockey skills for a future episode). But a funny thing happened to the Arrested Development alum en route to becoming Hollywoods go-to guy for arch comedy roles: Arnett became a father twice, at least. By day, he and his TV wife, Christina Applegate, raise a newborn daughter; by night, he and his real-life wife, Amy Poehler, raise two boys: Archie, 3, and Abel, 1. Im pretty childlike, Arnett explains from his Los Angeles home. I live a fairly goofy existence. My job requires I mess around a lot and make light of every situation. It turns out, thats how kids live. Oh, baby  or should we say, Oh, babies?

title: Philip Levine Still Knows How to Make Trouble
description: You were recently named Americas poet laureate. What has been most surprising about the gig?  How much attention its gotten. People like my doctor or the guy who sells me wine or the people in my gym come up to me and say, Oh, Phil, this is marvelous. Some of them didnt even know I was a poet. Now there are mobs of people when I give readings. I read at a high school in Pennsylvania, and there were 600 people.

title: The Origin of Spray Paint
description: That a paint salesman from northern Illinois created the tool through which rebels, gang members, artists and anti-Wall Street protesters alike have expressed themselves merely confirms that inventors can neither control nor predict the impact of their innovations. After all, Jack Dorsey never imagined that Twitter would facilitate Anthony Weiners self-immolation.

title: Whats the Easiest Way to Legally Get to the U.S. from Mexico?
description: Given the billions of dollars spent annually on border enforcement, not to mention the long lines at the various crossings, the most pleasant way to travel legally from Mexico to the United States might be on the borders only hand-drawn ferry. Every day, six wide-backed Mexican men use ropes and cables to pull an ersatz barge, El Chalan, a distance of about 10 car lengths across the Rio Grande from Los Ebanos, Tex., to Gustavo Daz Ordaz, Mexico, and vice versa. Sometimes passengers help out, too.

title: Nose Ring of Truth
description: In the very high-end home-furnishings showroom I own, we eliminated a great sales candidate because she had piercings in her nose and tongue. That decision does not fit with my personal beliefs, but I felt others would prejudge her and therefore our showroom. Was I wrong to eliminate her for this reason? Should I have told her why? ANNE AZIZ, TORONTO

title: Blood in the Water
description: For generations, the whale hunt has been a mainstay of life on the Faeroe Islands. The practice continues today, over the protests of animal rights groups.

title: After a Soaring Career, Joan Didion Considers Her Final Approach
description: Joan Didions new book, Blue Nights  the phrase refers to the long summer twilights in the Northeast, where she lives  is her first title in more than half a decade, and the waiting audience has never been as large. For years, Didion has stood as something of a literary beacon, guiding other writers through the chancy straits of narrative reporting. It was not until she published The Year of Magical Thinking in 2005, though, that her work became a signal light to travelers along the mainstream too. Magical Thinking narrated the unexpected death of her husband, John Gregory Dunne, through the rhythms of obsessive memory. Blue Nights takes a similar approach. The books chief subject is Didions daughter, Quintana, who died in 2005 after a long hospitalization, but the account ranges across several decades, scrutinizing memory fragments and details for clues foreshadowing Quintanas death. Didion dwells on her own ailments as well  she was 75 at the time of the writing and a victim of shingles, an aneurysm, neuropathy and a mysterious blackout  and although none of this territory is new, her account is sharp and unsettling in the alchemic proportions fans have come to expect. Reading Didion today, more than ever, means submitting almost fully to the strange authority of the voice on the page.

title: O Pioneers!
description: We moved to the suburbs with my lesbian moms in the summer of 1981. It was the end of Bohemian apartment living  the death knell of batik tapestries that doubled as bedspreads and room dividers and of the butterfly chair that scissored shut on anyone who sat in it.

title: Listening to the Axis of Evil
description: HOW should the United States and its allies deal with evil regimes that abuse their own people and threaten world order?

title: The Murakami Chronicle
description: My friend Tony Takitani is a politically active lawyer in Hawaii. Tony Takitani is also the title of a short story by Haruki Murakami. The connection? While vacationing on Maui, Murakami found an old campaign T-shirt from my friends failed State Senate bid in a thrift shop. Intrigued by the name, Murakami invented a life around it. Fortunately, my friend is nothing like the lonely character in Murakamis story, but it does make for a unique conversation piece. Art imitating . . . an old T-shirt? Strange imagination, indeed! CURTIS MILHAUPT, New York

title: Lex Luger Can Write a Hit Rap Song in the Time It Takes to Read This
description: A few years ago, before anyone knew his name, before rap artists from all over the country started hitting him up for music, the rap producer Lex Luger, born Lexus Lewis, now age 20, sat down in his dads kitchen in Suffolk, Va., opened a sound-mixing program called Fruity Loops on his laptop and created a new track. It had a thunderous canned-orchestra melody, like an endless loop of some bombastic moment from Wagner or Danny Elfman; a sternum-rattling bass line; and skittering electronic percussion that brought to mind artillery fire. When the track was finished, he e-mailed it to a rapper named Waka Flocka Flame. Luger had recently spent a few months in Atlanta with Waka, sequestered in a basement, producing most of the music for Wakas debut album. Waka had asked him for one more beat, one that could potentially be the albums first single.

title: How Students Can Take Charge of Their Education
description: Last month, The Timess Sunday Review published an Op-Ed article by Michael Ellsberg called Will Dropouts Save America? In it, he argued that our school system tends to stifle rather than promote creativity and that students do not learn essential skills and habits of mind needed to start businesses. He said that when it comes to job creation, he puts his faith in college dropouts who become entrepreneurs.

title: I Do Not Think That Word Means What You Think It Means, Hypocrisy Edition
description: OK, let me start by talking about Mel Gibson for a minute. Bear with me, this is actually relevant.

title: Asked & Answered | Stamberg Aferiat Architecture
description: With the opening of the Saguaro hotel in Scottsdale, Ariz., a collaboration between Joie de Vivre Hotels and the Sydell Group, a vibrant design has just blown into the Wests most western town. Standing out from Scottsdales archetypal gamut of beiges and whites, the Saguaro is a brightly hued haven, with nods to the native flora. The hotel was intended to be about Scottsdale, and, flanked by Old Town and the Civic Center Mall, it very much is, while still managing to look and feel like an oasis. The Moment sat down with the architects, Peter Stamberg and Paul Aferiat of Stamberg Aferiat Architecture, to talk about transforming the Old West into something more luminous and inviting.

title: An American Dancer Makes a Leap to the Russian Stage
description: David Hallberg, 29, a native of Rapid City, S.D., is the first American ever to be named a principal dancer at the Bolshoi Ballet.

title: Doris V. Amen, Funeral Director
description: Making the rounds with the director of a Brooklyn funeral home.

title: For Prostate Screening Guidelines, Public Comments Are Private
description: Time is running out for the public to comment on the controversial recommendations made last month by a federal advisory committee, which rejected widespread medical practice by saying that men should no longer be screened for prostate cancer.

title: Cain Dust-Up Doesnt Worry G.O.P.  Yet
description: The finger-pointing and fierce exchanges that have animated the Republican presidential race may violate Ronald Reagans often-cited, yet rarely followed, 11th Commandment to avoid speaking ill of fellow Republicans. But not all party leaders are fretting  yet.

title: Sam Anderson On IQ84 by Haruki Murakami
description: This week, Kathryn Schulz and Sam Anderson discuss the new novel IQ84 by Haruki Murakami; Harvey Araton describes the glory days of the New York Knicks in his book, When the Garden Was Eden; and we bid a fond farewell to the Book Reviews best-seller columnist, Jennifer Schuessler. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

title: A High-Tech Lynching by Harry Belafonte
description: For a brief moment this week, Herman Cains supporters took a time out from blaming a racist, liberal conspiracy for the tumult over recently reported sexual harassment allegations. Instead, they tried claiming that Rick Perrys team leaked the information.

title: TimesCast | November 4, 2011
description: The United States has modest job growth in October; Greece's leader faces a confidence vote; and New York's famed Rockettes have a new 3-D act.

title: News Corp. Starts Compensation Process for Phone Hacking Claims
description: News Corporation has begun a voluntary program that allows people who believe they have been the victims of phone hacking to apply online for compensation.

title: First, No More Guests; Now, Chelsea Hotel Says No More Art
description: At the end of a dusty hallway on the fifth floor of the Chelsea Hotel, an older woman wobbled from her apartment  Room 503  on Wednesday and began removing from the hallway walls several of her prints and photographs that have hung in the hotel for years.

title: Lawmakers Aim to Stop Defense Cuts if Debt Panel Fails
description: WASHINGTON  As pessimism mounted this week over the ability of a bipartisan Congressional committee to agree on a deficit-reduction plan, lawmakers began taking steps to head off the large cuts in Pentagon spending that would automatically result from the panels failure.

title: Off the Charts: Excess Stock Market Volatility
description: Excess stock market volatility   price moves that get reversed in a few days or weeks  has risen to levels seen only three times before in the past 60 years: after the 1987 stock market crash, near the bottom of the market decline in 2002 and during the financial crisis and recession of 2008 and 2009. The charts show the difference between the amount the Standard & Poors 500 moved over each 13-week period and the total of the daily changes, without regard to whether the daily move was up or down, and expresses the amount as a percentage of the index value at the beginning of each 13-week period. In a market that went up every day, or down every day, over a 13-week period, the figure would be zero. Highlighted areas show recessions.

title: In Changing Ecosystems, Winners and Losers
description: Two new peer-reviewed studies, one about forests and the other about oceans, predict that existing ecosystems will rearrange themselves over the next 70-plus years in response to global warming.

title: The Remains of North Brother Island
description: Daniel Avila, a New York City parks department photographer, documents the remains of North Brother Island, in the East River, where Typhoid Mary was confined until her death.

title: Lead Guitarist of Metal Band Found Dead on Tour Bus
description: The lead guitarist for the satirical heavy metal band GWAR was found dead on the bands tour bus Thursday after a concert in Minneapolis, the band announced through a statement posted on a metal Web site. Other members of the band discovered that the guitarist, Cory Smoot, was not breathing just before the bus crossed into Canada, where GWAR was scheduled to appear in Edmonton.

title: New Sex Scandal Attaches Itself to Strauss-Kahns Name
description: While Dominique Strauss-Kahn has faded into the background in the public consciousness in the United States, he has remained part of a front-page scandal in his native France.

title: Volatile, but Nearly Running in Place
description: RARELY has a stock market been so wild and moved so little.

title: True North | Mats Gustafson
description: When you walk into the artist and illustrator Mats Gustafsons apartment in Stockholm, youre not quite sure what era youre in. In the foyer, a turn-of-the-century painting of a bourgeois Swedish interior hangs beneath one of Isamu Noguchis oversize paper lanterns, and underfoot is a colorful mid-20th-century rug by Barbro Nilsson for the renowned Swedish workshop MMF. Under a midcentury nude painted by Birger Ljungquist, Gustafsons great-uncle, sits a simple 1950s stool by the Swedish designer Carl Malmsten. Walk through an angled doorway into the living room, a high-ceilinged space with the graceful proportions and architectural ornament typical of late-19th-century buildings, and the mix gets even richer. An upholstered 19th-century Swedish bench along the window and a group of slipper chairs, all from Gustafsons family, blend easily with sheepskin-covered wood chairs designed in the 1930s by Bruno Mathsson and tables by Josef Frank. Vases by Scandinavian Modern ceramics masters like Axel Salto and Berndt Friberg are clustered atop a traditional tiled fireplace, and the immaculate plaster walls (which are painted, aptly enough, Stockholm White) are hung with Gustafsons spare, elegant watercolors. Venture into the apartments long corridor, however, and youll find up-to-the-minute bathrooms and a sunny, south-facing kitchen in which crisp, utilitarian cabinets provide a clean backdrop for an antique wooden table and chairs. This is an interior thats modern and old-fashioned at the same time, and in all the right ways.

title: Hard-Line Factions Threaten Latest N.B.A. Negotiations
description: At 4 p.m. Saturday, two groups of weary adversaries will gather once more around a hotel conference table and try to settle the N.B.A. lockout  if they can only hold off the agitating factions behind them.

title: Rockettes 3-D
description: The classic Rockettes Christmas show at Radio City Music Hall gets revamped, with 3-D effects and karate-kicking dancers.

title: Rockettes, Rebooted for a New Era
description: FOR nearly 80 years families have been flocking to Radio City Music Hall to bask in the glory of the Rockettes, whose eye-high kicks have as much to do with the holidays as the Christmas tree at Rockefeller Center. Attending the Radio City Christmas Spectacular is an exercise in nostalgia. So who in her right mind would mess with such a time-honored tradition?

title: WatchList: A Parks and Recreation Road Trip
description: If the minimalist, semi-improvised charms of Parks and Recreation on NBC work for you, you can see them distilled to their essence in the shows first Web series, April & Andys Road Trip. (Full disclosure: those charms are largely lost on me, except when Amy Poehler is talking.)

title: Scratch the Ad and Sniff Out the Parody
description: IN the November issue of W magazine, set between a fashion spread on Madonnas coming film W. E. and a piece on the dissident Chinese artist Ai Weiwei, is an advertisement for Pizzazz, an evening-wear line. The campaign spotlights a sweet little girl, her lips streaked in scarlet, her doll-size body swathed in layers of tulle. A towering crown is perched on her curls.

title: Occupy Wall Street: How Should It Be Covered Now?
description: The Occupy Wall Street movement has certainly generated a lot of ink and bytes. Seven weeks into it, the journalistic challenge of covering it has probably grown in complexity. It is not simply a matter of covering the events attending to the individual protests in New York and scattered around the country. There are larger themes to address.

title: Laboring in the Shadow of Hollywood
description: IN January 1943 the Russian-born poet, essayist, former radical and future filmmaker Eleanora Deren wrote a friend that her husband, Alexander Hammid, was having a tough time finding work as a cameraman in Hollywood. The union, she wrote, was one of those racketeer things, though there might be a job at Paramount Pictures. There are other prospects, she added, but in Hollywood prospects are a dime a dozen. Four months later she and Hammid carved out a different future in the poetic form of Meshes of the Afternoon, a black-and-white, 14-minute silent film and a classic of the American avant-garde cinema that they shot a few blocks from the Sunset Strip.

title: Two Marathons: Good Idea or Bad?
description: The New York City Marathon made me smile this week. And then it made me frown.

title: Alabama Quarterback Has the Arm to Win It
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala.  Under Coach Nick Saban, the Alabama quarterback has been asked to go 50 miles per hour in a 55-m.p.h. zone. On third-and-12, the Saban quarterback will not always be asked to make the big throw downfield; often, he will be told to throw short and count on the receiver to break a tackle. Whether the quarterback was John Parker Wilson or Greg McElroy or, nowadays, A J McCarron, there has always been another firm hand  Sabans  at the wheel of the offense.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Manga Mania
description: There is lots of turnover on the manga list this week. Some of the series  which are in later volumes  seem as if they would be daunting to penetrate. All at Vol. 7: Black Butler, about a loyal servant who drifts from dinner parties to the underworld; Soul Eater, about a living scythe; Pandora Hearts, a riff on the Alice in Wonderland mythology; and Chis Sweet Home, about a kitten whose curiosity often leads him to trouble.

title: MF Global Funds Found at JPMorgan
description: After days of intensifying regulatory scrutiny into missing client money at MF Global, firm funds have been found at JPMorgan Chase, according to several people briefed on the matter. Its just not the missing money, rather assets that regulators have already counted, one person said.

title: And All That Stuff
description: SHOPPERS come in many forms, just as fashion critics do. Facebook has become a marketplace, joining eBay, Etsy and members-only sites, not to mention big-box e-commerce.

title: Heres to the Distaffers, the Stars of the Show
description: The 25th running of the Breeders Cup took place on October 24 and 25 at Santa Anita Park. For the first time that year, the races for females and male were segregated, with the distaff races taking place Friday, and the rest of the races run Saturday. In another historical departure (and another departure from history), the Breeders Cup Distaff was replaced with the Ladies Classic.

title: The Caucus | The Cain Non-Strategy
description: Nov. 4, 2011  Michael D. Shear on Herman Cains efforts to deal with the media frenzy around sexual harassment allegations with no discernible strategy.

title: What Makes an Airline Family Friendly? You Tell Us
description: Flying in coach is tough enough these days with airlines cutting back on services and with planes packed to the brim. Then add kids to the mix. (See related article for more.)

title: Are We There Yet? When Families Fly
description: SURELY they could spare a little milk, right?

title: Tracing His Menus Back to Chiang Mai
description: TO drive around Chiang Mai, Thailand, with the chef and restaurateur Andy Ricker is to experience a particular sort of hungry mans torment. That place, he said, pointing at a storefront or street stall, is known for stir-fried noodles, that other one for fish-head soup. We would pass right by. Elsewhere, he nodded toward a busy restaurant that he called the most famous place in town to get khao soi, a Chiang Mai specialty. Again, we drove past. By this point in his career, his standards are set. Too sweet, he said.

title: Time Warner Said to Bid for Dutch TV Company
description: In a continuing effort to shift its emphasis to content like television shows, movies and journalism, Time Warner has made a bid for the Dutch television production company Endemol.

title: Caucus Video: The Cain Non-Strategy
description: Michael D. Shear on Herman Cains week, during which he seems to be dealing with the media frenzy around sexual harassment allegations with no discernible strategy.

title: Shurman Celebrating the Marathons Every Mile, for the 29th Straight Time
description: On Sunday, fans watching the New York City Marathon will see elite runners finishing the race in just over two hours, legions of teams running for charities and people from around the world embracing the city one step at a time.

title: A Chef's Tour of Chiang Mai
description: The American chef Andy Ricker talks about the culinary riches of Chiang Mai, Thailand, which inspired his restaurants' menus.

title: Fantasy Football: Week 9s Toughest Picks
description: Jason and Justin Sablich are here to help you with your fantasy football team. The Sablich brothers will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy).

title: Nerves of Steel
description: Before she died in 1996 at age 61, the designer Isabelle Hebey said she would leave nothing undone, no aspirations unfulfilled. (Well, almost none: she always joked about redoing the Vatican.) Hebey even drew up new plans for her Paris apartment, tailored to the son who would inherit it, right down to rearranging the furniture. In planning her funeral, however, she did not go as far as another autocratic designer of her generation, David Hicks, who sketched his own coffin. But she did get to choose hers. It was very surreal, recalls Emmanuel Hebey, the noted mathematician and Isabelles son. The man who sold it to us was rather surprised.

title: A Tidy, Sleepy Stretch of Vancouver Wakes Up
description: Main Street in Riley Park, once quiet and off the tourist radar, has emerged as one of the citys most vibrant areas.

title: Restaurant Report: Isla de Flores 1900 in Montevideo, Uruguay
description: One of the best of Montevideos restaurants led by young Uruguayan chefs is Isla de Flores 1900, a six-table hole in the wall that specializes in locally sourced offal and meats (lamb, rabbit, beef, pork) prepared in a mix of European styles. The results manage to be both homey and high end.

title: In Nepal, Gliding With a Feathered Guide
description: THE air whistled past my helmet as I removed a cube of raw buffalo meat from the bag strapped to my paraglider harness and placed it in my gloved hand. While a soup of haze obstructed the views of the Himalayas one afternoon last spring, I was rewarded with tilting glimpses of the Nepalese city of Pokhara and of Phewa Lake below. The paraglider pilot seated behind me blew his whistle twice, and moments later, a brown Egyptian vulture swooped in an effortless arc, landing on my outstretched arm.

title: Letters: 36 Hours in Albuquerque
description: To the Editor: In addition to your suggestions in 36 Hours in Albuquerque (Oct. 23), Id offer: dinner at Jennifer James 101, and paddling on the Rio Grande (Quiet Waters Paddling offers guide-led kayak and canoe trips). And Albuquerque has one of the most vibrant street arts communities in the country. Murals enliven walls along Central Avenue. Neala Schwartzberg

title: Hotel Review: Mondrian SoHo in New York
description: THE UPSHOT

title: Letters: Airlines Holiday Tidings
description: To the Editor: Re Airlines Holiday Tidings (Practical Traveler, Oct. 30), flying is now painful. Those of us who traveled extensively decades ago when it was fun are fortunate that we can now enjoy other activities and other means of travel. European train travel can be a joy. Try it after your ship docks.

title: Thanksgiving Countdown | One of the Most Bizarre Recipes for Stuffing Ever Printed
description: From the Diners Journal mailbag (that is, the comments section):

title: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Afghanistan, India, Bahrain, and New York.

title: In the Clicks of a Mouse, a Betrayal
description: THREE years ago I discovered my husband was having an affair with a woman who had answered his ad in the casual encounters section of Craigslist. I was a 40-year-old suburban soccer mom and library volunteer. On a typical day I did freelance work in the mornings, picked the kids up from school, fixed dinner and helped with homework. My husband, a tall executive with a winning smile, came home each night around 6 with kisses all around, often straight from a prearranged encounter.

title: Cain Stands By the Koch Brothers
description: Herman Cain proudly said he stands with the billionaire Koch brothers on Friday, saying he was their brother from another mother.

title: Dear FloFab: We Ate Cheddar and Ritz Crackers for Christmas Eve Dinner
description: Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma, or a question about Thanksgiving etiquette? Ask FloFab.

title: Perry Discloses New Debts From Jet Travel
description: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas on Friday disclosed new travel-related campaign debts of almost $230,000 that appear to largely stem from improper underpayments to owners of private jets used by his presidential campaign.

title: A Visit to Typhoid Marys Domain
description: It took five minutes of wading through jungly vines. I think were standing where her house used to be, he said.

title: A Students Call for a Learning Revolution
description: Nov. 5, 12:44 p.m. | Updated I was struck last week by a Huffington Post essay written by Nikhil Goyal, a 16-year-old junior from Syosset High School on Long Island who is clearly part of what I call Generation E. The piece, Its Time For a Learning Revolution, was a student-eye-view of the need  and glaring opportunity  for innovating teaching (and learning) from the bottom up. (Hes writing a book on the subject.)

title: Watchdog Asks F.E.C. to Investigate Cain Campaign
description: A watchdog group on Friday asked the Federal Election Commission to investigate whether Herman Cains campaign and his campaign manager, Mark Block, violated federal law by allowing a tax-exempt organization to pay some costs associated with Mr. Cains presidential run.

title: Readers Tour Haruki Murakamis Tokyo
Faboo Food Links
description: Lets start with some animal news: I guess nobody ever accused China of being the standard-bearer of food ethics, but braised or stewed koala? Youve gotta be kidding.

title: Now Your Phone Talks Back and Humors You
description: ALEX JOHNSON, a freelance video producer in Indianapolis, has a self-esteem problem. Well, not really, but his new iPhone thinks he does.

title: Dippin Dots, Ice Cream of the Future, Files for Bankruptcy
description: Thursday was a sad day for amusement park aficionados, professional sports fans and moviegoers, as Dippin Dots, maker of the self-proclaimed Ice Cream of the Future that was sold wherever fun and frozen confections met, filed for bankruptcy protection.

title: Joe Drapes Breeders Cup Picks: Day 2
description: Selections for Saturdays Breeders Cup races at Churchill Downs (listed in order of preference):

title: Now Online | Design and Living 2011
description: The Design and Living issue starts with the house of the artist and alchemist Christian Astuguevieille, a true cabinet of curiosities. Mats Gustafsons Stockholm apartment, on the other hand, is a serene and surprisingly warm example of Scandinavian cool. And the artist Laurie Simmonss classic brick Georgian in northwestern Connecticut is really a dollhouse of magnificent proportions. Elsewhere, we encounter the artist Mika Rottenberg, whose videos transform mundane tasks into exercises in the strange and the sublime; the graphic designer Frith Kerr, whose Calvinist exterior belies a Rococo imagination; and the designer Tino Seubert, whose benches and chairs offer a front-row seat to great moments in history. Finally, theres a sneak peek at Anne Sebbas forthcoming biography of Wallis Simpson. Its a fantastic read  just dont expect a fairy tale ending. See all the stories here.

title: National Vehicle Theft Rate Continues to Drop, According to N.H.T.S.A. Data
description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration recently released final data on thefts of passenger vehicles from the 2009 model year, the most recent data available.

title: The Week in Pictures for Nov. 4
description: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a very early snowfall, a statue that moves to the finish line of the marathon and a junkyard soccer game in Queens.

title: Romney Outlines Entitlement Changes
description: Read an updated version of this blog post.

title: The Vogues in Tokyo
description: Heres a first: editors from all the Vogue magazinesseated together. They are in Tokyo for a special Fashion Night Out, on Saturday, to help support Japan and Japanese fashionand retailing afterthe earthquake and tsunami earlier this year.

title: With Baseball Over, Ratings Race Tightens
description: With baseball out of the way, it was a very close Thursday night battle for ratings supremacy between the broadcast networks. Fox narrowly won in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic as the detective drama Bones posted its highest-rated season premiere in three years to go with 10 million total viewers. The first ever results show of The X Factor held steady, matching its previous 18-to-49 Thursday rating and pulling in 11.3 million total viewers. CBS had the largest audience overall with The Big Bang Theory (15.5 million total viewers) and The Mentalist (13.5 million).

title: Uncovering Amazon Publishing
description: The legacy book publishers are pretty much open shops. If you want to know how many titles they are publishing this fall, just get a catalog and add them up. Amazon is taking a different tack, shrouding much of the plans for its publishing venture in the secrecy it extends to most of its business dealings. (Apple, no slouch at being close-mouthed, at least reveals how many iPads it sells. Amazon does not do the same with Kindles.)

title: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Afghanistan, Saudi Arabia, India and Bahrain.

title: Saabs Future in Flux as G.M. Considers Opposing Its Sale
description: DETROIT  General Motors said on Friday that it might block two Chinese carmakers from acquiring Saab, the Swedish brand it cut loose in 2010, throwing Saabs prospects for survival into doubt just days after it appeared to have been saved from collapse.

title: Running On
description: Thats the stirring finish of The Jericho Mile, above. I happened to see this TV movie when it was shown sometime in, the Internet Movie Database tells me, 1979. It made a big impression on me. Even though I had to ask my dad, sitting beside me, why Jericho  the perils of limited churchgoing, I guess  the story moved me. The music even more so: it was my first hearing of Sympathy for the Devil.

title: Flying Under the Radar
description: While its A7 sibling gets all the attention, the 2012 Audi A6 may win the hearts of more practical-minded buyers of luxury sedans.

title: I Do, Briefly
description: IN Hollywood, Mondays announcement from Kim Kardashian, that she had filed for divorce from the basketball player Kris Humphries, fell decidedly short of making a mark in the annals of short celebrity marriages. Seventy-two days is no record. Still, the hoopla served its purpose, in part, by advancing the plotline of the brides reality show, Keeping Up With the Kardashians.

title: Short Celebrity Marriages
description: The record books are full of couples whose marriages dissolved before the wedding china got chipped.

title: Levine Withdraws Again From Met Production
description: The conductor James Levine is withdrawing from Wagners Gtterdmmerung, the final installment of the Metropolitan Operas new Ring cycle, as he continues to recover from back surgery prompted by a fall, the Met said on Friday. Fabio Luisi, the Mets principal conductor, will take over the production for performances on Jan. 27 and 31 and Feb. 3, 7 and 11. Mr. Luisi will also conduct the Met Orchestra at its Carnegie Hall concert on Jan. 15. Mr. Levine, the Mets music director, has canceled all his performances so far this season because of the back ailment. The Met said he is still scheduled to lead three full Ring cycles in April and May.

title: Citigroup Redraws Organizational Map Again
description: Citigroups organizational chart has long required its own field manual. The management shake-ups are always messy, and the changes are often made under duress.

title: Photo Replay: Nov.4
description: A view of the day in sports, including horse racing at the Breeders Cup, sailing in Spain and ice skating in Shanghai.

title: Anthony D. Weiner, Hiding in Plain Sight
description: ON Halloween night at the Sky Rink at Chelsea Piers, a small group of men huddled around a television set while changing into their hockey uniforms, strapping guards to their shins, securing elbow pads with Velcro straps.

title: Two Painters: So Alike, So Different
description: PERIPATETIC museumgoers visiting both the Frans Hals show at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, which closed last month, and Caravaggio and His Followers in Rome, which opened on Oct. 16 at the Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth (after a run this summer at the National Gallery of Canada, in Ottawa), have a rare chance not just to see 13 Halses and 10 Caravaggios but also to compare these substantial bodies of work by two near-contemporaries: celebrated figure painters who might at first seem an unlikely pairing, but who turn out to share surprising affinities.

title: Cain: Up, Down or Sideways?
description: Herman Cain seems to have survived his campaigns roughest week better than most analysts, including yours truly, might have expected.Two polls conducted amid the swirl of accusations this week continued to have him essentially tied for the lead in the Republican field. In an ABC News/Washington Post poll conducted Monday through Thursday, Mr. Cain was at 23 percent, just behind Mitt Romney. And he was just ahead of Mr. Romney in a Rasmussen Reports poll conducted on Wednesday night, where Mr. Cain got 26 percent of the vote.

title: Keith Urban to Undergo Throat Surgery
description: Keith Urban, the country music star, will undergo surgery this month to remove a polyp from his vocal cords and then must rest his voice for an indefinite period, his publicist, Paul Freundlich, said in a statement.

title: Journalists Arrest Adds to Woes of Murdochs British Empire
description: LONDON  A journalist at the tabloid The Sun was arrested Friday on suspicion of making illegal payments to police officers, a sign that a scandal has spread beyond The News of the World to other papers in Rupert Murdochs British media empire.

title: Cardinals, Cubs, Red Sox Sorting Manager Candidates
description: The market is heating up for managers with the Cubs, Red Sox and Cardinals searching for the right candidates. And they all seem to be combing over the same group of names.

title: L.S.U. Star Toughened at New Orleans School
description: NEW ORLEANS  The practice field used by the St. Augustine High School football team is not a practice field at all. It is a park in this citys Seventh Ward, complete with a slide, a jungle gym and the smell of marijuana wafting through the air courtesy of loitering locals.

title: Loeb Calls for Yang to Quit Yahoo Board
description: 5:06 p.m. | Updated

title: High School, That Hilarious Minefield
description: WHILE the big-four networks crow about the ratings for New Girl and 2 Broke Girls and give full-season orders to unexceptional shows like Up All Night, heres a tip: The smartest, freshest, most moving new sitcom of 2011 finished its first season in September. On MTV.

title: Cain Accuser Claims Series of Unwanted Advances
description: Read an updated version of this blog post here.

title: The Name Changed, but Lost Nothing in Translation
description: ZWICKAU, Germany

title: Actor in a Supporting Role, Not the Dashing Leading Man
description: THE new Audi A6 has arrived. And from its debut on the luxury stage until the end of its days, this sedan will be the William Mapother of the Audi lineup.

title: Solyndra Auction Draws Huge Crowd
description: Theres nothing like a financial train wreck to draw a crowd.

title: Some History Lessons in Jazz From Players Past and Present
description: Aboriginal Music Society

title: Friday Night Music: More Civil Wars
description: I almost feel guilty for loving this group so much  their sound is so gorgeous that it surely must be bad for you. But its Friday, so lets indulge in a rendition of Leonard Cohen:

title: Los Angeles Auto Show Design Contest Goes Hollywood
description: The police, waitresses, the gangsters in Get Shorty  everyone in Los Angeles is working on a screenplay. Add car designers to the list.

title: Gatsby En Pointe
description: Something in the air has us reaching for The Great Gatsby. From the Elevator Repair Services epic, six-hour reading aloud of the novel from cover to cover to Baz Luhrmanns 3-D Leonardo DiCaprio vehicle set to open on Christmas Day next year, F. Scott Fitzgeralds meditation on the American dream is stirring a fresh round of adaptations. If there is an advantage to staging Gatsby as a ballet, an art form whose language is largely metaphorical, it might be that the storytelling does not compete with Fitzgeralds lyricism in ones ear. With the Washington Ballets latest production, which had its preview Wednesday night at the Kennedy Centers Eisenhower Theater, we learn there is another: the story, quite simply, wants to be danced to.

title: Dear Abby, Ann Landers ... and Me?
description: THE first response to my first-ever Social Qs advice column, which began appearing in this section of the newspaper in June 2008, hit my in-box at 8:41 on the morning of its debut. It was from Jessica Seinfeld: she loved it.

title: A Home for Those Who Hate Nursing Homes
description: In case you missed it, The Times reported earlier this week on an experimental type of resident-centered nursing home thats operating in more than 100 places nationwide.

title: Wild Mushrooms Make the Soup
description: COOL fall weather brings to mind woodsy flavors. Maybe its the smell of autumn leaves and damp soil, coupled with the occasional sunbeam. You want something hearty bubbling away on the stove.

title: Torrisi Partners Will Open a Restaurant on Thompson Street
description: The guys from Torrisi Italian Specialties say they will be taking over Rocco restaurant, the Italian standby on Thompson Street in Greenwich Village, and opening a new restaurant there next fall, Eater reports.

title: The Privileges of Chinas Elite Include Purified Air
description: BEIJING  Membership in the upper ranks of the Chinese Communist Party has always had a few undeniable advantages. There are the state-supplied luxury sedans, special schools for the young ones and even organic produce grown on well-guarded, government-run farms. When they fall ill, senior leaders can check into 301 Military Hospital, long considered the capitals premier medical institution.

title: Cultural References
description: A general advisory: if you think Im making some kind of pop or other cultural reference  to the Princess Bride, Bruce Lee, video games, etc.  I probably am. Economics and politics are too dismal to write about without having some fun along the way.

title: Auto Ego: Making Corvettes a Habit
description: Donald Pulver of Pennsylvania has been collecting classic Corvettes for decades, keeping most of the sports cars in original condition.

title: Ill Have the Cream of Wild Mushroom
description: Canned mushroom soup was a staple in my mothers pantry (yours, too?), useful for dozens of dishes, mainly casseroles, some memorable, most best forgotten.

title: Rookie Shows Experience Isnt Required
description: WHEN Demis Volpi learned that he would be choreographing a new work for American Ballet Theaters fall stint at City Center, it was almost too big an idea to take in. It felt, he said, a bit like being a little kid and trying to wrap your head around the idea that the universe is endless.

title: Occupied: Portable Bathrooms for Protesters
description: The banks, the taxation system and the military-industrial complex remain intact, but the protesters of Occupy Wall Street got something on Friday they have been keenly desiring for weeks: round-the-clock portable toilets.

title: College Football Creates Boisterous Rivalries on the Giants
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  College football has always been a regular topic of conversation in N.F.L. locker rooms, but recently a bit of tension has developed around that subject for members of the Giants defensive line.

title: Posting Photos of Other Peoples Children
description: I dont post photos of my daughter online. My feeling is that shes exposed enough in my books, articles and blogs. Maybe thats a rationalization, an arbitrary line, but its mine and I stand by it. Only once did I override that instinct: I let the Today show film her as part of a lead-in piece when my most recent book was released. I have regretted that decision ever since, not so much because they did anything unseemly with the footage  the clip was actually adorable  but because I relinquished control over how shed be presented. It was a misstep that still stings: I put my professional opportunity ahead of my parenting. But maybe I had to cross that line to know where it was.

title: Holly-What?
description: Images from the Alternative Projections series, which shows the avant-garde side of film in Los Angeles.

title: Nicholson Baker, William Safire and  Me?
description: On Saturday, I am supposed to speak to a group of aspiring journalists from Colgate University about, generally, the state of journalism and, specifically, the roles and duties of a copy editor. My presentation is tentatively called How Many Journalism Credits Do You Have Now? And Is It Too Late to Change Your Major to Computer Technology? And Can I Have a Job When Your Start-Up Goes Live? It will be a cautionary tale.

title: Look of The Moment | Lauren Santo Domingo
description: The Look: Decorated. Red velvet bows on both shoulders and a high/low combination of brooches. Girls in their 20s should wear costume jewelry and women in their 40s should wear diamonds, but in between its fun to mix the two, according to Lauren Santo Domingo.

title: Jan Brewer, Fighting for Special Interests and Cynical Politicos
description: Gov. Jan Brewer of Arizona has been promoting her new memoir this week. Its called Scorpions for Breakfast: My Fight Against Special Interests, Liberal Media and Cynical Politicos to Secure Americas Border.

title: Sleep Medication: Mothers New Little Helper
description: THE indiscriminate worries and ruminations that churn through the mind of Cheryl Downs McCoy are matters most working mothers have rifled through at some point: I need to call that guy about fixing the car. I think Ive run out my daughters favorite snack. Should I change the batteries in the smoke alarm?

title: Quite an Undertaker, in Brooklyn
description: Doris V. Amen, who owns Jurek-Park Slope Funeral Home in Brooklyn has a directing style all her own.

title: Timescast | Modest Job Growth
description: November 4, 2011 - 80,000 jobs were added in the United States in October, underwhelming economists and the markets.

title: Autodesk Bolsters 3-D Printing
description: Custom made and mass produced are getting harder to tell apart.

title: Hey, Isnt That ...?
description: IT may not have the ring of gym, tan, laundry, but former Representative Anthony D. Weiners post-scandal life as a new resident of Manhattan seems to revolve around playing hockey, going to the health club and dining out with his wife, Huma Abedin.

title: Big Apple Circus
description: The circus, now in its 34th season, recently opened a new show titled Dream Big at Lincoln Centers Damrosch Park.

title: DealBooks Week in Review
description: A look back on our reporting of the past weeks highs and lows in finance.

title: Striving, With a Doppelgnger, to Break Through Corporeal Limits
description: For many current choreographers one dance doesnt begin to tell the whole story. Maria Hassabi, born in Cyprus and based in New York since 1994, works in cycles: the roots of Show, her newest piece performed at the Kitchen on Thursday evening, were planted in 2007 with the creation of Gloria, a duet with the Greek dancer Hristoula Harakas. In it, the dancers moved from one position to the next, layering two solos on an empty stage and introducing the choreographers view of the body as sculpture.

title: Six Renovations
description: Before the first open house, it is often a wise idea for sellers to renovate. That can be as extensive as a full gut job, or as limited as painting cabinets and replacing appliances.

title: A Crown Heights School's Fall From Grace
A C.E.O.s Support System, a k a Husband
description: Heres to Mark Rometty.

title: The Final Countdown | Carlos Quirarte
description: The ING New York City Marathon is Sunday, and Carlos Quirarte, a co-owner of the Smile, is just about ready. This is my first one, he says. And possibly my last.

title: Psst, Seller: Your Stove Is Showing Its Age
description: FOR those who wince every time they look at the cracked Formica counters in the kitchen, the decision to sell the old apartment may be especially liberating.

title: Another Grim U.S. Unemployment Report
description: Jeff Sommer with Catherine Rampell on unemployment, David Gillen and Evelyn Rusli on LinkedIn, Gretchen Morgenson on MF Global and Robert Frank on flat taxes.

title: Rodent in a Roadster and Other Spectacles in a One-Ring Realm
description: Any circus with a capybara riding in a car impresses me. Any circus with a capybara, period.

title: The Colors and Sounds of Scriabin
description: Alexander Scriabin, the Russian composer, pianist, mystic and poet, was a stewing cauldron of creative forces. During his life, which was not long (he died at 43 of complications from an infection, in 1915), Scriabin claimed to have synesthetic associations of specific colors with musical keys, harmonies and sounds. The score to his ecstatic orchestra work Prometheus: The Poem of Fire includes a part for a color organ, intended to project colors into the concert hall.

title: Wistful Reflection and No Regrets: A Life Evoked by Mother and Son
description: The singer Sandy Stewart is the queen of calm. In a world in which everyone is shouting to be heard, Ms. Stewart  appearing with her son, the world-class jazz pianist Bill Charlap, at the Algonquin Hotels Oak Room  is a voice of reflection. As she and Mr. Charlap performed standards on Wednesday, you had the feeling of being in the presence of an empathic sibyl gently reminding you that life goes on.

title: Even With a Fancier Car, Mark Harmon Can Still Solve Crimes
description: With John Sandfords Certain Prey on Sunday night, USA takes a gamble on two venerable institutions: the made-for-television movie and Mark Harmon.

title: Radical Cameras in a Tumultuous Era
description: The work of the Photo League was trailblazing  and sometimes hell-raising.

title: Sporting Big Feet and a Heart to Match
description: IN five features over two decades Christopher Munch has cultivated a singular career on the margins of the independent film world. Although his debut, The Hours and Times (1991), was grouped with the emerging New Queer Cinema, Mr. Munch, 49, has never fit in with a movement, and its hard to think of another working American filmmaker with a similar sensibility or array of interests.

title: Modern Classics
description: Covers from past Penguin editions.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Nov. 4
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: Books Podcast: Murakamis Expanding Universe
description: In Sundays Book Review, Kathryn Schulz reviews Haruki Murakamis mega-opus 1Q84.

title: A Quest for Corvettes Just as the Factory Built Them
description: HUNTINGDON VALLEY, Pa.

title: Audi by Another Name
description: The August Horch Museum in Zwickau, Germany, celebrates the achievements of Audis founder, one of the most influential figures in German automotive history.

title: Dreadful Debut for Subaru
description: RUST IN PEACE

title: Another Nice Set Were In, Stanley
description: MOST of us who love Laurel and Hardy, Ive found, came across them first as children. For my generation, that meant the extensive exposure their short films and features received on television in the 50s and 60s, when they were a staple of Saturday-morning and after-school programming. The two-reel shorts, with their 20-minute running times, fit nicely into half-hour slots, with time left over for introductions by the local kiddie host and plenty of commercials for toys and candy.

title: Authorities in Florida Seize Painting on Loan to a Museum
description: A 16th century painting on loan to a Florida museum was seized Friday by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents because it is suspected of having been looted during World War II. The Pinacoteca di Brera in Milan, Italy, had loaned Girolamo Romanos 1538 painting, Christ Carrying the Cross Dragged by a Rogue, to the Mary Brogan Museum of Art and Science in Tallahassee in March as part of an exhibition of Baroque painting.

title: Honda Considers a Quick Upgrade of Civic
description: AFTER a thorough revamping of its perennially hot-selling Civic for 2012, Honda may return to the drawing board to address complaints that the redesigned car is too dull and too cheaply built.

title: Need Live Music or Not? Well, Why Not Try Both
description: Live music doesnt always improve a dance. For some choreographers, live musicians are expensively irrelevant to their work or threateningly distracting. Dusan Tynek is not one of those choreographers. The participation of the string quartet Ethel in the second program of his companys two-week run at the TriBeCa Performing Arts Center made for an especially vibrant Thursday night.

title: Israeli Juniors, 3 for 3, Keep a Streak Alive
description: The Israeli juniors have been on a tear, going three for three. Last year, they won the World Junior Team Championship. In July, they captured the European junior team title. And last month, they won the open Transnational Teams at the world championships.

title: Singles, Sex and Race in the Age of Bebop
description: A college jazz student once told me of peers who painstakingly tried to recreate the saxophone solos of Charlie Parker note for note. Parkers flights, of course, were improvised; the reproductions, naturally, ran the risk of losing spontaneity. Shadows, the Hoi Polloi theater companys staging of the landmark 1959 independent film by John Cassavetes, takes similar chances, and beats the odds.

title: Jockeys Call for Churchill to Continue to Contribute to Disability Fund
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Thoroughbred racings top riders Friday called for Churchill Downs Incorporated to reverse its decision to stop contributing annually to the Jockeys Guilds permanent disability fund.

title: City Will Take Bids for a Casual Replacement for Tavern on the Green
description: Parks Department officials confirmed a report on the DNAinfo blog thatthey will seek bidders to run a smaller, more casual restaurant at the former Tavern on the Green in Central Park.

title: Juho Pohjonen
description: Zankel Hall

title: Schola Cantorum de Venezuela
description: Alice Tully Hall

title: BROOKLYN PHILHARMONIC
description: Millennium Theater

title: A Divorce Seems to Resound and the Real Issue Is, Why?
description: All over America this week, parents faced a very modern problem: how to explain the Kim Kardashian divorce to their children.

title: Storm Has Vermont Scrambling to Find Beds for Mentally Ill
description: WATERBURY, Vt.  Among the casualties of the flooding that ravaged Vermont during Tropical Storm Irene was a faded brick hospital that housed the states most seriously ill psychiatric patients.

title: Artifacts | Maurizio Cattelan Gives His All
description: All summer long there were rumors. For his retrospective at the Guggenheim Museum, Maurizio Cattelan had a big surprise in store. He was making a secret new work. He was going to do something that had never been done before. Since Cattelan, 51, has anchored his career to provocation, everyone believed it.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Nov. 4
description: More Photographs

title: Oh, Those Blundering Americans!
description: It could be that just this once, the wise and world-weary British spy has it all wrong, and C.I.A. brutality actually prevented a terrorist attack. Maybe, just maybe, Israeli soldiers didnt deliberately kill an unarmed pro-Palestinian demonstrator.

title: When Two Beautiful Lives Begin to Unravel
description: NEW HAVEN  The young couple in Belleville, a quietly devastating new play by Amy Herzog, would seem to have everything going for them. Attractive, amiable and well educated, they are still playfully affectionate after five years of marriage. Sure, their funky new apartment in Paris is on the scruffier outskirts of the city, in the neighborhood that gives the play its title. But whats better than to be young, in love and living in Paris  anywhere in Paris?

title: Greek Leader's Uncertain Future
description: November 4, 2011 - Prime Minister George A. Papandreou faces an uncertain confidence vote, a day after calling off Greece's new debt deal.

title: Producer Explains Scrapping Funny Girl
description: The Broadway producer Bob Boyett had never heard so much bad news in a single week: Four longtime investors in his shows had each backed out of his latest, a $12 million Broadway-bound revival of the hit 1964 musical Funny Girl, he said in an interview on Friday.

title: Chic in Review | Occupy Soho?
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.
