title: #OccupyWallSt Roundup, Day 49
description: Rumors circulated of a looming eviction from Zuccotti Park after tensions between Mayor Bloomberg and Occupy Wall Street intensified. On Friday, protesters accused the mayor of twisting facts after he complained that the occupiers were endangering New Yorkers by not reporting crimes committed in Zuccotti Park. [Atlantic Wire, Occupy Wall St., City Room]

title: Education Law Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Antifracking Movement
description: To the Editor:

title: Homeless Veterans?
description: To the Editor:

title: John R. Opel, Who Made I.B.M. a Colossus, Dies at 86
description: John R. Opel, who presided over I.B.M. in its final period of dominance in the information-processing industry and oversaw the companys move into personal computers, died on Thursday in Fort Myers, Fla. He was 86.

title: Due Process for Dictators
description: To the Editor:

title: The World Leader in Health Care Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: Royal Delta Wins Breeders Cup Ladies Classic
description: So much for this being the day of the favorites. There was a few nice payouts on $2 bets to win Friday. However, Royal Delta, a slight 2-1 favorite, captured the $2 million Breeders Cup Ladies Classic.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,814 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Keeping It Simple and Convenient
description: JUST south of the Tappan Zee Bridge, Bistro Z at the Doubletree Hotel in Tarrytown could not be more convenient  not only for the passing traveler, but also as a gathering spot for local business and social events.

title: Patriots Are Masters at Learning From Losing
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  There are no signs of black bunting adorning any part of Gillette Stadium and, at 5-2, there is clearly no sense of impending doom among the New England Patriots. In their minds, they remain one of the elite N.F.L. teams.

title: Protesters Blocked From Returning to Bahrains Pearl Square
description: Hundreds of protesters were prevented from returning to a symbolic square in Bahrains capital, Manama, on Friday, following the funeral of a man the main opposition party said was beaten to death by security forces this week.

title: Siri Failure Leaves iPhones Mute
description: No wonder Apple says Siri  its voice-activated virtual assistant for the new iPhone  is in beta.

title: 15 Years That Changed Photography
description: Sixty years ago this week, the Photo League fell victim to Cold War witch hunts and blacklists, closing its doors after 15 intense years of trailblazing  and sometimes hell-raising  documentary photography. From unabashedly leftist roots, the group influenced a generation of photographers who transformed the documentary tradition, elevating it to heady aesthetic heights.

title: This Sunday: Butter With Your Toast, Mr. President?
description: Predicting the future may be impossible, but that doesnt stop millions of people from trying. And because so many of them do try, somebody is bound to be correct, and then that person is hailed as a genius until the next thing comes along and then theyre back to being fools like the rest of us.

title: Where the Menu Knows Your Name
description: CAN success spoil Chef Luis Restaurant? Not judging by the crowds at lunch and dinner at this cozy New Canaan hangout. Four years ago, the Guatemalan chef Luis Lopez opened a cramped, minuscule eatery that was jammed day and night, even without a liquor license. It was a real sleeper, with delicious food at fair market prices. He credited many of his culinary skills to his apprenticeship at Sol, an Italian restaurant a few doors away on the same street.

title: Three New Elements Named: Darmstadtium, Roentgenium and Copernicium
description: Calling Tom Lehrer.

title: Games to Watch on Saturday
description: NO. 1 LOUISIANA STATE AT NO. 2 ALABAMA8 p.m. Eastern, CBS

title: Bill Cunningham | Fall?
description: There was the expected surge in all-black, but more important were the neutrals mixed with fur vests and yards of scarves.

title: Free Lodging in Old-Brooklyn Elegance, Just for a Select Group
description: The hotel lobby buzzes like any other in New York on a weekday morning, as families from around the world excitedly examine maps, while bellhops in khaki pants and polo shirts give directions and load luggage carts.

title: Life Sentence for Possession of Child Pornography Spurs Debate Over Severity
description: Does downloading child pornography from the Internet deserve the same criminal punishment as first-degree murder?

title: Expressive Cabernet Francs
description: Chilly autumn nights call for warming, filling reds to accompany beef, lamband other hearty fare. Increasingly, cabernet franc seems a more interesting choice than simpler merlot, long touted as Long Islands signature grape and wine.

title: A Pub With Pirogi and Lamb Meatloaf
description: SAPSUCKERS Hops and Grub, on Main Street in Huntington, is a pub with a pedigree. Its owners, Nino Antuzzi and Kelley Danek, also run Red and Osteria da Nino, both in Huntington, and Caf Red in Kings Park. Food items served at Sapsuckers have pedigrees of their own: the bread is from Tom Cat Bakery in Queens, the organic eggs are from the nearby Makinajian Farm, the chicken is Bell & Evans and the pork, Berkshire.

title: Apple Doles Out Stock to Keep Top Executives
description: One of the biggest questions about Apples future has been whether its top executives would head for the exits after the death of the companys chief executive and cofounder Steve Jobs. Apple just gave them a big incentive to stay put.

title: Mets First Off-Season Move: Layoffs
description: The Mets announced Friday that they recently laid off nearly 10 percent of their 180 front-office employees, a development that will only further discourage a fan base bracing for the possible departure of Jose Reyes, their free-agent shortstop.

title: Hot Vietnamese Crepes or Grilled Chicken Satay
description: WHEN memories of a hot rice crepe trump those of the arugula-rich salad from my fall garden, its time to share the name of the restaurant that makes it.

title: Postcard From L.S.U.: N.F.L. Bloodlines Infuse the Tigers With Talent
description: BATON ROUGE, La.  While success on the field usually materializes because of work ethic and talent, a little boost from the gene pool never hurts.

title: March Against Pipeline Planned
description: Environmental groups are mobilizing for a demonstration at the White House on Sunday against the proposed 1,700-mile Keystone XL pipeline. A decision is expected from the State Department in coming months on whether to allow construction of the pipeline, which would carry heavy crude oil drawn from Alberta to the Gulf of Mexico. Environmentalists contend that extracting and burning the oil will increase greenhouse gas emissions and contribute to climate change. Some have expressed concern about potential contamination of the Ogallala Aquifer, which lies beneath much of the pipelines route, in the event of a spill. President Obama said that the decision would ultimately be his and that he would put a priority on health and safety.

title: Larceny Pays for Oklahoma State
description: Asked to cut through the smoke and mirrors, Bill Young, the Oklahoma State defensive coordinator, shuffles a few papers and asks for a timeout. Digging through the Cowboys defensive statistics rivals the forensic anthropological plot of a Bones episode. Even Young needs to pause occasionally as he considers what this seasons evidence means.

title: Online Protest of Bank Fees Gains Followers
description: Unhappy with the prospect of paying higher bank fees, Kristen Christian, a 27-year-old art gallery owner from Los Angeles, did more than complain to her 500 friends on Facebook. She organized a Facebook event for Saturday, Nov. 5. She called it Bank Transfer Day and urged people to move their money from large private banks to credit unions or somewhere else closer to home.

title: Operating in the Shadows of Power in Russia
description: MOSCOW

title: Focus
description: A decade back, I flirted with jogging enough to get a taste of its unique mix of ecstasy and agony. Ecstagony. Its an undeniable high, animal and spiritual at the same time. It seems to me, if it doesnt kill you, its actually good for you.

title: Focus
description: The filmmaker Jeff Scher presents an abstract celebration of the New York City Marathon.

title: Gov. Brewers Power Grab
description: In 2000, Arizonans voted to take the power of legislative redistricting out of the hands of statehouse incumbents and create an independent commission free from the gerrymandering of political bosses. This signal reform for fairer elections was blatantly undermined last week when Gov. Jan Brewer led fellow Republicans in the State Senate to oust the chairwoman of the independent commission on unsubstantiated charges of gross misconduct. What it really was was a gross power play by Governor Brewer to ensure a more Republican-friendly map.

title: More on Calculating Poverty
description: Poverty researchers have been debating alternatives to the traditional poverty rate for years. So its not surprising that some people wondered why we chose the particular method that we used for todays article about poverty.

title: Corzine Out as Search for MF Global Funds Continues
description: The missing customer money at MF Global is still missing.

title: Reviewing the Audi A6
description: In Sundays Automobiles section, Lawrence Ulrich reviews the Audi A6, a perennial thorn in the side of the BMW 5 Series and Mercedes-Benz E-Class that now finds itself in the shadow, at least aesthetically, of its sibling, the A7.

title: Edging Toward Equality
description: On Thursday, the Senate Judiciary Committee began consideration of a measure that would repeal the Defense of Marriage Act, the deplorable 1996 law that bars federal recognition of same-sex marriages and denies lawfully married same-sex couples benefits granted other married couples, including Social Security survivor payments and unpaid leave to care for a seriously ill spouse.

title: Salvaging Abandoned Bikes, Making Room for Others
description: THEIR frames molder and peel in the citys musty depths. Hundreds  perhaps thousands  rest in haphazard jumbles, their surfaces pocked with rust, their tubes airless and stiffened by time.

title: Facts Blur as Online Feud Ends in a Draw
description: MEXICO CITY  Some bloggers and Twitter users claiming to be part of the hacker movement Anonymous now say they have abandoned plans to expose collaborators working with the Zetas crime syndicate because the friend they say the gang kidnapped has been released.

title: With a Book, the Last Democrat in the White House Tries to Help the Current One
description: Last summer, as Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton celebrated the former presidents 65th birthday with a party at their rented Hamptons home, talk among their guests turned to President Obamas travails over the debt crisis and doubts about his re-election. Im really trying to help him, the white-haired former president said, shaking his head, but he seems to have lost his narrative.

title: The Lessons of Genocide, Taught by the Son of Parents Who Survived It
description: Just days after liberation, surrounded by starvation and disease, a young woman looked into a soldiers movie camera and described the horrors of the Nazi concentration camp at Bergen-Belsen.

title: Cemetery Walks and Gin Cocktails
description: As executive director of the Historic Districts Council, Simeon Bankoff has been an advocate for the preservation of the citys historic neighborhoods since 2000. Lately he has been immersed in a high-stakes battle to prevent Donald Trumps son-in-law, Jared Kushner, from crowning the Puck Building, a designated city landmark, with a two-story glass penthouse. Mr. Bankoff, 41, lives in a 105-year-old brick row house in Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn, with his wife, Hafina Allen, 40, a candidate for a masters in social work at N.Y.U.; their cat, Inky; and several pet rodents (three chinchillas, two guinea pigs and a hamster).

title: Lottery Numbers
Wild Turkeys Get a Taste of Domesticity, Much to a Boroughs Chagrin
description: Michael Budano is fearless. As a teenager in East Harlem, he polished the shoes of mobsters like Frank Costello and Joseph Valachi without blinking an eye.

title: A Good Day for Groupon and Internet Start-Ups
description: After a months-long journey filled with blunders, Groupon punched its ticket to the public markets on Friday. And the daily deals site got a warm reception, a welcome sign for Internet start-ups still waiting to go public.

title: Welcome Back
description: A year from now, Americans will choose whether to reelect President Obama or to replace him; they will pick 33 senators and every member of the House; and they will argue about it with each other all along the way. Campaign Stops will join this ongoing conversation by presenting the sharpest opinion pieces on the 2012 election, just as it did in 2008. Well hear from Times columnists and contributing writers and many other people who have something to say. Campaign Stops will examine the battle for public opinion state by state, focusing particularly on the ten or twelve states that emerge as key to the election. It will also be a laboratory of sorts for proposals to improve how we make our political choices.

title: The Prime Minister and the Sunnis
description: The authoritarian tendencies of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq are well known. But the arrest of more than 600 Iraqis whom the government describes as suspected former members of Saddam Husseins Baath Party and army is particularly cynical and reckless. With American troops scheduled to withdraw by years end, the last thing Mr. Maliki should be doing is stoking sectarian tensions.

title: Brooklyn Legislator Doesnt Testify at His Bribery Trial
description: William F. Boyland Jr., a Brooklyn assemblyman accused of taking bribes from a health care organization in return for carrying out official acts in Albany on its behalf, declined to take the stand in his defense on Friday, and his lawyers called only two witnesses before resting their case.

title: The Great Escape
description: On Nov. 7, 1861, Brig. Gen. Ulysses S. Grant withdrew his federal forces after a creditable but inconclusive battle against Confederates encamped at Belmont, Mo. But as the men withdrew to transports waiting for them along the Mississippi River, four soldiers from the Seventh Iowa Infantry hurried back to the battlefield to rescue their popular lieutenant colonel, Augustus Wentz, who had been struck in the side by a bullet and left behind.

title: After Years of Conflict, a New Dynamic in Wolf Country
description: JACKSON, Mont.   As a fourth-generation rancher, Dean B. Peterson has a complicated relationship with wolves.

title: Bypassing Obvious Stars, for One From Overseas
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.

title: Occupying the National Debate
description: The Occupy Wall Street protest continues to inspire demonstrators across the nation and beyond. At midweek, protesters of the economys woeful status quo were reported gathered in more than 70 American cities, while there were similar demonstrations in London, Frankfurt and, of course, Cannes, where the G-20 governments wrestled with the threat of more economic disaster.

title: Cain Accuser Tells of Pattern of Behavior, Lawyer Attests
description: WASHINGTON  The lawyer for one of the women who accused Herman Cainof sexual harassment said Friday that Mr. Cain engaged ina series of inappropriate behaviors and unwanted advancestoward his client over two months in the 1990s,and he directly accused Mr. Cain, a Republican presidential candidate, of not telling the truth about his behavior.

title: Prosecutors Target Gang in Harlem; 19 Charged
description: The street gang that prowled part of West 129th Street went by several names, including Goodfellas, One Twenty-Nine and the New Dons. Its specialty was firearms, authorities said, which members hid in storm drains, on rooftops and beneath mailboxes.

title: Hello, Its  a Message From Mitt Romney About Rick Perry
description: Mitt Romney may be skipping some major G.O.P. events in Iowa this week, but hes still got his eye on someone who isnt: his rival Rick Perry.

title: Silicon Valley Wows Educators, and Woos Them
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Three times over the last two years, school officials from Little Falls, Minn., have escaped the winter cold for two-day trips to Silicon Valley. Their destination: the headquarters of Apple.

title: Finding a Middle Ground for the Gray Wolf
description: The dynamic between ranchers and conservationists over the rebounding gray wolf population has begun to change.

title: Win Seals Fillys Title and Bolsters Motts Haul
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Bill Mott likes Churchill Downs. He should, as he is this storied racetracks leading trainer with more than 650 career victories. He likes the Breeders Cup Ladies Classic even better. No wonder: when Royal Delta rolled past the finish line Friday it was Motts fourth victory in the $2 million race and his second in a row.

title: Beckham Pushes to Finish Line in Last Year of Contract
description: CARSON, Calif.  In his last game before joining the Los Angeles Galaxy in 2007, David Beckham played on a sprained left ankle that received three cortisone shots. Yet he stayed on the field and helped Real Madrid win Spains first division.

title: The Aging of Spanish Democracy
description: Madrid

title: Gauging the Impact of Yiddish
description: MORE New Yorkers speak Yiddish at home than Korean, according to the 2010 Census, but that insight only begins to explain the impact of the language and its associated culture on the city. Two new books fill that void: Yiddishkeit: Jewish Vernacular and the New Land (Abrams ComicArts), edited by Harvey Pekar and Paul Buhle, and All Together Different: Yiddish Socialists, Garment Workers, and the Labor Roots of Multiculturalism (NYU Press), by Daniel Katz.

title: Opposites, Obama and Sarkozy Attract, if Uneasily
description: CANNES, France  Just a few hours after the United Nations Security Council authorized military action against Libya in March, President Obama placed a call to the French president, Nicolas Sarkozy.

title: The Weeks Business News in Photos
description: Ruth Madoff spoke out, the crisis in Europe took new turns and Groupon finally went public.

title: To Fix Housing, See the Data
description: In Miami recently, I met up with Laurie Goodman, a senior managing director of Amherst Securities. Id been trying to meet her ever since Id read an article that she had written in March entitled The Case for Principal Reductions. But our schedules never seemed to mesh. So when I noticed that we were both going to be at a conference in Miami, I wangled a breakfast appointment. It was one of the more illuminating breakfasts Ive had in a while.

title: A Floor Made for Dancing, but Not for Modesty
description: More than art was on display at an after-hours party at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Thursday night. A mirrored dance floor shimmered in the Temple of Dendur, but after a few turns on the floor it became clear to anyone wearing a dress  and almost every woman was wearing a dress  that this was a bad idea.

title: Saturday: One in a Biergarten
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  The first thing I noticed about this grid was the unusual pattern of black squares. It looked like the line through a circle symbol for something thats not allowed. The next thing I noticed was the six 15 letter entries: Im always impressed when constructors can make their long entries cross like that.

title: The Best Perk in Politics
description: We have been hearing a lot about important politicians and private jets.

title: Pursuing Self-Improvement, at the Risk of Self-Acceptance
description: SOMETIMES I get tired of always striving to be better  of knowing there are ways, endless ways, I can improve myself or members of my immediate family.

title: Romney Debt Plan Includes Medicare Overhaul and Social Security Changes
description: WASHINGTON  Mitt Romney, in a speech before a conservative group here on Friday, offered his most detailed plan yet to cut government spending and lower the federal debt, including an overhaul of Medicare and significant changes to Social Security.

title: Postcard From Alabama: Playing for the Stones, Rooting for the Tide
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala.  Chuck Leavell has traveled the world with the Rolling Stones, but he still calls Tuscaloosa home. And he still counts himself as a die-hard fan of Alabama football.

title: Students Repeat a Poems Slurs, Surprising the Poets and an Elite Bronx School
description: The poetry assembly on Tuesday morning at the Horace Mann School, in the Bronx, was meant to be provocative. The visiting poets who led it asked students to write words on index cards  remembrances, colors and references to pop-culture icons  that would then converge as poems.

title: Special Parking Rules
description: Because of Id al-Adha, the Islamic Feast of Sacrifice, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended on Sunday, Monday and Tuesday in New York City. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Texas Gun Instructors Ad Leads to State Inquiry
description: MASON, Tex.  Crockett Keller, a weapons instructor who runs a general store in this small town in Central Texas, needed a few more students for a recent concealed-handgun course. He decided to put an ad on a local country music radio station, but his attempt to prohibit certain students from signing up has jeopardized his state-certified status and earned him praise, condemnation and even death threats from people around the world.

title: MF Global Clients Fear for What They Left
description: Igor Gavrylov of Kiev, Ukraine, had about $100,000 at MF Global when it collapsed on Monday, although he managed to pull out $150,000 last week.

title: #trendingnyc: The Week on Twitter
description: Have you no sense of decency, Twitter-verse?

title: Settlement Prompts Fear About Cuts to Medicaid
description: When New York City agreed to pay $70 million this week to settle accusations of Medicaid fraud in a program intended to take care of disabled people at home, it seemed like a victory for the disabled.

title: Old Subway Pros, Separating Drunk From Wallet
description: In the world of crime statistics, there is a certain subsection of victim on the city subways: a reveler who, overserved during a night on the town, nods off on a train. He wakes with a flapping, precision-cut hole in his trousers and cool, thin air where his wallet used to be.

title: At Jefferies, Laying Bare Its Exposure to Euro Debt
description: After another day of investor anxiety about the Jefferies Groups exposure to European debt, the brokerage firm took the unusual step of detailing exactly what debt it holds from Greece, Italy, Ireland, Portugal and Spain.

title: Dont Call Herman a Monster
description: Oh, Herman.

title: Corrections: November 5
description: BUSINESS DAY

title: The Week in Pictures for Nov. 4
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a very early snowfall, a statue that moved to the finish line of the marathon and a junkyard soccer game in Queens.

title: Pursuing a Piracy Claim Against Apple
description: WOODBRIDGE, Conn.  David Gelernter is known for many things. As a pioneering computer scientist, he first earned renown by connecting computers together into collaborative networks. Then in 1993, he gained the kind of fame no one wants, as a victim of Theodore Kaczynski, the Unabomber, who mailed a pipe bomb to his office at Yale University that left him gravely injured.

title: A Church. A Shelter. Is It Safe?
description: HARD by the mouth of the Lincoln Tunnel, on one of the last ungentrified blocks of Midtown Manhattan, Metropolitan Community Church sits sandwiched between neighbors with pull-down metal gates, its front doors looking almost like the entrance to a loading dock.

title: Lufthansa in Preliminary Deal to Sell a British Unit
description: The International Airlines Group, the parent company of British Airways and the Spanish carrier Iberia, said on Friday that it had reached a preliminary agreement with Lufthansa of Germany to acquire its British Midland International unit. Details of the transaction, including a binding purchase agreement, were still being negotiated, I.A.G. said. The sale would also be subject to the completion of due diligence and clearance from competition regulators. News of the prospective takeover came as I.A.G. announced a 31 percent drop in third-quarter operating profit to 363 million euros, from 528 million euros a year earlier. The group blamed rising fuel prices and weaker travel demand from leisure passengers. Lufthansa had sought for several months to sell British Midland, which analysts have valued at 300 million to 400 million euros, or $414.5 million to $552.6 million.

title: Along the Route, Neighborhood Snapshots of New Yorks Progression
description: As dusk fell, a woman, head to toe in black, bounded down the sidewalk, with a leash in one hand and a baby tucked against her chest. By the curb, two men in suits loudly debated the stock market. And at a Mexican bistro, patrons sipped Chardonnay from stemless glasses under graffiti framed as art.

title: Taming Unruly Wind Power
description: For decades, electric companies have swung into emergency mode when demand soars on blistering hot days, appealing to households to use less power. But with the rise of wind energy, utilities in the Pacific Northwest are sometimes dealing with the opposite: moments when there is too much electricity for the grid to soak up.

title: Brazils Rising Influence Meets Resistance
description: Ambitious Brazilian projects in Latin America are meeting resistance and resentment  none more so than a plan to build a road through an indigenous territory in a remote corner of the Bolivian Amazon.

title: Brazils Long Shadow Vexes Some Neighbors
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia  Sandal-clad indigenous protesters have excoriated their president, calling him a lackey of Brazil. Angry demonstrations in front of Brazils embassy here denounced its imperialist tendencies. Bolivian intellectuals lambasted the So Paulo bourgeoisie, likening them to the slave hunters who expanded the boundaries of colonial Brazil.

title: A Changing Course
description: Snapshots along the New York City Marathon route show the citys evolution.

title: Occupy Wall Street Protest Reaches a Crossroads
description: THE signs seemed to point toward the end of Occupy Wall Street. The day after the city stripped the protesters encamped in Lower Manhattan of their generators and fuel, the Northeast was hit with a bone-chilling snowstorm that blanketed their tents and tarps with sleet and ice, and left at least one protester hospitalized for hypothermia. Yet the encampment at Zuccotti Park endured.

title: At the Film Market, Where Deals Are Made
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif.  A crusty old film business operative once said the Cannes film festival was like spending a week in Nicky Blairs. Youd have to remember the late Nicky Blairs namesake hang-out on Sunset Boulevard to get the joke.

title: Burdening Children With a Flawed Policy
description: Every fall, thousands of upper-middle-class parents here awake in night sweats, overcome by the anxiety of trying to get their children into costly and prestigious preschools. To say this, of course, is to say something as obvious as pork chops cost more at Dean & DeLuca than they do at Key Food. Two years ago an entire documentary film, Nursery University, was devoted to the subject. Over the years, the media have lavished so much attention on the difficulties endured by the well-off in the competition for elite education that many of us have retained only vague notions of the real challenges faced in the world of early child care and learning.

title: Podcast: Jobs Report, European Debt and the Flat Tax
description: Each month, the Labor Department issues a report on jobs and unemployment. It would be a relief to get one showing that jobs are being created in large numbers in the United States, and that unemployment in rapidly sinking.

title: Giants Secondary Faces Test in Patriots Passing
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Giants trip to New England on Sunday will represent the biggest test of their secondary thanks largely to a cast of Patriots stars who are in the midst of an impressive season even by their lofty standards.

title: The Complex 1980s, Viewed by 47 Artists
description: The 1980s were a complicated decade for American art. New York was back from the brink of bankruptcy, but gentrification was killing bohemianism. The art market flourished, but it also created a lopsided demand for painting and other market-friendly mediums. Art stars were born, but artists were dying of AIDS. All of this serves as a backdrop for Circa 1986 at the Hudson Valley Center for Contemporary Art in Peekskill.

title: L.S.U.-Alabama Assures Tuscaloosa of Many Winners
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala.  When it comes to the college football showdown between No. 1 Louisiana State and No. 2 Alabama on Saturday night, there are already plenty of winners.

title: The Fruits of Collaboration
description: In the end, most art is the result of collaboration. Paintings make their way into our lives because art dealers and curators show them and patrons collect them. Music, theater and dance productions require the coordinated efforts of performers and directors from the very beginning. Even literature involves a host of players, from editor to bookseller. But the five exhibitions on view at the Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum in Ridgefield  and one in the garden that was part of the grouping but closed earlier this month  are not about the patron-artist relationship. Nor are they large-scale projects that engage the community, as dozens of artists have done in recent years. Instead, several works showcase creative teams.

title: Faces Telling American Stories
description: Portraits were not just a popular genre in the early days of this nation; they were among the only art that patrons would pay for. As a result, many American artists went abroad, hoping to test their abilities on juicier subjects, like allegorical or historical epics. But portraiture has remained an important American genre, something that can serve as a springboard to larger ideas. This is evident in some of the works in American Portraits: Treasures From the Parrish Art Museum in Southampton.

title: A War of Currents, and Rival Geniuses
description: The darker side of Thomas Alva Edison is gradually revealed by Ben Clawson in his absorbing new play, The Dangers of Electric Lighting. The legendary inventors habits are messy, his ego is enormous, and he proves to be ruthless with his competitors.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Liberia: Candidate Withdraws
description: The opposition presidential candidate Winston Tubman, left, said Friday that he would not participate in Liberias runoff election set for Tuesday against President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, but the election commission said the vote would take place anyway. Holding elections when there are outstanding issues and challenges undermines our national peace and endangers our democracy, Mr. Tubman said in a statement to supporters after returning from a two-day trip to Abuja, Nigeria, where he met with President Goodluck Jonathan. He urged supporters to boycott the polls and said he would not recognize the new government.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Cardinals Bob Forsch, Dies at 61; Pitched in 3 World Series
description: Bob Forsch, who threw two no-hitters and won 163 games for St. Louis, more than any other Cardinals pitcher except the Hall of Famers Bob Gibson and Jesse Haines, died Thursday at his home near Tampa, Fla. He was 61.

title: Italy: Torrential Rains Kill 6
description: Torrential rains killed at least six people in Genoa on Friday, in the worst flooding the port city has seen in years, officials said. Entire neighborhoods were blocked, as water swept through the city after several streams overflowed. Some victims, including three children, drowned when water rushed through the building where they had sought refuge.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Gingrich Tailors Message at Iowa G.O.P. Dinner
description: DES MOINES, Iowa  With two months to go before the Iowa caucuses, Newt Gingrich appeared to help his chances on Friday night at the Ronald Reagan dinner, this states marquee G.O.P. fundraiser, winning wide applause with his proposal to challenge President Obama to unmoderated three-hour-long Lincoln-Douglas style debates.

title: Iraq: American Soldier Killed
description: An American soldier died in an attack in Iraq, the military said Friday in the first report of a combat fatality since President Obama announced last month that all United States troops would leave the country by the end of the year. An Iraqi security service official said the soldier died from a grenade thrown at his convoy in Kirkuk, north of Baghdad, on Thursday. Two other Americans have died in noncombat accidents since Mr. Obamas Oct. 21 announcement; the last combat fatality had been on Sept. 29.

title: Leader of FARC Guerrilla Movement Is Killed in Combat, Colombian Officials Say
description: The leader of Colombias largest guerrilla group was killed Friday in a military raid, Colombian government officials said.

title: George Washingtons Men, 200 Years Later
description: New Yorks Veterans Corps of Artillery dates to 1790.

title: Sam Fink, Letterer and Illustrator of Historical Texts, Dies at 95
description: Sam Fink, a calligrapher who in a series of books reverentially inscribed the precise texts of four historical documents  each a beacon of liberty  and illustrated them with sometimes whimsical, often pungent drawings, died on Tuesday in Jerusalem. He was 95.

title: No. 1 vs. No. 2, Through the Years
description: In the last 40 years, the Nos. 1 and 2 teams have met only 12 times in the regular season (not counting conference championship games). The No. 1 team has won seven times; only four times did the winner go on to win a national title. Here are six of the best No. 1 vs. No. 2 matchups.

title: Allen Mandelbaum, Translator of Divine Comedy, Dies at 85
description: Allen Mandelbaum, whose fluid, sensitive English version of Dantes Divine Comedy stamped his reputation as one of the worlds premier translators of Italian and classical poetry, died on Oct. 27 in Winston-Salem, N.C. He was 85.

title: Leonard Stone, Actor in Willy Wonka, Dies at 87
description: Leonard Stone, a familiar character actor on television and in films who had a memorable turn as an overindulgent father in the 1971 movie Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory, died on Wednesday at his home in San Diego. He was 87.

title: Arctic Hoop Dreams
description: The Tikigaq School of Point Hope, Alaska, with fewer than 60 students, has one of the states best basketball teams.

title: The World This Week, Part 1
description: A look back at the big news stories of the week.

title: The World This Week, Part 2
description: A look back at the big news stories of the week.

title: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
description: Jammu and Kashmir: Hundreds of students took to the streets in Jammu to protest the new recruitment policy of the state government. Under this policy, a new recruit would get only 50 percent of the basic pay for the first two years and 75 percent for the following three years without any allowances (The Indian Express).Manipur: A three-day total blockade called by Naga leadershas begun in parts of Manipur, despite an appeal by Home Minister P. Chidambaram and Chief Minister Okram Ibobi to suspend the agitation, reports the Assam Tribune.Nagaleaderssay this is to protest the Manipur governments agreementwithleadersof the Sadar Hills Districthood Demand Committee to create a new district.

title: Agudelo Summoned to Olympic Training Camp
description: The Red Bulls elimination from the M.L.S. playoffs late Thursday night came with a silver lining for at least one member of the team: with several free weeks on his hands, striker Juan Agudelo was called up to a training camp being held for the under-23 national team next week in Duisburg, Germany.

title: Despite Leaders Death, Colombian Rebels Remain Dangerous, Analysts Say
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  The killing of the top commander of Colombias largest guerrilla group dealt what might be the most severe blow yet to the four-decade-old insurgency, but security experts said Saturday that the rebels still had the ability to regroup and carry on the fight.

title: Finding a Middle Ground for the Gray Wolf
description: The dynamic between ranchers and conservationists over the rebounding gray wolf population has begun to change.

title: Concussion Safety and Leather Helmets
description: Bring back leather helmets? A recent study on helmet safety isnt going that far, saying modern helmets provide better protection against major injuries like skull fractures and brain bleeds. But the study did contain a surprise.

title: General Fired Over Karzai Remarks
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A senior American general stationed in Afghanistan has been fired for criticizing President Hamid Karzai in a published interview.

title: The Ride of Joseph OBriens 18-Year-Old Life
description: Two years ago on the annual OBrien family trip from Ireland to the Breeders Cup, Joseph OBrien might have been looking forward to an outing to Disneyland as much as he was to seeing a string of thoroughbreds trained by his father, Aidan OBrien, run their races at Santa Anita Park.

title: Andy Rooney, a Cranky Voice of CBS, Dies at 92
description: Andy Rooney, whose prickly wit was long a mainstay of CBS News and whose homespun commentary on 60 Minutes, delivered every week from 1978 until 2011, made him a household name, died on Friday in New York City.

title: A Championship That Doesnt Have All the Best
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  However successful the 2011 Breeders Cup turns out to be, it could have been a lot better. Once again thoroughbred racings year-end showcase has been robbed of its brightest stars.

title: Alex Ferguson: A Silver Anniversary for Uniteds Silver Collector
description: It says a lot about Alex Fergusons 25 years at Manchester United that it is hard for many to imagine the club without him. But United had a rich, full history long before Ferguson left the docks in Aberdeen to go into soccer management. There were the Busby Babes of the mid-1950s. The Munich disaster of 1958 that killed or injured many of them. The rebuilt team that won the European Cup in 1968. Stars like Duncan Edwards and Bobby Charlton, Denis Law and George Best.

title: 25 Years Later, a Marathon Finish Still Inspires
description: In Bob Wielands world, obstacles create opportunities and conquests breed inspiration.

title: Giants Cruz Mixing Cultures, and Scoring Touchdowns
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  When Victor Cruz scored his first regular-season N.F.L. touchdown Sept. 25, he immediately broke into a salsa dance in the end zone. It was meant as a tribute to his grandmother, who used to make him glide around the house with her when he was a child, but it became a point of pride for many Hispanics.

title: Big Yardage Out of Nowhere for the Bills
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Fred Jackson played football at tiny Division III Coe College in Iowa, in a midlevel arena league and, for one year, in Germany. He was underestimated and overshadowed, dismissed and discounted  even by his wife, Danielle, who selected another running back, Michael Turner of Atlanta, ahead of him in her fantasy football draft. And now?

title: Cowboys Season Is Slipping Away
description: IRVING, Tex.  Judging by all the clichs that surround them, the Dallas Cowboys surely realize their season has reached the Eve of Dysfunction.

title: Andy Rooney: 1919-2011
description: Long a mainstay of CBS News, his prickly wit and homespun commentary on 60 Minutes, made him a household name.

title: Kickers Are Becoming Cant-Miss Performers
description: When Rob Bironas runs on the field to attempt a field goal for the Tennessee Titans, he usually does not know how long it is. He finds that out by looking at the box score after the game. It is a quirk he developed early in his career, figuring that he uses the same leg swing whether the kick is from 20 yards or 50. Lined up near the team logo that spans the grass at midfield? Bironas knows only that that is pretty deep.

title: Thanksgiving With Squash on the Side
description: If youre looking for a new way to spice up your Thanksgiving table, consider one of these new winter squash recipes from Martha Rose Shulman. She writes:

title: Our Classic Picks
description: The Rails handicappers make their Breeders Cup Classic selections. Heres a look at how we did for the Triple Crown races. Make your picks along with us in the comments section below.

title: Mentors and Students Go on a Hunt
Skype Postpones Sweet Sorrow
description: THEY met in Costa Rica, on a summer community service program for teenagers. Within days they had fallen in love.

title: Controversial Qatari Club Wins Asian Champions League Final
description: JEONJU, South Korea  It has been 12 months to remember for soccer in Qatar as it added the 2011 Asian Champions League to the 2022 World Cup hosting duties as Al Sadd defeated Jeonbuk Motors in a penalty shootout Saturday to win the regional club championship

title: Another Ewing Plays in New York
description: Randi Ewing rose at the net, soaring to meet a volleyball in flight at Rose Hill Gymnasium in the Bronx. She raised her right arm and spiked the ball. Moments later, she defended the other side of the net, blocking an attempted kill.

title: Rebuilding the Cubs, Wrigley Included
description: CHICAGO  In hiring Theo Epstein as their team president, the Chicago Cubs are clearly hoping he can do for them what he did for the Boston Red Sox and break a title drought that defies logic.

title: Genuine Hypocrisy, And Attitudes Thereto
description: Not sure how much blogging I can do this weekend  Im doing some research for future writing, and need to buckle down for a bit. But heres an item that caught my eye, given what I wrote about hypocrisy yesterday:

title: Not All Names Are Fit to Print
description: How fast do I have to run to get in?

title: Qatari Club Takes Curious Route to Asian Title
description: JEONJU, South Korea  It has been 12 months to remember for soccer in Qatar, which added the 2011 Asian Champions League to the 2022 World Cup hosting duties when Al Sadd defeated Jeonbuk Motors in a penalty-kick shootout Saturday to win the regional club championship.

title: Live Analysis: L.S.U. and Alabama, Among Other Games
description: Paul Myerberg and The Times John Branch will be reporting on all of the days action in college football. Check back throughout the day for updates and analysis, to ask questions or to give us your observations, whether from your couch or from the bleachers. You can alsofollow Paul on Twitter for additional updates throughout the afternoon and evening.

title: Variety: A Timely Acrostic
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  People often ask me what the process is for receiving, solving and blogging the New York Times crossword and variety puzzles. The answer is that I get a stack of puzzles about a week ahead of time, then solve them and blog them according to deadline. I often feel like Im time-traveling into the future, because thats where my head is when Im working, and the feeling is particularly present when solvers ask me a question about the current days puzzle, because I have to travel back to remember the puzzle in question.

title: 20 Years Later, Still Alive, Still Lively
description: So where were you on the night of Nov. 7, 1991? I was in Madison Square Garden, watching Pat Riley bring his Knicks and the visiting Orlando Magic together to say a pregame prayer for Magic Johnson on the day Johnson revealed that he had tested positive for H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS.

title: The Zenyatta Experience, One Year Later
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  In many ways, it seems similar to a high school reunion. We seem to know each other well and have spent some great times together. We stood next to each other at race after race and recognize the T-shirts, football-style jerseys, hats and pins all carrying the pink and teal colors. The Zenyatta fans are extremely loyal and flew in from all parts of the country supporting their horse when she raced.

title: Idle N.B.A. Leaves Void in Cities Like Portland
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  A short walk from the Rose Garden, the home of the Portland Trail Blazers, a few customers trickled into the Spirit of 77 sports bar after it opened Thursday afternoon. They ordered pints of beer, hot dogs and other snacks. Some played a mini basketball game as hockey games blared on the large televisions.

title: Still Playing Catch-Up
description: Mary Keitany of Kenya is favored to win the womens race Sunday at the New York City Marathon. She might even set a course record, but one thing she will almost certainly not do is set a world record.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Jets Team Records Go All the Way Back, to Atlanta
description: If a player for the Winnipeg Jets scores five goals against the Rangers on Sunday night, will he tie the franchise record for goals in a game, set by the Jets of yore Willy Lindstrom in 1982 and Alexei Zhamnov in 1995?

title: Political Uncertainty Lingers in Greece
description: ATHENS  Hours after the government won a crucial confidence vote that made it more likely that Greece would receive the foreign aid it desperately needs, the countrys leaders on Saturday reverted to the type of political wrangling that threw Europe and its markets into turmoil last week.

title: Sad Proof of Europes Fallout
description: WHO you gonna believe, me or your own eyes?

title: The Denials That Trapped Greece
description: ATHENS   The warning was clear: Greece was spiraling out of control.

title: Far From Home and Fighting a Rare Disease
description: Numbers tell a stark story of Thonn McMillans battle for survival against a rare disease that has wreaked havoc on his body.

title: Perry the Antigovernment Politician Meets Perry the Government Beneficiary
description: As a Texas governor and presidential candidate, Rick Perry has repeatedly turned to the marketplace for policy solutions to health care and retirement security.

title: Risks Seen in Perry Plan for Switch to Pensions
description: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, who has long been a vocal critic of Social Security, outlined a plan last month that he said would preserve the program for all generations of Americans. But one part of his plan  to let state and local government workers opt out of Social Security  could add risk to their retirements while sapping money from the system.

title: Mladics Poor Health Is New Focus at The Hague
description: THE HAGUE  Each time Ratko Mladic has come to court, he has complained about his health  his fatigue, his stroke-weakened right arm, his kidney pains  emphasizing his ailments as if they were the central focus of his trial on war crimes and genocide charges.

title: A Tradition of Giving, From the Famous and the Unknown
description: The language of that first appeal in The New York Times was somewhat florid by todays standards, but it packed the desired punch. Fathoms deep beneath the exhilaration and joyousness of Christmas, it began, there is a world of desolation and hunger which few of the dwellers in light and air have had time or chance to realize.

title: Roubini On Internal Devaluation
description: Nouriel Roubini has a very good, very grim new paper on European prospects (no link). I particularly liked this passage:

title: Neediest Cases | Thonn McMillan
description: Thonn McMillan is a 17-year-old from Grenada who has Wegeners granulomatosis, a rare disease that causes inflammation of his arteries and veins and has harmed his lungs, kidneys and brains. He and his mother are on visitors visas while he is being treated in the United States.

title: 100 Years of Giving
description: The success of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has depended on the generosity of its donors, famous and not, who have been inspired to contribute. To date, the fund has raised $256,921,136.66. Here is a look back at a century of giving.

title: Live Analysis: Drosselmeyer Wins Breeders Cup Classic
description: Mike Smith and Drosselmeyer rallied in the homestretch to overtake Chantal Sutherland and Game On Dude by one and a half lengths to win the $5 million Breeders Cup Classic on Saturday at Churchill Downs.

title: A Few Minutes With Andy Rooney
description: Andy Rooneys weekly segment on 60 Minutes, in which he addressed mostly mundane subjects with varying degrees of befuddlement, vexation and sometimes pleasure, made him one of the most popular broadcast figures in the country.

title: Pakistan Indicts 7 in Bhutto Assassination
description: LAHORE, Pakistan  A Pakistani antiterrorism court indicted five militants and two police officers Saturday in the assassination of former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto, prosecutors said.

title: Former Coach at Penn State Is Charged With Abuse
description: A former defensive coordinator for the Penn State football team was arrested Saturday on charges of sexually abusing eight boys across a 15-year period. Jerry Sandusky, 67, who had worked with needy children through his Second Mile foundation, was arraigned and released on $100,000 bail after being charged with 40 counts related to sexual abuse of young boys.

title: Tortured by Solitude
description: Oakland, Calif.

title: The Politics of Austerity
description: The economic collapse of 2008 transformed American politics. In place of shared abundance, battles at every level of government now focus on picking the losers who will bear the costs of deficit reduction and austerity.

title: Merger of Memphis and County School Districts Revives Race and Class Challenges
description: MEMPHIS  When thousands of white students abandoned the Memphis schools 38 years ago rather than attend classes with blacks under a desegregation plan fueled by busing, Joseph A. Clayton went with them. He quit his job as a public school principal to head an all-white private school and later won election to the board of the mostly white suburban district next door.

title: Clicking Send Spurs Quake Anxiety
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  Already rattled by a swarm of small earthquakes last month, residents here were jolted by an authentic-sounding e-mail that said geologists were predicting a major earthquake in the coming weeks.

title: A King of Connections Is Techs Go-To Guy
Hoping to Save Money for the Government, Some Seek an End to the $1 Bill
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  It is not typical for a politician to admit using a coin to decide critical issues, but there was Representative David Schweikert, Republican of Arizona, fishing out a dollar coin from his pocket the other day.

title: Boat With 21 North Koreans Found Off South Koreas Coast
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Twenty-one North Koreans, including women and children, were found adrift in a boat off the west coast of South Korea last Sunday and asked for asylum, the South Korean military said Saturday.

title: Chirps and Cheers: Chinas Crickets Clash
description: BEIJING  Big Red Belly, his thick limbs nourished by a strict liver-tofu-ginger diet, should have been a contender. Instead, as his trainer watched in dismay, the young fighter nervously circled his more menacing adversary and then skittered to a corner of the ring, prompting jeers from a half-dozen spectators.

title: Deaths in Care: 16 Cases
description: A closer look at the circumstances of death surrounding 16 developmentally disabled people in state or privately run homes over the last decade.

title: The Death of James Taylor
description: Danny Hakim of The New York Times interviews the mother and sister of James Taylor, who died at age 41 while he was at a group home near Schenectady, N.Y.

title: In China, Cricket Fighting Undergoes a Revival
description: In the alleys of Beijing, crickets are facing off against one another in a uniquely Chinese bloodsport whose provenance extends back more than 1,000 years.

title: Term No. 10? Why Not, a Mayor Asks
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  This is a town that cherishes tradition.

title: Investigating Deaths in State and Privately-Run Homes
description: A selection of cases from the Commission on Quality of Care and Advocacy for Persons with Disabilities

title: Loulou de la Falaise, a Muse to Yves Saint Laurent, Dies at 63
description: Loulou de la Falaise, a muse to Yves Saint Laurent who was also a designer and a woman whose style resisted classification, died on Saturday at her home in the Vexin region of northwest France. She was 63.

title: Cricket Fighting
description: In China, crickets are pitted against each other on street corners as their owners watch and place bets on the matches.

title: Signs of Official Bias and Abuse Deepen Kyrgyzstans Ethnic Rifts
description: OSH, Kyrgyzstan  Nearly a year and a half after ethnic clashes ripped through this former Silk Road trading hub, ethnic Uzbeks, who suffered the brunt of the violence, face arbitrary arrest and often horrific abuse at the hands of predominantly ethnic Kyrgyz authorities, victims and local and international rights groups say.

title: Wanted: Worldly Philosophers
description: ITS become commonplace to criticize the Occupy movement for failing to offer an alternative vision. But the thousands of activists in the streets of New York and London arent the only ones lacking perspective: economists, to whom we might expect to turn for such vision, have long since given up thinking in terms of economic systems  and we are all the worse for it.

title: Women on Pedestals
description: IWAS waiting for the other shoe to drop.

title: Our Reckless Meritocracy
description: HERE is a story about the promise of America. A boy grows up in rural Illinois, the grandson of a farmer who lost everything in the Great Depression. He goes to his small-town high school and then attends his state university, where he walks onto the basketball team and graduates Phi Beta Kappa. He does a stint in the Marine Corps Reserves, gets his M.B.A. and then goes to work for one of the Midwests regional banks.

title: Indias Innovation Stimulus
description: New Delhi

title: His Libraries, 12,000 So Far, Change Lives
description: CAI LEI, Vietnam

title: The Invention of Outrage
description: IF youre just catching up on last weeks news, I suggest you sit down. Fast. What youre about to learn is incredible. Unthinkable. If you drink, grab one. Certain shocks cant be borne without absorbers.

title: Standing in the Schoolhouse Door
description: Surely Alabamas attorney general, Luther Strange, did not mean to summon the memory of Gov. George Wallace when he picked a fight with the Department of Justice last week over the states new immigration law.

title: Americas Deadly Dynamics With Iran
description: COMMUTING to work in Tehran is never easy, but it is particularly nerve-racking these days for the scientists of Shahid Beheshti University. It was a little less than a year ago when one of them, Majid Shahriari, and his wife were stuck in traffic at 7:40 a.m. and a motorcycle pulled up alongside the car. There was a faint click as a magnet attached to the drivers side door. The huge explosion came a few seconds later, killing him and injuring his wife.

title: Is This the WikiEnd?
description: IT appears all the more likely that Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, will be extradited to Sweden to be questioned on allegations of sexual misconduct from two women. A British courts ruling last Wednesday that he could be extradited, which Mr. Assange may appeal, puts his personal freedom in doubt.

title: If the Cake Isnt Ready, Just Say So
description: This interview with  Barbara DeBuono, president and C.E.O. of Orbis International, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant. Orbis is a global health organization that helps to treat and prevent blindness.

title: Population Control, Marauder Style
description: Last week, the United Nations announced that the worlds population had reached seven billion, but there have been times when it headed in the opposite direction, and not in pleasant ways. The savagery of the Mongol conqueror Genghis Khan may have culled the global population by about 11 percent; two bloody upheavals in China  the An Lushan Rebellion and the collapse of the Xin Dynasty  each may have felled about 6 percent of humanity. Those are but 3 of the 100 worst atrocities in history, as cataloged by Matthew White in The Great Big Book of Horrible Things, an amusing (really) account of the murderous ways of despots, slave traders, blundering royals, gladiators and assorted hordes. Estimating the tolls from such horrors is an inexact science, given wars nature and the mysteries of antiquity. The deadliest multicides are more plentiful in recent centuries, given that there were more people to kill and better ways to kill them on a grand scale. Even so, killings as a percentage of all humanity are probably declining. Here is a look at the sweep of human brutality presented in a timeline.

title: Is the Era of the Motorcycle Over?
description: ARE motorcycles pass? Are they sort of over? I ask as a rider of two-wheel Italian beauties that go very fast, gracefully streamlined subsonic technology from the Ducati factory in Bologna. I own two sport bikes and two racers. I ride racing motorcycles on the street. One of my motorcycles is capable of nearly 200 miles an hour. I write prose about motorcycles. I write poems about motorcycles.

title: Telling Americans to Vote, or Else
description: Washington

title: DNA Exonerations Continue, but Not for One Man
description: Hank Skinner has been pleading with the state since 2001 to no avail  to test DNA evidence he believes will prove his innocence. On Wednesday, he is scheduled to walk into the execution chamber in Huntsville to face the ultimate punishment for three murders that he maintains he did not commit.

title: The Courts GPS Test
description: There were no GPS tracking devices when the framers wrote the Fourth Amendments prohibition against unreasonable searches. But that does not mean this sometimes intrusive technology can be used against Americans without meeting constitutional standards.

title: A New Battle Over Contraception
description: The Obama administration made the right call in August when it issued new standards requiring all insurers to cover contraceptives without a deductible or a co-payment, starting next year. The White House now needs to resist pressure from House Republicans, the Roman Catholic Church and other groups out to eliminate or significantly weaken the contraceptives mandate.

title: Alms From China
description: As soon as European leaders agreed on yet another plan to stabilize their finances, President Nicolas Sarkozy of France was on the phone to his Chinese counterpart, Hu Jintao, to persuade him to invest in the rescue. Klaus Regling, head of the new financial bailout fund for the euro zone, went to Asia to drum up support.

title: Stewart Brand
description: Stewart Brand is best known as the editor of the Whole Earth Catalog, a counterculture compendium published twice a year between 1968 and 1972 and the only catalog to win the National Book Award. Its credo, Stay hungry. Stay foolish, influenced many of the hippie generation, most notably Steve Jobs. Mr. Brand currently divides his time working for the Long Now Foundation and Global Business Network, organizations he co-founded to encourage forward thinking and long-term development.

title: When Luck Is the Spark
description: To the Editor:

title: Wait Wait... Dont Tell Me
description: NPRs Wait Wait ... Dont Tell Me! is heard weekends on public radio stations across the country. (npr.org/waitwait)

title: Considering the Sources
description: Re The Times Gives Them Space, but Who Pays Them? (Oct. 30):

title: Sunday Dialogue: Incentives on Energy
description: A letter argued that large subsidies for renewable energy are not justified. But many readers countered that wind and solar power are vital to our energy future. Here is a sampling.

title: Why a Fallen Angel Is a Centerfold
description: THE celebrity blogs and the tabloid news sites like TMZ have been all aflutter over reports that Lindsay Lohan, before landing a new jail sentence last week for skipping court-ordered janitorial service at a morgue, managed to find time to pose nude for Playboy magazine for close to a million dollars. Then a couple of dissenting reports said Ms. Lohan had agreed to only partial nudity, which was a distressing comment on the economy these days. What have we come to when a million dollars no longer purchases the complete Montague? Back in the 50s, when Playboy was just getting started, the going rate for a centerfold shoot was $500.

title: In State Care, 1,200 Deaths and Few Answers
description: For James Michael Taylor, an evening bath became a death sentence.

title: The Problem With Flat-Tax Fever
description: CLOSE watchers of presidential politics werent surprised to see many of this years Republican hopefuls proposing to replace the nations progressive income tax with a flat tax. Such plans reliably surface every four years, and, just as reliably, sink without a trace.

title: In Ohio, a Hint About 2012
description: Republican state lawmakers in the Upper Midwest have been remarkably successful this year in stripping public employees of their bargaining rights, but that campaign could slam to a halt on Tuesday when Ohio voters get a chance to weigh in.

title: Thousands Still Without Power in Connecticut
description: This has been an excellent week to own a hardware store in Connecticut.

title: A Russian Robot, a Martian Moon
description: In a bold attempt to revive its long-dormant planetary exploration program, Russia is scheduled to launch a new, technologically sophisticated spacecraft this week to gather soil samples from a Martian moon and bring them back to Earth for analysis. Back in the early 1970s, the Soviet Union, after losing the race to land humans on the Moon, brought back lunar soil samples with robotic devices. It also became the first nation to put robotic devices on Venus and Mars.

title: And Now for Something Different
description: With international attention focused on the worsening European debt crisis, the economic, trade and security challenges in Asia have gotten less attention. That could change this week when President Obama hosts the annual Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation meeting in his home state, Hawaii, on Saturday, before heading to Australia and then to Bali for the East Asia Summit.

title: For Clues to U.S. Stocks, Look at Greek Bonds
description: ITS come to this. For day-to-day guidance on the likely direction of American stocks, theres an unlikely contrarian indicator: the battered Greek bond.

title: In the School of Innovation, Less Is Often More
description: SINCE the 1980s, the United States has increasingly depended on other nations for shrimp production. As scientists have struggled to find a way to increase yields, they have turned to a technology in which shrimp are farmed indoors in large, rectangular tubs of water, laid out side by side.

title: Leaving Iraq, U.S. Fears New Surge of Qaeda Terror
description: BAGHDAD  As the United States prepares to withdraw its troops from Iraq by years end, senior American and Iraqi officials are expressing growing concern that Al Qaedas offshoot here, which just a few years ago waged a debilitating insurgency that plunged the country into a civil war, is poised for a deadly resurgence.

title: An Online Answer to the DVR
description: SOME people who want to watch a movie at home wait for Netflix to mail it to them on a disc. Others click on a link at Netflix or other Web sites and immediately watch films, TV episodes or sports events streamed to them on the spot.

title: Ratings Inflation Leads to a Record Ranking
description: There are two firsts in the current ranking of the worlds top competitors, which was released on Tuesday. Four of the players have a rating (the number used to create the rankings) of 2,800 or higher, and 47 players have a rating of at least 2,700.

title: The Neediest Cases | Where Are They Now?
description: Following up with a beneficiary of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: A New President, and a Unions Last Stand
description: FOR 30 years, Ronald Reagans breaking of the federal air traffic controller strike has often been seen as a turning point in United States history, the moment when labor unions began an inexorable decline and when political conservatism came of age.

title: Tracking Caribou, Shooting Hoops, Winning Trophies
description: POINT HOPE, Alaska  Spring means murre eggs and bowhead whales. Summer is seals and salmon and berries. Fall and winter are a time to track caribou.

title: Dr. John F. Burke, Dies at 89; Created Synthetic Skin
description: Artificial skin had been the holy grail in treating burn victims for a century when Dr. John F. Burke began wrestling with some of the perennial obstacles to making it: finding a flexible material that would protect against infection and dehydration, that could be made from ordinary substances, that would not be rejected by a patients immune system and that would look like normal skin.

title: Sunday: Bakers Dozen
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Mmmm  cake. Who doesnt love a good slice of cake?

title: Less He Said, She Said in Sex Harassment Cases
description: A PUBLIC figure at the top of his game is suddenly tripped up by reports that he sexually harassed female employees. Whispers ensue, speculation abounds, details are unclear, his statements shift.

title: James Van Doren Dies at 72; Designer of Popular Shoes
description: James Van Doren, who designed the tenacious shoe that became a mainstay of California skateboard culture  and touched off a national fad after Sean Penn wore a black-and-white-checked pair in the movie Fast Times at Ridgemont High  died on Oct. 12 at his home in Fullerton, Calif. He was 72.

title: Romney, Always Campaigning for Others ... and for Himself
description: State auditors, county commissioners, sheriffs: no Republican candidate, it seems, has been insignificant enough to escape the glow of Mitt Romneys affections.

title: Fighting for Literacy, Library by Library
description: My Sunday column is about John Wood, the founder of Room to Read, and his efforts to build libraries around the world. And maybe an even more effective part of the program supports needy girls who might otherwise drop out  13,500 of them at the moment. Ive watched Woods efforts grow over the years, partly because of his marketing savvy and his compelling marketing story, and Im delighted that I could attend the ceremony in Vietnam where he handed out his 10 millionth book.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, November 6
description: With reports that Herman Cain was accused of sexual harassment in the 1990s dominating the news cycle, the Sunday talk shows are focused on the 2012 presidential race. But thats not all: With less than three weeks left for the Congressional panel tasked with deficit reduction to come up with more than $1 trillion in savings, lawmakers weigh in on whether the committee can beat the buzzer.

title: The Gridlock Where Debts Meet Politics
description: WASHINGTON  With Greece struggling to form a government that can force harsh austerity measures onto a weary public, Europe is in usual form, taking a couple of steps toward solving its fiscal crisis and then a couple of steps backward. Washington, meanwhile, is hoping that the latest deficit-reduction committee in Congress can succeed where others have failed.

title: Relenting on Car Sales, Cuba Turns Notorious Clunkers Into Gold
description: HAVANA  Until a few weeks ago, Erik Gonzlezs decrepit car did little more than devour his tiny income. He spent hundreds of dollars fixing the car, a 30-year-old Moskvich that his grandfather passed down to him in 2000. Even when it worked, Mr. Gonzlez could rarely afford to buy gas.

title: The Marathon Routes Evolving Neighborhoods
description: The New York City Marathon course has changed little since 1976, but the neighborhoods along the route have: most are richer, and their ethnic makeups have shifted.

title: Grand Jury Report on Jerry Sandusky
description: Read the full grand jury report detailing the charges against Jerry Sandusky.

title: Action to Fund Illinois Pension System Remains Uncertain
description: Lawmakers have tinkered on the edges of the state budget during the fall veto session, but it now appears they could close shop for the year on Thursday without plugging the deep hole at the budgets core: Illinoiss underfinanced pension systems.

title: The Powerbrokers
description: Five Chinese-Americans are among the candidates on the mayoral ballot in Tuesdays election. Ed Lee, interim mayor; David Chiu, president of the Board of Supervisors; Phil Ting, San Franciscos assessor-recorder; and Leland Yee, state senator, share their thoughts on the history and progress of the Chinese-American community in San Francisco.

title: Free Signs for Panhandlers Receive Mixed Reaction
description: There are 93,000 homeless Chicagoans, according to the Chicago Coalition for the Homeless, and many consider panhandling a necessity of life on the streets.

title: Quinn, Portrayed as Bumbling and Indecisive, Deserves a More Respectful Hearing
description: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: In Mayoral Election, Chinese-Americans Growing Power Is on Display
description: Astella Kung, 64, is known as the unofficial mayor of Grant Avenue, the heart of San Franciscos Chinatown. A short woman who speaks in a nasally Cantonese dialect, she is the owner of Ming Kee Game Birds, a dingy shop crammed with chickens, ducks and pigeons in wire-mesh cages.

title: Short, Gray and Trimmed, a New Star in the Campaign
description: Last November, the Bay Area was abuzz over beards  specifically, the beard of Brian Wilson, the San Francisco Giants relief pitcher who captured the nations imagination with his jet-black face sweater.

title: Lawmakers in a Bind Find Cover in Courts
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: Occupy Chicago Inspires Some South Side Groups
description: As more than 1,500 supporters of the Occupy Chicago movement prepared to march through the Loop recently, Willie J. R. Fleming, a neighborhood organizer from the South Side, grabbed a bullhorn and wedged his way to the head of the mostly white crowd.

title: Finally, an Album for a Rock Star Who Never Was
description: In 1979, under the headline Lone Star Legend, Rolling Stone profiled the Houston guitarist Rocky Hill, detailing his career, which was too often derailed by stubbornness and self-sabotage. The article refers to an unreleased album that the writer guessed might trigger Mr. Hills transition from a regional guitar hero to a national one.

title: Drosselmeyer Steals Classic in an Uprising of Long Shots
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  They were once engaged, Mike Smith and Chantal Sutherland. He is older and a Hall of Fame jockey. She is an up-and-comer whose interests extend to modeling and acting. Under the lights at Churchill Downs on Saturday night, however, they were just two riders on a couple of horses nobody thought had much chance of winning the $5 million Breeders Cup Classic.

title: Van der Sar Stepping Out of Nets for a Run
description: May 21, 2008, was the high point of Edwin van der Sars career. On the final shot of a penalty shootout he dove to his right to stop a waist-high penalty kick by Nicolas Anelka, and Manchester United was crowned European champions. On Friday at Jacob Schiff Playground in Harlem, Van der Sar took part in a penalty shootout of a different sort.

title: Police Force Wall Street Protesters Off Sidewalks
description: Hundreds of Occupy Wall Street demonstrators streamed into a desolate part of Foley Square on Saturday afternoon, but their slow-moving march turned chaotic as a phalanx of police officers issued orders to vacate the sidewalks  and then swept in to force the issue.

title: Jets at Bills: Matchup to Watch
description: Jets (4-3) at Bills (5-2), 1 p.m. Eastern, CBSMatchup to Watch: Shonn Greene vs. Buffalo defense

title: College Football Replay: Nov. 5
description: Two upsets jolted a division race in the Big Ten, as Iowa beat Michigan at home and Northwestern won at Nebraska, and the Wolfpack won a battle for North Carolina.

title: Photo Replay: Nov. 5
description: A view of the day in sports, including handball in Germany and bodybuilding in Mumbai.

title: Carbo Loading for the Masses
description: The marathon eve dinner was held Saturday at Tavern on the Green in Central Park, where 18,000 runners were expected to consume a few thousand pounds of carbohydrates from 3:30 to 8 p.m.

title: Lottery Numbers
Corrections: November 6
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Cain and Gingrich Meet for a Congenial Debate
description: THE WOODLANDS, Texas  The rancor that defined much of the last week on the Republican presidential campaign trail subsided a bit here on Saturday night, as Newt Gingrich and Herman Cain basked in each others company and the warm embrace of the Texas Tea Party for what was styled as an old-fashioned issues-focused debate.

title: 18-Year-Old Jockey Sets Record While He Can
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  It was a Breeders Cup day when the heartwarming collided with the heart-pumping as the best horses in the world convened in front of a crowd of 65,143 to determine which horses were the true champions.

title: Fast Start Puts Rangers on Path to Victory
description: The Rangers had their most inspired start of the season, taking a 3-0 lead before holding on to defeat the Montreal Canadiens, 5-3, Saturday at Madison Square Garden.

title: Catherine Pushchak, Daniel Fitzgerald
description: Catherine Anna Pushchak and Daniel Patrick Fitzgerald were married Saturday at St. George Ukrainian Catholic Church in New York. The Rev. Bernard Panczuk, a Ukrainian Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Stephanie Strauss and Blake Stuchin
description: Stephanie Jill Strauss, the daughter of Linda Strauss of Upper Gwynedd Township, Pa., and Charles Strauss of Upper Makefield Township, Pa., was married Saturday evening to Blake Harris Stuchin, the son of Marcie Stuchin and Miles Stuchin of New York. Rabbi Sarah H. Reines officiated at Guastavinos, a restaurant in New York.

title: Jess McIntosh and Jon-David Schlough
description: Jess Lane McIntosh and Jon-David Schlough were married Saturday afternoon at the Briar Patch Bed and Breakfast in Middleburg, Va. The Rev. Dr. B. Edmon Martin, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated.

title: Tracy Johnson and Scott McKinney
description: Tracy Ann Johnson, the daughter of Susan A. Johnson and William R. Johnson of Pittsburgh, was married Saturday evening to Scott William McKinney, a son of Carol McKinney and James C. McKinney of Minneapolis. The Rev. Dr. Edward Thompson, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Naples, Fla.

title: Alixandra Gould, Jeffrey Gonzalez
description: Alixandra Gould and Jeffrey Christopher Gonzalez were married Saturday evening in Newark. Rabbi Emily Losben-Ostrov officiated at the Newark Museum.

title: Beth Dolinsky, Carl Harper
description: Dr. Beth Gillian Dolinsky and Dr. Carl Morrison Harper were married Saturday evening at the William Aiken House in Charleston, S.C. The Rev. Jonathan W. Wright-Gray, an American Baptist minister, officiated, with Gadi Galili, the ritual director of the Park Synagogue in Shaker Heights, Ohio, leading Jewish prayers and rituals.

title: Elizabeth Morgan and Simon Talbot
description: Dr. Elizabeth Amy Morgan, a daughter of Barbara J. Morgan and David W. Morgan of Vero Beach, Fla., was married Saturday evening at her parents home to Dr. Simon George Talbot, a son of Mary Talbot and Dr. Richard Talbot of Nelson, New Zealand. Dr. Richard Milsten, an uncle of the bride who is a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: Jessica Winer, Christopher Chaput
description: Jessica Sarah Winer and Christopher Jacques Chaput were married Saturday morning at the Foundry, an event space in Long Island City, Queens. Sheldon M. Greenbaum, a justice of the Village of Port Washington North, N.Y., officiated, and Jerrold B. Winer, the brides paternal grandfather who is a retired judge of the Massachusetts trial court in Hampden County in Springfield, Mass., conducted the civil ceremony.

title: Amanda Kramer, William Borden
description: Amanda Susan Kramer and Dr. William Benjamin Borden were married Saturday evening. Rabbi Matthew D. Field officiated at the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington.

title: Sarah Perlman, Christopher Bremner
description: Henrietta Sarah Elizabeth Perlman and Christopher Evan Bremner are to be married Sunday evening at the Vizcaya Museum and Gardens in Miami. Rabbi Steven Weil is to officiate, with Cantor Simon Hass, a grandfather of the bride, also taking part.

title: Joanna Walters and Lisa McNulty
description: Joanna Mary Walters and Lisa Ann McNulty were married Saturday afternoon in a studio at New Dramatists, the New York playwriting center. Taylor Mac Bowyer, a Universal Life Church minister, led the ceremony.

title: Sarah Seltzer, Craig Blackburn
description: Sarah Beth Seltzer and Capt. Craig David Blackburn were married Saturday evening at the Garden City Hotel in Garden City, N.Y. Rabbi Steven Blane led a ceremony incorporating Jewish and Christian elements.

title: Kimberly Quicksilver, Matthew Salsbury
description: Kimberly Ann Quicksilver and Matthew Heller Salsbury were married Saturday evening. C. Gregory Brown, the municipal judge for the Town of Kiawah Island, S.C., officiated there at the Kiawah Island Club.

title: Jenna Kaufman, Eric Siegel
