description: Jenna Lauren Kaufman, a daughter of Susan Eileen Kaufman and Dr. Brian Stephen Kaufman of Dix Hills, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Eric Scott Siegel, a son of Merryl Siegel and Larry Siegel, also of Dix Hills. Rabbi Jeffrey Clopper performed the ceremony at Temple Beth Torah in Melville, N.Y., with Cantor Sandra Sherry-Pilatsky taking part.

title: Joaqun Tamayo Jr., Ruben Gonzales
description: Joaqun Ricardo Tamayo Jr. and Ruben James Gonzales were married Saturday evening in Washington. Glennda Testone, a friend of the couple who became a minister of the Open Ministry for the event, officiated at the Carnegie Institution of Washington.

title: Cari Wolfert, Jason Rubin
description: Cari Alison Wolfert and Jason Scott Rubin were married Saturday evening by Cantor Claire Franco at Battery Gardens, a Manhattan restaurant.

title: Neha Surie, Neel Patel
description: Neha Surie, a daughter of Bhavna Surie and Raman D. Surie of New Delhi, was married Saturday afternoon to Neel Bhaskerrao Patel, a son of Vaishali B. Patel and Dr. Bhasker P. Patel of Melbourne, Fla. Pandit Bhipin Bhatt, a Hindu priest, officiated at the East Ridge Country Club in Shreveport, La.

title: Lauren Thompson and Geoffrey Starks
description: Lauren Nicole Thompson and Geoffrey Adam Starks were married Saturday at Peachtree Christian Church in Atlanta. The Rev. James L. Bell III, a Disciples of Christ minister, performed the ceremony, with Sharon M. K. Kugler, the Yale University chaplain, assisting.

title: Michelle Roell, Lance Nealy
description: Michelle Leigh Roell and Sterling Lance Nealy were married Tuesday at the Municipal Marriage Bureau in New York. James Mitchell, a member of the office of the New York City clerk, officiated.

title: The Days Best in College Football
description: DAN HERRON, CARLOS HYDE AND BRAXTON MILLER The Ohio State players each topped 100 rushing yards in a 34-20 victory against Indiana, the first time three Buckeyes had done so since Scottie Graham, Carlos Snow and Dante Lee accomplished the feat against Northwestern in 1989. Herron had 141 yards, and Hyde and Miller each had 105.

title: N.B.A. Owners Give Players 4 Days to Accept Final Offer
description: A perilous four-month standoff between N.B.A. players and owners has been reduced to a four-day window, with an ultimatum that might destroy the 2011-12 season.

title: In Battle of No. 1 vs. No. 2, the Difference Is 3 Points
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala.  The pregame roar from Bryant-Denny Stadium carried long into the cool Alabama night, echoing through just about every corner of this football-mad state. All anyone around here could talk about the past two weeks was the so-called Game of the Century, No. 1 Louisiana State against No. 2 Alabama. But poor quarterback play, sputtering offenses and no touchdowns helped undermine the hype that surrounded this matchup of the nations top-ranked teams.

title: Top 25 Roundup: L.S.U and Oklahoma State Remain Unbeaten
description: 1. L.S.U. (9-0) beat No. 2 Alabama, 9-6

title: Giants at Patriots: Matchup to Watch
description: Giants (5-2) at Patriots (5-2), 4:15 p.m. Eastern, Fox

title: At Quarterback, Jefferson Gives L.S.U. the Lift It Needs
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala.  Just four months ago, Jordan Jefferson found himself facing a second-degree battery charge, the possibility of missing his senior season and much vitriol from Louisiana State fans. While the charges were reduced Sept. 30 and he found himself back on the team, his contributions had been minimal.

title: Oklahoma Hit by Earthquake for a Second Night in a Row
description: For the second night in a row, an earthquake rattled Central Oklahoma late Saturday night, waking residents, breaking dishes and generally startling people more accustomed to natural disasters from above than from below their feet.

title: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
description: Has Indias growth and development been an unprecedented success or extraordinary failure, ask Jean Dreze and Amartya Sen in Outlook Magazine this week. Both are true, they conclude. The authors say that what they warned of in a book written in the late 1980s has come to pass  Indias economy resembles Brazils of the time, with rapid growth alongside massive deprivation. India has fallen behind Bangladesh on a number of important social indicators, and is quite far behind China in terms of the use of public resources for social support.

title: Occupy Protests Around the Nation
description: Updated | Monday | 4:03 p.m. A protest by hundreds of Occupy Wall Street demonstrators who streamed into a square in New Yorks financial district on Saturday afternoon resulted in about 20 arrests when police officers told the slow-moving marchers to get off the sidewalks  and then swept in enforce their command, my colleague Al Baker reports on City Room.

title: In Pakistan, the Disheartened Cricket Fan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Watching a court in London send three of our cricket players to prison over match-fixing charges has been disappointing for Pakistani cricket fans, naturally, but less so than you may think.

title: Lord Mayor Celebrations in London Include Parade and Fireworks
description: Almost 800 years of history will convene once again on Nov. 12 as the Lord Mayor of London takes part in an annual tradition started in the year 1215  shortly after the King of England allowed the city of London to start electing its own leader. This new decree came with a caveat that the newly elected official would appear in person to swear allegiance to the Crown and almost every year since then the citys Lord Mayor has upheld the pact (even the Plague didnt stop the procession).

title: 8 Killed in Afghan Bombing Days After Mullahs Rebuke
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A suicide bomber killed eight people during religious celebrations in northern Afghanistan on Sunday, defying an admonition by the Talibans leader not to attack civilians.

title: Thailand Flooding Cripples Hard-Drive Suppliers
description: BANG PA-IN, Thailand  In the neck-deep floodwaters of an industrial zone here, workers are using Jet Skis and wooden skiffs to transport stacks of computer components out of waterlogged factories.

title: Channel Surfing: Trashopolis
description: We humans figured out practically as soon as we were invented that we needed clothing of some kind. And it was well back in the B.C.s that we realized agriculture was more efficient than the foraging-and-hunting thing. So why the heck was it only yesterday, comparatively speaking, that we tumbled to the fact that life would be vastly improved if wed stop walking around in our own trash and bodily wastes?

title: Live Blog: Mutai, Dado Finish Strong for New York City Marathon Victories
description: Geoffrey Mutai of Kenya proved how much more important it is to finish the New York City Marathon strong than to start it that way.

title: Greek Leaders Reach Deal to Form a New Government
description: ATHENS  Prime Minister George A. Papandreou and his chief rival agreed Sunday night to create a new unity government, under a new prime minister, that will move ahead with the countrys debt-relief deal with the European Union and then hold new elections. Mr. Papandreou agreed to resign once the details are completed on Monday.

title: Bracing for a Bullfrog Invasion
description: The consequences of climate change for animals can seem very direct, as with polar bears in a warming Arctic. Others involve leaps, like the case of an invasive bullfrog: by 2080, it could splash into some of South Americas most ecologically rich protected areas, disrupting unique hotbeds of biodiversity. At least, that is the prediction of a new study in the journal PLoS One.

title: Hip-Hop Kings, Shorn of Excess
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Just two guys sitting on a stoop, telling stories, lamenting the mistakes theyve made, expressing hope that the next generation might learn something from them.

title: Online and by Paper Airplane, Contributions Pour In to Chinese Dissident
description: BEIJING  In the days since the Chinese government delivered a punitive $2.4 million tax bill to the artist Ai Weiwei, thousands of people have responded by contributing money in a gesture that is at once benevolent and subversive.

title: Already Set to Sign Up for Next Year? Not So Fast
description: As if they cant get enough, many runners of the New York City Marathon log on to the New York Road Runners Web site the day after the marathon to register for the next years race.

title: 2011 New York City Marathon
description: Officially, 47,107 people started the New York City Marathon, the largest field in the marathons history.

title: Huntsman and Barbour Urge Cain to Come Clean on Accusations
description: Herman Cain faced fresh criticism on Sunday from some prominent Republican colleagues, and at least two of them called on him to be much more forthcoming about the allegations of sexual harassment that appear to be weighing on his presidential candidacy.

title: For the Womens Winner, Steady Race Beats a Bold One
description: For more than half of the womens race at the New York City Marathon, Mary Keitany of Kenya appeared to be turning conventional wisdom about this course on its head. She was flying through the early miles, ignoring all cautionary tales of the toll the course can take, seemingly intent on shattering the course record. By the 15-mile mark, her lead over the nearest competitor was nearly two and a half minutes.

title: Puss in Boots, Not Tower Heist, Leads the Pack
description: Tower Heist, an $85 million action comedy starring Eddie Murphy and Ben Stiller, was clawed at the weekend box office, landing in second place behind the animated holdover Puss in Boots.

title: Geoffrey Mutai Wins New York Marathon With Course Record
description: The footsteps keep getting faster, pounding like a drumbeat on the city streets. From Boston to London to Chicago this year, Kenyas marathon men have smashed course records in frenzied fashion, and they drilled the world record in Berlin.

title: Half a Century of Order and Discipline for a Junior High Principal
Does Flying With Children Have to Be So Bad?
description: Airlines dont much want us families, its true. Nor do many of our fellow passengers. And its not as if, as parents, we enjoy squashing ourselves and our children and our belongings into the tiny seats on crowded flights that now make up the flying experience. As Michelle Higgins writes in this Sundays New York Times, perks once offered to families, like early boarding, coloring books and cockpit tours, have disappeared on most flights (some long ago), while new baggage and seat fees can disproportionately affect the large flying family.

title: An Outspoken Mark Webber
description: Formula One suffers from having drivers who are constantly thinking of their sponsors and their image and hence not speaking their minds. They are talking in platitudes and trying to stay out of trouble. Actually, the same thing is starting to happen in the way they drive  or it risks happening, with all the penalties that are given for the least little failed overtaking effort.

title: An Outspoken Mark Webber
description: Formula One suffers from having drivers who are constantly thinking of their sponsors and their image and hence not speaking their minds. They are talking in platitudes and trying to stay out of trouble. Actually, the same thing is starting to happen in the way they drive  or it risks happening, with all the penalties that are given for the least little failed overtaking effort.

title: Quick Hits On A Busy Day
description: Column is going into some new territory for me, so more time on research than usual. Also, doing a local event in about an hour

title: Finding Inspiration in Drosselmeyers Victory
description: The 2010 Breeders Cup Classic was devastating. It did not have the fairy tale ending we were expecting. Watching Mike Smith as he wrestled with his emotions was very upsetting. How does one pick up the pieces when the reality of your life fails to match the movie in your mind?

title: With Friends in Both Places, Milbury Will Analyze Bruins-Islanders
description: In a rare visit to the press box, Mike Milbury is set to broadcast a game between the two N.H.L. franchises he worked for. Milbury will serve as the color commentator for the Versus telecast Monday night when the Boston Bruins host the Islanders.

title: Electric Carrier in Connecticut Still Counts 7% Without Power
description: Gov. Dannel P. Malloy of Connecticut said on Sunday that the states largest electricity carrier would not meet its goal of restoring power to 99 percent of its customers by midnight, and those affected entered a second week without electricity since the freak October snowstorm.

title: Twenty-Six Miles Along Recoverys Road
description: Joao Silva completed his first New York City Marathon in less than three hours, camera in hand. A year ago, he was lying in a hospital bed, his legs lost to a land mine.

title: Bodies in Motion: An Exchange
Weighing Pentagon Cuts, Panetta Faces Deep Pressures
description: WASHINGTON  Under orders to cut the Pentagon budget by more than $450 billion over the next decade, Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta is considering reductions in spending categories once thought sacrosanct, especially in medical and retirement benefits, as well as further shrinking the number of troops and reducing new weapons purchases.

title: Jets Meet One Challenge, and Then Fortify for Another
description: ORCHARD PARK, N.Y.  Shouts of jubilation followed the Jets as they sauntered off the field, into a tunnel and inside the visitors locker room at Ralph Wilson Stadium on Sunday. Their hollering had nothing to do with the first-place team they had just vanquished. It had everything to do with the first-place team they will play next week.

title: BPs Sale of Pan American Energy Stake Falls Apart
description: BPs plan to sell its majority stake in the Argentine oil producer Pan American Energy for $7.1 billion collapsed on Sunday after the would-be buyer, the Bridas Corporation, backed out.

title: Monday: Something Thats Fed Along a Street
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Todays puzzle is by our young friend David Steinberg, who was last seen getting us hip to all that text-speak the kids are using these days.

title: A Man Who Knew About the Electric Chair
description: Nobody killed more people, with more regret, than Lewis E. Lawes.

title: Operatic Pageantry With Gandhi, Dr. King and a Message of Pacifism
description: Over the decades before the New York Philharmonic discovered Philip Glass last week, with two performances of Koyaanisqatsi, the Metropolitan Opera paid sporadic but serious attention.

title: Downbeat Realms of Grunge
description: Set 20 years after Kurt Cobains death, Verse Chorus Verse, at the Cherry Lane Studio Theater, is one bitter valentine to the legacy of grunge. Written by Randall Colburn, a Chicago playwright, it extols that musical phenomenon even as it sifts through the lives of survivors wandering its smoking embers. The show, a collaboration between the Barefoot Theater Company and East 3rd Productions, has a heart clearly in rock: the business, the musicians way of life. But the story probes dark corners, using a ghastly actual incident that happened in Tacoma, Wash., as its historical point of origin.

title: A Shadowy Goddess as Musical Muse
description: The conductor Robert Spano has a well-deserved reputation for innovative programming, bolstered by 10 high-growth seasons as music director of the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra. Many New Yorkers remember his dynamic eight-year tenure as music director of the Brooklyn Philharmonic, which ended in 2004.

title: Troupes From Abroad Get a Warm Welcome
description: Are there any dance audiences more eager to love than those that sell out the Fall for Dance Festival at City Center? When the companies on the bill all come from abroad, as was the case on Friday night for the festivals fourth program, the quick-trigger ovations can feel like a form of hospitality. Basking in the warm welcome can be enjoyable, even if you dont agree on the merits.

title: Music For Tomorrows Column
An Aloof Romney in a Plane Encounter
description: Mitt Romney was polite as he took his seat in coach next to Carolyn McClanahan of Jacksonville, Fla., on a recent Delta flight to Boston. He thanked her when she said she appreciated his efforts to reform health care as the governor of Massachusetts and even posed for a photo with her.

title: Cain Back on Message, if His Rivals Will Allow It
description: THE WOODLANDS, Tex.  If Herman Cain has been less than clear about exactly what happened during his tenure as head of the National Restaurant Association in the late 1990s, when he was accused of sexual harassment, he is being perfectly clear about how he intends to conduct himself now.

title: For a Weekend, Oklahoma is Earthquake Country
description: Usually, the earth-moving events on an autumn weekend in Oklahoma are at the college football stadiums in Norman and Stillwater.

title: Born Along the Racial Fault Line
description: As a social studies major in his junior year at Harvard, Mark Whitaker attended a debate on the subject of ethnicity. One participant was the chairman of the department. Mr. Whitaker stood up to raise some questions.

title: Real People, Fake Tans, True-ish Stories
description: The most talked-about British television show of the last year is now freely available in the United States  not that youd know it. Previously visible only to those with all-region DVD or media players, The Only Way Is Essex has made its American premiere not on television but online at Hulu.com, a victory for Internet video in its guerrilla war against the TV industry.

title: Playwrights Ambitions, Reconsidered
description: What is the best new American drama of the first decade of this century?

title: Staying in the Vanguard for 25 Seasons, and Counting
description: Carnegie Hall is celebrating its 120th anniversary this year and many artists appearing there are heralding the 200th birthday of Franz Liszt. For the classical-music world, almost any coming or going prompts a party; in this, the New York composers collective Bang on a Can is no exception. Still, when David Lang, a founder of Bang on a Can along with Michael Gordon and Julia Wolfe, introduced the first event of the organizations 25th season from the Zankel Hall stage on Saturday night, his announcement was hardly boilerplate.

title: A Russian Touch Delivered Lovingly, With Gusto
description: These days for a foreign company to bring a program of ballets by the Russian choreographer Alexei Ratmansky to New York is to invoke the clich about hauling coals to Newcastle. You cant avoid his product here, and a contract at American Ballet Theater guarantees more through 2023.

title: Fusions in Song and Life
description: Instead of science fiction, think of it as alchemy. That is one way to view John Pizzarelli and Jessica Molaskeys brilliant new show, When Worlds Collide, at the Caf Carlyle. Their pairings of songs and voices from different eras and genres (the Beatles with Woody Herman, Antonio Carlos Jobim with Stephen Sondheim, and many more) are not destructive musical collisions in which planets explode. Instead of repelling each other, these alien climates, once in proximity, fuse, generate electricity and create an environment larger and more complex than the sum of its parts.

title: Siriuss Move to Bypass a Royalty Payment Clearinghouse Causes an Uproar
description: The flow of royalty payments, counted in pennies and nickels, may be the least glamorous part of the music industry. But because those royalties are the foundation of almost everyones paycheck, any change to the system can be controversial.

title: On the Ropes With Herman Cain
description: As a math major, Herman Cain undoubtedly knew from the start that running for president, if youre already rich and your main interest is in enhancing your revenue stream, makes no sense as a career move. Or, to cite the erstwhile presidential contender Mike Huckabee, Running for president is like sticking your face in the blade of a fan.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: A Site to Help Marketers Appeal to African-Americans
description: Advertisers are increasingly looking for ways to appeal to consumers of color, but first they need to understand that consumer.

title: Whats Thanksgiving Without Lady Gaga?
description: ABC announced that Lady Gaga, below in a dress made of meat, would perform and cook, and be interviewed by Katie Couric, over the course of a 90-minute prime-time special titled A Very Gaga Thanksgiving on Nov. 24. Lady Gaga will also direct the show for good measure. Eight songs will be performed, including a duet of The Lady Is a Tramp with Tony Bennett, and a Thanksgiving feast of deep-fried turkey and waffles will be prepared with the help of the chef Art Smith.

title: Is Nothing Sacred? Lip Syncing on X Factor
description: Producers of the singing competition show The X Factor, on Fox, have come under fire after a contestants noticeable lip-syncing gaffe occurred in a live episode on Thursday night. The contestant, Leroy Bell, left, was clearly out-of-sync with his own audio track during a performance of Without You by David Guetta and Usher, according to Entertainment Weeklys Web site. All 12 finalists took part in the opening number, but Mr. Bell missed his cue just enough that the cameras, and a portion of the shows audience, caught him not moving his mouth at all while his voice was heard through the speakers. In a statement released to Entertainment Weekly on Friday, Fox and the shows producers said: All competitive songs, including survival songs, are performed live to a backing track. Due to the finalists extensive preparation for their Wednesday night performances, the opening ensemble number on the results show is prerecorded, the same way as on other shows. One of those shows is Foxs American Idol, which dealt with a similar situation two years ago. After accusations of lip syncing were leveled then, a spokesman for FremantleMedia North America, the company that produces American Idol for Fox, admitted that the contestants sang along to their own recorded vocal tracks during group performances.

title: Paul Rudnick to Write a Young-Adult Novel
description: After a heated bidding war, Scholastic has acquired the rights to publish a new young adult novel by Paul Rudnick, the I Hate Hamlet playwright and New Yorker contributor, that will bring fantasy elements to the contemporary worlds of fashion and celebrity, according to his agent, David Kuhn. The still-untitled novel  Mr. Rudnicks first foray into the young-adult genre  depicts an 18-year-old girls journey to New York, where she meets a fashion designer who makes her an offer that seems too good to be true. The designer offers her a chance to become not only the most beautiful woman in the world but the most beautiful woman who has ever lived, Mr. Rudnick said in a telephone interview. And thats just the first chapter. He also said the book would explore the power of duty and the importance the world attaches to physical perfection, something that Id imagine young women have to deal with 24 hours a day. The deal includes an option for a second book that, according to Mr. Rudnick, may or may not be a direct sequel.

title: At the World Championships, Down One Is, Yes, Good Bridge
description: Has anyone won a best-played award for going down one in a contract? Probably not, but if it were ever to be given, perhaps this performance would earn it.

title: Star Show-Jumping Horse Dies During Competition
description: One of Canadas top Olympic athletes  a stallion named Hickstead  collapsed and died in front of hundreds of spectators while competing in Italy on Sunday. The horse had completed a nearly flawless round of show jumping at the sports highest level, the grand prix, before he crashed to the ground under his rider and died in the ring, as fans gasped in horror in the grandstands.

title: In the Shadow of Grand Resorts, a Town Hill Struggles
description: JACKSON, Wyo.  The ski slope that rises up the mountain just off downtown, called Snow King, dates from the 1930s, when this corner of the West all but folded up in winter, isolated and dark, and local people needed something to do. Getting rich from the snows that fall early and deep on the edge of the Teton Range in western Wyoming did not factor in.

title: Bit by Bit, Work Exchange Site Aims to Get Jobs Done
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Philip Rosedale tried to change the nature of play with Second Life, a virtual world of colorful online avatars that got a lot of attention a few years ago.

title: Fall for Dance
description: Photos from the performance at City Center.

title: Employing Softest of Sells for a Resort in Sun Valley
description: SEVENTY years after Sun Valley was a star of a Hollywood movie, the resort is producing films of its own.

title: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Consumer credit for September (Monday); wholesale trade inventories for September (Wednesday); trade deficit for September and import prices for October (Thursday); Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment for November (Friday).

title: 26.2 Miles to Be Faster at 3.1
description: When the hotel phone rang at 5 a.m. Sunday, Lauren Fleshman was already awake. Along with about 25,000 others in the New York field, she was running her first marathon. And she had the same hope, curiosity, excitement and anxiety as anyone else who had never run 26.2 miles.

title: A Lesson in Self
description: Joao Silva, a photographer for The New York Times who lost both legs in Afghanistan, discusses his recovery and competes in the handcycle competition of the New York Marathon, finishing in 2:38:14.

title: A Provocative French Newspaper Is Attacked, and Support Is Swift
description: PARIS  Adored by many, reviled by some, offensive to most everyone, the French satirical weekly called Charlie Hebdo has long reveled in the arch, if simple, art of provocation. Its pages are filled with vulgar caricatures and caustic humor, lampooning politicians, entertainers and media personalities of all stripes, and the newspaper has found itself a frequent presence at Paris courts, accused on several dozen occasions of defamation or inciting hate.

title: Ex-Customers of MF Global Asked to Post More Collateral
description: 7:43 p.m. | Updated

title: Word Crimes
description: Murong Xuecun is a novelist who writes about corruption in China. In the last year, he has emerged as one of the most outspoken critics of censorship.

title: Video: A Lesson in Self
description: Joao Silva, a staff photographer for The New York Times who lost both his legs in an Afghanistan land mine explosion in 2010, discusses his recovery and competes in the handcycle competition of the New York City Marathon, finishing in 2 hours 38 minutes 14 seconds.

title: Delicate Dance of Daytime
description: I had a dream about Anderson Cooper the other night. He was in a vast, cavernous studio and was hanging from the ceiling in a harness, far above the stage.

title: De Beers Makes Anglo American a Better Merger Catch
description: By taking full control of the De Beers Group, the worlds top diamond producer, the mining company Anglo American adds prestige to its holdings. At $5.1 billion, the price agreed to on Friday to buy the Oppenheimer family out of De Beers seems reasonable. But there is more to it: the deal is also another step toward a more straightforward Anglo, making it a more attractive merger partner.

title: Thrills Take Detour to a Sleepy Block
description: Most of the time what passes for excitement on 74th Street between Sixth and Seventh Avenues in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, is figuring out which neighbor will get to feed a lurking stray white cat.

title: For Markets in Europe, the Focus of Fear Moves to Italy
description: European efforts to solve a growing sovereign debt crisis have failed to quell market unease on the Continent, and the skepticism over Greece points to continued volatility this week.

title: Pushing Chinas Limits on Web, if Not on Paper
description: BEIJING  When the novelist Murong Xuecun showed up at a ceremony here late last year to collect his first literary prize, he clutched a sheet of paper with some of the most incendiary words he had ever written.

title: An Excerpt from Leave Me Alone: A Novel of Chengdu
description: An Excerpt from Leave Me Alone: A Novel of Chengdu.

title: NewsHour Changes Raise Questions at PBS
description: Its never good when a news organization loses its political editor just a year before a presidential election. But in the next two weeks, The PBS NewsHour will say goodbye not only to its political editor, David Chalian  he is becoming the Washington bureau chief for Yahoo News  but also its managing editor for digital news, Maureen Hoch, who is headed to the World Bank.

title: Murong Xuecuns Acceptance Speech for the 2010 Peoples Literature Prize
description: If I am not mistaken, the Peoples Literature magazine special action award was not bestowed for my literary achievement, but for my courage. Im embarrassed because I am not a brave person.

title: N.B.A. Needs Drastically Different Approach
description: The N.B.A. has long been known as a league of innovation.

title: Togetherness Helps Set Winner Apart
description: Once they were so close  a tight little family making its way through the hard streets of New York.

title: James A. Baker, on Reducing Nuclear Arms
description: To the Editor:

title: In God We Trust
description: To the Editor:

title: Making Tickets Disappear
description: To the Editor:

title: Were Having an Apartment Party  and Youre Not Invited
description: DEAR DIARY: As a long-term resident in my building, I have seen its makeup shift to younger families and single 30-somethings.

title: Obama and Lobbyists
description: To the Editor:

title: For the First to Run, a Separate Peace
description: The New York City Marathon welcomed its 47,438 runners on Sunday with a sprawling village on Staten Island where loudspeakers blared directions in English, German and French. Refreshment stands offered bagels and coffee. Grassy lawns beckoned runners to huddle in a sleeping bag while they waited for the marathon to begin.

title: U.S. Hangs Back as Inspectors Prepare Report on Irans Nuclear Program
description: WASHINGTON  An imminent report by United Nations weapons inspectors includes the strongest evidence yet that Iran has worked in recent years on a kind of sophisticated explosives technology that is primarily used to trigger a nuclear weapon, according to Western officials who have been briefed on the intelligence.

title: Jets Replay: Week 9
description: The Jets defense forced three turnovers in a 27-11 victory over the Bills in Buffalo.

title: Looking at Inequality in America
description: To the Editor:

title: In Echo of 08, Giants Beat Patriots
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  All week the questions came and all week the Giants repelled them, trying desperately to avoid reminiscing about their dramatic victory in Super Bowl XLII even as they prepared to play their first meaningful game against the New England Patriots since that 2008 night in the Arizona desert.

title: Frame-Up Suspect Levels a Murder Charge
description: It has all the makings of a Hollywood police thriller, a case in which the facts are decidedly stranger than fiction.

title: NBC Struggles for Its Footing
description: Coming into a new television season, about the only solace for the new management regime at NBC was that the networks prime-time fortunes had been so bad for so long, things could not get much worse.

title: Breeders Cup Over; Excitement May Not Be
description: Louisville, Ky.

title: In Tennessee, Following the Rules for Evaluations Off a Cliff
description: MURFREESBORO, Tenn.  Last year, when Tennessee was named one of the first two states to win a federal Race to The Top grant, worth $501 million, there was great joy all around.

title: Reefer Madness
description: MARIJUANA is now legal under state law for medical purposes in 16 states and the District of Columbia, encompassing nearly one-third of the American population. More than 1,000 dispensaries provide medical marijuana; many are well regulated by state and local law and pay substantial taxes. But though more than 70 percent of Americans support legalizing medical marijuana, any use of marijuana remains illegal under federal law.

title: The Dark Side of the Green City
description: Phoenix

title: D.E.A. Squads Extend Reach of Drug War
description: WASHINGTON  Late on a moonless night last March, a plane smuggling nearly half a ton of cocaine touched down at a remote airstrip in Honduras. A heavily armed ground crew was waiting for it  as were Honduran security forces. After a 20-minute firefight, a Honduran officer was wounded and two drug traffickers lay dead.

title: Accolades for Rooney, a Doubter of Accolades
description: Andy Rooney carried around the label for so long, it almost came to be his official title: national curmudgeon.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Id al-Adha, the Islamic Feast of Sacrifice, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended on Monday and Tuesday in New York City. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Race Barrier May Topple as Voters Pick Mayor
description: SAN FRANCISCO  This city with the countrys oldest Chinatown appears likely to elect a Chinese-American mayor for the first time on Tuesday, and for many residents it is a milestone long overdue.

title: Nicaragua Is Poised to Re-elect Ortega
description: TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras  President Daniel Ortega of Nicaragua was leading the polls for an election to a third term on Sunday, buttressing his status as one of Latin Americas most resilient voices at a time when Western powers, civic groups and the countrys news media are challenging his domineering ways.

title: Normal Life on Pause, and a Sense of Simmering Rage
description: ATHENS  The tiny jewelry shop in the working-class Athens neighborhood was open for business  barely.

title: Former General Elected President of Guatemala
description: GUATEMALA CITY  Otto Prez Molina, a former general during this countrys bloody civil war, was elected president on Sunday after promising to tackle rising crime with an iron fist and an expanded military.

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: In Sexual Abuse Case, a Focus on How Paterno Reacted
description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa.  On Saturday, March 2, 2002, according to Pennsylvania prosecutors, a Penn State University graduate student went to visit Joe Paterno, the universitys football coach. The student had a horrific story to tell: the night before, the graduate student had witnessed one of Paternos former coaches sexually assaulting a 10-year-old boy in the football facilitys showers.

title: On CBS, a Final Tip of the Hat to Andy Rooney
description: CBS on Sunday replayed Andy Rooneys words one more time, two days after the legendary 60 Minutes commentator died in New York City.

title: Penn State Scandal Shakes the Happy Valley Family to Roots
description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa.  Nestled in a mountain range, the idyllic community that surrounds the campus of Penn State is often referred to as Happy Valley. But on an otherwise sunny, peaceful Sunday, residents throughout the area awoke to blaring headlines and news of unthinkable child abuse crimes that led to the arrests Saturday of a prominent former assistant football coach and two top university officials.

title: Satirical Song, a YouTube Hit, Challenges Extremism in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A satirical song that takes a tongue-in-cheek swipe at religious extremism, militancy and contradictions in Pakistani society has become an instant hit here, drawing widespread attention as a rare voice of the countrys embattled liberals.

title: Rehearsal for Reconstruction
description: On the clear, crisp morning of Nov. 7, 1861, Sam Mitchell, a young slave living on the island of Port Royal off the coast of South Carolina, thought he heard thunder  which seemed odd, since there was not a cloud in the sky. He asked his mother, Tyra, what hed heard. It wasnt thunder, she said. The Yankees had come to give them freedom. A few miles away the largest fleet ever assembled by the United States was bombarding Fort Walker and Fort Beauregard, the two forts on either side of the entrance to Port Royal Sound.

title: Ever Wondered About Andy Rooney and Stationery?
description: When I was about to graduate from Colgate University, in 1980, I knew I wanted to be a journalist. But I also knew that there are no normal career paths in the news business. There are no formal training programs  and newspapers do not send recruiters to college campuses.

title: Committee of Players to Discuss Next Move
description: With weary gazes and weary voices, the leaders of the N.B.A. players union shuffled out of a hotel conference room early Sunday morning and tried to focus on a hazy horizon.

title: Communications Director Finds Energy in Fight Against Cancer
description: Steve Mendelsohn is not a luminary to the many thousands of spectators of the New York City Marathon, but he is a familiar sight to its legions of officials and volunteers, having worked every race since 1976, when it first came to encompass all five boroughs.

title: As Trial Nears, Carlos the Jackal Retains His Bluster
description: PARIS  He has lost much of his hair and, after a 10-day prison hunger strike last month, a bit of his signature paunch. But as he prepares to stand trial on Monday for a series of bombings he is accused of orchestrating in the early 1980s, Ilich Ramrez Snchez, better known as Carlos the Jackal, seems to have lost little of his bravado.

title: Obsessed With Taking the Plunge
description: It can get pretty lonely being the kind of person who goes over Niagara Falls in a barrel. Anna Edson Taylor (1838-1921) made her name more than a century ago by doing just that, and received oceans of publicity. Yet during the many years of her life portrayed in Queen of the Mist, Michael John LaChiusas obsessive musical portrait of an obsessive woman, she encounters only one true kindred spirit. And hes not exactly someone whose name youd want linked to yours for eternity.

title: Giants Find a Way; A Scuffling Brady and the Patriots Look a Bit Lost
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.

title: Catskill Town, Slow to Rebound, Shows Signs of Energy
description: PRATTSVILLE, N.Y.  More than two months after flood waters that engulfed this remote Catskill Mountains town knocked Dave Rikards Victorian house off its foundation, it remains frozen in a bow  as if bidding farewell to Main Street after a 100-year performance.

title: East River Copter Crash Takes 3rd Life
description: A third person has died as a result of a helicopter crash in the East River last month, the authorities said on Sunday.

title: Lottery Numbers
Deaths Put Focus on Pastors Advocacy of Spanking
description: Scrutiny of a book written by a Tennessee preacher and his wife advocating physical discipline of children intensified after the death of a third child at the hands of parents who used the book.

title: Preaching Virtue of Spanking, Even as Deaths Fuel Debate
description: PLEASANTVILLE, Tenn.  After services at the Church at Cane Creek on a recent Sunday, a few dozen families held a potluck picnic and giggling children played pin the tail on the donkey.

title: After a Bad Accident, Finding Resilience in Balloons
description: Inside a small, colorful shop in Brooklyn, Minnie Mouse is five feet tall and made entirely of balloons. This incarnation of the Disney character was the creation of Ianthe Cupid, who took pride in putting the finishing touches on it recently for the stores street display.

title: Jets Big Win Produces a Three-Way Tie for First
description: A capsule look at the Jets 27-11 victory over the Bills on Sunday.

title: Can They Police Themselves?
description: A series of scandals and crimes  very few of them uncovered by the New York Police Department  should leave no doubt that New York needs a strong, independent agency to investigate serious complaints about the citys police.

title: Gun Walking the Mexican Border
description: It turns out that Fast and Furious, the foolhardy government operation that allowed high-powered weapons to cross the border to Mexican drug cartels, was not a one-off. The Bush administration used the same improper tactic in Operation Wide Receiver in 2006-7.

title: Jamaica Bays Delights
description: At the outermost edges of New York City sits some of the most biologically productive public parkland on the Eastern seaboard  the 10,000 or so acres of open spaces, wetlands and waterways of Jamaica Bay. Not many New Yorkers know of this urban wilderness and for those who do, getting there and enjoying its natural beauty is a formidable task.

title: The Next Fight Over Jobs
description: The way the job market is going, it will never be robust enough to bring down the unemployment rate, now at 9 percent, or 13.9 million people. Monthly job growth has slowed to an average of just 90,000 new jobs a month over the past six months, a pace at which growth in the working-age population will always exceed the number of new jobs being created.

title: We Found Oil! Is That Good?
A Hidden Toll as States Shift to Contract Workers
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich.  Like many states and local governments struggling to cut costs, Michigan hopes to replace some government employees with contract workers who will do the same job for less.

title: Here Comes the Sun
description: For decades the story of technology has been dominated, in the popular mind and to a large extent in reality, by computing and the things you can do with it. Moores Law  in which the price of computing power falls roughly 50 percent every 18 months  has powered an ever-expanding range of applications, from faxes to Facebook.

title: Neediest Cases | Ianthe Cupid
description: Seven years ago, Ms. Cupid lost part of her leg in a highway accident, and she has been proving her resilience to friends, family, customers and, most important, herself ever since.

title: A Rematch Isnt Out of the Question

Miles grabbed someones cellphone and roared in laughter at a picture of himself tripping on the stadiums turf as he came out of the tunnel before the game.

title: Nasty, Brutish and Long: The Brilliance of the Modern Campaign
description: There we go again. After nonstop headlines a year before Election Day and nine debates between the Republican candidates (number 10 is scheduled to take place on Wednesday in Michigan), Americans are already grumbling that the 2012 presidential campaign is ugly and interminable. But these quadrennial complaints about campaigning miss the point. Presidential campaigns are nasty, long and expensive because they should be. Many aspects of campaigns that Americans hate reflect democratic ideals we love.

title: Norman Ramsey Dies at 96; Work Led to the Atomic Clock
description: Norman F. Ramsey, the Nobel Prize-winning physicist who developed a precise method to probe the structure of atoms and molecules and used it to devise a remarkably exact way to keep time, died on Friday in Wayland, Mass. He was 96.

title: Sid Melton, Comic Actor of Film and TV, Dies at 94
description: Sid Melton, a jug-eared character actor best known for his regular roles in the television shows Green Acres and The Danny Thomas Show and for his unflagging reliability as the comic relief in many science fiction and noir films of the 1950s, died on Wednesday in Burbank, Calif. He was 94.

title: Bowl Championship Series Standings
description: The B.C.S. rankings are determined by three components: the Harris Interactive poll, the USA Today coaches poll and the average of six computer rankings. Each component counts one-third toward a teams B.C.S. score.

title: Running to Honor Grete Waitz
description: Sundays race was dedicated to the memory of Grete Waitz, the nine-time winner who died of cancer in April at 57. Her husband, Jack, ran in her honor, his seventh marathon in New York. He finished in 3:50:41, his slowest clocked time but about a half-hour faster than he expected.

title: A First and a Record in the Wheelchair Divisions
description: History was made Sunday in the New York City Marathon wheelchair divisions. Masazumi Soejima became the first Japanese champion in any of the marathons races by winning the mens division in 1 hour 31 minutes 41 seconds, his personal best in New York. Soejimas previous best time was 1:37:31 last year, when he finished second to David Weir of Britain by two seconds.

title: Flu Can Be Fatal in Children With MRSA
description: A nationwide study has found that previously healthy children hospitalized with flu were significantly more likely to die if they were also infected with MRSA, or methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus. The findings are important because MRSA, which can cause skin and internal infections, is a growing concern among healthy children.

title: National Study Finds Widespread Sexual Harassment of Students in Grades 7 to 12
description: Nearly half of 7th to 12th graders experienced sexual harassment in the last school year, according to a study scheduled for release on Monday, with 87 percent of those who have been harassed reporting negative effects such as absenteeism, poor sleep and stomachaches.

title: Victory for Pro-Beijing Candidates in Hong Kong Local Elections
description: HONG KONG  Democracy advocates suffered a long series of defeats in neighborhood council elections here on Sunday, as pro-Beijing politicians successfully tapped anti-immigrant sentiment as well as public hostility toward environmental measures perceived as harming employment and increasing the governments construction costs.

Udhayakumar, coordinator of one opposition group,claimed that a mishap the nuclear power plant would wipe out several southern districts of Tamil Nadu and neighboring Kerala.

In the case of the week  which started on time; no football overruns  Alicia faced eight years in prison and a hefty fine as fallout from Lockhart Gardners defense of an American translator charged with aiding terrorists. (The firm was initially representing him in a lawsuit against the government, before things went south in a manner too complicated to get into here.) As a bonus, the case brought Titus Welliver back for a guest appearance as Glenn Childs, now a nasty federal prosecutor.

title: Trigger Fingers
description: We accept that Africa is a place that comes with risks, says the Ethos Water creator Peter Thum, but seeing a little kid with a gun is very jarring. So Thum (right) and John Zapolski (left) founded Fonderie 47, a company aimed at reducing Africas estimated 20 million assault weapons by turning the metal into jewelry. Working with the Mines Advisory Group, the company has helped remove more than 5,000 AK-47s from Congo. Designed with the jeweler Philip Crangi, each steel-and-gold signet ring (price on request; e-mail contact@fonderie47.com) finances the demolition of 75 more guns and is etched with the serial number of the weapon it once was.

title: Doctor Groups Seem Less Wary of Medicare Changes

title: Breakfast Meeting, Monday, Nov. 7

While every other network has generated a new hit, NBC, which needs hits the most, has not, they write, noting that without the strong ratings of the N.F.L. on Sundays, NBC would be struggling to stay out of fifth place in the ratings. Without football, NBC is now tied with the Spanish-language network Univision in those 18-49 ratings. [NYT]

Vain Glorious | The Dancing Hairdresser

My hair was like a born-again virgin  free from color, styling and heavy processing. It was ripe for the shearing. Shin, who was formerly with Frdric Fekkai (shampoo boy turned stylist with a cult following), opened his namesake salon a few months before my visit and offers cuts, color, keratin treatments, digital perms and Japanese straightening.

title: Theres a Kebab in My Tapestry!
description: ISTANBUL  In 1990, the year that globalization shifted into high gear and McDonalds opened an outlet in Moscow, a paper delivered at the Oxford Symposium on Food and Cookery entitled The Bayeux Tapestry Shish Kebab Mystery had French academics reaching for indigestion tablets. Its author, the textile specialist Robert Chenciner, pointed to a panel of that famous embroidery in which Norman knights celebrate their victory over the Saxons by grilling skewers of meat over an open fire. From this, Chenciner drew the bold conclusion that the tapestry must be a forgery or at least a much oversewn bit of cloth. There were no kebab takeaways in the Hastings of 1066, he reasoned, and it wasnt until the Ottomans visited Versailles in the mid-18th century that Turkish food came to France.

description: 4:01 p.m. | Updated

title: Businesses Feel the Pinch as China Tightens Lending
description: GUANGZHOU, China  David Huan had big dreams for his business, a factory in central China that makes picture frames ranging from glossy wood to the gilded and baroque. He wanted to expand production, and add new equipment and 400 to 600 workers atop the 400 he already employed.

title: Ticking Again: Reviving a Classic Timepiece
description: THE watch mavens at Tourneau have teamed up with J. Crew to revive a little-known Swiss watchmaker, Mougin & Piquard. The company, founded in the 1920s by Ernest Mougin and Paul Piquard, had designed traditional mechanical watches with a Parisian sensibility, much in the manner of the Mougin family, which made ornate timepieces in late-19th-century Paris.

title: Did You Participate in Bank Transfer Day?
description: This past Saturday was declared Bank Transfer Day by a grassroots movement. The credit unions, in particular, as well as small community banks then jumped on the idea.

title: New Nook Is Latest Entry in Tablet Wars
description: 1:30 p.m. | Updated Barnes & Noble answered Amazons challenge in the tablet wars on Monday, introducing a $249 color device called the Nook Tablet.

title: A Deleted Scene From 'Blue Velvet'
description: An exclusive deleted scene from David Lynchs Blue Velvet, with Kyle MacLachlan and Isabella Rossellini. The film, along with several other deleted scenes, is on Blu-ray Nov. 8.

title: Thanksgiving Side Dishes, Part 2: Gluten-Free Stuffings
description: Stuffing has always been high on my list of favorite Thanksgiving dishes. This year I wanted to play around with gluten-free dishes based on whole grains that could go inside a bird but also stand alone. So I looked in my pantry and pulled out all the half-full bags of the different colorful types of grains that Ive been working with lately. First I combined them in visually pleasing ways, and then I decided what else Id put into each stuffing (or pilaf, which is what these dishes really are).

title: Readers Respond: Jobless Benefits
description: Todays editorial notes that there are no plausible arguments against extending federal unemployment benefits. Benefits, the board says, do not reduce the incentive to get a new job.

title: Is Overregulation Driving U.S. Companies Offshore?
description: As my colleague Richard A. Oppel Jr. reported on Thursday, Gov. Rick Perry of Texas is arguing that companies are sending work abroad primarily because of overregulation in the United States, and not because labor is cheaper abroad.

title: The Chancellor and the Marathon
In Washington, Golden Reminders of Englands Dark Age
description: Rare artifacts from seventh- and eighth-century England are on display outside that country for the first time at the National Geographic Museum in Washington, in an exhibition that opened Oct. 29 and runs through March 4.

title: TimesCast | November 7, 2011
description: Greek leaders agree to form a new unity government; Italy's prime minister faces a crucial confidence vote; and Formula One racing comes to New Jersey in 2013.

title: My Three Favorite Rapper Debut Album Covers
description: Hip-hop album covers today have become pretty slick. The album art is often as anticipated as the album itself.

title: AMD Betting on Power Consumption
description: Advanced Micro Devices, the biggest producer of computer semiconductors after Intel, announced Thursday that it was cutting 10 percent of its staff, some 1,100 people.

title: Syria Unleashes Assault to Take an Unbowed City
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The Syrian government has launched a bloody assault to retake Homs, the countrys third-largest city, facing armed defectors who have prevented the governments forces from seizing it as they did other restive locales this summer, in what may stand as one of the most violent episodes in an eight-month uprising.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
description: AdKeeper, New York, hired two executives and promoted two others. Jon Gregg joined as senior vice president for advertiser solutions and Ravi Pillai joined as vice president for publisher relations. Also, MaryAnn Bekkedahl, president for advertiser solutions, was promoted to president, and David Murnick, vice president for client services and operations, was promoted to senior vice president for client services and operations.

title: On Television, a Big Crowd for L.S.U.-Alabama
description: Louisiana States 9-6 win over Alabama Saturday night was seen by an average of 20 million viewersthe most for a college football game on CBS since 1989 when 22.5 million viewers watched Miami defeat Notre Dame 27-10. The win solidified L.S.U.s no. 1 spot in the B.C.S. rankings. Alabama dropped from second to third.

title: Pine Trees Help Reconstruct a Long-Ago Drought
description: As they struggle to understand modern climate change, scientists have long realized the importance of reconstructing past climate variability. Thats the only way to gain a sense of perspective, to understand how anomalous modern climate events are or arent.

title: These Ad Stars Know All About Ads
description: Among the popular creative trends on Madison Avenue is using actual consumers  so-called real people  in ads rather than actors, models or celebrities. Now comes a campaign with a twist: The ads use real Madison Avenue people.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Q: (Reader)

title: In Letter to Union, Stern Details His Ultimatum
description: The ultimatum issued by the N.B.A. to its players over the weekend not only threatens them with a worse labor deal, but also a massive pay cut if they do not make a deal by Wednesday afternoon.

title: The Art of, and on, the Chez Panisse Menu
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: #OccupyWallSt Roundup, Day 52
description: Occupy Wall Street protesters are marching from Washington Heights to Zuccotti Park on Monday, almost the length of a half-marathon, in an attempt to unite city neighborhoods with the protest (albeit without leaving Manhattan). [End to End for 99 Percent]

title: I.R.S. Asked to Investigate Nonprofit Linked to Cain Campaign
description: A liberal-leaning watchdog group based in Wisconsin asked the Internal Revenue Service on Monday to investigate whether a tax-exempt organization linked to Herman Cains top campaign aide violated the law by providing air travel and other help to Mr. Cain earlier this year when he was exploring a presidential bid.

title: Joe Romm On Solar
description: The estimable Joe Romm explains the issues better than I did:

title: Monday Motorsports: In Nascar Sprint Cup Chase, Tony Stewart Writes a Comeback Narrative
description: Tony Stewart continued to play the upsetter of the 2011 Nascar Chase for the Sprint Cup, securing his fourth victory in eight tries on Sunday at Texas Motor Speedway.

title: Number Of The Beast Blogging
description: Under summary, see value  the current yield on Italian 10-years.

title: The Dangerous Cocoon of King Football
description: Really, we need to do something about big-time college sports.

title: Think Twice About That Hot New I.P.O.
description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived on the Bucks blog and on his personal Web site, BehaviorGap.com.

title: Bill Clinton Lays Out His Prescription for Americas Future
description: Bill Clintons new book, Back to Work, is really several books in one slender volume. Its a lucid one-man rebuttal of the Tea Partys anti-government agenda. A series of shrewd talking points for Democrats trying to hold on to the White House and battling for control of Congress in the midst of a sour economy and growing voter discontent. A self-serving reminder of the prosperity the country enjoyed during Mr. Clintons tenure in the White House, meant to burnish his legacy. And a practical set of proposals  some borrowed and some new, some innovative and some highly sketchy  for restoring economic growth and creating jobs.

title: Finger-Pointing From Within London
description: LONDON  Workers in Britains financial services sector have come in for criticism from all sides since the onset of the Great Recession. Now the critics are coming from within.

title: Floaters and Flashes, but Only a Preview
description: Dinner had just arrived at one of my favorite restaurants last month when the room began to swarm with insects and drifting bits of yarn. A moment later, I realized that they were actually inside my right eye  a mini-avalanche of the spots that doctors call floaters.

title: Act Fast to Save Sight if Signs of Danger to the Retina Appear
description: The eyes may be windows to the soul, but the retina is the brains window to the world. When the retina is injured, vision is seriously threatened and may be lost entirely if the problem is not quickly addressed.

title: Israel Denies Hackers Knocked Government Sites Offline
description: Several Israeli government Web sites, including those of the countrys military and security services, crashed on Sunday, just hours after a statement issued in the name of the hackers who call themselves Anonymous had threatened to target the country in retaliation for its blockade of Gaza.

title: US State Balances Of Payments
description: A number of readers have asked why the United States doesnt have internal problems with balance of payments imbalances comparable to those afflicting the euro zone.

title: Paterno Losing Public Opinion Battle
description: Penn State Coach Joe Paterno may not be a target of the legal system in the case against his former defensive coordinator Jerry Sandusky for sexually abusing children  as the cases prosecutors confirmed in a news conference Monday in Harrisburg, Pa.  but he has not fared well in the court of public opinion. That case is being tried in real time in the comments sections of various Web sites that have reported the story, including The Timess.

title: Woman Accuses Cain of Lewd Behavior; He Denies It
description: 9:33 p.m. | Updated The full report of this article is available here.

title: One Option for Corzine in MF Global Inquiry: the Fifth Amendment
description: Will Jon S. Corzine take the Fifth?

title: Unfamiliar Candidate for Mayor Strikes First in TV Ad Battle
description: The 2013 mayoral election is still two years away, but the first television advertisement of the campaign will make its debut on Tuesday.

title: TimesCast | Greece's New Government
description: November 7, 2011 - Greek leaders reach a deal for a transitional government, headed by a yet-to-be-named interim Prime Minister.

title: TimesCast | Berlusconi's Future
description: November 7, 2011 - Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi faces an uncertain future, as parliament prepares for a confidence vote on Tuesday.

title: Starz Gives Thumbs Up to Season 3 of Gladiator Series Spartacus
description: We cant predict for certain how the coming season of Spartacus: Vengeance will end, but were feeling confident that the gladiator hero of its title will live to fight another day. Thats because on Monday, the Starz cable channel announced that it has already committed to producing a third season of Spartacus even before its second season has begun.

title: Pleasures of Life in the Slow Lane
description: New Yorkers should love bicycling. Were control freaks. We want to get from here to there in a New York minute and moan about the subways and the buses, about lunatic taxi drivers and the gridlock that slows us down.

title: Photo Replay: Nov.7
description: The day in sports, from surfing in San Francisco to soccer in Jakarta, Indonesia.

title: An Injured War Photographers Marathon
description: Joao Silva, a photographer for The New York Times, lost both his legs last October when he stepped on a mine in Afghanistan. In February, he took his first steps on prosthetic legs. Amazingly, he competed this weekend in the New York City Marathon in the handcycle division, racing across the finish line in 2 hours 38 minutes 14 seconds.

title: Google+ Lets In the Corporations
description: Google is opening its social network, Google+, to companies, organizations and brands. With the move, it hopes to create novel kinds of relationships between people and products, while making inroads against Facebooks own popular corporate pages, partly by using Google search to promote pages.

title: Some War-Weary Somalis Find Respite at the Beach
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  After years of surviving under the yoke of fundamentalist Islamist militants, Somalis here are getting their swagger back.

title: After the Splat: Our Critic Is Back on the Bike
description: It was years ago, bicycling home from school. I hit a pothole, flew over the handlebars, and went splat against the brick wall of the building at the corner of Minetta Lane and Minetta Street. I managed to limp home. But the incident put me off biking for a long while.

title: 20111107-lens-7billionnew
description: 20111107-lens-7billionnew

title: Style in the Rough
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Drawing Dance: The Cunningham Company at Stanford
description: The Brooklyn artist Kenneth E. Parris III is on tour with members of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, documenting, through a series of drawings and paintings, their two-year Legacy Tour. After 58 years the company is scheduled to disband on New Years Day 2012. This is the 18th in a series of graphite drawings Mr. Parris plans to create from the road, providing a front-row seat to the final weeks of the companys journey. This weeks entry is from Stanford, Calif.

title: A Calm Guide to Afghan Chaos Moves On
description: The New York Times lost its longest-tenured journalist in Afghanistan in October. While foreign reporters rotate in and out of the country, Waheed Abdul Wafa was a perennial mainstay, dedicating his life to telling stories about a war that the rest of the world is becoming increasingly immune to.

title: Hartung Hoard Brings $4 Million at Auction
description: As the gavel dropped time and again, Lee Roy Hartungs motley collection of cars, motorcycles and automobilia was broken up at a highly anticipated auction outside of Chicago last weekend, ultimately bringing $4 million.

title: Subway Predators, Captured in Verse
description: Saturdays Crime Scene column was a cautionary tale of sorts about passing out on the subway after too many drinks and being relieved of your wallet by an old man with a razor.

title: Finding the Right C.F.O., Working With a Spouse and Other Thoughts From Readers
description: Thoughts, comments, questions and other feedback from readers:

title: Wife Taking Late Hits by N.F.L.
description: The Good Wife on CBS is an Emmy-winning show (for its star Julianna Margulies) with a committed, devoted audience.

title: Poison Centers Facing Greater Risks All Around
description: As a medical student, I took care of a small child hospitalized for an aspirin overdose. During my residency, I tended to a toddler who took his grandfathers cardiac pills, which touched off arrhythmias in his heart. From years of taking calls at night, I remember too many children who drank from a bottle of some household cleaning product hidden away under the sink.

title: Beauty Spots
description: These days, if you sing on television, you must also have a scent. Just ask Beyonc, Jennifer Lopez, Katy Perry or any of the following pop stars who introduced new perfumes this fall.COUNTRY STRONG The country pop singer-songwriter Taylor Swift has partnered with Elizabeth Arden for her first fragrance, Wonderstruck (starts at $49.50). Its name was taken from one of her songs, Enchanted, and its notes include freesia, apple blossom and vanilla.BERRY DANCING The Colombian-born, belly-dancing chanteuse Shakira has come out with S by Shakira Eau Florale (starts at $17; sold at mass retailers and drugstores nationwide). Its similar to the process you go through when writing a melody: certain chord combinations inspire different feelings in the listener, Shakira said in a press statement of her involvement in its creation. Notes are floral (jasmine, heliotrope) and fruity (blackberry, raspberry and blueberry).

title: Ravens and Steelers Deliver Viewers to NBC
description: After nearly a month of blowouts and less-than-appealing matchups, Sunday Night Football on NBC returned to form on Sunday in a hotly contested rivalry game in which the Baltimore Ravens defeated the Pittsburgh Steelers, 23-20, with a touchdown in the final seconds. The game dominated all ratings categories among the broadcast networks, according to preliminary overnight Nielsen estimates. Elsewhere, Once Upon A Time on ABC held steady in its third week, with 11.4 million total viewers. That fantasy drama was given a full-season order last Thursday, and its continued strong performance provides some welcome news for ABC since another freshman entry, Pan Am, has faded in the ratings after a strong start. It hit a series low of 5.2 million total viewers on Sunday.

title: State Officials Blast Penn State in Sandusky Case
description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa.  The Pennsylvania attorney general and the state police commissioner excoriated Penn State officials on Monday for failing over several years to alert the authorities to possible sexual abuse of young boys by a prominent football assistant.

title: Really? The Claim: Drink Eight Glasses of Water a Day to Protect the Kidneys
description: THE FACTS

title: Eggs Arent People
description: It is so rare to hear a Republican presidential candidate defy the extreme right on social issues that I had to take notice of Jon Huntsmans opposition to personhood activists.

title: Lying to Get My Children More Sleep
description: This weekend I set all the clocks back. About 7 on Sunday night (which was feeling a whole lot like 8 to me and four cranky children), I set them forward again. But not all the way. About half an hour. Just enough to give the children a little edge on whats always a sleepy week without my having to declare an early bedtime  and then listen to a chorus of complaint. I admit it: I lied, or at least, I created an atmosphere in which a lie was implied. But it was all for an excellent cause.

title: Thanksgiving Countdown | A Vegetarian Feast
description: A meat-free Thanksgiving dinner can be a colorful, hearty, robust Thanksgiving dinner. For those of you seeking festive vegetarian or vegan dishes, our colleagues on the Well blog have it covered, posting recipes every day as part of their Vegetarian Thanksgiving feature. Even more vegetarian recipes for entertaining can be found here.

title: Kala Azar: Four-Year Test Seeks Better Ways to Treat a Persistent Disease Spread by Sand Flies
description: A four-year test of drugs to treat a widespread parasitic disease called kala azar was announced on Monday by the governments of India and Bangladesh, Doctors Without Borders, the Drugs for Neglected Diseases Initiative and other groups.

title: Test for Hospital Budgets: Are the Patients Pleased?
description: Im a great kvetcher, said Pearl Schwartz, sitting in her hospital bed at NYU Langone Medical Center.

title: De Niro Could Play Madoff in Film for HBO
description: Robert De Niro, who has played all manner of menace to society, may next play Bernard L. Madoff. HBO confirmed Monday that Mr. De Niro is attached to play the Ponzi-schemer in a made-for-television film that is in development for the cable channel. But it cautioned that the film has not yet been put into production.

title: Intern Gap Frustrates Clinicians in Training
description: They call it the match. Every year, thousands of graduate students in clinical psychology pick the hospitals and clinics where they would like to do yearlong internships. They rank their choices. The internship programs also rank the applicants.

title: Orioles Expected to Name Duquette as General Manager
description: Its looking as if a fresh start is on the horizon for Dan Duquette, who was run out of Boston and vilified for the Red Sox failings during his run as general manager from 1994 to 2002. Duquette is expected to be named as the general manager for the Baltimore Orioles, according to The Baltimore Sun, to replace Andy MacPhail. The team has scheduled a news conference Tuesday to announce Duquettes hiring.

title: Keystone XL Pipeline Decision to Be Investigated
description: WASHINGTON  The State Departments inspector general will conduct a special investigation of the handling of the pending decision on the proposed Keystone XL pipeline in response to reports of improper pressure on policy makers and possible conflicts of interest, according to documents released on Monday.

title: In Iowa, Mitt Romney Outlines Programs He Would Cut as President
description: DUBUQUE, Iowa  Mitt Romney, clad in Tommy Bahama blue jeans and a blue plaid work shirt, took that stage at a metal fabrication shop here and offered two different scenarios a year from now.

title: Learn Your Lessons Well': The Alumni of Godspell
description: When the Broadway revival of Godspell opens Monday night, it will likely trigger memories of rainbow suspenders and recorder solos for many a former drama club member. The 1971 musical, conceived and first directed by John-Michael Tebelak, is a retelling of the story of Jesus and his disciples, told through parables and a rock-pop score by Stephen Schwartz (Wicked). As Mark Oppenheimer wrote in his Arts & Leisure essay: One school-gym performance after another of Bless the Lord and Save the People, among other hard-to-shake tunes, helped American religion accept contemporary music, even welcome it. It was what the kids wanted.

title: Selling Junk to Kids Department
description: In a USA Today story (can you tell Im traveling?) with the headline Burger King kids meals come with wearable cardboard crowns, we learn that the non-leading burger chain is equipping its non-happy-meals  BK Crown Meals (real creative: they used to be called BK Kids Meals)  with a cute little crown your tyke can wear on her cute little head. She can also check out interactive games that will, assuming BK is following the lead of other marketers of junk, encourage further purchases.

title: A Troubled Deal and the Law of Unintended Consequences
description: The effort by Skyworks Solutions to escape its $262.5 million deal to buy Advanced Analogic Technologies is a curious affair.

title: The Critic, the Commissioner and the Bike Lanes
description: Michael Kimmelman, The New York Timess architecture critic, recently cruised the bike lanes with Janette Sadik-Khan, transportation commissioner for New York City.

title: Hop Farmers Reviving Heady Days of Brewing
description: Cazenovia, N.Y.

title: A Hops Harvest in Brooklyn
description: They were hard to miss: flowering vines that climbed more than a dozen feet above a cramped garden patch near the busy intersection of Smith and Bergen Streets in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn. The flowers, it turns out, were hops  the sticky green buds that put the bitter into English bitter and the spicy snap into Czech pilsner. And with their recent harvest, New York City has made a small contribution to a brewing renaissance.

title: Pictures of the Day: India and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from India, Pakistan, Iran and Scotland.

title: Doctor Is Guilty in Michael Jacksons Death
description: LOS ANGELES  Michael Jackson, among the most famous performers in pop music history, spent his final days in a sleep-deprived haze of medication and misery until finally succumbing to a fatal dose of potent drugs provided by the private physician he had hired to act as his personal pharmaceutical dispensary, a jury decided on Monday.

title: Former Blue Man President Will Be Public Theaters Executive Director
description: The board of the Public Theater announced its new executive director on Monday, entrusting its $18.5 million operating budget and other business operations to a somewhat unusual pick: Patrick Willingham, the former president and chief operating officer of Blue Man Productions, a for-profit company that turned the Off Broadway production Blue Man Group into an international entertainment attraction.

title: Dream Weavers
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: In Portland, Ore., Being an E.V. Pioneer Brings Unforeseen Challenges
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  Sightings of the Nissan Leaf are a regular occurrence here on streets and freeways. Residents are retrofitting their older cars to run purely on electricity. D.C. fast chargers are being installed. And in August, a block on the campus of Portland State University became Electric Avenue.

title: Adele Undergoes Surgery on Her Vocal Cords
description: Adele, the British singer and songwriter, underwent surgery at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston on Monday to stop recurrent bleeding from a benign polyp on her vocal cords, a condition that forced her to cancel more than a dozen concerts this year in the United States and Britain, a spokesman for the hospital said.

title: Iraqi Governor Survives Assassination Attempt
description: BAGHDAD  The governor of Anbar Province survived an assassination attempt on Monday, the latest of several, when a homemade bomb blew up beside his convoy near the town of Abu Ghraib. The Sunni governor, Qasim al-Fahadi, was unharmed in the attack, but his spokesman said three guards were wounded.

title: Space: The Final Stimulus
description: Fools! Fools! The White House has issued a statement denying that there is any evidence that extraterrestrials exist.

title: Pictures of the Day: India and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from India, Pakistan, Iran and Russia.

title: Zuckerberg and Sandberg Discuss Facebooks Future
description: 2:21 p.m. | Updated Adding information about Mark Zuckerberg receiving advice from Steve Jobs.

title: The Truth About College Weight Gain
description: Its popular wisdom that college students put on 10 or 15 pounds their first year of school, a phenomenon often dubbed the freshman 15. But new research suggests that the notion of early college weight gain is a myth.

title: A Photographer in a Handcycle: He Works Fast
description: The great media critic A.J. Liebling was fond of saying about himself, in comparison to other writers, and we paraphrase: No one better was faster, and no one faster was better. But for 26.2 miles?

title: Preventing Accidental Poisonings
description: With an increasingly complex array of drugs found in many medicine cabinets, parents need to be reminded all over again about the importance of keeping medications away from young children, writes Dr. Perri Klass in the latest 18 and Under column:

title: Media Decoder: New Nook Is Latest Entry in Tablet Wars
description: Barnes & Noble answered Amazons challenge in the tablet wars on Monday, introducing a $249 color device called the Nook Tablet. Speaking at Barnes & Nobles store in Manhattans Union Square, William Lynch, the companys chief executive, set the new Nook directly up against Amazons recently released Kindle Fire, promoting what he described as the Nooks advantages in memory and multimedia capability. Read the full post at Media Decoder.

title: Vet Who Spoke About Carriage Horses Death Is Suspended
description: Updated Nov. 8, 11:06 a.m. | Two weeks ago, a carriage horse collapsed and died on its way to Central Park. The American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, which has oversight over New Yorks carriage horses, issued preliminary findings that the horse was not a healthy horse and was likely suffering from pain from stomach ulcers.

title: Michele Bachmann Warns Against Supporting Frugal Socialists
description: It is probably news to her rival Republicans, but in Michele Bachmanns eyes their policies mark them as no better than frugal socialists.

title: A Before-Its-Time Machine
description: Researchers are planning to build a working version of the Analytical Engine, which Charles Babbage conceived of in the 1830s but never completed.

title: It Started Digital Wheels Turning
description: Researchers in Britain are about to embark on a 10-year, multimillion-dollar project to build a computer  but their goal is neither dazzling analytical power nor lightning speed.

title: The Vietnam War, Retold in Images
description: Francis Ford Coppola and Michael Herr should demand credit. More than 30 years after they defined how the Vietnam War would look and feel in the American memory  in Mr. Herrs book Dispatches and Mr. Coppolas film Apocalypse Now  they should still be getting a special thanks in every Vietnam movie and television program.

title: Cain Video Directs Appeal to Iowa Farmers
description: Herman Cains campaign put out a new web video on Monday that assails the impact of environmental regulations on farmers.

title: Q&A: A Young Sailors Guide to the Islands
description: IN 2003, 8-year-old Alex Ellison and his family set sail in the Caribbean on their 46-foot Beneteau 473, Promise. They had intended to take a one-year trip from Essex, Conn., through the Caribbean to South America and back, but ended up spending almost five years living in the islands, celebrating birthdays in Grenada, Christmas in the Pitons and spending three years in the rain forest of Nevis. The world was now our classroom, Mr. Ellison wrote in his memoir, A Star to Sail Her By (May 2011, iUniverse).

title: Voter Fraud: Does It Happen?
description: Earlier today I dared the Internet to send me examples of voter fraud  particularly of a scale that would justify erecting barriers against whole groups of voters through photo ID requirements and other such pernicious nonsense.
