description: Michael Bay, the director of the Transformers franchise of films, has made high-adrenaline action sequences his trademark. It shouldnt surprise, then, that EA Games would ask Mr. Bay to direct the trailer for its new racing-simulator title, Need for Speed: The Run, which is being released on Nov. 15.

title: My Three Favorite Reasons to End It
description: Before anyone out there begins to worry: a little back story. I was tooling around the Web site of the Dalkey Archive Press, a great, tiny nonprofit press, and found the new issue of their literary review, Context. One of the articles has the too-good-not-to-click-on-it title 100 Good Reasons to Kill Myself Right Now.

title: Signature Postpones New Albee Play
description: The Signature Theater Company has indefinitely postponed its world-premiere production of Edward Albees play Laying an Egg, which was to have been a part of its inaugural season at its new Midtown space. Replacing it will be a revival of Mr. Albees play The Lady From Dubuque, starring Jane Alexander and directed by David Esbjornson, who was to direct Laying an Egg and who directed Mr. Albees The Goat, or Who is Sylvia on Broadway in 2002. Lady From Dubuque had a very brief Broadway run in 1980.

title: Einhorn Playing G.M. Long and Green Mountain Short
description: David Einhorn is nothing if not a contrarian. He called out Lehman Brothers for its accounting, has taken Microsofts chief executive to task and bet against the most darling stock this year, Green Mountain Coffee Roasters.

title: Pictures of the Day: Italy and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Liberia, Italy, Brazil, Russia, India and South Korea.

title: Draw for Concacaf Champions League Quarterfinals
description: Concacaf, soccers regional governing body for North and Central America and the Caribbean, held the draw for the quarterfinals (which begin in early March) of the Champions League Tuesday at its offices in Trump Tower in Manhattan.

title: Boston, Free and Easy (and Campus-Oriented)
description: Joyce, this cookie is as big as your face, one M.I.T. business student said to another, as they pounced on the oversize chocolate chip and oatmeal raisin treats left over from a lunchtime lecture on the Chinese economy.

title: Many Employers Have Restored Suspended 401(k) Matches, Analysis Finds
description: An analysis of 260 employers that suspended their 401(k) matching contributions in the depths of the recession has found that most have restored them, although some now offer a lower level of benefits.

title: A Board Complicit in MF Globals Bets, and Its Demise
description: The easy explanation for MF Globals downfall is that it was killed by Jon S. Corzines risky trading bets. Yet MF Global was torpedoed not only by Mr. Corzine but by its board.

title: Holder Urges Lawmakers to Support Efforts to Stop Gun Trafficking
description: WASHINGTON  Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. on Tuesday sought to move past the political furor over Operation Fast and Furious, the disputed Arizona gun trafficking investigation, to the wider problem of the flow of American firearms to Mexican drug cartels  and what he portrayed as roadblocks members of Congress have thrown up to stemming that flow.

title: Michigan States Aircraft Carrier Adventure
description: Michigan State Coach Tom Izzo loves to challenge his basketball team during the nonconference season, and hes come up with a doozy to kick off this season on Friday: playing No. 1 North Carolina on an aircraft carrier docked in the Naval harbor in San Diego, in a game called the Carrier Classic. President Obama is scheduled to attend, along with many active duty military in celebration of Veterans Day.

title: Networks Rebound From Scary Halloween
description: ABC was the most-watched network Monday night, and CBS claimed the top spot in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic as ratings for almost the entire network programming slate improved from last weeks poor Halloween performance. A two-hour edition of Dancing With the Stars on ABC averaged just over 18 million total viewers, by far the largest audience on the night. Meanwhile, Two and a Half Men on CBS has leveled out nicely at 14.5 million viewers while remaining the highest-rated Monday program in the 18-to-49 demo.

title: Mission Accomplishment: Exploring Veterans Challenges and Achievements
description: Overview | What veterans return home from war, what challenges and opportunities await them? How are some veterans finding meaning in their post-service lives? In this lesson, students examine some of the struggles that veterans face when they return home and then create displays that honor veterans and details the ways that veterans are making a difference in their communities.

title: Butz and Reaser to Star in How I Learned to Drive
description: Norbert Leo Butz (Catch Me if You Can) and Elizabeth Reaser (Twilight) will co-star in Second Stages production of Paula Vogels Pulitzer Prize-winning play How I Learned to Drive, the theater announced Tuesday. Directing duties will go to Kate Whoriskey, the former artistic director of Seattles Intiman Theater, which laid off its entire staff and closed its doors in April. (In August the theater took a step toward reopening when it hired a consulting artistic director.) The show is to begin previews on Jan. 24, 2012, with opening night set for Feb. 13.

title: Excerpt: 'The Good Wife'
description: The CBS drama, starring Julianna Margulies, has lost viewers since moving to Sundays.

title: Julie Taymor Sues Spider-Man Team Over Royalties
description: The director Julie Taymor, a key creator of the Broadway musical Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark, sued the producers of that $75 million show in federal court on Tuesday, claiming that they were profiting from her creative contributions without compensating her. The lawsuit seeks at least $1 million from the producers, as well as future royalty payments.

title: Finding the Humanity in the F.B.I.s Feared Enforcer
description: Even with all the surprises that have characterized Clint Eastwoods twilight film years, with their crepuscular tales of good and evil, the tenderness of the love story in J. Edgar comes as a shock. Anchored by a forceful, vulnerable Leonardo DiCaprio, who lays bare J. Edgar Hoovers humanity, despite the odds and an impasto of old-coot movie makeup, this latest jolt from Mr. Eastwood is a look back at a man divided and of the ties that bind private bodies with public politics and policies. With sympathy  for the individual, not his deeds  it portrays a 20th-century titan who, with secrets and bullets, a will to power and the self-promotional skills of a true star, built a citadel of information in which he burrowed deep.

title: Photo Ops
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Iowa Might Matter in 12 After All
description: So how much does Iowa matter? In recent Republican nominating contests, the states caucuses have hardly mattered at all. Republican nominations have tended to be predictable, with the party throwing its support behind a candidate early in the process.

title: Romney Says Allegations Against Cain Are Serious
description: Mitt Romney addressed the accusations of sexual harassment surrounding his Republican rival Herman Cain for the first time Tuesday, calling them particularly disturbing and serious in an ABC News and Yahoo interview with George Stephanopoulos.

title: Wheelies: The Facelift Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Making the Case for Minnie Minoso
description: It turns out that Minnie Minoso, the former Chicago White Sox star, is being remembered for the wrong decades  and it just might keep him from achieving baseballs greatest individual honor.

title: 20111108_FERRATO
description: 20111108_FERRATO

title: One Bank Dominates Headlines (Take a Wild Guess)
description: A single investment bank received 15.9 percent of all Wall Street media mentions in the first 10 months of 2011, according to a new study by HighBeam Research, a firm that monitors the media. Last year, the same bank received 17 percent in the same study. The bank also dominated headlines in 2009, picking up 15 percent of all mentions of major Wall Street firms.

title: Should You Worry About a Chubby Baby?
description: Should you, would you, put a baby on a diet and exercise program? Harvard obesity researchers have found that unusually rapid growth in infants doubles the risk that a plump, adorable baby will become an obese child. The author of the study, Dr. Elsie Taveras, says that such rapid growth should alert doctors to the possibility that babies might be overfed or spending too much time in strollers and not crawling around.

title: Trailer: Uncharted 3
description: The action sequel game is for the Sony Playstation 3.

title: Study Debunks Operation to Prevent Strokes
description: An operation that doctors hoped would prevent strokes in people with poor circulation to the brain does not work, researchers are reporting. A $20 million study, paid for by the government, was cut short when it became apparent that the surgery was not helping patients who had complete blockages in one of their two carotid arteries, which run up either side of the neck and feed 80 percent of the brain.

title: Students Press Congress to Sustain Investment in Science
description: 5:23 p.m. | Updated A group of graduate students has posted a letter and video message to Congress aimed at sustaining federal investment in basic science in an era of cost-cutting and political paralysis and polarization. They are looking for other graduate students to sign on. The letter is at standwithscience.org. Heres their YouTube callout:

title: Cain Rejects Latest Allegations
description: November 8, 2011  Republican Presidential candidate Herman Cain more forcefully confronts the sexual harassment allegations that have roiled his campaign for over a week.

title: Video: Crosby and Nash at Zuccotti Park
description: Graham Nash and David Crosby lead the Zuccotti Park occupants in a chant of No More War.

title: 200 Years Later, France Claims a Missing Artwork
description: PARIS  A painting that vanished without explanation from a museum in southwestern France nearly 200 years ago is expected to return shortly to French hands after officials informed the owner of the work, currently on display in Paris, that he is not, to his surprise, the owner.

title: The Gun Lobby and Military Suicides
description: Of all of the lobbying organizations that feed off fear, and rely for their funding and power on dividing Americans, one of the worst is the National Rifle Association.

title: A Vintage Trove in South Beach
description: Patti Stoecker is a hoarder, the rarefied kind. In the 1980s, Ms. Stoecker, then a model, used to party all night at the Mudd Club, wearing, as often as not, one of her mothers silky old slips. By the early 90s, she had begun collecting her own 40s-era variations, amassing them by the score and tie-dyeing them on her stove top in Easter-egg hues. For a time she consigned her slinky designs to local secondhand shops, but before long she was selling them from her house, against a dreamy backdrop of mottled peach-tone walls.

title: Beep Beep
description: Ryan Avent shocks me:

title: A Second Accuser Goes Public Against Cain
description: Karen Kraushaar, one of the two women who settled sexual harassment claims against Herman Cain with the National Restaurant Association, spoke publicly for the first time on Tuesday about her allegations against him.

title: Japanese Company Develops Robot Guide Dog
description: Guide dogs for the blind could soon be out of a job.

title: To Stop Iran, Lean On China
description: Washington

title: Mad About Bike Lanes. In Both Senses of the Word.
description: Boy, theres a load of free-floating anger out there. So many of the readers who commented on my ArtsBeat post and critics notebook praising New York Citys new bike lanes pointed fingers  at bikers, pedestrians, drivers or politicians. (And yes, I promise, AJ Michel, to work hard to keep my journalistic distance from city officials and everyone else I cover. I appreciate your vigilance.)

title: Look of the Moment | Florence Welch
description: The Look: Golden. A dcollet lace mermaid dress with long sleeves and a Victorian collar is completely enchanting.

title: Would a Swiss Bank Mash-Up Work?
description: Everyone knows two wrongs dont make a right, but one banking analyst, Kian Abouhossein of JPMorgan Chase, thinks that two less-than-perfect investment banks could make a compelling whole.

title: Document: Taymors Spider-Man Lawsuit
description: Julie Taymor, a creator of the $75 million Broadway musical Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark, has filed suit against the shows producers over unpaid fees. Here is the lawsuit Ms. Taymors lawyer filed. The full news story about the lawsuit is here.

title: Sex Education: Don't Fear It, Use It
Well-Bred, and Flailing on the Rocks
description: The playwright A. R. Gurney has proved a steadfast cartographer of shrinking territory: upper-class white Anglo-Saxon Protestantism in decline. In works like The Dining Room, The Cocktail Hour and Ancestral Voices, he has examined that cultures customs, analyzed its adherents, assessed its challenges. You can debate whether WASPdom is truly dying, but if so, Mr. Gurney has spent his career taking measurements for the coffin.

title: Top Seeds in Womens Soccer: Duke, Stanford, Florida State, Wake Forest
description: Duke, Florida State and Wake Forest  all of the A.C.C.  are three of the four top seeds in the N.C.A.A. womens soccer championship tournament. Stanford of the Pac-12 is the other No. 1 seed.

title: Scene City: Glamours Women of the Year
description: Jennifer Lopez, Laura Bush, Tory Burch and others are honored at Carnegie Hall.

title: A Bird, a Plane, an Upside-Down Rhinoceros
description: If you do nothing else today, please look at these remarkable photos of the airlifting of a black rhino, part of a conservation program for endangered species.

title: Close Encounters of the Rocky Kind
description: 7:55 p.m. | Updated |Tonight is a good time to track NASAs @asteroidwatch Twitter account, which Ive held out as a great example of how social media can help agencies, or individuals, track misinformation and spread solid information on important subjects.

title: Qaddafis Ex-Prime Minister Ordered Extradited to Libya
description: A Tunisian appeals court on Tuesday approved the extradition of Libyas former prime minister, making him the first escaped member of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis felled government to be ordered returned home into Libyan custody since the revolution that officially ended last month.

title: The New Generation of Cooking Apps
description: A look at the Baking With Dorie and Professional Chef cooking apps.

title: Israeli Minister Stresses Military Readiness
description: JERUSALEM  With rising tensions over Irans nuclear program fanning Iranian fury toward Israel, Ehud Barak, the Israeli minister of defense, said that if the country was forced into a war, the casualties on the home front would not likely amount to more than 500, if that many, and that the state of Israel would not be destroyed.

title: At Zuccotti Park, a Sound of the 60s
description: Jenna Mandaglio swayed gently to the music, waving a hand-crafted sunflower in her right hand.

title: (Very) Young Voice, Filling an August Hall
description: Attention, fans of fairy tales: This is the story of how Jackie Evancho, 11, came to perform before a mostly full Avery Fisher Hall on Monday night, for a crowd whose average age was somewhere in the area of grandparent, sprinkled with a few dozen wide-eyed young girls in Sunday dresses.

title: Democrats Criticize Romney for Opposing Auto Bailout
description: When Mitt Romney arrives in Michigan for the latest Republican debate on Wednesday, the Democrats will have a message waiting for him  Hit the road, Mitt.

title: Tribute to the Man of Mame and Dolly
description: Broadway musical aficionados  a quarrelsome breed  could argue until the cows come home about which larger-than-life diva is the ultimate Jerry Herman Girl. The word girl, of course, doesnt begin to do justice to the ageless, fun-loving matriarchs who inspired shows like Hello Dolly! and Mame. These women are such irrepressible life forces that the world gravitates around them like planets orbiting the Sun.

title: Raising the Bayou
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Crosby & Nash Occupy Wall Street
description: David Crosby and Graham Nash played an acoustic set at the site of the Occupy Wall Street protests that included Teach Your Children Well.

title: Closing With Surprises and Some Stumbles
description: When the tap dancer Maurice Chestnut and his jazz-funk band quickly kicked into a groove on Sunday at the opening of the final program of this years Fall for Dance Festival at City Center, the show was immediately on the right foot.

title: Pictures of the Day: Italy and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Liberia, Italy, Brazil and Russia.

title: Somebodys Lying
description: Herman Cain just went all in.

title: Creating a Pantheon of Beloved Underdogs
description: Jonathan Lethems fat, hip and garrulous new essay collection, The Ecstasy of Influence, is self-consciously in the tradition of books like Norman Mailers Advertisements for Myself and John Updikes Hugging the Shore, brilliant grab-bag volumes that blended criticism, journalism and introspection. So it makes a kind of sense that Mr. Lethem debated, he tells us, calling this book either Advertisements for Norman Mailer or, even better, Shugging the Whore.

title: #OccupyWallSt Roundup, Day 53
description: A bomb scare near Zuccotti Park on Tuesday morning turned out to be a false alarm. [City Room]

title: Bob Costas Will Host Show on NBC Sports Network
description: The NBC Sports Groups overhaul of the Versus network will continue next year with Bob Costas hosting a monthly interview show and quarterly town hall meetings similar to the ones he held during the years worked at HBO Sports.

title: Perfect Lives, Reinterpreted
description: Varispeeds one-day production of Robert Ashleys video opera.

title: A Fresh Stamp on a Veteran Composers Work
description: For any composer who also serves as his or her own primary interpreter, the question of legacy eventually arises. What happens when an artist is no longer able or available to perform?

title: Music to the Ears of the City Reeling From 9/11
description: Shot in the tense autumn of 2001 and only recently completed, The Love We Make is one of the most chipper responses to tragedy you are ever likely to experience. While the 10th anniversary of Sept. 11 played out on a television schedule crammed with heart-wrenching memorials and remember whens, a couple of cable networks began showing this cheery ride-along with Paul McCartney and friends as they prepared for the Concert for New York City.

title: Study Clarifies the Energy Savings in Retrofitted Buildings
description: While the practice of retrofitting buildings with energy-conserving technology like efficient boilers, high-quality windows and compact fluorescent light bulbs has been around for years, data on whether these changes result in any real savings has been virtually nonexistent. Now, a new study shows that these relatively straightforward fixes can significantly reduce spending on fuel and electricity.

title: Reviewing Rouge et Blanc
description: You dont hear much about fusion cuisine anymore. For that, we can largely be grateful. You can understand the excitement, back in the 1980s, as chefs trained in the European traditions discovered the wonders of the various Asian cuisines. How could they restrain themselves from trying to fuse east and west into dazzling dishes highlighting cultural contrasts?

title: From Britain, the Sounds of a Century
description: Tenebrae, a 17-voice British choir founded 10 years ago by Nigel Short, a former member of the Kings Singers, is best known to American listeners through its recordings: about a dozen of its own (on the Signum Classics label) and a few notable collaborations with Colin Davis and the London Symphony Orchestra (on LSO Live).

title: How to Speak French-Vietnamese
description: PART joy, part conundrum, Rouge et Blanc defies expectations.

title: 20111108-lens-TP-brett
description: 20111108-lens-TP-brett

title: Roemer and Colbert, Not Coordinating, Together
description: The Colbert Report Get More: Colbert Report Full Episodes,Political Humor & Satire Blog,Video Archive

title: App Smart Extra: Word Games
description: In last weeks App Smart column, I let the experts lead me toward a handful of great mobile games that I had somehow overlooked in recent years.

title: Health Law Survives Test in Court of Appeals
description: A federal appeals court in Washington upheld the Obama administrations health care law on Tuesday in a decision written by a prominent conservative jurist.

title: Week 9 Film Review: Palmer vs. Tebow
description: A closer look at Week 9, with the benefit of film analysis:

title: In a Queens Enclave, Often Shopping in Vain
description: When Nick Bate and his wife decided they wanted to rent an affordable apartment with a third bedroom, they looked across the East River from their Manhattan home to Hunters Point in Long Island City, Queens.

title: Pairing Bartok With Haydn
description: Turnover among musicians in longstanding ensembles is inevitable. Some, like the Guarneri String Quartet, simply disband. The esteemed Tokyo String Quartet  founded at the Juilliard School in 1969 by four Japanese musicians who studied together in Tokyo  will soon have none of its original members. The violist, Kazuhide Isomura, a founding member, and the second violinist, Kikuei Ikeda, who joined in 1974, recently announced that they would retire from the quartet in June 2013.

title: Rajaratnam Ordered to Pay $92.8 Million Penalty
description: A federal judge on Tuesday ordered the convicted hedge fund titan Raj Rajaratnam to pay a $92.8 million penalty, the largest ever assessed against a person in a Securities and Exchange Commission insider trading case.

title: The Hardening of Easy Dave
description: David Stern was not always fully sold on going the distance as the entrepreneurial shepherd of professional basketball, as the commissioner of the N.B.A.

title: All Together, Brava!
description: AMONG the women who were honored at Glamours annual Women of the Year awards on Monday night, Jennifer Lopez made the most memorable entrance, twice.

title: Facebook Says It Provides a Big Boost to Digital-Music Sites
description: How much have the new features that Facebook introduced in September helped digital-music services like Spotify, MOG and Slacker? According to Facebook, quite a bit. But some of those companies are still waiting for the new features to take effect.

title: A Glimpse Into North Korea
description: The Associated Press photographer David Guttenfelder takes a rare look at the lives of North Koreans.

title: N.B.A. Union Signals a Shift That May End the Lockout
description: The path to an N.B.A. labor deal, and the end to a 131-day lockout, came into sharper focus Tuesday, with the players signaling for the first time that they would accept the leagues proposed 50-50 split of revenues.

title: Baking With Dorie: Bundt Cake Icing
description: In a video from her new app, the baking expert Dorie Greenspan makes icing for a bundt cake.

title: The Professional Chef: Fresh Pasta
description: A video on how to make fresh pasta from the Professional Chef app.

title: Regulators Say Social Network Violated Child Privacy Law
description: Skid-e-Kids describes itself as a Facebook for children ages 7 to 14. It allows them to watch age-appropriate movies and socialize with their friends, and it stipulates that parents are in charge.

title: People Who Mistook Life for a Museum, and Vice Versa
description: The Performa biennial, now in full outrageously outsize swing across the city, is known for its big events: parties and premieres that, as is usually the case in the arts, have far more flash than substance.

title: The Serious Eats Book, Stuffed to the Cover
description: Its hard to know which is more astonishing, the amount of food stuffed into the 368 pages of Serious Eats by Ed Levine and the editors of Serious Eats (Clarkson Potter, $27.99 paperback), or its comprehensive coverage. It digs with gusto into whats mostly everyday fare across the country, deconstructing breakfast with sections on eggs, pancakes, breakfast sandwiches and the like, then moving on to burgers, pizza, sandwiches and hot dogs, barbecue, fried things, street food (carts and trucks) and baked goods. Venerable spots like Neptune Oyster bar in Boston and Faiccos Pork Store in New York share the pages with newer places, including Delancey, a pizzeria in Seattle. Youll find hash-slingers and locavore chefs, a White Castle burger as well as the finesse of breakfast at Boulettes Larder in San Francisco. Guides to styles of burgers, pizzas, hot dogs, lobster rolls and the like, and how to conquer some of these delicacies at home are included. I plan to tear out the essential seven-page directory of places listed in the book, and make several photocopies, to keep in the car and with my travel stuff.

title: A Spice Infuser for Simmering
description: This high-tech replacement for a length of cheesecloth can enclose herbs and whole spices to season a pot of stock, soup, stew, fruit simmering in wine or even holiday glogg. The perforated stainless steel orb, about the size of a tennis ball, has an opening for its snap-on top, a jaunty silicone cap sporting a tiny pom-pom so it can actually hang over the edge of the pan. It can withstand temperatures up to 240 degrees, well above boiling. And thinking ahead, is there a better stocking stuffer for a cook?

title: The Patriots Waive Haynesworth, Once a Defensive Star
description: It sounded like an experiment from an alternate football universe from the moment it happened late this summer: Albert Haynesworth, whose career has been marked by flashes of pass-rushing brilliance interrupting long stretches of uninterest and minimal effort, traded to the New England Patriots?

title: The New Generation of Cooking Apps
description: A look at the Baking With Dorie and Professional Chef cooking apps.

title: Are Cookbooks Obsolete?
description: FOR many cooks, the pleasure of Thanksgiving is in the planning. In early November, the recipe folders come out, along with dreams of learning to perfect a lattice pie crust, and the cookbooks covered with splatters and sticky notes that evoke holidays past.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,475 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,815 who have died as part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: City Plans to Move a School and Start a New One in East New York
Hurricanes Staal Reflects on Check That Injured Brother
description: NEWARK  Eric Staal, the Carolina Hurricanes captain and a winner of the Stanley Cup and an Olympic gold medal, is off to the worst start of his career, and one of the worst starts endured by any N.H.L. player this season. But he is sure that guilt is not behind it.

title: Media Decoder: Facebooks Boost to Digital-Music Sites
description: How much have the new features that Facebook introduced in September helped digital-music services like Spotify, MOG and Slacker? According to Facebook, quite a bit. But some of those companies are still waiting for the new features to take effect. Read more

title: Index Ventures Raises $700 Million Growth Fund
description: The venture capital firm Index Ventures has raised 500 million euros ($692 million) for a new fund that will focus on later-stage investments.

title: For Better Stuffing and Pie, Get Cracking
description: AFTER my uncle Sheldon moved to Dallas, he returned to Brooklyn for a visit flaunting a bolo tie, a splashy pair of cowboy boots and a nascent drawl.

title: To Raise Cash, Restaurants Turn to the Crowd
description: AARON LEFKOVE was struggling to raise close to $200,000 to open a New England-style clam shack in a Gowanus, Brooklyn, storefront.

title: Red Bulls: The View From the Back Line
description: LITTLE FALLS, N.J.  Tim Ream could be a poster boy for the Red Bulls season gone awry.

title: Getting the Crowd on Board the Flight, and Off
description: To the Editor:

title: Heavy D, Smooth-Talking Hip-Hop Star, Dies at 44
description: Heavy D, the smooth-talking and cheerful rapper who billed himself as the overweight lover M.C., died in Los Angeles on Tuesday. He was 44.

title: On War and Redemption
description: When I returned from Afghanistan this past spring, a civilian friend asked, Is it good to be back? It was the first time someone had asked, and I answered honestly. But I wont do that again. We werent ready for that conversation. Instead, when people ask, I make it easy for everyone by responding, Its fine. Thats a lie, though. Its not fine.

title: Q&A: YouTubes Rules for Video
description: Q.

title: In Videos, Glimpses of a Besieged Syrian City
description: Updated | Wednesday | 12:36 p.m. | As my colleague Nada Bakri reports, Syrian activists said, After six days of near-continuous bombing, the army and security forces sought Tuesday to tighten their grip on parts of Homs, in central Syria near the Lebanese border.

title: Court Casts a Wary Eye on Tracking by GPS
description: WASHINGTON  In an argument studded with references to George Orwells 1984 and the possibility that rapid advances in technology would soon allow the government to monitor everyones movements, the Supreme Court on Tuesday struggled to articulate how the Fourth Amendments ban on unreasonable searches and seizures should apply to the tracking of cars using GPS devices. The fit between 18th-century principles and 21st-century surveillance seemed to leave several justices frustrated.

title: Haiti: Group Seeks $250 Million From U.N. Over Cholera Epidemic
description: A human rights group filed claims on Tuesday seeking at least $250 million in damages from the United Nations and its peacekeeping force in Haiti on behalf of 5,000 cholera victims. The group, the Institute for Justice and Democracy in Haiti, accuses the peacekeeping force, known as Minustah, of inadequate troop screening and improper sanitation that, the group said, had caused Haitis cholera epidemic. More than 6,600 people have died and nearly a half-million more have been sickened since the cholera outbreak began in October 2010. The group also seeks establishment of a forum to hear its claims, which were filed with Minustahs claims office in Port-au-Prince. United Nations peacekeeping missions generally have immunity from actions in national courts. A spokesman for the United Nations Department of Peacekeeping Operations said the agency would have no comment until it had studied the claim.

title: Questions About the Safety of Fracking
description: To the Editor:

title: Amid Anger Over Idea of Charging Tuition, an Inquiry Is Urged on Cooper Unions Finances
description: As Cooper Union officials try to quell the uproar over news that the college may start to charge tuition, some students, alumni, faculty members and college trustees are advocating an inquiry into how the school got into such serious financial trouble.

title: Venezuela: Chvez to Hold Cancer Summit for Latin Leaders
description: President Hugo Chvez said he would host a cancer summit meeting in early 2012 for South American leaders who, like himself, have been treated for the disease. Mr. Chvez, left, who said he had surgery in June to remove a malignant tumor, said he would invite President Dilma Rousseff of Brazil; her predecessor, Luiz Incio Lula da Silva, who began treatment for throat cancer late last month; and President Fernando Lugo of Paraguay. There will be no cancer or force that can hold us back because Latin America is experiencing a rebirth, Mr. Chvez told Venezuelan state television on Sunday. He said would wait to hold the summit meeting until after Mr. da Silva completed his chemotherapy. After several rounds of chemotherapy, mostly in Cuba, Mr. Chvez, 57, said last month that he was cancer-free. Ms. Rousseff, 63, received a diagnosis of lymphatic cancer in 2009 before her election, and doctors have said she is currently free of cancer. Mr. Lugo, 60, who was found to have lymphatic cancer in August 2010, has undergone treatment in Brazil and has also been declared cancer-free.

title: In Defense of Corzine: A Former Aide Speaks Out
description: To the Editor:

title: Cooper Unions Finances
description: To the Editor:

title: Bloggingheads: Occupy and Violence
description: Adam Serwer, left, of Mother Jones and Katherine Mangu-Ward of Reason debate about violent protesters and the Occupy movement.

title: Clinton Aims for AIDS-Free Generation
description: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton on Tuesday called on the United States and other countries to use new scientific discoveries to create an AIDS-free generation in the world, but offered no clues about where the money would come from to finance that inspirational and costly vision.

title: Jury Begins Weighing a Legislators Fate
description: A federal jury in Manhattan ended its first afternoon of deliberations on Tuesday in the corruption trial of William F. Boyland Jr., a Democratic assemblyman from Brooklyn, by reporting in a note to the judge that it was at an impasse.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Eating With a Theme

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening

title: Questions on Sandusky Are Wrapped in a 2005 Mystery
description: One of the questions surrounding the sex-abuse case against Jerry Sandusky is why a former district attorney chose not to prosecute the then-Penn State assistant coach in 1998 after reports surfaced that he had inappropriate interactions with a boy.

title: Birreria
description: 200 Fifth Avenue (23rd Street); (212) 937-8910; eatalyny.com/eat/birreria.

title: A Multigenerational Home
description: A living arrangement that eases financial burdens in tough economic times.

title: Three Generations, Two Comfy Homes a Few Steps Apart
description: ON a recent Sunday evening, Wanda Urbanska and her family gathered around the table to catch up over cabbage and potato pierogies. Her 89-year-old mother, a retired college professor, sat across from Henry, her 14-year-old grandson, whose blue T-shirt matched the swaths of color in his hair. He told the women about the rave he attended the night before, where he jumped up and down for three hours.

title: Election Day, Nov. 8, 2011
description: Voters were to decide on contentious ballot measures in Ohio and Mississippi.

title: Co-Producer for Oscar Telecast Resigns
description: LOS ANGELES  Brett Ratner on Tuesday abruptly resigned as the co-producer of next years Oscar broadcast, after he used an anti-gay slur at a public event and made frank sexual remarks on Howard Sterns radio show.

title: Bien Cuit
description: 120 Smith Street, Boerum Hill, Brooklyn; (718) 852-0200; biencuit.com.

title: James Murdoch to Face More Questioning by Lawmakers
description: LONDON  James Murdoch may have embarrassing questions to answer when he returns to Westminster on Thursday to testify before a parliamentary committee investigating the phone hacking scandal that has engulfed the News Corporation. Documents released since his first round of testimony in July have cast doubt on his version of events, while fresh revelations have spilled out about his companys questionable practices.

title: A Dream of Homeownership, Still Beyond Reach
description: LIKE many young married people, Steve and Logan Kinney dream of owning a home. So after several years of diligent saving, the couple, both teachers, scoured the listings in Boerum Hill, the leafy Brooklyn neighborhood where they rented. But before long, they realized that home ownership would require living within the four walls of a studio. And even that was a stretch.

title: Pandit Proposes Benchmark for Comparing Banks Risks
description: Walter B. Wriston, the vaunted former chairman of Citibank, famously said that risk was a four-letter word. Vikram S. Pandit, chief executive of the larger successor organization, Citigroup, reckons it has nine letters: benchmark.

title: Report Undercuts Irans Defense on Nuclear Effort
description: WASHINGTON  Even as Iran on Tuesday angrily dismissed a new United Nations report on its nuclear ambitions as an American fabrication and a pretext for military action, some analysts said the reports wealth of data could complicate efforts by Iran and its allies to defend the nuclear program as peaceful.

title: They Walked Away, and Theyre Glad They Did
description: JON WITTENBERG and Bill Sawyer have never met. One lives in Walnut Creek, Calif., the other in Wilsonville, Ore. But if they did, the conversation might be littered with exclamations like, Thats exactly what happened to me!

title: Grand Experiment Meets an Inglorious End
description: So this is how the Grand Experiment  as Joe Paterno self-righteously called his campaign to prove that football excellence and academic integrity could coexist  ends: the most respected coach in the history of college football, maybe even all of college sports, is brought down by a sexual abuse scandal whose scope we are surely just starting to grasp. (Investigators have counted eight victims; there could well be dozens more.)

title: Moving to U.S. and Amassing a Fortune, No English Needed
description: More than 40 years after arriving in New York from Mexico uneducated and broke, Felix Sanchez de la Vega Guzman still can barely speak English. Ask him a question, and he will respond with a few halting phrases and an apologetic smile before shifting back to the comfort of Spanish.

title: Despite Critics, Mortgage Deduction Resists Change
description: IF you ask most people about the possibility of reducing or eliminating the tax deduction for interest on home mortgages, you will generally hear the same things that you would if you suggested altering Social Security benefits.

title: Letting the Banks Off Easy
description: The banks want California, and the Obama administration hopes they can get it.

title: Palestinian Bid for U.N. Membership Faces Near-Certain Defeat
description: The Palestinian bid to become a full member of the United Nations headed toward certain failure on Tuesday after the Security Councils membership committee deadlocked on the issue, according to a draft report by the committee.

title: The Secret Farm Bill
description: The Republican-manufactured budget crisis of this past summer  remember?  resulted in a solution thats hijacking what little representative democratic process we have left. Equally sad is that the so-called supercommittee  charged with creating an outline for reducing the deficit by $1.2 trillion over 10 years  may preclude full discussion of the farm bill.

title: Work Program for Foreign Students Will Not Expand During Review
description: The State Department will limit a popular cultural exchange program for foreign university students to its current size of about 100,000 students a year, a senior agency official said Tuesday.

title: For Duquette, a Chance and a Challenge
description: We know from Moneyball that a major league general manager can be a compelling lead character for a film. So consider this script outline.

title: Penn States Culpability
description: The sex-abuse scandal that has threatened the tenure of Pennsylvania State Universitys legendary football coach, Joe Paterno, and led to criminal charges against two high-level administrators offers a tragic example of the willful blindness that sets in when colleges worship sports.

title: How to Toast Nuts
description: In this weeks column, I write about finding the freshest nuts, which means, for the most part, buying them raw and toasting them yourself.

title: Estimating Expenses Before Buying Your First Home
description: If you are like most people embarking on their search for a first home, you will do a certain amount of math. You will look at your current budget, size up your down payment and figure out what sort of monthly mortgage payment you may be able to afford.

title: Cheerios Cheer Commercial
description: A promotion by Cheerios to bring cheer to military families and support the United Service Organizations is the subject of a commercial.

title: Acknowledging the Veterans on Their Day in the Limelight
description: FOR Veterans Day 2011, Madison Avenue will seem redder, whiter and bluer than it has in a long time.

title: After Long Ordeal, a Homeowner Can Stay Home
description: FOR two years, Althea Girard-Blakey toted a black canvas bag when she went to work, full of the enormous collection of papers documenting her request for a mortgage modification.

title: Wealthy Buyers Fuel Market for Second Homes
description: FAIGIE RICHMAN used to tell everyone that she never wanted to live in Florida. She enjoyed visiting her husbands family in Boca Raton, but the lifestyle simply did not suit her. She didnt play golf or tennis and had no desire to learn either. And she and her husband already owned a second home, on a pond in Rhode Island, that their three children loved.

title: Panel Emphasizes Safety in Digitization of Health Records
description: Poorly designed, hard-to-use computerized health records are a threat to patient safety, and an independent agency should be set up to investigate injuries and deaths linked to health information technology, according to a federal study released Tuesday.

title: Paterno, the King of Pennsylvania, Until Now
description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa.  It is hard to fully capture the stature and impact of Joe Paterno.

title: How a Financial Pro Lost His House
description: ONE night a few years ago, when the value of our home had collapsed, our debt was out of control and my financial planning business was shaky, I went to take out the trash.

title: Mom to N.B.A.: Play Ball!
description: I HAVE never followed basketball. Personally, I dont really care what happens in these talks the owners and players are having. I will never turn on the TV to watch a game. Im sure I wouldnt even know what team was in the playoffs when that time came. Im not the N.B.A.s audience. No money to be made off of me. My interests lie elsewhere.

title: Report on Nuclear Efforts Draws a Muted Response From the White House
description: WASHINGTON  When American intelligence agencies concluded four years ago that Iran had suspended efforts to build a nuclear weapon in 2003, the findings undercut the Bush administrations arguments for harsher international sanctions or even, from its more hawkish quarters, military intervention.

title: Lottery Numbers
A Ticket-Fixing Scandal and a Charge That Needed Dropping
description: By any measure, the arrest of Samantha Zucker seemed absurd: a 21-year-old college student, she and a friend wandered into Riverside Park after it had closed for the night, and she wound up being charged with trespassing. Because she did not have identification with her, the police did not issue her a summons. Instead she was arrested and held for 36 hours.

title: Syria and the Arab League
description: President Bashar al-Assad of Syria has made a mockery of the Arab League peace initiative. Since he signed the document, his security forces have mercilessly attacked the city of Homs with heavy weapons, hunted down army defectors and killed scores of pro-democracy protesters. The United Nations says 3,500 protesters have been killed in the crackdown on the popular uprising.

title: Bid to Alter Pension Plans Is Criticized
description: Two of New York Citys top labor leaders voiced anger on Tuesday about the agreement by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Comptroller John C. Liu to overhaul the citys pension plans.

title: Outsourcing Is Not (Always) Evil
description: On Friday, I wrote about two social enterprises  Samasource and Digital Divide Data  that extend computer-based employment to people with modest educations in developing countries. The strategy of harnessing the Internet to bring low-cost data management jobs to remote and impoverished communities has been called impact sourcing. Some estimate that the market for these services, $4.5 billion today, could rise to $20 billion by 2015, providing jobs to 780,000 people (pdf, p.14).

title: 78s, Photos, Even Sweat From Brow of a Legend
description: Another fragment of Louis Armstrongs legacy is back where it belongs.

title: Shares Dive as Olympus Scrambles for Answers
description: From the board room to the trading floor, Olympus struggled on Tuesday to contain a crisis that erupted after its admission that it had used $1 billion in payments to cover up losses on investments.

title: New From the Injured Rib of a Mastodon
description: Just when did humans first appear in North America? For years, scientists based that calculation on stone tools found in the 1930s near Clovis, N.M. They suggest, through radiocarbon dating, a culture that existed 13,000 years ago. But those weapons were too late to explain the hunting out of megafauna, like mastodons, near the end of the Pleistocene era. There was either a Clovis blitzkrieg,  a swift, cataclysmic killing by humans  or there were hunters living long before the Clovis tools were made.

title: Justices Rebuke a New Orleans Prosecutor
description: WASHINGTON  Donna R. Andrieu, an assistant district attorney in New Orleans, had the unenviable task at the Supreme Court on Tuesday of defending her offices conduct in withholding evidence from a criminal defendant. She made the least of it.

title: A Long-Awaited Apology for Shiites, but the Wounds Run Deep
description: BAGHDAD  As the United States ends its second war in Iraq, the legacy of the first one still haunts. The memory of the first President Bushs urging Iraqi Shiites to rebel against the government in 1991, and standing by as thousands were slaughtered, is a tragic counternarrative to the revolutions that have swept the Middle East and a torment that even now complicates relations between the countries.

title: Sleeping at Work to Keep Her Home
description: The view outside the train window never changes, save for the tint, or total absence, of the leaves across the Hudson River.

title: At Scene of Wall St. Protest, Rising Concerns About Crime
description: The arrest of a Crown Heights man last week on charges of sexually assaulting a protesterat Zuccotti Park added to an already raucous public discussion of lawlessness at the site, where a revolving group of demonstrators has been camped for nearly eight weeks. Stories of crimes and dangerous behavior, mostly anecdotal, have been used as fuel by those who say the protesters must go.

title: Study Finds Homeless Veterans Stay Homeless Longer Than Others
description: Once veterans become homeless, they are likely to remain homeless longer than non-veterans. And they are also more likely to report having serious health problems, according to a new report by an advocacy group, the 100,000 Homes Campaign.

title: Two Peas in a Pod
description: Goa, India

title: Wednesday: Call of a Siren
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  As we approach the time of year where some people remember whether there was enough room at the inn for a very special family, Paula Gamache returns to remind us that, while there might not be room at the inn for everyone, we can always fit the INN into other things. Thats a pretty neat trick, and keeping the accommodations for us is the INNKEEPER, smack in the middle of the grid at 36 Across.

title: What the Mortgage Interest Deduction Is Worth
description: Heres what a married couple, filing their taxes jointly, would save each year in federal income taxes depending on how much they earn, the size of their mortgage and the interest rate they are paying on a 30-year interest-only loan. The analysis uses interest-only loans to keep the principal and interest consistent through the year; it assumes no other itemized deductions for things like state income taxes, real estate taxes or charitable contributions.

title: A Defiant Cain, Newly Serious, Goes for Broke
description: It has been 20 years since Anita Hill accused Clarence Thomas of sexual harassment on live television and transfixed the nation. People are no longer as shocked, but they can still be tantalized by high-stakes brinkmanship. On Tuesday, viewers watched Herman Cain try to tamp down a scandal that has spread from he said she said to he said they said.

title: Struggling Actress Who Wields Script and Whip
description: Lightning flashes intermittently throughout Venus in Fur, the spooky sex comedy by David Ives that sizzled open on Broadway at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater on Tuesday night. But youre not really likely to notice. The flickering of those stage lights barely registers beside the incandescent Nina Arianda, the sensational young actress recreating the role that made her a name to watch when she first starred in the play Off Broadway. Portraying an actress giving the audition of a lifetime, Ms. Arianda is giving the first must-see performance of the Broadway season, a bravura turn that burns so brightly you can almost feel the heat on your face.

title: A Fool, His King and the Madness That Engulfs Them
description: Bill Irwin pops up like a daffodil in February amid the gray slush of the Public Theaters King Lear, which opened on Tuesday night, starring Sam Waterston and directed by James Macdonald. The image of a single bright flower in a bleak landscape comes to mind not just because Mr. Irwin is wearing a blazing yellow Pierrot outfit.

title: Ohio Turns Back a Law Limiting Unions Rights
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  A year after Republicans swept legislatures across the country, voters in Ohio delivered their verdict Tuesday on a centerpiece of the conservative legislative agenda, striking down a law that restricted public workers rights to bargain collectively.

title: Ex-Fugitive Is Suspected of New Plot
description: An inmate who led hundreds of police officers and state troopers through the woods of western New York in the summer of 2006 after escaping from jail using a can opener is once again proving to be a far-from-model prisoner.

title: Report Faults Border Patrol on Bus and Train Searches
description: For years, Border Patrol agents have been boarding domestic trains and buses in upstate New York, often many miles from the Canadian border, inspecting passengers IDs and arresting illegal immigrants.

title: Occupy Movement Inspires Unions to Embrace Bold Tactics
description: Organized labors early flirtation with Occupy Wall Street is starting to get serious.

title: Trouble Beside the Bay
description: Oakland, Calif.

title: U.S. Wont Investigate Former S.E.C. Lawyer Over His Madoff Ties
description: The Justice Department has decided not to pursue an investigation into the role played by a former top lawyer at the Securities and Exchange Commission in the calculation of payouts to victims of Bernard L. Madoffs Ponzi scheme.

title: Worker Dies After Being Rescued From Building Collapse in Brooklyn
description: Firefighters frantically dug through the debris of a five-story apartment building in Brooklyn that collapsed during construction on Tuesday, rescuing five workers from shards of corrugated metal that fell under the weight of freshly poured concrete. One of those workers later died, the Fire Department said.

title: Euro Crisiss Enabler: The Central Bank
description: THE escalating debt crisis in Europe has claimed the political career of one prime minister, George A. Papandreou of Greece, and threatened that of another, Silvio Berlusconi of Italy. Despite popular resistance, governments are racing to stay ahead of the bond markets by slashing their budgets. The drama of meetings, proposals, counterproposals and popular unrest seems destined to end in tragedy.

title: Paterno Speaks to Students at His House
description: Although his news conference Tuesday was canceled at the last minute, Penn State Coach Joe Paterno spoke to students who had gathered outside his home in State College, Pa., around 6 p.m.

title: Learning to Save Like the Japanese
Two Presidents Sharing a Moment
description: After another tense day of politicking and diplomacy, Derek Fisher pushed through a crowded hotel corridor and found himself staring at a master in the field. Bill Clinton smiled and quickly enveloped him in a hug  two Arkansas-born presidents sharing a fantastic moment of serendipity.

title: Further Tests Fail to Detect Salmon Virus
description: SEATTLE  Canadian fisheries and food safety officials said Tuesday that new government tests showed no evidence of a deadly salmon virus in fish that advocates for wild salmon reported last month contained traces of the virus.

title: Personal Foul at Penn State
description: WASHINGTON

title: Recuperating St. Johns Coach Stays Connected
description: As a pregame video played above center court at Carnesecca Arena on Monday night, the members of the St. Johns mens basketball team twisted their necks and gawked. For all but one of them, it was their first Division I basketball game. They needed somewhere to turn.

title: Deficit Panel Members Seeking to Avoid Blame
description: WASHINGTON  Members of a Congressional panel on deficit reduction are no longer trying just to solve the nations fiscal problems. Some are desperately trying to avoid blame for the possible collapse of a process concocted by Senate leaders to break an impasse between those who want to raise taxes and those who would prefer to cut spending by focusing on entitlement programs.

title: U.S. to Open New Areas to Offshore Drilling
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Tuesday announced its proposed five-year plan for offshore oil drilling, which calls for opening new areas in the Gulf of Mexico and Alaska but bars development along the East and West Coasts.

title: Word of the Day | chisel
description: chisel \chi-zl\ noun and verb

title: After the Breeders Cup, Fitting Finales
description: It didnt take but a day or so and the announcements of retirements of Breeders Cup contenders began to hit the Internet and social media.

title: Hal Kanter, a Creator of Julia Series on TV, Dies at 92
description: Hal Kanter, an Emmy-winning comedy writer, director and producer known for creating Julia, the first television series to center on the life of a black professional woman, died on Sunday in Encino, Calif. He was 92.

title: Margaret Field, TV Actress, Dies at 89
description: Margaret Field, an actress who appeared in countless television shows in the 1950s and 60s and who was the mother of the Academy Award winner Sally Field, died on Sunday at her home in Malibu, Calif. She was 89.

title: Who Believes Herman Cain?
description: I saw that. I saw you grimace when you read Herman Cains name in yet another headline. (Well, at least I imagined it.) Relax. This is about a narrow subject: conflicting poll results from major polling groups on who does or doesnt believe the allegations against him. All my numbers nerds say, Yeah!

title: David Ivess Sexy Comedy, Venus in Fur.
description: David Ivess Sexy Comedy, Venus in Fur.

title: After Drab Season, Red Bulls Regroup
description: LITTLE FALLS, N.J.  The Red Bulls season ended where they wanted it to end  Home Depot Center in Carson, Calif.  but not when they wanted to end it  Nov. 20, the date of the M.L.S. championship game.

title: The Washington Report with David Sanger and Kerry Nolan
description: The Washington Report with David Sanger and Kerry Nolan

title: Postwar and Contemporary Artworks Draw Record Prices at Christies
description: The worlds financial markets may be in turmoil, but for nearly three hours on Tuesday night the collectors and dealers at Christies overflowing salesroom seemed to be focused only on the price of art. People would rather have art than gold or paper, suggested the Los Angeles financier Eli Broad.

title: Corrections: November 9
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: How the Richards Family Lost Its Home
description: A personal financial planner, Carl Richards, got caught in the housing bubble.

title: My Parents Were Home-Schooling Anarchists
description: Tired of the constraints of the 40-hour workweek, my father, in 1972, quit his job in publishing. My parents were in their early 30s, and they had four children under 7. But we still wanted to explore the world, my father recalled recently. They bought six one-way tickets to Europe, leaving only a laughable $3,000 to subsist on. Young and idealistic, they thought they could easily educate us along the way. Life itself would become a portable classroom.

title: Aging Well Through Exercise
description: Is physical frailty inevitable as we grow older? That question preoccupies scientists and the middle-aged, particularly when they become the same people. Until recently, the evidence was disheartening. A large number of studies in the past few years showed that after age 40, people typically lose 8 percent or more of their muscle mass each decade, a process that accelerates significantly after age 70. Less muscle mass generally means less strength, mobility and among the elderly, independence. It also has been linked with premature mortality.

title: F.C.C. Push to Expand Net Access Gains Help
description: To sign up some of the estimated 100 million Americans who are not online, the Federal Communications Commission and private providers are trying to make broadband Internet access both less expensive and more valuable.

title: Gingrich Rises in Polls But Has Major Obstacles to Nomination
description: I forget whether I posted something on Twitter to this effect or simply kept the thought to myself, but there was a point in time at which I would have given Newt Gingrich not more than a 1-in-1,000 chance of winning the Republican nomination.

title: Democrats Expand Their Hold on New Jersey Legislature, Despite Christies Efforts
description: Gov. Chris Christie put his popularity, fund-raising clout and boasts of reining in government to work for his fellow Republicans in New Jerseys legislative elections on Tuesday, but he came up empty, as Democrats added slightly to their hold on power.

title: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Wednesday
description: The Municipal Corporation of Delhi overpaid 150 employees, costing taxpayers about $2 million, according to an enquiry conducted by the agencys chief auditor (Hindustan Times). R.K. Jain, the deputy chief auditor, is seeking recovery of the amount overpaid to the employees, who are all vaccination staff members. Recovery may be difficult though, as almost 30 of the employees have already retired.Uttar Pradesh Chief Minister Mayawati is likely to announce the reorganization of her sprawling state, in a move that her supporters see as a pre-election master stroke. The Times of India reports that Mayawati is planning to carve four new states out of Uttar Pradesh, the countrys biggest state, citing sources from her party. The state remains unwieldy even after the hilly region was sliced off to form Uttarakhand.

title: Bellone, a Democrat, Elected Suffolk Executive
description: The Democratic Party scored a pivotal victory on Tuesday as Steve Bellone was elected Suffolk County executive, enhancing the partys standing on Long Island and giving Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo a prominent new ally in the New York City suburbs.

title: NYT Front Page for 11/09/2011
description: NYT Front Page for 11/09/2011

title: A Start-Up Offers Help With Advertising on Facebook
description: Just as Google spawned hundreds of thousands of experts in picking the right keywords for search ads, social networks have spawned a new industry of people with expertise in social networking ads.

title: The Developing World, Leading on Climate Change?
description: In what may turn out to be one of the abiding ironies of global geopolitics, leadership on climate change seems to have suddenly passed from the developed to the developing world, as has public anxiety about the damaging effects of a changing climate.As recently as the Copenhagen summit in late 2009, the West blamed large developing countries such as China and India for scuppering the chances of a grand agreement to curb the emission of greenhouse gases. Poor developing countries argued they needed the right to pollute in order to catch up to the West in terms of economic development, while the rich nations clucked that the world could ill afford more carbon emissions.On the flip side, at the Cancun summit a year later, Indias then environment minister, Jairam Ramesh, was pilloried in the domestic press, and accused, by his own admission, of caving in to the United States in the final near-consensus plan that was agreed.

title: Gay Rights, Homophobic Wrongs
description: JOHANNESBURG  On April 28, 2008, the partially clothed body of Eudy Simelane was found in a ditch in Kwa Thema, a black township near Johannesburg. A national soccer star and a well-known lesbian human rights activist, she had been beaten up, gang-raped and stabbed 25 times in the face, chest and legs  even under the feet. This past April, in a case remarkably similar, the body of another lesbian was found in an alley in Kwa Thema. Noxolo Nogwazas head had been bashed to a pulp. Her eyeballs were found outside their sockets.

title: Nov. 9, 1965 | Northeast Is Hit by Blackout
description: On Nov. 9, 1965, at 5:27 p.m., a blackout occurred as several Northeastern states and parts of Canada were hit by a series of power failures lasting as long as 13 hours. The blackout covered 80,000 miles and affected more than 30 million people.

title: HSBC Warns of Challenges Even as Profit Rises 66%
description: 8:30 a.m. | Updated

title: Inside the C.B.I. (Well, the Building, Anyway)
description: The 5,000 employees of the Central Bureau of Investigation, Indias anti-corruption agency, seem to have an ever-expanding portfolio of high-profilecases. The agencys investigations run the gamut from the illegal mining case in the Bellary district of Karnataka state, to the tumultuous 2G spectrum allocation scam, to a new probe in the airline industry.For more than three decades the C.B.I. headquarters sat nestled next to the ministries it sometimes targeted, in the North Block of the government secretariat, a sandstone labyrinth of offices built during the British Raj era. But this April, the C.B.I. moved into a swanky, modern 11-story glass building, modeled after the Interpol headquarters in Lyons, France. The building houses 2,000 employees, and looks more like a multinational companys headquarters than a typical Delhi government office.

title: News Quiz | Nov. 9, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: China to Join Effort to Patrol Mekong River
description: BEIJING  China announced on Wednesday that it would join its southeastern neighbors to conduct police patrols on the Mekong River, after the killings last month of 11 Chinese crewmen in an area plagued by drug smuggling.

title: No Interim Government as Greek Disarray Goes On
description: ATHENS  Prime Minister George A. Papandreou went on national television on Wednesday evening to announce that a new interim government had been formed.

title: Its Not Just About the Millionaires
description: This election is about stark differences on economic policy, but one of the few fiscal issues on which Democrats and Republicans agree  surprisingly  is how to tax corporations. Every Republican presidential candidate, and even the guy who currently has the job theyre after, wants to lower rates. Raising them, or even maintaining them, might satisfy the anti-corporate angst of protesters and populists, but it wont come anywhere near paying off our debt.

title: 515, London Salon, Offers Lectures Short and Sweet
description: Since the early 19th century, when throngs of carriages clogging the road to the Royal Institution prompted the creation of Londons first one-way street, public lectures have never really gone out of fashion in the British capital. The latest incarnation is 515, a lecture series thats tuned this London tradition to the staccato attention spans of the Twitter generation.

title: Gilad Shalit and the Rising Price of an Israeli Life
description: On the afternoon of June 27, 1976, Palestinian and German terrorists hijacked an Air France flight originating from Israel and directed it eventually to Entebbe Airport in Uganda, where most of the non-Israelis on board were immediately released. More than 100 hostages remained, 83 of whom were Israeli. They were held for the next six days, until an elite team of Israel Defense Force commandos freed them in the famous raid known as Operation Entebbe. The name of the mission became synonymous with Israels refusal to give in to the demands of terrorists and its willingness to go to extraordinary lengths, and risk many lives, to free Israeli hostages.

title: Helping the People Beyond the Pain
description: Donna Ferrato started out photographing pleasure. She ended up confronting pain.

title: How Colleges Can Retain Science Majors
description: WHAT is STEM?WHAT is the math-science death march, according to David E. Goldberg, an emeritus engineering professor?

title: Test Yourself | Math, Nov. 9, 2011
description: Test your math skills with this question created by Bobson Wong at Math for America from the article Public Schools Face the Rising Costs of Serving Lunch.

title: Do Leaders Have Moral Obligations?
description: Joe Paterno, the long-serving head coach of Penn States football team  and other university officials, including the athletic director and the schools president  have been accused of doing nothing after hearing allegations that assistant coach Jerry Sandusky was responsible for sexually abusing at least one young boy. Some have called Paternos inaction a moral failure, while others contend that handling the matter was not his responsibility. What do you think?

title: Crisis in Italy Deepens, as Bond Yields Hit Record Highs
description: ROME  A day after Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi pledged to step down once the Italian parliament passes austerity measures, Italy was engulfed in political chaos that has pushed the euro zone to its biggest test yet and raised the once unthinkable prospect of a major industrial economy going bankrupt.

title: Rivers, Manning and Interception Follies
description: San Diego Chargers quarterback Philip Rivers insists there is nothing wrong with him. He has a league-high 14 interceptions; the most he has ever thrown in a season is 15. Im not hurt, Rivers told reporters. Ive thrown a handful of picks that I normally dont throw, and Ill probably throw some more throughout my career. There wont always be a reason why.

title: The Early Word: Defiant
description: Todays Times

title: Part 3: Answers to Your Questions on Applying With a Learning Disability
description: Marybeth Kravets is fielding questions this week on The Choice about applying to college with a learning disability, the subject of my column published over the weekend in The Timess Education Life supplement.

title: Who Gets Unemployment Benefits
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

title: Football Outsiders Has Jets Rated No. 1
description: You get the sense, in reading Aaron Schatzs explanation for how this is possible, that even he is scratching his head  at the same time as Rex Ryan would be nodding his.

title: 31 Indians Convicted in Violence That Killed Muslims in 2002
description: NEW DELHI  An Indian court found 31 people guilty on Wednesday of killing 33 Muslims in Gujarat State in 2002 during sectarian riots that left more than 1,000 dead. Convicted of murder, arson, rioting and criminal conspiracy, they were sentenced to life in prison and fined. Forty-two other defendants were acquitted.

title: Can You Trust Your Childs Coach?
description: How often do you think hard about the adults who work with your children? The teachers and coaches who lead sports teams, church groups and other programs make our lives as parents easier, and they make our childrens lives better. Theyre often parents themselves, and many of us find ourselves in coaching roles, working with other peoples children. I tend to take for granted my childrens safety when I send them off to a hockey game in a coachs car, or to an after-school club run by a teacher  until something happens to remind me to be less sanguine.

title: Stone Links
description: A gathering of philosophy-related links from the past week.

title: My Grand Experiment: Turning Off AdWords
description: Monday, October 24, 9:36 a.m.: As I explained in my last post, I recently found myself with a surprising new problem: all the work we can handle. Because our backlog of orders is as high as I want it to be, I decided to take the opportunity to run an experiment: What would happen if I stopped running Google AdWords?

title: For an Immigrant, a Shrinking Business and a Maze of Obstacles
description: In better times, Abel Cherubin maintained a staff of six at his tax preparation business in Brooklyn, drove a BMW and even purchased a plot of land in his native Haiti, where he planned to build a school.

title: How Bubbles Affect Our Financial Behavior
description: Those of you familiar with the collected works of Carl Richards know that he has a keen sense of how uncontrolled emotion and errant behavior can make a mess of your financial life. And now, with the story of his own short sale in Las Vegas, you know that he learned these things the hard way.

title: Breakfast Meeting, Nov. 9
description: Herman Cain held a news conference Tuesday afternoon to deny the accusations of sexual harassment made by a number of women who worked for him when he led the National Restaurant Association. He charged that the accusations had been ginned up by a Democratic machine and been kept alive by a hostile news media, particularly the Web site Politico, which broke the story. [NYT]

title: Nearly 500 Birds Found Dead Near Wind Farm
description: A West Virginia wind farm that I wrote about last month because of its battery installation was the site of a big bird kill in October, according to a consultants report for the Fish and Wildlife Service.

title: Schlumberger in Russian Joint Venture Deal
description: LONDON  Integra, a Russian oil services group, announced plans on Wednesday to spin off a joint venture with the American energy giant Schlumberger and list the company on the London Stock Exchange.

title: Kenyas Uncertain Campaign
description: NAIROBI  When on Oct. 16 Kenya sent hundreds of troops into Somalia, its perennially problematic neighbor, it was going to war for the first time in three decades. The operation was ostensibly a response to recent raids by Somali militants into northern Kenya to kidnap tourists and aid workers. More likely, though, the Kenyan government seized the occasion to try to root out the Shabab, a group of Islamist insurgents, which has become increasingly meddlesome and dangerous. But it is stepping into a political mess, and for the moment the Kenyan government seems to be shooting from the hip.

title: Paynes Productive Period
description: From 1999 to 2004, Alexander Payne wrote and directed three feature films. But it took him seven years to get his next movie, The Descendants, to the big screen.

title: Darren Aronofsky Gets a Reality Check from the Margaret Mead Film Festival
description: While his 2010 feature Black Swan could have presaged a career transition into ballet, Darren Aronofsky is sticking with the cinema for the time being. This month, Mr. Aronofsky, whose films include Requiem for a Dream and The Wrestler (as well as a disturbing new series of anti-drug public service announcements) is temporarily trading his directors chair for a different seat at the American Museum of Natural History, where he is heading the jury of its Margaret Mead Film Festival.

title: Hollywood Plans Big Binge for Christmas
description: LOS ANGELES  Six Oscar-caliber directors. Nine movies (at least). And just one Christmas.

title: The Director of Sideways Sees His Life Go Forward
description: SEVEN years. Thats how long it has been since the release of Sideways, which cemented Alexander Paynes status as one of this countrys most exciting movie directors, won him an Oscar for screenwriting and ratcheted up the anticipation for his next film  the sooner, the better.

title: Fear of Contagion Rocks Markets
description: Europes efforts to stem financial contagion foundered on Wednesday as investors dumped their holdings of Italian government bonds, prompting a global stock market sell-off.

title: Spending on Political Ads Spurs Local TV Mergers
description: The broadcast business is becoming more attractive to buyers after several painful years, Brian Stelter of The New York Times reports. Analysts say private equity firms that bought into the business years ago are ready to sell. Read more

title: For Goldman, Trading Losses on 21 Days in Third Quarter
description: 8:31 a.m. | Updated

title: Giants Victory Celebration, Then a Prayer
description: The Giants gave us an interesting peek at their workplace on Sunday night after their victory over New England.

title: Teenagers Tell Researchers Its a Cruel, Cruel Online World
description: State legislatures across the country have passed or proposed laws against what they call cyberbullying. But how do young people parse bullying from being mean online? And when it happens, what do they do about it?

title: Opinion Report: Penn State
description: From the editorial page

title: G.M. Posts Quarterly Profit, but Chief Calls It Insufficient
description: DETROIT General Motors reported its seventh consecutive quarterly profit on Wednesday but stressed the need for more cost cutting as profit margins declined. It also warned of a more difficult end to the year than Wall Street was anticipating.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: Rajaratnam Ordered to Pay $92.8 Million Penalty | A federal judge on Tuesday ordered the convicted hedge fund titan Raj Rajaratnam to pay a $92.8 million penalty, the largest ever assessed against a person in a Securities and Exchange Commission insider trading case.

title: A Plan to Send TriBeCa Students to Chinatown
description: For more local news, including local election results for Suffolk County executive, crime concerns at Occupy Wall Street, the successes of past immigrant entrepreneurs, and financial concerns at the free public college Cooper Union, see the N.Y./Region section.

title: Hanging on to Home, Even After a Fall
description: BERNIE AND JOYCE MURPHY are still convinced that they did everything right when they bought their home. And by all indications, they did.

title: Ultimate Grave Dance? Ruling Could Help Zell Recoup Part of Tribune Investment
description: On Monday, word came in The Chicago Tribune that Sam Zell, the architect of a deal that left the Tribune Company in bankruptcy with $13 billion in debt, may now be in line to recoup some of his initial $315 million investment because of a judges ruling on another class of debtor.

title: Tent Revival
description: To accompany her spring collections sporty graphic dresses and jumpers, the designer Stella McCartney teamed up with the International Trade Centers Ethical Fashion Program on a line of Kenyan-made accessories. I have actually never been to Kenya, says McCartney, who has done similar collaborations with Oceana and the Natural Resources Defense Council. But the project helps to use the widely available and affordable materials there. The tote bags ($330) and strappy sandals ($300) in python-patterned screen prints are made of recycled cotton safari tents and sewn by seamstresses in Nairobi. Go to saks.com.

title: After Ratners Resignation, a Single Question for the Academy
description: On Tuesday, Brett Ratner, the designated co-producer of this years Oscars, resigned after he used a gay slur during a Q. & A. session about Tower Heist, his latest blockbuster. One of the stars of that film, Eddie Murphy, is still scheduled to host the event.

title: Early Admission Returns to Princeton, and So Do the Applicants
description: Four years ago, Princeton and Harvard ended their early admission programs, in an effort to delay the beginning of the annual frenzy of applicants to secure a precious seat in the next freshman class. But when none of its main competitors followed suit, both institutions announced in February that they would once again offer applicants an opportunity to apply for admission in November, two months before the deadline for regular applications.

title: An Accounting of Programs That Aim to Help Troops
description: As the Iraq and Afghanistan wars have taken their toll on the physical and mental health of Americas service members and their families, the number of Pentagon programs intended to treat traumatic brain injury, or provide psychological, marital or spiritual support to the troops and their loved ones, has proliferated.

title: I Am A Frankfurter
description: And I say that with relish  although actually Im in Mainz, doing a couple of talks.

title: Childrens Books: Little Brothers, Good and Bad
description: There is little more annoying to a 4-year-old boy than his 2-year-old brother. But in this clever, offbeat picture book, there is little more endearing, or starkly amusing either.

title: Wednesday Reading: Choosing Wines for Thanksgiving Dinner
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: This Is The Way The Euro Ends
description: This is the way the euro ends.

title: What Were Reading
description: Reuters: Check those food labels, if you can. China says about 10 percent of its farmland is contaminated with heavy metals.  Nick Fox

title: In Tuesdays Election Results, Democrats See Hope for 2012
description: Just hours after polls closed Tuesday night, Democrats seized on scattered results across the country as evidence that voters are rejecting Republican policies and will return President Obama to the Oval Office in 2012.

title: Mayor Merryl Tisch? The Post Floats the Idea
Six Steps to a Thanksgiving Stir-Fry
description: This Thanksgiving, put your wok to work.

title: Voters Defeat Many G.O.P.-Sponsored Measures
description: Voters turned a skeptical eye toward conservative-backed measures across the country Tuesday, rejecting an anti-labor law in Ohio, an anti-abortion measure in Mississippi and a tightening of voting rights in Maine.

title: Ryan Skeen Joins Pera as It Expands
