title: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press on Thursday
description: The Gujarat riot decision dominated headlines Thursday, with The Hindu calling it the First Whiff of Justice for riot victims. Thirty-one people were convicted on Wednesday of murder and sentenced to life in prison for their involvement in the violence and arson that killed 33 Muslims, mostly women and children, one evening in March of 2002. Almost all the accused were Patels, people who owned land in the village, while the victims were mostly laborers in their own farms, The Indian Express writes in a recap of the events. As riots in the village escalated, Muslim men herded their women, children and elders into the localitys only concrete house, the paper writes. Inside the 10 foot-by-12 foot room in which they were cramped, bales of cotton were stacked. The rioters doused these bales in oil, locked the house from the outside and set it on fire.

description: In politics, certain things are not supposed to happen: Liberals never reject a tax increase. Conservatives always favor the strongest anti-immigration leader. And big corporations cant really buy an election because voters see through them.

title: CMA Winners Look Familiar, With Minor Disruptions

That would be Taylor Swift, the pop phenom, who outmuscled her competition on the heels of her triple-platinum album Speak Now (Big Machine).

title: Penn State Students Take to the Streets After Paterno Is Fired
description: Thousands of Penn State students and others took to the streets in State College, Pa., on Wednesday night after the universitys board announced that Joe Paterno, the 84-year-old head football coach who had led the team for 46 years, had been fired in the wake of a child sex-abuse scandal involving a former assistant coach. The universitys president, Graham B. Spanier, also stepped down.

title: Recall Election Claims Arizona Anti-Immigration Champion
description: MESA, Ariz.  For years, Russell Pearce, Arizonas most powerful legislator and the architect of its tough immigration law, has sought to make life so uncomfortable for illegal immigrants in the state that they pack up and go.

title: Princeton Is Swamped in Early Applications
description: Princeton, along with Harvard, canceled its early-admission program four years ago to delay the beginning of the annual frenzy of applicants hoping to secure a precious seat in the next freshman class. But when none of their main competitors followed suit, both institutions announced in February that they would once again offer applicants an opportunity to apply in November, two months before the regular deadline.

description: The young grew older and an oldster got younger on The X Factor Wednesday night as another live show, this one with songs drawn from the movies, produced some intriguing performances.

title: TransCanada Shuts Pipeline After Troubles With Power
description: The company proposing a controversial oil pipeline that would stretch from Canada to the Gulf Coast had a related pipeline shut down twice this week after it experienced power problems. The company, TransCanada, said that its Keystone pipeline, which runs from Alberta to Cushing, Okla., went down for three hours on Tuesday after a Canadian utility that powers the pipeline dealt with shortages. It shut it down again on Tuesday night to inspect equipment, but restarted it on Wednesday morning after finding nothing amiss, the company said. Nothing was related to the safety of the pipeline or compromised the safety of the pipeline in any way, a company spokesman said. The interruptions were ill timed for TransCanada, which is in the midst of a bitter battle over whether its proposed Keystone XL line will be approved by the State Department. Opponents of the pipeline, which would carry Canadian oil sands crude, are increasing efforts to have it rejected or rerouted amid concerns that a spill could damage the Ogallala Aquifer in Nebraska. And the State Departments inspector general agreed this week to look into assertions that an environmental review of the project was mishandled by the State Department because it was conducted by a company with financial ties to TransCanada.

description: Penn State students and others gathered after the firing of the universitys football coach, Joe Paterno, and president, Graham B. Spanier.

title: The Chvez Way
description: MONTREAL  Going to the Venezuelan consulate here is not a comfortable experience for me. From the big poster of Hugo Chvez on the wall to the stacks of strident anti-imperialist pamphlets and propaganda newspapers in the waiting room, the message is loud and clear: if youre not a dyed-in-the-wool Chavista, this is enemy territory.

title: South Africas Governing Party Set to Rule on Youth Leader
description: LONDON  South Africas governing party was set to rule on Thursday in a disciplinary hearing relating to Julius Malema, the vocal, populist leader of its youth wing who has cast himself as a kingmaker in the partys internal politics.

title: News Quiz | Nov. 10, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Test Yourself | English, Nov. 10, 2011
description: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article Banned by Many Airlines, These Bulldogs Fly Private.

title: Nov. 10, 1982 | Vietnam Veterans Memorial Opens in Washington
description: On Nov. 10, 1982, the first visitors toured the newly completed Vietnam Veterans Memorial near the National Mall in Washington. Commonly called The Wall, the memorial features a long V-shaped expanse bearing the names of all United States service members killed during the conflict in Vietnam/Southeast Asia.

title: Penn State Students Clash With Police in Unrest After Announcement
description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa.  After top Penn State officials announced that they had fired Joe Paterno on Wednesday night, thousands of students stormed the downtown area to display their anger and frustration, chanting the former coachs name, tearing down light poles and overturning a television news van parked along College Avenue.

title: Learning With New York Times Obituaries
description: Note: This edition of 6 Qs About the News is about The Timess Obituary section as a whole, and can be used with any days edition of The Times.

title: Those Magnificent Women in Their Flying Machines
description: Charming? Fetching? Adorable? Dont believe your eyes.

title: Dealing With Your Own Cultural Irrelevance (at Age 28)
description: Many years ago, my grandmother took me to McDonalds for lunch, and the toy that came with the Happy Meal was a cricket that chirped when you spun its wings. (A Mulan-related toy, if that matters.)

title: Werner Herzog Lives Dangerously
description: Your new documentary, Into the Abyss, focuses on 28-year-old Michael Perry, who was executed for killing a nurse and two teenage boys in order to steal a Camaro for a joy ride. Given your stated opposition to the death penalty, why not focus on a man like Troy Davis, who might have been innocent?  Whats wrong about Truman Capote writing In Cold Blood? Did he need to prove the innocence of someone? Perry knew I was not in the business of guilt or innocence. I was after completely different things, like whats it like for those who know exactly when and how they are going to die.

title: Is Europe on the Verge of a Depression, or a Great Inflation?
description: Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is the co-author of 13 Bankers.

title: Part 4: Answers to Your Questions on Applying with a Learning Disability
description: Marybeth Kravets is fielding questions this week on The Choice about applying to college with a learning disability, the subject of my column published last weekend in The Timess Education Life supplement.

title: Youth Leader Is Disciplined in South Africa
description: LONDON  After weeks of disciplinary hearings that were cast as a test of its resolve, South Africas governing party on Thursday suspended Julius Malema, the populist leader of its youth wing, for five years and told him to step down for bringing the party into disrepute.

title: Would You Want to Be Home-Schooled?
description: In a Magazine piece, a writer describes the home-schooled life she led in the 1970s when her parents bought six one-way tickets to Europe and took her and her three siblings on a long, free-form journey with the intention of educating them along the way. The mother taught the children basic math and grammar, but also included lessons like yoga and drawing  or canceled lessons altogether to let them explore.

title: An Interview With Mario Testino
description: Suzy Menkes talks with Mario Testino about his 30 years as a fashion photographer, the central role photography plays in creating a vision for a brand and how he gets his iconic candid shots.

title: A Pro Bowl Ballot at the Midpoint
description: With half of the season in the books, now is an appropriate time to start talking about Pro Bowl considerations. Heres my ballot (as filled out on NFL.com) at the midway point, determined by observations from film study (with statistics serving as an infrequent verification tool).

title: A Market Returns to Berlins Kreuzberg District
description: Kreuzberg, in Berlin, hardly wants for character. The neighborhood  a mix of Turkish immigrants, progressive youth and expats  sports the citys only Green Party district mayor; it also plays host to the annual May Day Riot Night, a sprawling electronic-music block party with a history of trouble once the sun sets.

title: France-U.S.  All Those Years Ago
description: Thirty-two years ago when the United States national team arrived in Paris it was preparing for an Olympics it would not attend and looking forward to beginning qualifying matches for a World Cup it would not play in until 1990.

title: Report Finds One in Three College Students Has Taken an Online Class
description: Nearly a third of all college students are now taking online courses, so said a new study released on Wednesday by the Babson Survey Research Group and the College Board.

title: Medical Schools Neglect Gay and Gender Issues
description: The middle-aged patient with long dark hair made it very clear that this was not her first urinary tract infection. Its because when I urinate, she said, I need to use a catheter. She opened the leather satchel on her lap and, to prove her point, pulled out a thin, red sterile length of tube covered in plastic.

title: Running on Natural Gas, Magnolia Special Roadster Completes Cross-Country Drive
description: No computers were harmed during the construction of this car, said J.T. Nesbitt, the creator of the Magnolia Special, a back-to-basics and entirely hand-built sports car powered by compressed natural gas.

title: SCA of Sweden to Buy Georgia-Pacific Unit for $1.8 Billion
description: LONDON  The Swedish hygiene and paper company SCA announced plans on Thursday to acquire the European tissue business of Georgia-Pacific for $1.8 billion.

title: Sikhs Celebrate Guru Purab
description: Sikhs across the globe celebrate Guru Purab or Guru Nanak Jayanti on Thursday, which commemorates the birth anniversary of the founder of Sikhism, and the first of ten Sikh gurus. The festival falls each year on Kartik Poornima or full moon day in the month of Kartik or eighth month of the Hindu calendar.

title: Earthquake Kills at Least 7 in Turkey
description: ISTANBUL  A 5.6-magnitude earthquake in the same region hit by a larger earthquake two weeks ago killed at least seven people and trapped others who had moved into damaged buildings that collapsed, new agencies reported on Thursday.

title: Economist Named to Lead Greek Unity Government
description: ATHENS  Lucas Papademos, a respected economist and former vice president of the European Central Bank, was named Thursday to lead a new Greek unity government that has pledged to abide by the tough terms of a European aid package in the hopes of saving the country from bankruptcy.

title: Brown Rice: Not Just for Hippies Anymore
description: In 1969, I ate my first bowl of plain, boiled brown rice, then proceeded to live on it for a week, replicating the diet of a hippie girl to whom I hoped to demonstrate my sex appeal. (It didnt work.) Twenty years later, brown rice became a minor but regular part of my repertory.

title: Will a New Software Release Get Silver Lining Out of Debt?
description: At the end of our last post, Carissa Reiniger, founder of Silver Lining Limited, was out of cash and about to miss payroll. Buying herself another few months, Ms. Reiniger told the other members of thebusiness group, she managed to negotiate a $250,000 convertible note with a friend.

title: City Bees Newly Discovered, Yet Here All Along
description: New York City has a bee to call its own.

title: Indias More Perfect Union
description: NEW DELHI  This summer, Maruti Suzuki, the largest car manufacturer in India, geared up to release the newest model of its bestselling car, the Suzuki Swift, only to find that its production lines had slowed to a crawl.

title: Benchmark Interest Rate In Britain Unchanged
description: LONDON  The Bank of England agreed Thursday to keep its main interest rate unchanged because of growing concerns that the debt crisis in Europe could push Britains economy back into recession.

title: Europes Growth Forecast Is Lowered
description: BRUSSELS  Europes economic outlook received a fresh dose of gloom Thursday, when the European Commission warned that the Continents economies were stalled and faced the risk of a double-dip recession.

title: Israeli Court Upholds Rape Conviction of Ex-President
description: JERUSALEM  Moshe Katsav, the former president of Israel, is expected to enter prison on Dec. 7 to begin a seven-year term for rape after the countrys Supreme Court on Thursday rejected an appeal of his conviction and sentence.

title: Perry Tries to Recover From His Oops Moment
description: 12:49 p.m. | Updated Rick Perry moved rapidly on Thursday to try to save his presidential campaign by laughing off questions about his departure from the race and trying to elicit empathy for a debate gaffe with a game on his Web site asking visitors what federal agency they would like to forget.

title: After Debate Gaffe, Perry Vows to Stay in Race
description: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas says he is not getting out of the race for the Republican presidential nomination, even as some pundits and Republican operatives say that his candidacy has suffered a blow that cannot be overcome.

title: If You Act Your Age, Whats Your Carbon Footprint?
description: Weve all heard that some countries produce more carbon dioxide per capita than others, with the United States among the leaders of the pack. But how do your individual emissions change over the course of a lifetime?

title: Anglo American Sells Chilean Stake for $5.39 Billion
description: LONDON  Anglo American has agreed to sell a 24.5 percent stake in its Chilean copper assets to the Mitsubishi Corporation for $5.39 billion, the largest mining acquisition ever by the Japanese company.

title: Week 10 N.F.L. Game Probabilities: A  Jets-Patriots Tossup
description: Its now the Jets turn to represent New York against the Patriots. The twist in this matchup is that the Jets think theyre a running team, when theyre actually more productive when passing. And the Patriots are thought of as a sophisticated finesse passing offense, when theyre also one of the best running teams in the league.

title: Brides Mind Is on Another Planet
description: Bang or whimper? Ice or fire? Divine plan or cosmic accident? Alien invaders or genetically enhanced apes? The end of the world is painful to contemplate but also hard to resist thinking about, partly because there are so many wild and scary imaginative possibilities.

title: Opinion Report: Tobacco Warnings
description: From the editorial page

title: Breakfast Meeting, Nov. 10
description: The Republican presidential debate on Wednesday night, which was shown on CNBC and was supposed to be devoted to economic issues, became memorable for  a major gaffe by Gov. Rick Perry of Texas. His very public, very awkward inability to come up with the name of a third federal agency he would like to eliminate was taken as a devastating error. Gone, for the moment, was the media focus on sexual harassment allegations that have emerged against Herman Cain, who has been leading in public opinion polls. So much so that immediately afterward, when asked on CNBC whether Mr. Perry was doomed by the performance, Mr. Cain was reassuring about a forgiving public. [NYT]

title: 4-Year-Old Is Shot, and Father Retaliates
description: For more local news, including the possible closing of Brooklyn hospitals in financial trouble, a shooting that wounded two people at a hospital in the Bronx, and details of a growing business in the city  the consultation of psychics for travel advice  see the N.Y./Region section.

title: Mary J. Blige to Celebrate Life, Past and Present, With Online Concert Broadcast
description: Fans of Mary J. Blige will get the performance of her Life and then some in an online concert she will play Nov. 17 at Club Nokia in Los Angeles. The Internet broadcast will be directed by Adam Shankman and promote the Nov. 21 release of Ms. Bliges new album, My Life II  The Journey Continues (Act 1), but also pay a substantial tribute to its best-selling 1994 predecessor, My Life.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: Clients Question CMEs Oversight of MF Global | As regulators hunt for $600 million in missing customer money at the bankrupt brokerage MF Global, many clients are aiming their anger at one of MF Globals primary regulators: the CME Group.

title: Lounge Act | Moss and Maharam
description: Talk about a makeover. Among the latest offerings at the SoHo design mecca Moss is this pair of vintage Eames Lounge Chairs, which Murray Moss decided to re-cover in Hella Jongeriuss Repeat Dot fabric from Maharam. The chairs (which have been manufactured by Herman Miller since 1956) have a built-in pedigree because theyre made with Brazilian rosewood veneer, the material that was originally specified by Charles and Ray Eames, but which was discontinued in 1992 when Brazilian rosewood landed on the endangered species list. Jongeriuss eye-popping fabric, however, is what really makes them  it takes a design icon from the Mad Men era and catapults it into the 21st century. (As with many Moss creations, these dont come cheap: the chairs are $16,000 each, or $30,000 for the pair.) Theyre just the first (or first two) in a planned series of one-off furniture pieces on which Moss and Maharam will collaborate. And for a glimpse of what other designs Maharam might bring to the project, see Maharam Agenda (Lars Mller Publishers), a new book on the innovative textile company by Michael Maharam, who has run the family-owned business with his brother, Stephen, since 1997. The book not only describes the brothers risk-taking design agenda, but it looks like an agenda, too, complete with a soft cover (an embroidered design by Jongerius) and woven bookmark  a tip-off right there that this isnt going to be your average corporate coffee-table book.

title: Thursday Reading: Home Generators Become Status Symbols
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Why Are College Students Defending Joe Paterno?
description: On Wednesday night I was watching ESPNs coverage of the firing of Joe Paterno, the Penn State football coach (an event whose magnitude one announcer just compared indirectly to the Kennedy assassination), and wondering how Id feel if my child was standing on Paternos lawn, or on the streets of State College, Pa., supporting a man who could hear a graphic description of a sexual assault on a young boy and then choose to walk away. Id like to hear one of those students support the argument that the coach deserves one more game. And then Id like them to tell me how theyd explain it to a 10-year-old.

title: TaskRabbit Looks to Expand Cities and Offer an A.P.I.
description: My colleague Jenna Wortham recently wrote about a number of companies that allow people to hire strangers to run errands. One of them was TaskRabbit, a San Francisco-based start-up.

title: Growing Long Island Cheating Scandal Now Includes ACT
Michael White to Open an East Village Pizzeria
description: Michael White says he loves pizza even if he doesnt serve it at any of his restaurants in New York.

title: Stephen King Goes to the Rescue of JFK
description: In all of Stephen Kings work there is an admixture of the ordinary and the supernatural  call it the weird quotidian. In his new novel, 11/22/63, it is a rabbit hole into the past that pops up in Lisbon Falls, a woebegone corner of Maine.

title: The Latest G.O.P. Cattle Show
description: The Republican Party foisted another one of its endless presidential debates on television viewers last night.

title: Video Shows Rage at Penn State After Paternos Ouster
description: Updated | 5:43 p.m. As my colleagues Nate Schweber and Mark Viera report, Penn State students, enraged by the firing of the legendary football coach Joe Paterno, stormed downtown State College, Pa., late Wednesday, chanting the former coachs name, tearing down light poles and overturning a television news van parked along College Avenue.

title: Errol Morris Interviews Stephen King
description: In the Nov. 13 issue of the Book Review, the documentarian Errol Morris reviews Stephen Kings new novel, 11/22/63. The book, like the film Morris is currently completing, is about the assassination of John F. Kennedy. Because of their overlapping interests, and because Mr. Morriss technique as a filmmaker is to chase down every clue, he requested an interview with Mr. King after finishing his review. The resulting Q. and A. is below, with Mr. Morriss introduction.  The Editors

title: Viacom Reports 33 Percent Gain in Profit
description: A robust television advertising market, climbing cable fees and box office sales from Transformers: Dark of the Moon helped bolster Viacoms profit 33 percent in the quarter that ended in September.

title: Have You Ever Heard the Term Omert? Murdoch Is Asked
description: 1:49 p.m. | Updated with video below Surely it was inevitable that things would get personal between Tom Watson, member of Parliament, and James Murdoch, News Corporations deputy chief operating officer.

title: Spotted on the Street | Lindsey Hufnagel
description: The Girl: Lindsey Hufnagel, a Parsons School of Design graduate, is the designer and founder of Horse and Nail handbags.

title: Rules for an Honorable Nightcap
description: The only trouble with the otherwise honorable nightcap is that it has a diabolical way of turning into two or three, thus ceasing to be a nightcap at all but instead a formula for a rough morning. Ive been down this road more than once, and it has taught me to regard the nightcap as a ritual performed to its greatest effect if I follow a few simple guidelines.

title: Defying Conventional Wisdom
description: In a column in todays Campaign Stops, Timothy Egan writes:

title: Ken Boyer and Tony Oliva Are on the Ballot. Why Not Dick Allen?
description: The Golden Era ballot for the voters on the Baseball Hall of Fame Veterans Committee is filled with very good players. Somedeserve induction and somedont. Yet whats most glaring is omission ofone name: Dick Allen.

title: What Were Reading
description: Wine Review Online: The new Germany: dry rieslings and good pinot noir. Ed McCarthy reports.  Eric Asimov

title: Guess Where This Is
description: Its time again for our weekly contest: guess the location of the photograph above.

title: Leading Off: Campus Chaos on a Sorry but Necessary Day
description: At Penn State, the adults finally showed up. They had been long awaited and inexplicably slow, as the university devolved into a leaderless circus in the days after its sexual abuse scandal unfolded. Early Wednesday, Coach Joe Paterno was still calling his own shots, as if his moral authority had somehow survived the tsunami of a scandal fueled by his own inaction. When the Board of Trustees did the right thing Wednesday night  and really, firing Paterno and Graham B. Spanier, the university president, was the only thing it could do  the Paterno cult of personality tried to strike back. Students protested, clinging to the mythic hero they did not want unmasked.

title: Olympus Again Delays Results Amid Inquiry Into Hidden Losses
description: The Olympus Corporation, mired in a scandal over a $1 billion cover-up, again delayed the release of its fiscal second-quarter earnings on Thursday, and the Tokyo Stock Exchange threatened to delist the companys stock.

title: Appetite for Budget Bill, but Success Is in Doubt
description: WASHINGTON  The idea of a balanced budget amendment to the Constitution is like pleated pants  both go in and out of style as the years go by, although in this town, both have their reliable devotees.

title: Video Highlights of Murdochs Testimony
description: As my colleagues Sarah Lyall and Alan Cowell report, James Murdoch on Thursday told a parliamentary panel investigating phone-hacking at a tabloid newspaper he oversaw that he did not mislead the panel at an appearance in July.

title: Poetry Pairing | The Woman With a Tumor in Her Neck
description: This weeks Poetry Pairing matches Wendy Videlocks The woman with a tumor in her neck with a Well blog post, When the Doctors Wife Has Cancer, by Peter B. Bach, M.D.

title: In an Undercover Investigation, One Big Snag: The Officer Was a Lousy Barber
description: The men came in one by one, sat down in the chair in front of the shops newest barber, and got their hair cut. They looked like customers at pretty much any other barber shop around the city. They paid, and went on their way.

title: Democratic Lawmakers Urge Obama to Veto Gun Measure
description: Two lawmakers are calling on President Obama to issue a veto threat against gun legislation working its way through Congress that would make it easier for people to carry concealed handguns across state lines, signifying growing concern among Democrats that the measure may reach the presidents desk.

title: Profile in Style | Sara Beltran
description: Finding a seashell on the beach hardly seems like a life-changing event, but it was exactly that for this globe-trotting jewelry designer who divides her time among New York, India and Mexico. Six years ago, Beltrn plucked an Anadara shell from the sand while working as an assistant on a Bruce Weber shoot in Virginia Beach. She cast it in gold, made it into a bracelet and, voil, Dezso, her line of sea- and sand-inspired jewels, was born. She spent three years in Jaipur learning about stones and honing her craft, and became addicted to Indias vivid colors and rich culture. Its a crazily beautiful, exotic country, Beltrn says. I love the textiles, the architecture, the incredible artisans. Its like Candy Land for creative people. Go to dezsosara.com. See more >>

title: In a Quest for Focus, Google Purges Small Projects
description: One day, the Google engineers developing a new photo-sharing app, Photovine, were dreaming that their app could be Googles next household name and basking in the glow of the $200 million that Google had paid to buy their start-up, Slide.

title: Taliban Attack U.S.-Afghan Meeting in Border District
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Taliban insurgents attacked a district government center in eastern Afghanistan on Thursday while American troops were meeting with local officials inside, wounding three American soldiers and killing three Afghan police officers, according to Afghan and American officials.

title: I Was That Home-Schooling Anarchist
description: My daughter Margarets piece in this weeks magazine about being home-schooled captures wonderfully a most unusual time in the life of our family  the good, the bad and the ugly. She describes my thoughts about education and how I grew to realize that I wanted to teach the children at home as well as I could. And I loved reading all the childrens horror stories she recounts about their first few days at school, which have become familiar punch lines to long-running family jokes. But when you think about it, whats so terrible about being a little confused on the first day of school? Ive been confused for the first few days of all the jobs Ive ever had, and so have my friends. Thats part of the process of beginning something new. Im sure Mary, Margaret, John and James would agree.

title: Wheelies: The Go West Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: 36 Hours in St. Lucia
description: An island chock full of natural attractions: hot springs, rain forests, mountains and the sea.

title: Rangers Surge Behind Gaboriks New Line
description: Since Coach John Tortorella put center Derek Stepan between Artem Anisimov and Marian Gaborik for parts of the game against Montreal on Nov. 5, the lines brilliant passing, puck-hawking and goal scoring have galvanized an otherwise spotty Rangers attack. In his third season in New York, Gaborik may finally have the linemates to lift him to the top of the scoring charts. Going into Fridays home game against Carolina, the Rangers has won five straight. Its early yet, and Tortorella shuffles lines constantly. But the Stepan-Anisimov-Gaborik troika is lighting the goal lamp like the Rangers Goal-a-Game (GAG) Line of Jean Ratelle, Vic Hadfield and Rod Gilbert did in the early 70s.

title: 36 Hours in St. Lucia
description: THE lush Caribbean island of St. Lucia has long been associated with luxury, thanks to its exclusive hotels and celebrity guests, from Oprah Winfrey to Justin Bieber. But the island has always had an earthy streak, and even high-end hotels offer rooms without a fourth wall (but with plenty of mosquito netting). In the dramatic Piton mountain region on the south end of the island, near the town of Soufrire, some historic estates are taking the earthy concept a bit further  one combines tourism with farming, another has opened a spa in the jungle canopy  and restaurants offer field-to-fork menus. All are within easy reach of St. Lucias abundant natural attractions, which include hot springs, rain forests, mountains and, of course, the sea.

title: Retail Health Care Competition Heats Up
description: Wal-Mart, which has had trouble partnering with vendors to offer health care, wants to expand again in an effort to compete with other retailers and drugstore chains for millions of potential customers insured through the new health care law.

title: Hugh Jackman: Back on Broadway
description: Hugh Jackman sings Steppin Out With My Baby in his 2011 concert on Broadway.

title: City to End Popular Parking Ticket Fine-Reduction Program
description: In the fraught, us-versus-them world of municipal parking enforcement, it seemed the closest thing to a win-win: plead guilty to a parking ticket, and pay a smaller fine. Big Bureaucrat gets a payday, and the Little Guy saves a few bucks.

title: A Shaken Italy Is Poised to Name a New Government
description: ROME  Italy pulled back from the brink on Thursday, as lawmakers seemed poised to usher out Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi and replace his government with a cabinet of technocrats most likely led by a former European Commissioner, Mario Monti.

title: Ayatollah Denounces U.N. Nuclear Report
description: The supreme leader of Iran added his voice on Thursday to the countrys bellicose backlash against the incriminating United Nations report about the Iranian nuclear program, warning any potential military attackers they would face a strong slap and iron fist.

title: A New Pin on the Art Map
description: LOS ANGELES  The postwar art of Southern California is a house with many mansions, a great number of which are now open for viewing. I refer of course to the cacophonous, synergistic, sometimes bizarre colossus of exhibitions known as Pacific Standard Time: Art in L.A. 1945-1980, which is rampant throughout the Los Angeles region.

title: Breakout Stars
description: Inspired by Hollywood  and more specifically the Chateau Marmont  these festive cocktail rings, the stateside debut of the Australian jeweler Samantha Wills, have names like Romancing the Stone and La Vie en Rose. Priced from $215 to $290, the cinematic sparklers have already been spotted on the likes of Kate Bosworth, Blake Lively and Drew Barrymore.

title: Bits: Whats Behind the New Look
description: The Bits blog has a new look. The design is more distinctive and the news easier to scan. (And we have a new logo.)

title: Theater Talkback: The Writings on the Wall
description: Have you ever been tempted at the theater to lean toward the stage and yell at the performers, What did you say? Im sure youve never actually done that. (If you have, you should be banned from theaters for life, even if you were drunk at the time.) But what with all the fuzzy amplification and diction-challenged actors on Broadway these days, even those with acute hearing may miss out on the occasional crucial line. Thats when you wish, if only for a moment, that the theater used supertitles, the way the opera often does.

title: Free Peoples Free Spirited Ball Gowns
description: Ball gowns are not what come to mind when you think of Free People. But on Thursday, the brand will introduce its first limited-edition gown collection. Just in time for the holiday season, the six-piece, eco-friendly line is being sold as a pop-up shop inside Free Peoples New York and Los Angeles stores until Sunday.

title: Room 77, a New Way to Search for Hotel Rates
description: For travelers who hop from Web site to Web site to compare hotel rates or find the best value, theres a new online tool aiming to be a one-stop shop.

title: Crosby May Return Soon
description: 2:21 p.m. | Updated The timetable for Pittsburgh Penguins All-Star Sidney Crosbys return to playing in games remains speculative, but there are signs he could be back soon. Crosby, who has been out since Jan. 5 because of a concussion, is practicing with the team.

title: 36 Seconds in St. Lucia
description: A look at the dramatic Piton mountain region on the south end of the island.

title: Snagging a Room With a View, Through the Web
description: People who are finicky about their hotel rooms have never had a problem haggling with the front desk to get sweeter lodgings  a bit more space, a little more distance from the ice machine, a grander view. Then there are people like me, who would rather not deal with the hassle of a round-trip to the hotel lobby to protest for an accommodation change, unless a room is truly uninhabitable.

title: On Our Radar: Spying on Greenpeace
description: A French court sentences a nuclear executive with the state energy company lectricit de France to three years in prison, with all but six months suspended, in a case that involved spying on Greenpeace. It fines E.D.F. 1.5 million euros (about $2 million). [The Guardian]

title: Week 10 in Fantasy Football: Favorable and Unfavorable Matchups
description: Jason and Justin Sablich are here to help you with your fantasy football team. The Sablich brothers will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy).

title: Sisters Unto Death
description: In his poem Death Fugue, written in 1944-45, the Romanian Jewish writer and labor camp survivor Paul Celan draws a stark opposition between two women: Your golden hair Margareta / your ashen hair Shulamith. With this juxtaposition of putatively Aryan and Jewish tresses (and names: Margareta is a long form of Gretchen, the name of the bonny blond Frulein in Goethes Faust; Shulamith is the black and comely princess in the Song of Songs), he evokes the facile yet deadly racism of the Third Reich. By contrast, the 230 heroines of A Train in Winter transcended precisely such differences  and many more besides  to make common cause against the Nazis.

title: Kutcher Proves Value of Knowing the Whole Penn State Story
description: It is rarely a surprise to discover that celebrities often live in a bubble, cut off from the kind of news filling the days of regular people. But actor Ashton Kutcher showed Wednesday night that when thats the case, you should probably stay entirely in the bubble instead of just peeking your head out now and then.

title: Italy Bond Market as Euro Proxy
description: LONDON  A day after panicky investors drove Italian bond rates well above 7 percent, reviving fears that the euro zone was heading toward a break-up, the market calmed somewhat on Thursday after Italy managed to attract strong buying interest for a shorter-term bond offering. Also helping buoy the market were rumors that the European Central Bank had stepped up its purchase of Italian bonds.

title: Helen DeWitts Immodest Proposal
description: More than a decade after her debut novel, The Last Samurai, impressed critics and readers alike, Helen DeWitt has returned with Lightning Rods, a funny, filthy volume that starts out innocently enough. Joe is a hapless hero, a failed salesman of encyclopedias and vacuum cleaners, who had once sold a single Electrolux and eaten 126 pieces of homemade pie in a time frame where most salesmen would hope to reverse the ratio of vacuum cleaners to pie. He spends his days entertaining himself in his rented trailer; he reads magazines, watches videos, and fantasizes about women and  wait for it  walls.

title: A Veteran Will March With Thoughts of Fellow Soldiers and Country
description: On Friday, I will walk in the Veterans Day Parade in New York City. It has been almost three years since I got back from Iraq and five months since I returned from a stint as an aid worker in Afghanistan. I am not sure what my emotions will hold, or what they will betray when I walk down those streets. Like many veterans I am uneasy with congratulatory recognition for a war that has yet to fire its last round. Mostly, I will be proud to follow a well-worn path.

title: The Age of Kennan
description: While writing this essay, I asked several young men and women what George F. Kennan meant to them. As it turned out, nearly all were essentially oblivious of the man or his role in shaping American foreign policy. Yet Kennan had fashioned the concept of containment in the name of which the cold war was conducted and won and almost concurrently had also expressed some of the most trenchant criticism of the way his own theory was being implemented. To the present generation, Kennan has receded into a vague past as has their parents struggle to bring forth a new international order amid the awesome, unprecedented power of nuclear weapons.

title: Up Front: Errol Morris
description: The documentary filmmaker Errol Morris, who reviews Stephen Kings novel 11/22/63 on Page 12, is well known for poking around history to challenge received wisdom. In The Thin Blue Line (1988), he questioned an 11-year-old murder conviction that was subsequently overturned. In 2004 he won an Oscar for The Fog of War, in which he pressed former Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara to revisit his decisions about Vietnam. And he is currently at work on a film about the Kennedy assassination, the same subject King explores in his novel.

title: 5-Year Term for Woman Who Killed Her Husband
description: A Queens woman who killed her husband after suffering years of abuse at his hands was sentenced Thursday to five years in prison on a weapons charge, less than the maximum sentence of 15 years but short of her request for further leniency.

title: Hemingway at Sea
description: It would be hard to exaggerate Ernest Hemingways influence over American literature, but his influence on our lives is probably larger still. Here he is in a letter to his mother, July 1924, describing the San Fermn bullfighting festival in Pamplona, Spain: It is a purely Spanish festa . . . and there are practically no foreigners. Two years later he published a novel set in Pamplona, and from that moment on his letters description of a sleepy town would never hold true again. The 2012 college grad who will be gored running with the bulls in Pamplona next July, and the thousands of others safely drinking too much behind the barriers, are all living out the fantasies of one man.

title: How Updike Judged
description: It is the fate of some writers to be accused of writing too well. In one form or another, the charge has been lodged against authors as different as Vladimir Nabokov (too clever), Richard Wilbur (too elegant) and Garry Wills (too authoritative). But among major American literary figures of recent times, John Updike is the one about whom the complaint (too fluent, too lavish, too prolific) is most common. Between his first book, The Carpentered Hen (1958), and his death in 2009, Updike produced more than 60 volumes: novels; story collections; nonfiction on anything from writers and artists to baseball, dinosaurs, Broadway and golf; childrens tales; poetry; a historical play; forewords; afterwords; and everything in between.

title: At a Michigan Diner, Cain Apologizes for His Princess Nancy Comment
description: YPSILANTI, Mich.  Herman Cain apologized on Thursday for referring to Nancy Pelosi, the former speaker of the House, as Princess Nancy during the Republican presidential debate in Michigan on Wednesday night.

title: Pacific Standard Time
description: A look at some of the works on display in Pacific Standard Time: Art in L.A. 1945-1980.

title: What Should Penn State Applicants Think?
description: In light of the resignation of the president of Pennsylvania State University on Wednesday and the firing of its football coach, Joe Paterno  each a casualty of an investigation into how the university handled accusations that a former assistant coach sexually abused young boys on campus  applicants for next years freshman class might be wondering about the implications for them.

title: A Workshop in Writing, Not Wizardry
description: ARTISTS in general, and writers in particular, as everybody knows, tend to be sensitive creatures who receive criticism like body blows. So theres considerable theater-of-cruelty entertainment in watching four fledgling novelists cringe beneath the blistering stares, scornful dismissals and disdainfully curled lips of Alan Rickman.

title: Interviews with the jazz chameleon Chick Corea and the British upstart King Krule.
description: This week: Interviews with the jazz chameleon Chick Corea and the British upstart King Krule, plus reviews of the weeks new releases. Jeremy Egner is the host.

title: Google+ Isnt Going Away
description: There sure are a lot of Google+ haters out there.

title: U.S. Delays Decision on Pipeline Until After Election
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration, under sharp pressure from officials in Nebraska and restive environmental activists, announced Thursday that it would review the route of the disputed Keystone XL oil pipeline, effectively delaying any decision about its fate until after the 2012 election.

title: Of Cellphones and Street Photography
description: There was a time when the citys sidewalks were teeming with eye candy for street photographers like Misha Erwitt.

title: Rick Perrys Intrade Flash Crash
description: During last nights Republican presidential debate, Gov. Rick Perry of Texas made an oops when he forgot the third of three federal departments he wanted to eliminate. As Nate Silvers blog post noted, Mr. Perrys odds of winning the Republican nomination halved within seconds on Intrade, an online market where people bet on the odds of various events.

title: Apps for Kids and Earbuds Galore
description: Deborah Forte, the president of Scholastic Media, discusses what makes a good app for children and Pedro Rafael Rosado tries out different in-ear monitors for gaming, exercising and commuting.

title: What Good Teachers Do When Students Fail
description: Last week, Jessica Lahey, a middle-school teacher, writer and blogger, gave her three classes of sixth, seventh and eighth graders tests. Things did not go well. In her blog post, Things Fall Apart, she wrote that the sixth graders were moving from regurgitation to interpretation and application.

title: Lauren & Francis
description: Lauren Fadeley and Francis Veyette first met in 1997 at a summer ballet school program in Philadelphia. Ten years later she joined the Pennsylvania Ballet and they were paired together again.

title: The Story Is in the Eyes
description: Brett Gundlock is a Toronto-based freelance photographer and  a member of Boreal Collective. He started taking photos of his friends on BMX bikes at 14. He changed his plans when studied at the SAIT photojournalism program in Calgary, Alberta.Now 25, hehas worked for three years as a staff photographer for National Post in Toronto. Mr. Gundlock left the Post to focus on his own work, including a project about the oil sands in Fort McMurray.

title: Popcast: Interviews with Chick Corea and King Krule
description: This weeks show journeys across oceans and generations, as we hear from Chick Corea, the 70-year-old American jazz pianist, and King Krule, 17, an emerging British singer-songwriter.

title: TimesCast | November 10, 2011
description: Rick Perry uses humor to try to move past his debate stumble; Greek leaders choose a new prime minister; and the sports columnist William C. Rhoden says Penn State should cancel Saturdays game.

title: Brazil Captures a Long-Sought Drug Lord
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  One of Brazils most-wanted drug lords has been captured, the authorities here announced Thursday, taken around midnight from the trunk of a car while he was attempting to flee Rocinha, one of this citys largest slums, ahead of a bid by security forces to seize control of the sprawling hillside territory.

title: F.D.A.: 1,200 Stores Violated Bans on Tobacco Sales to Minors
description: Over the last year, the Food and Drug Administration gave $24 million to 37 states and the District of Columbia to improve enforcement of laws banning the sale of cigarettes to people under 18 years old.

title: Starbucks Buys Premium Juice Maker
description: For Starbucks, the juice sector is looking particularly sweet.

title: Beneath the Streets of London
description: Is that vast labyrinth beneath London the Eighth Wonder of the World or the Ninth Circle of Hell? Ill admit to a bias. As a longtime commuter on the infernal Long Island Rail Road and a rider of a subway whose signs are in fluent fuhgeddaboudit, I know what I like in a train system. Even as an American pre-teenager growing up in London, I marveled at the Underground and navigated it alone with ease and awe. Im opting for Eighth Wonder.

title: Fix a Ticket? Kelly Says Never, but How About Selleck?
description: As television moments go, it was prescient.

title: Once Upon a Time in New York City
description: Every childrens book should be infused with emotion, starting with a sense of wonder. For me, the first great book of my childhood was The Story of Babar, by Jean de Brunhoff, published in the United States in 1933. When I was 5, a year before Pearl Harbor, my mother showed me the book at the public library in my Brooklyn neighborhood. She told me decades later that when she saw the look on my face, she borrowed Babar and took us both home. We would borrow it, and its successors, many more times. The book has stayed with me all my life.

title: Change of Address
description: As any parent who has had to reread the same bedtime story for nights on end knows, children crave consistency. And if any event can upend that cozy sense of security, its moving house. Could anything  short of monsters, bears and the dark  pose a bigger threat to a small childs well-being?

title: Get Stuffed
description: I was intrigued (make that wildly excited) when I heard there was a fancy hotel in Switzerland where Id be forced to eat meat, frites, cheese and chocolate and drink red wine and Champagne in order to lose weight. Was this a publicity ploy or a miracle?

title: Do-Over
description: For that ambidextrous creature known as the author-illustrator  or at least for the best among them  story and art, like mind and body, are almost impossible to pull apart. Certainly, the visual and verbal sides of the Caldecott medalist Chris Raschka, whose prose and illustration come across as seamlessly and elegantly intertwined, make it hard to argue that a books text or illustration are entirely separate entities.

title: TimesCast | Greece's New Prime Minister
description: November 10, 2011  Greek leaders choose Lucas Papademos, an economist, to be the new prime minister.

title: The Subconscious Shelf
description: As a teenage baby sitter, I went straight for the books. No sooner did the door close behind the spruced-up parents than I was on the prowl: the bedside table for erotica, the kitchen counter for cookbooks, the bathroom for magazines, and finally the official living-room shelves. Only then did I scan the refrigerator.

title: Heroes and Villains
description: Forbidden, discouraged or dismissed by adults, comic books have always been schoolyard currency, bought and swapped by children and read avidly by children themselves, whether eager or reluctant readers. (It was one way for the bookish to get the other kids to like them; trust me, I know.) But as Franoise Mouly, the art editor at The New Yorker and founder of the Toon Books line of comic books for children, has pointed out, children got left behind when comics became comix and superheroes acquired Shakespearean dimensions in graphic novels and film.

title: Sweet Land of Liberty
description: Whenever I see a book about historical aspects of African-American life, Im very much aware of the cringe factor. As a child raised in Harlem I dreaded whenever a black person appeared in one of my schoolbooks. Not that blacks were portrayed as ugly or bad in any way, but they almost always appeared as helpless victims. As a black child hoping to fit into American history with my white classmates, I was always made uncomfortable by images of my people as other.

title: In Abu Dhabi, the Season Begins to Wind Down
description: ABU DHABI  Formula One has arrived in Abu Dhabi to prepare for the penultimate race of the 19-race season, and only now does it really feel as if the season is really winding down. After Sebastian Vettel won the drivers title at the Japanese Grand Prix last month with several races left to run, the season started to feel like it was running on beyond its sell-by date.

title: In Abu Dhabi, the Season Begins to Wind Down
description: ABU DHABI  Formula One has arrived in Abu Dhabi to prepare for the penultimate race of the 19-race season, and only now does it really feel as if the season is really winding down. After Sebastian Vettel won the drivers title at the Japanese Grand Prix last month with several races left to run, the season started to feel like it was running on beyond its sell-by date.

title: Baby on the Way. Now What?
description: What could be more miserable, more doomed to squalor and regret and diminished expectations, than the pregnancy of an unmarried teenage girl? These truths are self-evident, providing that you are not yourself an unmarried teenage girl.

title: Portrait of the Artist as a Young Boy
description: What formative experiences make a great childrens book illustrator? In the case of Allen Say and Ed Young, both Caldecott medalists, the journey begins with unusual childhoods in wartime Asia. Connecting the dots from those beginnings to what would become long and successful careers, Drawing From Memory, by Say, and The House Baba Built, by Young, both picture books, portray the authors and artists as not-yet men.

title: Caught in the Web
description: In the darkest days of high school  when I agonized over girls, when I couldnt decide what to do about college, when I couldnt find a way to make my bushy hair not look stupid  I often wished that time travel would be invented. Perhaps one day my adult self might zip back through the decades for a quick visit to Whitefish Bay High.

title: Obamas Influential Mideast Envoy to Resign
description: WASHINGTON  Dennis B. Ross, a seasoned diplomat who has been one of President Obamas most influential advisers on Iran and the Middle East, announced Thursday that he would leave the White House, at a time when Israeli-Palestinian peace talks are frozen and tensions over Iran are flaring up anew.

title: Holiday Songs
description: Childrens books about holiday songs.

title: Bookshelf: Holiday Songs
description: THE HANUKKAH HOP!  By Erica Silverman. Illustrated by Steven DAmico.  32 pp. Simon & Schuster. $12.99.(Picture book; ages 3 to 6)

title: Pride and Perseverance
description: Three new biographical picture books portray children living through challenging circumstances: growing up in East Texas during the Depression, building a new life in the Bronx in the 1960s after escaping from Castros Cuba, and hiding from the Nazis in the Italian countryside during World War II. Perhaps theyll teach children today that even the greatest difficulties can be overcome through determination, optimism and familial love. At the very least, theyll provide an excellent moral lesson: If your biggest problem is not having the latest Webkinz, things could be a lot worse.

title: In MF Globals Wake, Regulators to Audit All Futures Firms
description: 8:01 p.m. | Updated

title: Manhattan Mysteries
description: Imagine the difficulty of creating an active crime-fighting protagonist in an age of helicopter parents. Far better to set a book 100-odd years in the past, when 12-year-olds didnt have curfews or receive parental cellphone calls every five minutes. Now there a writer can have some fun!

title: Reality TV Goes Where Football Meets the Hijab
description: IF anything made me an American, it was television. I learned English from soap operas  after kindergarten, curled up Mommy-side  and then beyond, the many hours she abandoned the sofa for the kitchen when I alternated between after-school cartoons and adult crime dramas. English came to me, and with it so many questions about what was happening on TV. But one that never hit home was why the people on the screen did not resemble my family. I suppose when your daily life involves acute consciousness of being a foreigner, you lack that sense of entitlement; self-identification with a popular representation of America was a luxury this newly transplanted Iranian immigrant didnt even know to lust for.

title: A Mortgage Modification That Actually Happened
description: In this weeks Which Way Home? section, I wrote about an East Palo Alto, Calif., woman who struggled for two years to obtain a modification of her mortgage, after she began to have difficulty making her monthly loan payments.

title: All the Wiser
description: In 1484, William Caxton, the man credited with introducing the printing press to England, brought Aesop to English speakers  and weve been reading him ever since. Aesop has been a part of the nursery for so long it is hard to imagine a jailed Socrates, awaiting execution, deciding that nothing is more important than turning the Greek slaves fables into poetry. Like the stories Plato called old wives tales, these fables have become part of the cultural bloodstream, passing wisdom from one generation to the next.

title: Lions and Hippos and Whales, Oh My!
description: The average North American toddler grows up with almost daily exposure to lions, hippos and elephants  even though most children have no contact with such creatures beyond a glimpse behind a wall during the occasional trip to a PETA-approved city zoo.

title: Letters on the Loose
description: There is no finer tradition in English-language education than transforming the letters of the alphabet into living, breathing objects of fun. Those of us who came of age in the 1970s and 80s may suppose that Sesame Street invented the concept  we might well be called Generation X because so many of us remember the letter X appearing in Muppet form on Guy Smileys Mystery Guest game show.

title: Mice, Twice
description: Children have demonstrated their endless appetite for stories about mice, from Geronimo Stilton to The Tale of Despereaux  the more courageous the better. Maybe its because children are wired to be curious about the escapades of creatures even smaller than they are; or maybe the enthusiasm for rodents is yet another variation on what made Toy Story so appealing: We all love to imagine whats going on when were not looking or in places we cant see, like behind the walls. Either way, mouse lit is a perennial favorite, and its enthusiasts will be tickled to discover two additions, both from veteran authors.

title: Choose Your Own Adventure
description: Those eternal picture book fixtures, adorable ducklings and idyllic clambakes, do not feature in Chris Van Allsburgs darkly fanciful works, nor do the friendly steam shovels and tugboats of storybooks past. Van Allsburgs books, starting with The Garden of Abdul Gasazi, published in 1979, and Jumanji, which celebrates its 30th anniversary this year, instead offer wonder with an edge to todays eerily savvy and media-smart children.

title: When Ends Dont Meet
description: For every hyperscheduled, extracurricular-activitied, turbo-texting, iPad-gaming middle schooler in America, there are those we dont hear about: the children whose parents dread the annual school supply list because they cant afford colored pencils and three-ring binders. The children who rely on their public school cafeteria for a free breakfast. The children who dont worry if theyre wearing the right American Eagle top, because theyre clinging to the few shirts they have.

title: Second Chances
description: For anyone who has survived divorce at close range, the opening of Bigger Than a Bread Box, an all-too-real story leavened by the appearance of a magical wish-granting breadbox, is almost unbearable. One minute, the family seems to be functioning normally: Rebecca Shapiro, the 12-year-old narrator, is doing her homework in the kitchen while her toddler brother, Lew, is upstairs in his crib at their home in Baltimore. The next, the lights go out  literally  and Mom is screaming about unpaid bills and being sick of it all, Dad responding with deflated sarcasm. The children are scared and in the dark in every miserable way.

title: My Friend the Ghost
description: Teachers and librarians are always searching for an ideal read-aloud: a book with a strong narrative voice, rich language and short episodic chapters that appeals to a range of ages. The very best read-alouds manage to get listeners, young or old, emotionally invested in the story  without, however, inducing them to fits of sobbing along the way.

title: The Ride of Their Lives
description: Maggie Stiefvaters violent, stand-out fantasy, The Scorpio Races, is set on the fictional island of Thisby, in either a near past or a dystopian future where there are cars and radios but no mention of television or the Internet. Here, young men are drawn to the barren beaches of the Scorpio Sea each November to compete in a brutal race astride capaill uisce (CAP-ul ISH-kuh), commonly known as water horses.

title: Marian McPartland Stepping Away From Keyboard on Her Piano Jazz Radio Show
description: 4:06 p.m. | Updated  Marian McPartland, the jazz pianist, is stepping down as the host of the Piano Jazz after more than three decades on the air, said a spokeswoman for NPR, Anna Christopher.

title: The Caucus | Beyond the 'Oops' Moment
description: Rick Perry uses humor to try to move past Wednesday's debate stumble.

title: The Unlikely Champion of  a Water Bottle Ban
description: Xanterra Parks and Resorts, an operator of lodgings, gift shops and general merchandise stores at national parks from Death Valley to the Grand Canyon, makes tens of millions of dollars selling its wares and lodgings to tourists. A small portion of those sales  maybe half of a percentage point  comes from selling water in plastic bottles.

title: At BMWs New Electric Subbrand, a Young Designer Makes His Mark
description: BMW scheduled a layover in Manhattan Wednesday for its i3 and i8, the first cars designed for BMW i, the Munich-based automakers new, electric-oriented subbrand. The concepts will make their formal North American debut at the Los Angeles auto show next Wednesday.

title: Whats in Store | Jack Spade
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: New Greek Leader Trusted but Untested
description: FRANKFURT  If there is a Greek alive who can command the trust of international creditors and European leaders, it is probably Lucas Papademos. But the bigger question may be whether the reserved economist, a former vice president of the European Central Bank, can win the trust of the exhausted Greek people and accomplish anything lasting in what may be little more than a cameo as prime minister.

title: 3 Officers to Face Discipline for Detaining City Officials at Parade
description: The Police Department will discipline three officers for an episode in which a city councilman and another city official were detained and handcuffed after the West Indian American Day Parade in September, according to the New York Civil Liberties Union.

title: Pictures of the Day: South Korea and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from South Korea, Afghanistan, Iran and Britain.

title: Lens: Final Call for Photos
description: Lens: Final Call for Photos

title: Wanted: A New Body Man for Obama
description: There is no one at the White House remotely like Reggie Love: President Obamas personal aide, meaning his shadow and assistant for all moment-to-moment needs, but also his basketball buddy, confidant, mentee and, by Mr. Obamas own description, little brother.

title: Caucus Video: Moving Beyond the Oops Moment
description: Michael D. Shear reports that Rick Perry uses humor to try to move past Wednesdays debate stumble.

title: New York Is More Than a Little Bit Country
description: Quick: Whats the biggest market for country music? Nashville? Dallas?

title: In Nation Plagued by Abductions, Search Is On
description: Kidnappings have plagued Venezuela in recent years and at times have directly affected major league baseball players. Several of them have had family members taken away at gunpoint and held for ransom.

title: Zuccotti Park Protester Charged With Assault
description: A dispute in Zuccotti Park on Wednesday night set off a chain of confrontations involving emergency responders and Occupy Wall Street protesters, the authorities said. A medical worker was injured and a man camped out at the park was charged with assaulting him and taken to Bellevue Hospital Center, they said.

title: Exit of Italian From Banks Leadership Eases Tension
description: FRANKFURT  A senior policy maker at the European Central Bank will leave to accept a position at Harvard, the bank said Thursday, resolving a political problem that had created tension between Italy and France.

title: Apple Takes iTunes to Other Kinds of Payments
description: Apple is reaching into Googles Wallet.

title: Two Performa Events Invite One Big Question
description: After attending two Performa events  Performa Ha! and Simon Fujiwaras The Boy Who Cried Wolf  and witnessing six different performances, I find myself wondering, what is performance art anyway?

title: Inside the List
description: TEXTING WHILE SHOWERING: The actress and comedy writer Mindy Kaling lands at No. 6 on the hardcover nonfiction list this week with her memoiristic essay collection, Is Everyone Hanging Out Without Me? (And Other Concerns). Kaling is best known as the gossipy customer service rep Kelly Kapoor on NBCs sitcom The Office, where shes also a writer, producer and sometime director  a quadruple threat, she says, what of it?  and for the convenience of that shows fans, the book includes a chart comparing and contrasting Kaling with her character. On the list of things Kelly would do that Kaling would not: Fake a pregnancy for attention and Text while showering. Something both would do: Fake our own deaths to catch a serial killer.

title: Editors Choice
description: 1Q84,  by Haruki Murakami. Translated by Jay Rubin and Philip Gabriel (Knopf, $30.50.) This ambitious imaginative novel, set in 1984, is simultaneously a mystery, a love story and a dystopian fantasy that raises questions of psychology and ethics.

title: Paperback Row
description: AND THE SHOW WENT ON: Cultural Life in Nazi-Occupied Paris,  by Alan Riding (Vintage, $16.95.) Riding, a former European cultural correspondent for The New York Times, brings to life the Parisian cultural scene of the 1930s and 40s. Vivid character sketches (Camus, Sartre, Cocteau, Piaf) show both the resistance and collaborationist sides of the German occupation, as Riding explores the role of artists and writers in times of national trauma.

title: Beyond the Book Report: Ways to Respond to Literature Using New York Times Models
description: Below, we present some alternatives to that classic classroom assignment, the book report. All of our ideas are inspired by The New York Times in some way, either because weve adapted an interesting format, or because we were inspired by an article, review, essay, interview or multimedia feature.

title: Corduroy Fans Prepare for the Fabrics Day of All Days
description: To prepare for the grandest day of them all, Joseph Blake Winston IV spent two hours cutting corduroy Wednesday night in Brooklyn, his cheeks flushed like those of a young man who had never held a sewing needle.

title: Apples AssistiveTouch Helps the Disabled Use a Smartphone
description: Plenty has been written about the new iPhone 4S, with its voice-controlled virtual assistant Siri, and about iOS 5, its software.

title: Ed Pauls, Developer of Indoor Skiing Machine, Dies at 80
description: Ed Pauls, whose frustration at running on ice-slick Minnesota roads led him to develop the cross-country skiing simulator known as the NordicTrack, died on Oct. 9 at his home in Montrose, Colo. He was 80.

title: Commentary: Penn State
description: Although Joe Paternos ouster enraged Penn State students, the sports columnist William C. Rhoden thinks the university should cancel Saturdays game.

title: Sports of The Times: Penn States Next Move
description: Although Joe Paternos ouster enraged Penn State students, William C. Rhoden thinks the university should cancel Saturdays game.

title: Nuclear Waste Is Likely to Come Up at Next Debate
description: Most of the Republican presidential candidates said exactly the right thing about nuclear waste when they debated in Las Vegas in October  that they were against opening the proposed repository at Yucca Mountain. But when they meet in Spartanburg, S.C., on Saturday, that will be exactly the wrong thing to say.

title: Asked & Answered | Charlotte Rampling
description: There arent many film stars who, entering their golden years, endure as icons of sensuality. Charlotte Rampling, 65 years old and un-retouched (both on screen and in real life), is one of them. The daughter of a British colonel and NATO commander, Rampling attended tony girls schools in France and England. She modeled briefly, before trying films, and burst onto the scene in Georgy Girl (1966), in which she played a flirt who is the embodiment of Swinging London. Today, after five decades on screen (including a star turn in Viscontis classic, The Damned), and modeling for everyone from Helmut Newton to Juergen Teller, Ramplings career shows no signs of abating. In The Mill and the Cross (currently in theaters), the Polish director Lech Majewskis visually ravishing examination of a Breugel painting, she takes on the Virgin Mary; in Melancholia (opening Friday), the bad-boy Danish director Lars von Triers latest, her character is based upon von Triers despised mother. And in the fashion world, Rampling continues to inspire: Marc Jacobs designed much of his fall 2011 collection for Louis Vuitton after her role in The Night Porter (1974), Liliana Calvanis controversial, S&M-infused drama about a death-camp survivors affair with a Nazi officer (think: leather caps and suspenders).

title: Academy Studying Options for Oscar Host
description: LOS ANGELES  Look for the motion picture academy to select a new Oscar host sooner rather than later, to replace Eddie Murphy. But Tom Sherak, the president of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, in a freewheeling phone conversation on Thursday morning, wasnt yet ready to name names.

title: The Drake Show to Go On at Penn State
description: In the on-campus chaos that broke out at Penn State University late Wednesday night following the firing of the football coach Joe Paterno and the universitys president, Graham B. Spanier, rumors began circulating that a Thursday evening concert at the 15,000-seat Bryce Jordan Center in University Park had been cancelled. That made a volatile situation even more explosive until Drake, the hip-hop artist booked for the show, tried to calm things down.

title: Blame the Women
description: One of the questions often asked when sexual harassment comes up is why women do not step forward more often. Why do they accept financial payments, often small ones, in exchange for not filing formal lawsuits?

title: Union Plus Prepaid Card Comes With a High-Yield Savings Account
description: Updated | Nov. 14, 2011 Working America does not require a donation to join, as stated in a previous version of this post.

title: Simone & Will
description: Simone Levine and Will Harrell met in 1999 at a meeting for progressive attorneys in NYC. Will said he tried to talk to her for 13 years.

title: Lens: Bronxites
description: Lens: Bronxites

title: From Football Coach to Case Study at Penn State
description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa.  The morning after Penn State fired Joe Paterno, the fabled football coach, and Graham B. Spanier, the university president, Kevin Donahue skipped his regular class and slipped into one called Joe Paterno, Communications and the Media.

title: Stanford Vs. Oregon: Fathers and Sons
description: No. 3 Stanford plays No. 6 Oregon Saturday night in Palo Alto, Calif. This week, The Quad will feature fans views of a game that has national title implications. The first post is by Jim Tankersley, Stanford class of 2000, the economics correspondent for National Journal magazine in Washington, D.C. And as always, we want to hear what you think.

title: A Twist of Fate
description: I WAS drifting my way through college, coming off a rough year in which Id started to suspect that the crushes Id had on women for as long as I could remember werent simply going to stop, when I met Oren.

title: Photo Replay: Nov.10
description: A look at the day in sports, including tennis in Paris, auto racing in Wales and golf in Australia.

title: Rick Perrys Brain Freeze
description: Sometimes even a healthy brain doesnt work the way its supposed to.

title: With a Bit of Bon Ami and a Lot of Care, the Half Moon Sails Back Into View
description: Time and the elements had seriously diminished The Arrival of the Halve Maen, 1609, a lovely, century-old stained-glass window that depicts Henry Hudsons sailing vessel, the Half Moon, on the river that would bear his name.

title: Sight Unseens Online Shop
description: Best-known as curators of art and fashion, Jill Singer and Monica Khemsurov, the founders of the webzine Sight Unseen, are introducing the sites first online shop today.Now, design and fashion devotees can find handmade necklaces and bracelets created by artists and designers who are used to working in other disciplines  perfect for anyone who likes one-of-kind accessories with a back story.

title: Cache of Curiosities
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Jury Acquits Assemblyman of Conspiring to Take Bribes
description: William F. Boyland Jr., a Democratic assemblyman from one of Brooklyns most prominent political families, was acquitted on Thursday of conspiring to take $175,000 in bribes in return for using his influence on behalf of a health care organization that runs hospitals in Queens and Brooklyn.

title: With Wings and Little Else: Behind Victorias Secret Fashion Show
description: Kanye West, Jay-Z, Nicki Minaj and Adam Levine share the catwalk with Victoria Secrets Angels.

title: Country Is Music to ABCs Ears
description: Some 16.3 million viewers tuned in to the 45th Annual Country Music Association Awards on ABC on Wednesday night, as Taylor Swift was named Entertainer of the Year. The show dominated all of prime time in all ratings categories. The numbers were very similar to last year, when the broadcast averaged 16.5 million viewers.

title: Snag in Joint News Conference for Cain Accusers
description: An updated version of this blog post can be found here.

title: Step Right Up. Buy Dinner With a Justice
description: The Federalist Society will have two very special honored guests at its annual dinner tonight in Washington, D.C.: Justices Antonin Scalia and Clarence Thomas.

title: Where Children Discover Their Inner Child
description: WHAT would you think if you visited a public restroom, and the toilet began to talk  in a female voice with a British accent no less  about the bodily function youd just performed?

title: Budget Shortfall Could Imperil Subsidies for Electric Vehicles
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  In a city as eco-conscious as this one, it shouldnt surprise that Chris Paines 2006 documentary, Who Killed the Electric Car?, is a bit of a cult favorite. A cautionary tale about the shortsightedness of automakers and politicians, it is also a call to action for those here who are busy promoting the development and adoption of E.V.s.

title: From Home Fires: A U.S. Veteran Revisits Baghdad as a Civilian
description: In case you missed it, Home Fires featured a great post by veteran and author Brian Turner on his return to Baghdad. Mr. Turner served from 2003-2004 as a sergeant in the 2nd Infantry Division. He went back as a civilian in December 2010 for reasons that werent wholly clear to him at the time he resolved to do it.

title: Romenesko Leaves Poynter After Conflict Over Quotes
description: 9:11 p.m. | Updated  Jim Romenesko, the blogger who developed a large and loyal following by chronicling and summarizing news in the media world, quit his post on Thursday evening after a bizarre spat with the institute that hosts his writing.

title: Romney Revels in Michigan Homecoming
description: TROY, Mich.  The day after Rick Perry had perhaps his most awkward debate stumble this cycle, Mitt Romney kept his focus trained squarely on President Obama, embracing his Michigan roots at a rally in Troy on Thursday and never once mentioning any of his Republican rivals.

title: Euro 2012: Eyes on Tallinn
description: Words of warning to the international soccer conscious or even those who do not know their Euro 2012 from their Euro Debt Crisis: If you are passing in the vicinity of orange, white and green festooned pubs Friday do not utter the words Luck of the Irish. You might get a Shepherds pie in the face.

title: In the Deep Forest, an Unusual Bond and Untamed Beauty
description: In his poem The Way West, Underground, from his collection Turtle Island, Gary Snyder writes vividly of The split-cedar/smoked salmon/cloudy days of Oregon,/ the thick fir forests. The books title refers to an indigenous creation story in which North America emerged from some soil placed on the back of a turtle by a woman who fell from the sky. In some versions of the story a muskrat helps her. The woman in Christopher Munchs lovely, delightfully idiosyncratic Letters From the Big Man, resplendent with its own dense forests and cloudy Oregon days, has already fallen to earth and is looking for a way back up or maybe just forward. She gets help from a sasquatch.

title: Distortions In Baffling Financial Statements
description: This has been a bad year for banks. With sovereign debt no longer trusted and widespread fears of a new recession in Europe, share prices of banks have fallen sharply.

title: Q&A: An Apple Software Error on a Windows System
description: Q.

title: The Cultural Osmosis Pop Quiz: Twilight Edition
description: Subject:  Erin Judge, 30, a writer in New York.

title: Where Angels Learn to Tread
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Museum of Modern Art Reunites Rivera Murals
description: When Diego Rivera came to New York from Mexico City in 1931 to paint murals for the Museum of Modern Art, The New Yorker wrote that he liked the Ghetto, the Savoy dance hall in Harlem, Little Italy, the Pennsylvania and Grand Central stations, and American plumbing.

title: iOS and Android App Downloads Expected to Hit 25 Billion in 2011
description: By the time this year ends, Apple and Android device owners will have downloaded more than 25 billion applications, according to new estimates from Flurry, a mobile analytics firm with offices in San Francisco and New York.

title: Old Vienna, via Australia
description: Two aging Viennese sisters lived together in Australia for decades, still bickering from time to time over childhood slights. Tim Bonyhady, a young relative, was regularly dropped off at their apartment in an unimpressive brick building in Sydney.

title: Neighborhood Joint | Haandi
description: A restaurant area known as Curry Hill is popular with cabdrivers who enjoy its Pakistani and Indian food.

title: The Other Problem With Perrys Oops Moment
description: Theres really no arguing with the consensus view that, after repeatedly courting calamity in prior debates, Rick Perry did grave damage to his presidential campaign Wednesday night. First the guy says that anyone who disagrees with him on illegal immigration must not have a heart, then he gets all twisted up while trying to attack Mitt Romney, and finally comes this new gaffe about  um  hang on a second  wait, itll come to me.

title: #OccupyWallSt Roundup, Day 55
description: Protesters walking from New York City to Washington stayed with a family in Elizabeth, N.J., Wednesday night

title: Home Cooking for U.S. OIympic Team
description: Though the United States under-23 mens national team, aka the Olympic team, is training in Germany through Wednesday, come early next year it will (or make that should) benefit from playing regional qualifying matches for the London Olympics in the good old U.S. of A.

title: Hacker, Cyclist, Executive, Spy
