description: lectricit de France, the giant power utility and the worlds biggest operator of nuclear power plants, was found guilty on Thursday of spying on Greenpeace in a bizarre and convoluted computer hacking case that also ensnared the disgraced American cyclist Floyd Landis.

title: 57 Seconds of Video From Oakland Shows the Power of Citizen Journalism
description: The Oakland Police Department is investigating two incidents of apparent misconduct by officers during a protest last week, which were recorded by activists and posted online.

title: When Bodies Stumble, Spirits Still Soar
description: JENNIFER BLUM, a 37-year-old lawyer from Oakland, N.J., played tackle football for more than a decade for the New York Sharks, a team in the Independent Womens Football League. She still loved football, but her body had begun sending her insistent messages: enough of this.

title: Where Cabbies Go for Biriyani
description: LATE at night, there are intervals when Urdu is the only language spoken in Haandi, a fanatically adored restaurant that may be the most popular after-hours spot in the area known as Curry Hill. It is as integral to some taxi drivers routines as the gas needed to refuel their cars.

title: Billy Crystal to Host Oscars
description: 5:28 p.m. | Updated Billy Crystal has agreed to take over the role of Oscar host from Eddie Murphy.

title: Workaday Soccer Fans, Kicking Off With the Sun
description: IVE been playing soccer for about 30 years, and not once have I had the chance to slide triumphantly on my knees across the slick grass, chest out, arms spread, celebrating a diving-header score. Never have I danced the samba with the corner flag after netting a cheeky goal. Nor will I ever cap a wonder-strike with a running back flip.

title: E*Trade Calls Off Its Efforts to Sell Itself
description: The E*Trade Financial Corporation said Thursday that its board had withdrawn the online brokerage firms efforts to sell itself, a process that began after one of its largest investors, the Citadel Investment Group, pressed the board to explore an auction.

title: The Life Reports
description: A few weeks ago I asked readers over 70 to send me Life Reports. I asked them to evaluate their own lives, taking a step back to write a brief essay on how they had done and what they had learned in the realms of private life, career, faith, community, work and self-knowledge.

title: Mass Slaughter on a Personal Level
description: Peter Englunds intense and bighearted new book, The Beauty and the Sorrow: An Intimate History of the First World War, begins with a long dramatis personae of the sort that can make your heart sink.

title: Lens: Danfung Dennis
description: Lens: Danfung Dennis

title: Bronx Students to Paris: Here We Come!
Theme Parks Help Drive a Strong Quarter for Disney
description: LOS ANGELES  If demand for spinning teacups is any indicator, consumers are more confident than anyone thought.

title: Everyday Lives, Filled With Teachable Moments
description: The news that a reality show about Muslim families in America would be carried by TLC, the cable channel that has built its current reputation on Jon and Kate Gosselin, polygamy and Toddlers & Tiaras, couldnt help giving you a little shudder. Had anyone thought this through?

title: Exploring Anguish and Absurdity of Killings, Wanton or Sanctioned
description: In Werner Herzogs new documentary, Into the Abyss, sorrow spreads like an oil slick on water. The movie finds, in a relatively banal, thoroughly senseless American story of crime and punishment, enough darkness to make you wonder about the title. Is death, which unites murderers with their victims and executioners, and ultimately with everyone else, the abyss that Mr. Herzog wants us to contemplate? Or is he directing our attention toward a black hole that sits in the middle of life?

title: Medal Nomination Rescinded for Paterno
description: The sexual abuse scandal that got Joe Paterno fired from Penn State has now cost him a chance to receive the Presidential Medal of Freedom.

title: Finding a Quality Drink at an Affordable Price in New York
description: In New York finding a quality drink at a happy hour price can be difficult. Just the thought of paying $15 for a skimpy glass of stale Pinot or worming up to a sticky bar to get a watery vodka and soda has this Miser feeling a little queasy.

title: Alcohol Applied Liberally to a Bitterly Busted Life
description: In a darkened theater a platform suspended from the ceiling sways back and forth above a sea of empty liquor bottles. Lying prostrate on it, balding and disheveled in a rumpled tie and jacket, is Donny, wrestling with a hangover of Olympian proportions. Or maybe its just the result of a fall he has taken. Whichever, he can barely stand.

title: From Sontag to Goodbar to Gob Squad, Its Under the Radar
description: Theatrical riffs on the 1975 novel Looking for Mr. Goodbar and on the work of Susan Sontag are among the pieces to be presented at the eighth annual Under the Radar festival, running Jan. 4 to 15 at theaters and performance spaces across New York City. The 12-day festival, which is overseen by the Public Theater, features new shows from nine countries, including Argentina, Italy, Japan and Poland.

title: The Look Said One Thing, The Voice Something Else
description: Allen Stone, a 24-year-old Seattle songwriter, was an unabashed throwback when he performed at a packed S.O.B.s on Wednesday night. He talked about cellphones and social networks and sang about, among other things, the clout of the Christian right and a culture of greed. But his music reached back four decades to the late 1960s and early 70s, when songwriters like Stevie Wonder, Marvin Gaye, Donny Hathaway and Bill Withers brought introspection and social commentary to soul music.

title: Tutored in Germany, Playing for the U.S.
description: As the United States mens soccer team begins ambitiously looking toward the 2014 World Cup in Brazil, it is beginning to redefine itself in a somewhat striking way, absorbing an increasing number of players who were born and raised in Germany and learned to play the game there with great skill.

title: Charlie Rose and Gayle King in CBS Early Plan
description: Coming soon to CBS: Charlie Rose, Gayle King and a complete makeover of The Early Show, the networks low-rated morning television show.

title: Precision And Polish For Quartet On the Rise
description: In the six years since its formation the Escher String Quartet has been checking off all the boxes expected of a rising ensemble. Good conservatory? The original members all completed their studies at the Manhattan School of Music. Prestigious summer plans? The new group was quickly invited to take part in Pinchas Zukermans and Itzhak Perlmans festivals.

title: Theater Listings  Nov. 11-17
description: Theater

title: One Step Toward Repealing DOMA
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee voted today in favor of a bill that would repeal the Defense of Marriage Act, a reprehensible Clinton-era law that discriminates against same-sex couples.

title: One Man, Five Wives and Lasting Questions
description: Sometimes a new opera that seems not to be cohering as a musical and dramatic whole leaves you feeling disengaged. Dark Sisters, a chamber opera by Nico Muhly that had its premiere on Wednesday night at the Gerald W. Lynch Theater of John Jay College, is a sensitive and unusual work. But, for me, it did not finally come together.

title: Cool Britannia
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Can Charlie Rose and Gayle King Revive CBSs Early Show?
description: Brian Stelter reports that CBS is putting the finishing touches on a two-hour news show that will defy the gauzy conventions of morning television by emphasizing hard news and employing a conversational approach like The View.

title: Movie Listings for Nov. 11  17
description: Movies

title: Richard Artschwager
description: David Nolan New York

title: Mika Rottenberg and Jon Kessler: Seven
description: Performa 11 at Nicole Klagsbrun Project Space

title: Not a Whodunit, but a Who Is It of Mysteries and Fluid Realities
description: When Haley, a character in Julia Jarchos Dreamless Land, wonders about her bosss odd behavior, her boyfriend, Martin, tells her, Im sure itll all come clear. Why? Because, he says, there arent really any mysteries. Au contraire, Martin. In Ms. Jarchos elusive play nothing really comes clear, as people and language are rendered mysterious and mysteriously off-kilter.

title: Tom Sachs: Work
description: Sperone Westwater

title: Flattery (Sincere?) Lightly Dusted With Irony
description: The Whitney Museum of American Arts survey of paintings, sculptures and photographs by the appropriation artist Sherrie Levine has a provocative subtitle, Mayhem. Thats strong language but not out of place.

title: Matthew Stone: Optimism as Cultural Rebellion
description: The Hole

title: Jack Strange: Deep Down
description: Tanya Bonakdar

title: Pop and Rock Listings for Nov. 11  17
description: Pop

title: Bishop Asks That Video Be Cut From Brooklyn Museum Show
description: After the Catholic League and several members of Congress objected last year to a video by the artist David Wojnarowicz, the Smithsonian pulled the work from a large group show, Hide/Seek: Difference and Desire in American Portraiture, at the National Portrait Gallery in Washington. The video, A Fire in My Belly, is again stirring up objections, this time from the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn, which objects to a sequence that shows ants crawling over a crucifix. The Brooklyn Museum plans to restore the video to the traveling Hide/Seek exhibition, which is scheduled to run there from next Friday through Feb. 12. Bishop Nicholas A. DiMarzio wrote to John Tamagni, the chairman of the museums board, about a month ago, requesting that the video be eliminated from the show, said Stefanie Gutierrez, the dioceses press secretary. Arnold Lehman, the director of the Brooklyn Museum, said the correspondence was private, but that he believed Mr. Tamagni had responded by assuring the bishop that nothing in the exhibition was meant to be offensive. Hide/Seek, which focuses on issues of sexual identity and gender, includes 67 artists and more than 100 works, Mr. Lehman added, saying the letter explained that we were reproducing the exhibition that was at the National Portrait Gallery as originally intended by curators. Before he died of complications from AIDS in 1992, Mr. Wojnarowicz testified in court about the video during a previous controversy and said he was thinking of how Jesus took on the suffering of the world. I wanted to make a symbol that would show that he would take on the suffering of the vast amounts of addiction that I saw on the streets, he said. And I did this because I saw very little treatment available for people who had this illness.

title: Jazz Listings for Nov. 11  17
description: Jazz

title: A Conjurer of Beautiful People, Back in Town
description: Andy Warhol was a piker compared with Cecil Beaton (1904-80). A British dandy in the Wildean mold, Beaton photographed fashion for Vogue and Vanity Fair; shot portraits of rich, famous and glamorous people; drew and painted cartoons, caricatures, apparel illustrations and theatrical sets with a deft hand; published six volumes of his diaries; and won three Oscars for his costume and set designs for the Hollywood movies Gigi and My Fair Lady.  He never had the impact on fine art that Warhol did, but from the Jazz Age of the 1920s to the Pop era of the 1960s he chronicled the doings of European and American high society with amazing energy. Like Warhol, he became a celebrity in his own right.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings for Nov. 11  17
description: Classical

title: Rick Perrys Big Oops
description: Is Rick Perry finished? And what do prairie dogs do in a hailstorm? I ponder these and other questions in my latest column over at the Caucus, the Timess political blog. Since the magazine is my home, were going to start cross-posting these columns here on the 6th Floor, and I hope all our magazine readers will weigh in.

title: Ode to Four Choreographers Work, With Coyness and Charm Thrown In
description: There are other ballet companies that could present a quadruple bill featuring choreography by Merce Cunningham, Paul Taylor, Twyla Tharp and Alexei Ratmansky, but only American Ballet Theater would. And does: witness Wednesday nights program at City Center, which featured works by each choreographer.

title: Dance Listings for Nov. 11-17
description: Dance

title: Museums New Center of Gravity
description: The three-year, $70 million remodeling of the New-York Historical Society is not just a cosmetic affair. That is clear the moment you approach the main entrances widened steps on Central Park West and see a bronze, life-size statue of Abraham Lincoln standing in casual welcome.

title: Defining the Art of Gravity With Strings and a Bow
description: There is an art to projecting seriousness of intent and gravity of expression without giving in to ponderousness and angst, and for the most part the violinist Leonidas Kavakos was its master during his recital at Zankel Hall on Tuesday evening.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for Nov. 11  17
description: Art

title: Keystone Oil Pipeline Decision Moved After Election
description: 11:00 p.m. | Updated below |When in doubt, punt.

title: The Making of the French President
description: The story of The Conquest, Xavier Durringers lightly fictionalized examination of President Nicolas Sarkozys ascent to power in France, may be Shakespearean, as its director insists in the films production notes. But the movie, which begins with Mr. Sarkozys election-night victory in May 2007, only intermittently rises above the tone of an arch, sniping drawing-room comedy peopled with mild caricatures.

title: Pictures of the Day: South Korea and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from South Korea, Afghanistan, Iran and Argentina.

title: Howard Stern Is in Talks to Be Judge on Americas Got Talent
description: NBC is in talks with Howard Stern to replace Piers Morgan as one of the judges on the networks hit summer talent competition Americas Got Talent.

title: Zynga: Bully or Meritocracy?
description: Mark Pincus has some explaining to do.

title: Spare Times for Nov. 11  17
description: Museums and Sites

title: F.T.C. Said to Be Near Facebook Privacy Deal
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Facebook and the Federal Trade Commission are nearing a settlement over deceptive practices related to several Facebook features, including its privacy settings, according to two people briefed on the settlement.

title: Dont Dare Cry for These Old Friends
description: MUCH like the mixing of gasoline and fire, the combination of Patti LuPone and Mandy Patinkin is one that you expect to yield explosive results. She has memorably portrayed authority figures like Eva Pern and Momma Rose, and hes commanded characters like Che Guevara and Georges Seurat (not to mention Saul Berenson, the stern C.I.A. chief he plays on the Showtime series Homeland). And neither performer is exactly known for being shy about expressing feelings, onstage or off.

title: 60 Minutes to Look at Lawmakers and Stocks
description: Some members of the Congressional brass are bracing for what seems to be shaping up as a tough 60 Minutes piece exploring whether their influence and control of legislation gives them a leg up in playing the stock market and making other investments.

title: In This Version of Rio, Violence and Gore Are All in a Days Work
description: Is it a public hunger for truth or for gore that has made Jos Padilhas slam-bang action thriller Elite Squad: The Enemy Within the highest-grossing film ever in Brazil? Probably both.

title: Bringing Faraway Worlds Closer, And Questioning Western Intrusions
description: It seems curious that as little biographical information exists in the recent books about the ethnographic filmmaker Robert Gardner as in his movies featured in the partial retrospective of his work starting today at Film Forum. For much of a career that has spanned more than a half-century and circumnavigated the globe, Mr. Gardner has trained the camera on people whose lives, rituals, beliefs and bodily ornamentation can seem so far from early-21st-century Western life as to be from another galaxy. Yet despite Mr. Gardners seeming reluctance to share personal details, the work in Robert Gardner: Artist/Ethnographer makes it clear that hes been telling his own story all along.

title: Spare Times: For Children, for Nov. 11  17
description: PUPPETS ON FILM

title: Past and Present
description: The New-York Historical Society returns to its home on Central Park West.

title: A Globetrotting Display With American Flair
description: Europe may be a drag on our economy, but at least it continues to send us some of its better art fairs. Miamis version of Art Basel, returning next month for its 10th edition, has been enormously popular; a stateside Londons Frieze will have its debut on Randalls Island this spring. And now the Pavilion of Art and Design, which began in Paris 14 years ago and expanded to London in 2007, has made a high-profile, auction-week entrance at the Park Avenue Armory.

title: Mayhem
description: A look at the Whitney Museum of American Arts survey of works by Sherrie Levine.

title: Consumer Groups Question Capital Ones HSBC Deal
description: Consumer groups want regulators to deepen their scrutiny of Capital Ones planned takeover of HSBCs American credit card business, one of two major deals that Capital One struck this year.

title: How Obama Can Win Ohio Again
description: The decisive referendum vote to repeal the bill that would limit collective bargaining by public sector unions has changed the political landscape in Ohio. Tuesdays vote on Senate Bill 5 could and should be a harbinger for the 2012 presidential election. By mounting a direct assault on public sector workers and the unions who represent them, Gov. John R. Kasich of Ohio may have done more to help Barack Obama win re-election than anything Obamas political team is likely to do over the next 12 months.

title: China as Paper Republic
description: In 1978, 18-year-old Yu Hua was assigned the task of administering vaccinations in southern China. The only needles available were barbed from overuse, and with each shot he extracted a scrap of flesh. At night, haunted by the sobs of children whose arms he had bloodied, he would grind the needles sharp until his fingers blistered. In the introduction to his new essay collection, China in Ten Words, he blames himself for making the children suffer, and says he should have tested a needle on his own arm  sacrificed his own chunk of flesh. It is a shrewd gambit for a Chinese writer seeking to speak his mind without bringing down the ire of the government: to begin by offering, in proper Maoist tradition, self-criticism.

title: Julian Barnes and the Emotions of Englishmen
description: Many literary careers have been made, and doubtless more will be, by conveying the inwardness, awkwardness and social anxiety that constrict British mores like a very tightly wrapped cummerbund. This suffocating self-consciousness lies at the heart of British humor, whether in the farcical scramble of trying to keep up appearances or the risible but sincere terror of being mocked  which sniping English schoolboys still fear, even when theyre grown up, bald and 70.

title: Going Over the Top, Then Downhill
description: The continued success of Adam Sandler  the audiences who flocked to Grown Ups can be counted on to show up for his new one, Jack and Jill  proves that everyone loves a sore winner. Back in the 1990s, when he was consolidating his stardom and working his id in epochal comedies like Billy Madison and The Waterboy, Mr. Sandlers puerile aggression had a naughty, anti-authoritarian kick. His genial hostility was a grinning rebuke to propriety, his brattiness a breath of fresh air in a prim and anxious culture.

title: Soldier Is Convicted of Killing Afghan Civilians for Sport
description: JOINT BASE LEWIS-McCHORD, Wash.  The soldier accused of being the ringleader of a rogue Army unit that killed three Afghan civilians last year for sport, crimes that angered Afghan leaders and villagers and rattled high levels of the American military, was found guilty of all charges on Thursday.

title: Annabelle Lyon, Dancer With Balanchine, Dies at 95
description: Annabelle Lyon, an American ballerina who danced with some of the most important companies in the formative years of 20th-century American ballet, died on Nov. 4 at her home in Mansfield, Mass. She was 95.

title: Cosmetologist Guilty in Silicone-Injection Death
description: An unlicensed cosmetologist was convicted of criminally negligent homicide in the Bronx on Thursday in the case of a client who came to her for silicone injections in her buttocks and died of a silicone embolism in her lungs, the Bronx district attorneys office said.

title: South Sudan Accuses Sudan of Bombing Civilian Camp Amid Fears of War
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Civilians fled as bombs fell on a camp for displaced people in South Sudan on Thursday, and President Salva Kiir accused the Sudanese government of planning to invade his newly independent nation.

title: Thwarting Paparazzi and Thugs
description: Cultivation and fine manners are nowhere to be found in the foul urban cesspool of William Monahans London Boulevard. This palpitating mess of a movie certainly doesnt lack for pungent atmosphere. Chris Mengess cinematography paints the city in shades of smeared lipstick, dried blood and grime.

title: Europes Meltdown, a Pretty Good Yarn
description: Once again, were faced with a potential economy-destroying thriller written in a language few of us understand. As in 2008, the only way to follow each beat of the story is to buy a copy of Stigums and read some of the worlds least exciting prose on the confusing credit instruments that will either save or destroy us all.

title: Its Dark, Twisted and Unexplainable
description: Sing to me, O Muse, of gods and men, of timeless legends and forgettable retreads. Speak of Immortals, and answer in all seriousness: did you even read that awful script?

title: At a Big Church, a Small Group Health Solution
description: About a year ago, Rev. Rick Warren, the pastor of Saddleback Church in southern California, was conducting a baptism when he noticed something. As with everything at this megachurch, with some 30,000 members, baptisms are large events  this time, 858 people were being baptized. Along about 500 I thought  this is my honest truth, it wasnt a very spiritual thought  were all fat, Warren told his congregation later. I know pastors arent supposed to be thinking that when theyre baptizing, but that was what I thought: were all fat. But Im fat, and Im a terrible model of this.

title: Where Cabbies Go for Biriyani
description: Late at night, there are intervals when Urdu is the only language spoken inside Haandi, a fanatically adored restaurant that may be the most popular after-hours spot in the area known as Curry Hill. It is as integral to some taxi drivers routines as the gas needed to refuel their cars.

title: The Top 10 Rick Perry Excuses on Letterman
description: 12:01 a.m. | Updated  Whats the best way to deal with a political gaffe that turns into a national punchline? For Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, the answer seemed to be: double down.

title: Two Rob Armored Car Guard of $100,000
description: A pair of men made off with about $100,000 after robbing an armored car guard who was making a delivery to a check-cashing store in the Bronx on Thursday morning, federal authorities say.

title: Paterno at the End: Far From the Coach We Thought We Knew
description: What were the young scholars really saying Wednesday night when they massed at Penn State and threw cans at police officers?

title: Liberias President Wins Boycotted Runoff Vote
description: MONROVIA, Liberia  Election officials announced on Thursday that Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, Africas only female president, had been re-elected by an overwhelming margin this week in a runoff vote that was marred by an opposition boycott.

title: Ahead of New Rules, Europes Banks Go on a Selling Spree
description: LONDON  Europes banking sector is ready for a shake-up as its largest financial institutions try to slim down their operations in response to the sovereign debt crisis.

title: Should Penn State Cancel Its Season?
Dreamscapes From a Singular Rock Group
description: The best concert films achieve a marriage of sound and image that feels effortlessly harmonious, and in that regard Inni, a musical portrait of the Icelandic band Sigur Ros, leaves most of its genre in the dust. Captured mainly in a dreamlike haze of throbbing black and white that perfectly mirrors the bands haunting, otherworldly songs, this eccentric profile is a shimmering example of what it means to show rather than tell.

title: A Crime Unfolds, Explodes and Ends, All in 7 Minutes
description: The 911 call came at 11:30 p.m. on Wednesday. The caller, an employee at a deli in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, said the store had just been robbed at gunpoint.

title: City Election Signals a Shift to the Right
description: To celebrate his unofficial victory in the San Francisco mayors race Tuesday night, Edwin M. Lee was joined onstage at the Palace Hotel by one of his most influential backers, Ron Conway, the Republican Silicon Valley investor.

title: Bound by Love and Disability, and Keeping a Vow Until the End
description: At age 7, Edwin Morales met Noemi Rivera. Three decades later, sitting in a Szechuan restaurant on the Upper West Side, he slipped a ring on her finger. Both families opposed a marriage, and nature itself seemed lined up against them. They used wheelchairs because of cerebral palsy and needed help taking care of themselves. Still, Mr. Morales said, We made a promise we werent going to leave each other again.

title: A Shortsighted Victory in Delaying the Keystone Pipeline
description: AFTER months of protests and more than a thousand arrests , environmental activists have succeeded in getting the United States government to indefinitely delay approval of the Keystone XL pipeline, which would carry oil-laden bitumen from Canada to the Gulf Coast. They are understandably jubilant, but their celebrations are shortsighted. The tactics and arguments that have won the day are ultimately as likely to retard clean energy development as they are to thwart dirty fuels.

title: Mortgage Settlement: Many Are Left Behind
description: Sometime next month, Raul Pea will give up his East Oakland home. Mr. Pea, a 40-year-old dishwasher, used a subprime loan from Countrywide Financial to buy his two-bedroom house for $359,000 in 2005. He is in the process of selling it in a short sale for just $100,000.

title: France Demands Inquiry Into S.&P. Error
description: The French government demanded an investigation of the Standard & Poors ratings agency Thursday after the company said it erroneously sent an e-mail to some subscribers suggesting that it had lowered Frances flawless credit rating. The episode briefly sowed turmoil in markets about the safety of the nations sovereign debt.

title: Escaping Nosy Parents, and the Morality Police, Too
description: A scattered yet engaging soap exalted by the particulars of its birth, Dog Sweat follows a handful of young Iranians as they pursue forbidden passions under the watchful gaze of a conservative Islamic society.

title: Despite the Fanfare, Little Proof of Election Irregularities
description: After what seemed like a particularly dirty mayoral election, San Francisco voters might be in the mood for a long, hot bath. But if the past is any indication, they can skip the soap  allegations of election malfeasance are most likely to remain only that: allegations.

title: ESPN Coverage Suffered for Lack of Live Pictures
description: ESPN covered the student unrest after the firing of Penn State Coach Joe Paterno as if it hadnt mastered this TV thing. So much of it was done by phone with reporters and analysts talking to studio anchors that they seemed to be trying to emulate Edward R. Murrow calling the London blitz on radio.

title: Transcripts From Nixons Watergate Testimony
description: On Thursday, the National Archives released 26 files from the records of the Watergate Special Prosecution Force. Included in the documents are these transcripts of Richard M. Nixons testimony before the Grand Jury in the Watergate investigation.

title: Leaving Camp Victory in Iraq, the Very Name a Question Mark
description: CAMP VICTORY, Iraq  For most of the war, nine gaudy palaces outside Baghdad  monuments to Saddam Husseins grandeur and questionable taste  served as the headquarters for the American military in Iraq.

title: Yearning to Breathe Free on the Web
description: Net neutrality  the idea that Internet service providers should not play favorites with Web sites and applications, and keep Web traffic equally open to all  is the focus of Barbershop Punk, an engaging, provocative documentary using one mans crusade against Comcast (now merged with NBC Universal) to explore issues of Web freedom. Robb Topolski, a former policeman, was a grandfather, software tester and barbershop-quartet baritone in Hillsboro, Ore., who found that Comcast, his Internet service provider, was interfering with his peer-to-peer sharing of public-domain material. The Associated Press picked up his story, and the Federal Communications Commission eventually issued a ruling against Comcast, since shot down by an appeals court.

title: Wedding Etiquette
description: Paying for the Pancakes

title: CNBCs Republican Debate Tops Cable Ratings
description: Heres another indication of heavy interest in the presidential election: the Republican presidential primary debate broadcast by CNBC on Wednesday night was the most popular program on all of cable during the time it was taking place.

title: Apple Uses Over-the-Air Software Update
description: Apple on Thursday issued a software update for its iOS 5 mobile platform that fixes a number of minor problems on the iPhone and iPad.

title: Twitter Ordered to Yield Data in WikiLeaks Case
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A federal judge on Thursday ruled that Twitter, the popular microblogging platform, must reveal information about three of its account holders who are under investigation for their possible links to the WikiLeaks whistle-blower site.

title: A Girl and Her Much Nicer Horse
description: Reinventing the Depression drama for new-millennium tweens The Greening of Whitney Brown follows the rehabilitation of a spoiled Philadelphia princess as she loses her luxuries and finds a horse.

title: Newly Released Transcripts Show a Bitter and Cynical Nixon in 75
description: For 11 hours of secret grand jury testimony 36 years ago, Richard M. Nixon, a disgraced former president, fenced with prosecutors over his role in the Watergate scandals, bemoaned politics as a dirty business played by both sides and testily  as he described his own demeanor  suggested he was the victim of a special prosecutors office loaded with Democrats.

title: A Violinist Brought to Life by His Students
description: For its first half-hour Gods Fiddler, a documentary about the violinist Jascha Heifetz, one of the 20th centurys greatest musicians, seems as if its going to be as cold as his playing was sometimes accused of being. But it warms up a bit when his former aides, accompanists and, especially, students start sharing their memories of this quirky, aloof man.

title: Leaving Camp Victory in Baghdad
description: The United States military is weighing what items of historical or memorial value should be taken out of Camp Victory before Dec. 31, when the last American soldiers leave.

title: An Aging Loser Gets the Girl(s)
description: Steve Guttenberg is probably supposed to be a lovable loser in A Novel Romance, a drab, clumsy film by Allie Dvorin, but he can manage to be merely annoying. Mr. Guttenberg, though, deserves only part of the blame for this unrewarding movie. Even a skilled actor, which he certainly isnt, wouldnt have been able to bring life to Mr. Dvorins shallow script.

title: Cyclist Fashion Is Diversifying, Way Beyond Spandex
description: When Gwen Lutz, a clothing designer and avid bicyclist, was asked to produce a bike fashion event at the annual San Francisco Bike Expo three years ago, she struggled to find outfits that would not seem out of place at work or in a bar. For so long, bike-centered apparel could be summed up in two words: neon Spandex.

title: Pacquiao Packs an Economic Punch in Las Vegas
description: LAS VEGAS  Despite the fact that Manny Pacquiao hails from the Philippines and came to stardom toward the end of his career, to this city and Nevada he represents far more than a talented boxer who plies his trade twice annually under their famous neon lights.

title: A Petri Dish of Activism, and Germs
description: The chorus began quietly at a recent strategy session inside Zuccotti Park, with a single cough from a security team member, a muffled hack between puffs on his cigarette. Then a colleague followed. Then another.

title: Perry Goes on TV to Regain Footing After Debate
description: WASHINGTON  Gov. Rick Perry of Texas tried to neutralize an onslaught of ridicule with a dose of humor on Thursday, appearing on television from morning until night in an urgent attempt to deflect grave concerns about his candidacy and to keep the Republican presidential race from advancing without him.

title: Leaving Camp Victory in Baghdad
description: The United States military is weighing what items of historical or memorial value should be taken out of Camp Victory before Dec. 31, when the last American soldiers leave.

title: Stanford Vs. Oregon: Now Much More Than a Pleasant Afternoon
description: No. 3 Stanford plays No. 6 Oregon Saturday night in Palo Alto, Calif. This week, The Quad will feature fans views of a game that has national title implications. This post is by John Arthur, the executive editor of The Bakersfield Californian and a 1970 graduate of Stanford. And as always, we want to hear what you think.

title: Ascent of a Woman
description: SEATTLE  Crawling along a ledge leading to the 13,775-foot summit of Grand Teton two months ago, Senator Maria Cantwell, Democrat of Washington, paused for an instant at the crux of the climb. The gap between her and the next solid footing was nearly half a vertical mile of thin Rocky Mountain air.

title: Abuse Inquiry Set Tricky Path for a Governor
description: For months, Gov. Tom Corbett of Pennsylvania had reason to suspect a sexual abuse scandal was going to explode at Penn State University. He also had no way to talk about it, or to prepare for it.

title: Deaths of Disabled in New Yorks Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Filling of Vacancies Lags in County Health System
description: Nearly two years after the Cook County Board of Commissioners voted to make more money available forH.I.V. and AIDS testing for detaineesentering the Cook County Jail, most of the men coming into jail are not being tested because of a lengthy delay in hiring a phlebotomist to do the job.

title: Upheaval at Penn State: The Night Paterno Was Fired

description: To the Editor:

title: Groupon Is Hot, but Is It Strong Enough?
description: For Kevin Willer, chief executive of the Chicagoland Entrepreneurial Center, Groupons $700 million initial public offering last week could be the start of something big.

title: Maam and Bless Your Heart: Southern Manners
description: To the Editor:

title: Mets Remain Vague About Status of Stars
description: With baseballs hot stove onlywarming up, Mets fans have been left to dissect the few vague public comments made by the teams front office about the potential comings and goings of twostar players.

title: With Fears of Asian Carp Fading, a Sleek Campaign to Revive Public Concern
description: There was a time, not long ago, when environmentalists could arouse fears of invasive Asian carp by highlighting videos of four-foot-long fish leaping out of downstate rivers or the discovery of carp DNA samples a stones throw from Lake Michigan.

title: Greece and Italy Seek a Solution From Technocrats
description: ROME  Under the white-hot pressure of the bond markets and the glare of European leaders, both Greece and Italy snapped into action on Thursday, looking to technocratic leaders to pull them back from the brink of chaos.

title: Leaving Obamas Shadow, to Cast One of His Own
description: For several months now, Reggie Love has been living two lives. Some days he is a part-time student at the University of Pennsylvanias Wharton School, pursuing a masters in business administration. On others he continues his role as personal aide, shadow, caretaker, basketball buddy and roving diplomat for the president of United States.

title: Even Cains Old Jokes Face Extra Scrutiny Now
description: It was another offhand joke by Herman Cain.

title: Mercy Not Sought or Given, Killer of Four Is Sentenced
description: RIVERHEAD, N.Y.  Amid the swirl of raw emotions in a Suffolk County courtroom on Thursday, one sentiment was clearly shared: David Laffer, who killed four people inside a Long Island pharmacy in June, deserved no leniency.

title: A Day Later, Rage Turns to Gloom
description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa. Only a few hours after a raucous downtown protest following the firing of Joe Paterno, the Penn State campus took on a funereal feel Thursday, with students struggling to come to grips with the magnitude of a sexual abuse scandal that has shaken this college town to its core.

title: Bloggingheads: Cain for Vice President?
description: Benjy Sarlin, left, of Talking Points Memo and Daniel Foster of National Review debate a possible Romney/Cain presidential ticket.

title: Can Italy Put Berlusconi Behind It?
description: Princeton, N.J.

title: Bankruptcy Rarely Offers Easy Answer for Counties
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.  When Alabamas Jefferson County filed for the largest municipal bankruptcy in American history this week, it looked a little like another domino had fallen.

title: A Final Proposal, With Hopes of a Vote
description: With one final proposal and one last ultimatum, the N.B.A. put the wheels in motion Thursday for a delayed season that could begin Dec. 15, or perhaps not at all.

title: After Downfall, Veteran Finds New Purpose
description: From his 12th-story window in the Bronx, Joseph Tomasello took in a panoramic view of the landscape by the evening light.

title: To Save Our Economy, Ditch Taiwan
description: Washington

title: Senate Approves Two Pieces of Jobs Bill
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate overwhelmingly approved two elements of President Obamas jobs bill on Thursday as members of a Congressional committee on deficit reduction struggled to overcome bitter partisan disputes over how much to raise taxes.

title: Concerns Raised for Boys in Sandusky Case
description: A lawyer who is advising some of the young men who said they were sexually abused by Jerry Sandusky, a former assistant football coach at Penn State, said Thursday that the university did not take into account how the firing of the longtime coach Joe Paterno might affect the accusers.

title: Tech Talk Podcast: Childrens Books on Tablets
description: Many children have become early adopters of touch-screen technology. Theyve taken to smartphones and tablets with ease. But what makes a good app for kids? Deborah Forte, the president of Scholastic Media, discusses how her publishing company approaches the app-creation process and what types of childrens books and characters adapt well to the transition from printed page to digital screen.

title: Mexico: Trafficking Suspect Caught
description: The army said Thursday that it had detained a man whom the United States considers one of the most-wanted drug traffickers from Mexico. Mexican authorities describe the man, Ovidio Limn Snchez, as a leader of the Sinaloa drug cartel, one of the largest and most powerful in Mexico. The United States, which accuses him of sending cocaine across the border, had offered a reward of up to $5 million for his capture. He was arrested Wednesday in the city of Culiacn and is expected to face extradition to the United States.

title: In N.H.L., Disclosure of Concussions Is Lagging
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Concussions continued to cast a long shadow over the N.H.L. on Thursday.

title: Cain on Camera Joking About Anita Hill
description: Watch the latest video at video.foxnews.com

title: War Resonates Anew on Hallowed French Ground
description: CHTEAU-THIERRY, France  The remains of some of the last American doughboys of World War I to be identified were found just a few years ago, buried in a vegetable garden in this little town, wine bottles clasped in their crossed arms. They had died of their wounds in a field hospital set up in an adjoining farmhouse.

title: Lottery Numbers
New to City, Statue Seeks Resting Place
description: One of the guest stars in the Veterans Day Parade on Friday is a 5,000-pound statue that just arrived in New York and still needs a permanent home.

title: Friday: Happy 11/11/11!
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Today is a special day, and its not just because we have a new puzzle by wunderkind Alex Vratsanos to solve. If you remember, Mr. Vratsanos set himself a goal to have a crossword puzzle published in The New York Times before he graduated from high school, and he succeeded. His debut was on the day of his graduation ceremony. Now, he is a student at the University of Delaware and is back to help us celebrate another big day.

title: The Inequality Map
description: Foreign tourists are coming up to me on the streets and asking, David, you have so many different kinds of inequality in your country. How can I tell which are socially acceptable and which are not?

title: An End to Chinas Real Estate Boom
description: Real estate transactions in China have slowed so quickly that thousands of brokers have been laid off and hundreds of offices have closed.

title: A Master of Mass Flirtation
description: Hugh Jackman practices safe sex like nobody else. His sweet-and-hot new show Hugh Jackman: Back on Broadway, which opened on Thursday night at the Broadhurst Theater, is a great, guilt-free platonic one-night stand. O.K., so maybe the guy tends to run on about himself (his dreams, his job, his family, you know the drill) and cracks a few too many hokey jokes.

title: McQueary Wont Coach in Game vs. Nebraska
description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa.  The Penn State assistant Mike McQueary will not coach against Nebraska on Saturday, the university said Thursday evening, because there had been multiple threats against him.

title: Government Policies Cool Chinas Real Estate Boom
description: SANYA, China  Chinas nationwide real estate boom became so manic last year that many would-be buyers camped in tents on the sidewalks of this tropical island city to be at the front of the line when condominiums went on sale  even though the condos had not yet been built.

title: Legends of the Fail
description: This is the way the euro ends  not with a bang but with bunga bunga. Not long ago, European leaders were insisting that Greece could and should stay on the euro while paying its debts in full. Now, with Italy falling off a cliff, its hard to see how the euro can survive at all.

title: Of Kentucky
description: The photographer Shelby Lee Adams captures the people who live in a holler where he was raised in Hazard, Kentucky.

title: City Delays Tighter Rules for Homeless People Seeking Shelter
description: Facing mounting criticism from the City Council and a lawsuit from advocates for the homeless, the Bloomberg administration on Thursday postponed until next month the imposition of tighter rules for homeless people seeking shelter.

title: Now, Italy
description: There was nothing unpredictable about the financial crisis now threatening to engulf Italy and perhaps bring down the euro. Economists and analysts have been writing about it for months, but Italian politicians, starting with Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, did almost nothing to head it off. And European leaders like Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany and President Nicolas Sarkozy of France did far too little to prepare for it.

title: Posadas Former Teammate Dissects His Own Path
description: Jorge Posada said earlier this week that his Yankees career was most definitely over.

title: Unesco Trims Its Budget
description: The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, known as Unesco, will trim its budget, restrict travel and publications, put all spending under review, and freeze any new projects between now and the end of the year after the United States withdrew its funding, its director general, Irina Bokova, said Thursday. Washington stopped providing funding, including about $65 million for the 2011 budget, after Unesco admitted the Palestinians as a full member. The United States has said it had no choice because legislation dating back to the 1990s mandates a complete cutoff of money to any United Nations agency that accepts the Palestinians as a full member. The United States provides 22 percent of the Unesco budget, and the withdrawal of funding has thrown the organization into crisis. Also on Thursday, Gabon announced that it would provide an extra $2 million for this years budget.

title: Passport Control
description: The Supreme Court heard argument this week in an unusual case about the executive branchs authority over foreign policy and whether the court can adjudicate a dispute between the president and Congress on the issue. The court should rule on the merits and hold that Congress overstepped its power.

title: Coal Project Hits Snag as a Partner Backs Off
description: WASHINGTON  The leading American effort to capture carbon dioxide from coal plants has hit a stumbling block that could imperil the project and set back a promising technology for addressing global warming, people involved in the venture said.

title: Russia: Hopes for Space Probe Fade
description: Hopes of salvaging an ambitious unmanned mission to Mars dwindled on Thursday, with Russian scientists failing to make contact with a multimillion dollar space probe that stalled in a low-earth orbit after the engines responsible for sending it toward Mars did not fire. Experts said that there was still a small chance the probes software could be reprogrammed and the mission saved, though there were growing fears that the craft, filled with toxic fuels, could crash to earth within days or weeks. With every orbit around the earth, the craft is losing altitude and speed, an official told the news agency Interfax. Officials involved with the space program told Russian news agencies that they made several failed attempts on Thursday to restart the engines on the Phobos-Grunt spacecraft, which was supposed to bring back soil samples from the Martian moon Phobos.

title: Rethinking Ways to Divide Living Space
description: IS there a mismatch between the housing New Yorkers need and the housing that gets built? Only 17 percent of dwelling units in the city are occupied by parents raising children under 25, according to the nonprofit Citizens Housing and Planning Council, but most new homes are designed with such traditional families in mind.

title: As Oil Production Rises, Libya Expects to Hit Prewar Levels by June
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  The acting Libyan oil minister, Ali Tarhouni, said on Thursday that so much progress was being made in resuscitating the countrys oil fields that production would return to more than 40 percent of its prewar level by the end of the year and completely recuperate by June.

title: An Audience of High School Students Gets a Life Lesson from Penns President
description: Are you anxious about getting into college? Amy Gutmann, president of the University of Pennsylvania, asked two hundred high school juniors and seniors on Thursday.

title: Lives During Wartime, Vol. 3
description: Last week, the editors of Home Fires invited readers to send their recollections and photographs of members of the United States Armed Forces in acknowledgment of Veterans Day. Below is a selection of those remembrances submitted by friends and family of veterans, and from veterans themselves. Last years Lives During Wartime post can be read here.

title: Jets Need Own Plan to Defeat the Patriots
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The Jets opponent Sunday night is familiar, and so is the challenge facing their defensive staff.

title: Time and Again, Big Multiples Fall
Living With Noises, Pleasant and Less So
description: WITH a baby on the way, Laura Clarke and Edward Jose knew they would soon outgrow their Harlem one-bedroom. So, during Dr. Clarkes pregnancy, they began the hunt for someplace larger. Unsure of what they wanted to buy, they could not make a decision.

title: One of Cains Accusers Is Waiting for Others to Come Forward, Her Lawyer Says
description: WASHINGTON  The lawyer for one of the women who have accused Herman Cain of sexually harassing them in the late 1990s said Thursday afternoon that she has been unable to coordinate a joint press conference with three other women who have made similar accusations.

title: Penn States Response
description: The Pennsylvania State University Board of Trustees made the only rational choice on Wednesday when it dismissed the football coach Joe Paterno for failing to pursue a horrific allegation of sexual assault of a child that was brought to his attention by a subordinate in 2002. Mr. Paterno, who failed to call the police, now concedes that he did not do enough to curb what prosecutors describe as a 15-year cycle of child rape and sexual assaults, perpetrated partly on university property, by Jerry Sandusky, Mr. Paternos former assistant coach.

title: The Danger of Contagion From Europe
description: The dangers from Europes growing financial crisis

title: Giants Baas Looking Forward to Knocking Heads With Former Teammates
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  David Baas, the Giants 312-pound center with a face as wide as the front of an old DeSoto, has reasons for wanting to play Sunday apart from the fact that he was a member of the San Francisco 49ers for six years.

title: Protection for the Ocean Food Chain
description: People do not eat menhaden, an oily little forage fish. But the fish that people do eat  like bluefish and striped bass  depend heavily on menhaden for their diet. So it is very good news that the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission, representing 15 eastern states and the federal government, has now moved to protect the menhaden, an essential link in the food chain whose numbers have plummeted over the last half-century. The commission voted to cut the menhaden harvest 37 percent by 2013, compared with 2010 levels.

title: Europes Banks Found Safety of Bonds a Costly Illusion
description: PARIS  As the bets that European banks made on United States mortgage investments went bust a few years ago, bankers piled into what they saw as a safe refuge: bonds issued by countries in Europes seemingly ironclad monetary union.

title: The Pedestrian Loses the Way
description: IN the future, perhaps our time will be known as the first decade of the Bicycle Wars, with righteous armies fighting over traffic lanes, bike paths and sidewalks, indeed over the very purpose of the streets themselves. Like many wars, its a question of territory, and the pedestrian has been losing for years.

title: Concerns for Belichick: Jets ... and the Patriots
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  In Bill Belichicks perfect world there is one overriding constant: an intense focus on the task at hand with no time or room for distractions.

title: What to Know When Interviewing With Cubs
description: Pete Mackanin is a smart guy. He has to be if he graduated from Brother Rice High School, a South Side citadel of learning where several scholars I know first embarked on the path to true knowledge.

title: Whos Winning the Republican Race? Everybody!
description: Polls indicating that Republican voters prefer this or that candidate for president are often as simplistic as they are hard to avoid. Many observers complain that media coverage of the campaign is too focused on the horse race. In some ways, though, the coverage isnt even as nuanced as that of a horse race, where horses are picked to win, but also to place or to show.

title: Elite Runners From Elite Schools Vie for a Title
description: Konrad Surkont is hoping to update his status on Facebook.

description: caprice \k-pres\ noun

title: Retiring Without a Home Loan
description: IT has long been an element of the American dream for a homeowner to burn the mortgage note and celebrate, as soon as he or she is able to pay it off. Conventional wisdom held that this would help pave the way for a debt-free retirement.

title: German-American Relations Paying Dividends
description: The names are old ones (Thomas Dooley), newly familiar ones (Jermaine Jones, Timmy Chandler) and a few most American fans are just learning (Fabian Johnson, Alfredo Morales). The German-American pipeline of soccer talent was put in place long before Jurgen Klinsmann, a German soccer legend, took over as coach of the United States national team, but he may stand to benefit from it more than any of his predecessors.

description: Mr. Craig, 56, is a senior vice president of Hines, in charge of the developers New York region.

title: Morris Philipson, Who Led the University of Chicago Press, Dies at 85
description: Morris Philipson, who steered the University of Chicago Press as it became the largest and one of the nations most important publishers of monumental scholarly works, modern fiction and postwar European philosophy, died on Nov. 3 in Chicago. He was 85.

title: National Spotlight Might Shine Too Bright for Gaffe-Prone Perry
description: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

title: Court Told of Payments to Councilman Seabrook
description: An associate of a Bronx city councilman testified on Thursday that the councilman, Larry B. Seabrook, regularly asked a political organization that he was affiliated with to reimburse him for a variety of expenses.

title: Wind Money Fuels Spending and Benefits in Small Schools
description: BLACKWELL, Tex.  When people complain about the weather here, Abe Gott, the school superintendent, just smiles.

title: Rich Man, Poor Man; Congress Has Both
description: WASHINGTON  A Texas multimillionaire, Representative Michael McCaul, Republican of Austin, recently topped a list of Congresss wealthiest members, and five other Texans joined him in the top 50.

title: Farmers Insurance Advertisement
description: J.K. Simmons appears in a humorous campaign for Farmers Insurance.

title: Calle 13 Wins Big at Latin Grammys
description: Calle 13, a Puerto Rican hip-hop group with Pan-American music, rebellious politics and a raunchy sense of humor, triumphed at the 12th annual Latin Grammy Awards, which were televised Thursday from the Mandalay Bay Events Center in Las Vegas. Entren Los Que Quieran (Everybody Is Welcome), the fourth Calle 13 album, was nominated for 10 awards this year, a record for the Latin Grammys. It helped that Calle 13s eclecticism qualified its songs for multiple categories Urban, Alternative, Tropical.

title: Funny Faces Meant to Whet Buyers Appetites

title: U.S.-France: 5 Matchups Worth Watching
description: Barcelona defender Eric Abidal will not be suiting up. Neither will Manchester City midfielder Samir Nasri, Manchester United defender Patrice Evra, nor Milan center back Philippe Mexs.

title: Immersing Yourself in the Story
description: Tired of news footage where all you can see is whats right in front you as the camera rolls down a road in a war-torn landscape? A new iPad app is about to change all that, immersing viewers in a near virtual reality where they can become director and editor.

title: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Friday
description: Prime Minister Manmohan Singh described Pakistans prime minister, Yousaf Raza Gilani, as a man of peace on Thursday, after emerging from a meeting with him on the sidelines of the SAARC Summit in the Maldives. Pakistan declared that Ajmal Kasab, accused in the November 26, 2008, attacks in Mumbai, is a terrorist who should be sent to the gallows. The two premiers pledged to write a new chapter in bilateral relations by resuming dialogue on all issues, including ones that had bedeviled ties (The Indian Express). Mr. Singh announced that India has decided to move toward a Preferential Trade Agreement with Pakistan, his return gift for Pakistans most-favored nation gesture. He also said that a liberalized visa regime would soon be implemented, replacing the current system (The Hindu).

title: Special Parking Rules
description: Because of Veterans Day, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended on Friday in New York City. Other regulations will remain in effect.

description: NYT Front Page for 11/11/2011

title: Leaving Camp Victory in Iraq
description: Andrew E. Kramer reports that, as American soldiers leave Camp Victory in Iraq, they must also be mindful of what theyre leaving behind:

title: Corrections: November 11
description: NEW YORK

title: High Ideals and Corruption Dominate Think Festival Agenda
description: When Tehelka held its first conference, in 2006, it was called Summit of the Powerless and took place in an auditorium at Jamia Millia Islamia University in New Delhi. The schedule was filled with earnest discussions of Naxalism, farmer suicides and the desperation of the urban poor.Last weekend, Indias most famous crusading investigative magazine hosted a very different sort of event: a glitzy and glamorous celebration of ideas called the Think Festival, held at a five-star resort in the tiny, sun-kissed state of Goa.

title: An Accidental Monument to African Ambivalence
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia  The African Union is now putting the finishing touches on its shiny new home  a calabash-domed conference hall and a curving blade of a tower  right on the site of the citys former central prison. Known to Ethiopians as Alem Bekagn, or farewell to the world, this plot of land has been a symbol of human rights abuses for three generations.

title: Arab League Support Sought in Pressuring Syria
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Two leading international human rights organizations are calling on the Arab League to back the referral of Syria to the International Criminal Court for committing crimes against humanity in its ferocious campaign to crush an eight-month uprising.

title: Crat Me No Techno, Continued
description: Henry Farrell links approvingly to an FT column criticizing the latest trend in euro wishful thinking, the installation of technocrats supposedly above politics to rule troubled nations:

title: Incestuous Amplification, European Style
description: Brad DeLong sends us to a piece by Nouriel Roubini from almost six years ago, describing how Giulio Tremonti, Italys economy minister, threw a hissy fit when Roubini suggested that Italy might have problems with its euro membership. And no, Im not being unfair  read Roubinis piece. It was quite something.

title: Liquidity Traps And Hawaiian Shirts
description: Its somewhat awesome to realize that many people in the world of finance are just now awakening to the reality that were in a liquidity trap. Heres the FT:

title: Original Original Sin
description: Giancarlo Corsetti reminds me that he made the point that the euro did nothing to correct the problem of original sin  borrowing in someone elses currency  last year. He was completely right.

title: Test Yourself | English, Nov. 11, 2011
description: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article Spotted Horses in Cave Art Werent Just a Figment, DNA Shows.

title: News Quiz | Nov. 11, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Nov. 11, 1918 | World War I Ends
description: On Nov. 11, 1918, fighting in World War I came to an end following the signing of an armistice between the Allies and Germany that called for a ceasefire effective at 11 a.m. it was on the 11th hour of the 11th day of the 11th month.

title: Anger in Happy Valley
description: WHO is Joe Paterno?WHO else lost his job in the fallout from a sex-abuse scandal at Penn State?

title: Do Presidential Candidates Need to Be Good Debaters?
description: Governor Rick Perry of Texas has had some difficulty in debates among contenders for the Republican presidential nomination, most recently this week, when he suffered a memory lapse during a debate about the economy. He said his error merely shows that he is human like like everyone else and that debate skills arent the most important consideration when it comes to being qualified for the presidency. What do you think?

title: Italy and Greece Act With More Force on the Debt Crisis
description: ROME  With Europe under mounting pressure to act quickly to tackle its debt crisis, the leaders of Italy and Greece moved forcefully on Friday to reinvigorate their governments and show their sincerity about economic austerity. Financial markets rallied on the news.

title: China Rolls Out Tighter Rules on Reporting
description: BEIJING  Chinese authorities this week announced new and tighter regulations governing journalists, one of several recent actions aimed at controlling rumors and diluting the influence of the nations rapidly growing microblogs.

title: Spinning Webs, Then Chasing Sugarplums
description: Last May Daniel Ezralow found himself in a nondescript conference room in a Shanghai hotel, scouting Chinese street dancers. It was an unlikely place for this choreographer, who a little over a month earlier had been consumed by the biggest and most expensive spectacle to hit Broadway in history: Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark, for which he had created movement both onstage and in the air. Monthly trips to Shanghai, as he was starting to make, would have seemed out of the cards.

title: Art Exchange Makes Prado in Madrid a Mini-Hermitage
description: Rarely do two major museums share their most precious holdings. But in celebration of the Spain-Russia Dual Year  dedicated to strengthening cultural and economic ties between the two countries  the Prado National Museum and the State Hermitage Museum in St. Petersburg agreed to exchange treasures, giving visitors to both institutions an unprecedented opportunity to see works outside their usual environment. Last winter, the Prado Museum sent 60 works to St. Petersburg. Now its Russias turn.

title: Last of 5 Parts: Answers to Your Questions on Applying with a Learning Disability
description: Marybeth Kravets has been fielding questions this week on The Choice about applying to college with a learning disability, the subject of my column published last weekend in The Timess Education Life supplement.

title: Week 10 Matchups: The Rivalry Everyone Is Talking About
description: Patriots (5-3) at Jets (5-3)Sunday, 8:20 p.m.Line: Jets by 1.5.The seventh annual Patriots Dynasty Deathwatch is under way. The team has lost two straight games, prompting the usual hand-wringing about eras ending and la belle poque coming to a melancholy fin. We have now endured over a half-decade of laments about how a team that routinely wins 11 to 16 games per year is not what it used to be, simultaneously criticizing Bill Belichick for his recent personnel decisions and genuflecting before the altar of his past accomplishments. No wonder otherwise sane people ardently root against this team.The Patriots need to prolong their dramatic swoon to William Shatner lengths, coupled with the usual noisy Jets chest thumping, has turned this into the most torturously overblown rivalry in the N.F.L. Unless you are a lifelong Jets or Patriots fan, you feel you have been clamped to your seat, eyelids taped open, neck immobilized and forced to watch. Its less a battle of two great teams (both are highly flawed this season) than a battle of attention hounds of differing styles. The Jets should win easily  the Patriots have only one starting-caliber cornerback to handle three very good Jets receivers  but let us again bid fond farewell to the glorious Patriots conversations that will dominate the following week make it almost not worth the trouble. Pick: Jets.

title: Its Carbon and Monoxide, the Old Detroit Perfume
description: I didnt think I could love Philip Levine any more than I already did, but then he gave this interview to Andrew Goldman in our Nov. 6 issue (in which, of his diminishing hostility  or at least overt hostility  toward the rich, he says: Ive met them now under silly circumstances, and they seem like hopeless jerks to me, for the most part). If youve ever worked a terrible job or felt some kinship with people who have to work too hard and who get too little of what they deserve, then Levine was your personal poet laureate long before he became Americas official poet laureate.

In industry lingo, Ms. Taylor is an esthetician, running her own two-person waxing studio, called ME Beauty, in Rochester, Mich.

title: The Breakfast Meeting, Nov. 11
description: James Murdoch, the 38-year-old deputy chief operating officer of News Corporation, never wavered in his testimony Thursday before a committee of the British Parliament. He insisted that he had learned only recently that phone hacking had been widespread at the companys now-defunct tabloid, The News of the World. Thus the question, distilled, was: What didnt he know, and when didnt he know it? [NYT]

title: On Our Radar: Will the Keystone Delay Benefit Enbridge?
description: Consultants suggest that the delay in a decision by the Obama administration on whether to approve the Keystone XL pipeline could benefit Enbridge, a company that is proposing construction of two new pipeline segments to carry oil sands crude from Canada to Texas. [Bloomberg BusinessWeek]

title: Sinopec Expands in Brazil With Stake in Energy Company
description: LONDON  Sinopec has agreed to invest almost $5.2 billion in the Brazilian operations of Portuguese energy company Galp Energia, the latest move in a global expansion by Chinas largest oil refiner.

description: Ron Santo, the best third baseman of his era and among the10 best ever, belongs in the Hall of Fame. Its that simple.

title: Notes From the Underground | Glenn Jones
description: A master of the art of fingerpicking, Glenn Jones performed several covers and original pieces recently at the West Park Presbyterian Church on the Upper West Side. In lieu of vocals, Jones paused between songs to talk about the stories behind them  say, a friends daughter, a landscape that moved him. The audience, absorbed in a silent spell, hung on every word. The performance was organized by the music curator Kate Lesta, who also stages the annual Communikey festival in Boulder, Colo.

title: From Romania, One Sweet Cylinder
description: A long rope of sweet yeast dough is tightly wrapped in a spiral around a wooden form, something like a rolling pin. It is then baked, slowly turning, often in a hearth. But unless you happen to be from a Transylvanian village, do not try this at home. Anna Kozma, who hails from Romania, said this special-occasion cake (called kurtoskalacs, or chimney cake) was just a provincial treat until after the fall of Communism, when entrepreneurs began opening city shops in Romania, Hungary and elsewhere in Europe.

title: An Interview With Francisco Costa

Poster Boy
description: Shepard Fairey, the influential street artist who last month designed an invitation for an Occupy Wall Street party in Times Square, is once again unfurling the income equality banner, this time to raise money for the homeless. The Robert Rauschenberg Foundation selected Fairey to inaugurate its Artist as Activist series; 100 signed prints of the new Fairey poster, The Future is Unwritten, will be available for purchase later today at artnet.com/auctions, starting at $1,250. Almost all of the proceeds benefit the nonprofit organization Coalition for the Homeless, which provides soup kitchens and job training for destitute New Yorkers. Fairey said that his poster references Depression-era styles like Art Deco, and that its title comes from Joe Strummer of the Clash, whom he called a dedicated advocate for the working class.

description: Every so often, the essay questions on the SAT exam have the ripped-from-the-headlines feel of an episode of Law and Order, as when the test-makers asked students in the spring if they considered reality television to be authentic.

description: In professional encomiums like this one, its always best to start with how long and how well you knew the person in question.

title: At Occupy Protests, Bearing Christian Witness Without Preaching

title: Body and Brain Both Stretched To Their Limits
description: IN 1991 John Jasperse presented his first evening-length show, Eyes Half-Closed, at Performance Space 122 with no expectation of where it would take him. Now, as he sits in a Midtown cafe 20 years later, his eyes are wide open as he contemplates the longevity of his career in contemporary dance. Thats a while, Mr. Jasperse said, not without a little awe, before letting loose a peel of his trademark laughter. A document of tenacity.

Its a homespun autobiographical collection of finger-lickin country and farm recipes, and the plan is to publish it online, free.  Glenn Collins

title: Site to Be Seen | ASOS
description: Fitting rooms, sales racks and lines at the register seem to stoke fear in many men, so a surplus of e-commerce sites have popped up to make online shopping not only convenient but appealing. Take, for example, ASOS, the Britain-based e-tailer that stocks a range of labels  from heritage (Filson) to high-end (Prada) to Scandinavian (Henrik Vibskov)  under one URL. The sites extensive mix of prices and styles caters to the male buyer who appreciates one-stop shopping. And streamlining the process even more is ASOSs affordable namesake line, which offers everything from slim, tailored classics (like these houndstooth trousers, $72) to trendier pieces (knit jacket, $198, and Fair Isle hoodie, $87).

description: The American balladeer James Taylor will plunge into the world of Charles Dickens. Mr. Taylor will play the role of Bob Cratchit in a production of A Christmas Carol by the Berkshire Theater Group next month. The show is adapted by Eric Hill from Dickens ghostly tale; Mr. Hill will co-direct along with E. Gray Simons III, the theater group said in an announcement on Friday. I know that James will bring his inherent charm and gentleness to bear in his portrayal of Bob Cratchit, a good and unpretentious man, Mr. Hill said. A Christmas Carol will run Dec. 17-30 at the Colonial Theater in Pittsfield, Mass.

description: BRUSSELS  Just days before it was to propose sweeping regulations for credit rating agencies, the European Commission on Friday joined calls for an investigation into Standard & Poors after the company erroneously sent out an e-mail suggesting that it had lowered the rating on Frances sovereign debt.

title: Ultimate Fighting Dips a Toe Into the Mainstream
description: In the beginning, the Ultimate Fighting Championship was like a brawl at a carnival, the mismatched combatants entering an octagonal cage to go at it until there was a knockout, surrender, doctors intervention or death. The very first match pitted a 415-pound sumo wrestler against a Dutch kickboxer who zestfully launched his foot into the bigger mans face. The blow left two teeth embedded in the attackers foot, with a third flying into the crowd.

title: Report Gives New Details of Chaos at Stricken Plant
description: Fukushima Daiichi Unit 1 was stuck in darkness, and everyone on site feared that the reactor core was damaged. It was the day after a huge earthquake and a towering tsunami devastated the plant, and the workers for Tokyo Electric Power Company knew they were the only hope for halting an unfolding nuclear disaster.

title: What Lies Beneath, and Behind
description: ON top of the obvious hurdles to getting a home sale finalized these days, some brokers say hidden environmental issues are more often showing up at the last minute: a new inspection turns up an underground oil tank no one knew was there; air quality monitoring suggests mold is growing behind basement wallboards; or perhaps the radon levels are high.

title: Seeking Your Questions on Scholarships and Student Loans
description: To help readers of The Choice navigate the maze of scholarships available to them  as well as to further their understanding of President Obamas recent proposal to ease the repayment of some student loans  Ive once again asked Mark Kantrowitz, a financial aid expert and founder of the Web sites finaid.org and fastweb.com, to spend a week in our virtual Guidance Office. Mr. Kantrowitz is the author of Secrets to Winning a Scholarship, published in February.

title: The Minimalist: Baked Broccoli Rabe With Parmesan
description: Broccoli rabe usually doesnt make it past a saut pan with garlic and olive oil, nor does it need to. But the extra step of baking it in the oven with a shower of grated Parmesan on top  which was suggested to me by the chef John Schenk, now at the Strip House, and which I wrote about in a 1997 Minimalist column  is one you should try.

title: The European Car Wreck
description: As I watched the governments in Italy and Greece change hands from the politicians who helped create the current disasters to little-known technocrats who will be conveniently blamed for not fixing them right away, I couldnt help but wonder  with a shudder  what would happen if one of the crop of Republican presidential hopefuls were put in charge there.

title: To Cut Costs, Dallas Symphony to Drop Five Concerts Next Season
description: The Dallas Symphony Orchestra will cut back on the number of subscription concerts it performs amid a cash crunch. Orchestra officials said this week that subscription concerts will go from 21 weeks this season to 16 next season; the five weeks instead will be devoted to community concerts. The move will save on production costs and fees paid to guest conductors, said David J. Hyslop, the orchestras interim president and chief operating officer. The orchestras musicians have agreed to forgo wages increases for the past two seasons and agreed to a wage freeze for this season and next, reflecting the same straitened circumstances experienced by many orchestras around the country. Mr. Hyslop said the orchestra has projected a $6.5 million budget deficit this season, but after an emergency appeal for donations to the board on Tuesday and the cost-cutting steps, that number should drop.

title: Wantful Aims to Revamp Gift-Giving Process
description: The holiday shopping season is just around the corner, and a new San Francisco start-up wants to make it easier to give the perfect gift  by letting the recipient have a say in the matter.

title: Inclusion: The Right Thing for All Students
Weekend Fare
description: Though the events, all weekend long, are varied  exhibits, tastings, cooking demonstrations and sales  they share a single obsession: chocolate. The 14th annual Chocolate Show, at the Metropolitan Pavilion, 125 West 18th Street (between the Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue), in Chelsea, will feature leading chefs like Jacques Torres, as well as small artisanal producers. This years show has a Kids Zone, where children can grab a handful of chocolate and win tickets to a production of Peter Pan at Madison Square Garden if they find a specially wrapped sweet. The show runs from 10 a.m. to 7 p.m. on Friday and Saturday, and from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. on Sunday. Adult tickets are $30 in advance or $35 at the door Friday and Sunday. Saturday tickets are $35 for adults and $40 at the door. Two children ages 5 through 12 can enter free if accompanied by an adult. Each additional child is $8, and children 4 and under are admitted free.

title: Nebraska Concerned About Safety of Its Fans
description: Nebraska knows there will be a football game Saturday at Penn State. And its a pretty big game, too, with the Huskers (7-2 over all, 3-2 Big Ten) tied for second in the Legends Division and the Nittany Lions first in the Leaders Division at 5-0, 8-1 over all.

title: A Gold Rush of Subsidies in Clean Energy Search
description: WASHINGTON  Halfway between Los Angeles and San Francisco, on a former cattle ranch and gypsum mine, NRG Energy is building an engineering marvel: a compound of nearly a million solar panels that will produce enough electricity to power about 100,000 homes.

title: Styled to a T | Hotel Bel-Air
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: The Films of Ernie Gehr
description: A selection of works from the filmmaker whose work will be shown in Los Angeles.

title: No Blockbusters Here, Just Mind Expanders
description: THERE are a multiplicity of adjectives that fit Ernie Gehrs experimental film and digital work: abstract, beautiful, mysterious, invigorating, utopian. The work can also be oblique; this is not a bad thing! His 14-minute film History (1970), to take one extreme example, largely consists of what looks like a sparkly black-and-gray blob that brings to mind a hallucination of a desert night sky, like van Gogh on acid. What youre looking at, and perhaps losing yourself in, isnt a representation of something outside the camera, but film itself: those clouds of dye in color film and churning grains in black and white that make up the actual image you see.

title: Wheelies: The What, Me Worry? Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Friday Reading: Room 77, a New Way to Search Hotel Rooms
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: A Scorched Earth Debut for Call of Duty
description: Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 3 produced a record $400 million in sales and 6.5 million units sold in its the first 24 hours after going on sale in the United States and United Kingdom, Reuters reported. The game, from Activision Blizzard, went on sale at midnight on Tuesday. The figure surpassed the previous record of $360 million set by Call of Duty: Black Ops, set last year. By contrast, the movie Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, Part 2, had gross receipts of $169 million for its opening weekend, tops for the year so far, according to Box Office Mojo.

title: Misunderstanding Racial Justice
description: Theres no more polarizing legal battle in America today than the one over the meaning of discrimination.
