On the left, many progressives insist that any policies and practices that disadvantage people on the basis of race, sex, age or disability should be illegal, and some have carried this principle to illogical extremes  suing to block ladies nights at singles bars, for example, or even to forbid Mothers Day. On the right, many conservatives insist that the Constitution is so colorblind that the government may never take race into account under any circumstances, and the Supreme Court under Chief Justice John Roberts has carried this principle to similarly illogical extremes  claiming that policies designed to integrate public schools, for example, are impossible to distinguish from those designed to segregate them.

title: The Writing Cure
description: Early in Joshua Codys sprightly, manic cancer memoir, [Sic], the author pauses to explain the musical significance of the golden ratio  the moment, almost two-thirds of the way through a composition, when the work often asserts its presence and opens up to take you in and it feels like the pilot has moved the throttle and you feel motion again. Curious readers may take this as a cue to flip ahead to Page 164, which is where (according to the Euclidean formula Cody graciously provides) the golden ratio falls in his own narrative. There they will find Cody on the verge of death, joined at his hospital bedside by his mother and the emotionally unstable pain management doctor who is about to become, disastrously, his girlfriend. They will find, in other words, the throttle shoved all the way forward. The resulting G-force of sex and death and insanity  and also, improbably, of music and math and modernist poetry  is the only evidence you need that for all its seeming formlessness, [Sic] is in fact as artfully constructed as a Tarantino film.

title: Premier Says Japan Will Join Pacific Free Trade Talks
description: TOKYO  In a contentious move that could make or break his government, Prime Minister Yoshihiko Noda said Friday that Japan would join talks toward an ambitious pan-Pacific free trade pact. The accord would potentially open up new markets for Japanese exporters but enrage the nations powerful farmers, who say their livelihoods would be wiped out.

title: The Rubber Duck Knows No Frontiers
description: While repainting Her Majestys bathroom in Buckingham Palace in 2001, a decorator noticed a particularly quirky object befitting a queen: a rubber duckie with its own crown. Naturally, he told a tabloid. The Sun was also amused: The queen, it reported, shares her royal bathtimes with a yellow rubber duck.

title: The Topic of Cancer
description: My boyfriend of one year has been given a diagnosis of terminal cancer. He has no family around, and I have been his primary caretaker. We had a wonderful relationship, but we had not discussed long-term plans, and his declining health has changed much between us. It is becoming harder for me to continue at this level. My desire to look after my own needs, personal and professional, and my guilt for feeling that I could be deserting him are becoming overwhelming. What is my responsibility? ANONYMOUS

title: Hurt All Over
description: Will you please see my sister? the young woman asked Dr. David Podell, who was a friend of a friend and had a reputation as a kinder version of TVs Dr. Gregory House. People told her that Podell was a doctor who specialized in diagnosing odd diseases, and she hoped he might finally solve the puzzle of her older sisters mysterious illness.

title: Forest of the Ancients
description: High in the White Mountains of eastern California is a group of trees that are among the oldest living things on earth.

title: Confessions of a Tweeter
description: It started June 25, 2008: Testing, testing. Is this thing on? My first tweet. I began by trying to make a few friends laugh. I had no idea how quickly tweeting would consume me. Before long I was posting 20 to 30 times a day, seven days a week. Some of my posts were funny, some sad, some vaguely existential  Living happily ever after is killing me  some flirty, some filthy. I posted daily for three years with only one exception  the day my father-in-law died. Eventually, I attracted about 25,000 followers. Not bad for a noncelebrity.

title: We Are Still Not Ready
description: Wil Hyltons article How Ready Are We for Bioterrorism? raised important concerns about how hard it is to protect the country from naturally occurring and man-made biological threats. He outlined how the lack of profitability and the bureaucratic hoops required to get vaccines and medical countermeasures to market can mean were often our own worst enemy. But he missed an equally important and extremely troubling part of the equation: cuts to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and to state budgets mean that even when we have medicines and vaccines, we arent in a position to get them to Americans quickly. Federal support for preparedness has been gutted, dropping 37 percent since fiscal year 2005, and state and local health departments have cut an estimated 44,000 workers between 2008 and 2010. After Sept. 11 and anthrax, we built up biodefense capabilities, but were moving backward. When the next tragedy strikes, we will not be ready. The price tag for lack of preparedness will be American lives.

title: Lynda Barry Will Make You Believe In Yourself
description: I had the pleasure of being in one of Lynda Barrys two-hour writing workshops. I will never forget how she talked about the critical voice inside our heads. She said that if someone walked up behind you and said the story you were writing was stupid, you wouldnt listen to them, so why do you listen to the voice inside your head telling you that very thing? It was life changing.

title: Reader Responses: Hurt All Over
description: Reader responses regarding a medical mystery of a young woman who endured a decade of relenting pain.

title: Jennifer Miller and Jason Feifer
description: IT all began with a semicolon.

title: Battered Souls, Seeking Salvation in Each Other
description: FOUR years ago the British actor Paddy Considine made his directing debut with a short film, called Dog Altogether, that begins with a man drunkenly kicking his dog to death. For Mr. Considine the challenge was clear. If in 15 minutes you have any compassion for this guy, Ive succeeded, he said. Now he has raised the stakes  widening both the emotional palette and the spectrum of human and canine abuse  in a feature-length film he wrote and directed, Tyrannosaur, centered on the same less-than-lovable protagonist. A menacing alcoholic whose fits of rage mask a lifetime of pain, Joseph (played by Peter Mullan) eventually lets down his guard when he befriends a battered wife.

title: More Screen Time for Kids Who Create Instead of Watch
description: Should those of us with firm limits on our kids technology time be rethinking our stance?

title: Best Illustrated Books of 2011
description: Selected pages from the New York Times Best Illustrated Childrens Books of 2011.

title: In Rain, an Omen of War
description: New Cadet Wilson, its raining on your R-Day! Do you know what that means?

title: TimesCast | November 11, 2011
description: Italy is one step closer to a government without Silvio Berlusconi; Arab League leaders consider suspending Syrias membership; and honoring Americas veterans.

title: Living In | Bay Shore, L.I.
description: A 12-square-mile hamlet in Islip that has a diverse housing stock, from upscale waterfront houses to more modest Capes and colonials to mobile homes.

title: 2014 World Cup: North Korea Eliminated; China on Brink
description: North Korea became the first nation that played in the 2010 World Cup to be eliminated from contention for the 2014 World Cup in Brazil when it lost, 1-0, to Uzbekistan in Tashkent in a World Cup qualifying match in the Asia region Friday.

title: A Hamlet With a Liquid Playground
description: AS the district director of guidance for the Bay Shore Union Free School District, Louis Balsamo gives tours to prospective students and their parents who are interested in moving to Bay Shore, a diverse Suffolk County hamlet on the shores of the Great South Bay.

title: Sweetness With Spine
description: THERE are some movie stars  like Joan Crawford or John Wayne  who are able to sustain their popularity across several decades, either maturing with their audiences or finding fresh ways to appeal to new generations of fans.

title: Eurofile | Weekend in Belgrade
description: Sometimes theres a pleasure in arriving in a place unburdened by too much knowledge of your destination: with none of the usual guidebook prepping, everything comes as a revelation. Aside from the fact that its the capital of Serbia, is located at the confluence of the Danube and Sava rivers, and was a pawn between the Turks and Austrians for several centuries, I knew almost nothing about Belgrade, the former capital of Yugoslavia. With blissful ignorance whetting my curiosity, I and a friend recently arrived at the Nikola Tesla airport and hopped a diesel-fume-spewing bus into the city.

title: 421a Tax Exemption: Dont Say You Didnt Know
description: TOD ABRAMSS condo at the Orion on West 42nd Street has a custom Valcucine kitchen, floor-to-ceiling windows and views that stretch from the George Washington Bridge to the Chrysler Building.

title: Protesters Urge Arab League to Suspend Syria as Deaths Mount
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Thousands of Syrians took to the streets on Friday, urging the Arab League to suspend the membership of the Syrian government, which they say has violated an initiative the league brokered to end the armed crackdown on the eight-month-old political uprising.

title: The Topsy-Turvy Dynegy Bankruptcy
description: As the Dynegy Chapter 11 case unfolds, the only thing that is certain is that nothing is exactly as it seems. Indeed, one has to worry that the entire case involves looking through the wrong end of the telescope.

title: Before the Kindle Fire, Some Misfires
description: The late Steven P. Jobs has been widely celebrated in recent weeks for his uncanny ability to anticipate what the masses want. Most mortals have no such forecasting skills, but that doesnt prevent some from making all sorts of predictions. Usually, these lie safely buried in the past, but occasionally they get resurrected to pound a point home.

title: Fantasy Football: Week 10s Toughest Picks
description: Jason and Justin Sablich are here to help you with your fantasy football team. The Sablich brothers will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy).

title: Thanksgiving Countdown | Just Add Bacon
description: Theres always a way to work in some bacon. Here are four recipes that will help you reach that goal this Thanksgiving. Add your suggestions in the comments section.

title: Why Do the Republican Debates Seem to Matter So Much?
description: There have been nine Republican presidential debates this year, and each one seems to have more influence over the course of the campaign than the last one. (And there will be another one on Saturday at 8 p.m. on CBS.)

title: Beyond Patience and Fortitude, an Incursion of Decibels
description: Ive been reading up on the history of the place, the composer and performer Ben Frost said. Its important to know your enemy.

title: Stacking Clean Energy Subsidies
description: Since 2009, extensive federal and state subsidies have been offered for solar power. An analysis by Booz & Company shows the ways in which government subsidies have turned one such project  NRGs California Valley Solar Ranch  into an almost surefire investment.

title: At Methuselah Grove, Where Trees Wait 5,000 Years for Their Close-Up
description: Domingo Milella first saw a bristlecone pine when a friend showed him an iPhone picture of a tree growing along the Methuselah Walk. It was one of the worlds oldest living trees, but at the time it didnt interest Milella as a photographic subject. He says, It came back to me only after a year, as if a presence that lingered, but never disappeared. Thats when Milella, whose work has previously appeared in T Magazine, suggested he shoot the tree for the magazine. In our business, a good idea doesnt ordinarily have a shelf life of a year, but given that some trees in the ancient bristlecone pine forest are likely 5,000 years old, we had a little more wiggle room with the publication date than usual. This one gave new meaning to evergreen, a journalistic term signifying a feature that can run at any time.

title: The New York Times Comedy Challenge
description: All around town this weekend you cant help but run into standups. Though, as Jason Zinoman has written, New York is a something of a sprawling comedy festival the entire year, there is actually a reason for the crush of jokes: the New York Comedy Festival is officially under way through Sunday. Of course, much of the bits you see onstage arent exactly Times-appropriate, so we decided to pose a challenge to select comedians: tell us your best clean joke. Watch them in action and vote for the one you think killed.

title: Off the Charts: Tracking the Rise in Sovereign Default Fears
description: As worries over the safety of some European sovereign bonds grew this year, volume in credit default swaps rose sharply, particularly in September. But the changes in net contracts outstanding rose at a much slower pace. The charts show the daily market rate on 10-year government bonds and the annual cost of a credit default swap to insure against default for a $10 million government bond for five years. They also show the weekly volume in such swaps and the net positions of all holders. The charts begin in July 2010, when information on swap volume became available.

title: Photo Replay: Nov.11
description: A look at the day in sports, including ice skating in Japan, cricket in South Africa and soccer in Budapest.

title: Duane Buck, Race and Capital Punishment
description: One of the things I would like to do with this blog is provide a space to discuss issues with a level of detail thats just not possible in a typical editorial, or perhaps issues that dont lend themselves to formal editorials, but are still worth talking about. Such posts might get a little wonky at times, but I hope you find them worth your while.

title: Off the Beaten Path
description: From obscure islands to boutique hideaways, destinations away from the crowds.

title: In Jamaica, a Musical Revival
description: Beaches, waterfalls and jerk chicken, all to a mento beat.

title: On Jamaicas Other Coast, a Musical Revival
description: LATE on a balmy Saturday evening in August, as Hurricane Irene churned far out in the Caribbean, the singer Albert Minott and his mento band, the Jolly Boys, were charming the crowd at the Bush Bar, a jungle-shrouded watering hole at the GeeJam resort in the Jamaican harbor town of Port Antonio. Nattily dressed and slim as an exclamation point, Mr. Minott, 73, slunk sensually across the stage as he delivered a soulful, gravelly voiced set that included Jolly Boys originals and covers of the Velvet Underground and Amy Winehouse.

title: Blithe Spirits
description: On a recent Saturday night in Boulder, Col., a warehouse in an industrial park on the citys southeast side was humming with live music, food trucks and people whod dropped by on bicycles for a martini. Which may seem customary in the Peoples Republic of Boulder  except that the warehouse isnt a new cocktail bar exactly but rather Boulder Distillery, one of the many small spirit producers that are multiplying all over the state.

title: Copter Crash Kills a Leader in Mexicos Drug Fight
description: MEXICO CITY  A helicopter crash killed Mexicos second-most-powerful official and seven others on Friday, dealing yet another blow to the countrys battle against a drug-and-crime scourge and leaving a battered nation in shock.

title: Touring Bequia
description: An hour from Barbados, an island of both simple and extravagant pleasures.

title: Saving Pets From Radiation in Japan
description: Eight months after the nuclear crisis in Japan, emergency workers are still struggling to understand the effects on the thousands of dogs and cats left wandering the streets in towns and villages near the damaged Fukushima nuclear plant. Many were left behind in the rush to evacuate by families who did not expect to be away for more than a short period.

title: Tax Burdens Tilt Coastal, and Systems Fairness Is Debated
description: THE wealthy have been the subject of much discussion lately, from the protesters on Wall Street to lawmakers in Washington. President Obama has even provided a definition of whos wealthy in arguing that taxes should be raised for those households with incomes of at least $250,000 a year.

title: Wall Street Wives Says It Has Landed Kenneth Starrs Wife
description: 4:58 p.m. | Updated

title: Teaching the Penn State Scandal
description: November 16 | Updated

title: TimesCast | Honoring Veterans
description: Corey Kilgannon speaks to service members on Veterans Day.

title: TimesCast | Syria and Its Neighbors
description: November 11, 2011 - Arab League leaders will meet on Saturday to consider suspending Syria's membership.

title: TimesCast | Italy Beyond Berlusconi
description: Italy's Senate passes an austerity bill, bringing it one step closer to a future without Silvio Berlusconi.

title: Perry Makes $1 Million Ad Buy on Fox News
description: Read an updated version of this blog post.

title: Out-of-the-Way Stays, Rugged to Refined
description: MOST hotels want attention. They advertise, bundle discounts and offer news-making packages. But if you want to escape the clamor, the following intimate accommodations  all off-the-beaten-path hideaways  offer island home-away-from-home experiences with all the privacy of a residential stay. All qualify as romantic, but each plays a different variation on the theme, ranging from rugged to refined. Each features owner management, cottage or suite quarters and, in most cases, kitchens that give you an excuse to shop at the local produce markets. Seekers of beach parties should book elsewhere.

title: Bequia: Getting Away From the Getaways
description: I JUST wanted to make a dinner reservation. But the restaurant owner had other uses for me.

title: A Young Sailors Guide to the Caribbean
description: IN 2003, 8-year-old Alex Ellison and his family set sail in the Caribbean on their 46-foot Beneteau 473, Promise. They had intended to take a one-year trip from Essex, Conn., through the Caribbean to South America and back, but ended up spending almost five years living in the islands, celebrating birthdays in Grenada, Christmas in the Pitons and spending three years in the rain forest of Nevis. The world was now our classroom, Mr. Ellison wrote in his memoir, A Star to Sail Her By (May 2011, iUniverse).

title: Your Go-Bag for the Caribbean
description: BAREFOOT all the time, and a lot of freedom.

title: A New Wave of Cool Drinks
description: An informal survey of cocktail enthusiasts around the Caribbean revealed four of the most popular drinks this season.

title: Ill Have the Red: Hot Sauce, Island by Island
description: JAMAICA is a land of deep and profound greens: hurricane-battered jungles, untrimmed coconuts delivered to villa doorsteps, sticky cannabis held in lacquered wooden humidors. But when I first visited the island in 2005, no green fascinated me as much as the contents of the glass jar handed to me one evening by Darren Lee, then the chef at Strawberry Hill, a luxurious resort in the mountains above Kingston. This green was rough and wet, but also glassy, and I recognized it immediately: These were pured Scotch bonnet chiles  hot as habaneros, but fruitier, almost sweet.

title: 14 Ways to Ditch the Crowds
description: Theres more to the Caribbean than mega-resorts and limbo contests. From Creole markets and cozy inns tolocal zouk joints and volcanic beaches, 14 ways to escape the predictable.

title: Yep, Thats Me on the Tasting Menu
description: Since 1992, Caribbean reefs have been invaded by lionfish, showy-looking but venomous and barbed Pacific natives. They most likely escaped from aquariums into the wild, where they have found plenty to feed on  and no natural predators.

title: Shooting Layups Where Publishers Dined
description: Theyve already turned the newsroom into a bowling alley. Why shouldnt the publishers dining room on the 11th floor of the old New York Times headquarters be turned into a basketball court?

title: Brands Lost in Translation
description: When Western products are translated into Chinese, the results can range from poetic to the metaphysical.

title: The U.F.C.: No Holds Barred
description: Fans of mixed martial arts know that Ulitimate Fighting Championship bouts can be a windmill of fists, two exhausted men wrestling on the ground or an exhibition of chokeholds.

title: Puppets on Film
description: Images from the BAMcinmatek series covering puppets (and muppets) in the movies.

title: Picking Brand Names in China Is a Business Itself
description: BEIJING  After a hard days labor, your average upscale Beijinger likes nothing more than to shuck his dress shoes for a pair of Enduring and Persevering, rev up his Precious Horse and head to the pub for a tall, frosty glass of Happiness Power.

title: Where Youll Still Find Judy Garland
description: Tommy Femia has been performing as Judy Garland for more than 20 years at an Off Off Broadway cabaret in Manhattan, and his parents and brothers are usually on hand.

title: The Boy Who Became Judy Garland
description: DOWN some dark stairs, past cases of empty beer bottles, in the brick warren beneath the Off Off Broadway cabaret called Dont Tell Mama, a middle-aged man helps his middle-aged brother adjust the blue sequined top that complements his black sequined skirt. Fifteen minutes to showtime.

title: Chevy Volt Fire Prompts Federal Investigation Into Lithium-Ion Batteries
description: 3:51 p.m. | Updated

title: Romney Comments on Perry Debate Gaffe
description: MAULDIN, S.C.  After a round table with veterans here, Mitt Romney on Friday offered his most expansive comments yet on Gov. Rick Perrys Oops moment in Wednesday nights debate, though he still steered clear of criticizing his rival.

title: Dot Connection: From Palestinian Politics to Tsunami Warnings
description: You may have followed developments as the United States pulled its funding for theUnited Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, known as Unesco, after the organization voted to makePalestineits 195th full member on Oct. 31. United States laws dating from the 1990s require an automatic cutoff ofAmerican funds under such a circumstance. On Thursday, the organization announced big budget cuts. Why is this relevant to Dot Earth?

title: Big Ticket | Sold for $19.5 million
description: It took six months from the day the contract was signed, a grueling approval process from one of the citys toughest co-op boards, and nearly $20 million, but a new apartment owner was finally able to join the illustrious ranks of the Manhattan elite who call 778 Park Avenue home.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Worlds Apart
description: New to the hardcover list is Flashpoint, written by Geoff Johns and illustrated by Adam Kubert. The story, at No. 2, will likely go down in comics history as the event that changed everything right before the next event that really changed everything. The focus of the action is the Flash, who one morning wakes up in a world that is very different than the one he had fallen asleep in the night before. Aquaman and Wonder Woman are at war, Superman is missing and someone unexpected is wearing Batmans cowl. This was presented to fans of the DC Universe as a notable event in the adventures of the heroes.

title: Future Farmers of America Convention
description: The Future Farmers of America has gone beyond its roots in agriculture, adding fields like genetics and logistics.

title: Seriously, Men Only Think Theyre Funnier
description: The Gist Men arent much funnier than women. They just think they are.

title: Veterans Old and Young Gather to March, and to Contemplate
description: The wind whipped through Madison Square Park in Manhattan on Friday as military men and women young and old mustered at the starting point for the Veterans Day Parade.

title: Kal Penn, a Star Turn on Both Coasts
description: WHATS the slacker half of the stoner duo of the Harold & Kumar movies to do when faced with an elaborate F.B.I. questionnaire for his White House security clearance?

title: Geeks Beat Out Aspiring Pop Stars Overall
description: The second live results episode of The X Factor carried Fox to another Thursday night ratings victory in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic despite falling 11 percent in that demo compared to last week and dropping to 10.2 million total viewers from 11.5 million last week.

title: Chain Saw Gang
description: The mens-wear designer Adam Kimmel is no stranger to a statement scarf or skinny, bare-chested male models. But Kimmel can also toughen things up, as he proves with his newest collection for Carhartt, a work-wear brand for hardy men with callused hands and steely stares who nevertheless find occasions to don $410 canvas blazers. The Moment recently sneaked a peek at the Adam Kimmel x Carhartt look book, which outfits three roguish, chain-saw-wielding members of the art collective Paintallica. This group, made up mostly of University of Iowa alums, works in nightlong spurts, carving totemic wooden structures with power tools. Paint, fire, beer, a range of motor vehicles and sometimes guns are involved. Were interested in the same things that guys who shop in Wal-Mart in Des Moines, Iowa, are interested in, said Dan Attoe, a founding member of the group (hes the bearded one pictured above). But we also know whats out in the world. Adam has a similar approach with Carhartt. Hes making something thats fashionable but that someone in a rural area can still appreciate.Adam Kimmel x Carhartt, $40-$425. Available next month at Barneys.

title: Pictures of the Day: Washington and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Washington, Virginia, Yemen and China.

title: What Will Bella Wear?
description: WHEN The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn  Part 1 opens on Friday, fans wont be at all surprised to see Edward utter, I do. They already know the plotlines of the books better than their own ancestries. But there is one mystery  the design of Bellas wedding dress  that has Twihards all astir and the studio behind the film, Summit Entertainment, as tightlipped as a sorority pledge.

title: Having Fun With Economy
description: The Sonic, Chevys replacement for the Aveo, offers distinctive styling and impressive performance, traits sorely lacking in its predecessor.

title: Q&A: Troubleshooting the Self-Restarting PC
description: Q.

title: Moodys Calls Pipeline Delay a Positive for TransCanada
description: OTTAWA  While some in Canada view the Obama administrations decision to delay the approval process for the Keystone XL pipeline, which would carry oil from Albertas oil sands to the Gulf Coast, as a serious blow to relations between their country and the United States, Moodys Investors Service offered a more positive take on Friday.

title: Puppets on Film at BAM
description: Heroes in half-shells, frogs with banjos and even killer tires are a part of a lively film series being presented by BAMcinmatek called Puppets on Film. For two weekends, Nov. 12-14 and 18-20, the Brooklyn Academy of Music will screen a variety of films that trade high-tech computer graphics and special effects for old-fashioned foam and fabric. The series comes just before the Muppets make a big-screen comeback in a new feature film. The Muppets are a part of this series as well, and for those nostalgic for Jim Hensons creations, the series will include both the original Muppet Movie, Muppet Treasure Island and the Henson-directed fantasy film The Dark Crystal. The slide show above looks at some of the kid-friendly (Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles) and not-so-kid friendly (Team America: World Police) movies the festival has to offer. More can be found at the BAM Web site.

title: Pictures of the Day: Washington and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Washington, Virginia, Yemen and China.

title: Release the Memo!
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee held an oversight hearing on Tuesday, and most of the news reports focused on Operation Fast and Furious. NPR said there were unanswered questions regarding what Attorney General Eric Holder knew about the bungled gun-trafficking scheme while it was still a scheme and before it was bungled.

title: Hi-Fi Phone Earbuds at a Sound Price
description: There are lots of earphones that produce good sound, and a lot that incorporate a microphone for phone use, but few that do both. And to find one that does both at a value price? Its a short list.

title: #OccupyWallSt Roundup, Day 56
description: Although many veterans have joined Occupy Wall Street, some believe the 99 percent are blissfully unaware of the daily triumphs and tragedies of those serving abroad in the military. [Washington Post]

title: Preventing Hospital Delirium
description: My family and I watched my mother suddenly descend into delirium during her hospital stay after surgery. I can assure you that anyone who has seen somebody lose her mind within a matter of hours  even if she comes back from the dark side  doesnt ever want to see it happen again.

title: Cars Burned and Swastikas Scrawled in Brooklyn Jewish Area
description: One or more vandals on Friday set fire to several parked cars and scrawled anti-Semitic graffiti on nearby benches in Brooklyn, in what the police said was a hate crime in a heavily Jewish neighborhood.

title: CME Group Offers $300 Million for MF Global Customers
description: The CME Group, the major exchange where MF Global did business, took the unusual step on Friday of pledging $300 million to help ailing customers of the bankrupt brokerage firm.

title: Turning Up the Pressure to Keep Gas in the Game
description: IT should come as no surprise when the headlines coursing out of news conferences during this weeks press previews of the Los Angeles auto show turn out to be strongly flavored with terms like hybrid and electric.

title: A Plan for Efficiency in the Rest of the Car
description: IN the Mazda canon, Skyactiv is a term that describes the companys systematic approach to improving fuel efficiency. Under the Skyactiv umbrella are gasoline and diesel engines, 6-speed manual and automatic transmissions, lightweight body structures and a host of chassis improvements.

title: Seeking Out the Elegant Quail
description: Jennifer Calkins, a biologist who teaches at Evergreen State College in Olympia, Wash., writes from Mexico, where she is studying the ecology, behavior and evolution of the elegant quail.

title: Kraft Gives Plum Assignment to Crispin Porter & Bogusky
description: Kraft Foods, the largest American marketer of packaged foods, is expanding its relationship with a new favorite agency, Crispin Porter & Bogusky, awarding it plum assignments in connection with the introduction of a Kraft product in the United States.

title: Crossing Over, No Translation Needed
description: FOR the last decade Anthony Santos, the lead singer of the bachata group Aventura, has been something of a secret hidden in plain sight. Though Aventura regularly fills Madison Square Garden and other arenas around the country and sells millions of records, Mr. Santos, known to his Latino fans as Romeo, has remained pretty much anonymous outside the Spanish-speaking world.

title: The Prince, the Showgirl, and the Stray Strap
description: IT all turned on a pin.

title: Batteries in Electric Cars Examined After Chevy Volt Fire
description: DETROIT  Federal safety regulators said Friday that they were examining lithium-ion batteries used in electric cars because a Chevrolet Volt ignited three weeks after it underwent a crash test.

title: Future Farmers Look Ahead
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Gamaliel Rizzo grew up in a brownstone apartment in Brooklyn and is studying to become a doctor. Still, he spent his high school years learning how to raise chinchillas, goats and alpaca and growing radishes, sunflowers and cilantro. He even worked on a dairy farm in the summer, all as a member of the Future Farmers of America.

title: Music, Not Movies, But Still Exploring Places of Darkness
description: THE creepiness in a David Lynch film comes as much from the soundtrack as from the Surrealistic images: the subtle melancholy of Laura Palmers theme in Twin Peaks, Isabella Rossellinis come-hither rendition of the title song in Blue Velvet. Mr. Lynch, the filmmaker, devotee of transcendental meditation and coffee distributor, has long dabbled in music himself; he has written songs for his films and others (often in collaboration with the composer Angelo Badalamenti), and he sang with Danger Mouse and Sparklehorse for their 2010 album, Dark Night of the Soul. Last week he released his solo debut, Crazy Clown Time (Sunday Best Recordings/PIAS America), a brooding electronic blues album with his highly processed vocals, created in his home studio with the engineer Dean Hurley. Mostly it starts with a jam, Mr. Lynch said. Dean now lately on drums and me on guitar, and out of the jamming comes some kind of form, like, lots and lots of garbage  you can picture a landfill  but some chunks of gold.

title: A Big Market, but Not Necessarily Dangerous
description: AS worries grew about sovereign credit in Europe this fall, the volume of trading in credit-default swaps on Italy, Spain and France soared. But there appears to have been little actual purchasing of insurance in all that activity.

title: Hooray for the Red, White and Bland
description: TESTED 2011 Jeep Patriot Latitude X 4X4 70th Anniversary Edition

title: Les Paul Dies at 94
description: Mr. Paul was a virtuoso guitarist and inventor whose solid-body electric guitar and recording studio innovations changed the course of 20th-century music.

title: Jazz Guitar Shrine Expands Beyond Jazz to Survive
description: For years the Iridium has been known as not only the home of Les Paul, the electric-guitar pioneer, but also as one of the citys premier jazz clubs, where on any given night you can hear big-name performers like the pianist McCoy Tyner or the bassist Charlie Haden.

title: At Last, a Small Chevy That Makes Some Waves
description: AS new-car names go, Chevrolet Sonic has a decent ring. It implies speed, amped-up sound, maybe a dash of pizazz. As with most auto names, interpretation is up to you.

title: For New-Car Buyers, Taking a Test Drive Now Seems So 1995
description: AT a time when consumers have become accustomed to buying flat-screen televisions from Amazon.com without ever seeing the picture quality and ordering shoes through Zappos.com without trying them on, is it any wonder that some would buy a vehicle without ever taking a test drive?

title: Last Impressions?
description: The Patriot, improved somewhat since its ignominious debut, hopes to get a second look from compact S.U.V. buyers before its too late.

title: Look of the Moment | Vanessa Paradis
description: The Look: Caped Crusader. A dash of metallic tweed does wonders to dress up a jacket and jeans.

title: Perry Finds Voters in S. Carolina Warm but Wary
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  Gov. Rick Perry of Texas strode down Sumter Street in the Veterans Day parade here on Friday morning, a day after doing a series of network interviews and an appearance on the David Letterman show  all meant to atone for his debate flub on Wednesday night.

title: This week: Floyd Norris on Italy and the global economy, Gretchen Morgenson on taxpayer-funded pensions for defense contractors, Amy Cortese on starting a community-owned store, David Segal on cellphone charges, and Tyler Cowen on Occupy Wall Street.
description: This week: Jeff Sommer with Floyd Norris on Italy and the global economy, Gretchen Morgenson on taxpayer-funded pensions for defense contractors, Phyllis Korkki and Amy Cortese on starting a community-owned store, David Segal on cellphone charges, and Tyler Cowen on Occupy Wall Street.

title: For Joan Baez, Another Protest
description: After Occupy Wall Street protesters received permission from the city to hold a Veterans Day concert in Foley Square, not far from Zuccotti Park, the organizer of the event, Aaron Black, had to improvise in finding an area to serve as a green room, where musicians could stay warm before performing.

title: The Life Report: David Leshan
description: The following Life Report was submitted in response to my column of Oct. 28, in which I asked readers over 70 to write autobiographical essays evaluating their own lives.

title: A Visit to Fukushima Begins
description: Eight months after the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power station was crippled by an earthquake and tsunami, the Japanese government is opening the compound and surrounding area to the media for the first time. On Friday, officials took a group of reporters, including Martin Fackler of The New York Times, on a tour of J-Village, a former sports center near the plant that is now being used to house workers laboring to bring the plants reactors under control. On Saturday, the reporters will tour the plant itself.

title: Nissan to Market D.C. Fast Charger for Under $10,000
description: Nissan North America, with its partner Sumitomo, will market a 480-volt D.C. fast charger in the United States next year, the automaker announced Thursday night. The charger will sell for less than $10,000, a precipitous drop compared to units now on the market, which cost as much as $50,000.

title: Stanford vs. Oregon: Ducks Have Speed; Cardinal Have Injuries
description: No. 3 Stanford plays No. 6 Oregon Saturday night in Palo Alto, Calif. This week, The Quad will feature fans views of a game that has national title implications. This post is by Dick Benster, a 1975 Stanford graduate. And as always, we want to hear what you think.

title: Final: France 1, U.S. 0; No Offense Again
description: Loc Rmy split open the United States defense in the 72nd minute and the American offense again failed to produce a goal as France defeated the United States, 1-0, in a friendly at the Stade de France in Paris on Friday.

title: DeKalb Avenue in Fort Greene, Brooklyn
description: Scenes from DeKalb Avenue in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, include dogs and children running free.

title: DeKalb Avenue Arrives, Tourists and All
description: DEPENDING on the time of day, DeKalb Avenue in Brooklyn can look like a sepia-toned photograph from the 19th century, a chic international playground, or, at its best, the New York City melting pot at a nice, gentle simmer.

title: Wall Street Wives Lines Up a Wife With Some Buzz
description: The reality TV show Wall Street Wives, which plans to track the lives of the women married to the barons of finance, may not yet have a development deal, but it has been steadily adding to its cast.

title: Everyone Into the Pool
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: The Weeks Business News in Photos
description: Wal-Mart became a popular place to cash checks, the debt crisis took several turns, Greeces prime minister was replaced and more in this weeks business news.

title: An Airbnb Tour of New York City
description: Ron Liebers observations and photos from a week of staying in apartment rentals and shares.

title: An Airbnb Tour of New York City
description: Ron Liebers observations and photos from a week of staying in apartment rentals and shares.

title: Get Yer Links Here
description: New York lawmakers are not happy that soda ads have been shown to target minorities, and are looking for ways to change that. Heres a study that examines how school bans on sugar-sweetened beverages affect consumption.

title: The Week in Pictures for Nov. 4
description: Subjects include turkeys on Staten Island, a longtime Dyker Heights principal, and a travel psychic.

title: An American Look at Fukushima, Minute by Minute
description: The new chronology of events at Japans Fukushima Daiichi plant, which we write about here, contains no new bombshells about the disaster. But in dry prose, it gives some additional indications of how bad things were after the quake and tsunami there and will probably be the basis for some lessons learned for the American industry.

title: Airbnbs Lodging Gets Tested, Yielding a Mixed Bag
description: For any fan of disruptive consumer technologies, watching Airbnbs rise has been all sorts of fun.

title: After Winning N.Y. Times Contest, Lifeboat No. 6 Makes Headlines
description: Writing headlines, take it from us, is hard work. So we were gratified when more than 20 of you stepped up and entered our Nov. 1 contest to write a New York Post-style headline about Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs third term, in homage to hizzoners performance on Conan OBrien spitting out Diddy in Doghouse Over Dingo Damage and the like.

title: U.S. Ambassador Explores His Roots
description: Gary Locke, the U.S. ambassador to China, visits his ancestral village.

title: Sisterhood Is Still Powerful
description: Two excellent reads: The oral history of Ms. in New York magazine and Caitlin Flanagans ode to Oprah Winfrey in The Atlantic. Read them together and you are reminded that modern feminism had, at its core, a mission to expose the private abuse of power. This was accomplished by talking  women talking in pairs, in groups and eventually in the pages of a mainstream magazine  about entitled men and concealed abortions and sexual harassment and other private humiliations and injustices. Oprah took it further, to national television and a truly mass audience. As Flanagan writes:

title: Chinese, but Not Their Leaders, Flock to U.S. Envoy
description: GUANGZHOU, China

title: Federal Dollars Pledged to Math and Science Programs
Romney Hosts Veterans Round Table in S.Carolina
description: MAULDIN, S.C.  Mitt Romney spent Veterans Day with a table full of veterans on Friday, sharing plastic plates of barbecue as well as ideas for improving conditions facing the nations service members as they return from war.

title: A Guest Conductor Leads Familiar Pieces
description: Returning to the New York Philharmonic podium for the first time since 1978, Bernard Haitink conducted the orchestra in Strauss and Beethoven on Thursday evening at Avery Fisher Hall. Next week he leads a program of Haydn and Bruckner.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Nov. 11
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: Obama Observes Veterans Day
description: President Obama observed Veterans Day at Arlington National Cemetery in Virginia on Friday.

title: The Taxation Gap
description: In this weekends Wealth Matters column, Paul Sullivan dares to suggest that New Yorkers (and people in San Francisco and Boston and other places with high costs of living) are overtaxed.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Nov. 11
description: More Photographs

title: Chic in Review | Marc Jacobs for Dior. Not!
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: DealBooks Week in Review
description: A look back on our reporting of the past weeks highs and lows in finance.

title: Reviewing the Chevrolet Sonic
description: In Sundays Automobiles section, Sam Smith reviews the 2012 Chevrolet Sonic, which is available as a hatchback or a sedan.

title: A Single Mom Gambling on Christmas Spirit
description: Is there an Unlikely Pairing of the Month prize? If so, the Hallmark Channel wins it for connecting the stripper from the sleazy Showgirls and the bumbling police lieutenant from Monk in Lucky Christmas, a pleasant if improbable original movie it serves up on Saturday night.

title: Renaissance Works in Which Exceptions Rule
description: If you ask an early-music fan to describe Renaissance sacred music in general terms, you will probably hear about seamlessly flowing Masses and motets, usually for five voices. But the Renaissance was a period of unusual invention and limit testing, and as soon as you think you have defined its norms, exceptions come plentifully to mind.

title: Penn State Puts McQueary on Leave
description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa.  The Penn State assistant coach Mike McQueary, who has emerged as a central figure in the sexual abuse scandal that has roiled the university, was placed on administrative leave, the acting president, Rodney A. Erickson, announced Friday.

title: A Focus on the Scourge of Spanking
description: To the Editor:

title: Health Gizmos Nagging Us About How to Live
description: To the Editor:

title: Nature in the City
description: Marielle Anzelone, a botanist and urban ecologist, reports from Inwood Hill Park in week eight of her Autumn Unfolds series on City Room.

title: Good Deed, Punished
description: I am a charitable person without deep pockets. So I usually volunteer my time. Recently I drove to a shopping center, and some high school boys asked me to donate to a food pantry. They handed me a list of items to buy. But I was running late for work and offered money instead. All I had in my wallet was 80 cents, which I gave them. (Im sure many items on the list cost less.) As I drove away, I saw them snickering at me, which made me feel awful. Should I call the charity or let it go?

title: Exploration With Myth, Memory and Movement
description: As far as immersive installation performances go, Emily Johnsons Thank-you Bar is as disarming as they come. Much of that is due to the light touch of its creator, who has lived in Minneapolis for 17 years but was born in Alaska of Yupik descent. Everything about her exudes charisma.

title: Readers Photos: Picturing Our World
description: What does the world look like today?

title: The Week in Pictures for Nov. 4
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include turkeys on Staten Island, a longtime Dyker Heights principal and a travel psychic.

title: Letters
description: Sleepless in America

title: Individual Links in a Rolling Chain
description: It must be a pleasure to dance the choreography of Lar Lubovitch. To yield appropriately to beautiful music, secure in the hands of a master craftsman who will never let you look less than attractive: This safe satisfaction must be what draws dancers to his company. No matter that the three typically well-made works on the first program of his two-week season at the Baryshnikov Arts Center were structurally similar and underwhelming.

title: When the Tarot Trumps All
description: IF you were to peruse all the decks of tarot cards listed on the Aeclectic Tarot Web site, you might want, in poker parlance, to fold then and there.

title: The Religious Exemption on Birth Control Coverage
description: To the Editor:

title: Ostracizing Syria
description: To the Editor:

title: Looking at Intimacy, for Bodies and Minds
description: Desire, as the choreographer Gesel Mason knows, is only one part of sex. Another may be guilt. Or insecurity. Or shame. But whats wrong with being an independent spirit and sleeping with whomever you want? In Women, Sex, & Desire: Sometimes You Feel Like a Ho, Sometimes You Dont, which opened at the Joyce SoHo on Thursday evening, Ms. Mason explores sexual behavior using two extremes  the whore and the prude  as a starting point.

title: Pent-Up Feelings Set Free by Puppets
description: Satan, the great tempter of mens souls, takes deceptively innocuous form in the frisky new comedy Hand to God, by Robert Askins, at the Ensemble Studio Theater. The particular demonic presence in Mr. Askinss play has nasty teeth and spooky eyes  fairly standard attributes  but hes also made of felt and yarn. Yes, the Devil is a sock puppet in this foul-mouthed, fun-packed play about the urges that drive good men (and women, and boys) to dirty deeds.

title: On Screen Wedding Gowns
description: Photos of wedding gowns from movie weddings.

title: Green Fades, Ambers and Golds Radiate
description: For a moment, I am rendered motionless, too much in awe to move. My eyes linger on the forested crest of the park ahead of me at the top of the road. It is a dazzling display of autumnal splendor. Loud, raucous and bright hues welcome us into the woods this Monday morning. The trees themselves seem to say, Come in.

title: Penn State Has Exemption From Disclosure Law
description: The criminal allegations against Jerry Sandusky, the former Penn State assistant football coach accused of sexually abusing young boys, have prompted questions about what officials at Penn State knew and when.

title: Rural French Baking, From Oven to Recipes
description: ON a splendid autumn Saturday in Hudson, in Columbia County, it is all but impossible to find a place to park on Warren Street  a mile-long stretch that hums with antiques shops, boutiques and storefront restaurants. But on most days, when Lisa Brickman, the baker in chief at Cafe le Perche, walks to work at midnight, she has the street pretty much to herself.

title: Last Call for Your Time Capsule Photos
description: Update | View the visual time capsule here.

title: Show of Hands, Please: Who Can Buy Art?
description: THE artist Cindy Sherman stood underneath Bangkok II, a new large-scale photograph by Andreas Gursky that was being unveiled Nov. 4 at the fortress-like Gagosian Gallery in Chelsea. Ms. Sherman stared in amusement as Mr. Gursky and Klaus Biesenbach, the MoMA P.S. 1 director, fawned over her sequined Marni handbag. Oooh, nice, cooed Larry Gagosian, the super gallerist. Are you coming by later?

title: On Patrol With Syrian Army Defectors
description: As my colleague Nada Bakri reports, a deadly crackdown on dissent continued in Syria on Friday, even as protesters returned to the streets in several cities.

title: All About Your Airbnb Experiences
description: In this weekends Your Money column, I took a weeklong lap of New York City, staying in five Airbnb rentals in five different neighborhoods. My goal was to see how much hassle I would have to endure in exchange for what amount of savings over comparable hotels.

title: In Ad Agency Merger, Vitro Takes on Skinny
description: Two smaller advertising agencies owned by MDC Partners are merging to form a single agency with offices on the East and West Coasts.

title: Trustee Cuts 1,066 Jobs at MF Global; CME Pledges Backing for Customers
description: The court-appointed trustee overseeing the liquidation of MF Globals brokerage unit laid off 1,066 employees on Friday, the biggest wave of job cuts at the firm since it collapsed into bankruptcy nearly two weeks ago.

title: Martha Raddatz Tells War Stories With a Human Angle
description: If there has been a glamour beat in television news in recent years, it may well be war correspondent.

title: Sandusky Earned $456,000 From Charity
description: The tax-exempt charity founded by Jerry Sandusky, the former Penn State defensive coordinator charged with 40 counts of abusing young boys, paid him $456,000 from 2000 to 2008, according to Deadspins lengthy look at the organizations federal tax filings.

title: Telling the Stories of War Through Many Voices
description: EVEN for a woman who has been known to jump out of helicopters, this fall has been particularly crazy, says Martha Raddatz, the senior foreign affairs correspondent for ABC News.

title: This Sunday: 1,028 Itty-Bitty People
description: It stands to reason that when we put a story on the cover we think its worthy of your time and effort, and this week there is no doubt about that. With the singularity of purpose that an intelligence officer brings to an interrogation room, Ronen Bergman has powerfully illuminated the past and present of Israeli prisoner exchanges, focusing on the recent swap of 1,027 Palestinians for a single Israeli soldier named Gilad Shalit. How can such a deal be justified in a nation that prides itself on not negotiating with terrorists? What about the citizens whove been killed and maimed by those now being freed? These are the questions that drive Bergmans story.

title: Local Ingredients Make an Ever-Shifting Menu
description: WITH its pale clapboard siding and mature rose bushes by the front porch, the Millstone Caf blends in so well with its neighbors that it appears to have been a fixture of Kent for years. The cafe actually opened 14 months ago, a long time for a restaurant, but a mere blip in the life of a village.

title: Player Ratings: U.S. (0) vs. France (1)
description: Drab. Dull. Defeatist. Depressing. Dreadful. If we gave letter grades here at Goal, the U.S. would get a D.

title: Bill Cunningham | The Fleet
description: In New York everything is over the top, and the New York City Marathon is no exception.

title: Museum of the Great War
description: Photos of the new museum in Meaux, France.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,816 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American this week:

title: Back Again From Italy, With Boar and More
description: THE culinary career of Nicola Moncada, the owner of Il Cinghiale in Little Ferry, has never left him in one place for all that long. Born in Sicily, he made his way to Florence, London, Paris and New York before returning to Italy and opening his first restaurant in Novara, 30 miles west of Milan, in 1995. In 2000, he followed a brother to New Jersey and opened Nicola Due in Little Falls, a small but popular B.Y.O. that, he says, served up a lot of chicken parm.

title: Annabelle Lyon, Dancer for Balanchine, Dies at 95
description: Annabelle Lyon, an American ballerina who danced with some of the most important companies in the formative years of 20th-century American ballet, died on Nov. 4 at her home in Mansfield, Mass. She was 95.

title: Bringing the War Home
description: MEAUX, France  Despite the opening on Friday of a Museum of the Great War here, it is difficult to conceive of what took place in 1914, in pastoral farm country just outside this small industrial town about 25 miles northeast of central Paris. But you can get some idea from the ornately writhing figure of Liberty entwined with the dead and dying in the seven-story-tall stone statue that was mounted here in 1932, a gift of Americans and sculptured by Frederick MacMonnies.

title: Herman Cains Wife Plans to Sit Down for a Television Interview
description: Introducing  Gloria Etchison Cain.

title: If It Involves Performing, Does That Make It Art?
description: After attending two Performa events  Performa Ha! and Simon Fujiwaras Boy Who Cried Wolf  and witnessing six different performances, I find myself wondering, what is performance art, anyway?

title: In Georgia, Some Vote to Stay Dry on Sundays
description: ELBERTON, Ga.  The joke in Georgia after Tuesdays election was that the most popular name on the ballot was Jack Daniels.

title: Henry D. Owen, 91, Dies; Shaped Global Fiscal Order
description: Henry D. Owen, an influential diplomat who helped institutionalize global economic summitry in the 1970s and who was considered an intellectual framer of the elite round table known as the Trilateral Commission, died on Nov. 5 in Washington. He was 91.

title: Lebanon: Hearing on Hariri Trial
description: A United Nations-backed court on Friday heard arguments on holding a trial in absentia for the four Hezbollah members who have been indicted in the killing of a former Lebanese prime minister, Rafik Hariri, in 2005. The prosecution of the Special Tribunal for Lebanon, near The Hague, argued that the Beirut government should do more to track down and hand over the men, or else present evidence to the court on why it cannot. The court issued arrest warrants for the men in June, but leaders of the powerful Hezbollah militia vowed that its members would never be found or detained. A prosecutor, Iain Morley, said it was too early to begin a trial without the defendants because a trial in absentia should be a last resort.

title: The Best of Scuttlebotthe Weekend Reading Edition
description: For your enjoyment over the weekend, heres what the reporters and editors of the New York Times tech staff found on the Web. Youll find the days full Scuttlebot feed on this page in the right-hand column.

title: City Operas Growth Plan Depends on Donors
description: When New York City Opera faced a financial emergency early this year, its leadership promised to overhaul finances and live firmly within the companys means. Last spring City Opera even decided to move out of its prestigious home at Lincoln Center to save money. But an internal planning document that lists a creeping deficit shows how hard it is to stick to such intentions in the costly world of opera.

title: Virginia: Shaken Reactors Cleared
description: The twin North Anna nuclear reactors, located about 10 miles from the epicenter of the Aug. 23 earthquake, are safe to restart, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said on Friday. The reactors were shaken more than their designers anticipated, and they are the first in the United States to have faced an extended shutdown because of an earthquake. Dominion, their owner, said it spent $21 million on inspections. Government regulators will monitor the start-up, which is expected to take about 10 days. The company agreed to improve its monitoring of the fault that caused the quake, which was felt across the East.

title: Iraq: Two Shot After Soccer Victory
description: Celebratory gunfire wounded two people in Baghdad on Friday after Iraq defeated China, 1-0, in World Cup qualifying play. Before the Asia Cup earlier this year, the Iraqi government banned celebratory gunshots, which are in part a legacy of looting of military arsenals in 2003 that widely dispersed guns to the population. Iraqis seem to pay no heed and shoot anyway, probably making victory shooting, and injuries from falling bullets, a part of soccer culture in Iraq for some time.

title: Blake Is Playing With Purpose and Supporting a Cause
description: James Blake doesnt mind bringing his comeback tour through New York a second time this year. Blake, a former top 5 player who sunk as low as No. 173 in the ATP rankings earlier this year, will recall his New York roots and the memory of his father at a fund-raiser Nov. 28 at Lincoln Center.

title: Timeline: The Penn State Scandal
description: A grand jury report detailed the alleged incidents of sexual abuse committed by Jerry Sandusky, who went on trial on June 11.

title: Turkey: Ferry Hijacker Killed
description: A Kurdish militant who had hijacked a ferry with 18 passengers on board Friday afternoon in northwestern Turkey was shot to death by Turkish commandos. The militant had threatened to detonate explosives if he failed to get media exposure, local officials said. The governor of Istanbul, Huseyin Avni Mutlu, told The Associated Press that the passengers were all safe and that the hijacker was a member of the terrorist organization. Earlier, Binali Yildirim, the transportation minister, told the semiofficial Anatolian News Agency that four or five militants, identifying themselves as members of a subdivision of the Kurdistan Workers Party, had overpowered the captain and demanded food and fuel. The ferry, named Kartepe, was en route to Golcuk from Izmit, both coastal towns on the Sea of Marmara.

title: Giants Bradshaw Out for 49ers Game, but Nicks May Play
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Giants running back Ahmad Bradshaw did not practice again Friday and was ruled out of Sundays game against the San Francisco 49ers, which was no positive development for a team hoping to try to pierce the N.F.L.s toughest run defense.

title: Japanese Dcor, Pan-Asian Menu
description: IN June, when Ten Ten Bistro moved into the Northgate Plaza in Mount Sinai, right next door to the highly regarded Chinese restaurant Lotus East II, this strip mall became the headquarters for Asian food in the area.

title: 2 Computers in Battle for Title Evaluate a Hand Differently
description: The 15th World Computer-Bridge Championship was held concurrently with the 40th World Team Championships in the Netherlands last month.

title: Podcast: Europe, Pensions, Wealth and Phone Bills
description: For much of the past week, financial markets have fretted more about Italy than about Greece, which had been the main focus of worries for many weeks.

title: Allies Have Doubts About Protesters in Wisconsin
description: MADISON, Wis.  They wander the marble halls, day after day, hollering at passing lawmakers. They have turned up in committee meetings wearing peculiar masks. They are occasionally carried away by the police for filming official proceedings (not allowed in the chamber galleries) and for holding small signs (also barred in the galleries) quoting from documents like the Constitution. One is accused of pouring a beer over the head of a Republican leader, the co-chairman of the joint finance committee.

title: The Gingrich Surge Has Come
description: Theres lots of buzz on Friday about national polls that are variously being interpreted as good news for Newt Gingrich, good or bad news for Mitt Romney, and good or bad news for Herman Cain. So lets take a step back and focus on the bigger picture.

title: Soy Diet Is Cruel and Unusual, Florida Inmate Claims
description: MIAMI  One too many bouts of flatulence and cramping has led a Florida inmate to sue the Department of Corrections, arguing that the prisons soy-based turkey dogs and sloppy Joes amount to cruel and unusual punishment.

title: Vicious Brats? No Wonder
description: We may prepare exquisite desserts, arrange tulips in crystal vases and pile rare art books atop the coffee table. But suitably provoked, even the most civilized among us will unleash the ferocious child who lives within  the one who scarfs down sweets with two hands, smashes the tulips, vomits on the books.

title: Happy to Call the City Home, More Now Move In Than Out
description: Juan Rosales had tired of his predictable life in Chicago, where he worked in City Hall. I had reached a point in my life when I, essentially, wanted to reboot and start over, Mr. Rosales said, and wanted to do so in a city that would make such a big decision worth the risk.

title: Win or Lose, a Big Game Comes With the Possibility of a Big Letdown
description: Alabama defensive end Jesse Williams decided he was going to crouch on the grass of Bryant-Denny Stadium late last Saturday night and rest a moment after the tumult of a big game.

title: To Catch Up, Perry Makes a Big Ad Buy
description: Ramping up his effort to recover from his embarrassing debate performance on Wednesday, Gov. Rick Perry of Texas purchased nearly $1 million in advertising time on Fox News Channel, an extraordinary commitment of resources intended to jolt his candidacy for the Republican presidential nomination back on track.

title: Arms and the Corrupt Man
description: London

title: Guess What Its Time For!
description: Its the weekend. The air is brisk, the leaves are tumbling, so its time for  yes!  another Republican debate!

title: A Skippers Dream Outlives His Beloved Yacht
description: PORTSMOUTH, R.I.  When a wooden yacht called the Petrel was recently demolished on Marthas Vineyard, two generations of sailors and boat enthusiasts blanched  including some on another island, Manhattan, where the yachts former owner used to offer $3.75 rides in New York Harbor.

title: Unrest in Syria Divides a Region as a Border Never Did
description: GORENTAS, Turkey  Rostom, a Syrian refugee, stood near the peak of this hilltop village, peering through binoculars in hopes of catching a glimpse of troop movements across the Syrian border, which lay at the bottom of the valley floor below.

title: Veterans Day Parade in New York
description: The 92nd Annual New York Veterans Day Parade took place on Fifth Avenue and included active officers, veterans groups, junior ROTC members and the families of veterans.

title: After 33 Years, Still Promising to Behave
description: You wouldnt know, watching the spiffy Long Wharf production  or is it really a re-production?  of Aint Misbehavin, that this Tony-winning musical has become something of a cottage industry. The stars have all performed it before. The director, choreographer and two of the main designers have been doing the show since its beginnings, in 1978. Its only the ninth go-round for the musical director.

title: Cains Paine
description: Who knew that all you need to be president of the United States is a modicum of common sense? All year, the candidates for the Republican nomination have been touting their intimate relationship with this humdrum way of seeing the world. Michele Bachmann claimed that everything I needed to know in life I learned in Iowa, which she left at the age of 12. Rick Perry told Iowans that unlike the current president, he doesnt have a lot of interest in studies when it comes to restoring economic health. We know what the problem is, he said. Its not magic, it is actually common sense. We shouldnt spend all the money. Even decidedly unfolksy Mitt Romney announced this week at a gathering of Americans for Prosperity, I believe we can save Social Security with a few common-sense reforms.

title: The Right Move on Keystone XL
description: President Obama made just the right call on Thursday when he delayed a final decision on the Keystone XL oil pipeline from Canada until 2013.

title: S.E.C. Punishes 8 Workers in Errors Tied to Madoff
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission disciplined eight employees for missteps related to Bernard L. Madoffs Ponzi scheme, with punishments as varied as suspensions or written reprimands, an agency spokesman said.

title: To Keep Up With Yankees, Look Beyond Sports Pages
description: The Yankees have long been famous for making news, even in the off-season. George M. Steinbrenner could make headlines by dropping millions on the latest free agent or by complaining publicly about the one he had dropped millions on a couple of off-seasons before.

title: Power Broker Savors a Victory in San Francisco
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Perhaps no one took more pleasure in the citys first election of a Chinese-American mayor than Rose Pak.

title: Coded Messages
description: In the 1970s, a military junta took over Uruguay, and repression and violence pervaded the everyday life of ordinary citizens; Rimer Cardillo made art that protested these conditions. Working in a dangerous atmosphere, however, he needed a visual language that would disguise and code his critiques. And so he did what artists in similar circumstances have often done. He turned to the natural world, specifically, insects.

title: Up Against the Wall
description: The scene is a freshman room at Yale, mid-50s. Four occupants. First week of classes.

title: A Bid to Get Film Lovers Not to Rent
description: LOS ANGELES  Hollywood has had enough of the sharp consumer shift toward renting movies through Netflix. Desperate to raise home entertainment profits, studios want people to start buying movies outright again, either digitally or on little silver discs.

title: As Foes Flounder, Gingrich Gets Bump in Poll
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Newt Gingrich got his meltdown out of the way early. Last spring he endured a series of setbacks, culminating with the resignations of nearly his entire campaign staff, a fund-raising drought and a descent into margin-of-error territory in the polls.

title: Tennessees Push to Transform Schools
description: Tennessee has a long way to go in improving its schools, but it has made significant headway in turning itself into a laboratory for education reform. It was one of the first states to test a rigorous teacher evaluation system, which was put in place this school year. Yet even before the results are in, political forces are now talking about delaying the use of these evaluations. State lawmakers and education officials must resist any backsliding.

title: Affirmation of Health Care Reform
description: A federal appeals court in the District of Columbia endorsed the constitutionality of health care reform this week in an opinion as notable for its authorship as for its legal reasoning. The majority opinion in the 2-to-1 decision was written by Judge Laurence Silberman, a stalwart of conservative jurisprudence whose views are said to be enormously influential in conservative legal circles.

title: Season Tips Off in Location Unlike Any Other
description: ABOARD U.S.S. CARL VINSON, CORONADO, Calif.  The premise seemed closer to fiction: the first college basketball game held on a 95,000-ton, Nimitz-class aircraft carrier, the court constructed on its flight deck, where fighter jets normally speed away, propelled by catapults that shoot them off at 150 miles an hour into war zones. Normal this was not.

title: Lottery Numbers
Photo Replay: North Carolina vs. Michigan State
description: North Carolina and Michigan State played each other on the deck of the aircraft carrier U.S.S. Carl Vinson.

title: A Taste for Reality TV Seen in Popularity of Presidential Debates
description: On Saturday night, eight Republican candidates will gather in South Carolina for the 10th presidential debate  and much will be riding on the outcome.

title: A Room of Her Own
description: Two years ago, when Naterly Perez was 18, she woke up in the hospital alive, and she was disappointed. She had tried to kill herself by swallowing a handful of Xanax and Tylenol after being arrested for intervening in a fight between a friend and another girl. A judge, after hearing her story, ordered her into a one-year mental health program at Brooklyn Community Services, where she now participates in daily group sessions and creative arts therapies.

title: Was Freedom Enough?
The Institutional Pass
description: Joe is a devout Catholic, a retired football coach named Vince McAneney told a reporter the other day. He was referring, of course, to Joe Paterno.

title: Loves, New and Old: A Comedy of Kinship Structures
description: Cindy and Greer, when they were together, were the kind of couple  New England lesbian academics of a certain age  who would never have had a television set in the house. Yet later, the sitcom Friends insinuates its way into their lives, and into the plot of Seven Homeless Mammoths Wander New England.

title: Atticus Teaches a Lesson in Racism
description: At first the set bothered me. For the Shakespeare Theater of New Jerseys fine and very touching, if sometimes off-key, production of To Kill a Mockingbird, the scenic designer, Anita Tripathi Easterling, has put the Finch familys homey front porch within spitting distance of Boo Radleys ominous front door. It cant be much of a dare for a child to run up and touch that door, despite the presence of the scary, reclusive man on the other side, if its never far away.

title: Penn State Officials, Including Paterno, Could Face Civil Lawsuits
description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa.  It may take years, but Penn State, its administrators and possibly even the former coach Joe Paterno could be the targets of civil lawsuits seeking extensive monetary damages once the criminal case against a former assistant coach is concluded, trial lawyers with experience in similar cases said Friday.

title: Subway Thief? Or Just an Expert on Wallets and Razor Blades?
description: The jailhouse visiting room was filling up and getting louder on Thursday, and so the oldest inmate there did not quite hear the question.

title: Plan Would Delay Sales of Generic for Lipitor
description: The biggest introduction of a generic drug in pharmaceutical history is being met with tough business strategies by Pfizer and pharmacy benefit companies, according to recent letters to pharmacists.

title: U.N. Officials Accuse Sudan of a Bombing
description: Senior United Nations officials sided with newly independent South Sudan on Friday in accusing Sudan of bombing a southern civilian encampment the day before. One United Nations official called for an investigation, suggesting that a war crime might have been committed.

title: EMI Is Sold for $4.1 Billion in Combined Deals, Consolidating the Music Industry
description: EMI, the venerable music company that is home to the Beatles, the Beach Boys and the Motown song catalog, has been sold for $4.1 billion through a pair of deals that usher in a new wave of consolidation in the music industry.

title: Discussion with Edward L. Ayers
description: Join Disunion on Monday, Nov. 14, at 2 p.m. on our Facebook page for a conversation with Edward L. Ayers, a noted Civil War historian and Disunion contributor, about his new book, Americas War: Talking About the Civil War and Emancipation on Their 150th Anniversaries. Dr. Ayers, the president of the University of Richmond, will answer questions about the book, the sesquicentennial and Civil War history.

title: Net Migration: A Bigger Apple
description: More people are calling New York City home.

title: No Goals, Again, for Struggling U.S.
description: ST.-DENIS, France  For the moment, Jurgen Klinsmann could scarcely care less about losses and victories.

title: CNN Sets Off a Debate on Race and Technology
description: For nearly two weeks, a debate ignited by a CNN documentary has raged on the Internet about the obstacles to success in Silicon Valley and whether the technology industry is as meritocratic and as color-blind as it aspires to be.

title: Norton Dodge Dies at 84; Stored Soviet Dissident Art
description: Norton Dodge, a genially rumpled economics professor who in the course of research trips to study arcana like tractors and workforce demographics managed quietly to amass the worlds largest collection of nonconformist Soviet art, died on Nov. 5 in Washington. He was 84.

title: Friend With Benefits
description: Government is not the enemy. Not always. Dont believe that right-wing malarkey.

title: Saturday: People Who See What Youre Saying
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Barry C. Silks puzzles have really grown on me.

title: Yemeni Forces Heighten Deadly Assault on Protesters in City Central to Uprising
description: ADEN, Yemen  Yemeni government forces attacked protesters and residential areas on Friday in the southern city of Taiz, killing at least 15 civilians and wounding dozens of others, residents said.

title: How One Company Performed Under Bain Capital
description: How an Illinois medical company performed under Mitt Romneys private equity firm, Bain Capital.

title: Sinopec Buys Stake in Portuguese Energy Company
description: Sinopec has agreed to invest almost $5.2 billion in the Brazilian operations of the Portuguese energy company Galp Energia, the latest move in a global expansion by Sinopec, Chinas largest oil refiner. Under the terms of the deal, the state-owned Sinopec will invest $4.8 billion for a 30 percent stake in Petrogal Brasil, a subsidiary of Galp Energia. The Chinese company will make lend an additional $390 million to the Brazilian business. Galp Energia will retain the remaining 70 percent of Petrogal Brasil. The deal values the companys Brazilian assets at $12.5 billion. Chinas energy companies have spent billions of dollars in recent years to gain access to new energy resources. In October, Sinopec agreed to buy Daylight Energy, a Canadian oil and natural gas producer, for about $2.1 billion. The Chinese company also paid $7.1 billion last year for a 40 percent stake in the Brazilian assets of the Spanish energy firm Repsol YPF.

title: Murdochs Former Allies Deliver a Counterpunch
description: LONDON  The day after James Murdoch appeared before a parliamentary panel investigating allegations of phone hacking at The News of the World tabloid, he was firmly locked in a high-stakes battle of wills with the tabloids last editor, Colin Myler, and a former legal manager, Tom Crone.

title: Europes Woes Pose New Peril to Recovery in the U.S.
description: WASHINGTON  For the second time in two years, European debt troubles threaten to slow the momentum of the fragile recovery in the United States.

title: On Campus, a Law Enforcement System to Itself
description: After the body of an Eastern Michigan University freshman was found in her dorm room in December 2006, naked from the waist down with a pillow over her head, the chief of the university police said there was no reason to suspect foul play, and let her parents believe she had died of natural causes.

title: Often at Center of Mayhem, Emergency Rooms Tend to Be Gunfire-Free Zones
description: It would seem almost inevitable, yet still hard to fathom: rival gang members, angered and perhaps aggrieved over some recent disagreement, seek to continue or end the dispute the next time they meet  even if that encounter occurs at a hospital.

title: Phillies Lure Papelbon From Boston
description: Jonathan Papelbon will depart the perennially pressure-packed American League East for the emerging crucible that is the National League East.

title: Classical Piano and Modern Design
description: Rafael Violy, the globetrotting architect who designed Jazz at Lincoln Center, has just completed the first green police station for the New York Police Department, scheduled to open on Staten Island in July, and is responsible for the master plan for the conversion of the Domino Sugar plant in Brooklyn to a residential development. He divides his Sundays between the drawing board and the keyboard: he owns nine pianos, and as a child in Uruguay he trained to be a classical pianist. Mr. Violy, 67, lives in TriBeCa with his wife, Diana, an interior designer. The couple, whose three grown children and three grandchildren live in the neighborhood, also have homes in Water Mill, N.Y., and London.

title: Milkshakes by Day, Spiked Ones at Night
description: On the gastronomically arriviste stretch of the Bowery near Second Street sits Peels, the latest from Taavo Somer, the trend-maker partly responsible for Freemans, where diners slip down an alley to eat venison under an array of antlers, and the Rusty Knot.

title: N.B.A. Players Weigh Legitimacy of Latest Ultimatum
description: One hundred-thirty-four days into the N.B.A. lockout, the bargaining calculus for players has changed. Their immediate concern is no longer revenue splits or tax rates, but how to gauge another league ultimatum.

title: Obama Trip Stresses Ties to Economies Across Pacific
description: SAN DIEGO  After a decade in which wars in the Middle East have dominated American foreign policy, President Obama began an eight-day trip around the Pacific Rim on Friday to inaugurate what he hopes will be a new era in which engagement with the fast-growing economies of Asia is paramount.

title: Independent Once Again After a Devastating Blaze
description: The blaze started on a chilly morning in February, in the basement below the first-floor apartment in Brooklyn that Mariya Vakhlis had rented for 20 years. It engulfed the two-story building, turning to cinder all her worldly possessions save for a blanket from her native Belarus and an album of photographs of relatives lost to the Nazis during World War II.
