title: An AIDS Gala, With Honors and a Few Red Carpet Jitters
description: Miguel Bos is a big deal in Latin America. He has won a Latin Grammy Award, recorded more than 20 albums and starred in more than 35 films. He has also raised significant money to fight H.I.V. and AIDS. We were impressed, and at an Aid for AIDS gala in TriBeCa on Tuesday honoring Mr. Bos and others for their good works, Nocturnalists correspondent wanted to hear more about what brought him here, in his own words.

title: For Disabled Care Complaints, Vow of Anonymity Was False
description: ALBANY  For years, New York State has assured its employees who care for the developmentally disabled that there was a way they could confidentially report any concerns they had about the treatment of those in their care.

title: Where to Eat?
description: APP Immaculate Infatuation

title: Cuomo Pledges to Fight Joblessness Among Minority Youths
description: SAN JUAN, P.R.  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, in a speech aimed at reaffirming his standing with the Hispanic community, vowed on Friday that in the next legislative session he would take on joblessness among young people in New Yorks States minority communities.

title: Rangers Roll to Sixth Straight Victory
description: Three goals in three minutes in the third period Friday night gave the Rangers a 5-1 win  their sixth straight victory  over Carolina at Madison Square Garden.

title: Somewhere There's a Cowboy
description: Orville Davis has retained his cowboy image, in the saddle and on the bandstand, for the past 35 years he has lived in New York City.

description: Orville Davis, a cowboy and musician, first came to New York in 1976 for a two-week vacation and has been here ever since.

title: Horses, Music and a Happy Cowboy
description: ORVILLE DAVIS jokes that there are plenty of city-slickers who make a living shoveling horse dung, but he does it literally.

title: Jets Receivers Looking to Maintain Momentum
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Wearing sweat pants, gloves and a thermal turtleneck, Jeremy Kerley was prepared for the coldest practice of the week Friday.

title: As Schools Sacrifice, TV Shows Flourish
description: On Tuesday afternoon, a hundred or so parents of New York City public-school children, most of them mothers from the leafier precincts of Brooklyn, gathered outside the Manhattan office of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo to rally against the potential extinguishing of the so-called millionaires tax. With $1.4 billion for schools cut from the state budget last year, these parents wondered why the governor was so committed to helping the well-off become even better positioned. Millionaire rhymes with fair and share, one placard announced.

title: Kidnapped Ballplayer Ramos Found Alive in Venezuela
description: Venezuelan security forces rescued the kidnapped Washington Nationals catcher Wilson Ramos in an airborne operation on Friday after finding him in a mountainous area of northern Venezuela, officials said.

title: Dragster Kings Resume a Rivalry, Slowly
description: Nearly 21 years after he was paralyzed when his top fuel dragster crashed on an exhibition run in England, Darrell Gwynn strapped himself into a red racecar at a track in Gainesville, Fla., and once again took on his flamboyant nemesis, the legendary Big Daddy, Don Garlits.

title: Shots Fired Near White House
description: Shots were fired from at least one car about a block away from the White House Friday night, and a loaded AK-47 assault rifle was recovered from the scene, the Secret Service said. The episode does not appear to be connected to the White House. President Obama was in California and Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. was in New York for Veterans Day observances, according to their public schedules. Secret Service officers heard gunfire near Constitution Avenue and 16th Street around 9 p.m., said Ed Donovan, a spokesman for the Secret Service. Two cars drove off west on the avenue before one, a black Honda, was found abandoned near 23rd Street, Mr. Donovan said. Witnesses told officers that a man fled the car on foot. Officers found the loaded assault rifle in the car, Mr. Donovan said. The authorities were searching for the people who may have been involved.

title: Data-Crunching Mayor Now Sees Power in Words
description: MAYOR MICHAEL R. BLOOMBERG is not, by his own admission, much of a wordsmith. He is forever mispronouncing names  even those of his own commissioners. He is impatient with speechwriters. And he rarely, if ever, practices his remarks.

title: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
description: Jammu and Kashmir: The Supreme Court of India on Friday expressed shock over the detention of two Pakistani nationals in Jammu and Kashmir jails for more than 40 years without facing trial. The court was hearing a plea filed by the state political party, Jammu & Kashmir National Panthers Party seeking the release of Pakistanis in prisons across India. The court has demanded a comprehensive status report from the national government on Pakistani detainees in Indian jails. (Kashmir News Live)

title: Newswallah: Bollywood Edition
description: Ra.One: The hot topic in Bollywood this week was Ra.One number-crunching. As the dust settled on Shah Rukh Khans ambitious video game-romance-revenge movie, the question remained: is it a hit or a flop? Kishore Lulla, CEO of Eros International, which co-produced and distributed the film, said that the film was a profitable venture from the first week itself.

title: Berlusconi Steps Down, and Italy Pulses With Change

title: Hodges Added to Hall Credentials After Playing Days

title: Understated Rookie Fuels Bengals Makeover
description: CINCINNATI  The wish list was prepared in March: a receiver, a quarterback, cornerbacks, linebackers, interior offensive linemen. After a season with only four victories and with a franchise quarterback intent on never returning, Coach Marvin Lewis could not be shy about all the parts the Cincinnati Bengals had to replace. It had been his job to relay to the front office that Carson Palmer would not play for them again, and now it was the Bengals job to find Palmers replacement.

title: Sights and Sounds on the Grounds of a Nuclear Disaster
description: Updated | Sunday | 7:19 p.m. Eight months after the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power station was crippled by an earthquake and tsunami, the Japanese government has opened the compound and surrounding area to the media for the first time. On Saturday, a group of reporters, including Martin Fackler of The New York Times, toured the plant. In this post, he describes his trip to the damaged facility:

title: The Angry Aftermath for a Program Gone Awry
description: A former Penn State defensive coordinator, Jerry Sandusky, was charged Nov. 5 with sexually abusing eight boys over a 15-year stretch. Two university officials stepped down after being charged with perjury in the case. Neither Joe Paterno, the longtime football coach, nor Graham B. Spanier, the university president, was charged, but questions were raised about whether they and an assistant, Mike McQueary, did as much as they could have done to stop the suspected assaults. Paterno and Spanier were fired last week, and McQueary was put on administrative leave. Here are some of the many letters readers sent to The Times.

title: A.F.C. East Title Is the Divide in an Otherwise Tight Rivalry
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  A veteran of Baltimores bruising twice-a-season tangles with Pittsburgh, Rex Ryan flung himself into his new rivalry  a decidedly lopsided one  with all the subtlety of a bazooka. He used his new platform as the Jets coach, in 2009, to spread his audacious gospel, that they would topple the mighty Patriots, that he would never smooch Bill Belichicks Super Bowl rings.

title: The Haas Family Tree Has Many Offshoots
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Whether by phone, text or in person, Bill Haas conducts a postround analysis of his play with his father, Jay, a professional golfer for more than 30 years.

description: There was an interesting bit of news Friday for the United States mens national team after another goalless outing in an international friendly  it will face a regional minnow, Antigua and Barbuda, when the Americans begin play next June in World Cup qualifying matches in the Concacaf region.

description: THERE are millions of Americans seeking love on the Internet. Little do they know that teams of scientists are eagerly watching them trying to find it.

description: ABOARD THE U.S.S. CARL VINSON  The presidency does have its perks. And for President Obama, basketballs fan in chief, one was the opportunity on Friday night to watch the No. 1 ranked college basketball team, the University of North Carolina Tar Heels, play the Michigan State Spartans on the flight deck of an aircraft carrier whose mission six months ago was to bury Osama bin Laden at sea.

title: Of Rookies and Symmetry at Abu Dhabi Practice

title: Tackling the 49ers Gore Doesnt Mean Youve Stopped Him
description: SANTA CLARA, Calif.  With about three minutes remaining in last months game between San Francisco and Philadelphia, 49ers running back Frank Gore took a handoff at the Eagles 12-yard line and cut through a hole in the line of scrimmage.

title: On Wikipedia, the Western Black Rhino Moves from Is to Was
description: In tracking the erosion of the worlds diverse array of living things, a new phenomenon is emerging: the spread of the past tense on wildlife entries in Wikipedia. The latest case of a description tipping from is to was comes in the listing for the western black rhinoceros, one of four subspecies of the black rhinoceros. On the new species red list issued by the International Union for Conservation of Nature, this subspecies has been declared extinct  moved from red to black.

title: A Scandal Is a Test of Bonds Old and New
description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa.  Five years ago last summer, on the first night in our new home after a move our children had made with great reluctance  if the threat to withhold grandchildren meets that description  there was something I wanted my 9-year-old daughter, Katie, to know.

description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  Its been a while since weve had a cryptic crossword from Richard Silvestri, and I, for one, am glad hes back. Mr. Silvestri can bring the clever clues and the laughs, and after the busy week I had, Im all for that.

description: THE so-called supercommittee in Congress has until Nov. 23 to find more than a trillion dollars of new savings in the federal budget.

title: A Store for the Town, by the Town

title: Even as Governments Act, Time Runs Short for Euro
description: BERLIN  The window of opportunity to save the euro is rapidly closing, as the sovereign debt crisis erodes the solvency of Europes banks and drives up borrowing rates for even once rock-solid countries like France.

title: Your Begonia Is Texting You
description: IT was only a matter of time. Plants have begun texting for help. Thanks to clever new digital devices, a dry philodendron, undernourished hibiscus, or sadly neglected wandering Jew can send its owner a text or Twitter message. Humans like to feel appreciated, so a begonia may also send a simple Thank-you text  when its happy, as gardeners like to say, meaning healthy and well-tended. Picture your Boston fern home alone placing Botanicalls. But why should potted plants be the only ones to reassure their humans? Another company has found a way for crops to send text messages in unison, letting their farmer know if shes doing a good enough job to deserve a robust harvest. What is the sound of one hand of bananas clapping? Probes monitoring the soil can send a range of prerecorded messages specific to each plants needs.

title: 100,000 Football Fans at Penn State Cheer, but the Mood Is Numb
description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa.  The tone for a Saturday football game under a bright sun was born in the darkness of a Friday night vigil at the epicenter of the Penn State campus. Spread across a grassy plain yards from the streets where demonstrators clashed with the police days earlier, several thousand students gathered holding lighted candles, a quickly organized rally in support of sexual abuse victims that concluded when a university bell tower chimed 10 times to mark the hour.

title: Billions Wasted on Billing
description: LAST year I had to have a minor biopsy. Every time I went in for an appointment, I had to fill out a form requiring my name, address, insurance information, emergency contact person, vaccination history, previous surgical history and current medical problems, medications and allergies. I must have done it four times in just three days. Then, after my procedure, I received bills  and, even more annoying, statements of charges that said they werent bills  almost daily, from the hospital, the surgeon, the primary care doctor, the insurance company.

title: Robert A. Scalapino, a Scholar of Asian Politics, Dies at 92

title: Deportations Under New U.S. Policy Are Inconsistent

description: WHEN I think about the sins of Joe Paterno, and the ignominious ending of his long and famous career, I think about Daro Castrilln Hoyos.

title: The Last Person
description: Jodhpur, India

title: Fighting Back, One Brothel Raid at a Time
description: ANLONG VENG, Cambodia

title: The Campaign Jungle
description: A series of television ads began running a few days ago supporting Gov. Rick Perrys presidential bid. They were the usual fare  conservative leadership that works  and they featured old photos of him in the Air Force and video from the trail. A casual viewer might assume they were run by his campaign, but they were run by a new phenomenon this year: the candidate super PAC  by far the most noxious weed yet to emerge in the lawless new jungle of campaign finance.

title: Gall in High Places
description: SILVIO BERLUSCONI isnt comfortable with English. Brett Ratner, Im guessing, hasnt mastered Italian. What a pity. Theyd probably get along like a palazzo on fire.

title: Generation Sell
description: EVER since I moved three years ago to Portland, Ore., that hotbed of all things hipster, Ive been trying to get a handle on todays youth culture. The style is easy enough to describe  the skinny pants, the retro hats, the wall-to-wall tattoos. But style is superficial. The question is, whats underneath? What idea of life? What stance with respect to the world?

title: Will This Election Be the Mormon Breakthrough?
description: THIS fall, we behold omens that will darken a year hence in the final phase of President Obamas campaign for a second term. His likely opponent, the Mormon Mitt Romney, will be a pioneer figure whatever the outcome, since no previous member of that very American church, the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, has ever secured a major-party nomination. Even should Mr. Obama triumph, a crucial precedent will have been established.

title: The New Progressive Movement
description: OCCUPY WALL STREET and its allied movements around the country are more than a walk in the park. They are most likely the start of a new era in America. Historians have noted that American politics moves in long swings. We are at the end of the 30-year Reagan era, a period that has culminated in soaring income for the top 1 percent and crushing unemployment or income stagnation for much of the rest. The overarching challenge of the coming years is to restore prosperity and power for the 99 percent.

title: A New Era of Gunboat Diplomacy
description: WASHINGTON

title: Remembering Flight 587, 10 Years Later
description: Under a canopy of bright blue sky, the 10th anniversary of the crash of American Airlines Flight 587 in Belle Harbor, Queens, was recognized on Saturday by some 500 relatives and friends of the victims.

title: Why Are Political Cartoons Incendiary?
description: AS the founding editor and publisher in the late 1950s of Monocle, a leisurely quarterly of political satire (that meant we came out twice a year) whose motto was In the land of the blind the one-eyed man is king, whenever the offices of a satirical magazine are firebombed, Im interested.

title: Hit and Run
description: RECENTLY my dog, Honey, was taking a walk in the neighborhood with her dog walker, Lauren, when she was clipped by a car. Honey bolted, yanking the leash out of Laurens hand  apparently dogs get a huge surge of adrenaline after being hit by cars.

title: Bradys Mandate
description: The duty of every American prosecutor is to see that justice is done, not to convict criminal defendants by any means. For a generation, the district attorneys office in New Orleans brazenly flouted this standard.

title: Russia, in From the Cold
description: After 18 years of stop-and-go negotiations, it is good news that Russia, the worlds 11th largest economy, finally sealed a deal on Thursday to enter the World Trade Organization and subject its unruly form of capitalism to the strictures of international law.

title: A Long, Winding Road to Marriage Equality
description: The fight for gay rights won important victories in the past few months. In July, it became legal for same-sex couples to marry in New York State. September saw the official end of the dont ask, dont tell policy that prevented gay people from serving openly in the military. On Thursday, the Senate Judiciary Committee approved a bill that would repeal the 1996 Defense of Marriage Act, the law that bars the federal government from recognizing same-sex marriages.

title: Wait Wait ... Dont Tell Me
description: NPRs Wait Wait ... Dont Tell Me! is heard weekends on public radio stations across the country. (npr.org/waitwait)

title: Who Is Occupy Wall Street?
description: OCCUPY WALL STREET has proved to be a difficult, sprawling story to report. Almost immediately after protesters began arriving at Zuccotti Park in downtown New York on Sept. 17, Times readers weighed in with concerns about the coverage.

title: Sunday Dialogue: Ideas for Cutting Military Spending
description: Readers respond to a former assistant secretary of defenses suggestions for Pentagon cuts.

title: Of Kentucky
description: Throughout my life I have experienced cultural diversity and continue to travel between two worlds, the hollers and cities. I was born in Hazard, Ky., and raised primarily in a holler called Johnsons Fork, in Letcher County, where only mountain people had lived for generations. People from both sides of my family were born, lived and died here. Neither of my grandfathers ever lived anywhere else. In true mountain tradition, they both gave land to my parents to build their home.

title: The Benefits of Fracking
description: To the Editor:

title: Money-Laundering Case Speaks to Border Fears
description: LAREDO The high walls of Alexander Estates, an affluent development nestled near this border citys country club and golf course, were supposed to keep the narcotics world at bay. But when federal agents raided the stately home of a downtown perfume salesman in January, it reinforced a notion that is feared by Texas leaders: the drug war spillover from Mexico is much broader than shootouts and kidnappings it is cloaked in the seemingly routine business transactions of the border economy.

title: Silvio Berlusconi: From Publisher to Politician
description: Silvio Berlusconi, Italys richest man, has served three times as the countrys prime minister.

title: In Favor of Dirty Jokes and Risqu Remarks
description: QUESTIONS about what Herman Cain did or didnt do after dinners years ago have carried the subject of sexual harassment back into the news.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, November 13
description: The arrest of a former assistant football coach at Penn State, Jerry Sandusky, on charges that he sexually abused young boys, put the university in the middle of a scandal over the last week and led to the removal of longtime coach Joe Paterno and the president, Graham B. Spanier. On Sunday, Gov. Tom Corbett of Pennsylvania, who has begun an investigation into the abuse accusations as the states attorney general, joins NBCs Meet the Press, Fox News Sunday and ABCs This Week to discuss the case.

title: As 9/11 Remains Are Identified, Grief Is Renewed
description: On Nov. 19, 2001, Susan Ainbinder Hutchins received a call saying that her son, Kevin Colbert, who worked at an investment bank on the 89th floor of 2 World Trade Center, had been identified among the ground zero remains.

title: With Sleepaway Camp, Trying to Keep Stability
description: Chocolate and smores. For Brianna Robeck, these are among her favorite things about camp. She spent the summer at Camp Louemma in Sussex, N.J., and spoke excitedly about her time there.

title: Joining on Somaly Mams Brothel Bust
description: My Sunday column returns to a regular theme  human trafficking  and recounts a raid on a brothel in northern Cambodia with one of my heroes, Somaly Mam. The youngest girl in the brothel had been trafficked from Vietnam a few months ago when she was in the seventh grade, meaning that she was born in 1999. That makes her about 12 years old.

title: Sunday: Either Way
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  The last time we saw Jeremy Newton and Tony Orbach team up, it was for the spectacular Sunday grid where we had to escape each room via an invisible door in the black squares (Across Lite, Solution, blog).

title: NBA Draft Pick Heads Back to School
description: Tobias Harris left Tennessee for the N.B.A. after his freshman year, but he returned to take classes and work out during the lockout.

title: Masters of the Game and Leaders by Example
description: Fewer than 2 percent of the 77,000 members of the United States Chess Federation are masters  and just 13 of them are under the age of 14.

title: Occupy Oakland and News Media Coexist Uneasily
description: Immediately after a man was shot to death Thursday afternoon near the Occupy Oakland encampment, Randy Davis, a cameraman for KGO-TV, turned his lens on a group of protesters helping the victim. Then part of the crowd turned on him.

title: In Richmond, Foreclosed Homes Breed a New Kind of Problem
description: When Deborah Huey was about to show two empty units of an apartment building she managed to a prospective tenant earlier this year, the deal was scuttled by views of a dilapidated, empty house across the street.

title: Writers Body Is Weaker, but Voice Remains Strong
description: Christopher Kelly writes a column for the Texas Report.

title: Sprinkle Chili Powder Over the Pineapple and Throw In Crab Meat? Why Not?
description: Last weekend in Napa Valley, at the 14th annual Worlds of Flavor conference hosted by the Culinary Institute of America in St. Helena, some of the worlds most notable chefs were taking culinary diversity to new, somewhat dizzying heights.

title: Tough Questions on Changing Teacher Evaluations
description: For the first time next year, thousands of Chicago Public Schools teachers will be evaluated based partly on how well their students are doing academically. Many fear they will face dismissal if the standards are not applied fairly.

title: An Unusual Library Finds a New Home
description: On a recent Saturday afternoon in Humboldt Park, a small band of volunteers scrambled to put the finishing touches on their librarys new home  the sixth in as many years for the Read/Write Library, Chicagos largest depository of grass-roots printed materials.

title: Liberal or Conservative, the Problem Is Ignorance
description: James Warren writes a column for The Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Its-It Factory
description: People living east of the Rockies may not have heard of this ice cream treat, but most in the Bay Area know the Its-It. There are several stories about the origin of the name, but the companys Web site says that in 1928, at a San Francisco beachfront amusement park called Playland, a pie shop owner named George Whitney put a scoop of vanilla ice cream between oatmeal cookies and dipped it in chocolate. Its It! he announced, and a local star was born. LOUISE RAFKIN

title: Evelyn H. Lauder, Champion of Breast Cancer Research, Dies at 75
description: Evelyn H. Lauder, a refugee of Nazi-occupied Europe who married into an illustrious family in the beauty business and became an ardent advocate for breast cancer awareness, raising millions for research, died on Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 75.

title: Wary Legislators Approve Speed-Detection Cameras
description: It took just seven days for Mayor Rahm Emanuel and his lobbying team to persuade a reluctant state legislature to pass a bill allowing speed-detection cameras near hundreds of schools and parks throughout Chicago.

title: After Berlusconi Resigns, Some Italians Rejoice
description: Ending an era in Italian politics, Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi resigned Saturday after Parliament approved austerity measures, my colleagues Rachel Donadio and Elisabetta Povoledo reported on Saturday.

title: Penn State-Nebraska Replay
description: In their first game since the firing of Coach Joe Paterno, the Penn State Nittany Lions lost at home to Nebraska, 17-14.

title: Gingrich: Bring the Debates On
description: GREENVILLE, S.C.  There may be one Republican candidate prone to memory lapses who wishes he never had to debate again, but Newt Gingrich cannot get enough of these events.

title: Highlights From the Republican Debate in S.C.
description: The Republican candidates for president gather for a debate Saturday night in South Carolina, where Gov. Rick Perry of Texas will get a chance to redeem his fumbling, forgetful performance in Michigan on Wednesday night.

title: On a New Stage, Rutgers Keeps Its Wits to the End
description: Greg Schiano took his team to Yankee Stadium on Saturday earlier than he would have if Rutgers had played almost anywhere else. He sent his players onto the grass field and told them to take all the photographs they wanted with their cellphones.

title: Berlusconi, Magnetic and Divisive, Whose Politics Were Personal
description: ROME  With a combination of savvy media domination, old-fashioned party politics and a salesmans preternatural charm, Silvio Berlusconi has dominated Italy more than anyone since Mussolini.

title: Obama Sees an Opening on China Trade
description: HONOLULU  President Obama promised to continue a frank dialogue on economic disputes with China as he met with its president, Hu Jintao, on the sidelines of a trade summit here on Saturday. But, he added, We should be rooting for China to grow.

title: A Paternos Long Walk to Cap an Emotional Day
description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa.  The Penn State quarterbacks coach, Jay Paterno, grew up here on McKee Street, less than a mile from campus and a short walk from the football field that his fathers coaching helped nearly triple in size to a 108,000-seat stadium.

title: Photo Replay: Nov. 12, 2011
description: A look at the day in sports, including Formula One racing in Abu Dhabi and golf at the Australian Open.

title: Republicans Debate in South Carolina
description: Republican presidential candidates discussed foreign policy in South Carolina on Saturday night.

title: Gov. Rick Perry on Foreign Aid
description: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas says that if he were president, foreign aid would start at zero for every country including Israel.

title: Police in Denver Move on Protesters
description: DENVER  The Denver police cleared a protest encampment allied with the Occupy Wall Street movement in a downtown square Saturday evening. Sixteen people were arrested, according to the police.

title: Rumors Drown Truth on N.B.A.s Proposal
description: Hours after the N.B.A. delivered its final collective bargaining proposal to the players union, the rumors and the rhetoric began to flow.

title: Republican Candidates on Torture
description: The Republican presidential candidates discuss torture.

title: Newt Gingrich on Mitt Romney
description: Newt Gingrich, former U.S. Speaker of the House, declined to elaborate on his comment about being unsure of Mitt Romneys capability of changing Washington.

title: Bachmann Campaign Accuses CBS News of Bias
description: While Michele Bachmann was debating Saturday evening, her campaign turned to Facebook to harshly accuse CBS News, a co-sponsor with National Journal, of limiting questions to her and suppressing our conservative message.

title: Up for Debate: Foreign Policy and Obama
description: SPARTANBURG, S.C.  The eight major Republican candidates for president joined in a united attack against President Obama as commander in chief during a debate here Saturday, but at times differed sharply over how to block Irans nuclear ambitions, the way forward with Pakistan and the use of torture.

title: PATH Service Returns After a Fire
description: 1:20 a.m. | Updated  Train service in the entire PATH system was suspended for several hours on Saturday night because of an electrical fire at a station in Jersey City, a spokesman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said.

title: Corrections: November 13
description: NATIONAL

title: Christopher Bendixen, Thomas Salatte
description: Christopher Carl Bendixen and Thomas Matthew Salatte were married Saturday afternoon at the Midtown Loft and Terrace, an event space in New York. Marie A. Marasovich, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: Rebecca Levy, Bryan Lanzman
description: Rebecca Jeannette Levy, a daughter of Susan R. Levy and Dr. Daniel Levy of Newton, Mass., was married Saturday evening to Dr. Bryan Alexander Lanzman, a son of Christine C. Farmerie and Dr. Jeffrey G. Lanzman of Pacific Grove, Calif. Rabbi David Adelson officiated at the Metropolitan Building, a restored factory in Long Island City, Queens.

title: John Balzano, Anthony Porto
description: John Christopher Balzano and Dr. Anthony Frank Porto were married Friday evening at the Saybrook Point Inn in Old Saybrook, Conn. Officiating was Judge Joette Katz, a former associate justice of the Supreme Court of Connecticut, for whom Mr. Balzano was a clerk from 2007 to 2008.

title: Emily Maynes, David Wardrop
description: Emily Courtland Maynes, the daughter of Janet L. Maynes and Richard F. Maynes of New Canaan, Conn., was married Saturday to David Michael Wardrop, the son of Deborah K. Wardrop and Michael G. Wardrop of Port Ludlow, Wash. The ceremony, at the Church of the Incarnation in New York, was led by the Rev. J. Douglas Ousley, an Episcopal priest and the churchs rector.

title: Haley Park, Matthew Ivey
description: Haley Park and Lt. Cmdr. Matthew William Ivey are to be married Sunday at the Cathedral of St. Matthew the Apostle in Washington. The Rev. Frank Herrmann, a Roman Catholic priest, is to perform the ceremony.

title: Sarah Charnes and Michael Paisner
description: Sarah Elizabeth Charnes and Michael Sylvain Paisner were married Saturday evening in Washington. The Rev. James H. Burch, of the Catholic Diocese of One Spirit, led a nondenominational ceremony at Meridian House, which is part of the Meridian International Center.

title: Deborah Batts and Gwen Zornberg
description: Judge Deborah A. Batts and Dr. Gwen Lois Zornberg were married Saturday evening at the St. Gregory hotel in Washington. Emily C. Hewitt, the chief judge of the United States Court of Federal Claims in Washington, officiated.

title: Alyssa Rapp and Hal Morris
description: Alyssa Jill Rapp and Hal Morris were married Friday evening at Lakeshore Country Club in Glencoe, Ill. Michele F. Lowrance, a judge of the Circuit Court of Cook County in Chicago, officiated. The couple met at Stanford, where each received an M.B.A.

title: Lily Louie, John Yuen
description: Lily Louie and John Xiang-Zhong Yuen were married Saturday afternoon in Manhattan. The Rev. Dr. Andrew Y. Lee, a Baptist minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Park Avenue Christian Church.

title: Simone Levine, William Harrell
description: Simone Alana Levine and William Clark Harrell were married Saturday evening in New Orleans. Rabbi Ellen R. Lippmann officiated at the Degas House, a bed-and-breakfast inn in New Orleans. Judge Margaret Alfonso, the Youth Court judge in Harrison County, Miss., and with whom Mr. Harrell has worked, took part.

title: Naomi Skop, Joseph Richter
description: Naomi Hillary Skop, a daughter of Joanne Skop and Charles Skop of Merrick, N.Y., is to be married Sunday to Dr. Joseph Rachmiel Israel Richter, a son of Devera Richter and Rabbi Chaim Richter of Hollywood, Fla. The bridegrooms father, who retired as the director of chaplaincy for the Jewish Federation of South Broward County in Davie, Fla., is to perform the ceremony at Temple Beth El in Cedarhurst, N.Y.

title: Shay Weiner, Yong Woo
description: Shay Raquel Weiner and Yong Jin Woo were married Friday at the New Orleans Pharmacy Museum in New Orleans. Nevin A. Weiner, the brides father, who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

title: Anna Kornbluh, Ezra Friedman
description: Anna Danielle Kornbluh and Ezra Henry Friedman were married Saturday at One Sixtyblue, a restaurant in Chicago. Judge Richard E. Tuttle, the brides maternal grandfather, who retired from California Superior Court in Calaveras County, officiated.

title: Stephanie Bonan, Samir Patel
description: Stephanie Bonan and Samir Harish Patel were married Saturday evening at the Bowery Hotel in New York. Salil K. Gandhi, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: Jillian Gumbel and William Robins
description: Jillian Beth Gumbel, the daughter of June B. Gumbel of Waccabuc, N.Y., and Bryant Gumbel of New York, was married Friday evening to William Russell Robins, a son of Bonnie G. Robins of Waccabuc and the late Alan M. Robins, who lived in Tarrytown, N.Y. Rabbi Brett S. Goldstein officiated at the Breakers, a resort in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Annabelle Gardre, Lateef Nurmohamed
description: Annabelle Marie Rene Gardre and Lateef Nasir Nurmohamed were married on Friday at the McDowell Mountain Golf Club in Scottsdale, Ariz. The Rev. Donald J. Priest, a nondenominational Christian minister affiliated with the Rhema Ministerial Association International of Oklahoma, officiated.

title: Monica Morales and Robert Mayer
description: Monica Morales, a reporter for WPIX-TV in New York, and Robert Adam Mayer, a photographer, were married Saturday by Msgr. William Belford at St. Patricks Cathedral in New York.

title: Carolyn Cassidy, Zachary McGee
description: Carolyn Anne Cassidy and Zachary Samuel McGee were married Saturday at the Four Seasons Biltmore in Santa Barbara, Calif. The Rev. Jerry Bellamy, a Universal Life minister, led a nondenominational ceremony.

title: Nancy Cook, Christopher Rowland
description: Nancy McLoughlin Cook and Christopher Frost Rowland were married Saturday at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. The Rev. Steven D. Paulikas, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: Roxanne Adams, Sherry Sylar
description: Roxanne Gail Adams and Sherry Lynn Sylar were married Friday afternoon at their home in Nyack, N.Y. Amanda L. Ebey, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: Karen Shafrir, Stephen Vladeck
description: Karen Elana Shafrir and Stephen Isaiah Vladeck were married Saturday evening at the Ronald Reagan Building and International Trade Center in Washington. Cantor Roy B. Einhorn officiated.

title: Charlotte Wang, Dominic Latella
description: Charlotte Wang, the daughter of Lillian Theresa Wang of Totowa, N.J., was married Friday to Dominic Anthony Latella, a son of Helen Theresa Latella and Joseph Vincent Latella Sr. of Springfield, Va. Henry F. Greene, a senior judge of the Superior Court of the District of Columbia, officiated at the Bethwood, an event space in Totowa.

title: Laurie Reese, David Ehrlich
description: Laurie Beth Reese and David Seth Ehrlich were married Saturday evening at the Sheraton Inner Harbor Hotel in Baltimore. Rabbi Ari Sunshine officiated with assistance from Cantor Sara Geller.

title: Jennifer Torres, Antonio Pagan
description: Jennifer Teresa Torres and Antonio Adrian Pagan were married Friday in an outdoor ceremony at the Crescent Beach Club in Bayville, N.Y. William J. Corbett, a retired village justice of Floral Park, N.Y., officiated.

title: Tara Kraft, James Horan
description: Tara Maria Kraft and James Francis Horan were married Saturday at the Camden Harbour Inn in Camden, Me. Linda Vaughn, a Maine notary, officiated at the ceremony, which was led by the Rev. Albert T. Maroun, an uncle of the bridegroom and a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Yonahton Bock, Ronald Kaplan
description: Yonahton Avraham Bock and Ronald Lee Kaplan were married Thursday evening at the Sixth and I Historic Synagogue in Washington. Rabbi Steve Greenberg officiated.

title: Daily Susman and Phineas Lambert
description: Daily Lacey Susman, the daughter of Judge Susan G. Braden and Thomas M. Susman of Washington, was married Saturday evening to Phineas Abraham Lambert, the son of Sheila S. Lambert and Bill G. Lambert of New York. Rabbi Jeffery A. Wohlberg officiated at the Willard Hotel in Washington.

title: Beatrice Springborn, Jacob Seidler
description: Beatrice Rose Donath Springborn and Jacob Aubrey Seidler were married Saturday evening at the Colony Palms Hotel in Palm Springs, Calif. Scott Lethbridge, an uncle of the bridegroom and a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: Sara Villagio, Matthew Lalli
description: Sara Beth Villagio and Matthew Joseph Lalli were married Saturday afternoon in Kings Park, N.Y. The Rev. Francis P. Vattakudiyil performed the ceremony at St. Josephs Roman Catholic Church.

title: College Football Replay: Nov. 12
description: Saturdays slate of college football games included T.C.U. upsetting Boise State and Oklahoma State blowing out Texas Tech.

title: Republican Debate Sponsored by CBS, The National Journal and the Republican Party of South Carolina
description: Sponsored by CBS, The National Journal and the Republican Party of South Carolina

title: Giants at Niners: Matchup to Watch
description: Giants (6-2) at 49ers (7-1), 4:15 p.m. Eastern, Fox

title: Patriots at Jets: Matchup to Watch
description: Patriots (5-3) at Jets (5-3), 8:20 p.m. Eastern, NBC

title: When Stanfords Moment Arrives, Its a Disaster
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.  Early Saturday afternoon, Stanfords campus was alive, a fervent optimism lingering in the air from the tree-lined parking lots (where tailgaters took turns beating an Oregon Duck piata) to the student section waiting area (where cheers and chants were led by bare-chested fans who painted letters on one anothers torsos).

title: In Tight 12 Rounds, Pacquiao Retains His Title
description: LAS VEGAS  In the back room inside his locker room deep in the MGM Grand, with security stationed inside and outside the closed door, with his post-fight suit-and-fedora ensemble hanging neatly in the corner, Manny Pacquiao could not have appeared more relaxed.

title: Top 25 Roundup: Stanford and Boise State Fall From Ranks of Unbeaten
description: 1. LOUISIANA STATE (10-0) beat Western Kentucky, 42-9

title: The Days Best in College Football
description: Brandon Weeden passed for 423 yards and 5 touchdowns and Joseph Randle, right, ran for 3 scores as Oklahoma State improved to 10-0 with a 66-6 rout of Texas Tech. Weeden, who completed 31 of 37 passes, threw touchdown passes of 2, 27, 28, 48 and 66 yards before leaving late in the third quarter. Randle scored on runs of 2, 1 and 10 yards.

title: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
description: In The Fall of the Middlewoman, Open Magazine looks at Niira Radias decision to vanish into the blue by closing up the public relations shop she built. Ms. Radia, who became a central figure in the investigation into the sale of second-generation wireless spectrum after Open published transcripts of her various conversations with businessmen and politicians, closed her business on October 30. In this speculative story, Open suggests, without a named source, that she left at the behest of political establishment types who were eager to see that the name of Tata Group, her largest client, was not dragged through the mud any more than it had been. Her disappearance would give a legitimate excuse to the CBI and ED to quietly close the relevant Radia files in the near future, the magazine said, referring to the Central Bureau of Investigation and the Enforcement Directorate.

title: In Paris, First-Ever French Retrospective of Diane Arbus
description: Though she has been celebrated widely in the United States, an exhibition of the work of Diane Arbus at the Jeu de Paume in the Tuileries gardens of Paris, is the first-ever French retrospective of the American photographer. The show, titled simply Diane Arbus, runs through Feb. 5 at the museum (1 Place de la Concorde; www.jeudepaume.org).

title: Iraq Criticizes Exxon Mobil for Its Deal With the Kurds
description: BAGHDAD  A deputy prime minister overseeing Iraqs oil industry criticized Exxon Mobil on Sunday over its effort to expand into the semiautonomous Kurdish region in the countrys north.

title: Canadian Cultural Imperialism
description: OK, that was fairly strange. Yesterday I appeared on a panel discussion in Puebla, Mexico along with Nick Kristof, Mark Spitz, and Oliver Stone.

title: After a Romney Deal, Profits and Then Layoffs
description: Mitt Romneys business career is a cornerstone of his campaign, reports Michael Barbaro of The New York Times. But his brand of capitalism had human costs and some messy financial consequences. Read more

title: Supply-Side Solutions? Beware (Wonkish)
description: Theres a new Vox paper suggesting that supply-side policies  structural reform that makes workers more productive, prices more flexible, or whatever  may be the answer to a liquidity trap. Some people may seize on this claim. So its worth pointing out that a casual interpretation here gets it all wrong.

title: Spam, Spam, Spam, Spam
description: You may see a lot of this comment was rejected tags. Thats because some vendor of knockoff clothing has somehow breached the Times spam filter, and I had to find a quick way to make a large number of comments go away. Its not personal!

title: Beyond Fracking, Another Use for Marcellus Shale
description: Via my friend Amy Lipton, a curator at EcoArtspace, I just discovered The Marcellus Shale Experiment. In this fascinating blog, the Philadelphia-based artist Jennie Shanker is chronicling her efforts to create ceramics using clay from the Marcellus Shale region  best known as a big new source for natural gas through the muchdebated method called fracking, or hydraulic fracturing (recently explored by Times columnist David Brooks).

title: For Executives, Cases for Hall Are Not Strong Enough
description: For five days last week, I blogged about the players eligible for the Hall of Fame on the Golden Era ballot, advocating for three to be inducted and five to be turned away. I feel strongly that Minnie Minoso has been unfairly overlooked, and Im convinced that Gil Hodgess managerial magic combined with his playing career should put him over the top and that Ron Santo, as one of the 10 best third basemen to play the game before 1990 (despite having the advantage of hitting in Wrigley Field), deserves entry. And while I wouldnt be horrified if Jim Kaat, Allie Reynolds, Louis Tiant, or especially Tony Oliva and Ken Boyer made it in, I dont think they belong.

title: Rio Slum Is Pacified in Advance of Games
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  About 3,000 police officers and soldiers moved into one of the largest slums here on Sunday in a pivotal effort by the government to assert control over lawless areas of the city ahead of the 2014 World Cup and 2016 Summer Olympics.

title: TNT, in Tie-In With Hyatt, Will Hold Armchair Detective Weekends
description: One of the more interesting trends in media is the effort by television channels and networks to find ways to bring their programming to life in the real world.

title: Immortals Leads the Way at the Box Office
description: Megawatt marketing campaigns powered two abysmally reviewed new movies to solid results at North American theaters over the weekend.

title: Getting Control of a Rio Slum
description: About 3,000 police officers and soldiers backed by helicopters and armored cars occupied one of Rio de Janeiros largest slums on Sunday.

title: Deficit Panel May Put Off Tax Deliberation
description: WASHINGTON  The top Republican on the joint Congressional committee on deficit reduction did not exactly radiate confidence on Sunday about the panels ability to reach a sweeping bargain by its Nov. 23 deadline. Instead, he signaled that the committee was contemplating a procedure that would allow it to delay the toughest choices about how to raise taxes.

title: Hamiltons Victory in Abu Dhabi Extends the Race for Series Runner-Up
description: ABU DHABI  Long before the sun set at Abu Dhabis twilight Grand Prix, the day had ended for the driver who had until then had a nearly flawless season.

title: Hamiltons Victory in Abu Dhabi Extends the Race for Series Runner-Up
description: ABU DHABI  Long before the sun set at Abu Dhabis twilight Grand Prix, the day had ended for the driver who had until then had a nearly flawless season.

title: At a Loss for Words After Oregons Emphatic Victory
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.  Nick Aliotti was speechless.

title: 2 Nutcrackers, One Apartment
description: This started long before all the stores put up the holiday stuff  before, even, they put up the Halloween stuff. David Parker and Keith Michaels apartment in the West Village has been all Christmas, all the time, since August.

title: Disruptions: The 3-D Printing Free-for-All
description: Downloading  quite often stealing, in the eyes of the law  music, movies, books and photos is easier than bobbing for apples in a bucket without water. It has kept legions of lawyers employed fighting copyright violations without a whole lot to show for their efforts in the past decade.

title: With Clock Ticking, an Economist Accepts a Mandate to Rescue Italy
description: ROME  Mario Monti, a former member of the European Commission, conditionally accepted a mandate on Sunday to form a new government in Italy whose main task will be to keep the country from being dragged under by Europes debt crisis.

title: Billy Crystal Is Gilded as Hero of Oscar Night
description: LOS ANGELES  Oprah Winfrey snagged an Oscar here on Saturday night, but the evenings hero  not present, though never out of mind  was Billy Crystal.

title: Paris Masters Triumph Is a First and a Boost
description: PARIS  A two-set lead was not enough for Roger Federer to shake free of Jo-Wilfried Tsonga at Wimbledon this year. But a two-set lead is all that is required for victory at this late stage of the tennis season, and so Federer finally got to hold up a trophy on the other side of Paris.

title: Occupy Wall Street Protesters Shifting to College Campuses
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  Goodbye, city park, hello, college green.

title: Man Held in Beating of an Elderly Woman
description: Updated, 10:35 p.m. | A homeless man accused of clubbing an elderly woman with a piece of wood on a Midtown street had to be subdued after acting erratically while awaiting arraignment on Sunday night, the authorities said.

title: Documents: Felons and Guns
description: The Times examined data from courts across the country on convicted felons who had their firearms rights reinstated and reviewed hundreds of pages of documents associated with those cases. In many instances, people who got their gun rights back went on to commit new crimes. Here are court records associated with several people with felony convictions who had their firearms privileges restored. Related Article

title: The Correct Pronunciation Of EC Is Eek
description: Ive managed to go a whole day without thinking about the euro, but tomorrows FT is online and I couldnt help myself.

title: Is Neuroscience the Death of Free Will?
Civil Wars: If I Didnt Know Better
Messiaen Moments, in Swells and Fanfares
description: You neednt be a pipe organ cabalist or an initiate of the new-music illuminati to be moved, even shaken, by Olivier Messiaens music for the instrument he played most of his life. Apparition of the Eternal Church, a 2006 film by Paul Festa, makes the point vividly; in it, Mr. Festa claps headphones on writers, performers and quasi celebrities, then captures their reactions of bemusement, perplexity and awe as they listen to Messiaens landmark 1932 piece, Apparition de lglise ternelle.

title: Chords of Repose at Composers Memorial
description: The Polish composer Henryk Gorecki died last Nov. 12, and to commemorate the first anniversary of his death Le Poisson Rouge and the Polish Cultural Institute presented two of his substantial chamber works in a free concert on Tuesday evening. Le Poisson Rouge was packed for the occasion: 45 minutes before the performance listeners who thought they had arrived early enough to get a seat were filling the standing room.

title: At Least Six Are Killed as Libyan Militias Clash on Coastal Highway Near Tripoli
description: ZAWIYAH, Libya  Two rival militias fought a sporadic but deadly gun battle just west of Tripoli over the weekend, blocking traffic on the vital coastal road between the Libyan capital and the Tunisian border. The outburst of violence was among the worst to come to light since the killing of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi last month.

title: France Keeps a Watchful Eye on Turmoil in Italy
description: First it was Athens. Then Rome. Could Paris be next?

title: Gaining Maximum on Defense at a Computerized Showdown
description: The second semifinal at the World Computer-Bridge Championship in the Netherlands last month was between Wbridge5, one of the pretournament favorites, and Shark Bridge.

title: Roger Christian, Olympic Hockey Star, Dies at 75
description: Roger Christian, whose four-goal game propelled the United States to its first gold medal in Olympic ice hockey, an improbable championship at the 1960 Squaw Valley Winter Games, died Wednesday in Grand Forks, N.D. He was 75.

title: Returning One Kind of Kiss With a Kiss-Off
description: It turns out, a kiss is never just a kiss.

title: A Pianists Composition Rounds Off Debut Recital
description: The 23-year-old pianist Nobuyuki Tsujii, blind from birth, is said to have achieved pop-star status in his native Japan since he shared the gold medal at the 2009 Van Cliburn International Piano Competition with Haochen Zhang, from China.

title: Legendary Gaze Burns Through Time and Trouble
description: Albert Grossman, who had put together Peter, Paul and Mary as a folk-singing trio, once suggested to Judy Collins that she become part of a trio too. She would sing with two other women, Judy Henske and Jo Mapes. We can call you the Brown-Eyed Girls, he said.

title: Astonishing Views of a Luminous, Bustling Planet
description: Nov. 26, 12:29 a.m. | Update |Heres a fresh NASA remix of Space Station time-lapse imagery, in this case with Peter Gabriels Down to Earth, from Wall-E:

title: Monday: Bridge Positions
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Are you a good bowler? Mark Feldman offers us a bowling theme today, and if youre really good, you will score a strike, a spare and a split. Technically speaking, this counts as a double theme, because the second half of each theme entry has to do with money. And, as the final theme entry, Mr. Feldman wraps things up with the entry BOWLED OVER at 61 Across. Nicely done.

title: Newsweek, Mired in Red Ink, Cancels Longtime Political Series
description: It has been one of Newsweeks signature ventures and a staple of American political journalism since 1984.

title: At His Essence, Smokin Joe Was More Than Just a Symbol
description: On Monday at Enon Tabernacle Baptist Church in Philadelphia, thousands ofmourners paid theirrespects to Joe Frazier, the former heavyweight boxing champion who died last week.

title: Bitter Departure for Miamis Ballet Patriarch
description: Morning class at the Miami City Ballet had just ended one day in late September when the dancers and staff gathered in the main studio for a companywide meeting with their founder, artistic director and patriarch, Edward Villella.

title: Cities and Global Warming: San Franciscos Experience
description: To the Editor:

title: Keeping It Honest: Choreography That Stays True to Itself
description: The most intense performance at the Merce Cunningham Studio on Friday was given by a dead choreographer. No, not the ghost of Mr. Cunningham, but rather Anna Sokolow, who died in 2000 at the age of 90. She appeared in a film shot at Ohio State University in 1966. Teaching students her Odes, created the year before, she corrected them with such barking ferocity that I feared she might bite.

title: Sharing Hoop Dreams of a Compositional Strategist
description: Virtually every consideration of George Lewis, an imposing performer and scholar now serving as a professor and the vice chairman of the music department at Columbia University, will invoke the term trombonist-composer. If youve encountered Mr. Lewiss playing, stressing instrumental prowess seems natural; if you havent, dip into an album like Anthony Braxtons Quartet (Dortmund) 1976, and you will hear instantly why Mr. Lewis is revered among avant-garde jazz aficionados.

title: Putting the Brakes on Web-Surfing Speeds
description: BERLIN  State-of-the-art Web surfing, for all of its breathtaking speed, can be baffling. A favorite page gets hung up. A data-intensive application, like playing a video or downloading large files, stutters or stops. Is it the telecommunications operator? Is it the Web site? Is it the smartphone or the computer? Or just a sign of Internet thrombosis?

title: A Creatures Comforts in a Time of Need
description: Animal Planet is familiar as the home of garish shows like Fatal Attractions and My Extreme Animal Phobia. On Monday night, though, it goes for the touching rather than the tacky with Saved, a new series about people who were in need of some kind of spiritual boost and received it from an animal.

title: Antihunger Campaign Forgoes Images of Starving Children
description: ACTION Against Hunger, a nonprofit group that fights malnutrition, is running a public service ad campaign that uses nontraditional, abstract imagery, rather than photos of starving children, to gain support.

title: Singer and Pianist Continue Their Onstage Dialogue
description: The collaboration between the Austrian mezzo-soprano Angelika Kirchschlager and the French pianist Jean-Yves Thibaudet at Zankel Hall on Saturday evening may have looked like a luxury pairing of established artists at the top of their games. But these two go way back. When Mr. Kirchschlager made her memorable United States debut, at Alice Tully Hall in 1995, Mr. Thibaudet, though already commanding attention as a soloist, was her accompanist.

title: Is Mandatory Voting a Good Idea?
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Guys Grow Up One Night
description: There is only one note in Two-Man Kidnapping Rule, and even thats not well played. A story of three guys who find that their lives get more complicated as they grow older, Rule makes this less-than-profound discovery in its first 15 minutes then spends the large part of two hours repeating it again and again, and then some more.

title: The Public Fixation on Lindsay Lohans Travails
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Punish Fraud
description: To the Editor:

title: Support for Raising Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: Blast Kills Commander at Iran Base
description: One of the top commanders in Irans ballistic missile program was among those killed Saturday in an explosion at a base for the Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps, the group said in a statement on Monday.

title: Steelers Turn Things Around
description: CINCINNATI  The oddity of the Pittsburgh Steelers season could be summed up in one statistic: the defense that produced 35 turnovers last season on the way to the Super Bowl had just four this season, leaving the Steelers struggling for consistency. They could not make a critical play to stop the Baltimore Ravens 92-yard touchdown drive in the waning moments of their game last week, and on Sunday, against the A.F.C. North-leading Cincinnati Bengals, the Steelers were again faced with the possibility of a painful collapse.

title: Gloria Cain Says Allegations Dont Square With Her Husband
description: Two weeks after accusations of sexual harassment against Herman Cain emerged, his wife, Gloria Cain, has opened up publicly about the matter, saying, Im thinking he would have to have a split personality to do the things that were said.

title: Another Look at Sweeney Todd
description: Sweeney Todd will return to the West End in London early next year when the latest production of the Stephen Sondheim-Hugh Wheeler musical takes up residence at the Adelphi Theater, just a mile from the fictional barbershop in the show, the BBC News Web site reported. The production recently concluded a run at the Chichester Festival Theater in Sussex, England, where it garnered high praise from London critics, especially for its lead actors, Michael Ball (The Woman in White) and Imelda Staunton (Vera Drake). Mr. Ball played the serial-killing barber while Ms. Staunton filled the role of Mrs. Lovett, his landlady. Previews of the London production are to begin on March 10 with a planned run of six months.

title: Showtime Renews the Series Weeds
description: Showtime has announced that its comedy Weeds, with Mary-Louise Parker as a suburban mom turned drug kingpin, will return for an eighth season. Production will start next year on 13 new episodes. Despite diminishing returns in the ratings  the most recent season averaged less than one million viewers an episode  the show is still the highest-rated comedy for that premium cable channel and has earned multiple Emmy nominations, including one for best comedy series in 2009.

title: Israeli Government Backs Limits on Financing for Nonprofit Groups
description: JERUSALEM  A committee of Israeli cabinet ministers voted Sunday to back two bills aimed at curtailing the support of left-wing nonprofit groups from foreign governments.

title: Protest T-Shirt Generates Anger
description: A T-shirt inspired by the Occupy Wall Street movement and created by Rocawear, whose founders include the hip-hop star Jay-Z, was pulled from the companys Web site over the weekend. The move came after a company spokesman told Business Insider that proceeds from sales of the shirts would not be donated to the protest movement, Entertainment Weekly reported on its Web site. Photos of Jay-Z in the shirt  with the phrase Occupy Wall Street altered to read Occupy All Streets  appeared on Twitter earlier in the week, and the shirt was to be released on Friday. But the spokesmans statement led to accusations on Twitter and elsewhere that the rapper was trying to profit from the protests, and the shirt soon disappeared from the companys Web site. Jay-Z, near left, with Russell Simmons, is currently touring with Kanye West to promote their album, Watch the Throne.

title: Sweet Judy Blue Eyes
description: Judy Collins has written a new memoir.

title: The Governors Awards
description: Photos from the third annual event in Los Angeles.

title: Reality TVs Instant Stars Populate a Magazine
description: Reality television stars tend to lack certain attributes: discretion, shame, gainful employment. One thing they dont seem to want for is exposure.

title: Barbara Grier, Publisher of Lesbian Books, Dies at 78
description: Barbara Grier, a founder of one of the most successful publishing houses for books by and about lesbians, including a nonfiction chronicle about lesbian nuns that became a phenomenon after it drew complaints from Roman Catholic officials, died on Thursday in Tallahassee, Fla. She was 78.

title: For Pacquiao, a Victory Comes at a Painful Cost
description: LAS VEGAS  Shortly after his latest fight, Manny Pacquiao lay flat on his back on a wooden table in Locker Room No. 2 at the MGM Grand. Tissue paper covered all of his face except for the area around his right eye. He gripped the arm of his wife, Jinkee, with his right hand, squeezing tightly.

title: Newspapers Digital Apostle
description: Last week, John Paton met with executives of the MediaNews Group, the second-largest newspaper chain by circulation in the country, home to papers like The Denver Post, The Detroit News, The Salt Lake Tribune and a broad swath of dailies throughout California, including The San Jose Mercury News.

title: Israel Lobbies Discreetly for More Sanctions After U.N. Report on Iran
description: JERUSALEM  Israel hopes that a United Nations report released last week cataloging suspect activities in Irans nuclear program will finally force major countries to make sanctions painful enough that Iran will stop its uranium enrichment program.

title: Foxs U.F.C. Broadcast a Hit With Viewers
description: Foxs hourlong Ultimate Fighting Championship broadcast Saturday night was seen by an average of 5.7 million viewers  more than for any previous U.F.C. event and the most for a televised fight of any kind in eight years, the network said Sunday.

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: Recruiting Veterans, Columbia Finds an Impressive Applicant Pool
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif.  Two years ago, in an effort to attract more veterans to Columbia, Curtis Rodgers, a dean of admissions, began recruiting at military bases. Almost immediately he noticed differences between the Marines and the typical 18-year-old Ivy League applicant.

title: In Twist, Manning and the Giants Fall Short in the Fourth
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The ball was batted down almost as soon as it left Giants quarterback Eli Mannings hand, and he could only stare after it. Red jerseys were bouncing all around him, but Manning stayed rooted to his spot, one hand resting on his hip. The San Francisco 49ers were giddy; Manning just looked stunned.

title: Now Funny People Can Get Respect (and Course Credit at U.S.C.)
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  Crammed into a booth at the Nate n Al Delicatessen  the professionally funny call it the commissary  Barnet Kellman, David Isaacs and Jack Epps Jr., from the University of Southern Californias School of Cinematic Arts, were trying to explain over a plate of pickles why those who create screen comedy deserve academic respect.

title: Why Do Top Schools Still Take Legacy Applicants?
When Sites Drag the Unwitting Across the Web
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Can an online algorithm track down your child?

title: William Aramony, United Way Leader Who Was Jailed for Fraud, Dies at 84
description: William Aramony, who built United Way of America into one of the nations premier charities but was forced out as president and went to prison for six years for misusing funds to support a lavish lifestyle and a teenage mistress, died on Friday in Alexandria, Va., where he lived. He was 84.

title: A Lifetime of Battling Bias
description: In Richard Lapchicks long battle against racial bias in sports, numbers have been his oral weapon of choice, reliable and irrefutable, though admittedly not the most effective means of commanding a room.

title: Restoring Gun Rights to Felons
description: Every year, thousands of felons across the country have their gun rights reinstated, often with little or no review.

title: Massachusetts Mulls Letting Bars Offer Happy Hours
description: BOSTON  This city has a robust bar culture, with trivia nights, $1 oyster specials and plenty of other perks to keep patrons coming. But not since 1984, when Cheers was new to television, has Massachusetts allowed bars to hold happy hours.

title: Some Lessons in Damage Control
description: While the turmoil at Penn State has been the academic equivalent of a Category 5 storm, it will probably not have much long-term impact on the university, experts say.

title: Mobs Strike Embassies After Group Bans Syria
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Turkey sent planes to evacuate its diplomats families from Syria on Sunday after a night of attacks on foreign embassies in Damascus, the capital. The events seemed sure to deepen Syrias most pronounced isolation of the four decades of Assad family rule.

title: Banks Quietly Ramping Up Costs to Consumers
description: Even as Bank of America and other major lenders back away from charging customers to use their debit cards, many banks have been quietly imposing other new fees.

title: Rising Bank Fees
description: Banks are raising fees to make up for revenue declines elsewhere.

title: Well Qualified, but Facing Uphill Fight
description: ROME  In the news media he is known simply as Super Mario. But Mario Monti, the likely leader of Italys new government, which is being formed amid a crisis that threatens the European monetary union itself, will face a strong challenge in living up to his admiring nickname as he tries to steer his country from the brink of economic turmoil and through the machinations of Italian politics.

title: How League Offer Could Alter Movement and the Market
description: In the reimagined, recalibrated N.B.A. of the future, Carmelo Anthony would have a tougher time forcing his way out of Denver. LeBron James would take a steeper pay cut to flee Cleveland. Gilbert Arenas would be a free agent, instead of a payroll albatross.

title: Costume Shot Unnecessary, Obama Says
description: HONOLULU  Is the silly shirts photo of Asia-Pacific leaders now history?

title: Felons Finding It Easy to Regain Gun Rights
description: In February 2005, Erik Zettergren came home from a party after midnight with his girlfriend and another couple. They had all been drinking heavily, and soon the other man and Mr. Zettergrens girlfriend passed out on his bed. When Mr. Zettergren went to check on them later, he found his girlfriend naked from the waist down and the other man, Jason Robinson, with his pants around his ankles.

title: Cuomo Tries to Shore Up the Support of Minorities
description: SAN JUAN, P.R.  The crowd of Hispanic legislators and business leaders from New York, sipping cocktails at a sleek hotel overlooking the Atlantic Ocean, abruptly halted their conversations as Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, fresh off a 1,600-mile flight, came in through a side entrance on Friday.

title: N.B.A. Labor Proposals
description: The summaries of three contract offers from the N.B.A. to the players union.

title: Traffic to Stymie Even the Batmobile Shows the Two Sides of Movie Production
description: The Queensboro Bridge was where Simon and Garfunkel felt groovy, where Woody Allen and Diane Keaton watched dawn break in Manhattan, where the city could be seen, as F. Scott Fitzgerald wrote, in its first wild promise of all the mystery and the beauty in the world.

title: Looking Ahead to Economic Reports This Week
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include retail sales for October, the Producer Price Index for October and business inventories for September (Tuesday); Consumer Price Index for October and industrial production and capacity utilization for October (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims, housing starts for October and Philadelphia Fed manufacturing index for November (Thursday) and leading economic indicators for October (Friday).

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: A Frugal Fleet to the Rescue
description: Washington

title: Lottery Numbers
Alternate-Side Parking Brings Peace
description: Canton, N.Y.

title: EMI and Warner Not Meant to Be
description: The music gods have meddled again with EMIs destiny. In the minds of many, the union of the British music company  home to the Beatles and the Beastie Boys  with its American rival Warner Music was supposed to be just a matter of time. But the star-crossed match has been knocked off course again by an EMI breakup involving Sony and Vivendis Universal Music.

title: Neo-Nazis Suspected in Long Wave of Crimes, Including Murders, in Germany
description: ZWICKAU, Germany  Neo-Nazi terrorists are responsible for a crime wave reaching back more than a decade that includes the murders of at least 10 people, including immigrant shopkeepers and a police officer, German government officials said Sunday. The group is also suspected in more than a dozen bank robberies and a bombing in Cologne, they said.

title: Deficit Panel Seeks to Defer Details on Raising Taxes
description: WASHINGTON  With a little over a week left to reach a deal, members of the Congressional deficit reduction panel are looking for an escape hatch that would let them strike an accord on revenue levels but delay until next year tough decisions about exactly how to raise taxes.

title: Tie to Penn State Seems Unlikely for Its Next Coach
description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa.  After a loss to Nebraska on Saturday, it became apparent that Penn State was attempting to create a narrative to move forward. Rodney Erickson, the universitys interim president, and the football teams interim coach, Tom Bradley, pushed themes of solidarity, healing and trying to bring some good of an awful scandal.

title: Health Law Puts Focus on Limits of Federal Power
description: WASHINGTON  If the federal government can require people to purchase health insurance, what else can it force them to do? More to the point, what cant the government compel citizens to do?

title: Obama Talks Up Free Trade and Jobs at Asia-Pacific Meeting
description: HONOLULU  With the weak domestic economy and his re-election hopes as the backdrop, President Obama made job creation the theme of an annual trade summit meeting on Sunday as the United States, for the first time in nearly two decades, hosted leaders of Pacific Rim nations.

title: They Like Transparency, Until They Dont
description: The New York City public advocate, Bill de Blasio, has started an investigation into why the city fails so miserably to release even the most routine data requested under the states Freedom of Information Law. Mr. de Blasio cited a request his office made last November for documentation on delays in school bus service. He is still waiting for the documents, but he recently got one of many lovely letters that explain how the Department of Education is still working on his request.

title: Internet Architects Warn of Risks in Ultrafast Networks
description: SANTA CLARA, Calif.  If nothing else, Arista Networks proves that two people can make more than $1 billion each building the Internet and still be worried about its reliability.

title: A Blue-Ribbon Indictment
description: A 645-page report from the United States Sentencing Commission found that federal mandatory minimum sentences are often excessively severe, not narrowly tailored to apply only to those offenders who warrant such punishment, and not applied consistently. That is especially so for sentences of people convicted of drug-trafficking offenses, who make up more than 75 percent of those given federal mandatory minimum sentences.

title: A New Civil Rights Movement
description: Alabamas ruling class has dug in against the storm it caused with the nations most oppressive immigration law. But Latinos in the south are moving now to protect themselves.

title: On the Rise in Alabama
description: Alabamas ruling class has dug in against the storm it caused with the nations most oppressive immigration law. Some of the laws provisions have been blocked in federal court; others wont take effect until next year. But many Alabamans arent waiting for things to get worse or for the uncertain possibility of judicial relief or legislative retreat. They are moving to protect themselves, and summoning the tactics of a civil rights struggle now half a century old.

title: Obama in Honolulu: This Is My Birthplace
description: HONOLULU  Its too bad Rick Perry and Donald Trump were not here over the weekend.

title: Are Giants Too Reliant on Manning Magic?
description: A capsule look at the Giants 27-20 loss to the 49ers on Sunday:

title: Vouchers for Veterans
description: American health care is remarkably diverse. In terms of how care is paid for and delivered, many of us effectively live in Canada, some live in Switzerland, some live in Britain, and some live in the unregulated market of conservative dreams. One result of this diversity is that we have plenty of home-grown evidence about what works and what doesnt.

title: Zealots Remorse
description: A welcome touch of resistance is in the air toward Grover Norquist, the conservative lobbyist and Capitol Hill fixture who has been brilliant at wrenching a simplistic pledge from all but six House Republicans to never, ever increase taxes.

title: Week 10 Live: Jets-Patriots Win Probability
description: The Fifth Down will track the win probability for the Jets and the Patriots throughout Sunday nights showdown at MetLife Stadium. We did it for the first meeting between the teams in Week 5, but a quick review for those unfamiliar with the metric from Advanced NFL Stats.

title: Challenges to the Health Law
description: Legal cases where the individual mandate has been challenged.

title: How Romney Could Win
description: Election Day is nearly a year off and the first primaries arent until January, but Im ready to skip ahead to the main event. The last serious hope of the Tea Partiers, Rick Perry, and their last not-so-serious hope, Herman Cain, are in campaign death spirals. Unless God has a cruel sense of humor, Newt Gingrich will pass like a tantrum. That leaves us with a general election between two serious and certifiably sane candidates. Phew!!

title: New Austerity Incites a Bitterness the Postwar Generation Did Without
description: LONDON  Before he died of Lou Gehrigs disease in 2010, the historian Tony Judt recalled childhood days just after World War II in a debilitated Britain that was slowly ceding its empire and its pre-eminence.

title: Major Humanitarian Group Leaves a South Sudan Region
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Growing violence along the border between Sudan and South Sudan caused a major humanitarian aid group to withdraw over the weekend.

title: Oops Moment Takes On a Life of Its Own
description: http://www.hulu.com/watch/299649/saturday-night-live-cold-opening-gop-debate-3

title: You Won the Right to Wed; Now Comes the Tough Part
description: It would not be inappropriate to bring a few handfuls of rice to toss at the climax of Standing on Ceremony: The Gay Marriage Plays, a collection of monologues and short plays that opened on Sunday night at the Minetta Lane Theater. This mostly genial, often funny omnibus is essentially a staged celebration of the recent advances in winning marital rights for gay and lesbian couples, and how the changing laws are changing lives.

title: A Finger Slips, and the Bachmann Camp Pounces
description: It is not exactly a state secret that the news media tend to lavish more coverage on perceived front-runners in presidential campaigns.

title: N.Y. Lawmakers Confer in Puerto Rico
description: SAN JUAN, P.R.  For a few days every November, the place for New York State politicians to see and be seen is not Angelos 677 Prime in Albany or the Regency Hotel in Manhattan, but a resort hotel in the Caribbean.

title: Economy in Japan Shows Signs of Strength
description: TOKYO  Japans economy grew at a 6 percent annualized rate in the third quarter, signaling a strong recovery after the devastating tsunami in March. Still, a slowing global economy and a stubbornly strong yen cloud the outlook for Japan, the worlds third-largest economy.

title: Giants Replay: Week 10
description: Action from the Giants 27-20 loss to the 49ers in San Francisco in a matchup of two first-place teams.

title: Photo Replay: Nov. 13
description: A look back at the day in sports, including rugby in France, college basketball in Maryland and speedboat racing in Florida.

title: For a Homeless Child, a Long Ride to 4th Grade
description: Every night, N-Dia Layne would set the alarm on her mothers cellphone to 4:45 a.m. If the two of them were not on the subway platform at 103rd Street and Broadway by 6:20 a.m., there was no way N-Dia would be on time for school.

title: Jamestown Thought to Yield Ruins of Oldest U.S. Protestant Church
description: JAMESTOWN  For more than a decade, the marshy island in Virginia where British colonists landed in 1607 has yielded uncounted surprises. And yet William M. Kelsos voice still brims with excitement as he plants his feet atop a long-buried discovery at the settlements heart: what he believes are the nations oldest remains of a Protestant church.

title: Bowl Championship Series Standings
description: The B.C.S. rankings are determined by three components: the Harris Interactive poll, the USA Today coaches poll and the average of six computer rankings. Each component counts one-third toward a teams B.C.S. score.

title: For Annoyed Neighbors, the Beat Drags On
description: It was well after midnight when Kyle Brooks was jolted awake by an ungodly banging.

title: After Months of Making Do, a Mother Is Ready to Once Again Make a Home
description: Elizabeth Johnson-McKinney surprised her son, Xavier, when she told him they were moving to a bigger house.

title: After an Anti-Semitic Episode, a March With a Message
description: Two days after the sight of flaming cars and anti-Semitic graffiti horrified a heavily Jewish neighborhood in Brooklyn, residents, elected officials and others took part in a march on Sunday against hatred and intolerance.

title: Regions Will Compete for New York State Cash
description: Think of it as American Idol for policy wonks and economic development types.

title: Educating a Changed Town
description: Juan Perez, the principal of Kepley Middle School in Ulysses, Kan., reflects on growing up as a migrant, educating future generations and finding home.

title: Hispanics Reviving Faded Towns on the Plains
description: ULYSSES, Kan.  Change can be unsettling in a small town. But not long ago in this quiet farming community, with its familiar skyline of grain elevators and church steeples, the owner of a new restaurant decided to acknowledge the communitys diversity by adding some less traditional items to her menu. Cheeseburgers. French fries. Chicken-fried steak.

title: The Gulf of Morality
description: Theres a gulf as wide as the ocean between the average politically active conservative and the average politically active liberal. We dont just have political differences; we view the world through very different eyes. So wrote John Hawkins, who runs Right Wing News, at the beginning of the year.

title: A Child Whos Picky About Dogs, and Other NYTimes.com Reader Tales
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Chelsea Clinton to Report for NBC
description: NBC announced Monday that it has hired Chelsea Clinton to become a full-time special correspondent for NBC News.

title: Googles Lab of Wildest Dreams
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  In a top-secret lab in an undisclosed Bay Area location where robots run free, the future is being imagined.

title: Fire Aside, Other Kindles Also Shine
description: If you think that the pace of technological progress is already too fast, youd better not look at e-book readers. Youll get whiplash.

title: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Monday
