description: A report on Jammu and Kashmir State recommends that the central government recognize the dual and special status of Jammu and Kashmir; review all laws imposed on the state after 1952 and respect the right of Kashmiris to travel freely across both sides of the Line of Control, Indias border with Pakistan, reports The Indian Express. Kashmirs tenuous relationship with Delhi lies at the heart of its political problems, the report says.

title: Changing Face of the Rural Plains
description: Growth in the population of Hispanics in the Great Plains  especially in rural areas, where even small growth can have an outsize impact  is filling some of the void left by a declining white population. The Hispanic population in the seven Great Plains states shown below has increased 75 percent, while the overall population has increased just 7 percent.

title: Mark Howe, the Proto-Nicklas Lidstrom, Is at Last in the Hall of Fame
description: On Monday night, Mark Howe will at long last be where he belongs: in the Hockey Hall of Fame. Howe became eligible for election to the Hall in 1998, three years after his distinguished 22-season career ended, butonly now ishebeing ushered into a club in which he has long deserved membership. Yet even that is somehow fitting for Howe, whose quiet excellence tended to be overlooked throughout his career.

title: Word of the Day | husbandry
description: husbandry \hz-bn-dre\ noun

title: NYT Front Page for 11/14/2011
description: NYT Front Page for 11/14/2011

title: Jets Reminded Whos in Charge
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  It was all there for the Jets, everything they wanted, everything they craved. The opportunity to unseat New England in the A.F.C. East, to hasten the Patriots decline, to shift the balance of power in a division long ruled by Tom Brady and his loyal foot soldiers, perhaps once and for all. Instead, the soaring Jets and the plummeting Patriots swapped roles.

title: H. Gobind Khorana, 89, Nobel-Winning Scientist, Dies
description: H. Gobind Khorana, who rose from a childhood of poverty in India to become a biochemist and share in a Nobel Prize for his role in deciphering the genetic code, died on Wednesday in Concord, Mass. He was 89.

title: Jets Replay: Week 10
description: A look at the New England Patriots 37-16 victory over the Jets at MetLife Stadium.

title: What Do You Want in the Future?
description: If you could build something for the future, what would it be?

title: Third-Rate Showing for Jets
description: A capsule look at the Jets 37-16 loss to the Patriots:

title: A Weekend of Arrests and Confrontations at Occupy Protests Around the U.S.
description: In their article about the movement of Occupy protest encampments from public parks to college campuses, my colleagues Malia Wollan and Elizabeth A. Harris report that there were confrontations between protesters and the police in several cities this weekend.

title: Good Wife Watch: Many Cases, Not Much Movement
description: The best moment of Death Row Trip, Sundays episode of The Good Wife (Season 3, No. 8): Carys response when Dana assures him that theres nothing going on between her and Kalinda. I am not a lesbian, Dana announces, to which Cary replies, I know a lot of people who werent anything until they met Kalinda.

title: Indias Godot: Economic Reforms 2.0
description: The World Economic Forums India Economic Summit in Mumbai has hosted several prominent figures from the business and political worlds  Mukesh Ambani, chairman of Reliance Industries, and Anand Sharma, the commerce minister, have been among them  but one guest seems to have disappointed many by not showing up: Economic Reforms 2.0.

title: Corrections: November 14
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: News Quiz | Nov. 14, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Russian Rocket Gives NASA a Lift to Space Station
description: MOSCOW  A Russian Soyuz rocket blasted off through heavy snowfall in Kazakhstan on Monday morning, beginning a two-day trip to ferry three astronauts to the International Space Station. The flight opens a new era of American dependence on Russia, and eventually on commercial enterprises, for manned space travel, after the end of NASAs space shuttle program in July.

title: Spokesman for Taliban Denies Report of His Arrest
description: KHOST, Afghanistan  A Taliban spokesman whose provocative and taunting media reports have often infuriated Afghan and Western officials firmly denied that he had been captured Monday.

title: Nov. 14, 1889 | Nellie Bly Begins Trip Around the World
description: On Nov. 14, 1889, two female journalists, Nellie Bly of The New York World and Elizabeth Bisland of Cosmopolitan magazine, left New York to begin a trip around the world. The 25-year-old Bly had conceived of the idea after reading Jules Vernes book Around the World in 80 Days, and Cosmopolitan decided to raise the stakes by sending Bisland to challenge her.

title: One Destination in Common: The Bronx
description: The Bronx is no stranger to the Dutch. After all, they employed the Swedish seafarer Jonas Bronck, who in 1639  along with his Dutch wife  settled the area that would adopt his name. Despite that long history, some of Chantal Heijnens friends in Amsterdam thought it was odd she chose to live there when they moved to New York in 2008.

title: Test Yourself | Math, Nov. 14, 2011
description: Test your math skills with this question created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the article The China Conundrum.

title: Far From Washington, Obama Defends His Policies
description: KAPOLEI, Hawaii  President Obama will be far from Washington this week meeting with Pacific Rim allies, but on Sunday he weighed in on simmering domestic issues, warning Congressional Republicans that voters will turn them out if they do not pass some of his job-creation proposals.

title: The Black Market Peso Exchanges NRI Connection
description: Vikram Datta, who moved from India to the United States in 1983, was known by his neighbors as a polite family man. United States prosecutors say he is also a major player in the decades-old system of laundering drug money and reinvesting it back into the economy, writes Julian Aguilar, with The Texas Tribune, a non-profit news organization partnered with The New York Times.

title: The Euro in Crisis
description: WHAT is the sovereign debt crisis in Europe?WHAT event related to the crisis took place in Italy on Saturday?WHAT changes are likely in store for Greece?

title: Four Questions Before U.S.-Slovenia
description: While there is no shame in losing by one goal to a powerful France team in front of a partisan crowd at the Stade de France, the manner in which the United States national team lost just such a game on Friday does cause some concern.

title: The Early Word: Political Trends
description: Todays Times

title: Dining Club in Mumbai Brings Foodies Together
description: Dining in Mumbai can be overwhelming for new visitors. So what better way to familiarize yourself with the local cuisine than to meet up with other food lovers over dinner? Thats the mission behind Pet Pujaris  literally, devotees of the stomach. As the groups key descriptor on its Facebook page says: foodie meet ups and foodie bonding.

title: What Percentage Lives in Poverty?
description: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

title: Metro Pucks: Rangers and Devils Winning, While Its Getting Late Early for Islanders
description: Our weekly review of the New York metropolitan regions hockey clubs.

title: Week 10 Quick Hits: Giving 49ers and Alex Smith Their Due
description: A quick tour of the games in Week 10, including some terrible tackling, an Eagles team that cant close and Tim Tebows (count em) two pass completions in a victory:

title: Do You Shop at Locally Owned Businesses?
description: So-called big box stores and online retailers have been changing the shopping landscape for years. Where does this leave locally owned businesses? Does your community have Mom and Pop shops or a downtown shopping district where you can buy everyday items like greeting cards? If so, do you shop there? What, in general, guides your decisions about where you spend your money?

title: Wyoming Congresswoman to Endorse Romney
description: The presidential campaign of former Gov. Mitt Romney of Massachusetts is scheduled to announce the endorsement of Representative Cynthia M. Lummis of Wyoming on Monday morning, adding a Tea Party voice to its chorus of Congressional endorsements.

title: On Fourth-and-Inches, Why Not Use a Quarterback Sneak?
description: Theres a healthy debate to be had about whether Falcons Coach Mike Smith made the right decision to go for it on fourth-and-inches from his own 29 in overtime against the Saints on Sunday. The results said No, and afterward Smith took full responsibility for the loss.

title: Pattern of Illegality Is Cited at News of the World
description: LONDON As a government-commissioned inquiry into Britains journalistic practices opened on Monday, its chief lawyer delivered a series of bombshell revelations about what he called a thriving cottage industry of illegality at the defunct News of the World tabloid.

title: For McConnell, a Case for Divided Government
description: Mitch McConnell, the Senate Republican leader and a cagey political thinker, got a lot of attention last year when he said his No. 1 political goal was to topple President Obama. He also frequently notes that the best opportunity for making major legislative achievements is when control of the government is divided between the parties.

title: This Week in Small Business: Focus!
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.

title: Complaint Box | Patter by Proxy
description: I live 30 floors in the air in Battery Park City, which means I make many vertical trips in the close confines of an elevator with small children and dogs. The mores here are that all communication is to be conducted through them.

title: Why Mike Smiths Fourth-Down Call Against Saints Was Correct
description: An analysis of a fourth-down call by Falcons Coach Mike Smith against the Saints has become almost an annual occurrence on the Fifth Down.In December 2010, the Falcons punted, and the Saints won. Smith was criticized on The Fifth Down. In December 2008, the Falcons punted, and the Saints won. Smith was criticized on the Fifth Down.

title: In a California Vineyard, Bluebirds Earn Their Keep
description: In an innovative study, nest boxes installed at a California vineyard attracted hundreds of birds that picked the farmers crops clean of pests in exchange for the free housing. The experiment is heartening news for conservationists amid reports of shrinking habitats and population declines for so many species.

title: Breakfast Meeting, Nov. 14
description: Steven Levy of Wired magazine profiles Jeff Bezos as Amazon ships its first Kindle Fire tablets today. The piece sets up Amazon vs. Apple. Apple is fundamentally a hardware company  91 percent of its revenue comes from sales of its coveted machines, compared to just 6 percent from iTunes, he writes. Amazon, on the other hand, is a content-focused company  almost half of its revenue comes from sales of media like books, music, TV shows, and movies  and the fire-sale-priced Fire is designed to be primarily a passport to the large amount of that content thats available digitally. [Wired]

title: Study Finds Co-Payments Discourage Drug Treatments
description: A new study published on Monday shows patients are more likely to take their medicine when they do not have to help pay for the prescriptions. The study, which appears online in the New England Journal of Medicine, focused on patients with health insurance who had heart attacks.

title: Berkshire Amasses 5.5% Stake in I.B.M.
description: Warren E. Buffett, the chairman and chief executive of Berkshire Hathaway, revealed on CNBC that his conglomerate had amassed 64 million shares of I.B.M, a stake of about 5.5 percent.

title: Opinion Report: Civil Rights in Alabama
description: From the editorial page

title: King of Jordan Becomes First Arab Leader to Tell Syrias Assad to Quit
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  King Abdullah of Jordan added his voice on Monday to the growing pressure on the president of Syria to relinquish power, becoming the first Arab leader on Syrias doorstep to call for a change in government to end the increasingly bloody political uprising there.

title: Rex Ryan Transcript: An Apology to Jets Fans
description: Jets Coach Rex Ryan, who will play a Patriots fan in a coming Adam Sandler movie, sounded like a fan of the Patriots when he said early Monday morning: They beat us twice. We think were as good as they are, but clearly, were not.

title: Bank of America to Sell Most of Its Stake in Chinese Lender
description: Bank of America announced on Monday that it would sell most of its remaining holdings in China Construction Bank to a group of unidentified investors, in a bid to bolster its capital buffer.

title: CNBCs Interview With Buffett
description: Warren E. Buffett, chairman and chief executive of Berkshire Hathaway, sat for a lengthy interview on CNBC on Monday.

title: Immigrant Aid, Special Ed on Regents Agenda
Sheldon Benardo: The Accidental Principal
A Homeless Child Struggles for Stability
Wading in Thailands Murky Waters
description: BANGKOK  In the industrial estate of Lat Krabang, a few kilometers from Bangkoks international airport, Honda workers clad in ghost white are standing around the shuttered factory, like the idle employees of a suspended space program. The floodwaters are approaching from the north and the east, raising canal levels and bubbling up through drainage systems. One of the men says that the defenses  sandbags and plastic sheets  can withstand one meter of water, but no more.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: Berkshire Amasses Big Stake in I.B.M. | Warren E. Buffett, the chairman and chief executive of Berkshire Hathaway, revealed on CNBC that his conglomerate had amassed 64 million shares of IBM, a stake of about 5.5 percent.

title: Reporters Suit Up, Visit Fukushima Nuclear Plant
description: The Japanese government has begun allowing reporters to visit the area in and around the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power station, including The Timess own Martin Fackler. It wasnt pretty, but it was hard to look away at the combination of a man-made and natural disaster, one with catastrophic consequences:

title: From Excelsior to Where Is Mine?
description: For a couple of centuries, New York States official motto has been Excelsior, which presumably has nothing to do with an inordinate early American fondness for wood shavings. It is usually translated from the Latin as Ever Upward. A lovely sentiment. Would that it were always true.

title: Superfraud
description: Its a bird! Its a plane! Its a turkey!

title: Vain Glorious | Soap & Glory
description: What: Soap & Glory

title: Fall of Berlusconi Has Domino Effect at Venice Biennale
description: The newly appointed president of the Venice Biennale has withdrawn, mainly because to the demise of his chief supporter, Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, the Italian minister of culture, Giancarlo Galan, has announced.

title: Austerity Then And Now
description: Alan Cowell has an interesting piece contrasting public attitudes toward austerity now with attitudes toward the austerity that was the norm in postwar Britain  and beautifully described by the late Tony Judt. As he notes, one major difference is that back then the sacrifice was shared.

title: Monday Reading: Time to Book Trips Involving Sun and Sand
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: The 1% Across Space And Time
description: How is it possible that I didnt know about the World Top Incomes Database until I stumbled across it this morning? Arent the people at INET supposed to let people like me know about these things?

title: Readers Street Style: Winter Whites
description: The best of readers street fashion for the week of Nov. 7.

title: Bookshelf
description: Before she was made empress, how Catherine the Great suffered! In his gripping new biography, Catherine the Great (Random House, $35), Robert K. Massie reveals a young woman lorded over by a tempestuous monarch, a meddling mother and a man-child husband who raised hunting dogs in her sleeping chambers. (She couldnt even get a tooth pulled without insult; the palace surgeon tore out a piece of her jaw in the process.)

title: Police Officer Accused of Infiltrating Occupy Oakland Says He Supports the Movement
description: Updated | 12:41 p.m. As my colleague Malia Wollan reports, Hundreds of police officers in riot gear circled the Occupy Oakland encampment downtown on Monday morning, making arrests and flattening tents.

title: A Personal View of the Bronx
description: Some of Chantal Heijnens friends in Amsterdam thought it was odd when she moved to New York with her husband in 2008 and took up residence in one room of a five-room flat in the Bronx.

title: Flying on Chicken Fat
description: Gasoline for cars is commonly blended with corn ethanol. In the last few weeks, airlines have started using blends, too, but their feedstocks are more varied, including chicken fat, algal oil, used fryer grease and parts of inedible plants.

title: Justices to Hear Health Care Case as Race Heats Up
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday agreed to hear a challenge to the 2010 health care overhaul law, President Obamas signature legislative achievement, setting the stage for oral arguments by March and a decision in late June as the 2012 presidential campaign enters its crucial final months.

title: Unicredit Looks to Raise $10.3 Billion
description: Confronted by a quarterly loss and new capital requirements, UniCredit, the largest Italian bank, said on Monday that it would raise $10.3 billion and eliminate 5,200 jobs in Italy in the next few years.

title: What Were Reading
description: The Guardian: Jay Rayner takes on slow eaters. They never notice the rest of their party of six stabbing themselves in the back of the hand with forks, or fixing nooses to the light fittings as an exit strategy, while they poke laboriously at whatever they have ordered.  Nick FoxInside Scoop SF: To those who say no wine is worth more than $3 or so a bottle, Jon Bonn says, Pshaw (or words to that effect).  Eric Asimov

title: Research Offers Hope for More Efficient Oil Sand Industry
description: Several years ago, Paul Painter, a professor of polymer science at Pennsylvania State University, saw a news report about the deaths of hundreds of ducks that landed on a tailings pond near an oil sands mine in the Canadian province of Alberta. The ducks had become coated with residual petroleum floating on the pond, which was filled with wastewater from the process used to extract oil from the strip-mined sands.

title: Split Personalities and Political Spouses
description: Herman Cains wife, Gloria, has been pretty quiet so far, but in an interview conducted Sunday on Fox News (itll be broadcast Monday evening), she defended her husband against the sexual harassment accusations that surfaced about two weeks ago. She told Greta Van Susteren that her husband totally respects women. She also noted: Im thinking he would have to have a split personality to do the things that were said.

title: Investigation Into Saturn Aura Transmission Flaws Is Broadened
description: 12:03 p.m. | Updated

title: More Depression for Mothers and Singles With Breast Cancer
description: Women who have children living at home and single women have higher levels of depression in the months after treatment than other breast cancer patients, new research shows.

title: Afghan Oil Fields Arent a Curse  Yet
description: SAR-E POL, Afghanistan  The Afghan government has a knack for botching everything: if Afghan officials were cooks, as the saying goes, they could ruin rice. The Chinese, by contrast, have an impressive record over the last couple of decades, and their achievement in the sphere of rice-cooking goes without mentioning.

title: Monday Matchup: Vikings at Packers
description: Vikings (2-6) at Packers (8-0), 8:30 p.m. Eastern, ESPNLine: Packers by 13

title: Chinese Students Flock to U.S., as Americans Seek Out Less Traditional Countries
description: A record 723,277 international students were enrolled at United States colleges and universities last year, according to Open Doors, the Institute of International Educations annual report, released on Monday.

title: Numberplay: The Missing Slice
description: Thirty-two slices? You hesitate slightly. We can do that. One Deluxe cut into 32 slices.

title: Cromer to Direct Tribes at Barrow Street Theater
description: 3:38 p.m. | Updated Nina Raines new comedy, Tribes, will have its North American premiere at the Barrow Street Theater starting in February, the producers announced on Monday. The production will be directed by David Cromer, who in 2009 collaborated on Our Town at Barrow Street with the producers of Tribes, Scott Morfee, Jean Doumanian and Tom Wirtshafter.

title: Chimpanzee Stories
description: Photos and biographies of a few of the chimps, some with long histories, others with uncertain futures, at Chimp Haven and The New Iberia Research Center, both in Louisiana.

title: Lending a Hand to Banks, but Not to Nations
description: FRANKFURT  Is it time for the European Central Bank to be as generous to countries as it is to banks?

title: Chimps Days in Labs May Be Dwindling
description: NEW IBERIA, La.  In a dome-shaped outdoor cage, a dozen chimpanzees are hooting. The hair on their shoulders sticks straight up. Thats piloerection, a sign of emotional arousal, says Dr. Dana Hasselschwert, head of veterinary sciences at the New Iberia Research Center. She tells a visitor to keep his distance. The chimps tend to throw pebbles  or worse  when they get excited.

title: Edible Selby | Olive Garden
description: La Tte Dans les Olives, a sliver of a food shop and restaurant in the 10th Arrondissement, is the work of Cdric Casanova, a slack-rope walker who spent 15 years performing in traveling circuses, most recently Cirque du Soleil. Casanova developed a passion for Sicilys fruity olives during summers he spent there as a child  his father is Sicilian  and wanted to share them with his hometown, Paris. The tiny picerie offers oils and handpicked olives from his favorite growers, along with tapenades, sun-dried tomatoes and other seasonal delicacies. The way people react to good olive oil is like what I see in the circus, Casanova says. People smile. They love it. Go to interactive feature >>

title: Taking the Air Out of a Season
description: It was comforting to realize the frauds we had to deal with Sunday were merely of the professional football variety. It required no soul-searching to watch the Jets being exposed as 90 percent hot air, the Lions unmasked as unthreatening bullies, or the Chiefs as ... gee, Im not even sure what analogy fits there but for some reason they evoke the image of squashed Bubble Wrap. Sure, you could comb the injury bin and start to feel queasy about the real toll the N.F.L. takes, but for a day, gosh, it sure beat contemplating college footballs full-scale ethical seizure.

title: Police Clear Occupy Oakland Encampment, but Protesters Return
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  Protesters returned to a downtown plaza Monday evening, after hundreds of police officers raided the Occupy Oakland encampment there early Monday, arresting 33 people and flattening tents.

title: The New York Times Comedy Challenge: Standings Update
description: With so many shows scheduled over the last five days in conjunction with the annual New York Comedy Festival, we decided to pose a challenge to select comics: Tell us your best clean joke. (The networks may have relaxed their standards but we at The New York Times are standing firm.) A mix of established performers and up-and-comers took us on: Jim Gaffigan, Michael Che, Rachel Feinstein, Leah Bonnema, Angelo Lozada and John ODonnell. We posted their entries here and asked you to vote. Whose bit killed? Voting closes at the end of the day, so you still have a chance to weigh in.

title: New Policy on Substitutes Leads to More in Permanent Slots
Long Road Ahead for Most American States
description: Michigan, Nevada and Rhode Island will probably have to wait another six years before they are back to the number of jobs they had before the recession struck, according to economists at IHS Global Insight.

title: DealBook: Berkshire Amasses 5.5% Stake in I.B.M.
description: Warren E. Buffett, the chairman and chief executive of Berkshire Hathaway, revealed on CNBC that his conglomerate had amassed 64 million shares of I.B.M, a stake of about 5.5 percent. Read the entire post on DealBook.

title: App City: Where to Eat?
description: NYT Techs own Joshua Brustein moonlights as a columnist in Sundays Metropolitan section. Check out his latest on dining apps for New Yorkers here.

title: Daily Report: Googles Secret Projects
description: A story that is sure to be at the center of the tech conversation today is Googles Lab of Wildest Dreams, a look by Claire Cain Miller and Nick Bilton of The New York Times at Google X, the top-secret lab where Google is working on a list of 100 shoot-for-the-stars ideas  from robots to space elevators (in theory, rocketless travel to outer space along a cable attached to Earth) to ways to connect the Internet to ordinary household items like coffee cups and refrigerators.

title: Will Cloud Computing Make Everything (and Everyone) Work Harder?
description: What do the following have in common: Computers, limousines, empty beds and stay-at-home moms?

title: Moodys Buys Majority Stake in Indian Research Firm
description: NEW DELHI  Moodys said on Monday that it had bought a majority stake in Copal Partners, a company that provides research and analysis for banks, hedge funds and private equity firms using analysts in India and other emerging markets.

title: Can Virtual Schools Really Replace Classrooms?
description: If the home-schooling anarchist parents in the Sunday Magazine played to a fantasy of what home schooling could be  the traveling, the rebellion against the authority of the classroom, the rugged individualist children  then The Wall Street Journals counterpoint, My Teacher Is an App, is the disillusioning reality for many.

title: Reaching a Comfort Level With Geoengineering
description: Until recently, the idea of coping with climate change by means of geoengineering was something it seemed no one wanted to talk about. Even people who saw potential merit in deliberately altering conditions on Earth or in the atmosphere to mitigate climate change feared that if people thought there was an engineering fix, it would encourage them to abandon efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions

title: Karzai Call for Meeting of Elders Questioned
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Despite criticism from neighboring countries, threats from the Taliban and calls for a boycott from some political opponents, President Hamid Karzai has called a loya jirga, the traditional grand council of Afghan elders and leaders, in an attempt to gain popular support for a long-term partnership with the United States, Afghan officials and analysts say.

title: I Like the New Coldplay. Sue Me.
description: I mentioned to the magazines editor that the new Coldplay record was pretty good. He told me to leave his office. Actually, first he said, Oh, Im gonna tweet this. Then he kicked me out.

title: How Closing a Credit Card Affects Your Credit Score
description: Do you have a chunk of credit-card debt that you keep bouncing from card to card to take advantage of an attractive balance transfer offer? Or have you opened new credit card accounts just so that you can collect extra miles or some other enticing bonus?

title: Klinsmann Has Time on His Side
description: It probably shouldnt be a surprise that some fans of the United States national team expect Jurgen Klinsmann to be further along in his makeover of the squad. Klinsmann and U.S. Soccer danced around each other for so long before he finally got the job that it almost seems as if he has had it for three years, not three months.

title: The Meatball Shop Goes Vegetarian
description: The Meatball Shop in Manhattan is famous for its meatballs, of course. On a given day you might find a Reuben Ball or a Chicken Cordon Bleu Ball or just a classic beef meatball with tomato sauce.

title: The S.B.A. Says Its Culture Has Changed
description: In a recent post about the incidence of fraud in federal contracting programs for small businesses, the Small Business Administration came in for some criticism from the agencys inspector general, Peggy E. Gustafson. Ms. Gustafson, whose office is independent from the rest of the agency, testified before Congress recently that the agency needed to change its culture and become more aggressive in punishing contractors who misrepresent themselves as small companies in order to win government work.

title: Ex-Coach Denies Charges Amid New Accusations
description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa.  Close to 10 additional suspected victims have come forward to the authorities since the arrest of the former Penn State defensive coordinator Jerry Sandusky on Nov. 5 on 40 counts of sexually abusing young boys, according to people close to the investigation. The police are working to confirm the new allegations.

title: Q. & A. With a Newspaperman Who Thinks Print Is Overrated
description: On Monday, we ran a story about John Paton, a long-time newspaper executive who thinks the problems with print media may be solved by printing less. The conventions of a news story require that a long conversation get boiled down to a few pithy quotes. Because of the size of Mr. Patons gamble  he is now running both the Journal Register and MediaNews newspaper chains  we thought it might be worthwhile to run a longer version of the interview. The following conversation has been edited for clarity.

title: Site to Be Seen | Patrik Ervell
description: For the brand loyalist theres an abundance of designer-specific e-commerce sites. Leave it to the minimalist Patrik Ervell to be ahead of the curve with an online destination thats one of the cleanest and easiest to shop. Organized into only a few basic categories, Ervells perennial favorites (like this padded shirt, $370, and leather backpack, $670) are brilliantly presented on models in motion, so that shoppers can get all angles and details of the clothing theyre considering. Should they be looking to branch out beyond the staples, there are runway offerings like this pleather flight suit, $1,200, too, that make the web site  like the collection  anything but monotonous.

title: Really? The Claim: Exercise Can Ward Off Migraines
description: THE FACTS

title: Bachmann Goes Negative on Rivals Online
description: Representative Michele Bachmann of Minnesota hasnt spent much lately on traditional advertising, but she is waging a campaign to secure as much free media attention as she can.

title: The Caucus Click: Cain Family Photo
description: From left, Karol Cain, Mr. Cains daughter in law; Vincent, his son; Celena Jackson, his granddaughter; Melanie Cain-Jackson, his daughter; Mr. Cain; Gloria Cain; Preston Jackson, his grandson; and Greta Van Susteren.

title: Combat Injuries Can Change Lives in Surprising Ways
description: As I walked through the sliding doors at my local Veterans Affairs clinic last week, I couldnt help but cringe at the morose scene in front of me. Sitting in the small, overcrowded waiting area were the former fighters of our nations wars, both past and present. Veterans from every conflict since Korea seemed to be represented. The Vietnam vets, with their worn out olive-drab field jackets, outnumbered the rest, but a few Korean, Desert Storm, Iraq and Afghanistan veterans were scattered throughout.

title: Friend-of-Court Filings Mushroom, and a Law Professor Takes Issue
description: WASHINGTON  Not long ago, a law professor at Harvard received a routine request. Would he add his name to a brief from a group of law professors urging a federal court to uphold the health care overhaul law?

title: Buy This House, and Wave Hello to the Governor
description: The listing is not particularly remarkable: a World War II-era, Cape-style house just outside Mount Kisco, N.Y., with a cherry wood and granite kitchen and four bathrooms selling for $699,000, a modest price by the standards of leafy Westchester County villages. But what the listing does not reveal is that buying the house will make one a neighbor of New Yorks governor.

title: Video Sports of The Times: Will Mark Sanchez Ever Grow Up?
description: The Jets latest loss to the New England Patriots raises the question of whether quarterback Mark Sanchez will ever be able to lead the team to elite status.

title: Monday Motorsports: Edwards and Stewart Enter Sprint Cup Finale In Virtual Dead Heat
description: The chatter preceding the Kobalt Tools 500 centered on Carl Edwards, the points leader in the Nascar Chase for the Sprint Cup, and Tony Stewart, who trailed him by three points. Though neither driver logged a victory on Sunday at Phoenix International Raceway, the post-race focus remained fixated on the two drivers and the three points that still separated them.

title: Bolshoi Is Stung by Loss of Two Stars
description: Natalia Osipova and Ivan Vasiliev, major stars of the ballet world and two of Russias best-known classical artists, said on Monday that they were leaving the storied Bolshoi Ballet in Moscow for the Mikhailovsky Theater in St. Petersburg.

title: Rahul Gandhi, Angry Young Man?
description: Rahul Gandhi, the heir-apparent of Indias ruling Congress party, seems to be trying to transform his image from a mild-mannered, reluctant politician to an angry firebrand.

title: Is Mark Sanchez Good Enough?
description: William C. Rhoden on the Jets loss to the Patriots.

title: Can Extreme Climate Confusion be Avoided?
description: This post is a tale of two climate conferences, and a forecast for a substantial risk of climate confusion later this week.

title: A Famous Neighbor: Is Having One a Good Thing?
description: Even the most hardcore celebrity hound might not be excited to find the paparazzi on the lawn next door. But wouldnt the presence of a famous neighbor bump property values, providing measurable cachet to ones block or building?

title: The Euro Zone Crisis and the U.S.: A Primer
description: The potential effect of the euro zone crisis on the United States has been the subject of several recent articles, including Annie Lowreys on Saturday. Heres a primer summarizing the three main channels through which the fiasco across the Atlantic could hurt the American economy: trade, stock markets and (most worrisome) a contagious credit crisis.

title: Performa Takes on Bergman
description: Ive never been so happy to see death as I was Friday night at the Museum of the Moving Image. Alas, my happiness was short lived.

title: Moodys Invests in Indian Research
description: Moodys said on Monday that it had bought a majority stake in Copal Partners, a company that provides research and analysis for banks, hedge funds and private equity firms using analysts in India and other emerging markets.

title: Googles Mobile Stars Fall on Alabama
description: The song Blues in the Night includes a lyric that begins, From Natchez to Mobile, from Memphis to St. Joe. Now, marketers will be watching the results of a campaign that extends from Mountain View to Mobile.

title: Look of the Moment | Tilda Swinton
description: The Look: Icy. A crisply tailored satin and silk tuxedo in slightly off shades of shimmery ivory and winter white looks terrifically slick and smart.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Q: (Reader)

title: Quarterback Shuffle Is Keeping the Redskins Running in Place
description: For the Washington Redskins, there was some good news Sunday despite their fifth consecutive loss. When Philadelphia lost to the Arizona Cardinals at home, it ensured that the biggest debacle in the N.F.L. this season would be the Eagles, whose fans called for Andy Reids job on the way out of the stadium.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
description: Leo Burnett Canada, Toronto, was named the winner of the first Agency of the Year honor presented by the Advertising and Design Club of Canada at its 62nd annual awards show. Leo Burnett Canada is part of the Leo Burnett Worldwide unit of the Publicis Groupe.

title: Publisher and Two Top Editors Are Out at Newsweek/Daily Beast
description: 3:15 p.m. | Updated The publisher and two high-ranking editors at Newsweek and The Daily Beast are leaving their jobs, a string of departures that signal distress inside the company as it struggles to turn its fortunes around.

title: Part 1: Answers to Your Questions on Scholarships and Student Loans
description: To help readers of The Choice navigate the maze of scholarships available to them  as well as to further their understanding of President Obamas recent proposal to ease the repayment of some student loans  Mark Kantrowitz, a financial aid expert and founder of the Web sites finaid.org and fastweb.com, is spending this week in our virtual Guidance Office. Mr. Kantrowitz is the author of Secrets to Winning a Scholarship, published in February.

title: Screening: Doctors Paid for Heart Tests Order More
description: Doctors who earn money for cardiac stress testing are much more likely to prescribe the tests than those who dont, a new study has found.

title: No Time to Sulk for the Jets
description: If the season ended today  and, boy, are the Jets glad it doesnt  they would rate as the seventh-best team in the A.F.C. The problem for them is, only the top six reach the playoffs. Their hopes of winning the division were all but squashed Sunday night by a 37-16 loss to New England, a defeat that forced the Jets to recalibrate their expectations. Once again a wild-card berth  and the road games that come with it  appears their best chance at making the postseason.

title: A Watch-and-Wait Prostate Treatment
description: With controversy raging over whether men should be screened for prostate cancer with the PSA blood test, the experience of one man in his 80s suggests an alternative to a simple yes-or-no response, as well as options for prevention and treatment that men of all ages might consider.

title: Death of a Heavyweight
description: Friends, family and fellow boxers paid their respects to the boxer Joe Frazier at a funeral on Monday after he died last week from liver cancer at age 67.

title: Black Sabbath, the Iron Men of Rock, to Reunite
description: The four original members of Black Sabbath have announced they will reunite next year to release their first album of new songs in three decades and to embark on a world tour.

title: Farmers Find Rewards in Helping Bog Turtles
description: The future of the bog turtle, North Americas tiniest reptile and one of its rarest, is in the hands of private landowners who are being given incentives to help it recover, wildlife biologists say.

title: Deutsche Banks Ackermann Wont Take Chairman Role
description: FRANKFURT  Josef Ackermann unexpectedly canceled plans to become chairman of Deutsche Bank when he retires as chief executive in May, possibly heralding his departure from the public stage after a decade as one of the most powerful and controversial figures in European banking.

title: Hazards: Solvent Linked to Higher Parkinsons Risk
description: A new study of twins has found that trichloroethylene, or TCE, a solvent widely used in refrigerants and as a metal degreaser, is associated with an increased risk of Parkinsons disease.

title: TimesCast | November 14, 2011
description: The Supreme Court agrees to hear a health care overhaul law challenge; police raid the Occupy Oakland protest; and one police officer accused of infiltrating that protest says he supports it.

title: Should Hall of Famers Have to Shine Internationally Too?
description: Four new members will be enshrined in the Hockey Hall of Fame in Toronto tonight, and the consensus is that a better quartet has not been so honored in many years. Ed Belfour, Doug Gilmour, Mark Howe and Joe Nieuwendyk are all names familiar to any hockey fan and each had a lengthy and successful career in the N.H.L.

title: Jets Down, and at Their Most Dangerous
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

title: Fred Neuhouser
description: The philosopher Fred Neuhouser on inequality and secular theodicy.

title: Hilary Mantel to Write Wolf Hall Sequel
description: Hilary Mantel, winner of the 2009 Man Booker Prize for Wolf Hall, a historical novel about Henry VIIIs adviser Thomas Cromwell, will follow it with a sequel, Bring Up the Bodies, her publisher said on Monday. The book is scheduled for release in fall 2012 by John Macrae Books, an imprint of Henry Holt and Company.

title: An Interview with Fred Neuhouser
description: This video is part of a weekly series of interviews with contemporary thinkers and philosophers on questions that matter.

title: Near Zuccotti Park, Protesting the Protest
description: Businesses and neighbors of the protesters in Zuccotti Park plan to attend a counter-rally on Monday objecting to the demonstrators continued presence. Local restaurant administrators said they believed the protest would begin at 5 p.m. on the steps of City Hall.

title: Cardinals Find Their Manager; Cubs and Red Sox Continue Searching
description: The interviews are chugging along as the big managerial openings with the Cardinals, Cubs and Red Sox entail differing obstacle courses.

title: Exploring China, Taste Buds First
description: Alice Waters and Amy Tan dine in Beijing.

title: Teenagers Having Sex Are a Minority
description: About 43 percent of unmarried teenage girls and 42 percent of unmarried teenage boys have had sexual intercourse at least once, according to new research from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. In 2002, the last year such a report was published,45.5 percent of girls and 45.7 percent of boys had had sex by 19.

title: Exploring China, Taste Buds First
description: BEIJING  The historic restaurants in Beijing are often best avoided. Residents here leave it to tourists to go to Quanjude for roast duck. Likewise, Dong Lai Shun, a famous mutton hotpot restaurant near the Forbidden City, has seen better days.

title: Prognosis: No Competition Yet Between HPV Types
description: The two vaccines against human papillomavirus together target the four types of HPV that cause a large majority of cervical and anal cancers. But there are more than a dozen other cancer-causing HPV types, and scientists have been concerned that as more people are vaccinated, these types could begin to flourish.

title: Google Reveals Tweaks to Its Search Algorithm
description: Google on Monday revealed 10 recent changes to its search algorithm that affect results as diverse as those that are date-specific and those that are in Hindi.

title: In TV Special, Gabrielle Giffords Reveals Her Struggle to Recover
description: video platformvideo managementvideo solutionsvideo player

title: The Best of Scuttlebot
description: Heres what the reporters and editors of The New York Times tech staff found on the Web. The full Scuttlebot feed is on this page in the right-hand column.

title: Cornmeal for Thanksgiving and Year-Round
description: My Recipes for Health this week arent Thanksgiving recipes per se (enough already!), but theyd be welcome at a Thanksgiving table. I include cornmeal in my grouping of Thanksgiving foods, as corn is one of the Native American foods that sustained the Pilgrims during their first difficult years in the colonies.

title: N.B.A. Season in Peril as Players Reject Offer
description: The union representing National Basketball Association players formally disbanded Monday and declared it would take its labor standoff with the leagues owners into federal court, a development that pushed the league as close as it has ever been to losing an entire season of play.

title: Consumer Reports Poll Shows Support for Stronger Fuel-Economy Standards
description: A poll conducted by Consumer Reports in late October showed that an overwhelming majority of American consumers would support higher fuel-economy standards and would be willing to pay a premium for high-efficiency vehicles.

title: Case Study | Quinine Syrup
description: As befits the pointy-headed elevation of all simple things, gourmet attention is now being paid to the humble gin and tonic. Specifically, to the tonic. Why would one bother? Whats broke? Well, since the 1970s, the default Schweppes and Canada Dry tonics in the United States have been made with high-fructose corn syrup, which renders them blowsy and a bit toothless. If you are the type of imbiber who seeks out a specific gin (or vodka) on which to base your drink, doesnt the larger proportion of that drink  which in this case comprises at least twice the volume of the spirit  deserve equal scrutiny and care?

title: Thanksgiving Countdown | Gravy Alternatives
description: As Mark Bittman has pointed out, gravy is but one of many sauces that can bring flavor and moisture to a plate of turkey and stuffing, like parsley pure, eggless barnaise or bourbon barbecue sauce. Theres homemade cranberry ketchup, or cherry ketchup, tangy and sweet. Or you could top your turkey with a different kind of staple sauce altogether: simple, classic pesto.

title: Gathering at the Wake for Western Dominance
description: In his 2003 book,  Empire, which was published here in the immediate wake of the United States-led invasion of Iraq, the popular British historian Niall Ferguson argued that the United States was an empire in denial and was capable of playing an imperial role in the world today, much the way Britain once did, in the 19th century.

title: Keeping Greens Green
description: Q. When greengrocers drench vegetables with water every few minutes, does it keep them fresh or hasten spoilage?

title: Its Spelled T-O-R-T-U-R-E
description: There are moments when a politicians character bursts through the spin, sound bites and ideological chanting. Voters have to watch for them, because they can be fleeting.

title: Drawing Dance: Cunningham in Minneapolis
description: The Brooklyn artist Kenneth E. Parris III is on tour with members of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, documenting, through a series of drawings and paintings, their two-year Legacy Tour. After 58 years the company is scheduled to disband on New Years Day 2012. This is the 19th in a series of graphite drawings Mr. Parris plans to create from the road, providing a front-row seat to the final weeks of the companys journey. This weeks entry is from Minneapolis, Minn.

title: A Busy Love Life, Built With a Mothers Help
description: The muriqui monkeys of the Atlantic Forest in Brazil, a highly endangered species numbering only about 1,000, live in an egalitarian society.

title: On a Mountaintop, Dreaming of the Next Step
description: As some of you may know, were a family of five who embarked in July on a year of living in the Maine woods, relocating from our house in the New Jersey suburbs. We spent the first few months off the grid on a lake in the north woods, and weve been in what we call the winter house for about five weeks now. (As an aside, we are renters, not owners, in Maine.)

title: MF Global and the Problems With Murky Accounting
description: The collapse of MF Global shows how easy it is to obscure risky investments and the pitfalls that can occur when those problems surface. By minimizing its exposure to European sovereign debt, the firm lost credibility in the market and eventually got hammered as fears over possible bond defaults rose.

title: JPMorgan Names 2 Executives to New Posts
description: After moving several members of his senior leadership team this summer, Jamie Dimon, JPMorgan Chases chairman and chief executive, has started to reshuffle the ranks a layer or so down.

title: Disney Acquires Parent Blogging Network
description: In a bid to expand its digital footprint, the Walt Disney Company announced on Monday that it had purchased Babble Media, an online site for parents that features hundreds of bloggers.

title: Cain Accusers Ex-Boyfriend Supports Harassment Claims
description: Nov. 15, 9:10 a.m. | Updated  Victor Zuckerman, a pediatrician, said on Monday that he was dating Sharon Bialek in the 1990s when she told him that Herman Cain had touched her inappropriately.

title: Last-Drink Playlist: Extended Play Edition
description: As I put together my Perfect Last-Drink Playlist for my column about nightcaps, I was surprised to discover how fewamong the gazillions of songs about drinkingtake on the nightcap directly. So I loosened the parameters a bit, to include songs about the moments when one might drink a nightcap (The Wee Small Hours of the Morning), and what one might drink (Cognac Blues). Of course, by the time Id given my editor the playlist, I thought of other numbers I wished Id included, especially Lotte Lenyas unrivaled Alabama Song.

title: PAC Sponsors Huntsman Ad Campaign in New Hampshire
description: Jon M. Huntsman Jr. has staked his ailing presidential bid on a strong showing in the New Hampshire Republican primary. Now hes going to have some help.

title: Krzyzewski: Paterno a Great Man in Horrific Situation
description: DURHAM, N.C.  In June, Penn State football coach Joe Paterno and Duke basketball coach Mike Krzyzewski sat down together to tape a show for ESPN about ethics, integrity and issues associated with college athletics called, Difference Makers: Life Lessons with Paterno and Krzyzewski.

title: Timescast | Occupy Oakland Raids
description: Hundreds of police officers raid the Occupy Oakland camp, and a police officer accused in a viral video of infiltrating Occupy Oakland speaks out in support of the movement.

title: What Can I Prepare Before the Actual Day of Thanksgiving?
description: Q.

title: Cloaks of Invisibility, Switched in a Flash
description: About half a mile below the surface of the Pacific Ocean, small squid and octopuses face a camouflage conundrum.

title: TimesCast | New Focus on Health Care Law
description: November 14, 2011  The Supreme Court agrees to hear a health care overhaul law challenge.

title: Ask About Restoring Gun Rights to Convicted Felons
description: In an article and a video report in Mondays New York Times, Michael Luo examined how easy it is in many states for people with felony convictions to get their gun rights reinstated.

title: Cain Appears Flustered When Asked About Libya
description: 4:28 p.m. | Updated Herman Cain appeared flustered when asked during an interview Monday about his views on the Obama administrations support of the Libyan uprising.

title: Two Sides to Every Store
description: CHRISSIE MILLER of Sophomore, a line of sportswear basics with a bit of an edge, and Lindsey Thornburg, known for her wool blanket cloaks, have gone into business together: their new boutique, named 143, will open Friday at 143 Ludlow Street, (212) 780-0900. We had crushes on each others lines, Ms. Thornburg said. On one side of the whitewashed and baby-blue shop are the Thornburg cloaks and bohemian layered-chiffon dresses, which run from $700 to $2,000; on the other side is Sophomore, designed with Madeleine von Froomer, with drawstring pants and floral dresses, $50 to $400.

title: Ordering Thanksgiving Pies From Artisanal Bakers
description: THE best pie is personal, made from a stained recipe card in your grandmothers ringlety handwriting, with flour on your nose and eyelashes.

title: Photo Replay: Nov.14
description: The day in sports included the Southeast Asian Games in Indonesia and a victory by Brazil over Egypt in an international soccer friendly.

title: Towers of Power
description: CINEMATIC villains love modern architecture: just think of all the Bond baddies holed up in their sleek hideaways, or maybe Jackie Treehorn, the pornographer-shylock of The Big Lebowski, who surveys the Los Angeles oceanfront from the luxury of a mod mansion by the architect John Lautner (who also designed the Elrod House in Palm Springs, Calif., featured in the Bond classic Diamonds Are Forever). The sharp lines and minimal interiors of modern architecture make a convenient shorthand for filmmakers who wish to telegraph a characters malevolent intent, and a counterpoint to the traditional values ostensibly conveyed by traditional architecture.

title: Calming Schools by Focusing on Well-Being of Troubled Students
description: Mark Ossenheimer, principal of the Urban Assembly School for Wildlife Conservation in the Bronx, threw out a name to add to the list of teenagers in trouble.

title: Want More Parents? Make Them Want to Come
Shirin Neshats Performa Contribution
description: Performa lore is inextricably bound up with the Iranian artist Shirin Neshat. In 1998, RoseLee Goldberg, the visual-art performance biennials founder, wondered what would happen if Ms. Neshat translated her work in video and photography into live art. One result, in 2001, was Logic of the Birds. Ms. Neshats first foray into performance, it led to the creation of Performa as a vehicle for pushing performance forward while educating people about its past.

title: Pictures of the Day: Oakland and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from California, Thailand, Pennsylvania and Iran.

title: Biochemistry: Scientists Decode the Protective Element Sickle Cell Anemia Offers Against Malaria
description: Scientists believe they have finally figured out how the mutation that causes sickle cell anemia also protects against fatal malaria.

title: Greek Greens Pie With Cornmeal Crust
description: This is a beautiful, rustic and comforting dish adapted from recipes from Epirus, a mountainous region of northwestern Greece. The cornmeal crust is like a thin layer of polenta both above and below the greens, which are fragrant with dill, mint and parsley. I use fine cornmeal, which is sometimes packaged as corn flour. Its important to let the pie sit for 30 minutes after baking so that the crust can set.

title: A Portable Glow to Help Melt Those Winter Blues
description: Jan Brehm lives in rainy Portland, Ore., and she has always dreaded this time of year, when the days get shorter, her mood plummets and all she wants to do is crawl into bed and eat cookie dough.

title: Pictures of the Day: Oakland and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from California, Thailand, Pennsylvania and Iran.

title: Behind the Veil
description: BLACK veils, usually reserved for religious ceremonies, goth brides and Daphne Guinness, are bringing some dramatic flair to street and cocktail dress. In Paris, at last months round of fashion shows, the French designer Faustine Rome looked like a latter-day Marlene Dietrich from Shanghai Express, in a veiled cloche, ruffled cape (in lieu of feathers) and studded bangles (todays pearls?).

title: Thank You, Supercommittee
description: Whenever people worry that the American electorate has become hopelessly divided, I like to point out that were remarkably united on at least one issue: Everyone dislikes Congress. The latest New York Times/CBS News poll found that only 9 percent of Americans approve of the way lawmakers are handling their jobs. And more than four out of five Republicans, Democrats, and Independents actively disapprove. (President Obamas 46 percent approval rating looks like massive support by comparison.)

title: The Art of Science
description: Selected images from Princeton Universitys Art of Science competition.

title: Polls Apart
description: An interesting day for polling. On one side, a majority of Americans now support the individual mandate. Since thats the core of health reform, this basically means that proponents are slowly winning the argument. If we make it to actual full implementation, this reform will be irreversible.

title: Critics Picks: The Public Enemy
description: A. O. Scott looks back at the 1931 gangster classic starring James Cagney.

title: With New Service, Speeding Up the Commute on 34th Street
description: Manhattans 34th Street is known for the Macys flagship store and city buses that move like mud. Macys is here to stay, but the Bloomberg administration is hoping the pokey buses will be going the way of Gimbels.

title: A Wave of Partner Retirements at Goldman Sachs
description: The cost-cutting at Goldman Sachs is now reaching the top ranks of the firm.

title: Turning a Page | Cara Benedetto at Taxter and Spengemann
description: Cara Benedettos debut solo show at Taxter and Spengemann, Breaking Waves (How Fake Stakes Ate the Cake), hard-core in every sense of the phrase, is a puzzling and provocative accumulation of imagined correspondences written and signed by a cast of vivid, often angry authors to the people who have done them right and wrong in life.

title: Mental Monetary Disorders
description: Brad DeLong has been blogging about von Mises and his belief  shared by a number of people to this day  that any economic expansion driven by monetary expansion must somehow be unsound and destructive.

title: Saints Continue Winless Streak on Coin Flips
description: With the Saints losing both coin tosses in Sundays victory against the Falcons  the one before the game and the one before overtime  they have now lost all 11 tosses this season. The odds of that are 1 in 2,048.

title: Medical Nuances Drove No Vote in Mississippi
description: JACKSON, Miss.  When her children woke up on Wednesday morning, Atlee Breland told them, Mama won her election.

title: Credit Suisse Changes Compensation Practices
description: All signs suggest bonuses on Wall Street will be lower this year. But on Monday, employees at Credit Suisse Group received some good news: less of their compensation will be deferred to future years.

title: #OccupyWallSt Roundup, Day 59
description: These are turbulent times in Occupy encampments around the country. City officials closed down camps in at least six cities over the weekend and early Monday, after three people died in encampments late last week. Salt Lake City police ordered the closing of the camp in Pioneer Park after a man was found dead in his tent in what the police said was possibly a drug overdose combined with carbon monoxide poisoning. Last week, a protester in Burlington, Vt., shot himself in an apparent suicide, and in Oakland, a 25-year-old protester was shot and killed on the outskirts of the encampment in Frank Ogawa Plaza. Evictions in Portland, Denver, St. Louis, Salt Lake City, Burlington and Oakland were largely peaceful, but more than 60 people were arrested nationwide. [Daily Kos, MSNBC, CNN]

title: For Beginning Runners, Advice Can Be a Hurdle
description: I wrote a column last month discussing whether runners should train with a coach  and not a single reader wrote in to ask how to find a coach. But many asked about something else.

title: A Rout for NBC as Well as the Patriots
description: The Sunday Night Football game between the New England Patriots and the New York Jets was by far the No. 1 program in all ratings categories, giving NBC an easy victory over all for the night (the Patriots also had an easy win, 37-16). Once Upon a Time on ABC was the highest-rated scripted program and has been very steady the last three weeks, hovering between 11 and 12 million total viewers (with 11.3 million this week).

title: In the Wild, Finding More Than a Feminine Side
description: The Western marsh harrier is a typical hawk. It has a sharp beak and talons, which it uses to kill other creatures for food and to defend its territory. Its the kind of bird that exemplifies military virtues, and its no wonder that it has a fighter jet, the British-made Harrier, named after it. Recent science, however, has discovered another side to the harrier that may not fit as well with the rather macho military image. Some harriers have evolved an alternative lifestyle  cross-dressing.

title: Light Therapy for Dark Days
description: For the millions of Americans who suffer from mild to severe winter blues  a condition called seasonal affective disorder, or S.A.D.  bright-light therapy is the treatment of choice, with response rates comparable with those of antidepressants, reports todays Consumer column.

title: Witnesses Recordings Help Explain Air Accidents
description: When the oxygen masks dropped from their overhead compartments on a Frontier Airlines flight from Denver on Oct. 13, Andrew Vos put his on and looked out the window. We were dropping down into these mountains, he said.

title: Update: The Pumpkins of Kane Street
description: As promised, a return visit to the pumpkins of Kane Street in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn.

title: Recipe for the Moons Magnetic Field: Spin and Stir
description: When astronauts from the 1969 Apollo 11 mission returned to Earth with about 50 pounds of lunar rocks and soil, scientists were surprised to find that some of the samples were magnetized. The Moon has no magnetic field, so it must have had an unknown magnetic past.

title: Flashy Pieces From a Flashy Composer
description: Liszt, one of the most innovative composer-pianists of the 19th century, pioneered the modern solo recital format and performed both his own works and those by other musicians during his flamboyant concerts. So it seemed fitting that the 29-year-old Hungarian pianist Adam Gyorgy offered one of his own compositions during a concert dedicated to Liszt at Carnegie Hall on Sunday evening.

title: Barriers to Bone Care (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Tomorrows Psychologists (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Philbin Packs Up His Desk, but Not His Stories
description: In Regis Philbins office at the studios of WABC television on the Upper West Side, the shelves were about half empty last week, as he wound down the days to his final appearance, Friday morning, on Live With Regis and Kelly.

title: Jury Out on E-Cigarettes (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: A Little Old Work Fills a Big New Space
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  Across the street from my hotel here is the stately stone Lyric Theater. Built as a Shriners hall in 1926, it has also served as a Red Cross blood collection center, a playhouse, a radio studio and a movie theater called the Capri.

title: A Crab Walk Amid Quiet of a Library
description: At the New York Public Library on Sunday night the musician Ben Frost issued a sublime rejoinder to the institutions usual hush. The Rose Main Reading Room shook with the sound of six electric guitars being endlessly strummed and a brass sextet on the balcony. Before that, inside the entrance guarded by the librarys marble lions, the Australian choreographer Lee Serle presented a dance.

title: Critics Picks Video: The Public Enemy
description: Americas love affair with movie gangsters shows no signs of letting up. A. O. Scott looks back at one of the films that helped spark that passion, The Public Enemy from 1931. Directed by William Wellman, the film stars James Cagney as a prohibition-era Chicago mobster named Tom Powers. Tom and his cohorts begin as petty thieves, but they rise in the criminal underworld once alcohol is outlawed. Mr. Scott praises Cagneys performance, along with that of his co-star and love interest Jean Harlow.

title: Today, Chelsea Clinton Became a Journalist
description: The hiring of Chelsea Clinton by NBC News was greeted with skepticism by some in the news business on Monday.

title: A New Video Series From Sony Masterworks
description: Sony Masterworks will begin offering a new series of online video called Legends of Broadway featuring interviews with notable theater artists. The series, at MasterworksBroadway.com, begins Wednesday with a clip of Stephen Sondheim, above, discussing the making of the original cast recording of West Side Story.

title: In China, Car Brands Evoke an Unexpected Set of Stereotypes
description: BEIJING  Cars in the United States tend to come fully equipped with stereotypes. Ford Crown Victoria: law enforcement professional. Toyota Prius: upscale yuppie environmentalist. Hummer: gas-guzzling egotist.

title: Behind the Cover Story: Ronen Bergman on the Gilad Shalit Swap
description: Ronen Bergman is a political and military analyst for the Israeli newspaper Yedioth Ahronoth and the author of, among other books, By Any Means Necessary: Israels Covert War for Its P.O.W.s and M.I.A.s. He is currently at work on a history of the Mossad. The story about Israels exchange of 1,027 prisoners for Gilad Shalit, who was abducted five years ago by Hamas in a firefight on the border of the Gaza Strip, is Ronens first cover article for the magazine.

title: Death of a Heavyweight
description: Friends, family and fellow boxers paid their respects to the boxer Joe Frazier at a funeral on Monday after he died last week from liver cancer at age 67.

title: Beyond planet Earth, taking care of our closest relatives and when your brain just wont deliver.
description: Beyond planet Earth, taking care of our closest relatives and when your brain just wont deliver.

title: Priming Germans for the Holocaust
description: Engineering Evil, a History Channel special on Tuesday night, is devoted to the details of how the Nazis carried out the Holocaust, so you expect to learn about things like crematorium design, and you do. But another kind of engineering  call it human engineering  is also revealed here.

title: Lens: 911 Aerials
description: Lens: 911 Aerials

title: New Albums From Caveman, Los Campesinos! and the Fall
description: CAVEMAN

title: Mayor Reports Steady Growth, and Demand, for Citys Hotels
description: At a tourism promotion whistle-stop in Long Island City, Queens, on Monday, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg celebrated the rising number of hotels opening in the city and the important jobs they provide.

title: Herman Cain on Libya
description: Ive already devoted one blog post to Herman Cain today, so Im reluctant to spill more e-ink on the Republican candidate. But do yourself a favor and watchMr. Cain attempt to talk about Libya.

title: Im Tired of Canned Cranberry Sauce. Can You Recommend a Recipe?
description: Im tired of canned cranberry sauce that still holds the shape of the can. Can you recommend a recipe?  @DavidOchoa

title: Porgy: No New Scene, Some Hard Feelings
description: There will be no revisionist happy ending in the coming Broadway production of The Gershwins Porgy and Bess. A new scene, in which the title characters have a final emotional encounter meant to deepen their love story, has been dropped. But some hard feelings remain, at least on the part of the shows director and its lead producer.

title: State Names Lawyer to Investigate Cheating
Rushdie Runs Afoul of Webs Real-Name Police
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The writer Salman Rushdie hit Twitter on Monday morning with a flurry of exasperated posts. Facebook, he wrote, had deactivated his account, demanded proof of identity and then turned him into Ahmed Rushdie, which is how he is identified on his passport. He had never used his first name, Ahmed, he pointed out; the world knows him as Salman.

title: Happy Trails
description: It can feel as though youve somehow gone back in time when youre driving up the looping curves of Route 17 in northern Vermont and take one last turn, toward the spine of the Green Mountains, to suddenly find what appears to be the movie set of a small 1960s ski resort brought painstakingly to life. There is a cluster of quaint yellow and blue rustic clapboard buildings. A rutted dirt parking lot. A single-chair lift rising into the clouds over narrow trails that seem to pitch and hurtle down the mountain.

title: Bishops Open Religious Liberty Drive
description: BALTIMORE  The nations Roman Catholic bishops opened a new front in their fight against abortion and same-sex marriage on Monday, recasting their opposition as a struggle for religious liberty against a government and a culture that are infringing on the churchs rights.

title: Where No Museum Has Gone Before
description: A sneak peek at the exhibition Beyond Planet Earth: The Future of Space Exploration, at the American Museum of Natural History.

title: Oh, the Places We Could Go
description: The high point was when I got to bomb Mars.

title: Assembly Speaker Injured in Bicycle Accident
description: Many New York politicians returned to work on Monday with a fresh suntan from their time at a conference in Puerto Rico this weekend.

title: Liz Magic Lasers Political Theater of the Absurd
description: The artist Liz Magic Lasers commissioned work for Performa11, I Feel Your Pain, promised both a romance drawn from the playbook of political theater and a 21st-century version of the living newspaper (a bit of Russian Constructivist agitprop). It does not disappoint on either count.

title: Post-Madoff, a Greater Awareness of Ponzi Schemes
description: Nearly three years after Bernard L. Madoffs gigantic fraud imploded, federal authorities say they are cracking down on Ponzi schemes in greater numbers.

title: Hawaiian Singer Played Occupy Protest Ballad for Asian Conference Leaders
description: Updated | 11:47 p.m. As my colleague Jackie Calmes reported, President Obama decided not to force world leaders attending the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum in Honolulu over the weekend to wear Hawaiian shirts. But the White House did arrange for a local musician, Makana, to serenade the world leaders with tunes played in the Hawaiian slack-key guitar style known as ki hoalu.

title: A Russian Artists Fashionable Flights
description: There are plenty of arresting moments in Idols, an exhibition of photographs by Gilles Larrain of the denizens of Maxs Kansas City in the 1970s. Mr. Larrains searingly colorful portraits  the likes of Harvey Fierstein, Taylor Mead, Holly Woodlawn and the New York Dolls vamping in shrill makeup and assorted states of dishabille  were first published in the 70s. Since going on view earlier this month at the Steven Kasher Gallery in Chelsea, theyve drawn a steady stream of visitors.

title: Lens: Winter Aerials
description: Lens: Winter Aerials

title: Former MF Global Employees Sue Over Layoffs
description: Former employees of MF Global sued the failed brokerage firm on Monday in separate lawsuits, arguing that they were laid off in violation of labor laws and seeking class-action status.

title: Site to Resell Music Files Has Critics
description: Music fans looking to clear out some clutter can always try to sell their old CDs. But can someone resell an old digital music file of Thriller thats languishing on a computer?

title: Whatever Court Rules, Major Changes in Health Care Likely to Last
description: This article is by  Reed Abelson,  Gardiner Harris and  Robert Pear.

title: NBC Overhauls Prime Time, Benching Community and Prime Suspect
description: Facing problems on almost every night of the week, NBC announced wholesale changes to its prime-time schedule Monday, which were focused mainly on strengthening two nights, Mondays and Thursdays.

title: Chilean Judge Drops Abuse Case but Condemns Priest
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  A Chilean judge dismissed criminal charges on Monday against the Rev. Fernando Karadima, once one of Chiles most prominent and respected Roman Catholic priests, allowing him to avoid prosecution over accusations that he had sexually abused three teenagers.

title: Elizabeth, an Iguana With Many Friends, Dies at 19
description: Her blood was cold, but her heart, her keepers said, was warm.

title: Comparing Two Health Care Laws
description: The similarities and differences between the Massachusetts health care plan that Mitt Romney signed into law as governor in 2006 and the federal plan that President Obama signed into law in 2010.

title: Qatar Wields an Outsize Influence in Arab Politics
description: DOHA, Qatar  Qatar is smaller than Connecticut, and its native population, at 225,000, wouldnt fill Cairos bigger neighborhoods. But for a country that inspires equal parts irritation and admiration, here is its rsum, so far, in the Arab revolts: It has proved decisive in isolating Syrias leader, helped topple Libyas, offered itself as a mediator in Yemen and counts Tunisias most powerful figure as a friend.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,817 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

title: Staterooms, Not Dorms, All Thanks to Mold
description: ST. MARYS CITY, Md.  Kimberly Fitzgerald, a freshman at St. Marys College of Maryland here, loves it when people ask where she lives.

title: Why Herman Cain Is Unfit to Lead
description: HARD as it has been to watch, harder still to live through, the spectacle of Herman Cains dodging sexual harassment allegations is a real step up for the status of women. Their sexual treatment is now part of the open political process, rather than a smarmy rumor to be passed among cognoscenti in the dark.

title: Some Students Grumble About Higher Ones Debit Card Fees
description: Students on some college campuses are simmering with discontent over Higher One Holdings Inc., a company that provides debit cards and bank accounts to students receiving financial aid.

title: Before We Bomb Iran, Lets Have a Serious Conversation
description: It is common for candidates in presidential primaries to use bellicose language to prove their toughness. This kind of rhetoric is especially useful in Republican primaries, where audiences have a firm belief in the use of military power to solve problems. But toughness and wisdom are not the same thing.

title: Still Full of Fire, Krzyzewski Is Set to Break Record for Wins
description: DURHAM, N.C.  Duke was set to tip off last Dec. 29 against North Carolina-Greensboro, a team that had virtually no chance of knocking off the Blue Devils, who were ranked No. 1. And most everybody knew it.

title: Rhode Island: East Providence Gets an Overseer
description: For the second time in 18 months, the state of Rhode Island intervened in the fiscal affairs of a city Monday, saying East Providence was too low on cash to keep providing essential services to its 48,000 residents.

title: Barclays Capital Rises, Big-Boy Checkbook in Hand
description: The American pipeline operator Kinder Morgan struck one of the biggest deals of the year nearly a month ago with its $21.1 billion purchase of a rival, the El Paso Corporation.

title: Britain: Missiles May Be Used to Protect Games
description: Britain will deploy ground-to-air missiles if they are judged operationally necessary to protect the 2012 summer Olympic Games in London, Defense Minister Philip Hammond told Parliament on Monday. With less than nine months to go before the Games, Mr. Hammond offered reassurances about safety in the wake of British newspaper articles saying concerns about the adequacy of security arrangements had been raised by the United States. All necessary measures to secure the security and safety of the London Olympic Games will be taken, including  if the advice of the military is that it is required  appropriate ground-to-air defenses, Mr. Hammond told the House of Commons. Police spokesmen have said that 12,000 officers will be deployed to protect the Olympic sites, as well as at least 10,000 private security guards, and that British military units will be on standby if needed.

title: An App Answers, Whats Your Name Again?
description: There are only so many times and ways you can politely say, Uh, Im sorry, your name again is?

title: Norway: Accused Oslo Gunman Appears in Court
description: Anders Behring Breivik, an avowed anti-immigrant extremist who has admitted to killing 77 people in a rampage in Norway last summer, appeared at his first public court hearing in Oslo on Monday, declaring himself a military commander in the Norwegian resistance movement. It was the first time victims and families of those killed in the shooting spree at a youth camp on Utoya Island were permitted in the courtroom with Mr. Breivik, left. At one point Mr. Breivik asked permission to address survivors, but the judge refused. The judge turned down a request by defense lawyers to move Mr. Breivik from solitary confinement, but ruled that he should be allowed access to newspapers, television and other media starting Dec. 12.

title: Do Nice Phones Finish Last?
description: The new HTC Radar is the first 4G Windows phone on the market. It is a nice phone. Really nice. But with the recent release of LTE network phones with brawny dual-core processors and the recent iPhone 4s, is nice good enough?

title: Agencies Fulfill Their Holiday Wishes With New Executives
description: THIS time of year, advertising agencies are focused on the mad dash to Christmas, helping clients maximize opportunities to reach consumers during the crucial holiday shopping season.

title: Merkel Urges More Unified Continent to Save Euro
description: LEIPZIG, Germany  Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany warned reluctant members of her conservative party in no uncertain terms on Monday that deeper political integration was necessary if Europes common currency was to be saved.

title: Where Soccer Has Been a One-Way Ticket Out
description: KIGALI, Rwanda  In the fading light and steady rain at Amahoro Stadium, the Eritrea national soccer team trained in silence Monday as it prepared for one of its most important matches since securing independence from Ethiopia in 1993.

title: Affiliation, Before and After Scandal
description: In the wake of the sexual abuse scandal that is roiling Penn States football program, some are wondering whether there could be long-term effects on recruiting, donations and the long-term reputation of the university.

title: Romneys Team Prepares for Obama, Too
description: WASHINGTON  As Mitt Romney prepares for Republican contests in Iowa, New Hampshire and beyond, his aides have been traveling the country filming stories for the battle they hope will follow against President Obama, spotlighting unemployed Americans who have given up on hope and change.

title: A Nuclear Facility We Dont Need
description: Los Alamos, N.M.

title: Lawyer for N.F.L. in Lockout Joins Players in N.B.A. Fight
description: Sports and law apparently make strange bedfellows. David Boies, the prominent lawyer who just months ago defended the N.F.L. during its lockout, has switched sides and will now represent the N.B.A. players in their fight against the leagues lockout.

title: Libya: Town Rallies Against Pro-Qaddafi Label
description: Residents from a town outside of Tripoli that had been accused on Libyan news broadcasts of supporting Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, who was captured and killed last month, rallied in the capital Monday to demand an apology for what they called slanderous reports.
