The protesters, from Warshefana, claimed that a television station supporting the transitional government, Libya al-Ahra, had falsely labeled them as pro-Qaddafi and incited gunmen from another town, Zawiyah, to take up arms against them. Fighting between gunmen from both towns has killed several men since last Thursday. The violence subsided by Monday, after mediation from the transitional government and elders. Many Libyans say Warshefanas population did include many people with pro-Qaddafi sentiments.

title: Knuckleheads and Worse, Bringing Guns in Carry-ons
description: EVERY day, screening officers find four to five guns in carry-on bags at American airports, according to John S. Pistole, the head of the Transportation Security Administration.

title: Rule Changes to Be Discussed
description: The N.H.L.s general managers will convene in a Toronto hotel Tuesday and debate whether a rule change is needed to limit the neutral-zone trap. The trapping issue emerged last Wednesday at Tampa Bay when the Philadelphia Flyers refused to advance the puck against the Lightnings 1-3-1 trap. The Lightning, in turn, refused to forecheck. So on several occasions, totaling about four minutes of playing time, a Flyers defenseman stood motionless in his own zone with the puck while four Lightning players stood motionless at their various stations in the neutral zone and a fifth stood idle deep in his own zone.

title: Sending a Harsh Message, U.S. Issues First Fine for Tarmac Delays
description: Airlines are warned: no lengthy delays this winter.

title: Fund-Raising by City Comptroller Is Investigated
description: Federal authorities are investigating the fund-raising operation of the New York City comptroller, John C. Liu, seeking records from his campaign and from a city contractor whose employees were listed as having contributed thousands of dollars to his campaign, people with knowledge of the matter said.

title: Deficit Panel Still Talking as Others Focus on Spending Bills
description: WASHINGTON  As members of the Congressional deficit reduction panel retreated to conference rooms Monday to continue negotiations, House Republicans and Senate Democrats were putting their final touches on a series of spending bills that they hope will avert another showdown over short-term financing of the government.

title: Q&A: Finding Fonts for All
description: Q.

title: Departures Unsettle Newsweek
description: Newsweek was jolted by three high-level departures on Monday, a sign that the merger a year ago with The Daily Beast has left the magazine deeply unsettled.

title: Major Ad Blitz for Huntsman in New Hampshire, by Group Backed by His Father
description: Providing perhaps a last-chance boost to the flagging presidential hopes of former Gov. Jon M. Huntsman Jr. of Utah, an outside group that is supported by his father, a billionaire chemical executive, and other wealthy backers plans a major advertising campaign on his behalf in New Hampshire starting on Tuesday.

title: N.H.L. General Managers to Discuss Rule Changes
description: The N.H.L.s general managers will convene at a suburban Toronto hotel Tuesday for their annual fall meeting to debate whether a rule change is needed to limit the neutral-zone trap, after exactly one mildly controversial game.

title: Mexico: Presidents Sister Loses Governors Race
description: The sister of President Felipe Caldern lost a tight race for governor of his home state, Michoacn, in an election marred by threats and violence attributed to organized crime. Luisa Mara Caldern, who like her brother belongs to the conservative National Action Party, lost by two percentage points to Fausto Vallejo Figueroa, the candidate of the Institutional Revolutionary Party, which is making an aggressive effort to retake the presidency next year. Mr. Vallejo garnered 35 percent of the vote, Ms. Caldern, 33 percent, and a candidate from the Democratic Revolutionary Party, which has dominated there recently, got 29 percent. Ms. Caldern had hoped to score a symbolic victory for the party, which is trailing in presidential polls. But it has lost several recent elections for governor there.

title: Margaret Atwood Named Mentor in Rolex Arts Program
description: The Canadian author Margaret Atwood and the French theater director Patrice Chreau are among the six artists who will serve as mentors in dance, film, literature, music, theater and visual arts as part of a program sponsored by Rolex.

title: The Tobacco Horror Show
description: Im sure youve noticed those TV ads for pharmaceutical products that include an incredibly long list of side effects and possible hazards recited by a cheerful voice as men and women are shown living the happy lives made possible by a drug that can inflict on them everything from bloating and joint pain to death. This combination of positive and negative communications is mandated by the government requirement that drug manufacturers must disclose all the risk factors attending the product they are hawking.

title: Geron Is Shutting Down Its Stem Cell Clinical Trial
description: The company conducting the worlds first clinical trial of a therapy using human embryonic stem cells said on Monday that it was halting that trial and leaving the stem cell business entirely.

title: Plan for Bus Terminal Tower Is Dropped
description: For more than a decade, a prominent New York developer has sought to build a glass skyscraper over the Port Authority Bus Terminal, transforming an eyesore at the west end of Times Square into an architectural showpiece.

title: Philadelphia and the Boxing World Pay Tribute to Frazier
description: PHILADELPHIA  Joe Frazier answered the final bell Monday, a pair of boxing gloves and a championship belt draped across his coffin, eulogized as an ordinary man who achieved extraordinary greatness in the ring, an average Joe who brought decency to a brutal sport.

title: Giving Their Children a Place to Lay Their Heads
description: When Olga and Alexander Vartsaba won the green card lottery and moved from Russia to the United States in 2002, they believed their luck had finally changed.

title: Bank Excuses on Foreclosure Growing Stale
description: The Bank of America lawyer laid down a patented rhetorical move heard in courts across America. Your Honor, this Orange County, N.Y., homeowner  a New York City police officer  didnt make enough money to qualify for a mortgage modification. He didnt send us the right documents.

title: Odd Receipt Has Star Turn at Officials Trial
description: Of the many misdeeds that federal prosecutors have attributed to City Councilman Larry B. Seabrook, one has received more attention than any other: the purchase of a snack (a bagel and a drink) and a request for reimbursement of $177.

title: Lacking Experience as a Manager, but Not Confidence in Doing the Job
description: The day before he interviewed to be the next manager of the St. Louis Cardinals, Mike Matheny visited the Busch Stadium office of the man he hoped to replace. Tony La Russa was there, clearing out the mementos of more than 2,500 games with St. Louis and more than 5,000 as a major league manager.

title: Book Shopping for the Holidays
description: Sundays Times Book Review included the Childrens Books section, which always precedes the holidays, and which I look forward to every year. Besides being the usual good read for lovers of childrens books, its an ideal shopping guide for the aunt, parent or friend who does all of her holiday shopping for the younger set at the bookstore. I was a book-obsessed child, and the flat packages that meant hours of vacation pleasure to me were what I most wanted to find under the tree. I give books for the simple reason that I love books, but unless a child has a favorite series (and doesnt yet possess them all), its tough to book-shop for kids past the picture-book age and feel reasonably confident in your chances of success.

title: Viktor Bout Trying to Overturn Conviction in Arms Plot
description: A lawyer for Viktor Bout, the Russian businessman convicted in a plot to sell weapons to Colombian terrorists, has asked a federal judge to overturn the verdict and hold a new trial because one of the jurors may have been unduly influenced by a Nicolas Cage movie based on Mr. Bouts life.

title: One Secret Buffett Gets to Keep
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission usually doesnt let investors keep many secrets. Except if youre a major player like Warren Buffett.

title: Experiment on Subways Will Shift Pain to Weekdays
description: They are the three words no subway rider wants to see: weekend service advisory, a sure sign that smooth travels do not lie ahead.

title: Boley Injury Could Leave the Giants Weakened
description: In a season in which the Giants have dealt with numerous injuries to critical players, defensive end Justin Tuck  himself one of the afflicted this year  offered a telling statement when asked late Sunday about middle linebacker Michael Boleys potentially missing a game or more.

title: An Apology of Enclaves
description: No, apology is not the collective noun for enclaves. The accepted term is a complex of enclaves  although more imaginative suggestions are welcome. Nor do I feel the need to apologize for enclaves. Yes, these geopolitical anomalies  for the uninitiated, a chunk of one political or ethnic unit lying wholly within another  have caused their fair share of misery and grief. But fascination with a subject does not equal approval of all its phenomena; herpetologists need not apologize for snakebites.

title: Even in Bankruptcy, Dodgers Can Make Big Offer to Kemp
description: The Los Angeles Dodgers are operating under bankruptcy protection, yet they are on the verge of signing their star outfielder, Matt Kemp, to a contract said to be worth $160 million over eight years.

title: Cain Stumbles in Assessing Foreign Policy
description: Herman Cain became badly flustered on Monday when asked to assess President Obamas policy toward Libya, raising new questions about his command of foreign policy as he lurched over five minutes from awkward pauses to halting efforts to address the issue.

title: Quietly, Google Gets Its View of the Park
description: As gold leaves drifted to the ground in Central Park on Monday, a strange-looking vehicle joined the parks stream of pedicabs, bicycles, baby carriages and skateboards. It was straight out of Roald Dahls imagination, at once sinister and innocent  an ungainly contraption cooked up by, say, Good Humor and the K.G.B.

title: Students Lose Zeal for Aiding Obama Again
description: LAS VEGAS  For much of the presidential election of 2008, Barack Obamas campaign was Emma Guerreros life. She was one of a dozen volunteers who showed up at an Obama campaign office here every night, taking time from her studies at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas, to be part of what she still remembers as the most exciting period of her life.

title: Cuomo Sees Budget Gaps This Year and Next
description: Continued tumult in the financial markets and the prospect of a weak bonus season on Wall Street have significantly darkened the states financial condition and could force legislators back to Albany to find additional spending cuts before the end of the year, officials in the state budget office said on Monday.

title: Lottery Numbers
A Place to Occupy and Get Results
description: Occupy Congress has garnered far less attention than the global protest movement that started as Occupy Wall Street in Lower Manhattan. But politicians helped create the financial crisis. Fresh news of American lawmakers trading on inside information is further reason for mistrust.

title: Learning About Nerves and Sudden Noises
description: IGREW up traveling. Im not one of those people who can sit still on a beach or at a pool. I have to be doing something, going somewhere.

title: Farewell to the Business Center
description: The hotel business center is not what it used to be.

title: Indian States Roads Become a Protest Tool
description: IMPHAL, India  All summer, Homindon Singh Lisams phone rang off the hook. As a doctor and hospital administrator in Indias remote Manipur State, he is no stranger to triage. But this was different.

title: Keystone Pipeline Will Be Rerouted
description: At a special session of the Nebraska Legislature, a state senator announced Monday that TransCanada had agreed to adjust its intended route of the Keystone XL oil pipeline to avoid the environmentally sensitive Sand Hills region of the state.

title: The Conspiracy at Lick Creek
description: As the forests surrounding the Great Smoky Mountains passed their autumnal peak foliage in early November 1861, a group of potters and farmers gathered at the Greene County, Tenn., home of Jacob and Henry Harmon. There the brothers, joined by Christopher Haun, Henry Fry and Jacob Hinshaw, finalized their plot to destroy the nearby Lick Creek railroad bridge on Nov. 8. This was no local conspiracy, however. More than 100 fellow East Tennessee Unionists plotted to simultaneously burn eight other railroad bridges as far away as northeast Alabama, effectively severing all rail and telegraph connection between Virginia and the heartland of the Confederacy.

title: Cains Wife Steps Into Role She Has Long Avoided
description: The part of candidates spouse vouching for her husbands character is not a role Gloria Cain ever prepared herself to play.

title: Tuesday: Smells Fishy to Me
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  Does something smell fishy here to you?

title: Unpredictable on the Mound, Less So on the Links
description: Four knuckleballers were playing golf.

title: In Esquire, Taymor Says She Was Unfairly Maligned by U2 Leaders Over Spider-Man Woes
description: In a new interview with Esquire magazine, the theater director Julie Taymor accuses Bono and the Edge of U2  her former collaborators on the Broadway musical Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark  of maligning her as exhausted and overwrought as a bogus explanation for ousting her from the production in March and then overhauling the show as they saw fit.

title: High Emotion and Intrigue After Iran Blast
description: Irans supreme leader presided Monday over a vast state funeral for a founder of Irans missile program and 16 other members of the Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps who were killed in an explosion Saturday, in an emotional ritual that underscored the commanders importance and Tehrans rising sense of confrontation with the West over its nuclear program.

title: Syrian Refugees Languish in Turkey
description: About 7,600 Syrian refugees live in camps in Turkey after fleeing a brutal crackdown in Syria by President Bashar al-Assad. With the violence continuing in Syria, some appear to be settling in for what may be a long stay.

title: Ways to Measure Inequality in America
description: To the Editor:

title: Investigating Police Conduct in New York City
description: To the Editor:

title: The 9/11 Remains: For Families, the Pain Endures
description: To the Editor:

title: Better Scientific Research
description: To the Editor:

title: For Refugees From Syria, a Visit With No Expiration Date
description: BOYNUYOGUN, Turkey  The Turkish government describes the refugee camp here as a temporary residence for the countrys Syrian guests, but very little about it looks temporary.

title: The Butcher and the Frazier-Stander Bout
description: Ron Standers hard knocks didnt end after his four-round fight against Smokin Joe Frazier in 1972.

title: Where Nothing Is Black and White, or Even Gray
description: It doesnt seem right to call the zone thats occupied by Thomas Bradshaws Burning a gray area. This repellent and magnetic play, which opened on Monday night at the Acorn Theater in a New Group production, is way too lurid to be gray.

title: The Torture Candidates
description: As hard as it is to believe, the Republican candidates for president seem to have learned very little from the moral calamities of the administration of George W. Bush. Three of the contenders for the partys nomination have now come out in favor of the torture known as waterboarding. Only two have said it is illegal, and the rest dont seem to have the backbone to even voice an opinion on the subject.

title: A Light in the Barn
description: Every now and then, I forget to turn off the lights in the barn. I usually notice just before I go to bed, when the farms boundaries seem to have drawn in close. That light makes the barn seem farther away than it is  a distance Im going to have to travel before I sleep. The weather makes no difference. Neither does the time of year.

title: Taking, and Restoring, the Rights of Felons
After Frazier Kept the Belt, a Long Shot Withstood the Blows
description: OMAHA

title: In Egypt, Fears of Mubaraks Outlawed Party, the Remnant, Loom Over Vote
description: MANSOURA, Egypt  Mortada Mansour, the man accused of directing the notorious Battle of the Camel during the Tahrir Square protests in February, came to a courtroom in this provincial city to defend the right of former regime stalwarts to run in the coming parliamentary elections.

title: Perry Asks Voters to Overlook His Lack of Polish at the Podium
description: BETTENDORF, Iowa  Gov. Rick Perry of Texas declared Monday night, Im the first to admit, Im not the most polished candidate out there, but he urged Republicans to look beyond his rhetorical shortcomings and focus on his plan to upend the status quo in Washington.

title: Health Reform and the Supreme Court
description: The Supreme Courts decision to review the constitutionality of health care reform means it will be issuing a ruling in the middle of the 2012 presidential campaign. This can be a highly politicized court, and, for the public good and its own credibility, it must resist that impulse.

title: Torture and Exceptionalism
description: If we truly believe ourselves to be exceptional, a model for all the world and an example for all of history, then why would we practice torture?

title: Penn States Long Road Back
description: I cant remember the last time I watched a regular season college football game, but, on Saturday, I turned on the Penn State-Nebraska game. Coming into it, Penn State was ranked 12th in the country and Nebraska was No. 19, so the experts expected a close game. I cant say thats why I watched.

title: Lets All Feel Superior
description: First came the atrocity, then came the vanity. The atrocity is what Jerry Sandusky has been accused of doing at Penn State. The vanity is the outraged reaction of a zillion commentators over the past week, whose indignation is based on the assumption that if they had been in Joe Paternos shoes, or assistant coach Mike McQuearys shoes, they would have behaved better. They would have taken action and stopped any sexual assaults.

title: Les Daniels, Historian of Comic Books, Dies at 68
description: Les Daniels, one of the earliest historians of comic books  from the launching (off the doomed planet Krypton) of Superman in 1938 through the countercultural comix movement of the 60s  and an author of horror novels, died on Nov. 5 at his home in Providence, R.I. He was 68.

title: Irving H. Franklin, 93, Dies; Improved Batters Grip
description: For many decades, almost no major league baseball players wore batting gloves. Partly because of Irving H. Franklin, almost all do today.

title: Dr. Paul Epstein, Expert in Public Health, Is Dead at 67
description: Dr. Paul Epstein, a public health expert who was among the first to warn of a link between the spread of infectious disease and extreme weather events, adding a new dimension to research into the potential impact of global climate change, died on Sunday at his home in Boston. He was 67.

title: Giving Fraud a Bad Name
description: Charles Ponzi didnt invent his eponymous pyramid scheme  but he lent star power to one of the oldest scams in the book. He also believed that his plan could have become a legitimate business.

title: A Start-Up Offers a New Way to Search the Web
description: Though Web search is dominated by Google and supplemented by link-sharing on Facebook and Twitter, a start-up, Trapit, which opens to the public Tuesday, thinks it can offer a smarter, more personalized way to search for topics.

title: Word of the Day | cherubic
description: cherubic \ch-r-bik also cher--\ adjective

title: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Tuesday
description: Chief Omar Abdullah met the prime minister and other top leaders on Monday, in a bid to create consensus at the highest level of government on the withdrawal of the Armed Forces Special Powers Act (The Hindu). The meetings came after a army officers in the state argued last week against the laws revocation, claiming there is a Pakistani presence in the area (Hindustan Times). Mr. Abdullah expressed confidence in the partial withdrawal of the law.The parliamentary committee scrutinizing the Lokpal bill says it should not cover the judiciary branch of government (Indian Express). In a move that was denounced by Team Anna, the panel also recommends reducing the penalties for frivolous complaints from five years imprisonment to six months.

title: Why Is the U.S. on the Wrong Track?
description: Woe is us.

title: NYT Front Page for 11/15/2011
description: NYT Front Page for 11/15/2011

title: City Reopens Park After Protesters Are Evicted
description: New York City on Tuesday reopened the park in Lower Manhattan where the Occupy Wall Street movement was born not long after a judge upheld the citys move to clear the park and bar the protesters from bringing back their tents or sleeping overnight.

title: In Mumbai, the $50,000 Slum Shack
description: You reach the house of Indu Prakash Vaidya, a 32-year-old housewife, by trekking down a two-foot-wide alley through an inch of stinking, wet mud, filled with plastic bags and kitchen scraps.Her 200-square-foot shanty, in Rajiv Gandhi Nagar, in the Dharavi neighborhood of Mumbai, has faulty electrical lines, no water supply and a non existent sewage system. Still, Ms. Vaidyas house is her most prized possession. If I decide to sell it, it will fetch me more than Rs 10 lakh rupees, or about $24,000, she estimates, based on the offers she has been getting.

title: Dont Forget the Clients You Already Have
description: At Door Number 3, we spend a lot of time and energy focused on growth. Our 15-person shop has a full-time person dedicated to bringing in new business, leading the response to requests for proposals, getting out there networking, building and working databases. But we dont always give as much attention to the customers we already have. As 2011 rolls to an end, I am reminding myself that its time to set in motion something I began last year.

title: For Obama, a Day Off in Hawaii for Fund-Raising and Golf
description: KAPOLEI, Hawaii  Monday was a down day for President Obama between rounds of Pacific Rim summitry, and he made the most of it with some golf and fund-raising among friends old and new on a day of idyllic weather in his native state.

title: Corrections: November 15
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Put Eric Wynalda in the Win-Now Category
description: Some soccer people believe the mere term friendly international is a nave and offensive oxymoron.

title: Mrs. Obama Reaches Out to Military Women
description: KAPOLEI, Hawaii  Michelle Obama, who traveled here with her husband for an economic summit of Pacific nations, attended a job fair for military veterans and spouses on Monday and commiserated with the women in the group.

title: News Quiz | Nov. 15, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Occupy Movement Could Declare Victory and Scale Back Camps, Founder Suggests
description: In a new tactical briefing issued on Monday, hours before the Occupy Wall Street camp was raided by the police, the editors of Adbusters, the Canadian, anti-consumerist magazine that dreamed up the movement, suggested that it might be time for the protesters to declare victory  and scale back the camps before winter sets in.

title: Nov. 15, 1969 | Anti-Vietnam War Demonstration Held
description: On Nov. 15, 1969, the Vietnam Moratorium Committee staged what is believed to be the largest antiwar protest in United States history when as many as half a million people attended a mostly peaceful demonstration in Washington. Smaller demonstrations were held in a number of cities and towns across the country.

title: UBS Names Sergio Ermotti as Chief Executive
description: LONDON  UBS has chosen Sergio P. Ermotti, who has run the Swiss bank on an interim basis since September, to become its permanent chief executive.

title: Hispanics Bring Demographic and Cultural Shift to the Midwest
description: WHO are bringing about a demographic shift in the town of Ulysses, Kansas?

title: Above Ground Zero With a Camera and a Bluff
description: Gregg Brown recalls walking to his East Village home three days after Sept. 11, 2001, unable to escape the sight of makeshift Missing posters and the smell of destruction that hung in the air like funeral incense. Late that night, the phone rang in his apartment  not unusual, since it was the number he listed in the Yellow Pages for his photography business under the words: We Do Photo Video  24 Hr. Rush Jobs Welcome.

title: Test Yourself | English, Nov. 15, 2011
description: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article Reality TVs Instant Stars Populate a Magazine.

title: From Nablus to Jerusalem
description: NABLUS, West Bank  Last Saturday, I arrived at the Nablus train station, a low, thick-walled stone structure, in time to board the 3:20 pm to Jerusalem. Some 20 passengers were waiting at the entrance, mostly young men and women, with a few people old enough to remember the days of train travel during the British Mandate over Palestine. The excitement was palpable: It was our chance to take a ride to Jerusalem, a city we are barred from visiting, bypassing the Israeli checkpoints along the way. As I entered the station, a porter in a dark blue uniform issued me a ticket on the Green Line. The journey would take 30 minutes, with stops planned at Hawwarah, Zatara, Uyun al Haramiya, Attarah and Kalandia  all existing checkpoints. I made my way to the waiting room. It was barren, except for low tables with brochures entitled Palestine Connected showing local train networks and their destinations. Gaza. Jaffa. Haifa. Beersheba.

title: Are You a Brand?
description: An Op-Ed writer argues that youth culture today is characterized by an entrepreneurial spirit in which everyones selling something  themselves, an idea, a lifestyle, social responsibility. Do you think that description characterizes you and your friends, and your generation?

title: Chinese Artist Posts $1.3 Million to Seek Tax Bill Review
description: BEIJING  The celebrated Chinese artist and dissident Ai Weiwei on Tuesday posted the equivalent of $1.3 million with Chinese tax authorities in an effort to contest accusations of tax fraud that he says are politically motivated.

title: Signs of Broad Contagion in Europe as Growth Slows
description: The borrowing costs of nations at the heart of Europe jumped sharply on Tuesday, the latest evidence of broader contagion across the Continent as economic growth stalled.

title: Champagne House Outside of Paris Hosts Sound-Themed Art Show
description: Less than an hour from Paris, in the historic city of Rheims, Champagne and contemporary art rub shoulders in the depths of Pommerys vaulted cellars.

title: Tebows Numbers, in a More Positive Light
description: Tim Tebow was 2 of 8 passing for 69 yards on Sunday. He has completed less than 50 percent of his passes in each of his games this year. Hes averaging just 131.5 passing yards per game in his four starts, not counting an average of 24 yards lost because of sacks in each game.

title: Part 2: Answers to Your Questions on Scholarships and Student Loans
description: To help readers of The Choice navigate the maze of scholarships available to them  as well as to further their understanding of President Obamas recent proposal to ease the repayment of some student loans  Mark Kantrowitz, a financial aid expert and founder of the Web sites finaid.org and fastweb.com, is spending this week in our virtual Guidance Office. Mr. Kantrowitz is also the author of Secrets to Winning a Scholarship, published in February.

title: Ask the Elder Law Attorney: Family Loans
description: Craig Reaves, past president of the National Academy of Elder Law Attorneys, practices elder law in Kansas City, Mo., and fields occasional questions from New Old Age readers. Submit yours to newoldage@nytimes.com. Please limit your queries to general legal issues, as Mr. Reaves cannot respond with personalized legal advice.

title: Trying Out the Worlds First In-Car Music-Streaming System
description: Here are some of the problems with listening to music in your car (which is otherwise awesome):

title: The Balanced Budget Amendment Delusion
description: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of the coming book The Benefit and the Burden.

title: The Early Word: Challenge
description: Todays Times

title: Nisshin Steel and Nippon Metal to Merge
description: Nisshin Steel and Nippon Metal Industry on Tuesday announced plans to merge in a deal that would create the second-largest maker of stainless steel in Japan.

title: Updates on the Clearing of Zuccotti Park
description: Updated, 5:38 p.m. | The day after the police cleared Zuccotti Park of the Occupy Wall Street protesters in an overnight raid and arrested hundreds of people, a judge ruled Tuesday afternoon that the city had the right to enforce rules against having camping gear in the park.

title: As the Police Moved In, the Word Went Out: Its Happening
description: The police began showing up by the hundreds just after midnight. Scores of officers arrived in vehicles that had been staging over by the Brooklyn Bridge but were now at Zuccotti Park. They surrounded the encampment of tents and tarps and booths that the Occupy Wall Street protesters had built and lived in for nearly two months.

title: Doubling Down on Southfork Kitchen
description: Its November in the Hamptons. Your restaurant isnt half full half the week. You have become a Saturday night special, a destination for weekenders and anniversary celebrators; the fall-off from the summer is not a surprise, just steeper than expected. You dont know if its the weather, the uncertain economy, the occupation of Wall Street, or your own particular issues.

title: On the Soccer Field, a Roster Full of Refugees
description: In a Wednesday night league held on Roosevelt Island, the sidelines are clearly marked, but the games are very much without borders.

title: Carbon Trading Initiative a Success, Study Says
description: The Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative, a 10-state program that has been testing a carbon dioxide cap-and-trade system, may be in trouble, with New Jersey planning to drop out and other states considering doing the same.

title: Help Document the 2012 Ground Game
description: Elections, for most people, can be like icebergs: what you see is only a small portion of the whole campaign. In an age of micro-targeted direct mail, Facebook ads and robocalls, voters can experience a campaign in very different ways than their neighbors do, to say nothing of the view that reporters traveling with candidates get.

title: Loss Puts Head of Kingfisher Airlines on Defensive
description: MUMBAI, India  At a raucous news conference on Tuesday that began almost two hours late and lasted almost that long, Vijay Mallya defended Kingfisher Airlines from accusations of mismanagement and instead blamed taxes, oil prices and a competitive industry for the companys financial troubles.

title: Court Health Care Decision Poses Risks For Romney
Breakfast Meeting, Nov. 15
description: The New York Police Departments late-night move on Zuccotti Park, the home of the Occupy Wall Street movement, caught the news media off-guard as much as it caught the protesters, with Twitter becoming a vital way for reporters to communicate during the police action. Of course, Mayor Bloombergs office took to Twitter to notify the public at roughly 2 a.m., media members and protesters alike.

title: Phrases Gone Astray
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

title: Phrases Gone Astray
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

title: The Debut of the Collection
description: Today, The New York Times introduces the Collection, a fashion app exclusively for the iPad that brings together in one spot all the fashion coverage offered by Thursday and Sunday Styles, T Magazine, The Moment and The International Herald Tribune. The Collection is a visual playground where you are encouraged to explore the latest in fashion news, from reviews by Cathy Horyn and Suzy Menkes to Bill Cunninghams On the Street videos. You can also click on more than 150 designer galleries from the current season.

title: Syria Faces New Threats as Opposition Seeks Allies
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Buoyed by rising international pressure on the Syrian government, Syrias opposition courted support from the Arab League and Russia on Tuesday, and Turkey, a central player in the growing crisis, threatened new economic penalties against Syria, its increasingly isolated neighbor.

title: Thai Army Uses Flooding to Take on Friendlier Role
description: BANGKOK  Troops and army trucks are rolling through the streets of Bangkok again. But this time it is not to battle protesters or overthrow a prime minister.

title: Supreme Court Order Would Allow Arroyo to Leave Philippines
description: MANILA  The Philippine Supreme Court ruled Tuesday that Gloria Macapagal Arroyo, the former president, could leave the country despite accusations of corruption and electoral fraud.

title: Opinion Report: Health Care and the Supreme Court
description: From the editorial page

title: Morning Take-Out
description: TOP STORIES

title: TimesCast | Zuccotti Park Is Cleared
description: Nov. 15, 2011  New York City police cleared Zuccotti Park of protesters early Tuesday.

title: A Telecom Pushes Its Cloud Strategy
description: 10:19 a.m. | Updated with AT&T announcement.

title: Bali Wood
description: The sun was about to set on the Indonesian island of Bali when Ben Ripple and Frederick Schilling, owners of the artisanal food company Big Tree Farms, led me through their new chocolate factory near Ubud. It was still under construction as we stepped into a titanic inner chamber with a high pitched roof, the last light of the day streaming dramatically through a long, narrow skylight at the peak, allowing the 30 or so builders to keep working. Several of them cheerfully called down to us from their tinkertoy-like scaffolding as we picked our way through the piles of construction materials. Were building the Big Tree cathedral, Ripple said.

title: Brees Has Unitass Streak in His Sights
description: Before the final week of the 2010 regular season, I noted that Drew Brees and Tom Brady had thrown at least one touchdown pass in each of their teams first 15 games. Brady threw a pair of touchdown passes against Miami in the season finale last season, and has thrown at least one touchdown pass in every game this year, giving him 25 consecutive games with a touchdown pass. But Brees also kept his streak alive in Week 17 last season. In fact, after throwing for two touchdowns against the Falcons on Sunday, Brees has now thrown a touchdown pass in 37 consecutive regular-season games.

title: Axa Retires Its Gorilla, Who Pushed Retirement Planning
description: Advertising in the insurance category is filled with colorful characters, among them the Geico gecko, Flo the clerk for Progressive and the menace known only as Mayhem in Allstate campaigns.

title: Mayor Bloomberg Steps In
description: Forty-five years ago  long before most Occupy Wall Street protesters and perhaps some of their parents were born  a Republican senator from Vermont named George D. Aiken proposed a way for the United States to ease out of a war in Vietnam that was widening and starting the tear this country apart.

title: A Program to Turn Around Troubled Students
Zuccotti Park Is Cleared and Cleaned in the Dark
description: The New York Police Department moved in early Tuesday and ordered the Occupy Wall Street protesters out of Zuccotti Park.

title: Breathtaking, Still
description: I think Im supposed to be jaded about views like this, which Ive had many times. But the wonder of the worlds greatest city never fades.

title: New York Police Clear Zuccotti Park
description: After the New York Police Department cleared Zuccotti Park of Occupy Wall Street protesters, many were allowed to move back in, though without tents.

title: Jeff Kinneys Favorite Books From Childhood
description: Today marks the publication of Diary of a Wimpy Kid: Cabin Fever, the sixth book in Jeff Kinneys blockbuster series of illustrated chapter books for young readers. The latest arrives with much fanfare and a jaw-dropping 6 million copies in its first print run, making a total of 58 million copies of Wimpy Kid books in print in the United States and Canada.

title: In Innovation Race, China Is Not Yet a Rival, Study Says
description: Innovation is a decidedly tricky thing to measure. Patents are the most widely used yardstick, but they are an imperfect gauge of innovation at best.

title: Home Cooks Rethink Sweet Potatoes
description: Sweet potato casserole topped with marshmallows has become a staple of many Thanksgiving tables. But if youre ready to rethink this iconic holiday dish, a community of home cooks is here to help.

title: Tuesday Reading: Light Boxes Help Fend Off Winter Blues
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: What Were Reading
description: The E-Advisor Blog: Not all fast food turns a quick buck. From McSpaghetti to Wendys Superbar to the Taco Bellbeefer, 10 innovations that fell flat.  Patrick Farrell

title: Childrens Investment Fund Takes Stake in News Corp.
description: LONDON  The British hedge fund manager Chris Hohn recently bought an $833 million stake in News Corporation, even as police investigations about the media companys illegal phone-hacking practices continue on both sides of the Atlantic.

title: Closeup: Climate Extremes and Global Warming
description: Later this week, as I noted on Monday, the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, meeting in Kampala, Uganda, will issue its report on ways to manage risks from extreme events in a changing climate.

title: Bad Times for Mr. Good Times
description: Vijay Mallya faced a hostile audience Tuesday, as his Kingfisher Airlines reported a third quarter loss, Vikas Bajaj writes.

title: Insurance Mandate May Be Health Bills Undoing
description: WASHINGTON  As Barack Obama battled Hillary Rodham Clinton over health care during the Democratic presidential primaries of 2008, he was adamant about one thing: Americans, he insisted, should not be required to buy health insurance.

title: On Our Radar: Rerouting the Keystone XL Pipeline
description: TransCanada agrees to find a new route for the Keystone XL pipeline that will skirt the environmentally sensitive Sand Hills area and the Ogallala aquifer in Nebraska. Still, the project cannot move forward anytime soon; a State Department spokesman says the federal governments own review could conclude as early as the first quarter of 2013. [Reuters]

title: Jean-Paul Goudes Bodies of Work
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Quietly, Google Gets Its View of the Park
description: Google, which already offers 360-degree street-level views of New York City and other cities, has turned its attention to parks and other locations inaccessible by car with its Trike, a panoramic camera system with nine lenses mounted on an oversize tricycle. Read the full New York Times article by Lisa W. Foderaro.

title: If Charles Dickens Had Been Jewish . . .
description: Ebenezer Scrooge might discover he would die laughing if the Ghost of Christmas Future took him to see Jackie Hoffmans new show, Jackie Hoffmans a Chanukah Charol. This wacky comedian, whose holiday shows have become a tradition for New Yorkers, will star at New World Stages in a new pseudo-autobiographical one-woman production inspired by Patrick Stewarts a Christmas Carol.

title: Amid New Lawsuits, Prospects Weaken for 2012 Baltimore Grand Prix
description: BALTIMORE  Drivers, race officials, broadcasters, government agencies and local businesses were nearly unanimous in their praise for the inaugural Baltimore Grand Prix, held over Labor Day weekend this year on the streets around the citys Inner Harbor.

title: Retailers See a Split in Behavior of Shoppers
description: At Wal-Mart, shoppers cut back on staples like milk and meat that had price increases of a few cents. At Saks Fifth Avenue, they paid full price for shoes and designer fashions at a rate higher than before the recession.

title: Investing in Packers, Wallet and Soul
description: GREEN BAY, Wis.  In any other place, they would be called souvenirs, documents suitable for framing, or even a sham. But here in the heart of Packers country, they are stock certificates that confer to the owner a microscopically thin and perhaps meaningless slice of the hometown team.

title: Box.net Looks Towards Custom Applications
description: Cloud computing may be entering its next big test: Can the big players make lots of other people rich?

title: English King to Have Brief Reign in Beijing
description: 9:25 a.m. | Updated After more than 18 months of negotiations  Richard III, starring Kevin Spacey, opened in Beijing last Friday, according to Agence France-Presse.

title: Sino-Forest Report Rejects Fraud Claims, With Caveats
description: OTTAWA  A panel of directors of the Sino-Forest Corporation rejected claims of fraud at the Chinese company in a report released on Tuesday. But the document also makes clear that the panel was unable to verify some of the company data and statements at the heart of the case.

title: Once Wary, Apple Warms Up to Business Market
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Steven P. Jobs never cared much for selling Apple products to big businesses.

title: Reporters Say Police Denied Access to Protest Site
description: 4:26 p.m. | Updated As New York City police cleared the Occupy Wall Street campsite in Zuccotti Park early Tuesday morning, many journalists were blocked from observing and interviewing protesters. Some called it a media blackout and said in interviews that they believed that the police efforts were a deliberate attempt to tamp down coverage of the operation.

title: Joseph Altuzarra Wins His Prize
description: During that tense moment Monday night between the now-traditional serving of chicken potpie and the announcement of the Council of Fashion Designers of America/Vogue Fashion Fund winners for the year, while the designers of the 10 nominated labels sat anxiously, Diane von Furstenberg walked over to the table where Joseph Altuzarra was sitting and pinched the designer on his cheek. She held that pinch for a good 30 seconds and asked him a question in French.

title: My Three Favorite Terrible Cover Songs
description: I dont know why, but Ive always loved novelty songs. The first cassette I ever asked my parents for was Weird Al in 3-D. One of my favorite subgenres of novelty music is the wrong and inappropriate cover song, as pioneered by the great William Shatner. (My other favorite subgenre? Jazz-singing rodents.) Of course there are a million awful cover songs out there, but only a few are truly, spectacularly Shatner-level awful. Rolling Stone recently took a poll of the 10 worst covers, and Miley Cyruss cover of Smells Like Teen Spirit won first prize. Ill leave that one out, was kind of obvious. So here are my top three. They are the worst, and I love them.

title: Wheelies: The King of the Road Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Romneys Early-State Obstacle Course
description: Were getting to the point where its worth paying a fair amount of attention to the early-state polls. At the same time, with all the volatility in the Republican field, its sometimes hard to tell whether a strong poll in Iowa or a weak one in Florida reflects something unique to that state or a national trend instead.

title: Fee-Free A.T.M.s, in Exchange for Advertising
description: A young New York entrepreneur has one word in response to complaints about high A.T.M. fees: Advertising.

title: U.S. 3, Slovenia 2: Pushing Early on Offense, the U.S. Gets by Slovenia
description: 2:13 p.m. | Updated Edson Buddle, Clint Dempsey and Jozy Altidore scored first-half goals as a surprisingly offense-minded United States national team beat Slovenia, 3-2, in a friendly in Ljubljana on Tuesday afternoon.

title: Eclectic Lineup for Humana Festival of New American Plays
description: Premieres of works by Lisa Kron, Idris Goodwin, Mona Mansour, Courtney Baron, Greg Kotis and Lucas Hnath will be offered at next springs Humana Festival of New American Plays in Louisville, Ky., one of the most prestigious showcases for original theater in the country.

title: The 2011 CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund Awards
description: Designer Joseph Altuzarra takes the top prize at the 2011 CFDA Awards.

title: Mayor Bloomberg's Press Conference
description: November 15, 2011  Mayor Bloomberg addresses the clearing of Zuccotti Park at a news conference.

title: For Putin, a Peace Prize for a Decision to Go to War
description: BEIJING  The Chinese committee that awarded this years Confucius Peace Prize minced no words in honoring the winner, Vladimir V. Putin, prime minister of Russia.

title: Only One in Three Full-Time Students Pays Full Tuition
description: Many students are actually paying less now to attend college than they would have five years ago, Judith Scott-Clayton writes over on the Economix blog. (The Choice somehow missed this post a few days ago, but its still worth bringing to your attention today.)

title: ReDigi, Reseller of Digital Music, Responds to Industry Criticism
description: In Tuesdays New York Times, Ben Sisario wrote about ReDigi, a company in Cambridge, Mass., that has taken up a novel mission  developing a system for reselling digital music files that is legal and secure. Last week, the Recording Industry Association of America sent the company a cease-and-desist letter, saying that the service, in fact, infringes on copyright.

title: For Australian Golfers, Success Starts at Home and Continues Abroad
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Like a proud parent, the Australian golf legend Greg Norman snapped a photograph of the television screen for posterity. It was late Sunday afternoon on April 10, and three Aussie golfers  Geoff Ogilvy, Jason Day and Adam Scott  were in a logjam near the top of the leader board in the final round of the Masters.

title: F.D.A. Is Urged to Issue More Alerts About Drug Risks
description: The Food and Drug Administrations efforts to issue safety signals when it is alerted to potential health risks of prescription drugs isnt working well to notify the public or guide doctors to alternative medicines, new research indicates.

title: More Parents Sought for Teacher Conferences
For the N.B.A., the Battle Goes to Court
description: The N.B.A.s idiocy finally hit the big fan on Monday, spraying whatever tiny shards remained of the leagues credibility into the ether. The players finally had enough of the leagues collective bargaining and hit the red button sitting in front of them, even as you got the sense they had no idea what the red button meant. To them, it represented their only way to fight back against owners intent on crushing them and braying about it afterward.

title: Brooklyns Dekalb Market: A Tidy Flea, but What to Buy?
description: WHEN I visit a rural area, which I do only with great reluctance, there is often someone there urging me to awake before dawn with flashlight and steaming thermos, as if for a whale watch, and visit the local flea market.

title: The Get | Cole Haan Wingtips
description: Once you get a load of these new hand-stained brogues from Cole Haan, you will never think of a wingtip in quite the same way again. For its winter collection, the iconic American brand worked hard at blending its comfortable technology (Nike Air cushioning  even in heels) with cutting-edge design. This includes everything from sexy stilettos in the Maria Sharapova line to these iridescent oxfords for women. At first glance they seem totally traditional, except for an odd sheen. But shine a light on them and youre suddenly wearing twinkle toes.

title: Mens Soccer Top Seeds: North Carolina, Creighton, Connecticut, and Boston College
description: The University of North Carolina is the No. 1 seed in the 2011 N.C.A.A. mens soccer championship tournament. Creighton is the No. 2 seed, the University of Connecticut is third and Boston College is fourth. The first round begins Thursday, with the national championship game scheduled for Dec. 11.

title: Other Sites Hope N.Y. Raid Will Energize Cause
description: BOSTON  Hours after New York Police officers raided Occupy Wall Street, the protest that spurred a nationwide movement of demonstrators camping in front of government buildings and financial institutions, protestors around the country said Tuesday that they hoped the breakup of the New York encampment would energize the movement but that it would otherwise have little impact on their own protests.

title: Daily Report: Apple Now Wants Your Workplace
description: A lot has been written about Apples appeal with consumers. Nick Wingfield, a Times technology reporter, takes a look at how the company is faring with corporate customers.

title: Drawing Each and Every Tiny Palestinian for the Cover
description: Our most recent cover was quite the challenge for the illustrator Tim Enthoven. He spent 60 hours illustrating 1,028 people for our article on Gilad Shalit. By hand.

title: A New Poll Shows a Tight Four-Way Race in Iowa
description: With seven weeks to go before the Iowa caucuses, a new poll finds the contest there far from settled, with four Republican candidates locked in a tight race and most voters saying they could still change their minds.

title: Answers on Felons and Gun Rights
description: Updated | 4:40 p.m. On Tuesday, the reporter Michael Luo of The Times is answering reader questions prompted by his recent article on how easy it is in many states for people with felony convictions to get their gun rights reinstated.

title: Perry Proposes Overhaul of Washington
description: BETTENDORF, Iowa  Gov. Rick Perry of Texas on Tuesday announced a proposal to alter the federal government that ranks among the most radical plans offered by any major Republican presidential candidate this year  and one that legal analysts say will almost surely never happen: making Congress operate part time with half pay, and ending lifetime tenure for federal judges.

title: Slice Aims to Organize Your Shopping, Electronically
description: As shopping swings into gear for the holidays, a new service called Slice aims to help consumers organize and track their purchases electronically. Slices service first appeared earlier this year as a tool on Yahoo, and last month it introduced its own Web site. Now, its unveiling a mobile app that lets you track your items on your iPhone. (An Android version is also in the works).

title: Intiman Theater Cites Progress in Fund Raising for Summer Season
description: The Intiman Theater in Seattle may be down, but its not yet out. After suspending its operations the financially struggling regional theater is trying to raise $1 million to stage four productions next summer, and the board announced on Monday that it had so far raised $100,000 from board pledges and $100,000 from an anonymous donor, according to The Seattle Times.

title: Assembly Speaker in No Mood to Discuss His Bruise
description: WASHINGTON  Sheldon Silver, speaker of the New York State Assembly, is always tough to pin down, but never more so than this week, as the most powerful Democrat in the State Legislature has repeatedly declined to release basic information about a bruising injury to his face and head.

title: U.F.C. Sues State Over Ban on Mixed Martial Arts Bouts
description: For four years, the Ultimate Fighting Championship has lobbied the New York State Legislature to overturn its 1997 ban on live professional mixed martial arts fighting.

title: Maine Republicans Want to Get There (Vote Suppression) From Here (Vote Turnout)
description: Republicans in Maine are a determined lot.

title: Moving the Movement: Analyzing the Future of Occupy Wall Street
description: Overview | What is the current status of the Occupy Wall Street movement? What effects has it had so far, and where is it going from here? In this lesson, students react to current news, read an Opinion piece about its role in history, and do an analysis of the strengths and weaknesses of the movement to make predictions about its future.

title: Just a Minute: Keeping the Press at Bay in Zuccotti Park
description: During Tuesday mornings police action to clear Zuccotti Park, the home and birthplace of the Occupy Wall Street protest, members of the press were cleared out, too. Brian Stelter describes the scene early Tuesday morning, as he interviewed reporters who were prevented from covering the way the police carried out the order by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to remove the protesters from the park.

title: Report Calls for Changes in the Energy Department
description: WASHINGTON  Already under fire for granting a $535 million federal loan guarantee to Solyndra, the Department of Energy now faces a critique from within.

title: Bain Capital Seeks to Cash Out of LinkedIn
description: With LinkedIns shares still flying high six months after their debut, one of the companys early backers is cashing out.

title: Naked Ambition | Marina Abramovics Museum Gala
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Charlie Rose and Gayle King Join The Early Show on CBS
description: 1:35 p.m. | Updated CBS News on Tuesday announced a top-to-bottom reboot of The Early Show, its long-suffering morning news broadcast, with Charlie Rose and Gayle King at the helm. The moves will take effect in January.

title: After Almost 11,000 Miles, Jay Leno Closes In on a Year Without Refueling His Chevy Volt
description: LOS ANGELES  Jay Leno is nearing a milestone.

title: More Wizardry for Harry Potter Director: A Dr. Who Film
description: After spending much of the last decade directing films in the Harry Potter series, David Yates is ready to embark on a new film franchise: Dr. Who, Daily Variety reported. This British television series, which ran from 1963 to 1989 before beginning a second broadcast life in 2005, is one of the BBCs most popular exports.

title: In Its Ads, Target Sees Itself as Playing the Helpful Elf
description: Another combatant is climbing into the ring for the battle for consumer dollars as the 2011 Christmas shopping season gets under way.

title: And the Winner of the New York Times Comedy Challenge Is
description: Jim Gaffigan, whose lack of sympathy with slow-moving pedestrians in Times Square  so they use walkers? theyre still in his way  made 2,102 of you laugh.

title: After an Earlier Misstep, a Minutely Planned Raid
description: Hundreds of police officers were involved, some of them wearing riot helmets. The overnight hours of Monday into Tuesday were chosen because Zuccotti Park would be at its emptiest. The operation was kept secret from all but a few high-ranking officers, with others initially being told that they were embarking on an exercise.

title: Miami After Dark (Without the Swells)
description: There are some easy tricks to keeping things cheap in Miami. Before you go, keep an eye out for flight specials and do some savvy hotel room bidding on Priceline. Once youre there, spend your days on the beaches of South Beach (free) and at the galleries of the Design District (free), while taking your meals at Cuban diners and sandwich shops (cheap and cheap). (See If You Go, below, for details.)

title: A Complicated Maneuver for Control of Yahoo
description: The Yahoo sale process may be taking a detour.

title: Should Penn State Bow Out of Bowl Consideration?
description: On the Op-Ed page of Tuesdays Times, the columnist Joe Nocera took a hard look at what he saw as seriously warped priorities at Penn State after the child sexual abuse scandal surrounding the football teams former defensive coordinator Jerry Sandusky. Nocera wrote that he was not only bothered by the institutions response over the years to reports of possible abuse, but how the student body has reacted since Sanduskys arrest and the subsequent firing of Coach Joe Paterno.

title: Photo Replay: Nov.15
description: A view of the day in sports, with stunt drivers and World Cup soccer qualifying.

title: Support Workers' Union Will Sue City Over Layoffs
Are Teenagers Really Having Less Sex?
description: The number of unmarried teenagers between the ages of 15 and 19 who reported to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention that theyve had sex has dropped below 50 percent. The C.D.C.s research, based on data collected from 2006 to 2010, shows that about 43 percent of unmarried teenage girls and 42 percent of unmarried teenage boys say, on a survey administered by a C.D.C. interviewer but conducted largely on a laptop with headphones, that theyve had sexual intercourse at least once. In 2002, the last year such a report was published, 51.1 percent of girls and 60.4 percent of boys said they had had sex by 19.

title: Romney Assails Obama for Lazy Remark
description: 4:35 p.m. | Updated  COLUMBIA, S.C.  Mitt Romney attacked President Obama on Tuesday for making what Mr. Romney described as disparaging remarks about Americans, singling out comments over the weekend in which the president said the United States had gotten lazy in trying to attract new business.

title: Monetary Fund Urges China to Ease State Controls on Banking
description: SHANGHAI  The International Monetary Fund warned China on Tuesday that tight government management of the nations banking and financial system was creating a steady build-up in vulnerabilities that could eventually damp economic growth.

title: American Migration Reaches Record Low
description: The share of Americans who move their homes in a year has reached a record low, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: New Report Cites Strong Start-Up Culture of Dance in the City
description: Dance organizations in New York City are entrepreneurial and innovative, despite having to scramble for money and rely on part-time, contract and volunteer labor, according to a 30-page report by Dance/NYC, the citys dance advocacy group, which will be released this week. The group drew on information about 127 nonprofit dance makers and organizations, culled from the statewide Cultural Data Project, which offers detailed data on finances, programs and employment in arts and culture.

title: A Missions Troubles Offer Window on an Unsteady Region in Afghanistan
description: They came carrying cases of frozen meat, downloaded episodes of their favorite TV shows, baby wipes and enough firepower to light up the surrounding mountains for three days. First Platoon, Charlie Company would be spending the next week protecting the only road in Kunar Province from inside of Checkpoint 2.5; a cramped, heavily fortified American outpost.

title: Almodvar on Almodvar
description: Pedro Almodvar had put on his sunglasses, even though we were in a basement office. Theres too much light, he said of the fluorescents. I work with light, but I dont like too much. Almodvar appears just as you imagine him, like a stubby human exclamation point, inverted in the Spanish style, topped with a porcupine poof of gray-white hair. Hes charming. Dont worry, he whispered when a publicist indicated that our time was already running short.Im the boss here.

title: One Man, Two Guvnors Coming to Broadway From Britain
description: The National Theater of Britains production of One Man, Two Guvnors, directed by Nicholas Hytner, is coming to Broadway in the spring. James Corden, who is reprising his role as the hapless Francis Henshall, has appeared on Broadway before in The History Boys and in a BBC television sitcom, Gavin and Stacey.

title: ATP Finals: Will There Be Any Room for a New Face?
description: Eight men have qualified for next weeks Barclays ATP World Tour Finals at the O2 Arena in London, a considerable achievement for each given the number of players vying to play in the year-end championships and the scarcity of available spots. But based on the recent distribution of tennis most sought-after hardware, it would be reasonable to suggest that half of them might as well book an early flight now.

title: European Union Softens Bid to Rein in Ratings Agencies
description: BRUSSELS  The European Commission on Tuesday backed away from tough measures to blunt the power of credit ratings agencies, but insisted that its new proposals could still help tamp down volatility in the financial markets.

title: Discover Canada, With the Help of Canadians
description: For travelers in Canada seeking the midnight sun, native wood carvings or the best mountains to ski, theres a new online resource.

title: Landmarks Panel Rejects Second Penthouse Plan for Puck Building
description: The Landmarks Preservation Commission has not shut the door entirely on Jared Kushners plan to construct a residential penthouse atop the Puck Building at Lafayette and Houston Streets, but it told him Tuesday that he had to try a lot harder to reduce its bulk and visibility.

title: Iraqi Cabinet Approves Royal Dutch Shells Natural Gas Contract
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqs cabinet approved a multibillion-dollar contract on Tuesday for Royal Dutch Shell, the Anglo-Dutch energy giant, to collect the vast amount of natural gas emitted, and currently burned off, as oil is pumped to the surface at three major oil fields in the south.

title: New Consumer Agency Beefs Up Its Staff
description: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is going through a growth spurt.

title: After Eviction, Zuccotti Protesters Scramble to Respond
description: Occupy Wall Street protesters were trying to organize a response to their eviction early Tuesday morning from Zuccotti Park in Lower Manhattan.

title: Greek Polenta With Onions and Raisins
description: This is adapted from a recipe I came across in The Glorious Foods of Greece, by Diane Kochilas. During World War II, when many Greeks died of starvation, cornmeal was one of the few foods people had to eat. Older Greeks eschewed it after the war because it reminded them of those difficult years. Diane has unearthed some wonderful dishes in her travels throughout the country. I use my easy oven method rather than the traditional top-of-the-stove method for cooking the polenta.

title: Yeasted Country Bread With Cornmeal
description: Cornmeal is used in many breads in the Mediterranean and southern Europe, especially in Turkey and Portugal. It contributes wonderful texture.

title: Class Parent: What if Nobody Wants to Play With Me?
A Longer Stairway to a Better Complexion?
description: LIKE the progressively more-complex choreography on Dancing With the Stars, expanded steps are coming to skin care.

title: Levin and McCain Strike Deal Over Detainee Handling
description: 7:50 p.m. | Updated A highly charged political dispute over the handling of terrorism detainees is taking a turn: the top Democrat and Republican on the Senate Armed Services Committee have reached a tentative agreement on a proposal. But their deal cut out the White House and could provoke a rebellion by other Senate Democrats.

title: MF Global Trustee Seeks Approval of Customer Claims Proceedings
description: The court-appointed trustee overseeing the liquidation of MF Globals brokerage unit sought permission on Tuesday to set up a claims process for customers of the failed firm, helping pave the way for additional payouts.

title: What a Cain Administration Might Look Like
description: While Herman Cains foreign policy stumbles have raised questions about his command of the facts, he says he would consult with military officials and other expert advisers to guide him through the thicket of world affairs.

title: A Fierce Battle of Video Games
description: The world of multiplayer, online video war games is dominated by the Battlefield and Call of Duty series. Since their original release in the early 2000s, these series have been competing for market prominence.

title: The Place | Florida, Part One
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: NYCs Mayor Bloomberg Confronts Occupy Wall Street
description: Like so many other people in New York, Ive been riveted by the reports of last nights confrontation between the city and the Occupy Wall Street protesters  the 1:30 am police raid to clear Zuccotti Park of tents and sleeping bags, followed by a courtroom hearing.

title: S.B.A. Loan Questions Answered on C-Span
description: On Monday, The Agenda took to the airwaves to talk about the Small Business Administrations loan programs. Well, not really the airwaves, as the program appeared on cable. For about 40 minutes on C-Spans Washington Journal, I spoke about the S.B.A.s record year for lending and answered questions from small-business owners.

title: F.H.A. Audit Sees Possible Bailout Need
description: WASHINGTON  Chances are nearly 50 percent that the Federal Housing Administration will need a bailout next year if the housing market deteriorates further, the agencys independent auditor said in a report released Tuesday.

title: Israeli Army May Need to Hit Gaza, General Says
description: JERUSALEM  Israels military chief of staff warned Tuesday that the repeated rounds of escalated violence in the south would eventually require Israel to carry out another large-scale military operation in Hamas-controlled Gaza.

description: Lens: OWS

title: Pictures of the Day: New York and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from New York, Afghanistan, Yemen and Haiti.

title: For One Man, Hawaii Is a Land of Problems
description: In a voice-over at the beginning of The Descendants, Matt King (George Clooney) challenges the myth, endemic among mainlanders, that Hawaii, where he lives, is a paradise on earth. His brief rant is buttressed by images of poverty and grime that are powerful but also slightly misleading, since Matts story is not  or at least not explicitly  one of deprivation or social inequality.

title: Clearing a Park, and Reviving a Movement
description: Give Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg credit  he cleared a park and probably revived an occupy movement all at once, and without the tear gas, nightsticks and rubber bullets that seem de rigueur in Oakland.

title: Interviews With Giffords and Sandusky Draw Viewers
description: Two exclusive interviews provided large ratings boosts to their respective networks on Monday night.

title: The Reanimator
description: 1 1/2 ounces straight rye whiskey

title: 11 States Seek Relief From No Child Provisions, in Return for Raising Standards
description: Eleven states applied for waivers exempting them from key provisions of the No Child Left Behind law by the federal governments first deadline, promising in return to adopt higher standards and carry out other elements of the Obama administrations school improvement agenda, the Department of Education said on Tuesday.

title: What Can I Drink at Thanksgiving Besides Wine?
description: Q.

title: Player Ratings: Slovenia (2) vs. U.S. (3)
description: It was hard to see it all through the fog in Ljubljana, but there was a lot to take out of the United States national teams 3-2 victory over Slovenia on Tuesday.

title: Pictures of the Day: Zuccotti Park and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from New York, Afghanistan, Yemen and Haiti.

title: The Times Names a New Restaurant Critic and Dining Editor
description: The New York Times named Pete Wells, its Dining editor for the last five years and a veteran of Food & Wine and Details magazines, as its new chief restaurant critic, the newspaper announced on Tuesday.

title: Players Express Frustration With Lockout
description: As the N.B.A. labor dispute slides further toward nuclear winter, as Commissioner David Stern put it, players are not keeping their thoughts quiet. Theyre frustrated, want to get back to playing basketball, and are turning to Twitter to express themselves. And as always, proper spelling and punctuation are optional on Twitter, so read their thoughts without your grammar police hat on.

title: Baby Sweet Potatoes, Big Enough to Stand Alone
description: Heres the best argument against putting marshmallows on the sweet potatoes: Serve baby sweet potatoes, which need only be scrubbed and roasted to turn into rich candy themselves.

title: For Costas, Sandusky Interview Came as a Surprise
description: When Bob Costas arrived at the studios of the new NBC newsmagazine program  Rock Center Monday night, he was prepared to interview Joseph Amendola, the lawyer for Jerry Sandusky, the man at the center of the pedophilia accusations that have rocked Penn State University.

title: Leap of Faith Heading to Broadway Next Fall
description: Broadway producers are planning a fall 2012 opening for Leap of Faith, a musical starring four-time Tony Award nominee Raul Esparza (Company) that was adapted from the 1992 Steve Martin film about an evangelical con man who is offered a chance at redemption. Thomas Viertel, one of the lead producers, said on Tuesday that closed-door developmental readings of the musical last week drew strong feedback from an invited audience, including potential investors, leading the producers to deem the show ready for Broadway.

title: Mining Lifes Hardships for a Vein of Comedy
description: Laughs are always erupting, like bubbles from the depths of tar pits, in the writings of Samuel Beckett. I sometimes wonder if his reputation for annihilating pessimism owes as much to photographs of him in the winter of his life  the glowering eyes, the craggy face and the set mouth beneath a shock of hair that seemed to scream, Egad! No more!  as it does to his actual writing. A good production of Waiting for Godot is as funny as any given episode of Curb Your Enthusiasm. (In fact, Larry Davids vision of life may be a few shades darker than Becketts.)

title: Prosecutions for Bank Fraud Fall Sharply
description: Federal prosecutions for financial institution fraud have tumbled over the last decade, despite the recent troubles in the banking sector, according to a new analysis of Justice Department data by the Transactional Records Access Clearinghouse (TRAC) at Syracuse University.

title: Female Comedians, Breaking the Taste-Taboo Ceiling
description: In a Rolling Stone interview from 1979, Johnny Carson, host of Tonight and the most important gatekeeper in comedy for decades, gave his take on female comics.

title: Familiar Police Presence in Park Says He Was Kept in the Dark
description: Even the Hipster Cop was not hip to it.

title: Heat and Friction, Sexual and Racial
description: Foul-mouthed grit and working-class angst are the prevailing moods in two taut solo shows at this years Brits Off Broadway series at 59E59 Theaters, though one production is more convincing than the other.

title: Kansas City Bishop Makes Deal to Avoid More Criminal Charges
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  In a deal to avoid a second round of criminal charges, a Roman Catholic bishop in Kansas City has agreed to meet monthly with a county prosecutor to detail every suspicious episode involving abuse of a child in his diocese for the next five years.

title: Styled to a T | Three as Four
description: The People
