title: Smith Electric to Build Trucks in the Bronx
description: New York would never be mistaken for the Motor City, but on Tuesday, Smith Electric Vehicles announced that it intended to assemble electric trucks in the South Bronx, adding 100 jobs to the region. A package of more than $6 million in state and city incentives sweetened the deal.

title: Catching Up on TV Shows, Past and Present
description: THE ADVENTURES OF TINTIN: SEASON ONE (Shout! Factory, 2 discs, $19.93) Before Steven Spielbergs Adventures of Tintin arrives this winter and imprints its motion-capture versions of Tintin, Snowy and Captain Haddock on our brains, devoted readers of Hergs comic strips might want to check out this 1991-92 television series. A Canadian-French production that was later shown on HBO, its pedestrian, as far as the drama is concerned, but has one inestimable advantage for the purist: The 2-D animation remains absolutely faithful to the look of the original. Season 1 adapts seven of the Tintin books in 13 episodes, including classics like The Crab With the Golden Claws and The Blue Lotus.

title: OWS at the Crossroads
description: Now that Mayor Michael Bloomberg and the New York courts have taken the occupy out of Occupy Wall Street, theres a lot of buzz about what the movement should do next. Thats obviously not up for me to decide, nor do I want to, but the group has reached a crossroads.

title: App Smart Extra: Stylin Styluses
description: Last weeks App Smart column, on note-taking apps, mentioned a few apps aimed at people who like to scrawl on their tablets, whether with a finger or a stylus. That prompted a few letters from readers who wondered which stylus they should use.

title: Services That Feed Nostalgia for the Recent Digital Past
description: A year ago today, I spent the day working from a local coffee shop. As the sun began to set, I picked up some takeout from my favorite eatery and spent the rest of the night writing in my living room.

title: Big City Book Club: Coming Attractions
description: Next up for the Big City Book Club is Breakfast at Tiffanys, Truman Capotes classic 1958 novella of bittersweet Manhattan self-invention. (You can catch the live online conversation on the City Room blog on Tuesday, Nov. 29, between 1 and 4 p.m.) Some of you may be reading the book for the first time, but I suspect youve all seen the 1961 Blake Edwards film that followed. The book and movie are, of course very different in tone, which is something well be talking about. In anticipation of our conversation, Ive pulled some articles from The New York Timess archives that cover the complications of adapting the book for Hollywood (pdf) at a time, well in advance of Pretty Woman, when depictions of prostitution werent necessarily welcome onscreen, including Janet Maslins review of Fifth Avenue, 5 A.M., Sam Wassons recent book about the making of the film.

title: Tip of the Week: Barcode Scanning Apps
description: Serious shoppers can use their smartphones camera for more than just snapping photos of the things they want to buy. With a barcode scanner app installed, the phones camera can be used to scan an items bar code (also known as the Universal Product Code). Once scanned, most apps present a list of places and prices the scanned item can be found, which makes comparison-shopping even easier on the go. RedLaser and PriceGrabber are two apps that offer iOS and Android versions, as does Pic2Shop, which also works on Windows Phone. Search your phones app store for others.

title: Judge Temporarily Bars Eviction of Boston Protesters
description: BOSTON  A judge granted a temporary order on Wednesday requiring the city to refrain from any police action to evict the Occupy Boston demonstrators from Dewey Square, where a small city of about 150 tents has functioned for a month and a half.

title: Reader Feedback: Why American Migration Might Be Falling
description: In response to my post Tuesday on the record low level of migration in the United States last year, an astute reader referred me to a recent paper in The Journal of Economic Perspectives on this subject.

title: To Behold, Maybe Even to Read
description: This years best gift book, for a crazy person you really, really like  as opposed to those people for whom you simply need to purchase a safe, distinguished, booklike object  is almost certainly this one: WHAT THE HELL ARE YOU DOING?: THE ESSENTIAL DAVID SHRIGLEY (Norton, $35). Its a funny, sick, morally stimulating mind-bender, the best bathroom book of the new decade.

title: The Economy Isnt Obamas Only Challenge
description: Theres a lot of talk now about the many reasons that President Obama faces a perilous path to re-election  starting, of course, with the torpid economy and a dysfunctional political system. But I wouldnt overlook the underlying, more structural challenge in the electoral map that would be vexing Mr. Obama and his strategists even if the economic picture werent quite so bleak.

title: Interim Greek Government Wins Confidence Vote
description: ATHENS  Greeces new interim government comfortably won a vote of confidence on Wednesday, though the unity of the coalition, which must secure crucial rescue financing and save the country from default, appeared tenuous.

title: A Self-Immolation in Tiananmen Square Is Reported
description: A man set himself on fire in Chinas heavily policed Tiananmen Square last month, according a report in The Daily Telegraph on Wednesday, in the first known case of a self-immolation at the politically sensitive site in Beijing in nearly a decade.

title: Evernote Takes On Web Reading With Clearly
description: Evernote, an application that has gained momentum by providing an easy way for people to quickly capture things they want to remember, is determined to branch out past its humble note-taking origins.

title: Fund-Raiser for Liu Is Accused of Role in Illegal Donations
description: A fund-raiser for the New York City comptroller, John C. Liu, whose campaign finances are under federal investigation, was arrested on Wednesday morning on charges that he helped illegally funnel thousands of dollars into Mr. Lius campaign account, according to court papers and people briefed on the case.

title: Berkeley Reveals Plan for Academic Center in China
description: SHANGHAI  The University of California, Berkeley announced this week that it plans to open a large research and teaching facility here as part of a broader plan to bolster its presence in China.

title: Chrysler to Hire 1,100 Workers in Toledo, Ohio
description: TOLEDO, Ohio  Chrysler said Wednesday that it would add 1,100 jobs at a sport utility vehicle plant here as it spends $1.7 billion developing new models for its Jeep brand.

title: Irving, Maynard, and Me (Wonkish)
description: Im going to be a bit grouchy right now, and unfairly so. Via Mark Thoma, I see that David Glasner is worried about what appears to be a need for negative real interest rates, and suggests that this may be close to concerns about the liquidity trap.

title: Look of the Moment | Joan Smalls
description: The Look: In the Mood for Love. An intricate black lace dress and long sleeves are all romance, even when paired with tougher Deco-metallic heels.

title: A Record Win for Coach K
description: Duke Coach Mike Krzyzewski set the mens Division I record for coaching victories by beating Michigan State on Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Chevrolet Camaro ZL1 Puts the Power, and the Top, Down
description: Shown on Tuesday, Nov. 15: 2013 Chevrolet Camaro ZL1 convertible.

title: Lightning Round
description: David Brooks: Gail, there have been a lot of news events of minor importance hitting us all at once so lets play lightning round. First, did you see the Herman Cain video clip on Libya, the one in which he is asked whether he supports Obamas policy there and he stumbles around desperately trying to remember which country Libya is (the little one north of Israel maybe?), what just happened there (Lawrence of Arabia?) and what Obamas policy might actually be.

title: TimesCast | November 16, 2011
description: Arab League foreign ministers meet to formalize Syria's suspension; Hamas' public relations efforts; and the media blackout of the clearing of Zuccotti Park.

title: Where Is Microsofts Office for Tablets?
description: During a very brief annual shareholder meeting on Tuesday, Microsofts chief executive, Steven A. Ballmer, said: We are in an era where the range of smart devices is continuing to expand. That is a fantastic thing for Microsoft.

title: CO2 on the Up and Up
description: To my eye, this animated graph, produced by the federal Earth Systems Research Laboratory, is one of the best attempts to put the recent human-driven surge in carbon dioxide concentrations in the atmosphere into long-term context:

title: Warning to Rahm and Ari Emanuel: Big Brother Was Watching, and He Has a Book
description: Zeke Emanuel, perhaps the least-known brother in the power trio that includes Rahm and Ari, has written a memoir of his childhood and adolescence as a member of the Emanuel family, his publisher said on Wednesday.

title: DVDs, From Fresh Offerings to Old Favorites
description: We keep reading that the silver disc has died and gone to technology heaven, its place to be taken by streaming media from the Internet cloud. But if DVDs and Blu-rays are obsolete, they are showing an awful lot of life this holiday season, with a wide selection of new and classic titles presented with depth, definition and supplementary features that streaming video is not yet in a position to provide.

title: Angry Landscapes Up Close and Far
description: The Angel Esmeralda, the title story in Don DeLillos first ever collection of short fiction, is a dazzlingly told tale of despair and ruination, the dream of redemption and the testing of faith. Set in the Bronx and featuring a nun on the lookout for a miracle, this 1994 story prefigures portions of Mr. DeLillos 1997 masterwork, Underworld, but it also stands on its own as a beautifully realized and singular work of fiction.

title: A Long, Long Road to Recycling Nuclear Fuel
description: The question of what to do with spent nuclear fuel from civilian power reactors has stirred renewed interest in reprocessing  that is, chopping up the fuel, retrieving materials that can power a reactor and possibly recovering the most troublesome waste products so they can be broken up in the reactor into easier-to-handle elements.

title: Xing Wu Pan Criminal Complaint
description: Xing Wu Pan, who gathered donations for a citywide candidate in New York in the 2013 election, is accused of fraud. The candidate is said to be New York City comptroller, John C. Liu.

title: Jets Head to Denver With Memories of a Season-Altering Victory
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  It looked bleak for the Jets, safety Jim Leonhard said. Like a complete long shot, guard Matt Slauson said. Just hope and pray, running back LaDainian Tomlinson said.

title: Joe Paternos House and the Estate Tax Question
description: So why did Joe Paterno, the former Penn State football coach, sell his home to his wife for the paltry sum of $1?

title: Appeals Court Allows New Trial for Bruno
description: A federal appeals court on Wednesday overturned, as was expected, the corruption conviction of Joseph L. Bruno, the upstate Republican who was once one of the most powerful men in New York State government.

title: Ristretto | Bear Pond Espresso: How Much Sexy?
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: From Bad Boy to Good Dog
description: JOHN BARTLETT, the mens wear designer, stood outside an empty store on Seventh Avenue near Charles Street in the West Village. Until recently he would have been inside, selling his mens line to charmed shoppers. Some would have known him from his glory days as a fashion darling who staged hot-ticket runway shows and made pronouncements to the news media. Now, the windows were covered with butcher paper; with some trepidation, Mr. Bartlett, 48, stuck his head inside the debris-covered space and sighed as he looked at racks and shelves that once held his assertive and playful clothes.

title: App Design and Cloud Work
description: The author and creative team discuss the new app version of 1,000 Places to See Before You Die, and Quentin Hardy finds new uses for cloud computing.

title: The Washington Report with David Sanger and Kerry Nolan
description: The Washington Report with David Sanger and Kerry Nolan

title: Exiled Tibetan Abbot Rebukes China Over Monks Troubles
description: The chief abbot and spiritual leader-in-exile of a Tibetan monastery at the epicenter of a series of self-immolation protests against Chinese rule spoke out forcefully in New York on Wednesday, detailing what he called new and harsh repressive measures taken against the monks at the monastery since the immolations started in March.

title: Shooting for Global Change
description: Some serious photographers might cringe at being called amateurs. Not Antonio Amendola  he wears the badge proudly.

title: Adele Speaks (on Her Blog)
description: Writing on her blog, the British soul singer Adele joked with fans that she was practicing a mime show after undergoing surgery in Massachusetts to stanch the bleeding on a benign polyp on her vocal cords.

title: With a Russian in a Tajik Jail, Moscow Aims Its Reprisal at Migrant Workers
description: MOSCOW  The imprisonment of a Russian citizen in Tajikistan has touched off reprisals against ethnic Tajik migrant workers in Russia who say they have been unjustly targeted for arrest and deportation.

title: TimesCast | Suspending Syria
description: November 16, 2011 - Arab League foreign ministers meet in Morocco to formally suspend Syria.

title: Play About Abuse in Ireland Will Arrive in New York
description: A critically acclaimed one-man play about institutional abuse of children that created waves in Ireland when it was first produced in 2003 will be coming to New York. James X, written and performed by Gerard Mannix Flynn, will begin performances on Dec. 6 and open on Dec. 9 at 45 Bleecker Theater.

title: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Afghanistan, Lebanon, Italy and Russia.

title: Noormans Kil
description: TO the list of newfangled bar trends (speakeasies, rooftop lounges, faux Victorian saloons) comes another  specialty bars that focus on a single liquor. Case in point: Noormans Kil, a whiskey-and-grilled-cheese bar that opened in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, in August.

title: Its Not Just the Economy
description: A few weeks back, Nate Silver, The Timess resident statistical wizard, wrote a fascinating cover article for the magazine about President Obamas chances for re-election, based on a bunch of different data. One challenge facing Obama that hasnt been talked about, though, is the modern disadvantage inherent in being a Democratic nominee. Heres a column I just wrote over on the Caucus blog, putting this campaign in the context of recent political history.

title: Its Delicious. But Is It a Vegetable?
description: Im finding it hard to figure out what, exactly, Republicans think about vegetables. Herman Cain, who as we know always chooses his words with the greatest of care, called vegetable pizza sissy pizza on Monday. But House Republicans are suggesting that pizza is itself a vegetable. So does that mean all pizza is for sissies?

title: Company Offers Web Sites a Button for Visitors Privacy Settings
description: For businesses that want an easy way to put a privacy button on their Web sites, a company called BrightTag has introduced a new method for them to offer one, and for consumers to find the button.

title: Anger Erupts in Thailand Over Plans for Amnesty
description: BANGKOK  The Thai government faced a political uproar on Wednesday after details surfaced of a proposed prisoner amnesty that the countrys opposition says is designed to pardon Thaksin Shinawatra, the prime minister ousted in the 2006 military coup.

title: Opposition May Rejoin Political System in Myanmar
description: BANGKOK  After more than two decades of persecution by Myanmars military, the party of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi says it will decide Friday whether to rejoin the political system, a potential milestone for a country that appears to be gradually emerging from years of dictatorship and oppression.

title: Glee Hitting Some Sour Notes With Viewers
description: O Glee fans, where hast thou gone? A year ago the musical dramedy was a dominant force for Fox on Tuesday nights in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic, easily finishing first in the segment.

title: A TV Character and a TV Critic, Both Named Genzlinger: Coincidence?
description: I dont know how many Genzlingers there are in the United States, but I do know there are so few of us that when one encounters another to whom hes not related, both consider it an odds-defying miracle on a par with winning the lottery or being struck by lightning. So you can imagine my surprise when, on Tuesday nights episode of New Girl on Fox, a character named Genzlinger turned up.

title: Fox Plans Early Sneak Preview to Help Film
description: Updated, 5:38 p.m. | LOS ANGELES  Whats old is new: 20th Century Fox said on Wednesday that it would use a modern twist on one of Hollywoods hoariest marketing tactics  the sneak preview  to help sell the forthcoming comedic drama We Bought a Zoo.

title: Photo Replay: Nov.16
description: A look back at the day in sports, from the South East Asian Games to the N.I.T. Season Tip-Off.

title: Re-election Strategy Is Tied to a Shift on Smog
description: WASHINGTON  The summons from the president came without warning the Thursday before Labor Day. As she was driven the four blocks to the White House, Lisa P. Jackson, the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, suspected that the news would not be good. What she did not see coming was a rare public rebuke the president was about to deliver by rejecting her proposal to tighten the national standard for smog.

title: South Park Team to Keep at It for Five More Years
description: Some South Park fans wondered if the end was near for the animated series earlier this year when Trey Parker and Matt Stone turned in an episode that centered on the cynicism and unhappiness of the main characters, complete with the playing of the Fleetwood Mac song Landslide. A metaphor, maybe? Maybe not. On Wednesday Comedy Central, the channel that has shown 15 seasons of South Park, said it had signed up Mr. Parker and Mr. Stone to write, direct and edit the series through 2016, thus reaching a 20th season.

title: The Place | Florida, Part Four
description: BOAT TO TABLE

title: Young Rapper Rides Internet to the Top of the Chart
description: The Internet, we hear all the time, levels the playing field for music. With the global and instantaneous reach of digital distribution, and social medias ability to quickly amplify any trend, you might expect that the top rungs of Billboards sales charts would frequently be filled with unknown acts that have broken through with a catchy song.

title: The New Head of the M.T.A. Is Cool, for Now
description: Joseph J. Lhota, whose captainship of the lumbering vessel that is the Metropolitan Transportation Authority began this week, has a reputation for being gruff and blustery: just the qualities, many civic watchers say, that are necessary to keep the agency afloat.

title: What Should I Bring to My Boyfriends Parents Home?
description: Q.

title: Female Cadets Signal Slow Change in Afghan Police Force
description: In a class of almost 300 Afghan men, Tamana Tanha, 20, is the only woman training to become a noncommissioned police officer in Mehtar-Lam, the capital city in Laghman Province in East Afghanistan. There are approximately 20 to 30 female police officers in the entire province.

title: Live Updates: Inside MF Globals Bankruptcy Hearing
description: A proposal to set up a claims process for customers of MF Global is the focus of a hearing on Wednesday at the federal bankruptcy court in Manhattan. DealBook is proving live coverage of the proceedings beginning at 3:30 p.m.

title: Four Astronauts Are Honored by Congress
description: Congress awarded the Congressional Gold Medal on Wednesday to four American astronauts, including the first American man to orbit the Earth and the crew of the first mission to land on the moon.

title: The Caucus | Scrutinizing Newt Gingrich
description: Nov. 16, 2011  Michael D. Shear reports on the increased focus on the former speaker of the House, not only on his work for Freddie Mac but also on his shifting stands on issues.

title: Porsche Unveils Design Plans for Corporate H.Q. in Atlanta and Experience Center in L.A.
description: In two years, frequent fliers circling above Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport may glimpse a Porsche badge out their windows. The atrium of the automakers new North American headquarters, scheduled to open in late 2013, will be shaped to resemble the shield adorning Cayennes, Panameras, Caymans, 911s and Boxsters.

title: Mazda CX-5 Aims at the Compact-Crossover Market
description: Introduced on Wednesday, Nov. 16: 2013 Mazda CX-5 crossover.

title: Widening Split in Europe on the Virtue of Austerity
description: PARIS  Throughout Europes long debt crisis, Germany has prescribed the same strong remedy to its troubled neighbors: a stiff dose of fiscal discipline.

title: A Radio Gig for Bill Wyman, Erstwhile Rolling Stone Bassist
description: Bill Wyman, the former bass player for the Rolling Stones, will host a three-part series on satellite radio starting this month, Sirius XM Radio said on Wednesday. He plans on playing the songs of his favorite blues and rock musicians, discussing his musical influences and telling anecdotes from his long career, the network said.

title: Tailgating Recipes: Better Than Seven-Layer Dip
description: Football without tortilla chips is like the Colts without Peyton Manning. So any tailgate party worth its weight in cheese needs some sort of dip to go with those chips. Regan Jones, an Auburn graduate and registered dietitian, offers a variation on the classic seven-layer dip, with fresh ingredients and reduced-fat cheese. Its a nutritionist-approved option perfect for even the pickiest of football food fans, she writes.

title: Caucus Video: Scrutinizing Newt Gingrich
description: Michael D. Shear reports on the increased focus on the former speaker of the House, not only on his work for Freddie Mac but also on his shifting stands on issues.

title: Scene City: Rosy Night for Silver Screen
description: Karl Lagerfeld and Anna Wintour honor Pedro Almodvar at MoMA Film Benefit.

title: What Sweden Knows About Orgasms
description: As part of my research for my cover article in this Sundays magazine on sex-positive sex education, I read academic Kristin Lukers excellent 2006 book, When Sex Goes to School: Warring Views on Sex  and Sex Education  Since the Sixties. Near the end of the book, in the chapter Politics of Sex, she addresses the issue of sex education and pleasure in a way that really resonated with my own reporting. She tells how she visited sex-education classes in Sweden  considered a kind of nirvana for people who are comprehensive sex-ed advocates  and reported on an instructors response to the question What is an orgasm, and why do people talk about it so much?

title: A Night for Art, Fashion and Film
description: WONDERING whos behind the hedges is usually a summertime activity. But on a drizzly Tuesday evening, the lobby of the Museum of Modern Art was walled off behind verdant dividers, shielding the powerful, talented and glamorous at the museums fourth annual Film Benefit.

title: When Did Childbirth Become Everyones Business?
description: I was tricked into a natural childbirth. As the midwife hauled me from birthing tub to hallway walk to music-filled, softly lit delivery room, I kept saying, no, thanks. No more tub. No music. Narcotics. Now. Actually, birth being what it is for me, I screamed it. But my midwife was determined that I would become the natural childbirth success story Id never particularly wanted to be.

title: #OccupyWallSt Roundup, Day 61
description: Details of the raid on Zuccotti Park continued to emerge Wednesday. City Councilman Ydanis Rodriguez held a news conference Wednesday to talk about what he called an assault on him by police officers arresting him during overnight eviction Tuesday of the protesters in the park. I did not provoke the N.Y.P.D., said Mr. Rodriguez, his left eye visibly bruised and cut. He said that as he tried to cross Broadway after encountering officers nearing Zuccotti Park, an officer forced him to the ground. [Daily News]

title: Primates in the Lab: Debating the Use of Chimpanzees in Medical Research
description: Overview | In this lesson, students learn about legislation to end research on chimpanzees in the United States. They debate the issues surrounding research on chimpanzees, consider their own opinions on the topic, and draft letters to their representatives in Congress.

title: Video: When Journalists Get Evicted Along With Their Subjects
description: Brian Stelter and David Carr discuss the rough handling of journalists during the clearing out of the Occupy Wall Street protesters early Monday morning, and how that influenced the way the story was reported. For one thing, much of the footage of those events was taken by the protesters themselves, rather than journalists.

title: For Felicity Jones, Her Clothes Play the Role, Too
description: THE night before filming a wedding scene for the Sundance Film Festival hit Like Crazy, Felicity Jones had a vision of the exact shade of nail polish that would make her character  the desperately besotted Anna  seem duly childish. So the 27-year-old British actress spent hours driving from pharmacy to pharmacy in Los Angeles until she found it: OPI Baby Blue.

title: Site to Be Seen | LN-CC
description: In the luxury mens-wear market, a ton of e-tailers have emerged to service the Dior Homme fan in Boise, Idaho, and the Givenchy fanatic from Boulder, Colo. And while sites like Ssense and Park & Bond serve a broad, appeal-to-all selection of designer items in a department store sort of way, the lesser-known London-based boutique LN-CCs Web supplement takes a more specific, avant-garde approach to merchandising. There, in addition to music and books, youll find Balenciaga bombers among Junya Watanabe Fair Isle blazers and Ann Demeulemeester trousers. Here, a Maison Martin Margiela coat, about $1,768, Jil Sander sweater, about $577, Comme des Garons Homme Plus T-shirt, about $230, and Dries Van Noten pants, about $292.

title: The Inner Pat Nixon
description: It was the vice presidency that John Nance Garner invidiously compared to a bucket of warm spit, but the role of first lady of the United States has got to be just as bad. Only Eleanor Roosevelt and Hillary Clinton notched autonomous accomplishments of historical weight, though Abigail Adams and Dolley Madison also hover in the national pantheon. Sad to say, most presidential spouses  not necessarily through any fault of their own  achieve little of lasting note. Constrained by high-stakes politics and societys sexism, they can at best champion a safe, domestic cause like literacy or fitness before dissolving into the history books as yet another presidential helpmate.

title: Religious Groups Offer Help to Evicted Protesters
description: A loose coalition of religious leaders from around the city, calling themselves Occupy Faith, are trying to assist the Occupy Wall Street protesters, who are now barred from sleeping overnight at Zuccotti Park in Lower Manhattan.

title: Q. and A. With Donatella Versace on H&M Collection
description: THE Versace for H&M collection, which goes on sale in Europe today and in the United States on Saturday, has already generated enough buzz that it can qualify as a success for the designer Donatella Versace, even if she doesnt sell a single hot-pink suit. Not that thats likely, given the track record of such collaborations and the hype they create. Here, excerpts from a Q&A with Ms. Versace.

title: On the Alert for Misleading Ads
description: Kevin Tuerffs message is clear: Companies should not be making false claims about how green their products are to gain an incremental improvement in market share.

title: Have a Little Faith?  At NYU, the Debate Rages On
description: Pascals wager met American Idol Tuesday night when a capacity crowd gathered at a New York University auditorium to vote on the resolution: The World Would Be Better Off Without Religion.

title: Lunchtime in Los Angeles
description: Sprints, or even modest power walks, between press conferences will set many a belly rumbling on the first day of press previews at the Los Angeles auto show. Here, a few early birds beat the throngs to the Nissan stand on Wednesday, where a converted NV200 van dispensed grilled-cheese sandwiches.

title: Rancho San Jose, Quelele and a Flat
description: Jennifer Calkins, a biologist who teaches at Evergreen State College in Olympia, Wash., writes from Mexico, where she is studying the ecology, behavior and evolution of the elegant quail.

title: Extensions for Desert Cities, Hand to God, Lughnasa, Mountaintop
description: Lincoln Center Theater has extended the Broadway run of Other Desert Cities, Jon Robin Baitzs play about dark secrets in a wealthy Palm Springs family. Originally scheduled to run through Jan. 8, tickets are now on sale through March 25 and the run is open-ended. The show, with a cast that includes Stockard Channing, Rachel Griffiths, Stacy Keach, Judith Light and Thomas Sadoski, received mostly positive reviews when it opened earlier this month at the Booth Theater.

title: The Life Report: Judy Eddy
description: The following Life Report was submitted in response to my column of Oct. 28, in which I asked readers over 70 to write autobiographical essays evaluating their own lives.

title: Romanian Film Festival Heads to Lincoln Center
description: After five years in TriBeCa, the annual Romanian Film Festival in New York is moving uptown. In a sign of expanding interest in the innovative cinema coming out of the Eastern European country, this years edition, which is scheduled to begin on Nov. 30 and conclude on Dec. 6, will be held at Lincoln Center, where the Film Society of Lincoln Center has signed on as a partner.

title: Deficit Panel Urged to Resist Gimmicks
description: A progressive group in Washington is urging members of the Congressional deficit committee to resist what it calls a siren song from liberals and conservatives to protect their pet projects, according to a letter obtained by The Caucus.

title: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Afghanistan, Lebanon, Italy and the Philippines.

title: TimesCast | Media Decoder
description: November 16, 2011  Brian Stelter and David Carr discuss the rough handling of journalists during the clearing out of the Occupy Wall Street protesters early Monday morning.

title: Shopping Snapshots: Nov. 17
description: Black veils; an Isabel Marant t-shirt; and store 143 opens up on Ludlow Street.

title: Coda Prices Sedan at $40,795
description: Coda Holdings said in Los Angeles Wednesday that its long-delayed battery sedan has gone into production as a 2012 model and would be sold, with a 10-year, 100,000-mile battery warranty, for a base price of $40,795, inclusive of the destination charge.

title: Paying Tribute to a Jazz Legend, in Spanish This Time
description: In his musical career the jazz saxophonist David Murray has always been omnivorous, which helps explain why, after playing on more than 150 albums, he has finally turned his sights to the Nat King Cole repertory. But Mr. Murrays taste can also be quirky, which is why his latest project focuses on a relatively obscure phase of Coles career: two albums that the singer and pianist recorded in Spanish in 1958 and 1962.

title: Politics and Pizza
description: The pizza, it turns out, is political.

title: Scouting Report
description: OPENINGS

title: Homes for $535,000
description: A 1781 house in the Hudson valley, a penthouse in Houston and a contemporary in Iowa city

title: Pox Parties in the Age of Facebook
description: The offer  for lollipops infected with chickenpox virus  appeared on Facebook last month and quickly circulated among parents who oppose vaccinating their children against diseases.

title: Sharpening Tone, Perry Ad Takes On Obama
description: A new advertisement by Rick Perry takes a sharper tone than his previous ads, taking aim at President Obamas comment last weekend that American businesses had been a little bit lazy in taking for granted that new investment would want to come to the United States.

title: Say It With Tickets Under the Tree
description: As the recently opened Other Desert Cities reminds us so compellingly, the holidays are the time when families gather together, drink too much, say too much and ultimately scream too much. If you want to save the wear on your psyche  not to mention your vocal cords  why not give the gift that says it all for you? I mean theater tickets  to plays and musicals that implicitly speak the confessions, lamentations and recriminations that you wisely refrained from spilling all over the turkey and cranberries so that your loved (and not so loved) ones might eat in peace.

title: What You Get for ... $535,000
description: HOUSTON

title: Fun With Khrushchev in 50s Moscow
description: You may not always belly laugh during Iron Curtain, but youll probably smile throughout. A musical comedy that delights in the pun, the groaner and the quick aside, the show is sometimes far from great. But it is consistently good. And thats no small praise.

title: Controlling the Message in Gaza
description: Stephen Farrell reports on Hamas and its growing use of propaganda to solidify support in Gaza.

title: The Best of Scuttlebot
description: What the editors and reporters of The New York Times tech staff spotted on the Web:

title: Whats the Best Way to Serve Baby Sweet Potatoes?
description: Q.

title: TV Picks, Crowd-Sourced
description: The New York Times Fall TV Ratings Game has come and gone. Times readers who thought they knew better than the network executives which shows would succeed and which would fail submitted their fantasy lineups by Oct. 1 and predicted which shows would be cancelled first. And who can argue with them?

title: National Book Awards Go to Salvage the Bones and Swerve
description: 11:08 p.m. | Updated Jesmyn Ward won the National Book Award for fiction on Wednesday night for Salvage the Bones, a haunting tale of the struggles of a 15-year-old pregnant girl as a hurricane bears down on her fictional Gulf Coast town of Bois Sauvage, Miss.

title: Former Assistant Paints a Less-Than-Flattering Picture of Paterno
description: Matt Paknis has a unique view of Penn State, its football program and former coach Joe Paterno and most of all, the child sexual abuse scandal that has enveloped all three. Paknis, 49,was a graduate assistant under Paterno for two years in the late 1980s andsays that he is also a survivor of childhood abuse.

title: An Island Adviser Sees Promise in Durban Climate Talks
description: It feels like a bit of a stretch. But Mark Lynas, the author of The God Species and an adviser to the leadership of the low-lying Indian Ocean nation of Maldives, swears there could be meaningful outcomes when the annual climate-treaty talks, after a bland performance in Cancn, Mexico, open in Durban, South Africa, at the end of the month.

title: Asked & Answered | Lawrence Weschler
description: Its hard to keep up with Lawrence Weschler. The celebrated author of over a dozen books of literary nonfiction is, in this age of self-branding, defiantly unbrandable. An artist who draws money and tries to spend his drawings; the eccentric proprietor of Los Angeless Museum of Jurassic Technology; the aftermath of the Yugoslav wars: this is Weschlers idea of a beat. (Fittingly, a journal he founded some years back was called Omnivore.) He has devoted years of inquiry into political movements and the curious nature of artistic expression, most famously in his 1982 biography of the artist Robert Irwin, Seeing Is Forgetting the Name of the Thing One Sees. His newest book, Uncanny Valley: Adventures in the Narrative (Counterpoint Press), collects pieces, previously published in Artforum, The New Yorker, Wired and elsewhere, about such disparate subjects as digital animators and human-rights monitors, but which are connected by the kind of distinct, inimitable narrative thread only Weschler can weave. On the eve of a discussion of the book at the Open Society Institute in New York, The Moment spoke to Weschler about Richard Avedon, war films and why he was so embarrassed to discover a drawing of him by David Hockney, pictured above, in the home of a Chicago art collector.

title: A Stone House in a Majorca Wine-Making Village
description: Residential property prices are selling 10 to 20 percent below levels reached during the height of Spains housing bubble.

title: The Last of the Wicked Years, and Other New Books
description: One Broadway blockbuster and 7 1/2 million books in print later, Gregory Maguire pulls the final curtain on his Wicked Years fantasy series. For several other writers this month, questions of good and evil are far more down to earth.

title: Voices: A Thoughtful Debate Over Inclusion
At a Bronx School Where They Are Welcome, Parents Turn Out
House Hunting in ... Majorca
description: A STONE HOUSE IN A MAJORCA WINE-MAKING VILLAGE

title: A French Instrument for a Piece From Paris
description: Though the American organist Jon Gillock lives in Paris, he has maintained his close association with the Church of the Ascension in Greenwich Village. He returned on Tuesday to play the churchs new Manton Memorial Organ, a magnificent French-built instrument rare to New York that was dedicated in May.

title: Adolf and Eva
description: Hitler could not have wished for a better girlfriend. In this first full-scale biography of Eva Braun, the German historian Heike B. Grtemaker examines the known sources for Brauns life and emerges with a highly readable and consistent portrait of an ordinary woman who loved sports, fashion and jazz; and who was, without a doubt, utterly devoted to the man history has seen as evil incarnate.

title: Agent Says Cuban Defector Plans to Be in Big Leagues
description: MILWAUKEE  The uncertainty associated with pursuing international free agents has been one of the recurring themes of the general managers meetings this week at the Pfister Hotel.

title: Cadillac XTS: A Flagship Equipped With a Search Engine
description: Introduced on Wednesday, Nov. 16: 2013 Cadillac XTS.

title: Racewalking, but Not to London
description: OWEGO, N.Y.  After training along the country roads of this village to the south of the Finger Lakes, Erin Taylor-Talcott recently achieved a qualifying time for the 2012 Olympic trials in the 50-kilometer racewalk.

title: Its Not About Them. Its About the Sad Stuff
description: Im an instagrammer. A casual one. Not like this guy, but a garden-variety one. I was forcibly dragged into it by a tech-savvy friend. But now Im committed. I yearn for the little hearts of collective approval. And I look at the world with fresh eyes. On my lunch break.

title: Wait Wait  Its the BBC!
description: Could the public radio show Wait Wait  Dont Tell Me! soon have a weekly perch on television?

title: Sleeping vs. Lying Down, and Other Murky Issues
description: The rules posted  and now enforced  at Zuccotti Park seem straightforward enough. No camping. No sleeping bags. No lying down. No bikes or skateboards or in-line skates. No engaging in any other activities prohibited by law or statute.

title: Curtain Up, Light the Lights, Open the Books
description: If you like to take the easy route when doing your holiday shopping rounds  and who doesnt?  theres a natural choice this season for that theater lover on your list. Last year you probably snapped up and wrapped up that shiny new book of lyrics by Stephen Sondheim. This year you can do precisely the same.

title: Cornel West to Take a Job in New York
description: Cornel West, the peripatetic public intellectual and political activist, plans to finish out a teaching career that has taken him from Yale to Harvard to Princeton by moving back this coming summer to Union Theological Seminary in the City of New York, where he began as an assistant professor in 1977.

title: The Brunch Party Takes Over Clubs
description: A smorgasbord of clubby New York restaurants has transformed lazy midday gatherings into orgies of overindulgence.

title: For the Thanksgiving Cook, a Recipe Manager to Celebrate
description: Im tired of inviting the usual suspects to my Thanksgiving Day feast.

title: In a Finnish Forest, a House Blends In
description: Measuring 800 square feet, an austere house on a lake in Finland disappears into the trees.

title: Stage Scenes: Elaine Paige
description: A look at some of the actresss past performances.

title: The 3 P.M. Brunch With the 4 A.M. Vibe
description: BRUNCH, an occasion for flapjacks, Bloody Marys and meandering conversation, is traditionally the most sluggish of meals. But a smorgasbord of clubby New York restaurants have transformed lazy midday gatherings into orgies of overindulgence with blaring music, jiggling go-go dancers and bar tabs that mushroom into five figures.

title: Kia GT, the Brands Rear-Drive Concept, Arrives in Los Angeles
description: Shown on Wednesday, Nov. 16: Kia GT design study.

title: Embracing Handels Leaping Arias and Duets
description: The Theater of Early Music, a Canadian period-instrument and vocal ensemble led by Daniel Taylor, the countertenor, expands and contracts to suit the project at hand. Mr. Taylor brought a compact version to Weill Recital Hall for a Handel program on Tuesday, and though he was listed in the program book as both countertenor and conductor, there was no conducting to be done. When the instrumentalists had the spotlight  in trim, zesty accounts of a passacaglia (from HWV 432) and the Giulio Cesare Overture  Mr. Taylor left them to it.

title: Tied to Songs of the Past, but a Nod to the Present
description: The page turner may soon go the way of the rotary phone if more pianists use iPads instead of old-fashioned paper scores, as the pianist Sam Haywood did during a recital with the violinist Joshua Bell at Carnegie Hall on Monday.

title: Decision 2013
description: For some time the Obama administration had appeared to be signaling its likely approval of a plan to lay a high-pressure oil pipeline from Canadian tar sands right on top of the main water supply to much of the Midwest. Last week, however, after thousands of protesters  ranging from ranchers and farmers to ordinary Americans concerned about the catastrophic harm that could be done if that pipeline were to leak  surrounded the White House, the administration announced that it was delaying a decision until 2013.

title: Hillarycare: The Sequel
description: Barack Obama achieved more significant change in domestic policy during the first two years of his presidency than any president since Richard Nixon has over the course of four or eight. Thats because in 2010 Obama signed into law the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act. We dont know how this story will end, but theres now a law on the books that, for all its many shortcomings and unpopularity, will extend health coverage to most of this countrys uninsured. According to the Congressional Budget Office, the share of legal nonelderly residents who have health insurance will rise from 83 percent to 94 percent. Thanks to the Affordable Care Act, some unquantifiable number of people will live who would otherwise die.

title: Ricky Gervais Will Return to Golden Globes, Despite Past Controversy
description: LOS ANGELES  The Hollywood organization behind the Golden Globe Awards will give the British comedian Ricky Gervais another chance as host despite his barbed comments that overshadowed its last ceremony. Mr. Gervais, in Twitter posts late Wednesday, indicated that he had agreed to return as the ringmaster for the Jan. 15 show, which will be telecast live.

title: Hyundai Azera Finds Niche Between Sonata and Genesis
description: Introduced on Wednesday, Nov. 16: 2012 Hyundai Azera.

title: This World Can Be Far From Easy, and Its Time for You to Face That Truth
description: If you have illusions about anything, Bebe Neuwirth is here to remind you in no uncertain terms that thats what they are: illusions. Her show, Stories With Piano #3 at Feinsteins at Loews Regency, an improved version of a brilliant act she brought to the club three years ago, might as well be called Tough Love.

title: Pepper Spray and Ayn Rand Deployed Against Occupy Seattle Protesters
description: Several Occupy Seattle protesters, including an 84-year-old woman, were doused with pepper spray by the police on Tuesday night, as my colleague Jess Bidgood reports.

title: What Are Some Festive Cocktails That Are Easy to Make for a Big Group?
description: Q.

title: Grover and the Giant No-Taxes Pledge
description: Polls will tell you that a majority of Americans recognize the need to raise taxes. A group of about two-dozen American millionaires have signed a letter to Congress asking for tax hikes that would affect them directly. They even sent a delegation to Washington today to make that case.

title: Spains Leader Faces Debt Worries
Protesters Find Their Belongings in Chaos at a City Garage
description: After filling out a detailed invoice of missing items (black ski pants had to be more specific, one police officer told her) and showing identification, Melissa Pham entered the hulking, block-long Sanitation Department warehouse on the West Side of Manhattan with a mandatory police escort.

title: Dodgers Sue Prime Ticket in TV Rights Dispute
description: The Los Angeles Dodgers, intent on selling their future television rights as soon as possible, filed suit against Prime Ticket, which currently carries the teams games, for interfering in the sale process.

title: The Place | Tee Time Meets Me Time
description: Camilo Villegas, 29, is a professional golfer whose notoriety can be attributed to both his athletic achievements and his curious public image. A fitness freak, the handsome Colombians hard-won physique sets him apart even among his increasingly toned competitors on the P.G.A. tour. The muscles in Villegass arms are like a bas-relief when he grips the golf club, Karen Crouse noted last year in The Times. His tight shirts set off his boxers biceps. Indeed, Villegas cuts quite the swath: he belly-flops onto the green to size up a putt, like a stalking lioness. He has posed nude for ESPN The Magazine. He color-coordinates his wristbands, hats and belts. (Hes a clotheshorse off the course, too, gushing on Twitter about the latest collection at the J. Lindeberg store in SoHo.)

title: The School Tour: Eyes Wide Open
F.D.A. Approves Drug for Bone Marrow Disease
description: The Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday approved the first drug to treat myelofibrosis, a rare but potentially life-threatening bone marrow disorder.

title: The Designer  Retailer Union Remains Lucrative
description: Collaborations are proving to be both a reliable business model for retailers and a business in themselves.

title: A Marriage of Economic Convenience
description: THE scene on Nov. 8 at a shopping party to preview the new Versace for H&M collection was fairly predictable, if you didnt count the midnight concert by Prince. When the racks of gold-studded dresses and tropical-print shirts were finally unveiled, in a temporary store on a Hudson River pier, the invited fashion editors, celebrities and Nicki Minaj quickly picked them clean. Many of the women in the crowd made beelines for the collections mens clothes, Style.com said. There was still a line outside the shop at 2:30 a.m.

title: A Look at the Show Cars
description: New models and other highlights from the industry showcase in Los Angeles.

title: Car Strikes Activist for Pedestrian Safety, Killing Her
description: Patricia Dolan, an activist in Queens who refused to drive and fought tirelessly for pedestrian safety, was struck and killed by a car Tuesday night, the police said, after stepping off a bus two blocks from a transportation committee meeting she was planning to attend.

title: Say, Can You Make Phone Calls on That Camera?
description: SAN FRANCISCO  As the technology that powers smartphone cameras has steadily improved, the point-and-shoot has become an endangered species. Taking pictures with a smartphone has become so popular, it even has its own name: iPhoneography, or smartphoneography for those with non-Apple mobile phones.

title: Occupy Wall Street: The Next Chapter
description: To the Editor:

title: Empress of All the Russias
description: How delightful to discover that Robert K. Massie, 82 years old, hasnt lost his mojo. At a heft befitting its subject, his long-awaited Catherine the Great: Portrait of a Woman is a consistently nimble and buoyant performance, defying what might in a lesser writers hands prove a deadly undertow of exhaustively researched historical facts. Of course, Massie, who has spent almost half a century studying czarist Russia, has always been a biographer with the instincts of a novelist. He understands plot  fate  as a function of character, and the narrative perspective he establishes and maintains, a vision tightly aligned with that of his subject, convinces a reader hes not so much looking at Catherine the Great as he is out of her eyes.

title: Invitation to a Dialogue: The Health Care Law
description: To the Editor:

title: New Housing Models for a Changed New York
description: A new residence built to house tenants who had been homeless is part of a broader effort to re-think urban housing in New York.

title: Parenting Wisdom From a Mining Town
description: Aboutfour years ago this week, I traveled to Big Stone Gap, Va., to spend two days with the parents of two N.F.L. running backs, Thomas Jones, and his younger brother, Julius, then starters for the Jets and the Dallas Cowboys. What struck me most about their family was not that two of seven children ended up sharing an N.F.L. job title  what are the odds?  but that all seven children from that town in coal country in southwest Virginia went to and graduated from college.

title: Looking at Obamas Record on the Environment
description: To the Editor:

title: The Cash-and-Carry House
description: THE house was just $1. The catch? A delivery charge of nearly $22,000.

title: Better Care for the Disabled
description: To the Editor:

title: Libya Returns to Oil
description: Reporter Clifford Krauss discusses the future of Libyas oil industry. Libyas interim government predicts output will be back to preconflict levels by June.

title: Google Opens a Digital Music Store
description: 8:26 p.m. | Updated Looking to extend its reach as a hub for entertainment and social networking, Google introduced a set of music features on Wednesday, including a download store to compete with iTunes.

title: The Shoah Foundation Widens Scope
description: LOS ANGELES  Since Steven Spielberg established the Survivors of the Shoah Visual History Foundation in 1994, the organization has devoted itself exclusively to the memory of Holocaust survivors. Its archives house more than 50,000 video interviews, in 32 languages, with survivors from 56 countries  the largest such collection in the world.

title: Former Madoff Trader to Plead Guilty
description: A former trader at Bernard L. Madoff Investment Securities is expected to plead guilty on Monday to conspiring to defraud firm customers beginning in the early 1970s, two decades earlier than Mr. Madoff claims to have started his Ponzi scheme.

title: Two Performa 11 Duets, Distinct Yet Conversant in Their Shared Themes
description: This citys fall season is infuriating and exhausting: a relentless assault of performances that seems designed to make serious art-goers go crazy. Where else do people sigh with relief upon hearing that show X was terrible, knowing they can strike it from their must-see list?

title: Angies List Prices Offering at $13
description: After an extended pause, Internet start-ups are slowly finding their way to the public markets again.

title: A Party With a Faint Scent of Blood
description: Norman Mailer, who was known to head-butt people at literary soirees, might have appreciated the Battle of the Books.

title: Time to Start Grading Middle Schools on High School Readiness
Surprises Arise When Computers Play Cards
description: The 64-board final of the World Computer-Bridge Championship, held last month in the Netherlands, was between two programs that had never taken the title. They were Q-Plus Bridge from Germany and Shark Bridge from Denmark.

title: Thursday Matchup: Jets at Broncos
description: Jets (5-4) at Broncos (4-5), 8:20 p.m. Eastern, NFL Network and Ch. 11 in New York areaLine: Jets by 6.

title: Does Congress Hear the Occupiers?
Minaya May Find Match With Blue Jays
description: MILWAUKEE  Omar Minaya is weighing possible job opportunities from a few teams to be a special assistant to a general manager or to be a scout, including an offer from the Toronto Blue Jays.

title: Former Player Sues Knicks Over Medical Issue
description: Cuttino Mobley, whose N.B.A. career ended in 2008 because of concerns over a heart condition, is suing Madison Square Garden, claiming that the Knicks forced him to retire as a cost-saving measure. He is seeking unspecified damages.

title: Allen Hirsch on His Homage to a Monkey
description: Signs come and go above New York City diners and rarely are they tributes to anything but commerce. The aluminum portrait and larger-than-life photographs on the roof and adjacent to the restaurant La Esquina, at 106 Kenmare Street in SoHo, however, are something else entirely: an homage by the New York City painter Allen Hirsch to Benjamin, his capuchin monkey who died at the age of 14, that is as much a reflection of a broken heart as any light on Broadway. To Mr. Hirsch, who had cut holes in the ceiling of his loft so that Benjamin could run from room to room and had allowed Benjamin to play with his daughter when she was a child, the monkey was not a pet, but a fellow creature I take care of.

title: At Home With Marilyn in England
description: In July 1956, Marilyn Monroe flew to England to film The Prince and the Showgirl, a comedy that her co-star and director, Sir Laurence Olivier, didnt find very funny. (He quickly grew tired of the actresss on-set breakdowns.) It was a critical period for Monroe: she was newly married to her third husband, the playwright Arthur Miller, and was trying to shed her bombshell image so she could play more serious roles.

title: Canvas Opens a Chelsea Location
description: A year ago, the first Canvas store opened in SoHo. Last week, a second one quietly opened in Chelsea, in a space that for years housed the Door Store. The space in SoHo doesnt have enough room to show our complete furniture collection or the vintage pieces we sell, said Andrew Corrie, the owner. Here we can properly display everything.

title: Market Ready
description: Q. Can green updates increase the value of my home? If so, what are the most cost-effective options?

title: A Filtered-Water Jug for Company
description: Some products just seem to resist good design. Filtered-water pitchers, for instance, which have squatted on refrigerator shelves for years.

title: Sales at Knoll, Broadway Panhandler and More
description: Pillows, rugs and runners are up to 70 percent off during the Judy Ross Textiles sample sale, through Saturday (a Fauna 18-inch-square pillow, pictured, regularly $195, is $80); 22 East 17th Street (Broadway), Suite 931, (212) 842-1705 or judyrosstextiles.com.

title: A Glass Forest Grows in TriBeCa
description: Jeff Zimmerman, a Brooklyn artist who works in glass, spent more than six months creating the all-encompassing installation of bronze-and-glass vines currently on display at R Gallery in TriBeCa.

title: In a Hut in Haiti, Waiting for Spirits
description: I HAD a house in Haiti, in the hills above the North Atlantic coast. The house appeared as if out of a dream: my dream to have a foothold in the country. Like many concepts do in Haiti, the phrase pied  terre became literal, material.

title: Totally Green Apples
description: GROVETON, N.H.

title: Turning a Life Around, With Help From a Clubhouse
description: When I get angry I have to hit something, so I do it here, John Halloran said as he stood in the Kid Kelly Boxing Gym in Brooklyn.

title: A Finnish House Channels a Spartan Past
description: VASKIVESI, Finland

title: Woods Duo Stumbles, but U.S. Shines in Presidents Cup
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Tiger Woods and his former caddie, Steve Williams, shook hands on the first tee. It was shocking when they shook hands again only 12 holes later after Americas dynamic duo got drubbed.

title: Shopping for Fishbowls
description: Ave Bradley, the vice president of design for Kimpton Hotels, searched for free-form fishbowls.

title: Saving by the Bundle
description: On a typical night in the emergency room, a patient shows up short of breath, suffering from emphysema or heart failure or maybe both, as well as diabetes and high blood pressure. Doctors and nurses administer inhalers to ease his breathing and diuretics to take off excess fluid, and admit him to the hospital. Over the next few days, interns and residents furiously adjust his medications and fix his diet. He is discharged with a stack of prescriptions. A week or two later, chances are good hell be right back in the emergency room.

title: After Day of Quiet, More Occupy Protests Planned
description: Along the western edge of Zuccotti Park, for nearly two months the plazas nexus of zealous drummers and curious passers-by in Lower Manhattan, a lone man sitting on a marble ledge scribbled in his journal on Wednesday morning.

title: Fishbowls
description: AS the vice president of design for Kimpton Hotels, a company based in San Francisco, Ave Bradley spends a lot of time trying to anticipate what a traveler might need  even something as improbable as a temporary pet.

title: Mr. Rogerss Very Tough Neighborhood
description: THE playwright J. T. Rogers enjoys one of New York Citys briefest commutes. Most days he leaves his apartment in Park Slope, Brooklyn, and strolls past elm trees, brownstones and his sons elementary school to his office, just a few blocks away.

title: Audit Finds Errors in Calculating Pensions in Bankruptcies
description: The federal agency that takes over failing pension plans in corporate bankruptcies has made errors in calculating benefits, according to an audit released Wednesday, raising the possibility that some retirees have been getting too much or too little.

title: Witness Says He Gave Defendant a Match, Then Left as 5 Died in a 78 Fire
description: NEWARK  The star witness weighs 168 pounds, according to prison records, but to look at him, one wonders what he must have had in his pockets when they put him on the scale. He shuffled into court Wednesday to testify in the quintuple-murder case that hangs on his slumped shoulders like the two-sizes-too-large, borrowed dress shirt with which he had been outfitted for the occasion.

title: Infiniti JX35 Moves the People  Seven of Them
description: Introduced on Wednesday, Nov. 16: 2013 Infiniti JX35.

title: Simeone Foundation Named Automotive Museum of the Year
description: The Simeone Foundation in Philadelphia on Wednesday was named Automotive Museum of the Year by a committee of judges convenedby the enthusiast magazine Octane and EFG International, a sponsor of heritage races worldwide. The committee included Ian Callum, the design director of Jaguar; Jay Leno, the late-night television host; and Nick Mason, the drummer for Pink Floyd. Other museums considered included the Petersen in Los Angeles and the National Motor Museum of England.

title: A Silicon Valley Dream Grows in Guatemala, Despite the Risks
description: GUATEMALA CITY  Seventh floor: geeks, computer screens, embryonic businesses  including one offering digital monsters from artists who worked on The Chronicles of Narnia film series.

title: Oregon Tests iPads as Aid to Disabled Voters
description: Could the iPad someday supplant the voting machine?

title: At Protest, a Rebuke Each Night for Cuomo
description: ALBANY  Robert B. Eaton, a freelance writer and Occupy Albany protester, has a new routine. At 11 each night, just across from the Capitol, he walks from a city park into a contiguous state park and is promptly arrested by the State Police for violating a curfew imposed by the Cuomo administration.

title: How Much Time Do I Need to Reheat Vegetables for 30?
description: Q.

title: Delphi Prices at $22 a Share
description: Delphi Automotive, the auto parts maker that emerged from bankruptcy two years ago, priced its initial public offering at $22 a share, raising about $530.1 million, a person briefed on the matter told DealBook on Wednesday.

title: Garden Books a Meet as Millrose Games Go Uptown
description: USA Track and Field will host a new meet at Madison Square Garden on Jan. 28 to replace the Millrose Games, which next year will be held at the Armory Track and Field Center in Upper Manhattan for the first time.

title: On a Big Day for Managers, Francona Says Hell Sit Out a Year
description: MILWAUKEE  On a day when two major league managers were honored for their work in the past year, the futures of two men in the running for managerial positions next season began to crystallize as well.

title: A Career Occupation
description: A week before police evicted protesters from Zuccotti Park, Tim Weldon quit his job in Connecticut to be closer to the Occupy Wall Street movement.

title: 2 Elements of Jobs Bill Pass House Unanimously
description: WASHINGTON  The House on Wednesday approved a measure that would repeal a tax-withholding requirement on government contractors and provide tax incentives for companies that hire veterans, sending President Obama the first, relatively modest components of his jobs bill for his signature.

title: Tea Party Group Presents Its Own Debt Commission Report
description: As the Congressional committee charged with reining in the deficit nears its deadline for coming up with a way to cut it by at least $1.2 trillion over 10 years, the Tea Party  or at least, a small group aiming to represent the Tea Party  is presenting its own ideas.

title: More Money Can Beat Big Money
description: Cambridge, Mass.

title: As New Graduates Return to Nest, Economy Also Feels the Pain
description: Like most of her friends, Hollis Romanelli graduated from college last May and promptly moved back in with her parents.

title: The Smokers Surcharge
description: More and more employers are demanding that workers who smoke, are overweight or have high cholesterol shoulder a greater share of their health care costs, a shift toward penalizing employees with unhealthy lifestyles rather than rewarding good habits.

title: Russia: Chechen Poet Shot to Death
description: A Chechen poet known for speaking out against separatists in his volatile native region was shot to death outside his home in Moscow late Tuesday night in what investigators said was probably a contract murder. The poet, Ruslan Akhtakhanov, 58, left, was also known to be a supporter of Chechnyas leader, Ramzan A. Kadyrov, who described the victim in a statement posted to the Chechen government Web site as a shining representative of the Chechen intelligentsia. On his own Web site, Mr. Akhtakhanov said he began writing poetry after being kidnapped by bandits, a term usually used to describe separatist fighters in Chechnya.

title: Fiat 500 Abarth: A Small Stinger for America
description: Shown on Wednesday, Nov. 16: 2012 Fiat 500 Abarth.

title: The Same Tough Call? Well, Not Quite
description: For the last two weeks, Patrick Witt, the most prolific passer in the history of Yale football, wrestled with a decision that pitted a historic educational opportunity against one final chance to play in The Game against Harvard.

title: With MF Global Money Still Missing, Suspicions Grow
description: Nearly three weeks after $600 million in customer money went missing from MF Global, the search for the cash has been hampered by the bankrupt brokerage firms sloppy record-keeping, an increasingly worrisome situation that has left regulators frustrated and customers in the lurch.

title: An Assault on the Amazon
description: Xingu National Park, Brazil

title: Steinbrenner Says Yanks Need Only Fine-Tuning
description: MILWAUKEE  At baseballs owners meetings last year, Hal Steinbrenner, the Yankees managing general partner, fielded numerous pointed questions about the explosive situation the team faced as it negotiated a new contract with Derek Jeter. Those inquiries made for an awkward and at times painful off-season.

title: Shots Fired at the White House
description: A car with a semiautomatic assault weapon in it was found abandoned several blocks from the White House.

title: A Presidents Religion
description: The Stone is featuring occasional posts by Gary Gutting, a professor of philosophy at the University of Notre Dame, that apply critical thinking to information and events that have appeared in the news.

title: Lottery Numbers
Schedule for World Cup Qualifiers Released
description: Last Saturday the United States learned the teams it would be playing in the next round of qualifying matches for the 2014 World Cup  Jamaica (which had already been seeded), Guatemala, and Antigua and Barbuda.

title: Lottery Numbers
U.S. Hones Warnings to Egypt as Military Stalls Transition
description: CAIRO  Brazen attempts by Egypts interim military rulers to hold on to power long after elections have elicited a sharp reaction domestically and for the first time have prompted Washington to warn about the potential for new unrest.

title: Inquiry Grew Into Concerns of a Cover-Up
description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa.  A critical break in the investigation of Jerry Sandusky came via a posting on the Internet: a random mention that a Penn State football coach, years before, might have seen something ugly, but kept silent.

title: 2013 Ford Flex Hunts for the Endless Summer in L.A.
description: What is it? Its as close as Ford comes to building a classic station wagon for the North American market, but dont call it a station wagon. Introduced as a 2009 model, the three-row, seven-passenger box is getting its first significant updates for the 2013 model year.

title: After Giving Up Job for Occupy Protest, Questions for Future
description: Last week, Tim Weldon, 35, quit his job in Connecticut and moved from home to devote his time to Occupy Wall Street. I think this will end up being the biggest and best career move I ever made, he said in an interview.

title: Was Paterno Trying to Keep His Job?
description: This is a follow-up to previous columns on Penn State, The Institutional Pass and Penn States Long Road Back.

title: Leasing Los Angeles
description: The parrot on his shoulder seemed half as tall as my wife. But when the five-foot man who owned the castle  a wiry circus performer and the son of vaudevillian acrobats  perched the squawking flirt on Linas shoulder, I wasnt worried. Given our fantastical setting it could have been worse  a rabid panda or a randy dolphin  and I was already in a state of fight-or-flight zen after driving up 60-degree slopes, making hairpin turns on narrow Laurel Canyon roads, sans railings, only to arrive at a makeshift palace with turrets, seemingly built for Muppet royalty.

title: Mets Mark 50 Years, Good and Bad
description: On Nov. 16, 1961, the Mets introduced their skyline-and-Brooklyn Bridge logo. They had not yet played a game.

title: In Alabama, Calls for Revamping Immigration Law
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.  An increasing number of state lawmakers say they are willing to consider critical changes to Alabamas sweeping anti-immigration law, part of which appears to make proof of citizenship or legal residency a requirement even for mundane activities like garbage pickup, dog licenses and flu shots at county health departments.

title: Feuding Hurts G.O.P.s Hopes to Win Senate
description: WASHINGTON  In a chamber of ample egos and matching oratory, Senator Bob Casey, the Pennsylvania Democrat, is understatement defined, his excitement most often registered by some extra eyebrow activity.

title: 3 Accused of Theft Using a Device at A.T.M.s
description: Using card-reading devices and hidden cameras at Chase A.T.M.s near Union Square, three men stole more than a quarter of a million dollars from nearly 1,500 customers this year, according to an indictment unsealed on Wednesday.

title: Legal Teams for Players and N.B.A. Update Suits
description: As N.B.A. players await a hearing on their lawsuit against the league, additional legal maneuvering continues on a parallel front.

title: Europes Contagion
description: Two years of gross mismanagement of the euro-zone debt crisis have all too predictably produced a wider crisis of market confidence that now threatens the entire 17-nation euro zone. This weeks formation of new technocrat-led governments in Greece and Italy has not calmed fears. Practically every euro zone country is paying the price in higher interest costs and ebbing economic growth.

title: Plan B to Raise $200 Million for Mets Is Going Slowly
Mets Look to Improve Bullpen
description: MILWAUKEE  The Mets are moving cautiously through this free-agency period, warily eyeing the teams pursuing Jose Reyes while beginning to modestly address their own pressing needs.

title: In Search of the Perfect Fit, Honda Goes Electric
description: Introduced on Wednesday, Nov. 16: 2013 Honda Fit EV.

title: Protesters Storm Kuwaits Parliament
description: Citing witnesses and local media, Reuters reports that dozens of Kuwaitis briefly stormed Kuwaits Parliament building late on Wednesday as hundreds more demonstrated outside, demanding the resignation of Prime Minister Sheikh Nasser al-Mohammad al-Sabah.

title: The Killing in Syria Goes On
description: The brutal crackdown on pro-democracy protesters by President Bashar al-Assad of Syria has left more than 3,500 people dead. International pressure for his removal is finally building  but not fast enough.

title: Ozone Regulations: Industry Makes Its Case
description: Maps show areas that might violate a stricter ozone standard proposed by the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: Route Proposals May Ease an Oil Pipeline Bottleneck
description: OTTAWA  With the timing, and perhaps the future, of the Keystone XL pipeline project from Canadas oil sands to the Gulf Coast now uncertain, two alternatives to the hotly contested project have begun emerging.

title: Two Giants Rattled by Fatal Shooting in Chelsea Nightclub
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  When shots rang out early Tuesday morning at the Juliet Supper Club, Victor Cruz and Chris Canty hit the floor. The two Giants, who were among a number of professional athletes at the Chelsea nightclub, said Wednesday that the experience left them reflective and considerably shaken.

title: Open the Records at Penn State
description: The sexual abuse scandal that has engulfed Penn State is looking more and more like a cover-up, even as more potential victims step forward. Those investigating the case need to determine what university officials knew, when they knew it and what they did about allegations of sexual assault lodged against Jerry Sandusky, a former assistant football coach, in 1998 and afterward.

title: Thursday: Something Lost in the Wash
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  This is a magical puzzle, but I didnt realize how magical it was until after I had finished.

title: Lawyer Outlines Methods Used by British Paper in Hacking Case
description: LONDON  A lawyer representing 51 people who say they were victims of phone hacking and press intrusion told a hearing on Wednesday that his clients and their families had been followed, spied on, threatened, harassed, vilified, blackmailed and driven to suicide attempts by a British tabloid run amok.

title: Visa to Offer Mobile Payments in Developing Nations
description: Visa has been hard at work on a mobile digital wallet that it hopes to roll out early next year. But thats not the only mobile market the credit card company has its eye on.

title: Required Reading From Senator Coburn
description: Senator Tom Coburn, a Republican from Oklahoma, has once again broken with his partys dogma, this time with a new report  Subsidies of the Rich and Famous. It convincingly argues that theres real revenue to be netted to help wrestle down the deficit if Congress dared to crack down on indefensible boons for the top brackets.

title: Sharp Decline in Revenue Is Forecast for California
description: LOS ANGELES  Californias budget problems show no signs of abating.

title: From Shore to Forest, Projecting Effects of Climate Change
description: While the long-term outlook for grape-growers in the Finger Lakes region is favorable, it is less than optimal for skiers and other winter sports enthusiasts in the Adirondacks. Fir and spruce trees are expected to die out in the Catskills, and New York Citys backup drinking water supply may well be contaminated as a result of seawater making its way farther up the Hudson River.

title: Old Times, Not Necessarily Good Times
description: Thickets of George Orwells robust prose fill the stage in Ryan Kiggells adaptation of Burmese Days, which opened on Wednesday night at 59E59 Theaters as part of the Brits Off Broadway festival. But only rarely do these relatively purple passages transcend their literary origins, despite Mr. Kiggells efforts to hack through the verbiage of an author still finding his voice.

title: Something to Shoot For
description: You may have noticed that Congress is unpopular.

title: Lunch in Zuccotti Park: Carry In, and in the Rain, Carry Out
description: As I surveyed the menu at a halal food cart, two women in jeans and scarves walked up and placed their orders. They said they worked in 1 Liberty Plaza, one of the buildings facing Zuccotti Park, but had not ventured out to buy their lunch in weeks.

title: Mayor Urges Detroit to Accept Drastic Action to Fix Finances
description: DETROIT  In an address broadcast live on television stations across this city, Mayor Dave Bing told Detroit on Wednesday evening that its finances were in dismal shape and that without major concessions from unions, the privatizing of some city services and layoffs, Detroit would run out of money by early next year.

title: World Cup Qualifying Set
description: The schedule for the next round of qualifying for the World Cup in the United States region was released. The Americans are in a four-team group with Jamaica, Guatemala and Antigua and Barbuda. The top two teams will advance to the next round. The schedule for the United States team is: June 8 versus Antigua and Barbuda, June 12 at Guatemala, Sept. 7 at Jamaica, Sept. 11 versus Jamaica, Oct. 12 at Antigua and Barbuda, and Oct. 16 versus Guatemala.

title: Cutting Off Unesco, U.S. May Endanger Programs in Iraq and Afghanistan
description: PARIS  Some important programs affecting American interests in Iraq are at risk because of Washingtons cutoff of money to Unesco, officials of the organization say. Unesco programs in Afghanistan will also be affected, but to a lesser degree.

title: The Face of Modern Slavery
description: Phnom Penh, Cambodia

title: Professor of Profits
description: As a young graduate student pursuing an advanced degree in modern European history, Newt Gingrich wrote a dissertation titled Belgian Education Policy in the Congo: 1945-1960. Thereafter, in the course of writing 23 books, the scholar-politician pontificated on many subjects, from the pope to a pouting sex kitten, who appears for a quick romp in a novel about the Civil War.

title: Majority Leader Gives Deficit Panel Wide Berth
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Eric Cantor of Virginia, the powerful House majority leader, enjoys expressing his views. He travels frequently around the country selling the House Republican agenda, makes flattering YouTube videos, holds lengthy weekly news conferences and is a regular on the talk show circuit.

title: Speaking of Blast, Iranian Describes Work on Weapons
description: The explosion last weekend in Iran that killed 17 members of the armed forces, including a founder of the countrys missile program, occurred while researchers were working on weapons capable of delivering Israel a strong punch in the mouth and disrupted their project by a few days, the Iranian military chief of staff said Wednesday.

title: Gingrichs Freddie Mac Payday
description: In a column in todays Campaign Stops, Timothy Egan writes:

title: China: Bus Crash Kills Students
description: Eighteen preschoolers died Wednesday when their badly overloaded school minibus was rammed head-on by a coal truck, according to the official Xinhua news agency. The bus driver and a teacher also died, and 44 children were injured. The bus  with just nine seats, according to Xinhua  had been carrying 64 people. The crash immediately generated outrage on Twitter-like microblogs, with commentators accusing the government of poorly regulating school buses. The truck driver was taken into custody, Xinhua reported.

title: Energy Secretary to Defend Solyndra Loan to Congress
description: WASHINGTON  An unrepentant energy secretary will square off on Thursday with a Republican-led committee that has spent months arguing that his department showed political favoritism and incompetence when it approved a $535 million loan guarantee for Solyndra, a California manufacturer of solar modules that later went bankrupt.

title: Reasonable Expectations
description: The other day, stopped at a red light in downtown New Haven, I looked up and noticed cameras pointing in all four directions of the intersection. Probably they were cameras designed to detect red-light runners. Or maybe their purpose was general surveillance. No matter  the point was that big brother was watching. Big brother, as we all have plenty of reason to believe, is watching everyone.

title: Lee Pockriss, Songwriter Behind Itsy Bitsy Bikini, Dies at 87
description: Lee Pockriss, who wrote the music for midcentury pop hits like Itsy Bitsy Teenie Weenie Yellow Polka Dot Bikini, Catch a Falling Star and Johnny Angel, died on Monday at his home in Bridgewater, Conn. He was 87.

title: Heavy-Duty Lenses for Smartphone Cameras
description: Attachments for smartphone cameras are turning the smartphones into much more flexible tools.

title: Irwin Schneiderman Dies at 88; Guided the City Opera
description: Irwin Schneiderman, a lawyer and a philanthropic leader who guided the New York City Opera through a decade of ups and downs, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 88.

title: Corrections: November 17
