description: FRONT PAGE

title: Al Boeke, Architect Who Sought Ecological Harmony, Is Dead at 88
description: The Pomo Indians, who once inhabited the land, were long gone the day in 1962 when Al Boeke flew in a small plane over the pristine beaches, steep bluffs, wind-swept woods and sheep-grazed meadows along the Pacific Coast in Sonoma County, Calif., about 150 miles north of San Francisco.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,819 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Man Arrested After Video Threat
description: A man who said he planned to firebomb Macys was arrested on Wednesday on charges of making terrorist threats, after a video of remarks he had made at an Occupy Wall Street protest in Manhattan surfaced online.

title: Electronics Price Predictor Is Now Mobile
description: In June, Oren Etzioni, the brains behind airline price predictor Farecast, brought forth Decide.com, a Web site that predicted the future prices of laptops, cameras and televisions. With a Wait or Buy signal, it gave you the probability prices would change or that a new model was coming.

title: Think Like a Doctor: Excruciating Stomach Pain
description: The Medical Mystery: Can you solve the case of a young man with stabbing abdominal pain and an unusual family cancer history?

title: Accenture Calls on Clients to Help Make a Statement
description: THE Chinese have the year of the tiger. Accenture has life after Tiger.

title: U.S. to Review Cases Seeking Deportations
description: The Department of Homeland Security will begin a review on Thursday of all deportation cases before the immigration courts and start a nationwide training program for enforcement agents and prosecuting lawyers, with the goal of speeding deportations of convicted criminals and halting those of many illegal immigrants with no criminal record.

title: Would-Be Engineers Hit Books the Hardest, a Study Finds
description: Business majors spend less time on course work than other college students, but they devote more hours to nonschool duties, like earning money and caring for family members. In contrast, engineering students spend the most time studying and the least on outside demands.

title: Word of the Day | seethe
description: seethe \seth\ verb

title: District 2 Council Rejects Two Rezoning Plans
Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Thursday
description: The government published rules outlining the liability that nuclear equipment suppliers to Indias government-operated power plants would face in the case of an accident. The rules are unlikely to completely satisfy concerns of the U.S. government, which signed a landmark civilian nuclear agreement with India in 2006, and American vendors like General Electric, which have lobbied for India to exempt suppliers from liability. The new rules place a 15 billion rupee ($300 million) cap and effectively limit liability to the first five years of operation. (The Hindu)A special court in Mumbai freed seven Muslim men who were accused of planning and carrying out a series of bomb attacks in 2009 in Malegaon, a town in Maharashtra. The men, who have said they are innocent, have been in jail for five years. The case against them weakened significantly last year after a right-wing activist reportedly confessed to the crime. (Indian Express)

title: House Approves Bill Making Travel Easier for Gun Owners
description: WASHINGTON  The House passed legislation on Wednesday that would require states that issue concealed gun permits to recognize similar licenses from other states. The vote was 272 to 154.

title: Illinois: Rape and Murder Convictions Vacated
description: A Cook County Circuit Court judge, noting that new DNA evidence would probably change the result in a new trial, on Wednesday vacated the convictions of four men in the 1994 rape and murder of Nina Glover, a prostitute whose body was found in a dumpster in Chicago. Judge Paul P. Biebel Jr. said that although the men had initially confessed in great detail, DNA recovered from semen in the victims body cast significant doubt on the confessions. DNA testing shortly after the murder excluded all four men. And last May, the DNA was matched to another suspect, Johnny Douglas, who had been convicted of a very similar rape and murder. The states attorney, Anita Alvarez, who had opposed vacating the convictions, has three options: she can appeal the ruling, retry the men  Terrill Swift, Michael Saunders, Harold Richardson and Vincent Thames  or dismiss the charges.

title: Illinois: Chicago Budget Gets Unanimous Consent
description: The inaugural budget of Mayor Rahm Emanuel of Chicago, which pits unpopular cuts and fees against the citys growing fiscal crisis, won unanimous approval from all 50 aldermen on Wednesday. The $8.2 billion budget leans heavily on politically charged cost-saving measures like consolidating police and fire departments, closing mental health clinics, laying off city workers, reducing library hours and increasing some fees.

title: NYT Front Page for 11/17/2011
description: NYT Front Page for 11/17/2011

title: Jets at Broncos: Matchup to Watch
description: Jets (5-4) at Broncos (4-5), 8:30 p.m. Eastern Thursday

title: X Factor Watch: Not Quite Rocking Out
description: It was rock night Wednesday on The X Factor, but only one real rock star turned up: Josh Krajcik, who owned the evening with his rendition of the Foo Fighters song The Pretender. The performance brought all four judges to their feet and solidified Mr. Krajciks place as one of the top contenders.

title: In Bihar, Turning Guns into Farm Tools
description: Blacksmith Sunil Thakur had never felt as important in his life as he did on Nov. 4, when the district police chief, an executive magistrate and a posse of junior officials visited his makeshift roadside furnace.

title: Pakistan: U.S. Strike Is Said to Kill Taliban Militants
Pakistan: Suicide Bombing Kills 2 Police Officials
description: Two police officials were killed in a suicide bomb attack late Wednesday night when three people, including a woman, blew up their vehicle during a police chase in the southern port city of Karachi, according to police and government officials. The bombers were driving in an upscale neighborhood when the police tried to stop them, leading to the chase. The police said they were unsure whom the bombers had meant to attack. Karachi has a history of ethnic, sectarian and militant-related violence.

title: Nuclear Watchdog Seeks Mission to Iran
description: LONDON  Adding new pressures on Tehran over its disputed nuclear program, the head of the United Nations nuclear watchdog group said Thursday that he wanted to send a high-level mission to Iran to investigate a report by his agency that Iranian scientists had engaged in secret and possibly continuing efforts to construct a nuclear weapon.

title: Nov. 17, 1973 | Nixon Declares I Am Not a Crook
description: On Nov. 17, 1973, President Richard M. Nixon held a news conference before Associated Press managing editors in Orlando, Fla., in which he defended himself against a number of allegations. Most of the questions related to the Watergate break-in, which had become even more of a scandal a month earlier with the Saturday Night Massacre. Other questions focused on reports that he had cheated on his tax returns.

title: News Quiz | Nov. 17, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Reading About Recent Exhibits in the Art & Design Section
description: Note: This edition of 6 Qs About the News uses several recent Times articles about art and design. Each question links to the article in which an answer can be found.

title: Why Not Break Up Citigroup?
description: Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is the co-author of 13 Bankers.

title: The Fracturing of Pennsylvania
description: Amwell Township is a 44-square-mile plot of steep ravines and grassy pasturelands planted with alfalfa, trefoil and timothy in the southwestern corner of Pennsylvania. Its home to some 4,000 people, most of whom live in villages named Amity, Lone Pine and Prosperity.

title: Test Yourself | English, Nov. 17, 2011
description: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article Joe Frazier, Ex-Heavyweight Champ, Dies at 67.

title: How They Move Your Whole House
description: FOR anyone who has ever suffered through the agony of a move (towers of boxes, miles of packing tape, untold numbers of annoyed friends), it seems like the ideal solution: just take the whole darn house, beds and all, and plop it in another location.

title: What Do You Read, and How Do You Read It?
description: We recently did a post on the future of reading about how books and reading habits are changing because of technology. What kinds of things do you read in an average day, and how do you read them? For instance, do you read novels you find at bookstores or libraries, or do you buy and read them on an e-reader? Do you read news or follow current events about a hobby or interest? If so, do you do so mostly on your computer or phone, or in print? Do you often follow links on social networks like Facebook or Twitter? How would you characterize the kinds of things you read that way?

title: Bransons Empire to Buy Bank Owned by Britain
description: LONDON  The British government agreed on Thursday to sell Northern Rock, the lender it nationalized more than three years ago, to Virgin Money, which is controlled by Richard Branson, in a deal that represents a loss for Britains taxpayers.

title: The Early Word: China
description: In Todays Times:

title: Confrontations Abound at Outdoor Art Show in Prague
description: Expect to be confronted with the unexpected at an open-air exhibition in Prague with the appropriate title of Confrontations. Jaroslav Andel, the artistic director at DOX Center for Contemporary Art created the show, which takes inspiration from an older Czech art form: the pairing of contrasting images. The exhibition runs Nov. 18 to 26 on the plaza between the National and Nova Scena theaters.

title: Sneak Peek at Our Great Performers Shoot
description: Heres a behind-the-scenes peek at the filming last week of one of the videos for our annual presentation of original films starring the actors who gave the years most memorable performances. This years concept is supercool, and our director is having wicked fun with it. The films will make their premiere online in advance of a corresponding portfolio of photographs in the Dec. 11 issue of the magazine.

title: Week 11 N.F.L. Game Probabilities, and the Tebow Factor
description: Tim Tebow is breaking the game probability model. How can a quarterback lead his team to victory while going 2 for 8, for 69 total passing yards? Its widely accepted that passing efficiency is the main driver of team success, but what if an astounding 8.6 yards per attempt comes on only two completions?

title: Part 4: Answers to Your Questions on Scholarships and Student Loans
description: To help readers of The Choice navigate the maze of scholarships available to them  as well as to further their understanding of President Obamas recent proposal to ease the repayment of some student loans  Mark Kantrowitz, a financial aid expert and founder of the Web sites finaid.org and fastweb.com, is spending this week in our virtual Guidance Office. Mr. Kantrowitz is the author of Secrets to Winning a Scholarship, published in February.

title: Arab League Offers Syria a Reprieve as Deaths Mount
description: RABAT, Morocco  In what amounted to a surprise reprieve, the Arab League offered to send civilian and military monitors to Syria on Wednesday to determine whether it was abiding by a league-brokered peace plan to end the crackdown on the countrys eight-month uprising. The move countered the leagues startling decision five days earlier to suspend Syria.

title: Billions Lost by Olympus May Be Tied to Criminals
description: TOKYO  Japanese officials say that at least $4.9 billion is unaccounted for in a financial scandal at Olympus and are investigating whether much of that money went to companies with links to organized crime.

title: Dear Dr. Mallya, Sir Richard Is On the Line
description: A lion-maned airline baron with a voracious appetite for publicity, love of fast carsand a bevy of beautiful, red-skirted female employees was suddenly under fire.

title: Engineering Majors Most Likely to Burn the Midnight Oil
description: Students who major in engineering and the physical sciences can expect to spend more hours in the library than those who take a concentration of courses in business and social sciences, according to a national survey of more than 400,000 undergraduates at nearly 700 colleges and universities.

title: Obama Addresses Troops at Final Stop in Australia
description: DARWIN, Australia  Fresh from announcing an expanded American military presence in Australia, a plan that has angered China, President Obama came to this remote northern town that will be the base of operations and told American and Australian troops it is the perfect place.

title: Is It Improper to Turn Thanksgiving Into a Potluck? And How Do I Tell My Guests?
description: Q.

title: Bringing the Tasting Room to the Living Room
description: Using a technology that sounds more NASA than Napa, TastingRoom.com reformats wines from their original retail packaging into 50- and 100-milliliter, single-serving bottles. Technicians re-pour some 1,000 varieties of wine inside an oxygen- and particle-free Plexiglas clean room, which is 40 feet long and protected from contamination by a pair of airlocks, similar to the entry and exit vestibules on a spacecraft. Tiny bottles mean consumers can sample high-quality individual wines without committing to buy a traditional 750-milliliter bottle of each one.

title: Storybook Ballerinas True-Life Adventure
description: IN the fall of 1976 A Very Young Dancer leaped into the imaginations of a generation of little girls. This childrens book by the photographer Jill Krementz chronicled the day-to-day life of a 10-year-old student from the School of American Ballet, following her to class and through her starring role as Marie in New York City Ballets Nutcracker, for which she was handpicked by George Balanchine himself. (George Balanchines Nutcracker, performed by City Ballet, begins its 57th season on Friday at the Koch Theater.)

title: A Radical Rethinking of Thanksgiving Leftovers
description: Everyone (yes, literally) says that leftovers are the best part of Thanksgiving, but Im not psyched for dry meat on bread with a ton of mayonnaise, or even that exotic alternative, cranberry sauce.

title: Tech Talk Podcast: App Design and Cloud Work
description: In this weeks podcast, we ask how you convert a popular 1,200-page travel guide into an interactive iPad app. As the latest edition of 1,000 Places to See Before You Die arrives in stores this week, its author, Patricia Schultz  along with David Link and Joe McCambley of the Wonderfactory digital design studio  discuss how they created the books companion app.

title: Long Past Knocking Heads, Nightstick Now Kneads Bread Instead
description: Harry Rosenblum spent a recent afternoon rolling out dough to make egg noodles at the Brooklyn Kitchen, a food emporium he owns in Williamsburg.

title: Commodities Lead a Downward Trend
description: Stocks and commodities slid on Thursday and the euro erased an earlier gain as concern grew that Europes debt crisis would worsen and lawmakers would fail to agree on plans to cut the American deficit.

title: A Phone App for Switching Out Your Light Bulbs
description: How many mobile-phone apps does it take to change a light bulb?

title: Republican Ads Turn More Aggressive
description: As the Republican presidential candidates begin to turn their attention to the airwaves in the final six weeks before voting begins, two strategies are starting to become clear.

title: Gadgetwise: Electronics Price Predictor Is Now Mobile
description: In June, Oren Etzioni, the brains behind the airline price predictor site Farecast, brought forth Decide.com, a Web site that predicted the future prices of laptops, cameras and televisions. With a Wait or Buy signal, it gave you the probability that prices would change or that a new model was coming. There was one flaw with it. You need this information in the store as much as at home or in the office on your PC. The company promised a mobile app and it is now in the Apple App store.

title: Media Decoder: Google Opens a Digital Music Store
description: Looking to extend its reach as a hub for entertainment and social networking, Google introduced a set of music features on Wednesday, including a download store to compete with iTunes.

title: Which Pitcher Should the Yankees Sign?
description: Mark Buerhle, C.J. Wilson and Edwin Jackson are free agents. John Danks, James Shields, Gio Gonzalez, Gavin Floyd and Wandy Rodriguez could be available through a trade. Does the Yankees rotation need one of these guys (and if so, who)?

title: Edward, You May Now Bite the Bride
description: Dawn isnt the only thing that gets broken in The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn  Part I, the latest and best of the movies about a girl, her vampire and their impossible, ridiculously appealing  yes, I surrendered  love story. Marked by a canny mix of violence and chastity, the franchise has always had plenty of broken heads to go along with its pure thoughts, but here it also features a marital bed reduced to kindling after a rough night. If that doesnt sound like the series that has kept millions of prepubescent viewers virtuously rapt, youre right. But little Bella is all grown up now, and while Edward is still more zomboid than juicily predatory, this time not everything else on screen is dead too.

title: Breakfast Meeting, Nov. 17
description: The National Book Awards were announced Wednesday night at Cipriani Wall Street, and Julie Bosman reports in ArtsBeat that the winner for fiction was Jesmyn Ward for Salvage the Bones, from Bloomsbury, a novel about a Gulf Coast familys preparations as a hurricane bears down.

title: Scheduling Chaos at Another Queens High School
Clashes and More Than 240 Arrests on Protests Day of Action
description: Two months after it began in New York, Occupy Wall Street carried out a Day of Action on Thursday featuring an attempt to delay the opening of the New York Stock Exchange, demonstrations on the subways, a sit-in in the roadway at the base of the Brooklyn Bridge and unscheduled clashes with the police in Zuccotti Park that left a protester with a bloodied face and an officer with a lacerated hand.

title: Default, Inflation, the Blooey Factor, and the Rubicon Effect
description: Antonia Fatas has a thoughtful post questioning whether the lack of ones oneown currency really matters; he writes,

title: Gingrich on Defensive Over Freddie Mac Fees
description: For roughly six years, Newt Gingrich worked closely with high-level officials at the government-sponsored mortgage company Freddie Mac. As a highly paid consultant, he coached them on how to win over the conservatives who consider their company an anathema, spoke to their political action committee and offered general advice as they worked to stave off various threats to Freddie Macs survival, several people familiar with his role there said on Wednesday.

title: A Silicon Valley Dream Grows in Guatemala
description: For now, it is just a single brick building in Guatemala City called Campus Tecnolgico, with workspaces, programming classes and eco-friendly signs asking people to turn off lights in unused bathrooms. But Damien Cave reports in The New York Times that the developers goal is to turn this five- or six-block area in the citys center into an entrepreneurial campus and a residential outpost for the hip, savvy, successful and young.

title: Is It Safe to Cook a Reagan-Era Frozen Turkey?
description: Q.

title: Subsiding Inflation
description: Calculated Risk informs us that key measures of inflation have subsided. Still no hyperinflation by 2010.

title: Opinion Report: Before Its Too Late
description: From the editorial page

title: Welcome to the News Business, Ms. Clinton
description: If ever a development was bound to create jealousy and an urge to ridicule, it was the announcement the other day that Chelsea Clinton started working at NBC News as a special correspondent. She had to be the most untrained and least experienced new hire by a major network since, oh, since NBC in 2009 made Jenna Bush Hager, another presidential daughter with questionable credentials, a correspondent on its Today show.

title: Thursday Reading: An App To Help You Find Better Lightbulbs
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: A Day of Protest, and Arrests
description: Two days after the Occupy Wall Street encampment was cleared at Zuccotti Park, demonstrators held a day of action in New York, resulting in more than 175 arrests.

title: Lawyer Resigns After Liu Asks Him to Suspend an Internal Fund-Raising Review
description: Updated, 9:25 p.m.|The former state attorney general hired last month by City Comptroller John C. Lius campaign to conduct an internal review of its fund-raising practices resigned on Thursday, a day after a federal inquiry focused on Mr. Liu led to criminal charges against one of his fund-raisers.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: With MF Global Money Still Missing, Suspicions Grow | Nearly three weeks after $600 million in customer money went missing from MF Global, the search for the cash has been hampered by the bankrupt brokerage firms sloppy record-keeping, an increasingly worrisome situation that has left regulators frustrated and customers in the lurch.

title: Timely | Reel People
description: The artist and filmmaker Meredith Danluck and the director of photography Jake Burghart met while working on Garbage Island, a documentary about the North Pacific Gyre for Vice magazines Web site.

title: Not All Rivers Reach the Sea
description: When the conservation writer Jonathan Waterman decided to investigate the health of the Colorado River, he took it to extremes. In the spring of 2008, he packed up his supplies and set out on a 1,450-mile source-to-sea journey down the Colorado River.

title: Gingrich May Have Unlikely Ally in Obama on Lobbying
description: Newt Gingrich explains away his work for the Freddie Mac mortgage giant by insisting on the rather fine distinction that he was never, officially, a registered lobbyist.

title: What Were Reading
description: Poetry Foundation: Its only a week away, folks. Time to start summoning that kitchen magic.  Jeff Gordinier

title: Star Manager Giving Up Legg Mason Fund
description: Bill Miller, a legendary mutual fund manager, said Thursday he was stepping down from the Legg Mason fund that had long made him a star on Wall Street until the volatile years after 2006 brought his fund and his stellar track record hurtling to earth.

title: The Big Sleazy
description: For the third time in 16 years, the Supreme Court is taking up the question of why prosecutors in New Orleans seem to have so much trouble with the law. Smith v. Cain, a case heard last week, outlines truly shocking misdeeds going back decades. And an article in The Times-Picayune makes clear that problems continue.

title: The Place | Florida, Part Five
description: MIAMI BEATS

title: On Our Radar: Arguments Fly at Hearing on Fracking
description: More than 850 people pack a middle school auditorium in Dansville, N.Y., to express their views on the New York State Department of Environmental Conservations proposed rules for natural gas drilling in the Marcellus Shale. [The Buffalo News]

title: Poetry Pairing | To My Dear and Loving Husband
description: This weeks Poetry Pairing matches Anne Bradstreets To My Dear and Loving Husband with a Metro column about a husband whose wife recently died.

title: FARC Forever?
description: BOGOT  On Nov. 4, after years of military raids and a number of near-misses, Colombian troops killed the 63-year-old Guillermo Len Senz, a k a Alfonso Cano, the commander of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC. President Juan Manuel Santos of Colombia called this the biggest blow to the Marxist group in its 47-year history.

title: Words of a Euro Doomsayer Have New Resonance
description: LONDON  The euro zone was crumbling, just as he had long predicted, yet Bernard Connolly, Europes most persistent prophet of doom, still faced a skeptical audience.

title: End of the Rainbow Finds a Broadway Home
description: End of the Rainbow, a hit London drama-with-music about Judy Garlands final months, will play in New York this spring at the Belasco Theater, one of the last Broadway houses to announce its booking for the coming theater season. The shows producers announced on Thursday that its star, the British actress Tracie Bennett, who received critical praise for the West End production, will be joined on Broadway by Michael Cumpsty (the 2008 revival of Sunday in the Park With George) as her gay pianist, Anthony; Tom Pelphrey (a daytime Emmy Award winner on Guiding Light) as her young fianc, Mickey; and Jay Russell in various other roles. Written by Peter Quilter and directed by Terry Johnson (a Tony Award winner in 2010 for La Cage aux Folles), End of the Rainbow will begin preview performances on March 19; the show will open on April 2 instead of the previously announced April 3.

title: How Do We Define Bullying?
description: Does it matter that we cant define bullying if we know it when we see it?

title: A Fair A.T.M. Fee? Many Consumers Say Zero
description: As the events of the last couple of months have shown, Americans do not like to pay bank fees. Indeed, a new survey shows, a majority think the only acceptable A.T.M. fee is no fee at all.

title: Lens: Klaus Pinchlers Museum
description: Lens: Klaus Pinchlers Museum

title: Jets Defender Improves With Help From Revis
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  After dressing for practices in a lonely corner as a rookie, Kyle Wilson became Darrelle Reviss neighbor in the Jets locker room this year, apparently because Revis insisted on it. Time to move onto the block, Revis told Wilson with a smile.

title: Day 2: Inside MF Globals Bankruptcy Hearing
description: A proposal to make cash distributions to MF Global customers was the focus of a hearing on Thursday at the federal bankruptcy court in Manhattan. DealBook provided live coverage of the proceedings.

title: Guess Where This Is
description: Its time again for our weekly contest: guess the location of the photograph above.

title: Pairings for Day 2 of the Presidents Cup
description: The United States team leads the International team, 4-2, after the first-round matches at the Presidents Cup in Melbourne, Australia. Despite a surprising rout of Tiger Woods and Steve Stricker by Adam Scott and K. J. Choi, the Americans put on an impressive show, particularly by two Presidents Cup rookies, Bubba Watson and Webb Simpson, who teamed up to beat Ernie Els and Ryo Ishikawa, 4 and 2. Concerns about the weather led officials to move up tee times for the second round by two hours to 9:35 a.m. local time, which is 5:35 p.m. Thursday in the Eastern time zone. Here are the pairings for the fourball matches.

title: U.N. Court in Cambodia Recommends Freeing Defendant Ill With Dementia
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia  A tribunal backed by the United Nations that is trying top leaders of the Khmer Rouge announced on Thursday that a sister-in-law of the regimes former leader, Pol Pot, was unfit to stand trial and should be released because she suffers from dementia.

title: How Far in Advance Can I Buy a Fresh Turkey?
description: Q.

title: 36 Hours in Santa Barbara
description: Over the past few years, the city has made room for a new downtown scene humming with cool shops and laid-back wine bars.

title: Eritrean National Team Heads Home Intact
description: KIGALI, Rwanda  The Eritrea national soccer team might have been knocked out of 2014 World Cup qualification after its 3-1 defeat to Rwanda in Kigali on Tuesday, but the teams management scored a small victory of sorts.

title: No Basketball, Fewer Bar Customers
description: The players are locked out. The fans are depressed. And now the N.B.A. stalemate has claimed a whole new class of victims: New Yorks bar owners, who say theyre losing as much as a third of their revenue because sports fans and tourists arent showing up to watch games.

title: TV Picks, Crowd-Sourced
description: The New York Times Fall TV Ratings Game has come and gone. Times readers who thought they knew better than the network executives which shows would succeed and which would fail submitted their fantasy lineups by Oct. 1 and predicted which shows would be cancelled first. And who can argue with them?

title: Newly Surfaced Tagore Manuscript Up for Auction
description: A previously unknown manuscript by the Nobel Prize-winning poet and artist Rabindranath Tagore is being sold at Sothebys in New York on Dec. 13.

title: 36 Hours in Santa Barbara, Calif.
description: RECOMMENDATIONS about what to do in Santa Barbara invariably include references to the celebrities who have settled along this beautiful stretch of Californias central coast. Want to take an afternoon hike? Head into the hills near Oprahs house. Looking for a place to eat? Try the taqueria that Julia Child adored. Just 100 miles north of Los Angeles, this quiet beach community has long been a hideaway for celebrity heavyweights. But over the past few years, the city has also made room for a new downtown scene humming with cool shops and laid-back wine bars, mobile food trucks and casual restaurants. Its Santa Barbara for every budget  whether you debarked from a private jet at the citys new $63 million airport terminal or cruised into town off Highway 101.

title: Protests Illustrate Dire Economic Anxiety, Bloomberg Says
description: As Occupy Wall Street protesters massed in Lower Manhattan on Thursday morning, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg was in Midtown, telling an audience of business leaders that the protests were a dire sign of the publics economic fears.

title: Cant Anybody Here Play These Games?
description: The sports world has been positively prolific in producing villains these days. They seem to roll off the assembly line daily now. Penn State, of course, has created a category all its own, but the field around them is crowded with Tiger Woods and Michael Vick; the N.B.A., which occupies the unique position of having a fight where no one is rooting for either side; the still-screwing-things-up Red Sox.

title: How LaMichael James Got Back Into the Heisman Conversation
description: LaMichael James edged his way back into the Heisman Trophy race in much the same way that the Oregon Ducks regained their standing in the B.C.S. championship conversation: through a perfect mix of stellar play and unforeseen stumbles from other contenders.

title: Hearty Holiday Main Courses for Vegans
description: While vegetarian diners are happy to fill their plates with Thanksgiving side dishes, many chefs still want to serve their non-turkey-eating guests a substitute for the meaty main course.

title: Online Advertising Group Hires New Chief
description: The Network Advertising Initiative, a group promoting self-regulation in online advertising, announced on Thursday that Marc Groman, the chief privacy officer for the Federal Trade Commission, would become the organizations next executive director and general counsel.

title: New albums from Drake, Romeo Santos and The Fall
description: This week: Jon Caramanica on Drake; Larry Rohter on Romeo Santos; and reviews of new releases by Caveman, Los Campesinos! and the Fall. Ben Ratliff is the host.

title: Paprika, a Recipe App That Lets You Get Organized
description: Over in the Tech department, The Timess App Smart columnist, Bob Tedeschi, has a roundup of food-related apps.

title: With New M5, BMW Finds Itself on the Redemption Trail
description: LOS ANGELES  The M5 badge has been around since 1988. By some automakers standards, the intervening 23 years would be pretext to make the fifth-generation M5, which was introduced to a North American audience on Wednesday here  and to the world at the Frankfurt auto show in September  something of a throwback.

title: Angies List Soars, But Delphi Disappoints
description: For the initial public offerings market, its still a tale of the haves and the have-nots.

title: France Nouveau
description: Most foreigners who come to the south of France think of Marseille as an exit or entry point. Its convenient, only an hours drive from Avignon and the hill towns of the Vaucluse and so many other lovely places in Provence. In Marseilles small airport, you buy a 1 euro cup of machine coffee and you get on a plane headed for Paris or home, your mind filled with one version of France: idyllic little towns with churches and castles, lush green valleys, fruit trees in serried ranks, Provenal linens, village markets, antiques, lace, espadrilles, vineyards, lavender, handcrafted pts, local wines, artisanal goat cheese.

title: Interview With Scott Bateman
description: Scott Bateman, Ph.D. student at the University of Saskatchewan showed this poster at the HCIR research conference at Google in October.

title: Design Unveiled for Tower at Atlantic Yards
description: The developer Bruce C. Ratner unveiled the design Thursday for what would be the worlds tallest prefabricated steel structure, a 32-story residential building in Brooklyn at the corner of Flatbush Avenue and Dean Street in the $4.9 billion Atlantic Yards project.

title: Zombiegate!
description: Every week, when The New York Times Book Review goes live on our Web site, Twitter lights up with links and opinions about its contents. But when Glen Duncans review of Colson Whiteheads new zombie novel, Zone One, appeared a few weeks ago, the response was heavier  and harsher  than usual. Mr. Duncan, like Mr. Whitehead, is a highly literary prose stylist who ventured into supernatural territory with his well-received last novel (The Last Werewolf), and his thoughts on genre touched a nerve. We asked him if he wanted to clarify his review or reply to his critics; his response is below.  The Editors

title: The Life Report: D.R.G.
description: The following Life Report was submitted in response to my column of Oct. 28, in which I asked readers over 70 to write autobiographical essays evaluating their own lives.

title: Coda and General Electric, Joined at the Power Cord
description: LOS ANGELES  GE Energy announced Wednesday evening that its 240-volt wall-mounted WattStation electric vehicle charging unit would be official equipment for the coming Coda E.V.

title: Neighborhood Joint | Leeds Radio
description: A Williamsburg electronics shop, one of the oldest in the country, carries hundreds of thousands of analog electronic parts, all manufactured before 1968.

title: A Canceled Meeting Between Cain and a Newspaper
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Has the usually gregarious Herman Cain become camera-shy and taciturn, at least when it comes to meeting with newspaper editorial boards? It might seem that way. On Thursday, Mr. Cain, back in this early voting state for the first time since early October, was scheduled to meet with The Union Leader of New Hampshire for a one-hour question-and-answer session that would be videotaped for the papers Web site.

title: Daily Report: Voting With an iPad
description: The spread of the iPad beyond the consumer market to business is one of the most noteworthy trends of the year. The device has also found advocates among educators and, in many remarkable ways, among the disabled. Katharine Q. Seelye, a New York Times reporter, reports that Oregon became the first state in the country to use iPads to allow people with disabilities to vote, and it intends to use them again for another election in January. Several other states are expected to follow suit with iPads or other tablets, possibly as early as for next years presidential election.

title: Pajama Caper
description: Its nice to see that Kinsey Millhone hasnt grown cynical (or, worse yet, mellowed) since she took on her initial case almost 30 years ago in Sue Graftons first alphabet mystery. In V IS FOR VENGEANCE (Marian Wood/Putnam, $27.95), the California private eye is still so hard-nosed about upholding the law that she gets a buzz from turning in a respectable-looking woman whos boosting silk pajamas from the lingerie department at Nordstroms. But when the humiliated thief dives off a 400-foot-high bridge, apparently a suicide, Kinsey regrets her superior attitude and goes to work for the womans fianc, trying to track down her criminal associates and find out who might have helped her off that bridge.

title: Smiling at the Old Days, and the Ones Still Ahead
description: FORGET her signature song, Memory. Elaine Paiges real signature is her laugh: deep, throaty, suggestive of indiscreet and dishy stories to come: Heh-heh-heh-heh. A little bit of a tease, that laugh; getting dirt  even nice, sweet who-you-going-out-with-these-days dirt  from the first lady of British musical comedy, now featured in the Broadway revival of Follies, is at first a bit of a slog.

title: Lifes a Happy Song
description: Bret McKenzie and Kermit the Frog sing a song from the coming movie The Muppets.

title: Not Two Words, but One; Trust Becomes an Issue
description: A decade after 9/11, and nine years after a the New York Police Department created a unit devoted to understanding terrorism and working against it, the Police Department has decided on a name change.

title: Return of The Munsters? Maybe.
description: Though no clamor for a comeback had been heard, The Munsters may be returning to television.

title: House Leaders Plan Facebook Hackathon
description: While House Republican and Democratic leaders are finding it difficult to agree on spending cuts, they are coming together next month for Capitol Hills first-ever Facebook Hackathon. The goal is to find new ways to use the social network to make information about the legislative process more transparent and to help members of the public more easily engage with lawmakers.

title: Cat-and-Mole Games on the Mexican Border
description: Authorities in San Diego and Tijuana, Mexico, trumpeted the news this week that they had seized more than 17 tons of marijuana and closed down a tunnel used to smuggle drugs under the border between the two countries.

title: Armed Groups Are on Rise in Syria, as Are Civil War Fears
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  For the second day in a row, deserters from the Syrian Army carried out attacks on symbols of the Assad governments centers of power, targeting the youth offices of the ruling Baath Party on Thursday after firing rocket-propelled grenades on a military intelligence base on Wednesday, activists said.

title: Battles Begin Early for Female Recruits in Afghan Army
description: Zainab is a cadet at the female Officer Candidate School called Malalai Company at the Kabul Military Training Center, roughly eight miles east of the capital. She sat on her bed at the female barracks on a recent day being comforted by two other female cadets. She said she did not feel well because two days before, her fianc had threatened her with knife and told her he would kill her if she did not leave the Army.

title: On Composing for Kermit the Frog
description: Before we get to the Flight of the Conchords or the tricky art of writing funny songs for beloved puppets to sing, we need to talk about Figwit. Because should you enter Bret McKenzie into Google, youll find that the first suggested search is not, say, Bret McKenzie Conchords or even Bret McKenzie Muppets but Bret McKenzie Lord of the Rings. Intrigued, you will investigate further. And you will learn that McKenzie, a native New Zealander, had a three-second role as a nameless elf in Lord of the Rings: Fellowship of the Ring in 2001. (His father, Peter McKenzie, is a part-time actor who played a larger role in the film, as the human Elendil.) Furthermore, a sharp-eyed Israeli woman spotted the then-not-famous McKenzie and, smitten by his elfin beauty, dubbed him Figwit. (Its an acronym for Frodo Is Great . . . Who Is That?!?? which she claims is a more or less accurate transcription of her original reaction to seeing the elf.) This woman then established a Web site, Figwitlives.net, dedicated to all things Figwittian. There were local news stories. There were roving bands of Tolkienites that trailed McKenzie to Conchords shows. There was even a tongue-in-cheek documentary created in part by McKenzies girlfriend (now his wife), Hannah Clarke, which contains this quote from Ian McKellen when asked about Figwit: I do remember there were some very attractive young girls. Which one was he? McKenzie explains the Figwit phenomenon like this: My brother was also an extra. Basically all tall and skinny New Zealanders were elves in the film.

title: Whats a Good Entree for a Vegan/Vegetarian Thanksgiving?
description: Q.

title: Reuters Will No Longer Let Reporter Who Worked for Saleh Cover Yemen
description: 3:41 p.m. | Updated  The Reuters news agency on Thursday defended the work of one of its Yemen correspondents amid outrage from opposition activists over his employment by the government as a personal translator to President Ali Abdullah Saleh.

title: Getting the Message Across to Your Employees
description: How do you get your employees to think like you? During a recent meeting of our business group, Alexandra Mayzler raised that question as she weighs expanding her business, Thinking Caps Tutoring, into new markets. Thinking Caps currently has locations in New York City and Austin, Tex. Ms. Mayzler is considering opening a Houston outpost,but said she wants to be sure systems are in place before taking the plunge.

title: Tracing the History of the Pilgrims
description: Walking in the footsteps of Americas first settlers, from English farmlands to the urban streets of the Netherlands.

title: Excerpt: 'Private Lives' on Broadway
description: Paul Gross and Kim Cattrall in the Broadway revival of Noel Cowards Private Lives, at the Music Box Theater. (Video courtesy of the production.)

title: A Haven for Lovers of the Analog
description: WHEN an insurance company declared the merchandise at Leeds Radio not pilferable last year, it meant that the stores hundreds of thousands of analog electronic parts  all manufactured before 1968  were unlikely to be stolen anytime soon.

title: An Edge in Science Among the Foreign-Born
description: Ive previously written about the wage advantage  as well as the simple likelihood of finding and holding onto a job  that comes with a bachelors degree in science, technology, engineering or math.

title: Without Fanfare, Belichick and Brady Become Top Coach-Quarterback Combination
description: An under-reported story line from last Sundays Jets-Patriots game was that Bill Belichick and Tom Brady became the winningest head coach-quarterback tandem of the Super Bowl era (since 1966). They registered their 117th regular-season victory to move past Don Shula and Dan Marino, who totaled 116 for the Miami Dolphins from 1983-95.

title: Protesters Shutting Down the Subway? Depends on What You Watch
description: Much of what is said on television about the Occupy Wall Street movement is opinion. Some is factual. And sometimes, its hard to tell the difference.

title: Now Showing | Eames: The Architect and the Painter
description: More than any other American designers, Charles and Ray Eames helped define the postwar Modernist aesthetic. Their furniture filled houses, offices and airport terminals. Their films, like Powers of Ten, (video) made us think about big questions and small in new ways. Their information overload approach produced multiscreen installations, like Glimpses of the USA, for the National Exhibition in Moscow in 1959 and their I.B.M. Pavilion at the 1964 Worlds Fair in New York, which foreshadowed the way information is presented on the Internet. And their work was presented with an artistry that made it look effortless. Of course, it wasnt.

title: Among Compact Crossovers, Best in Class Proves a Highly Contentious Title
description: LOS ANGELES  At the unveiling of the Mazda CX-5 on Wednesday, the automaker promised press conference attendees that the new small crossover would deliver best-in-class fuel mileage.

title: Euro Debt Worries Shift to Spain and France
description: PARIS  Italy, the third-largest economy of the euro bloc, has spent days struggling in the market spotlight. On Thursday, however, investors turned their attention to the No. 2, France, and No. 4, Spain, whose borrowing costs spiked during the day.

title: Mushroom Magic
description: Hedgehogs, fairy clubs, hawks wings and candy caps: these are just a gladeful of the fungal eruptions that have captivated Eugenia Bone, the intrepid  when not encountering grizzly bears  author of one of the most beguiling books Ive read this year. A generous sprinkling of amateur photos only adds to the charm of Mycophilia. I was especially taken by a black-and-white snapshot of 30 sturdily dressed mycophiles trotting briskly en masse across a field, heading toward the days quarry: delectable, hard-to-find morels. Some morel-pickers, Bone informs us, carry extremely tiny baskets  because they dont want to alert the mushrooms to their intentions.

title: TimesCast | November 17, 2011
description: Occupy Wall Street protesters clash with the police while trying to reach the New York Stock Exchange; and a Pennsylvania town becomes a focal point in the contentious fracking debate.

title: Food Truck Fight Shifts to SoHo
description: The long-simmering feud between merchants and mobile food carts on the sidewalks  as well as food trucks established on the street  has boiled over once again, this time in SoHo. At a Community Board 2 dustup on Monday night, first reported on Thursday by DNAinfo.com, residents and merchants blamed the city for lax enforcement of the laws governing street vendors.

title: Don DeLillo and the Varieties of American Unease
description: The older you get, the more jarring it can be to turn on the news and behold newly minted pundits sounding off on the import of dramatic changes rocking the nation  pundits who look as if theyre barely out of high school. How do these youthful commentators come by their rapid-fire insights? Does somebody tweet them their lines? Is there a meme? Don DeLillo takes this sense of generational perplexity one absurdist step further in Hammer and Sickle, the longest of the nine excellent stories in The Angel Esmeralda, the first collection of his short fiction.

title: Tanglewood Planning a Trip Down Memory Lane
description: A vivid purple and pink sunset dissolved into night while bright lamps blazed inside a vast tent as the Boston Symphony Orchestra began playing Beethovens Leonore Overture No. 3 before 5,000 people. The date was Aug. 5, 1937, and it was the orchestras first concert at an estate known as Tanglewood. Next July 6, 75 years later, the Boston Symphony will reproduce the program (which included Beethovens symphonies No. 5 and 6) during the latest version of the Tanglewood Music Festival, the orchestra said on Thursday. The festival runs from June 22 to Sept. 2.

title: Week 11 in Fantasy Football: Favorable and Unfavorable Matchups
description: Jason and Justin Sablich are here to help you with your fantasy football team. The Sablich brothers will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy).

title: Subaru BRZ Concept STI Breaks Loose From All-Wheel-Drive Template
description: Introduced on Wednesday, Nov. 16: Subaru BRZ Concept STI

title: Panel Hears Defense of Loan to Solyndra
description: WASHINGTON  The bankruptcy of Solyndra, the solar power company that took $528 million in government loans, was extremely unfortunate, Steven Chu, the energy secretary, told lawmakers on Thursday. But he rejected a suggestion put forward by a Republican that he or his department should apologize.

title: How to Make Creamy Mashed Potatoes
description: Melissa Clark demonstrates how to make rich mashed potatoes without lumps.

title: A Mothers Fight for Newborn Hearts
description: As a pediatric cardiologist, I had grown increasingly concerned over the years about the many seemingly healthy newborns who left the hospital, only to return a few hours or days later in shock as a result of undetected heart problems. Two years ago, I wrote about the problem on the Well blog in an article, Screening Babies for Broken Hearts, in which I described a simple, cheap and painless screening test to check newborns for potentially lethal heart defects.

title: 4  3  2  1   Beaujolais Nouveau!
description: Cadillac and Detroit were originally French words one a proper name, the other a geographic term. So maybe it was not so far-fetched that this years batch of Beaujolais nouveau, the wine many Americans consider quintessentially French, arrived at a party where it was drunk for the first time in a Cadillac that was made in Detroit.

title: Imagining the Lives of the Great Explorers
description: Just like the subjects of her singular new collection of stories, Sabina Murray is an explorer  someone with a hankering to visit places others tend to avoid. Where better for such a writer to poke around than inside the heads of those extraordinary individuals who themselves set off to survey the unknown?

title: John Caseys Work Out Book
description: In his author photos, the aggressively bearded John Casey often glares at the camera as if hes just ordered the landlubbing cameraman off his skiff. Casey is the author of four novels, but hes best known for the National Book Award-winning Spartina, a beautifully written portrait of a Rhode Island fisherman, and Compass Rose, a sequel devoted to the fishermans daughter. Id always assumed the author spent his mornings writing and his afternoons mending trawl nets.

title: Dead Dog Comes Back to Haunt Artist
description: The New York sculptor Tom Otterness may be known for his whimsical and warm sculptures of animals and cartoon-like characters, but in San Francisco, a lurid act from his past has come back to haunt him.

title: World War II, From the Ground Up
description: Do we really need another history of World War II? The book market is overflowing with them, and new ones seem to appear at almost weekly intervals. Vast though the conflict was, we probably know more about it than any other war in history. Sir Max Hastings, author of this latest survey, has already written no fewer than eight books about key campaigns and personalities of the war. Has he got anything new to say?

title: Backers of Proposition 8 Can Challenge Court Ruling
description: The California Supreme Court ruled Thursday that proponents of Proposition 8  which banned same-sex marriage in California  have legal standing to challenge the decision by a lower court judge overturning the ban, after the states governor and attorney general refused to defend the proposition.

title: From Homelessness to an Ad Campaign, With Employment Along the Way
description: When Betty Jo Fain was a homeless woman struggling with a drug and alcohol problem, the last thing she imagined was being the face for an advertising campaign promoting jobs at a naval shipbuilding company. On Thursday, her face was that face for Austal USA, the shipbuilding company where she works as a welder.

title: What Do I Need to Know to Make Delicious, Not-Lumpy Mashed Potatoes?
description: Q.

title: To Study Quail, With a Little Help
description: Jennifer Calkins, a biologist who teaches at Evergreen State College in Olympia, Wash., writes from Mexico, where she is studying the ecology, behavior and evolution of the elegant quail.

title: Winter Wonders | Buttoned Up
description: T tracks what stylish women are wearing to keep warm.

title: United States of Hunger
description: Casey Mulligan noted Wednesday on Economix that United States spending on food stamps had skyrocketed since the recession began. A new Census Bureau report provides a look at just how big the program has become. Last year, more than one in 10 families received food stamps, with some states having significantly higher participation rates. In Oregon, the share was nearly one in five.

title: Bernadette Peters and Martin Short Linked to Possible Revival of I Do! I Do!
description: The Tony Award-winning actors Bernadette Peters and Martin Short will meet with a team of theater producers this month to discuss a possible Broadway revival of I Do! I Do!, the 1966 Tom Jones-Harvey Schmidt musical about the trials and tribulations of a married couple over a 50-year period, according to theater executives familiar with the discussions.

title: Banks in Italy Find an Unusual Liquidity Lifeline
description: LONDON  The London Stock Exchange is becoming the lender of last resort for many banks in Italy as concerns over the countrys debt levels squeeze liquidity out of the Italian financial market.

title: Consumer Agency Seeks Comments on Private Student Loans
description: 10:30 p.m. Updated to revise email address for submitting comments.

title: Court Refuses to Extradite Killer Wanted in Hijacking
description: MADRID  A Portuguese court denied on Thursday an American request to extradite the fugitive murderer and hijacker who was apprehended in September in a village outside Lisbon where he had lived since the 1990s, his lawyer said.

title: A Day of Protests as Occupy Movement Marks Two-Month Milestone
description: Protesters across the country demonstrated en masse Thursday, snarling rush-hour traffic in several major cities and taking aim at banks as part of a national day of action to mark the two-month milestone of the Occupy Wall Street movement.

title: Hints of Tension Chip at a Heros Welcome for Cuomo
description: COLONIE, N.Y.  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo was received as a hero on Thursday at a meeting of the states Democratic Party, with elected officials crediting him for several critical victories in local government elections last week, and the governor highlighting those elections as a referendum on his first 10 months in office.

title: TimesCast | Protesters Clash with Police
description: Nov. 17, 2011  Occupy Wall Street protesters clashed with the police while trying to reach the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Outfits That Walk Between 2 Worlds
description: A mainstay on the citys charity circuit, Muffie Potter Aston was formerly the United States executive vice president of marketing and advertising for Van Cleef & Arpels. A Washington, D.C., native, she lives on the Upper East Side with her husband, the plastic surgeon Dr. Sherrell Aston, and their twin 6-year-old daughters, Ashleigh and Bracie.  BEE-SHYUAN CHANG

title: Gothic Fantasy, Hard-Boiled Crime and Zombies
description: As a gift, a video game really should keep on giving. When you give someone a game that truly appeals to his or her tastes, skills, motivations and interests, you should be providing many hours of stimulation and entertainment. Here are some of my favorite games of 2011; there ought to be something for just about any player except hard-core shooter fans (who have all bought Battlefield 3 or Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 3 already) and superhero fans (who are playing Batman: Arkham City).

title: Zynga Shakes Up Ranks
description: Zynga, which is headed for an initial public offering in the next few months, is shaking up its upper ranks.

title: Kuwait Tightens Security After Protest in Parliament
description: Stung by a surprise burst into Parliament by protesters, Kuwaits ruler ordered tighter security in the building on Thursday and vowed that his oil-rich country, which has so far dodged the Arab Spring upheavals that have shaken the region, would not tolerate preplanned sabotage.

title: Bombing Continues in Sudan, Creating a Crisis
description: With journalists and outside observers mostly prevented from entering the Southern Kordofan and Blue Nile areas of Sudan, its very difficult to track the developing human rights crisis there. But Donatella Rovera, Amnesty Internationals Senior Crisis Response Director, recently visited the area, and has provided a rare look from behind enemy lines.

title: Ground-Floor Internet Meme Oppty! Buy Now!
description: Im never early on the Internet-meme cycle. Im always happy to be delighted by biting Charlie or baffled by Amber Lamps. But by the time I get the link to whatever hilarious video is shooting around the Web, 388 million others have already viewed it, made their own spoofs and moved on.

title: Yale Reviewing Coachs Rhodes Candidacy
description: Yale University said Thursday that it would review a claim made by its football coach, Tom Williams, that he was a Rhodes scholar candidate when he was a student at Stanford University.

title: Italys New Premier Offers Broad Plan to Reform Finances and Spur Growth
description: ROME  Mario Monti, the newly chosen prime minister of Italy, unveiled an ambitious growth-boosting program before the Italian Senate on Thursday, warning that Italy and Europe faced a moment of serious emergency and calling on lawmakers for national unity and responsibility.

title: A League of Their Own?
description: Instead of caving to the unreasonable demands of N.B.A. owners, players should use their star power and take their show on the road, says William C. Rhoden.

title: The X-Men Go to College
description: Chris Claremont, one of the most influential writers of X-Men comics, known for his engaging, complex plot lines and strong female characters, is donating his archives to Columbia Universitys Rare Book and Manuscript Library. The archive will be the first step in establishing Columbia as a research resource for cartoonists and comic book writers.

title: Sports of The Times: A League of Their Own?
description: Instead of caving to the unreasonable demands of N.B.A. owners, players should use their star power and take their show on the road, says William C. Rhoden.

title: Lessons Learned: Creating a Life Reports Project
description: Overview | How can we tap into the wisdom of the older members of our families and communities? What useful lessons can be learned from looking back at the choices made over the course of a long lifetime? In this lesson, students share what they have learned from the experiences and wisdom of the older people in their lives, read Life Reports written by Times readers over the age of 70 and write and share their own reports from the present or their imagined futures. They end by soliciting and displaying Life Reports from community members.

title: Will They Stay or Will They Go?
description: Back in June senior officials in the Department of Homeland Security announced a new deportation policy: They would encourage prosecutors to use more discretion, to focus on removing illegal immigrants whod committed serious crimes. This was a good thing, but hardly an epic breakthrough, since they should have been doing that all along.

title: Pelosi Mocks Perry in Rejecting Debate Request
description: A potentially epic debate between Representative Nancy Pelosi of California and Gov. Rick Perry of Texas isnt going to happen after all.

title: How I Became a Teacher
Competition for Cobble Hill School Site
A New Twist on Airline Fees: Pay to Arrive?
description: PARIS  While air travelers have grown accustomed to paying extra for everything from an in-flight meal to pillows to checked bags, a group of passengers traveling from India to Britain on Thursday were confronted with what may be a new low in the industrys pay-as-you-go trend.

title: Popcast: Drake and Romeo Santos
description: This week the New York Times pop music writers discuss a platinum-selling rapper in search of new sounds and a Latin music superstar in search of new audiences.

title: A West-Meets-East Feast
description: The New York dining scene is crazy. I mean, you can eat practically anything you want at any given hour, says James Lelonde, the chef and co-owner of San Franciscos acclaimed pop-up cafe SloMoSF. New York chefs visit San Francisco to showcase their cooking all the time but not vice versa. So were trying to offer something a little different.For three days, starting tomorrow, Lelonde and his SloMoSF partner Ryoji Kajikawa will team with Kelly Geary of Brooklyns Sweet Deliverance to host a series of weekend dinners featuring their unique culinary spin. Equipped with diverse backgrounds, each chef brings something different to the table: Kajikawas skills are rooted in traditional Japanese techniques; Lelonde is heavily influenced by fresh Californian cuisine, favoring unusual twists on classics; Geary is passionate about cooking with whats seasonal and local. Just imagine the possibilities when you combine the skill sets of these three spirited epicureans.

title: Task Force Urges Greece to Improve Tax Collection
description: BRUSSELS  Greece is owed billions in unpaid taxes, but the prospects for collection are very low because the authorities have not yet simplified the system nor taken measures to curb tax evasion, the European Commission said Thursday.

title: Reading Club | Sex Ed
description: For our first Reading Club selection, on character education, we heard from 536 students, and were delighted and impressed by the conversation.

title: Vaulting Back to Form Using a Long Putter
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  The question of when Adam Scott will fulfill his potential has dogged him for years. He won the Players Championship at age 23, and with each passing year the pressure has mounted. Only a victory for Scott in one of golfs four majors will satisfy those posing the questions.

title: Astros Get New Owners and a Different League
description: MILWAUKEE  Baseballs yearly general managers meetings and quarterly ownership meetings, held jointly this week here at the Pfister Hotel, ended Thursday with a sequence of activity that ensured significant changes to the sport moving forward.

title: The Cunningham Countdown: A Day for Merce in Chicago
description: The choreographer Merce Cunningham (1919-2009) was born in Centralia, Wash., and spent 70 years of his life based in New York. But his work, like that of so many dancers and choreographers who travel the country and the world, had many homes.

title: Occupy Wall Street Protesters Clash With Police
description: Hundreds of Occupy Wall Street protesters marched on the New York Stock Exchange on Thursday, engaging in scuffles with the police throughout the day.

title: In the Pilgrims Footsteps, Through England and the Netherlands
description: LAST Thanksgiving my wife was trying to explain to our granddaughter, Lizzie, 5 at the time, that some of her ancestors had been participants at the original 1621 feast in Plymouth. I know, said Lizzie, who apparently had been learning about Thanksgiving in school. Were Indians!

title: Science and the Dangerous Climate Question
description: Richard Betts, the head of the climate impacts section of Britains Met Office, recently left a comment on the skeptic* blog Bishop Hill stating that thresholds for climate danger, such as the much ballyhooed 2-degree limit enshrined in recent climate pledges, were not determined by science:

title: Fox and CBS Rebound, but ABCs Modern Family Rules on Its Own
description: Fox and CBS both rebounded from their substandard performances last week (when they faced off against the Country Music Awards on ABC) to achieve a ratings split on Wednesday: Fox won the night in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic thanks to The X Factor while CBS had the most total viewers. Modern Family on ABC was once again the highest rated show of the night, though it dropped to a season low in the 18-to-49 category and in total viewers (12.9 million). Criminal Minds on CBS was a close second with 12.5 million total viewers.

title: Thanksgiving Re-enacted
description: November is showtime for a certain segment of the re-enactor set, a month in which they try to gently correct that stereotypical image of the first Thanksgiving.

title: Thanksgiving Re-enactments, From Utah to Plymouth, Mass.
description: NO journalist wants to have to begin an article this way, but the record must be kept straight.

title: Yelp Files for I.P.O.
description: Yelp officially threw its hat into the I.P.O. ring on Thursday, with the filing of its prospectus.

title: New Porsche 911 Greets Its North American Public
description: Shown on Wednesday, Nov. 16: 2012 Porsche 911 Carrera and Carrera S.

title: Arrest Warrant and Criminal Complaint for Oscar Ortega-Hernandez
description: Federal authorities charged a 21-year-old Idaho man on Thursday with attempting to assassinate President Obama.

title: For N.B.A. Players, China Is Up (and the D-League Down )
description: When Deron Williams signed with Besiktas back in July, he was supposedly opening the floodgates. N.B.A. players were expected to follow him across the Atlantic in search of steady income and legitimate competition. The various European leagues were seen as a plentiful resource for players without any obligation to their N.B.A. employers, and a first-class fallback plan in case the collective bargaining negotiations stalled.

title: Demand, Demand, Demand
description: Calculated Risk sends us to two papers by Amir Sufi and Atif Mian using county-level data to investigate the causes of the recession. Their work strongly supports the balance-sheet view: a fall in demand from highly indebted households is the big story, and you can confirm that by showing that the big declines in nontradable employment  that is, employment in industries that sell locally  is in those countries where debt levels were high.

title: Cain Says We Need a Leader, Not a Reader
description: NASHUA, N.H.  Herman Cain began his stump speech at a rally here today with one of his signature lines: Aw, shucky ducky! he said. I feel good today.

title: Green Car of the Year: The Full-Contact Edition
description: LOS ANGELES  Traditionally, the second day of the Los Angeles auto show begins with the announcement of the Green Car of the Year award. At this, a show that generally has a green tint to it, the award can act as a lightning rod of guilt: Think that 650-horsepower Shelby GT500 is sexy? Meet its natural born buzzkill, the Prius V.

title: MF Global Is Said to Have Used Customer Cash Improperly
description: MF Global improperly diverted customers cash for its own use in the days before its bankruptcy, an act that regulators believe may help explain why $600 million of customer funds remains missing, people briefed on the investigation say.

title: Nooks Specs Are Exaggerated, Again
description: 6:51 p.m. | Updated with comment from Barnes & Noble and Amazon.

title: In Gunshots, a Trail of Threats Is Reported
description: WASHINGTON  Federal authorities on Thursday charged a 21-year-old Idaho man with attempting to assassinate President Obama  saying he had told one friend that the president was the Antichrist and that he needed to kill him, according to a complaint filed in federal court.

title: A Tea Party Hearing in the Senate That Wasnt
description: UPDATED 5:12 p.m.: A self-styled Tea Party debt commission was foiled Thursday in its effort to hold a Senate hearing on its proposals to reduce the deficit.

title: Vows: Frederick & Lawrence
description: In this homemade video, Lawrence Rodriguez says that 25 years later, Frederick Barnfield is still the first person he's ever dated.

title: Photo Replay: Nov.17
description: The day in sports included high school football championship games in Wisconsin and ice dancing in Paris.

title: Block Party
description: It was our managing editor, George Gene Gustines, who suggested we do a T made of Legos for our winter travel issue. Im a huge fan of Legos and spent hours building houses and superheroes out of them as a kid, he said. Of all my childhood toys, I probably miss them the most. Representatives at Lego led us to Sachiko Akinaga.

title: Movie Listings for Nov. 18-24
description: Movies

title: Pop and Rock Listings for Nov. 18-24
description: Pop

title: Theater Listings: Nov. 18  24
description: Theater

title: Jazz Listings for Nov. 18-24
description: Jazz

title: Madoff Explains Everything
description: As i watch the politics swirl around the Occupy Wall Street movement, I find myself thinking about Bernie Madoff. Bear with me here; this might even make sense.

title: A City Light on Tourists
description: Gothic architecture, winding streets and hearty cuisine await in Rennes, a medieval city just two hours from Paris.

title: Q&A: Multitasking on Mobile Phones
description: Q.

title: History and Youth in Rennes, Brittany
description: WHILE ogling an oversize wheel of Camembert at a bountiful summer farmers market in Rennes, Brittany, I momentarily perked up from my lost-in-cheese stupor at the surprising sound of two British tourists in conversation. It was the first time I had heard someone else speaking English since we had arrived in Rennes 24 hours earlier. It was August, when Parisians leave for their holidays and the Americans arrive, a phenomenon thats hard to miss while trailing crowds in the French capital.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings for Nov. 18-24
description: Classical

title: San Diego Newspaper Sold to Powerful Local Developer
description: The hotel developer Doug Manchester bought his hometown newspaper, The San Diego Union-Tribune, for above $110 million, voiceofsandiego.org reported on Thursday afternoon.

title: Why Dont More Moms Coach?
description: Mothers are rare sights on the coachs bench for youth sports at every level. Co-ed, boys, girls; it doesnt much matter. Overall estimates for women coaches of youth sports range from 4 percent all the way up to nearly 10 percent, with the numbers being a little lower for boys teams and a little higher (up to 11 percent!) for girls. Whatever your sport: hockey, soccer, baseball, softball  its Dad, not Mom, whos in the dugout, on the sidelines or behind the bench.

title: Dance Listings for Nov. 18-24
description: Dance

title: Manager Who Claimed to Own Facebook Shares Charged With Fraud
description: It may be the new, new thing in fraud.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for Nov. 18-24
description: Art

title: Citys Jobless Rate Climbs to 8.8%
description: New York Citys unemployment rate rose to 8.8 percent in October, as the citys recovery from the recession continued to falter.

title: Inside the New Clyfford Still Museum
description: Sandra Still Campbell narrates a look at a new museum in Denver that is dedicated to the work of her father, the artist Clyfford Still.

title: Theater Talkback: Why the Funny Girl Cancellation Is No Laughing Matter
description: Say Hello Gorgeous to a new star, runs a tag line in the ad for Funny Girl in the Ahmanson Theater programs being passed out at performances of the new musical Bring It On. But the theaters 28,000 subscribers wont be getting a chance to do any such thing.

title: Seven Tips for Better Group Portraits
description: Group shots are always a challenge, but family holiday gatherings present a special set of problems. You cant hold a group together long amid the distractions of bowl games, family Xbox tournaments and sweet-potato pie. Andrew Boyd, a photojournalist and educator, has written extensively about group shots on his blog, The Discerning Photographer. Heres his recipe for getting it right.

title: Crushing the Cost of Predicting the Future
description: Large and diverse sets of data have become abundant as more information is posted on the Internet, from stock prices and news pages to sensor readings. Now the cost of analyzing and visualizing that data is dropping fast, too, with implications for all kinds of decision-making.

title: African Union Considers Sending Ethiopian Troops to Somalia
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The African Union is considering an ambitious plan to stabilize Somalia that could involve using thousands of Ethiopian troops to open a new front against the Shabab militant group, officials of the union said Thursday.

title: Amid the Grim Streets, a Pair of Weary Souls
description: In the first few minutes of Tyrannosaur, Joseph  played with granitic intensity by the great Scottish actor Peter Mullan  kicks a dog to death, smashes a store window and picks a fight with three much younger men in a bar. It should be noted that he is one of the nicer people in this movie, the directing debut of the actor Paddy Considine (My Summer of Love, In America).

title: Spare Times: For Children for Nov. 18-24
description: AKC MEET THE BREEDS

title: UBS Outlines How It Plans to Carry Out Turnaround
description: When Sergio P. Ermotti entered the chandelier-drenched ballroom at the Waldorf Astoria hotel in Manhattan for his first investor day at UBS as chief executive, he started choking on a piece of food, prompting a few attendees to joke that he may have bitten off more than he can chew in taking the top spot at the beleaguered Swiss bank.

title: Spare Times for Nov. 18-24
description: Around Town

title: Prophet Royal Robertson: No Proud BastardsProject Stewart Home
description: White Columns

title: H. C. Westermann: A Human Condition
description: Lennon, Weinberg

title: Matisse and the Model
description: Eykyn Maclean

title: Richard Pousette-Dart: East River Studio
description: Luhring Augustine

title: Jim Hodges
description: Gladstone Gallery

title: Supervillains Everywhere and Barely Time to Think
description: The title character of Jrme Salles picturesque international thriller The Heir Apparent: Largo Winch is the swashbuckling hero of a series of Belgian graphic novels by Jean Van Hamme and illustrated by Philippe Francq. As played by Tomer Sisley, a lean, handsome 37-year-old French actor, he is a charismatic screen presence so long as he doesnt speak. When he delivers the movies wooden dialogue (in three languages) in a near monotone, his glamour evaporates.

title: Channel Surfing: The Shrimp Combo Platter
description: I dont know if the Endless Shrimp promotion is still running at Red Lobster, but its certainly Endless Shrimp night Thursday on television.

title: Abstract Expressionist Made Whole
description: Denver

title: Highlighting Influence of Asia Behind Artwork
description: Exhibitions at Asia Society often reveal an unfamiliar dimension to an artists work. When the society presented a show about the Japanese neo-Pop artist Yoshitomo Nara last year, for example, it examined how his passion for music influenced his art. A new exhibition by the installation artist Sarah Sze will explore her process and her interest in traditional Chinese painting.

title: Romances New Format
description: EVEN though my mother has a wonderful marriage with my father, she keeps her ex-boyfriends alive for my siblings and me like guest stars on a sitcom. Each is drawn in quick strokes according to how generous she is feeling on that particular day.

title: 2012 Honda CR-V: Cautious Makeover for a Best-Selling Crossover
description: Introduced on Wednesday, Nov. 16: 2012 Honda CR-V.

title: Pictures of the Day: Greece and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Greece, New York, Thailand and Ghana.

title: They Have Standing
description: Some gay rights groups were disappointed today when the California Supreme Court ruled that the sponsors of Proposition 8, ProtectMarriage, have standing to defend the discriminatory law, even though Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger and Attorney General Jerry Brown had refused to do so.

title: Rwandan Is Convicted in 1994 Killings
description: KAMPALA, Uganda  It was one of the most notorious cases in the 1994 genocide in Rwanda. In a normally sleepy lakeside town, more than 2,000 Tutsis driven from their homes accepted a local priests offer of refuge in his church. But it was a ruse, and after days of siege the building was bulldozed, killing them all.

title: Annie Hall and Family, Off the Screen
description: Diane Keatons book about her life is not a straight-up, chronological memoir. Its a collage that mixes Ms. Keatons words with those of her mother, Dorothy Deanne Keaton Hall, who died in 2008. Since Ms. Hall left behind 85 scrapbooklike journals, a huge and chaotic legacy, there is every reason to expect that Ms. Keatons braiding of her own story with her mothers in Then Again will be a rambling effort at best.

title: 200 Are Arrested as Protesters Clash With the Police
description: Thousands of protesters across the country flooded streets, squares, bridges and banks on Thursday, snarling traffic and often clashing with the police in a show of support for the Occupy Wall Street movement, two months to the day after the demonstration began.

title: Navigating Through Time and Space
description: Theres a way that the distressed walls of the Brooklyn Academy of Musics Harvey Theater resemble compressed layers of sediment: the exposed brick, the peeling paint, the rough plaster patches, everything seemingly crumbling like sheered-off rock exposed to the elements.

title: A Fresh Devotion to the Older Ways
description: The young vibraphonist Warren Wolf, from Baltimore, plays music that doesnt argue with the most popular and usable parts of jazzs past. It doesnt hesitate or erase its own tracks. It uses swing, blues, virtuosity, cuteness, directness and seldom wanders from a sense of tune. His working band, which played at 92Y Tribeca on Wednesday night, is called Wolfpack, and in the way the music dominated the audience, that made sense.

title: Solyndra Has a Cousin in the Poorhouse
description: At a hearing on Thursday that lasted five and half hours, Republicans on the House Energy and Commerce Committee grilled the energy secretary, Steven Chu, on the bankruptcy of the solar panel manufacturer Solyndra and asked what other loan recipients might be in financial trouble.

title: At the Altar of Design, When Self-Expression Met Mass Production
description: All that has been written since the death of Steve Jobs last month is a reminder of how passionate modern consumers can be about the things we buy and how fascinated we are by the people who make and sell them. The appeal of those Apple gadgets  so sleek and logical, so cool and friendly and flattering to whoever picks them up  is obvious enough, but the exact nature of Mr. Jobss contribution has been harder to specify. Was he a visionary innovator or, as Malcolm Gladwell recently argued in The New Yorker, a tireless tweaker of the inventions of others? Was he primarily a designer, an engineer, a computer nerd or an artist? A benevolent guru or the center of a cult of personality?

title: Jim Parsons May Go From Sheldon to Harvey
description: The Emmy Award-winning actor Jim Parsons (The Big Bang Theory) is in talks to return to Broadway this spring to play Elwood P. Dowd in the Pulitzer Prize-winning comedy Harvey, about a man who claims to be friends with a six-foot-tall rabbit no one else can see.
