Two theater executives familiar with the discussions, who would only disclose the unconfirmed production on condition of anonymity, said Mr. Parsons was negotiating with Roundabout Theater Company about starring as Elwood. Representatives for Mr. Parsons and for Roundabout declined comment on Thursday.

title: A London Design Maverick as a Pragmatist
description: Thomas Tait was in New York last week for London Showrooms, a presentation of young British fashion talent. Actually, Mr. Tait is Canadian, educated at a technical school in Montreal. In 2010, he completed the masters program in womens wear at Central Saint Martins in London, whereupon he joined that distinguished race known as the Young Fashion Designer.

title: Nude Blogger Riles Egyptians of All Stripes
description: CAIRO  Aliaa Magda Elmahdy apparently thought she was striking a blow for sexual equality and free expression in Egypt when she postednude photographs of herself on a blog. Instead Ms. Elmahdy set off a wave of outrage here, stoking conservative Islamist sentiments that many liberals fear will undermine their prospects in the countrys parliamentary election next week.

title: Filthy Gorgeous
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Pictures of the Day: Greece and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Greece, Italy, New York and Texas.

title: Arts and Crafts Pioneer Is Subject of New Book
description: Marie Zimmermann, an heiress to a straw-importing fortune, did not need to work for a living. She nonetheless ran a metalsmithing studio in New York from the 1910s to the late 30s, partly to prove herself to the men who doubted women could succeed in that gritty profession.

title: Two Weeks in Kolkata
description: The photographer Max Vadukul and his son, the writer Alex, discuss their trip to Kolkata for the Winter Travel issue of T Magazine.

title: 2013 Spark Broadens, but Doesnt Ignite, Chevrolet Product Portfolio
description: LOS ANGELES  Chevrolet gave journalists their first viewing of its subcompact 2013 Spark on Wednesday at the 2011 Los Angeles auto show. The car is expected to go on sale next summer.

title: Lens: Crime Scenes
description: Lens: Crime Scenes

title: Down the Aisle, Laden With Family Baggage
description: Watch as the mighty Ellens  Burstyn and Barkin  go head to head, playing an embattled mother and daughter, in Another Happy Day, the emotionally overwrought debut feature from Sam Levinson (son of Barry). This wedding melodrama, in which generational and marital factions of a strife-torn family collide, seems acutely aware of its place in the lineage of a genre that it carries to a screeching decibel level.

title: A Small World, With All the Bells and Whistles
description: THE Kingston Model Railroad Club has been meeting in Kingston, N.Y., since 1937. Mostly its a members-only affair, with enthusiasts gathering to build and maintain their trains and generally schmooze, but once a year they invite the public into their intricate miniature worlds on rails in the Hudson Valley. Tony Cenicola has been photographing them for the last decade. Here are some of his favorite scenes, like the diner from 2009, which could be straight out of an Edward Hopper painting, and an image, from 2003, of a 3-year-old named Elizabeth waiting for a tiny train to chug by. In another photograph, Bill Brandt reattaches a trolley to an overhead wire in a tableau from this years exhibition. The open house runs through Dec. 4, Sundays only, noon to 5 p.m., on Susan Street; (845) 334-8233. The trains are old and new, from kits and from scratch, all customized by club members.

title: H.P. Gives Relationals Whitworth a Board Seat
description: Hewlett-Packard said on Thursday that it had named Ralph V. Whitworth, the head of the hedge fund Relational Investors, to its board as the computer giant seeks to head off potential campaigns by activist shareholders.

title: Medieval Foes With Whimsy
description: If, by some typically improbable turn of events, Homer Simpson were to unearth from his backyard an old chest containing a chess set from medieval times, what would the pieces look like? Chances are they would resemble the lovable little contestants beautifully carved from walrus tusks by anonymous artisans in the famous cache known as the Lewis Chessmen.

title: A Search for Self-Discovery, Two Left Feet and All
description: All dancing, all singing, all wisecracking, the animated penguins from down under (way under) return in Happy Feet Two, an amiable sequel with not much on its mind other than funny and creaky jokes, and waves of understated beauty. Lighter in mood, softer in political outlook and less narratively ambitious than the first Happy Feet (2006), the new movie takes place in Antarctica, where thousands of emperor penguins hang out doing familiar animated penguin things, like gobbling fish, braving the weather and breaking into tightly choreographed song and dance.

title: A Classified-Ads Site for Lonely Scribes
description: If writers have a way with words, thats not always the case with love, and even less so with money. Thats why the Miser is thankful for people like Kaitlin Phillips, the creator of n+personals, a free classified-ads site for lonely scribes seeking companionship.

title: A Sons Favorites Are an Acquired Taste
description: My 23-year-old son is in his first semester of graduate school. He e-mailed us that he would be bringing his brand-new 28-year-old girlfriend home for Thanksgiving. In the same message, he told us they had become vegans and made several suggestions about dishes I might cook for them: quinoa, seitan and tempeh. I have never heard of these foods. And Im not thrilled that my son is going out with an older woman in what is supposed to be the beginning of a challenging graduate program. Your thoughts? Anonymous

title: New Acquisition: A Welcome Mat
description: THIS month, the New-York Historical Society reopened its Central Park West fortress, with renovations designed to entice more visitors to what was designed as an airtight vault for history. The societys president, Louise Mirrer, said the governing idea was all about opening history up to the public; its not just dead people. The transformed main floor of the old tomb is a stunner.

title: All the Single (Old) Ladies
description: I sometimes hear women in New York lament that there are many more single gals than single guys around. To that I say: Just wait until you turn 90.

title: The City, Inside Yet Out
description: DONT think David Roffe is only a New York City tour guide.

title: Enlightenment by Way of Adventure
description: What do you do in New York once you tire of the bar scene, eat your way through Yelps Best of restaurants and conclude that watching Film Forum documentaries is simply too passive? If youre just the right amount of curious, adventurous or even a touch voyeuristic, you might sign up for a SideTour.

title: The New Bad Boys Decide to Do the Reforming
description: Filmed in shades of blue and gray, the dour Norwegian drama King of Devils Island evokes a blood-chilling climate of eternal winter. Its setting is the Bastoy Residential School, a reformatory for maladjusted boys, 11 to 18, that operated for a half-century until the 1950s on an Alcatraz-like island.

title: Inheriting a Home, and a Loan
description: THE death of a family member may bring a barrage of sadness, a bequest of property  and a mortgage to repay.

title: Cryogenically Frozen in the 1970s
description: Theres a noticeable imbalance in Woody Allen: A Documentary, a three-and-a-half-hour American Masters biography spooling out on Sunday and Monday on PBS. The first chapter, the longer and better of the two, follows its subject through just the first 10 films of his career, ending with Stardust Memories. Then the programs director, Robert Weide, stuffs Mr. Allens 31 subsequent features into the 90 rushed minutes of the second night.

title: Excerpt: Woody Allen: A Documentary
description: A scene from a new American Masters special about Mr. Allen that will debut on PBS on Sunday.

title: And the Winner in New Hampshire Is
description: The votes are in in the first-in-the-nation primary state  at least the votes among 250 fifth and sixth graders from across New Hampshire who voted in the Kids Primary conducted by the Institute of Politics at St. Anselm College in Manchester.

title: A Rising Rental Market in the North
description: IT appears another housing boom is under way, but just for rentals.

title: Excerpt: 'Woody Allen: A Documentary'
description: A scene from a new American Masters special about Mr. Allen that will debut on PBS on Sunday.

title: In Poland, an Architects-Eye View
description: Its probably safe to say that Kacper Kowalski is one of few people in Poland  or anywhere  hoping for a bitterly cold and snowy winter. Hes an aerial photographer who floats over the landscape in paragliders and geoplanes, as he did last year when an wicked winter freeze wreaked havoc on roads, airports railways and ports.

title: How Do You Drink Your Vodka? Fluffed, No Chaser
description: To stand out in the crowded vodka category of the distilled spirits market, brands try all manner of methods to get attention. A particularly popular tactic is to go naughty in advertising and marketing efforts, with themes and images that walk the fine line between wicked and evil.

title: Your Home, Your Castle
description: Sea Cliff

title: Huntsman Plays Down Fathers Role
description: Jon M. Huntsman Jr. on Thursday addressed questions about his relationship with his wealthy father amid speculation about whether Jon M. Huntsman Sr. would come to the aid of his sons flagging campaign.

title: Three Realtor Associations Under One Umbrella
description: LENGTHY commutes to cheaper houses far from New York City jobs are not a new trend, but stubborn unemployment and a stalled housing market seem to have affected the outward march like adrenaline.

title: Q & A
description: Clean the Windows, or Buy New Ones?

title: David Cooper
description: Mr. Cooper, 52, is the president and chief executive of WSP Flack + Kurtz, a building systems engineering company and a subsidiary of the WSP Group of Britain. WSP Flack + Kurtz provides a wide range of consulting, design and engineering services. Current projects include work at the Waldorf Astoria hotel and the Atlantic Yards in Brooklyn. Mr. Cooper recently celebrated 30 years at the company.

title: Time Capsule With Pulse on Present
description: The Mexican muralist Diego Rivera (1886-1957) was one of the great artists of his time. Is he one of ours? The Museum of Modern Art, which is revisiting the retrospective it awarded to Rivera in the 1930s, certainly thinks so. Im not convinced, even though some of the paintings in Diego Rivera: Murals for the Museum of Modern Art seem ripped from todays headlines. In The Uprising, protesting laborers are brutally suppressed by uniformed soldiers; the stratified New York cityscape of Frozen Assets tops a bank vault with a crowded homeless shelter.

title: Preoccupying Opera: Youthful Acts of Dissent
description: There are many impressive things about Kommilitonen!, the new opera by Peter Maxwell Davies, with a libretto by David Pountney, which had its American premiere at the Juilliard School on Wednesday night. Best of all is Mr. Daviess exhilarating score. Here, for once, is a modern opera that exudes musical modernism. The spirited conductor Anne Manson drew an incisive, colorful performance of this demanding score from the Juilliard Orchestra.

title: Period Instruments Breathe New Life Into a Musical Hero
description: During the last few weeks in New York it has been hard to miss a familiar baleful countenance staring out from a poster pasted up at a construction area, or perhaps from a banner on a Web site. Thanks to a clever advertising campaign for the classical radio station WQXR-FM, Beethoven is everywhere, rendered in the style of the street artist Shepard Fairey and adorned with a quirky logo: OBEY THOVEN.

title: Elephants and Bishops
description: Besides being exceptional works of art, the Lewis Chessmen are a historical marker in the development and spread of the game.

title: Loans Lose All Value, and More
description: Boscovs, a regional chain of department stores based in Reading, Pa., has received an honor few companies get. Its name, like Googles, has become a verb.

title: Dealbook: H.P. Gives Relationals Whitworth a Board Seat
description: Hewlett-Packard said on Thursday that it had named Ralph V. Whitworth, head of the hedge fund Relational Investors, to its board of directors as the computer giant seeks to fend off potential campaigns by activist shareholders. Read the entire post on Dealbook..

title: The Fight Over Vaccines and Autism, Continued
description: If the title of your documentary is The Greater Good, shouldnt you at least define what that is? Apparently not, as this emotionally manipulative, heavily partial look at the purported link between autism and childhood immunization would much rather wallow in the distress of specific families than engage with the needs of the population at large.

title: More Power and New Noses Define Lincoln MKS and MKT
description: Introduced on Thursday, Nov. 17: 2013 Lincoln MKS and MKT.

title: The Wish List Is Not Negotiable
description: FOR the first years of their marriage, Jennifer Betit Yen and Peyton Worley were bicoastal. They had met in law school at Boston University. But Ms. Betit Yen soon fell into acting. After she got a role in an independent film, she seized the opportunity, left her job and moved to Los Angeles.

title: Enticing Renters to Cross the Bridge to Queens
description: ON a recent afternoon the view across Court Square, in eastern Long Island City, Queens, took in an auto body shop and parking lots, and aging factories beyond. The Citicorp Building and other office towers cast shadows across streets. Places to shop were nonexistent.

title: This Gay American Life, in Code or in Your Face
description: Hide/Seek: Difference and Desire in American Portraiture, a diligent exhibition centering on 20th-century portraits and self-portraits of or by gay artists, is now at the Brooklyn Museum, and it is more or less intact. Which is to say that once again, nearly a year after it was first mounted at the Smithsonians National Portrait Gallery in Washington, it includes A Fire in My Belly, a four-minute excerpt from a video made in 1986-87 by David Wojnarowicz, who died of AIDS in 1992, at 37.

title: Recovering Artifacts of Holocaust Victims
description: We dont know who among the prisoners at Maidanek, a Nazi concentration camp in Poland, first decided to bury some personal items in a field just before being sent to the chamber. But we do know that many other prisoners followed suit and that the gesture was not futile.

title: A Wide Audience for the Republican Debates and the Developing Shadow Campaign
description: A Wide Audience for the Republican Debates and the Developing Shadow Campaign

title: Revisiting a Brazilian Dance Troupes Brush With Fame
description: Dzi Croquettes, about an all-male dance and theater troupe of that name that had a moment of fame in the 1970s in Brazil and then Europe, is in one sense a lazy sort of documentary. It asserts the groups importance primarily through interviews with the members themselves and a handful of ardent fans (Liza Minnelli among them). But if the film doesnt measure up as a piece of historical scholarship, it does manage to be a rather touching exploration of the troupes life cycle: achieving notoriety, then being torn apart by fame, then being destroyed by forces beyond its control.

title: Smashing Glass Guitars
description: The disappointing Women Who Rock begins with a clip of James Brown singing Its a Mans World, which hints that whats coming might be a serious exploration of the obstacles women faced in achieving rock stardom. But the film, by Carol Stein and Susan Wittenberg, quickly degenerates into cheerleading, serving up exactly the names youd expect and only the most obvious of insights.

title: Drone Journalism Arrives
description: Now that cellphone cameras have turned every protester with a Twitter account or a YouTube channel into a potential multimedia journalist, police officers in several American cities appear to be having trouble distinguishing between activists and reporters.

title: Hide/Seek
description: Photos from the exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum.

title: Cain Gets Secret Service Protection
description: 7:13 p.m. | Updated Herman Cain will get protection from the United States Secret Service starting Thursday night as he continues to campaign for the presidency, representatives of the agency and Mr. Cains campaign said.

title: From Edisons Trunk, Direct Current Gets Another Look
description: Thomas Edison and his direct current, or DC, technology lost the so-called War of the Currents to alternating current, or AC, in the 1890s after it became clear that AC was far more efficient at transmitting electricity over long distances.

title: Bloggingheads: Are We the 99%?
description: Michelle Goldberg, left, of The Daily Beast and Conn Carroll of The Washington Examiner debate whether Americans agree with Occupy Wall Street.

title: Living Along a Contentious Border
description: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

title: Before and After (the Kids)
description: THIS is one way Jay and Julie Rossi sum up their nearly 13 years of marriage: 16 jobs, 4 apartments, 2 houses, 2 Subarus, 2 children, 8 fish and 4 couches.

title: Portrait of a World War II Double Agent
description: What do you call a spy who may be the best actor in the world? Bovril (a brand of beef extract) doesnt quite sing, though the British handlers of Juan Pujol Garca used it before settling on the more apt Garbo.

title: The Life Cycles of a Jewish Cemetery
description: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

title: Frankfurt Goes to Hollywood
description: The 2011 Los Angeles auto show offered the first chance for many automotive journalists to glimpse cars that were first unveiled at the Frankfurt auto show in September.

title: Leveraged Moveouts
description: WHEN real estate was booming, many New Yorkers joined in the rush to turn their houses and apartments into ATMs, withdrawing cash through home-equity loans, or flipping them.

title: Rampant Sociopaths Messing With Peoples Heads
description: Silver Tongues, like its twisted antiheroes, is a cynical, ice-cold tease. At its center lurk Gerry (Lee Tergesen) and Joan (Enid Graham), a pair of mysterious, middle-aged sociopaths who move from town to town messing with peoples heads. On its fringes lie the remnants of their victims, regular people whose lives will never be the same.

title: Tips for Starter Landlords
description: HOMEOWNERS who become landlords, either by choice or by circumstance, may find that new and unfamiliar tasks like collecting rent, dealing with late-night repairs and sifting through potential tenants will sour even the sunniest personality.

title: Twentysomething in Need of a Life Coach
description: Comprising small, near-perfect scenes played out largely at dinner tables and on couches, The Lie wonders if its possible to rewrite lives and remake choices.

title: Homemaker Devises a Suburban Smackdown
How Can I Reheat My Turkey Without Drying It Out?
description: I have to cook the turkey the day before Thanksgiving, but I dont want to serve it cold the next day. How do heat it up, so it doesnt dry out and my guests dont know it was cooked the day before? Its 18-20 lb turkey. Veronica, Princeton

title: A Day of Protest, and Arrests
description: Two days after the Occupy Wall Street encampment was cleared at Zuccotti Park, demonstrators held a day of action in New York, resulting in more than 175 arrests.

title: A Simple Menu for a Bipartisan Breakfast Club
description: WASHINGTON  Every two weeks or so, a dozen House Republicans and Democrats repair to an office on Capitol Hill for bad croissants and lukewarm coffee, and to chat about the legislation they would like to enact together. They are not a committee, they are not a caucus; their group does not really even have a name. But in the 112th Congress, what they are is sort of remarkable.

title: Todays Scuttlebot
description: What the editors and reporters of The Timess tech staff spotted on the Web:

title: The Finger-Pointing Over Penn State
description: To the Editor:

title: Is It Time to Take Away the Bankers Bonuses?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Computer Programmer Is a Child
description: To the Editor:

title: Failure Is Good
description: Its a bird! Its a plane! Its a complete turkey! Its the supercommittee!

title: Dok-Ing Automotiv: A Show-Stealing Croatian Upstart Makes Debut in Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES  If there were an award for Most Unique Car at the 2011 Los Angeles auto show, a judge would be hard pressed to explain a vote in favor of anything other than the XD electric vehicle from Dok-Ing Automotiv.

title: Disenfranchise No More
description: Mississippi voters just approved a new law requiring voters to show photo identification at the polls. But that law will not go into effect immediately, thanks to the Voting Rights Act. Instead Mississippi will get in line behind Texas and South Carolina as the Department of Justice examines each states voter ID laws, in a process known as preclearance. The Justice Department will allow each law to go into effect only if the state can show its law will not have a racially discriminatory purpose or effect. Such proof may be hard to come by: a recent study by The Associated Press found that African-American voters in South Carolina would be much harder hit by that states ID law than white voters because they often dont have the right kind of identification.

title: Sale of Astros Gets Baseballs Ducks in a Row
description: The Houston franchise has played 50 years in the National League. First named for a handgun  the Colt .45  and then for the space program, the Astros have specialized in innovations whose time has passed: artificial turf, the domed stadium, uniforms with colorful horizontal stripes. No Hall of Famer wears the open-ended star on his plaque, and the Astros, who have never won a World Series game, bottomed out with 106 losses last season.

title: An Ill-Fated Firm Is Ready to Move On
description: Is the Washington Research Group the Wall Street version of Joe Btfsplk, the Lil Abner comic-strip character who walked around with a dark cloud over his head and brought misfortune to everyone around him?

title: For Struggling Tuck, a Sackful of Concerns
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Justin Tuck does not like what he sees when he looks in the mirror these days, and part of it, admittedly, is the beard.

title: Cubs Name Manager as Red Sox Consider Valentine
description: MILWAUKEE  The Chicago Cubs named Dale Sveum as their manager on Thursday, selecting a veteran coach who, just a day before, seemed about to become the new manager of the Boston Red Sox.

title: Dulcie Gray, Stalwart British Actress, Dies at 95
description: Dulcie Gray, a stalwart of British stage, screen, radio and television who won enthusiastic reviews when she made her Broadway debut at age 80 with her husband and frequent acting partner, Michael Denison, died on Tuesday at Denville Hall, a home for elderly actors in Middlesex, England. She was 95.

title: Sears Loss Hits $421 Million, and Gaps Profit Is Off 36%
description: The Sears Holdings Corporation, the retailer controlled by the hedge fund manager Edward S. Lampert, reported a steeper third-quarter loss than a year ago on Thursday as sales declined in Canada.

title: At Penn State, a Bitter Reckoning
description: State College, Pa.

title: Gingrich Staffers Who Quit in June Return to Campaign
description: For Newt Gingrich, the latest twist on what goes around, comes around has an unusual personal dimension. On top of his surge in polls and fund-raising, Mr. Gingrich has rehired two of the Iowa staff members who quit during a mass exodus from his campaign in June.

title: Coachs Rhodes Claim Under Review by Yale
description: NEW HAVEN  Yale University began an internal review Thursday to determine if its football coach, Tom Williams, was being truthful when he listed himself as a Rhodes scholarship candidate on his rsum.

title: Lincoln and the Mormons
description: Mormons! America just cant get enough of them.

title: The Oops in the O for Oregon
description: EUGENE, Ore.  When University of Oregon football fans cheer their team, they often hold out their hands in the shape of the letter O, for Oregon.

title: John Lius Credibility
description: With the arrest of one of his fund-raisers and the federal investigation into his campaign finances, John Liu, the New York city comptroller, needs to shut down his fund-raising operation immediately. His explanation  that he did not know about illegal donor practices  is not good enough. If he cannot manage his own campaign, why should the public trust him to oversee the citys $66 billion budget and its $120 billion pension fund?

title: Lyrics Briefly Draw a Penalty After a Columbia Loss
description: The history of university band mischief is long and colorful, stretching back to the irreverence of the 1960s. In some of the most notable instances, bands have staged a tribute to birth control, mimicked the napalming of a Cambodian village, ridiculed the spotted owl controversy in Oregon and made fun of Notre Dames Catholicism by dressing the drum major in a habit and using a cross as a baton.

title: Politics and Clean Air
description: President Obamas decision in September to scuttle stricter national standards for smog may well go down as the worst environmental decision of his administration  unless, of course, even more damaging retreats lie ahead. The decision was a setback for public health, a victory for industry, which had lobbied strongly against the standards, and a public embarrassment for the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, Lisa Jackson, who had proposed them.

title: Lottery Numbers
Group in U.S. Hoped for Big Payday in Offer to Help Qaddafi
description: WASHINGTON  To a colorful group of Americans  the Washington terrorism expert, the veteran C.I.A. officer, the Republican operative, the Kansas City lawyer  the Libyan gambit last March looked like a rare business opportunity.

title: Out of the Spotlight, Until the Met Needed a Tenor
description: Until a few weeks ago, Jay Hunter Morris had spent much of his early 40s in the invisible universe of the backup opera singer, a life that included selling Rollerblades in Central Park and passing out towels at gyms.

title: New Offenses Speed the Demise of College Records
description: Houston quarterback Case Keenum threw his 135th touchdown pass on Oct. 27, breaking the Football Bowl Subdivision record. He also threw his 136th, 137th, 138th and 139th, reaching the end zone a total of nine times in a 73-34 win over Rice.

title: From Elephants to Bishops
description: Discovered in Scotland more than 800 years ago, the Lewis chess set, featured in "Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone," is now on display at the Cloisters.

title: Williamson Prosecutor Asserts a Change of Heart
description: GEORGETOWN  John Bradley says he is evolving.

title: Thinking Outside the Bus
A Push to Promote Familiar Brands Online
description: BETWEEN now and New Years Eve, food marketers are hoping their products become the soup, frosting, snacks, candy, gravy, cereal and stuffing as dreams are made on.

title: Pillsbury Commercial
description: Pillsbury is wooing shoppers through a campaign carrying the theme "Holiday ideas made easy."

title: Exceptional Court Coverage
description: C-Span asked Chief Justice John Roberts Jr. this week to let the network televise the upcoming Supreme Court arguments in the case challenging the health care law. The justices have not permitted TV cameras in their courtroom, but this landmark case, which will affect every American, should surely be an exception to that rule.

title: The End Game Lands the N.B.A. in Court
description: David Stern tried optimism, transitioned to gloom and dabbled in threats before turning alarmist.

title: Utility Reform Eluding Japan After Nuclear Plant Disaster
description: TOKYO  In a direct act of rebellion against Tokyo Electric Power Company, which owns the crippled Fukushima nuclear plant, the local government in Tokyo is moving swiftly to build a huge natural gas facility that would generate as much electricity as a nuclear reactor.

title: Gingrich Faces More Scrutiny Over Corporate Clients
description: In July 2009, before the health care debate became a topic of angry discussion around the country, Newt Gingrich weighed in on what would be one of its flashpoints  end-of-life care provisions to help families decide whether terminally ill patients should avoid aggressive, and costly, medical measures.

title: San Diego Union-Tribune Sold to Hotelier for More Than $100 Million
description: The San Diego Union-Tribune, one of the largest and most influential newspapers in California, was sold to a local developer for above $110 million, voiceofsandiego.org reported Thursday afternoon.

title: Ricky Wyatt
description: After Ricky Wyatt died, the circle that gathered around him to say goodbye was small. Just a clutch of people in a funeral chapel in Tuscaloosa, Ala., friends and family members and some of those who had traveled beside him on a long journey toward justice for the mentally ill and disabled.

title: Hamas-Appointed Court Fines Gaza Banks
description: GAZA  In what could be the first of many such decisions, a Hamas-appointed court this week ordered two major banks in Gaza to pay tens of millions of dollars in back fees and fines for refusing to accept the taxing power of the Hamas government, rather than its West-Bank-based rival, the Palestinian Authority.

title: Eritrea Players Return Home After Losing World Cup Qualifier
description: All 18 players on Eritreas national team flew home after a 3-1 defeat at Rwanda in a match Tuesday that knocked the team out of 2014 World Cup qualification. It was Eritreas first away match since 2009, when 12 members of the team did not return after a regional tournament in Kenya. They claimed asylum, and 11 were later granted political asylum in Australia. More coverage at nytimes.com/goal.

title: Connecticut Utility Chief Quits After Delays in Restoring Power
description: Jeffrey D. Butler, who was the beleaguered face of Connecticuts biggest utility as it struggled for more than 10 days to restore power to hundreds of thousands of homes and businesses after a late-October snowstorm, resigned under pressure on Thursday.

title: Patent Case Will Test Court
description: The United States Supreme Court has a chance to reverse the mission creep in patent law. The system is supposed to reward inventors but not stifle innovation. Fuzzy and overly broad concepts like thought processes generally are not protected. Yet one company, Prometheus Laboratories, reckons it owns a method for interpreting how patients react to a drug.

title: Boeing Reports a Record Sale
description: The Boeing Company said Thursday that Indonesias Lion Air would sign an agreement to buy 230 new 737-model jetliners with a list value of $21.7 billion, a record transaction for the company.

title: Friday: Lead-In To an Exciting Announcement
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Welcome to Friday the 13th. Dont bother looking at your calendar; its not really the 13th. But there are a whopping 13 fresh entries in Joe DiPietros grid today, and I had so much fun solving this puzzle that Ive decided it has to be some sort of notable day. If you have any other standards-friendly suggestions, feel free to leave them in the comments.

title: Drug Highs and Irreversible Lows
description: Dael Orlandersmiths Horsedreams begins with a paean to Saturday night. At first it seems like mere scene-setting when Desiree, dancing at a club, describes her week as a prelude to letting loose, but it becomes an apt metaphor for an unbalanced life.

title: An Enduring Marriage of Wit and Lust
description: Theres more than one way to wear a bath towel. Thats the sum total of Kim Cattralls entrance costume in Richard Eyres larky revival of Nol Cowards Private Lives, which opened on Thursday night at the Music Box Theater.

title: Should Candidates Have to Pass a Civics Test?
Pakistani Envoy Offers to Resign Over Memo
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistans ambassador to the United States, Husain Haqqani, has offered to resign amid a political and diplomatic storm in Pakistan over a mysterious memo, which asks for American help in dealing with the Pakistani military and Mr. Haqqani is accused of orchestrating.

title: Low Expectations, and Trepidation, Over Meeting a Debt Deadline
description: Expectations that the special Congressional committee will strike a deal on debt reduction by Wednesdays deadline could not be much lower. The committees own members have played down the odds. Stock prices may already reflect the likelihood of a punt. And one of the major ratings agencies has said the lack of an agreement, by itself, will not result in a downgrade of government debt.

title: Inspector Visits Sardis. Free Cheese Ends.
description: It was a tradition at bars like the ones in Sardis in the theater district: a communal cheese pot with a knife sticking out, and some crackers. First-nighters or late-nighters grabbed the knife and a cracker, spread the cheese  cheddar  and ate. Some called it dinner.

title: In Late Show Preview, Cain Talks 9-9-9 Plan
description: Herman Cain will appear on CBSs Late Show With David Letterman  on Friday, and a short preview of the appearance, which was taped Thursday, shows a smiling, relaxed candidate chatting about his economic plan.

title: Lawmakers at Loggerheads on Deficit
description: WASHINGTON  With just days remaining before their final deadline, members of a Congressional panel on deficit reduction made frenzied efforts on Thursday to overcome an impasse, but appeared to be talking past one another and reported no tangible progress toward an agreement.

title: The Technocratic Nightmare
description: During the first half of the 1990s, I lived in Brussels and wrote about the European Union, among other subjects, for The Wall Street Journal. This was the heyday of European integration. Helmut Kohl, Franois Mitterrand and Jacques Delors were in power, negotiating the Maastricht Treaty and organizing the common currency.

title: Syracuses Boeheim Stands By Assistant Accused of Abuse
description: Syracuse University placed the associate head basketball coach Bernie Fine on administrative leave Thursday night after a former ball boy for the team told ESPN that he was molested by Fine.

title: Even in Churches, Wall Street Protesters Cant Escape Watch of Police
description: Several dozen Occupy Wall Street demonstrators were sleeping on the cushioned pews of a United Methodist church on the Upper West Side on Thursday morning when one of them spotted a man in plainclothes wandering through the sanctuary, apparently counting heads.

title: European Rift on Banks Role in Debt Relief
description: FRANKFURT  The financial stability of Europe has come down to one institution, the European Central Bank, which is now under heavy new pressure to rescue the euro  or possibly see it collapse.

title: U.S. Military Goes Online to Rebut Extremists Messages
description: MacDILL AIR FORCE BASE, Fla.  The morning sun had barely cast its fresh light over Tampa Bay when Ardashir Safavi  born in Iran, a refugee to Turkey, educated in the mid-Atlantic states  was up and patrolling two dozen Persian-language Web sites, hunting militant adversaries in cyberspace.

title: First Lady Takes On the Role of Staff Energizer
description: Young campaign workers looked up from their pizza at Obama re-election headquarters in Chicago one evening last month to find an unexpected guest: the first lady of the United States, there to deliver a surprise pep talk.

title: New York Family Courts Say Keep Out, Despite Order
description: New York States Family Courts were ordered to be opened to the public with much fanfare in 1997, supposedly allowing anyone to witness the cases of domestic violence, foster care and child neglect that inch through by the hundreds of thousands every year. But now, 14 years later, the Family Courts remain essentially, almost defiantly, closed to the general public.

title: Laid Off and Struggling to Provide, but Hoping Daughters Will Get Out
description: Ever since her high school took her on a college tour, Natalia Burks has had her heart set on going to Morgan State University in Baltimore to study forensic science. She has no connection to Baltimore, having grown up in subsidized housing on Edgecombe Avenue in West Harlem. But there was something about the romance of that tour that made Ms. Burks, now 18, believe she could go outside the customary boundaries of her life.

title: Im a Mormon Advertising Campaign
description: To counter negative perceptions of their religion, leaders of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints commissioned an advertising campaign highlighting the lives and diversity of regular Mormons.

title: Mormons Ad Campaign May Play Out on the 12 Campaign Trail
description: After Sunday worship in recent months, Mormon bishops around the country gathered their congregations for an unusual PowerPoint presentation to unveil the churchs latest strategy for overcoming what it calls its perception problem.

title: Perrys Latest Attacks Distort Obamas Words and Past
description: Over the past several days, Gov. Rick Perry of Texas has claimed that President Obama called Americans lazy. And then he sharpened the attack, suggesting that Mr. Obama grew up a child of privilege.

title: A Mormon Ad Buy, and the Political Sensitivities
description: The ads that the Mormon Church is running to soften its image are notable not only for where they are being shown  but where they are not.

title: Texas Right Offers Fast Embrace to G.O.P. Newcomer
description: Like Senator Marco Rubio in Florida, Ted Cruz is trying to stage an upset in the Republican primary for the Senate race.

title: A Test for the Tea Party in Texas Senate Race
description: RICHLAND HILLS, Tex.  The National Review cover proclaimed him the great conservative hope. George Will declared him as good as it gets. Influential conservatives endorsed him and gave him speaking slots alongside presidential candidates at national gatherings, where the crowds rewarded him with standing ovations.

title: Clinton Set to Visit Myanmar as Obama Cites Progress
description: BANGKOK  Citing flickers of progress in Myanmars political climate, President Obama announced Friday that he was sending Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton on a visit next month, the first by a secretary of state in more than 50 years.

title: Vatican Threatens Legal Action to Stop Benetton Ad
description: The Vatican said Thursday that it would take legal action to prevent the distribution of an advertisement by the Benetton clothing company showing Pope Benedict XVI kissing a prominent Egyptian imam. The Vatican said it had told its lawyers in Italy and abroad to take the proper legal measures to block the use of an altered photo it considered damaging to not only to the dignity of the pope and the Catholic Church but also to the feelings of believers. Responding to earlier protests, Benetton said Wednesday that it would withdraw the ad, part of a campaign of photo montages showing religious and political leaders kissing. A company spokesman apologized for causing offense, saying the ad campaign was intended to combat hatred.

title: The Cocktail Party: A Subtle Blend of Political Views
description: Do you enjoy a cocktail? Do you also have disgust for the state of the political discourse in this country?

title: Britain: Occupy Protesters Defy London Deadline
description: Protesters occupying land around St. Pauls Cathedral, part of a worldwide movement against economic inequality, defied a deadline from London authorities on Thursday to remove their sprawling encampment or face legal action. City officials left eviction notices across the camp on Wednesday, saying that unless tents were removed by 6 p.m. Thursday, the city would seek a court eviction order. Hundreds of tents remained after the deadline. Protesters said they had no intention of moving and were wary after forceful police evictions in similar camps across the United States. The legal action will be likely to take weeks, the city said, though the initial hearings could take place as soon as next week. Wed still like to sort this without court action, a spokesman said, but from now on we will have to have any talks in parallel with court action, not instead.

title: Deadly Storms Tear Through the South
description: ATLANTA  A severe weather front that ripped through five Southeastern states on Wednesday, killing at least six people and injuring scores, marked the beginning a fall storm season that is likely to bring more trouble to a region that has barely recovered from an unusually deadly string of spring tornadoes.

title: Corrections: November 18
description: FRONT PAGE

title: NYT Front Page for 11/18/2011
description: NYT Front Page for 11/18/2011

title: Word of the Day | ignominy
description: ignominy \ig-n-mi-ne, -m-ne also ig-n-m-ne\ noun

title: Another Poor Showing by Sanchez
description: A capsule look at the Jets 17-13 loss to Denver.

title: Mayors Next Big Test: Negotiations With Labor
description: After Mayor Rahm Emanuels highly public five-week push to win City Council approval for his first annual budget, the next phase of the mayors efforts to restore Chicagos fiscal health will take place mostly behind closed doors.

title: In the End, the Jets Cant Stop Tebow
description: DENVER  This is what frustration looks like: Rex Ryan, standing behind a lectern, appearing to fight back tears, his eyes red, his voice quavering. This is what frustration sounds like: Darrelle Revis saying that he was shocked, over and over and over again. This is what frustration feels like: abject helplessness, as Eric Smith watched Tim Tebow sprint around the corner, watched him race to the end zone, watched him celebrate the touchdown that sank the Jets on Thursday night and, maybe, for the year.

title: #OccupyWallSt Roundup, Day 62
description: Although protesters did not achieve their goal of shutting down the New York Stock Exchange on Thursday morning, one protester was able to get to the second floor of the stock exchange wearing a suit and posted a pro-OWS sign there.

title: Berkeley Crackdown Raises Fear of Move Backward
description: On Tuesday, protesters wheeled blackboards and pianos onto Sproul Plaza at the University of California, Berkeley. Thousands gathered near the famous steps for a day of teach-ins, music and speeches  one of the largest protests on the campus since the 1960s.

title: Financing for Meals on Wheels Threatened
description: On Tuesday morning, an elderly woman lowered a wicker basket tied to a rope from the second-floor window of a low-income apartment building in South Berkeley. On the sidewalk outside the buildings gate, Freya Fuchs, a volunteer driver for Meals on Wheels, caught the basket and put a hot meal into it: baked catfish with Veracruz sauce, toasted barley, soup, broccoli and a banana. The woman hoisted the food back up into her home.

title: Changes in Redistricting Are Near, but March Is Still the Month to Watch
description: Federal judges proposed new political maps for the state late Thursday, and hope to have new Congressional and legislative maps in place for Texas on the Monday after Thanksgiving.

title: Humphriess Endorsement Party: Its Not About the Watch
description: With the N.B.A. season on hold, with visions of David Stern and David Boies dancing in your basketball-deprived head and with the issues of contracts, fairness and what is due consuming more time than it should, we turn to more weighty issues.

title: Graffiti Taggers Turn to Trees, With Some Possibly Harmful Effects
description: Outside Elixir bar in the Mission district of San Francisco, graffiti taggers have left their mark  not on the wall, but on the living. Every tree on that 16th Street block has been spray-painted in shades of purple, red, white and black.

title: Award Unites Artists, Collectors and a Museum
description: They come in buses, 50 or so Bay Area contemporary art collectors, consultants and enthusiasts, to visit 30 select emerging artists every two years. For six Saturdays, the well-heeled lot traipses through small studios and edgy galleries, looking at delicate line drawings and sprawling sculptural installations alike, to meet the people they hope will become the next generation of Bay Area visual art stars.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for

title: Tunnel Worker Dies Under Grand Central Terminal
description: A worker was killed by falling concrete in a tunnel under Grand Central Terminal on Thursday evening, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said.

title: As Vote on County Budget Nears, Unions Resist Call for Unpaid Days Off
description: After weeks of working behind the scenes, Toni Preckwinkle, the Cook County Board president, has lined up bipartisan support for most of her proposed 2012 budget, observers say, including a raft of targeted tax and fee increases.

title: Jets Replay: Week 11
description: A look at the Denver Broncos 17-13 victory over the Jets.

title: Farmer Is Down; People Come Out to Help
description: Even for a farmer as strong as Glenn Bolander, with hands as rough as sandpaper and a stance that reaches 6-foot-4, emotions get rubbed raw with heartache. His wife, Carol, is battling cancer.

title: Wind Makes Play Tough, but U.S. Stays in Front
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Greg Norman, the captain of the International team at the Presidents Cup, issued a warning on Tuesday.

title: Truths and Excesses Do Battle in Speech by Teachers Union Leader
description: In ardently arguing that the emperor has no clothes, Karen Lewis took off her own.

title: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Friday
description: In an attempt to counter perceptions of political drift, the central government is introducing a slew of long-awaited second-generation economic reforms in coming weeks, including one that will allow foreign direct investment in multi-brand retail enterprises and permit foreign airlines to invest in domestic aviation companies (Hindustan Times). The steps come two days after the government announced it would allow foreign direct investment of up to 26 percent in pension funds and establish a pension regulator.

title: A Conversation With Jairam Ramesh
description: Jairam Ramesh became Indias new Minister for Rural Development in July, after a tumultuous stint as the Minister of Environment and Forests. The rural development ministrys massive $20 billion annual budget is the central governments largest, after defense.

title: As Myanmar Eases Controls, U.S. Sees Diplomatic Opening
description: BANGKOK  The long-isolated nation of Myanmar embarked on a potentially decisive shift in direction on Friday, as its main opposition leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, agreed to rejoin the countrys political system and Hillary Rodham Clinton prepared to become the first secretary of state and highest-ranking American to visit the country in half a century.

title: News Quiz | Nov. 18, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Nov. 18, 1976 | Spanish Parliament Chooses Democracy
description: On Nov. 18, 1976, Spains parliament, the Cortes, voted, 425-59, in favor of a bill to establish a democracy after 37 years of dictatorship. The bill called for the dismantling of the Cortes and the political system established by the former dictator, Gen. Francisco Franco

title: U.S. Plans New Sanctions Against Irans Oil Industry
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration plans to impose a new round of sanctions against Irans petrochemical industry, a Western official briefed on the plans said Friday, less than two weeks after a United Nations report published evidence that the Iranian government was working on a nuclear weapon.

title: U.S. Establishes Military Base in Australia
description: WHO will be deployed to Australia?

title: Test Yourself | English, Nov. 18, 2011
description: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the Op-Ed piece The Thrill of Boredom.

title: Should People Be Allowed to Obscure Their Identities Online?
description: The writer Salman Rushdie emerged victorious in a spat with Facebook over his identity, in which the social network company required him to use his legal given first name, Ahmed. The conflict has given more attention to the whole question of identity online. Should people be allowed to be anonymous, or obscure their identities, online? Or should they be required to identify themselves? Something in between?

title: Are We All Ugly Indians?
description: On a warm, sunny Saturday morning this month, about a hundred men and women gathered on Church Street in the heart of Bangalore. Dressed in white T-shirts, plastic gloves and masks that concealed their identity, they held brooms, mops and small buckets of paint. The group set out to clean the major roads of Bangalore, wielding placards that read Kaam chalu, mooh bandh (speak less, work more).

title: Filthy, Gorgeous Kolkata
description: Father and son Max and Alex Vadukul traveled to Kolkata this summer, to photograph the citys thinkers, writers and artist. The misunderstood city welcomed our curiosity. Its grim slums, incessant Ambassador taxi horns and unpleasant street odors tested us at first, but we eventually developed a great affection for the place, Alex writes in this article for T, the New York Times Style Magazine. A slide show of their portraits is here.

title: Russias War Against Rainbows
description: MOSCOW  Propaganda of homosexuality: the wording sounds almost quaint in English, like a panicky phrase out of the 1970s backlash to the early gay liberation movement in the United States. But in Russia, the phrase is current: This week lawmakers have been talking of banning propaganda of homosexuality  whatever the phrase may mean.

title: Nothing Sacred About Arts Festival in London
description: Theres something undoubtedly tongue-in-cheek about the title of the Sacred: Keeping the Faith festival. Sacred, which runs from Nov. 24 to 28 in London at the Chelsea Theatre (7 Worlds End Place; www.chelseatheatre.org.uk) is an adventurous, boundary-pushing series that features a wide variety of international theater, dance, music and film.

title: Tackling Income Inequality
description: Laura DAndrea Tyson is a professor at the Haas School of Business at the University of California, Berkeley, and served as chairwoman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Clinton.

title: The Early Word: Motivator in Chief
description: Todays Times:

title: Part 5: Answers to Your Questions on Scholarships and Student Loans
description: To help readers of The Choice navigate the maze of scholarships available to them  as well as to further their understanding of President Obamas recent proposal to ease the repayment of some student loans  Mark Kantrowitz, a financial aid expert and founder of the Web sites finaid.org and fastweb.com, is spending this week in our virtual Guidance Office. Mr. Kantrowitz is the author of Secrets to Winning a Scholarship, published in February.

title: Tim Tebow in His Words After Driving Denver to Victory
description: It looks as if well just have to get used to it.

title: Obamas Trip Emphasizes Role of Pacific Rim
description: BALI, Indonesia  President Obama discussed maritime security, nuclear nonproliferation and disaster aid at an Asian summit meeting on Friday, but just his presence on this resort island telegraphed his main message: that the United States is turning its focus to the booming Asia-Pacific region after a decade of preoccupation with wars in Iraq and Afghanistan.

title: A Musical-Satire Interlude
description: Recently I saw Tim Minchin perform at Town Hall in New York. Minchin is an Australian comic who plays a mean piano and sings satirical songs  a modern Tom Lehrer in skinny jeans and teased hair who cavorts onstage barefoot. Seeing Minchin and then reading Adam Sternberghs profile of Bret McKenzie, who is one-half of the duo Flight of the Conchords, in this weeks magazine made me think a lot about the clever art of musical satire. And by think a lot, I mean that I spent a great many hours on YouTube laughing at guys singing funny songs and tirelessly culling the ones not too profane to post. This was work, people. Here you go:

title: NYSE and Deutsche Borse Offer Deal Concessions
description: LONDON  Deutsche Brse and NYSE Euronext announced plans Friday to divest businesses in Europe and open up other operations to rivals, in an effort to win regulatory approval for their proposed $9 billion merger.

title: Rate This Jets Loss
description: A little free therapy for Jets fans  (Its best to let it all out.)

title: Debating the Use of Google AdWords
description: Thanks to everyone who took the time to reply to my last post. Id like to respond to some of the comments, because, well, just because.

title: Week 11 Matchups: Ugly but Effective
description: Chargers (4-5) at Bears (6-3)Sunday, 4:15 p.m.Line: Bears by 3.5.

title: Bank Chief Rejects Calls to Rescue Euro Zone
description: FRANKFURT  In his first speech as president of the European Central Bank, Mario Draghi complained on Friday that Europes political leaders had been too slow to carry out their own plans to address the debt crisis.

title: Send in the Clouds
description: Like pretty much everyone in Ecuador, Roque Sevilla drives fast. I hurtle with him from the capital of Quito down two and a half hours of gut-stirring switchbacks, losing elevation with every turn. The sugar-cane and cattle farmsteads tumbling past on either side dwindle steadily, while the surrounding forests gain in age and power.

title: Breakfast Meeting, Nov. 18
description: 8:55 a.m. | Updated  The business of politics is good business for TV, CBSs chief executive, Leslie Moonves, said Thursday during a question-and-answer session at a Hollywood Radio and Television Society luncheon at the Beverly Hilton in Beverly Hills, The Los Angeles Times reported. With its range of TV and radio stations, CBS could collect as much as $250 million of the estimated $2.4 billion that is expected to be generated by political campaigns across the country, The Times wrote. Such sums have only grown larger because of a 2010 Supreme Court ruling allowing unlimited campaign spending by corporations and unions.

title: On Our Radar: A Polluted River as Art Experiment
description: A public art initiative seeks to raise awareness of the polluted state of Indias Yamuna River by linking it with Germanys far cleaner Elbe, where a similar exhibition has been organized. [Associated Press]

title: U.N. Panel Finds Climate Change Behind Some Extreme Weather Events
description: At least some of the weather extremes being seen around the world are consequences of human-induced climate change and can be expected to worsen in coming decades, a United Nations panel reported on Friday.

title: Opinion Report: Court TV
description: From the editorial page

title: SABMiller Raises Fosters Bid on Tax Ruling
description: LONDON  The brewing giant SABMiller announced on Friday that it would raise its cash offer for Fosters to compensate for a tax ruling by Australian authorities.

title: Climate Panel Charts Extreme Weather in a Warming World
description: Watch live streaming video from ipcc34thsessionenglish at livestream.com

title: Tell the Critic Where to Go!
description: Hello, my name is Pete Wells. Im getting ready to start a new job, and Id like your advice.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: Investigators Are Said to Zero In on Suspect Borrowing at MF Global | With $600 million in customer money still missing, investigators have discovered hundreds of millions of dollars in suspect borrowing at MF Global, people briefed on the investigation say.

title: U.N. Court Appeals Release of Khmer Rouge Defendant
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia  Prosecutors asked judges in a United Nations-backed trial Friday to delay the release of the highest-ranking female member of the Khmer Rouge after the court ruled that she was unfit to stand trial because she suffers from dementia.

title: A Haven for Lovers of the Analog
description: When an insurance company declared the merchandise at Leeds Radio not pilferable last year, it meant that the stores hundreds of thousands of analog electronic parts  all manufactured before 1968  were unlikely to be stolen anytime soon.

title: The Voice of a Woman
description: TEL AVIV  On Sept. 5th, nine military cadets of the Israel Defense Force officer training school, all Orthodox Jews, walked out of an official event marking operation Cast Lead. A group of soldier-singers had taken the stage, but when a woman started her solo, the nine cadets stormed out. Four of them refused to come back to the hall, despite being warned that they were breaching an order, and two days later were expelled from the school.

title: Officials Pledge Help for Queens High School
First Time in World Finals Is the Charm for U.S. Underdog
description: Mardy Fish had dropped all that weight and kept it off. He had shored up his forehand and his endurance, finally committed himself to consistency and no-regrets exploration of the full range of his tennis talent.

title: Warning! Cheese!
description: Those little pots of cheese spread and crackers, and bowls of nuts, that Sardis laid out on its bar are now verboten, James Barron reports. After a recent inspection, health officials said they were unsafe because they are not protected from potential source of contamination. Who knew?

title: Fracking in One Town
description: A small town in Pennsylvania sits on one of the largest fields of natural gas in the world, making it a focal point in the contentious fracking debate.

title: Spotted on the Street | Hana Mayeda
description: The makeup artist Tina Turnbow runs into real beauty on the streets of New York City.

title: X Factor Watch: We Want a Recount
description: Two burning questions from Thursday nights X Factor results show:

title: One on One: Walter Isaacson, Biographer of Steve Jobs
description: Walter Isaacson is the author of Steve Jobs, the best-selling biography published last month. The following is an edited version of our interview.

title: Egypt Islamists Demand the End of Military Rule
description: CAIRO  Tens of thousands of Islamists jammed Tahrir Square on Friday, demanding the swift exit of Egypts interim military rulers in the most significant challenge to their authority since the ouster of President Hosni Mubarak nine months ago.

title: The Life Report: Mac Cato
description: The following Life Report was submitted in response to my column of Oct. 28, in which I asked readers over 70 to write autobiographical essays evaluating their own lives.

title: Camaraderie of the Long-Distance Runners
description: On the winding trails of LaTourette Park, a pack of young runners emerges from the distance, their maroon and gold uniforms weaving through the autumn landscape under a gentle shower of leaves. They hang tough, they hang together, true to the motto on their shirts: Vir Fidelis.

title: Can You Recommend a Few Nice Cocktails That Use the Same Spirits?
description: Q.

title: What Were Reading
description: Fox New York: Arnold Diaz reports on restaurants that dont post their health department grades if theyre less than A or have bad inspections after getting an A. Via Eater.  Nick Fox

title: Up Front: David Greenberg
Once a Realm of Stars, a Temple Is Now Bereft of Them, and Their Money
description: Here is how the Actors Temple went from being an Orthodox synagogue to a Conservative one  at least for a time.

title: An Effort, Years in the Making, to Capture the Mystery
description: The story of a faithful man, and of the unique offering he will be making on Sunday to his church, begins in a Southern California backyard in March 1974. That man, today a prominent Manhattan doctor named James Marion, is then a 10-year-old boy, and he is startled by the sound of screams from inside his familys home.

title: Boulder Dash
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Philippines Ex-President Is Arrested on Fraud Charges
description: MANILA  The former president of the Philippines, Gloria Macapagal Arroyo, was arrested in her hospital room on Friday on charges of election fraud, her lawyer said, after days of dramatic struggle with the government over whether she would be allowed to leave the country for medical treatment.

title: Galaxy Wins M.L.S. Title (in FIFA 12)
description: Home-field advantage has been translated into home-screen advantage.

title: Inside the List
description: UNBROKEN STREAK: Happy B-day  thats B for best seller  to Laura Hillenbrand, whose book Unbroken has now spent a full 52 weeks on the hardcover nonfiction list: long enough to sit up and respond to its name, according to that other perennial best seller, What to Expect When Youre Expecting. Unbroken tells the story of Louis Zamperini, an Olympic runner who was taken prisoner and tortured by the Japanese during World War II. It entered the list at No. 2 last Dec. 5, just below another book about war and torture, George W. Bushs Decision Points, and just above Jay-Zs Decoded. Hillenbrands book has outlasted more than a hip-hop stars and a two-term presidents, though. Impressively, its also vanquished her own previous best seller, Seabiscuit, which logged 30 weeks on the list back in 2001-2 before making way for the paperback edition. Well never know whether Man O War could have beaten his grandson Seabiscuit, but now we have proof that Prisoner O War can.

title: 2013 Infiniti IPL G Convertible: More of Everything, Except a Roof
description: LOS ANGELES  What is IPL? Its a valid question, given how quietly Infiniti has introduced its in-house performance arm. But analogies to well-known German equivalents dont apply here; there is no 6.3-liter, 700-pound-feet-torque biturbo V-8 lying around the Nissan-Infiniti skunkworks, at least that theyll admit to.

title: Rick Rosss Health Problems Delay Release of New Album
description: Island Def Jam has postponed the release of Rick Rosss next album until next year because his recent health problems have delayed production, Billboard reported.

title: Editors Choice
description: CATHERINE THE GREAT: Portrait of a Woman,  by Robert K. Massie (Random House, $35.) A juicy and suspenseful life of the minor German princess whose ambition, wiles, luck and strategic marriage helped her become Empress of All the Russias.

title: Amgen Agreement on Anemia Drug
description: Moving to protect a lucrative monopoly against impending competition, Amgen has reached an agreement that will preserve its status as the main supplier of anemia drugs to one of the nations two large kidney dialysis chains. The dialysis chain, DaVita, agreed that Amgens drug, Epogen, will account for at least 90 percent of its purchases of that type of anemia drug through the end of 2018. DaVita will get discounts and rebates on the drug, Amgen said in a regulatory filing Friday morning. Read the article by Andrew Pollack.

title: Paperback Row
description: AT HOME: A Short History of Private Life,  by Bill Bryson (Anchor, $15.95.) In A Short History of Nearly Everything (2003), Bryson took a cosmic perspective on the creation of the universe. With At Home, he set out to write a history of the world without leaving home. Guiding readers on a tour of his house  a former rectory built in 1851 in an English village  Bryson uses each room as a means to explore the domestic artifacts we take for granted.

title: Think Like a Doctor: Stomach Pain Solved!
description: On Thursday, we challenged Well readers to figure out the mystery of a 29-year-old doctor who had abdominal pain, elevated calcium levels and bumps on his nose, and whose father and uncle had died young from unusual cancers.

title: Exceptionalism Argument May Prove Potent for Republicans
description: Few themes have recurred more regularly in the race for the 2012 Republican presidential nomination than American exceptionalism, and few are as potentially powerful  or divisive.

title: After an Intense Day, Rest and Reorganizing
description: So what comes after an action-packed Day of Action?

title: Murakami and Memory
description: To the Editor:

title: Mastretta MXT: A Mexican Lotus?
description: LOS ANGELES  Proof that Mexico has a soup-to-nuts automaker within its borders was on display here at the Los Angeles auto show this week, as the 2011 Mastretta MXT was officially introduced to the international motoring press.

title: Midnight Rising
description: To the Editor:

title: The Next Best Thing to Herding Cats
description: It is a sport in which the contestants sometimes lie down in the middle of the field, unmotivated and bemused.

title: Regis Philbin Sticks to No-Tears Pledge on Final Show
description: 11:00 a.m. |Updated  Regis Philbin Hamming It Up to the Very End

title: A Broader Mission
description: To the Editor:

title: Sitting in Judgment
description: To the Editor:

title: Business-Dress Rehearsal for Thanksgiving: The Feast in the Company Cafeteria
description: I had Thanksgiving dinner yesterday. Roast turkey, gravy, cranberry sauce, Brussels sprouts, a modest scoop of sweet potatoes. I begged off when it came to the cornbread stuffing because Ive been trying to go easy on the carbs these days, and also, you know, um, it wasnt actually Thanksgiving.

title: Did Israel Actually Lose the 1967 War?
description: Let me list, at the outset, the many things that the diminutive but disproportionately interesting state of Israel is not. I do this in recognition of the fact that mere mention of Israel can send its critics into paroxysms of rhetorical excess seldom heard outside ESPN. So: Israel is not a fascist state, nor is it a theocracy nor, for that matter, is it a fascist theocracy. It is not an apartheid state, a totalitarian state or, God forbid, a Nazi state. It is, for its region in particular, a model of Western values, a country in possession of a robustly independent judiciary; a boisterous, appropriately unkempt press; a mature and activist civil society; and an assortment of fearless and effective human rights organizations.

title: F.D.A. Revokes Approval of Avastin for Use as Breast Cancer Drug
description: The commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration on Friday revoked the approval of the drug Avastin as a treatment for breast cancer, ruling on an emotional issue that pitted the hopes of some desperate patients against the statistics of clinical trials.

title: This week, historian David Greenberg assesses Ann Beatties new novel, Mrs. Nixon: A Life; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Alexander Star takes an anthropological view of Afghanistan; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news.
description: This week, historian David Greenberg assesses Ann Beatties new novel, Mrs. Nixon: A Life; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Alexander Star takes an anthropological view of Afghanistan; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news.

title: Umberto Eco and the Elders of Zion
description: When I was first learning quantum mechanics, I would occasionally feel compelled to lodge a complaint on behalf of common sense. My physics teacher would fix me with his twinkling gaze and intone, Truth is stranger than fiction. He was right, and not only about the behavior of elementary particles. Umberto Ecos latest fiction, The Prague Cemetery, is choreographed by a truth that is itself so strange a novelist need hardly expand on it to produce a wondrous tale. Eco forthrightly explains that all his major characters but one are historical figures; but a reader unaware of how close to the truth Eco is hewing might be inclined to award him more points for inventiveness than he earns. This is not to say that Eco doesnt earn points for inventiveness, nor that a novel cant succeed on other grounds. It is just to say that sometimes truth is stranger than fiction.

title: A Marc Jacobs Collection Goes Missing
description: It has been described as a heist, the fashion crime of the season: the announcement, Thursday afternoon, that the Marc Jacobs spring/summer 2012 collection had been stolen on the way from Paris to London, where it was to be paraded in front of the press.

title: Afghanistan: What the Anthropologists Say
description: Ten years after the Talibans leaders fled their country in apparent defeat, the war in Afghanistan has become what one observer calls a perpetually escalating stalemate. As in Iraq, the United States military has responded to bad news with counterinsurgency: eliminate troublemakers in the dark of night, with the most lethal arts, and befriend tribal elders by day, with cultural sensitivity and expertise. The Army has gone so far as to embed credentialed social scientists with front-line troops in Human Terrain Teams that engage in rapid ethnographic assessment  conducting interviews and administering surveys, learning about land disputes, social networks and how to operationalize the Pashtun tribal code.

title: Families That Most Need Guidance Counselors' Help Don't Always Get It
In the Fast Lane, Biking in Tel Aviv
description: WE were biking through the Jaffa flea market in southern Tel Aviv when we found ourselves in a narrow alley, threading our way past vintage clothing, stacks of Oriental rugs and a life-size neon likeness of Marilyn Monroe.

title: Tel Aviv on Two Wheels
description: In this flat city snarled by traffic, cycling is a popular alternative mode of transport.

title: In Storm-Ravaged Prattsville, a Bar Is Reborn
description: PRATTSVILLE, N.Y.  Tropical Storm Irene uprooted life for hundreds of people in this small town in the Catskills. On Friday, one thing will return to normal: the Prattsville Tavern is scheduled to reopen at noon.

title: From Here to Oaxaca
description: Where are we when we are before the end yet after the beginning? We are in the midst of life, where everything happens. Before the end and after the beginning, one celebrates a perfect sixth birthday, looks for a job, has an affair, remembers old girlfriends, suffers a stroke. These are the moments Dagoberto Gilb describes in his elegiac third story collection, Before the End, After the Beginning.

title: Pairings for Day 3 of the Presidents Cup
description: It is Day 3 at the Presidents Cup at Royal Melbourne Golf Club in Australia, with the United States team holding a 7-5 lead over the International team. Todays action will feature two sessions  five morning foursomes and five fourball matches in the afternoon. Steve Stricker and Nick Watney of the United States team and K.T. Kim and Y.E. Yang of the International team will sit out the mornings matches, but must play in the afternoon session. Below are the pairings for the morning session. Notably, Tiger Woods is in match against Adam Scott and former caddie Steve Williams for the second time in the event. (The captains, Fred Couples and Greg Norman, will announce the pairings for the afternoon session later today.)

title: A Lighter Shade of Green at L.A. Auto Show
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Importing Italian Cuisine
description: There was absolutely no reason for Alfred A. Knopf to publish a substantive book on high-end Italian cooking in the 1950s. Few homemakers at the time were even aware that Italian cooking had a high end. Americas aspirational cuisine was French, and ambitious home cooks had their hands full trying to perfect coq au vin and crpes suzette. Unless you were lucky enough to have grown up in an Italian family, Italian food meant spaghetti and meatballs, and Betty Crocker had a nice, easy recipe for it.

title: Can the Packers Go Undefeated? (And Other Questions from Readers)
description: Judy Battista, who covers the N.F.L. for The Times, answers readers questions:

title: Daily Report: Military Goes Online to Rebut Extremists Messages
description: The militarys Digital Engagement Team, established in 2008 by the militarys Central Command, is the focus of an article by Thom Shanker and Eric Schmitt of The New York Times. The teams mission is to counter extremist ideology, promote cultural awareness and explain U.S. interests, Maj. David E. Nevers, the teams chief officer, told The Times.

title: 2 Oklahoma State Coaches Die in Plane Crash
description: The Oklahoma State womens basketball coach and an assistant coach were killed Thursday night when the small plane that carried them on a recruiting trip crashed in Arkansas, the university said.

title: Editors Choice
description: GEORGE F. KENNAN,   (Penguin Press, $39.95.) Gaddis, a Yale professor, has written a magisterial biography of the man who both invented the cold war policy of containment and was its perspicacious critic.

title: In Big South, Final Game Means Something Again
description: On Saturday, for the third straight year, Stony Brook will face Liberty in the regular-season finale in a game that will determine the Big South championship.

title: Paperless Boarding?
description: To the Editor: Re A Boarding Pass on Your Screen (Practical Traveler, Nov. 6), its a young technology, but when it works, it works really well. While it may not be terribly useful on vacation, the technology really shines when youre traveling on business and making last-minute flight changes. More than once Ive been able to make earlier flights by checking in from my phone and getting to the airport 20 to 30 minutes before my flight.

title: So You Think You Can Be a Morning Person?
description: This column appears in the Nov. 20, 2011 issue of The New York Times Magazine.

title: A Pause in the Tebow Argument
description: To enjoy the conclusion of Thursday nights Broncos-Jets game, you did not have to buy into the legend of Tim Tebow or care one whit about his religion or politics or the ridiculousness of the Tebowing craze. You didnt even have to hate the Jets or detest the word Sanchize, although that would be a plus. Even without all of that, it was possible to sit back and marvel at how preposterous Tebows winning touchdown drive was, after 54 minutes of acting as if he had stumbled into a football game for the first time and decided to play quarterback.

title: Answers to Where on Earth to Eat?
description: ITS no secret that Anthony Bourdain knows his way around food  but hes also a world traveler, who has eaten in hundreds of spots around the globe. His new show, The Layover, on the Travel Channel, has him visiting cities for 48 hours or less, looking for the best places for travelers to eat and drink. Here are excerpts from a conversation about some all-time favorites.

title: How Graphic Should Sex Education Get?
description: How much time should a high school student devote to sex education? In four years of school, a student in a district on a semester schedule might take a total of 48 classes, with more than half going to core subjects and some smaller number of electives: language, music, art, theater (more in a school that offers more than six classroom periods daily). Starting in January, New York City public high school students will spend at least one of those semesters in a mandatory sex education class (as will middle schoolers). The sex ed can take place in (or take the place of) existing health education classes or be added to the curriculum, and what is taught and how is left to the discretion of the schools.

title: At Agriturismo, Mark Strausmans Farm-to-Table Approach
description: Mark Strausman has built his reputation as a chef creating Italian food for the haute crowd at Freds at Barneys New York, one of Manhattans top see-and-be-seen lunch spots. But Mr. Strausman always dreamed of opening a country restaurant that would become a draw for its good food and country setting.

title: Cant Place the Name, but the Typeface Is Familiar
description: With the opening two months ago of the National September 11 Memorial, the black-white-and-blue 9/11 Memorial trademark has turned up just about everywhere in Lower Manhattan, even on subway signs that have never before been branded with the logo of a private corporation.

title: Eating in Copenhagen? Lucky You
description: NOT since the 90s, when El Bullis establishment as the most heralded restaurant in the world sparked a culinary transformation in northeastern Spain, has a city changed its image as an eating destination the way Copenhagen has done recently, leaving the rest of Scandinavia  and indeed Northern Europe  to catch up. In the last couple of years, as the citys most prominent restaurant, Noma, has received one accolade after another, insiders have flocked to Copenhagen to sample what Nomas chef, Ren Redzepi, has done with Nordic cuisine. Down-to-earth but remarkably novel, his hyperlocal approach combines woods and sea in ways that are distinctively, if not Danish, then at least Scandinavian.

title: Made-for-TV Movies, Reborn on Cable
description: ITS a scene a movie studio might once have spilled a little blood for: Bill Pullman, stepping into the shoes of Harrison Ford as Rusty Sabich, the prosecutor turned suspected murderer in Presumed Innocent, the 1990 hit based on the thriller by Scott Turow. Marcia Gay Harden as Rustys brilliantly deranged spouse. Alfred Molina as the defense lawyer Sandy Stern. And Mr. Turow himself, who, despite initial resistance to writing a sequel, revisiting the Sabich saga some 20 years later.

title: Going Abroad, Staying Authentic
description: SLUMPED in the back seat of a Singapore cab, punchy after a 17-hour flight but rising to the challenge of the omnipresent camera, Anthony Bourdain gets a little silly about the odorous consequences of long-distance air travel combined with subpar airplane food. Bringing up one of his favorite whipping girls, his fellow Travel Channel host Samantha Brown, he grins like a schoolboy and delivers the zinger: Sam Brown has an assistant who stands outside the bathroom and runs in and takes the blame.

title: Fresh Gospel and Old Schools
description: Jessica Reedy

title: Weekend Fare
description: For every burger sold between 11 a.m. and midnight on Friday at Fresh and Fast Burgers, 111 East 23rd Street (Park Avenue South) in the Flatiron district, a burger will be donated to the Bowery Mission, which serves people who are homeless, to supplement Thanksgiving donations next week.

title: Smart Finds in San Francisco Amid Its Grit
