description: At the north end of the Valencia Street corridor youll find the Mission Police Station and the odd shouting inebriated denizen on the same block as camera-phone-wielding French tourists and high-end home-design stores.

title: Friday Reading: Dont Cook That Reagan-Era Turkey
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Hotel Review: La Belle Juliette, in Paris
description: THE UPSHOT

title: D.H.S. Responds on Deportation
description: A representative from Homeland Security, Matt Chandler, took issue with a blog post I wrote yesterday about a new deportation policy, arguing that Id unfairly questioned the departments intentions.

title: Where Should I Go Out for Thanksgiving Dinner?
description: Q.

title: Japans Capsule Hotels Go High Tech and High Style
description: EVENING was falling in the old Japanese capital of Kyoto, and I was tucking myself into a container slightly larger than a refrigerator. I pulled down the shade and, after a bit of contorting, lay down, the wall a few inches from my feet. It was a dainty little space, about 3  feet wide and 6  feet long, charmingly traditional with rice-paper latticework and two woven-reed mats. I felt like an origami crane as I folded my 6-foot-2-inch frame into this tatami capsule.

title: Mayor Warns of Potential School Bus Strike
At Murrow, Missing Mr. Fattorusso, Ms. Totillo, Ms. Leone and Ms. Senia
Big Ticket | Sold for $15.5 Million
description: A four-bedroom apartment in the Superior Ink building at 400 West 12th Street that sold for $15.5 million was the most expensive sale of the week, according to Streeteasy.com. And with each square foot of gilded space costing $4,234, it is one of the priciest non-penthouse purchases of the year, brokers said.

title: Lens: Turning Point  Liz Hingley
description: Lens: Turning Point  Liz Hingley

title: Dodge Charger Super Bee and Challenger Yellow Jacket Pack Hemis and Heritage
description: LOS ANGELES  Back in the day, 1968 to be exact, a Dodge Coronet was stripped down, offered with a Hemi, renamed the Super Bee and rolled out as part of the Scat Pack, Dodges exclusive coterie of high-performance cars. In 1971, the Charger inherited the Super Bee name. In either configuration, the Bee distinction was a hit with muscle-car enthusiasts, who could enlist the limited-edition cars as commuters or as fierce drag-strip competitors.

title: Fill-In | Chinese Brands
description: Directions: Fill in the blanks in several paragraphs in this article from the Business section, Picking Brand Names in China Is a Business Itself.

title: Lady Miss Kiev
Deal Assures Market for Anemia Drug
description: Moving to protect a lucrative monopoly against impending competition, Amgen has reached an agreement that will preserve its status as the main supplier of anemia drugs to one of the nations two large kidney dialysis chains.

title: Rembrandts on Exhibit, for Adults Only
description: Long dismissed as dirty little secrets, Rembrandts erotic etchings have been known to collectors for centuries but rarely seen by the public. In 2001 the British Museum exhibited several of the prints. Now, the World Erotic Art Museum (weam.com) in Miami Beach is showing the entire collection together  20 etchings  for the first time.

title: James Franco and Laurel Nakadate Rough It With Tennessee Williams
description: A certain rough-around-the-edges improvisational looseness  a sense of something coming together before your eyes, or not quite  may be one of the things that distinguishes performance art from theater. Even so, the commissions brought forth by Performa 11 over the past two weeks have tended toward an excessive disjointedness, alleviated by brief flashes of brilliance. This was the case Sunday afternoon at the Abrons Art Center on Grand Street, where the video artist Laurel Nakadate and the versatile actor James Franco collaborated on Three Performances in Search of Tennessee. It seemed very much a work in progress.

title: A New Wall Street Photo Meme: Bankers Carrying Boxes
Delusions Of Mobility
description: Greg Sargent sends us to Paul Ryans latest  an attempt to debunk the CBO report on income inequality. As usual, Ryan makes me think of Ezra Kleins old line about Dick Armey: hes a stupid persons idea of what a smart person sounds like.

title: Off the Charts: Germanys Strong Recovery
description: Since the world economy hit bottom in 2009, Germany has mounted one of the strongest recoveries of any major country. But the rest of the euro zone has lagged. The charts show changes in real gross national product since the second quarter of 2009 of nine countries in the euro zone, as well as the three largest industrial nations not in it  the United States, Britain and Japan.

title: The Barefoot Way
description: Christopher McDougall is an ardent proponent of barefoot running, but as the number of tendo-achilles and calf injuries related to running barefoot rises, it is clear to those of us who treat ailing runners that this is not the ideal form for everyone. Just as there are alternate styles of swimming or hitting a baseball, biomechanics shows us that runners should develop their own style to maximize performance.

title: Obama By the Numbers
description: I read with great interest Nate Silvers article, Handicapping Obama 2012, in connection with the models used in his and others analyses. One question I would have liked to see addressed: Per Silvers model, if the categories of approval ratings and the national economic performance are still unimproved (or if they worsen) by the 2012 election, Obama will not be able to defeat Romney, given the latters moderate ideological score. Yet large percentages of Republicans are still displaying an anybody but Romney attitude sufficient to propel a series of extremist candidates into a tie with him. That being the case, why the assumption that the multitudes of apparent Romney haters (that is, those rejecting him when he is manifestly the most electable candidate in the pack) will support him in 2012?

title: Housewives, Rebranded
description: In 2000, Charlotte Brunsdon published a book called The Feminist, the Housewife and the Soap Opera, which asked: Why were the feminist critics of the 1970s so interested in the soap-opera genre? The reasons, Brunsdon argued, varied but were largely tied to the fact that soap operas helped feminist theorists define themselves in opposition to what the books jacket refers to as an imagined other, the soap-opera-watching housewife.

title: Damage Control
description: My daughter briefly dated a boy who clearly had many psychological problems. He confided in my daughter that his brother molested him throughout his childhood, until he was old enough to put a stop to it. He said he never told the many therapists his parents dragged him to, and would die before telling his parents. Now he works part time in child care and is considering a career in nursing. Based on my limited knowledge that certain behaviors often repeat, am I wrong that he poses a danger to children? Dont his parents have a right to know? What, if anything, should I do? ANONYMOUS

title: Stephanie Madoff Mack Keeps Busy
description: In your book, The End of Normal, you write about a girlfriend setting you up on a blind date with your future husband, Mark Madoff, whom she described as one of the wealthiest men in New York. Was that appealing?  No. I never wanted to be some sort of socialite, and I dont think thats what Mark wanted. He always told me that one of the reasons he liked me so much from the beginning is because I wore a Timex.

title: The 1.7-Sketch-Per-Mile Marathon
description: Christoph Niemann draws and tweets 45 sketches during the New York Marathon.

title: Packing Heat at the Gate
description: The first thing you notice upon entering Mitiga Airport in Tripoli is a series of signs with the word No in capital letters next to illustrations of automatic weapons. The second thing is just how liberally most Libyans interpret these rules.

title: The Turkey-Lurkey Bowl
description: By far the worst place to play football in Central Park is the raised field adjacent to the Metropolitan Museum. On all four sides there are opportunities for catastrophic injury. The least dangerous boundary is the west end zone, with its two tulip trees and their thick, spread branches  excellent for dashing in your brains while sprinting at full speed after a Hail Mary. The east end zone is worse. It terminates at a chest-high fence, beyond which is a 20-foot drop onto a concrete ramp. One sideline falls off in a steep, ankle-mangling declivity; the other is the Mets Temple of Dendur gallery  a wall of glass.

title: The Brning Thing
description: Joe Weisenthal tells us about an analyst willing to risk a Godwins Law citation; Dylan Grice of SocGen points out that it was the deflationary policies of 1930-32, not the inflation of 1923, that brought you-know-who to power.

title: Can You Suggest a Vegetarian Main Course That Is Also Dairy- and Gluten-Free?
description: Q.

title: TimesCast | November 18, 2011
description: Steps toward liberalization in Myanmar lead to a planned United States visit; tens of thousands of Islamists protest Egypt's military; and this week in the 2012 Republican presidential race.

title: 5 Ways to Think About Nuisance Fees
description: If you have any doubt about the impact of the Bank of America debit card fee episode, consider a couple of things.

title: Or Maybe Jabba The Hutt
description: An email to Brad DeLong:

title: Annoying Orange Parlays YouTube Success Into a TV Series
description: The Cartoon Network has decided to do a deal with the Annoying Orange, the smart-alecky Web series that attracted over 800 million views on YouTube.

title: For Some, Free Music Is an Investment That Pays Off
description: Whats the value of a careers worth of Internet buzz? Approximately 175,000 albums sold in one week  then look out below from there.

title: Heaven Is a Place Called Elizabeth Warren
description: On the campaign trail in Massachusetts last month with the Senate candidate Elizabeth Warren, I bore witness to acts of extreme giddiness: a 20-year-old student jumping up and down, exclaiming, Oh, my God, I am obsessed with her; a third-year law student of Warrens comparing her to a superhero (Wonder Woman wishes she could be Professor Warren); a man stopping Warren on the street and introducing himself as the guy who recently passed her a mash note on a plane (I was hitting on you, he said).

title: The Glamorous Way to Carve a Turkey
description: By the 1960s, when consumers were besotted with electrical appliances, companies searched for new products to meet demand. The markets for larger goods were already saturated, so they experimented with smaller kitchen conveniences. And despite sometimes dubious utility, they were easy to sell: Don Drapers used electric ice-crushers for martinis; homemakers bought electric can openers. It was in this culture of demand that Jerome L. Murray  he of the audible pressure cooker and airplane boarding ramp  patented an early electric knife in 1964. G.E., which introduced its own model at a 1963 homes show, was quick to enter the market.

title: With Rainfall and Aid, the Number Facing Starvation in Somalia Drops by Half a Million
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The drought-induced famine crisis in Somalia has eased somewhat, United Nations officials said on Friday, with the number of people facing imminent starvation dropping to nearly 250,000 from 750,000 because of rainfall and increased aid deliveries.

title: U.S. Racing and the Rocky Factor
description: Within a few minutes on Friday I read a really funny and inspiring story in the French sports daily LEquipe, and then the depressing news that the organizers of the United States Grand Prix had confirmed that they were likely to push the race in Austin back to 2013.

title: U.S. Racing and the Rocky Factor
description: Within a few minutes on Friday I read a really funny and inspiring story in the French sports daily LEquipe, and then the depressing news that the organizers of the United States Grand Prix had confirmed that they were likely to push the race in Austin back to 2013.

title: The New Rules About Consumer Fees
description: Does the fee have any relationship whatsoever to the cost of the service? Do companies understand that they dont have much leeway if we already are angry with them? Is a company telling the whole truth when it imposes a new fee? Are we getting something really neat in return? And are we worrying too much about the wrong types of fees  and not enough about ones that are truly consequential?

title: Designing Malcolm Gladwells Doorstop
description: This February, e-book sales surpassed those of their paper counterparts for the first time. While digital books are clearly here to stay, the New York Times best-selling author Malcolm Gladwell recognizes that printed books can be beautiful, covetable objects that enhance the experience of reading. He hired Brian Rea, a frequent Times Magazine illustrator, and Paul Sahre, a designer who also frequently contributes to the magazine, to collaborate on the visuals for a new art box set, Malcolm Gladwell: Collected. Its an illustrated collection of three of his books: The Tipping Point, Blink and Outliers.

title: New Calls to Press Syria From France and Turkey
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  France joined Turkey in calling for greater international effort to exert pressure on Syria to stop its bloody crackdown on protesters, as at least 15 more people were reported killed on Friday.

title: Sunny Jacobs and Peter Pringle
description: MOST married couples will tell you that the things they hold in common helped cement their relationships. For Sonia Jacobs, 64, and Peter Pringle, 73, married in New York last Sunday, common ground was the decade and a half each had served on death row before their convictions were overturned for the murders that they steadfastly maintained they did not commit.

title: In the Labyrinth of Turkey Pricing, a Reason Under Every Giblet
description: IM about to go out and buy a turkey. And naturally, because I write about finance, I was thinking about how much I would pay for it and, more specifically, whether the rising price of agricultural commodities and fuel had affected the cost.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Twin Sightings
description: The ever-imaginative writer Alan Moore pulls off a nice trick this week as his Neonomicon, illustrated by Jacen Burrows, arrives on the hardcover and softcover graphic novels list. The tale, about two F.B.I. officers investigating murders that are tied to a rogue agent, is at No. 6 on the hardcover list and No. 2 on the softcover one.

description: The documentary In-Justice: The Story of Afghan Women in Jail was financed by the European Union to show what Afghan justice can mean for its women.

description: Goldman Sachs has appointed 261 new managing directors, according to a list obtained by DealBook. It is the smallest class since 259 were named managing director in 2008, reflecting a broad cost-cutting effort at the firm.

description: Friends whose short memories did not register that the Yorkville section of Manhattan was once home to numerous German and Eastern European beer halls tried to discourage Pamela and Alan Rice from opening a beer store there. They said that the Upper East Side is too upscale for beer, and people drink wine, Ms. Rice said.

title: Comptroller, Facing Inquiry, Promises Full Accounting of His Fund-Raising
description: City Comptroller John C. Liu, whose campaign finances are under federal investigation, called the accusations of fund-raising improprieties quite embarrassing on Friday and promised New Yorkers a full accounting.

title: Fire and Ice
description: AS if two 25-carat black opals werent enough, these showstoppers by the New York jeweler  Kimberly McDonald also contain white and gray diamonds, rubies and natural Burmese sapphires that were hand-carved in the 1920s. These are bar none, my all-time favorite earrings, Ms. McDonald said. Opal is the only material that seems to possess an internal light. And, of course, no two are the same. The sapphires are unusual and exquisite. Available at Bergdorf Goodman, for $142,670.

title: In Europe, Even a Powerhouse Is Losing Steam
description: SINCE the world economy hit bottom in early 2009, Germany has been the engine of growth in Europe. No major industrial economy  in or out of Europe  has grown as rapidly. But new figures released this week indicated that the German economy was growing at its slowest rate since the recovery began, and that much of Europe was no longer growing at all.

title: U.S. Rookies Lead Way At the Presidents Cup
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Matt Kuchar had something to say. It was the start of the United States teams news conference after the second day of play at the Presidents Cup, and a roomful of reporters sat armed with questions. Kuchar had other thoughts.

title: Iger Says No Hurry to Replace Regis Philbin

Iger, the chief executive of the Walt Disney Company, which owns ABC, said the search for the next Regis Philbin may be protracted.

title: Rereading Joe Paterno, 2004 Edition
description: As the sexual-abuse case at Penn State continues to unfold, much of the unfolding means looking back. Above all, there are the law-enforcement and institutional investigations into what happened over the last dozen-plus years. Then theres the journalistic impulse to cast a now-darker eye over past events, both small and innocent as well as large and iniquitous. In that first category, some of those lesser moments were themselves journalistic ones. Theres Jack McCallums 1999 Sports Illustrated profile of Jerry Sandusky, the former Penn State assistant football coach accused of molesting several young boys, which McCallum returned to last week on SI.com. Bill Lyons column about Sandusky that same year in The Philadelphia Inquirer, which Josh Levin reconsiders at Slate.

title: An Uprising With Plenty of Potential
description: In the wake of this weeks eviction of protesters from Zuccotti Park in New York and other urban campgrounds around the country, its tempting to dismiss the Occupy Wall Street movement as little more than a short-lived media phenomenon. The issues that spawned the movement  income inequality, money in politics and Wall Streets influence  were being drowned out by debates over personal hygiene, noise and crime.

title: London Eyes
description: In a sea of bespoke everything, from suits to shoes, it is surprising that bespoke glasses are hard to come by. Cutler and Gross just introduced what it says is the first bespoke frame service in the world, at its chic flagship store in Knightsbridge, London. Frames fanciers can make a selection from more than 4,000 styles, dating from 1969 to present, in the stores top-floor mirrored atelier. Frames can be made in the exact color to match a suit or dress, or even feature vintage lace. If the perfect frames are hard to find, you can design your own shape. All of the glasses are handmade in Italy and take a minimum of six weeks to make, so order now for the holidays. The kicker? Your name, or your beloveds if you so choose, laser-inscribed on to the inside temple.Madonna, Kate Moss and Claudia Schiffer are fans.Bespoke service starts at $950. 16 Knightsbridge Green, London; 011-44-207-581-2250; cutlerandgross.com.

title: Reading Bones to Identify Genocide Victims
description: Bones are lifes records. The forces of a lifetime  diet, accidents, age  are inscribed upon them. Forensics experts use bones to interpret these stories, or so-called osteobiographies, which can identify a persons identity and cause of death.

title: The Red Sox and Bobby Valentine: A Better Fit Than We Think?

title: Balanced Budget Amendment Falls Short in House
description: The House failed Friday to approve a balanced budget amendment to the Constitution, a central piece of the Republican fiscal agenda.

title: Film Is Dead? What Else Is New?
description: A few weeks ago I traveled to a college on Long Island to give a lecture  in other words, to stand up in front of a room full of people, ramble for a few minutes about movies and movie criticism, and then spend the rest of the hour answering questions. It was the middle of the day, and the audience was composed, in what looked like roughly equal numbers, of undergraduates and older students enrolled in continuing education courses. Half of the people were 25 and under, the other half 65 and over, leaving me smack in the generational middle and, as it happened, bouncing vertiginously, from one question to the next, between the future and the past.

title: In London, Wireless Charging for E.V.s Gets a Power Surge
description: With the ink barely dry on its announcement that it had acquired HaloIPT, the wireless electric-vehicle charging company, Qualcomm, the wireless technology conglomerate, said this week that it planned to demonstrate HaloIPTs technology in London next year. The project would be supported by the British government, city agencies and private industry partners.

title: After 2 Years, Joy Behar Is Leaving HLN

title: Accessible, From All 4 Corners of the World

Spaced at intervals along the street, also known as Cristoforo Colombo Boulevard, are businesses like Ginos Focacceria, the Bari Pork Store, S.A.S. Italian Records and the Villabate Alba bakery.

title: Photo Graphic
description: Its not often that pieces from a designers collection end up in a gallery before they make it into stores, but such is the case for the designer Dries Van Noten. An exhibition that opened in Vienna yesterday, and that will later travel to Hong Kong, Tokyo and Paris, features a selection from Van Notens spring 2012 collection alongside photographs by the London-born artist James Reeve that inspired them. Among the pieces are Reeves photo of buildings in La Rouviere, a housing complex in Marseille, and the shirt that Van Noten applied it to. I liked the mystery, the lights at night, the moment of wonder, where youre questioning whats happening on the other side of the windows, says Van Noten of the image. Reeve, too, considers the picture quite voyeuristic. Its like 1,000 small colorful television screens all lined up in rows on the hillside, he says. I have often seen people peering into the windows, trying to discover what kind of activity is going on inside. Other pieces on view with their corresponding photographs include Van Notens bridge shift and Circus, Circus top. Im used to seeing my work as two-dimensional, Reeve says. It was inspiring to see Dries translate it into dynamic forms  the way the ruffle skirts seem to almost play with the lights as they move, the colored crystals that he sewed into the windows of La Rouviere. I thought that was a really beautiful idea.

title: Wasting Medicare Money?

And that perhaps explains the sellout crowd when Mr. Ghosn appeared as a lunch speaker at the Japan Society in Manhattan on Thursday, with a talk titled The New Normal: Driving Change Through Crisis.

The local charity founded by Jerry Sandusky, the former Penn State defensive coordinator who earlier this month was charged with 40 counts of sexually abusing young boys, is preparing to fold as it tries to reconstruct what it knew, and did, about any suspicions or allegations against Sandusky over the years.

title: Conductor Flies Freely Over Critical Gulfs

To judge from his astonishing number of CDs and DVDs, Mr. Jacobs, the 65-year-old Belgian-born conductor and former countertenor, is one of the biggest stars in the proliferating world of early-music performance. He might seem to be right up there with the conductors John Eliot Gardiner and William Christie, who both recently appeared in New York.

title: Site to Be Seen | J. Crew
description: J. Crews business was founded on catalog orders and customer service, so its no surprise that its Web site offers one of the most thorough and pleasant online shopping experiences. What is a revelation, however, is the brands enthusiasm for collaborating with and supporting up-and-coming, lesser-known and top-quality heritage brands, which it does on the sites In Good Company service. (The Hill-Side, Mister Freedom and Barbour are among the labels featured.) Though thats not to discount the companys own in-house merchandise, including the Ludlow suit, which remains to be the best-fitting suit under $700. Here, the Ludlow two-button suit jacket ($425) and pants ($218), Western shirt ($128) and Fair Isle camp socks ($18.50).

title: Books Podcast: Pat Nixons Receding Self
description: Why did the novelist Ann Beattie compose an intimate portrait of Pat Nixon, whom she describes as a person I would have done anything to avoid? In this weeks Book Review, the historian David Greenberg reviews Ms. Beatties unlikely quasi-biography, quasi-novel and notes that Nixons inscrutability, her otherness, makes her an inviting subject for the novelist to imagine.

title: Fashion Without End
description: Its clear that one could board a plane after the Paris ready-to-wear shows and keep going, traveling to the various fashion weeks around the world. Its not exactly a dream. But you do wonder: what happens in places off the Milan-Paris-New York grid?

title: City Opera Begins a Season That Is Set on Many Stages
description: Who Are You New York?: The Songs of Rufus Wainwright, presented at the Rose Theater at Jazz at Lincoln Center on Thursday night, was not just an evening for this singer and songwriters ardent fans to savor his music, which was performed sensitively by four young singers in the first half and inimitably by Mr. Wainwright at the piano after intermission. It was also the official opening of New York City Operas first peripatetic season.

title: State Judge Assures Family Courts Will Be Open to All
description: New York States chief judge said Friday that he was taking steps to assure that the states family courts are open to the public, after a report was published showing wide disregard for the open-courts policy in the citys family courts.

title: Picture Framing, the Cukor Method
description: OVER the course of his long career in Hollywood (he directed his first film, Grumpy, in 1930 and his last, Rich and Famous, in 1981) George Cukor came to be known as a great director of actors  or more specifically, of actresses. Among his more famous female collaborators were Greta Garbo (Camille, 1936), Joan Crawford (A Womans Face, 1941), Judy Holliday (Born Yesterday, 1950) and Katharine Hepburn, whom he directed in 10 films, from A Bill of Divorcement (1932) to The Corn Is Green (1979).

title: For N.B.A. Owners, Its a Waiting Game
description: Heres a sobering thought: as the N.B.A.s fans wait for word that negotiations over a new collective bargaining agreement will resume in some form, the leagues owners will instead focus their efforts on projecting an image of power. The urgency that brought those owners and the now-defunct National Basketball Players Association within a few minor system considerations of a deal is now gone, and in its place is a vague time line formed by a drop-dead date for cancellation of the entire season (likely in early January), a relatively slow-moving legal process, and the owners whims.

title: New Yorks Leggy Darlings Saving the Holiday, 36 Karate Kicks at a Time
description: On Wednesday night this dance critic went to Radio City Music Hall to watch a video game. Really, I was there to check in on the Rockettes and the latest edition of the Christmas Spectacular, now in its 79th year. Those New York darlings are still kicking high, but it was a new number that I had to view through 3-D glasses that proved nearly the best dance in the show.

title: Communion of Movement and Fatherhood
description: When you walk into the Chocolate Factory for Chase Granoffs new work, intuition is preceding over my understanding, you find him behind a table serving bread on plates and wine in mason jars. As at a tasting, he describes what hes offering, his quiet, genial manner the opposite of a hard sell. After a while, he moves to the center of the room, takes off his glasses and shoes, and dances a solo in a similar key.

title: Now Online | T Travel Winter 2011
description: The winter travel edition of T sets out on a quest for adventure, starting in Utahs Canyonlands, where the model Heidi Mount takes a hike through her childhood stomping grounds. Next its off to Ecuador for a look at how an ambitious new lodge hopes to save the cloud forest by opening it to tourism; then father and son Max and Alex Vadukul make a pilgrimage to the divine chaos of Kolkata, to meet the citys leading cultural figures. We also meet Balis own Willy Wonkas and their new bamboo chocolate factory; the shadowy mistress of Ukraines fashion set; and a former circus performer who now preaches the gospel of olive oil in Paris. Along the way, T touches down in the skiing utopia of Vermonts Mad River Glen; in the eternal French melting pot of Marseilles; and in Florida, for a tour of whats buzzing in the Sunshine State.

title: Jabras Sport Bluetooth Headset Is Just Right For Rainy Runs
description: Runners of a certain age will remember a time, not too long ago, when the idea of a light pair of wireless sports headphones was ludicrous. Devices that even partially fit the bill were large, bulky, and had a surprisingly short battery life. However, the Jabra Sport Bluetooth headset may finally set us all free.

title: Porsche to Build in Atlanta and California
description: IN two years, air passengers circling above Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport may glimpse a Porsche badge out their windows. The atrium of the automakers new North American headquarters, scheduled to open in late 2013, will take the shape of the shield on Cayennes, Panameras, Caymans, 911s and Boxsters.

title: Friday Night Music: Sarah Jarosz
Todays Scuttlebot: Spotify, Yelp and a Zoetrope
description: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times are always looking for the most interesting items on the Web. Todays selection includes real-world animated GIFs and political ads on Pandora.

title: Kennedys Death Revisited, Old Frame by Old Frame
description: The awful anniversary is upon us once more, which means that somebody must be looking yet again at the assassination of John F. Kennedy.

title: Signs of Solitude in a Bustling City
description: We tend to think of cities  and New York in particular  as noisy, nerve-jangling places. So its surprising how many of the 60-plus paintings, photographs and other items on view in New York, New York! The 20th Century exude silence.

title: Wheelies: The Potsdam Bread-Van Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Reviewing the 2012 Mercedes-Benz SLK350
description: In Sundays Automobiles section, Lawrence Ulrich reviews the Mercedes-Benz SLK350, a two-seat convertible that has polished up its packaging and performance for 2012.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Nov. 18
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: LivingSocial Set to Raise About $200 Million
description: LivingSocial is aiming to raise close to $200 million from new and old investors, according to two people briefed the matter.

title: Bundt Cake Is Good (and They May Not Miss the Pie)
description: PIE might be the iconic Thanksgiving finale, but its not the only option for a sweet ending.

title: If You Dont Have a Bundt Pan
description: Not everyone has a bundt pan, and if you dont, you can bake this apple bourbon cake in two 9-inch loaf pans instead. The baking time might be shorter, so start checking at 45 minutes. An added advantage, youll have two cakes, meaning you can bring (or serve) one and save the other.

title: Goldmans Cohn May Be Interviewed in Gupta Case
description: Gary D. Cohn, the president of Goldman Sachs, is expected to be interviewed by the government in its insider trading case against Rajat K. Gupta, a former director of the bank.

title: Spitting Sad About the Bloody Uprisings in Iran
description: If you asked people to name one image they associated with the violent Iranian protests in 2009, many would probably pick the horrifying video of Neda Agha-Soltan, the young woman shot to death on a street in Tehran: blood everywhere and, more than that, her unfathomable eyes meeting the cameras gaze.

title: Federal Subsidies for Renewable Energy
description: To the Editor:

title: The Pains of Evisceration and Unrequited Love
description: The dungeon master, that eight-sided-dice-wielding arbiter in any Dungeons & Dragons game, serves as a potent metaphor in She Kills Monsters, Qui Nguyens deceptively breezy and rather ingenious comedy.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Nov. 18
description: More Photographs

title: Killer Charms: Grin, Shrug and Strangle a Soprano or Two
description: Why are serial killers always so delightful? Is there a charm school for maniacs, where Hannibal Lecter learned elocution and Freddy Krueger picked up his cheerful wit?

title: Why Cant a Brined Bird Make Good Gravy?
description: Q.

title: Campus Law Enforcement and Sexual Assault Cases
description: To the Editor:

title: Gun Rights for Felons?
description: To the Editor:

title: Haydn and Bruckner, Confidently Sketched
description: In the second of two programs offered by the eminent Dutch conductor Bernard Haitink during his present guest engagement with the New York Philharmonic, he plotted a steady course through the tried and true: Haydns Symphony No. 96 and Bruckners Symphony No. 7. As another reviewer noted last week, a conservatism seems evident in the Philharmonic this season; on the other hand, it made sense that Mr. Haitink, absent from the Philharmonic podium since 1978, would want to focus on music that he clearly holds dear.

title: High Fives, 56 Times
Rogue Web Sites
description: To the Editor:

title: The Patience of a Computer Can Make It Useful as a Teacher
description: A couple of days ago I received an e-mail from a reader saying that I should not write about computer programs because they play so badly.

title: The Week in Metro Pictures for November 11
description: Subjects include the Annual Veterans Day Parade, the 10th anniversary of the crash of American Airlines Flight 587 and the eviction of Occupy Wall Street.

title: A Night to Ponder Birth, Death and Dreams
description: How Much Is Enough? Our Values in Question is theater as encounter group. It feeds off audience members, who are called on to talk about things like birth, death and time; to bow their heads and raise their hands if they feel frightened or lonely; to slow dance (the shows most theatrical moment); and even, in one case, when a male performer asked a straight man what it would be like if they had sex, to agree to a kiss.

title: Some Songs About Travel, Sung by a Carefree Guide
description: Charm. To what extent is it an innate gift, an emanation some people are born with like an especially pleasing body scent? And to what extent is it a cultivated set of manners whose goal is seduction? Watching the cabaret singer Andrea Marcovicci glide through her paces at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel on Wednesday evening, I decided it must be both. In any dedicated charmer, I figured, instinct and guile fuse into an irresistibly captivating presence; after that, it all seemingly comes naturally.

title: Rangers Surge Behind Balanced Scoring and Stalwart Defensemen
description: The Rangers enter Saturday nights game in Montreal with a seven-game winning streak. Even after skating-intensive workouts, there were smiles in every corner of the Rangers practice facility this week.

title: Kindle Fire Said to Bleed a Bit Less Red Ink
description: After Amazon announced it would charge $199 for the Kindle Fire, a big question was how much  not whether  the company would lose money on every device sold. According to a new teardown report on the device, the answer is: not as much as expected.

title: A Career Provocateur
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Marina Abramovics Crossover Moment
description: Who best to design a gala for an art museum than an artist herself?

title: Cain Suggests the Taliban Are Running Libya
description: Read an updated version of this post.

title: Chic in Review | Marc Jacobs, Fashion Victim!
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: Advances in Medicine Lead Stars to Surgery
description: The rash of singers who have canceled concerts this fall to undergo throat surgery  Adele, Keith Urban, John Mayer  might suggest that touring takes a terrible toll on the vocal cords. Yet doctors who specialize on vocal issues point to something else to explain the cancellations: new diagnostic tools and surgical techniques.

title: Reminiscences of a Gay Utopia
description: THE Pavilion dance club, a hedonistic playground for three generations of gay men in Fire Island Pines, burned down Monday night, stirring memories in gay communities in New York City and beyond.

title: This Sunday: A Pennsylvania State of Mind
description: As states go, Pennsylvania is not one to crave attention, certainly not the kind its receiving now with the Penn State scandal. In this weeks magazine, we dont delve into that story  our colleagues at the newspaper are doing an excellent job with it, and a few years back, we published a profile of Joe Paterno thats worth rereading  but our two biggest features happen to take place in the state.

title: Seeing in Crisis the Last Best Chance to Unite Europe
description: BERLIN

title: Capitalizing on Collapse
description: A new political calculus is emerging on both sides of the aisle now that it looks as if the Joint Select Committee on Deficit Reduction may fail to reach an agreement by Wednesdays deadline.

title: California: Crystal Cathedral Will Be Sold to Catholic Diocese
description: A bankruptcy judge has allowed the Roman Catholic Diocese of Orange to buy the Crystal Cathedral, the megachurch where the Hour of Power religious program is filmed, for $57.5 million. The sale will allow Crystal Cathedral Ministries to pay its creditors and emerge from bankruptcy. The diocese plans to consecrate the church, in Garden Grove, as a Catholic cathedral. The judges decision came on Thursday after a bidding war between the diocese and Chapman University. The university had hoped to use the property as a satellite campus and had offered Crystal Cathedral Ministries a hope of buying back some of it. The cathedral board endorsed the Catholic plan. The ministry will be allowed to remain in its current location for three years, and its leaders have vowed to continue operations at another location.

title: Heart Rate Monitors Fine-Tune Players Fitness
description: STORRS, Conn.  As soccer practice began one recent afternoon, each University of Connecticut player grabbed a puck before he kicked a ball. The puck was a small rectangular transmitter that attached to a chest strap and was worn beneath the players jerseys.

title: Doing the Ethical Thing May Be Right, but It Isnt Automatic
description: FOR the last few weeks, the sex abuse scandal at Penn State and the harassment claims against the Republican presidential candidate Herman Cain have been fodder for discussion at my house. The same is true, I assume, around the country.

title: De Rosario Named M.L.S. M.V.P.
description: D.C. United midfielder Dwayne De Rosario was named Major League Soccers Most Valuable Player on Friday, capping a year that saw him play 33 games for three teams, but none in the playoffs.

title: Towers, a Tunnel, Noise, Lessons and a Library
description: WHEN it comes to buildings, size matters  more so today than ever before, Kate Ascher writes in The Heights: Anatomy of a Skyscraper (Penguin Press). In this lushly illustrated book, Ms. Ascher meticulously and lucidly deconstructs the design of manmade towers from the foundation on up to the imperatives of physical and psychological security in a terror-conscious society.

title: Pairings for Day 3 Fourball Matches at the Presidents Cup
description: After Saturdays morning session at the Presidents Cup, the United States team leads the International squad, 11-6. The American duo of Bubba Watson and Webb Simpson, Presidents Cup rookies, remained undefeated in the morning session Saturday, beating Robert Allenby and Geoff Oglivy, 3 and 2. Below are the pairings for the afternoon fourball session. The American captain Fred Couples chose to rest Phil Mickelson, who is undefeated so far, because he wanted Mickelson fresh for the singles matches Sunday. David Toms is also sitting out this round for the U.S., with Robert Allenby and Ryo Ishikawa out for the International squad.

title: Europe Fears a Credit Squeeze as Investors Sell Bond Holdings
description: Nervous investors around the globe are accelerating their exit from the debt of European governments and banks, increasing the risk of a credit squeeze that could set off a downward spiral.

title: Gingrich Answers Attacks on His Web Site
description: After a week of revelations about his business dealings after he left Congress, the former House Speaker Newt Gingrich has added a new page to his Web site answering the new questions, and some old ones, too.

title: Brazil Officials Criticize Chevron Over Oil Spill
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Chevron came under intense scrutiny in Brazil on Friday over an oil spill at an offshore field the company operates, with federal investigators here threatening fines for Chevron and potential prison terms for its officials if they are found guilty of violating environmental contamination laws.

title: Selling Candy to Kids
description: To combat the rise in childhood obesity, Congress in 2009 asked the Federal Trade Commission and three other government agencies to create voluntary nutritional standards for foods that are marketed to children. In April, the interagency group released sound recommendations to guide self-regulation by the food industry.

title: Toasting Architecture at Lincoln Center, With Wine by the Grass
description: Our work started early Monday evening. Riding the D train to Lincoln Center, we spotted a celebrity standing across from us, and thought to rifle for our notebook. A straphanger beat us to it. Youre John Lithgow, the commuter said. Mr. Lithgow confirmed it. The man said he was surprised to see the actor taking the subway. (We admired the mans gall. Need a job? Call us.) Its the best way to get around, Mr. Lithgow said. The subway doors opened.

title: Gary Chapmans Growing Marriage Seminar
description: Hundreds of couples attended Gary Chapmans Growing Marriage seminar at an Ohio church.

title: Honk if You Agree There Is a Difference Between Free Speech and Noise
description: DENVER  Horn-honking, as a statement of frustration or joy or who knows what behind the wheel, has been part of the American fabric since the first Ah-OO-gah from the first Model A.

title: Satirizing Putin With Boldly Poetic Flair
description: MOSCOW  An elegant after-work crowd packed into the Estrada Theater last week, having shelled out as much as $250 for an evening devoted to laughing at Vladimir V. Putin.

title: Republican Financial Plans
description: Our topic for today is: Where do the Republican candidates for president get their money?

title: An Incremental Change
description: In the summer, the Obama administration promised it would review its deportation policies, and, this week, it promised that it really means it. Maybe one day immigration officials will even tell the public the results. In the meantime, the review is a good idea, but its serious pitfalls are reminders of the rising costs of our national failure to fix a broken immigration system.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,476 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,822 who have died as part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: Natural History, Not-So-Natural Setting
description: Klaus Pichler was wandering home from a bar one morning when he noticed a light coming from a basement window at Viennas Museum of Natural History. Even at that hour, he thought, someone was hard at work inside.

title: N.C.A.A. Begins Penn State Inquiry
description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa.  The N.C.A.A. has sent Penn State a letter announcing it will begin an inquiry into the universitys institutional control and ethical conduct stemming from the sexual abuse charges against the former assistant football coach Jerry Sandusky.

title: As Deadline Nears, Deficit Panel Is Still at Deep Impasse
description: WASHINGTON  Just 72 hours before a deadline to present Congress with a plan to cut $1.2 trillion from the nations deficit, members of a joint Congressional committee remained at a deep impasse on Friday after Democrats rejected a new Republican proposal devised with the help of Speaker John A. Boehner.

title: Dont Give Up on Sanctions
description: Washington

title: Deal With the Devil Foreseen by Romney
description: With something of a literary flourish, Mitt Romney expressed pointed doubts on Friday about the ability of the members of a Congressional panel on deficit reduction to reach an acceptable solution, predicting that any recommendations could be a Faustian bargain that would cut money from the military budget.

title: Militias and Army Jostle for Influence in Libya
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  The armed militias that emerged from Libyas civil war and units of the fledgling Libyan National Army are pressing the interim government for places in a new cabinet, which is expected to be seated shortly.

title: Bill Cunningham | Tinted Town
description: The fashion statements are varied, but sleeveless fur jackets are the hit of the season.

title: Week in Pictures for Nov. 18
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the Annual Veterans Day Parade, the 10th anniversary of the crash of American Airlines Flight 587 and the eviction of Occupy Wall Street.

title: Labor Board May Speed Union Votes
description: A proposed federal rule to speed union elections, a step opposed by business groups, may be adopted before the end of the year, a Republican member of the National Labor Relations Board said on Friday.

title: ABC Plans Midseason Replacements of Man Up and Pan Am
description: ABC, which has seen the needle for its prime time fortunes turn upward with the introduction of several successful new series this fall, on Friday announced mid-season changes to its schedule. The changes include the introduction of some stop-gap reality shows, a new drama the network is especially high on and a comedy featuring cross-dressing to replace an expected cancellation.

title: Modern Chinese, Bold and Flavorful
description: AS a child, I loved to dine out with my parents in San Franciscos Chinatown. Off a steep side street, we would descend a short flight of stairs and squeeze into a traditional wood-paneled stall. The waiter would tap on the door before entering with each course: egg-drop soup, fried rice, chicken chow mein, black tea and, at meals end, brittle fortune cookies whose sometimes inscrutable pronouncements I always took to heart.

title: Jamie Pierre, Free Skier Known for Feats of Daring, Dies at 38
description: In 2006, Jamie Pierre skied off a 255-foot cliff in the backcountry of Grand Targhee, Wyo., plummeting nearly headfirst and without a helmet for more than four seconds. He struck the deep powder at the base of the cliff with such force that friends had to dig him out.

title: U.S. Foursomes Widen Lead
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Tiger Woods won his first Presidents Cup match, and the United States won four of five foursomes on Saturday morning and extended its lead to 11-6.

title: The Inside Man
description: For months, Newt Gingrich tried to ingratiate himself with the Republican Partys right wing by tearing down the two government-sponsored mortgage companies, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. He joined the counterfactual conservative chorus that prefers to blame the companies for the housing crisis rather than the banks. He lamented their cozy relationship to Washingtons insiders. And he was rewarded with a swell of support from the anybody-but-Mitt-Romney crowd.

title: Syracuse Assistant Denies Sexual Abuse Claims
description: SYRACUSE  Bernie Fine, an associate head basketball coach at Syracuse University who has been accused of sexually assaulting a former ball boy, issued a denial Friday through his lawyer, saying, These allegations are patently false in every aspect.

title: Vilifying Rival, Wall St. Rallies for Senate Ally
description: The warning has ricocheted around the financial world in recent weeks, in conversations at Midtown restaurants and Washington fund-raisers, carrying urgent appeals for money from financial executives around the Northeast: The battle to re-elect Senator Scott P. Brown, the Republican from Massachusetts, just got a little more interesting.

title: A Trip to the Pub on Memory Lane
description: THE Lawson Pub in Oceanside, which opened in September, is a welcome newcomer in these budget-conscious times. It has a talented chef, delicious food and easy-to-take prices.

title: What Goes With Yams
description: A cast-iron Thanksgiving traditionalist, I always have a standard turkey dinner, served unfailingly at 4 p.m. Since I cherish the idea of reruns, it seems logical to recommend for Thanksgiving some Long Island wines that have given me particular pleasure during 2011.

title: 28 Indicted in Theft of Steakhouse Patrons Credit Card Data
description: The customers went for the dry-aged sirloin and tender cuts of filet mignon, like many at New York Citys better steakhouses. And, like many, they handed their credit cards to the waiters after their meals, expecting to tip, sign and be on their way.

title: At Prep School, Rolling Up Sleeves and Working the Soil
description: LAKEVILLE, Conn.

title: Baum Weighs In After Uproar
description: Mr. Nocera  You have destroyed everything and everyone related to Steven J. Baum PC. It took 40 years to build this firm and three weeks to tear down.

title: After a Horrific Crash, a Stark Depiction of Injustice in China
description: BEIJING  Days after a nine-seat van crammed with 62 kindergartners slammed into a coal truck in northwest China this week, killing 21 children and two adults, the 21st Century Business Herald  a state-run, reliably nationalistic newspaper  did something extraordinary.

title: There but for Fortune Go the Straphangers
description: Theres no Wayne Newton serenading in the lounge yet, but the citys first casino is already booming on the fringe of Queens, offering less-than-Vegas glitz at the end of a long subway ride from Manhattan. Bird watchers on their way to the Jamaica Bay Wildlife Refuge used to be the main enthusiasts taking the A train that far. But thousands of beaming gamblers poured from the trains to wait in long lines at the opening last month, anxious for action.

title: Decline of American Exceptionalism
description: Is America exceptional among nations? Are we, as a country and a people and a culture, set apart and better than others? Are we, indeed, the shining city upon a hill that Ronald Reagan described? Are we chosen by God and commissioned by history to be a model to the world as George W. Bush said?

title: Tax Pledge May Scuttle a Deal on Deficit
description: Three-quarters of Americans  including more than half of Republicans  say they believe that any deficit reduction plan should include tax increases, according to a recent New York Times/CBS poll. But Congressional Republicans are not so sure.

title: Boys Swimming on Girls Teams Find Success, Then Draw Jeers
description: During his first-period broadcast Monday, the Norwood High athletic director Brian McDonough congratulated Will Higgins for breaking the meet record in the 50-yard freestyle the previous day at the Massachusetts South Division fall swimming and diving championships.

title: Richard H. Kuh, Ex-Manhattan Prosecutor, Dies at 90
description: Richard H. Kuh, a lawyer and former Manhattan prosecutor who jousted in celebrated cases with the likes of Lenny Bruce and Claus von Blow, died on Thursday in Manhattan. He was 90.

title: A Culinary Circus, Fresh From the Lab
description: Montclair, N.J.

title: After 2 Bad Losses, Jets Face Tough Path
description: DENVER

title: A Now-Rare Tunnel Accident Claims a Workers Life
description: It seemed like a headline from another era: a worker killed while constructing a gargantuan train tunnel 140 feet below the surface of Manhattan.

title: Lottery Numbers
In Reversal, Columbia Lets Band Perform
description: Columbia University reversed its decision to bar its band from the final football home game on Saturday after the band apologized for ridiculing the 0-9 Lions by changing words in the schools fight song after last weekends loss.

title: Jon B. Lovelace, Mutual Fund Industry Leader, Dies at 84
description: Jon B. Lovelace, an early leader in the mutual fund industry who helped turn his firm, the Capital Group, into one of the largest money management companies in the nation, died on Wednesday at his home in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 84.

title: Saturday: Pattern of Highs and Lows
description: Administrivial Non-Standard Puzzle Alert! The puzzle for tomorrow, Sunday, Nov. 20, has some unusual features. In the print version of this crossword, some squares (containing slashes) in the Across and Down answers do not actually cross. Write both parts of the answers in those squares. Then use the central Across answer to interpret them properly to spell an appropriate final word.In the online version of this puzzle, the slashes are replaced by circles, and the program will accept either one of the answers that goes in that square, but not both (because of electronic restrictions). Although this Across Lite version does work, it is recommended that solvers download and print out the PDF version of this puzzle. As a second-best alternative, print out this Across Lite version and solve on paper.Dont worry. Just give it a try; it will make much more sense as you go.

title: Jurors Weigh Five Deaths and One Unpredictable Defendants Fate
description: NEWARK

title: A Computer Brings the World to a Reclusive Woman
description: Mary Dunn found her first computer in the garbage at her building in Hells Kitchen around 1990. She borrowed a monitor from a friend, and slowly taught herself how to use the machine.

title: City Plans for Strike by School Bus Drivers
description: The Bloomberg administration set in motion on Friday a broad contingency plan for a school bus drivers strike, sending letters to parents and principals and buying hundreds of thousands of MetroCards for students who could be left without transportation. But a statement by the unions president indicated that the timing of a strike, if one were to be called, was unclear.

title: Group Sues Over Albany Redistricting, Saying 12 Elections Are in Jeopardy
description: As the State Legislature and the governor argue over how best to draw a new political map for New York State, a group of community leaders has filed a lawsuit asking a federal judge to take control of the contentious redistricting process.

title: Settled In at Rutgers, Sanu Breaks Records
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J.  Mohamed Sanu was ineligible to play football as a senior at South Brunswick High School because he was 19. Rather than enroll in a prep school, he decided to stay at South Brunswick, where he could practice and help the coaches.

title: Older, Suburban and Struggling, Near Poor Startle the Census
description: WASHINGTON  They drive cars, but seldom new ones. They earn paychecks, but not big ones. Many own homes. Most pay taxes. Half are married, and nearly half live in the suburbs. None are poor, but many describe themselves as barely scraping by.

title: A Dude Ranch at a Crossroads
description: The family that runs the Triangle X Dude Ranch in Grand Teton National Park is challenging the governments efforts to open up the concession to competitive bidding.

title: A Dude Ranch Rests Hopes on a Rockefeller Deal
description: MOOSE, Wyo.  John D. Rockefeller Jr. fell in love with the West here, and left his fingerprints all over the place.

title: Detroit to Lay Off 9 Percent of Its Public Work Force
description: The jobs of 1,000 city employees in Detroit, or about 9 percent of that citys public work force, will be eliminated early next year, Mayor Dave Bing announced on Friday, adding new, painful details to his plan to save the city from running out of money.

title: Prospects Improve for Sept. 11 Suits Against Nations
description: WASHINGTON  A series of surprise developments in the courts and Congress has given thousands of Sept. 11 victims perhaps their best chance in the 10 years since the attacks to press lawsuits against Saudi Arabia, Afghanistan and other nations that they believe were financially complicit.

title: Giants Top Pick Remains Patient as His Debut Nears
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Prince Amukamara returned from practice Friday to discover that someone, or some people, had yanked the contents from his locker and tossed them on the floor, leaving the stool he usually sits on perched on top, upside down.

title: Fate of a U.S. Base Heightens Tensions in Iraqs Contested North
description: RAMADI, Iraq  The American military has not yet left an air base along the contested internal border between the semiautonomous Kurdistan region and the rest of Iraq, but a dispute has already broken out over which side will control the strategic site once the Americans leave.

title: Composer Puts Her Trust in the Soloist
description: By her own account, the composer Jennifer Higdons life has taken a surreal turn. Swept up in a swirl of lectures, performances and awards ceremonies  last year she won the Pulitzer Prize and a Grammy  she has, in rapid fashion, been accepted into the rarefied ranks of contemporary composers whose works are both widely played and wildly praised.

title: Documentary Short List for Oscars Released
description: LOS ANGELES  The Oscar documentaries short list is in, some industry favorites are out, and that makes it a typical year for the documentary branch of the Academy of Motion Pictures Arts and Sciences, which almost always manages to puzzle and provoke with its choices. On the list of 15 documentaries, from which nominees and the winner will be drawn, are:

title: Clean and Sober, but Still Addicted
description: Romeo and Juliet they are not. Jackie and Veronica, the lovers at the center of The ____________ With the Hat, are foulmouthed, uncouth and long past the first fine careless rapture that made them a couple. Yet somehow this harsh, funny, ultimately affecting play by Stephen Adly Guirgis lets us see right through their fights and lies and egregiously bad behavior to their eternal but star-crossed love.

title: From Cain, More on Libya
description: Herman Cain has repeatedly criticized the news media for what he calls its obsession with his answer to a question about Libya posed by an editorial writer in Milwaukee this week. His confused-looking pause, stares at the ceiling and mangled response were captured on video by The Milwaukee Journal Sentinel, and reporters have been asking about the five-minute clip ever since.

title: An Uncomfortably Small, and Shrinking, World
description: Nothing draws people together like a crisis. The reigning global conversation at the moment  if one is to judge by newspaper headlines  is about the worldwide economic mess. Before that, however, the state of our environment dominated our collective consciousness. It is this second issue that is addressed in Marina Zurkow: Friends, Enemies and Others at the Montclair Art Museum.

title: Niche Voters Giving Paul Momentum in Iowa Polls
description: VINTON, Iowa  Steve and Cindy Anders belong to one of Iowas most politically savvy movements  Christian home-schoolers, whose organizing on behalf of Mike Huckabee in 2008 was one of the secrets behind his upset victory in the states Republican caucuses.

title: Changing the Tune in Huntington
description: Huntington, N.Y.

title: Man Is Sought in Attacks on 6 Women
description: The police were searching on Friday for a man who they said had sexually assaulted six women in the Bronx in the span of about six hours, violently groping them.

title: Podcast: European Debt, Bank Fees and Beats Headphones
description: New governments have been installed in Italy and Greece and Greek debt restructuring is under way, but European credit markets remain shaky.

title: European Banks Reducing Sovereign Debt
description: European banks divested themselves of some of their sovereign debt at the end of 2010.

title: An Extra Set of Eyes at the Museum
description: APP Beyond Planet Earth

title: Haiti: Plans for Army Are Delayed
description: President Michel Martelly on Friday put off a plan to reinstate Haitis armed forces until a commission he plans to appoint next week reports on the best way to proceed. The plan to bring back the military, disbanded in 1995 after years of participating in coups and human rights abuses, has been criticized by diplomats, who believe fortifying the national police would be the better use of resources. But Mr. Martelly, playing up national pride as much as security, promised the new military would be apolitical and could eventually replace United Nations peacekeepers, in place since 2004.

title: The Weeks Business News in Photos
description: European protests spread to Paris, oil flows returned in Libya, Occupy Wall Street lost its Zuccotti Park home and an REI is coming to Manhattan.

title: Re-engineering New York: More Than a Sci-Fi Dream?
description: At an urban-planning conference last week, Mary Ann Tighe, a prominent commercial real estate broker and glamorous presence in any room full of people who think about sewage flow, aligned herself against a certain strain of traditionalism. The most powerful woman in New York, according to a recent ranking by the business publisher Crains New York, Ms. Tighe lamented returning home from China to a skyline she now views only in the quaintest terms.

title: Corrections: November 19
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Bordering on Poverty
description: The Census Bureaus new measure of poverty adjusts for cost of living and includes government benefits and income lost to taxes, health care and work expenses.

title: Man Sought in Bronx Attacks
description: The police said the sexual assaults in the Bronx occurred on Thursday in the span of about six hours. Video courtesy of the New York Police Department

title: Its Not All Fun and Games
description: Kati London, head of products for the social-game developer Zynga in New York, spends her week experimenting with ways to make interactions between machines and humans more social. She has worked on games like CityVille and Drop7. On Sundays, she turns her attention to her personal life, visiting friends and exploring in Manhattan or hiking upstate; she also finds time for projects like Botanicalls, a system to send Twitter posts or voice messages to caretakers from plants that need watering. Ms. London, 35, lives in Chelsea with her long-time partner, the artist Kjell Otterness, and their baby daughter, Ulla London Otterness.

title: Technology Footprint: Starting Up in New York
description: A majority of the more than 400 technology start-ups in New York City are located in Midtown South, within blocks of venture capital investors and veteran startups.

title: The Grande Dame of Staten Island
description: At 91, Edith Susskind, who is known for her flamboyant hats, still sells gifts and still is a fixture of the boroughs luncheon scene.

title: The Paper Chase
description: In recent years, a law schools reputation has been all but defined by the number and quality of the law review articles produced by its faculty.

title: Students Accused of Cheating Are Expected to Turn Themselves In
description: At least seven people are expected to turn themselves in to the authorities next week on allegations of cheating on college admissions exams, according to a person briefed on the matter, as part of a scandal on Long Island in which students are accused of paying people to take the SAT reasoning test and the ACT test for them.

title: The Grande Dame of Staten Island
description: THERE were hundreds of high-hatted ladies at a luncheon on Staten Island on Thursday, but it was the tiniest one who seemed to be making the biggest hit.

title: From Safety of New York, Reporting on Distant Home
description: WHEN news breaks in Nigeria, Omoyele Sowore is there. His Web news operation was the first to publish a photo of the Nigeria-born underwear bomber arrested in December 2009, and when a suicide bombing this summer shook a United Nations building in Abuja, Nigerias capital, he was the first to publish on-the-ground reports and photos. During the presidential election in Nigeria in April, he published real-time photos, videos and reports from the field, exposing instances of ballot rigging, and attracting over eight million page views in one month.

title: On the Move, in a Thriving Tech Sector
description: WHEN the tech firm Yipit moved last month from General Assembly, a communal office campus on 20th Street and Broadway, to its own loft space on 18th Street and Fifth Avenue, its 14 employees simply grabbed their coffee cups and MacBook Airs and did the job on foot.

title: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
description: Jammu and Kashmir: Farooq Abdullah, federal minister for new and renewable energy, on Thursday supported his son and state Chief Minister Omar Abdullahs decision to withdraw the Armed Forces Special Powers Act from parts of the state. He said the chief minister is the boss in the state and the federal government should consider his views on the controversial act (Kashmir Live).Manipur: The central government has proposed a supra state body for the Naga people settled in Manipur, Assam and Arunachal Pradesh, according to the Sangai Express. This is a part of the continuing negotiations between the Nationalist Socialist Council of Nagaland and the Ministry of Home Affairs on its demand for a sovereign Nagaland. While state boundaries would not change, the proposed councils for Naga-dominated areas outside Nagaland would exercise effective control there, reports the Nagaland Post.

title: Out on the Town, Always Online
description: At a dinner party with friends in TriBeCa recently, Zander Rafael, 26, barely used his phone at all.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: In a Video, White House Shooting Suspect Called Himself Modern-Day Jesus Christ
description: In a video intended as an audition tape for Oprah Winfrey, the 21-year-old Idaho man accused of firing an assault rifle at the White House last week expressed frustration with the United States government and called himself the modern-day Jesus Christ that you all have been waiting for.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Newswallah: Bollywood Edition
description: Baby Bachchan: Bollywoods First Baby arrived on Nov. 16. Aishwarya Rai Bachchan, wife of actor Abhishek Bachchan and daughter-in-law of iconic superstar Amitabh Bachchan (Time magazine once referred to them as Bollywoods Father, Son and Holy Babe) delivered a baby girl. At 9.52 a.m. on Wednesday Abhishek broke the news on Twitter and immediately, the social networking site went into overdrive with other celebrities (Shah Rukh Khan, Karan Johar, Javed Akhtar) congratulating the family and discussing her cute-quotient (director Ram Gopal Varma tweeted I just hope that she has more Aishwarya than Abhishek). Within the hour, Baby B was trending on Twitter. The electronic media, however, was unusually restrained. In early November, the Broadcast Editors Association had circulated an internal memo dictating conduct for coverage of the birth (guidelines included that the story would not be treated as breaking news and no cameras or broadcast vans would be sent to the hospital). Television channels stuck to the code and both Bachchans  Amitabh and Abhishek  thanked the media (on Twitter again) for respecting the familys privacy. Bachchan senior also assured the media that time would be allotted to them, for both print and television, but said that the immediate priority was to get some sleep.

title: Part 6: Answers to Your Questions on Student Loans and Scholarships
description: To help readers of The Choice navigate the maze of scholarships available to them  as well as to further their understanding of President Obamas recent proposal to ease the repayment of some student loans  Mark Kantrowitz, a financial aid expert and founder of the Web sites finaid.org and fastweb.com, is spending this week in our virtual Guidance Office. Mr. Kantrowitz is the author of Secrets to Winning a Scholarship, published in February.

title: The Weekend Word: Pessimism
description: Todays Times

title: Libyan Fighters Catch Qaddafis Last Fugitive Son
description: ZINTAN, Libya  Libyan militia fighters on Saturday captured Seif al-Islam el-Qaddafi, the last fugitive son and onetime heir apparent of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, setting off nationwide celebrations but also exposing a potential power struggle between former-rebel factions over his handling.

title: My Head Wont Stop Talking
description: On This Week tomorrow. Well be talking about how to train your cat.

title: Blooey
description: Two weeks ago I wrote about the Blooey Factor:

title: Christy Romer On Fiscal Policy
description: A speech she gave two weeks ago (pdf). Its a very good summary of what we know and how we know it. A sample:

title: Whether Star or Star-Crossed, Beckham Has Left His Mark on M.L.S.
description: David Beckham has always possessed a flair for the dramatic, so why should it be any different now?

title: Re-evaluating a Gruff, Tough Yankee
description: With 182 victories and 1,423 strikeouts over 13 seasons, the hard-throwing Yankees pitcher Allie Reynolds lacked the shoo-in credentials of 300 wins or 3,000 strikeouts to usher a pitcher into the Baseball Hall of Fame.

title: Buccaneers Freeman Still Facing High Expectations
description: TAMPA, Fla.  As a teenager, Josh Freeman had an impressive DVD collection, and his favorites transcended the action-and-adventure genre: the epic N.F.C. title games between the Cowboys and the 49ers, the Broncos back-to-back Super Bowl victories, the Bills stretch of conference dominance. The outstanding quarterbacks mesmerized him. Troy Aikman and Steve Young, John Elway and Jim Kelly  and, especially, Brett Favre.

title: Giants Not Totally in Tune With Radio Helmet on Defense
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Early last week, Giants safety Kenny Phillips referred to linebacker Michael Boley as the voice of the defense. Phillips was being literal; on the field, Boley calls out the formations and coverages before each snap.

title: Letters to the Editor
Can Gary Chapman Save Your Marriage?
description: I HAD never heard the word gonads mentioned from a church pulpit. But on a picnic-perfect afternoon in August, as more than 1,000 people crowded into the Brentwood Hills Church of Christ outside of Nashville, Gary Chapman, a 73-year-old Southern Baptist pastor and author of the mega-selling phenomenon The Five Love Languages (7.2 million copies and counting), was talking about what he calls Christianitys great sex swindle.

title: A Texas-Size Gap on the Calendar
description: The fight songs are finally accurate.

title: Reads and Reactions
description: In this edition: presidential forecasting models, toast, surges and more.

title: Games to Watch on Saturday
description: NO. 17 NEBRASKA AT NO. 20 MICHIGANNoon, ESPN

title: Live Analysis: College Football Saturday
description: Bill Pennington and Zach Hillesland will be reporting on all of the days action in college football, starting with Nebraska-Michigan at noon ET and followed by Penn State-Ohio State, U.S.C.-Oregon and many others. Check back throughout the day for updates and analysis, to ask questions or to give us your observations, whether from your couch or from the bleachers.

title: U.S. Holds Lead Entering Presidents Cup Singles
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Trailing 13-9 heading into Sundays 12 single matches at Royal Melbourne Golf Club, Ernie Els called on the ghost of an earlier tournament to lift the International team to victory at the Presidents Cup.

title: Final Singles Pairings for the Presidents Cup
description: The International team snapped a stretch of losing eight consecutive sessions in the Presidents Cup by winning three of the five matches in Saturdays afternoon four-ball competition, but the United States still held a 13-9 leading heading into Sundays 12 singles.Note: All times in this table are Eastern Standard Time on Saturday. Live television coverage is on the Golf Channel. The final round will be re-broadcast on NBC on Sunday.

title: Day Returns to Australia With Much to Celebrate
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  As Jason Day dodged raindrops on the first tee at Royal Melbourne on Saturday, the Fanatics, the Australian supporters known for their affection of their countrys sports teams, serenaded one of their own.

title: Tech Visionaries and the Succession Question
description: Founders stay too long, and they chase out the next generation of leaders, says Kevin Rollins, who served three years as chief executive of Dell before he was replaced by the companys founder, Michael S. Dell.

title: Obama and Asian Leaders Confront Chinas Premier
description: ABOARD AIR FORCE ONE  President Obama and nearly all the leaders at an Asian summit directly confronted China on Saturday for its expansive claims to the resource-rich South China Sea, putting the Chinese premier on the defensive in the long-festering dispute, according to Obama administration officials.

title: Incredible Europeans
description: I had some hopes for Mario Draghi; he has just done his best to kill those hopes. In his view, its all about credibility, defined thusly:

title: Violent Protests in Egypt Pit Thousands Against Police
description: CAIRO  A police action to roust a few hundred protesters out of Tahrir Square on Saturday instead drew thousands of people from across Egyptian society into the streets, where they battled riot police officers for hours in the most violent manifestation yet of growing anger at the military-led interim government.

title: Texas and Texas A&M Will Say Farewell
description: On Thursday, the Aggies and the Longhorns will say their goodbyes in the last scheduled game of their storied college football rivalry.

title: Variety: A Filling Acrostic
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  With Thanksgiving coming up here in the United States, most peoples thoughts turn to family gatherings and food. The feast of Thanksgiving, in whatever form pleases you most, is undoubtedly the most daunting meal to put together if you are the one responsible for hosting. If youre lucky, everyone brings a dish that everyone else finds palatable, taking a lot of pressure off the family chef.

title: Second in 08, Romney Mines Iowa for More Votes
description: Mitt Romney finished second in the Iowa caucuses, performing well in some of the states most populated counties and winning 24 of them over all. This time, his strategy has been to replicate his 2008 showing and to win over some of the 35,000 Republicans who supported Fred D. Thompson, John McCain and Rudolph W. Giuliani, as well as a share of Mike Huckabees votes, which will most likely be split several ways.

title: FIFAs Puskas Award: Top Goals of the Year
description: Heather OReilly, a Jersey girl, is the only woman among the nine men in the running for FIFAs Puskas Award, which is given for the goal of the year. The award is named for the famous Hungarian player Ferenc Puskas.

title: Redefining the Union Boss
description: NOT long ago, truckers pulled off highways across America and tuned in to someone whose CB handle was Troublemaker.

title: Afghanistan Has Big Plans for Biometric Data
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Afghanistan has many dubious distinctions on the international-rankings front: 10th-poorest, third-most corrupt, worst place to be a child, longest at war. To that may soon be added: most heavily fingerprinted.

title: Two-Man Race in Finale; Nascar Will Have a New King
description: Tandems and tantrums, secret fines and public posturing have given Nascars Chase for the Sprint Cup playoff its share of drama, culminating on Sunday with two drivers competing for the championship.

title: What Links a Sinking Boat and Rising CO2?
description: In responding to this weeks post on who gets to define dangerous human-driven climate change, Philip S. Wenz of Corvallis, Ore., proposed a maritime analogy for judging and responding to risks from accumulating greenhouse gases. The post merits standalone Your Dot display (a feature reserved for cogent or compelling non-anonymous commentary.)

title: Kris Jenkinss View of Life in the N.F.L. Trenches
description: The Carolina Panthers selected Kris Jenkins in the second round of the N.F.L. 2001 draft. He was on four Pro Bowl teams and named All-Pro three times in seven seasons with them. In 2002 and 2003, he was a dominant player on the Panthers defensive line, helping them reach the Super Bowl for the first time.

title: Want to Lead? Learn to Nurture Your Butterflies
description: This interview with  Kathleen L. Flanagan, president and chief executive of Abt Associates, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant. Abt is a consulting firm specializing in health, social and environmental policy, and international development.

title: Scare Tactics in Greece
description: AS the debt mess in Europe deepens, bankers are pressing Greeces bond holders to swallow big losses.

title: Mobile Deals Set to Lure Shoppers Stuck in Line
description: As retailers battle to draw customers into their stores on Black Friday, online merchants are plotting a cunning ambush  offering an arsenal of mobile-only deals intended to pick off shoppers as they wait in line.

title: Police and Protesters Clash in Tahrir Square
