description: Accounts

title: Corrections: November 21
description: SPORTS

title: Learning to Play the Game to Get Into College
description: BOSTON  There is rarely a minute when Nathaly Lopera, a high school senior, isnt working to improve herself.

title: City Bomb Plot Suspect Is Called Fan of Qaeda Cleric
description: A Manhattan man who became fascinated by the American-born Muslim militant Anwar al-Awlaki was arrested on charges of plotting to build and detonate bombs in New York, city officials announced on Sunday night.

title: Finding Comfort in a Connection
description: LINWOOD, N.J.  It was the night before the last home game of the season and that meant there was a team pasta party to attend, another opportunity for Ted Khoury to work the serving line, check in with the boys, one by one.

title: John G. Smale, Procter & Gamble Chief, Dies at 84
description: John G. Smale, who as chief executive led Procter & Gamble through a period of extraordinary growth, and then helped engineer a turnaround of General Motors as its chairman, died on Saturday at his home in Cincinnati. He was 84.

title: Driven to Get Into College
description: Nathaly Lopera has excelled at Newton North High, a school with enormous resources, in part by figuring out whom to ask for help.

title: Fatal Accident at Yale Bowl Highlights Tailgating Debate
description: NEW HAVEN  For administrators at Yale and Harvard, it is a nightmare to be confronted every other fall: how to best regulate the student tailgate area at the alcohol-fueled, tradition-bound spectacle known reverently as the Game.

title: Sanford Garelik, Former Mayoral Candidate, Dies at 93
description: Sanford D. Garelik, a former New York City mayoral candidate and a City Council president who served the city amid the fiscal and criminal turmoil of the 1970s, died Saturday in Manhattan. He was 93.

title: Eva Monley, Intrepid Scout for Film Locations in Africa, Dies at 88
description: Eva Monley, a Hollywood location manager whose fluency in Swahili made her a linchpin in the creation of scores of movies filmed in Africa between 1950 and the 1990s, including The African Queen and Out of Africa, died on Nov. 12 at her home in Nanyuki, Kenya. She was 88.

title: Photo Replay: Nov. 20
description: A view of the day in sports, including soccer, gymnastics, football and auto racing.

title: Lottery Numbers
California University Puts Officers Who Used Pepper Spray on Leave
description: The University of California, Davis, said Sunday that two police officers had been placed on administrative leave after using pepper spray on seated protesters at the campus on Friday during a demonstration aligned with Occupy Wall Street.

title: Video Is Said to Show Protesting Veteran Beaten by Oakland Police
description: Video said to capture the alleged beating by the police of an Iraq and Afghanistan war veteran who says he was peacefully protesting as part of the Occupy Oakland, Calif., movement on Nov. 2, emerged on Friday, when a witness provided it to The Guardian newspaper.

title: Galaxy Win Title in What May Have Been Beckhams M.L.S. Finale
description: CARSON, Calif.  When David Beckham joined the Los Angeles Galaxy in 2007, he made it clear that he had two overriding objectives. He wanted to help raise the profile of Major League Soccer, and he wanted to bring a championship to the Galaxy.

title: Giants Drop Ball in Comeback Bid
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  A week ago, the Giants shrugged off questions about the second-half struggles of recent years, batting them away like gnats on a humid night. What happened in previous years is irrelevant, they said, from Coach Tom Coughlin on down. This year is different, they said. We are different.

title: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Monday
description: At least 13 people were killed and dozens injured after afire broke out at a community center in northeast Delhi during a meeting of more than 1,000 eunuchs from across the country, reports The Times of India. Attendees said the casualties were a result of poor organization and no exit signs.

title: Word of the Day | spangle
description: spangle \spaN-gl\ noun and verb

description: NYT Front Page for 11/21/2011

title: Giants Replay: Nov. 20
description: Eli Mannings fumble with less than two minutes to go sent the Giants to their second straight loss.

title: Cigna in Deal to Sell Health Insurance in India
description: MUMBAI, India  Cigna, the health insurance company, will enter the fast-growing Indian market in a joint venture with a consumer goods company best known for its pressure cookers and other appliances, executives said.

title: Good Wife Watch: A Season-Turning Moment
description: Stop it.

title: Giants Offensive Line Caves In
description: A capsule look at the Giants 17-10 loss to the Eagles:

title: The Long View: AFSPAs Bitter Roots
description: For several weeks now, Omar Abdullah, the chief minister of Jammu and Kashmir, has been campaigning vigorously to have the Armed Forces Special Powers Act (or AFSPA) withdrawn from his state.

title: Tortures Future
description: As a candidate in 2008, President Obama stated categorically, Well reject torture  without exception or equivocation. During his first month in office, he made good on his pledge, signing an executive order prohibiting torture or inhumane treatment. There is no reason to doubt that the order has been followed. This was a huge step forward for the United States.

title: Egypts Cabinet Offers to Resign as Protests Rage
description: CAIRO  The cabinet offered its resignation on Monday to Egypts transitional military rulers as security forces carried out an increasingly lethal crackdown on three days of violent street protests, reviving the uncertainty about Egypts future that marked the earliest days of the Arab Spring.

title: News Quiz | Nov. 21, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: In First Class, a World Apart
description: The gap between first class and coach has never been so wide, as airlines compete for the lucrative business and first-class traveler on long-haul international flights.

title: Nov. 21, 1964 | Verrazano-Narrows Bridge Opens
description: On Nov. 21, 1964, the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge was opened, connecting Staten Island and Brooklyn. It surpassed San Franciscos Golden Gate Bridge as the worlds largest suspension bridge, with a 4,260-foot-center span between two 693-foot towers. The bridge is so large that its design called for the towers to be angled slightly away from each other to compensate for the curvature of the Earth.A large ceremony was held for the opening of the upper deck of the two-deck bridge, attracting dignitaries like Mayor Robert Wagner, Gov. Nelson Rockefeller and Robert Moses, known as the master builder of mid-20th century New York City. The ironworkers who built the bridge, however, boycotted the ceremony when Moses did not invite them to participate.

title: Dissident Leader Expected to Run for Myanmar Parliament
description: HONG KONG  Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the leader of Myanmars main opposition movement, is likely to run for Parliament in a coming election, senior members of her party said on Monday. It would be the first time Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi, the Nobel laureate who is the face of democracy in Myanmar, has run for office.

title: When the Walls Come Down
description: JOHANNESBURG  I am sitting in front of the entrance to my new two-story flat in upmarket Sandton in northern Johannesburg, admiring the colorful bed of flowers planted at my doorstep. Two women in their sixties walk around the block several times, and each time they pass I notice their increasingly sweaty brows, evidence of an impressive effort to stay fit. They look like they might be training for a race, complete with sport shoes and sweat bands on their wrists.

title: Test Yourself | Math, Nov. 21, 2011
description: Test your math skills with this question created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the infographic (Less) Popular Science.

title: Credit Risks in Europe Push Stocks Downward
description: Stock prices and bond yields declined on Wall Street on Monday, as credit risks in Europe overpowered any market concerns over the failure in Washington to reach a deficit reduction package.

title: Throwing, Passing and Signing
description: HOW many University of Oregon football players are currently enrolled in an American Sign Language course?

title: The Early Word: Failure
description: Todays Times

title: Carnegie Hall Benefit Honors the Rolling Stones
description: The annual concert at Carnegie Hall to benefit music education programs for the poor will have a Rolling Stones theme this spring, the events organizer, Michael Dorf, announced. Rosanne Cash, Steve Earle, the Carolina Chocolate Drops and others have signed on to perform all 21 tracks from the Rolling Stones classic collection Hot Rocks 1964-1971, on the 40th anniversary of its release. The concert will take place March 13 and the proceeds will go to support nonprofit organizations that provide music classes to impoverished youths, among them the Church Street School of Music, Young Audiences, Music Unites and the Pinwheel Project. Mr. Dorf, who owns the City Winery, has raised about $600,000 for charity with similar concerts over the last seven years, asking contemporary musicians to pay tribute to the music of older artists. Past shows have focused on the songs of Joni Mitchell, Bob Dylan, Bruce Springsteen and the Who, among others. This year, at least 21 solo artists and groups will be on the bill to interpret songs by the Stones, including the Mountain Goats, Rich Robinson of the Black Crowes and Glen Hansard.

title: Christmas Cribs Celebrated at Rome Exhibition
description: Few holiday traditions are more Italian than making presepi  the cribs that sit in Christmas nativity scenes. Its said that, all the way back in 1223, St. Francis of Assisi himself created the worlds first nativity scene. Now, nearly 800 years later, many worry that the craft of creating and displaying handmade presepi is languishing.

title: Which Is More Important: Talent or Hard Work?
description: Weve all heard that hard work is the key to success. But a recent study found that the profoundly gifted still have an edge over peers who have less natural talent but are perhaps more dedicated to improving their skills. Have you experienced the power of talent over hard work? Or have you found that success comes to the person willing to put in the most time and effort to achieve it?

title: Week 11 Quick Hits: Romo as Mr. November
description: A quick tour of Sundays Week 11 games:

title: Young Keeps His Composure and Keeps Eagles Season Alive
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

title: Lloyds Names Interim C.E.O., if Needed
description: LONDON  The Lloyds Banking Group said on Monday that it was preparing for an extended absence of its chief executive, Antnio Horta-Osrio, who left more than three weeks ago to recover from stress and exhaustion.

title: Bad Manners by DeSean Jackson, but Still a Blown Call
description: The DeSean Jackson taunting penalty against the Giants was an interesting blown call Sunday night (and one that the superb NBC crew uncharacteristically failed to notice). Jackson absolutely deserved a 15-yard flag for taunting.

title: Complaint Box | Beware the Squirrelstein
description: While I was growing up in suburban Connecticut, squirrels kept their distance. If you stepped within 10 feet of them, they scurried away. This is certainly not the case in New York City, where squirrels really know how to hustle.

title: This Week in Small Business: Everything Is Super!
description: Whats affecting my clients, my small business and other small-business owners this week.

title: Breakfast Meeting, Nov. 21
description: Breaking Dawn  Part I, the fourth film in The Twilight Saga franchise, was No. 1 at North American theaters, taking in about $140 million, the fifth-highest total for an opening weekend, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office data.

title: Fired Olympus C.E.O. to Press Board on Fees
description: TOKYO  Michael C. Woodford, the ousted chief executive of scandal-racked Olympus, said Monday that he planned to return to Japan to meet with companys board on Friday to press directors to disclose more information about exorbitant merger fees that he and investigators have called into question.

title: Alleghany to Buy Transatlantic for $3.4 Billion
description: 7:07 a.m. | Updated

title: New Delhi, Now More Polluted Than Beijing
description: India has recently pulled far ahead of China on one dubious development marker  air pollution in the countrys capital.

title: United States and Its Allies Expand Sanctions on Iran
description: WASHINGTON  Major Western powers took significant steps on Monday to cut Iran off from the international financial system, announcing coordinated sanctions aimed at its central bank and commercial banks. The measures, a response to a recent United Nations report warning about Irans nuclear activities, tighten the vise on Iran but still fall short of a blanket cutoff.

title: Can Mediocre A.F.C. Save the Jets?
description: The Jets, at 5-5, are a mediocre team. Butat least they have a lot of company.

title: Testimony in British Hacking Inquiry Takes Debate Beyond Murdochs Empire
description: LONDON  The actor Hugh Grant said Monday that British tabloid newspapers had broken into his home, accessed medical records and menaced his family as part of a cowardly, bullying and shocking press culture whose targets were not just celebrities, politicians and the police, but also people left vulnerable by misfortune.

title: Prosecutors Describe Khmer Rouge Leaders Organized and Systematic Atrocities
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia  Opening statements in the most significant stage of a United Nations-backed trial of Khmer Rouge leaders began here on Monday with a horrifying and detailed account of the atrocities of a regime that a prosecutor said was responsible for the deaths of one-fourth of the population during its four-year rule from 1975 to 1979.

title: Visa and Shopkick Give Rewards for Making Purchases
description: In time for Black Friday, Visa and Shopkick, which makes a mobile app that rewards people for walking into stores, are offering rewards for making purchases.

title: Gilead to Buy Pharmasset for $11 Billion
description: 9:44 p.m. | Updated

title: Monday Reading: How to Become a Morning Person
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Opinion Report: Fixing Medicare
description: From the editorial page

title: At Rikers, a Waiting List for Solitary Confinement
description: For more local news, including reports about a man being arrested on charges of plotting to build and detonate bombs in New York, a blocked attempt by Occupy Wall Street protesters to stage a drum circle by Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs residence, and a fatal accident at the Harvard-Yale game that has put a spotlight on tailgating regulations, see the N.Y./Region section.

title: Tom Coughlin Transcript After Loss to Eagles
description: As Sam Borden noted, Giants Coach Tom Coughlin ripped into his team during his postgame address after the loss to the Eagles. The Giants offensive line was pushed around, and that didnt sit well with Coughlin. The offenses troubles also led to this Yogi Berra-like pronouncement: It was what they were doing; it wasnt what we were doing because we didnt do anything.

title: Sex Ed, With an Emphasis on the Sex
Morning Take-Out
description: Theodore Forstmann, Private Equity Pioneer, Is Dead at 71 | Theodore J. Forstmann, a colorful financier and philanthropist who helped pioneer leveraged buyouts, died on Sunday. He was 71.

title: Styled to a T | Miranda Kerr
description: The Trend

title: Strangers on the Web, Exchanging Presents
description: This item could make you feel a lot better about being stalked.

title: Fairy Tales
description: One repeated gripe Ive had about news coverage in the Lesser Depression is the way deficit-hawk myths about markets are often reported as facts. Again and again, slight upticks in interest rates have been attributed  in news stories, not opinion pieces  to debt fears, despite the complete absence of any actual evidence to that effect.

title: Shop, Look, Listen
description: Danielle Kosann may have gone into the family business (her mother is the jeweler Monica Rich Kosann), but this 25-year-olds forte is tech style. With her new e-commerce site, shoplooks.com, visitors get to browse through their favorite look books  from Madewell to Carven  without ever having to switch tabs. Call it stream-of-consciousness shopping. Its the kind of thing that sparks imagination, Kosann says. Straight from the source, heres what well want this holiday season.

title: What Were Reading
description: Slice: The pizza maven Adam Kuban goes head to head with his wife over the virtues and faults of Di Faras in Midwood, Brooklyn. She doesnt like it, and makes a pretty strong case. (The joint is so smoky, she writes, that its like eating in a coal mine.)   Nick Fox

title: G.E. Wants Software for the Industrial Internet
description: Mention General Electric and what comes to mind is heavy-duty industrial equipment like power-plant turbines and jet engines, not software.

title: Can Jose Bautista Sneak Away With the M.V.P.?
description: The American League Most Valuable Player award will be announced at 2 p.m. Monday, and I really have no clear sense of who will win. Usually, from talking to fellow writers (including many voters) and getting the general feeling around the league, you can tell where momentum is leaning. Not this time.

title: Spacing Children Farther Apart Benefits Older Siblings
description: How far apart should you space your children?

title: Tebow Wins Praise, but His Wild Passes Pose a Problem
description: Now, the latest incarnation of the Tim Tebow phenomenon: Tebow as N.F.L. measuring stick.

title: Monday Motorsports: Tony Stewart Outlasts Carl Edwards to Win Third Nascar Sprint Cup
description: During the 10-race Sprint Cup chase, Carl Edwards averaged a finishing place of 4.9, better than any produced by Jimmie Johnson during his five-year championship reign from 2006 to 2010. Yet on Sunday at Homestead-Miami Speedway, averages were no substitute for victory.

title: For Kitchens That Make the Grade, or Dont
description: Now you can rate Moms kitchen at Thanksgiving, by giving her an A. Or the edgier choice: Grade Pending.

title: Street Style: Tribal Prints
description: The best of readers street style for the week of Nov. 14.

title: Putin Is Booed at Sporting Event
description: Accustomed to displays of fealty and fawning coverage by the news media, Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin of Russia appeared fazed when he was met by a chorus of boos after he began addressing the crowd at a martial arts match over the weekend. The Associated Press reported that one person could be heard shouting Leave!

title: Project Suggestions for the Google X Lab
description: Last week Claire Cain Miller and I wrote about Google X, a top-secret lab where Google is imagining, and building, the future.

title: Do Small-Business Owners Feel Overtaxed and Overregulated? A Survey Says No
description: Among many small-business advocates, it has become an article of faith that uncertainty about new regulations and higher taxes is frustrating the ambitions of small-business owners.

title: Armchair Ethicist, Flu Season Edition
description: Between 1 and 5 p.m. E.S.T. today, November 21, you can discuss the following letter with the Ethicist, Ariel Kaminer.

title: For the Giants and the Bears, Cloudy Days Are Here Again
description: In the N.F.L., fortunes can change in a minute. One minute, youre the Giants team that just beat the Patriots and are leading your division and boasting the only Manning healthy enough to play quarterback, and the next minute youve hacked up two straight games, including one to an Eagles team given up for toast. And one minute, youre the resurgent Bears, puffing out your chests and telling everyone about the magic of Jay Cutler, and the next youre staring down a future field-generaled by Caleb Hanie. Yikes!

title: Springsteen and E Street Band Plan First Tour Since 2009
description: Bruce Springsteen and the E Street Band, who have not toured since 2009, will be going out on the road beginning in mid-2012 on what Mr. Springsteens Web site describes as a global tour, with some dates in Europe already announced and performances in North America and other locations confirmed. The shows will be the first for the band since Clarence Clemons, the saxophonist who for decades served as Mr. Springsteens onstage foil, died of complications of a stroke in June.

title: Have N.F.L. Questions? Judy Battista Has Answers
description: How many games can the Bears win without Jay Cutler? How good is Carson Palmer this season? And how important is the Giants-Saints game? Judy Battista, the N.F.L. reporter for The Times, will again answer selected questions from readers this week. Use the comment field below to ask your questions, and the answers will appear on The Fifth Down on Wednesday.

title: Opposition Meeting With British Highlights Syrias Isolation
description: ISTANBUL  Syrias political opposition widened its outreach on Monday, sending representatives to Britain as the Syrian government withstood signs of further isolation over an uprising that is increasingly resembling a prolonged armed struggle to oust President Bashar al-Assad.

title: MF Global Trustee Says Shortfall Could Exceed $1.2 Billion
description: The amount of customer money missing from the collapsed trading firm MF Global may be more than $1.2 billion  double previous estimates  the trustee dismantling the firms brokerage unit said on Monday.

title: Look of The Moment | Emma Watson
description: The Look: Cropped. A crystal-embellished top and a high-waisted skirt come together neatly with a skinny bow belt.

title: Monday Matchup: Chiefs at Patriots
description: Chiefs (4-5) at Patriots (6-3), 8:30 p.m. Eastern, ESPN Line: Patriots by 15 1/2

title: Turkey Tips: Unwrapping the Turkey
description: Melissa Clark provides tips on taking the turkey out of the bag and getting it ready to season and cook.

title: Excerpt: 'Blood and Gifts'
description: A scene from J. T. Rogers's new play about the Soviet-Afghan war of the 1980s. (Video courtesy of Lincoln Center Theater.)

title: How Do I Get Started With My Turkey?
description: Q.

title: Really? The Claim: Chewing Gum Can Prevent Ear Infections
description: THE FACTS

title: Broadway revivals of Godspell and Jesus Christ Superstar
description: Broadway revivals of Godspell and Jesus Christ Superstar

title: China Bends to U.S. Complaint on Solar Panels but Plans Retaliation
description: HONG KONG  Chinese solar panel makers plan to shift some of their production to South Korea, Taiwan and the United States in hopes of defusing a trade case pending against them in Washington, according to industry executives.

title: Do Pies Need to Be Defrosted Before They Are Baked?
description: Q.

title: Women Rule at American Music Awards
description: Young female vocalists dominated the American Music Awards on Sunday night, with Taylor Swift and Adele each winning in three different categories and Rihanna, Beyonc and Nicki Minaj also picking up trophies.

title: Unearthing the Surprises Within a Child's Mind
Protesters Arrested at Bank-Account Closing  Sue City
description: Updated, 4:44 p.m. | On the afternoon of Oct. 15, Heather Carpenter walked into a Citibank branch in Greenwich Village and closed her account as a form of protest against bank fees.

title: About Op-Docs
description: Op-Docs is The New York Times editorial departments award-winning section for short, opinionated documentaries, produced with wide creative latitude and a range of artistic styles, covering current affairs, contemporary life and historical subjects.

title: Waiting for Failure
description: As I read the background story on the collapse of the super committee talks in the Times today, I felt depressed. Its not like I wasnt prepared for this: The committees membership and rules seemed certain to produce a stalemate.

title: Republicans and Obama Can Agree on Criticizing Chinas Trade Practices
description: WASHINGTON  Chinas swift economic rise, and a presidential election dominated by fears of a declining American economy, have produced a rare convergence: Republican contenders talking tough about China, and a president who is already getting tough on it.

title: On a Dispiriting Night for the Giants, Herzlich Is a Highlight
description: Mathias Kiwanuka was mostly glum as he discussed the Giants Sunday night loss to the Philadelphia Eagles. His expression, particularly as he answered questions about how the team appeared to be pushed around by the Eagles, remained dour and downcast.

title: Bahrains Forgotten Revolt
description: The Bahrain government managed a tactical victory over the revolt but may have destroyed a society that took pride in its cosmopolitanism.

title: Jefferies Continues Its Defense
description: The Jefferies Group cant seem to shake its critics.

title: Is It O.K. for Doctors to Turn Away Unvaccinated Children?
description: Ariel Kaminer, the Ethicist for The Times Magazine, will respond to readers comments on the 6th Floor blog from 1 to 5 p.m. today on the subject of whether its ethical for pediatricians to refuse routine care to families who do not immunize their children. Will she address whether parents who dont vaccinate their kids would even want that care? Or if allowing pediatricians to turn away certain patients would effectively limit the antivaccine choice to parents who can afford to pick and choose among providers? Will the whole thing devolve into yet another online debate on vaccination, and how society should handle the families  like 77 percent of kindergarten parents at a Waldorf school written about recently in The Times  who (without medical necessity) skip the shots?

title: Bahrain Is Nervously Awaiting Report on Its Forgotten Revolt
description: MANAMA, Bahrain  Bahrains forgotten revolt sometimes reads like the script for a film of international intrigue, where the truth remains elusive.

title: A Step Forward for RNA Interference
description: The once hot and then cold field of RNA interference might not be dead yet.

title: Beauty Spots
description: Its holiday gift-set time. If youre looking for a collection of luxurious makeup to brighten up the season, here are three standouts:

title: Customer Service, Ranked Either Naughty or Nice
description: For a second year, Consumer Reports has compiled a holiday report card of customer service policies that it deems either naughty or nice.

title: In Dance, Borrowing Is a Tradition
description: The Nutcracker season is almost upon us  but can you be sure who choreographed all of the versions you might see? Last year, as I toured the United States in a Nutcracker marathon, I observed how more than 12 American productions featured the Sugar Plum pas de deux that Lev Ivanov choreographed for the 1892 original in St. Petersburg. But in only one case was the pas de deux  whose adagio, early on, features a beautifully spectacular phrase unlike anything else in 19th-century ballet, with the ballerina seeming to peel herself open in her partners arms  actually credited to Ivanov.

title: Californias Campus Movements Dig In Their Heels
description: LOS ANGELES  It has become something of an annual tradition on California college campuses, in what is perhaps the most prestigious state university system in the country: the state makes large cuts in public universities, they in turn raise tuition, and students respond with angry protests.

title: Ravenous | The Stuffing Theory
description: He who controls the stuffing, controls the universe! In a recent Thanksgiving-themed episode of South Park, these portentous words came from the mouth of Myles Standish, the military leader of the Plymouth Colony. If you missed the episode, the Pilgrims and Indians were both from outer space, and had a long-held but recently broken truce over their respective rights to the stuffing caves  and mayhem and hilarity ensues.

title: Talking Comedy With John Landis
description: For many American moviegoers in the 1980s, John Landis was a household name. He sealed a place in the pop-culture canon by directing a series of blockbusters that often starred some of the countrys biggest comedians.

title: Retailers Enliven Catalog Offerings Through Apps
description: Many retailers, as varied as Saks Fifth Avenue and Wal-Mart, are putting out new iPad apps in time for the holiday season, reports Claire Cain Miller of The New York Times. She says these apps do away with scrolling through pages of items online and make shopping more entertaining. About 60 percent of tablet owners use them to shop and many, especially young people, say they prefer shopping on tablets to smartphones and even computers.

title: The Shifting Balance Between Raising Taxes and Cutting Spending
description: The percentages from tax increases versus spending cuts in past deficit reduction deals

title: A Gingrich Alternative to Social Security
description: Contending that Social Security provides a dismal return to retirees on a lifetime of burdensome tax payments, Newt Gingrich proposed giving younger workers the option of a private savings account.

title: Videos Capture Violent Scenes in Egypt
description: Protesters clashed with police for a third straight day in the streets around Cairos Tahrir Square on Monday, as my colleagues David D. Kirkpatrick and Liam Stack report.

title: How a Foul Worked in the Giants Favor
description: When is a penalty a good thing? The Giants found an odd way to make a foul work in their favor Sunday night against the Philadelphia Eagles.

title: Patterns: Heart Study Suggests Place Matters
description: In the so-called stroke belt in the Southeast, cardiovascular disease rates are much higher than in the rest of the country. Scientists generally believe that is because people in the region have higher rates of such risk factors as smoking, obesity and diabetes.

title: Many Layers of Meaning in Royal Trip to Ramallah
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  King Abdullah II of Jordan visited the West Bank for the first time in a decade on Monday and conferred with President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority as both men begin risky reconciliation efforts with the Islamists of Hamas.

title: Egypt Clashes Enter Third Day
description: Egypts military leaders struggled to contain protests as demonstrators clashed with forces in Cairo.

title: Happy Hour at the Thanksgiving Table
description: If you are among the skeptics who think vegan cooking is boring, maybe youre just not adding enough alcohol.

title: 25 Recordings Chosen for Grammy Hall of Fame
description: The National Academy of Recording Arts & Sciences, which oversees the Grammy awards, is adding another 25 recordings to its Grammy Hall of Fame, which honors works at least 25 years old that exhibit qualitative or historical significance. The works to be inducted in 2012 are an unusually diverse lot, ranging from Cole Porters Anything Goes, a single from 1934, and the Rolling Stones Exile on Main Street, an album from 1972, to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jrs historic I Have a Dream speech, taken from a spoken-word album issued in 1963, and the influential Anthology of American Folk Music, from 1952.

title: Update: Pumpkin Horror of Kane Street Worsens
description: The pumpkins of Kane Street in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, continue on their disgusting trek toward their certain demise. As reported by Corey Kilgannon of The Times, an array of 100 carved pumpkins created by Jane Greengold  of Cobble Hill will attempt to cling to their stations for several more weeks.

title: Informers Role in Terror Case Is Said to Have Deterred F.B.I.
description: The suspect had little money to speak of, was unable to pay his cellphone bill and scrounged for money to buy the drill bits that court papers said he required to make his pipe bombs. Initially, he had trouble drilling the small holes that needed to be made in the metal tubes.

title: Romney Blames Obama for the Collapsing Deficit Talks
description: 2:36 p.m. | Updated NASHUA, N.H.  Mitt Romney sought to blame President Obama for the collapsing talks on deficit reduction, intensifying criticism on Monday that he had been delivering over the weekend in New Hampshire.

title: Daily Report: Google Keeps Pushing at Microsofts Windows
description: It has been more than 4 1/2 years since Google began its cloud computing challenge to Microsofts lucrative Office division, maker of Microsoft Word and PowerPoint. It has had some wins, reports Quentin Hardy in an article on Google Apps in Mondays New York Times. But the question remains how much of a dent Google is making in Microsofts business.

title: Photo Replay: Nov. 21
description: The day in sports worldwide, from college basketball in Hawaii to a soccer final in Indonesia, where two people died as a wave of fans entered the stadium.

title: At Mercedes-Benz Stand, AMG Muscles In on the Spotlight
description: LOS ANGELES  There is plenty of eye candy at the Mercedes-Benz stand during the 2011 Los Angeles auto show, which opened to the public on Nov. 18. But the real treats are to be found mostly under various hoods.

title: TimesCast | November 21, 2011
description: Violent clashes continue in Cairo and spread to other cities; Congressional leaders concede that a sweeping deficit agreement is near failure; and Khmer Rouge leaders go on trial.

title: Breakfast Comrade to Write Memoir of Lucian Freud
description: The painter Lucian Freud, who died in July at the age of 88, spent many of his Saturday mornings with an intimate group of friends at Clarkes restaurant in London, only steps from his home. Those Saturdays will be recalled in Breakfast With Lucian, a memoir by Geordie Greig, the editor of The London Evening Standard, his publisher said on Monday.

title: Facebook Chat With Andrew Rosenthal
description: On Tuesday at 1 p.m. EST, Im hosting an hour-long Facebook conversation about domestic politics and the presidential campaign. The chat will take place on the New York Timess Facebook page: facebook.com/nytimes.

title: #OccupyWallSt Roundup, Day 66
description: The police chief at the University of California, Davis, and two police officers were placed on leave after pepper-spraying sitting protesters like a gardener using pesticide, as Gawker put it. [New York Times, Gawker]

title: For a Bills Fan, All Hope Is Lost
description: Three weeks ago, my four-year-old son, Leo, wore a brand-new Bills hat his grandfather in Buffalo sent him to his Virginia preschool. It was a gift purchased in celebration of the teams glorious 5-2 start that had all of Western New York in the kind of delirious fog of Bills fever that hasnt gripped the region since the glory days of the 1990s.

title: Polls Highlight Risks to G.O.P. in Breakdown of Budget Talks
description: The likely failure of the special Congressional deficit committee to reach an agreement will come as no surprise to most Americans, with recent polls showing broad majorities lacking confidence in the committees ability to reach a deal.

title: Disparities: In the E.R., the Elderly Get Less Pain Relief
description: Older people who go to an emergency room in pain are less likely to get medication for it than younger people with similar levels of distress, a new analysis has found.

title: Court-Appointed Investigator Offers Scathing Report on Prosecution of Senator Stevens
description: WASHINGTON  A court-appointed investigator has found that the high-profile prosecution of the late Senator Ted Stevens was permeated by the prosecutors serious, widespread and at times intentional illegal concealment of evidence that would have helped Mr. Stevens defend himself at his 2008 trial, a federal judge disclosed on Monday.

title: Prognosis: Strokes Risk Factors Warn of Mental Harm
description: The risk factors that predict stroke also predict mental impairment, a new study has found, even in people who have never had a stroke.

title: Thought Of The Day
description: From David Rosenbergs Breakfast with Dave (no link):

title: Cancer or Weird Cells: Which Sounds Deadlier?
description: My friends mother got terrifying news after she had a mammogram. She had Stage 0 breast cancer. Cancer. That dreadful word. Of course she had to have surgery to get it out of her breast, followed by hormonal therapy.

title: Romney to Show First TV Ad of Campaign
description: Mitt Romney is set to show his first television ad of the presidential campaign on Tuesday in New Hampshire, spending $134,000 for spots scheduled to run until Sunday. The ads will attack President Obama over his economic leadership and begin on the day the president will visit the state to discuss his plans for turning around the economy.

title: Occupy Ec10
description: I have nothing useful to say about the walkout on Greg Mankiw. Robin Wells does, however, have some judicious thoughts. And yes, thats her speaking for herself.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Q: (Reader)

title: Greenberg Sues U.S. Over A.I.G. Takeover
description: Maurice R. Greenberg, the former chief executive of the American International Group, sued the United States Treasury and the Federal Reserve Bank of New York on Monday, contending that their takeover of the insurer in the fall of 2008 was improper and that the Fed breached its duty to A.I.G. shareholders when it unwound the companys disastrous bets on mortgage securities.

title: Ex-Saturn Plant to Reopen, And G.M. to Add 700 Jobs
description: DETROIT  General Motors on Monday said it planned to bring nearly 700 jobs back to its idled assembly plant in Spring Hill, Tenn., next year for work on any of the companys cars whenever extra production is needed.

title: 5 Reasons Selling Your Business Is Like Thanksgiving Dinner
description: I had a professor in graduate school who once compared the world of business to Thanksgiving dinner. His comment was directed at a room full of students who, at the time, were intent on climbing the corporate ladder. According to him, those of us who were willing to work hard and get advanced degrees would have the ability to leave the chaos and humiliation of the little kids table (supervisory and front line management positions) and graduate to sitting with the grown-ups (director level and above). And wasnt that what we all aspired to?

title: Festive Mood Accompanies Crosbys Return to Penguins
description: PITTSBURGH  Its a great day for hockey, as they say in this city, and Monday has been just that. Sidney Crosby will play tonight after a 320-day absence, forced by the most closely chronicled concussion in the sport.

title: Which Sides Can Be Adapted for a Slow Cooker?
description: Q.

title: The Get | Thakoon Boot
description: The printed shoe is all the rage right now. (If you can imagine, heel height is almost beside the point.) From Thakoon, this graphic paisley on a moto-cowboy boot is a clever extension of the designers fall collection, which was full of energetic prints that were inspired by royal courts and the Masai tribes colorful dress code; consider this the perfect take-away. And if the print is a little loud for you, it comes in deep navy velvet, too. We know, tough call.

title: Jaguar Continues to Push Limits of Performance and Price
description: LOS ANGELES  In the hierarchy of luxury brands once owned by the Ford Motor Company, Jaguar operated under a glass ceiling.

title: Verlander Named A.L. Most Valuable Player
description: Detroit pitcher Justin Verlander was named the American League most valuable player Monday, becoming the 10th pitcher to win the award and the first since 1992.

title: Looking For Insight In All The Wrong Places
description: One ongoing source of puzzlement for me  something Ive written about before  is the continuing popularity of inflationista/deficit hawk views among many investors, on and off Wall Street, despite the fact that this world view has been disastrously wrong again and again for the past few years.

title: Trailer: North of South, West of East
description: A look at North of South, West of East, a new film by Meredith Danluck.

title: President Obama Signs Veterans Tax Credit Bill
description: If anyone doubted that veterans remain potent political symbols, they need look no further than Congresss ability to set aside partisan gridlock last week and overwhelmingly enact legislation providing tax credits to businesses that hire veterans. Flanked by veterans advocates, President Obama signed the bill into law this morning.

title: Rihannas Talk That Talk Synth-Perfect for an Earlier Time
description: Distinctionlessness has become something of a calling card and a weapon for Rihanna, the most consistent pop star of the last five years. Last month she became the fastest solo artist in history to have had 20 Top 10 singles on the Billboard Hot 100, slower only than the Beatles. And she has pumped out these hits with little regard for style or mood  breezy dance tracks rub up against poignant, gothically ruptured rock-soul ballads. Her voice is, for the most part, certifiably blank, which is to say it belongs everywhere.

title: Juilliard and Signature Theater Team Up for New Program for Drama Students
description: Beginning next fall the Juilliard School and the Signature Theater company will collaborate on a new program for Juilliards drama students, to be based at the new rehearsal and performance space being built for Signature on West 42nd Street. The partnership coincides with the creation of a new masters degree in theater that Juilliard will offer as of next year and is meant to give drama students there a transition to a working actors career through readings and workshops in a professional setting.

title: In Bodys Shield Against Cancer, a Culprit in Aging May Lurk
description: Until recently, few people gave much thought to senescent cells. They are cells that linger in the body even after they have lost the ability to divide.

title: Kicking Cans, Budget Woes and Other Risks Down the Road
description: 11:26 p.m. | Updated below |The failure of Congress to take meaningful steps on debt and taxes, yet again, is reminiscent of societys treatment of other looming risks.

title: Giving Shad a 30-Year Chance
description: State and federal wildlife officials have a rare opportunity to stem the decline of American shad on the Susquehanna River, a Chesapeake Bay tributary crucial to annual spawning runs.

title: Jay Bernstein
description: The philosopher Jay Bernstein on the social subject and dependency.

title: Ferrer Surprises Murray
description: No. 5 seed David Ferrer provided the first real surprise of the 2011 ATP World Tour Finals, dismissing third-seeded native son Andy Murray 6-4, 7-5 and throwing what had looked like a straightforward round-robin group into considerable upheaval.

title: An Interview With J.M. Bernstein
description: This video is part of a weekly series of interviews with contemporary thinkers and philosophers on questions that matter.

title: A Struggle for Financing After a Promising Discovery
description: The discovery that aging can be delayed in mice is just the kind of experiment one might suppose would be supported by the National Institutes of Health, the government agency that spends $30 billion a year on financing biomedical research.

title: Panel Fails to Reach Deal on Plan for Deficit Reduction
description: WASHINGTON  Leaders of the Congressional committee charged with finding at least $1.2 trillion in deficit reductions conceded on Monday that panel members had failed, setting up what is likely to be a yearlong political fight over the automatic cuts to a broad range of military and domestic programs that would go into effect starting in 2013 as a result of their inability to reach a deal.

title: How Do VapoRub Ads Spell Relief? D-A-D
description: After finding success with a campaign that declared, Thank you, Mom, a leading marketer is turning its attention to Dad.

title: Foreclosure Firm Steven J. Baum to Close Down
description: A law firm that had become a lightning rod in the controversy over mortgage-foreclosure practices has shut down, costing 89 employees their jobs.

title: Stringer Tries to Give Transportation Projects a Push
description: Scott M. Stringer has seen the future, and it is creaky, over budget, and behind schedule.

title: Turmoil in Egypt
description: No one knows what the revolution in the Arab worlds largest and once most important country will bring  a state dominated by Islamists, perhaps, or a country mired in misery, disappointment or simmering unrest.

title: Drawing Dance: The Cunningham Company in South Bend
description: The Brooklyn artist Kenneth E. Parris III is on tour with members of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, documenting, through a series of drawings and paintings, their two-year legacy tour. After 58 years the company is scheduled to disband on New Years Day 2012. This is the 20th in a series of graphite drawings that Mr. Parris plans to create from the road, providing a front-row seat to the final weeks of the companys journey. This weeks entry is from South Bend, Ind.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
description: Allen & Gerritsen, Watertown, Mass., hired three employees for new posts. They are Andrew Mastrangelo, director for corporate communications; Marcy Rose, quality assurance manager; and Elizabeth Sklar, emerging technology and digital strategist.

description: As a journalist whos covered American politics for the last 24 years, and who covered the Soviet Union as a foreign correspondent before that, Ive learned to appreciate the dark art of political propaganda.

title: A Rare Isotope Helps Track an Ancient Water Source
description: The Nubian Aquifer, the font of fabled oases in Egypt and Libya, stretches languidly across 770,000 square miles of northern Africa, a pointillist collection of underground pools of water migrating, ever so slowly, through rock and sand toward the Mediterranean Sea.

title: A Hard Turn: Better Health on the Highway
description: After driving hundreds of miles, the last thing Roy Williams, a truck driver from Denton, Tex., wanted to do was exercise. After a day trapped in the cab, stopping only to gorge on greasy fare at truck stops, who could think of working out?

title: True Romance
description: She was a designer learning the ropes at Levis and Ralph Lauren. He was a photographer and drummer playing the Brooklyn music scene. They met after a concert, fell in love and started making clothes. Les Aperizes is Laurence Nguyen and Brian Tamborellos debut spring collection. And like their story, the couples style is wildly romantic: preciously made petal-collar silk dresses, blouses detailed with hand-embroidered French knots and fluidly tailored trousers (all priced between $240 and $1,350). Before ever sketching, we like to talk about a woman as if were writing a character and imagine what she wears throughout different times in her life, says Nguyen, who sees herself as the lines dreamer and Tamborello as its down-to-earth craftsman. Regarding the latter, the cut is slouchy sexy and thoughtfully undone. Tamborello says: We ask ourselves, Can we picture our clothes on every character? Will they age beautifully with her?  Stores like Barneys New York and Ikram in Chicago sure think so.

title: TimesCast | Violence in Egypt Continues
description: Violent clashes continue for a third day in Tahrir Square, as protesters demand the ouster of the military government.

In its place, the Public will be reviving Gatz, the popular Elevator Repair Service theatrical adaptation of F. Scott Fitzgeralds The Great Gatsby, for seven weeks between March and May.

Then there are the tight limits on the importing and screening of foreign movies, which cast a shadow on attempts to bring new film experiences to China.

Three retro Warby Parker shapes  wayfarers, oversize aviators and Lennon-round frames  were custom-made with three Suno-designed prints: a pixelated geometric design, roses on a grungy brown background and an abstract stained-glass print.

title: Suspect Held in White House Shooting Appears in Court

description: Companies including Motorola Mobility, Lego, Deutsche Bank and Bloomberg L.P. signed up to use a new trademark, WindMade , to show that at least 25 percent of their electricity was generated by wind power. The brand is sponsored by Vestas, a wind turbine manufacturer. The company hopes to develop a widely recognized industry trademark akin to the Fair Trade and Organic labels.

description: In todays Personal Health column, Jane Brody comes to terms with her inner hoarder, taking steps to clean up and clear out her three-story home filled with stuff. She writes:

title: Dwight Garners Picks for 2011
description: ALFRED KAZINS JOURNALS by Alfred Kazin. The great American literary critic Alfred Kazins passions  for sex, for novels, for ideas, for talk, for city life  spill from these journals, edited by his biographer, Richard M. Cook. This is one of the great diaries and moral documents of the past American century. What it lacks in cohesiveness it makes up in its frankness, its quick-pivoting angularities. Kazin dismisses his journals at one point as a disorderly pile of shavings. That disorder only adds to their amplitude. (Yale University Press, $45)

title: Michiko Kakutanis Picks for 2011
description: MOONWALKING WITH EINSTEIN: THE ART AND SCIENCE OF REMEMBERING EVERYTHING by Joshua Foer. A smart, funny meditation on the mysteries of memory featuring the author, in a Plimpton-esque turn, undergoing a year of memory training and competing against the countrys best mental athletes in the U.S.A. Memory Championships. (The Penguin Press, $26.95)

It was a bizarre instrument, one he had never seen before in his years as a hip-hop producer, but he was going to play it that night in concert.

title: Perry Signs an Evangelical Pledge
description: In an effort to woo evangelical voters in Iowa, Gov. Rick Perry of Texas has become the third Republican presidential candidate to sign a pledge to oppose gay marriage, to appoint only faithful Constitutionalists as judges, to stay loyal to his spouse, to shrink the size of the federal government, and to oppose Islamic law, among other things.

title: Solitary Refinement
description: On Nov. 13, the celebrated Modernist designer Eva Zeisel turned 105. As if this werent impressive enough, Zeisel marked the occasion by publishing a memoir about the 16 months she spent in a Soviet prison in the 1930s, during which time she tried to commit suicide by cutting her wrists with a copper wire pulled from a toilet. For many years Eva did not want to make her prison experiences public, in part because she was afraid that the K.G.B. would come after her in the U.S., said her daughter, Jean Richards.

description: The brilliant hues of moths and butterflies are not from pigmentation, like the colors of our skin or eyes. Rather, they come from tiny structures in the scales that scatter light to produce colors.

title: Critics Picks Video: Hannah and Her Sisters
description: This week, A. O. Scott gives thanks to Woody Allen for his film about family and renewal, Hannah and Her Sisters. Mr. Scott is not certain whether this is Mr. Allens greatest film, but he says its the film that offers the clearest and most coherent expression of his view of the world.

title: Violins Take Center Stage in a Repertory Reincarnated
description: According to the Bach-Werke-Verzeichnis (Bach Works Catalog, commonly abbreviated as BWV), Johann Sebastian Bach composed more than 1,100 works. For some performers that prodigious output isnt enough. Fresh arrangements of Bachs music have been a booming industry for ages, especially among musicians whose instruments or ensembles Bach did not use. And Bach was himself an inveterate tinkerer, with both his own pieces and those of other composers.

title: Wresting Bachs Music From Its Western Moorings
description: Lincoln Center has been exploring the idea of transcendence in its White Light Festival this year by way of early and modern works from the classical music canon, as well as several theatrical offerings in which music was a central component. Whether each performance proved a portal to transcendence is a matter for individual listeners to decide; the ones I heard succeeded more often than not. And you could hardly have hoped for a finale better suited to the theme than Passio-Compassio, the Ensemble Sarband concert that closed the festival on Saturday evening at Alice Tully Hall.

description: Young Adult

title: A Sextet From Mendelssohn, Made for Showing Off
description: Mendelssohn was one of the most precociously talented musicians in history, and his cultured, affluent parents knew it. Twice a month their Berlin home became the site of elaborate Sunday musicales featuring members of the family and musicians brought in for the occasion. Like any attention-grabbing teenager, Felix enjoyed showing off.

title: K.K.R. Is Said to Be Near Deal for Samson
description: Henry R. Kravis, the private equity titan, was born in Tulsa, Okla., the son of an oilman.

title: Hewletts Profit Falls 91%, but It Beats Expectations
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Meg Whitman tried to stay positive Monday, even as she was managing sharply lower expectations about Hewlett-Packards near-term prospects.

title: A Big Bolshoi Opening From a Cinema Seat
description: Excitement was high in the sold-out BIG cinema on East 59th Street in Manhattan on Sunday morning when Ballet in Cinema screened a live HD transmission of the Bolshois production of The Sleeping Beauty, starring David Hallberg. Mr. Hallberg is making ballet history by becoming the first American to join this Moscow company permanently. The first glimpse of him in a pre-performance warm-up prompted some members of the cinema audience to applaud.

title: The White Party
description: In the wake of the 2008 election, conservative Republican strategists like Karl Rove, Grover Norquist and William Kristol warned that their party faced even worse defeats if it continued in its anti-immigrant posturing.

title: Getting a Handle on Why 4 Equals Green
description: Grapheme-color synesthesia is a peculiar neurological condition in which people involuntarily experience colors when thinking about letters, numbers or words.

title: An Idea as Much as a City
description: In The Aeneid, his classic epic about the founding of Rome, Virgil wrote of that citys destiny  of its leader young Romulus building walls of Mars and of its people, the Romans, for whom there would be no limits, world or time, only the gift of empire without end.

title: After Rhino Horn Seizure, Conservationists Seek Enforcement
description: Authorities at the Hong Kong International Airport made a record seizure of illegal rhino horns last week, estimated to be worth about $2.2 million, officials said.

title: Timely | Alex and Victor Carril: Paris Match
description: Over the 26 years theyve spent growing up in the Marais, the identical twins Alex and Victor Carril have earned a reputation for street brawling  with each other  in their picturesque Paris neighborhood. When the director Pascal-Alex Vincent caught wind (as all locals eventually do) of these hot twins who fight, he cast them in his short film Bb Requin, which competed at Cannes in 2005, and later as the leads in Donne-Moi la Main, a movie inspired by their bellicose proclivities. As villains in this months Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows, the twins will undoubtedly earn even wider recognition. But until then they keep busy making hip-hop music videos and working on their fashion line, Is Not Dead. And they both hold court nightly in the cafes near their family home on the Place du March Sainte-Catherine.

title: A Quiet Push to Grow Crops Under Cover of Trees
description: HELENA, Mont.  On a forested hill in the mountains north of Montanas capital, beneath a canopy of pine and spruce, Marc and Gloria Flora have planted more than 300 smaller trees, from apple and pear to black walnut and chestnut.

title: Joan of Arc Tells Her Story, and a Choral Force Replies
description: Joan of Arc, the national heroine of France, has inspired innumerable literary and musical works, including an oratorio in 1935 by the Swiss composer Arthur Honegger. The 600th anniversary of her birth, though a matter of some dispute, will be celebrated next year, and the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra, choosing not to wait, presented Honeggers infrequently performed Jeanne dArc au Bcher (Joan of Arc at the Stake) on Saturday evening at Carnegie Hall.

title: Crosby Returns to Form, and the N.H.L. Exhales
description: PITTSBURGH  Sidney Crosby spent 320 days recovering from the most closely chronicled concussion in hockey history. When he finally returned to the ice Monday night after missing 61 games, it took him 5 minutes 24 seconds to do what he does best.

title: Breaking New Ground
description: Nevin Cohen teaches sustainable food systems, environmental policy and urban planning at the New School, and focuses on the evolution of municipal food policy. Kubi Ackerman is a research coordinator at the Urban Design Lab at the Earth Institute at Columbia University; he focuses on food systems and urbanization projects. Im an admirer of the work both of them do and invited them to write about the New York City Department of Environmental Protections important proposals for environmental infrastructure initiatives.

title: A Millepied Work
description: Benjamin Millepied, the recently retired principal dancer of New York City Ballet, is forming a collaborative performing arts company and has been commissioned to create a full-length work to be performed in September at the Walt Disney Concert Hall in Los Angeles, the groups producer, Charles Fabius, said on Monday. The group will be called L.A. Dance Project and involve filmmakers and visual artists, Mr. Fabius said, as well as the composer Nico Muhly, who will write the score for the work, which was commissioned by Glorya Kaufman Presents Dance at the Music Center. Mr. Fabius described L.A. Dance Project as a curatorial arts collective that would perform and recreate collaborative dance works. Mr. Millepied, 34, who spent 16 years at City Ballet, created the steps for the movie Black Swan.

title: Dispute Over Money Delays 9/11 Museum
description: The scheduled opening next year of the National September 11 Memorial Museum has been delayed because of a $156 million dispute between the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and the foundation responsible for running the museum, according to people familiar with the discussions. The Port Authority, which is responsible for the construction, has stopped approving new contracts, slowing work on the underground museum, which was to open on Sept. 11. The organizations have been arguing over the money for nearly 18 months, and tensions rose recently as Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has sought to exert more control over construction projects in the city. Last month Mr. Cuomo nominated one of his deputies, Patrick Foye, to run the Port Authority and asked the agency to take over the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, a joint city and state enterprise that has been working on the redevelopment of the World Trade Center site. The National September 11 Memorial and Museum at the World Trade Center Foundation, whose chairman is Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, has maintained that poor management and delays by the Port Authority between 2006 and 2008 cost it more than $100 million. The delay in approving construction contracts was reported by The Wall Street Journal on Monday. Michael Frazier, the foundations communications director, said Monday, We are working with the leadership of the Port Authority to come to an immediate resolution that allows this historic project to move forward. Steve Coleman, a spokesman for the Port Authority, said, Were working cooperatively with New York City and the memorial foundation and that work is continuing.
