title: Vatican: Cardinal Who Resigned Amid Scandal Retires
description: Cardinal Bernard Law, who resigned as archbishop of Boston in 2002 amid a sex abuse scandal in the Roman Catholic Church, has retired from his post at the St. Mary Major Basilica in Rome, the Vatican said Monday. The Vatican said that the pope had accepted Cardinal Laws resignation upon his turning 80, and had replaced him with Monsignor Santos Abril y Castello of Spain. Cardinal Law, the first United States bishop to step down in the scandal, that began in Boston and spread nationwide. He was accused in hundreds of lawsuits of moving around priests known to have abused children and not reporting the abuse to the police. Victims had criticized the Vatican for having given Cardinal Law the post at St. Mary Major and for allowing him to serve on a Vatican committee that appoints bishops. Cardinal Law will remain a cardinal but being over 80 cannot vote in a conclave.

title: Rupert Murdoch Sells Nearly All His Nonvoting News Corp. Shares
description: Rupert Murdoch has sold almost all of his nonvoting shares in News Corporation, but because of the companys dual-class voting shares he still controls the company.

title: Pepper-Spray Incident Spawns Remixes
description: Not long after a video of police officers dousing seated Occupy Wall Street protesters in the face with pepper spray surfaced online, it incited anger and disbelief.

title: India: Court Orders Murder Charges Against Police
description: A state high court ordered Monday that murder charges be filed against police officers who killed four people, including a 19-year-old college student, claiming they were terrorists gunned down in a shootout in 2004. An investigation later found that the victims had been shot at point blank range. The Gujarat state high court agreed with the investigations findings and ruled that the police officers should face charges. Advocates for the victims, who included a 19-year-old college student, said the killings were part of a pattern of so-called encounter killings, in which Gujarat police officers killed people, usually Muslims, and later claimed they were terrorists.

title: Parking on the Holidays: A New York Story
description: To the Editor:

title: American Music Awards Red Carpet Highlights
description: The red carpet at music awards shows isnt as stuffy as the ones at other awards shows, like the Oscars or the Golden Globes. Musical artists seem to feel more comfortable experimenting with their looks. That said, there were some hits, misses and surprises on the red carpet at the 39th annual American Music Awards in Los Angeles on Sunday night. The highs and lows were as diverse as the looks themselves.

title: How to Cook Butternut Squash for a Crowd
description: Melissa Clark roasts butternut squash, a simple, delicious Thanksgiving side dish.

title: News Organizations Complain About Treatment During Protests
description: A cross-section of 13 news organizations in New York City lodged complaints on Monday about the New York Police Departments treatment of journalists covering the Occupy Wall Street movement. Separately, 10 press clubs, unions and other groups that represent journalists called for an investigation and said they had formed a coalition to monitor police behavior going forward.

title: What Is the Best Way to Cook Butternut Squash?
description: Q.

title: Pakistan: 15 Soldiers Killed in Baluch Ambush
description: An army major and 14 paramilitary soldiers were killed Monday when they were ambushed by Baluch nationalist militants in Baluchistan Province, a military spokesman said. The attack, the worst suffered by the Pakistani military in the province in several years, occurred in Kohlu district, a stronghold of the Marri tribe, which has been at the forefront of the Baluch armed resistance movement.

title: Russia: Missiles May Be Deployed if U.S. Talks Fail
description: A Russian official said Monday that if talks with the United States on missile defense broke down, Russia was prepared to deploy tactical missiles to Belarus, the southern region of Krasnodar and the western enclave of Kaliningrad. The deployment would ensure that American interceptor missiles could not neutralize Russias nuclear capability, a military official told Interfax, speaking on the condition of anonymity. President Dmitri A. Medvedev said Monday that Russias response to the American missile shield should not close the door to negotiation.

title: At PWC, They Now Have Names
description: The Public Company Accounting Oversight Board today released its annual inspection reports on two of the Big Four: KPMG and PricewaterhouseCoopers. They are the first to come out this year. The reports on Ernst & Young and Deloitte & Touche will presumably follow.

title: Brazil: Chevron Faces Fines of $83 Million in Oil Spill
description: Chevron faces fines of as much as $83 million for an  oil spill this month off the coast of Rio de Janeiro, the authorities said Monday. The fines reflect the governments anger over Chevrons handling of the spill. Chevron may also face additional fines and legal penalties, officials said. Haroldo Lima, head of the National Petroleum Agency, said the spill could complicate Chevrons hopes of gaining access to new offshore exploration areas. Federal investigators said Chevron employees might also face prison terms. Chevron said in a statement that it had not yet received official notice of any fines and would respond if it did.

title: Tax Write-Off Now, Charity Later
description: Newton, Mass.

title: Djokovic Ends Series of Struggles With Three-Set Win
description: Most books written about a given tennis season start with the Australian tournaments in January and end with the United States Open in September. The remaining months at the end of the campaign are usually relegated to an epilogue, if included at all.

title: Early Applications Flood Harvard
description: Harvard said on Monday that 4,245 students filed single-choice early action applications by its Nov. 1 deadline. That number is more than double the size of Harvards anticipated incoming freshman class for 2012, and a 5.9 percent increase from 2007, when early admission was last in effect at Harvard. Under the program, students are prohibited from filing early applications with other private colleges in the United States. Yale University has reported that it received 4,310 early applications for admission, an 18 percent decrease from last year, perhaps influenced by the reinstatement of early admissions at Harvard and Princeton. Application figures at 40 schools are available on The Choice blog, nytimes.com/thechoice.

title: N.B.A. Players Merge Lawsuits; No Hearing Date Set
description: Two antitrust lawsuits filed by players against the N.B.A. were merged on Monday in the hope of bringing a swifter judgment against the league, and a swifter end to the lockout.

title: Republicans Are Endangering National Security
description: Washington

title: Hearing Set in Leak Case
description: Pfc. Bradley Manning, accused of providing thousands of secret documents to the antisecrecy organization WikiLeaks, will face an evidentiary hearing beginning Dec. 16, Army officials said Monday. The public hearing at Fort Meade, Md., is the militarys equivalent of a grand jury and is called an Article 32 hearing. Private Manning, 23, was arrested in Kuwait. He faces a possible life sentence if convicted of three dozen charges, including aiding the enemy, for passing secret military reports and diplomatic cables to WikiLeaks.

title: Arizonas Coach to Be Rodriguez
description: Rich Rodriguez, fired last winter after a miserable 15-22 record with Michigan, will become the new Arizona coach, according to a person briefed on the decision.

title: Does the U.S. Need Troops in Australia?
Separating You and Me? 4.74 Degrees
description: The world is even smaller than you thought.

title: App Smart Extra: Local Shopping Info
description: Last weeks App Smart column featured cooking and shopping apps for Thanksgiving and Black Friday. The shopping apps mentioned, however, failed to include a brand new one that deserves consideration.

title: A Vroom of Ones Own
description: Why bother with die-cast cars that you have to push with your fingers, adding your own sound effects? Mattel has created a lifelike Lightning McQueen, the star of the Disney Pixar Cars movies, that does it all for you.

title: Inspired by High Line, Park Is Envisioned With Sights Set Low
description: Ever since it opened in 2009, the High Line has drawn out-of-town visitors who hope to replicate its success. Observers of the elevated park on the West Side of Manhattan have come from nearby municipalities like Jersey City and Philadelphia and places as far away as Hong Kong.

title: Q&A: Finding New Finance Software
description: Q.

title: As Layoffs Rise, Stock Buybacks Consume Cash
description: When Pfizer cut its research budget this year and laid off 1,100 employees, it was not because the company needed to save money.

title: Euro Blind
description: The past days, weeks and months have seen countless descriptions in the news media of the crisis in the euro zone and Greeces role as its leading actor as a tragedy. But is it? Well, yes, but not in the sense in which it is usually discussed, and the difference is important and revealing.

title: Share Buybacks by Companies Are Rising
description: Companies are buying back more of their shares

title: Doctor Is Accused of Selling Prescriptions
description: A doctor suspected of prescribing thousands of painkillers to a man who murdered four people in a Long Island pharmacy pleaded not guilty on Monday in the sale of prescriptions to a Queens man who died of an overdose.

title: The Supercommittee Collapses
description: The smoke from the smoldering failure known as the deficit supercommittee spread heavily across Capitol Hill on Monday, allowing Republicans to obscure the simple truth about the failure to reach an agreement. The only reason the committee failed was because Republicans refused to raise taxes on the rich, and, in fact, wanted to cut them even below their current bargain-basement level.

title: Screening Still a Pain at Airports, Fliers Say
description: The lines will still be long and the screening still invasive at airport checkpoints this Thanksgiving.

title: A Reasonable Decision on Avastin
description: The Food and Drug Administrations withdrawal of its approval for Avastin to treat advanced breast cancer is causing understandable anguish and anger among women who believe the drug has saved or prolonged their lives. But the agency followed the scientific evidence, which showed the drug was not as effective as it first seemed, and that its severe side effects outweighed its benefits for a vast majority of patients.

title: Postal Chief Seeks Ability to Cut Costs to Stem Loss
description: WASHINGTON  Unless Congress passes far-reaching legislation soon to give the Postal Service the flexibility it needs to cut costs, the agency will suffer disastrous losses that could jeopardize its long-term future, Patrick R. Donahoe, the postmaster general, warned on Monday.

title: Alabamas Shame (Cont.)
description: The self-inflicted wounds from Alabamas most-abusive-in-the-nation immigration law just keep on coming. Last week, a manager for Mercedes-Benz, visiting from Germany, was pulled over in his rental car by a police officer in Tuscaloosa near where a Mercedes plant builds sport-utility vehicles. The manager didnt have his drivers license with him, and only a few months ago he just would have been given a ticket. But Alabamas new law, now in effect, demands tougher action against suspected illegal immigrants. The manager was arrested and taken to police headquarters.

title: A Community With Money? Of Course Marketers Want In on That
description: PROFESSIONALS of all stripes have no end of networking possibilities, with social networks like LinkedIn and Facebook. Now one particular segment, the gay professional, has a new networking venue  and advertisers are taking note.

title: The Two Moons
description: In 1951, Samuel Lubell invented the concept of the political solar system. At any moment, he wrote, there is a Sun Party (the majority party, which drives the agenda) and a Moon Party (the minority party, which shines by reflecting the solar rays).

title: Expansion Draft Best XI
description: Major League Soccer released the protected and unprotected players from each team in advance of Wednesdays expansion draft, when the Montreal Impact will select 10 players. The complete list is here. Teams can only lose one player. Most designated players are not exposed to the draft; players classified as Generation Adidas and Homegrown are protected automatically.

title: Jury in Trial of a Newark Lawyer Says It Is Split
description: NEWARK  Jurors in the case of a Newark defense lawyer charged with taking part in the murder of a witness in a drug case said Monday that they were divided.

title: Granny Loves Gingrich
description: Young Republicans have a message for their partys newest rising star, Newt Gingrich: theyre just not that into him.

title: Romney Heats Up Campaign in New Hampshire With an Ad Attacking Obama
description: NASHUA, N.H.  Moving the campaign into a more combative phase, Mitt Romney is set to show his first television commercial of the campaign on Tuesday in New Hampshire, attacking President Obama over his economic leadership on the same day the president will visit the state to discuss his plans for turning around the economy.

title: Low-Tax Cigarettes, Made in Store, Draw City Lawsuit
description: Sometimes a cigar is just a cigar, as Freud supposedly said, but when is a cigarette a cigarette?

title: Nature, Enclosed
description: The Giraffe Behind the Door

title: Republican Debates Put Moderators in Hot Seat, Too
description: Weeks of work can go into preparing for political debates. There is anticipating possible questions, composing snappy rejoinders and reviewing hours of television footage.

title: Lottery Numbers
Verlander Returns the M.V.P. to Pitchers
description: Early in the last decade, when he was still an unblemished legend, Roger Clemens invited me to Houston to interview him in the trophy room of his home. The centerpiece of the display was a stone wall with his Cy Young Awards encircling the most sacred and rarest prize for a pitcher: the most valuable player.

title: A Way to Finance Europes Rescue
For Deficit Panel, Failure Cuts Two Ways
description: WASHINGTON  The latest Congressional failure to agree on a plan for balancing the governments books could yield a surprising result: a sharp reduction in annual federal deficits, larger than anything contemplated by the special panel that reached its fruitless finale on Monday.

title: Popular Talk Show on Bravo Will Expand to 5 Nights
description: The crowded world of late-night television will have a new and potentially imposing competitor in January when Bravo will turn its successful Watch What Happens Live show, hosted by Andy Cohen, into a five-night-a-week entry at 11 p.m.

title: Trusting Transparency Will Work
description: Im sure the letter was too long and too emotional.

title: Libya Tries to Build Army That Can March Straight and Defang Militias
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  The marching can hardly be called crisp as the new Libyan National Army takes form in daily drills at an abandoned air force base here.

title: Artists at Home
description: Many of the original residents of Westbeth, which opened as subsidized housing for artists in 1970, still live there.

title: Why Doesnt No Mean No?
description: In 1998, The New York Times published a front-page article suggesting that two new drugs, angiostatin and endostatin, might finally win the war on cancer.

title: The Umbrella Man
description: On the 48th anniversary of the assassination of President John F. Kennedy, Errol Morris explores the story behind the one man seen standing under an open black umbrella at the site.

title: A Transcendent, if Rare, American Outreach
description: BEIJING  It was the kind of moment that the organizers of the Asia Societys cultural mission to China had been hoping for. As the Chinese-American cellist Yo-Yo Ma performed an eclectic, quirky concert showcasing American culture, one of Chinas rising political stars gave her blessing, standing up to wave to the crowd between pieces.

title: A Blow to Pinstripe Aspirations
description: Earlier this fall, Steve Ferdman celebrated getting a job offer from Credit Suisse in the usual Wall Street fashion. Over expensive oysters and dark rum cocktails at a trendy Manhattan restaurant with his parents, he toasted landing the full-time position after working six months as a consultant without benefits.

title: The Way We Were
description: We live in a time of lead. Gone is the Golden Age. Today, things are bad. Tomorrow, theyll be worse.

title: France, and Sarkozy, Look Vulnerable as Euro Crisis Persists
description: PARIS  With the humiliating defeat on Sunday of the Socialists in Spain, the two-year euro crisis has already toppled eight governments, sending shivers of anxiety through the lyse Palace and even the White House.

title: Rich in Success, Rooted in Secrecy
description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa.  One of the great paradoxes of the Penn State scandal is evident on the face of Graham B. Spanier, the universitys ousted president.

title: Romneys First Television Ad Attacks Obama on Economy
description: Mitt Romney previewed his first television ad  set to go on the air in New Hampshire on Tuesday, with a $134,000 buy behind it  to Sean Hannity of Fox News on Monday evening.

title: The Umbrella Man
description: For years, Ive wanted to make a movie about the John F. Kennedy assassination. Not because I thought I could prove that it was a conspiracy, or that I could prove it was a lone gunman, but because I believe that by looking at the assassination, we can learn a lot about the nature of investigation and evidence. Why, after 48 years, are people still quarreling and quibbling about this case? What is it about this case that has led not to a solution, but to the endless proliferation of possible solutions?

title: Police Suspect Mother in 5-Year-Olds Disappearance in Phoenix Suburb
description: GLENDALE, Ariz.  The police here arrested the mother of a missing 5-year-old girl on a child abuse charge on Monday and said they believed she might have played a role in the disappearance of the girl, Jhessye Shockley, who they said was presumed dead.

title: Tuesday: One Called Hizzoner
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  Victor No, Not the Film Director Fleming is a busy man. In addition to his day job as a judge in a Little Rock, Ark., traffic court, he constructs puzzles for many different venues (more about that below), and is an official at the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament. Even so, he was kind enough to send some notes on the evolution of this interesting theme, which follow.

title: Old Friends Reunited Once Again
description: A serious case of whiplash hovers as a distinct possibility throughout An Evening With Patti LuPone and Mandy Patinkin, a concert performance and mutual lovefest from these veteran musical theater stars that opened on Monday night at the Ethel Barrymore Theater.

title: Choosing Sides in Afghanistan: Spies Playing in the Great Game
description: The gifts referred to in the title of Blood and Gifts, a superb new play by J. T. Rogers about the long history behind the American involvement in Afghanistan, are on ominous view throughout the play. Big boxes are carried onstage and cracked open to reveal piles of artillery. Shiny new rifles are waved in the air like harmless toys. Suitcases full of dollars are handed over with a cool smile.

title: John Neville, Shakespearean Actor and Munchausen Star, Is Dead at 86
description: John Neville, who played Romeo to Claire Blooms Juliet, Hamlet to Judi Denchs Ophelia and Othello to Richard Burtons Iago (and vice versa), but who may be best known in the United States as the title character in the exuberantly loopy film The Adventures of Baron Munchausen and a recurring one in the television series The X-Files, died in Toronto on Saturday. He was 86.

title: Republicans in Indiana to Seek Law Limiting Unions
description: Republican leaders in Indiana on Monday declared as their top legislative priority making Indiana a right to work state, setting the stage for a new battle over union rights that has already consumed many states.

title: Corrections: November 22
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Mariners Dutch Outfielder Killed; Brother Is Suspect
description: Greg Halman retreated to Rotterdam whenever he could, looking for respite from the long grind of the baseball season. Halman, a promising outfielder for the Seattle Mariners, loved returning to the Netherlands, where he was born, as it allowed him to be closer to his family.

title: Pull of Family Reshapes U.S.-Cuban Relations
description: MIAMI  For two consecutive years, Stephanie Vrcia, 11, a sixth grader here, has done something that was unimaginable five years ago. She has spent four weeks in Havana, playing hide-and-seek with her cousins and going to the beach with her aunts and uncles. When summer vacation ended, her mother flew out to bring her back to Miami.

title: Fresh Look for Author, and for Land He Lauded
description: PETRPOLIS, Brazil  When the Viennese-born writer Stefan Zweig moved in 1941 to this city of imperial palaces nestled in the mountains near Rio de Janeiro, he was one of worlds most translated authors, renowned for his taut novellas exploring passion, obsession and despair.

title: Moogy Klingman, Songwriter and Original Member of Utopia, Dies at 61
description: If pop music, at its best, can be called a series of evanescent but magically eternal moments, Moogy Klingman lived the concept. He jammed with the likes of Jimi Hendrix, Chuck Berry and Bo Diddley, produced a rare album featuring Eric Clapton, Jeff Beck and other superstars, and helped write the song that Bette Midler made her theme, Friends.

title: After Tropical Storm, Flooded Apartment Is Just One More Obstacle to Overcome
description: The day after Tropical Storm Irene hit New York, in August, Yugely Nuez walked into her basement apartment in Brooklyn and stepped into a nightmare.

title: Baseball Signs Off on an Owners Past
description: Sports leagues prefer to approve new team owners who are trouble-free and will be grateful supporters of their commissioners. Dull, quiet, extremely rich and publicly charitable are also prized qualities.

title: Sharpton Calls Limbaughs Remarks About First Lady a Distraction
description: Just how racially heated will the 2012 presidential election get?

title: CUNY Students Protesting Tuition Increase Clash With Police
description: A daylong rally by City University of New York students against a planned tuition increase turned turbulent Monday evening when marchers ignored police requests to clear the lobby of a building where the universitys trustees were meeting and 15 people were arrested.

title: In Art Fraud Case, Defendant With a History Receives a Six-Year Sentence
description: In the small 19th-century painting, a young girl is seated in a straight-backed chair, looking forlorn, as if troubled by her role in the strange story of theft and deception that culminated in a Manhattan courtroom on Monday.

title: Reporters Meet the Fists of the Law
description: In the aftermath of the Occupy Wall Street eviction from Zuccotti Park, a mayoral aide e-mailed reporters.

title: A Failure Is Absorbed With Disgust and Fear, but Little Surprise
description: Does the American political system even work anymore?

title: Romneys Making the Right Play in Iowa
description: Jeff Zelenys weekend story about how Mitt Romneys campaign will exert more rather than less effort in Iowa deserves your attention. It reflects what is perhaps the most important strategic decision that any Republican candidate will make this year.

title: The Perfect Stocking Stuffer: A Chocolate Lady Gaga Shoe
description: Among the 220 Lady Gaga-themed holiday gifts that went on sale Monday night at Barneys New York was a shoe made of chocolate for $95.

title: Obama Weighed Risks of Engagement, and Decided to Give Voters the Final Say
description: WASHINGTON  In remaining aloof from the special deficit committee in Congress even as it collapsed on Monday, President Obama showed his calculation more clearly than ever before: Republicans will never agree to raise taxes on the wealthy to balance any spending cuts, so let the voters decide.

title: Youth Pleads Guilty to Killing Gay Classmate
description: LOS ANGELES  Brandon McInerney, the teenager accused of killing a gay eighth-grade classmate in 2008, pleaded guilty to second-degree murder, the Ventura County District Attorneys Office announced Monday. He will spend 21 years in prison.

title: Islanders Response to Late-Night Meeting? Another Blowout Loss
description: Disgusted with his teams performance in a 6-0 home loss to the Bruins last Saturday, Islanders Coach Jack Capuano decided he was not going to wait until a scheduled practice Sunday to address his team. After the news media completed their interviews and the players were finished with their postgame workouts and medical treatments, Capuano conducted a lengthy team meeting in the Islanders locker room at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Stimulus Measures Set to Expire at Years End Will Be Next Fiscal Battle
description: WASHINGTON  The likely failure of the bipartisan Congressional deficit committee has opened the door for a year-end showdown on expiring stimulus measures that are adding billions of dollars to workers pockets and, economists say, buoying the fragile recovery.

title: Numberplay: Personality or Issues?
description: Whats the best way to elect the most appropriate candidate to public office  the one most likely to do a good job? How do we prevent trivialities from clouding the issues and allow a persons true qualities to shine through? Is there any voting system that does this better than the others? This is the focus of a scenario submitted by a prolific Numberplay puzzle contributor, Ravi Kumar Meduri. Here is his make-believe voting simulation:

title: After Getting Pushed Around, Giants Are Angry at Not Pushing Back
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Group therapy convened here Monday as the Giants players sat together  as they always do  to dissect the film of the game from the night before, then broke into their positional units  as they always do  for a more casual breakdown.

title: Red Sox Put Valentines Strategy to Test
description: The Boston Red Sox have set up an extensive and rigorous interview process for their vacant managerial position involving pointed questions about in-game strategy, with video accompaniment and specific scenarios of almost every situation a manager might encounter in the course of a baseball season.

title: NYT Front Page for 11/22/2011
description: NYT Front Page for 11/22/2011

title: Jets Project Confidence, but Victories Matter Most
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  After a weekend off, the Jets returned to practice feeling confident that they would win their next game. Not only that, they said, but they still believe in one another and, if they execute correctly and play mistake-free football, they can win two in a row and, eventually, even make the playoffs.

title: Word of the Day | expansive
description: expansive \ik-span(t)-siv\adjective

title: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Tuesday
description: The rupee closed at an all-time low of 52.15 to the dollar, as foreign investors fled riskier assets, the Business Standard reports. The Bombay Stock Exchanges Sensex index also fell 2.6 per cent.A special investigation team told the Gujarat High Court on Monday that Ishrat Jahan, a 19-year-old college student, was murdered along with two others by the Ahmedabad Crime Branch on June 15, 2004 (Hindustan Times) The investigation team, headed by officer Rajiv Rajan Verma, implicated more than 20 policemen, pointing to forensic, medical and material evidence which they claim shows the victims were shot before the encounter date of June 15, 2004. Gujarat police maintain that the three were Lashkar-e-Taiba members, aiming to kill Chief Minister Narendra Modi. The court may pass the case to a central investigation agency (Times of India).

title: Tape Tops a Live Game
description: Overnight television ratings showed that Foxs tape-delayed broadcast of the game between Chelsea and Liverpool on Sunday afternoon was almost twice the rating of the M.L.S. final that evening. The E.P.L. game drew a 1.5 rating, according to Nielsen, which translates to about 1.5 percent of viewers in 56 of the biggest markets in the United States. The M.L.S. final attracted a rating of 0.8.

title: Ferrer Turns Back Murray
description: David Ferrer, the fifth seed, provided the first real surprise of the ATP World Tour Finals in London, defeating third-seeded Andy Murray, 6-4, 7-5. Murray appeared weary throughout the match. He made only 46 percent of his first serves, and hit more than twice as many unforced errors (44) as winners (21). In a later match, Novak Djokovic beat Tomas Berdych, 3-6, 6-3, 7-6 (3).

title: Wisconsin Men Win Title
description: Wisconsin won the N.C.A.A. mens cross-country title in Terre Haute, Ind., finishing 42 points ahead of second-place Oklahoma State. The Arizona freshman Lawi Lalang was the individual winner. Sheila Reid of Villanova won her second straight womens title, while Georgetown was the womens team champion.

title: Back on Big Stage, Crosby Dazzles
description: PITTSBURGH  After scoring two goals and two assists in his first game back from a 61-game absence with a concussion, Sidney Crosby was momentarily at a loss for words. Just being back out there, I cant really describe it, he said.

title: UConn Shows Resolve, if Not Star Power
description: HARTFORD  So this is what it is like for Connecticut womens basketball when the second-ranked Huskies must climb a mountain instead of starting at the preseason summit.

title: Rapid Redux Breaks Record
description: Rapid Redux won his 20th consecutive race, breaking Zenyatta and Peppers Prides modern record for consecutive wins, at Mountaineer Racetrack.

title: Eunuchs Mourn After Deadly Blaze
description: Footwear, mangled plastic bottles and tattered fabric mixed with charred debris at the fire-ravaged site in the east Delhi neighborhood of Nand Nagri on Monday afternoon. This is all that was left at a community center compound where a makeshift tent  erected for a large congregation of eunuchs, or transgender people, from across India  went up in flames on Sunday evening.

title: News Quiz | Nov. 22, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Champions League Tuesday Preview: Bayern Wants a Win, City Needs One
description: The Champions League returns on Tuesday with the first day of the penultimate round of the group stage. Manchester City is hoping to bring its English league form to the continent, Inter Milan is hoping to leave its league form at home, and Bayern Munich is hoping to leave everyone else behind and clinch a place in the next round. Heres Tuesdays schedule (all games start at 2:45 p.m. Eastern unless noted):

title: Deal to Hasten Transition in Egypt Is Jeered at Protests
description: CAIRO  Egypt careened through another day of crisis with no end in sight as hundreds of thousands of people occupying Tahrir Square jeered at a deal struck on Tuesday by the Muslim Brotherhood and the military that would speed up the transition to civilian rule on a timetable favoring the Islamist movement.

title: China Outlines Cuts in Carbon Emissions
description: BEIJING  With global climate talks set to begin next week, China on Tuesday issued the most comprehensive document yet on its plans and negotiating positions on emissions.

title: Nov. 22, 1963 | President Kennedy Is Assassinated
description: On Nov. 22, 1963, President John F. Kennedy was fatally shot while riding in an open-top car through Dealey Plaza in Dallas. Two bullets struck the president, the first in his back and throat and the second in the back of his head. Gov. John Connally of Texas, another passenger, was also shot, though he survived. Jacqueline Kennedy and Nellie Connally, the mens wives, were also in the car but were not injured.The New York Times reported on the assassination: Mr. Kennedy apparently was hit by the first of what witnesses believed were three shots. He was driven at high speed to Dallass Parkland Hospital. There, in an emergency operating room, with only physicians and nurses in attendance, he died without regaining consciousness.

title: Pepper-Spraying of Students Puts University Campus in Spotlight
description: WHO was placed on administrative leave after students were pepper sprayed?

title: In Indiana, a Hometown Soon to Change
description: Robb Hill  grew up among farms and forests several miles outside Utica, Ind., a small town along the Ohio River. He helped neighbors bale hay and fished in a nearby creek almost every weekend, rain or shine. It wasnt Tom Sawyer, but it was a good life.

title: Test Yourself | English, Nov. 22, 2011
description: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article U.S. Troops to Leave Iraq by Years End, Obama Says.

title: Do Your Parents Support Your Learning?
description: According to a recent study, parental involvement is strongly associated with high performance on a standardized test that measures 15-year-olds reading comprehension as well as math and science problem-solving. Do your parents support your learning? Did they read to you when you were little? Do you think their level of involvement now has anything to do with your test scores and grades?

title: An App to Help Win Black Friday
description: Black Friday, the busiest shopping day of the year, is just around the corner, but a free iPhone app called TapBuy can help you get a jump on the other holiday shoppers.

title: At Madrid Show, Colorful Posters and Stark Photography
description: Though Juan Gattis many accomplishments in photography, fashion and graphic design have established him as an artist with a wide range, he is probably best known for designing influential posters for Pedro Almodvars films. Starting with a poster for Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown in 1988, Mr. Gatti has collaborated with the filmmaker many times, leaving his mark on the visual aesthetics of many of the directors films. Indeed, posters for films including Talk to Her, Broken Embraces and this years The Skin I Live In line the walls of Contraluz, the first exhibition that traverses the length of Mr. Gattis career  although the actual focus of the show lies elsewhere.

title: Analyzing ESPNs Total Quarterback Rating
description: In August, ESPN announced a new way to measure quarterbacks: Total QBR. As you would expect, many writers weighed in with their thoughts. Few football fans have faith in the traditional passer rating system; even fewer understand how it works. Thats one of the reasons ESPN spent several years charting every N.F.L. play and seven monthsdevising a system that would not only represent a step forward from the traditional passer rating but would also be easier for fans to understand. Total QBR grades quarterbacks in some innovative ways:

title: In the Woods of New Hampshire, a Reshaper of Vintage Automobiles
description: BETHLEHEM, N.H.  Theres nothing quite like a broken leaf spring to shape the aluminum hood of a 1965 Shelby 427 Cobra S/C.

title: Balancing the Budget, for Real
description: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of the coming book The Benefit and the Burden.

title: Q&A: Skipping Software Updates
description: Q.

title: Economic Insecurity
description: With the Census Bureau fine-tuning its definition of poverty, a group of near poor has emerged  those who are not officially poor but are perilously close to it.

title: The First Word on the London Riots
description: LONDON  Is anything in art more overrated than distance? Distance, were told, is what must come between a momentous event and any work of art created around that event, or else the art may be short on reflection and digestion. The long view, a step back, space to unknot our emotions  all are necessary for art. This point of view was thrown around with abandon on the 10th anniversary of 9/11: too soon was a phrase much overused to explain the absence still of any great art about that day. Yet if reflection and digestion have their place, theres a problem with distance and its distance.

title: South Korea Approves Free Trade Pact With U.S.
description: SEOUL  Members of President Lee Myung-baks governing party, coughing from tear gas sprayed by an opposition legislator, rammed a free-trade agreement between South Korea and the United States through Parliament on Tuesday, ratifying a deal that has sharpened a political divide between the government and the opposition and between big business and voters unhappy with deepening economic inequality.

title: After an Eviction, Digging Through a Surplus of Donations
description: In a back room on the first floor of an office building on lower Broadway, with wires dangling from tent-sized holes in the ceiling and organizers folding piles of sweaters across the room, Occupy Wall Street opened its mail on Monday.

title: One Way to Simplify Phone Chaos
description: Four years ago, Andie Jones found herself overweight, out of shape and feeling generally unhealthy, thanks in large part to the demands of a high-powered career in marketing. After figuring out a new set of eating and exercise habits that got her health back on track, she started helping family, friends and colleagues do the same  and got so much satisfaction out of it that two years ago she walked away from her job for a career reboot. After taking some certification courses, she put up a shingle for Be Well Nutrition, a nutrition and weight-loss coaching service specializing in helping time-strapped business executives and parents.

title: Tokyo and Osaka Exchanges Reach $1.1 Billion Merger Deal
description: TOKYO  The Tokyo Stock Exchange, Japans largest, on Tuesday announced a $1.1 billion merger deal with the Osaka Securities Exchange that would create the worlds third-largest exchange, as measured by the value of listed stock

title: Democrats Say Romney Ad Distorts Obamas Comments
description: 5:37 p.m. | Updated Democrats reacted ferociously on Tuesday to Mitt Romneys first campaign commercial, an ad that distorted comments by President Obama to make it look like he was running away from his record on the economy.

title: Judge Extends Plea Deadline for Former UBS Trader
description: LONDON  A London judge ruled on Tuesday that Kweku M. Adoboli, a former UBS trader charged with fraud, could have an additional four weeks to look at evidence and get legal advice before entering a plea in a case that grew out of a $2.3 billion trading loss at the Swiss bank.

In the case of the Muppets, you make a leap of faith and hope that the charm of these Jim Henson creations, which once flooded childrens television and movies, remains irresistible.

title: A Son of Santa Claus Takes the Reins
description: Why is it that out of all the holidays, only Christmas ever needs to be saved? When was the last time you saw a movie about a madcap, heroic effort to save Flag Day?

title: Breakfast Meeting, Nov. 22
description: Facebook has decided to create its own smartphone  code name Buffy, as in the vampire slayer  enlisting the Taiwanese company HTC to build it with the social network integrated at the core of its being, according to report in AllThingsD, part of Dow Jones. (Neither Facebook nor HTC would confirm the report.) The phone will not make it to market for 12 to 18 months and is expected to use a modified version of the Android operating system created and released by Google, the Web site reported. While some online commentators questioned the wisdom of Facebook entering the hardware business from scratch, the AllThingsD account described the decision as about independence: Google and Apple run the two major smartphone operating systems, giving Facebook little say over its mobile destiny.

title: South Africa Passes Law to Restrict Reporting of Government Secrets
description: JOHANNESBURG  Brushing aside protests by press-freedom advocates and heroes of South Africas anti-apartheid struggle, Parliament overwhelmingly passed a contentious bill on Tuesday that will severely restrict the ability of journalists to report any information deemed to be a government secret.

title: Janet Maslins Picks for 2011
description: DESTINY OF THE REPUBLIC: A TALE OF MADNESS, MEDICINE AND THE MURDER OF A PRESIDENT by Candice Millard. A staggering tale about the American presidency by a historian who, as she did in The River of Doubt, her book about Theodore Roosevelt, zeroes in on what other historians overlook. Ms. Millard digs deeply into the turmoil that got James A. Garfield elected, the lunacy that got him shot and the medical malfeasance that turned a minor wound into a mortal one. Her story is so full of outsize figures  not least of them the unexpectedly noble Garfield  that Alexander Graham Bell is only a bit player. (Doubleday, $28.95)

title: Books to Send, Recommend Or Just Lend
description: PARALLEL universes are a hot topic for scientists these days. Theyre a hot one for book critics too. In some parallel world it is theoretically possible that a critic could read every single book published by English-speaking Earthlings in 2011 and list the 10 that are best. Some of those books might even be about parallel-universe theory.

title: Abortion Case Loses Ground, but Issue Stays Hot in Kansas
description: OVERLAND PARK, Kan.  The prosecution of a Planned Parenthood affiliate here, the first such criminal case in the nation, has been treated locally as something of a proxy in the battle over abortion rights. Derided by supporters of the organization as politically motivated, the prosecution was celebrated by opponents as the capstone of increasingly aggressive actions here and elsewhere against Planned Parenthood, which provides abortions and other services at clinics around the country.

title: Should Airlines Police What We Watch in Flight?
description: Daniel Craig as James Bond, naked and tied to a broken cane chair, being whipped. That was the scene that taught me to think twice about in-flight movies, although in this case we were on the bus to Boston, with Casino Royale (rated PG-13) shown on dangling, inescapable screens above us. The two 5-year-olds in my care observed it silently, then turned their attention back to the Disney movie theyd chosen to bring along, fortunately not intrigued by either the torture or a variety of other educational scenes that followed.

title: More From the Financial Pro Who Lost His Home
description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog. His new book, The Behavior Gap, will be out in January.

title: Samurai Shopper | The 1% Solution
description: What? Havent finished holiday shopping yet? The Samurai Shopper, as usual, is leagues ahead of you. This is not due to my overarching fabulousness, its just that the Samurai family consists of the Samurai Spawn, born on Boxing Day, Dec. 26. We still apologize to Spawn for creating her at such an awkward moment. Who knew?

title: Daily Report: Separating You and Me? 4.74 Degrees
description: One of the most talked-about articles Tuesday is the revelation that there are not six degrees degrees of separation between any two people, but 4.74 degrees. John Markoff and Somini Sengupta, reporters for The New York Times, write that the original six degrees finding, published in 1967 by the psychologist Stanley Milgram, was drawn from 296 volunteers who were asked to send a message by postcard, through friends and then friends of friends, to a specific person in a Boston suburb.

title: If Youre a Venture Capitalist, Youre Most Likely a White Man
description: The color of money is rarely discussed in Silicon Valley. Which is why, when a CNN program recently brought it up, it unleashed an intense outpouring in the technology blogosphere. Cleverly, it also generated a flurry of free publicity for a provocative CNN documentary on African-Americans in technology, weeks before it aired.

title: Taxing Job Creators
description: Mark Thoma sends us to the new Journal of Economic Perspectives paper (pdf) on optimal taxes by Peter Diamond and Emmanuel Saez. Its a tough read (Im still working on it myself), but theres one discussion that I think helps make a useful point about current political debate.

title: There Is a Safe Way to Cut Military Spending. Think Congress Will Do It?
description: Now that members of the Congressional deficit reduction committee have failed to do their jobs (with a BIG assist from leaders of the House G.O.P.), the Pentagon could be looking at more than $500 billion in required spending cuts. Thats on top of about $450 billion in cuts that are already planned for the next 10 years. As they say in Washington, a few billion here, a few billion there and eventually it adds up to real money.

title: Let It Bleed Cover Art Up for Sale
description: If you are ready and able to stand a little blood-letting of your bank account, the original cover artwork for Let It Bleed, the Rolling Stones album that has been described as having one of the greatest covers of all time, is for sale at the next Entertainment Memorabilia auction at Bonhams in London on Dec. 15. The artwork is estimated to sell for 30,000-40,000, roughly $47,000 to $62,500.

title: Marylands Unlikely Run to the Field Hockey Championship
description: In the latter part of the last decade, the University of Maryland field hockey team entered each season as the prohibitive favorites to capture the national championship. It didnt only have a chance to make a run to the title-game; it was a near-guarantee.

So in her makeup trailer, Michelle went trough the transformation one last time.

title: On Monday Night, Gronkowski Was an M.V.P.

title: Can the Bulldog Be Saved?
description: In the first half of Georgias football game against South Carolina in 2009, Uga VII, who had been dozing on a bag of ice in his air-conditioned sideline doghouse, was cajoled onto the field to pose for pictures with some cheerleaders and Gov. Sonny Perdue. Uga (pronounced UGH-uh) wore his trademark red Georgia jersey and spiked red leather collar, and he looked bored as an ESPN cameraman shoved a camera in his wrinkly, smooshed bulldog face.

title: Shake Up in the Top Ranks at Glamour
description: Glamour magazine, long the reliable cash cow for Cond Nast, has replaced its publisher after a string of recently disappointing advertising results.

title: Glamorous Sex Goddess, Longing to Be Human
description: In 1976, the year that Marilyn Monroe would have turned 50, Larry McMurtry wrote that she is right in there with our major ghosts: Hemingway, the Kennedy brothers  people who finished with American life before America had time to finish with them. Almost a half-century after her death, the world, or at least its necrophiliac fantasists, still havent finished with Monroe and try to resurrect her again and again in movies, books, songs and glamour layouts featuring dewy and ruined ingnues. Maybe its because its so difficult to imagine her as Old Marilyn that she has become a Ghost of Hollywood Past, a phantom that periodically materializes to show us things that have been.

description: 8:21 p.m. | Updated

title: For Distressed Young Bankers, a Symphony of Small Violins
description: In Bonfire of the Vanities, the 1987 novel that would become the canonical chronicle of Wall Streets era of excess, Tom Wolfe described the financial sector as a gilded playpen where mere boys, with smooth jawlines and clean arteries, boys still able to blush, were buying three-million-dollar apartments on Park and Fifth. These aspiring Masters of the Universe, he wrote, were living in the season of the rising sap.

title: Ad Watch: Romney Takes On Obama
description: Mitt Romneys campaign began broadcasting its first television ad in New Hampshire on Tuesday  the same day that President Obama visited the state to talk about his plan to turn around the economy.THE SCRIPTThe words, On October 16, 2008 Barack Obama Visited New Hampshire, flash across the screen before spliced video of Mr. Obamas campaign in 2008 begins: Thank you. Thank you New Hampshire. How is everybody doing today? I am confident that we can steer ourselves out of this crisis. Whos been in charge of the economy? We need a rescue plan for the middle class. We need to provide relief for homeowners. Its going take a new direction. If we keep talking about the economy, were going to lose.

title: Should I Brine My Turkey?

title: Updating Facebook Status, to Divorced
description: Soon after I married my Army officer husband, an acquaintance gave me a photocopied page of an old-school military spouse handbook as a lark. As part and parcel of being a good military spouse, it entreated new spouses to have at least two pairs of white gloves on hand at all times as well as a well-stocked stationery box. The first was deemed necessary to make the best possible impression on all the higher-ups a wife might meet as her husband made his ascent through the ranks.The second, of course, was recommended to help the new spouse stay connected with friends and family as she started her wonderful new adventure as a soldiers rock and helpmeet.

title: A Deeper Look at China, Coal and CO2

title: Women Take a Stand in Kabul
description: I was nervous when I woke up on July 14, 2011. The signs were ready, the pamphlets and flyers printed, and my attire for the day picked. I had received calls from the police, confirming that they would send us 10 officers for security. Media was informed and womens organizations contacted. Everything was ready, but I was nervous.

title: Leafless in Seattle
description: Putting together a salad in the summer is almost too easy, when baby greens, fresh herbs and ripe tomatoes are all available for the tossing. You have to be more creative as fall moves into winter, a time when few dishes have the snap and crunch of raw produce. That is to say, seasonal raw produce from this hemisphere.

title: Taming Unruly Desires and Invisible Monsters
description: A Dangerous Method, David Cronenbergs new film, starts out with a case of hysteria. A woman, clumsily restrained by nondescript handlers, writhes and howls inside a horse-drawn carriage, her mania at once drowned out and underscored by the thunder of hooves and the shrieking of strings on the soundtrack.

title: Ragnar Kjartansson Wins Performa Award for Bliss
description: The Icelandic artist Ragnar Kjartansson has won the inaugural Malcolm Award at Performa 11, the visual art performance biennial. Mr. Kjartansson received the award from Lou Reed at a crowded party at the Bowery Hotel on Monday evening, where the Performa grand finale was held.

description: Paul Motian, a drummer, bandleader, composer and one of the most influential jazz musicians of the last 50 years, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. He was 80 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Sexist Messages on Baby Clothes
description: Do clothes make the baby? If youve shopped for kids clothes even once in the past decade, you know that if thats true, then what clothes make the baby girl, at least, is ready to fit right into her assigned gender category. Shes a Cutie Pie, shes a Cupcake, shes a Very Important Princess  and shes Pretty Like Mommy but not, unless you shop for her in the boys section (and why not?), Smart Like Daddy.

title: Russia Debates Whether Boos Were for Putin
description: MOSCOW  Jeff Monson, an American mixed martial arts fighter, may have lost his match in Moscow on Sunday before a crowd of 20,000 that included Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin. But Mr. Monson, known as The Snowman, has become an unlikely political foil for opponents of Mr. Putin, as Russians debate whether the boos and jeers after the bout were directed at the fighter or the prime minister.

description: The use of chemicals to control protests has received attention recently, but Tuesday may have been the first time that tear gas was used in a legislative session by a lawmaker.

title: Presents Wrapped in Strings (Chords, Too)
description: For years now we have been hearing dire warnings that recordings  at least the kind you can hold in your hand and wrap up as gifts  will become extinct at any moment. And it is certainly true that the major classical labels are mere shadows of their former selves. But with smaller, independent labels and, increasingly, performing institutions themselves picking up the slack, CDs and DVDs continue to pour in, many of them of the highest quality. So the classical music critics of The New York Times had little difficulty in once again filling out a list of 25 records, as fine a lot as in many a boom year. Here are the choices. JAMES R. OESTREICH

title: Ratings Shrink Presidents List for Judgeships
description: WASHINGTON  The American Bar Association has secretly declared a significant number of President Obamas potential judicial nominees not qualified, slowing White House efforts to fill vacant judgeships  and nearly all of the prospects given poor ratings were women or members of a minority group, according to interviews.

title: N.B.A. General Managers Descend on Maui Invitational
description: LAHAINA, Hawaii  Its an interesting scene at the Maui Invitational, which is more than a three-day pre-Thanksgiving basketball tournament that brings together some major programs. This year, its also the gathering spot for N.B.A. general managers with a lot of time on their hands.

title: Pakistans Ambassador to the U.S. Is Forced Out
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Husain Haqqani, the embattled Pakistani ambassador to the United States, resigned Tuesday in the wake of accusations that he had sought American help to rein in the powerful Pakistani military.

title: Bag of Tricks
description: In honor of Art Basel Miami, which opens next weekend, Christian Dior asked the Berlin artist Anselm Reyle to design a collection of colorful accessories. Of his collaboration with the Avenue Montaigne couture house, Reyle notes: As an artist, I have a fascination with dubious taste, so collaborating with Dior, a symbol of good taste was exciting. He didnt turn the house on its head so much as on its side. The neon stitching on Diors quilted cannage bag has been tilted to reflect the artists fiddling with tradition. The limited-edition flats, totes and jewelry will be available in Christian Dior boutiques come January. They might be camo, but dont expect to blend in.

title: Following in Forstmanns Footsteps

The New York Times has a quarter-page ad from JPMorgan Chase that reads More than a valued client. More than a great partner. Our dear friend. In Memoriam Theodore J. Fortsmann.
