title: Breakfast Meeting, Nov. 23
description: The Tribune Company, which is trying to emerge from bankruptcy protection, agreed to pay its former chief executive, Randy Michaels, $675,000 in a settlement stemming from his abrupt resignation from the company last year, The Chicago Tribune reported. The company will also cover $50,000 in Mr. Michaelss legal fees. Mr. Michaels resigned under pressure, following reporting in The New York Times that detailed numerous instances of outlandish, often sexual behavior by Mr. Michaels and other top executives. The Tribune reported that he had demanded $900,000, the pro-rated portion of his 2010 management bonus, arguing that he was effectively terminated without cause, which would trigger the payment under terms of the bonus plan. The payment needs to be approved by a bankruptcy court judge.In Tuesday nights Republican presidential debate on CNN, which was devoted to national security issues, The Caucus live blog took note of the higher profile of Representative Ron Paul, the libertarian from Texas, who often can be hard to spot at these seemingly weekly encounters. As Trip Gabriel wrote for The Caucus, Mr. Pauls campaign had claimed after the last debate hosted by CBS News that he got only 90 seconds of air time, but Tuesday night he played a more central role, serving as a dramatic foil to his rivals. He clashed with Newt Gingrich over the the Patriot Act, and Rick Santorum over profiling of travelers, including Muslims.

title: Wednesday Reading: When Caller I.D. Becomes Fake I.D.
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Europeans Clear Western Digital Deal for Hitachi Unit
description: Western Digital has secured antitrust approval from the European Commission for its $4.3 billion acquisition  of Hitachis hard drive unit, after agreeing to sell some production assets.

title: The Tussle Between Energy and Ecology Moves to the Australian Outback
description: Heres a Dot Earth Postcard from the outback  specifically from the Bimblebox Nature Refuge, a 20,000-acre patch of drylands ecosystems in Queensland, Australia, whose owners are fighting a plan to mine surface and subterranean coal seams to supply Chinas relentless needs.

title: Opinion Report: Vladimir Putin
description: From the editorial page

title: Clashes in Egypt Enter a Fifth Day
description: Security forces continued to clash with demonstrators on Wednesday, the fifth day of violence, as protesters jeered a deal to speed up the transition to civilian rule.

title: Nokia Siemens to Cut 23 Percent of Work Force
description: BERLIN  Nokia Siemens Networks, the equipment joint venture of Nokia and Siemens, said Wednesday that it planned to cut almost a quarter of its work force as it sought to bolster profit in a stagnating market for network gear.

title: X Factor Watch: Whered That Accent Come From?
description: It was a give-thanks night on The X Factor on Tuesday, so what are we thankful for?

title: The Murdochs Hug It Out
description: Screenplay by ETAN COHEN

title: Me and My Man Shed
description: In a world where even man caves  the dimly lit redoubts where men are left to tinker and socialize with other men  are falling prey to D.I.Y. home improvement television shows, two men on the South Shore of Long Island have found shelter for their creature comforts in the most unlikely of places.

title: A Sullen March Toward Winter
description: There are strange days on the streets of New York. A buoyant autumn, in which occupy protests became almost a carnival and New Yorkers gloried in cacophonous complaint, has devolved into a sullen march toward winter.

title: JPMorgan Said to Buy MF Global Stake in London Metal Exchange
description: LONDON  JPMorgan Chase has agreed to buy a 4.7 stake in the London Metal Exchange for $38.9 million from the bankrupt brokerage MF Global, according to people with knowledge of the deal.

title: Group Led by K.K.R. to Buy Samson for $7.2 Billion
description: A consortium led by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts agreed on Wednesday to buy the Samson Investment Company, one of the largest privately held energy companies in the country, for about $7.2 billion. It would be one of the biggest leveraged buyouts since the financial crisis.

title: The Unintended Consequences of Tech Stock Repurchases
description: My colleague Nelson Schwartz has a story in Tuesdays paper about share buyback programs, and how companies can sacrifice their growth when they repurchase their own shares. The way this story has worked out recently in the high technology sector makes the story particularly timely.

title: Student Rumors Triggered Long Island Cheating Investigation
New York Film Critics Circle Will Vote Without Seeing Extremely Loud
description: In an effort to be the first critics group to announce its picks for the best films of 2011, the New York Film Critics Circle will be leaving at least one possible contender off its list: the film adaptation of Jonathan Safran Foers novel Extremely Loud and Incredibly Close.

title: Patent for Amgen Drug May Undercut Health Care Plan
description: Amgen said Tuesday that a new patent had been granted that could protect its big-selling drug Enbrel from generic competition for 17 more years, a development that could undermine some of the savings contemplated in the federal health care legislation.

title: Microsoft Signs Nondisclosure Agreement With Yahoo
description: 8:03 p.m. | Updated

title: Tailgating Recipes: Mini Mile-High Apple Pies
description: Thanksgiving weekend is on the way, so we thought this weeks tailgate party needed a little holiday flavor. For that, we turned back to Celia Erickson, executive chef and member of the class of 2012 at Cornells School of Hotel Administration.

title: Week 12 N.F.L. Game Probabilities: Harbaugh vs. Harbaugh
description: Thursday nights game is intriguing because the two teams are so similar, right down to the DNA of the head coaches. The 49ers visit the Ravens in a contest of middling offenses and strong defenses. Heres how the two teams stack up in the core facets of team efficiency:

title: When Is a States Right Not Right? When Big Donors Are at Stake
description: Two questions come to mind when I think about states rights. First, why are we still having this conversation 150 years after the Civil War? And then, what principles govern its modern-day proponents? That second question might just be harder to answer than the first.

title: What Were Reading
description: The New York Times: Follow-ups on two raging New York controversies: The city health department insists it did not order the end of the venerable pots of free cheese at Sardis bars; the restaurant, begging to differ, says the communal snack is history. And Starbucks baristas who locked bathrooms out of disgust with sloppy customers face a new antagonist: their company, which has ordered the restrooms reopened.   Patrick FarrellThe Local/East Village:  Also, news of two breaking battles: Neighbors complain of the smell of rancid bacon from the new IHOP. (At times its so pungent, one said, that it clouds her thinking.) And DNAInfo.com reports that a West Side community board has told the city that the new Tavern on the Green should be a casual restaurant, after an East Side board said they wanted a fancy one.  Nick Fox

title: Sandwiches After a Vegetarian Thanksgiving
description: The post-Thanksgiving sandwich is a favorite tradition for eating up leftover turkey. But what about the rest of the leftovers?

title: Meyer Takes Time to Think About Ohio State Job
description: Ohio State met with Urban Meyer on Wednesday, and the possibility that he will become the football coach there next season is close to becoming a reality. Still, the final word on Meyer and Ohio State will not come until after Saturday, when the Buckeyes play Michigan in their final game of the regular season.

title: More Students Charged in Long Island SAT Cheating Case
description: The Metro and education reporters Jenny Anderson and Winnie Hu provide an update in Wednesdays Times on the Long Island SAT fraud investigations, which began two months ago after a college freshman was caught impersonating high school students on test day and sitting for the exam under their names.

title: How The Sound of Music Became One of Salzburgs Favorite Things
description: More than a half-century after The Sound of Music immortalized the von Trapp familys flight from Austria on stage and screen, the first-ever Salzburg production of that Rodgers and Hammerstein musical has made audiences (if not the hills themselves) come alive with approval, The Associated Press reported.

title: A Cease-and-Desist for a Sculptor on the Shore
description: Four Fridays ago, Doug Schwartz spent the morning as he has most Fridays for more than a decade: stacking rocks and bits of ruin into pillar-like sculptures on a desolate stretch of the South Shore of Staten Island.

title: A Holiday Crash Course in Manners
description: My kids have terrible table manners.

title: Outward Bound
description: The next vacation fix for been-there-done-that travelers.

title: Tata Empire Chooses a New Chairman
description: HYDERABAD, India  The largest Indian business group, Tata Sons, on Wednesday appointed an insider whose family owns about 18 percent of the company to succeed its longtime chairman, Ratan N. Tata.

title: Tip of the Week: Cleaning Up the Desktop
description: Desktops can get quickly littered with stray icons for files and folders, but there is a quick way to tidy things up. In both Windows 7 and Mac OS X, just right-click on the desktop (or hold down the Control key while clicking with a one button Mac mouse) to see your options on the contextual menu.

title: Kicking Off an Animated Holiday Season
description: Thanksgiving and football: firmly established. Thanksgiving and animation: coming on fast.

title: Mobile Money for the Next 2 Billion People
description: Mobile phones are probably the most successfully deployed technology in history, effectively reaching more people than computers, electricity or plumbing in less than 15 years. Now they may start taking over money.

title: In a Small Texas Town, a Fight Over Late Drinks
description: GUN BARREL CITY, Tex.  The American political divide is often characterized as red versus blue. But some of the most intense political battles in small-town Texas are fought on a far older division: wet versus dry.

title: Daily Report: Can You Trust Caller ID?
description: Plenty of people rely on a quick glance at their phones caller ID screen to decide whether a call is worth picking up. But as Matt Richtel reports in Wednesdays Times, caller ID is not foolproof. Regulators in many states have been hearing increasing numbers of complaints about spoofing: the name on the screen looks innocuous or even alarming, like F.B.I., but answering the call reveals a telemarketer on the other end.

title: Questions Over Whether Terror Suspects Aid in Inquiries Was Voluntary
description: The governments disclosure of a plot to assassinate the Saudi ambassador to the United States last month came with some reassuring news: the suspect, an Iranian-American, was in custody, had confessed and had provided valuable intelligence on Irans role in supporting the plan.

title: How to Really Tell Time
description: Impatient children have been known to wonder: Whats the difference between in a moment and in a little while?

title: Checking Eligibility for U.S. Mortgage Refinance Program
description: Last month the federal government announced changes aimed at making it easier for many borrowers who owe more on their home loans than their houses are worth to refinance into lower-cost mortgages.

title: Russia Elevates Warning About U.S. Missile-Defense Plan in Europe
description: MOSCOW  Russia will deploy its own missiles and could withdraw from the New Start nuclear arms reduction treaty if the United States moves forward with its plans for a missile-defense system in Europe, President Dmitri A. Medvedev warned on Wednesday.

title: Thanksgiving Is Un-American
description: Think, for a minute, about what happened on the original Thanksgiving. (Yes, I know that there are doubts about what really happened, but never mind.)

title: Is Tebow More Mobile Than Vick? (And Other Questions from Readers)
description: Judy Battista, who covers the N.F.L. for The Times, answers readers questions:

title: Paul Solman Is Shrill
description: Here:

title: Harbaugh Infuses the 49ers With His Will to Win, at All Costs
description: Can a players career be defined by a single play? In Jim Harbaughs case, the traits that made him a successful player and now a head coach can be traced to a game on Sept. 23, 1996.

title: A Gigantic Scam
description: Thats pretty much what Andrew Haldane, the executive director for financial stability at the Bank of England, is calling a large part of modern finance:

title: Appeals Court Keeps Yellowstone Grizzlies on Threatened List
description: The government may not yet go ahead with its plan to remove grizzly bears in the Greater Yellowstone region from the endangered species list because of the Endangered Species Act, an appellate court found on Tuesday.

title: Seeing Things | The Newest Branch
description: The designer David Wisemans delicate site-specific installations, which include a canopy of cherry blossoms, a cascade of lilies of the valley, and sinuous wisteria vines, are most often commissioned for intimate private spaces. Until now, that is. With the opening of the new West Hollywood Library this fall, Wisemans work goes public for the first time.

title: Report of the Bahrain Independent Commission of Inquiry
description: The study on Bahrains upheaval marks the most comprehensive document on security force actions during any of the revolts that have flared across the Arab world this year.

title: Thanksgiving Videos
description: To get you in the spirit.

title: Week 12 in Fantasy Football: Favorable and Unfavorable Matchups
description: Jason and Justin Sablich are here to help you with your fantasy football team. The Sablich brothers will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy).

title: The Harbaughs Sibling Rivalry
description: The Brothers Harbaugh dont quite spark the same moral and ethical questions that the Brothers Karamazov did, although little brother Jims emotionally charged postgame handshake with Detroits Jim Schwartz this season could have been a nice plot device in a sprawling Russian epic.

title: All Shook Up? Try All Boxed Up
description: Are collectors and music nerds now the only people buying albums? Apparently thats the judgment behind many of this years gargantuan boxed sets.

title: Clues to Raymond Chandlers Life and Career in Sale of His Books and Papers
description: The very nicest thing Hollywood can possibly think of to say to a writer, Raymond Chandler wrote, is that he is too good to be only a writer. Chandler may have been only a writer himself, but he was a singularly influential one, whose body of work includes the classic detective novels The Big Sleep and Farewell, My Lovely and contributions to the screenplays for Double Indemnity (written with Billy Wilder) and Strangers on a Train. Now a sale of books and papers from Chandlers personal collection offers a unique look at his legacy and literary influence, not to mention his uneasy relationship with that showmans paradise, as he called it, known as Hollywood.

title: Why Not Pull the Trigger on Greek Default Swaps?
description: The question about why credit-default swaps written on Greek debt will not be triggered by the voluntary exchange of private debt that is in the works has been the subject of much recent commentary but little deep analysis.

title: Man Cleared of 1978 Newark Killings; He Says Doubts Will Linger
description: NEWARK  Lee Anthony Evans, a mason, plumber and father charged last year with committing five cold-case murders that no one could prove ever happened, turned around and went back to his old life on Wednesday with the same scowl he wore at his arrest.

title: Health Tips From the Thankgiving Help Line
description: The Dining section has been fielding questions from readers about Thanksgiving quandaries, including health-related concerns among holiday diners.

title: Continental Drift in Manchester
description: From their lofty perch at the top of the English Premier League, Manchester City and Manchester United have a combined record of 20-1-3, a gaudy combined goal differential of plus-48. But after Tuesdays games in the UEFA Champions League, both teams from Englands northwest are in danger of not progressing past the group stage of the top continental club tournament.

title: From a Military Wife, Words on War
description: In 2001, I was standing on a street, watching a plane hit a tower and watching bodies, the bodies of people who were jumping out of windows, watching them fall through the sky and down. I ran that day, away from the fiery towers and dust. And in the days that followed, I ran away from the rubble, away from New York City  all the way to another state, where I would meet a man who was in the military, who would become my husband.

title: 36 Hours in Porto, Portugal
description: Portugals second-largest metropolis has a jam-packed new nightlife district and a blossoming creative scene.

title: The Art of Destruction
description: YAFRAN, Libya  In a country where creativity was stifled to ensure the pre-eminence of one man, art can be the best revenge. Inside the gutted shell of a building that once housed a Qaddafi-regime intelligence unit, the paint of a new mural of a tree whose roots are feeding on the blood of fallen rebel fighters is drying on the wall. The house was half-destroyed in fighting between Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis forces and the rebels who brought him down  and thats exactly the way the artist Belgassem Grada hopes it will stay.

title: Torture Used on Protesters in Bahrain, Report Says
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Security forces in Bahrain used excessive force, including torture and the extraction of forced confessions, against detainees who were arrested in a sweeping crackdown early this year during protests that deeply polarized the country, according to a report  by an independent commission that investigated the uprising and its aftermath.

title: For Penn State, a Strange Idea of Normal
description: Now that the tide of national outrage has ebbed, moved on to places like Davis, Calif., the atmosphere at Penn State has begun to change. Sure, there are still stories of new victims of the former assistant coach Jerry Sandusky reportedly coming forward and harrowing tales of alleged victims already identified. But they are hardly enough to counter a stronger wave, the pull toward everything getting back to normal at the university.

title: 36 Hours in Porto, Portugal
description: FOR years, Portos motto was, in essence, Youve tried the wine; now try the city! But these days Portugals second-largest metropolis  an attractively faded hillside city of venerable town houses and Baroque churches  no longer needs to coast on the reputation of its famous digestif. A jam-packed new night-life district is taking shape, and a blossoming creative scene features everything from an upstart design center to the avant-garde Rem Koolhaas-designed Casa de Msica, a stunning concert space. And theres great news for oenophiles as well. With the Douro regions emergence as a hotbed of prize-winning red wines  not just port  Porto (also known as Oporto) can now intoxicate you with myriad vintages, new ambitious restaurants and even wine-themed hotels.

title: Winter in Moscow
description: The colder months dont stop the city from enjoying itself. Just bundle up, go ice skating and follow the locals into bustling shops and restaurants.

title: Its Mild Cognitive Impairment. Now What?
description: How would you react to a diagnosis of mild cognitive impairment  memory problems that allow you to continue normal daily activities, but presage an increased likelihood of developing Alzheimers disease within a few years?

title: Giving Thanks for Teachers
The Competition Between Solar and Nuclear Energy Moves to Mars
description: NASAs last two Mars rovers, Spirit and Opportunity, launched in 2003 and carried solar panels, but the new Mars rover that the space agency is scheduled to launch on Saturday morning from Cape Canaveral uses nuclear power, a fact that did not escape the partisans of nuclear power here on Earth.

title: Does Trussing Make the Turkey Cook Faster?
description: Q.

title: In 1962, a Thanksgiving Stunner for Lombardis Packers
description: The undefeated and seemingly unstoppable defending champions from Green Bay sweep down into Detroit, where a determined bunch of Lions await.

title: Moscow in the Snow
description: THEYRE like mountain goats, these women. Skittering up, over and around the ice sheets and the snow slicks on every sidewalk in central Moscow, their spike-heeled boots somehow finding purchase on the sharp, crusty surface. Some of them are texting while they do it.

title: G+ Hangout | November 22, 2011
description: Jenna Wortham and Sam Grobart discuss technology, social networking and journalism with The Timess Google+ community in their first video hangout.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Re What Makes an Airline Family Friendly? (In Transit blog, Nov. 4), I travel with my 3-year-old daughter a few times a year and I always bring snacks, toys and books for her and something to drink. Im not clear why parents expect the airlines to provide them with things for their child that they can easily bring from home. I do feel sympathy for the mother separated from her 2- and 5-year-old, though. That is sheer lunacy!

title: Its Not the Carriers, Its the Kids
description: HORRIBLE. Annoying. Distasteful. Miserable. These are a few of the words used by readers to describe traveling with children  whether their own or someone elses  on planes in response to my Nov. 6 article, Are We There Yet? When Families Fly.

title: Where to Find Treasure in Trash
description: AMY HUGHES turns junk into treasure.

title: Hands Off, Mom and Dad. This Tablet Is for Children.
description: Created specifically for children, Nabi is a $200 Android tablet from Fuhu that doesnt kid around when it comes to things like the ability to plug into a HD screen, by way of a mini-HDMI port, or a multitouch screen that plays real apps like Cut the Rope and Fruit Ninja.

title: Gifts Upon Gifts

title: Youre Driving a Bus Full of Kids With a Curve Ahead
description: [2:43 p.m. | Update |  Theres now a searchable cache for the newly disclosed East Anglia e-mails. Heres the Revkin search result.]

title: Downtown Beirut Finds Its Pulse
description: A new city center is emerging with a number of alluring new independent art galleries, fashion showrooms, stylish restaurants and cocktail lounges.

title: Oakland Gets a New There
description: ON a recent warm afternoon in the Uptown neighborhood of Oakland the streets were alive with activity. Crowds participating in Art Murmur, a monthly art walk, spilled out of galleries like Johansson Projects (2300 Telegraph Avenue; johanssonprojects.com) and Hatch Gallery (492 23rd Street; hatchgallery.org). Its hard to imagine that this area, just north of downtown Oakland, was abandoned and plagued with crime just a few years ago. Now it bustles with hip bars, places to hear music and interesting restaurants that have even lured San Franciscans across the bay.

title: More Than a Road Trip
description: While other photo collectives have done fine group work, Luceos project on rural America, Few And Far Between, stands out.

title: Hotel Review: Desert Riviera, Palm Springs, Calif.
description: THE UPSHOT

title: On Eve of 2011 Finale, Formula One Faces Problems From a Strange Land Called America
description: Formula One, the open-wheel race series, subsists on high drama. But after the 2011 season concludes with the Brazilian Grand Prix on Sunday in So Paulo, off-track intrigues from a land long shunned by the sport, the United States, await reconciliation by race officials and teams.

title: White House Turkeys Walk the Walk, Talk the Talk
description: WASHINGTON  A presidents work is never done.

title: Haciendas and Pulque in Tlaxcala, Mexico,
description: Escaping the hazy-brown air of Mexico City for a traditional rural town of big skies and history.

title: What Can I Do to Lighten Up Thanksgiving?
description: What can I do to lighten up Thanksgiving dinner?  John M., Overland Park, Kan.

title: Di Fara Pizza Reopens After Passing Inspection
description: The popular Brooklyn restaurant Di Fara Pizza reopened around noon on Wednesday, a week after the city health department closed it for 67 sanitary violations, including mice and fly infestation.

title: Amid Scandal, Chairman of Troubled Lender Will Quit
description: HYDERABAD, India  SKS Microfinance, a once-admired lender to poor Indian women that has had a stunning fall from grace in the last year, said Wednesday that its executive chairman, Vikram K. Akula, would step down from his post.

title: An Old-World Escape Near Mexico City
description: I ARRIVED in Tlaxcala, the small capital of Mexicos smallest state, on the Sunday before Mexican Independence Day, Sept. 16. The town was overlaid with banners and lights in the red, green and white of the national flag. At dusk, there were celebratory firecrackers and, in the morning, the cloudless sky was a piercing aquamarine.

title: Pimp My Gun
description: Its illegal to import high-powered, semiautomatic weapons unless they are recognizably for sporting purposes.

title: For American Samoa, a Win Ignites a World Cup Dream
description: APIA, Samoa  American Samoa had played 30 mens soccer matches since starting international play in 1994. It had lost all 30, by a combined score of 229-12, and was tied for last in the FIFA world rankings.

title: Q. and A. With Pat LaFontaine on N.H.L.s Progress on Head Injuries
description: Pat LaFontaine spoke Monday about Sidney Crosbys return from the concussion that kept Crosby out for 10 months for an article in todays Times. But LaFontaine, the scoring star of the 1980s and 90s whose career was marked by a series of concussions, spoke at much greater length and depth on the subject.

title: My Brother Owes Me $25,000. Do I Ask Him for the Money Before or After We Carve the Turkey?
description: Q.

title: Finding the Cheap Gaps in the Holiday Calendar
description: Looking for inexpensive holiday-time getaways? Go for the dead zones: the weeks between Thanksgiving and Christmas, or right after New Years.

title: Links for Thanksgiving Eve
description: First, the really bad news: Spains famously long lunches appear to be under threat. Everything else pales next to that.

title: Our Teenage Photographer of Teenage Lust
description: Please meet last weeks cover photographer, Olivia Bee. Shes 17, and its a challenge to describe her without using the word wunderkind. She started taking photos at 11, quickly established a devoted cult following and has since exhibited her work all around the world. Olivia has an exceptional way of capturing the sweet side of being a teenager. Her photos are romantic and innocent-seeming, even when the kids in the pictures are doing not-so-innocent things. So of course we thought shed be perfect to shoot our cover story about sex-positive sex education. The concept was to illustrate teenage lust without actually showing anything. No faces and nothing explicit, just gestures.

title: Drakes Rise and Adeles Record on the Album Charts
description: This week on the pop music charts, Drake has a big opening and Adele breaks a record set by Michael Jackson.

title: The Supper Clubs of Wisconsin
description: From Madison to Milwaukee, these old-fashioned fine-dining establishments are still going strong.

title: In Wisconsin, Supper Clubs Open to All
description: IN the era of the eyedropper-wielding cocktail artiste, I take pleasure in the fact that there are still guys like Tom Kelly around. Mr. Kelly, the longtime bartender at the Al-Gen Dinner Club in Rhinelander, Wis., has a neatly trimmed gray mustache, wears a shamrock tie pin and makes what I will unreservedly call the perfect gin martini. It is served limpid and glacially cold with two plump olives (or, if youre feeling particularly old-school, two pickled mushrooms) and a minimum of conversation. Im just part of the real estate, he said genially when asked how long hes been at the job.

title: Back to the 50s, Trying to Escape Freedoms Pitfalls
description: IVE never understood why slide shows were supposed to be this terrible thing to be put through, said the playwright Jordan Harrison, recalling the prevideo age. I thought they were endlessly fascinating  people would put in this carousel, and I would see their cruise to Capri, and there would be photos of the menu with their oysters Rockefeller.

title: Heel Height Times Tweets?
description: THE 1920s notion of a hemline index, in which the economist George Taylor posited that skirt lengths rise and fall in relation to the economy, suggests that fashion is socially determined. In a modern twist, a report about the direction of high heels, issued by I.B.M., proposes that fashion can now be determined through social media.

title: As Investors Flee Groupon, Outlook for I.P.O.s Darkens
description: Unable to break a three-day slide, shares of Groupon tumbled again on Wednesday, as more investors dumped shares.

title: James Murdoch Has Quit British Newspaper Boards
description: LONDON  James Murdoch, widely seen as the heir apparent to the News Corporation global media business of his octogenarian father, Rupert, has stepped down as director of two subsidiaries that publish Murdoch-owned newspapers in Britain, the company said on Wednesday. It was the first publicly acknowledged adjustment in the younger Mr. Murdochs newspaper responsibilities since the British tabloid phone hacking scandal that has enveloped the company.

title: Himalayan Highway
description: A frozen river becomes a highway connecting Zanskars few dozen villages to the rest of the world during a two-month window in the heart of the Himalayan winter.

title: A Himalayan Highway, but Only in Winter
description: WE had been walking on the slick, frozen surface of the Zanskar River for 20 minutes when Urgain Dorjay, our lead guide, motioned for us to halt. He squinted up at the rock face, uncharacteristically tense as a voice called out from above.

title: Can Record Shops Make Themselves Heard on Black Friday?
description: When Record Store Day began in 2007, the idea was to create a sort of retail holiday that would help out struggling music shops  and celebrate the successful ones  by offering exclusive releases by big-name musicians. That year about $30,000 worth of special records were sold at stores, according to Michael Kurtz, a founder of Record Store Day and the president of Music Monitor Network, a coalition of independent shops.

title: Kielbasa
description: ITS not quite the same as a sausage fest. Kielbasa is the name of a new gay party held every two weeks in the traditionally Polish neighborhood of Greenpoint, Brooklyn. While the name may sound lewd or over-the-top camp, the party itself is pretty tame.

title: New School Is Squeezed Between Landlord and Occupiers
description: 6:11 p.m. | Updated

title: Nibbles for Holiday Entertaining
description: Mark Bittman prepares simple, sophisticated bites for your holiday platter.

title: Obamas Pick to Head Medicare and Medicaid Resigns Post
description: WASHINGTON  Dr. Donald M. Berwick, the official in charge of Medicare and Medicaid, who became a symbol of all that Republicans dislike in President Obamas health care policies, said on Wednesday that he was resigning.

title: TimesCast | November 23, 2011
description: Yemens president agrees to step down; protesters gather in Tahrir Square for a fifth day; and a peculiar Thanksgiving tradition lives on in Washington.

title: Pictures of the Day: Cairo and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Egypt, Yemen, South Korea and Switzerland.

title: All About Food
description: Updated: November, 2014

title: The Cunningham Countdown: An Exhibition at the Walker Art Center
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Merce Cunningham, John Cage and Robert Rauschenberg are seated in a row and talking about their artistic partnership, delighted to be together. This is in a 1987 filmed interview thats playing on perpetual loop in the current Cunningham/Rauschenberg exhibition at the Walker Art Center here. There was a carte blanche trust, says Rauschenberg about their radically modernist collaborations between 1952 and 1977, in which music, dance, and design were brought together only in performance or at dress rehearsal. Independence was to be respected.

title: Retailers Push Fed for Yet Lower Debit Fees
description: WASHINGTON  Retailers won a big victory last summer when the Federal Reserve halved the fees that banks and credit card companies were charging them to process debit card transactions.

title: Given a Reprieve, Tipsarevic Falls Again (Literally)
description: It had all been going so well for Janko Tipsarevic.

title: Mothers Create a Grammar Guide for the Text Generation
How Are We Defining College Readiness?
Fewer Viewers Tune In for Dancing and Singing
description: While the two-hour season finale of Dancing with the Stars on ABC was the highest rated program of the night on Tuesday, it was unable to reach the bars set by previous season-ending episodes of that show. When J.R. Martinez won the title, 19.4 million total viewers tuned in, down from 24 million last year, with a 23 percent drop in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic. It was the lowest rated fall finale ever for Dancing in the 18-to-49 category.

title: What Are Snacks I Can Serve That Are Not Too Filling?
description: Q.

title: Ex-Khmer Rouge Leader Blames U.S.
description: PHNOM PENH  A Khmer Rouge leader told a court Wednesday that a secret campaign of U.S. bombing during the Vietnam War had contributed to the rise of the radical Communist movement that ravaged Cambodia three decades ago in one of the bloodiest episodes of mass killing in the last century.

title: Politics? Nah, Too Easy. Lets Talk Religion.
description: Gail Collins: David, we almost always talk about politics. Today lets pick something less contentious. How about religion?

title: 7 in Renegade Amish Group Charged With Assaults
description: Federal agents arrested the leader of a renegade Amish group and six others in eastern Ohio on Wednesday and charged them with hate crimes for a series of beard- and hair-cutting assaults against Amish men and women.

title: N.B.A. and Players Resume Negotiating, With Christmas Day in Their Sights
description: Negotiations to end the N.B.A. lockout have quietly resumed, with the goal of reaching a deal in time to stage a 66-game season that would start Christmas Day.

title: A Question of Fairness
description: A tempest in a coffee pot is bubbling in the world of fair trade, the socially responsible food movement that seeks to lift farmers in the developing world out of poverty by offering them a premium for crops like coffee, cocoa and bananas. And the fight will soon reach your local Starbucks, Wal-Mart and Whole Foods.

title: Fatalism and the American Dream
description: Two of my colleagues have alluded to a recent Pew Research Center report on American exceptionalism, paying particular attention to the fact that Americans are more likely to say their culture is superior to others than are people in Germany, Spain, Britain or France.

title: 20-Year Sentence for Text Messages Against Thai King
description: BANGKOK  A retired truck driver was sentenced to 20 years in prison on Wednesday for sending cellphone text messages that a court deemed insulting to Thailands monarchy.

title: James Murdoch Has Stepped Down From Newspaper Boards
description: James Murdoch has left his position on the board of the News Corporation subsidiaries that oversee the companys British newspaper unit including The Sun, a tabloid, and The Times of London, according to British regulatory filings made public on Wednesday.

title: Can I Make Stuffing and Mashed Potatoes Today?
description: Can I, and should I make the stuffing and mashed potatoes the day before Thanksgiving? Gwen, NYC

title: Sugarland Is Sued By Victims of Indiana Stage Collapse
description: A lawsuit filed by 44 survivors and the families of 4 people who were killed when a stage collapsed in August at the Indiana State Fair has named the country band Sugarland in the suit, along with producers and other organizers of the concert, The Associated Press reported. Sugarland, the country music duo of Jennifer Nettles and Kristian Bush, was minutes away from performing at the fairgrounds in Indianapolis on the evening of Aug. 13 when a gust of wind that exceeded 60 miles per hour caused the stage to collapse. The accident, which occurred hours after a severe thunderstorm watch was issued, resulted in the deaths of seven people and injuries to dozens more, and video of the frightening scene spread rapidly across the Internet.

title: Lens: Refer to Sunday Review Anastasia Taylor Lind Feature

title: Children of the Hyphens, the Next Generation

She was about as likely to take my fathers name as she was to sport a veil at the wedding. She would remain Ms. Tuhus. Nine months later, the surname for their new baby (me) was self-evident. My parents yoked their names into a new one: Tuhus-Dubrow.

title: Mamas Boy
description: The concept novel, like its musical equivalent, has always been a risky endeavor. At its ingenious best  Nabokovs Pale Fire, say, or more recently, David Mitchells Cloud Atlas  the result has moved the needle of serious fiction forward, proving, as it nowadays must always be proved, that the novel is a still-evolving form. For a certain type of author this is rarefied and intoxicating air, a culmination of years of experimentation with voice and structure. That the atmosphere so far up is also cluttered with spectacular misfires and out-of-print debris only makes the challenge that much greater  or foolhardy.

But the great pleasure of such physically daunting novels is that theres room for the reader to wander for weeks, lost in the world the author creates. Unfortunately, in Parallel Stories, one is too often merely lost.

title: What Muncie Read
description: As we lurch into the digital age, people are kicking up hoary generalizations about Americans and their reading habits. No one reads anymore, Kids used to read Hamlet, not Twilight,  We used to have more time to read. But these canards are based upon conjecture, anecdote and idealized views of the past. In fact, we know very little about which books Americans used to page through: the history of reading is largely circumstantial, based upon diary entries or sales figures.

title: A Slice of Heaven in Amsterdam
description: AMSTERDAM  The 17th-century houses and narrow streets that line Amsterdams three main canals are deemed so exceptional that Unesco added the area to its World Heritage List in 2010. Many of the houses were built during Hollands Golden Age in the 1600s; any alterations to their gabled facades are strictly forbidden.

description: Readers, the Thanksgiving Help Desk works both ways, and now we need your help. We received the following question, combed our archives and asked our in-house experts, but we did not turn up anything that met this description:

title: Digital Downloads Sub for Weighty Scores
description: Digital gadgetry has increasingly been making its mark on classical music performance. It hit a milestone this week at the New York Philharmonic. Jeffrey Kahane, the pianist and conductor who is making a guest appearance at the orchestra, used an iPad on Tuesday instead of a score to lead the orchestra in a Mozart symphony.

title: Standing by Their New Musical, Fingers Crossed
description: When the $16 million musical Wonderland flopped on Broadway in May, after New York critics once again eviscerated the work of its composer, Frank Wildhorn, theater investors envisioned a bulls-eye target on his next show, Bonnie & Clyde. A few pulled their money out of that Broadway-bound musical, recalled one of its lead producers, Kathleen Raitt, while others dropped from a $250,000 to a $25,000 commitment.

title: Classical Conducting? Theres an App for That
description: Jeffrey Kahane offered glimpses of both the past and a possible future in his performance with the New York Philharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall on Tuesday evening. In the first half of the program he conducted works by Bach and Mozart from the harpsichord, a nod to the practice of the time, and later he was both soloist and conductor in Beethovens Piano Concerto No. 1. He played the Beethoven from memory, but for the Mozart, he used an iPad instead of a conventional score. Seeing the device perched on the harpsichords music stand called to mind the cover of Wendy Carloss Switched-On Bach album, on which the bewigged composer stands before a Moog synthesizer, though the iPad is elegantly miniature by comparison.

title: An Actress and a Role Balance Two Worlds
description: The playbill for the new Broadway comedy Chinglish identifies the actress who plays Xi Yan as Jennifer Lim. But on her passport, Ms. Lims given name is Zhenhua, whose meaning can be translated as authentically Chinese.That very quality helped Ms. Lim win the role of the imperious Chinese government bureaucrat who becomes the unexpected ally of a hapless American businessman in David Henry Hwangs play, her Broadway debut. Born in Hong Kong and trilingual in English, Mandarin and Cantonese, Ms. Lim, 32, saw in the character of Xi Yan traits that strongly reminded her of her own family and background and was quick to incorporate them into the performance.

title: Generous Exuberance, Inspired by the 1980s, Fresh From France
description: Outside of, say, gospel or disco, pure ecstasy  not the sexual kind, necessarily  can get short shrift in pop music. Cynicism is often the preferred mode, every moment of optimism and good will threatened by at least one shadow. Listening to an artist express sheer joy has become rare, a pleasure so unfamiliar it sometimes no longer feels like pleasure, but shock.

title: A Cornucopia of Thanksgiving Multimedia
description: My Thanksgiving Day will begin in earnest around 8:30 a.m. with the starting gun of the Port Washington Turkey Trot, the five-mile road race through my hometown. I took an unconventional approach to training this year  I began carbo-loading in August. Ill be easy to find on the course; just look for the drooling vultures overhead. And then sometime Thursday afternoon, my mother will roll out a Thanksgiving dinner for 30, which the 10 of us will dutifully attack as if we are the Spartans at Thermopylae. Surviving these two feats of strength and endurance, I will have earned some serious couch time, and thus will commence the perfect Thanksgiving multimedia extravaganza:

title: Lets See Whats Inside That Pretty Head
description: IN general, movies would rather look at women than analyze them  except when the lady in question is (at least apparently) a little screwy. David Cronenbergs Dangerous Method seems an unlikely subject for a film: its about the beginnings of psychoanalysis, when Sigmund Freud (played by Viggo Mortensen) and Carl Jung (Michael Fassbender) were trying to figure out the best techniques for teasing revelations from the reluctant subconscious of a disturbed patient. But because the analysand, a young Russian woman named Sabina Spielrein, is played by the lovely Keira Knightley, her mental-health issues are therefore interesting, just as they were when the sufferer was Ginger Rogers (Lady in the Dark), Olivia de Havilland (The Snake Pit), Joanne Woodward (The Three Faces of Eve), Tippi Hedren (Marnie), Catherine Deneuve (Repulsion), Gena Rowlands (A Woman Under the Influence), Isabelle Adjani (The Story of Adele H.), Liv Ullmann (Face to Face), Jessica Lange (Frances), Naomi Watts (Mulholland Drive) or Natalie Portman (Black Swan). Some of the movies disturbed women get the proper treatment  psychiatric and cinematic  and many do not, but even when the analysis fails, the looking remains.

title: Language and the Limits of Coherence
description: Robert Ashley, certainly since composing the groundbreaking multimedia opera Perfect Lives from 1977 to 1983, has been a profound and evocative storyteller, however obliquely his tales may resonate. Language  the idioms, cadences and signature jargon of spoken American English  is central to Mr. Ashleys idiosyncratic conception. Even so, his fusion of text, music and stage action rarely refutes a tenuous connection to opera as conventionally defined.

It is far from the first time that Irish and African-American dance have crossed paths. The braiding of those traditions over a few centuries is what gave the world American tap dance.

title: Like His Creator, a Busy Guy
description: Michael Connelly begins The Drop as if its a work already in progress. Maybe thats because there is always a Connelly project in progress, or so it seems. So far this year he has already published The Fifth Witness and welcomed the  film version of his novel The Lincoln Lawyer. He also played himself in a couple of short films, one on the making of The Lincoln Lawyer. And these are only the parts of his life that have been well publicized. Theres no mistaking the fact that Mr. Connelly is a busy guy.

title: Tracy Letts Steps in, Complete With Speedo
description: The actor John Mahoney has left the Steppenwolf Theater Company production of Penelope in Chicago because of a death in his family, allowing the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright (and actor) Tracy Letts (August: Osage County), left, to take his place in the cast, the theater company announced. Mr. Letts joined the Steppenwolf ensemble in 2002. Penelope, by the Irish playwright Enda Walsh, is a comedy directed by Amy Morton, a member of the company. Scheduled to open next Thursday, it is set on an island off the coast of Greece, where a contemporary Penelope awaits her husbands return from war and serves as the object of competition among four Speedo-clad men  including Mr. Letts  camped in an empty swimming pool.

title: Students Take Reins and Find Their Way
description: The orchestral studies program at the Juilliard School, as at most conservatories, is geared mainly toward teaching conductors to lead and players to follow. But if that has long been the standard model of symphonic performance, it is no longer the only one. With the success of the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra, the art of building an interpretation and performing it without a conductor has gained currency, and now Juilliard is teaching that method as well.

Its a rather obvious visual metaphor for Mr. Elos brand of slice-and-dice choreography, but it could also be the poster for many a ballet company these days: half-classical, half-contemporary, stuck together with no real sense of a governing vision or even personality.

description: Its pretty easy to conclude that the world is spinning down the toilet.

title: An Earlier November in the New World
description: On Thanksgiving its usual to think back to that first feast, one far better known in custom and imagination than it is in fact. What is certain is that in 1620, when the Mayflower was rounding into shoal waters near Cape Cod, there was little reason, apart from faith, to expect that the settlement its passengers hoped to found would succeed. By the following autumn more than half of the 101 humans on board the Mayflower would be dead.

title: On Aging Baby Boomers, and the Question of Where to Live
description: The 72 million American baby boomers, born between 1946 and 1964, are turning 65 at the rate of roughly 10,000 a day, and many are considering not just how to age (with or without annuities? soy sauce? crows feet?), but also where. Wid Chapman, an architect, and Jeffrey P. Rosenfeld, a gerontologist who specializes in the relationship between aging and the built environment, collected 33 examples of residences that have been recently designed to bridge the distance between ones vital and declining years.

title: Back to the Land in the Catskills
description: The farm where Fabio Chizzola, a fashion photographer, and his wife, Laura Ferrara, a stylist, have made a home.

title: An Upstate Farm Brings a Fashion Photographer Back to His Roots

title: East Hampton Opens Its Doors
description: On Saturday, architecture and design enthusiasts will have a chance to peek inside five impressive private residences in East Hampton, N.Y.

title: A Collapsible Shower Stall, From Duravit
description: Open Space, a new product from Duravit, is, simply put, a collapsible shower stall.

title: 10 Young Upstarts Strut Their Stuff in Miami
description: The upstart design exhibition Inventory 02: Soul Does Matter opens in the Miami Design District on Saturday, at 7 p.m., three days before the more established Design Miami show. The curator, Thais Fontenelle, described it as a chance to promote 10 wonderful young-and-upcoming designers, whose prices start at $100.

title: Marazzi Italian Tile Opens a New York Showroom
description: Marazzi, the Italian tile company, opened its first New York showroom this month, in the Flatiron district.

title: Breaking Through the Clouds at the Debate
description: Amid the bombast and hooey at Tuesday nights Republican presidential debate, a few candidates took sensible and occasionally even courageous positions.

title: The Day After Thanksgiving: Enough Said
description: All items at Dinosaur Designs will be 20 percent off Friday (the Art-range Abstract Scoop Salad Bowl, pictured, originally $560, will be $448); 211 Elizabeth Street (Prince Street), (212) 680-3523 or dinosaurdesigns.com.au.

title: In a Year Dominated by Scandal, Some Rays of Hope
description: In a year when sports too often melted into scandal, its even more important on Thanksgiving to remember those who deserve a thank-you note:

title: Witness in Councilmans Trial Says His Signature Was Forged
description: A man who ran two nonprofit groups that were closely associated with City Councilman Larry B. Seabrook testified on Wednesday that his signature was forged on contracts and time sheets for Mr. Seabrooks girlfriend and one of his sisters, both of whom received payments from the groups.

title: China: Fatal School Bus Crash Heightens Calls for New Standards
description: Chinas government had been drafting new safety standards for school buses for two years when an accident last week killed 21 preschoolers and two adults, a state newspaper reported. Many Chinese were outraged by the crash, in which a nine-seat minivan crammed with 62 children rammed into a coal truck in Gansu Province. Xu Mei, a spokeswoman for the Ministry of Education who was quoted in The Legal Mirror of Beijing, said at least 10 government agencies had been researching school bus systems for two years and had collected good experience from schools with good solutions. She said the Education Ministry had ordered the standards to be quickly issued in the wake of the crash. The priority now, the article quoted her as saying, is to make sure that there will be no more accidents with existing school buses.

title: Opening Day for Shoppers Shows Divide
description: As the busiest retail weekend of the year begins late Thursday night, the differences between how affluent and more ordinary Americans shop in the uncertain economy will be on unusually vivid display.

title: Mets Owners Will Face Jury if Madoff Case Goes to Trial
description: The owners of the Mets will face a jury should there be a trial in the case filed against them by the trustee for the victims of Bernard L. Madoffs fraud, a federal district judge ruled Wednesday. The Mets owners had opposed a jury trial.

title: 2 Views on Subway Project: Delay Work to Clear Air, or Carry On and Profit Sooner
description: Francisco R. Quijada and Gus Sofronia, both longtime business owners along Second Avenue, know how frustrating the construction of the new subway line can be. Both have watched their businesses suffer from the huge enclosures that have been built in front of their buildings. And both have asked customers to ignore the steady drilling and hammering that emanate from beneath their feet.

title: The Poor, the Near Poor and You
description: What is it like to be poor? Thankfully, most Americans do not know, at least not firsthand. And times are tough for the middle class. But everyone needs to recognize a chilling reality: One in three Americans  100 million people  is either poor or perilously close to it.

title: Penn State Testimony Requested
description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa.  Local judges have recused themselves from handling the Jerry Sandusky sexual abuse case, and lawyers for two Penn State officials who were indicted for perjury have begun to raise questions about the background of the prosecutions chief witness, himself a Penn State assistant coach.

title: Shopping for Carving Sets
description: Jessica Applestone of Fleishers Grass-Fed and Organic Meats searched for distinctive carving sets.

title: Carving Sets
description: CARVING a turkey is a very greasy, messy operation, even in the best of circumstances, said Jessica Applestone, a butcher who owns Fleishers Grass-Fed and Organic Meats in Brooklyn and Kingston, N.Y., with her husband, Josh. You want to be alone in the kitchen with a pair of rubber gloves, a really sharp knife and a big glass of booze.

title: Secrets of a Great Spiral: The Grip and the Release
description: Organized Thanksgiving football is believed to date to 1876, when the Intercollegiate Football Association decided to schedule its inaugural championship game on the holiday. The first professional game to be played on Thanksgiving came almost a half-century later, in 1920, when Fritz Pollard and the Akron Pros defeated Jim Thorpe and the Canton Bulldogs, 7-0.

title: France: Noriega to Be Extradited
description: A Paris court on Wednesday approved the extradition of Panamas onetime dictator, Manuel Antonio Noriega, left, to his homeland, clearing the way for his return after two decades in French and American prisons. Prime Minister Franois Fillon of France signed an extradition order for Mr. Noriega, 77, earlier this year, but a date of departure has not been determined, officials said. Panamanian courts have convicted Mr. Noriega in absentia in connection with the killing of political opponents, as well as on charges of embezzlement and corruption. He faces three 20-year prison terms in Panama, which he ruled from 1983 until 1989, when he was ousted by an American invasion. Convicted in a United States court in 1992 on charges including drug trafficking, Mr. Noriega was imprisoned in Florida before his extradition to France last year. A French judge sentenced him to seven years in prison on charges that he laundered $3 million in Colombian drug money through international banks and into French accounts in the late 1980s. The Panamanian president, Ricardo Martinelli, has vowed that Mr. Noriega will serve his Panamanian sentences in prison, and not under house arrest, despite his age and reported ill health, according to The Associated Press. The A.P. also quoted Mr. Noriega as telling the court through an interpreter: I want to return to Panama and prove my innocence.

title: Egypts Unfinished Revolution
description: More than 100,000 Egyptians did not risk their lives in Tahrir Square last winter just to see another military-backed tyranny. Military leaders  supposedly only running things until civilians can be elected  have used the nine months since they helped oust Hosni Mubarak to try to stifle democratic change and protect their own power.

title: Corruption Case Against Developer Is to End
description: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan have agreed to drop charges against a real estate developer who was charged in the political corruption case that ensnared State Senator Carl Kruger and seven other people, according to a court document.

title: Second Coalition Leader in Greece Backs Debt-Relief Deal
description: ATHENS  After refusing to do so for weeks, the leader of New Democracy, the second-largest party in Greeces interim government, sent a letter to the countrys foreign creditors on Wednesday pledging to support a debt-relief deal. But it was not clear whether the move would break a political deadlock that was preventing Greece from receiving badly needed rescue funds.

title: Kyrgyzstan Sees Instability at End of Afghan Mission
description: The departing president of Kyrgyzstan, the small but strategically important Central Asian country that houses a vital American air base for supplying the NATO war effort in neighboring Afghanistan, expressed deep concern on Wednesday about the potential for a contagious economic collapse in Afghanistan when foreign military forces withdraw.

title: Lottery Numbers
Liu, Under Scrutiny, Is Returning Donations
description: John C. Liu, the embattled New York City comptroller, has begun to return thousands of dollars in campaign contributions in the wake of a federal investigation into his fund-raising practices, his campaign said Wednesday.

title: Muslim Brotherhood Struggles to Find Its Balance in Egypts Whirlwind
description: CAIRO  New divisions in the Muslim Brotherhood appeared on Wednesday as a senior leader hinted that it might walk away from a deal struck with Egypts interim military rulers, reflecting signs of confusion and hesitation as the Brotherhoods most viable bid for power in eight decades has become tangled in the uncertainty and anger gripping Egypts streets.

title: First, He Blew the Whistle on Olympus. Next, He Wants to Lead Its Comeback.
description: TOKYO  When Olympus fired Michael Woodford, its British chief executive, in October, the company said he had been unable to conform to Japanese-style management.

description: OZARK, Ark.  Brenda Farmer and Willie Blanscet have sat across from each other on the Butterball bagging line for 17 years, 102 cold, raw turkeys sliding by in front of them every minute.

title: Amid Signs of Rebellion, Putin Seeks Tighter Grip
description: MOSCOW  With parliamentary elections 11 days away, Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said Wednesday that the country could not afford to let political opposition or disagreement jeopardize stability, sovereignty, the welfare of the people, and he implored lawmakers to unite behind his tightly controlled rule so that the boat does not really turn over.

title: Thursday: Alphabet Quartet
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  I have to say right off the bat that I really enjoyed solving this puzzle  there were some great entries and clues here  but Im not sure the theme worked for me. Maybe Im just being too picky. Ill leave you to decide.

title: NYT Front Page for 11/24/2011
description: NYT Front Page for 11/24/2011

title: Turkey: Apology for 30s Massacres
description: Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan publicly apologized for the killings of thousands of Kurds in the southeast part of the country by the Turkish military from 1936 to 1939. If it is necessary to apologize on behalf of the state, I will apologize, and I am apologizing, Mr. Erdogan said in a televised speech during a party meeting in Ankara. The apology, however, followed the recent arrests of thousands of Kurdish activists, including academics, writers, lawyers and prominent social figures, on terror-related charges as part of the governments campaign against the Kurdish insurgency. Nearly 14,000 Kurds were killed in attacks by the army and air force in Dersim, which is now called Tunceli.

title: Gingrichs Words on Immigration Become a Target
description: DES MOINES  An intense debate over immigration flared among the Republican presidential candidates on Wednesday as Mitt Romney declared that Newt Gingrich offered a new doorway to amnesty when he called for a humane immigration policy to avoid deportation for people who are deeply rooted in their churches and communities.

title: Spotlight Back on Kerry, but Reshaped Role Eludes Him
description: WASHINGTON  A feverish scrum of reporters was in such pursuit of Senator John Kerry last Friday that he was chased all the way from a Senate meeting room to the subway under the Capitol, where in the chaos a blizzard of secret papers from debt reduction talks went flying from his arms. It was an inelegant moment, particularly for a onetime Democratic nominee for president, but Mr. Kerry stooped down and gathered up his own documents before he made an escape.

title: How the Day Will Play Out: Butterfat, Nickelback and Fantasy Quarterbacks
description: The games start at 12:30 p.m., 4:15 p.m. and 8:20 p.m. Eastern. The turkey goes in the oven just after dawn. The family is told to arrive at 2 p.m. sharp, which means they come sometime between noon and Saturday. Thanksgiving is the holiday you set your watch to, especially if you are a football fan. Here is a minute-by-minute breakdown of Thursdays festivities, on and off the field.

title: Canadian Court Rules That Polygamy Ban Is Constitutional
description: OTTAWA  British Columbias Supreme Court ruled Wednesday that Canadas 121-year-old criminal law banning polygamy is constitutional.

title: Israel Halts Payments to Palestinians, Adding to Fiscal Woes
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  The Palestinian Authority, in over its head financially as foreign donors renege on pledges and local banks have reached their limits, has an even more serious money problem: Israel is refusing to transfer tax and customs payments that account for two-thirds of its revenue.

title: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Thursday
description: Indias two key stock indexes plunged more than 2 percent on Wednesday, weighed down by a slumping rupee and a global economic downturn that shows no sign of abating, Mint reports. The Sensex dropped 2.27 percent Wednesday, and is down 10.6 percent in the last 10 trading sessions, the paper reports. The broader Nifty dropped 2.2 percent. The rupees slide continued, which raises the price of crucial imports and further imperils the governments hopes of robust growth this year.

title: Ruth Stone, a Poet Celebrated Late in Life, Dies at 96
description: Ruth Stone, a poet who wrote in relative obscurity until receiving the National Book Award at the age of 87 for her collection In the Next Galaxy, died on Nov. 19 at her home in Ripton, Vt. She was 96. Her death was announced on Tuesday by her daughter Abigail Stone.

title: Anne McCaffrey, Author of Dragonriders Fantasies, Dies at 85
description: Anne McCaffrey, a science-fiction writer widely known as the Dragon Lady for her best-selling series of young-adult novels, Dragonriders of Pern, died on Monday in County Wicklow, Ireland. She was 85.

title: Andrea True, Singer of Disco Hit, Dies at 68
description: Andrea Truden arrived in New York from Nashville in 1968 with a yearning for stardom and no fixed idea about how to achieve it. She landed bit parts in a slew of movies, including The Way We Were. She sang in nightclubs, wrote music for television commercials and, for a while, found steady work as an actress in the citys burgeoning pornographic film industry.

An exception that continues today is Crawford Market, in South Mumbai, where residents and visitors alike can find Western items like Camay soap, Kraft cheese, Fa deodorant or a pack of Pampers diapers.

title: Switched at Rebirth
description: When the musical On a Clear Day You Can See Forever opened on Broadway in 1965, the main character was Daisy Gamble, a daffy young woman who turned out to be the reincarnation of a 18th-century English aristocrat named Melinda Wells. The shows composer, Burton Lane, wrote lush melodies to reflect the dreamy Daisy, while Alan Jay Lerners script was a star vehicle for Barbara Harris, playing both Daisy and Melinda. On hand to propel the plot was another character, a psychiatrist who draws out Melinda through hypnosis and then falls for her.

title: Sparkling, Swooning and Suffering Wordlessly
description: Remember the old days, when movies were glorious, magical and mute? Neither do I. But the passing of the silent era from memory into myth is what The Artist, Michel Hazanaviciuss dazzling cinematic objet dart, is all about. This is not a work of film history but rather a generous, touching and slightly daffy expression of unbridled movie love. Though its protagonist mourns the arrival of sound, The Artist itself is more interested in celebrating the range and power of a medium that can sparkle, swoon and suffer so beautifully that it doesnt really need to have anything to say.

title: Get Her to the Greek
description: The word sandal has Hellenic origins. So it makes sense that the Greek native Christina Martini chose the island of Crete for embarking on her first footwear line, Ancient Greek Sandals. Our idea was to make our sandals look like they were archaeological finds but with a modern twist, says Martini, who spent a number of years designing shoes at Balenciaga and Louis Vuitton before branching out on her own. With subtle nods to the goddesses  Persephone, Aphrodite and Athena  the sandals vegetable-tanned leather and handmade construction will merit compliments of mythic proportions.

title: How Can I Get My House Ready in a Hurry?
description: This isnt quite dining and wine, but I bet you can help anyway. Im having a dozen of my in-laws to dinner on Thursday. Cooking, baking and beverages are under control, but not my house. How about some tips about getting the house ready? Anything from cleaning to setting a festive table. (For extended seating, well use our picnic table, which wont leave much room to maneuver in either the living room or dining room.) Jennifer, Syracuse, N.Y.

title: Bob Dylans Songs Honoring Amnesty International
description: The year 1962 produced two debuts: the establishing and formal naming of Amnesty International as a permanent human rights advocate, according to its official history, and Bob Dylans first album. Nearly 50 years later, those two facts will become indelibly joined when a benefit recording project of Mr. Dylans music is released. More than 80 performers are covering four CDs worth of his songs, numbering about 75, Amnesty said. The album is called Chimes of Freedom: The Songs of Bob Dylan Honoring 50 Years of Amnesty International and will be released in North America on Jan. 24 and elsewhere on Jan. 30. The performers include Sting, Patti Smith, Pete Seeger, Miley Cyrus, Joan Baez, Jackson Browne, Maroon 5 and Elvis Costello. Most of the recordings are being released for sale for the first time, except for Chimes of Freedom, recorded by Mr. Dylan in 1964, Amnesty said.

title: Do I Really Have to Chill a Pie Crust for Three Hours?
description: Q.

title: National Gallery Cracks Down on Scalped Tickets
description: The National Gallery in London says it is cracking down on ticket-scalping for a major exhibition of the works of Leonardo da Vinci, which opened on Nov. 9. BBC News reports that the gallery will enforce warnings that resold tickets will be cancelled without refund and admission will be refused to the bearer, and is asking resale Web sites to halt the practice. The museum declined to say how it would identify scalped tickets, according to the BBC. The show has drawn large crowds, and on Thursday, the U.K. eBay site listed the starting bid for a pair at up to $250 and the Viagogo site had a ticket as high as $389.01. Tickets through the museum cost 16 pounds, or about $25. Leonardo Da Vinci: Painter at the Court of Milan runs through Feb. 5.

title: Ilan Bracha
description: Mr. Bracha, 36, is the chairman of the newly opened Manhattan office of Keller Williams Realty  Keller Williams New York City. Before opening the franchise earlier this year, the Israeli-born Mr. Bracha was a managing director of Prudential Douglas Elliman and, through his Bracha Group, one of Ellimans top-producing residential brokers.

title: How Can I Peel the Inner Skin Off Chestnuts?
description: Q.

title: Spreading Inner Peace, but Living With Turmoil
description: Crazy Wisdom, Johanna Demetrakass documentary about Chogyam Trungpa, a Tibetan who was instrumental in bringing Buddhism to the West, clearly loves its subject well. Too well. Ms. Demetrakass film bathes in Trungpas glow and spends much time with his followers, who talk about his teachings and his impact on their lives. (He died in 1987, at 48.) But the movie goes mushy when it should be critical, and leaves you with questions that its not prepared to answer.

title: Wish List for a Fairy Tale End to the Season
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  The titles were already decided four races ago, but the seasons final race in So Paulo this weekend already looks like a big party. The paddock was full of journalists and other visitors on Thursday and the drivers were in a mood to sum up their seasons.

title: Wish List for a Fairy Tale End to the Season
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  The titles were already decided four races ago, but the seasons final race in So Paulo this weekend already looks like a big party. The paddock was full of journalists and other visitors on Thursday and the drivers were in a mood to sum up their seasons.

title: Spare Times for Nov. 25-Dec. 1
description: Around Town

title: Spare Times: For Children, for Nov. 25-Dec. 1
description: Untapped!

title: Theater Listings for Nov. 25-Dec. 1
description: Theater

title: What Should I Do if My Turkey Is Ready Early?
description: Q.

title: Movie Listings for Nov. 25-Dec. 1
description: Movies

title: Pop and Rock Listings for Nov. 25-Dec. 1
description: Pop

title: Jazz Listings for Nov. 25-Dec. 1
description: Jazz

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings for Nov. 25-Dec. 1
description: Classical

title: Dance Listings for Nov. 25-Dec. 1
description: Dance

title: Where Exactly Is the Thickest Part of the Thigh?
description: Q.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for Nov. 25-Dec. 1
description: Art

title: A Kings Verse Fails to Prevent His Decline
description: Richard II is essentially one long, lilting diminuendo, as Shakespeares titular monarch philosophizes and blunders his way into an early grave. J. R. Sullivans production for the Pearl Theater Company struggles at times to maintain the dramatic tension along this silver-tongued but lead-footed course, yet it does have the distinction  surprisingly rare for a troupe that relies heavilyon its versatile resident actors  of finding a role ideally suited to one of its performers.

title: How Do You Get Stains Out of Tablecloths?
description: Q.

title: Displaced, Disaffected and Desperate to Connect
description: The English title of A Brighter Summer Day, Edward Yangs chronicle of disaffected youth in Taiwan in 1960, comes from Are You Lonesome Tonight?, which was a hit for Elvis Presley that year. One of the teenagers in this sprawling, melancholy and surpassingly beautiful film sings in a rock n roll band, and he tries, phonetically and with the help of a friends sister who studies English, to decode the songs haunting, enigmatic lyrics.

title: The Life of a Courtesan, Viewed From the Inside
description: Madeline (Alice Barnole), the tragic figure at the heart of Bertrand Bonellos somber, hypnotic film House of Pleasures, is a prostitute known as the woman who laughs at LApollonide, an elegant Parisian brothel at the end of the 19th century. Early in the movie, when she entertains a handsome young client who produces an emerald, she wonders out loud if the gift is a proposal.

title: How Do I Carve the Turkey?
description: Q.

title: How Do I Know if My Turkey Is Cooked?
description: Q.

title: Packers Undefeated as Lion Is Tossed
description: DETROIT  As the defending Super Bowl champions, the Green Bay Packers go into every game expecting to absorb their opponents best shot. This was especially true on Thursday when they faced their division rival from Detroit in a game that abounded with hype and hope and history.

title: How Long Should I Let My Turkey Rest Before Carving?
description: Q.

title: The Thanksgiving Help Line Signs Off
description: The Help Line is closing down for the holiday. Hopefully by now, your turkey is roasting to crispy perfection, your potatoes are mashed, your table is set. Maybe youve even eaten and are fighting it out for the leftovers. (And yes, it is socially acceptable to have brought your own Tupperware.)

title: A Saloon on Staten Island
description: Adobe Blues stands out for its garish Southwestern dcor, beer selection and music.

title: Mosey In and Wet Your Whistle
description: PEOPLE tend to quicken their pace when walking along Staten Islands north shore, where a cold industrial landscape can make even the most stoic New Yorker feel bleak. For many on Lafayette Avenue, though, their destination is a cozy refuge with amber lights that hint at subtropical warmth: Adobe Blues Restaurant.

title: European Court Overturns Rule on Illegal File Sharing
description: PARIS  The highest court in the European Union said on Thursday that Internet service providers could not be required to monitor their customers online activity to filter out the illegal sharing of music and other copyrighted material.

title: Photo Replay: Nov.24
description: A look at the day in sports, from Thanksgiving football to kangaroos at the Australian P.G.A.

title: Loan Request by Uranium-Enrichment Firm Upends Politics as Usual
description: WASHINGTON  The only American-owned company capable of enriching uranium is asking for government help to modernize its plant and remain in business.

title: Chocolate-Filled Love Story With Marshmallow on Top
description: Enjoyment of Jean-Pierre Amriss confection, Romantics Anonymous (Les motifs Anonymes) may depend on your taste in chocolate. If you prefer it dark and bittersweet, this delicately flavored but sugary treat could cloy. For everyone else, the tale of two pathologically shy chocolate makers who are meant for each other but are too afraid to connect is a mug of warm cocoa with marshmallow topping that produces a comfy feel-good glow.

title: Getting Reacquainted With an Old Friend
description: To anyone who regularly attends choral concerts in New York, Kent Tritle is surely a name to be reckoned with. As the organist and choral director of the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola on Park Avenue from 1989 until this summer, Mr. Tritle nurtured one of the citys most formidable music programs. Factor in his activities as the music director of Musica Sacra and the Oratorio Society of New York, his regular show on WQXR-FM and his steady roles with the New York Philharmonic, the Juilliard School and the Manhattan School of Music, and Mr. Tritle can seem ubiquitous.

title: Portugal Downgrade Hurts Stocks in Europe
description: PARIS  European stocks and the euro fell Thursday after a credit agency cut Portugals sovereign debt to junk, or below investment grade.

title: Michael Grandage To Form Theater Company
description: Michael Grandage, director of the Donmar Warehouse theater and known to New York audiences this season for his Metropolitan Opera production of Mozarts Don Giovanni, is striking out on his own. Mr. Grandage is leaving the Donmar in London at the end of the year, and in an interview with that citys Evening Standard said he would form his own commercial company, without a home base. After 15 years running established companies, It seems entirely appropriate to think about what I can take from those years, form a company thats buildingless and go out and make work, he told the newspaper. It feels right at 49. The Evening Standard said that he and his executive producer at the Donmar, James Bierman, have formed Michael Grandage Productions. Mr. Grandage said he also hoped to make an independent movie.

title: ABC Wins Ratings
description: With the other networks taking a holiday from their regular prime-time schedules, ABC emerged as No. 1 in all ratings categories on Wednesday thanks to its usual comedy lineup. A new episode of Modern Family led the way, with 12.6 million total viewers, followed by The Middle, at 9.1 million, according to Nielsen estimates. Elsewhere, a special Wednesday live results episode of The X Factor drew 8.5 million total viewers and put Fox in second place for the night in the advertiser-coveted 18-to-49-year-old demographic. CBS was in third place with a slate of repeats and a recap episode of Survivor: South Pacific.

title: 3 Blasts Kill at Least 10 at Market in Southern Iraqi Oil Port
description: BAGHDAD  A series of three explosions in a crowded market on Thursday killed at least 10 people and wounded dozens more in the southern city of Basra, an important center of the Iraqi oil industry where many international companies have offices.

title: An Electronic Eye on Hospital Hand-Washing
description: Beeps and blinking lights are the constant chatter of a hospital intensive care unit, but at the I.C.U.s in North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, N.Y., the conversation has some unusual contributors. Two L.E.D. displays adorn the wall across from each nurses station. They show the hand hygiene rate achieved: last Friday in the surgical I.C.U., the weekly rate was 85 percent and the current shift had a rate of 91 percent. Great Shift!! the sign said. At the medical I.C.U. next door, the weekly rate was 81 percent, and the current shift 82 percent.

title: Measuring Risks at Europes Banks
description: European banks are about to indulge in some sleight of hand. Though they have been told by regulators to raise 106 billion euros ($143 billion) of capital by next summer, that does not mean they will issue that amount of new equity.

title: Womens Professional Soccer Fights to Keep Its Top Status
description: The top professional soccer league for women, which has only five teams, is in danger of losing sanctioning from US Soccer, the sports governing body in the United States.

title: Top Womens League in Danger of Losing D1 Sanctioning
description: The top-flight professional soccer league for women, which has only five teams, is in danger of losing sanctioning from US Soccer, the sports governing body in the United States.

title: Pushing On-the-Go Gadgets, Google Makes Its Pitch in Mobile
description: THE song Blues in the Night includes a line that begins, From Natchez to Mobile, from Memphis to St. Joe. Now, marketers are studying the results of a campaign that extends from Mountain View to Mobile.

title: No N.B.A., So Basketball Fans Turn to the A.B.A.
description: The streets were eerily desolate last Friday night in downtown Richmond, the East Bay city where unemployment hovers around twice the national average. But outside the Richmond Memorial Auditorium, which recently hosted a womans roller derby match and a local amateur boxing night, fans lined up to see the brand-new Richmond Rockets professional basketball team.

title: Egypt Orders 3 American Students Released, and Journalist Is Assaulted in Detention
