description: CAIRO  An Egyptian court on Thursday ordered the release of three American students who had been arrested during protests in Cairos landmark Tahrir Square, and an Egyptian-American journalist said that she had been beaten and sexually assaulted while in detention.

title: For Online Retailing Holdouts, a Final Holiday Season of No Sales Tax
description: California shoppers have one last chance to avoid paying state sales taxes on many of their online purchases this holiday season.

title: As Fewer Americans Serve, Growing Gap Is Found Between Civilians and Military
description: WASHINGTON  A smaller share of Americans currently serve in the Armed Forces than at any other time since the era between World Wars I and II, a new low that has led to a growing gap between people in uniform and the civilian population, according to a new survey.

title: Overhauling the Post Office for the 21st Century
description: The United States Postal Service spent its 200th year fending off default and pleading with Congress to give it the authority to compete in the booming world of e-commerce. Designed as a quasi-private business run without public financing, the Postal Service, nevertheless, is firmly under the thumb of the Capitol, where compromise is urgently needed if the service is to profitably reform.

title: Why We Spend, Why They Save
description: Princeton, N.J.

title: Morocco Vote Will Be First Since Reform of Parliament
description: RABAT, Morocco  Under pressure from the Arab Spring uprisings, King Mohammed VI of Morocco proposed a new constitution last summer providing for a more empowered Parliament. On Friday, voters will go to the polls to determine its makeup.

title: The Life Reports
description: A few weeks ago I asked people over 70 to send me Life Reports  little essays in which they evaluate their own lives. A few thousand people have written in, and Ive been posting an essay a day on my blog.

title: The Solyndra Mess
description: The Republicans on the House Energy and Commerce Committee appear to have hit the pause button on their investigation into the failure of Solyndra, a solar panel maker that entered bankruptcy proceedings in September, defaulting on a $528 million federal loan.

title: Italy, Hoping to Raise Billions, Plans Property Sale
description: MILAN  Weeds engulf the asphalt, fig trees droop over the cracked roads and the eight buildings are in poor repair. It takes a good deal of imagination to envision this former air force depot on the outskirts of Milan as home to new apartment buildings, thoroughfares, stores and perhaps even a small park.

title: Battling Over Birth Control
description: In August, Kathleen Sebelius, the secretary of health and human services, announced new rules that included contraceptives for women in the package of preventive health care services that all insurers must cover without a deductible or co-payment beginning next year.

title: Ladybug, Ladybug, Welcome Back Home: Good News for the Official State Insect
description: The bug is back.

title: The Age of the Superfluous Worker
description: AMERICA, like other modern countries, has always had some surplus workers  people ready to work but jobless for extended periods because the job creators, private and public, have been unable or unwilling to create sufficient jobs. When the number of surplus workers rose sharply, the country also had ways of reducing it.

title: Rival Palestinian Leaders Meet but Fail to End Rift
description: JERUSALEM  President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority and the leader of the rival Islamic group Hamas met Thursday and the sides agreed to go ahead with elections in the Palestinian territories next year, according to officials, even as they failed to resolve differences over an interim unity government to prepare for the vote.

title: Support Builds for a Plan to Rein In Medicare Costs
Arkansas Emerges as Unlikely Contender
description: Arkansas Coach Bobby Petrino had seen enough of the bullying of his first-year starting quarterback, Tyler Wilson, by the Alabama defense. When Wilson was shoved to the ground by the outstretched palms of a defensive lineman, prompting an unsportsmanlike-conduct penalty, Petrino waited one more series, then rescued Wilson by taking him out of the game early in the fourth quarter.

title: Shelagh Delaney, Author of the Play A Taste of Honey, Dies at 72
description: Shelagh Delaney, a British playwright and screenwriter who reached the height of her literary fame at 19 as an angry young woman  a characterization she detested  with the premiere of her play A Taste of Honey, died on Sunday at her daughters home in Suffolk, England. She was 72 and lived near Filey, a village in Yorkshire.

title: For War of 1812 Bicentennial, Indifference From Albany
description: SACKETS HARBOR, N.Y.  Clayton F. Nans, a 57-year-old retired Marine colonel, halted his Chevrolet pickup truck near Lake Ontario recently and pointed to a grassy embankment. It was the very spot, he said, where British troops first made landfall in this upstate village, before American soldiers fought off their invasion.

title: Hints of a Comeback as Woods Secures Deals
description: Tiger Woods was the No. 1 golfer in the world when he emerged bruised from a car accident outside his home on Thanksgiving night 2009, and his reputation was tarnished by his subsequent admission of marital infidelities. Now, after two years of injuries, lackluster play and damage control, he appears to be turning a professional corner.

title: It Shouldnt Take a Panic to Spur Responsibility
description: If it is known that the Bank of England is freely advancing on what in ordinary times is reckoned a good security  on what is then commonly pledged and easily convertible  the alarm of the solvent merchants and bankers will be stayed. But if securities, really good and usually convertible, are refused by the Bank, the alarm will not abate, the other loans made will fail in obtaining their end, and the panic will become worse and worse.

title: Iraqs War Widows Find Little Comfort
description: Iraq faces a gender imbalance as decades of conflict have left an estimated one million widows. Many hope, against the odds, to marry again.

title: After Nearly 9 Years of War, Too Many Widows
description: BAGHDAD  Noria Khalaf giggled and then, embarrassed, covered her smile with a fold of her black robes. Yes, she said, she would like to marry again. It had been four years since her husband died, and her children needed a father.

title: Workers Feeling Squeezed by the N.B.A. Lockout
description: NEWARK  For nearly five months, David Stern and Derek Fisher have been the public faces of the N.B.A. lockout. As the leagues commissioner and the president of the players union, they have dueled across the negotiating table and in front of the television cameras while struggling to forge a new collective bargaining agreement.

title: Fridays Deals May Not Be the Best
description: Oren Etzioni writes articles about artificial intelligence for scholarly journals, is a renowned expert on data mining and gained fame when Microsoft paid $115 million for Farecast, an airline-ticket price predictor he founded.

title: Oregon and the Death Penalty
description: Gov. John Kitzhaber took a firm moral stand when he announced that he would halt an execution scheduled in Oregon next month and would block other executions while he is in office, until 2015.

title: Beyond the Record Lows, Data on Police Shootings Offer a Wealth of Details
description: Last year, 52 officers from the New York Police Department fired a total of 236 bullets during confrontations with suspects. About half of the officers used a two-handed grip on their firearm, as the department encourages, while the others shot one-handed. And in a sign of just how tense these 33 separate shooting episodes were, and how rapidly they unfolded, only one officer reported using the guns sight before firing.

title: Idiosyncrasy Runs Deep in the Soil of Wyoming
description: CHEYENNE, Wyo.  The rallying cry of states rights has resonated under many statehouse domes since President Obamas election, fueled as it usually has been in its many appearances over the years by a ferociously conservative anti-Washington sentiment.

title: Voice Messaging Services Aimed at the Masses
description: SINGAPORE  Amitabh Bachchan, one of Bollywoods biggest movie stars, writes a blog and is widely followed on social media. The Big B, as he is affectionately called, started blogging in 2008 and has more than 1.5 million followers on Twitter.

title: Unmasked: Voters in the Harris Poll Take Their Assignment Seriously
description: As college football teams jostle for positions in the Bowl Championship Series standings, questions about the systems efficacy continue to create debate.

title: We Are the 99.9%
description: We are the 99 percent is a great slogan. It correctly defines the issue as being the middle class versus the elite (as opposed to the middle class versus the poor). And it also gets past the common but wrong establishment notion that rising inequality is mainly about the well educated doing better than the less educated; the big winners in this new Gilded Age have been a handful of very wealthy people, not college graduates in general.

title: Cowboys Edge Dolphins and Put Pressure on Giants
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Tony Romo looked and sounded like a veteran quarterback finally ready to shed his image as a gunslinger with superficial numbers.

title: India: Maoist Reportedly Killed
description: The police in West Bengal said Thursday that they had killed a man they believe to be a top leader of the Maoist guerrillas menacing a broad swath of India. The leader, Mallojula Koteswara Rao, was better known as Kishenji and was a top member of the leftist insurgencys politburo. If his killing is confirmed, it will be a major victory for Indian officials, who have been struggling to end the armed struggle in some of the poorest regions of central India. Kishenji often acted as a spokesman for the rebels, giving interviews with his face obscured.

title: To Advance Their Cause, Foundations Buy Stocks
description: Earlier this year, the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation invested $10 million to acquire a stake in Liquidia Technologies, a biotechnology company working on new ways to deliver vaccines.

title: In New York, Mexicans Lag in Education
description: In the past two decades, the Mexican population in New York City has grown more than fivefold, with immigrants settling across the five boroughs. Many adults have demonstrated remarkable success at finding work, filling restaurant kitchens and construction sites, and opening hundreds of businesses.

title: War of 1812
description: War of 1812 sites around New York, as well as the State Archives and other historical organizations, are planning events to celebrate the bicentennial of the war.

title: My End of the Food Chain
description: In a memorable riff of candor, Theodore Roosevelt once spoke of something he felt when going to war, saying he knew what it is like when the wolf rises in the heart.

title: 3 Olympus Executives Resign Ahead of Crucial Meeting
description: TOKYO  On the eve of a highly anticipated board meeting that will be attended by Olympuss ousted president, Michael C. Woodford, the company said the board was prepared to step down once the company was on the road to recovery from an accounting scandal.

title: A Job Too Big for One Title
description: When Sergei Kostitsyn, last seasons leading scorer for the Nashville Predators, flew from Minsk, Belarus, to New York to renew his Canadian visa, he was not met by his agent or a Predators official or someone from the N.H.L but by Susanna Goruveyn.

title: Mexico: 26 Bodies Found in Cars
description: Twenty-six bodies were found inside three abandoned vehicles on a busy road in the heart of Guadajalara, Mexicos second-largest city, state officials said Thursday. Many victims had Milenio Zetas written on their chests. A message was left in one of the vans clarifying that this is a battle between cartels and not with ordinary citizens. It also referred to the governments of Jalisco, where Guadalajara is located, and Sinaloa, where 16 people were found charred on Wednesday.

title: Canada: U.S. Mobster Killed
description: Salvatore Montagna, who once controlled the Bonanno crime family in New York, was murdered near Montreal on Thursday. The Quebec police confirmed that the body of a man was found in a river shortly after witnesses heard gunfire. While the police did not identify the victim, several news organizations reported that it was Mr. Montagna. In 2009, he was deported from the United States to Canada, where he was born before being raised in Sicily. It is widely believed that Mr. Montagna was trying to take control of Montreals organized crime families.

title: Looking Beyond Election Day
description: Most political analysis of Americas awful economy focuses on whether it will doom President Obamas reelection or cause Congress to turn toward one party or the other. These are important questions, but we should really be looking at the deeper problems with which whoever wins in 2012 will have to deal.

title: Officials Push for Clarity on Oil and Gas Leases
description: Federal lawmakers, bank regulators and law enforcement officials are broadening their efforts to ensure that the growing number of oil and gas leases being signed by landowners across the country comply with mortgage rules and do not create new risks for lenders, appraisers or landowners.

title: Image Expert Shapes Romney (His Hair, Anyway)
description: BELMONT, Mass.  Voters routinely ask about it on the campaign trail. Pundits chronicle the slightest changes in its presentation. There is a Facebook page devoted to it  not to mention an entire blog. Has it always been this good? read a recent online entry.

title: Games to Watch on Friday
description: NO. 3 ARKANSAS AT NO. 1 L.S.U.

title: To Teach a Child: The Parents Role
description: To the Editor:

title: In Hard Times, Rethinking Plans for Retirement
description: To the Editor:

title: Neurotic Comedians?
description: To the Editor:

title: Preserving the Amazon
description: To the Editor:

title: African Union Force Makes Strides Inside Somalia
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  When the first batch of African Union peacekeepers landed at Mogadishus decrepit airport in 2007, they were immediately shelled by insurgents with mortars and given little chance of success. This was Somalia after all, the graveyard of several other doomed interventions, and the African Union soldiers were a last resort for a deeply troubled mission.

title: Legalizing Marijuana
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections: November 25
description: NATIONAL

title: Garcia Returning to Yankees
description: The Yankees have agreed in principle to a one-year deal with the veteran right-handed pitcher Freddy Garcia, according to a person who was briefed on the agreement.

title: Broadway Hits Make Most of Premium Pricing
description: The producers of Hugh Jackmans song-and-dance-and-bump-and-grind show on Broadway were so bullish about his popularity that, even before the first performance last month, they raised prices from $155 to $175 on dozens of orchestra seats for the 10-week run. The bet is now paying off handsomely, so much so that the producers are increasing premium prices for the best seats in the house: what were $250 tickets are now going for $275, $325 or even $350, depending on the demand at particular performances.

title: Christopher Ma, Washington Post Executive, Dies at 61
description: Christopher Ma, the Washington Post Companys senior vice president for new business development and publisher of Express, the companys free commuter tabloid newspaper for the Washington area, died in New York City on Wednesday. He was 61 and lived in Washington.

title: Pat Passlof, Painter of Shimmering Abstracts, Dies at 83
description: Pat Passlof, an Abstract Expressionist painter whose canvases vibrate with unpredictable line and thick, luminous color, died on Nov. 13 at her home in Manhattan. She was 83.

title: Lynn Margulis, Evolution Theorist, Dies at 73
description: Lynn Margulis, a biologist whose work on the origin of cells helped transform the study of evolution, died on Tuesday at her home in Amherst, Mass. She was 73.

title: Friday: Cerecloth Feature
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Sometimes I think that ones reaction to a puzzle really depends on ones mood. Todays puzzle by Joe Krozel, while it has some fresh entries and challenges, mostly just left me scratching my head. As always, your mileage may vary.

title: In Cairo, Reflection as Revolt Pivots Again
description: CAIRO  By morning, the first cement block in the wall went up. Then another and another, until no one  not the idealistic youths demanding the revolution go on, not the soccer fans looking for a fight, not the downtrodden simply demanding something more  could see across the street that had emerged as the arena for this weeks uprising in Egypt.

title: Protesters Look for Ways to Feed the Web
description: Social media has played a vital role in the Occupy Wall Street movement since it began as a Twitter experiment in July, when the anticonsumerism magazine Adbusters posted a suggestion for a Sept. 17 march in Lower Manhattan. And over the last two months, protesters used cellphones and social sites like Twitter, Facebook and YouTube to spread their message around the world.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,826 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Wednesday:

title: League Warns Syria to Admit Monitors or Risk Sanctions
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  In a humiliating affront for the Syrian government, Arab foreign ministers called Thursday for Syria to agree to admit international monitors within 24 hours or face economic sanctions, while activists reported new clashes between army troops and defectors that left 29 dead across the country.

title: From a Community Center, Hope and a Holiday Meal
description: They came to Harlem for a communal turkey dinner with all the trimmings. Hundreds of families, many disadvantaged, took part in a tradition that stretches back 21 Thanksgivings: those who cannot afford to carve $50 out of their budgets for turkey, stuffing and cranberry sauce gathering for a meal catered by the Food and Beverage Association of America.

title: 17-Year-Old From China Repeats as Womens Chess Champ
description: In the growing rivalry between the emerging superpowers China and India, Beijing scored a symbolic victory on Thursday: a Chinese woman won a chess match.

title: Five Injured in Brooklyn Fire
description: A fire ignited by careless smoking in bed swept through a Brooklyn row house on Thursday, critically injuring a child and a woman and hurting three others, including a man who broke a third-floor window and scrambled, screaming, to a neighbors awning for safety, officials and witnesses said.

title: A New Kind of Election Monitor in Russia, the Smartphone
description: MOSCOW  When a small-town mayor from Russias governing party recently offered tens of thousands of dollars in government cash to a veterans group in exchange for votes in next months parliamentary elections, it appeared to be business as usual.

title: The Life Report: Hugh Nazor
description: The following Life Report was submitted in response to my column of Oct. 28, in which I asked readers over 70 to write autobiographical essays evaluating their own lives.

title: Fatal Attacks Tied to Raid by Kenya
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  At least four people, three of them civilians, were killed Thursday in a wave of attacks in northern Kenya that the authorities believe were connected to the countrys recent incursion into Somalia.

title: The Life Report: Marguerite E. Moore
description: The following Life Report was submitted in response to my column of Oct. 28, in which I asked readers over 70 to write autobiographical essays evaluating their own lives.

title: The Life Report: Gilda Zelin
description: The following Life Report was submitted in response to my column of Oct. 28, in which I asked readers over 70 to write autobiographical essays evaluating their own lives.

title: Lottery Numbers
Irish Palates, Enticed by Other Carbs, Are Losing Their Taste for a Signature Starch
description: The primacy of the Roman Catholic Church and the centrality of the pub are not the only staples of Irish life under threat. Fresh potatoes are losing their place as the carbohydrate of choice on the Irish plate, prompting a national campaign to arrest the decline.

title: Another Start-Up, but This One Is a Church
description: Aaron Monts, pastor of Ikon Christian Community in San Francisco, stood before his flock on a recent Sunday, resplendent in his version of churchly garb: a tan hoodie, plaid shirt and sneakers.

title: Keeping Marital Secrets Closeted
description: THIS summer, soon after gay marriage became legal in New York, my sons held a wedding for my former husband and his partner of over 30 years. The grandchildren were flower girl and ring bearers. The wedding thrust me back to the time when we faced a terrible choice and decided to stay married for the children. Thats what motivated my then husband and me to carry on our incomplete marriage for its last nine years, and thats how we explained our actions after the divorce. It was a convenient truth, and also a self-serving one.

title: TV Takes a Close Look at a Marijuana Haven, Just Before the Law Does
description: Orange County and Beverly Hills have The Real Housewives. The San Francisco Giants had The Franchise on Showtime last summer.

title: Payments to Doctors by Pharmaceutical Companies Raise Issues of Conflicts
description: Thousands of Texas doctors, researchers and medical experts  including more than 100 who are employed by the state and are paid with taxpayer dollars  routinely supplement their salaries with income from pharmaceutical companies.

title: Colleges Out West, Joining the Big East?
Palins Disappearing Act Holds a Warning for Perry
description: In the array of governors who turned to national politics  a collection that includes four of the last six presidents and a horde of contestants who didnt make it  Rick Perry looks a lot more like Sarah Palin than like George W. Bush. And not just in his politics.

title: Brownsville Protects Chess Legacy at Its Schools
description: Budget cuts may have taken more than $30 million out of the Brownsville Independent School Districts budget for the next two years, but administrators say they are working to preserve financing for one key pot of money: the chess budget. This academic year, it totals $400,000.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

title: For Skilling, There Is No Such Thing as Bad Weather
description: Rain had fallen in sheets all morning, and powerful wind gusts challenged umbrellas. The sunshine that occasionally peeked through an ominous cloud cover was misleading  temperatures would plummet in the afternoon.

title: As Schools Face Closing, New Lines Are Drawn
description: Closing down underperformingpublic schools in Chicago has historically been a traumatic process, with battle lines drawn between affected communities and district leaders.

title: Raising Awareness of Sex Trafficking, One Lecture at a Time
description: Chicago just hosted an infuriatingly insightful show and tell on sex trafficking, with a West Side pimp providing the sordid show and a prominent legal scholar providing the tell.

title: Pantries Face Shuttering if Donations Keep Dropping
description: Twenty years had passed since Lynette Tuck had last set foot in the Albany Park Food Pantry.

title: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Friday
description: The proposed Lokpal, or anti-graft watchdog, could become a constitutional body, the parliamentary panel scrutinizing the bill declared on Thursday. The panel also said that the provision of setting up the Lokayuktas, or state equivalents, will be included in the same bill. There was still no consensus on bringing the office of the prime minister under the Lokpals watch (Hindustan Times).

title: Major Archaeological Find: Graffiti by Johnny Rotten
description: An apartment with graffiti by Johnny Rotten of the Sex Pistols is an important historical and archaeological site, according to a paper published in the journal Antiquity, the BBC reported. Rotten, born John Lydon, drew on the walls of the bands London apartment in 1975 because he disliked a recent redecoration. The tabloid press once claimed that early Beatles recordings discovered at the BBC were the most important archaeological find since Tutankhamens tomb, wrote John Schofield and Paul Graves-Brown, archaeologists at the University of York. The Sex Pistols graffiti in Denmark Street surely ranks alongside this and  to our minds  usurps it. The graffiti mainly consists of eight cartoons drawn in black marker in the upper room of the apartment, now used as offices. The authors say the drawings are a direct and powerful representation of a radical and dramatic movement of rebellion. The art depicts Mr. Lydon and other members of the band, including Sid Vicious and their manager, Malcolm McLaren. The current occupants of the house have said they have no plans to remove the graffiti.

title: NYT Front Page for 11/25/2011
description: NYT Front Page for 11/25/2011

title: Penguin Will Allow Lending Of E-Books, at Least Temporarily
description: Readers who want to borrow Penguin e-books from libraries through their Kindles have won a reprieve. Penguin on Wednesday reversed course and said its e-books on the devices would be available at least through the end of the year, The Associated Press reported. Earlier in the week Penguin said that it would halt the availability because of security concerns. Publishers have grown increasingly nervous that the checking out of e-books remotely from libraries would hurt sales.

title: Another Concert For Philip Glass
description: A fifth concert has been added to a four-day festival early next year in honor of the 75th birthday of Philip Glass. The new concert will feature works by Nico Muhly, Tania Lon, Vijay Iyer and Zack Glass, Mr. Glasss son. The concerts will take place from Feb. 23 to 26 at the Park Avenue Armory, and constitute its second Tune-In Music Festival  the latest example of how the armory is playing an increasingly important role in the New York performing-arts scene. Most of the works during the festival will be by Philip Glass, below. But in the additional concert, scheduled for noon on Feb. 26, Mr. Muhly will perform his own compositions for piano and will be joined by the violist Nadia Sirota; Ms. Lon will play original piano works; Mr. Iyer will perform with the South Indian guitarist Prasanna (who goes by the one name) and Nitin Mitta, a tabla player; and the guitarist and vocalist Zack Glass will perform songs of Ruben Gonzalez, a singer-songwriter, with Mr. Gonzalez.

title: 10 Things That Really Happened on A Very Gaga Thanksgiving
description: Perhaps some time after your Thanksgiving dinner, possibly in a stuporous, tryptophan-induced state, you turned on your television to see a glistening, eyebrowless humanoid engaging in acts for your ostensible entertainment. And while you may have concluded this was all a dream or a hallucination, let us assure you that A Very Gaga Thanksgiving was an actual holiday special that featured the pop star Lady Gaga and was indeed broadcast on the ABC network. And among the real occurrences that happened on this real program:

title: In Manipur, Women Take the Lead
description: India is the land of a million mutinies, in V. S. Naipauls indelible phrase, but almost all the mutinies I have witnessed have been led and populated by men. When the farmers of Uttar Pradesh demonstrate against a new highway, they leave their wives at home. When the Jats agitate for caste-based job and education preferences by sitting on railway tracks, their daughters remain in the village, their faces, in all likelihood, covered by dupattas.

title: From U.S. and Tahrir Square, Pressures Converge on Egypts Military
description: CAIRO  Egypts interim military rulers faced the most significant challenge in a week of escalating protests on Friday as the Obama administration threw its weight behind the Egyptians who flooded into Tahrir Square to demand that the generals relinquish power, and new signs of unity emerged among street protesters and the political elite.

title: For Black Friday First-Timers, Not a Night of Conversion
description: They were the Black Friday novices: people who, drawn by the earlier-than-usual store openings or economic necessity, decided to try their hands at shopping on the busiest day of the retail year.

title: In Vote in Morocco, Many Stay Skeptical
description: CASABLANCA, Morocco  Yassine Bousalim, a 26-year-old chef from the poor neighborhood of Derb Sultan, where lingering smells of garbage fill the air, watched voters come and go on Friday from the polling station across the street, with an air of disgusted detachment.

title: A Sense of Urgency in Africa
description: Robin Hammonds study of the mentally ill in Africa, Condemned, started with a chance encounter.

title: Hong Kong Jeweler Plans $3 Billion I.P.O.
description: 4:19 p.m. | Updated

title: Using Apples Find My Mac Feature
description: The disappearance of a device is far and away the most serious digital security and privacy risk that owners of Apple laptops and mobile devices face.

title: North Koreas Children in Need of Food Aid, Agencies Warn
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Koreas harvests this fall were expected to increase by 8.5 percent compared with a year ago, but the most vulnerable segments of the population, especially young children, still urgently need international aid, two United Nations agencies said Friday.

title: A Dams Unexpected Winners
description: NEW TEHRI, India  I have long harbored a predisposition against dams. Recent history overflows with evidence of the damage wrought by stopping-up ancient rivers, and of the deep social costs that come from driving communities off their ancestral lands, despite the best-laid bureaucratic plans.

title: Suspension Looms for Suh, but for How Long?
description: Taking the temperature in Detroit, where people were steaming after Ndamukong Suh was ejected for dribbling a Packers head against the turf and then stomping on his arm (video available here).

title: Week 12 Matchups: Somethings Happening Here
description: Browns (4-6) at Bengals (6-4)Sunday, 1 p.m.Line: Bengals by 8.5.

title: The Supreme Court and Health Care
description: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

title: Prague Christmas Markets Come Alive
description: While American retailers brace for the post-Thanksgiving shopping rush, cities across Europe are primping for a slightly different kind of holiday tradition: the much-anticipated opening of the regions storied Christmas markets  and Prague is no exception.

title: Q&A: Facebook Photos Missing in Action
description: Q.

title: Should We All Go Gluten-Free?
description: The singer was a no-show. The Gluten Free Expo in Sandy, Utah  one of the nations largest events dedicated to foods untainted by wheat  was going to have to start without the national anthem. But Debbie Deaver, the expos founder, didnt have time to worry about that. The song, to be honest, was the least of her problems.

title: Who Wants to Shop in a Big Box Store, Anyway?
description: As foreign retail giants gear up to enter the Indian market after Thursday nights cabinet decision, discussion is already running hot.

title: Cultivating Gratitude, Theirs and Mine
description: Marjorie Ingall is worried about raising entitled, bratty, ungrateful little weasels. I wish I didnt share this fear, which is magnified every time my children go near any members of our extended family, all of whom walked to school in the snow uphill both ways, chanting Gregorian songs of gratitude to their parents, their God and their country the entire time.

title: Banks Ties to Olympus Scrutinized
description: TOKYO  A number of European banks are under investigation by Japanese authorities to determine whether they helped the management of Olympus hide irregular payments, according to a person with detailed knowledge of the governments continuing investigation.

title: At the Met, One Role Too Many for Its Boss
description: For some time now, most of the talk within and without the Metropolitan Opera has centered on how long the company can continue without a music director in place. James Levine, still grappling with multiple health problems, has not conducted since May. The recent announcement that he would withdraw from the new production of Wagners Gtterdmmerung, which opens on Jan. 27, was sad news but not surprising.

title: Gifts Upon Gifts Upon Gifts
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: The Cultural Osmosis Pop Quiz: Pop-Music Edition
description: Before you see the correct answers below, you can go take the quiz.

title: With Economy Slowing, the Indian Rupee Tumbles
description: MUMBAI, India  For several months, India has suffered the double misfortune of a slowing economy and high inflation. Now, it has another problem: a rapidly depreciating currency.

title: Video: Bringing Fiscal Discipline To The European Periphery
description: And note the explanation of the stability pact at 4:00.

title: Breakfast Meeting, Nov. 25
description: The Egyptian-American journalist Mona Eltahawy took to Twitter on Thursday to say that she had been sexually assaulted by security forces after being arrested at the protests in Cairos Tahrir Square. Her Tweeted reporting on the attacks she suffered during her 12 hours inside the Interior Ministry building has been collected at The Guardian. Her account includes a photo of her arms in a cast, after X-rays showed they had been broken, and her recollection, The whole time I was thinking about article I would write. [The Guardian]

title: Their Own Facts
description: David Frum of Axis of Evil fame  who is some kind of distant cousin of mine  has an excellent piece in New York explaining his apostasy from the modern GOP. Best line:

title: Retirement Islands for Orangutans
description: An innovative plan to create man-made islands for sick and injured orangutans in Indonesia is offering hope of a better life for animals who have previously been destined to spend their remaining days in cages.

title: Latest Updates on Black Friday Sales
description: If youre going out to shop for Black Friday deals now, youd better hurry  some stores opened in time for Thanksgiving dessert. So far, our correspondents, the news services and Twitter are all reporting good crowds at many malls across the country. But are they buying? The Lede blog follows New York Times retail reporter Stephanie Clifford and the Black Friday action through most of the day.

title: Murky Signals for Congress on Insider Trading
description: It took a recent report on 60 Minutes to galvanize Congress into action after the program criticized members who made profitable securities trades based on information they had learned on Capitol Hill. In a recently published book, Throw Them All Out, Peter Schweizer asserted that members of Congress may be exempt from some insider trading laws.

title: Sunday in the Magazine
description: Hugo Lindgren, editor of The New York Times Magazine, presents his first video editors note previewing the stories in Sundays issue.

title: Death By Accounting Identity
description: Martin Wolf has a somewhat despairing-sounding column this morning, in effect pleading with the Cameron government to admit that the laws of arithmetic must apply. Good luck with that.

title: Black Friday Shoppers Come Out at Night
description: With many stores moving back their opening times for Black Friday deals to Thanksgiving night, some shoppers said they came for the deals, and others to extend their holiday celebrations.

title: Sweden Proposes Higher Capital Requirements for Banks
description: LONDON  The Swedish government proposed higher capital requirements for the countrys largest banks Friday as authorities sought to strengthen Swedens financial system in the midst of the European debt crisis.

title: Shoppers Are Staying Home and Logging On This Season
description: As stores lure shoppers with Black Friday deals as early as Thanksgiving Day, many shoppers are planning to stay on their couches and shop online.

title: This Sunday: Chubbs Visits the Magazine
Early Scuffling at Black Friday Sales
description: Black Friday got off with a bit of turmoil in some cities, with news agencies reporting at least some pushing and shoving, but also flare-ups of violence. A 55-year-old woman was shot and wounded during a robbery around 1 a.m. that Myrtle Beach, S.C., police say was related to Black Friday shopping, according to The Associated Press.

title: Consultants in the Cloud
description: Earlier this week we published an article about Google Apps, and Googles struggle to displace Microsoft Office and Sharepoint inside large corporations. While Google has worked without a large consulting partner, it should be said that several smaller consultancies are working to encourage companies to adopt Googles cloud-based office productivity software.

title: The Not-So-Invisible Empire
description: Imagine a political movement created in a moment of terrible anxiety, its origins shrouded in a peculiar combination of manipulation and grass-roots mobilization, its ranks dominated by Christian conservatives and self-proclaimed patriots, its agenda driven by its members fervent embrace of nationalism, nativism and moral regeneration, with more than a whiff of racism wafting through it.

title: How It Went
description: Kurt Vonnegut died in 2007, but one gets the sense from Charles J. Shieldss sad, often heartbreaking biography, And So It Goes, that he would have been happy to depart this vale of tears sooner. Indeed, he did try to flag down Charon the Ferryman and hitch a ride across the River Styx in 1984 (pills and booze), only to be yanked back to life and his marriage to the photographer Jill Krementz, which, in these dreary pages, reads like a version of hell on earth. But then Vonneguts relations with women were vexed from the start. When he was 21, his mother successfully committed suicide  on Mothers Day.

title: So Much Depends
description: William CARLOS WILLIAMS was a furious poetic revolutionary  furiously working over a lifetime to reinvent American poetry, furious at poetry he considered backward, and at critics and editors who didnt get it. To many, including me, he was the greatest poet of the 20th century. Unlike Eliot and Pound, two of his rivals in importance, he refused to be an expatriate. When Pound wrote him from overseas, urging Williams to leave America, Williams incorporated the advice into a brutally terse and powerful poem in praise of staying home. He spent virtually all his life in Rutherford, N.J., close to the American voices that enthralled him. He was determined to make them the basis of a new poetic diction, one that has hugely influenced American poets and poetries since. Its not too much to say he was our Dante, making a distinctively American language out of slang, jokes, complaints and rants. Williams did this by endlessly reworking heavily enjambed line breaks and stanza breaks in exquisitely casual and deceptively ordinary poems  a red wheelbarrow shining after a rainstorm, a fire engine tearing through city streets, a woman whose body is covered with moles. He did this alone, and largely ignored by the mediocre stars of American literary life. His capacious, rigorously humane work has a delicacy of ear that hasnt yet been surpassed. All this, and poetry was his night job  his days were spent as hardworking Dr. Williams of North Jersey.

title: A Good Run
description: This is a difficult time in which to present an account  and what amounts to a defense  of the Wests rise to pre-eminence and its unequaled influence in shaping the world today. The West is on the defensive, challenged economically by the ascent of China and politically and militarily by a wave of Islamist hatred. Perhaps as great a challenge is internal. The study of Western civilization, which dominated American education after World War II, has long been under attack, and is increasingly hard to find in our schools and colleges. When it is treated at all, the West is maligned because of its history of slavery and imperialism, an alleged addiction to war and its exclusion of women and nonwhites from its rights and privileges. Some criticize its study as narrow, limiting, arrogant and discriminatory, asserting that it has little or no value for those of non-European origins. Or it is said to be of interest chiefly as a horrible example.

title: Enthusiasms
description: Jonathan LETHEMS hefty and remarkable new miscellany, The Ecstasy of Influence, is his fifth book since his best-selling breakthrough of 2003, the hefty and remarkable bildungsroman Fortress of Solitude. It follows the fanciful story collection Men and Cartoons (2004), the memoiristic criticism collection The Disappointment Artist (2005), the rock novel You Dont Love Me Yet (2007), and the, well, hefty Manhattan novel Chronic City (2009). There have also been side projects, including They Live, a book-length critical essay about the John Carpenter film, and Believeniks, a pseudonymous collaboration about the 2005 Mets. And thats not counting the five 90s novels (and two story collections). The man writes a lot.

title: In the Air, On the Sea
description: t times during the months after the Japanese attack of Dec. 7, 1941, a tall, patrician-looking Japanese-speaking American could be seen wearing a red smoking jacket and bedroom slippers, puffing on his pipe and pacing the concrete floor behind an unmarked basement door at the Pearl Harbor Navy Yard in Hawaii: Joseph Rochefort was the leader of Station Hypo  the rapidly expanding group of green-eyeshade-wearing analysts who were working 22-hour days, among candy-bar wrappers and pictures of pinup girls, in the race to crack JN-25-B, Japans all-important wartime code.

title: George F. Kennan
description: To the Editor:

title: Real Housewife of the Renaissance
description: Attention, sisters! Tired of office politics? Sick of petty intrigue, backstabbing and gossip-filled boardrooms? Disheartened by the bombastic spectacle of national political campaigns? Confused about how women are supposed to have it all  motherhood, military might, the presidency  and wondering why you would even want to? Meet the Renaissance countess Caterina Riario Sforza de Medici. She has some lessons for us.

title: War and Intelligence
description: To the Editor:

title: Ristretto | Woodsman Tavern
description: On a recent swing through Portland, Ore., I took note that that standard price for a drink in any of a number of the towns more diligent cocktail bars is $8. Sometimes its $6, sometimes its $10, but $8 seems to be the magic number  for that sum youll get a cocktail impeccably crafted in flattering light by somebody with the shoulders to pull off Pendleton Plaids. Advantage: PDX.

title: The Ad Man Behind Occupy Wall Street, and Buy Nothing Day
description: Theres a fascinating article in the New Yorker by Mattathias Schwartz that is largely about Kalle Lasn, a rogue retired marketing consultant I interviewed just before Thanksgiving, 2007  the first year of this blog  about his Buy Nothing Day campaign.

title: In Native Witch Hazel, a Stunning Endnote
description: See a larger version of the forest from this week. Compare with the enlarged version of last weeks image.

title: Australia Approves SABMillers Takeover of Fosters, With Conditions
description: LONDON  Australian authorities gave their approval to SABMillers proposed $11 billion takeover of a brewing rival, the Fosters Group, but added conditions to the deal.

title: Another View: A Fair Way to Handle Madoff Claims
description: Katharine Gresham was assistant general counsel for appellate litigation and bankruptcy at the Securities and Exchange Commissions Office of General Counsel from 1990 to 2010.

title: Friday Reading: Ten Gift Ideas for the Frugal Traveler
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: A Redo for Q in New James Bond Movie
description: Even if you cant remember who James Bonds adversary was in a given movie or what Agent 007 was supposed to be saving the world from, you can probably recall the nifty, surreptitious and often lethal gadgets provided to him by Q, the pseudonymous tech wizard of Her Majestys Secret Service. The characters Q division was named in Ian Flemings novels, and a forerunner of the character, called Major Boothroyd, appears in the inaugural Bond film, Dr. No. But the avuncular Q is most closely associated with Desmond Llewelyn, the actor who played the role in 17 Bond movies beginning with From Russia With Love (in 1963) and ending with The World Is Not Enough. John Cleese took over the character briefly, and Q has so far made no appearances at all in the rebooted Bond films starring Daniel Craig. But all of that  cue that jazzy theme music  is about to change.

title: Black Friday Shoppers Come Out at Night
description: With many stores moving back their opening times for Black Friday deals to Thanksgiving night, some shoppers said they came for the deals, and others to extend their holiday celebrations.

title: Another View: Sarbanes-Oxley and the Legacy of Enron
description: Michael W. Peregrine, a partner at the law firm of McDermott Will & Emery, advises corporations, officers and directors on issues related to corporate governance, fiduciary duties and internal investigations.

title: Olga Bloom, Violinist and Violist Who Created Bargemusic, Dies at 92
description: If music can salve the soul, imagine hearing it accompanied by the balm of a rivers undulations, the twinkle of the Manhattan skyline, the soothing flow of river traffic. Audiences at Bargemusic, the citys floating concert hall moored at Fulton Ferry Landing in Brooklyn, have that experience several nights a week. It is one of the more magical places on the classical music scene and, for that matter, in all of New York.

title: Six Named as Finalists for Hugo Boss Prize
description: The Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation has announced six finalists for its 2012 Hugo Boss Prize. The $100,000 prize, named for the German mens wear company that sponsors it, is given every two years to an individual who has made an important contribution in contemporary art. In addition to cash, the winner is awarded an exhibition at the Guggenheim Museum in New York.

title: Egypt Military and Protesters Dig In for a Long Standoff
description: The White House urged Egyptian interim military rulers to handover power as tens of thousands of demonstrators poured into Tahrir Square.

title: Leading Off: The Stomp That Roared
description: O.K., lets see if we have this straight: Lions defensive tackle Ndamukong Suh spends the season whining about being called a dirty player, pouts his way to the commissioners office for an explanation of why referees keep littering his vicinity with yellow flags and generally carries on like a 5-year-old bully who keeps getting dragged to the principals office, and he tries to sway your opinion of him by stomping a Packers player in a Thanksgiving day game?

title: Focusing on the Jewish Story of the New Testament
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Growing up Jewish in North Dartmouth, Mass., Amy-Jill Levine loved Christianity.

title: Death By Hawkery
description: What the world needed in this global deleveraging crisis was deficit spending and higher inflation targets. What it got was fiscal austerity and obsessive concern with inflation risks that werent real. Hence the catastrophe now unfolding.

title: Hockeys Ties to Special Events
description: Growing up on Long Island, Kevin Gilroy dreamed of playing hockey in Madison Square Garden. He finally got there two years ago  only to see 16,000 people in red and white. Cornell fans, that is.

title: Up Front: Robert Christgau
description: Reviewing Jonathan Lethems new essay collection, The Ecstasy of Influence, on Page 15 this week, the eminent rock critic Robert Christgau lets on that he favors Lethems nonfiction over most of his fiction. I love novels, Christgau said in a recent e-mail. I was an English major like so many rock critics, and I bonded with my fiction-writing wife over Sister Carrie and The Man Who Loved Children. But though I read a few dozen novels a year, I dont keep up. In 2011 I preferred Eudora Weltys Losing Battles and Colm Toibins Brooklyn to Jennifer Egans Visit From the Goon Squad, some old Martin Beck mysteries to a recent Henning Mankell.

title: Did You Need Us to Tell You That Twilight Could Cause Seizures?
description: Setting foot into a screening of The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn  Part 1, the latest installment in the hit film series about the romance between a mortal girl and a sparkly vampire boy, may induced an unexpected kind of overstimulation: a few viewers say they have experienced epileptic seizures that, The Guardian reports, could be a result of rapidly changing colors in the films climactic childbirth scene.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE MEMORY CHALET,  by Tony Judt (Penguin, $15.) Before he died in August 2010, of a motor neuron disease that left him clearheaded but immobile, the historian Tony Judt dictated a series of vivid autobiographical sketches. Each brings the smallest details of personal experience  home, food, travel, education  into the larger frame of history.

title: The Minds Ear
description: Morning commute in America. I was fully conscious, but there were no more thoughts. Then I felt drawn into what seemed like a vortex of energy. . . .  At the wheel of her Subaru, driving east on (perhaps) the Massachusetts Turnpike, a woman is afloat on, adrift in, the Germanic guru-tones of Eckhart Tolle. Raw winter light irradiates the car, fixing every scratch on the windshield in a constellation of worldly damage, and Tolles voice  deep but somewhat nasal, as if he has a tiny Jedi Master lodged in his sinuses  snuffles spiritually from the speakers. I could feel myself being sucked into a void. . . . Suddenly there was no more fear.

title: Will in the Middle
description: Shakespeare scholarship is one of the worlds thriving industries, with no factories but worldwide workshops. While you are reading this, there must be hundreds (thousands?) of worthies turning out articles and books from pole to pole. But Garry Wills has upped the ante with a simultaneous pair of books. Though modest in size (hardly a drawback), they gain added interest from being the works of an eminent historian who has frequently ventured elsewhere  e.g., to the Roman poet Martial and St. Augustine  but here strikes out into, for him, not entirely new but for many of us surprising territory.

title: Soul Man
description: Ahmet Ertegun was the first person to ask Ella Fitzgerald for her autograph, in 1935. He lived long enough to party for days on end with Kid Rock and Pamela Anderson, and died in 2006, after falling backstage at a Rolling Stones show on the Upper West Side. It wasnt the prettiest, most dignified death. But Ertegun  who appreciated good jokes, bad women, booze, bad jokes and good women, in any given order  would have enjoyed the obituaries.

title: Two Brains Running
description: In 2002, Daniel Kahneman won the Nobel in economic science. What made this unusual is that Kahneman is a psychologist. Specifically, he is one-half of a pair of psychologists who, beginning in the early 1970s, set out to dismantle an entity long dear to economic theorists: that arch-rational decision maker known as Homo economicus. The other half of the dismantling duo, Amos Tversky, died in 1996 at the age of 59. Had Tversky lived, he would certainly have shared the Nobel with Kahneman, his longtime collaborator and dear friend.

title: Get Stuffed | A Cup o Pumpkin Pie
description: Before you devour your second (third?) slice of Moms leftover homemade pumpkin pie, opt for a still seasonal but healthy alternative: an organic, sugar-free pumpkin pie smoothie. Created by Dr. Frank Lipman, the founder and director of the Eleven Eleven Wellness Center in Manhattan  which promotes good medicine, like lifestyle changes through diet, nutrition, exercise and stress management  this dessert complies with his challenging but not impossible 14-day-long Be Well food-and-shake cleanse ($200). The gluten-free treat substitutes unsweetened vanilla almond milk for cream and calls for organic pumpkin and a little raw honey or cinnamon in place of sugar. When you eat sugars, your body gets an initial surge of energy, your body scrambles to process it, and then you crash, Lipman says about sugar, a depression-linked carbohydrate. This process triggers the body to crave more sugar, and a vicious cycle of craving, eating and crashing begins. Sounds alarmingly familiar, eh? On the bright side, Lipman does promote a lot of sleep to combat sugar cravings around the holidays. The easy-to-follow recipe is below, so you can nap and have all the taste of pumpkin pie you want this holiday season.Pumpkin Pie Smoothie  Serves 1

title: For Hallberg, a Month Inside the Bolshoi Pressure Cooker
description: For the South Dakota native David Hallberg his appearance on the storied main stage of the Bolshoi Ballet last Friday was, he said beforehand, probably the most important appearance of his career  a stress-filled test of whether the Bolshois artistic director, Sergei Filin, had made a good bet in bringing him to Moscow as the companys first American principal dancer.

title: Wedding Etiquette
description: Inviting Co-Workers

title: Inconspicuous Consumption
description: No man but a blockhead ever wrote except for money, Samuel Johnson declared. As the Internet is destroying the business model that has historically supported high-quality journalism, movies, music and television, the conventional wisdom in Silicon Valley is that Johnson was wrong. Information wants to be free, because the cost of getting it out is getting lower and lower, technology activists have insisted, selectively quoting the technology thinker Stewart Brand. (In fact, Brand said in the same 1984 speech that on the other hand, information wants to be expensive, because its so valuable.) According to the worldview embodied by Google and Facebook and many of the best minds in the legal academy and public-interest community, the culture business is collapsing because the old-style media executives who run Hollywood, cable television, the record companies and newspapers have failed to adjust to the expectations of a demanding new generation of media consumers who want free movies and books and music and news wherever and whenever theyre online.

title: Correction
description: An entry on the combined print and e-book nonfiction best-seller list last Sunday for No Regrets omitted the name of one of the co-authors, and an entry for the book on the hardcover nonfiction list misstated the publishing imprint. The book, by Ace Frehley, was written with Joe Layden and John Ostrosky, not just Layden, and its imprint is Gallery/VH1  Gallery/MTV was the imprint of an earlier edition.

title: New Leader for Chinas Largest TV Network
description: The Central Committee of the Chinese Communist Party has announced that Hu Zhanfan is taking over as president of China Central Television, better known as CCTV, a state-run organization that is the largest television network in the country, according to a report by Xinhua, the state news agency. Mr. Hu was vice minister of the State Administration of Radio, Film and Television, an agency that regulates some of Chinas largest media industries and is widely thought to be conservative. The current head of CCTV, Jiao Li, will take a new position in the government, Xinhua reported on Thursday without giving more details. Mr. Jiao was appointed president of CCTV in May 2009, and before that served in the publicity department of the partys Central Committee. Since a policy meeting in October, Chinese leaders have been pushing for various changes and regulations in cultural industries, media organizations and the Internet.

title: Splendor in the Stars
description: Vincent VAN GOGH tends to be remembered as an art saint whose radiant paintings of sunflowers and starry skies seem somehow imbued with moral valor. He identified with the poor and marginalized, and looked upon art as a humanitarian calling. He died unknown, at age 37, and you suspect he will always be a shining hero not only to people who worship art but to those who feel their own talents remain insufficiently acknowledged by their peers  meaning, most everyone.

title: The Case of Juan Rivera
description: DNA analysis has helped exonerate dozens of people who had confessed to violent crimes. But against Juan Rivera, prosecutors used new and novel theories to explain away the scientific evidence.

title: Inside the List
description: HIS AND HERS: Most weeks, the hawkish and the mawkish coexist peacefully on the fiction list: its not hard to picture an old married couple retiring to bed with separate but equal best sellers by, say, Daniel Silva and Danielle Steel. Its a comfortable state of affairs, and one thats pretty much guaranteed to drive you bonkers if youre an adman-turned-novelist who wants your work in the hands of every man, woman and child on earth  if you are, for instance, James Patterson, the worlds most successful author of adult fiction (according to Guinness) and the smartest marketing guy I ever met (according to a tribute on Pattersons Web site). Patterson was chairman of the J. Walter Thompson ad agency for six years, and you can just see him scrutinizing that old couple in their flannel pajamas: how do I reach both of them? For Patterson, the answer since 2001 has been to write (or co-write) romances as well as the action-packed thrillers that made him famous. And its worked. In June 2008, Patterson scored simultaneous best sellers with the suspense novel Sail and the romance Sundays at Tiffanys. This week he does it again, as Kill Alex Cross, the latest entry in his signature detective series, storms the hardcover fiction list at No. 1, and his romance novel The Christmas Wedding holds strong at No. 9 in its fifth week.

title: La Guardia Loses Swiss Cheese Ice Cream Cone, and Some History
description: If you havent flown through La Guardia Airport in recent months, youre in for a surprise.

title: Weekend TV Guide, Nov. 26-27: Tracking U.S. Players in Five to Watch
description: The United States national team will not be playing any more soccer this year andMajor League Soccer is hibernating until spring (actually, late winter). But fans of American soccer  and American soccer players  will have plenty to watch during the remaining weeks of 2011.

title: Wired for Sound
description: Ive gotten used to the Look.

title: What Goes Around
description: Along with jazz and speakeasies, the 1920s were also the heyday of the American carousel.

title: Accusing the Accuser
description: Someone wrote an anonymous letter to the Administration for Childrens Services stating that I had physically abused my children on various occasions in broad daylight in my neighborhood. With nothing to hide, I allowed the A.C.S. to interview my children and their caregivers, and I was cleared. Against all odds, I then found out who wrote the letter. Im mad, but Im reluctant to turn her in lest she face a harsh penalty. Should I pursue the case or let karma do its job? ANONYMOUS

title: Cache n Carry
description: Its happening again, and by it, I mean moving, and by again, I mean an inexplicable number of times for someone not in the military. This time the spur is the sale of my building.

title: The Evolution of Fleece, From Scratchy to Snuggie
description: Even in the heyday of the polyester age  during the height of John Travolta and white bodysuits  when people wanted to stay warm, they still wore wool. And that venerable material had its downsides. It was notoriously itchy. When it got wet, it stank. And moths liked to eat it.

title: Jerry Hobbs' Confession
description: The man who confessed to killing his daughter and her friend was released last year, after five years in jail, due to new DNA evidence.

title: Noel Gallagher Is on His Own
description: You once said the only reason you werent crazy was that its only solo artists who go mad. Two years ago you left Oasis and just recently released High Flying Birds, your solo debut. Have you turned into a narcissistic lunatic?

title: The Human Swap
description: The inability of Israeli society, Ronen Bergman writes, to tolerate even a single soldier held in captivity is likely to continue to have horrific consequences. He reminds us that more than 1,000 Palestinians, among them those convicted of murdering nearly 600 Israelis, are being released in exchange for Gilad Shalit. And nearly half of the prisoners released in previous disproportionate exchanges have resumed their murderous activities. Many innocent Jews are likely to pay with their lives for the Israeli governments abdication of responsibility for the safety of all its citizens.

title: Watching People Watching People Watching
description: We begin with an archetypal American scene. A young boy and his sister are sitting on a living-room couch watching TV. All we can hear is dialogue: the iconic patter between Darth Vader and Luke Skywalker at the end of their first lightsaber duel. Luke accuses Vader, with Skywalkerly navet, of killing his father. To which Vader responds with arguably the most powerful gotcha in the history of film: I am your father.

title: The Prosecutions Case Against DNA
description: By the time Juan Rivera was taken to Lake County for questioning on Oct. 27, 1992, the search for Holly Stakers killer had gone cold. Two and a half months had passed since the 11-year-old girl was raped and stabbed while baby-sitting for two little children, and with the killer still at large, neighborhood-watch groups had formed and wary parents kept their children indoors. The Lake County police had pursued nearly 600 leads and interviewed about 200 people but were not close to making an arrest when they hooked Rivera up to a polygraph machine and began questioning him about his whereabouts on the night of the murder.

title: Famous Minds, Keeping Secrets
description: THIS week The New York Timess chief film critics, Manohla Dargis and A. O. Scott, discuss two new movies that explore the hidden lives of well-known historical figures.

title: A First Plunge Into Directing Is Hardly Routine
description: London

title: Millions Spent in Albany Fight to Drill for Gas
description: ALBANY  Energy companies have been pouring millions of dollars into television advertising, lobbying and campaign contributions as the administration of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo enters the final phase of deciding when and where to allow a controversial form of natural gas extraction that is opposed by environmental groups.

title: K.K.R.s Energy Billionaires Club
description: Which of the following individuals is an oil-and-gas magnate who has made billions of dollars through a deal with Kohlberg Kravis Roberts in the last three years?

title: Unlikely Look at Sex and the City
description: STEVE McQUEEN, the London-born artist-turned-filmmaker, has dark memories of his first visit to New York City. Literally: he was here for the 1977 blackout.

title: No Ending, Spoiled or Otherwise, in Sight as The Mousetrap Begins Its 60th Year
description: It might be the longest-standing spoiler alert in theater history: The Mousetrap, the London stage production of the Agatha Christie mystery that still asks its audience not to reveal the killers identity, began its 60th year on Friday and announced a tour of Britain among other special events to mark the murderous milestone.

title: Room With a Purview
description: Are hotels really the new community centers? The incorrigible Will Self checks out the scene and discovers its not so bad.

title: A Voice Suggests Door-Busters Can Wait
description: Anthony Hardwick never thought of himself as an activist or even much of an organizer. He grew up in Kansas City, Mo., graduated from Park University in Missouri in 2009, and looked for a job by scouring the Internet for cities with low unemployment rates. He settled on Omaha, where he found two  as a shopping cart attendant at Target and a printing supervisor for OfficeMax. There he met his fiance, Denise Holling.

title: The Holiday Reality Check
description: I spoke to a couple of veteran geriatric care managers in the Boston area earlier this week. They were braced for ringing phones today, their own sort of Black Friday surge.

title: A Sputtering Djokovic Loses to Tipsarevic
description: Through three round-robin matches at the ATP World Tour Finals, Novak Djokovic hasnt exactly put a cherry on top of his remarkable 2011 season.

title: Alabama-Auburn: Once More With (Intense) Feeling
description: There are no professional teams in the state of Alabama and there are only two teams, separated by only 160 miles, that matter. Fans are forced to choose sides at birth Alabama or Auburn.

title: Weekend Fare
description: Shoppers out and about on Black Friday can stop by Ellabess in the Nolitan Hotel, 153 Elizabeth Street (Kenmare Street) in NoLIta, for a free cup of hot chocolate (one serving per person) until 11:30 p.m. The restaurant is also offering alcoholic hot chocolate specials.

title: Humor's Healing Power
description: The former Army staff sergeant, who was nearly killed in Iraq in 2007, talks about how comedy can soothe wounds--and awkwardness. (Source: Galileo Media Arts)

title: Capturing a Tradition, Blow by Blow
description: THE big, bald man at the end of the bar extended a huge hand and introduced himself as the filmmaker Ian Palmer and his slighter, gentler-looking companion as the bruising bare-knuckle boxer James Quinn McDonagh.

title: Channel Surfing: The Sing-Off
description: The Fox singing competition The X Factor has been getting most of the attention this fall, but over on NBC The Sing-Off has been chugging along with better music and without the cheesy manufactured dramatics. This week, fans are voting on the three groups remaining on that show, building up to a live finale on Monday night.

title: Photo Replay: Nov.25
description: A look at the day in sports, from golf in China to rugby in Australia.

title: Cutting the Pain of War With a Punchline
description: Its a rather jarring sight: a guy missing his left ear and part of his right, who has no hair on his head and whose face is a patchwork of scars and skin grafts, stands at a microphone, making jokes about being, well, a guy missing his left ear and part of his right, who has no hair on his head and whose face is  You get the idea.

title: A Leap Forward That Tugs Backward
description: AT least one eternal truth can be abstracted from D. W. Griffiths 1915 film The Birth of a Nation: people can be very, very advanced in some areas, and very, very backward in others.

title: TimesCast | November 25, 2011
description: The White House released a statement backing Egypt's protest movement; and nearly two years after the earthquake in Haiti, many still live in condemned homes.

title: Tombs, Sonic Booms, Miracles and Immortals
description: Atlas Sound

title: A Comedians Act Is Leaner but Not Meaner
description: CARLOS MENCIAS life has lately been about transformations: transformations in perspective, attitude and how he deals with his emotions.

title: A Pair of Pop Queens Flaunt Winning Hands
description: LATE last summer, with barely more than a weeks notice, the indomitable pop whirlwind known as Beyonc descended on the Roseland Ballroom for four nights: a canny undersell and a tacitly hopeful push for her fourth album, 4 (Columbia). About a month later, the adult-contemporary powerhouse Adele headlined the Royal Albert Hall in her native London: an aspirational milestone, and the gilded consequence of a second album, 21 (XL/Columbia), that needed no further pushing.

title: A Whole Lot of Sublimation Going On
description: THE phrase Angel Reapers comes from a Shaker hymn that in turn derives from the Gospel of Matthew, whereby angels cull mankind to save the chosen few. The choreographer Martha Clarke found the hymn in a pile of sheet music her musical director Arthur Solari had gathered in preparation for her new show about the Shakers. Ms. Clarke proposed the title to her collaborator, the playwright Alfred Uhry. Both found it evocative, they say, even if they werent quite sure at first what it meant.

title: Study Finds Limited Sensitivity of Climate to CO2
description: Recalling the perils of single-study syndrome, its still important to note a new study that appears to go a long way toward narrowing the extent of possible warming projected well into this century from the buildup of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere. Eric Berger of the Houston Chronicledescribes the research, published today in Science. The work, led by researchers at Oregon State University, hadsurfaced earlierbut has now survived peer review.

title: A Community of Survivors Dwindles
description: ONE thing about life in New York: wherever you are, the neighborhood is always changing. An Italian enclave becomes Senegalese; a historically African-American corridor becomes a magnet for white professionals. The accents and rhythms shift; the aromas become spicy or vegetal. The transition is sometimes smooth, sometimes bumpy. But there is a sense of loss among the people left behind, wondering what happened to the neighborhood they once thought of as their own.

title: 100 Years of The Neediest Cases Fund
description: This year marks the 100th anniversary of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, a nonprofit charity launched by Adolph S. Ochs, a publisher of The New York Times, to aid those in need.

title: Its Your (Virtual) World. Feel Free to Roam or Slay.
description: Want to get lost? Play The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim.

title: Mosey In and Wet Your Whistle
description: People tend to quicken their pace when walking along Staten Islands north shore, where a cold industrial landscape can make even the most stoic New Yorker feel bleak. For many on Lafayette Avenue, though, their destination is a cozy refuge with amber lights that hint at subtropical warmth: Adobe Blues Restaurant.

title: Where The Money Is
description: Ive been getting the predictable hysterical reactions to todays column. And its true  Im a Sharia Jewish atheist Marxist who hates America! Bwahahaha!

title: TimesCast | November 25, 2011
description: Protesters gathered in Tahrir Square for one of the largest demonstrations since the February uprising, but not all Egyptians believe the protests are good for the country.

title: Musical Conversation
description: My conversation with the guys at Sound Opinions is up. You can listen to us as a streaming mp3 here, and download the podcast here.

title: The Slow-Pitch Ambassadors to Cuba
description: HAVANA  Wearing orange jerseys  well, T-shirts, really  the Cuban players lined up along the first-base line at Mella Field. We were in blue, along third. All of us held our caps over our hearts, and the Cuban National Concert Band played two national anthems, first the United States, then Cubas, followed, for some reason, by The Pink Panther Theme.

title: Preview: Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim
description: A live-action trailer for Skyrim, the latest installment in the Elder Scrolls series.

title: S.&P. Cuts Belgiums Rating to AA
description: PARIS  Standard & Poors lowered its rating on Belgiums sovereign debt on Friday, the latest in a string of downgrades issued this week on European countries and banks that have been hit by the European debt crisis.

title: Moody's Downgrades Hungary
description: PARIS  Moodys Investors Service has cut Hungarys credit rating to below investment grade, or junk, just a week after the country said it would seek aid from the International Monetary Fund to help it maintain an investment grade.

title: Heading Home From the South Pacific
description: Jack Dumbacher, curator of ornithology and mammalogy at the California Academy of Sciences, writes from Milne Bay, Papua New Guinea, where he is studying island birds and their diseases.

title: As Crisis Mounts, Europes Central Bank Stands Back
description: FRANKFURT  To some people, the European Central Bank seems like a fire department that is letting the house burn down to teach the children not to play with matches.

title: Living Amid Ruins in Haiti
description: Many Haitians displaced by the 2010 earthquake left the tent camps and returned to severely damaged houses in danger of collapse.

title: Smugness Comes Standard
description: EASING along the New York State Thruway in a Buick LaCrosse, I am enjoying the hushed cabin and technological amenities of an entry-level luxury car as I keep an eye out for diminutive gas hogs like the Honda Fit and the Mazda 2.

title: More Than Just Scenery
description: Georges Remi, the artist behind The Adventures of Tintin, was an avid car collector whose passion for automobiles was revealed in his work.

title: Models Take A Final Bow
description: A last look at some of the cars that wont be back in 2012.

title: Tintin Film Casts Cars Among Star Performers
description: NEXT months American debut of The Adventures of Tintin will serve as an introduction for many moviegoers to a character long adored by Europeans, the boy reporter with a nose for mystery and a trademark tuft of orange hair.

title: Arrests and Attacks on Women Covering Protests in Cairo
description: The documentary film maker Jehane Noujaim was released on Friday by Egyptian security forces after being held for 36 hours.

title: More Back Story on Steve Jobss Biological Father
description: A new biography of Steve Jobs illuminates many parts of his life, but one question it never fully answers is why he didnt want to have any connection with his biological father.

title: How to Make the Case for Higher Pay
description: So youve been keeping your head down, working as hard as you can  glad, you tell yourself, that you even have a job.

title: Involuntary Layoffs, Even for Cars
description: THE turn of the automotive model year usually brings a host of discontinued cars, and this go-round is no exception. As 2011 winds down, some 17 models have gotten the ax, from market weaklings to long-running strong sellers.

title: Exorcising the Phantom Wipes
description: OIL-GULPING Audis and Scions with failed ignition coils are among the mechanical ailments covered in the latest technical service bulletins.

title: On Fiats Wish List: More Buyers for 500
description: WITH all the pageantry of a Christmas parade and the subterfuge of a Potemkin village, the Fiat 500 by Gucci made an appearance in the holiday windows at Saks Fifth Avenue on Nov. 21.

title: Tom Wicker, Times Journalist, Dies at 85
description: Tom Wicker, one of postwar Americas most distinguished journalists, who wrote 20 books, covered the assassination of President John F. Kennedy for The New York Times and became the papers Washington bureau chief and an iconoclastic political columnist for 25 years, died on Friday at his home near Rochester, Vt. He was 85.

title: Lady Gaga Special No Turkey for ABC
description: Based on the early Nielsen ratings Lady Gaga may not become a Thanksgiving mainstay like Charlie Brown, but A Very Gaga Thanksgiving still posted solid numbers on Thursday night for ABC with a total audience of 5.7 million viewers. The 90-minute special, where Gaga performed a handful of songs and showed off some curious wardrobe choices, was ABCs highest-rated show in that time period  9:30 p.m. to 11  in four years.

title: A Genre-Bending Musical Pitch to Ad Agencies
description: The old joke about asking how to get to Carnegie Hall and being told practice! is getting a rewrite by a music licensing company, which is asking how to get to Madison Avenue and answering in an unusual way.

title: Would You Dare to Ask for a Raise Now?
description: Its hard enough to ask your boss for a raise in normal economic times. So would you be putting yourself at risk if you ask now?

title: The Week in Pictures, Nov. 25
description: A look back at the past weeks events in New York City and the region.

title: Homebody? Not in This Building
If You Like the Condo, Share It With Friends
description: AS much as people love to look at property listings, they also love to voice their opinions about what they see. To facilitate this, one real estate agency, Bond New York, has incorporated the Facebook commenting system on its Web site, allowing users to Like a property and express their thoughts about it.

title: Profits Are High, Wages Are Low and Taxes Are Below Average
description: Profits are higher, wages are lower and taxes are below average

title: For Business, Golden Days; For Workers, the Dross
description: IN the eight decades before the recent recession, there was never a period when as much as 9 percent of American gross domestic product went to companies in the form of after-tax profits. Now the figure is over 10 percent.

title: Reviewing the 2012 Buick LaCrosse
description: In Sundays Automobiles section, Christopher Jensen reviews the 2012 Buick LaCrosse, a midsize entry-level luxury sedan that gets a fuel-economy boost from the new eAssist system that helps the 4-cylinder engine achieve 25 m.p.g. in the city and 36 on the highway. As Mr. Jensen writes:

title: Gretchen Morgenson on rolling back rules for derivatives trading, David Gillen and Natasha Singer on the gun business, and Robert Shiller on the super committee and unemployment.
description: Gretchen Morgenson on rolling back rules for derivatives trading, David Gillen and Natasha Singer on the gun business, and Robert Shiller on the super committee and unemployment.

title: Whiting Weighs In on Incident Between Hamilton and Massa
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  Perhaps Lewis Hamilton is returning to his old self after winning a race in Abu Dhabi two weeks ago, and setting the fastest time during Fridays practice sessions at the Brazilian Grand Prix. Still, the weekend has just started, and Sebastian Vettel was only a tenth of a second behind.

title: Whiting Weighs In on Incident Between Hamilton and Massa
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  Perhaps Lewis Hamilton is returning to his old self after winning a race in Abu Dhabi two weeks ago, and setting the fastest time during Fridays practice sessions at the Brazilian Grand Prix.
