Still, the weekend has just started, and Sebastian Vettel was only a tenth of a second behind.

title: L.S.U.Arkansas at Halftime: B.C.S. Chaos Is a Possibility
description: BATON ROUGE, La. There are 30 minutes left in L.S.U. vs. Arkansas. Thirty minutes before we could have some real chaos in the Bowl Championship Series.

title: Where to Party at Art Basel Miami Beach
description: HAS it been a decade? Art Basel Miami Beach marks its 10th edition this week, no longer the new kid on the collector circuit, but a mandatory stop for any self-respecting art player. In some very social circles, it even overshadows the original in Switzerland, as far as the partying, the opulent dinners and the unbridled hobnobbing are concerned.

title: Big Ticket | Sold for $15.5 Million
description: The $15.5 million sale of an apartment at the Carlyle Hotel on the Upper East Side, that cynosure of all things civilized and repository of secrets for presidents and starlets alike, was the most expensive of the week.

title: Whats in a Name? Ask Google
description: KALIA is a stripper name, but Kaleya is not, her parents-to-be concluded.

title: Road Trip to Cuba
description: Players from the Eastern Massachusetts Senior Softball League traveled to play a series of games against teams in Cuba, the leagues fourth such visit there since 2009.

title: A Special Woman as Inspiration
description: IN todays style landscape, chockablock with twentysomethings who were weaned on fashion-happy films like Clueless and Unzipped, the dream of a fierce or frolicsome career (or both) as a fashion designer has exercised a serious pull.

title: A Strange New Role: The Star
description: Photographs of Michelle Williams throughout her acting career.

title: Banks Build Contingency for Breakup of the Euro
description: PARIS  For the growing chorus of observers who fear that a breakup of the euro zone might be at hand, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany has a pointed rebuke: Its never going to happen.

title: For Michelle Williams, an Unfamiliar Role: The Star
description: HERE is 45 minutes in my life. Actually, 58 minutes 50 seconds, according to the counter on my tape recorder when I finish my conversation with the actress Michelle Williams in the bar of the Bull and Bear Steakhouse in the Waldorf-Astoria, and her publicist, a harried-looking woman named Cari, whisks her away. A bottle of red wine sits unfinished on the table. I pay the check for my $30 hamburger  she wanted only cocktail nuts  and for the glass of wine I ordered while I was waiting for her, and my thoughts skip a beat, releasing me from the scene. ...

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Nov. 25
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: Beer-Related Gifts for Wedding Registries
description: Beer glasses and other accessories as gifts.

title: A Toast!
description: A GIFT of wineglasses has long been a staple on wedding registries. But with beer drinkers refining their tastes to frothy heights once seen only among wine connoisseurs, why not consider a gift of fancy beerware to match couples tastes for the latest double I.P.A. or exotic-flavor stout?

title: Dont Complicate It
description: WHEN it comes to what they wear, men seem to be sandwiched between fashion and nostalgia. At least they have been for the last decade or so.

title: In Commodities World, Safe and Secure Sometimes Isnt
description: THE scariest thing about MF Globals bankruptcy four weeks ago is not that a venerable firm led by a former Goldman Sachs chief executive and New Jersey governor collapsed. It is that MF Globals customers have not yet gotten all their money back. And with the report this week from the court-appointed trustee that as much as $1.2 billion appears to be missing, many customers are worried that theyll ever see that money again.

title: Lessons for Investors in MF Globals Collapse
description: Customers of the bankrupt commodities brokerage firm MF Global have not had an easy time since the firm collapsed on Oct. 31. Some customers commodities trading accounts have been transferred to other firms, though not the full value. And those who had securities accounts or who held cash in their accounts have not seen any of their money yet.

title: Bill Cunningham | Spotting Cats
description: One of the few discernible fashion trends is the prevalence of spotted cat. It is most often sighted in shoulder bags and scarves.

title: On Black Friday, a Steady Business for Traffic Agents
description: Black Friday may be a boon for retailers, but they arent the only ones who do a brisk business on that day. New York Citys traffic enforcement agents are notoriously busy on the day after Thanksgiving, when many car owners mistakenly assume that parking regulations, like alternate-side parking rules, are suspended.

title: The Week in Pictures for Nov. 25
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the possibility of a school bus strike, a thwarted bomb plot and preparation for the Thanksgiving holiday.

title: Syria Lets Arab League Deadline on Observers Pass
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syria on Friday ignored an Arab League deadline to accept observers to oversee a peace deal to end more than eight months of bloodshed, with activists saying that several protesters and soldiers were killed during clashes across the country.

title: M.L.S. Cup: A View From Mexico
description: After spending most of the last 45 days in Mexico Guadalajara with an eye planted on the States  as the M.L.S. final drifts into memory and American soccer goes into hibernation  the action in Mexico is heating up.

title: Out of the Darkness
description: THERE was a time when my wife, Giulia, said Yes to almost everything I suggested. But before she consented, there was always an unnatural pause, a pause so small it may have gone unnoticed by others. But it was painfully obvious to me. That pause did not come from her; it came from the antipsychotic medication she had to take.

title: An International Flavor at the Fall Championships
description: The Fall North American Championships, organized by the American Contract Bridge League, began in Seattle on Thursday.

title: In the Right Age
description: I am on a dating site called OKCupid.com and list my age as 33, even though I am actually 43. When people meet me, they assume I am in my late 20s or early 30s. I feel fortunate to get away with looking so much younger than I am without Botox. My plan is to admit my true age on a second or third date, and hope hell forgive me. Or should I correct my age now?

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Gender Bending Romance
description: Though Im often reluctant to begin reading a series several volumes in, there are two arrivals on the manga list this week that have me reconsidering that stance. At No. 9 on the list is vol. 5 of Arisa, by Natsumi Ando, about Tsubasa who impersonates her twin sister Arisa at her school and remains undercover to find out why she attempted suicide. Apparently everyone in Arisas class has a secret and it involves mysterious text messages to someone named King. At No. 10 on the list is vol. 5 of Until the Full Moon, by Sanami Matoh. That series follows Marlo, a half-werewolf-half-vampire, who becomes something else in the light of a full moon: a girl. Adding to the complications is the fact that David, a vampire playboy, is interested in Marlos female form. And Marlos parents are not the least bit frazzled: if their doctor friend cant help Marlo, their son, they seem fine with David marrying Marlo, their daughter.

title: So Big, Performa Now Misses the Point
description: Performa 11, the visual art performance biennial, has come and gone, completing its sprawling three-week marathon with an awards ceremony on Monday. It left me feeling once more grateful for its artistic largesse and revelations, if a bit more dazed and confused than usual.

title: College Students Replace Poverty With Creativity
description: LIKE so many college students these days, Margaux Malyshev was desperate for cash.

title: The Agony of Gift-Giving in a City That Has Seen It All
description: Several years ago, while roaming around a used-book store on a trip to Rhode Island, I found a pristine old copy of Randall Jarrells 1954 novel, Pictures From an Institution. It had a great cover done in bold graphics and cost $5. I bought it with the intention of giving it to a friend later in the year, someone who would appreciate both the object itself and the scavenger manner in which it had been found.

title: Podcast: Derivative Trading, Unemployment and the American Gun Business
description: The Dodd-Frank law aimed to tighten financial regulations in hopes of preventing another meltdown. Among other things, it called for greater transparency in the trading of derivatives.

title: A Look at Apples Spot-the-Shopper Technology
description: A Black Friday visit to the Apple Store in Palo Alto, Calif., offered a glimpse of the new technology Apple is using to speed purchases.

title: A Nod to St. Cecilia, Patron Despite Herself
description: Whatever you make of St. Cecilia, the patron saint of music, the ensemble Tenets idea of honoring her feast day in a concert presented by Trinity Wall Street on Tuesday was a lovely one. What others have made of her is a long story, or several of them.

title: The New Roomie Proves That Three Is a Crowd, Especially When He Overshares
description: At TV Land, the creation of new comedies goes beyond simple formula  its closer to cloning, or something involving algorithms. Feed the computer a premise  three guys share an apartment because they all have the same divorce lawyer  and it tells you which sitcom veterans you need to hire.

title: Gail Marquis and Audrey Smaltz
description: AUDREY SMALTZ said that she wanted to stop being a complainer, as she put it, and that she needed to know who she was. I really had no idea, she said.

title: French Museums Atone for a Colonial History
description: PARIS  You walk through a garden lush with overgrowth, a cultivated wilderness with exotic grasses gone deliberately to seed. Inside the effect is the same: You enter the eerily atmospheric hall where you meander past artifacts from Oceania, Africa and other realms beyond Europes borders, as speckled daylight seeps through window scrims decorated with forest foliage. The displays are lush with miscellany: here, an ivory statuette of a goddess from the Tonga islands that once was shown in an 18th-century curiosity cabinet; there, a desiccated human skull, covered in black-colored beeswax, acquired in early-20th-century Papua New Guinea.

title: Fugazi Rises Again, in Online Archive
description: Fugazi, the single-mindedly independent post-punk band from Washington, was famous for how it operated in concert. From its first shows in 1987 until it went on indefinite hiatus 15 years later, the group kept ticket prices low  $5 or so  and, to the relief of some fans and the annoyance of others, often paused when things got too wild in the mosh pit.

title: Australia Eases Policy on Detaining Asylum Seekers
description: SYDNEY, Australia  The government announced a significant shift on Friday in its policy toward asylum seekers who try to reach the country by sea, moving away from its use of open-ended detention in favor of a plan that allows applicants to live and work in the country while their claims are processed.

title: Grading a Teacher Evaluation System
description: To the Editor:

title: Schmekel, a Band Born as a Laugh
description: THE basement auditorium of the Jewish Community Center on the Upper West Side is a sincere space. Big, brown and bare, it suggests a school gym, a place for officially sanctioned fun  which made a recent concert by Schmekel, a raucous klezmer-core punk band made up of 100% trans Jews, all the more surprising.

title: Weekend Guide Nov. 26-27: Non-U.S. Edition
description: By popular demand, Rob Hughes of The International Herald Tribune previews some of this weekends matches in Europe.

title: Former F.B.I. Chief Asked to Oversee MF Globals Bankruptcy
description: Louis J. Freeh, the former director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, was asked on Friday to become the trustee for MF Global as it seeks to unwind itself in bankruptcy court.

title: The Unbelievers
description: RONNELLE ADAMS came out to his mother twice, first about his homosexuality, then about his atheism.

title: 35 Floors Above the Floats
description: Each Thanksgiving, Asiate  the Asian-fusion restaurant on the 35th floor of the Mandarin Oriental Hotel at Columbus Circle  becomes a skybox where smart-set locals and affluent out-of-towners gather early to look down at the Macys Thanksgiving Day Parade. Starting at 7 a.m., there is a prix fixe breakfast  this year, $68 for adults and $48 for children  during which Asiates normal menu (wagyu beef, butter poached lobster) is set aside for more traditional parade-watching fare (scrambled eggs, Special K). On Thursday, the diner-viewers included a group of visiting Saudis, a silver-haired gentleman and his date, and the Peters family of Hinsdale, Ill., on a six-day whirlwind tour of the big city.

title: After Slow Start, L.S.U. Stays Perfect
description: BATON ROUGE, La.  L.S.U. is simply different this season. The Tigers have shed their reputation as a somewhat flaky, burlesque team led by a quirky coach whose daring sideline decisions always seemed to come with one second left on the clock.

title: Inequality in the Air: The 1 Percent and the 99
description: To the Editor:

title: Tour Guides Nobody Tips
description: APP UrbandigPLATFORM iPhone and iOS devicesPRICE Free

title: Veterans Medical Care
description: To the Editor:

title: The Witch Wears Silk Suits
description: IT was the night before Thanksgiving, and the Witch Queen of New York was not stirring her brew or flying on her broom.

title: Religious Liberty
description: To the Editor:

title: Formal Defect Inquiry of Volt Battery Begins
description: DETROIT  Federal safety regulators on Friday said they have begun a formal defect investigation of the Chevrolet Volt because a second battery caught fire after a crash simulation.

title: Anti-H.I.V. Trial in Africa Canceled Over Failure to Prevent Infection
description: A new trial of a microbicide gel to protect women from infection with H.I.V. was canceled Friday after researchers reported that it was not working.

title: At Harbor, Answering an S.O.S.
description: SUSAN HENSHAW JONES, the new president of the comatose South Street Seaport Museum and the captain, by default, of its deteriorating fleet of historic vessels, dug the heels of her black pumps deeper into the splintered boardwalk at Pier 16, bracing herself against the November wind pirouetting off the harbor.

title: AT&T Spars With F.C.C. Over Withdrawal of T-Mobile Deal
description: Nothing is easy when it comes to AT&Ts proposed $39 billion takeover of T-Mobile USA  apparently not even when it comes to withdrawing the deal from the government approval process.

title: Letter
description: To the Editor:

title: Ugandas Oil Could Be Gift That Becomes a Curse
description: KAMPALA, Uganda  When billions of barrels of oil reserves were found in Uganda five years ago, the discovery seemed like a gift from heaven to many in this poor, landlocked country.

title: Djokovic Out After Loss
description: Novak Djokovic lost his second match in round-robin play at the ATP World Tour Finals in London, falling to his fellow Serb Janko Tipsarevic, 3-6, 6-3, 6-3. It was Tipsarevics first win over Djokovic, as well as his first over a No. 1-ranked player.

title: In Quiet Part of Russia, Putins Party Loses Steam
description: ARSENYEVO, Russia  It was a grim-faced crowd that gathered last week at the Palace of Culture in this village, making its way past decrepit housing blocks, broken streetlights and a statue of Lenin.

title: Good Words for Grietje
description: The Aug. 7 F.Y.I. column had an item, First Lady of the Night, about Grietje Reyniers, whose scandalous conduct in the New Amsterdam of the 1630s was written up in official records at the time. Marie E. Velardi, a 10th great-granddaughter of Ms. Reyniers who has studied genealogical records and histories of New Amsterdam, wrote that while there was no one definitive work on the Reyniers-Van Salee family, she believed that the view of Ms. Reyniers as a highly immoral woman was one-sided. An edited version of Ms. Velardis letter follows.

title: A New Capital of Call Centers
description: MANILA  Americans calling the customer service lines of their airlines, phone companies and banks are now more likely to speak to Mark in Manila than Bharat in Bangalore.

title: Multicultural One-Man Team
description: At Northwestern University, inside the office of fellowships, Steven Hill likes to tell visitors that he advised the Mexican wrestling team. He adds: His names Larry. Hes really big. This is true. Strange, yes, but true, too.

title: Romney Dominating Race for Endorsements
description: When we last checked in on Republican candidates endorsements  an important measure of party and institutional support that historically has some predictive power for nomination races  we found former Gov. Mitt Romney of Massachusetts in a good but not great position.

title: Legal Education Reform
description: American legal education is in crisis. The economic downturn has left many recent law graduates saddled with crushing student loans and bleak job prospects. The law schools have been targets of lawsuits by students and scrutiny from the United States Senate for alleged false advertising about potential jobs. Yet, at the same time, more and more Americans find that they cannot afford any kind of legal help.

title: Family Fun, Out of the House
description: Landscapes dotted with tiny dolls, a scale model of a candy-making machine, an all-Lego city with running trains and a frosted gingerbread replica of Radio City Music Hall are among the diverse works in four family-friendly exhibitions now open in and around the county.

title: Tom Wicker, a Columnist Not Afraid of Controversy
description: Tom Wicker, an iconoclastic columnist for The New York Times, became one of postwar Americas most distinguished journalists.

title: Fair Pay for Hard Work
description: Something akin to justice may finally be at hand for the nations nearly two million home care aides.

title: Meaning in Madness
description: Milton Greek, who has been diagnosed with schizophrenia, believes that decoding the messages in delusions can help some people recover.

title: As Catholics Prepare for New Mass Translation, Parish Carves Its Own Path
description: The midmorning Mass held at Corpus Christi Church in Morningside Heights last Sunday was either a week ahead or nearly 40 years behind the mainstream of American Roman Catholicism, depending on how one looked at it.

title: China Looks Into U.S. Energy Trade Policies
description: HONG KONG  Chinas ministry of commerce announced on Friday that it had opened an investigation into whether American subsidies and other policies in the solar, wind and hydroelectric sectors had unfairly hurt the industrial development of Chinas renewable energy industries.

title: The Battle Hymn of John Brown
description: On Nov. 17, 1861, Julia Ward Howe traveled with her husband Samuel, then director of the Armys Sanitary Commission, to review a Union camp outside of Washington. Howe recalled the troops singing the army songs so popular at the time, noting especially their enthusiasm for the lyrics, John Browns body lies a-mouldering in the ground; His soul is marching on. One of Howes companions, the Rev. James Freeman Clarke, made a suggestion: Mrs. Howe, why do you not write some good words for that stirring tune?

title: Police and the Press
description: In many countries, using a camera or taking notes can get you into trouble. That is not supposed to happen in New York City. Yet as police cleared Occupy Wall Street protesters from Zuccotti Park in Lower Manhattan on Nov. 15, a number of journalists were roughed up and arrested. Many were prevented by police from documenting what happened that night.

title: Finding Purpose After Living With Delusion
description: ATHENS, Ohio  She was gone for good, and no amount of meditation could resolve the grief, even out here in the deep quiet of the woods.

title: The Rain It Raineth
description: Its raining, I think, and then wonder what the it is that is doing the raining. Ordinarily, thats just a linguistic question. But on a cold November day, it feels like a philosophical problem. It makes no sense to say the clouds are raining when the sky is so solidly, grayly felted. In the pasture, the horses stand, hair slicked, hind legs cocked. I conclude that what is raining is the rain, a phrase that sounds like the opening of a grim, Anglo-Saxon lyric.

title: O.K., Now Ron Paul
description: Ron Paul, the libertarian congressman from Texas, now seems to have an outside chance of winning the Iowa caucus vote. Not the presidential nomination. It seems highly unlikely that the Republicans are going to give the nod to a guy who disapproves of the Patriot Act and marriage licenses.

title: Wedding Bells Drown Out Locker-Room Chatter
description: An N.F.L. locker room is a temple of masculinity. There are jock straps on the floor. Helmets hung on hooks. Shoulder pads resting on shelves, with ribbons of dried-out sweat running along the seams.

title: Under Rule, Hailing a Cab for a Stranger Can Be Illegal
description: Recently, a man named Juan Bannister approached a stranger on Seventh Avenue in Midtown Manhattan. Do you need a taxi? Mr. Bannister asked, according to a subsequent police report. Can I get you a taxi? Just wait here; youre next.

title: For U.S., Risks in Pressing Egypt to Speed Civilian Rule
description: WASHINGTON  Ever since tens of thousands of protesters converged on Tahrir Square in Cairo for the first Day of Revolution exactly 10 months ago, the Obama administration has struggled to strike the right balance between democracy and stability. In the early morning hours on Friday, President Obama came out on the side of the Arab street, issuing a call for the Egyptian military to quickly hand over power to a civilian, democratically elected government.

title: Panasonic Plans a Plant for Solar Equipment
description: Panasonic said on Friday that it would invest 45 billion yen ($582 million) to build a plant for solar cells and modules in Malaysia in a move to increase its share of the global market. The factory will also produce wafers and have a production capacity of 300 megawatts a year, the company said. Panasonic, based in Osaka, Japan, intends to sell modules worth 1.6 gigawatts worldwide in the year ending March 2016, Masato Ito, an executive officer, said at a news conference. The companys previous target was 1.5 gigawatts. The company picked Malaysia for the new plant to hedge risks of a strong yen and for its reliable infrastructure for power and water, Tetsuhiro Maeda, a senior vice president of Sanyo, a unit of Panasonic, said at the conference. Production will begin in December 2012 and the plant, which will be built in the Kulim Hi-Tech Park in Kedah, in northern Malaysia, will employ about 1,500 people.

title: Nursing a Marble Horse Back to Health
description: A COUPLE of years ago, Franklin Hill Perrell, the executive director of the Roslyn Landmark Society, got a surprising phone call from an acquaintance. There was a historically important statue in the backyard of a house that was being sold, the caller said, urging Mr. Perrell to go look at it.

title: Eating, Sleeping, Praying, and Writing All About It
description: LAST Sunday, we asked you to tell us how you spent the day, as New Yorkers like Henrik Lundqvist, Mario Batali and Star Jones have done in this space over the last two and a half years, and heres what we discovered: for tens of thousands around the globe, at least part of Sunday was spent using Twitter or Facebook to tell The New York Times what you did on Sunday.

title: Stars Flock to Atlanta, Reshaping a Center of Black Culture
description: ATLANTA  Cynthia Bailey, arguably the most glamorous of the Real Housewives of Atlanta, shivered in a sleeveless red shift, microphone in hand.

title: Irish Life Suspends an Effort to Sell a Unit
description: Irish Life and Permanent, the mortgage lender controlled by Irish taxpayers, said it had suspended efforts to sell its life assurance unit after bids were too low. The lender halted the sale process amid very challenging market conditions, Eoin Dorgan, a spokesman for the Irish Department of Finance, said in a statement. The Irish government plans to split insurance operations from the unprofitable bank unit. Taxpayers injected 2.7 billion euros into the company in July as part of the countrys 62 billion euro bailout of its banking system. The government owns 99.5 percent of the firm.

title: The Death of the Fringe Suburb
description: Washington

title: To Rethink Sprawl, Start With Offices
description: San Francisco

title: Inquiry Into Press Tactics Turns the Tables on Tabloids
description: LONDON  It is a story made to order for the sensation-hungry tabloid newspapers that have millions of avid readers in Britain: a roll call of A-list celebrities and crime victims pouring out  day by day, live on the Internet  the personal miseries they say they have endured in seeking to protect the everyday normality of their private lives.

title: Jeno Paulucci, a Pioneer of Ready-Made Ethnic Foods, Dies at 93
description: First it was Chun King, the canned Chinese food that became a mainstay in American cupboards in the postwar decades. Then it was the pizza roll, a hybrid of Italian and Chinese fast food that acquired similar status in the kitchen freezer. Jeno Paulucci, a food magnate, had a hand in both of those contributions to the American diet, founding the companies that produced them. He died at 93 on Thursday at his home in Duluth, Minn.

title: Occupy L.A. to Be Evicted on Monday
description: LOS ANGELES  The Occupy Los Angeles protesters have probably received a warmer reception than most of their counterparts elsewhere in the country. With vocal support from the City Council, the protesters have been allowed to remain on the lawn outside City Hall for almost two months, without any major confrontations with the police.

title: The Ballad of John and Jessica
description: For the last five years, the Cafe Carlyle, perhaps the premier cabaret venue in New York City, has devoted the month of November to an act featuring John Pizzarelli, a jazz guitarist and vocalist, and his wife, Jessica Molaskey, a Broadway actress and singer.

title: U.S. Uses an Insurgent Attack to Send a Message to Iraqis
description: BAGHDAD  The American military command in Iraq usually declines to acknowledge insurgent rocket strikes on its bases, not wanting the enemy attackers to know whether they have hit something. But the Americans made an exception on Friday.

title: Egypt Military Tries to Woo Wider Public to Keep Power
description: CAIRO  Some call it the silent majority. In Egypt these days, the preferred term is the Party of the Couch. And in that ill-defined constituency, sometimes more myth than reality, Egypts ruling military has staked its credibility as it seeks to fend off the greatest challenge yet from protesters seeking to force it from power.

title: Blind Man in New Jersey Challenged Again on Guns
description: ROCKAWAY, N.J.  Judging by what the authorities say about him, Steven Hopler has really been testing the limits of the Second Amendment.

title: Oil Rigs Bring Camps of Men to the Prairie
description: TIOGA, N.D.  As much as the drilling rigs that tower over this once placid corner of the prairie, the two communities springing up just outside of town testify to the galloping pace of growth here in oil country.

title: A Housing Shortages Imperfect Solution
description: Man camps are filling the holes for housing as thousands of workers floods parts of North Dakota to work the bustling oil fields.

title: Taking on Beckett, in One Act
description: THE last time Brian Dennehy was at Long Wharf Theater, three years ago, he was in a one-act production, Eugene ONeills Hughie, playing a lonely, aging man pretty much talking to himself.

title: Small Wonders, Made by Hand
description: A COMBINATION of remarkable ingenuity and pure fun can be found in two exhibitions at the Stamford Museum and Nature Center: Visions of Gingerbread III: The Sweetest Architects and All Aboard With Bill Probert and Friends II, each of which demonstrates meticulous planning, design and construction skills.

title: Jets Have the Blueprint for a Playoff Run: Their Big Finish in 2009
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  With the postseason fast approaching, Rex Ryan said this week that the Jets had run out of breathing room.

title: Israels Other Occupation
description: Jerusalem

title: After Easing Burden on Body and Mind, a Young Man Begins to Follow His Dream
description: Not so long ago, Marcos Vargas was an overweight, depressed high school dropout who could not face what he called a hostile learning environment and troubles with a girlfriend. He spent most of his time wallowing in his mothers apartment in the Bronx, subsisting on a diet of fried chicken, pork chops and soda.

title: Lottery Numbers
For Gruff Yankee Pitcher, Another Chance at the Hall
description: With 182 victories and 1,423 strikeouts over 13 seasons, the hard-throwing Yankees pitcher Allie Reynolds lacked the shoo-in credentials of 300 wins or 3,000 strikeouts to usher a pitcher into the Baseball Hall of Fame.

title: Talks on Cluster Bomb Restrictions Collapse
description: GENEVA  Despite last-minute attempts to broker a compromise, American-led efforts to conclude an international treaty restricting use of cluster munitions collapsed on Friday in the face of opposition from countries that said it did not address their humanitarian concerns and would undermine existing international law.

title: Stumbling Upon a Castle in the Forest and Deciding to Finish It
description: TUPPER LAKE, N.Y.  Moving through his unfinished mountain home, Andy Ramsgard carries a leatherbound book full of sketches.

title: Freshening Up a Holiday Classic
description: TRADITION plays a large part in spurring the annual march of Nutcracker ticket holders into New Jersey theaters and arts centers each holiday season. And while there are real differences among the many companies presenting it, change often takes the form of tweaks rather than dramatic overhauls.

title: In Judges Brooklyn Courtroom, Made-for-TV Drama Without the Cameras
description: Wearing wide hoop earrings and an Italian gold costume ring that rested as heavy as a gavel on the bench, Judge Patricia Mafalda DiMango leaned forward to address the teenage defendant.

title: For Perry, Life Was Broadened and Narrowed by the Military
description: COLLEGE STATION, Tex.  Rick Perry arrived on the campus of Texas A&M University in the tumultuous fall of 1968, cut his hair short, regulation military style, and donned a uniform. College students across America were rising up against the Vietnam War, but Mr. Perry, a member of the Corps of Cadets here, would not be among them.

title: Saturday: Plane For a Space Cadet
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  O.K., time to work off the turkey, people. This is a tough grid and were going to burn some calories figuring out some of these entries, but we can do this. Its also an interesting visual appetizer to the big Sunday entree coming up. Theres no connection between the grids, but youll see what I mean.

title: A First in Cup Qualifying for a Player and a Team
description: APIA, Samoa  Jonny Saelua did not always envision herself as an international soccer player. What she really wanted to do was join a dance company and travel the world just performing.

title: Last Chance, Visitor: Leave the Cake With the File in It Right Here
description: The boxes are opened on Tuesdays. Inside this week: six cellphones, three canisters of pepper spray, eight blades of various sorts (including a steak knife). Also, two forks, two pairs of scissors, something wrapped in plastic, a hypodermic needle and  now here was something strange  a calculator.

title: Evangelical Leader Rises in Brazils Culture Wars
description: FORTALEZA, Brazil

title: Russian Ballet, Brooklyn Flavor
description: Most of the teachers at the Brighton Ballet Theater School of Russian Ballet hail from the former Soviet Union, and most of their pupils are of Russian descent, but the boroughs diversity still comes through.

title: Classic Greek Fare, Above the Fray
description: GEORGE and Nick Kringas, who opened Nemea Greek Taverna in Mamaroneck about six months ago, learned a good deal about the restaurant business at Nikos, their parents place, in White Plains. That experience, combined with Georges training at the French Culinary Institute, seems to be paying off.

title: Talks Resume in Hope of a Christmas Tip-Off
description: On a frantic Black Friday in Midtown Manhattan, the most enticing deal in reach was not in an expensive Fifth Avenue department store, but in a cavernous office building next door. There, in a quiet law office, negotiators tried one last time to end the N.B.A.s labor crisis and to bring back pro basketball in time for the holidays.

title: J. Edgar Hoover, Sex Deviates and My Godfather
description: Baltimore

title: Traditional Thai, but With Surprises
description: WHEN was the last time you were surprised by mee krob, those sweet, crispy rice noodles that appear on many a Thai menu, or by pad Thai, which has a way of losing its luster after only a few bites? You might find yourself surprised, and pleasantly so, at Ridge Thai, a tiny but well-focused restaurant in downtown Ridgewood.

title: Games to Watch on Saturday
description: OHIO STATE AT NO. 17 MICHIGAN

title: Known for Big Portions, a Local Chain Expands
description: BUTERAS is a well-known name on Long Island. The first outpost of this homegrown mini-chain opened 20 years ago in Massapequa, followed by Woodbury in 1999, Smithtown in 2007 and Sayville just last year. The original moved to Seaford from Massapequa in 2008.

title: Gas Deal With Belarus Gives Control of Pipeline to Russia
description: The Russian government agreed on Friday to offer Belarus loans and a discounted price on natural gas worth more than $14 billion, tying Belarus, Russias small, authoritarian neighbor, into an even tighter union with Moscow.

title: All of the Flavor With Little of the Effort
description: THE greater part of the holiday season is still ahead, but entertaining can be simplified, and kitchen time reduced, through the use of in-store prepared foods  if not on the actual holiday, then during those hectic days preceding it. The three shops that follow are representative of the kinds of efforts being made by independent grocery stores around Connecticut.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: The Weeks Business News in Pictures
description: Financial woes at the United States Postal Service, a vote on a free trade pact in South Korea, a tempest in the fair trade movement and the (barely) post-Thanksgiving start to the holiday season were among the weeks top business stories.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Mexico: Complaint Over President Is Filed With Hague Court
description: A Mexican human rights lawyer, Netza Sandoval, filed a complaint on Friday against President Felipe Caldern with the International Criminal Court in The Hague, claiming that Mr. Caldern covered up and tolerated war crimes and crimes against humanity. The document, signed by 23,000 Mexicans, also accuses organized crime syndicates, Public Security Minister Genaro Garca Luna, and the countrys army and navy of partaking in the systematic repetition of abuses against civilians. Mr. Sandoval said he wanted to ensure that the courts chief prosecutor, Luis Moreno-Ocampo, begins monitoring the situation in Mexico, where more than 45,000 people have been killed since Mr. Caldern began his offensive against drug traffickers in 2006.

title: After Taking In Refugees for Years, a New Hampshire City Asks for a Pause
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  This city has long been a resettlement site for refugees, sent here by the State Department for a chance at a better life. More than 60 languages are spoken in the school system, with Somalis, Sudanese, Iraqis and other recent arrivals mixing with children whose ancestors came from Quebec to work in the mighty textile mills along the Merrimack River.

title: Sena Jurinac, Longtime Soprano in Vienna, Dies at 90
description: Sena Jurinac, whose creamy soprano and elegant, sincere musical style made her a favorite of opera fans and critics alike during a career spanning four decades, died on Tuesday at her home near Augsburg, Germany. She was 90.

title: Rev. Maurice Chase, Father Dollar Bill, Dies at 92
description: Every Sunday morning for three decades, the Rev. Maurice Chase would drive to Los Angeless most desperate neighborhood, where he would hand out crisp new one-dollar bills, along with a handshake and a blessing.

title: Jimmy Norman, R&B Singer Who Worked With Marley and Hendrix, Dies at 74
description: Jimmy Norman, a rhythm-and-blues singer and songwriter who worked with Bob Marley and Jimi Hendrix early in their careers and was involved in a longstanding dispute over songwriting credit for the song Time Is on My Side, died on Nov. 8 in Manhattan. He was 74.

title: Corrections: November 26
description: FRONT PAGE

title: For Obscure Iranian Exile Group, Broad Support in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON  At a time of partisan gridlock in the capital, one obscure cause has drawn a stellar list of supporters from both parties and the last two administrations, including a dozen former top national security officials.

title: Belarus: Rights Activist Sentenced
description: A prominent human rights activist in Belarus was sentenced to four and a half years in prison after a trial for tax evasion that Western governments denounced as politically motivated. As head of the well-known rights group Vyasna, the activist, Ales Belyatsky, has provided legal assistance and moral support to opponents of Belaruss authoritarian president, Aleksandr G. Lukashenko. The authorities in Belarus opened a criminal case against Mr. Belyatsky after officials in Poland and Lithuania mistakenly handed over information about his financial accounts in those countries. Officials from both countries later apologized.

title: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
description: Jammu and Kashmir: On Wednesday, the federal minister of state for home, Jitendra Singh, informed the Rajya Sabha, or the upper house of the Parliament, that police fire had killed 91 civilians and injured 494 civilians in the state during 2010 (Kashmir Live).

title: For American Samoa, a Series of Firsts
description: James Montague writes again from Samoa, where American Samoa earned its first international victory this week, followed that up with a tie and did both with a defender who is believed to be the first transgender athlete to appear in a FIFA world championship competition.

title: Phillipines Overtakes India as Hub of Call Centers
description: The Philippines has overtaken India as the worlds call-center capital, Vikas Bajaj reports.

title: Newswallah: Bollywood Edition
description: Desi Boyz: On-screen professions in Hindi cinema are getting more unconventional. Heroes no longer play doctors, engineers or executives and heroines arent towing the teacher/nurse/college gal line, either. Case in point: this weeks release Desi Boyz, in which the heroes Nick Mathur (played by John Abraham) and Jerry Patel (played by Akshay Kumar) become pole dancers in a London strip club. A look at some of the new-fangled Bollywood jobs:

title: N.B.A. Reaches a Tentative Deal to Save the Season
description: Six weary figures rose from their chairs early Saturday morning, their expressions telegraphing the conclusion to the N.B.A.s five-month labor crisis: Basketball is back in business, with a new labor deal that heavily favors the owners, despite some last-minute concessions.

title: Tensions Flare Between U.S. and Pakistan After Strike
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistani officials said on Saturday that NATO aircraft had killed at least 25 soldiers in strikes against two military posts at the northwestern border with Afghanistan, and the countrys supreme army commander called them unprovoked acts of aggression in a new flash point between the United States and Pakistan.

title: Forecasting End of Rex Ryan Era
description: Will Leitch of New York Magazine writes that no matter what happens against the Bills on Sunday .

title: Egypt Braces for Fresh Clashes After Protesters Death
description: CAIRO  The killing of an unarmed demonstrator by the police on Saturday threatened to stir up new protests here as Egypts military rulers and political parties braced for potential chaos surrounding the parliamentary elections scheduled to start on Monday.

title: A Facebook Chat on the Plight of Rare Wildlife  With a Twist
description: Thanks to a Tumblr post by Cem Aridag, a Turkish journalist in my new Blogging a Better Planet course at Pace University, I became aware of a creative approach to conveying the plight of endangered wildlife  a mock Facebook chat involving a tiger, panda, rhinoceros and other species facing various threats:

title: Banco Santander Chief Executive Is Given Pardon
description: LISBON  Spains departing Socialist government granted a pardon on Friday to Alfredo Senz, chief executive of Banco Santander, commuting a three-month prison sentence and a temporary ban from working as a banker. Instead, Mr. Senz must pay a fine.

title: A Large Side of Drama at Waffle House Diners
description: AVONDALE ESTATES, Ga.  The two men accused of robbing a string of Waffle House restaurants in Georgia and Alabama had a routine. They placed to-go orders, and after the food was cooked, the police say, they pulled out guns and demanded all the stores cash. Sometimes they ate, sometimes they did not.

title: Variety: Ring Toss
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  What a refreshing palate-cleanser! Ring Toss is a new puzzle  to me, at least  and I have to say I really enjoyed the multiple layers of detective work that I had to do in order to get to the alleged activity I was supposed to be performing (I admit to nothing).

title: Mysterious Europe
description: What I have never understood, and still dont understand, is how European leaders think this is going to work out. Whats the plan? Or lacking a plan, whats the story with a happy ending?

title: In Iraq, Bombs Kill at Least 11 in 2 Attacks
description: BAGHDAD  Bombs exploding in and around Baghdad on Saturday shattered the stillness of a crystalline autumn day in the desert as violence continued during the American military withdrawal from Iraq.

title: Homeless Youth Struggles to Build a Life in Chicago
description: Dressed in black baggy jeans, a gray tank top and a Harley Davidson cap skewed backward, Juan Gallaher stood under a cool late-fall drizzle devouring a peanut butter and jelly sandwich from the Night Ministrys homeless-youth-outreach van at Belmont Avenue and Halsted Street.

title: Live Analysis: Rivalry Weekend
description: Paul Myerberg will be reporting on all of the days action in college football. Check back throughout the day for updates and analysis, to ask questions or to give us your observations, whether from your couch or from the bleachers. You can also follow Paul on Twitter for additional updates throughout the afternoon and evening.

title: Egyptian Bloggers Document Deadly Clash
description: As my colleague David Kirkpatrick reports from Cairo, tensions between Egypts military-led government and protesters increased on Saturday after a man who was run over by a police vehicle at a demonstration died from his injuries.

title: Moderate Islamist Party Winning Morocco Election
description: RABAT, Morocco  A moderate Islamist party appeared Saturday to have won parliamentary elections in Morocco, the second time in weeks that voters in the region have chosen Islamists in elections brought on by the Arab Spring.

title: In London, Federer Reaches 100th Final
description: The 16-time Grand Slam champion Roger Federer reached the 100th final of his career by holding off David Ferrer, 7-5, 6-3, in the first semifinal of the ATP World Tour Finals on Saturday in London. Federer, seeded fourth in the tournament, is 69-30 in his previous 99 finals.

title: Protests Continue as Elections Draw Near
description: One person died in clashes with police in Cairo as protesters rejected the militarys appointment of new Prime Minister Kamal el-Ganzouri and demanded the generals cede power.

title: Policy-Making Billionaires
description: OVER the past 30 years, as the gap between wealthy and poor grew ever wider, total philanthropic giving almost tripled, according to annual estimates published by the Giving USA Foundation and the Center on Philanthropy at Indiana University. In an age of widening partisanship and plummeting trust in government, this outpouring of philanthropy has produced a distinct breed of philanthropist: The policy-making billionaire.

title: Vettel Beats Mansells Record of Pole Positions in a Single Season
description: SAO PAULO  Sebastian Vettel scored the 30th pole position of his career in qualifying for the Brazilian Grand Prix, but more importantly, it was his 15th pole spot of the season, which tops the record set in 1992 by Nigel Mansell.

title: Vettel Beats Mansells Record of Pole Positions in a Single Season
description: SAO PAULO  Sebastian Vettel scored the 30th pole position of his career in qualifying for the Brazilian Grand Prix, but more importantly, it was his 15th pole spot of the season, which tops the record set in 1992 by Nigel Mansell.

title: Parity, Great for N.F.L., May Hurt N.B.A.
description: All along, Commissioner David Stern was dreaming of an N.B.A. Christmas, a gift reopening on ABC. In announcing the tentative settlement of a five-month lockout early Saturday with the players leader, Billy Hunter, Stern said the league intended to begin what can technically be classified as the 2011-12 season with a televised tripleheader on Dec. 25.

title: Maria Wing and Albert Motley
description: Maria Joan-Margariete Wing and Albert Bernell Motley were married Saturday by the Rev. Stephen D. Thorne, a Roman Catholic priest, at St. John the Evangelist Roman Catholic Church in Philadelphia.

title: Myriam Cifuentes and Nicholas Goodbody
description: Myriam Yovanna Cifuentes, the daughter of Myriam C. Vargas and Ral W. Cifuentes of Bogot, Colombia, was married Saturday afternoon to Nicholas Toll Goodbody, the son of Sandra T. Goodbody and Thomas B. Goodbody of Washington. Richard A. Levie, a retired District of Columbia Superior Court judge, officiated at the home of the bridegrooms parents.

title: Laurie Goodman, Peter Andresen
description: Laurie Rene Goodman and Peter Ragnar Andresen were married Saturday evening at the Ritz-Carlton, South Beach, in Miami Beach. Rabbi Jonathan S. Kaplan officiated.

title: Sarah Odio and Andrew Torlage
description: Sarah Pro Odio, the daughter of Maran Pro Odio and Cesar H. Odio of Miami, and Andrew Michael Torlage, a son of Gilbert and Jenny Torlage of Pietermaritzburg, South Africa, are to be married Sunday at Giants Castle Nature Reserve in KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa. The Rev. Mabel Dalby, an Anglican priest, is to perform the ceremony with the assistance of the bridegrooms father, a deacon at the Anglican Cathedral of the Holy Nativity in Pietermaritzburg.

title: Elyse Katz and Jeffrey Lavine
description: Dr. Elyse Bari Katz, a daughter of Dr. Terri F. Katz and Dr. Lawrence A. Katz of Cresskill, N.J., was married Saturday evening to Dr. Jeffrey Seth Lavine, a son of Eileen Lavine and Norman Lavine, also of Cresskill. Rabbi Aaron Leibowitz, a cousin of the bride, officiated at Cipriani 42nd Street in New York.

title: Dana Winik, Joseph Kekst
description: Dana Sara Winik, a daughter of Esther F. Winik and Dr. Steven P. Winik of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Joseph Jacob Kekst, a son of Carol S. Kekst and Gershon Kekst of New York. Rabbi Malcolm Thomson officiated at the Pierrein New York.

title: Shari Swaaley, Noah Suchoff
description: Shari Brooke Swaaley and Noah Avraham Suchoff were married Tuesday evening at their Manhattan apartment. Mitchell J. Danziger, an acting State Supreme Court justice in the Bronx and a cousin of the bride, officiated. On Sunday, Rabbi Craig Scheff is to perform a religious ceremony at the Wilshire Grand Hotel in West Orange, N.J.

title: Allison Raisfeld, Robert Jaeger
description: Allison Rose Raisfeld, the daughter of Jane G. Raisfeld and Lee J. Raisfeld of Merrick, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Robert Harris Jaeger, the son of Peggy Jaeger and Steven M. Jaeger of North Hills, N.Y. Rabbi Barry Dov Schwartz performed the ceremony at the Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Roslyn, N.Y.

title: Thomas Kelly, Gregory Reardon
description: Thomas James Kelly and Gregory Joseph Reardon were married Saturday evening in New York. Colleen Kelly Sanders, a sister of Mr. Kelly who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, led the ceremony at the New Leaf restaurant in Fort Tryon Park.

title: Aliza Wohl, Avi Sadiky
description: Aliza Grabel Wohl and Avi Hirsh Sadiky are to be married Sunday afternoon at the Congregation Brothers of Israel in Elberon, N.J. Rabbi Yudy Shemtov is to perform the ceremony.

title: Laura Banish, Siddique Abbasi
description: Laura Nichole Banish and Dr. Siddique Akbar Abbasi were married Thursday evening at Montys Banquets, a catering hall in Chicago. Imam Omer M. Mozaffar officiated in a ceremony that incorporated Muslim and Christian wedding traditions.

title: Dan Kempson and Zachary Altman
description: Alexander Mackay-Smith Kempson and Zachary Clayton Altman, both baritones, were married Saturday evening at the Tribeca Rooftop, an event space in New York. Dona D. Vaughn, a Universal Life minister who taught them in the opera program at the Manhattan School of Music, officiated.

title: Susanne Menden-Deuer and Tatiana Rynearson
description: Susanne Menden-Deuer and Tatiana Ann Rynearson were married Saturday on the shore of Lake Placid in Lake Placid, N.Y. Erik K. Rynearson, Ms. Rynearsons brother, who became a Universal Life Church minister for the occasion, officiated. On Dec. 23, Gabi Hffel, a registrar for Wachtberg, Germany, is to officiate at a civil ceremony in the Wachtberg town hall.

title: California Bullet Train Project Advances Amid Cries of Boondoggle
description: SACRAMENTO  Across the country, the era of ambitious public works projects seems to be over. Governments are shelving or rejecting plans for highways, railroads and big buildings under the weight of collapsing revenues and voters resistance.

title: The Importance of Painting a Clear Picture
description: This interview with  John Riccitiello, chief executive of Electronic Arts, the video game maker, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: On Twitter, Comments by Basketball Players Are Gleeful
description: In an age when technology has all but erased anonymity, Twitter has turned into the microphone of choice for those who want a voice. Within hours of the handshake agreement early Saturday that all but ended the nearly five-month N.B.A. lockout, players started posting messages to express their relief and happiness.

title: Inventive or Error Filled, Draws Have Their Charms
description: It is natural to focus on tournament games that ended decisively. After all, they determine the winners.

title: For Occupying Protesters, Deadlines and Decisions
description: PHILADELPHIA  Cooperative is the word usually used here to describe the relationship between the campers of Occupy Philadelphia and the city, a birthplace of the constitutional right to free speech and assembly.

title: Out of Work, and Trying to Stay Positive
description: She had to miss her fathers funeral in Jamaica last year because she could not afford to go. Fresh fruits and vegetables are now a luxury. She keeps her hair short, cutting it herself to avoid the expense. Her only new clothing in more than two years has been a dress her sister paid for and a $25 blouse she bought for an interview. These are the sacrifices, large and small, that Dionne Henry has had to make since losing her job.

title: A Stealth Giant in the Gun Industry
description: Many major gun makers, including the 195-year-old Remington Arms, have quietly passed into the hands of one private company, the Freedom Group.

title: Occupiers Evicted From the New School; Graffiti Is Left Behind
description: A weeklong occupation at the New School in Greenwich Village ended with a whimper on Friday morning when university officials evicted the handful of remaining protesters from a campus gallery that was defaced sometime before they left.

title: How Freedom Group Became the Big Shot
description: SCARBOROUGH, Me.

title: Bachmann Renews Attack on Gingrich Over Immigration
description: Representative Michele Bachmann renewed her attack on Saturday of Newt Gingrich over illegal immigration, saying once again that he favored amnesty for the 11 million illegal immigrants in the United States.

title: Slipping Backward on Swaps
description: WALL STREET loves to do business in the shadows. Sunshine, after all, is bad for profits.

title: Oklahoma Wallets and Pride Were Hurt
description: OKLAHOMA CITY  The Thunder are Oklahomas only major pro sports franchise, and few N.B.A. cities viewed the news of a labor agreement with more welcome relief. The team, in its third season, reached the Western Conference finals last season, and Thunder fans have an emotional stake unlike their counterparts most other places.

title: In Coming Elections in Congo, Expectations of Fraud and Fears of Violence
description: KINSHASA, Congo  A sense of menace hangs over the long, dirty boulevards of this African metropolis.

title: Critics Say Budget Cuts for Courts Risk Rights
description: NASHUA, N.H.  For years, state courts across the nation have been scraping by on the support they get from state and local government budgets. Since the financial crisis of 2008, those budgets have been tightened in new ways that are being felt in courthouses and communities across the country.

title: Engineers Return to China Leads to Jail and Limbo
description: BEIJING  After two decades of working as a successful engineer in the United States, Hu Zhicheng decided to return to China in 2004 and apply his rich experience to designing catalytic converters for the nations booming automotive industry.

title: Cairo Undone
description: All these months later, the revolutions ardor fading, Tahrir Square feels less a model, more an inspiration.

title: A History of Violence
description: In Argentina, a rise in street crime is reflected in the increasing aggression among groups of soccer hooligans.

title: In Argentina, Violence Is Part of the Soccer Culture
description: BUENOS AIRES  Three fans of the soccer club San Lorenzo de Almagro slipped past security guards after a closed-door practice last month and berated players on the field for their recent losses.

title: Schottenheimer Feels the Pressure as the Jets Offense Sputters
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  On top of his offensive call sheet, Brian Schottenheimer regularly writes four words that are important to him. Three are the names of his wife and their two children. The fourth is fist.

title: A Familys Billions, Artfully Sheltered
description: As he stood in the opulent marble foyer of a Fifth Avenue mansion late last month, greeting the coterie of prominent guests arriving at his private art gallery, Ronald S. Lauder was doing more than just being a gracious host.

title: TV Attack Ads Aim at Obama Early and Often
description: Inside the debate halls, the clash may be Republican versus Republican. But offstage, conservatives are mounting a unified and expensive air assault on the candidates common opponent: President Obama.

title: Redefining a Position, With 15 Years of Catches
description: FLOWERY BRANCH, Ga.  The N.F.L. tight end once belonged to the brotherhood of big uglies  unheralded offensive linemen whose main duties were confined to blocking, not flinching before the snap and not being caught holding. What distinguished him from peers was the sporadic pass aimed his way.

title: Working Hard, Yes, but for Fair Pay?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Store of Their Own
description: To the Editor:

title: The Language of Sexual Assault
description: Re Confusing Sex and Rape (Nov. 20):

title: Dont Know How? Well, Find Someone Who Does
description: IS advanced technical knowledge necessary to become an inventor? Look at the story of Katherine Bomkamp, and you will see that it isnt.

title: 3 Men Forged 2 Decades of Labor Peace
description: Sometime early in Bud Seligs celebration of baseballs new collective bargaining agreement on Wednesday, he wondered if the two sides had needed to go through the pain of 1994 in order to achieve the peaceful  and very profitable  coexistence they enjoy today. It was almost certainly meant as a rhetorical question. Selig answered with a casual perhaps. But there is nothing rhetorical about the question. And the answer to it is a most emphatic yes.

title: Turn On the Server. Its Cold Inside.
description: TO satisfy our ever-growing need for computing power, many technology companies have moved their work to data centers with tens of thousands of power-gobbling servers. Concentrated in one place, the servers produce enormous heat. The additional power needed for cooling them  up to half of the power used to run them  is the steep environmental price we have paid to move data to the so-called cloud.

title: Ovechkin Slows, as Do Capitals
description: Sidney Crosbys comeback is front and center in the N.H.L., but prominent in the background are the struggles of Alex Ovechkin, who less than two years ago was neck and neck with Crosby for the title of best player in hockey.

title: They Are Still Penn State, but They Arent the Same
description: It was the morning after the Penn State scandal broke when my son Alex called from State College to say he had just read the 23-page grand jury finding of fact and was sick to his stomach. He asked if I had seen it and I told him that I had, that it was going to be the darkest episode in the universitys history and that I didnt see how Joe Paterno could survive.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Kelly Rowland
description: Kelly Rowland is a recording artist who got her start with the group Destinys Child. More recently, she collaborated with several European performers, notably the French singer Ndiya and the Italian singer Tiziano Ferro, and the French D.J. David Guetta, with whom she recorded the international dance hit When Love Takes Over. Her solo album Here I Am, released in August, made its debut at No. 1 on Billboards R&B/Hip-Hop chart.

title: Two Wall Street Titans, and a Seven-Year Tiff
description: AS Wall Street smackdowns go, this ones a doozy.

title: The Fire Bell of Unemployment
description: THE failure of the Congressional supercommittee to come up with any agreement on the budget deficit makes it even less likely that Congress will rise above its partisan divisions and act on behalf of the millions of out-of-work Americans.

title: Craven Political Crudits
description: BARACK OBAMA hates Thanksgiving and all that it represents.

title: The Enduring Cult of Kennedy
description: THE cult of John F. Kennedy has the resilience of a horror-movie villain. No matter how many times the myths of Camelot are seemingly interred by history, they always come shambling back to life  in another television special, another Vanity Fair cover story, another hardcover hagiography.

title: In the Arab World, Its the Past vs. the Future
description: IN 2001, a book came out about George Mitchells diplomatic work in Northern Ireland that was entitled To Hell With the Future, Lets Get On With the Past. One hopes that such a book will never be written about todays Arab awakenings. But watching events unfold out there makes it impossible not to ask: Will the past bury the future in the Arab world or will the future bury the past?

title: President as Piata
description: A YEAR before President Obama faces re-election, take a look at what has happened to other Western leaders confronting voters in this economic vortex.

title: Team Obama Gears Up for 2012
description: AS North Carolina Republicans tell it, the Obama for America volunteers stole in under cover of night and stayed, undetected  noticed belatedly only because of election results across the state.

title: Thanksgiving With Grammy Hall
description: EVERY Thanksgiving Mom and Dad and my siblings, Randy, Robin and Dorrie, and I piled into the station wagon and headed to Grammy Halls Spanish duplex on Rangeview Avenue in Highland Park, Calif. Dad pulled the car up the concrete driveway to the home of his mother, Mary Alice. Nobody knew where she got the money to buy a building, but she did. And she managed to hold on to her 3,000-square-foot stucco box until she and her sister, Sadie, died next to each other on hospital beds in the dining room, the same room where we ate our annual Thanksgiving dinner.

title: Going After the Pirates
description: Online piracy is the bane of the Internet. Still, bills proposed in the House and the Senate have overreached. The legislation needs to be tightened to protect intellectual property without hindering online speech and innovation.

title: In Showdown, Cameras Roll and Fists Fly
description: The HBO crews were out in full force at Madison Square Garden on Saturday to record the first Rangers-Flyers game of the season, and the teams were most accommodating. It took them only four seconds to start fighting and begin an afternoon of wild fisticuffs, nonstop chirping, rampant hostility  all the makings of good television.

title: The Famine Next Time
description: Cambridge, Mass.

title: The Curious Don Young
description: Say this for Congressman Don Young: He is thoroughly predictable and, on energy and environmental matters, almost always wrong.

title: Willpower: Its in Your Head
description: IS willpower an illusion? Is the traditional notion of a deep mental reservoir of strength a fiction?

title: Small Plates
description: Now that appetizers are often served as entrees in restaurants, life seems more complicated.

title: Tom Wicker, 1926-2011
description: THE first thing that comes to mind about Tom Wicker is his reporting on the assassination of John F. Kennedy. He was in Dallas with the president on Nov. 22, 1963. He was as stricken as the rest of us, but he was a professional. He wrote fast and accurately, making us feel the chaos in Dallas, raising the questions that would be explored in the years ahead.

title: Of Poor Farmers and Famous Men
description: To people in parts of Hale County, Ala., it isnt Let Us Now Praise Famous Men, its that book, the one everyone knows, even those who havent read it. The one that even now can stir the descendants of the families in it to feelings of irritation, weariness and sometimes seething anger.

title: Sunday Dialogue: Anonymity and Incivility on the Internet
description: Readers debate the benefits and drawbacks of requiring real names in online postings.

title: Mr. Romney on Foreclosures
description: Since the housing bubble began to burst six years ago, prices nationwide have fallen by a third. Nearly $7 trillion of home equity has been wiped out. Currently, some 14.7 million homeowners owe $700 billion more on their mortgages than their homes are worth. Going forward, prices are likely to fall further as banks put a backlog of foreclosed properties on the market. As home prices fall and more homeowners sink underwater, there will be more foreclosures and more price declines.

title: Cairo Undone
description: THERE is a notion of Cairo, and of Egypt, in which its residents have long sought refuge. Unlike other Arab countries, their borders drawn with imperial whim, lines too straight on a map to make sense, Egypt is a true nation, and Cairo a true capital. Celebrated is the sense of its unity.

title: Money At The Top
description: A bit more on the subject of whether theres significant money to be raised through higher taxes on the very rich. As it happens, theres a recent analysis from the nonpartisan Tax Policy Center that bears quite closely on this subject.

title: Family Struggles Over Justice, Charity and Memory
description: WHEN my wifes family gathered for a reunion this summer, the 60 or so cousins who made it to Santa Cruz, Calif., agreed to create a fund that would channel donations to a cause they all cared about: the plight of refugees.

title: A Family Debate
description: A family debate becomes a window into many Jews struggle with what seem to be increasingly contradictory commitments: to Israel, to justice, to the alleviation of suffering, to the preservation of memory.

title: Stony Brook Arrives, Marching Band and All
description: When Stony Brook won the Big South Conference football title on Nov. 19, nearly 8,000 fans cheered in a $22 million stadium; many of those spectators stormed the field to celebrate as time expired. Sixty-three Seawolves players were on athletic scholarships. And a 170-piece marching band, that staple of college football pomp, provided a soundtrack for the teams triumph.

title: Readers Weigh in on Obama
description: My Sunday column argues that President Obama is, in market terms, oversold; as we approach an election year, lets look at other candidates and remember the context. Sure, we have our disappointments with Obama, but he also has legitimate achievements that tend to be overlooked in this economic downturn. And hes tacking against unbelievable headwinds, economic and political: no president is going to be popular with 9 percent unemployment. All in all, I think hes been better than many critics on left and right acknowledge.

title: The 50-50 Solution
description: THE euro crisis is deepening, the government in Washington cant cut the deficit or reduce unemployment, and the economy is lurching into recession.

title: Sunday: Yin/Yang
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  First things first: What a gorgeous grid! Jeff Chen returns to us today with what I consider to be a kind of masterpiece: not only has he set the grid swirling with Yin and Yang, but some of the entries/elements themselves exhibit Yin and Yang characteristics. Ill explain.

title: Running a Red Light. Stealing a Wallet. The Cameras Are Watching.
description: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Odumegwu Ojukwu, Breakaway Biafra Leader, Dies at 78
description: Odumegwu Ojukwu, an Oxford-educated Nigerian colonel who proclaimed the Republic of Biafra in 1967 and led his Ibo people into a secessionist war that cost more than a million lives, many of them starved children whose skeletal images shocked the world, has died at a hospital in London. He was 78.

title: At Quarterback, the Non-Cutler, but Fear Not
description: Dan McGrath writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Basil DOliveira, a Symbol for Cricket and for Equality, Dies at 80
description: Just as Jesse Owens and Jackie Robinson pursued their athletic dreams and developed superlative skills before altering history, Basil DOliveira, who was classified as colored under South African apartheid, wanted only to play at the highest levels of his sport, cricket. His struggle to do that in a country of government-enforced racial segregation became a powerful symbol in the ultimately successful fight against apartheid.

title: Sergio Scaglietti, Sculptor of Sleekly Tailored Ferraris, Dies at 91
description: Sergio Scaglietti, who used intuitive genius and a hammer  seldom blueprints or sketches  to sculpture elegant Ferraris that won Grand Prix races in the 1950s and 60s and now sell for millions of dollars, died on Nov. 20 at his home in Modena, Italy. He was 91.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, November 26
description: Congressional leaders from both parties will gather Sunday to examine the collapse of the deficit deal, which could lead to significant cuts in military and domestic programs. Contenders for the Republican presidential nomination and a leader from the Congressional Progressive Caucus will also discuss the political fallout from the deals collapse.

title: Sure, Post a Review. But the Last Word Wont Be Yours.
description: YOU would like to move your car across the country, but youd rather not drive it. So you hunt around online for a car transportation company, which will strap your vehicle to a truck and roll it to your destination.

title: College Football Replay: Nov. 26
description: Rivalries mark the last big weekend of the regular season, with Michigan defeating Ohio State, Auburn battling Alabama and Kentucky notching its first win against Tennessee in 26 years.

title: A Military Camp Works to Be a Good Neighbor
description: CAMP BULLIS  Reddish-brown cedar chips from recently cleared trees spread across a patch of ground in this United States military installation, in sharp contrast to the jungle-like growth nearby.

title: For-Profit Certification for Teachers Is Booming
description: DENTON  One afternoon in mid-November, Jeff Arrington scattered 80 paper gingerbread men labeled with numbers across the floor of his high school disaster-response class.

title: Bills at Jets: Matchup to Watch
description: Bills (5-5) at Jets ( 5-5), 1 p.m. Eastern, CBS

title: With a Formula One Race Now Iffy, It Remains Unclear Who Is the Lead Driver
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: Border Fence Upends a Valley Farmers Life
description: Oscar Casares wrote this column for texasmonthly.com.

title: Starting a Business: The Romance vs. the Reality
description: SOME people who toil discontentedly in corporate cubicles regard entrepreneurship as the cure for all workplace ills. Only when theyve experienced running a business personally do they find that the reality is much different.

title: A Passion for Coaching
description: I WAS born in Harrisburg, Pa., the oldest of four children. My father owned and managed a gas station. When I was 7, my parents decided that they wanted to live in a warmer place, and decided on South Florida.

title: Assessing the Roles of Lees Top Supporters
description: On election night a couple of weeks ago, former Mayor Willie L. Brown Jr. of San Francisco celebrated Mayor Edwin M. Lees victory in style at the downtown Palace Hotel, toasting friends as he twirled through the room.

title: Creative Financing Deals May Cost City $68 Million
description: An effort by the San Francisco Municipal Transportation Agency to earn money nearly a decade ago through creative solutions could end up as a financial debacle that costs the city $68 million or more, a delayed effect of the nationwide subprime mortgage crisis, financial analysts and legal experts said.

title: Even Unfinished, the New Bay Bridge Inspires Artists
description: Millions of pounds of hulking concrete. A $50 million blue crane, rising hundreds of feet in the air above the Bay. Deep red scaffolding girding huge stretches of the unfinished span.

title: Post-Uprising, a New Battle
description: CAIRO  Through elections, protests, government formations and armed struggle, Arab countries in an arc from Libya to the gulf were engaged this past week more than ever in attempts not to simply overthrow leaders, but to decisively shape the orders that follow.

title: Noise Abatement Display Room
description: Travelers who peer into a particular small, dark room at San Francisco International Airport may wonder about its colorful monitors. The machines, which are usually unmanned, collect information on Bay Area flight traffic to be analyzed by the airports Noise Abatement Office. Behind the room, away from public view, workers in a hive of cubicles study data and decibel levels  of both the aircraft and the complaining public.  LOUISE RAFKIN

title: New Turmoil as President Comes Back to Yemen
description: SANA, Yemen  President Ali Abdullah Saleh returned to Yemen on Saturday night, days after he signed an agreement in Saudi Arabia yielding his powers to his deputy and amid increasingly confusing signals about the structure of the countrys leadership.

title: Phone Hacking Tied to Terrorists
description: Four people in the Philippines hacked into the accounts of AT&T business customers in the United States and diverted money to a group that financed terrorist attacks across Asia, according to police officials in the Philippines.

title: Woman Who Escaped From Police Car in Handcuffs Is Recaptured
description: A woman who escaped from the back of a police car on Friday after being arrested for robbing a cabdriver in Brooklyn was recaptured by the police a day later, the authorities said.

title: Rangers-Flyers Alumni Game Rosters
description: Some Rangers old-timers who will skate Dec. 31 in the Rangers-Flyers alumni game at Citizens Bank Park in Philadelphia as part of the Winter Classic festivities were on hand at the Garden on Saturday. Mike Gartner, looking trim at 52 after a career in which he scored 708 regular-season goals, was asked if he still had his legendary speed. If I did, Id still be playing, he said.

title: Alabama Looks Set for a Rematch With L.S.U.
description: AUBURN, Ala.  In the dim light outside the visitors locker room under Jordan-Hare Stadium on Saturday night, the politicians in Crimson wondered why there should even be a debate about whether they were fit to play for a national championship.

title: Tsonga Edges Berdych to Reach Final
description: Jo-Wilfried Tsonga held off Tomas Berdych, 6-3, 7-5, to book his spot in the final of the ATP World Tour Finals in London, the Frenchmans biggest final since his improbable run to the Australian Open final in 2008.

title: N.B.A. Players Held Firm on Some Points
description: For nearly 150 days of an anxiety-filled lockout, N.B.A. players made every concession imaginable  on salaries and free-agent rules and payroll limits. But in the final hours of negotiations, they at last extracted some key compromises from the league.

title: Photo Replay: Nov. 26
description: A view of the day in sports, from golf amid the lush foliage of southern China to soccer on the sands of Dubai.

title: Boston U. Edges Cornell
description: Ross Gaudets overtime goal gave Boston University a 2-1 win over Cornell in the Red Hot Hockey game at Madison Square Garden.

title: In Argentina, Violence Is Part of the Soccer Culture
description: Dont miss the article on the often-violent Argentine supporters clubs known as barra bravas by Alexei Barrionuevo and Charles Newberry in Sundays Times.

title: The Queen Is Dead; Long Live the Queen
description: WATCHING a video of their dance, Supernatural Wife, on a laptop in the sunny kitchen of Annie-B Parsons and Paul Lazars Brooklyn home last August, one could easily imagine how the couple work together. They stood over the computer, Mr. Lazar uncomfortable because of back pain, but as eager as his wife of 23 years to talk about their process. At first, it seemed as if he took a back seat in the conversation. But his shyer demeanor masks a tough certainty, whereas she surprisingly quite often follows his lead.

title: Corrections: November 27
description: FRONT PAGE

title: The Days Best in College Football
description: MATT ROARK The Kentucky wide receiver, with the Wildcats missing their top two quarterbacks, filled in behind center with 124 yards on 24 carries as the Wildcats (5-7, 2-6 Southeastern Conference) ended a 26-game losing streak to Tennessee with a 10-7 victory in Lexington.

title: How the Top 25 Fared
description: 1. L.S.U. (12-0) beat No. 3 Arkansas, 41-17, Friday

title: Newswallah: Long reads edition
description: Tehelka digs deep into the story of a young man killed by Gujarati police in 2003 on suspicion of being a terrorist, part of a pattern of such police shootings, almost all involving young Muslims. A court ruled last week that the most sensational of these killings, that of a young college student named Ishrat Jehan, was staged. But as the Tehelka article reports, hers was hardly an isolated case:

title: Win for Stanford, Record for Luck, but No Title Shot
description: STANFORD, Calif.  The fourth- and fifth-year Stanford football players were introduced in alphabetical order before their game Saturday night against Notre Dame. In the middle of the pack was quarterback Andrew Luck, who received the loudest ovation of the 23 players from the packed house at Stanford Stadium.

title: Federer Saves His Best for Last
description: No matter the year, Roger Federer always seems to find his form at the ATP World Tour Finals.

title: (Very) Old Meets New at Manuscripts Show in London
description: A trove of medieval- and Renaissance-era illuminated manuscripts, collected by the kings and queens of England between the 9th and 16th centuries, is on display in London.

title: Isolating Syria, Arab League Imposes Broad Sanctions
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The Arab League deepened Syrias international isolation on Sunday by imposing a battery of economic sanctions meant to sever most trade and investment from the Arab world, an unprecedented step against a member state.

title: In Cypress Hills, a Little-Known Monument to Journalisms Short Memory
description: Aging reporters know, long before they are gone, that they are already forgotten; their scoops and exclusives and front-page triumphs no more than historical footnotes. If that.

title: In Russia, Evidence of Misstep by Putin
description: MOSCOW  Two months after Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin revealed his intention to reclaim the Russian presidency, he returned on Sunday to the same podium, facing the same sea of rippling flags, to accept his partys nomination.

title: Gingrich Gets Key Endorsement in New Hampshire
description: 10:38 a.m. | Updated New Hampshires largest newspaper, The Union Leader of Manchester, endorsed Newt Gingrich in the 2012 Republican presidential race, a rebuke to Mitt Romney, who holds a commanding lead in most polls in the state.

title: NATO Giving Afghans More Areas to Control
