description: SAROBI, Afghanistan  Afghan forces will assume control of their own security in 18 new areas, some of them still troubled by insurgents, bringing half of the countrys population under the governments nominal authority, Afghan officials said Sunday.

title: Hedge Fund Ireland
description: Update: And heres the paper (pdf). A bit more complicated  among other things, Ireland seems to have run up debt in part by becoming a major importer of errors and omissions. But still broadly it looks like the nation-as-hedge-fund picture.

title: The Obama Spending Non-Surge
description: Blogging is a lot like teaching the same class year after year; youre always encountering the same arguments youve refuted in the past, and you want to demand why they werent listening the last time.

title: In Mexico, Quertaro Ousts Chivas
description: With so much attention in the soccer world focused on the Manchester Uniteds, Barcelonas, Real Madrids, Milans, et. al., in Europe it was easy to miss the ground shifting in Mexico Saturday night when unfancied Quertaro sent mighty Chivas of Guadalajara packing in the quarterfinals of the Apertura playoffs. It was the first time Quertaro had won a playoff series.

title: PBS Introduces New Television Channel in Britain
description: As Britain takes its news media to task, an American import, the Public Broadcasting Service, hopes to make a name for itself by offering a sober antidote to the tales of tabloid newspaper excesses that have been leading the news bulletins of late.

title: After Strike in Pakistan, Rage and Damage Control
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The political fallout from a NATO airstrike in Pakistan that was operated out of Afghanistan and killed at least two dozen Pakistani soldiers became clearer on Sunday, as Pakistan seethed over the attack and the United States scrambled to contain the damage to an already frayed relationship.

title: Time Runs Short for Europe to Resolve Debt Crisis
description: LONDON  Eighteen months into a sovereign debt crisis  and after many futile efforts to resolve it  the endgame appears to be fast approaching for Europe.

title: Liverpool and Manchester City Share Points
description: In the finest of British soccer aphorisms  it was a cracking contest.

title: Cain Acknowledges Shift in His Fortunes
description: WASHINGTON On a day when Newt Gingrich received the endorsement of an influential New Hampshire newspaper and remained atop the frequently shifting Republican field, Herman Cain acknowledged the slip in his own presidential fortunes but blamed it on false accusations and news media confusion.

title: For B.U. and Cornell, Red-Hot Rivalry Continues at Garden
description: The junior forward Ross Gaudet scored with 2 minutes 12 seconds left in overtime to send No. 15 Boston University past No. 17 Cornell, 2-1, on Saturday night in front of a capacity crowd of 18,200 at Madison Square Garden.

title: The Euro Curse
description: Joe Weisenthal has a smart post comparing Sweden and Finland. Both look solid, and fiscally are in good shape. But where Swedish bond yields have been plummeting, Finnish yields have risen. As he says, this looks like the penalty Finland is paying for being part of the euro and lacking a lender of last resort.

title: Feeling Thankful: Lockout Edition
description: With the lockout over and the players getting ready to go back to work, I find myself very thankful, even if Thanksgiving was a few days ago.

title: Webber Wins  After Vettel Loses Gearshift
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil  Mark Webber won the Brazilian Grand Prix on Sunday after mechanical problems slowed his Red Bull teammate, the world champion Sebastian Vettel, who started the race from a record 15th pole position of the season.

title: Webber Wins  After Vettel Loses Gearshift
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil  Mark Webber won the Brazilian Grand Prix on Sunday after mechanical problems slowed his Red Bull teammate, the world champion Sebastian Vettel, who started the race from a record 15th pole position of the season.

title: Words of Praise for an Iranian Exile Group Described as a Cult by Its Critics
description: As my colleague Scott Shane reports, several former United States officials have been paid to make speeches in support of a banned Iranian exile group, the Mujahedeen e-Khalq, or Peoples Mujahedeen, known as the M.E.K.

title: New Translation of Catholic Mass Makes Its Debut
description: Roman Catholics throughout the English-speaking world on Sunday left behind words they have prayed for nearly four decades, flipping through unfamiliar pew cards and pronouncing new phrases as the church urged tens of millions of worshipers to embrace a new translation of the Mass that more faithfully tracks the original Latin.

title: The Tweets of War: Whats Past Is Postable
description: Hitler spent decades plotting his campaign for world domination. Alwyn Collinson, 24, a recent graduate in Renaissance history from Oxford University, hatched his own plan to invade Poland in a mere five days.

title: The Physics of the Laboratory, and the Chemistry of the Heart
description: LOS ANGELES  Despite much learned talk about the game-changing scientific discoveries in radioactivity it portrays, Radiance, a new drama by Alan Alda at the Geffen Playhouse here, doesnt emit much in the way of theatrical light.

title: A Crucial Win With a Postseason Feel
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Again and again, the Jets have expressed their desire to host a playoff game, for the route to the Super Bowl to travel through a loud and hostile MetLife Stadium. That goal eluded them two seasons ago. Last season, too.

title: Scaling the Wall in the Head
description: Walls are back in fashion. Walls and fences. Not long ago, you may recall, Republican presidential candidates expressed their devotion to them. In October Michele Bachmann signed a pledge to support the construction of a fence that would run the entire length of the United States-Mexico border. Not to be outdone, Herman Cain voiced his support for an electrified border fence, one juiced up enough to be lethal: Touch it and die. As someone who grew up behind the Iron Curtain, I happen to know how the device works; in a certain way, we invented it (we should have copyrighted it). The ability to cross the lethal fence used to be part of the East-European survival kit.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: After Nightmarish Crash, Safetys N.F.L. Dream Lives On
description: When the Giants march onto the Superdome field on Monday night to play the New Orleans Saints, Chad Jones will run out with them. Jones will be wearing his Giants uniform; he will be on the sideline. He will do everything except play.

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: A Wrathful God, or Not, if You Buy His Book
description: He hates the Ten Commandments in exactly the same way Don McLean hates American Pie. He adores the most obscure and antiquated Old Testament strictures, for each outdated relic of an obsolete mode of living is like a child to me. He identifies himself as Maker of Little Green Apples; Rester of Merry Gentlemen; and Sole Knower of the Beach Boys. He inflicted the Potato Famine on Ireland because he was angry at the potatoes. Why? They know why.

title: Trading a Loser and Gaining an Extra Winner
description: SEATTLE  At the Fall North American Championships here the Nail Life Master Open Pairs was won late on Saturday by Justin Lall of New York City and Ishmael Delmonte from Australia. They finished one-ninth of a board ahead of Doug Doub of West Hartford, Conn., and Adam Wildavsky of New York City. Third were Eric Greco of Wynnewood, Pa., and Geoff Hampson of Las Vegas.

title: Twilight Beats Newcomers at Box Office
description: LOS ANGELES  A family film free-for-all over the holiday weekend ended with puppets doing cartwheels, elves wondering what went wrong and Martin Scorsese somewhere in between.

title: Dewdrop, Candy Canes and Sugarplum Fairy, Liberated by Familiarity
description: On Friday, after shoppers had battled one another for bargains that might not have existed, balletgoers of many ages gathered at the David H. Koch Theater for a more reliable holiday ritual. As New York City Ballets Nutcracker began its annual run of performances there, the tree telescoped on cue, the seven-headed Mouse King was vanquished, snowflakes swirled, and flowers waltzed. The Christmas magic in George Balanchines imperishable staging, as in Tchaikovskys score, is built in, guaranteed.

title: Bills Johnson Mocks Burress Shooting in Celebration
description: Touchdown celebrations are all about drawing attention to yourself, but the Bills Stevie Johnson ventured into edgy territory Sunday when he mocked Jets receiver Plaxico Burress by pretending to shoot himself in the leg after scoring on a short catch in the second quarter.

title: A Composer Lets the Birds Call the Tune
description: As the composer John Luther Adams once said of his work in an interview, It began with birds. The earliest piece in what Mr. Adams calls his active catalog is songbirdsongs, written from 1974 to 1980. In nine movements lasting just under an hour it places the listener in the middle of the natural world, the controlled chaos of birds, water and wind.

title: A Digital Future Not Quite Here for City Ballet
description: More than a year after its completion at a cost of several million dollars, a sleek media control room equipped to help the New York City Ballet record its performances for digital archiving and for theater broadcasts has languished unused.

title: Goth Stalwarts in Gloomy Fettle Recall 3 Albums
description: At the Beacon Theater on Friday night there were fans of the Cure, the long-running and influentially dismal British band; fans of the first three Cure albums, which the band was playing back to back; and people who were just excited to be at a Cure show  any Cure show  in 2011. The Venn diagram of those three groups probably doesnt include anyone overly keen to hear Descent, a sulking instrumental B-side from 1981.

title: Human Treasure Hunt: Scavenging for Moldable Models
description: In the annals of tell-alls about how pristine raw materials become shinier and tastier and more palatable, you have The Jungle, Fast Food Nation and now Scouted, the reality show about scavenging for potential models that has its premiere Monday on E.

title: Opera Based on the Play Doubt Is in the Works
description: John Patrick Shanley is set to create an opera based on his Pulitzer Prize-winning play, Doubt, with the help of the composer Douglas J. Cuomo (Arjunas Dilemma), Playbill.com reported. Commissioned by the Minnesota Opera, the production will feature a libretto by Mr. Shanley and music by Mr. Cuomo and is slated to have its premiere in 2013 as part of the companys 50th anniversary season. The original play won four Tony Awards in 2005, including best play and best director. The 2008 film adaptation, directed by Mr. Shanley and starring Meryl Streep and Philip Seymour Hoffman, received five Academy Award nominations, including for best adapted screenplay.

title: George Michael Cancels Tour Dates
description: George Michael has canceled the remaining dates for his European tour after being hospitalized in Vienna with severe pneumonia, the BBC News Web site reported. Mr. Michael, 48, right, who sang with the 1980s pop group Wham! before starting a successful solo career, was admitted last Monday. Although his condition has stabilized, and he is responding to treatment, Mr. Michael has been advised by doctors not to perform the remaining 14 dates of his Symphonica tour, according to a statement from Mr. Michaels publicist.

title: Stockard Channing Makes Quick Return
description: Less than a week after having arthroscopic surgery on her right knee,  Stockard Channing returned on Friday to her role as Polly Wyeth in Jon Robin Baitzs Other Desert Cities at the Booth Theater, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Channing, 67, missed seven performances after injuring her knee backstage on Nov. 18. She plans to continue to perform in the role, though her understudy, Lauren Klein, will take over for Wednesdays matinee performance, according to Lincoln Center Theater representatives. This drama about a dysfunctional family also stars Rachel Griffiths, Stacy Keach and Judith Light.

title: Pentagon Invites Dancing With the Stars Winner
description: Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta has invited the soldier-turned-actor J. R. Martinez, who won the most recent Dancing With the Stars competition, to meet him at the Pentagon, The Associated Press reported. During a call on Friday, Mr. Panetta told Mr. Martinez that he demonstrated the strength and resilience of wounded veterans, said Capt. John Kirby, a Pentagon spokesman. Mr. Martinez, 28, has credited his military training for his performance on the show. He and his professional partner, Karina Smirnoff, above, defeated the partners Rob Kardashian and Ricki Lake in the finale broadcast on Tuesday. Mr. Martinez was severely burned over more than 40 percent of his body when the Humvee he was driving in Iraq struck a land mine in 2003. After dozens of operations over nearly three years, he became a motivational speaker and in 2008 won a role on the former ABC soap opera All My Children.

title: Moderate Islamist Party to Lead Coalition Government in Morocco
description: RABAT, Morocco  A moderate Islamist party achieved major gains in Moroccos parliamentary election, according to final returns announced by the government on Sunday, giving it the right to lead a coalition government. King Mohammed VI is now expected to choose a prime minister from the party, Justice and Development.

title: Monday: Much-Kicked Body Part
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  What? Oh, the title of todays post? The answer is SHIN. Why, what were you thinking?

title: From Previews to Success, a Tangled Web
description: After myriad problems in previews, Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark is now making money.

title: Turn on the Cash: After a Year, Spider-Man Earns Its Weekly Keep
description: One year after naysayers were predicting a quick death, the musical Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark is doubling down on Broadway, forgoing potentially lucrative overseas tours in the near term to try to refine the New York production and burnish the long-term value of the show.

title: Weinstein Sends Hollywood an Oscar-Time Mash Note
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  There he was, Harvey Weinstein, master of the movie awards game, flanked by a golden Oscar much taller than he, and two dark- haired granddaughters of Charlie Chaplin, the King of Silents.

title: Protecting Clean Water
description: To the Editor:

title: Denying Public Access to Family Court Proceedings
description: To the Editor:

title: Disruptions: Fliers Must Turn Off Devices, but Its Not Clear Why
description: Millions of Americans who got on a plane over the Thanksgiving holiday heard the admonition: Please power down your electronic devices for takeoff.

title: Asset Sale May Be Next for AT&T
description: Rethink possible. That is both AT&Ts marketing slogan and an apt summary of the challenges it faces now that its planned $39 billion purchase of T-Mobile USA looks increasingly doubtful.

title: Hollywood Labor Fight Looms as Money for Benefits Wanes
description: LOS ANGELES  Bitter disputes over health and pension payments to union members have created plenty of drama in states and cities this year. But do not look for a movie about it  Hollywood will be too busy dealing with a labor crisis of its own.

title: The Nutcracker
description: Photos of George Balanchines The Nutcracker at Lincoln Center.

title: Looking Ahead to Economic Reports This Week
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include new home sales for October (Monday); the Standard & Poors/Case-Shiller home price index for September and the third quarter, and consumer confidence for November (Tuesday); pending home sales for September and the Federal Reserve beige book (Wednesday); the ISM manufacturing index for November and construction spending for October (Thursday); and unemployment for November (Friday).

title: The Show Is Starting, Please Turn On Your Cellphones
description: Its a taboo of the digital era: using a cellphone in a darkened theater. Some performance spaces, like Carnegie Hall, politely flash a notice reminding patrons to turn off electronic devices, while others, like the Alamo Drafthouse cinema chain in Texas, go so far as to eject violators.

title: Montserrat Figueras, Catalan Soprano, Dies at 69
description: Montserrat Figueras, the glamorous, powerfully emotive Catalan soprano who along with her husband, Jordi Savall, created ensembles that revitalized the performance of early music, died on Wednesday at her home in Bellaterra, Spain. She was 69.

title: In Liverpool, Moment of Silence Followed by Impassioned Roar
description: On a night as hard as any in recent times to feel the love for English soccer, Liverpool and Manchester City fought out a compelling, ferocious and ultimately equal Premier League game Sunday at Liverpools Anfield stadium.

title: Ron Lyle, Who Met Ali for Title, Dies at 70
description: Ron Lyle, who learned to box while in prison for murder and went on to fight Muhammad Ali for the heavyweight championship and wage a memorably furious battle with George Foreman, died on Saturday in Denver. He was 70.

title: Recovery Doesnt Stop After Injuries Heal
description: Almost four years after sustaining severe head injuries and having his nose severed by a skate during an N.H.L. game, the former linesman Pat Dapuzzo is working as a scout for the Toronto Maple Leafs. The move, although an important step on the road to physical and emotional recovery, follows a decision he made earlier this year whose implications could extend well beyond his personal healing.

title: The Branding of the Occupy Movement
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Kalle Lasn, the longtime editor of the anticonsumerist magazine Adbusters, did not invent the anger that has been feeding the Occupy Wall Street demonstrations across the United States.

title: In Newark, a More Welcoming Response to Occupiers
description: NEWARK  The protesters attracted no drum circles but bobbed their heads to the rap music blasting from a passing sedan.

title: A Reporter Entangled in the Story
description: Last summer, Amelia Hill, a special investigations correspondent for the British newspaper The Guardian, helped crack open the countrys hacking scandal for all to see. Working with her colleague Nick Davies, she pulled back the veil on the mind-boggling hacking of the murder victim Milly Dowlers phone by The News of the World.

title: Just Asking About J. Lo, Coke Zero and Cookies
description: IT is time again to ask 20 questions about advertising, marketing, the media and popular culture.

title: Francis H. Cabot, 86, Dies; Created Notable Gardens
description: Francis H. Cabot, a financier and self-taught horticulturalist who created two of the most celebrated gardens in North America and helped preserve scores of others, died on Nov. 19 at his home in La Malbaie, Quebec. He was 86.

title: Election Financing: Paths and Pitfalls
description: To the Editor:

title: The Giant of Strength From Toe to Head
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  When the Giants and the New Orleans Saints play Monday night, there will be at least 20 players in the Superdome who weigh more than 300 pounds. There will be fleshy linemen and muscle-bound pass rushers battling to be proved the stoutest.

title: I. Michael Heyman, Smithsonian Leader, Dies at 81
description: I. Michael Heyman, who led the Smithsonian Institution in the 1990s during a period of significant expansion and fierce controversy over the exhibiting of the Enola Gay, the plane that dropped an atomic bomb on Hiroshima, died on Nov. 19 at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 81.

title: Disney Releases Marvel App
description: When reading books, some children like to turn the page, others like to swipe the screen.

title: An Amateur With a Pros Resolve
description: SAN MARTIN, Calif.  Collegiate golf is the acoustic version of the pro game: unamplified by applause, announcers, grandstands, clacking electronic scoreboards or chattering caddies. For upward of five hours, the competitors are essentially alone with their thoughts.

title: Vasily Alekseyev, 69, Champion Weight Lifter, Dies
description: Vasily Alekseyev, the Soviet super heavyweight lifter who won 2 Olympic gold medals and set 80 world records, reigning as the so-called worlds strongest man in the 1970s, died Friday at a heart clinic in Badenhausen, Germany. He was 69.

title: Texans Begin to Feel the Pain of One Injury Too Many
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.

title: Oklahoma Continues String of Recent Mild Earthquakes
description: The generally placid, well-mannered state of Oklahoma has developed a very West Coast habit of late: the state, it seems, has got the shakes.

title: Santas Schooled in Restraint
description: The economic downturn is forcing some to help curb childrens expectations.

title: Deadline Passes for Occupy Philly to Dismantle Camp
description: In center city Philadelphia, hundreds gathered outside City Hall in a show of solidarity ahead of a city-imposed Sunday evening deadline to clear a campsite there. The protesters braced for a police sweep, but it did not take place immediately after the 5 p.m. deadline, surprising few.

title: An Olympic Youth Appeal
description: Continuing its effort to make sure young media consumers dont miss the coming Olympics, the International Olympic Committee is focusing the latest iteration of its promotional campaign on the 12- to 19-year-old market.

title: Educating Santa
description: The Charles W. Howard Santa Claus school in Midland, Mich., teaches aspiring Santas everything from dance lessons to beard grooming.

title: In Gloomy Economic Times, Santas Learn to Help by Curbing Expectations
description: MIDLAND, Mich.  Here, at the nations oldest, most celebrated, school for would-be Santa Clauses, much has stayed exactly the same over its nearly 75 years. A proper Claus ought to have pleasant breath, his beard curled just so and a hearty laugh that rumbles not from the throat but from deep below the diaphragm.

title: Hey, Hey, Hey, Goodbye?
description: Under the N.B.A.s new labor deal, every team can waive one player and remove his salary from the cap. The so-called amnesty provision could help teams create cap room or save millions on the luxury tax. (The player is still paid.) Here are five bad contracts worth expunging:

title: Poof! Goes a Bad Contract, if Any N.B.A. Team Wishes
description: In the N.B.A., where bad contracts are more common than lane violations, every team executive dreams of a way to expunge his mistakes.

title: Newspapers Endorsement Has Been Leading Indicator in New Hampshire
description: On Sunday, The Union Leader of Manchester, New Hampshires largest newspaper, endorsed Newt Gingrich for president. The endorsement represents one of the most tangible signs of parts of the conservative establishment coming around to Mr. Gingrich, who to date has received very few endorsements from Republican elected officials. It also represents a blow to Mitt Romney, who had led all polls of the state.

title: In Fog of War, Rift Widens Between U.S. and Pakistan
description: WASHINGTON  The NATO air attack that killed at least two dozen Pakistani soldiers over the weekend reflected a fundamental truth about American-Pakistani relations when it comes to securing the unruly border with Afghanistan: the tactics of war can easily undercut the broader strategy that leaders of both countries say they share.

title: Chinese Exports Show Trouble for Asian Economies
description: Chinas manufacturing engine is sputtering, which bodes ill for other Asian exporters like Japan and South Korea. Theyre counting on China to offset slowing demand from the United States and Europe. But much of what China imports goes into making its own exports. And even what bona fide domestic demand is left is likely to be affected by a trade slowdown.

title: Partnership Preserves Livelihoods and Fish Stocks
description: HALF MOON BAY, Calif.  Stevie Fitz, a commercial fisherman, was pulling up his catch in one of his favorite spots off of Point Reyes in June when he saw something terrifying  in his nets were nearly 300 bocaccio, a dwindling species of rockfish protected by the government.

title: Once a Protector, Now Grateful for Her Own Rescue
description: Once, while most New Yorkers slept, Marjorie Suarez would be wide awake.

title: For a Weekend, at Least, Retailers See Record Numbers
description: Spurred by aggressive promotions from retailers, American consumers opened their wallets over the holiday weekend in a way they had not since before the recession, setting records in sales and traffic.

title: Greeks Balk at Paying Steep New Property Tax
description: NEA IONIA, Greece  Ioannis Chatzis is 86 and lives in a tiny, single room, surviving on a pension that is just enough to pay for food and care for his bedridden wife.

title: Syracuse Fires Fine After New Allegations in Molestation Case
description: With clipboard in hand, the Syracuse associate head coach Bernie Fine was a continual presence at the side of Jim Boeheim as the Orange mens basketball program bloomed into a national power. But as the scope of molestation allegations against Fine grew over the weekend, the university decided to fire him.

title: Senator Questions Extension of Tax Cut
description: WASHINGTON  The No. 2 Senate Republican, Jon Kyl, expressed concern on Sunday about President Obamas proposal to continue a reduction in the Social Security payroll tax and questioned whether the tax cut had fostered the creation of jobs, as Democrats say.

title: The Perils of Celebrating Before Anythings Won
description: East Rutherford, N.J.

title: Power Ceded, Yet President of Yemen Declares Amnesty
description: SANA, Yemen  Ignoring calls by his opponents to stop announcing decisions that affect the country, President Ali Abdullah Saleh declared a general amnesty on Sunday for people who had committed follies during the uprising and political crisis that began in Yemen 10 months ago.

title: Bowl Championship Series Standings
description: The B.C.S. rankings are determined by three components: the Harris Interactive poll, the USA Today coaches poll and the average of six computer rankings. Each component counts one-third toward a teams B.C.S. score.

title: Bees and the City
description: To the 19,200 species of bees on this planet, a researcher named Jason Gibbs at Cornell University has just added 11 more, all of them from the Eastern United States. More interesting still, four of the bee species come from New York City and its immediate environs.

title: Zyngas Tough Culture Risks a Talent Drain
description: Zyngas chief executive, Mark Pincus, got an earful from employees last month.

title: A Vacancy That Needs to Be Filled
description: Now that Congressional Republicans will no longer have Dr. Donald Berwick to demonize as head of the federal agency that runs Medicare and Medicaid, is it too much to hope that they will declare a cease-fire and allow quick confirmation of his proposed successor?

title: Still Fighting Against AIDS
description: The latest report from the United Nations agency in charge of the global fight against AIDS reveals substantial success by some measures and stagnation by others. The challenge, in tough times, that must be met is to find enough resources to capitalize on scientific breakthroughs and keep the campaign moving forward.

title: Friend? Foe? A Republican Scorecard
description: Moments before the start of a recent presidential debate at Dartmouth College, Mitt Romney and Herman Cain flung open the doors to their closet-size green rooms and ran into Newt Gingrich.

title: Lincolns Do-Nothing Generals
description: The Civil Wars first year was one marked by inactivity and battlefield frustration. There was just one major battle, at Bull Run, and only a handful of minor engagements, most of them semi-guerrilla fighting in and around Missouri.

title: L.S.U.-Alabama Rematch for Title Is All but Certain
description: Advocates of the Bowl Championship Series, the relentlessly criticized method college football uses for picking its national title game, often stick to the talking point that every week feels like a playoff.

title: Youth Leader in Egypt Straddles Line of Revolution and Electoral Change
description: CAIRO  Over the past week, just as his campaign to capture a Parliament seat for Egypts strongest liberal party should have reached its zenith, Zyad Elelaimy stopped giving speeches and migrated back to the place where he made his mark 10 months ago: Tahrir Square.

title: Thanksgiving Weekend Sales Were Strong This Year
description: Retail sales were up sharply this Thanksgiving weekend

title: Lottery Numbers
Rough Times Take Bloom Off a New Years Rite, the Rose Parade
description: PASADENA, Calif.  With its peppy bands, whimsical floats and flood of flowers, the Rose Parade here has long been a symbol of the hopes of a New Year.

title: From Ashes of Olympic Bid, a Future Rises for the Far West Side
description: Late in his first term, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg suffered a stinging defeat when, after an extensive planning and public relations effort, New York City lost its bid to host the 2012 Summer Olympics.

title: Federer Comes Out on Top
description: In his 100th final, Roger Federer outsteadied Jo-Wilfried Tsonga, 6-3, 6-7 (6), 6-3, Sunday at the ATP World Tour Finals in London, capturing his 70th career singles title. The victory made Federer the first man to win the year-ending championships six times and extended his winning streak to 17, his longest since 2009.

title: Are Germany and France Drifting Apart?
Things to Tax
description: The supercommittee was a superdud  and we should be glad. Nonetheless, at some point well have to rein in budget deficits. And when we do, heres a thought: How about making increased revenue an important part of the deal?

title: The Price of Intolerance
description: Its early yet for a full accounting of the economic damage Alabama has done to itself with its radical new immigration law.

title: New Life, Surprisingly, for ABC Prime Time
description: The prospects for ABC and its new chief programmer, Paul Lee, hardly looked rosy at the start of the fall television season.

title: The Politics of Economics in the Age of Shouting
description: I share a virtual neighborhood with a legion of Times reporters, editors and columnists who know more than I will ever know about business and economics. (Look! Right over there: a Nobel-prize-winning economist!) In this humbling company, on this intimidating matter, who am I to tell anyone what to think? And so my plan was, frankly, to avoid the subject.

title: Lululemon Athletica Combines Ayn Rand and Yoga
description: OTTAWA  Lululemon Athletica, the retailer of yoga pants and hoodies, has long decorated shopping bags with slogans that appear to have been lifted from self-help books. But this month its bags have asked a question that some may find more provocative: Who is John Galt?

title: A Laugh on the Subway, and Other NYTimes.com Reader Stories
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Today Repeats Come to the Late-Night Rescue
description: This fall, NBC quietly started to repeat the fourth hour of the Today show, starring Kathie Lee Gifford and Hoda Kotb and usually seen at 10 a.m., the next day at 2 a.m.

title: With Blocks, Educators Go Back to Basics
description: Huddled together on the reading rug of a prekindergarten classroom on the Upper West Side, three budding builders assembled a multilayered church with a Gothic arch. Nearby, another block artist created a castle with a connecting courtyard. Meanwhile, a fifth toiled earnestly on a shaky tower, eliciting oohs and aahs from across the room when it came tumbling down.

title: Euro Zone Leaders Weigh New Budget Rules
description: BERLIN  Euro zone leaders are discussing a deal among themselves to institute strict new budget rules for their countries, rather than go through the long, complicated process of amending European Union treaties. By acting more quickly, they hope to reassure skeptical financial markets and encourage the European Central Bank to do more to fight the deepening sovereign debt crisis on the Continent.

title: Speeding Through an Intersection of New and Old
description: For years, the prospect of an oblong intersection on West 72nd Street was part of a larger battle over the future of the Upper West Side. Now that that future has arrived, the intersection has become a gateway between two parts of the neighborhood with very different approaches to resolving community problems.

title: Federal Cuts Give Maine a Chill as Winter Approaches
description: BANGOR, Me.  Michele Hodges works six days a week but still cannot afford a Maine winters worth of heat for her trailer in Corinth, a tiny town where snowmobiles can outnumber cars.

title: Gingrich Eager to Be More Than an Anti-Romney
description: For Newt Gingrich, this is when it gets serious.

title: Egypts Turmoil Overshadows First Post-Mubarak Vote

description: WASHINGTON  Fighting from behind in the final days of the 2008 presidential election, Senator John McCain found a weapon in an unscripted encounter between his opponent, Senator Barack Obama, and a voter.

title: The Future of the Obama Coalition
description: For decades, Democrats have suffered continuous and increasingly severe losses among white voters. But preparations by Democratic operatives for the 2012 election make it clear for the first time that the party will explicitly abandon the white working class.

Prosecution Explains Jury Tampering Charge
description: Julian P. Heicklen, a 79-year-old retired chemistry professor, has often stood on a plaza outside the United States Courthouse in Manhattan, holding a Jury Info sign and handing out brochures that advocate jury nullification, the controversial view that if jurors disagree with a law, they may ignore their oaths to follow it and may acquit a defendant who violated it.

title: Word of the Day | asymmetric
description: asymmetric \a-s-me-trik\  adjective

description: Stocks and the euro rose sharply Monday, as investors took heart at signs that European leaders were pushing toward new measures to rescue the currency union.

title: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Monday
description: India and Pakistan will hold their first-ever joint court proceedings, when a judicial commission from Pakistan comes to India to authenticate Ajmal Kasabs statement in Mumbai. Mr. Kasab has been convicted for his role in the 2008 Mumbai terror attacks. It is a unique case, where the lawyers are from Pakistan, the witnesses are from India, and the judge will be an Indian, a source told The Indian Express.

title: Los Angeles Police Withdraw After Occupy Eviction Deadline Passes
description: LOS ANGELES  It had all the makings of a showdown: shouting protesters, police officers in riot gear, with batons drawn as they pushed forward to disperse the crowd. But in the end, as the deadline for Occupy Los Angeles protesters to clear their tents from City Hall passed early Monday morning, there was hardly a commotion.

title: News Quiz | Nov. 28, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Hanging By a Thread
description: After a tumultuous year, the Broadway musical Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark turns one.

title: After Mumbai Remembrances, Anger
description: This past weekend, the third anniversary of the three-day siege of Mumbai that began Nov. 26, 2008, and left more than 170 dead, a series of remembrances were held.

title: In a Surprise, Calm Prevails in Egypts Elections
description: CAIRO  Unexpectedly large crowds of Egyptians on Monday defied predictions of bedlam and violence to cast their votes in the first parliamentary elections since the ouster of President Hosni Mubarak.

title: Killings and Intimidation Mar Elections in Congo
description: KINSHASA, Congo  Ballot boxes on fire, rebel fighters gunning down poll workers and outbursts of mob violence marred Congos national elections on Monday, only the second time this vast and troubled country has held anything resembling a democratic vote.

title: Nov. 28, 1943 | Allied Leaders Meet at Tehran Conference
description: On Nov. 28, 1943, President Franklin D. Roosevelt, Prime Minister Winston Churchill of Britain and the Soviet leader Josef Stalin met in Tehran during World War II for the start of a four-day conference. It was the first meeting between the Big Three Allied leaders.News of the conference was not released until three days after its completion, when it was announced by Moscow radio. The Dec. 4 New York Times reported that Moscow radio had not indicated the nature of political and military discussions that took place in the Iranian capital, but it was generally assumed they dealt with the coordination of military plans for the final assault on Nazi Germany and with the unification of political plans for making peace with Germany on the basis of unconditional surrender.

title: In Cairo, a Painterly Cast of Characters
description: The most recent images of Egypts ongoing upheaval depict chaotic crowds of anonymous young men and women. But since Miguel Angel Snchezmoved to Cairo in 2009, he has singled out the individual, bathing them in dramatic light and shadows like old master portraits.

title: The Start of a New Era for Roman Catholics
description: WHAT change occurred over the weekend in the Catholic Mass?WHAT are two examples of the new wording?

title: Hack a Mole
description: MONTREAL  Something is amiss in Venezuelas Twittersphere: all of a sudden, opposition figures with a long history of criticizing the government of President Hugo Chvez have flipped, posting hearty praise for Chavismo and streams of invectives against their own camp. Has the government made a great leap in winning over new followers? Hardly. Instead, one after another, opposition figures have had their accounts taken over by progovernment hackers.

title: Test Yourself | Math, Nov. 28, 2011
description: Test your math skills with this question created by Bobson Wong at Math for America from the article Stone-Washed Blue Jeans (Minus the Washed).

title: Dire Warnings Are Building on European Debt Crisis
description: PARIS  European leaders faced mounting pressure on Monday to overcome divisions and move ahead quickly with new plans to prevent the euro currency region from fracturing, as warnings multiplied that the crisis could endanger the global economy and cause credit to dry up in the banking system.

title: Berlin Exhibit Explores Magnitsky Case
description: A permanent exhibition at the Checkpoint Charlie Museum (Friedrichstrasse 43-45; mauermuseum.de) in Berlin exposes a modern-day saga of governmental corruption, coercion and torture. The Sergei Magnitsky case revealed egregious abuses of power that continue to plague Putins Russia and which ultimately led to the tragic demise of the 37-year-old tax attorney Magnitsky, while he was held captive in a maximum security Russian prison.

title: Week 12 Quick Hits: Denvers Defense Wins Another
description: A quick tour of Sundays Week 12 games, including an eerie silence in Philadelphia, a star turn by a punter and a costly celebration by a receiver.

title: Occupy Economics
description: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

title: Lawmakers Look to Rein In Their Investing
description: The coverage was hard-hitting and shocking to some: Members of Congress received special opportunities to get in on the ground floor of stock offerings, and were actively trading in shares of companies whose prosperity they influence and whose conduct they help to regulate.

title: What Time Should Black Friday Sales Start?
description: In addition to the shopper who was said to have used pepper spray on her competitors, Black Friday 2011 will be remembered for store openings that took place at midnight or earlier, meaning that Black Friday actually started on Thanksgiving. What do you think about this? Did you shop the early sales or know people who did?

title: Ken Russell, Director Fond of Provocation, Dies at 84
description: Ken Russell, the English filmmaker and writer whose outsize personality matched the confrontational brashness of his movies, among them Women in Love and The Devils, died on Sunday at his home in Lymington, England. He was 84.

title: Transforming the Sarangi into a Supple Human Voice
description: Ustad Sultan Khan, the renowned sarangi player and classical singer who diedSunday, was sought after by Bollywood composers and traveled with George Harrison, but in India he earned the most respect for reviving a dying art.

title: Joe Kapp, the C.F.L.  and a 48-Year-Old Grudge
description: They played the Grey Cup on Sunday in Vancouver, but the C.F.L. battle that many people wanted to discuss happened at the Canadian Football League alumni luncheon two days earlier. Joe Kapp, 73, fought an old C.F.L. adversary, Angelo Mosca, also 73, on the stage.

title: Complaint Box | Gift Registries
description: The joy of gift-giving is over. Finding that certain something that will elicit shrieks of surprise: a thing of the past. Lost forever is the warmth of knowing that a friend or family member thought long and hard about just what to give you. Also gone  the laughter when a loved one opens a third blender or fourth wok.

title: This Week In Small Business: What Would Canada Do?
description: Whats affecting my clients, my small-business and other small-business owners this past week.

title: Breakfast Meeting, Nov. 28
description: Ticket sales for Hollywoods five-day Thanksgiving sales period  an important springboard to Christmas  totaled about $234 million, an 11 percent decline from the period a year earlier, Brooks Barnes reported. The No. 1 film was a holdover, The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn  Part 1 (Summit Entertainment), which took in an estimated $62.3 million during the long weekend. It had a two-week total of $221.3 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles ticket data. At No. 2 was a new release, The Muppets (Walt Disney Studios), which had estimated ticket sales of $42 million.

title: A Note to Readers
description: This week Im in Paris, France. Ill still write in this space, but not as much as usual. So Ive asked David Firestone, who covers politics for the editorial board, to pick up the slack. Youll notice his byline throughout the week.

title: The New Oscar Season
description: Melena Ryzik looks at the newest slate of Oscar contenders and polls New Yorkers for their opinions.

title: Andy Reid, DeSean Jackson and Endings for Eagles
description: The two longest-tenured coaches in the N.F.L. met on Sunday in Philadelphia. After the game, fans and columnists questioned whether Andy Reid, No. 1 on the list, should keep his job. Of course, it was Philadelphia, so thats never not going to be a question.

title: Monday Reading: The Dwindling Power of a College Degree
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

description: Today, the OECD warns that things are looking vewy, vewy bad:

description: Defying expectations of chaos and violence, unexpectedly large crowds turned out to vote.

title: Were Baaa-ack
description: Its post-Thanksgiving, pre-NBA return and at least a few weeks until the next Republican debate. All of which means that its time once again for the Carpetbagger to strap on our heels and our celebrity bull detector (who are we kidding; we wear these every day) and hit some red carpets in pursuit of the latest news about stars, filmmakers, hangers-on, enablers and their enduring, ever-shimmering quest for Oscar glory, or at least a nice bump in DVD sales.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: DEAL NOTES

title: Breakeven Bad
description: One measure Ive been tracking lately is the German 5-year breakeven. Thats the difference between the interest rate on ordinary German 5-year bonds and the interest rate on 5-year bonds that are indexed to inflation (as measured by the euro area harmonized CPI); because one bond is protected against inflation while the other isnt, the breakeven amounts to an implicit market forecast of inflation.

title: Guardians of the Peace, and Guardians in the Press
description: Antigovernment demonstrators took to the streets of Manhattan, marching helter-skelter from the Battery to the United Nations. Several hundred were arrested.

title: Daily Report: Zyngas Big Risks
description: As Zynga, the maker of popular social games like FarmVille and CastleVille, moves toward a public stock offering, its business practices and its chief executive, Mark Pincus, are getting plenty of scrutiny. Evelyn M. Rusli writes in Mondays Times that the companys internal culture is something like an endless war: Employees log long hours, managers relentlessly track progress, and the weak links are demoted or let go. She talked to former senior employees who fear that this relentlessness could damage the company. Start-ups including Rovio, the maker of Angry Birds, have rebuffed acquisition offers from Zynga.

title: Opinion Report: Alabamas Immigration Law
description: From the editorial page

title: Principals' Rebellion Against Evaluations Grows
On Black Friday, Pepper Spray Carried the Day
description: Each year, retail reporters are expected to step to Black Friday, that hardy perennial of trend stories, and find a fresh angle. (Before the opening gong even sounded, we learned that $395,000 Ferraris were hot and Wal-Mart was not.)

title: The Author as Your Average Joe
description: Joseph Gordon-Levitts star turns in 50/50 and Inception may have overshadowed the recent success of his online passion project, hitRECord.org. The Web site invites artists from all walks of life to collaborate with the actor, resulting in music, short films and, now, a picture book called The Tiny Book of Tiny Stories ($15). The sweetly amateurish story collection is the first in a trilogy of titles from It Books, part of the publishing giant HarperCollins. Here Gordon-Levitt, 30, explains why this book deal is not just a coup for his young company but also an object lesson in how it works.

title: So Did Tebow Play Well?
description: Not according to ESPNs Total QBR, a relatively new rating system that assigned Tim Tebow a low score of 29.7 in Denvers overtime victory against San Diego on Sunday.

title: A Shopping Day Invented for the Web Comes of Age
description: Cyber Monday may have started as a made-up occasion to give underdog e-commerce sites jealous of Black Friday a day of their own, but it has become an undeniably real thing  surprising even the people who invented it.

title: Monday Matchup: Giants at Saints
description: Giants (6-4) at Saints (7-3), 8:30 p.m. Eastern, ESPNLine: Saints by 7

title: Bowie Shoots Down Report of Musical Based on His Songs
description: The idea of a stage musical shaped around the songbook of David Bowie may sound like a beautiful moonage daydream, but it apparently wont come to fruition unless the godfather of glam rock ch-ch-ch-ch-changes his mind.

title: With Asset Sale, Tepco to Raise $2.4 Billion
description: TOKYO  The Tokyo Electric Power Company, operator of the crippled nuclear power plant at Fukushima, said on Monday that it would raise 186 billion yen, or $2.4 billion, by selling its entire stake in the mobile network operator KDDI.

title: Syria Calls the Arab Leagues Sanctions Economic War
description: DAMASCUS, Syria  The Arab League declared economic war on Syria when it leveled broad trade sanctions against it, Syrias foreign minister, Walid al-Moallem, said on Monday, warning that the country could use its strategic location to retaliate.

description: The Guardian: Craving something lighter before the Christmas parties kick into high gear? Heres an array of tempting recipes for vegetable curries.  Jeff Gordinier

description: Gawker Media on Monday named new editors for two of its most prominent sites, the flagship Gawker and the sports and mens lifestyle site Deadspin.

description: November 28, 2011 - Unexpectedly large crowds of voters turned out to cast their votes in Egypt's first parliamentary election since the ouster of Hosni Mubarak in February.

description: Nearly 200 nations open a global conference on climate change, with industrialized countries arguing that big developing economies like China, India and Brazil must submit to emissions targets regardless of whether wealthier countries set global warming in motion. [Reuters]

title: New Wave of Bombings Raises Toll for Iraqis
description: BAGHDAD  A yellow taxi loaded with explosives blew up at the crowded front gates of a prison north of Baghdad on Monday morning, killing at least 13 people, many of them security guards or civilians waiting to visit jailed family members.

title: The Case Against Banning Chocolate Milk
description: Heres the clearly very sensible Penny McConnell of the Fairfax County school system, in Virginia, on chocolate milk: Banning a food may not be as helpful as the more complicated task of teaching kids to look at their whole plates, and make good choices.

title: Barney Frank to Quit House After 30 Years
description: 5:32 p.m. | Updated  NEWTON, Mass.  Representative Barney Frank, the tart-tongued liberal who has served in the House of Representatives for 30 years, said Monday that he had decided to retire in 2012 after his Massachusetts district was recently redrawn and it became clear that he would have to fight harder than he wanted for re-election.

title: Works by Disney, Before He Started Mousing Around, Are for Sale
description: Long-lost works by Walt Disney are suddenly sprouting like the bits of a chopped-up broom brought magically to life.

description: As he waits to learn whether the Boston Red Sox will hire him to be their next manager, Bobby Valentine took time to visit the tsunami-ravaged city of Sendai in Japan on Monday.

description: The best of readers street style for the week of Nov. 21.

description: Its bead versus bead  each about to slide down a wire and into a soft wax disk. The wires are identical except for a bump. On one wire the bump faces up, and on the other wire it faces down.

title: Surprise! There Are Already  Oscar Controversies
description: If you were busy following the Greek debt crisis  and of course you were; Kardashian is a Greek name, right?  let the Bagger catch you up as, lo and behold, there has been scandal in awards land already. In descending order of interest to water-cooler watchers, cinephiles and film industry insiders:

title: Shocker: Readers of News of the World Vanish
description: News of the World, the 168-year-old newspaper that was closed in July by News Corporation in the wake of phone-hacking revelations, seems to have taken its readers with it.

title: Monday Motorsports: A Win for Mark Webber Closes Historic 2011 Formula One Season
description: Not always dutifully, Mark Webber played second fiddle in 2011 to Sebastian Vettel, his Red Bull teammate, as Vettel strung together one of the most dominant seasons in Formula One history. At the Interlagos circuit in the state of So Paulo, Brazil, he finally got the upper hand, though it required an assist from an ill-tempered gearbox.

title: Icahn Offers to Buy Metals Company
description: 1:07 p.m. | Updated

title: Pakistan Rejects U.S. Account of NATO Strikes Along Border
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Prime Minister Yousaf Raza Gilani angrily protested the NATO strikes that killed two dozen Pakistani soldiers over the weekend, even as early American and Pakistani accounts of the events diverged sharply and it remained unclear exactly what precipitated the attack.

title: Julie Conason: Learning Through Relationships
Bad Tidings
description: After the wave, the author, a self-absorbed Frenchman filled with self-pity, experienced a life-changing emotion: empathy. The following excerpt is adapted from Lives Other Than My Own, which was published in September by Metropolitan Books.

title: The Fallout Over Syracuses Abuse Scandal
description: On the heels of the recent and continuing events at Penn State University, another college is also under scrutiny surrounding allegations of child molestation. As Pete Thamel reported in Mondays Times, Syracuse University dismissed its longtime associate head basketball coach Bernie Fine on Sunday night after three accusers came forward and a graphic taped telephone conversation from 2002 emerged.

title: Gingrich Says Hes Conservative Alternative to Romney
description: Newt Gingrich, who not long ago was urging his fellow Republican candidates to avoid tearing one another apart in pursuit of the partys presidential nomination, took a new approach on Monday by explicitly declaring: I dont claim to be the perfect candidate; I just claim to be a lot more conservative than Mitt Romney.

title: 40 Years on the Court, and Its Not Even Halftime
description: How many basketball players in pickup games around New York City still have a killer two-handed set shot?

title: A Deeper Scowl for the Pumpkins of Kane Street
description: The sidewalk seems a not-so-distant resting place for some pumpkins in an array of 100 carved by Jane Greengold of Cobble Hill, Brooklyn. The wretched decline of the tortured scowls is a Halloween tradition being closely watched by City Room.

title: Tribeca Film Festival Names New Artistic Director
description: 12:46 p.m. | Updated

title: The Immigrant Fitness Test
description: Last week, the editorial board praised Newt Gingrich for breaking from the Republican pack and supporting a path to legal residency for long-time illegal immigrants. Now Mr. Gingrich is starting to flesh out that ideasince he has revived his standing on the right wing of the party and appears to think hes got a shot at the nominationbut it turns out to be much less thoughtful and generous than it appeared during the debate.

title: Iran Moves to Downgrade Its Relations with Britain
description: Iran enacted legislation on Monday to downgrade relations with Britain, in retaliation for intensified sanctions imposed by Western nations last week to punish the Iranians for their suspect nuclear development program. Britain promised to respond robustly.

title: The Sudden Pivot at Syracuse
description: Sometimes scandals make the accompanying outrage easy. At Penn State, it was all but served on a platter complete with a doily and silverware. The child sexual abuse scandal of Jerry Sandusky came with an 18-month grand jury investigation and a university in full turtle mode. With Syracuse, even if you wanted to greet the firing of the assistant basketball coach Bernie Fine for similar abuse allegations with the same sense of horror, even if its the right thing to do, its just more complicated.

title: A New Old Way to Fish
description: Fisherman and an environmental group are working together to bring a collapsed fishery back from the brink by using older fishing methods and new technology.

title: Backup Quarterbacks Lead Playoff Chase
description: It has become the portrait of the season, a quarterback standing disconsolately on the sideline, sometimes surrounded by trainers, but often alone with his splint or brace or sling.

title: Plan for a Memorial Splits Newports Old Guard
description: NEWPORT, R.I.  When Doris Duke was clearing a patch of derelict buildings here in the late 1970s to create a modest patch of open space known as Queen Anne Square, she was sometimes spotted personally directing the backhoe drivers at dusk, acting as both foreman and steward of the enormous fortune that she lavished on such restoration projects.

title: What Rikers Visitors Saw, and What Really Happened
description: The long line of women and children and, much more scarce, men outside Rikers Island on visiting day is never what youd call happy to begin with, with mothers corralling cranky children and shouting over the roar of jets, practically within reach, leaving neighboring La Guardia Airport. It does not take much to set this group of people off.

title: Drowning in Grovers Lake
description: Never mind drowning the US government in a bathtub: Grover Norquist is trying to drown the whole economy in a lake:

title: Barney Franks War of Words With Wall Street
description: Barney Frank, the famously grumpy Massachusetts representative, who announced on Monday that he will not seek re-election next year, has had a 16-term legacy studded with legislative accomplishments.

title: How the Fed Rescue Benefited Banks
description: A report by Bloomberg News offers a new way of quantifying the Federal Reserves vast efforts to save financial companies from collapse during the crisis that peaked in 2008.

title: Lens: Harvey Wang
description: Lens: Harvey Wang

title: Childrens Weight Does Not Affect Safety of Child Seats, Researchers Find
description: As long as children ride in a properly positioned seat for their height and weight, child safety and booster seats provide adequate protection in a crash, regardless of whether a child is underweight or overweight, according to a study released by the Childrens Hospital of Philadelphias Center for Injury Research and Prevention.

title: Judge Blocks Citigroup Settlement With S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON  Taking a broad swipe at the Securities and Exchange Commissions practice of allowing companies to settle cases without admitting that they had done anything wrong, a federal judge on Monday rejected a $285 million settlement between Citigroup and the agency.

title: Steven Pinker
description: An interview with the Harvard psychologist and linguist on violence, language and Twitter.

title: Baseballs New Schedule Should Be All About Rivalries
description: Baseball, that most traditional of sports, is once again making a radical shift. For the third time in two decades, it is realigning. The latest move will transfer the Houston Astros from the National League Central to the American League West, giving each division 5 teams and each league 15 teams, creating the need to schedule at least one interleague series at all times.

title: Human Natures Pathologist
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Steven Pinker was a 15-year-old anarchist. He didnt think people needed a police force to keep the peace. Governments caused the very problems they were supposed to solve.

title: On the Campaign Trail with Harvey Weinstein
description: LOS ANGELES  The Artist, a mostly silent film that played well abroad, is finally open  and into the Oscar race  in the United States. As we reported here, Harvey Weinstein is doing his best to make the film a contender, even bringing two granddaughters of Charlie Chaplin to a screening at the Academy itself.

title: The Power Politics of Water Struggles
description: When youre driving through a war zone, your instinct may be to roll up the car windows. Wrong move. A bullet is less likely to hit you than to strike the glass, which will shatter and probably cause injuries. It takes firsthand experience to learn these tricks of the trade, and for years, Mark Zeitoun has sought out such experience.

title: Pinkerisms
description: Selections from Steven Pinkers writings on language, evolution and the mind.

title: The Just This Once Money Trap

title: Behind the Cover Story: Benoit Denizet-Lewis on Bulldogs
description: Benoit Denizet-Lewis, the author of Sundays cover article on bulldogs, began writing for the magazine in 2002, when he was 26. Since then, he has written six cover articles and numerous features, including his recent piece about his ex-gay friend, Michael Glatze. He is also the author of America Anonymous: Eight Addicts in Search of a Life.

title: Chait on the Democrats, Frum on the Republicans
description: In addition to Frank Richs piece on the parallels between Barack Obama and J.F.K., whose premise I disputed rather vigorously in yesterdays column, New York Magazines politics issue included provocative pieces by Jonathan Chait (on why Democrats are perpetually dissatisfied with their presidents) and David Frum (on why Republicans have lurched into extremism and folly). I agree with many of the points that both authors make, but I think that both pieces indulge in a kind of partisan bias in reverse: Instead of giving their own side too much credit, they make their own sides vices seem somewhat more distinctive than they really are. For instance, here is Chait contrasting Democratic infighting with Republican loyalty:

title: CUNY Prepares for More Student Protests
description: As City University of New York trustees prepare to vote Monday afternoon on a series of tuition increases over the next few years, the school system is bracing for a possible repeat of the conflict that marred last weeks hearing on the increases.

title: TimesCast | November 28, 2011
description: Egypt votes in a historic parliamentary election; Congolese voters encounter problems at the ballots; and the first anniversary of "Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark."

title: The Rakoff Rejection

description: George Kateb is a Professor Emeritus in the political science department at Princeton University.

description: The long fight for Transatlantic Holdings appears to be finally over.

description: Q: (Reader)

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
description: The Acorn division of Totes-Isotoner, Lewiston, Me., which sells footwear, selected Kelliher Samets Volk, Burlington, Vt., as its agency. Billings were not disclosed for the assignment, which had been handled by local design companies.

title: Lana Peters, Stalins Daughter, Dies at 85
description: Her three successive names were signposts on a twisted, bewildering road that took her from Stalins Kremlin, where she was the little princess, to the West in a celebrated defection, then back to the Soviet Union in a puzzling homecoming, and finally to decades of obscurity, wandering and poverty.

title: In New Ads, Some (Drinkers) Like It Hot
description: Remember the commercials that proclaimed Reeses Peanut Butter Cups offered two great tastes that taste great together? A campaign for a new variety of a venerable liqueur is serving up a similar idea, with a Cajun twist.

title: An Interview With George Kateb
description: The philosopher on a good life in a damaged world.

title: Prosecutor Who Cant Avoid Trouble
description: There is probably no more sobering measure of the changing landscape of on-screen entertainment than the downward trajectory of Scott Turows legal thrillers.

title: For the Jets, a Victory That Exposed Some Weaknesses
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Jets defended the Bills final drive Sunday  the one that stalled at the Jets 24, after three straight incompletions  with zone coverage. Or, as Darrelle Revis put it, the dont let them in the end zone strategy.

title: True Color
description: One of New York Citys hottest hair colorists, Frdric Fekkais Reyad Fritas, can spin straw into gold. I see a lot of overprocessed, dry hair out there, he says. Not on his glossy girls, bien sur. We get their hair into amazing condition and give them color that sparkles.

title: Really? The Claim: Coffee Can Prevent Some Medications From Working
description: THE FACTS

title: Rebels Resume a Crackdown on Somali Aid
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  The Shabab militant group, which has already blocked many aid agencies from reaching starving people in Somalias famine zones, ordered 16 more aid agencies to shut down on Monday. Heavily armed Shabab fighters then raided the offices of several aid groups, looted equipment and accused the aid workers of being spies.

title: Youssou NDour to Put Music on Hold and Turn to Politics
description: With his country gearing up for a hotly contested presidential election early next year the Senegalese singer and songwriter Youssou NDour, one of the biggest stars of the world music genre, is putting his career on hold to plunge into the political fray. Its not clear in what capacity  as a candidate for public office himself, or just lending his prestige and support to someone already in the running  or for how long, but he made the announcement over the weekend and set a date to stop performing.

title: Photo Replay: Nov. 28
description: A view of the day in sports included flag waving at cricket matches, a volleyball spike, and perhaps a cue shot at the world snooker championships that began in India.

title: Drumbeat of World War II, Tweet by Tweet
description: So you thought Twitter, the popular social media site, was only good for whats happening now? Minute-by-minute updates on your friends, celebrities and latest news? No more. While you can still keep tabs on what happened 20 seconds ago, some feeds offer a chance to brush up on military history.

title: The decline of violence, a medical adventure story and a hunt for the cure for AIDS.
description: The decline of violence, a medical adventure story and a hunt for the cure for AIDS.

title: #OccupyWallSt Roundup, Day 73
description: Perhaps slower to act after all that turkey, city officials allowed Monday morning eviction deadlines to pass with little change for Occupy protests in Los Angeles and Philadelphia. The Los Angeles police said they were focused on clearing streets for the morning commute and arrested four protesters for blocking traffic. In Philadelphia, protesters who held an eviction party Sunday night were still waiting for things to change early Monday afternoon. Nine people were arrested in Augusta, Maine, for demonstrating at the governors mansion after their encampment was closed. [New York Times, Portland Press-Herald]

title: File Under: Huh? Norton Hires Actors to Stage Facebook Status Updates
description: Another advertiser is joining in a popular trend, producing and sponsoring live content that can be watched online.

title: Flavorful and Sustainable Fish
description: If youre concerned about which fish are environmentally safe to eat, you cant do better than consulting the Web sites of the Monterey Bay Aquarium or the Environmental Defense Fund for their handy pocket guides for buying seafood (or choosing it in a restaurant). I printed one and put it in my wallet this week, and cooked fish for dinner every night. My son loves seafood, so he didnt object.

title: Google Pulls the Plug on a Renewable Energy Effort
Hallmark Hall of Fame Has Rough Start on ABC
description: After proving to be a stable presence on broadcast television for more than 60 years, the Hallmark Hall of Fame is off to a rough start in its new home at ABC. This feel-good film franchise was dropped by CBS in May, after a 16-year partnership, only to be picked up in July by ABC.

title: New Hope of a Cure for H.I.V.
description: Medical researchers are again in pursuit of a goal they had all but abandoned: curing AIDS.

title: Capitals Turn to Hunter to Spur Underperforming Stars
description: The Washington Capitals know there is a problem, and now hope their former star and team captain Dale Hunter is the solution.

title: A Closer Look at Teeth May Mean More Fillings
description: Until 2010, Amelia Nuwer, 22, visited the same dentist every year in Biloxi, Miss., her hometown. And every year she came back with a clean bill of dental health: no fillings necessary.

title: Election Monitoring Crowd-Sourced in Egypt
description: Although some prominent Internet activists decided to boycott Mondays elections in Egypt to protest continued military rule, many well-known bloggers spent the day working as self-appointed election monitors. Using the same social media tools that helped them to force Hosni Mubarak from office, the bloggers posted images of long lines at polling places and passed on reports of apparent violations of the electoral code.

title: It Could Be Old Age, or It Could Be Low B12
description: Ilsa Katz was 85 when her daughter, Vivian Atkins, first noticed that her mother was becoming increasingly confused.

title: Pakistan: Children With Pneumonia Fare Better With Home Treatment, Study Finds
description: Letting lady health workers in rural northern Pakistan treat children with severe pneumonia in their homes worked better than the established practice of telling parents to take them to a hospital, a new study has found.

title: TimesCast | Bridging Cairos Divisions
description: November 28, 2011 - Along July 26th Street are Cairo's toiling and privileged, its Islamists and less pious, and on election day, Egypt's divides were bridged, if only for a moment.

title: Doctor and Patient, Bound by Mutual Dependency
description: A doctor is sitting at his desk, waiting for the last patient of the day. The patient is very late. The doctor has called his phone: no answer.

title: Mission Not Accomplished
description: Matt Yglesias and Kevin Drum say the right thing about revelations that big banks got very easy terms during the financial crisis: the real scandal isnt so much that those banks got rescued as that the rest of the population didnt.

title: Federer Wins on Court but Not at Polls (Not That He Was Interested)
description: Roger Federers triumph over Jo-Wilfried Tsonga at the Barclays ATP World Tour Final on Sunday was an exclamation point on a season-ending, 17-match win streak that has reinvigorated his career at a time when some were beginning to question his ability to beat the worlds top players.

title: A Setback for Electric Cars
description: DETROIT  Even as they pour money into developing a range of electric vehicles, automakers have acknowledged that widespread sales of battery-powered models are years away.

title: Risks: Partial Hysterectomies Affect Menopause
description: Younger women who have hysterectomies that preserve the ovaries almost double their risk of early menopause, a new study has found.

title: Are Dentists Overtreating Your Teeth?
description: Have you had a rash of fillings after years of healthy teeth? The culprit may be microcavities, and not every dentist thinks they need to be treated, reports todays Science Times.

title: Childbirth: Benefits Seen in Clamping the Cord Later
description: Waiting three minutes or longer before clamping a newborns umbilical cord reduces the prevalence of iron deficiency at four months, a large trial has found.

title: Romney Supporters Take to the Phone Lines
description: 3:15 p.m. | Updated  Call it the Mitt Blitz.

title: Supreme Court TV? Nice Idea, but Still Not Likely
description: WASHINGTON  A couple of weeks ago, the Supreme Court agreed to hear a constitutional challenge to President Obamas health care law. The case is a once-in-a-generation blockbuster, and the court underscored its importance by scheduling five and a half hours of oral arguments, the most in any case since 1966.

title: Mercury Creeps Upward, Ignoring That Its Nov. 28
description: So you believed the forecasters who said the temperature on Monday would soar to the upper 60s and beat the late-November record. You thought about wearing a T-shirt and shorts to the 5:30 p.m. holiday tree lighting at 63rd Street and Broadway. You fantasized about tropical temperatures the rest of the week.

title: In the Bronx, a Collision of Cars, Celebrity and Copyright
description: Jennifer Lopezs recent My World television spot for Fiat is proving to be about as unlucky as Sherman McCoys South Bronx detour in Bonfire of the Vanities.
