description: If you qualify for pretax transit benefits, youll probably see the perk shrink starting in January.

title: At C. Wonder, Something Feels Familiar
description: THE designer Tory Burch might not be the gayest divorce in town, but she is certainly one of the most doggedly productive. Her distinctive crest, two facing Ts that resemble a medieval cross, bedecks ballet flats from Manhasset to Myanmar; her signature caftans billow above thousands of tummies; the vice presidents wife carries one of her handbags. The golden-haired Ms. Burch, mother of three and stepmother to three more, has also dated Lance Armstrong, and, though she has resisted the term socialite (heck, who wouldnt?), is often photographed at parties wearing a chunky statement necklace and an enigmatic grin.

title: Beginners and Take Shelter Pick Up Spirit Nominations
description: Beginners continues its indie roll, earning nominations for best feature, best screenplay and best director at the Film Independent Spirit Awards, the West Coast answer to the Gothams. Another Bagger favorite, Take Shelter, picked up nominations in those three categories, alongside the likely Oscar contenders The Descendants and The Artist; Michael Shannon, the star of Take Shelter, also earned a nod for best male lead.

title: A Tutoring Company Learns a Lesson
description: In my last post, Alexandra Mayzler pondered the best way to train the tutors she hires to work for her company, Thinking Caps Tutoring. She had devised a manual but feared she wasnt presenting the information it contained in a compelling or memorable way.

title: Barry Llewellyn, a Founder of the Heptones, Dies at 63
description: Barry Llewellyn, a founding member of the popular Jamaican harmony trio the Heptones, died on Nov. 23 in St. Andrew, Jamaica. He was 63 and lived in Brooklyn.

title: F.T.C. Settles Privacy Issue at Facebook
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Accusing Facebook of engaging in unfair and deceptive practices, the federal government on Tuesday announced a broad settlement that requires the company to respect the privacy wishes of its users and subjects it to regular privacy audits for the next 20 years.

title: Indoor Maps for Android Users
description: Today, Google announced that its Google Maps Android app would feature indoor mapping data for several airports, stores and shopping malls in the United States and Japan. Heres the press release announcing the new feature.

title: #OccupyWallSt Roundup, Day 74
description: Occupy Wall Street protesters may have cheered Judge Jed S. Rakoffs ruling Monday against the Securities and Exchange Commissions proposed settlement with Citigroup, but a friend of his says, Dont confuse Judge Rakoff with some member of the Occupy Wall Street movement, citing his career defending investment banks and corporations as a litigator. [DealBook, BusinessWeek]

title: Are Your Children at Risk From Vaccine Exemptions?
description: Vaccine refusal rates are going up. The Associated Press reports a rise in the number of parents in many states who either dont vaccinate their children or who limit vaccinations. In eight states, including Washington and Colorado, more than 1 in 20 kindergartners attending public school havent had all of the shots that are required for school attendance, with many choosing to skip shots for philosophical reasons.

title: Basketballs Misguided Fixation With Starting
description: A place in the starting lineup is one of the N.B.A.s most overrated currencies. In actuality it indicates nothing, other than that a given team prefers to have a particular player on the floor to complete a specific lineup. Sometimes the starting five consists of the top five players on the roster, but more often it is a group that has been configured to manage strength and weakness, balance starters and reserves, and create a meaningful product out of a roster of moving parts.

title: Sony Music Executive to Rejoin Bertelsmann
description: 3:37 p.m. | Updated

title: Even With Reruns, CBS Is No. 1
description: Even with CBS showing a full slate of repeats the other broadcast networks could not compete on Monday night as CBS ranked first in total viewership and in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic segment, according to Nielsen. New episodes of Terra Nova and House on Fox made only slight gains compared to last week against the weakened competition, with 7.2 million total viewers and 7.3 million respectively. ABCs presentation of How the Grinch Stole Christmas drew 7.7 million viewers.

title: Brother, Can You Spare a Line?
description: This past summer I drove across the country interviewing people who had lost their jobs since 2007  since the housing market disintegrated, since Lehman Brothers evaporated, since layoffs subsumed the work force. I asked for details about the climactic phone call, the conference room, the look of the sky out the window, the security escort, the drive home: all the particulars of the experience.

title: Support for Tea Party Drops Even in Strongholds, Survey Finds
description: 11:11 p.m. | Updated  The full report of this article is available here.

title: Google and Apple Are Both Winners in Mobile Race, Report Says
description: It is not very often that you get two winners and two losers in the same competition. Yet according to a new report to be issued Wednesday by Nielsen, the market research firm, Google and Apple are both winning in the mobile smartphone race.

title: A Worrisome Snag in the E.C.Bs Bond-Purchasing
description: An effort by the European Central Bank to intervene in government bond markets hit a technical shortfall Tuesday, raising new questions about how long the central bank can avoid taking bigger steps to address the euro regions debt crisis.

title: 2nd Bribe Case for Lawmaker Just Acquitted
description: Even to those accustomed to the sins of New York politicians, the latest trials and tribulations of Assemblyman William F. Boyland Jr. may have hit a new low.

title: New York Film Critics Circle Go With The Artist
description: All day long the New York Film Critics Circle has been posting the results of its much-earlier-than-usual year-end voting on Twitter, a slow drip of news somewhere between live-tweeting World War II and those moments when Doogie Howser would sit typing pensively on his blue computer screen (Carrie in Sex and the City or Jenna in Awkward for later generations).

title: A Call for Lower College Costs
description: In an article posted on The Timess Web site, our colleague Tamar Lewin writes that Education Secretary Arne Duncan on Tuesday pushed higher education officials to think more creatively  and with much greater urgency  about how to contain the spiraling costs of college and reduce the burden of student debt on our nations students.

title: The Pace of Reform Accelerates in Myanmar
description: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton is scheduled to arrive in the country on Wednesday as a show of support for its transformation to a nascent democracy.

title: From Spring to Winter: Explaining the Egypt Elections
description: Overview | What is happening in Egypt in the aftermath of revolution? How does the situation in Egypt compare with other nations that have experienced uprisings in the Arab World? In this lesson, students get updated on Egypt and then develop a series of current events talks for their community on what has happened to the Arab Spring as it turns into Arab Winter.

title: For AMRs Now-Former Chief, a Long Career Felled by Chapter 11
description: Throughout his eight-year tenure as the AMR Corporations chief executive, Gerard J. Arpey had consistently emphasized one strategic point: He would not put the airline into bankruptcy.

title: Choosing Between the Rich and Everyone Else
description: Republicans have been railing against the latest Democratic plan to extend the payroll tax cut, and its pretty clear why. Of all the contortions theyve been forced to make by their refusal to raise taxes on the rich, this is the most painful. It is the one that will affect average Americans the most directly, and will starkly illustrate the advantage Republicans prefer giving to the rich over everyone else.

title: Traffic Warnings, 17 Syllables a Sign
description: Look! Its a street signwith a haiku underneath.They are new, Tuesday.

title: Demarchelier in the Studio
description: Cathy Horyn interviews the celebrated fashion photographer Patrick Demarchelier on his book Dior Couture.

title: Asset Managers Lottery Claims Raises Controversy
description: 4:25 p.m. | Updated

title: Human Centipede Sequel Is Banned Again, This Time in Australia
description: In the latest twist in the multilegged tale of The Human Centipede 2 (Full Sequence), that shock horror film has now been banned in Australia, weeks after it made its premiere at the countrys Brisbane International Film Festival.

title: Opening the Doors of Dior
description: SAINT LAURENT, Chanel, Dior: the names of the most famous Paris houses sort of dance off the tongue. Their histories defeat the idea that younger generations might be bored with old things. And a stream of books and films helps to assure that they wont be.

title: Cain Reassessing Candidacy
description: The move by Herman Cain comes a day after an Atlanta woman named Ginger White gave details of what she said was a 13-year affair with him.

title: TimesCast | American Airlines Bankruptcy
description: The parent company of American Airlines files for Chapter 11.

title: How Does the American Airlines Bankruptcy Affect You?
description: American Airlines, which filed for bankruptcy on Tuesday, is among the last of the major carriers to do so, raising predictable questions for customers about how the changes will affect them. Based on what can be gleaned from the bankruptcies of other airlines over the past few years, the general answer is that at least for the short term, the experience of flying with American will remain largely the same, though changes are likely down the road.

title: Week 12 Film Review: Del Rios Last Stand
description: A closer look at some games from Week 12, with the benefit of film analysis:Texans O vs. Jaguars D

title: Notes From a Young American in Congo: The Election
description: There is no government in Congo, Maman Marie Nzoli, director of the local non-profit organization COPERMA, said over a year ago.[Joseph] Kabilas government is a government that doesnt exist.

title: In Only Nine Months, Book of Mormon Earns Back Its Broadway Costs
description: 6:09 p.m. | Updated

title: Apps for Autistic Children
description: The iPad has been hailed by many as a life-changing device for children on the autism spectrum or with other special needs, helping them to communicate or develop fine motor skills. But the market is so flooded with apps for special-needs kids that it can be overwhelming to find good ones. Our friends at the Gadgetwise blog have offered a roundup of Web sites that review these apps (and dont take referral fees from the manufacturers). Read more at Gadgetwise.

title: Come Together
description: On Sunday night, the fashion collective Three as Four opened its highly anticipated exhibition Insalaam Inshalom at the Beit HaIr Center for Urban Culture in Tel Aviv, bringing to fruition a project over two years in the making. Covering the walls of the four-story building in fabric printed with their spring collections central motifs, which are made of a mix of Muslim and Jewish symbols, the designers Gabi Asfour, Adi Gil and Ange Donhauser invited 10 artists to show works that relate to the projects central notion: that Judaism and Islam can live side by side. Weve accumulated the energy of artists and performers who are like-minded,Asfour said. We tried to balance things from all sides, though its always difficult.

title: A Pastry From Brittany Making Waves Stateside
description: Who could pass up something billed as the fattiest pastry in all of Europe? Thats how the kouign-amann, a specialty of Brittany in France, was described to me when I visited the region this summer.

title: inSALAAm inSHALLOm
description: A film by the fashion collective threeASFOUR for "inSALAAm inSHALLOm," a new show at the Beit Ha-Ir Center for Urban Culture in Tel Aviv.

title: Boeheim Has Explaining to Do
description: Jim Boeheims involvement in the abuse scandal at Syracuse differs from that of Joe Paternos at Penn State, but he may suffer the same fate, and it may be justified, says William C. Rhoden.

title: The Life Report: Karen Matarangas
description: The following Life Report was submitted in response to my column of Oct. 28, in which I asked readers over 70 to write autobiographical essays evaluating their own lives.

title: 20111129_BAGHDAD
description: 20111129_BAGHDAD

title: After a Brief Reversal, MSNBC Pulls Ahead of CNN
description: CNNs re-emergence as the top ratings competitor to the Fox News Channel seems to have been short-lived.

title: Yanks Calm Is Sign of No Pressing Needs
description: Pay attention to the Yankees this time of year, and you remember certain myths of past off-seasons. Bubba Crosby was once the answer in center field, not a free agent named Johnny Damon. Alex Rodriguez would be shunned if he opted out of his contract. Mark Teixeira was too expensive to pursue. Rafael Soriano was not worth the sacrifice of a first-round draft pick.

title: Photo Replay: Nov.29
description: South Koreas Samsung Lions won the 2011 Asia Series, the Los Angeles Galaxy of M.L.S. toured Asia and the world snooker championships continued in India.

title: Sports of The Times: Boeheim Has Explaining to Do
description: Jim Boeheims involvement in the abuse scandal at Syracuse differs from that of Joe Paternos at Penn State, but he may suffer the same fate, and it may be justified, says William C. Rhoden.

title: Bankruptcy Hearing for AMR
description: The AMR Corporation is in bankruptcy court for its first day of Chapter 11 hearings. The parent company of American Airlines, it is seeking approval for a flurry of customary motions that will keep its lights on as it seeks to cut costs in bankruptcy protection.

title: Pictures of the Day: Iran and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Iran, Egypt, Congo and Pakistan.

title: At Diamond Foods, Accounting Weighs on Pringles Deal
description: It appears that not even Diamond Foods knows what the future holds for its proposed acquisition of Procter & Gambles Pringles brand of chips. Behind the uncertainty of Diamonds deal are competing narratives of a company that is either the victim of an attack by short-sellers or otherwise responsible for its own troubles.

title: Design Competition for an AIDS Memorial Begins
description: The coalition behind the plan to create an AIDS memorial in St. Vincents Triangle Park is kicking off an international design competition and has selected a panel of judges. At the helm will be Michael Arad, the designer of the poignant and provocative 9/11 memorial in the footprint of the former World Trade Center.

title: The Revkin Collection in the Climate E-mail Release
description: 8:39 p.m. | Updated below |Since Nov. 19, 2009, when someone unknown distributed a large batch of climate-related e-mail messages extracted from servers at the University of East Anglia, and now again with a newly released cache, Ive noted that I appear repeatedly in the exchanges, both as a message author and subject. Heres the search result for my name.

title: Americans Used to Be Much More Anti-Tax
description: In addition to his Economix post, Bruce Bartlett also has a Tax Notes column today looking at public support for raising taxes (instead of or in addition to cutting spending) to narrow federal deficits. He found dozens of surveys conducted over the last year showing that most Americans believe that taxes should be part of any deficit reduction package.

title: S.&P. Cuts Its Ratings for 15 Banks
description: 9:37 p.m. | Updated

title: TimesCast: American Airlines Bankruptcy
description: The parent company of American Airlines filed for bankruptcy protection in an effort to reduce labor costs and shed its heavy debt load.

title: Proposed High School Angers Parents at Gifted and Talented School
Skype Can Expose Your Location, Researchers Say
description: Remember when a prankster could make himself a general nuisance by calling your home phone and quickly hanging up?

title: The Giving Spree | Shalom Harlow
description: Who: The model Shalom Harlow.

title: Primary Sources
description: Its usually boring when critics criticize critics or analysts analyze their fellow analysts. As Yeats put it in Nineteen Hundred and Nineteen,

title: Reviewing Fatty Cue
description: Last month, after reviewing Rouge et Blanc, the French-Vietnamese restaurant in SoHo, I speculated here at Diners Journal on the status of fusion cuisine. While many of the restaurants that gave fusion a bad reputation have thankfully passed on, the notion of blending the techniques and ingredients of multiple cultures pervades restaurants today.

title: A Roadhouse With a World View
description: CONSIDER butter. Its exalted, whether in the copious amounts that flavor and enrich classic French haute cuisine, in the supremely pure examples reverently served at Per Se, or even in the farmer-labeled bars peddled at the shop on the corner.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Facebook Bans at Work and Emoticons
description: Heres what the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web.

title: Music Is Love, and Love Is Music
description: For Frank Ocean, love is in many ways music itself. In his elegant, savvy, slightly crooked postsoul, he shifts sneakily between the two topics, singing about love as a byproduct of music and using the subject of music to dig deep about love.

title: A Visual Valentine for the Lower East Side
description: A butcher, dwarfed by his towering wall of sausages. Women hunched over sewing machines in a crowded room. A Jewish pillow maker.

title: Ginger-Glazed Short Ribs
description: Adapted from Home Cooking With Jean-Georges by Jean-Georges Vongerichten (Clarkson Potter, 2011)

title: Bananas in Lime Syrup
description: Adapted from The Family Meal: Home Cooking With Ferran Adri by Ferran Adri (Phaidon, 2011)

title: Turkey Increases Pressure on Syria Over Oppression
description: ISTANBUL  Turkish officials continued Tuesday to step up pressure on Syria, saying they would consider having their military cross the border to impose a safety zone if the Assad government failed to stop killing citizens demanding democratic change.

title: Creatures Big and Small, Remaking a 16th-Century Legend
description: Before there was Rocky Horror, before there was Frankensteins monster, before even the sorcerers apprentices broom, there was Golem: the original man-made being gone awry.

title: Trailer: The Legend of Zelda
description: The Legend of Zelda: Skyward Sword, for the Wii, updates the beloved game from Nintendo's past.

title: The Top of the World, Then Prison in Siberia
description: Soviet Communism may have toppled, but in high places in the Kremlin the old authoritarian mind-set still prevails. Enemies of the power elite can be arrested, tried on trumped-up charges and imprisoned in a system as labyrinthine and secretive as it was during the Soviet era. At least that is the perspective on Russian political power games expressed in Khodorkovsky, the German filmmaker Cyril Tuschis sympathetic documentary portrait of the persecuted Russian oligarch Mikhail Khodorkovsky, who ran afoul of the former Russian president Vladimir V. Putin, who is now prime minister.

title: Chuko
description: 552 Vanderbilt Avenue (Dean Street), Prospect Heights, Brooklyn; (718) 576-6701; barchuko.com.

title: Caf de la Esquina
description: 225 Wythe Avenue (North Third Street), Williamsburg, Brooklyn; (718) 393-5500; esquinabk.com.

title: RIM Reacts to Bring-Your-Own Devices Policies
description: OTTAWA  The maker of the BlackBerry announced details on Tuesday of how it will try to bring some BlackBerry features to Apple iPhones and iPads as well as smartphones and tablet computers running Googles Android operating system.

title: Rewriting History (Second Revision)
description: Most journalists  and regular people, too  dream of knowing what the worlds most influential figures are saying, thinking and plotting in their most private moments. And thats why we have Hollywood.

title: States Receive Health Care Grants
description: Hoping to alleviate concerns of states, the Obama administration on Tuesday said it would award nearly $220 million in new federal grants to states to set up exchanges where uninsured Americans may eventually be able to buy medical coverage as part of the federal health care law.

title: Egyptians Turn Out for a Second Day of Voting
description: Polls opened for a second day of voting on Tuesday in the first parliamentary elections since the ouster of President Hosni Mubarak.

title: 24-Hour Arty People | Ts Art Basel Miami to Do List
description: The artist Rirkrit Tiravanijas beach towel for Art Production Funds Works on Whatever editions pretty much sums it up. Art Basel Miami Beach, now in its 10th year, kicked off today, and if you plan to take it all in  and see some art  you are going to be busy indeed. Ts impartial to-do list, below, even allows for some quality beach time, so dont forget to throw in that towel.

title: Punch Lines for the Right and the Left
description: If all of Americas registered Republicans were struck by an ideology-specific bird flu, and 50 among them had to be placed in a secure bunker to repopulate the species entirely, P. J. ORourke would hold a place on many peoples list, mine included.

title: A Warm-Hued Beginning for Quartets New Violinist
description: The Juilliard String Quartets first violin chair was once its rock of stability: Robert Mann held it from the groups founding in 1946 through 1997 and saw the players in every other position change at least once.

title: Now a Word (and a Dance) by a Sponsor
description: Advertising a pharmaceutical product must be a tricky business; theres so much cognitive dissonance involved. Think of the television commercials that show images implying happy outcomes, while a voice simultaneously lists at length everything that could go wrong. Or take the home page of a Web site promoting the anti-H.I.V. drug Reyataz: a column of side-effect warnings fights for space with photos of a woman stretching and leaping, perfectly toned, the picture of health. Underneath her is one more disclaimer: not a patient dramatization.

title: Cyber Monday Shopping Surpasses Expectations
description: The final numbers for holiday gift shopping on Cyber Monday are rolling in, and online sales beat early expectations, making Monday the biggest online shopping day on record.

title: TimesCast | Protesters Storm Embassy
description: Protesters ransacked the British Embassy in Tehran.

title: Supporters Buy Ad Urging Palin to Run
description: Sarah Palin supporters just wont give up.

title: Iraq War Presidential Drop In
description: BAGHDAD  As the Times Mark Landler reports, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. arrived in Baghdad Tuesday night for an unannounced visit to mark the twilight of the United States militarys presence in Iraq with ceremonies thanking American and Iraqi troops for their work and sacrifices, and meetings with Iraqi leaders on the road ahead for the two countries.

title: Older Music Refracted Through a Modernist Prism
description: There were only two relatively short contemporary works in the remarkable recital performed by the tenor Ian Bostridge and the composer and pianist Thomas Ads on Monday night at Carnegie Hall. Yet this was inspired programming: strategic choices, in the context they set up, teased out the modernist resonances in older music, even a cycle as familiar as Schumanns Dichterliebe.

title: Footnote
description: Richard Fleeshman and Caissie Levy, above with Mr. Fleeshman, who are playing the lead characters Sam and Molly in the London production of Ghost: The Musical, will reprise their performances in the Broadway staging this spring, the producers said on Tuesday. The show is scheduled to begin preview performances at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater on March 15 and open on April 23.

title: U.S. to Take Over Orchestras Pensions
description: A federal bankruptcy judge has agreed to let the federal government take over the Philadelphia Orchestras pension plans, saying the orchestra was unlikely to survive if it tried to keep running them itself. The two pension plans, one for musicians and the other for staff members, cover about 200 people. Some musicians are likely to have their pensions reduced after the takeover. Although the governments Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation insures defined-benefit pensions, its insurance is limited. In the past symphony orchestras competed for and retained top talent by promising generous pensions, so musicians with many years in the Philadelphia Orchestra probably have earned benefits above the insurance limit. The orchestra, which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in April, had asked for the governments help with its pensions, saying that it could not raise money if donors thought their dollars might end up in a troubled pension fund. The pension funds are set up in a way that makes the orchestra bear all the investment risk. When the orchestra emerges from bankruptcy its musicians and staff members will have retirement plans under which they bear the investment risk.

title: Raising a Teenager? Whats Not to Hate?
description: Parenting is one of those words, like veggie, that worm their way into common parlance on the back of infectious social preoccupations. We are a nation obsessed with how to raise children and how to eat, perhaps because weve become so bad at both.

title: Images Show Devastation at Iran Base After Blast
description: The large, deadly explosion at an Iran military base in Iran on Nov. 12, which Iranian authorities have called an accident that set back research work there by a few days, appears to have been far more devastating than their description suggested, according to an analysis of newly released commercial satellite images of the blast site.

title: A New Shot at Mortgage Relief
description: Like millions of other homeowners, William D. Compton would like to refinance his mortgage so that he pays less each month for his three-bedroom house in Gulf Breeze, Fla. With the savings, he figures he could afford a few extra movies and restaurant dinners or he could buy a new stove and brakes for his car, purchases he has postponed because finances are so tight.

title: In Whirlwind of an Election in Congo, Votes May Become Victims, Too
description: KINSHASA, Democratic Republic of Congo  A volatile combination of suspicion, shootings, political clashes and voting breakdowns continued in Congo on Tuesday, the second day of nationwide elections, with some areas still casting ballots, others counting votes and initial results showing a big victory for the opposition here in the capital.

title: When the Chefs Come Home
description: IN the food world, chefs are the 1 percent, and the rest of us are the 99 percent. At this time every year, we dream of catching crumbs from their tables: shiny new cookbooks, stuffed with recipes so brilliantly simplified as to lift us up to their level.

title: Slotted Spoon at MoMA Stores
description: Good design results in an everyday utensil that can go from kitchen to dinner table without raising its pinky and that even deserves gift-wrapping for a cook. This sleek, shiny stainless-steel slotted spoon with an extra deep bowl can lift pieces of meat, chunks of fish and mussels in their shells from a casserole or serving dish. It can also dredge up macerated fruit from a bowl of wintry glogg and transport it neatly into punch cups. A ladle will take care of the liquid.

title: Tea Time for All Ages (Fairy Dust Optional)
description: WHEN my mom and I used to come into the city at Christmastime to see The Nutcracker or the holiday windows at Saks Fifth Avenue, chances are we would end up at tea. Formal tea at one of the hotels  the Plaza or the Palace  was its own rabbit hole, an upholstered salon filled with elegant women who left lipstick prints on the rims of their cups and murmured their secrets along the banquette to the flourishes of live harp music.

title: A Zeal for Democracy in Ghana
description: In the fleet-footed, engagingly volatile documentary An African Election, the director Jarreth Merz hurls himself into the thick of a political contest defined by high hopes and even higher anxieties.

title: Council Resolution Calls for Support of Occupy Wall Street
description: Three City Council members introduced a resolution Tuesday that would formalize support for Occupy Wall Street and its message condemning economic inequality.

title: Once Again, Paulson Regrets the Error
description: In his third-quarter letter to investors, John A. Paulson, the billionaire founder of Paulson & Company, apologized yet again for his hedge funds disastrous slide this year.

title: Clip: Khodorkovsky
description: A scene from the documentary "Khodorkovsky," directed by Cyril Tuschi.

title: Pecan, a Cafe, Opens on the Upper West Side
description: A bright, modern, uptown branch of Pecan, a cafe whose TriBeCa parent has a homier personality, has joined a spate of new restaurants and food shops that have opened or soon will open on the Upper West Side. Coffee and breakfast items start things rolling, followed by sandwiches, salads and soups, including several vegetarian choices, like a roasted sweet potato sandwich and a black lentil salad. Delivery is not available yet, but for now takeout is a fine option. Wine and beer are also coming. And if you opt to drink your well-made coffee at one of the long white tables, a barista (like Ricardo Palma, above, who is also a cook) will serve it in china.

title: Among Great Wines, Plenty of Choice
description: I HAVE never been one of those people who feel they live in the wrong era. I am eternally grateful, for example, to draw breath in the age of anesthesia. But I have occasionally lamented that I was born just a few years too late.

title: A Hard Cider From an Heirloom Apple
description: Many cider makers will tell you it takes several kinds of apples for a well-balanced drink. But the Oregon producer Original Sin, where Gidon Coll has been making blended ciders, has an outstanding new one made from a single heirloom varietal, the Newtown Pippin. This hard cider, pressed from an apple with historic roots in the New York region, has a Champagne delicacy and refreshing acidity that make it a fine aperitif or mealtime quaff. In a different style, the rosy Cherry Tree Hard Cider, Mr. Coll used a mixture of apples blended with tart cherries, creating a mellow drink that can handle charcuterie or dessert.

title: Reviewing Caf de la Esquina at Wythe Diner
description: La Esquina opened in SoHo in 2005 with an unlisted phone number and an attitude. Frank Bruni described it as Studio 54 with chipotle instead of cocaine. Six years later, it has spawned a sequel, of sorts, in Williamsburg, Brooklyn: Caf de la Esquina at Wythe Diner, the subject of one of this weeks Dining Briefs.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening

title: Reggae for When the Lights Were Low
description: Lovers rock  homegrown British reggae of the late 1970s to 80s  earned its name when the lights were turned low. Songs like Janet Kays Silly Games and Louisa Marks Caught You in a Lie were the soundtrack for slow, intimate dancing, scrubbing, that was all about bodies rubbing against bodies in the dark.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Gingerbread Dwellings

title: One Love: The Rastafarian Origin Story
description: Riffing on an unlikely nexus of black radicalism and white college students, the satirical newspaper The Onion once ran an item headlined Bob Marley Rises From Grave to Free Frat Boys From Bonds of Oppression.

title: As Tasty Morsels, Pig Wings Take Flight
description: St. Cloud, Minn.

title: To Keep Paul, the Hornets Could Let Him Help Build the Team
description: The tentative agreement between the N.B.A.s players and owners doesnt contain any particularly shocking elements; most of the new rules are natural compromises between the two sides, with the players finally getting some of the system considerations they had previously deemed to be paramount.

title: Tenants Trying Again to Buy Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village
description: For the second time in six years, the tenants at Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village are seeking to buy the financially troubled complexes, which have served as a leafy refuge for generations of middle-class families in high-priced Manhattan.

title: With Romney, a Time for the Press and a Time for the People
description: TAMPA, FLA.  Mitt Romney came to Tampa to talk about trade policy, but the press wanted to talk about  anything but trade policy.

title: The Years Notable Cookbooks
description: Its hard to do justice to all the great cookbooks published this year, but here are some of the Dining staffs favorites:

title: The Politics of Economics: Feedback
description: So many readers agreed with the thesis of my last column  economics has been corrupted by the same virus that has hit the rest of our national discourse  that my contrarian, live-to-argue side almost wanted to take it all back. But, no. Fortunately, enough people found things to disagree with that we need not suffocate in a big kumbaya hug. Let me respond to a few of the more popular complaints.

title: Bloggingheads: Debating Colonoscopies
description: John Horgan, left, of Scientific American and George Johnson of The Cancer Chronicles debate the value of cancer screening.

title: Reviewing Chuko
description: Ramen is a complicated business, requiring endless minute adjustments of stock and seasoning, along with a certain reckless imagination. At Chuko, a ramen shop that opened in August in Prospect Heights (and the subject of one of this weeks Dining Briefs), the chefs and owners, Jamison Blankenship, David Koon and James Sato, make a valiant effort to achieve the fathomless broths, suffused with umami, found in Japan.

title: Diamond Foods Makes Odd Moves
description: Things arent getting any better for the snack food maker Diamond Foods. A month ago, it delayed its $2.4 billion plan to buy Pringles from Procter & Gamble in order to look into accounting concerns. Now, the company is burying news about the inquiry and increasing payments to a couple of directors who are walnut growers. These and other inconsistencies dont seem to augur well for the investigation, or its deal with Procter & Gamble.

title: Treating People With Schizophrenia
description: To the Editor:

title: Support for Iranian Group
description: To the Editor:

title: Changes for the Jaguars, From the Very Top Down
description: The Jacksonville Jaguars owner, Wayne Weaver, woke up Tuesday with a long to-do list.

title: Food Aid Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Toyota and Subaru Preview Their Rear-Wheel-Drive Coupes
description: Leading up to their formal debuts at the Tokyo auto show, two long-gestating rear-wheel-drive coupes co-developed by Toyota and Subaru have been previewed in production form.

title: Chile Indicts Ex-U.S. Officer in 1973 Killings
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  A Chilean judge indicted a former United States Navy officer on Tuesday in the killings of two United States citizens shortly after a 1973 military coup here.

title: U.S. Settles Suit Over Anthrax Attacks
description: WASHINGTON  The federal government has agreed to pay $2.5 million to the widow and children of the first person killed in the anthrax letter attacks of 2001, settling a lawsuit claiming that the Army did not adequately secure its supply of the deadly pathogen.

title: Vonns Divorce Will Also End a Skiing Partnership
description: Virtually inseparable on the ski racing circuit since 2005 and married four years ago during a snowy, idyllic ceremony at the base of a Utah mountain, Lindsey and Thomas Vonn each filed for divorce last week, ending a partnership widely celebrated in the wake of Olympic success and multiple World Cup titles.

title: Invitation to a Dialogue: Which Way on Taxes?
description: To the Editor:

title: An Interview With Carolina Herrera
description: Jessica Michault of The International Herald Tribune talks to the designer about the Twilight wedding dress, her relationship with Rene Zellweger, and working with family.

title: The Future of China
description: To the Editor:

title: Facebook May Be Forced to Go Public Amid Market Gloom
description: Facebook is in a corner.

title: How to Free Congresss Mind
description: WHEN it comes to changing the toxic partisan gridlock in Washington, the Beatles got it just about right: You tell me its the institution/Well, you know/Youd better free your mind instead.

title: Galleon Chiefs Lawyers Seek to Delay Prison Term
description: Raj Rajaratnam, the hedge fund manager convicted of insider trading, is set to report next week to a federal penitentiary in Ayer, Mass., to serve an 11-year sentence.

title: American Pie Still Homemade, but With a New Twist
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.  To step into the Tin & Lint bar here is to be surrounded by stories. Carved into the wooden walls, booths and benches are 30 years of names, dates and declared loves: Mike was here; Don loves Joanna 4EVER; Amy and Jennifer, 1989.

title: Lines Grow Long for Free School Meals, Thanks to Economy
description: Millions of American schoolchildren are receiving free or low-cost meals for the first time as their parents, many once solidly middle class, have lost jobs or homes during the economic crisis, qualifying their families for the decades-old safety-net program.

title: Judge Says Suit to Void Marriage Act May Proceed
description: Harshly criticizing Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo for the tactics he used to win approval of same-sex marriage, a state judge has ruled that a lawsuit challenging the enactment of New Yorks Marriage Equality Act can proceed.

title: Pushing Latin American Banks to Lend
description: MEXICO CITY  As economic turmoil whiplashes banks in Europe and poses new threats to American financial institutions, the view from Latin America is very different. Well off the radar screen of the global economic crisis, Latin Americas banks have proven their sturdiness, emerging relatively unscathed from the collapse.

title: In Interview, Romney Sets Stage for Gingrich Rivalry
description: So, what does Mitt Romney really think of Newt Gingrich?

title: Recalling Days on the Run With Abducted Children
description: The week before they abducted their eight children from a foster care center in Queens, Nephra and Shanel Payne stocked up at Costco on supplies and dry goods, like graham crackers, diapers and infant formula for Nefertiti, their 11-month-old daughter. They stashed family photos and important documents in a storage facility and crammed a basketball and a football  essential for traveling with a Little League teams worth of boys  into their car.

title: Apples Siri Stumbles Over an Abortion Question
description: Nov. 30, 8:28 p.m. | Updated  See Apples response to this issue.

title: Muzzling the Rainbow Nation
description: Johannesburg

title: Cain Speaks on Foreign Policy, Avoiding Accusations
description: HILLSDALE, Mich.  Seemingly unbowed by the escalating scandal about his sexual conduct, Herman Cain addressed a crowd of several hundred in a college gymnasium here Tuesday night, but he made no mention of the allegations against him, instead focusing on vague and optimistic foreign policy ideals.

title: Cleveland Turns Uptown Into New Downtown
description: CLEVELAND  Since 1950, when its population peaked at 914,808, Cleveland has steadily shed residents and jobs. In 2010, just 396,815 people lived within the city limits, almost 81,000 fewer than a decade before, and about the same number of people who lived in Cleveland in 1900.

title: Facing Generic Lipitor Rivals, Pfizer Battles to Protect Its Cash Cow
description: For the last year, Pfizer has been laying the groundwork to combat the looming competition against Lipitor, forging deals with insurers, pharmacy benefit managers and patients to meet or beat the price of its generic replacements.

title: What Would Gandhi Do?
description: New Delhi

title: Understating Greeces Problems
description: Ratings agencies missed the economic problems in Europe.

title: Giving Where It Works
description: At Fixes, we often argue that good ideas are plentiful  but ways to keep them going are hard to find. Thats why we pay a lot of attention to sustainability, especially financial sustainability. Life is always precarious for programs that depend on government financing or charitable donations, particularly so today. So we choose many of the programs we highlight because they have found a creative new way to sustain good work, often through combining social and for-profit missions.

title: Details Emerge on MF Globals Last-Ditch Effort to Fill Shortfall
description: After MF Global discovered a nearly $1 billion shortfall in customer money in the early hours of Oct. 31, the brokerage firm lined up a last-ditch  but ultimately unsuccessful  effort to fill the hole, according to people briefed on the matter.

title: Making Local Food Real
description: You might think it would be difficult to find a cheerful and optimistic farmer the year a hurricane wiped out most of the crop, but I did so in Burlington, Vt., the day after Thanksgiving. I was visiting the Intervale Center, a nonprofit that manages a 350-plus-acre flood plain not far from downtown.

title: Obama Is Facing a Replay of 08 Hurdles in Hillary Country, Pa.
description: SCRANTON, Pa.  It was trivia night at Kildares bar here, and among the teams competing was a group of history teachers from Scranton High School. They easily won the round that tested their knowledge of American presidents, including that the last one with facial hair was William Howard Taft.

title: For 92nd St. Y, a Break From Wall St. Worry
description: Clients of John A. Paulson, the billionaire hedge fund manager, have had a brutal year, absorbing losses of as much as 50 percent.

title: Valentine Is Chosen to Manage Red Sox
description: For more than a century, the rivalry between the Yankees and the Boston Red Sox has been the stuff of legend, filled with large personalities and fiery competitors. Now add to that caldron Bobby Valentine, one of the more colorful and controversial figures in recent New York baseball history.

title: Gingrich Gave Push to Clients, Not Just Ideas
description: Newt Gingrich is adamant that he is not a lobbyist, but rather a visionary who traffics in ideas, not influence. But in the eight years since he started his health care consultancy, he has made millions of dollars while helping companies promote their services and gain access to state and federal officials.

title: F.C.C. Report Details Merger Shortcomings
description: The Federal Communications Commission said it had allowed AT&T to withdraw an application to buy T-Mobile USA. Separately on Tuesday, the agency released a report that officials said outlined the $39 billion deals shortcomings.

title: College Athletes Move Concussions Into the Courtroom
description: The punt soared through the night air, arriving just before the tackler crashed into Derek Owens. No penalty flag was thrown, and Owens maintained one would not have been justified. It was football, the sport he still loves, despite his concussions.

title: Morocco: Islamist Named Premier
description: King Mohammed VI of Morocco appointed as prime minister on Tuesday the head of the moderate Islamist party that on Friday won the countrys first elections under a new constitution, the royal palace said. The king chose Abdellilah Benkirane, the general secretary of the Justice and Development Party, to form a coalition government. The new Constitution, drafted by the king in response to calls for more democracy inspired by the Arab Spring, still reserves important powers for the king, including over military and religious matters.

title: No Money for a Living Wage? But Fat Abounds
description: Everyone knows what marbled steak looks like, with the streaks of fat running through the red meat, right in front of your eyes. The marbled public works project is harder to recognize, but it most certainly exists.

title: Tahrir's Candidate
description: Zyad Elelaimy first emerged in January as a main voice of the youthful revolutionaries in Tahrir Square. Now he is running for a Parliament seat as a candidate in Egypt's strongest liberal party.

title: In Congress, Role Reversal Over Federal Payroll Tax Cut
description: WASHINGTON  In a sharp role reversal, Democrats and Republicans have become divided over whether to extend a federal payroll tax cut enjoyed by working Americans this year, with Democrats leading the charge for the tax break and many Republicans demanding that the cut be paid for if it is extended at all.

title: Giants Have Little Time to Fix What Ails Them
description: The day after the Giants lost to the Philadelphia Eagles last week, there was palpable anger from the players, a genuine frustration over an opportunity lost. The Eagles, for all their preseason hype, have proven eminently beatable and the Giants did not hide their rage over letting a victory slip away.

title: The Arab Awakening and Israel
description: Israel is facing the biggest erosion of its strategic environment since its founding. It is alienated from its longtime ally Turkey. Its archenemy Iran is suspected of developing a nuclear bomb. The two strongest states on its border  Syria and Egypt  are being convulsed by revolutions. The two weakest states on its border  Gaza and Lebanon  are controlled by Hamas and Hezbollah.

title: Lottery Numbers
For S.E.C., Court Ruling on Penalties Ties a Hand
description: WASHINGTON  When a Wall Street firm trades billions of dollars of securities a day and sometimes showers seven-figure bonuses on top executives, regulators are hard-pressed to fashion a penalty that really hurts.

title: Cain, Support Eroding, Weighs Dropping Bid
description: WASHINGTON  The leading conservative voices who have come to Herman Cains defense began backing away on Tuesday as he acknowledged that he was reassessing his Republican presidential bid, uncertain that he could withstand a report of an extramarital affair after accusations of sexual harassment and stumbling foreign policy responses.

title: Mexico: Accuser of Police Is Killed
description: Prosecutors said Tuesday that their primary line of investigation in the killing of an activist who had criticized the police was the possibility that he had ties to organized crime. The activist, Nepomuceno Moreno, had accused police officers of kidnapping his 18-year-old son last year. He was shot to death on Monday in the northern state of Sonora. Members of the group that had served as a platform for Mr. Moreno, the Movement for Peace with Justice and Dignity, said state and federal authorities did not protect him when he requested it; the authorities said they had not received any requests for protection. Mr. Morenos son is still missing.

title: So Near the Garden but Still Miles Away
description: Chris Paul mentioned moving boxes, Carmelo Anthony and New York  magic phrases that, with a little clever splicing, would leave Knicks fans all aflutter.

title: Y.M.C.A. Adopting Health Policies for Youth
description: WASHINGTON  The Y.M.C.A., one of the nations largest child-care providers, intends to announce Wednesday that it is adopting new healthy living standards, including offering fruits, vegetables and water at snack time, increasing the amount of exercise and limiting video games and television for youngsters in its programs.

title: Too Much Holiday Food? This Campaigns for You
description: PEPTO-BISMOL, the brand of stomach remedies, traditionally has highlighted the symptoms it relieves, with commercials in the 1970s featuring pained-looking actors whose torsos expanded as if reflected in funhouse mirrors, and the promise that the pink product coats, soothes, relieves.

title: Beyond Glory
description: Mention black soldiers in the Civil War today, and most people will immediately think of the 1989 film Glory, in which relatively enlightened Union officers train and then lead an all-black infantry regiment into battle. Part of the films power comes from the way that it gives the impression that employing black Americans as soldiers was a radically new idea.

title: Single Spark Sets Off a Long Year of Debt
description: In July 2009, Jose Antonio Ithier woke up coughing and struggling to breathe. Plumes of black smoke were choking his lungs.

title: In Chapter 11, a Bid to Cut Costs at American Airlines
description: After resisting for a decade, the parent company of American Airlines announced Tuesday that it would now follow a strategy that the rest of the industry chose long ago: filing for bankruptcy protection so it can shed debt, cut labor costs and find a way back to profitability.

title: My Man Newt
description: WASHINGTON

title: Ratings Firms Misread Signs of Greek Woes
description: In a stern pronouncement, Moodys Investors Service this week warned of rising prospects for multiple defaults by countries in the euro zone and credit rating downgrades of nations across Europe if leaders should fail to resolve the spreading debt crisis.

title: Don DeVito, Producer of Bob Dylan Albums, Dies at 72
description: Don DeVito, a longtime Columbia Records executive who produced albums for Bob Dylan and others, died on Friday in New York. He was 72.

title: National Report Praises School-Choice System for New York City Students
description: New York has the most effective school-choice system of any of the nations largest school districts, allowing students and parents the most freedom and providing them with the most relevant information on educational performance, according to a new Brookings Institution report scheduled for publication online Wednesday.

title: Germanys Denial, Europes Disaster
description: Each day Europe inches closer to a full economic meltdown, but Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany is still blocking what is needed: a real bailout of Europes weakest economies by their richer neighbors or the European Central Bank.

title: An Intolerable Burden of Proof
description: The Supreme Court ruled in 2002 that it is unconstitutional to execute mentally retarded criminals, finding that the death penalty cannot be justified for these offenders because they are morally less culpable.

title: Lockout Is to Be Partly Lifted
description: For the first time in 153 days, N.B.A. players will be allowed back in N.B.A. gyms when the league partly lifts the lockout on Thursday. The league sent a memo to all 30 teams on Tuesday informing them of the move.

title: U.S. Motives in Myanmar Are on Chinas Radar
description: BEIJING  When Myanmars military leader, Gen. Min Aung Hlaing, arrived here on Monday in a crisp tan uniform and a matching cap, he got a welcome from the very highest levels of the Chinese government.

title: Some Thoughts for the Shopping Season
description: The big banks canceled plans for new debit card fees after their customers rebelled and members of Congress objected. But if Americans think their debit card problems are over, theyre wrong.

title: Wednesday: Things Understood by Few
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  I consider Wordplay to be an ongoing cocktail party of sorts, where everyone can come to discuss the puzzle, the words contained therein, and anything  within reason  that those words might evoke. It both humbles and inspires me to watch how you all check in with each other, help each other through the solving process, encourage newcomers, amuse us with stories, and even look out for one another on a personal level. Wordplay is a very special place, and I am happy to be a part of it.

title: China: Dissidents Wife Questioned
description: Lu Qing, the wife of the dissident artist Ai Weiwei, was questioned by the Beijing police for more than three hours on Tuesday afternoon, said an assistant who was with her. The officers asked Ms. Lu about her company, Beijing Fake Cultural Development Ltd.; personal details; and a housing project the company designed in Inner Mongolia several years ago. On a police form, Ms. Lu was listed as a suspect rather than a witness, the assistant said. She was told not to leave Beijing. Mr. Ai, a frequent critic of the Communist Party, was detained for 81 days this year and faces charges of tax evasion.

title: When Apartment Rents Climb, Landlords Can Say The Computer Did It
description: The lease renewal notices that landlords send out annually have contained little good news for renters in recent years: Rents are up and vacancies down around the country. And having resigned themselves to paying more, renters may wonder whether the new number on their lease was plucked out of thin air.

title: Group Predicts 28% Gain in Carmaking Jobs by 2015
description: DETROIT  Employment in the auto industry will return to prerecession levels by 2015, with carmakers and their suppliers adding about 167,000 jobs by then, according to estimates by an auto industry research firm.

title: Suffolks Mean Streets
description: The police in Suffolk County, Long Island, are seeking a court injunction this week that would prohibit alleged gang members from hanging out with one another in a designated safety zone  in this case, the commercial center of Wyandanch, a predominantly black and Hispanic hamlet beset by poverty and crime.

title: Key Witness Inconsistent During Trial of Official
description: One of the main government witnesses in the corruption trial of City Councilman Larry B. Seabrook testified on Tuesday that she had consulted a doctor about her diminishing memory, then offered contradictory accounts on several important points in the case.

title: Where Should That Lottery Check Go?
Support for Boeheim Is Followed by Win for Syracuse
description: SYRACUSE  Standing and flashing an occasional smile, Syracuse Coach Jim Boeheim faced the television lights and the pointed questions.

title: The Huntsman Handicap
description: I dont claim to be the perfect candidate, Newt Gingrich told a South Carolina radio station last week, as he settled into his role as the latest not-Romney in the Republican race. I just claim to be a lot more conservative than Mitt Romney and a lot more electable than anybody else.

title: Ups and Downs of the Cain Candidacy
description: Herman Cain has been losing his standing in the polls since claims of sexual harassment surfaced last month.

title: Patrice ONeal, Boisterous Comedian, Dies at 41
description: Patrice ONeal, a stand-up comedian who boisterously took on controversial topics like race, AIDS and his own struggle with diabetes, died on Tuesday. He was 41 and lived in New Jersey.

title: Rates of Increase in Subsidized Lunches
description: The proportion of fourth graders eligible for the federal governments school meals program has increased nationwide since 2007.

title: Democratic Voters Waver in Scranton
description: President Obama faces a replay of 08 hurdles in Hillary Country, Pa.

title: Qatars Capital Glitters Like a World City, but Few Feel at Home
description: DOHA, Qatar  Along a skyline that feels as ambitious as it is ephemeral, there is a building named for its design  the Tornado. The renowned architect I. M. Pei built a museum here in a quest for the essence of Islamic architecture. Another tower, built by another famous architect, is sheathed in an exoskeleton and suggests a Saracen helmet.

title: Matthew P. Sapolin, Who Led Bloombergs Office for Disabled, Dies at 41
description: Matthew P. Sapolin, the Bloomberg administrations disabilities commissioner, died of cancer on Tuesday. He was 41.

title: Perry Gains Endorsement From an Arizona Sheriff Tough on Immigration
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Rick Perry is polling at only the single digits in New Hampshire, and the question on this Tuesday was: Can a hard-nosed Arizona sheriff who was sued by the Justice Department and is known for aggressive pursuit of illegal immigrants  and for making inmates wear pink underwear  help him gain traction six weeks before the primary?

title: Rangers Hold Off Crosby and Penguins
description: All eyes were on Sidney Crosby at Madison Square Garden on Tuesday night, but the players to watch were Marian Gaborik and Brad Richards as the Rangers took a 4-3 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins in a clash between clubs with the N.H.L.s best percentage records.

title: Highly Skilled May Wait Less for Visas
description: In a rare show of bipartisan comity on the angrily contested issue of immigration, the House of Representatives on Tuesday passed a bill that tweaks the visa system to allow more highly skilled immigrants from India and China to become legal permanent residents.

title: Ex-President of Ivory Coast to Face Court in the Hague
description: PARIS  The former president of Ivory Coast, who took his country almost to the brink of civil war after losing an election last year, was unexpectedly handed over into international custody on Tuesday and was flown overnight to the Netherlands, where the prosecutor at the International Criminal Court in The Hague has accused him of crimes against humanity, Ivorian government officials said.

title: Support for Tea Party Falls in Strongholds, Polls Show
description: Support for the Tea Party  and with it, the Republican Party  has fallen sharply even in places considered Tea Party strongholds, according to an analysis of new polls.

title: Short Week and Tough Questions for Giants
description: During a typical week, the Giants begin practice on Wednesday around noon, after going through morning meetings where that weeks game plan is introduced by the coaches.

title: Andrew M. Kramer, Leading Labor Lawyer, Dies at 67
description: Andrew M. Kramer, a lawyer who handled dozens of labor disputes for major corporations and helped old-line manufacturers figure out how to cope with crushing health care costs for retirees, died on Nov. 21 at his home in Potomac, Md. He was 67.

title: Senate Approves Requiring Military Custody in Terror Cases
description: WASHINGTON  Defying the Obama administrations threat of a veto, the Senate on Tuesday voted to increase the role of the military in imprisoning suspected members of Al Qaeda and its allies  including people arrested inside the United States.

title: For Red Sox, Life Just Got Very Interesting
description: Nobody knows if Bobby Valentine, the new manager of the Boston Red Sox, will guide his team out of its third-place malaise. We might not know until the very end of the regular season. But the journey to get there will be fascinating.

title: Massachusetts: Effort to Close Reactor Is Denied
description: A licensing panel at the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has turned down the states effort to block renewal of the operating license of a reactor because of the Fukushima Daichi accident in Japan. The reactor, Pilgrim, resembles the reactors at Fukushima and is on the coast, at Plymouth, but in July the commission received a report from a task force that concluded that the Fukushima accident did not indicate any imminent risk to public health and safety from American reactors. Several states have tried unsuccessfully to block license extensions for reactors within their borders. Vermont could not stop re-licensing of a similar reactor, Vermont Yankee, owned by the same company as Pilgrim, Entergy, but the state is still trying to close it by denying a state permit.

title: Path Tries Again With a Wider Network
description: Path, a photo mobile social network, began with great promise late last year.

title: Private Dollars Revive a Solar Panel Plan for Military Housing
description: An ambitious project by a California company to install solar panels for more than 100,000 military housing units has been revived with private financing after it failed to receive a loan guarantee from the federal government.

title: How Exercise Benefits the Brain
description: To learn more about how exercise affects the brain, scientists in Ireland recently asked a group of sedentary male college students to take part in a memory test followed by strenuous exercise.

title: Word of the Day | hazardous
description: hazardous \ha-zr-ds\  adjective

title: NYT Front Page for 11/30/2011
description: NYT Front Page for 11/30/2011

title: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Wednesday
description: Prime Minister Manmohan Singh, whose government has frequently been criticized for paralysis on policy, has pledged not to reverse the decision to allow foreign direct investment in retail, which could see big-box stores like Walmart, Tesco and Carrefour set up shop in India (Economic Times). I am confident that foreign direct investment in retail will help to bring modern technology in the farm sector, less wastage and more jobs, Mr. Singh said Wednesday.

title: Massachusetts: State Takes Over Lawrence Schools
description: The state board of education voted Tuesday to take over the Lawrence Public School system, an embattled district where fewer than half of students graduate from high school in four years. It is the first district to be taken into receivership after a 2010 law empowered the state board of education to take such action on chronically underperforming schools. Mayor William Lantigua requested the state take the action, which comes as the districts former superintendent prepares to face trial for fraud and embezzlement, and Mr. Lantigua himself navigates a series of recall efforts.

title: The Adidas Samba Tees Off; and Soccer Shoes With a Chip
description: I have a confession to make: Ive been an Adidas-head ever since my dad dug deep into his pocket and forked over $75 (at least thats what I think it was) to buy me a pair of Tokyo track spikes when I was in high school about 100 years ago. They were the lightest, the coolest, the bluest shoes on an old cinder track. Did they make me faster? Not likely. But man, they sure looked good.

title: Corrections: November 30
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Long Wait For Green Cards Could Soon End
description: The United States House of Representatives on Tuesday passed a bill that will allow more highly-skilled immigrants from India and China to become legal permanent residents in the United States, Julia Preston reports.

title: News Quiz | Nov. 30, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Britons Strike Over Extended Austerity Measures
description: LONDON  Hundreds of thousands of public employees walked off their jobs in schools, hospitals, airports, courtrooms, libraries, museums and government offices on Wednesday, as British workers became the latest in Europe to demonstrate mass fury at government austerity measures.

title: As Britain Closes Embassies, Irans Isolation Could Complicate Nuclear Issue
description: LONDON  With Britains decision to close its vandalized embassy in Tehran on Wednesday and expel all Iranian diplomats from London, Iran appears to have moved a major step closer to international pariah status. That isolation could complicate efforts by Western governments to halt what they have identified as Irans covert efforts to acquire nuclear weapons, according to diplomats and others who monitor Iranian affairs.

title: Life in Limbo for Chin Refugees
description: Thirty-year-old Biathleng fled Myanmars Chin State for Delhi in June, with three children and a teenage wife. I have an appointment for my refugee card, he says carefully, when asked about his new life.

title: Ex-President of Ivory Coast Arrives in the Hague to Face Charges
description: PARIS  The former president of Ivory Coast, who took his country to the brink of civil war after losing an election last year, was unexpectedly handed over into international custody and flown overnight to the Netherlands. In a statement on Wednesday after he arrived in the Hague, the International Criminal Court said Laurent Gbagbo allegedly bears individual criminal responsibility for four crimes against humanity: murder, rape, persecution and inhuman acts.

title: North Korea Reports Progress on New Reactor
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea reported brisk progress in building a new nuclear reactor and producing enriched uranium on Wednesday. Although the statement appeared to invite international inspectors to verify that the facilities are for peaceful purposes, it was the latest sign that North Korea is pressing ahead with its nuclear program.

title: Nov. 30, 1995 | President Clinton Visits Northern Ireland to Support Peace Process
description: On Nov. 30, 1995, President Bill Clinton became the first United States chief executive to visit Northern Ireland, touring the cities of Belfast and Derry to show support for the peace process.The New York Times reported, The president has been more deeply involved than any of his predecessors in the intractable problems of this island, an involvement that caused him to cast aside the fears of other presidents that a trip here might fray relations with the British.

title: Test Yourself | Math, Nov. 30, 2011
description: Test your math skills with this question created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the article Online High Schools Attracting Elite Names.

title: American Airlines and Bankruptcy
description: WHO is the new chief executive of AMR Corporation, which operates American Airlines?

title: Building a Better Mitt Romney-Bot
description: Your story about dust regulation captures my interest, Mitt Romney said to the farmer, sounding as if he actually meant it. It was a late October afternoon in Treynor, Iowa, the setting for one of those campaign meta-events at which a presidential candidate enjoys a casual moment with real people that is in fact carefully staged and dutifully broadcast by multitudes of local and national reporters hovering a few feet away. In this instance, Romney was participating in a round-table discussion with a dozen local businessmen  his kind of folks  and exhibiting his teachers-pet flair for spewing out entrepreneurial minutiae.

title: The Eurozone
description: An illustrated map.

title: Europes Financial Crisis, in Plain English
description: Much like our own recent housing crisis, the European financial mess is unfolding in a foreign language. It is the lingua franca of financial obscurity  sovereign credit spreads and other terms that most people dont need, or care, to know.

title: Do Photoshopped Images Make You Feel Bad About Your Own Looks?
description: Before you answer the question, take a look at the 10 before-and-after photos that illustrate this article.

title: Turkey Moves to Intensify Sanctions Against Syria
description: ISTANBUL  Turkey took steps on Wednesday to freeze the Syrian governments financial assets, impose a travel ban on senior Syrian officials and cut off transactions with the countrys central bank, sharply escalating international pressure on Damascus in response to its continuing violence against civilians.

title: Why Not Rahul for U.P. Chief Minister?
description: If Uttar Pradesh were an independent country, it would be the worlds fifth most populous nation, just behind Indonesia and ahead of Brazil, a nation with 35 times U.P.s land mass.

title: Clash Between NATO and Pakistani Forces Defused
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A cross-border incident involving NATO and Pakistani forces was quickly defused early on Wednesday with no loss of life, according to Brig. Gen. Carsten Jacobson, the spokesman for the American-led international coalition here.

title: Greeted Quietly, Clinton Arrives in Myanmar
description: NAYPYIDAW, Myanmar  Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton arrived here on Wednesday to measure the depth of the political and economic opening that the countrys autocratic, military-dominated government has unexpectedly begun.

title: British Inquiry Is Told Hacking Is Worthy Tool
description: LONDON  He admitted that he and his colleagues hacked into peoples phones and paid police officers for tips. He confessed to lurking in unmarked vans outside peoples houses, stealing confidential documents, rifling through celebrity garbage cans and pretending that he was not a journalist pursuing a story but Brad the teenage rent boy, propositioning a priest.

title: Occupy Protesters Evicted in Two Cities
description: LOS ANGELES  The steel-mesh fence went up around the perimeter of City Hall Park here early Wednesday morning. Behind it, fields of dirt and brown grass were covered with the detritus of what had been one of the largest Occupy encampments in the country: tarps, tents, discarded bottles, coolers, protest signs, a torn-up dollar bill, a California drivers license and a beat-up acoustic guitar.

title: Bankers, Too, Cast a Safety Net
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

title: Where You Can Give It Away, in Berlin
description: Last summer, Andreas Richter, a 28-year-old computer programmer who lives in Berlin, wanted to get rid of some stuff: clothes, DVDs, a set of drinking glasses. He didnt want to throw out the items  still perfectly useful  but he also didnt want to have to schedule pickups or use DHL for a couple of T-shirts. So instead, he got out his power tools and built a telephone-booth-sized structure that he called Givebox on his street in Mitte (Steinstrasse 37b). Since then, the project has taken on a more interactive aspect and has expanded to other locations and even other cities.

title: The Early Word: Influence
description: In Todays Times:

title: Measuring Tebow, and Punishing Suh
description: On Monday, Brian Burke of Advanced NFL Stats, a Fifth Down contributor, took a crack at the Tim Tebow riddle.

title: David Nalbandian's Enduring 'Obsession'
description: Often  too often for polite company  David Nalbandian could not be bothered.

title: Coming Soon to the Sidewalks: A New Look for Scaffolding
description: Built from steel pipes and used plywood, they snake their way a million feet (or 190 miles) along New Yorks sidewalks and have long been considered egregious eyesores.

title: Turning Thanksgiving Day Into Black Thursday
description: I have spent my entire life in retail, as did my father and both of my grandfathers. I have always thought of it as an honorable profession.

title: Breakfast Meeting, Nov. 30
description: DealBook explains some of the thinking behind the report that Facebook (no relation) may be planning an initial public offering in the spring to raise $10 billion, with a company valuation of $100 billion. In short, Steven M. Davidoff, the Deal Professor, writes, Facebook just has too many shareholders. When a United States company has 500 or more shareholders of record it must soon begin filing reports with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including audited financial information. Facebook is likely to reach 500 in April 2012, he writes, and most companies conclude that if they are going to be subject to much of the regulation that comes with being public, they might as well just go ahead with an I.P.O. and get the full benefits of being public.

title: On Our Radar: Mining Dispute in Peru
description: A  corporation halts work at the $4.8 billion Minas Conga gold operation in Peru after protests against mining that left at least 17 wounded. Farmers worry that the vast mining operation will exhaust water resources. [Bloomberg Businessweek]

title: Inflation Fears Easing, Chinas Central Bank Turns to Lifting Growth
description: HONG KONG  Chinas central bank, in a surprise move on Wednesday, shifted its economic focus from fighting inflation to stimulating growth by freeing the nations commercial banks to lend more money.

title: Crowding Concerns Raised Over Cobble Hill Charter School
Morning Take-Out
description: TOP STORIES

title: Opinion Report: Gang Injunctions
description: From the editorial page

title: Coal Minister Meets With Greenpeace, Tiger
Regulator Raises Serious Concerns About Toronto Exchange Deal
description: Canadas competition regulator has serious concerns about a plan by 13 financial institutions to purchase the Toronto Stock Exchanges parent company for 3.8 billion Canadian dollars, the acquirers said on Wednesday.

title: This Faust Builds Atom Bombs (He Still Sings)
description: It is best to put aside any knowledge you may have of Goethe when attending a performance of Gounods Faust. There is beautiful music  stirring ensembles and a few gotcha arias  in Gounods score. But this melodramatic opera is anything but philosophical.

title: Police Make New Arrest in British Hacking Inquiry
description: LONDON  A 31-year-old woman has been arrested as part of the investigation into voice mail hacking at Rupert Murdochs now-defunct News of the World, police officials said Wednesday.

title: Wednesday Reading: Tips on Earning and Spending Points
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Life in Baghdad: An Intimate Portrait
description: In Holland, we dont know anything about the Iraqi people, said the Dutch photographer Marieke van der Velden. When we hear Iraqis are killed  if they have no face, then we feel no hurt.

title: There Is Something Not Rotten
description: In the state of Denmark:

title: Enforcing Mediocrity
description: MOSCOW  A few things you wont see in Moscow this week.

title: The Debt Ceiling
description: From GQ:

title: Another Special Day, Another Retail Dollar
description: It has become increasingly clear that the countrys best hope to climb out of its economic doldrums may be to keep coming up with snappy sales gimmicks attached to specific days of the week. Thats what now passes for a recovery plan. New York, with its many retailers, hardly stands apart from the trend.

title: Daily Report: F.T.C. Settles With Facebook on Privacy Policies
description: The federal government on Tuesday accused Facebook of engaging in unfair and deceptive practices and announced a broad settlement that requires the company to respect the privacy wishes of its users and subjects it to regular privacy audits for the next 20 years, reports Somini Sengupta in the New York Times.

title: 6 Central Banks Act to Buy Time in Europe Crisis
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve and other major central banks moved on Wednesday to help foreign banks more easily borrow and lend money, seeking to forestall a breakdown of global financial markets and giving Europe more time to wrestle with its debts. The latest round of interventions by central banks, including the expansion of an existing Fed program that lets foreign banks borrow dollars at a low interest rate, reflects growing concerns that Europes financial problems are hampering growth.

title: Questions Of Confidence
description: Some readers have asked why, given my scornful discussions of the confidence fairy story about fiscal austerity (will that be my lasting contribution to economic discourse?), Im willing to take seriously the idea that ECB rate hikes had a huge impact via expectations.

title: New York Rated Tops in Nation for School Choice
Thats a (Re)Wrap
description: During the holidays there are essentially two types of people: those that relish in receiving and those who find greater joy in giving. The subjects of todays story fall primarily in the latter category. Theyre the people who make presents their most presentable by swapping traditional wrapping paper for more unconventional, economical and environmentally mindful materials. Anything is better than a giant roll of unrecycleable metallic Santas, says the Bodkin designer Eviana Hartman, who paints brown paper with pastel watercolors and uses once-trashed treasures, like sheets of architectural blueprint, when making the perfect parcel. But it isnt all arts and crafts. A really easy option is to give gifts in colorful, reusable tote bags, like Baggu, Hartman says.

title: Good Boy! Good Supporting Actor!
description: Here is an Oscar campaign the Bagger can support thoroughly, even without the ministrations of highly paid consultants, glossy ads or red carpet hijinks (although we would take a funny YouTube reel). The fine folks over at Movieline have started an awards push for Uggie, the exquisitely emotive pup in The Artist.

title: Christmas, Plain and Fancy
description: If you drive through the typical suburban tract in December, the houses seem grouped in two categories: There are the homes vigorously festooned in blinking multicolor, with life-size Santas and 3-D nativity scenes rendered in glowing plastic. And there are the others, their tended lawns unmarred by seasonal gnomes and Rudolph paraphernalia, with perhaps a single tree draped in tasteful white lights.

title: HBO Says Time is Right for Ricky Gervaiss Lifes Too Short
description: When Ricky Gervais completes his third go-round in January as host of the Golden Globe Awards (and the monthlong non-apology tour that will surely follow), he wont immediately go into hiding: hell be back on HBO the next month with his new comedy series, Lifes Too Short, which will make its debut on Feb. 19, the cable channel said.

title: Iraq Would Accept U.S. Soldiers as Trainers
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqs prime minister signaled Wednesday that he was open to the eventual return of American troops as trainers, underscoring the reality that the United States is likely to be involved in this countrys security even after the last soldiers depart in the coming weeks.

title: The 10 Best Books of 2011
description: Choosing our 10 Best Books of the Year was not an arbitrary process, but neither was it a scientific one. How could it be, when the editors here, like all readers, respond subjectively to any work of fiction or nonfiction? The one guideline for the 10 was that they had to have been reviewed in our pages sometime in the past 12 months.

title: The 10 Best Books of 2011
description: In 2004, the Book Review, which had previously offered a selection of the years Notable Books and Best Books, began limiting the number of Notables to 100 and the Best Books to 10. Choosing 100 is hard enough. Whittling that number to 10 is even harder, though the process is always interesting. And as is so often the case with lists, the numbers contain subsets that are interesting in themselves, suggesting coincidences, trends and patterns within.

title: Oliviers Twist
description: Since Olivier Theyskens exudes an edgy romanticism with his poetic long hair, he has always seemed like a Belgian goth. At the end of the last century, when he was a 21-year-old prodigy, he made clothes with a hint of darkness and dressed Madonna in a long frock coat for the 1998 Academy Awards.

title: Time Warner Picks New Head for Time Inc. Magazine Unit
description: 7:34 a.m. | Updated As Time Warner searched for a top executive to run its sprawling magazine unit, it did not look just outside the company. It looked outside the publishing industry.

title: In Praise of Grover Norquist
