description: I debated the Americans for Tax Reform impresario at the American Enterprise Institute last night (Ill link to the transcript whenever it becomes available), and since I spent the evening arguing that his Taxpayer Protection Pledge has failed to actually protect taxpayers I thought Id say something nice about him this space. Like any good activist, Norquist is a monomaniac about his issue: Everything in American politics revolves around taxes, all good things flow from tax cuts, no deal that increases taxes can ever benefit America, etc. etc. As I said at AEI, I think this view is mistaken, and that focusing obsessively on tax rates has proven to be an insufficient and even counterproductive strategy for actually limiting the size and scope of government. (Steven Hayward elaborates a bit on this argument in his recent essay on conservatisms intellectual blind spots.) And worse, because taxpayers are liable for tomorrows debts as well as todays tax rates, even the pledges present success at keeping rates relatively low may look like a pyrrhic victory in the long run.

title: The Kindle Fire: Clunky but Content-Rich
description: As gadget reviewers have pointed out, the newly released Amazon Kindle Fire isclunky and slow  in keeping with Amazons sense of style. But it seems it is being purchased in droves by consumers and ispoisedto become the second-most-popular tablet in the United States, after Apples iPad.

title: What Were Reading
description: The Perennial Plate: Quit your jobs and start planting seeds, New Yorkers! This video will make you want to.  Jeff Gordinier

title: Bleeding Britain
description: These days, ambulance-chaser economists like yours truly have an embarrassment of riches: so much is going wrong, in so many places, that one hardly knows where to start.

title: Banks Act, Stocks Surge and Skeptics See a Pattern
description: A move announced by central bankers on Wednesday to contain the European debt crisis resulted in euphoria in global stock markets, but it also prompted skeptics to wonder: will this time be different?

title: Oscar Controversy, in Many Languages
description: Many of the 63 films submitted in the competition for the 2012 Academy Award for best foreign-language film have not yet even begun a commercial run in an American theater, and some never will. But since its introduction in 1947, the category of best foreign-language film is one that has always been marked by controversy, intrigue and speculation, and this years contest is already proving to be no exception.

title: For Small Fishermen, a Fairness Issue
description: In an article in Mondays paper about an experiment off the central California coast, I mentioned a program introduced by the Pacific Fisheries Management Council to combat overfishing. Known as catch share, the program allocates quotas of overfished species to various vessels.

title: Lessons in Home Cooking From Star Chefs
description: In todays Dining section, Julia Moskin reviews several new cookbooks that promise lessons in home cooking from some of the worlds most celebrated chefs.

title: More Americans Planning Holiday Travel This Year
description: Its that time of year again, and more Americans are saying they will take a trip of at least one night during this holiday season, a recent survey found.

title: Jonah Hills Expanding Comfort Zone
description: THERES a scene from Jonah Hills new movie The Sitter that youll probably never see, in which things got a little too real.

title: Valentine in Boston? Thats Entertainment
description: Now the fun begins.

title: Teaching Etiquette in the Age of the Evite
description: Im trying to teach my 13-year-old son, Nathaniel, to be polite. In a Facebook and Evite world, this is no easy thing.

title: For Coaches, Its Hiring (and Firing) Season
description: As Jack Del Rio can now unhappily confirm, we are well into the heart of coach-firing season. Its a curious time of year, when most people are festively preparing for the holidays or the playoffs or bashing the Bowl Championship Series like a piata, coaches are entering their real estate agents into speed dial and packing up the family photos.

title: Fracking Forum Moves to New York City
description: Hearings on the controversial natural gas drilling process known as hydraulic fracturing move today to New York City, a locus of opposition to the states plans to approve the practice.

title: Now Playing | Madewells Choose Your Own Adventure Video
description: Tea or coffee? Geek chic or glam adventurer? Sparkle or confetti? These are just some of the choices you get to make when playing Madewells fun new fashion adventure video. Choose tea with the model Dree Hemingway and watch her swap a yarny sweater and glasses for a.) a white shirt and coral pencil skirt, or b.) denim shirt, sequined skirt and trapper hat. Opt for coffee with the stylist Marina Muoz and help her dance her way out of pajamas into either a.) a strapless dress and peony-purple sweater, or b.) minty pants, plaid shirt and boyfriend blazer. You have five seconds to pick accessories, dress code and party decorations from there. What makes the video so amazing is that you control it, says Madewells head of design, Kin Ying Lee. You choose every direction the video takes  from what pieces she wears to which party she goes to  the options are endless. Its completely addicting. Featuring user-directed technology developed by the interactive multimedia company Interlude, and directed by Nagi Sakai with music written and performed by Katie Herzig, the video makes its world premiere here on The Moment. Press play to play!

title: The Other New Zealand Muppet Movie Connection
description: As awesome as are the Muppets, there is a hilariously offensive film which is the muppets exact reverse, and, coincidentally, also linked to the New Zealand/Peter Jackson/Muppet connection that Adam Sternbergh wrote about for the magazine. As I began researching his article, I was reminded of the most fantastically warped Muppet-style movie ever made: Meet the Feebles, Peter Jacksons second full-length feature  a film that surely must lurk somewhere in the mind of every New Zealander about the age of Bret McKenzie.

title: Told to Diversify, Dock Union Offers a Nearly All-White Retort
description: What part of diversity dont you understand?

title: Not-Lobbyists in Name Only
description: Washington teems with highly paid influence peddlers who proudly disdain the title of lobbyist. Mere lobbyists get their hands dirty from shaking and their loafers muddy with scandal. Besides, the real money comes from setting up public affairs shops, offering strategy consulting, or commissioning polls and focus groups for industries that need a big tax loophole or a government contract.

title: Toyota Fun-Vii: The Car as Mobile Mood Ring
description: Recent reports, like this one from the BBC, warn automakers that young people are more devoted to their mobile phones than to their automobiles.

title: Three Coffee Study Sites
description: S. Amanda Caudill, a doctoral student at the University of Rhode Island, writes from Costa Rica, where she is assessing mammal diversity on coffee farms.

title: The Huntsman Handicap
description: In this weeks column for Campaign Stops, I discuss the most electable conservative remaining in the Republican field  the much-overlooked Jon Huntsman:

title: When Flavor Meets Virtue
description: Feeling a little like a cleanse, or perhaps just something a tad less heavy after all that holiday fare? Me too. Still, we all want something good for dinner, and I never really want to sacrifice flavor for virtue.This weeks City Kitchen features an easy fish dish with sesame and ginger, designed with both health and pleasure in mind. Sesame, often used in nearly every cuisine, is considered quite healthful. It is rich in antioxidants, vitamins and minerals. Ginger, too, can make this claim, as well as other countless health-giving qualities. Thankfully, they taste good too, providing lots of flavor, especially for light, low-fat dishes. Its win-win.

title: Lens: Seth Mydans post
description: Lens: Seth Mydans post

title: A Stephen King Thriller: What Motivated Oswald?
description: To the Editor:

title: Link Between Russian Far East and Alaska Restored
description: The Russian carrier Vladivostok Air plans to start flying between Siberia and the United States in July, the only direct service between the two regions.

title: As American Bases Dwindle, Soldiers Have Less Time to Dwell
description: CONTINGENCY OPERATING BASE BASRA, Iraq  Here under the smoke-smudged desert skies, the future lies two and a half hours to the south, at the Kuwaiti border that marks an end of sorts for the last troops in southern Iraq.

title: Buffett to Buy Omaha Newspaper Company
description: Berkshire Hathaway, Warren E. Buffetts Omaha-based business conglomerate, announced on Wednesday that it would purchase The Omaha World-Herald Company, publisher of Nebraskas principal daily newspaper, The Omaha World-Herald, and six other daily papers, and owner of World Marketing, a direct-mail company.

title: For Transfer, a No-Huddle Scholarship
description: LAWRENCEVILLE, Ga.  Until last year, Francis Kallon Jr. was a lifelong Londoner to whom football was a sport engaged without helmets and almost entirely with feet.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: The Artist
description: This season on The Carpetbagger, well be taking a look at some of the behind-the-scenes features weve done for films that are likely to be Oscar contenders. Well also be peering deeper into the craft of those in the film industry who arent marquee names.

title: Zipcar Plants a Tire, Tentatively, in U-Haul Territory
description: Residents of the Bay Area have a new means of moving across town, picking up furniture or hauling the bands gear to a gig.

title: In Myanmar Countryside, Reforms Bring Little Relief
description: HTAN PIN, Myanmar  Farmers in this hamlet outside Myanmars commercial capital, Yangon, have never heard of Hillary Rodham Clinton, and they shrug when asked about democracy, a word they do not recognize.

title: Why Its Getting Harder, and Riskier, to Bet the House
description: In March 2008, about nine months after he bought a steel-processing business, Precision Steel Services in Warren, Mich., for some $750,000, Shailesh Kumar went to two banks in search of a $350,000 loan.

title: Notes From the Underground | MNDR
description: Best known outside of electronic music circles as part of Mark Ronsons stable, Amanda Warner and her band MNDR have been building an international following with a series of rotation-heavy singles and high-profile tour appearances. The band performed in Brooklyn recently to inaugurate Converses almost-too-good-to-be-true free recording studio project, Rubber Tracks, with Warner slathered in the artist Jamie Carreiros projection of symmetrical, free-flowing visuals, which were as much a part of the show as the music.

title: On Wall Street, Some Insiders Express Quiet Outrage
description: Last week, I had a conversation with a man who runs his own trading firm. In the process of fuming about competition from Goldman Sachs, he said with resignation and exasperation: The fact that they were bailed out and can borrow for free  its pretty sickening.

title: American Wont Be the Last Airline Bankruptcy
description: On Tuesday morning, I found myself flying back from Los Angeles after the unexpected death of my father-in-law, a longtime public defender who had a million times more real courtroom experience than a former big law type like myself could ever have (five years, two uncontested motions). He will be missed.

title: Have N.F.L. Questions? Judy Battista Has Answers
description: Will any team sign Brett Favre? Will Andy Reid coach the Eagles next year? What is the most surprising team in the N.F.L.? Judy Battista, the N.F.L. reporter for The Times, will again answer selected questions from readers this week. Use the comment field below to ask your questions, and the answers will appear on The Fifth Down on Friday.

title: Should Owners Have to Bet the House?
description: An article weve just published focuses on how common it is for small-business owners to tap their home equity to start, expand and maintain their businesses.

title: Other Voices: Life on Planet 3.0
description: Michael Tobis, a climate scientist and software engineer long at the University of Texas Institute for Geophysics, describes himself as a sustainability nerd, neo-Texan, Internet addict.

title: Why Gingrich May Be the Last Anti-Romney Standing
description: Its natural to look at the latest Republican polls, five weeks from the Iowa caucuses, and marvel at the weirdness of it all. In a party well stocked with successful governors and ambitious senators, how can it be that the guy leading the field at this late date is Newt Gingrich? Could the last man standing against Mitt Romney really turn out to be a washed-up politician who has never been elected to anything outside a single Congressional district, and who managed to pull off the most calamitous campaign rollout since New Coke?

title: A Brooke Astor Auction Planned by Sothebys
description: For decades Brooke Astor was a tireless supporter of a variety of causes and institutions including the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Pierpont Morgan Library (now the Morgan Library & Museum), the Animal Medical Center of New York and the New York Public Library. So before she died in 2007, at 105, she selected a number of charitable organizations to benefit from her estate.

title: A Contract to Stop Driving
description: The continuing battles over car keys  including how long older drivers can safely operate automobiles, under what conditions, when its time to stop and who gets to decide  have come up many times here. Its one of the toughest issues families confront.

title: Airlines Cut Back, Hotels Step In
description: YOU dont have to fly first-class to get V.I.P. treatment at the airport  if you stay at the right hotel. As more and more guests show up harried after airline delays, baggage issues and other travel hassles, hotels are stepping in with new services designed to make the airport experience less stressful. From wardrobe storage to airport concierges, heres a rundown of some of the options being offered.

title: Vain Glorious | Tenovertens New Nail Polish
description: Nadine Ferber and Adair Ilyinsky, the co-owners of Tenoverten, the stylish TriBeCa nail salon, were inspired by client feedback when concocting the formula for their new polish collection, and since their client list is filled with fashion-world heavies who know their Peridot from their Bordeaux, the partners couldnt have asked for a better focus group. People love certain aspects of different polishes, Ferber says, pointing out that some of her customers choose Essie because it lasts the longest, while others rave about Chanels color choices. It became about how to meld the best of everything into one product, Ilyinsky says. After months of research in the field, the duo nailed their first six shades, which are named after streets in downtown Manhattan. A bright blue polish called Commerce was inspired by the West Village street where Ferbers clothing boutique, Mick Margo, is located. Church is a burnt red alternative to Wicked (a popular Essie shade), and Reade, a metallic charcoal, was named for the salons home base. With its five-free formula (no formaldehyde resin, camphor, formaldehyde, toluene or dibutyl phthalate) and easy-to-hold brush (the salons technicians work from 10 a.m. to 10 p.m., so a little attention to ergonomic detail was in order), this new polish deserves a big hand.

title: Palestinians to Receive Payments, Israel Says
description: JERUSALEM  Israel agreed on Wednesday to transfer to the Palestinian Authority about $100 million in tax and customs payments that it has withheld for four weeks in protest over the Palestinians membership efforts at the United Nations and pursuit of power-sharing with Hamas.

title: The Not-Romneys
description: David Brooks: Gail, which was your favorite not-Romney boomlet? Did you like the Bachmann Spring, the Cain Supernova, the Trump Tornado or the Gingrich Comet?

title: In Gingrichs Words, Promoting His Clients
description: The St. Petersburg Times has tracked down audio from the health transformation summit at the Florida State Capitol that Newt Gingrich and his for-profit Center for Health Transformation held in 2006, and which The New York Times wrote about today. At the event he promoted some of his private clients  paying members of the center  to state lawmakers.

title: Why Miami Shouldnt Abandon Mike Miller
description: The pressure for a team like the Miami Heat to improve is never-ending, as dominance will only bring calls for more dominance, and victories will be met with demands for more victories. Its only natural, after all, that much would be expected of a team with such potential. But those expectations fly in the face of one important fact: the avenues of improvement for Miami are closing off rather quickly.

title: Cain Pledges to Stay in Race
description: 10:54 p.m. | Updated  The full report of this article is available here.

title: Changes in the Lunch Line for Some Schools
Commuters, Your Despair Is Restored
description: It might take the Metropolitan Transportation Authority months to fix a broken escalator, but mess with the Worlds Most Depressing Subway Poem and the agency will spring to action in a jiffy.

title: Judges Focus on Flight Risk of Galleon Chief
description: 9:52 p.m. | Updated

title: From Bathroom Basic to Fashion Accessory
description: A few years ago, a heart-shaped USB flash drive that was covered in black Swarovski crystals was atop my holiday wish list. The drive was only one gigabyte (I need at least four), but who cared? The appeal was turning something mundane like a memory device into a fashion accessory.

title: TimesCast | November 30, 2011
description: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton arrives in Myanmar; Britain downgrades diplomatic ties with Iran; and six central banks take joint action.

title: David Milch Strikes Deal to Bring Faulkner Works to HBO
description: 3:15 p.m. | Updated

title: Political Standoff Escalates in South Ossetia Over Vote
description: MOSCOW  Thousands of protesters took to the streets on Wednesday in South Ossetia, a rebel Georgian enclave dependent on Russian financial aid, where their presidential candidates invalidated victory over a Kremlin-backed rival in the election last weekend has provoked an escalating political standoff.

title: Mitt Romney Talks About Himself, Not Obama, in New Ad
description: Mitt Romneys campaign released its second television ad on Wednesday, a spot that is notable for having what the former Massachusetts governors last ad did not: a positive message.

title: Scandal at Finmeccanica Revives Questions in Italy
description: ROME  For weeks now, the influential chairman of Finmeccanica, the state-backed Italian military equipment group, has been resisting calls to resign, even as the company sinks ever deeper into a widening kickbacks scandal and posts disappointing returns.

title: President Obama: Veto the Defense Authorization Act
description: When President Obama came into office in 2009 he promised to shut down the Guantanamo Bay detention camp and end the extra-judicial system that his predecessor had created to imprison terrorist suspects without trial, often without even filing charges. He has broken that promise.

title: As Economy Lags, Cuomo Reconsiders Tax Stance
description: Faced with a worsening financial climate, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said Wednesday that he was contemplating whether to propose changes to the state tax code, and he did not rule out the possibility that he would seek to raise taxes on wealthy New Yorkers.

title: TimesCast | Inside Myanmar
description: November 30, 2011 - While Secretary of State Clinton assesses Myanmar's steps toward democracy, our reporter takes to the streets of the country where most foreign journalists have been barred.

title: Artifacts | The Activist Inside Us
description: The first World AIDS Day, in 1989, was called A Day Without Art. Museums and galleries closed or hung black streamers in place of significant artworks, or hosted memorials for the thousands whom the H.I.V. virus had already killed. Initiated by Visual AIDS, a support group, what was to be a national day of mourning actually signaled the start of the 90s culture wars.

title: Congressman Presses California on Fuel-Economy Standards
description: Suspecting that California regulators may be exerting unlawful influence over the agencies that determine federal fuel-economy standards, Representative Darrell Issa has begun an inquiry into the practices of the California Air Resources Board, or CARB, the agency charged with setting pollution standards for the state.

title: The Failed Potential of the Progress Reports
#OccupyWallSt Roundup, Day 75
description: Protesters gathered in Madison Square Park to meet arriving delegates from the aerospace and defense industries to a conference hosted in part by Credit Suisse bank. A rally to protest war profiteers is planned for 4:30 p.m. in the park. [NBC New York]

title: Soviets Invade Finland, in Real Time
description: RealTimeWWII, the World War II Twitter feed we profiled this week that has attracted some 155,000 followers, began on Aug. 31 with Adolf Hitlers 1939 invasion of Poland, in violation of Germanys non-aggression pact with the Soviet Union. Now, its the Soviets turn to show what-for. After days of rumblings, the Red Army has invaded Finland.

title: Gounod's 'Faust' at the Met
description: Marina Poplavskaya and Jonas Kaufmann in a scene from the Metropolitan Opera's production of "Faust." (Video courtesy of the Met.)

title: Ex-Sheriff Is Accused in Sex Case Tied to Drug
description: DENVER  Patrick Sullivan was the kind of lawman Coloradoans loved: a straight-shooting Republican sheriff who once crashed a Jeep through a fence to rescue two deputies from a gunman and pleaded with legislators to keep assault weapons off the street lest any more citizens get shot.

title: Park Avenue and East 87th Street, 1:30 p.m.
Machinists and Boeing Reach Deal
description: After decades of bitter relations, Boeing and the machinists union vowed a new era of cooperation on Wednesday as they announced a far-reaching four-year contract extension that would raise wages, improve pensions and add thousands of new assembly jobs in Washington State to build an updated version of its 737 jet.

title: The Up-Close-and-Personal Candidate? A Thing of the Past
description: COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa  The aspiring Republican presidential candidates have logged countless hours in the living rooms of voters, pitching their platforms and firing jabs at President Obama.

title: A Supportive Crowd at Syracuse
description: SYRACUSE  High above the Carrier Dome court, in the last row of Section 311, a group of longtime Syracuse basketball fans attends each home game with a roll of tape and a large orange banner. It reads 311 Heaven and gets taped on the wall behind them, underneath seven retired jerseys of former Orange stars.

title: Shopping Snapshots: Dec. 1
description: French import Sandro opens; Camel colored coats; a Pamela Love Trunk Show and more.

title: Nintendo Says the 3DS Holds Its Own Against Game Apps
description: Nintendos dominance of the portable gaming market is in question now that popular gadgets like Android smartphones, iPhones and iPads offer games that are much cheaper than those on game cartridges.

title: Pictures of the Day: Los Angeles and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Los Angeles, Yemen, Britain and Egypt.

title: Playwright Criticizes Casting in Hartford for The ____________ With the Hat
description: 6:03 p.m. | Updated In a rare attack by a playwright on a professional production of his own work, Stephen Adly Guirgis took to Facebook on Wednesday to assail the casting of two white actors as the Puerto Rican lead characters in the Hartford regional production of his play The ____________ With the Hat, which was a Tony Award nominee for best play. The Hispanic Organization of Latin Actors has also complained to the theater, TheaterWorks, noting that the production had casting calls in New York City, a training ground for many Hispanic actors.

title: Campaigning on Fox
description: Some candidates have been relying on television appearances on Fox to get out their messages.

title: TimesCast | Britain Downgrades Relations
description: November 30, 2011 - Tensions rise as Britain closes its embassy in Tehran and orders Iranian diplomats out of London.

title: Spotify Introduces Apps to Point Listeners to Music
description: 3:02 p.m. | Updated In the jargon of digital music, the streaming service Spotify offers a lean-in experience, meaning that a user needs to know what to look for and must type in the names of the desired songs or artists. By comparison, Pandora is more lean back: you just press play and let it go.

title: Big Ten Refutes Needing Seat-Fillers for Championship
description: Looking for something to do Saturday night? How about taking a trip to Indianapolis for the first Big Ten football championship game, to watch Michigan State take on Wisconsin at Lucas Oil Stadium.

title: Foreclosure Crisis Isnt Even Halfway Over, Analysis Finds
description: A new analysis suggests that the tide of home foreclosures isnt going to recede soon.

title: Lens: Cambodia
description: Lens: Cambodia

title: Are All Politics Still Local?
description: Barack Obama has George W. Bush beat at one thing: travel to battleground states. As The Wall Street Journal reported:

title: No Greater Role Than His Own
description: RICHARD PHILLIPS, a portrait painter who traffics in glossy erotica and celebrity images, stood at the door of his studio in the Starrett-Lehigh building in Chelsea the other day. Outside, in the wide hallway, a line of languid models waited by an agency next door. One was changing from flats to hellishly high heels. Many stared into space.

title: Newt Again, and Again
description: I first wrote about Newt Gingrich in this cover piece for the magazine back in 2009, just after President Obama took office. There are few more confounding figures you can write about in politics and perhaps none who elicit such strong responses from our readers. Heres my latest column over on the Caucus blog, about why it is that Gingrich (everyone calls him Newt, really) has managed to outlast his better-equipped rivals.

title: On Lens: An Intimate Portrait of Baghdad Today
description: Our colleagues over at the Lens blog have a great post today on a side of Baghdad that you dont normally see: its personal side, shown through sometimes quiet, sometimes playful, sometimes somber pictures of the normal lives of everyday Iraqis. Marieke van der Velden, a Dutch photographer, collected the images as part of Baghdad Today, a project that she undertook in August of this year. Michael Kamber writes: Ms. van der Veldens recent photographs of daily life  not death  in Baghdad make you feelBaghdad Today, forms one of the most intimate portraits of Iraqi life to emerge since the 2003 American invasion.

title: 2 Governors Asking U.S. to Ease Rules on Marijuana to Allow for Its Medical Use
description: The governors of Washington and Rhode Island petitioned the federal government on Wednesday to reclassify marijuana as a drug with accepted medical uses, saying the change is needed so states like theirs, which have decriminalized marijuana for medical purposes, can regulate the safe distribution of the drug without risking federal prosecution.

title: Secret Santa in the Senate
description: Lets leave aside those questions of naughty and nice. Scores of senators this year are feeling festive, and plan to exchange gifts, Secret Santa style, across party lines.

title: Central Banks Take Joint Action
description: Six central banks agreed to lower the cost of borrowing dollars for foreign banks to help ease the European debt crisis.

title: CBS Wins With a Fashion Show and Rudolph
description: CBS has every right to call its Victorias Secret Fashion Show one of the hottest holiday specials of the year.

title: Notes From the Underground | A Place to Bury Strangers
description: A wall of sound does not even begin to describe the effect on the ears when the New York band A Place to Bury Strangers performs. From the pulsing floor, through your toes, and up your spinal column, everything in your body starts to tremble. By the time you remember to stuff some tissues your ears, your mind is already reeling from the cocktail of endless guitar rumble, thundering drums and hysterical visuals. If you are into this kind of experience, which I happen to be, A Place to Bury Strangers, fronted by Oliver Ackerman and backed by Dion Lunadon and Gavin Haag on bass and drums respectively, is a must-see. More than just a shock to the system, the trios music is completely solid.

title: The Life Report: Wayne McWilliams
description: The following Life Report was submitted in response to my column of Oct. 28, in which I asked readers over 70 to write autobiographical essays evaluating their own lives.

title: Crunching the Numbers: Exploring the Math of the Debt Crisis
description: Overview | What consequences do countries face by being in debt? What obstacles do they face trying to get out? In this lesson, students investigate the mathematics of being in debt by exploring and analyzing debt-crisis data. Through collecting and crunching economic information, calculating debt-repayment, and exploring the concept of financial risk, students apply quantitative skills that will help them better understand the crisis of being in debt, abroad or at home.

title: A Cool Reception to a Ban on Fur
description: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif.

title: Michael Bensons Planetary Landscapes
description: A multi-media artist digitally processes raw image data from deep space missions to create large-format landscapes that sometimes resemble places on Earth.

title: Countdown Begins for H.P.s WebOS Decision
description: Hewlett-Packard hasnt yet made up its mind about what to do with WebOS, a mobile operating system in which it invested billions of dollars so it could create an iPad rival. In fact, the company needs another two weeks.

title: Tokyo Auto Show: Volkswagen Cross Coupe Concept
description: Volkswagen showed new versions of the Up city car and a number of turbodiesel models at the Frankfurt auto show in September, as well as a mildly redesigned CC sedan at the Los Angeles show this month, but the company, aiming to become the worlds largest automaker, saved an all-new design for the Tokyo auto show.

title: A Thermostat Thats Clever, Not Clunky
description: Steve Jobs may have transformed a bunch of industries, but his great skill wasnt really inventing. Instead, he was the worlds greatest makeover wizard. Hed look at some industry, identify what had been wrong with it for years, and then figure out how to make it beautiful and simple and joyous.

title: Eclectic as Ever, Sundance Unveils Competition Lineup
description: 11:20 a.m. | Updated  LOS ANGELES  Love and sex, not necessarily in that order. Bleak self-scrutiny. Quirk, sometimes in the extreme.

title: A Look at Berwicks Tenure as Medicare Chief
description: 4:25 p.m. | Updated to fix link to Health Affairs article.

title: Republicans Push Quick Permit for Keystone XL Pipeline
description: Republican lawmakers in Congress introduced legislation on Wednesday that would require the Obama administration to issue a construction permit for the controversial Keystone XL pipeline within 60 days unless the president decided the project was not in the national interest.

title: Mingling With the Veterans at Art Basel Miami Beach
description: GETTING to Art Basel Miami Beach is one thing. Feeling included in the four-day spasm of hush-hush openings, Dionysian dinners and overhyped parties is quite another.

title: Johanns Sees Change in Mood for Tax Increase
description: Another Republican senator has opened the door to tax increases on high earners as a way to pay for a payroll tax cut, showing more movement in the party ranks after resistance all year to tax increases.

title: Art Basel Miami Beach: Tuesday Night
description: Parties for Ferrari and White Cube gallery kick off the10th year of Art Basel Miami Beach.

title: Alaska, Texas and the Wide Sky Between
description: Photo lovers within driving distance of Buffalo, will be well rewarded by a visit to the Albright-Knox Art Gallery this fall to catch Victoria Sambunariss solo exhibition, Taxonomy of a Landscape. Sambunaris is a New York-based photographer who has been trekking across the U.S. for a decade. More than 30 images from her travels make up her first show to appear in a major U.S. museum. The examples above hardly do justice to their scope and exquisite detail. Which is why you should see the huge prints  some measure as large as 55-by-77 inches  in person.

title: Reindeer, Crime and Underwear Pay for CBS
description: The 1-2-3 scheduling punch of Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer, NCIS and the Victorias Secret Fashion Show, while perplexing, proved to be a knockout for CBS on Tuesday night as the network finished No. 1 in total viewership and in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic. Rudolph at 8 p.m. brought in 12.7 million viewers while a repeat of NCIS at 9 p.m. drew 13.4 million. At 10 the Victorias Secret Fashion Show enjoyed its highest 18-to-49 rating ever, up 35 percent compared to last year and its largest total audience since 2002, at 10.3 million viewers.

title: Faust at the Met
description: The Metropolitan Opera presented Gounods Faust on Tuesday night, a co-production with the English National Opera.

title: Bookshelf
description: Photographed by Sophia Schorr-Kon, Balance: European Hardcore (Mark Batty Publisher, $40) catalogs the sweaty, fist-swinging hordes that mosh across the continent  including miners, teachers, luxury-car salesmen and Subway sandwich managers.

title: Shen Wei Dance at Park Avenue Armory
description: The troupe performed at the Armory.

title: The Caucus Click: Obama in Scranton, Pa.
Undaunted by a Great Canvas, Filling It With Spectacle
description: The airplane-hangar dimensions of the Park Avenue Armorys Drill Hall would daunt many choreographers. But Shen Wei has triumphed in larger spaces. Hes the man who helped synchronize 16,000 performers in the Birds Nest stadium in Beijing for the opening ceremonies of the 2008 Olympics. And on Tuesday he took full advantage of the halls expanse with a mere 32 dancers. Scale is not his problem.

title: Despite Scandal, Applications to Penn State Rise
description: The abuse scandal at Pennsylvania State University does not appear to have slowed applications to the schools undergraduate programs.

title: What The Central Banks Did Today
description: Ill outsource this to Mark Thoma.

title: Expect Some Toning Down of Antipiracy Bills, Says Movie Industry Supporter
description: LOS ANGELES  Look for changes in the proposed antipiracy legislation that has giants in the entertainment and technology industries squared off against each other, but nothing extensive enough to please all of the legislations opponents. That was the message from Michael OLeary, the senior executive vice president for global policy and external affairs of the Motion Picture Association of America, during a telephone news briefing on Wednesday.

title: Rating the Credit Raters
description: My colleagues Julie Creswell and Graham Bowley had an article on the front page of The New York Times on Wednesday about how credit ratings agencies missed or badly misread signs of trouble in Greece.

title: Riccardo Chailly Cancels Boston Symphony Concerts
description: The Boston Symphony Orchestra announced on Wednesday that the conductor Riccardo Chailly, widely thought to be a potential candidate to become its next music director, had canceled concert engagements for the next two months for health reasons, including two weeks as guest conductor in Boston.

title: Pictures of the Day: Los Angeles and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from California, Yemen, England and Sri Lanka.

title: Predicting a Red-Light Runner? M.I.T. Has an Algorithm for That
description: A green light at an intersection may offer a driver the legal right to proceed, but it offers no guarantee of safe crossing. Researchers at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology have developed an algorithm to predict when an oncoming vehicle would be likely to run a red light.

title: Mafia Is Accused of Immigration Fraud to Lure Strippers
description: That New Yorks strip clubs have been inhabited by entrepreneurial mobsters is nothing new.

title: Jeremy Scott, Fashions Last Rebel
description: Jeremy Scott, survivor of the anti-fashion era.

title: Jeremy Scott, Fashions Last Rebel
description: A MAN on roller skates with Vulcan eyebrows, drag queens, club weirdoes and fashion cognoscenti gathered at Jeremy Scotts September fashion show, a hair-metal-meets-hillbilly reverie. First Mr. Scott conjured a promiscuous denim world. One model wore fringed cut-offs so tight Daisy Duke would be appalled.

title: Stone Links
description: A gathering of recent philosophy-related links.

title: Michael Bubl and Nickelback in Photo Finish Atop the Charts
description: 5:33 p.m. | Updated In a rare photo finish at the top of the Billboard charts, Michael Bubls holiday record squeezed past a new album by Nickelback to clinch the No. 1 spot by a margin of only 419 copies.

title: The Great Designers at the Museum at the Fashion Institute of Technology
description: A two-part survey from the permanent collection of the Museum at the Fashion Institute of Technology.

title: From Bloody Conflict, a Trial Begins
description: Finbarr OReilly is a Canadian photographer based in Africa for Reuters. On Lens, he has written about caricatures of Muammar el-Qaddafi; the road from Tripoli to Tobruck in Libya; doorways in Helmand Province, Afghanistan; and bonding with subjects in conflict zones. His work on white poverty in South Africa was featured in June 2010. Follow him on Twitter: @finbarroreilly.

title: A Quebec Country House on 253-Acres
description: An eight-bedroom stone and wood country home built in 1825 on 253 acres near Quebec City is on the market for $2.8 million.

title: A Museums Encyclopedic Closet
description: THE GREAT DESIGNERS, a two-part survey from the permanent collection of the Museum at the Fashion Institute of Technology, approaches its subject alphabetically. Part 1 opens this week with a fitted black suit and a chenille leopard-print polo by Azzedine Alaa from 1991 and closes with a purple silk halter ensemble trimmed with ropes by Zoran, circa 1979.

title: Big Dance Theater at BAM
description: The company presented Supernatural Wife in its Brooklyn Academy of Music debut on Tuesday evening.

title: House Hunting in ... Quebec
description: A 19TH-CENTURY COUNTRY HOUSE ON A 253-ACRE ESTATE IN QUEBEC

title: Fulton Street, Downtown Brooklyn, 2:02 p.m.
Investigator Finds Violations at Shuang Wen School
Piers Morgan Struggles to Beat Kings Ratings
description: Piers Morgan, who succeeded Larry King at the beginning of this year, appears to be having trouble attracting any more viewers than Mr. King did.

title: A Battle in San Francisco Over a Garden of Memories
description: The Grove, showing Thursday on PBS in honor of World AIDS Day, is a nicely made study of the difference between a personal memorial and a public one. It is also, perhaps unintentionally, a statement about how far the United States has come in dealing with the disease, compared with other parts of the world, where it is still the early 1980s.

title: Cain Revelations Weigh on G.O.P. Governors Meeting
description: ORLANDO  As Herman Cain was reassessing his bid for the Republican presidential nomination on Wednesday, the partys governors were assessing how he has handled the string of allegations about his sexual conduct toward women.

title: Homes for $1.36 Million
description: A penthouse overlooking Boston harbor, a beachfront cabin in Hawaii, and an 1895 Victorian in Park City, Utah

title: On Belonging to Western Civilization
description: A day when Americas Federal Reserve has apparently decided to play John J. Pershing to the latest European crisis seems like as good a time as any to talk about that old warhorse, Western civilization and particularly the debates kicked up by Civilization: The West and the Rest, Niall Fergusons latest tome. Though perhaps debates is too high-minded a word, since the most prominent argument has featured Pankaj Mishra accusing Ferguson (in a vituperous London Review of Books review) of being a neo-imperialist, whites man burden-toting Euro-chauvinist, followed by Ferguson threatening to sue Mishra for libel. But I did think this comment from Brad DeLong raised some interesting issues. Hes objecting to the idea, raised by Fergusons book and emphasized by Donald Kagans Times review, that European colonialists did good as well as evil, and that the Western imperialist project has to be credited with positive legacies as well as with grave crimes. Heres Delongs retort:

title: What You Get for ... $1.36 Million
description: HAUULA, HAWAII

title: As More Occupations End, a Protester Wounded in Oakland Describes His Ordeal
description: As my colleague Jennifer Medina reported, police officers broke up Occupy protest encampments in Los Angeles and Philadelphia early on Wednesday, arresting hundreds of protesters. Hours later, officers in Phoenix used pepper spray twice to disperse protesters gathered outside an upscale resort.

title: Icahn Urges WebMD to Buy Back $1 Billion in Stock
description: Ready or not, WebMD, here comes Carl C. Icahn.

title: In the Heisman Race, a Video for Luck
description: The race for the Heisman Trophy gets dramatic with this production for Stanford University quarterback Andrew Luck.

title: Market Ready
description: Q. I have an overflowing wall of books in my living room. Should I store them or reorganize them to make it look less cluttered?

title: The Giving Spree | Lazaro Hernandez
description: Who: Proenza Schoulers Lazaro Hernandez.

title: Chants, Boos and Celebrities at a Hearing on Fracking
description: An update on the state hearing in New York City to solicit public comment on hydraulic fracturing, or fracking:

title: Behind the Gilded Gates of the ____ and ______
description: Michael Gross took a bus tour of stars homes while researching Unreal Estate, his latest exercise in class-conscious voyeurism. That would be funny if it werent so sad. Sure, Mr. Gross has interviewed people who live large in the gilded ghetto made up of Bel Air, Beverly Hills and Holmby Hills, a region that he actually refers to as La-La Land. But his reportorial position is that of a gawker-stalker whose curiosity and cupidity far outweigh his reportorial talents. Whats more, he has made a career out of this.

title: Tip of the Week: Using Google by Voice
description: While it is not quite as helpful as Apples Siri personal assistant, Google has a voice-activated feature in its software that lets you search the Web by speaking your search terms out loud. Google Voice Search is available in its mobile apps for the iPhone, BlackBerry and Nokia S60v3 mobile phones. Depending on which version of the software is installed on the phone, Android users have their own options, including the Google Search widget, the Voice Actions app for Android or other apps from the Android Market.

title: In Tasmania, Nature on Display
description: For one couple, a home in the midst of Tasmanias untamed beauty seemed like a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity.

title: Wifes Sacrifice, a Flirtation With Death
description: When making your Brooklyn Academy of Music debut, a little drama doesnt hurt. For theirs, Paul Lazar and Annie-B Parson, the husband-and-wife directors of Big Dance Theater, turned to a reliable source: ancient Greece.

title: In Tasmania, a Place to Watch Nature TV
description: HOBART, Tasmania  Around 11 years ago, Drew Beswick and his future wife, Bea van Heerden, took a vacation from their cramped London apartment to Tasmania, the Australian island where Mr. Beswick had grown up.

title: Go Ahead, Touch Someone. You Just Might Take Her Home.
description: Usually when a couple say they met in the theater, they mean they were in the cast or on the stage crew together. Patrons who venture to the show at Joes Pub on Thursday night may find themselves constituting a different class entirely: audience members who were more or less ordered to couple up by the performer.

title: 3 Upper West Side Owners to Shut Illegal Hotels
description: Updated, Dec. 2 | After a lengthy legal battle, the owners of three Upper West Side residential buildings have agreed to stop using their properties as low-cost hotels. The city hailed the deal as a victory for the community, but it has raised new concern among some residents about the buildings future.

title: Seasonal Cheer With Drawl
description: Twenty years have passed since Steve Tyrell applied his gruff-friendly stamp to the 1936 standard The Way You Look Tonight in the remake of the movie Father of the Bride and gently but firmly dragged it into the rock era. That recording has since made Mr. Tyrell the paternal wedding voice of our time. His singing in a craggy Texas drawl, with a heavy New Orleans influence, suggests a modern all-American dad holding a mint julep as he tends barbecue with a big grin on his face.

title: Where Selling Pot Is No Longer a Backroom Deal
description: Anyone who has ever bought pot in a cloudy Baggie or a wad of tinfoil while someone flushes in the next stall will be impressed by the modern face of marijuana retailing as portrayed in the new Discovery Channel program Weed Wars.

title: U.S. Military Press Office Iraq, Signing Off
description: BAGHDAD  With a short e-mail, the United States military press office in Baghdad press released itself out of existence. The announcement on Wednesday was a model of brevity. Of clarity, not so much.

title: Were Redecorating!
description: SPECIAL POST  Over the next few days, you will be seeing a new look to your online puzzle home, at least in the space where you leave your comments. The New York Times is excited to announce the re-design of the comment section, and I think youre really going to like what you see.

title: 12 Things You Didnt Know Facebook Could Do
description: The designers and engineers who build Facebook are anything but complacent about their success. They face a constant threat from the career-centric LinkedIn, specialized upstarts like Instagrams mobile photo network and now Googles fast-growing Google+, an attempt to improve on Facebooks core design that has picked up tens of millions of users in its first few weeks.

title: Another Shot: AK-47s as Jewelry
description: WHEN Cara Buono arrived at the Emmy Awards in September, nominated as best guest actress in a drama series for her role as Dr. Faye Miller in Mad Men, she wore a $150,000 political statement in her lobes. These earrings, she said, are made from AK-47 gun metal.

title: The Buzz
description: Must-attend parties, talked-about openings and fashionable night spots for the week ahead.

title: London Underground | The Prozac of Print
description: With the darker days and cold weather upon us, it is hard not to be drawn to the ray of sunshine that is Self Publish, Be Happy. The founder, Bruno Ceschel, a writer and lecturer in photography at Camberwell College of Arts, promises self-fulfillment through making your own photo books and enjoying the work of others. After several years working in traditional publishing, Ceschel is keen to celebrate the D.I.Y. attitude and energy of self-publishing, which, with the ease and affordability of digital photography, printing and distribution, is now accessible to all.

title: King of the PG-Rated Night
description: ON a recent Wednesday, Scott Lipps, the president of One Management, a modeling agency, stood in the penthouse of the Mondrian SoHo hotel, where a dinner for an AIDS charity was taking place. Friends describe Mr. Lipps as a fashion world Woody Allen, and entering the party he seemed touchingly neurotic, explaining that he was unsure if hed been formally invited.

title: Apps That Make You Feel Like Dancing
description: Dancing with the Stars has helped spur interest in ballroom dancing, but for many who would like to follow in the footsteps of the stars, lessons are often too expensive, too far away and socially awkward in the extreme.

title: American Masculinity, Shown in All Its Angst
description: On Monday night, when Natalie Portman helped introduce the first-ever tie for best feature at the Gotham Independent Film Awards, she noted that the winners, Beginners and The Tree of Life, took on the big ideas: love, death, human connection. She couldve added: boyhood, fatherhood and how to look good in a suit. Both Beginners, an indie, multigenerational romance from the director Mike Mills, and The Tree of Life, Terrence Malicks sweeping ode to Americana (and earth), are wide shots at the notion of American masculinity, as it is and was.

title: Photo Play and Power Shopping
description: Steve Lohr of the Times discusses new tools that can detect excessive retouching to digital photos and Patrick Carter of Digital Folio explains how his companys price-comparison application works.

title: Saharan Anthems, Ethereal but Insistent
description: The power of patience defines the Tuareg rock of Bombino, a guitarist and singer from Niger who brought his band to Le Poisson Rouge on Tuesday night. Bombinos music is unhurried, undemonstrative, meditative and quietly adamant. It comes out of the Sahara, carrying the desert landscape in its sound.

title: The Literary Cubs
description: REBECCA CHAPMAN, who has a master of arts in English and comparative literature from Columbia University, hit bottom professionally last summer when she could not even get a job thatdid notpay. Vying for an internship at a boutique literary agency in Manhattan, Ms. Chapman, 25, had gone on three separate interviews with three people on three different days. They couldnt even send me an e-mail telling me I didnt get it, she said.

title: M.L.S. Hot Stove: Free Agency, Soccer-Style
description: Adam Cristman, Youre traveling through another dimension  a dimension not only of sight and sound but of mind. A journey into a wondrous land whose boundaries are that of imagination. Thats a signpost up ahead: your next stop: the Twilight Zone! or in this case, Major League Soccers re-entry draft, with a whistle stop in Indonesia.

title: A Quintet in Its Comfort Zone, With a Little Youth in the Mix
description: The deep, dark-maple tone that Christian McBride elicits from an upright bass is one of jazzs forthright pleasures, and so is the pleasure he seems to extract from it himself. On Tuesday night, in the first set of a five-night run at the Village Vanguard, he took the stage exuding luxurious comfort  in a black skullcap with a gold peace-sign medallion draped over black velour  and began filling the room with his sound. His solo introduction, shapeless but soulful, eventually led to a major blues in sauntering tempo, and the rest of his quintet fell neatly into step.

title: Other Orchestras Fear Paying Price for Philadelphia Pension Crisis
description: A great orchestras glory lies partly in continuity, the passing of musical traditions among generations of longstanding members. And a good pension in the precarious world of the arts is one element that helps keep players ensconced in their chairs, ensuring that handoff of artistic heritage.

title: An Imposing Museum Turns Warm and Fuzzy
description: In some ways the San Francisco Museum of Modern Arts expansion is like the many other recent building efforts by cultural institutions around the country. It is costly ($325 million), time consuming (due to be completed in 2016) and ambitious (the square footage will more than double).

title: Changing How We Pay for Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: TV at the Supreme Court: A Law Professors Brief
description: To the Editor:

title: Knockout Hinges on Decision: Ruff or Discard?
description: SEATTLE  At the Fall Nationals here, two major events were decided on Monday. The Mitchell Open Board-a-Match Teams was won by James Cayne of New York City; Michael Seamon of Dania, Fla.; and Giorgio Duboin, Antonio Sementa, Lorenzo Lauria and Alfredo Versace from Italy.

title: Obama Delivers His Pitch for the Payroll Tax Cut in Scranton
description: SCRANTON  President Obama cast himself as a populist fighter Wednesday during a quick trip here as he tried to increase pressure on Congress to extend the payroll tax cut.

title: Fighting the Governor One Percent Label
description: Gov. Andrew Cuomo campaigned vigorously against renewing the New York surtax on high earners, which expires at the end of the year, insisting against all evidence that it would drive the wealthy out of the state. On Wednesday, however, he acknowledged (on Fred Dickers radio show) that he is thinking of redrawing New Yorks notoriously unfair tax code. And while he gave no indication that he was changing his position on the so-called millionaires tax, he did not rule out increasing taxes on the rich as part of a general overhaul.

title: Irish Panel on Abuse Cites Failures by Church
description: DUBLIN  Authorities in the Roman Catholic Church in Ireland were slow or did nothing to notify civil authorities and the Vatican of hundreds of allegations of clerical child sexual abuse over several decades, according to independent audits of six dioceses published simultaneously on Wednesday.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: The Convenience Economy and Personal Data as Currency
description: Heres what the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web. The full list can be found in the right hand column of Bits.
